DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Mayor invited to attend 2008 World Water Congress in Vienna

TEXT.P: The chief executive of the London-based International Water Association (IWA) met with Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin Monday and invited him to attend the 2008 IWA World Water Congress and Exhibition in Vienna, scheduled for Sept. 7-12.

Hau thanked IWA Paul Reiter for assisting Taiwan in obtaining the right to host the third IWA-Asia Pacific Region Regional Group (ASPIRE) Conference in Taipei Oct. 18-22, 2009. The IWA has chosen the Taiwan International Convention Centre in Taipei as the venue of the biennial conference.

Reiter told Hau that the "Taiwan Night" presented by Taiwan's delegation at the first IWA-ASPIRE in Singapore in 2005 was so successful and impressive that it helped Taiwan win the right to host the third conference.

The IWA was founded in September 1999 -- the result of a merger of the International Association of Water Quality and the International Water Supply Association. The organization has 10,000 individual and 400 corporate members in 130 different countries.
The 2008 IWA World Congress and Exhibition in Vienna, also a biennial event, will bring together 3,000 water professionals to advance their common goal of sustainable water management.
The congress will provide an opportunity to members of the world water community to exchange ideas and debate key issues underlying the science and practice of water.

DOC.HEADLINE: New coral reefs discovered in Shanyuan Bay off Taitung County

TEXT.P: Much to the excitement of marine ecologists, new coral reefs have been discovered in Shanyuan Bay off the southeastern county of Taitung, a local biodiversity researcher reported Monday.

"The Shanyuan Bay coral reefs span a broad area of water and contain a wide diversity of coral strains, " said Chen Chao-lun, an associate researcher at the Research Center for Biodiversity under Academia Sinica, Taiwan's most prestigious academic institution.

"Coral communities can be found in waters one kilometer off the coastline at a depth of eight to 10 meters, " Chen said, adding that the coral reef located closest to the coast is only 50 meters away from the shore.
Chen surveyed waters in Shanyuan Bay earlier this month as part of a study of coral reef habitats in eastern Taiwan's coastal regions.
He recorded 110 coral strains, roughly one-third the total number of species documented in Taiwan waters. Among them, 94 were stone corals, 11 were soft corals and five were polyp corals.
"The number indicates that Shanyuan Bay's coral diversity is similar to that around Green Island," Chen explained.

Shanyuan Bay, located just off the coast from Taitung City, also boasts a dense and diverse cornularia coral community in which a wealth of fish, shrimp and shell species live, a phenomenon not seen in the Kenting and Green Island areas, Chen said.
A mature, well-developed polyp coral community also exists in three-to-five- meter-deep waters in the bay, another rarity for Taiwan, Chen said.

Most encouraging was that a stem of Oulophyllia bennetthae coral was discovered in the bay, Chen said, adding that it marked the first time that the coral strain normally seen in the Indian Ocean was recorded in Taiwan waters.

"Although this coral species is spread over a wide area, the frequency of its appearance is very low," Chen explained, adding that the existence of the one- meter-high, 60-centimeter-wide coral underscores the diversity of Taiwan's coral communities.

Chen's study coincides with a United Nations global coral reefs survey, as 2008 has been designated the International Year of Reefs to enhance public awareness of the importance of protecting coral reefs and their ecosystems.
Chen said he was impressed by the special coral reef ecological scenes beneath Shanyuan Bay, with various kinds of soft corals growing on large reefs.
"Its beauty and biodiversity rival those found in the Kenting area more than 10 years ago and can even compare with those found off Green Island and Orchid Island," Chen said.
With a five-storey holday resort sitting on the bay's left bank, Chen said he is worried that the coral reefs in the region could face a fate similar to those in the Kenting area.

Noting that coral-reef ecosystems are critical to fishery resources, leisure fishing and tourism, Chen urged relevant government agencies to take immediate steps to better manage and protect the Shanyuan Bay coral reefs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mobile operator to recycle old cell phones

TEXT.P: Taiwan's second largest telecom operator kicked off a countrywide campaign Monday to recycle used cell phones to prevent harmful substances from contaminating landfills and recover valuable metals.

To promote the recycling of phones and accessories, Taiwan Mobile Co. has earmarked more than NT$10 million (US$328,947) to equip its 506 stores around Taiwan with recycling boxes, Harvey Chang, the company's president, announced at a press conference.
Those who turn in their cell phones will receive a small solar flashlight, Chang said.

Citing statistics released by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), Chang said that fewer than 20 percent of local users' out-of-use cell phones are recycled even though 60 percent to 80 percent of all cell phone parts are recyclable.

Chang said that through recycling, one kilogram of gold and silver could be recovered from 66,000 and 97,000 phones, respectively, according to figures released by the Japan-based Telecommunications Carriers Association (TCA).
Recycling is also critical because of the harmful substances contained in handsets, including lead, mercury and cadmium, that could contaminate garbage dumps.

While Taiwanese acquire mobile phones at a fast pace, buying 7 million handsets last year according to an International Data Corporation (IDC) survey, too many users leave their old phones at home, Chang said.

Aside from the recovery of valuable materials, recycling the phones could help save energy. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency estimated that the electricity conserved by recycling 10,000 mobile phones would be enough to power the lives of 19 families in the United States for one year.
The conserved energy is also tantamount to a reduction of greenhouse gas emissions produced by 14 passenger cars for a year, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH reports 1st fatality from acute viral hepatitis A this year

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (D0H) reported Monday the country's first death from acute viral hepatitis A this year.

Lin Ting, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said the victim was a 30-year-old man who sought treatment March 11 at a medical center in southern Taiwan. He was in a state of delirium and died March 14 because of liver and kidney failure.
Lin said the man's death was closely related to a hepatitis A infection.
"Hepatitis A was prevalent in Taiwan in earlier days, " Lin said, noting that a lot of Taiwanese over 50 years old have been infected.
But with improvements in environmental hygiene and eating habits, the number of people contracting the infection through contaminated food or drinking water has declined dramatically.
"This year, though, the number of the hepatitis cases is worrisome," Lin said.
He noted that there are already 82 confirmed cases of hepatitis A so far this year, compared with the 42, 57, 62, 49, 45 cases during the same periods in the past five years.
"The upward trend is obvious," he said.

Among the 82 cases, 47 cases are young men under 30 years old, and among them, 17 were students from 8 to 28 years old, an indication "that the risks of younger men being infected with hepatitis A are increasing," he added.
Taiwan has not reported a hepatitis A outbreak for a long time, and the antibodies in the immune systems of the younger generation have diminished, he said.
More frequent meals outside the home and closer contact with people from Southeast Asia and China have contributed to rising risks, he said.

Health officials urged the public to avoid eating raw food or drink dirty water to avoid being infected with the disease, whose symptoms include fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, vomiting and an upset stomach.

Hepatitis A vaccines are available, but Taiwan currently only gives free shots to children between 2 and 12 years old in 30 aboriginal villages in mountainous areas, nine plains villages adjacent to the mountainous areas, and on the Taiwan-controlled islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

Others have to be inoculated at their own expenses. One shot for an adult will cost between NT$1,500 (US$49.2) and NT$2,000, while one shot for a child is around NT$1,000. Two shots are needed to ensure protection against the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 1, or the 25th day of the second month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1572: The Dutch War for Independence from Spain begins.
1578: William Harvey, British physician and anatomist who discovered the circulation of blood, is born.
1815: Prince Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck, Prussian statesman and first chancellor of the German Empire, is born.
1908: Japan puts into practice a six-year compulsory primary education system.
1924: Adolf Hitler is sentenced by a court to five years in jail for high treason. He was released on Dec. 20.
1924: The Republic of China's Central News Agency is established in Canton by the ruling Kuomintang.
1930: Yen Hsi-shan, Feng Yu-hsiang and Li Tsung-jen revolt against the ROC National Government.
1938: The Emergency National Congress of the Kuomintang in Wuchang elects Chiang Kai-shek as its director-general and decides to organize a People's Political Council and a "Three Principles of the People" Youth Corps.
1940: The Nationalist government issues a circular to all levels of the nation's governments to call Dr. Sun Yat-sen the "National Father of the Republic of China."
1945: U.S. forces invade the Japanese island of Okinawa.
1959: The Dalai Lama arrives in India from Tibet.
1960: The United State launches Tiros I, its first weather satellite.
1965: King Hussein of Jordan appoints Prince Hassan, his younger brother, as his heir.
1968: Ma Ssu-tsung, former president of mainland China's "National Music Academy," and his wife arrive in Taipei from the United States.
1975: Cambodian President Lon Nol flees to Indonesia as Khmer Rouge guerrillas close in on Phnom Penh.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan visits the Taiwan Machinery Show at the grounds of the China External Trade Development Council.
1984: Chang Gung Memorial Hospital completes the first human pancreas transplant in Asia.
1986: The new Value Added Tax (VAT) system is inaugurated in Taiwan.
1989: Namibia gains independence from South Africa.
1992: President George Bush pledges that the United States will help finance the 24-billion dollar international aid fund for the former Soviet Union.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui starts a four-day visit to the United Arab Emirates and Jordan.
1996: Britain proposes slaughtering 15,000 of its cattle every week for the next six years in order to fight mad cow disease.
1996: Japan's Mitsubishi Bank and Tokyo Bank merge to become one of the world's largest banks, Tokyo-Mitsubishi Bank.
1998: Israel accepts a United Nations resolution calling for its withdrawal from south Lebanon.
2000: Acting Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan says that he expects the party will rise again by winning the elections for legislators and county magistrates in two years and by regaining the presidency in 2004.
2001: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presents a "Key to Taipei" to Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama, saying that "the city always welcomes you and is always opened to you."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is easy to serve, but difficult to please. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will not be pleased. But in his employment of men, he always takes into consideration their capacity. A fool, on the other hand, is easy to please, but difficult to serve. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will be pleased. But in his employment of men, he expects them to be able to do everything."

DOC.HEADLINE: Two senior military officers disciplined for political campaigning

TEXT.P: Two senior military officers who participated in activities supporting specific candidates prior to two recent elections were disciplined for violating administrative neutrality, the Ministry of National Defense said Tuesday.

The decision, involving Gen. Chi Lin-lien and Gen. Fei Horng-po, who serve as strategic advisers to President Chen Shui-bian, was made during a personnel evaluation meeting, the ministry said in a statement.
Chi was cited for his attendance at a fundraising dinner held by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative candidate Lee Wen-chung last December ahead of the Jan. 12 legislative election.

Fei was found to have behaved improperly by attending a Feb. 26 symposium at which opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou unveiled his defense policy ahead of the March 22 presidential poll.
The ministry said Chi was given two demerits, because while he claimed he had not known the event was a fundraising dinner until he got there, he nevertheless spoke at the event.
Fei was given one demerit, as he did not speak at the symposium, the ministry said.

The two cases came under public scrutiny after the enlisted son of DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh was criticized for violating the military's neutrality by attending one of his father's campaign rallies.
But the ministry said Tuesday that conscript Hsieh Wei-chou was not punished, considering that his participation was purely a family affair and that he made no speech at that rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
DPP needs overall review after 3 major setbacks: defeated candidate

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) needs to undergo a comprehensive internal review now that it has suffered three major election setbacks over the past three years, defeated DPP presidential candidate and party chairman Frank Hsieh said Monday night.
Hsieh made the remarks in an interview with cable television network SET TV, his first public interview since losing to Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang (KMT) in the March 22 presidential election.

In the interview, Hsieh refrained from allocating blame for the defeat, even when asked if his loss was the result of a lackluster performance by President Chen Shui-bian and corruption scandals plaguing the president's family members and close aides during his second term in office.
"As a vanquished candidate, I myself should be the one to be reviewed, and I'm not in a position to openly review others, " Hsieh said.

With the DPP also having lost the mayoral and magistrate elections in December 2005 and the legislative elections on Jan. 12, 2008, Hsieh said the party desperately "needs an overall review rather than to target any specific individuals."
He said that having served as premier and party chairman, "I have to take my share of the responsibility."
Asked about Vice President Annette Lu's claims that his loss resulted from his attempt to draw a clear line between himself and the president, Hsieh said "that is open to public opinion."
But Hsieh noted that he was at a marked disadvantage in his campaign compared to when President Chen ran for election in 2000 and re-election in 2004.

The DPP's approval ratings are lower today than they were previously, Hsieh said, and Chen had NT$2 billion at his disposal to spend on his campaigns compared to Hsieh's NT$500 million to NT$600 million.

Hsieh, who announced last Friday that he would stay on as party chairman to bring the demoralized party back to its feet, also dismissed reports that he would compete in the May 25 race for party chairman.
"I will not run for party chairman, nor will I endorse or work behind the scenes for anyone for the post, " he added, insisting that he would only serve as caretaker party chief until May 25.

The defeated DPP presidential candidate said he favors an open and transparent process in selecting a new party head. Those interested in the post should make their names known so they can be scrutinized, Hsieh said, rather than having an election decided by backroom dealings or "underhanded maneuvering" as had occurred in the past.

Hsieh also indicated that he would not encourage Lee Ying-yuan, the DPP's secretary-general and one of Hsieh's key campaign managers, to run for the post, as Lee, 55, is still young and could run for public office.

Those who choose to run for public office should not serve as party chairman because it would be difficult to maintain strict impartiality, especially as primaries create divisions within a party, Hsieh asserted.
He said the party chairman needs to concentrate on the post and serve out his two-year term.

On his suggestion to reopen an investigation into the presidential election- eve shooting incident in 2004 during which President Chen and Vice President Lu were slightly injured, he said the shooting was real but society had become polarized over the issue due to different political affiliations.
"If the case is proved real and not staged as the KMT has claimed, then the wrongs to President Chen should be addressed, but if the case is bogus, then society needs to learn the truth." Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of foreign laborers tops 360,000

TEXT.P: Taiwan was host to more than 360,000 foreign laborers as of the end of February, with those from Indonesia forming the largest group, according to figures released Tuesday by the Council of Labor Affairs.
At the end of February, the number of foreign laborers in the country totaled 362,782, up 3,679 from the month-earlier level.

By sector, 184,542 people, or 50.87 percent, were employed in the manufacturing sector; 163,815 people, or 45.16 percent, were working as caregivers; and 7,937 people, or 2.19 percent, were employed in the construction industry.
There were also 3,947 people who were hired as crewmen on Taiwanese fishing boats and 2,541 people who were employed as domestic helpers.
By nationality, 120,910 people, or 33.33 percent, were Indonesian, with more than 105,000 of whom employed as caregivers.
Taiwan had 86,293 Thai laborers, or 23.79 percent of the total, with more than 77,900 of them working in the manufacturing sector and more than 6,500 employed in the construction industry.
There were also 85,895 laborers from the Philippines in Taiwan and 69,655 from Vietnam.
By region, Taoyuan County was home to the largest number of foreign laborers at 72,349, followed by Taipei County at 49,569 and Taipei City at 37,901.

DOC.HEADLINE: Relations with Nauru strong despite delay of state visit: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) refuted reports Tuesday that relations between Taiwan and South Pacific ally Nauru are on alert after the suspension of a state visit to Taiwan by Nauru's president.
The ministry insisted that bilateral ties remain close and unchanged.

"Taiwan maintains close contact with both the ruling and opposition parties in Nauru. Therefore diplomatic ties between the two countries will not be affected by the political deadlock within Nauru, " MOFA spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said at a regular press briefing.
Nauru currently faces a political standoff after a no-confidence motion against the government failed in mid-March.

Although the motion was blocked, the opposition's David Adeang took over as speaker of Nauru's 18-member Parliament, and he has called on the president to resign, dissolve the house or seek re-election to end the impasse.
Nauruan President Marcus Stephen was forced to suspend a state visit to Taiwan that was scheduled for March 29-April 2 to deal with the parliamentary stalemate.

Describing a report in Taiwan's Liberty Times that bilateral relations between the two countries are on high alert because of the political uncertainty as "mere speculation, " Yeh said cooperation projects in agriculture and port development remain unchanged.
"The suspension of President Stephen's state visit is simply because of Nauru's internal affairs, " she said, denying that it had anything to do with China's intervention.
China has been trying to suppress Taiwan's international space by using financial aid to lure Taiwan's diplomatic allies, especially in the Pacific region, to switch their allegiance to Beijing.
Many expect cross-Taiwan Strait relations between Taiwan and China to improve following President-elect Ma Ying- jeou's inauguration on May 20.
But the Foreign Ministry warned there would be no diplomatic honeymoon for the new government as there were signs that China was not easing its campaign to diplomatically suppress Taiwan.

Taiwan and Nauru had been allies for 22 years before former Nauruan President Rene Harris shifted diplomatic allegiance in 2002 from Taiwan to China. On May 2005, then President Lugwig Scotty signed a joint comunique in Taipei on the re- establishment of diplomatic relations between the two countries.

Stephen was sworn in as president of Nauru on Dec. 19, 2007 after Scotty was ousted in a vote of no confidence. Harris has been mentioned as the country's likely leader if the opposition returns to power.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County chief honors model communities

TEXT.P: Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan bestowed citations on 11 model communities around the county Tuesday, expressing his gratitude to the county's people for their contributions to improving the environment.
Cho honored the representatives of the 11 communities with laurel wreaths and received agricultural products grown in those communities as gifts in return.
The 11 communities, which include Taoyuan, Yungle, Wutsuo and Hualun communities, have also been classified as model communities by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration.

Noting that Chaunghua County is the only county in the country that has had communities win model community medals for 10 consecutive years, Cho said it reflected the consistent efforts of local residents to improve their living environment.

According to Chuanghua County officials, among the 512 communities around the county, 285 have established environmental protection volunteer groups to better protect the quality of their communities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Peer ostracization main concern of children calling foundation hotline

TEXT.P: Being ostracized by one's peers is the main concern among children phoning the Child Welfare League Foundation's hot line for children, according to a report released by the foundation Monday.
The report revealed that 32 percent of the 2,703 kids who called the foundation's hotline last year said their biggest worry was being shunned by their peers.
It marked the sixth straight year since the 0800-003-123 hotline was set up in 2002 that this concern has topped the list.

The foundation, which is devoted to improving the nation's child welfare services, set up the hotline for children to speak with social workers and volunteers and share their thoughts and emotions in order to help them ease the pressures and burdens they face.
Of the 2,703 calls to the hotline last year, over 70 percent were made by girls, according to the report.
The report's finding that nearly one-third of the children who used the hotline expressed concerns about being ostracized by peers tallies with the results of the foundation's campus survey in 2005.

In that survey, 65 percent of the child respondents said they had experienced being excluded from the group or being subjected to ridicule at some point in their lives, with 90 percent of those kids feeling sad, angry or embarrassed as a result, and a small number even contemplating suicide.
Second on the list of troubles expressed by kids using the hotline last year was pressure resulting from a heavy homework workload, representing 18 percent of the calls.
The third most common reason children used the hotline last year was excessive interference by parents or guardians in their lives, according to the report.

The report also found that more and more boys are phoning the hotline to ask questions related to sex and sexuality, with a total of 82 such calls to the hotline last year, or ten times the number five years earlier.

The hotline received a significant number of calls from girls who lack confidence because of dissatisfaction with their physical appearance for various reasons, ranging from feeling overweight to considering themselves ugly in comparison with their pop idols.
A total of 115 girls called the hotline with such concerns last year, more than 3.5 times the number of calls by boys for similar reasons.

Another trouble expressed mainly by girls was excessive comparison of themselves to other people by members of their family, with 41 girls calling the hotline last year for this reason, or almost seven times the number of boys who did so.

The fourth major trouble expressed by kids who phoned the foundation's hotline last year was a lack of any outlets through which they could talk about their feelings, with 6.1 percent of the calls falling in this category.
Many of these callers said they do not understand why adults only express their expectations and use their authority without ever listening to what the children have to say.

As of the end of last year, the foundation's Children's Hotline had received a total of nearly 66,200 calls since being set up in 2002, an average of about 47 calls in the three hours the hotline is open between Monday and Friday from 4:30 p.m. to 7:30 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved down 190 points to close at 8,330, with 61,686 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May lost 195 points to finish at 8,310, with 563 contracts traded, while June futures dropped 182 points to close at 8,306, with 44 contract transactions.
September futures decreased 171 points to finish at 8,078, with 38 contract transactions, while December futures moved down 181 points to close at 8,058, with 25 contracts traded.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index slid 152.87 points Tuesday to finish at 8,419.72, with a market turnover of NT$131.48 billion (US$4.34 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 8,520 for April; 8,505 for May; 8,488 for June; 8,249 for September and 8,239 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both dropped.
