June TF futures moved down 12.6 points to close at 1,100, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: President hopes to attend U.S. think tank forum after leaving office

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian told the visiting head of U.S. think tank American Enterprise Institute (AEI) Monday that he hopes to attend the World Forum organized annually by the institute after his second term in office concludes on May 20.
At a meeting with AEI President Christopher DeMuth, Chen said that AEI holds a World Forum in Colorado each June and invites Taiwan's foreign minister or representatives to attend.
He noted that he had attended the AEI forum when he served as a legislator and as mayor of Taipei and hoped to attend the gathering again.

Chen also recognized AEI's Asian Studies Program for its contributions to promoting friendship and cooperative relations between Taiwan and the United States and said he would seek support from every sector of society to help AEI set up an Asian Freedom Forum.

Meanwhile, the president praised a report released in February by the Taiwan Policy Working Group, which was composed of members of AEI and international consultancy Armitage International, for its clear analysis and stimulation of widespread discussion.

Expressing his heartfelt gratitude for AEI's support of Taiwan over the past few years, Chen praised the visit to Taiwan last August of John Bolton, an AEI scholar and former U.S. permanent representative to the United Nations, and AEI's hosting of a video conference last September during which Chen discussed Taiwan's application for membership in the United Nations.
The president also mentioned that only with the assistance of AEI was first lady Wu Shu-chen able to visit Washington D.C. and deliver a speech at AEI in September 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: President, president-elect debate '1992 consensus'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) exchanged divergent views Tuesday of the so-called "1992 consensus, " which has been proposed as the basis for Taiwan and China to resume stalled dialogue.

In the first meeting between the two since the March 22 presidential election, the Presidential Office had planned to have Chen and Ma pose for photographers for five minutes before meeting behind closed doors.
But the five minutes stretched to nearly an hour as the two elaborated on their views of the "1992 consensus."
Ma's spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said later that the meeting was held in a positive atmosphere, although Ma had suggested an open meeting throughout.
The Office of the President had advocated a private meeting so that Chen could brief Ma on classified information related to Taiwan's defense, security and foreign diplomatic situations.

The "1992 consensus" -- a term coined by former Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi in 2000 -- refers to a "one China, different interpretation" understanding that the KMT claims was reached during talks held in 1992 in Hong Kong between representatives of Taiwan and China.
Under the agreement, both sides agreed to disagree on the definition of "one China," according to the KMT.
President Chen said he noticed that Ma has suggested that the two sides resume talks based on the understanding, but he reiterated that he himself "couldn't accept the term."
Chen suggested "three uncertainties" regarding the "1992 consensus, " questioning whether it actually exists, its substantive content, and its possible development and changes.
"One has to be highly vigilant if the resumption of cross-strait talks are built on uncertainties," Chen said.

He said that both former President Lee Teng-hui and Koo Chen-fu, the late chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation and Taiwan's top negotiator with China in the 1990s, said the consensus didn't exist.
"Using a non-existent term as the basis for cross-strait talks is questionable," Chen pointed out.
He also said that China is opposed to "one China and one Taiwan" across the Taiwan Strait or "two Chinas," and Taiwan should not engage in "wishful thinking."
Chen stressed that China wants one China, while Taiwan wants two different interpretations and questioned what would happen if Taiwan failed to get what it wanted but fell into the "one-China" trap.
"Will this not violate your fundamental principle of Taiwan-centric policy and the best interests of the people? the president asked Ma.
Ma stressed that the "one China, two different interpretations" formula was one that satisfied neither side but that both could reluctantly accept.

Ma said that after assuming office on May 20, he will immediately open discussions with China on trade issues, direct transportation links, tourism, and even a peace agreement, which will provide a good gauge of both sides understanding and acceptance of the formula.
If China says no, that there is only one China and no different interpretations, then "we'll quit the talks, because we couldn't continue the talks," Ma added.
But if the consensus exists, Ma said, "we should talk."
The president-elect assured Chen that he would be a worthy successor.
"You've passed the baton to me, and I will not drop it. I couldn't possibly sell out Taiwan. My love for Taiwan is not less than yours," Ma said.
He stressed that he will safeguard the "nation's sovereignty and take care of people's best interests."
"We all love Taiwan, but we've different ways to deal with China," Ma said, adding that "now it's our turn, and we'll have the opportunity to try our way."
If Taiwan, China and the United States can all accept the consensus, then the risks of cross-strait conflict should diminish, Ma said.

The one-hour open meeting began with Chen and Ma speaking positively of each other, and Chen expressed the hope that after he steps down on May 20, it will mark the end of confrontation between his supporters and opponents and ring in the Ma era.
Chen said that he passed the Taipei mayoral baton to Ma in 1998, just as he will pass the presidential baton to Ma on May 20 this year.
"Maybe it's God's will, or some may say it is coincidence, or some could even say that it is a happy occasion on the political scene," Chen said.
The president said that between now and May 20, his top priority will be the transfer of power. He hoped that "this is the first meting, but will by no means the last" if any needs arise.

Ma said he cherished the election results, vowing to "obey the majority, respect the minority, and engage in dialogue with those with different views, " now that the KMT has a firm grip in both the executive and legislative branches of the government.

Although Taiwan's people had chosen him by a clear majority, they had not completely repudiated the DPP, Ma said, adding that he hopes the DPP, which has been thrown into disarray due to two major election setbacks this year, will regroup for a fresh start.
He said he is "willing to engage in fair competition rather than perpetual bickering with the DPP."

Also attending Tuesday's meeting were Chan Chuen-po, director of Ma's office, and Chan Chi-shean, a Ma adviser and former superintendent of Chi Mei Hospital in Tainan County, where President Chen was treated for a gunshot wound on the eve of the 2004 presidential election.
President Chen was accompanied by Presidential Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen and Lin Teh-shun, director of President Chen's office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices opened higher but closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 152.87 points to close at 8,419.72.

Finishing lower for the second consecutive day, the bourse opened at 8,593.2 and fluctuated between 8,608.95 and 8,419.72 during the day's session. A total of 5.05 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$131.49 billion (US$4.34 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues losing 6.1 percent, the most of any sector. Textile stocks dropped 4.9 percent, cement stocks fell 3.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares shed 2.7 percent, foodstuff issues were down 2.4 percent, banking and financial shares lost 2.3 percent, paper and pulp issues slid 2.1 percent, and machinery and electronics shares fell 0.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,540 to 642, with 282 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$8.09 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Cost at pump to drop until April-end vote
Gasoline prices are set to fall by 25 yen per liter after the ruling bloc and opposition camp failed to agree Monday on extending provisional extra levies on gas and other auto-related taxes.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: S-E Asia and China forge links with road network.
A new road now makes it possible to drive from Singapore to Beijing, connecting markets and also mirroring an ancient trade route that once linked South-east Asia to southern branches of the Silk Road in the 13th century.
The Lianhe Zaobao: US Fed to become super cop and overhaul financial regulatory system.
The United States government has proposed the most far-ranging overhaul of the U.S. financial regulatory system.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Zimbabwe awaits official vote tally.
President Robert Mugabe and his ruling party were defeated in presidential and parliamentary elections, according to the opposition and independent observers, but there was deafening silence Sunday from the Zimbabwe Election Commission, which released almost no results. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGDPP Sir Ken Macdonald: Detaining terror suspects for over four weeks is not needed
Powers to allow terrorist suspects to be detained without charge for 42 days are not needed and are unlikely to find favour with the judges who would have to approve them, the Director of Public Prosecutions said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Milan to host Expo 2015.
Milan won its bid to host the Universal Exhibition in 2015, the Paris-based selection board of the International des Expositions announced Monday. The theme of the Expo will be "Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life."

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post:GAO Blasts Weapons Budget
Government auditors issued a scathing review yesterday of dozens of the Pentagon's biggest weapons systems, saying ships, aircraft and satellites are billions of dollars over budget and years behind schedule.
The Washington Times:Bigger role for Fed panned
A Treasury proposal yesterday would grant the Federal Reserve new powers to supervise hedge funds, investment banks and other major financial players during emergencies, but critics say the real problem is the Fed's unwillingness to use the broad regulatory authority it already has to prevent emergencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Students suggest replacing Suhua expressway with ferry service

TEXT.P: A group of university students who said they are concerned about the controversial Suao-Hualien expressway construction, requested during a protest Tuesday that the caretaker Cabinet refrain from making the final decision on the project, and suggested that the incoming government consider alternative transportation solutions.

One of the group's organizers questioned the motives of he Environmental Protection Agency, which is expected to approve the project, in convening a meeting on the issue less than two weeks after the March 22 presidential election.
"An important case like the construction of the Suao-Hualien Expressway should not be decided by the caretaker Cabinet," said Tsai Zhong-yue, one of the leaders of the demonstration.
He urged that the new government, which will take office in May, to consider other transportation solutions "such as a high-speed ferry," instead of the expressway.

In 2007 Japan introduced a high-speed ferry service to provide public transportation between Hokkaido and Honshu, the Japanese mainland. This type of ferry can be adapted to Taiwan's marine conditions, organizers of the demonstration said, adding that it can operate during the monsoon season without any problem.

According to the students, most of whom are from Hualien, the ferries, which cost NT$3 billion each, can travel at speeds of 65 to 70 km/h, and can make the run between Suao and Hualien in 80 minutes. Six ferries would be adequate to accommodate the volume of passengers in eastern Taiwan, they suggested.

"The construction of the expressway will take about 10 years -- it is not a solution for people in eastern Taiwan who need transportation immediately," said Pan Han-shen, secretary general of the Green Party Taiwan, who, along with other environmentalists, came out in support of the students' demonstration.
Pan agreed that a high-speed ferry would be a cheaper and better solution to the transportation problem in the area, compared to the expressway, which may cost more than NT$100 billion.
The 86-kilometer expressway, designed to boost the economy of eastern Taiwan, was conditionally approved by an EPA Environmental Impact Assessment subcommittee in early March.

But the demonstrators argued that the idea of an expressway was not the only means of improving the economy and facilitating traffic in eastern Taiwan. Making improvements to Taiwan Highway 9 and the North-Link railway line are also possible alternative solutions, they suggested.

The also expressed concern over the safety of the expressway project and its impact on the bio-ecological system, saying that the plans include about 40 km of tunnels that pass through 11 fault areas in the region where earthquakes occur frequently.

The association, comprised of several groups of university students, focuses mainly on matters related to climate change, but refused to be tagged as "environmentalist," in the hope of extending its advocacy to social issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:Insurers Faulted as Overloading Social Security
The Social Security system is choking on paperwork and spending millions of dollars a year screening dubious applications for disability benefits, according to lawsuits filed by whistle-blowers.
The Wall Street Journal: UBS Seeks Fresh Capital, Expects $19 Billion in Write- Downs
UBS AG said Tuesday that it will ask shareholders to approve up to 15 billion Swiss francs ($15. 07 billion) in additional funds to shore up its dwindling capital base as it unveiled a quarterly loss of 12 billion francs, the result of major losses on U.S. mortgage securities.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to hold major conferences to set party's future direction

TEXT.P: A preparatory committee of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) decided Tuesday to invite party members and members of all sectors of society to take part in several planned conferences to discuss the party's future direction, orientation and reform.
The conclusions reached at these conferences will be sent to the DPP Central Executive Committee and the party congress for approval.

The meeting included DPP Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan, former Presidential Office Secretary-General Chuo Jung-tai, Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang, and former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung.

After the meeting, Lee said that academics, representatives of civic groups, members of the party who have held governmental posts, and local government chiefs from around the island will be invited to take part in the planned conferences to offer their opinions on the party's future direction.
He added that three such conferences for party members will be held in northern, central and southern Taiwan.
The preparatory committee is scheduled to meet again April 7 to further discuss the planned conferences, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. couple adopts baby when it was suspected of being HIV positive

TEXT.P: A U.S. couple on Tuesday adopted a local 16-month-old baby boy, having gone through with adoption procedures even when he was suspected of being infected with the AIDS-causing virus, HIV, but the baby later tested negative.
The child,named Marshall, was abandoned at a shelter shortly after his drug addicted mother gave birth to him. He was suspected of being HIV-positive because his mother was positive.
Despite knowing this, a couple from Texas decided to go ahead with procedures to adopt him. During the adoption process, the boy was confirmed to be HIV negative.

"Marshall is special to us because he is now our son, " the child's adopted father Joshua Bush said at an adoption ceremony, adding that it did not matter to him or his wife whether Marshall was HIV positive or negative. "We are grateful that God has chosen us as parents of Marshall."

Left at a shelter, Marshall was later placed in another shelter run by the Garden of Mercy Foundation (GMF) , a local charity dedicated to limiting the spread of HIV and eliminating discrimination against those-infected with the virus in society.

The Bushes, who already have a 10-year-old daughter and an 8 year-old son, came in contact with Marshall through their volunteer work with the charity on weekends, Chang Li-shu, chairwoman of the charity foundation, said.

Commending the love of the Bushes as "boundary less, " Chang said that even though Marshall was at one time suspected to be HIV positive, the couple never reduced their love for him and decided to have him as a member of their family.
After six months of efforts, including going through the Taiwanese and U.S. application process, the Bushes finally were allowed to adopt Marshall, Chang added.
Marshall's birth mother is currently in prison.
Another four foreign couples are currently applying to adopt babies from Taiwan suspected of having HIV. The infants are currently being cared for at the charity.

Some 50 newborn babies in Taiwan are suspected of being infected with HIV or having full-blown AIDS through their mother every year, said Lu Chun-yi, a pediatrician at National Taiwan University Hospital.
"If we can provide appropriate medical treatment to the babies, the infection rate may be reduced from 40 percent to one percent," Lu said.

In order to show more concern for underprivileged people, Liu Chun-hsiang, director of the Division of Welfare Services for Children and Youth, in Taipei City's Department of Social Affairs said "the public should be educated."
"Most people in our society misunderstand HIV/AIDS, and I hope everyone can join the work to take care of AIDS babies," Liu said.
Chang urged people "to be brave enough to show concern about the HIV/AIDS infected babies because they need our love."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA subsidizes health care sector to boost industry innovation

TEXT.P: Ten companies won an overall subsidy of NT$18. 3 million (US$0.61 million) from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to boost technological innovations so as to upgrade health care facilities and services, the ministry's Department of Industrial Technology (DOIT) said Tuesday.

The subsidy is part of MOEA's "Innovative Technology Applications &Services Program (ITAS)", a 2008 program which combines the Program for Innovative Technology Applications (ITAP) and Innovative Service R&D Program (ISP).

Integrating the two programs' resources, the ITAS could help stimulate new business opportunities for the industry through diversified development of novel operation models, said Wu Ming-chi, Deputy Director of the department.
"The MOEA aims to advance industry sectors by adopting the latest technologies to upgrade their business operations," Wu said.

Medicare company Medtecs International and Wanfang Hospital are among the 10 companies that received the subsidies for their projects. Their projects will cost NT$48.6 million, meaning 62 percent of the budget still requires private funding.

The project of Medtecs International will combine Information Technology (IT) with health care services to provide patients with at home medicares, using digital interactive TV to monitor patient's status and provide more timely medication.

Wanfang Hospital's project aims at helping sick elderly recover from old age illnesses through the playing of computer games. The hospital believes helping seniors maintain a playful attitude and good mood will help them rehabilitate.

So far the two programs, ITAP and ISP, launched in the late 1980s, have subsidized roughly 40 projects each year, said Frank Yang, director of Innovative Technology Applications & Services Project Office.

In 2007, the two programs had attracted 142 project applicants, with 66 of them winning government financial support, a total amount of NT$480 million, Yang added. The maximum amount of subsidy for each company is NT$30 million within three years, he said.

Since its launch in 1988, the ITAP has successfully helped more than 300 companies from a variety of industry sectors, including IT industrial e-Business and Innovation Service to develop new operating models and establish benchmarking for other companies to follow.
Those companies have invested over NT$10 billion in self-raised funding and employed over 5,000 staffs in both advanced IT applications and management innovation.

DOC.HEADLINE: BTCO launches art exhibition at new office

TEXT.P: The British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) held a reception Monday to welcome British artist Susan Stockwell and her work, which is being exhibited at the new offices of the BTCO.

"I am delighted that the BTCO has been able to host this exhibition -- the first to make use of the public area in the new offices we moved into in January this year, " said BTCO Director Michael Reilly. "Susan's meticulous and detailed work provides a contrast to the spacious, minimalist design of the offices themselves."
He added that Stockwell's residency in Taipei last year came under the auspices of the Taiwan-U.K. Artists' Fellowships Program and is an excellent example of U.K.-Taiwan cooperation in the arts.

Stockwell transformed materials such as calligraphy paper, paper cut-outs, needlework, paper, and scrolls into her residency project, "Mapping the City, " and developed a new interpretation of "Line Drawing" during her three-month stay at Taipei Artist Village in the winter of 2007.

During her second visit to Taipei, the celebrated British artist brought her art back to demonstrate again her perception of Taipei City and her experience of the culture in Taiwan, which were transformed into esthetic works to create a dialogue between different people and cultures.

"The work is sort of abstract. You wouldn't notice those things when you look at it, " Stockwell said. "I tried to make it beautiful and use these interesting materials, which people are familiar with but often take for granted, and change the way people look at them."

Stockwell has established a reputation for using everyday materials, much of it already worn out or discarded, not just to create imaginative works but to deliver powerful messages, often about identity.
Through her research into Taiwan's history and her tours of Taipei city, Stockwell became impressed with Taipei's temples, shrines and monks, all mixed in and part of a concrete jungle.

"Obviously Taipei grew very rapidly and had a big (economic) boom. However, it has retained a kind of friendliness, and people seem to be quite laid back as if they are living in another time, " she said. "It's a sort of nice mix here -- it's very new and modern but it's also got old bits."
She added that Taipei is more relaxed and friendly compared to Hong Kong or Shanghai.
Her work, "Taipei Arteries," a cut-out of a red bus road map that illustrates the road arteries of the city and also symbolizes human veins, is particularly interesting to viewers.

"It is very special how the artist transformed the network of urbanites' everyday life into some kind of artistic totem, " said Jenny Hsu, a student at the Institute of Fashion and Communications Design at Shih Chien University.
Stockwell said that she likes the idea of crossing over, from human anatomy to streets, fusing maps of the body and maps of the city.
The exhibition, which is open to the general public free of charge from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. on weekdays, starts April 1 and ends on May 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.087 to close at NT$30.318.
A total of US$1.57 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.455 and fluctuated between NT$30.274 and NT$30.461.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man arrested for threatening to kill Buddhist Master Wei Chueh

TEXT.P: The Nantou County Police Bureau announced Tuesday that police arrested a man a day earlier for making telephone threats last month to kill Buddhist Master Wei Chueh, founding abbot of the Chung Tai Chan Monastery in the county's Puli township.

Lin Yi-min, head of the police bureau, said his officers traced the suspect, 45 -year-old Wu Chien-hua, to the central city of Taichung and arrested him under the direction of Taichung Public Prosecutor Huang Yung-fu.

According to Lin, the police officers searched Wu's residence and found a Chunghua Telecom IC phone card with which the threatening call was made from a public phone booth March 23. Wu admitted making the call.

Wu, a construction worker, told police he made the threats against Master Wei Chueh and his followers after learning from media reports that the Buddhist master had urged the monks and nuns of the monastery and other followers to boycott the two referendums held alongside the March 22 presidential election.

The two referendums, related to Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, were defeated because only 26 percent of the electorate took part in the voting, failing to pass the threshold of at least 50 percent.
Expressing remorse, Wu said he made the threatening phone call "on the spur of the moment" and that although he is a political enthusiast, he had no intention of harming anyone.
Wu will be referred to the Public Prosecutors' Office in Nantou County and charged with intimidation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Int'l orchid show receives NT$2.4 bil worth of export orders

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taiwan International Orchid Show held last month in southern Taiwan's Tainan county has received more than NT$2.4 billion (US$78.69 million) in export orders, a 65 percent increase from last year's show, the county's magistrate Su Huan-chih announced Tuesday.
Su said the show attracted more than 200,000 visitors from Taiwan and abroad as well as 2,000-plus buyers from 24 countries. during its 10-day run which ended on March 17.
Some of the orders for several species or patent species were in the quantity of millions, Su said.

This year, the American Orchid Society (AOS), which was asked to send officials to the show to serve as judges, broke a record in the number of orchid plants to which it gave the highest honor, said Lee Chang-yu, president of the Taiwan Orchid Growers' Association.

Lee said that six orchid plants received the highest honor of first class certificate from the American society, breaking the society's record. The American group usually metes out around a dozen such certificates a year.
This also marked the first year that the American judges gave out more than four of the top certificates to a single show since its establishment in the 1920s.

Lee noted that due to competition from such European flower producing giants as the Netherlands, Taiwan orchid growers have continued to cultivate new orchid species and upgrade its productivity to "maintain a certain competitive edge in the international community."
He said he was optimistic export orders for next year's orchid show will be even higher.

This was the fourth year the annual show had been held at the International Flora Exhibition Center of the Taiwan Orchid Plantation. The exhibition was organized by the Taiwan orchid association and jointly sponsored by the Tainan County government and semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council.

Orchids are one of Taiwan's major exports, accounting for over 50 percent of the total value of Taiwan's horticultural exports, with the Taiwan Orchid Plantation playing an important role in Taiwan's increasing orchid exports each year.

Taiwan exported NT$1.84 billion worth of orchids in 2006, a year-on-year increase of 24.1 percent, with butterfly orchids, or phalaenopsis, accounting for NT$1.15 billion of the total, according to customs statistics.
Known as the "Kingdom of the Butterfly Orchid", Taiwan is the world's largest exporting country of the flower. About half the world's butterfly orchid varieties are bred in Taiwan.

Taiwan's orchid export orders secured at the Taiwan International Orchid Show totaled NT$800 million in 2005, NT$1 billion in 2006 and NT$1.5 billion in 2007, according to figures compiled by the Tainan County government.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC Corp. to continue fuel price freeze in April

TEXT.P: The state-owned CPC Corp., Taiwan, the country's biggest oil refiner, announced Tuesday that the company will continue its freeze on gasoline and diesel prices in line with government policy.

CPC officials said that if calculated according to the floating oil price system, the price of unleaded gasoline should be increased by NT$4 per liter, while the price of diesel should be increased by NT$4.4 per liter.

They noted that world crude oil prices have increased by 34.84 percent since last September, far surpassing the 12 percent cap for a gasoline price freeze, but added that the company will nevertheless continue the freeze.

The officials said the company has absorbed all the losses incurred due to surging world oil prices, losing NT$6.8 billion in January and NT$6.4 billion in February. It is estimated that the losses will amount to more than NT$9 billion in March, with the total losses in the first quarter surpassing NT$22.2 billion.

They added that the company had increased its fuel supply by an average of 26 percent as of Monday, higher than its original estimate, after its rival, Formosa Petrochemical Corp. (FPCC) -- Taiwan's biggest private refiner -- announced a price hike last week, leading to a run on CPC filling stations.
The FPCC announced that its gasoline and diesel prices would be increased by NT$2.8 and NT$3.1 per liter from March 29 in response to surging costs.
The CPC officials said that with the continued freeze, the CPC will lose even more if they sell more.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said the CPC's gasoline and diesel fuel accounts for 78 percent of the domestic market share, but judging from the 26 percent increase in CPC fuel supplies, all FPCC customers have switched to the CPC stations over the past few days.
The officials said they still have enough production to meet the increased market demand and that the company is also maintaining a 60-day stockpile.
The MOEA ordered a freeze on the floating mechanism last November 2007 out of concern that continuous hikes would fan inflationary pressure.

The CPC adopted a floating pricing mechanism in January 2007 under which it adjusted its fuel prices on a weekly basis in response to crude oil price fluctuations. The system was then replaced by a monthly adjustment mechanism last September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier renews promise of peaceful transition

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterated Tuesday that his Cabinet will comply with the relevant laws during the caretaker period to ensure a peaceful transition of power to the new administration.

Speaking at the conclusion of an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan, Chang said compared with 2000 and 2004 when the election outcome drew protests among some people, the results of the March 22 presidential election were readily accepted by the public, which, he said, demonstrated the maturity of Taiwan's democracy.

Chang gave the assurance that while the Cabinet will make sure the government continues to function normally, it will also comply with the legal restrictions regarding personnel appointments and policy declarations in the period prior to the new president's inauguration on May 20.

Reviewing the achievements of the Democratic Progressive Party administration over the past eight years, Chang noted that local workers, who had no retirement coverage eight years ago, are now guaranteed pensions under a new retirement program.

Chang further noted that elderly farmers, who previously received an allowance of only NT$3,000 per month, are now given NT$6,000 per month and that the national pension program, which was still only on paper eight years ago, is set to be implemented in October this year.
In addition to the improvement in the country's social security network, Taiwan's technological development has also made major strides, he pointed out.

He cited the fact that there were no 12-inch wafer foundries in Taiwan eight years ago, and that today there are 17, with that number expected to increase to 20 next year. Also, the display panel industry had almost no presence in Taiwan eight years ago, but now large display panels made in Taiwan are seizing the biggest share of the global market, the premier said.

Other accomplishments by the DPP administration include the completion of the high-speed railway system and the Hsuehshan Tunnel as well as the launch of Hakka Television Service and Indigenous Television Service, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 25% of foreign mothers do not understand children's homework: poll

TEXT.P: The results of a recent survey show that 25 percent of the foreign mothers of local children have difficulty understanding their children's homework and parent-teacher contact sheets, and are thus unaware of their children's needs and behavior at school.

The survey was conducted between October and December of last year by Yeh Yu- ching, an associate professor at National Chiayi University, among 306 foreign mothers of elementary- and kindergarten-aged children around Tainan City in southern Taiwan, 207 of whom are from China and 99 of whom are from Vietnam.

The survey, commissioned by the city's Family Education Center, found that 48 percent of the foreign mothers are worried about their children's behavior at school, while 54 percent of them are deeply concerned about their children's future.
Fifty percent do not want their families labeled as problem families, the survey results show.

Although more than 70 percent of the foreign mothers have their husbands' support with regard to their children's education, 26 percent of them, mostly Vietnamese, still have problems understanding their children's homework, due largely to the language barrier.

The results also show that more than 50 percent of the foreign mothers suffer many annoyances in their day-to-day lives, with many of them feeling strong pressure regarding the education of their children.
As these mixed families are often economically less privileged, many civic groups have repeatedly called for more concern from the public for new immigrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan urged to help Taiwan enter WHO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/08 21:25:23 (By Yang Ming-chu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese medical leader called on the Japanese government Tuesday to help Taiwan enter the World Health Organization (WHO) as soon as possible, saying that the fate of both countries are closely linked in a regional health network.
Wu Shu-min, chairman of the Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan, made the remarks at a seminar held in Tokyo at the invitation of Japan's Asia Affairs Research Council.
According to Wu, when severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) broke out between 2002-2003, there were 1,706 SARS cases around the world, 774 of which were fatal, including 13 people from Taiwan.
"The epidemic caused much panic in Taiwan, with almost all economic activities stopped due to fear that the disease might be spread further," Wu said.
Using its experience in fighting SARS, the Taiwanese government later drew up a series of measures to combat avian influenza, Wu added.

"In addition to preparing the anti-avian flu medicine Tamiflu, 25 million masks and 5 million sets of quarantine clothes, Taiwan has a National Health Command Center that is in charge of controlling diseases efficiently," Wu said.
"If Japan wants to prevent avian flu, it should cooperate with Taiwan, " he went on.

Noting that there are more than 300,000 foreign laborers working in Taiwan and some 2 million visits made by tourists and traders between Taiwan and Japan a year, Wu said the disease could spread in a very short time should an outbreak occur.
He urged the Japanese government to push the WHO to admit Taiwan. According to Wu, Japan contributes 19.25 percent of the WHO's budget, just behind the 22 percent provided by the United States.

He also pinpointed China as the biggest problem in epidemic prevention, citing the example that some 15 percent of birds smuggled from China to Taiwan carry the highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus, while some 14 billion chickens and pigs in China are raised in unsanitary conditions.

In addition, he continued, the Chinese government habitually conceals the real epidemic situation within its borders and its people seldom seek medical help from hospitals. "All these are unfavorable factors for epidemic prevention work," Wu said.
He said there have already been 350 avian flu cases around the globe among humans, with more than 20 fatalities.
Experts have speculated that 20 percent of the world population would be infected by avian flu in the event of an epidemic, with more than 100 million deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmentalists urge action on Earth Day

TEXT.P: Several environmental associations announced Tuesday a series of activities to mark Earth Day which falls on April 22, urging the public to take concrete action in their daily lives to reduce carbon emissions.

Earth Day was initiated in the United States in 1970s, the period during which the consumption of leaded fuel was at its peak, with the aim of enhancing people's awareness of environmental protection. It became an international event in 1990 with the participation of 141 countries worldwide, including Taiwan.
More than 500 million people from 184 countries, representing 17,000 organizations will participate in the international event this year, under the theme of "climate change," the associations said.

"We call on individuals to make an effort in their daily lives to help reduce carbon emissions, " said Hong You-lun, director of an association whose goal is to promote the welfare of local communities.

He further indicated that people can contribute to environmental protection on a daily basis by avoiding "all-you-can-eat buffets," which he said usually lead to over-eating and waste, and by choosing locally produced rather than imported food, as the shipment of food is also a source of carbon emissions.

Jiang Hui-yi, a member of an environmental education association, encouraged people to plant gardens on their rooftops or balconies where they can grow spices and some types of fruit such as lemons and tomatoes.
"Even if the quantity grown is small, it brings to the 'cement jungle' some greenery, and to our life a natural taste," she added.

One of the main 2008 Earth Day programs invites people to send letters to their legislators and local authorities, asking them to stop building coal-fired power plants, to develop renewable energy, and to guarantee low-income families' rights in the fight against climate change.
The environmental associations are also urging people to cut back on the use of electric appliances and private vehicles on Earth Day.
A series of activities, including concerts, workshops, excursions on foot, a film festival and book fair will be held islandwide from April to June, the associations said.
More information about Earth Day can be found on the Web site of Taiwan Earth Day Network: www.earthday.org.tw

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition on Western medicine in Taiwan opens

TEXT.P: An exhibition showcasing the history of the development of Western medicine in Taiwan through a presentation of photos, books and a reconstruction of a hospital ward was officially opened to the public Tuesday.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Lin Huoy-fen, executive secretary of the Taipei City Archives, said that through the exhibition, titled The Story of Doctors, "the public can get a better understanding of how Western medicine was introduced to Taiwan."

According to Lin, the show, which recounts a number of stories about early medical practitioners, is designed to take the audience on a voyage of discovery through the history of Taiwan's medical development during three eras.

The three eras -- the Presbyterian missionary period, the Japanese colonial government period and the post-war period -- were suggested by the late Dr. Du Tsung-min (1893-1986) , the first Taiwanese person to receive a degree in Western medicine.

Chen Yong-hsing, executive director of the Taiwan Medical Humanitarian Foundation (TMHF) -- one of the event organizers -- expressed hope that the exhibition will help acquaint younger generations with the medical achievements of their forefathers.

Noting that the TMHF was founded in 1997 with the aim of promoting medical humanitarianism and cultural development in Taiwan, Chen added that "we have to learn about the history of Taiwan's development, as well as the spirit of our ancestors."

Chiang Chao-gen, executive director of the Chiang Wei-shui Cultural Foundation, said that not only does the exhibition present apart of the country's history, it also reflects the importance of humanitarianism in medicine.

"We have to learn from our ancestors about selflessness, " said Chiang, a descendent of the late Dr. Chiang Wei-shui (1891-1931) who was seen as a political revolutionary during the period of Japanese colonial rule.

The Story of Doctors, organized by the TMHF and the Department of Cultural Affairs of Taipei City Government, is being staged at the New Cultural Movement Memorial Hall in Taipei City from April 1-May 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA promotes industrial strategies at APEC forum

TEXT.P: An official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) expressed his concern Tuesday for Taiwan's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the face of an increasingly competitive global market, citing capital and innovation as key factors to their future development.

The MOEA, which is hosting a forum of Small and Medium Enterprises Working Group (SMEWG) under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) , hopes to promote its main industrial strategies in the panel discussions at the meeting.
"The number one challenge for SMEs is the heavy capital required to start a business," said Yun- Lung Yeh, Deputy Director General of the Small & Medium Enterprises Administration under the MOEA.

Nothing that investment loans and production costs are the major burdens on SMEs, Yeh said that while the gross profit margin for average small and medium enterprises is usually bigger than for large enterprises, small businesses record only one third or one fourth of the net profit margin of large enterprises.
"This indicates that it is not a matter of revenue, but a matter of making real profit," he stressed.

Another problem smaller companies face is insufficient capital to the fund research and development (R&D) that could enhance product innovation, he said, adding that there were however some alternatives.

"Companies with smaller investments could instead adopt the business models of acquisition & development (A&D) or connection and development (C&D) to increase their chances of staying in the market," Yeh advised.
Smaller companies need to develop high-end, value-added products rather than settle for being downstream manufacturers, he added.
The MOEA has several plans in progress for SMEs to develop their operations, including a proposal for enterprise start-up and incubation and an SME Credit Guarantee Fund.
The SME Credit Guarantee Fund, which has a total budget of NT$5 billion this year, makes its easier for SMEs' to secure credit guarantees in order to obtain loans.

Yeh also suggested that Taiwan's aging society and its low birth rate could mean new business opportunities, as changing demographics can help boost "emerging industries" such as the senior service industry.

The forum, which is being held from March 30 to April 4 in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, has attracted officials and business representatives from 21 APEC members and observer countries. Juan Carlos Capunay, Executive Director of the APEC Secretariat and Teng Theng Dar, CEO of Singapore Business Federation are among the resource persons at the forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cap on oil prices to remain until May: Premier

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has decided to maintain the cap on the price of oil products from Taiwan's state-run oil company in April, but whether it would continue doing so in May will depend on world market conditions at that time, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday.

Chang said that the Executive Yuan decided to ban state-owned CPC Corp., Taiwan from raising its product prices owing to grave concerns over the country's overall economic interests, despite a proposal by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to remove the cap.

Some people speculated that the current government was unwilling to raise the price of gasoline and other fuel products, saving the unpleasant task for the incoming presidential administration, but Chang rejected such claims.

"I keenly hope that the public would not use a political viewpoint to judge the issue, because it is not just an issue about the profitability of state-run enterprises, " he explained, adding that state companies are not set up to just make money.

Chang made the remarks to reporters prior to a Legislative Yuan session. The Apple Daily reported Tuesday that a recent poll has found that 47.55 percent of the respondents said that they support price hikes by the CPC Corp., after its private rival, Formosa Petrochemical Corp., increased the price of its gasoline and diesel goods late last week.

Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang (KMT) beat the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) candidate Frank Hsieh with a broad margin of more than 2.21 million votes in the March 22 presidential election. The president-elect is scheduled to be sworn in on May 20.

Formosa Petrochemical, Taiwan's biggest private refiner, increased the price of its gasoline and diesel products by NT$2.8 per liter and NT$3.1 per liter, respectively, beginning Saturday, in response to rising costs. The price increases will remain in effect until the end of April, the company said.

The premier questioned how the entire society would respond if the government raises fuel and oil prices at this critical time when an appreciating New Taiwan dollar has slashed the competitiveness of local export businesses, although he acknowledged that maintaining a freeze on product prices is not an effective solution.
The New Taiwan dollar has appreciated by about 8 percent against the U.S. dollar in recent days.

"The government's top priority at present is to heed the nation's overall economic development and assist the underprivileged and the small and medium- sized businesses to tackle rising product prices, " he asserted.
Turning to the news that the MOEA would call a public hearing to explore public opinion regarding the CPC Corp.'s price increases, Chang said that the MOEA is welcome to do so.
Since the March 22 presidential race, the MOEA has twice proposed that the Executive Yuan lift the freeze on the state oil provider's product prices.

The Executive Yuan's Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun said during the legislative session the same day that the government's decision to keep gasoline and fuel prices stable was made jointly by the Cabinet, not solely by Chang or Deputy Premier Chiou I-yen.

Responding to Chen's remarks, KMT Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang accused the current caretaker DPP administration of using a political approach to deal with an issue of grave concern to the people's everyday life.

"Premier Chang should assume the responsibility to adequately address the issue now, despite the fact that there is only more than one month to go before the inauguration of the new government, " Hsieh argued.

The MOEA ordered a freeze in November 2007 of a floating oil pricing mechanism adopted by the CPC Corp. in an effort to curb inflationary pressures, particularly as the presidential race was approaching.

The state-owned oil supplier adopted the floating pricing mechanism in January 2007 under which it adjusted its domestic fuel prices on a weekly basis in response to crude oil price fluctuations. The system was replaced by a monthly adjustment mechanism last September.

DOC.HEADLINE: President should take most blame for DPP election defeat: ex-lawmaker

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian should take the biggest share of the blame for the ruling Democratic Progressive party's (DPP's) defeat in the March 22 presidential election, a former DPP legislator said Tuesday.

Tuan Yi-kang, former chief convener of the disbanded New Tide faction of the DPP, told a press conference that as the individual wielding the greatest power in both the DPP and Taiwan for the past eight years, Chen must shoulder the biggest portion of the blame for the defeat of DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang.
Tuan expressed hope that a review of why the DPP lost the election will not turn into a "witch hunt."

"I hope we are not setting up a straw man as a target for all the arrows and have it burned," Tuan said, adding that other DPP members should also be held responsible for the election loss, although it would be difficult to apportion the blame in exact percentages.

He said one of the reasons for the DPP's defeat is that the party's clean image was tarnished because DPP members condoned the dubious integrity of a few individuals and allowed the problem to become one of "collective moral depravation."

Tuan said he will not run for DPP chairman, a post Hsieh said he will not relinquish until after May 20. He said the next DPP chairman does not have to be chosen through direct election and that he is opposed to selecting the next DPP chairman according to approval ratings measured by polls.
"The new DPP chairman, who must have substantial support within the party, can be elected by the DPP Central Executive Committee or the Central Standing Committee," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. County hopes for closer ties with sister Taichung County

TEXT.P: Contra Costa County, California, is hoping to strengthen sister county ties and enhance bilateral cooperation with Taichung County in central Taiwan, according to a visiting U.S. official Monday.
Susan Bonilla, Contra Costa County's supervisor of District Four, expressed the hope to Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng Monday during her visit to Taichung.

Speaking on behalf of Contra Costa County, Bonilla said the county, located in the San francisco Bay Area of California, wants to enhance its cooperation with Taichung County in a variety of aspects, such as economy, education, art, and culture, based on a resolution made by the five-member Contra Costa Board of Supervisors.
Contra Costa County is governed by five supervisors. Each of whom is elected on a non-partisan basis from a separate district where he or she lives.
Bonilla received a warm welcome from Huang, who told Bonilla that Taichung County is also willing to strengthen bilateral relations through more frequent exchanges and interactions.

Huang told Bonilla that Taichung County enjoys abundant natural and cultural resources. Its thorough traffic facilities, including a highway network, a sea port and an airport, as well as the high speed rail system, will benefit future development, Huang added.

Taichung's complete infrastructure and development potential has made the county a preferred investment destination, Huang said, adding that investment amount of the Central Taiwan Science Park which covers the county has reached NT$1.7 trillion (US$55 billion) within five years.

Bonilla told Huang that Taiwan gives her a homey feeling because she was born in Taiwan and studied at the Morrison Academy--an international Christian school-- in Taichung City, which borders Taichung County in central Taiwan.
She also invited Huang to visit suburban Contra Costa which has a population of about 1 million to gain a better understanding of the sister county.

The two counties forged sisterhood ties in 1983, and since then has enjoyed a solid friendship and started many cooperation and exchanges. In 2004, the two sides exchanged views on promoting policies on environmental protection, including water resources, processing of waste, green architecture, and urban development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing will not make major changes in Taiwan policy: MAC

TEXT.P: Beijing is not expected to make any major shift in its policy toward Taiwan in the near future, even though the Kuomintang (KMT), which has vowed to improves ties with China, will return to power May 20, according to a statement issued Monday by the Taipei-based Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

Although it is widely hoped that the KMT's presidential election victory last month will bring about a breakthrough in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Taiwan should not be too optimistic because many uncertainties still exist between the two sides, the statement said.
President-elect Ma Ying-jeou will assume office May 20, ending eight years in office for the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
The statement came after the council called an advisory meeting on the development of Taiwan-China relations after the presidential election.
The statement quoted meeting participants as saying that China has a consistent stance on Taiwan and that it is unlikely China will make a massive policy adjustment in the short term.
At the moment, China is believed to be adopting a "wait-and-see" attitude toward the new KMT government, the statement went on.

Nevertheless, advisory experts said the two sides are likely to resume talks and suggested that government agencies start to enhance the abilities of their negotiating teams, prioritize future negotiation agendas and conduct political risk assessments.
They added, however, that no timetable should be set for each agenda.

Some experts also said that China is generally expected to ease its diplomatic suppression of Taiwan after the elections, but in fact, it had begun blocking Taiwan's participation in the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the highest decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO) -- prior to the elections.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said that in early March, China asked other countries to cooperate with Beijing to block Taiwan's attempts to join the WHA at the annual meeting slated for May 19-24.
In addition, the experts went on, it was also reported that Chinese President Hu Jintao might sign a communique during a visit to Japan in May to further limit Taiwan's international space.
Precautionary measures must be taken soon, they suggested.

Meanwhile, other experts said Beijing had yet to finalize its interpretation of the results of the election and two accompanying referendums on Taiwan's U.N. membership bid, neither of which cleared the threshold required for them to be considered valid.
As a result, it is not clear whether Beijing will shift its Taiwan policy from opposing Taiwan independence to promoting unification between Taiwan and China, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weekend cross-strait charter flights need accompanying measures: TAA

TEXT.P: Weekend charter flights between Taiwan and China that, according to President- elect Ma Ying-jeou, will begin July 1, will require some key accompanying measures to ensure that they are profitable, Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) Chairman Su Hung-i said Tuesday.
Su, who was elected March 24 as the new head of the TAA, made the comments during an unofficial meeting with reporters.

The TAA was commissioned by the government in 2005 to conduct bilateral aviation talks with its Chinese counterpart, the Cross-Strait Shipping Exchange Association, in a bid to set up direct transport links between the two sides.
The two organizations succeeded in making direct cross-strait charter flights a reality for four major festivals -- Lunar New Year, Tomb-Sweeping Day, Dragon Boat Festival and Mid-Autumn Festival.
Regular direct air travel and shipping services are not available across the strait due to the political stalemate between the two sides since 1949.

However, Su voiced concern that custom from China-based Taiwanese businessmen alone will not be sufficient to sustain weekend charter flights, despite the fact that there are no technical difficulties in offering such flights based on the current platform for direct holiday charter flights.

This means, Su said, that Chinese tourists must also be allowed to visit Taiwan using the planned weekend charter flights in order to boost passenger loads and ensure at least 60 percent capacity, he explained.

According to Su, the TAA will call a meeting of Taipei-based aviation companies to explore their demands in anticipation of the establishment of the weekend flights and relay their needs and expectations to the relevant government authorities.

Ma repeatedly promised before his March 22 election victory that direct weekend cross-strait charter flights will kick off July 1, to eventually pave the way for regularly scheduled flights between the two sides. He also pledged that Chinese tourists will be allowed to visit Taiwan from that same day.

The president-elect has promised that Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan and Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan will handle direct flights to and from Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Xiamen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Preparatory meetings for APEC forum opens in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: A series of preparatory meetings for the forum of an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) working group on small and medium enterprises (SMEs) opened Monday in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
The main objective of the Small and Medium Enterprises Working Group is to encourage the development of small and medium enterprises in the region.

Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang, accompanied by Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Chiu Tai-san, on Monday presided over a ceremony in the city to mark the opening of the five days of meetings.

The five meetings, organized by the ministry's Small and Medium Enterprise Administration, will consider ideas and help set the agenda for the APEC Small and Medium Enterprises Working Group (SMEWG) forum which will be held in Peru from Aug. 29-30.
Officials and business representatives from 21 APEC members and six observer countries are attending the meetings, two of which will be open to the public.
Four of the five meetings are a training workshop on flu prevention, a high- level meeting on SMEs and local development, a symposium on SMEs' tax affairs and a symposium on SMEs economic strategies.
Information products prepared by eight APEC membership bodies such as Taiwan and Peru will be displayed at pavilions throughout the preparatory session, officials said.
APEC is an inter-governmental forum for facilitating economic growth, trade and investment in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former DPP official gets 12-year sentence for sodomy with minors

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court sentenced a former official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Tuesday to 12 years and two months in prison for sodomizing three children in 2004 and 2005.

Tsai Mao-hsiung, 56, was found guilty of having sex with the three junior high school boys while he served as director of the DPP's Sijhih City office. He was expelled from the party after his arrest in June 2005.

At his Shihlin District Court trial, the paedophile was sentenced to 16 years in prison, but the High Court reduced the sentence to 14 years and two months after finding him less liable on charges of intimidating and injuring the three children.
Police arrested Tsai in June 2005 and searched his residence and office, where officers from the Criminal Investigation Bureau found nude photographs of the boys and other evidence.
According to the police, Tsai met the children in an Internet cafe in 2004 and had sex with them regularly while plying them with alcohol and illicit drugs to keep them under his control.
Tsai can still appeal the case to the Supreme Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu City kicks off festival featuring coastal events

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu city government in northern Taiwan kicked off a month-long festival Tuesday that will feature a series of activities each weekend along its 17-km coastline.
The activities -- designed to introduce the city's attractions to the public and boost tourism -- will include a paintball game, a beach cleanup and a group wedding.
The opening of the festival came as Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-tzer and other city officials inaugurated a tourist center, the result of six years of efforts to transform the city's coastline.
Speaking at the inauguration ceremony, Lin said the city government is seeking to turn the new coastal scenic area into "Taiwan's Mediterranean."
The area features the blue-and-white, Mediterranean-style tourist center, a seashell park, a windmill-shaped clock tower, large fish sculptures and four "rainbow bridges," Lin went on.

It also features an extensive bicycle lane network that covers a seashore park, a countryside path, a lake and a wetland area, according to He Chih-ming, the tourism chief of the city, which houses Taiwan's main semiconductor production center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to subsidize cervical cancer vaccine

TEXT.P: Medical professionals in Taiwan would like to see the government subsidizing the cost of cervical cancer vaccines, and are suggesting that there is room for price negotiations as there are two types of approved vaccines on the market, an obstetrics and gynecology doctor said Tuesday.

Cheng Wen-fang, a gynecologist at National Taiwan University Hospital, said the government should encourage the use of the two vaccines to help lower the risk of cervical cancer and to reduce medical costs.

Neither of the two vaccines is included on the list of treatments covered by National Health Insurance and a complete set costs over NT$10,000 (US$330), Cheng said, adding that the price is too high for disadvantaged women.

The Department of Health (DOH) on Monday approved a second cervical cancer vaccine, which is delivered in the form of three injections and is recommended for females between the ages of 10 and 25 to offer protection against the virus that causes most cases of cervical cancer.

According to Cheng, the vaccine spurs the development of antibodies against human papillomavirus (HPV) types 16 and 18 and these antibodies are still 100 percent viable in the system five and a half years following vaccination. In Western advanced countries, 70 percent of cervical cancer victims are found to have been infected with these two strains of HPV.
However, the efficacy of the vaccine varies depending on the age of the recipient, Cheng said, adding that it is two to five times more effective in females aged 10-15 than in the age group of 16-25.
It will require more than five years of further research to determine whether the newly approved vaccine can also provide long-term protection for women over 25, Cheng said.
In October 2006, the DOH approved the first type of cervical cancer vaccine, which is delivered in three doses and is recommended for females aged 9 to 26.
The two vaccines are designed to block the most common strains of human papillomavirus (HPV) -- types 16 and 18 -- which cause 70 percent of cervical cancer cases in Europe and the U.S., Cheng said.

The two vaccines also provide cross-protection against HPV types 52 and 58 which are associated with cervical cancer, and are also effective against HPV types 6 and 11 which cause genital warts, Cheng said.

Cheng said the common HPV strains in Taiwan are slightly different from those usually found in Europe and the U.S. Research carried out by foreign experts on virus samples collected in Taiwan last year showed that 62-63 percent of cervical cancer was caused by HPV types 16 and 18, 8-9 percent by type 58, 7 percent by type 52, 4percent by type 45, and 3-4 percent by type 31.

Some 17 of the more than 200 types of HPV are associated with cervical cancer. Most infections caused by HPV disappear within seven to eight months, while some persist and escalate, eventually developing into cancer.
In Taiwan, about 5,700 women are diagnosed every year with cervical cancer and about 900 die of the disease on average, annually, according to Department of Health statistics.

Women 30 years old and over in Taiwan are allowed free Pap smear tests for cervical cancer once a year. The chances of recovery from the disease is said to be close to 100 percent, if it is discovered early.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan airport's cargo volume drops to 15th globally

TEXT.P: The Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan, the country's main gateway, ranked 15th in the world in terms of cargo volume handled in 2007, down two notches from the year before, according to the results of a survey released recently.
It was the first time the airport had dropped to such a ranking since 2004, according to the survey conducted by the Geneva-based Airports Council International (ACI).
The airport was in 14th place in 2003, but rose to 13th place in 2004 and stayed there until 2006, the survey shows.
The cargo volume handled last year, recorded at over 1.65 million metric tons, declined for two years in a row, according to the survey results.
In terms of tourist visits and plane volume, the airport failed to rank among the world's top 30, the results show.

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened sharply higher Wednesday.

The weighted price index was up 158.87 points at 8,578.59 on a turnover of NT$4.95 billion (US$163.27 million) at the open. The index lost 152.87 points, or 1.78 percent, to close at 8,419.72 Tuesday.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$30.222 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.096 from Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 2, or the 26th day of the second month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
742: Charlemagne, King of the Franks and founder of the first empire in Western Europe after the fall of Rome, is born. His court at Aix-le-Chapelle becomes the center of the Carolingian Renaissance.
1792: The first silver dollar of the new U.S. currency is struck in Philadelphia by the Bank of the United States.
1801: Britain's Admiral Horatio Nelson, aboard the HMS Elephant, sinks the pro- French Danish fleet off its home port of Copenhagen.
1805: Hans Christian Andersen, the Danish writer of fairy tales including "The Emperor's New Clothes" and "The Ugly Duckling," is born.
1840: Emile Zola, the French realist novelist whose books include "Therese Raquin," "Nana," "Germinal," and " La Terre," is born.
1872: Samuel Finley Breese Morse, the American painter and inventor who refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name, dies at the age of 81.
1902: The first U.S. movie theater is opened in Los Angeles, California.
1912: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China resolves to move the seat of the government to Beijing.
1917: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, summons a special session of Congress to declare war on Germany. At the Paris Peace Conference in 1919, he included the establishment of the League of Nations in the Treaty of Versailles.
1922: Soviet leader Nikolai Lenin appoints Joseph Stalin as general secretary of the Communist Party.
1938: The Spanish Civil War ends with General Franco's fascists as the victors.
1947: The United Nations Security Council votes to appoint the United States as the trustee for Pacific Islands formerly held by the Japanese.
1951: General Dwight Eisenhower assumes command of all allied armies in Europe and the Western Mediterranean area.
1953: Karl L. Rankin becomes American ambassador to the ROC.
1954: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the Extradition Law.
1965: The ROC government declares that "protocols" signed recently by the Beijing regime with Afghanistan are illegal and not binding on China.
1971: Garuda Indonesia Airlines makes its maiden flight to Taipei.
1973: Brig. Gen. Majed Al Haj Hassan and two other members of a Jordanian military goodwill mission arrive in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1974: Georges Pompidou, president of France, dies at the age of 62.
1974: Madame Gloria de Lopez Arellana, the first lady of Honduras, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1981: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo is re-elected chairman of the Kuomintang by acclamation at the 12th National Congress in Taipei.
1982: Argentine military forces invade the British Falkland Islands.
1983: Chang Da-chien, a noted Chinese painter, dies in Taipei at the age of 85.
1991: Diego Maradona, star of Napoli soccer team, flies home to Argentina hours before being banned from every sporting activity in Italy after failing a dope test.
1996: Lech Walesa, Poland's first post-war democratic president, resumes his old job as an electrician at the Gdansk shipyard.
1997: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich meets with ROC President Lee Teng-hui during a four-hour visit to Taipei. Gingrich praises Taiwan's political progress and economic achievements.
1997: The Statute Governing Relations with Hong Kong and Macau is promulgated by President Lee Teng-hui to go partially into effect on July 1, 1997 for Hong Kong, and in 1999 for Macau.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian denies that he sent an American scientist as special envoy to mainalnd China to discuss cross-strait relations with Beijing leaders.
2001: Exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama says in Taipei that he wants to pursue "a genuine autonomy" for Tibet, not independence. He makes the remarks while delivering a speech at the Legislative Yuan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is dignified, but not proud. A fool is proud, but not dignified."

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect's U.S. visit still being negotiated: spokesman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/08 12:52:53 (By Y.F. Low and Jorge Liu)

TEXT.P: The office of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou is still negotiating with the U.S. government over his request to visit the United States before his May 20 inauguration, one of Ma's aides said Wednesday.
The outcome of the negotiations will be made public as soon as the sides come to a decision, said Ma's spokesman, Lo Chih-chiang.

Lo was responding to a report that Ma has withdrawn his request, which has created a dilemma for Washington because it would like to see better relations with Taipei but may worry about irritating China by allowing a visit by Taiwan's president-elect.

Douglas Paal, former director of the American Institute in Taiwan's (AIT's) Taipei Office, told the Central News Agency Tuesday in Washington D.C. that it would be very difficult for Ma to have his wish fulfilled because the administration of President George W. Bush has its own concerns.
Paal said he heard that Ma had retracted his visit request, but added that the information had not been verified.
Ma raised the possibility of visiting the United States before he is sworn in during a meeting with incumbent AIT Taipei Office Director Stephen Young last week.
Over the past few days, there have been reports that Washington has rejected Ma's request.
During his visit to Taiwan last week, AIT Chairman Raymond Burghardt reportedly complained that the United States had been caught unprepared by Ma's unexpected move.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hungarian lawmakers call for closer business ties with Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, April 1 (CNA) 04/02/08 13:04:50 (By Lin Yu-li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Members of a pro-Taiwan group in the Hungarian Parliament proposed new initiatives Tuesday to enhance business and trade ties between Hungary and Taiwan.

Jozsef Ekes, chairman of the parliamentarian Hungary-Taiwan Friendship Association, said that with bilateral exchanges between Hungary and Taiwan continuing to grow, a Taiwan-Hungary business and trade association should be established to help deepen trade, technology exchanges and investment between the two countries.
Ekes said his group is more than willing to help Hungary-based Taiwan companies make inroads into the vast European Union market, using Hungary as a springboard.

Hungary joined the EU as a member in 2004, and its total bilateral trade with Taiwan has more than doubled since then, growing from US$354.98 million in 2004 to US$873.88 million in 2007. Exports from Taiwan to Hungary accounted for 92 percent of that trade last year.
Ekes made the remarks in a speech at a luncheon in Budapest Tuesday hosted by Kao Shuo-tai, Taiwan's representative to Hungary, in honor of members of the Hungary-Taiwan Friendship Association.

Ekes, who visited Taiwan last month to obverse the presidential election, said he was impressed by what he saw in Taiwan, specifically praising the fast and accurate counting of the vote and the high level of participation of Taiwan's young voters.

He said he believes that after the presidential election -- won by opposition Kuomintang candidate Ma Ying-jeou with more than 58 percent of the vote -- cross-Taiwan Strait relations are expected to be less tense in the years to come.
"Taiwan's democratic election has established an exceptionally good example for China to emulate," he added.

Kao said he appreciated the support Ekes' group has given Taiwan. He also promised that his office will make every effort to help strengthen bilateral exchanges between the two countries' business sectors so as to create a positive investment climate for both countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Briton runs to raise funds for Taiwan patients

TEXT.P: A 27-year-old British English teacher kicked off an around-the-island run in Keelung, northern Taiwan, Wednesday aimed at raising funds to help patients of rare disorders in Taiwan and cancer patients in Britain.

Neil O'Maonaigh-Lennon, who has taught English in Taiwan for just over a year, launched his month-long run from Keelung's Chungcheng Park accompanied by Keelung Mayor Chang Tung-jung and a group of foreign nationals and Taiwanese marathoners.
Mayor Chang presented O'Maonaigh-Lennon with a "thank you" certificate and a donation as tokens of appreciation for the compassion the marathoner has shown to Taiwan's people.

O'Maonaigh-Lennon, who tells people to call him "O'Neil" because his name is long and difficult to pronounce, said he will attempt to run 42 kilometers -- the length of a marathon -- every day in his bid to raise funds for the Taiwan Foundation for Rare Disorders and Cancer Research UK.

From Keelung, O'Maonaigh-Lennon headed to Jioufen -- a hilly town located near an abandoned gold mine that has become a popular tourist destination -- and Pingsi -- a sleepy mountainous village -- in Taipei County.
He will then run to the northeastern city of Yilan and the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung before arriving in the southernmost county of Pingtung.

From Pingtung's National Kenting Park -- located at the southernmost tip of Taiwan proper -- the runners plan to turn north to the west-coast counties of Kaohsiung, Tainan, Chiayi and Yunlin, in that order.

After arriving in Taichung City, central Taiwan, they will continue to head north, eventually arriving in Taipei City on April 29 and wrapping up the 30-day around-the-island run in Guandu -- a wild bird santuary town from where the Danshuei River flows out to the Taiwan Strait -- on April 30.

There are an estimated 1,000 to 2,000 people in Taiwan suffering from rare disorders, with only about 15 doctors trained in the special diseases, according to the private Taiwan Foundation for Rare Disorders.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan students make dream of traveling to S'pore come true

TEXT.P: A group of elementary students from Jhuangwei Township in Yilan County will get the chance to visit Singapore later this month thanks to the kindness of local councilors and their own efforts over the past year in raising funds to make their dream come true.

The 37 students from Sing Nan Primary School in the eastern county will depart for Singapore on April 14 for a five-day visit to engage in exchanges with elementary students in the city-state and show off their unique unicycling skills.
In recent years, elementary students from Hong Kong, Singapore and other foreign places have visited the school in Jhuangwei on exchange programs, helping local students broaden their perspectives.
However, according to Sing Nan's principal Liu Hsi-hsin, many of the students at the school often asked him when it would be their turn to travel abroad for exchanges.

Liu said he responded to the students' questions by pointing out that the foreign students received support from their governments in traveling to Taiwan but that if the students at Sing Nan wanted to travel abroad, they would have to pay for the trips themselves.

The strong desire of the students touched the hearts of faculty as well as the students' parents, who together came up with a "making dreams come true" plan last year to raise funds for the students' travel abroad.

Under the plan, the parents, staff and students set up stands at major events at the school or other locations around the township to sell handicrafts and local delicacies, such as peanut candy, cucumbers pickled in soya sauce and roselle preserves, that they had made themselves.
The students' efforts attracted the attention of several Yilan County councilors and other county residents and moved them to help the students achieve their dream.
Through their hard work and the kindness of the councilors and members of the local community, the students were able to raise about NT$500,000 (US$16,500) over the course of the year.
The figure is enough to cover over half the cost of the Singapore trip, with each student only having to pay NT$8,000, and poor students only having to pay NT$4,000.
During their trip, the students will visit the Binhai Art Centre, the Singapore Underwater World, the Science Centre, and many other sites, according to Liu.

Liu said that in addition to sightseeing, the students will also put on a unicycle performance at Hong Wen Elementary School and donate four unicycles to schools in the city-state to spread this unique form of exercise abroad.

DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Drivers flock to pumps as extra tax ends Drivers looking to fill their tanks lined up Tuesday in front of service stations nationwide as the "temporary" surcharge on the gasoline tax expired.
