The Prime Minister faces an urgent task: Find and field those who can take over from him before he turns 70.
Already 56, Mr Lee Hsien Loong is seeking political talent in their 30s and early 40s, one of whom he hopes will emerge as his successor.

Singapore's Prime Minister told Straits Times and Lianhe Zaobao yesterday that the Cabinet update is a continuous process, and there will be at least a cabinet reshuffle before next election.

Treasury Secretary Henry M. DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan continues to work with U.S. on trade issues

TEXT.P: The government will continue to negotiate with Washington on ways to tackle trade barriers that the United States says are preventing it from gaining full access to Taiwan's market, a Bureau of Foreign Trade official said recently.

The Office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) on March 28 released its 2008 National Trade Estimate Report (NTE) on the status of 62 trading partners, noting significant barriers to U.S. trade and investment and the USTR's response to those barriers.

The report said the U.S.' access to Taiwan's market continued to suffer from business software piracy, counterfeit pharmaceuticals, pharmaceutical pricing, restrictions on U.S. beef and other restrictions in Taiwan.

"Bilateral negotiations with the U.S. have been held on these trading concerns, showing Taiwan' s sincerity in dealing with the U.S., " Hsu Chun-fang, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade, said Tuesday.
Hsu stressed that the bureau has responded to U.S. concerns through the Economic Division under the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the U.S.

Although the NTE report raised a number of concerns over barriers to Taiwan's market, it presented a generally positive view of Taiwan's trade policies, including measures on standards and inspection and export subsidies, she said.

"The report has also made reference to the positive outcomes of the meeting on Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) held last July in Washington D.C., in aspects of agriculture, Intellectual Property Rights (IPR), and government procurement," she noted.

In its report, the USTR said it would give its highest priority to eradicating trade barriers by pushing for congressional approval of free trade agreements that had already being signed with Colombia, Panama and South Korea, and expediting the Doha round of negotiations under the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Boosted by the Dow Jones index, which moved up 391.47 points, Taiwan share prices surged Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 185.6 points to close at 8,605.32.

Rebounding after two consecutive days of losses, the bourse opened at 8,578.59 and fluctuated between 8,619.78 and 8,519.67 during the day's session. A total of 5.02 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$146.69 billion (US$4.84 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares and banking and financial shares both advancing the most at 2.9 percent. Textile stocks rose 1.2 percent, cement stocks increased 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares were up 0.6 percent, and foodstuff issues went up 0.2 percent.
Two of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down 0.4 percent and paper and pulp issues dropping 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,574 to 577, with 322 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$8.29 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect wants issuance of inaugural stamps postponed

TEXT.P: The office of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou requested the state postal company Wednesday to postpone the issuance of stamps marking his May 20 inauguration, calling the "Taiwan" marking on local postage stamps "controversial."
Ma's office said in a statement that the matter should only be dealt with after Ma's inauguration because there are other more important issues on the president-elect's agenda.
Sources close to Ma said, however, that he believes the country's official title should be used on stamps because they are symbolic of a country's sovereignty.
Taiwan's post office has issued stamps to mark the inauguration of the country's president since 1996, when Lee Teng-hui became Taiwan's first directly elected president.

The state-owned post office has printed "Taiwan" in Chinese and English on its postage stamps rather than "Republic of China" since changing its name from "Chunghwa Post Co." to "Taiwan Post Co." in February 2007.

The change was made as part of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's efforts to change the names of state-owned enterprises that contain references to China. "Chunghwa" means "Chinese" or "China" in the Chinese language.
The DPP argued that the name rectification campaign would help avoid confusion resulting from Taiwan-based organizations carrying names that were similar to those used by organizations in China.
However, during a recent interview with the media after his March 22 election, Ma argued Chunghwa Post Co.'s name change was "unlawful" because it has yet to complete the required legal procedures.
The statement released by Ma's office referred to the company as "Chunghwa Post Co." rather than "Taiwan Post Co."

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien County promotes non-toxic farming with restaurant chain

TEXT.P: The Hualien county government's Agriculture Bureau formed an alliance with the Su Hang restaurant chain in Taipei Wednesday to promote non-toxic farming and the idea of sustainable development.

Lin Ching-shuei, director of the Kuang Feng Farmers' Association, said that by forming the alliance, the Hualien county government hopes that people will become more aware about agricultural products from the county and will be able to identify with the idea of non-toxic farming.
The Su Hang restaurant is famous for its Jiangsu-Zhejiang cuisine, which is normally considered salty, oily and unhealthy.

"We hope that the general public will associate products of non-toxic farming with `health and quality,' " he added. "We expect this kind of cooperation will create a win-win situation for consumers, restaurants and farmers."

Non-toxic farming in Taiwan was launched by Hualien Magistrate Hsieh Shen-shan in 2004 to provide agricultural products that are grown organically without synthetic fertilizers, pesticides or livestock feed additives. The certification process is in accordance with legal standards to maintain soil productivity and control pests.

There are several differences between organic farming and non-toxic farming -- regular tests are carried out by 15 qualified inspectors on the farms rather than having samples submitted by farmers themselves as is the case with organic farming testing.

In addition, all products must pass an examination 10 days before going to market. Non-toxic farming includes agriculture, fish and livestock, while organic farming focuses more on agricultural products.

"There are three goals of promoting non-toxic farming -- to let consumers eat healthy food, to protect the environment and to help agricultural transformation, " said Chen Hsiou-ching, spokeswoman of the non-toxic farming group.
She said non-toxic agriculture is high-quality agriculture that not only guarantees an income for farmers but also pushes the economic development of Hualien County.

"It is also a concept of sustainable development, " she said, adding that "with the increased incomes, more and more farmers will want to become involved in non-toxic farming and therefore our environment will improve."
Besides "green" agricultural methods, all products of non-toxic farming use environmentally friendly packaging materials such as polylactic acid (PLA), a biodegradable resin derived from cornstarch.
Chen said that every product has an agricultural practice certificate in the form of a sticker that shows the traceability of the product -- who grew it, and when and how it was made.
"By knowing where the product comes from, consumers feel safer and many of them have become regular customers," she went on.

Chen added that the non-toxic farming project has also generated a surprising windfall, in that "many farmers gain an enormous sense of accomplishment after switching to non-toxic farming because they are playing the role of a `food doctor, ' providing healthy food to customers," she said.

Exhibitions for non-toxic farming products were organized by the Hualien county government in Macau and Toronto in 2006 and 2007, respectively, with great success. At present, the project includes 368 farmers in Hualien County, as well as five logistical centers. Consumers can also order non-toxic products through the Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to offer scholarships for Latin American students

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) is planning to offer scholarships to allow outstanding students from Latin America to pursue master's or doctorates or learn mandarin Chinese in Taiwan, ministry officials said Wednesday.

Under a recently reached agreement with 17 leading universities in Central and South America, the MOE is set to offer 20 scholarships for students from the region, according to officials from the ministry's Bureau of International Cultural and Educational Relations.

The bureau made the decision to offer the scholarships after faculty members from National Chiao Tung University traveled to Latin America Feb. 28-March 7 for a meeting with superintendents from the 17 national universities named in the agreement that was struck during the meeting.

According to the bureau's plan, 10 scholarships, amounting to NT$25,000 (US$828) per student per month, will be made available for three years in the case of doctoral students and two years in the case of master's students.
Another 10 scholarships, amounting to NT$20,000 per student per month, will be offered for mandarin Chinese study in Taiwan for periods ranging from three months to a year, the officials said.
The first batch of scholarship winners are expected to arrive in Taiwan in September at the earliest, they noted.

It is hoped that the students, after pursuing their advanced studies in Taiwan, will eventually become members of the elite in their home countries and will be able to contribute to further consolidating bilateral business or diplomatic exchanges with Taiwan, the officials said.
Most of the scholarship winners will study at National Chiao Tung University in Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan, the officials went on.

Despite the fact that most of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies are in Central and South America, the number of students from that part of the world who study in Taiwan accounts for less than 1 percent of all foreign students studying here, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for April rose 239 points to close at 8,570, with 65,511 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May moved up 246 points to finish at 8,553, with 683 contracts traded, while June futures increased 240 points to close at 8,546, with 51 contract transactions.
September futures gained 236 points to finish at 8,314, with 58 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 250 points to close at 8,306, with 36 contracts traded.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 185.6 points Wednesday to finish at 8,605.32, on a market turnover of NT$146.69 billion (US$4.82 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 8,331 for April, 8,307 for May, 8,306 for June, 8,078 for September and 8,056 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
April TE futures gained 11.95 points to close at 326, with 6,482 contracts traded, while May TE futures moved up 11.15 points to finish at 324.4, with 79 contract transactions.
June TE futures rose 8.65 points to close at 321.65, with two contracts traded, while September TE futures increased 12.2 points to finish at 321, with one contract traded.
December TE futures gained 6.75 points to close at 315.05, with one contract traded.
April TF futures moved up 38 points to close at 1,132, with 4,543 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures increased 34 points to finish at 1,129, with 72 contracts traded.
June TF futures rose 28.6 points to close at 1,128.6, with two contract transactions, while September TF futures gained 28.4 points to finish at 1,112.8, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nicaragua receives 400 metric tons of rice donated by Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/08 17:00:05 (By Ramon Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Nicaragua has received another 400 metric tons of rice donated by Taiwan, the Nicaraguan government said in a statement Wednesday.
The shipment is part of a donation totaling 5,300 metric tons promised by Taiwan for this year. Taiwan donated 1,600 metric tons of rice to the Central American ally last year.
The Nicaraguan government said the rice will be sold to low-income households at "fair prices."
The rice, which will be sold at 9.92 cordobas (US$0.52) per kilogram, will be available at 342 retail locations around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Watoto Children's Choir arouses awareness of AIDS in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Watoto Children's Choir, which continues its tour of Taiwan with a performance in Hsinchu City Wednesday night, has called attention in Taiwan to the devastating impact of AIDS in Africa and around the world.

Composed today of 18 orphans aged between 7 and 13 whose parents died of AIDS, the Watoto Children's Choir has staged many fundraising concerts around the globe since it was formed in 1994 to raise awareness of Africa's AIDS crisis and the devastation the continent has suffered from war.
Watoto, the name of the village in Uganda where the choir got its start, means "children" in Swahili, one of the most widely spoken languages in East Africa.

The choir is touring Taiwan at the invitation of World Vision Taiwan and is appearing in six cities between March 28 and April 6. After its performance in Hsinchu, the group will sing in Tainan on April 4 and Kaohsiung on April 5 before ending its tour in Yilan on April 6.

World Vision Taiwan President Hank Du said more than 25 million people around the world have died of AIDS, leaving 15 million children orphaned, which is why World Vision had launched the program it calls "HOPE" to promote AIDS prevention and concern for AIDS orphans.
According to Du, the Watoto Children's Choir, which has performed at the White House, first visited Taiwan in 2006 and received considerable public acclaim.
On Tuesday, the children of the choir visited Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-tzer and did their best to use chopsticks in enjoying a lunch featuring Hsinchu delicacies.
"Wherever there are children, it is paradise," Lin said. "If there are children, there is hope."
For his part, Du expressed gratitude to Lin for his interest in the AIDS issue and his support for the Watoto Children's Choir concert.

DOC.HEADLINE: First foreign bank branch opens in Taitung

TEXT.P: Dutch bank ABN AMRO opened an outlet in the southeastern Taiwan county of Taitung Tuesday, making it the first foreign bank to set up a branch in the county.
ABN AMRO acquired all 32 branches of the Taitung Business Bank last September after it won a government bid for the troubled lender.
The ABN AMRO Taitung branch is marking the opening with an event that features an art exhibition and free health checks for members of the public, a bank official said.

The bank and its employees also donated a total of NT$1.6 million (US$52,773.93) in cash to St. Mary's Hospital in Taitung in an effort to help address the problem of insufficient medical resources in the county, the official said.
St. Mary's hospital, founded in 1953 by a group of missionaries and nurses from the Swiss Confederation, serves as a major medical center for Taitung residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese scientist awarded membership in prestigious Russian academy

TEXT.P: The Russian Academy of Engineering Sciences has selected a geoscientist from the Taoyuan-based National Central University (NCU) as a foreign member, marking the second time that a Taiwanese scholar was awarded such a prestigious title, NCU said Wednesday.
According to a statement issued by the university, Professor Liou
Yuei-an was notified of the honor by the academy in mid-February and has accepted an invitation to attend the award ceremony in the Russian capital of Moscow in May.
Tsai Chen-shui, an Academia Sinica member and a professor at National Taiwan University, in 2001 became the first Taiwanese member of the 900-member Russian academy.

Liou said in a press interview that he was "surprised" at the news of the award, and he thanked the Cabinet-level National Science Council and the government- funded National Space Organization for their support over the years.
Liou, the sitting director of NCU's Center for Space and Remote Sensing Research, specialized in the areas of remote sensing and atmospheric science research, according to the statement.

Liou, aged 45, earned two master's degrees and two doctorates from the University of Michigan in six years. After graduation, he joined the NCU faculty and participated in various satellite observation projects, including France's SPOT, Germany's CHAMP, LANDSAT and GPS/ Met of the United States, and Taiwan's FORMOSAT-2 and FORMOSAT-3.

Liu and his team at NCU developed an innovative technique in the process -- radio occultation observation -- in which the researchers first record the signals sent by a global positioning system (GPS) and the signals received by low Earth orbit satellites, and then compare the variances in two sets of data to reconstruct the atmospheric conditions and gravitational waves in the transmission pathway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office dismisses allegations over CAL's aircraft deal

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office on Tuesday rebutted reports that the office had tried to orchestrate a major aircraft purchase deal by China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's largest air carrier, before the March 22 presidential election.
"The reports were by no means true," the office said in a statement, adding that the deal was "strictly CAL's business considerations, which had nothing to do with the Presidential Office."
The office said it regretted the "groundless" and "irresponsible" reports, especially because the reporters had not checked with the Presidential Office first.

The office was responding to reports by "Next," a weekly magazine which said CAL Chairman Ringo Chao hastily inked a NT$120 billion (US$3.97 billion) agreement on Jan. 25 to buy 20 A350-900 aircrafts from European manufacturer Airbus, although the aircraft is still under development and will not be delivered until 2015.
CAL has confirmed it has signed a deal to buy that many of the aircrafts from Airbus at the price reported.
Several opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers in the Legislative Yuan's transportation committee on Wednesday criticized the deal.

KMT Legislator Chen Keng-teh asked why the CAL paid a down payment of 20 percent, or around NT$27 billion, instead of the usual 3 percent, adding that "it is a reasonable doubt that the money is a form of kickback."

Another KMT legislator Huang Chao-hsun questioned why the final deal inked was NT$16 billion more expensive than the highest price CAL would pay, according to guidelines set by former CAL Chairman Philip Wei.

Oliver Yu, Transportation and Communications vice minister who concurrently serves as a board director of China Aviation Development Foundation, CAL's largest shareholder, said at the committee meeting that CAL submitted the proposed deal last December to be considered at a foundation board meeting, which was presided by Tsai Duei, who is Transportation and Communications minister and chairman of the foundation.
The meeting, after affirming CAL's need to upgrade its fleet and maintenance capacity, "respected the airline's professional decision and approved the deal," Yu said.
Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Billy Chang also said the administration agreed to CAL's plan to phase out its aging fleet.
But both of them said that they "were not aware of the financial arrangement in the deal."

The United Daily News, a mass-circulation local paper, quoted CAL Chairman Chao as saying Tuesday that the company's decision to buy from Airbus is because it offered better terms than Boeing, the U.S. aircraft manufacturer.
Chao said that Airbus could deliver the aircrafts in 2015, while Boeing's 787 planes will only be delivered in 2018.

Chao denied that the deal was more expensive than originally estimated, saying that the company has estimated that buying one A350 aircraft will save around US$5 million in fuel costs and loans a year.
The deal includes 14 firm orders with a further six on option for aircrafts with a capacity of approximately 366 seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of senior citizens in Taipei hits record high in 2007

TEXT.P: The number of people aged 65 and over continued to increase in Taipei City in 2007, reaching 314,515 as of the end of the year, according to figures released Wednesday by the city government.

The number marked an increase of 8,812 people, or 2.64 percent, from the year- earlier level, with the number of seniors as a percentage of the city's population rising to a record high of 11.96 percent.
The city's aging index -- the number of people aged 65 and over per every 100 people aged under 15 -- stood at 74.43 percent as of the end of 2007.

City government officials said that in order to cope with the obvious greying of the city's population, the government has been implementing measures to improve the welfare and services for senior citizens.
In 2007, the city government provided 193,607 household services and 41,038 daycare services to the elderly and issued gift money to 222,120 seniors, the officials said.

In addition, 7,229 seniors took part in activities organized by the city government for the elderly in 2007, while 917 seniors participated in 14 elderly volunteer service teams set up by the city government, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet reports on achievements in transportation, infrastructure

TEXT.P: The Cabinet on Wednesday issued a report on the achievements of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's ministries and agencies in charge of transportation and public infrastructure during the past eight years of DPP rule.

It was the first of a series of such reports on the accomplishments of the various ministries and agencies under the Executive Yuan to be issued over the coming weeks before the May 20 inauguration of Ma Ying-jeou from the opposition Kuomintang. Ma was elected in a decisive victory on March 22 as the next president.

Speaking with reporters, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said the Executive Yuan will issue reports on its administrative record in the areas of economics, finance, public security, education and culture, and governance during its final weeks.

Chang said the reports are being issued for three reasons -- to let the public know about the administration's achievements while in power, to provide a last chance for reflection before the transfer of power in May, and to reflect on whether the administration has come through on its promises, and if it hasn't done so in some instances, to examine the reasons for this.

Ministries and agencies in charge of transportation and public infrastructure, including the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior and the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, all have done an outstanding job in implementing President Chen Shui-bian's policies in these areas, Chang said.

Chang noted that during the DPP administration's eight years in power, the total length of Taiwan's freeways has increased by 127.3 percent, while the total miles of expressways that have been widened has increased by 427.57 percent.

He further said that following delays in its construction due to factors, including flooding, the Hsueshan Tunnel was finally opened in June 2006, becoming Southeast Asia's longest tunnel at 12. 9 kilometers.

The premier also noted that all sections of Taiwan's High Speed Railway came into operation on March 2, 2007, with the total number of passengers surpassing 19.6 million since its inauguration. He added that the railway has become one of Taiwan's main modes of long-distance travel and has provided a stimulus to the nation's overall economy.

On the tourism industry front, Chang said the government has invested a lot of resources over the past eight years to upgrade its quality. He added that the efforts have borne fruit, with the number of tourist arrivals jumping by 50 percent since 2000 when the DPP administration came to power.
He also noted that the administration has done a lot to improve the nation's water conservation, including establishing a Water Resource Agency as well as a committee to deal with related problems.

The administration has also carried out several flood-control projects, including a major project on the Keelung River, Chang noted. He added that the Keelung River project proved effective when Typhoon Nali hit the island, with over 1,000 hectares of land being spared from flooding because of the project.
Chang also pointed to the various "green area" projects launched by the administration over the years, which have helped improve the quality of life in communities around the nation.
He added that the administration allocated NT$16.18 billion on renewal projects in central and southern Taiwan to upgrade residential communities in those areas.

As part of efforts to improve the environment in townships and villages, the administration effectively utilized private investment to increase the water treatment facilities in these areas, noting that the ratio of households connected to sewage treatment systems increased from just 7.1 percent when the DPP came to power to 17.5 percent at present.

Chang also noted that rising construction material prices over the past year have presented the agencies in charge of public infrastructure development with a major challenge. In response, the Executive Yuan set up a task force on stabilizing prices as well as a construction material price adjustment mechanism to keep the impact of inflation to a minimum so that public infrastructure development projects could continue unimpeded.

In conclusion, the premier thanked the staff of the various ministries and agencies in charge of transportation and public infrastructure for their efforts and strong performance over the past eight years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group calls for focus on safety, happiness of children in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked 12th but did poorly in categories that assessed "happiness" and "safety, " compared to 21 advanced countries in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), a local child welfare promotion organization said Wednesday.

The Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF) called for President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and his incoming administration to fulfill their campaign promises of promoting child welfare afer they take office on May 20 as the non-governmental organization released a report on the state of local children.
"Children are the future of our country. Only by promoting the welfare of our children can we create a harmonious society with a brighter future," said CWLF Chairwoman Feng Yien.

The report, which was based on UNICEF's 2007 report on the welfare of children and a survey conducted in Taiwan last year, reviewed the state of Taiwan's children under five indices, namely economy, health, education, happiness and safety.
The results show that Taiwan, calculated along with the figures from the 21 OECD countries, ranked 12th overall, while Sweden, the Netherlands and Denmark, in that order, topped the list.

Taiwan lagged behind in the categories of "happiness" and "safety, "ranking 19th and 16th, respectively, an indication that much more could be done to make children in the country feel safer and more satisfied with their lives.

Only around 60 percent of the children in the survey said that they often have dinner with the whole family, which was lower than the average 78.5 percent among other countries and far below Italy's 93.8 percent.
Also, 21.7 percent of the children in Taiwan said that they often feel lonely -- a figure that shows the need for greater parental attention and companionship.
However, Taiwan ranked well in the "health" index, placing 3rd behind Sweden and Spain. The report indicated that most of the children in Taiwan eat fruits and have breakfast every day.

Chairwoman Feng offered six proposals under which the government could improve child welfare, including increasing the education budget, establishing a community care system for pregnant women and infants, and amending the Children's and Juvenile's Welfare Law every two or three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors begin probe into alleged irregularities in aircraft deal

TEXT.P: Prosecutors have begun a probe into suspected irregularities in a major aircraft purchase deal by China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's largest air carrier, the director of the Special Investigation Unit of the Supreme Prosecutors Office said Wednesday.

Chen Yun-nan said that after recent reports about possible irregularities involved in CAL's NT$120 billion (US$3.97 billion) deal with European aircraft manufacturer Airbus to buy 20 A350-900s, the unit has taken the initiative to conduct a probe.
"The prosecutors have questioned related personnel of CAL and China Aviation Development Foundation on the matter, " Chen said. The foundation is the largest shareholder of CAL.

His remarks came as the weekly magazine "Next" reported Wednesday that CAL Chairman Ringo Chao hastily signed a NT$120 billion agreement to buy the aircraft from European aircraft manufacturer Airbus although the aircraft is still under development and will not be delivered until 2015.
The deal was NT$16 billion more expensive than the highest price CAL would pay according to guidelines set by Philip Wei, former CAL chairman, the reports also said.

Chen said the prosecutors understand that 14 of the 20 aircrafts will be delivered starting 2015, which will phase out CAL's present six A340-300 passenger aircrafts. The deal also includes an option to buy a further six aircrafts.

Prosecutors have looked into related information provided by CAL and its foundations, and summoned personnel for questioning to see if the deal has run counter to normal practice, and are looking into whether the down payment is unusually high, Chen said.
"The prosecutors are looking along the line of breach of trust, dereliction of duty as well as embezzlement," Chen added.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators on Wednesday questioned the Transportation and Communications Vice Minister Oliver Yu and Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Billy Chang over the matter, but both of them said they "were not aware of the financial arrangement in the purchase deal."
Yu, a board director of China Aviation Development Foundation, said CAL submitted the proposed deal last December to be considered at a foundation board meeting.
The meeting respected CAL's professional decision and approved the deal, according to Yu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan qualified to be WHO observer: Cabinet spokesman

TEXT.P: Cabinet spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey reaffirmed Wednesday that Taiwan is qualified to join the World Health Organization (WHO) as an observer, adding that the issue of what name the country should use in its membership bid "is open to discussion."

Shieh made the remarks prior to the annual meeting of the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the WHO's governing body, scheduled to open May 19 in Geneva, one day before President-elect Ma Ying-jeou takes office.

Since 1997, Taiwan has been trying unsuccessfully to obtain observer status at the WHA. Last year, the government changed its policy and applied for formal membership of the WHO, a move that was opposed by the United States, the European Union and Japan.

Raymond Burghardt, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, reiterated last week during a visit to Taiwan that the U.S supports WHA observer status for Taiwan but opposes its application for WHO membership.
Taiwan was forced to leave the United Nations and subsequently all U.N.-affiliated organizations such as the WHO when the People's Republic of China was admitted to the U.N. in 1971.

Commending Taiwan on its contributions to world health and describing them as important and remarkable, Shieh said that "without Taiwan's participation in the WHO, the network of epidemic prevention and control around the world will be inadequate."

He said the casualties caused by the 2003 outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) could have been reduced if Taiwan had been part of the international health network, as it would have enabled the country to receive more medical aid and get better and quicker access to the most up-to-date information on the disease.
According to the Department of Health under the Executive Yuan, 664 SARS cases were reported, 73 of which proved fatal, in the 2003 outbreak.

Shieh continued that this year, work on Taiwan's attempt to join the WHO is already under way and added that "our goal will not be changed" despite the new administration set to take the reins of power May 20.
The government will continue preparatory work for Taiwan's participation in the WHO, regardless of the Cabinet resignation that will take place in mid-May, Shieh said.

As for the name Taiwan intends to use for the WHO membership application, Shieh said it will depend on the decision of President Chen Shui-bian and the relevant government organizations, including the Presidential Office, the National Security Council, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Government Information Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG We have created human-animal embryos already, say British team Embryos containing human and animal material have been created in Britain for the first time, a month before the House of Commons votes on new laws to regulate the research.

DOC.HEADLINE: Heart broken DPP stalwart allegedly self-immolates

TEXT.P: A stalwart supporter of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) allegedly committed suicide Wednesday by setting himself afire in an apparent expression of grief and indignation over the party's loss in two major elections this year, sources close to the DPP said.

Liao Shu-hsin, 45, director of the Taipei operation of Voice of the Ocean -- an underground pro-independence radio station headquartered in Taichung, central Taiwan -- was found dead in a fire at his office in Hsinchuang, Taipei County around 1 a.m. Wednesday.
Taipei County police said they have launched an investigation into the case to find out why and how Liao died.

Chang Chih-mei, CEO of Voice of the Ocean, said the radio station is opposed to Liao's extreme means of expressing his anger and indignation, but added that the station will do whatever it can to help Liao's family in the wake of the tragic incident.

Chang said that Liao had been in low spirits ever since the DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh lost the election to his Kuomintang (KMT) rival Ma Ying- jeou on March 22 on the heels of the DPP's crushing defeat in the Jan. 12 legislative polls.
"Liao also made a will after the elections, anticipating that the dream of building a 'Republic of Taiwan' had become even more distant," Chang said.
He added that many supporters of and listeners to Voice of the Ocean have shaved their heads in an expression of their grief and anger over the DPP election losses.

At a news conference Wednesday, DPP caucus whip William conveyed condolences to Liao's family over his supposed self-immolation, and urged the party's supporters to "look forward" and to view the results and process of the just- concluded presidential election as a victory for Taiwan's democratization, rather than a failure on the part of any individual.
Lai promised that "the DPP will rise again and return to power and will build Taiwan into a normal, independent nation."
He urged all friends of the DPP to join the party's "comeback" efforts, and to definitely avoid any extreme actions to hurt themselves.

In a statement released Wednesday, the DPP caucus attributed Liao's alleged suicide to three possible reasons -- worry that the incoming KMT government will suppress "freedom of speech" in Taiwan, indignation over governmental efforts to crack down on underground broadcasting stations, and the DPP's bruising defeat in the presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suhua expressway plan should be decided by new Cabinet: CEPD

TEXT.P: Chang Ching-sen, the vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , surprised a confirmation meeting on the construction plan of the Suao-Hualien expressway held Wednesday by abruptly suggesting that the controversial plan should be left to the new Cabinet.
"The caretaker government should not deprive the new government that will take office in May of its decision-making right, " said Chang during the meeting.
The construction of a Suao-Hualien expressway was a campaign promise of President Chen Shui-bian in 2000.
Despite also being one of the proposed expressway's environmental impact assessment (EIA) subcommittee members, Chang has very seldom attended any EIA meetings.
He added that the National Expressway Engineering Bureau (NEEB) should amend its construction plan and hand it over to the new Cabinet after May 20, when the new administration takes office.

He also questioned the transport-handling capacity of the expressway and the budget for the plan, which has been increased to about NT$12.95 billion instead of the original NT$9.3 billion due to the rising price of raw materials. This, he noted, will result in a drop in the benefit-cost ratio.

Leaving in the middle of the meeting, Chang told reporters that his remarks, which left the expressway plan in an uncertain situation, were his personal opinions and do not necessarily represent the government's position.
Describing Chang's remarks as "moral and conscientious, " Lin Su-zhen, another subcommittee member, said however that the CEPD should have shown its position earlier.
Asked if the government intends to leave the controversial issue to the new Cabinet, Lin said there is "reasonable doubt" that this is the case.
After two-and-a-half hours of discussion, the EIA subcommittee, judging the documents and data insufficient, demanded that the NEEB complete its report on the construction plan.
It was unclear whether the EIA subcommittee will be convened before or after May 20.

Some subcommittee members also challenged the necessity of the expressway, saying that the NEEB did not make sufficient investigations and assessments of the site, such as geological conditions, security systems and potential for traffic jams, as well as the impact on the lives of the people in the area, many of whom are aborigines.
The 86-km expressway connecting Suao and Hualien along the eastern coast of Taiwan, is designed to boost the economy of the poorest region of the island.

Environmentalists say the construction, estimated to take eight to 10 years to complete, might have a negative impact on the ecology of the region and that the expressway, with 40 km of tunnels, might be dangerous because of its proximity to fault lines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most children feel happiest in parents' company: survey

TEXT.P: Some 60.7 percent of local children who responded to a recent survey said their happiest moments are when they are in their parents' company, according to the survey results released Wednesday.

The survey on children's attitudes toward happiness and money was conducted by international financial conglomerate Citigroup and the If children's theater company among students at 32 elementary school in Taipei, Hsinchu and Kaohsiung cities and counties, plus Taichung City, with 2,437 valid samples collected.

Good health was named by 52.1 percent of the respondents as the thing that makes them happiest, while 10.7 percent cited travel overseas and just 8.3 percent cited wealth, according to the survey results.

Hsinchu County had the highest percentage -- 66.7 percent of the respondents -- who said they feel happiest when they are with their parents, while nobody in the county said that having a lot of money would make them happier.
The results also show that 58.5 percent of the respondents receive an allowance from their parents, with a majority getting less than NT$100 each week.

Hsinchu County had the highest ratio of respondents who said they manage their finances, with 38.9 percent doing book-keeping, compared with 21 percent -- the lowest percentage of the regions covered -- in Taipei County.

Meanwhile, most of the Hsinchu respondents said they spend less than 30 percent of their allowance on eating and entertainment, and save the rest or use it to buy stationery and books. In comparison, more than 50 percent of the respondents in Taipei County said they spend most of their allowance on entertainment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Quit smoking campaign to kick off

TEXT.P: The International Quit and Win 2008 campaign will start May 2, with a top prize of NT$600,000 (US$19,750) waiting for smokers who kick the habit, officials of the Bureau of Health Promotion (BHP) said Wednesday.
The biennial International Quit and Win competition was initiated in 1994 by the National Public Health Institute of Finland and is supported by the World Health Organization (WHO).
Taiwan first joined the competition in 2002, with each contest receiving a warm response from the public over the years.
The event in Taiwan is organized by the John Tung Organization, a local non- profit organization for tobacco control, and the BHP under the Cabinet-level Department of Health.
The officials said at a press conference that participants who succeed in stopping smoking for the four weeks from May 2 will have the chance to win prizes through a lucky draw.
The campaign is open to adults older than 18 who have smoked for more than a year, with each participant requiring one person to serve as his or her witness.
Actor Ho Hao-chieh and his entertainer wife He Jia Xin attended the press conference with their son, becoming the first couple to register their participation in the contest.
Ho said he wanted to quit smoking for the health of their son, who has allergy problems.
"Besides, smoking is quite money-consuming, " Ho said, admitting that the NT$600,000 prize is very attractive.

Sun Yueh, a famous entertainer and a permanent volunteer of the John Tung Foundation who was once a heavy smoker, noted that there are some 4 million smokers in Taiwan and that he believes their families all hope they will quit smoking.
Sun urged all smokers to quit the habit "for the people they love."
Anyone interested in taking part in the contest should register before May 1 and can visit the competition's Web site at www.e-quit.org for more information, the organizer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Israeli drama to be staged in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The first Israeli drama to be presented in Taiwan -- a contemporary version of Sophocles' Antigone -- will be staged at the National Theater in Taipei April 3, April 5 and April 6, Hsieh Tsui-yu, deputy director of the National Chiang Kai- shek Cultural Center, announced Wednesday.

The Antigone is a joint production of Habimah National Theatre of Israel and Cameri Theatre of Tel Aviv, and is adapted from a Greek tragedy by Sophocles written in 422 BC. It is directed by Hanan Snir, one of Israel's most prominent directors who uses a mixture of modern and ancient techniques in the presentation.

Noting that the show is the first cooperation project between the National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center, which manages the National Theater and the National Concert Hall, and Israel in 21 years, Hsieh said he hopes it "will bring a new experience to all our audiences."
"Those who deeply love drama cannot miss it, " Hsieh said at a rehearsal press conference at the National Theater.

Referring to the program as the fruits of a visit to Israel by Ping Heng, a former artistic director of the center, Israeli representative to Taiwan, Raphael Gamzou, said he hoped "there will be more fruits in Taiwan in the future."

Because the Antigone underlines the consequences of the deed of a leader on other people's lives, Gamzou said, "this is a very good example of cultural exchanges in our (Israeli) democracy and in your (Taiwanese) democracyKespecially in this fascinatingly political season in your democracy."
He added that it also reflects the need for the leader of a nation to be accountable.
The presentation of the Hebrew version of Antigone with Chinese subtitles is part of the National Theater's International Theater Festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet approves WTO plan to provide cheap drugs to poor nations

TEXT.P: The government approved an amendment Wednesday to a World Trade Organization (WTO) agreement that would waive property rights and thus allow underdeveloped countries access to cheaper generic drugs for fatal diseases such as AIDS.

The Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) Council under the WTO had a proposed compulsory licensing system to authorize pharmaceutical companies in eligible WTO member states to manufacture and export cheaper generic drugs to less developed nations, without having to pay the patent holders.

The WTO's General Council has asked all its members nations to obtain approval by their own lawmakers and to notify the WTO no later than December 31, 2009, in order to make the pharmaceutical products available to less developed countries that have inadequate funds and medical capacity to deal with fatal diseases.
Taiwan, Singapore, South Korea and some other countries have decided not to take advantage of the concession, except in cases of national emergency.

Citing the need to play a responsible role in the international community, the Cabinet urged that the Legislative Yuan to pass the amendment, following the Cabinet's approval of the plan Wednesday at its weekly meeting.

"With its capability to assist other WTO members, Taiwan should serve the international community by passing the amendment, a gesture that could also boost the country's status, " said Premier Chang Chun-hsiung.

The Legislature will first have to approve the amendment, then Taiwan's patent regulations will also have to be revised to waive the intellectual property rights on certain drugs, before Taiwan can notify the WTO of its formal adoption of the measure.
In 2007, Canada became the first member state to notify the WTO of its compulsory license to export generic drugs to Rwanda for AIDS treatment.

The WTO decided to implement paragraph 6 of the 2001 Doha Declaration on the TRIPS agreement and Public Health in 2003, with the aim of helping to provide treatment in less developed countries for life threatening diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: More free copying machines to be offered on 100 university campuses

TEXT.P: Some 1 million students attending 100 local universities will be able to use copying machines free of charge by the end of this year under the sponsorship of various local companies, a spokesman for a local advertising company said Tuesday.

At present, Impress Technology Ltd. Corp. has installed copying machines at 40 colleges in northern and central Taiwan to provide free services to students, said Luis Lu, president of the Taipei-based company.

Describing the free copying machines as a mutually beneficial marketing strategy between consumers, advertisers and the company, Lu said that each sheet of copying paper provided in the machines carries a full-color advertisement on one side from the company's advertisers, whose target customers are aged 18-24.
Lu said the company copied the new marketing strategy from Japan, where the strategy has become very popular since 2005 when some Japanese college students came up with the idea.

Lu said that in Japan, some vending machines provide free coffee or other beverages to consumers after an infrared scanner confirms that they have watched a 30-second commercial played on a screen mounted in the machines.
Lu noted that in just the past two weeks, 200,000 sheets of the free copying paper have been used by local college students.
Tsai Wen-bin, head of a student association at National Taiwan Normal University, told local newspapers that he and his peers have found the marketing idea "very attractive."
"The only downside is that these free sheets cannot be used to print official documents or reports because of the advertisements on the back," Tsai pointed out.
The copying cost for an A4-sized sheet of blank paper is NT$0.7 at schools, NT$1 at copying stores and NT$2 at convenience stores.
Taiwan has an estimated 164 universities with a combined 1.32 million students.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic minister not to resign over fuel price hike controversy

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen said Wednesday that he would not resign over a controversy about whether a price freeze on the state oil company should be removed to allow it to hike the price of its products after its private rival did so last week.
Chen made the announcement while fielding reporters' questions after a weekly meeting at the Executive Yuan.

Chen stressed that he will serve in his post until May 19, the day before Taiwan's new president will be inaugurated, because he wanted to avoid further complications in a matter that has turned into a political issue after the March 22 presidential election.
"I have not offered to resign as a way to settle the issue. Besides, communications between the Executive Yuan and the MOEA remain smooth," he said.

According to Chen, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) had, prior to the election, suggested the Executive Yuan allow CPC Corp., Taiwan to raise its product prices to reflect its costs due to skyrocketing crude oil prices in international market.
But all the political parties asked for a freeze on the company's prices at that time, and "that's the reason why the MOEA ordered a freeze late last year on the company's pricing," he explained.
The MOEA in November 2007 ordered the price freeze in an effort to curb inflationary pressures, particularly as the legislative and presidential elections were approaching.

The state-owned oil supplier adopted a floating pricing mechanism in January 2007 under which it adjusted its domestic fuel prices on a weekly basis in response to international crude oil price fluctuations. The system was replaced by a monthly adjustment mechanism last September.

Despite the fact that the MOEA has after the presidential race twice suggested the Executive Yuan remove the cap on the company, Chen said his ministry has to respect the decision made by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to maintain the cap.

Premier Chang said a day earlier that the Executive Yuan decided to maintain the state oil provider's product prices at their current levels in April, but whether it will continue doing so in May will depend on market conditions at that time.

Earlier Wednesday, a group of the KMT's legislative caucus members called a news conference at the Legislative Yuan urging the MOEA to re-impose the floating oil pricing system by working out complementary measures, including subsidies for public transportation systems, within two days.

As a result of the freeze on CPC Corp.'s product prices, the state oil company is set to incur a loss of about NT$7.5 billion (US$227 million) per month, acting KMT legislative caucus whip Hsieh Kuo-liang said.

KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao contended that the company must not continue with the price caps, arguing that there is no reason why the whole society should suffer to spare vehicle drivers of price hikes.

According to Lai, the reason why the lawmakers made a resolution late last year demanding that CPC Corp. not further hike its product prices was because the state company had hit its government-set target of earnings. The company earned NT$11.4 billion for the whole of last year, he noted.

Formosa Petrochemical Corp., Taiwan's biggest private refiner, increased the price of its gasoline and diesel products by NT$2.8 per liter and NT$3.1 per liter, respectively, beginning March 29, in response to rising costs. The price increases will remain in effect until the end of April, the company said.
The price hike by Formosa Petrochemical has driven many car drivers to purchase oil at CPC Corp. gasoline stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum to display paintings by Chang Da-chien

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum has put on display 10 selected paintings of internationally acclaimed modern Chinese artist Chang Da-chien (1899-1983) from April 2 to June 25 to commemorate the 25th anniversary of his passing.
Visitors can see Chang's works on the second floor in the west wing of the museum. The paintings include a self-portrait of Chang, which he painted on his 75th birthday.

Also on display is a colossal work, "Panorama of Mount Lu," which Chang began to paint three years before he died but left unfinished. The ambitious work, measuring nearly two meters high and 10 meters long, incorporates a range of styles that Chang had mastered in his lifetime. Although one-fifth of the painting was left undone, it is still considered one of his finest works.

The museum also opened Chang's former residence in Waishuanghsi, a northern suburb of Taipei, to the public. The place has been named the Chang Da-chien Memorial Hall, with the adjoining garden being Chang's final resting place.

Chang, who wore a long beard and carried a walking stick wherever he went, created an image of himself as "an ancient figure in a modern time." He has been hailed as one of the greatest Chinese artists in modern times.

Chang was born into a wealthy family on May 10, 1899 in Szechuan province, China. He briefly entered a Buddhist monastery before beginning serious study of Chinese calligraphy and painting at the age of 19.

After a three-year stay in Japan with his brother to learn commercial weaving and textile dyeing, Chang settled in Shanghai in 1919 to study under prominent artists Tseng Hsi (1861-1930) and Li Jui-ching (1867-1920) . He not only learned painting techniques from the two teachers, but also developed his talent in calligraphy and poetry.

In his early years as an artist, he trained himself by copying the works of renowned masters before he was able to develop his own style and bring fresh, innovative elements into traditional Chinese painting.

His first exhibition of 100 paintings in 1926 was a great success. In 1939, while China was waging a war against Japanese aggression, he went to the remote desert outpost of Tunhuang in Gansu province, where he spent more than two years copying the legendary murals in the Caves of the Thousand Buddhas.

At the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949, Chang traveled between Hong Kong, Taiwan, India and Argentina before he and his family settled down on a farm outside Sao Paolo, Brazil in 1954. From there, he traveled frequently to major cities in the United States Europe and Asia to exhibit his paintings.
He moved from Brazil to California in 1967 and lived there for eight years before relocating to Taiwan in 1977 and lived in Taipei until his passing at 84.

In his later years, he combined a unique splashed-ink technique with the masterly texture strokes of his early years in his works. The prolific artist left behind some 5,000 paintings, with the motifs ranging from figures, birds and flowers to landscapes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to celebrate ICFD, provide better facilities for cyclists

TEXT.P: The Department of Transportation (DOT) of the Taipei city government opened a workshop Wednesday that focused on preparations for International Car Free Day (ICFD), and vowed to build a friendlier environment for cyclists in the Taiwan capital.
In preparation for ICFD, which will be observed on September 22, DOT officials reported at the workshop on a series of projects linked to the international event.

"We don't want to limit ICFD as a one-day activity -- it should be a day when people try to take more environmentally friendly actions in general, " said DOT Director Luo Shiaw-shyan, who presided over the workshop. He also suggested that it should be a day when people vow to better protect the environment.

On ICFD, the use of private vehicles will be limited to some busy areas and everyone will be allowed to take public transportation for free, so as to encourage people to help reduce air pollution, a DOT official said.
The DOT also announced a series of projects, such as the construction of additional bike paths in Taipei, to encourage more cycling.
The DOT said it is undertaking a "rent-a-bike" program similar to that in Paris, where there are more than 20,600 bicycles available for rent around the clock at 1,451 stations.

Luo said the DOT plans to build more bicycle lanes in the city, and he called for more people to choose bicycles over fuel-consuming vehicles as their means of travel. An exclusive bicycle path will be built along Dunhua North and South Roads in the downtown area in 2008, he said.
In Taipei city, 39.9 km of bike-pedestrian paths and 18.6 km of exclusive bike paths were in service at the end of 2007, the DOT noted.
The department hopes to build 40.5 km of bike-pedestrian paths and 9.5 km of exclusive bike paths in 2008, and in three years time to have a total of 150 km of bike paths in service, Luo said.

He added that international visitors to the 2009 Summer Deaflympics and the 2010 International Flower Exposition, which are both to be held in Taipei, will be able to utilize the rent-a-bike program and ride along the new paths.

ICFD, initiated in the 1990s in Europe, was adopted by the Taipei City government in 2002, with the participation of 3,000 people. Its objective is to raise awareness of air pollution, reduce greenhouse gas effects and promote the use of public transportation.

In 2007, the number of participants in ICFD rose to 65,000, and the utility rate of public transportation in Taipei City for that year rose to 48.3 percent from 37.8 percent in 2002, according to the DOT.
"We hope that the ICFD will become a movement in Taipei in the future," said Luo.

DOC.HEADLINE: Task force asked to assess countermeasures to price hikes

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung ordered relevant government agencies Wednesday to submit an assessment to the Executive Yuan next week of feasible measures to help low-income families tackle rising product prices.

Chang issued the order while presiding over a meeting of a product price stabilization task force under the Executive Yuan. Officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Fair Trade Commission reported on the rising costs of raw materials and their efforts to prevent hoarding and price manipulations in the local market.

As global research has found that consumer product prices will continue to climb this year at a faster pace than last year, the relevant government authorities must keep a close watch and come up with effective measures to help the underprivileged combat increasing product prices, although those prices have remained relatively stable in Taiwan, Chang said.

According to the premier, the authorities concerned were asked to present the key report following a similar program launched last week by the South Korean government which banned price hikes on 52 basic items, including eggs, cooking oil and bread.
According to a foreign wire service report, fighting inflationary pressure is the top priority of the South Korean government led by President Lee Myung-bak, who took office only a month ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan faces four potential crises: legislative speaker

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that the incoming administration of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou will face four crises, including a dire financial situation.
Wang made the remarks while addressing a seminar for CEOs in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, at the invitation of the Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission.

In addition to the present ethnic divisions, tense cross-strait relations, bipartisan squabbling and slow economic development, the nation also faces several crises that pose potential threats to its development, Wang said.
He said that since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took office in 2000, Taiwan's economic development has stalled.
Taiwan has slipped to last place among the "four dragons," he said, referring to Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea as the other three dragons.
But at a time of stalled economic development and drastic decreases in tax revenues, the government's debts have continued to climb, he said.
"Each citizen had to shoulder nearly NT$200,000 (US$5,520) in government debts, " Wang said, adding that the nation is in dire financial straits.

With slower economic development, local investors have become more guarded, unemployment remains high, and the gap between rich and poor has widened, he said, adding that Taiwan is becoming an "M-shaped society."
The jobless rate remains between 3 and 4 percent, and consumers are becoming more cautious in their spending, an attitude that he said will impact on domestic demand as people become poorer.
The last factor is that the nation risks being marginalized in international community, Wang said, noting that since 2000, politics has taken precedence in public life.

The DPP administration has promoted crafting a new constitution, renamed state- own enterprises to drop "China" from their titles, removed statues of the late President Chiang Kai-shek and other legacies of his rule, and promoted referendums for U.N. membership under the name Taiwan, he stated.
"These acts have more or less resulted in shrinking international support for Taiwan," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 stray dogs fly to new homes in U.S.

TEXT.P: Thanks to the concerted efforts of local and U.S. animal rights activists, 15 disabled stray dogs left Taiwan for the United States Wednesday aboard a China Airlines (CAL) plane to find new homes and build new lives.

"It marked the largest single shipment of stray dogs from Taiwan to the United states for adoption in recent memory," said Ni Ching-tai, an Animal Rescue Team Taiwan (ARTT) volunteer who is in charge of the team's cross-border stray-dog adoption affairs.
All of the dogs were physically disabled strays that were rescued by ARTT volunteers from around the country, Ni said, adding that each of them had a miserable past and needed good care.

According to Ni, the 15 dogs will first stay at shelters run by animal rights groups in Los Angeles and Seattle, on arrival in the United States. After they get accustomed to the new living environment, animal rights groups will arrange for them to be adopted by pet-loving American families.
The ARTT mobilized more than 50 volunteers to help prepare for the delivery and China Airlines offered a 50 percent discount on the freight fares.
Over the past three years, Ni said, the ARTT and its American counterparts have jointly arranged for 600-plus stray dogs rescued from around Taiwan to find new homes on the U.S. West Coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police bust car theft ring, arrest 17 suspects

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau announced Tuesday that police have busted a car theft ring and arrested 17 suspects after storming 12 automotive service shops and junkyards in central and southern Taiwan in the past few days.

A spokesman for the bureau said various police units joined the operation to raid the crime syndicate's establishments in Taichung City, and in the counties of Tainan, Yunlin and Chiayi. Police officers seized 11 stolen cars, 50 car computers, two car engines and a range of automotive parts from stripped cars.

According to the spokesman, the car theft ring was led by a man identified as Weng Hung-jung. The members of the ring would only steal expensive models valued at over NT$3 million, such as Porche, Lexus, Mercedes-Benz and BMW.

The criminals would contact the owners of the stolen cars and ask them to pay large sums of money to have their vehicles back. If the owners refused to comply, the thieves would strip the cars, sell the usable parts and get rid of the rest as scrap metal.
An initial investigation showed that the car theft ring stole hundreds of expensive cars in the past year and made an illegal profit of more than NT$10 million (US$330,085).
The 17 suspects, some of whom are used car dealers and owners of auto parts stores, will be referred to the Public Prosecutors Office in Tainan and charged with theft.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Hsinchu International Glass Art Festival to close April 20

TEXT.P: The 2008 Hsinchu International Glass Art Festival being held at the Hsinchu City Glass Museum will close April 20 and those who have not seen the exhibition should grasp the final opportunity, the Bureau of Cultural Affairs under the Hsinchu City Government said Tuesday.
The biennial event is sponsored by the city government. The theme of this year's festival is "Mermaids Touring the Glass Fairyland, " with more than 100 works featuring the motif on display.

In addition to works of the mermaid motif by local artists, the exhibition include 50 glass masterpieces by artists from 10 countries, including the United States, Germany, Italy, Britain, Australia, Israel, India and Japan.
There is also a Year of the Rat Exhibit, featuring works by prominent local artists.
The Glass Industry Promotion Hall is also displaying some 500 glass products by over 30 domestic companies.
Visitors will have the opportunity to watch the artists work on weekends. They will also have hands-on opportunities to create their own glassworks and take them home.
Hsinchu, which has dubbed itself the "city of culture and science, " has organized the biennial events since 1995. The 2006 festival attracted more than 410,000 visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP head suggests moving forward party chair election to May 18

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh suggested Wednesday that the election of new party head be moved up one week to avoid a leadership vacuum when his term expires on May 20.

Hsieh, the defeated DPP candidate in the March 22 presidential poll, suggested at a regular meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee that the DPP chairmanship election be held on May 18 instead of May 25 as previously scheduled.
He said that this will allow for a "seamless transition" and will avoid a situation of the party being without a leader in the period between May 20 and May 25.
Hsieh reiterated that he will not stand for election, and he advised other party officials, including DPP Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan, not to compete for the post.

"If incumbent party officials want to run, they should quit their posts immediately," Hsieh said, noting that "these same officials are the ones who have to deal with election matters and it would therefore be hard for them to remain strictly impartial."
"It is not my duty to persuade or dissuade anyone from running for the position," Hsieh said, noting that he is now a "caretaker" chairman.
He made the comment in response to a suggestion by DPP
legislative caucus whip Ker Chien-ming that the party should
nominate a candidate through consultations.

Hsieh also suggested that more people be allowed to vote in the chairmanship election, saying that members aged 18-35 should be allowed to take part in the poll even if they have not been in the party for a year. The DPP charter stipulates that members are eligible to vote only if they have been in the party for at least one year. enditem/ pc

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT vice chairman denies 'testing the waters' report

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman John Kuan denied Wednesday a media report that his upcoming visit to China is aimed at exploring the bottom line of Beijing's Taiwan policy when the KMT returns to power in May.
"The report carried in the latest issue of Next weekly magazine was not true and has caused me some confusion," Kuan said in a press statement.

Kuan said he is indeed scheduled to head an academic delegation to visit Shanghai in mid-April for scholastic exchanges, but he stressed that he has not been authorized by the party's president-elect Ma Ying-jeou to contact any Chinese authorities.
"I have received no authorization from Ma to hold talks with China on any issues on his behalf," Kuan said in the press statement, adding that his China visit has nothing to do with Ma.

Noting that he serves as president of an academic association dedicated to U.S. study which has maintained regular exchanges with Fadan University in Shanghai, Kuan said his upcoming visit is simply for the purpose of sharing views and ideas on academic topics. He also denied the Next magazine report that he will receive an honorary doctoral degree from Fudan University during his visit.

Ma scored a decisive victory in his race with Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the March 22 presidential poll, paving the way for the KMT to return to power after having been in opposition for eight years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't ready for partial opening of yuan conversion: MAC

TEXT.P: The government has completed preparations for a partial opening of cross-strait currency conversion, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Wednesday.

The nation's top China policy maker said a currency clearing and settlement mechanism agreement will have to be signed between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait before Taiwan can fully open up the exchange of yuan, the Chinese currency.
Given the political factors involved, "it will be difficult, although the government has made preparations," Chen said.

Chen's remarks came after President-elect Ma Ying-jeou pledged in an interview with Reuters earlier in the day to push for direct cross-strait charter flights on weekends and to open up Taiwan to Chinese tourists as soon as possible after he takes office on May 20.
To facilitate the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists, Ma said, he would promote a full conversion between the yuan and New Taiwan dollar before the end of this year.

When asked if Taiwan can unilaterally open for currency conversion before Taipei and Beijing sign a currency clearance and settlement mechanism agreement, Chen said currently overseas business units (OBUs) or distribution business units (DBUs) of foreign currency designated banks can accept yuan, but as the yuan is not a strong currency internationally, there is no reason to ask financial institutions to take possible currency exchange risks.
More importantly, Chen said, a full opening of yuan conversion in Taiwan will mean the exchange of huge sums of money, therefore "a currency clearance and settlement mechanism is essential."

But he said preparations for partial opening have been completed. If China is ready to allow its nationals to come to Taiwan for tourism, the government will have only to amend a cross-strait law, the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, to start the currency exchange in Taiwan proper.
Taiwan opened for yuan conversion in the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu on a trial basis in October 2005.
Chen estimated that if Taiwan allowed up to 1,000 Chinese tourists per day and each of them converted up to 20,000 yuans, that would be "within the range of control."
In the future, there will be yuan conversion counters at the airports, international hotels, major scenic spots and foreign currency exchange designated banks, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 3, or the 27th day of the second month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1859: The Hsiahai Chenghwang Temple, one of the oldest temples in Taiwan, is formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1881: Alcide de Gasperi, the Italian statesman who became prime minister in 1945 and led Italy during its successful post-war reconstruction, is born.
1882: Jesse James, head of the notorious outlaw James Gang and mastermind of countless bank and train robberies, is gunned down by Robert Ford, one of his own gang, at his home in St. Joseph, Missouri.
1897: German composer Johannes Brahms dies in Vienna at the age of 64. His works, which blended classical tradition with the new romantic impulse, include concertos, symphonies, chamber music, and choral compositions.
1898: Henry Luce, the American publisher who founded Time, Life, and Fortune magazines, is born.
1903: Chou Jung, author of "The Revolutionary Army," dies in jail in Shanghai at the age of 21.
1922: Joseph Stalin is appointed general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party.
1930: Helmut Kohl, the German chancellor who stayed in power for a record 16 years until his defeat by Gerhard Schroeder in 1998, is born.
1933: Four Britons in two Westland biplanes make the first flight over the peak of Mount Everest in the Himalayas.
1946: Directed by the Soviet Union, the so-called "Inner Mongolian Autonomy Movement Committee," is established in Chengteh, Jehol Province.
1948: US President Harry Truman signs the Marshall Plan, allocating US$6 billion in aid to 16 European countries to help reconstruction after World War II.
1962: President and Mme. Philbert Tsiranana of the Republic of Madagascar arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The Dalai Lama establishes a Tibetan office in New York.
1971: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with the Republic of Cameroon.
1973: The International Federation of Asian and Western Pacific Contractors Association opens its 12th convention in Taipei.
1975: S. K Chow, ROC minister of state, leaves for Riyadh to express the condolences of the Chinese government in the death of King Faisal.
1975: The Free China Relief Association marks its 25th anniversary.
1975: The ROC Control Yuan passes a resolution impeaching Hsu Chi-wei, commissioner of the Department of Education under the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1976: An 11-member Japanese Diet mission including former Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi, arrives in Taipei to mark the first anniversary of the death of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: Dr. Montanaro, Paraguayan minister of the Interior, arrives in Taipei for Chiang's memorial services.
1982: Bueno Aires celebrates the invasion of the Falkland Islands while the United Nations says Argentina must pull out.
1991: Martha Graham, American dancer and choreographer, dies at the age of 97. A central figure in modern dance, she founded the Dance Repertory Theatre in New York City in 1930.
1992: Two weeks after a non-communist parliament is elected, Albanian President Ramiz Alia resigns.
1996: A plane carrying US Commerce Secretary Ron Brown crashes in stormy weather on a hillside outside Dubrovnik, Croatia, killing all 33 aboard.
2000: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng says that the KMT has agreed to let Defense Minister Tang Fei serve as President-elect Chen Shui-bian's premier in his "personal capacity."
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and visiting Liberian President Charles Taylor signed a joint communique Tuesday calling on all nations to resolve international differences through dialogue, negotiations and other peaceful means.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man of strong, resolute, simple character approaches closely the true moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 stray dogs fly to new homes in U.S.

TEXT.P: Thanks to the concerted efforts of local and U.S. animal rights activists, 15 disabled stray dogs left Taiwan for the United States Wednesday aboard a China Airlines (CAL) plane to find new homes and build new lives.

"It marked the largest single shipment of stray dogs from Taiwan to the United states for adoption in recent memory," said Ni Ching-tai, an Animal Rescue Team Taiwan (ARTT) volunteer who is in charge of the team's cross-border stray-dog adoption affairs.
All of the dogs were physically disabled strays that were rescued by ARTT volunteers from around the country, Ni said, adding that each of them had a miserable past and needed good care.

According to Ni, the 15 dogs will first stay at shelters run by animal rights groups in Los Angeles and Seattle, on arrival in the United States. After they get accustomed to the new living environment, animal rights groups will arrange for them to be adopted by pet-loving American families.
The ARTT mobilized more than 50 volunteers to help prepare for the delivery and China Airlines offered a 50 percent discount on the freight fares.
Over the past three years, Ni said, the ARTT and its American counterparts have jointly arranged for 600-plus stray dogs rescued from around Taiwan to find new homes on the U.S. West Coast.
