DOC.HEADLINE: Scrapping Chiang-related holidays step to end personality cult: Chen

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday his administration's decision last year to abolish official observation of the birth and death of the late President Chiang Kai-shek was a step toward ending the personality cult that was prevalent during the authoritarian period of Taiwan's past.

Chen made the statement in an article published in the latest issue of his online newsletter, in which he commented on Tomb-Sweeping Day, which falls on April 4 this year and for the first time in more than 30 years has been separated from the commemoration of Chiang's death on April 5, 1975.

Chen pointed out that Tomb-Sweeping Day, which is one the 24 seasonal spells in the lunar year, is actually marked on the 105th day after the winter solstice on the lunar calendar and may therefore fall on April 4, April 5 or April 6 on the regular calendar.

However, Chen noted, in the 32 years since Chiang's death, Tomb-Sweeping Day in Taiwan has been observed on April 5 so as to coincide with the commemoration of Chiang's passing, a situation which the president said had "misled the public into thinking that the two events were concurrent."

"The practice of combining the authoritarian personality cult with a cultural holiday was not only diametric to our goal of ending single-party state and authoritarianism, but also triggered many controversies," Chen said.

With this in mind, the Ministry of the Interior last year abolished the official commemoration of Chiang's birth on Oct. 31 and his death on April 5, the president stated. The decision helped to restore Tomb-Sweeping Day as a purely civic festival during which the people remember their ancestors and family members who have passed on, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA warns not to fall for Congolese consul imposter

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) warned the general public Thursday to beware of a man who is claiming to be "a consul of the Democratic Republic of the Congo based in Taipei," stressing that Taiwan does not have diplomatic relations with the African country.

Liu Bang-zyh, deputy director-general of MOFA's Department of African Affairs said at a regular press briefing that the ministry had received several calls asking whether there was a Congolese embassy or consulate in Taiwan, as a man in Taipei had been professing to be a diplomat of the Western African country.
However, to date, there have been no reports of attempts by the man to defraud or swindle anyone.
"Taiwan and the Democratic Republic of the Congo do not have diplomatic relations, nor is there any official reciprocal representation, such as consulates, in either of the two countries," Liu noted.
He stressed that the Congolese government never sought the Taiwan government's approval to appoint anyone as an honorary consul in Taiwan, therefore the public should beware of an imposter.

Taiwan currently has 23 diplomatic allies, four of which are on the African continent. They are Burkina Faso, Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe, Kingdom of Swaziland and Republic of The Gambia.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP raps president-elect for rejecting 'Taiwan'

TEXT.P: A group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers lambasted President-elect Ma Ying-jeou Thursday over his reservations regarding the "Taiwan" mark on local postage stamps, and accused Ma of discarding the name "Taiwan" like "toilet paper" after using it to win the March 22 election.

The lawmakers were referring to a request by Ma of the Kuomintang (KMT) that the state postal company postpone the issuance of stamps to commemorate his May 20 inauguration on grounds that the "Taiwan" mark on the stamps is "controversial" and that "Taiwan" is not the country's official name. The DPP legislators noted that Ma had no such reservations when he used the slogan "Taiwan marches forward" in his election campaign.

The state-owned post office has been printing "Taiwan" in Chinese and English, instead of the country's official name, "Republic of China, " on its postage stamps since February 2007 when its name was changed from "Chunghwa Post Co." to "Taiwan Post Co."

The change was made as part of the DPP administration's efforts to revise the names of state-owned enterprises that contained references to China to avoid confusion with similarly named organizations in China. "Chunghwa" means "Chinese" or "China" in the Chinese language.

Expressing regret and surprise at Ma's decision on the commemorative stamps, the DPP lawmakers asked whether he would rename everything that included the word "Taiwan" in its title, after his inauguration.

"Does the word 'Taiwan' sound so unpleasant to the ears? How is it that Ma, before the election, claimed he would do anything for Taiwan but is taking a different stance now that the election is over?" asked DPP Legislator Chen Ting- fei.

Yeh Yi-jin, a DPP legislative caucus whip, argued that the the DPP administration's decision to rename "Chunghwa Post Co." was aimed at protecting national interests, although the move was criticized by the KMT as catering to the DPP's pro-Taiwan independence ideology.

If the incoming KMT administration led by Ma were to restore the company's original name to uphold the party's "great China" ideology, the KMT would be making the very mistake it attributed to the DPP, Yeh said.
"We urge the KMT to be consistent," Yeh said.

During a recent interview with the media after his election, Ma argued that Chunghwa Post Co.'s name change was "unlawful" because it had not been processed though the required legal channels, a statement that gave rise to speculations that the new government might restore the company's original name.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA urges South Africa-bound passengers to stay vigilant

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Thursday warned passengers bound for South Africa to be extra vigilant regarding their personal safety as public security in the African country has been deteriorating.

There have been recent reports of several diplomats and tourists being tailed and robbed upon arrival in South Africa, said Liu Bang-zyh, deputy director- general of MOFA's Department of African Affairs.

"Because the South African government still has not initiated any measures to efficiently counter the escalation of crime, the government of the United States has also been considering issuing a travel advisory to its citizens," he said.
"Although a yellow-level travel advisory has not yet been issued for travelers going to South Africa, Taiwanese visitors to the country should pay attention to personal safety," he advised.

Liu noted that the deterioration of public security in South Africa has resulted in part from an influx of Zimbabwean refugees, millions of whom fled to the country over the past three decades due to the disastrous economic situation in their homeland.
In addition, the economy of South Africa is also suffering, and along with the global economic slowdown, has spurred an increase in the unemployment and crimes rates, he said.
He urged travelers to avoid South Africa unless absolutely necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Australia announce scholarship programs

TEXT.P: The National Science Council (NSC) and representatives of the Australian government have jointly announced the continuation of two scholarship programs to encourage Taiwanese scholars, professionals and students to study in Australia.

The programs are part of a bilateral effort to enhance educational exchanges and cooperation between the two countries, NSC Minister Chen Chien-jen said at an announcement ceremony held at the NSC building Wednesday.

The Australian government has provided a total of NT$25.5 million (US$838,816) to 22 Taiwanese students in the past two years, Chen said, noting that it was the biggest sum compared to the scholarships offered by the other 36 countries that have similar agreements with Taiwan.
The Australian government will gradually increase the amount, which will be doubled by 2011, he added.
The application period for the scholarships this year is from April 9 to July 31.

The NSC will also provide 10 openings in its annual scholarship program this year for local doctoral students in the field of nanotechnology or biotechnology research, with each student eligible to receive a maximum of NT$900,000, Chen said.

Describing Australia as one of the top choices for Taiwanese students who wish to study abroad, Chen said that in 2007 there were approximately 10,000 Taiwanese students enrolled in postgraduate programs there.
Robin Warren, a co-winner of the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 2005 and Steve Waters, a representative of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office (ACIO) in Taiwan, were also at Wednesday's ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: Screening of CAL airplane deal 'legal': CAA

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's largest air carrier, did not violate any screening requirements in its recent airplane purchase deal, a top aviation official said Thursday.

The statement came one day after Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers questioned whether CAL had signed a deal with European aircraft manufacturer Airbus to buy 20 A350-900 aircraft for over NT$130 billion (US$4.3 billion) before obtaining official approval to do so.

However, Billy Chang, head of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, said at a news conference that the proposal had been properly processed.

Chang explained that last December CAL submitted the procurement plan to the CAA detailing the air carrier's intention to place an order for 14 of the 20 new aircraft, to phase out the six A340-300 passenger jets it was operating, and to maintain an option to buy an additional six new Airbus aircraft.
The CAL plan also explained the method of payment, sources of funds and financial forecast, Chang said.

Before approving the plan, the CAA was also apprised of how CAL would maintain the planes and whether the use of the new aircraft would be in line with Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport regulations, he added.

Chang said that on Jan. 21, a vice president of CAL told the CAA that the deal was an emergency case, which prompted the CAA to step up the screening process and to approve the plan the following day.
Chang did not elaborate on the nature of the emergency. CAL signed the contract with Airbus the same day it received approval from the CAA.

In response to speculations that the deal had cost CAL an extra NT$10 billion and an excessive 3 percent licensing fee, Chang said local airlines are not required to include the price and the licensing fee in any aircraft procurement proposals submitted to the CAA.
Such amounts are regarded as commercial secrets and are therefore not subject to CAA screening, Chang pointed out.

Noting that it is up to airlines to decide on the type of planes they want to buy, Chang said that the CAA screening focuses mainly on whether maintenance of the aircraft is in line with existing rules.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins 2nd place in Bakery World Cup
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 2 (CNA) 04/03/08 17:41:19 (By Tsai Hsiao-ying and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Three Taiwanese bakers, who represented the country at the 2008 Bakery World Cup in Paris, on Wednesday won second place in the competition and took home two individual prizes.
The bakers, Wu Chun-pao, Tsao Chih-hsiung and Wen Shih-cheng, entered the finals of the competition, which were held March 31-April 2, after beating opponents in the Asian qualifying rounds last May.

The Taiwanese team, competing on March 31, presented the panel of judges with home-style bread of a special flavor. They spent eight hours making the bread from mainly flour, dried longan and rum, and shaping them to feature the traditional Chinese lion and dragon dance motif.
The trio won second place, behind the French team and ahead of Italy which placed third.

In addition, Wu and Tsao each won an individual prize in the European style and artistic baking categories, which means that they qualify to enter the first international competition for individuals bakers slated to be launched in 2010.
Wu is from the southern port city of Kaohsiung, Tsao from Tainan City also in the south, and Wen from the northern city of Taipei.

The triennial baking competition, in its seventh edition this year, brought together 12 national teams, including the top three winners in the 2005 competition -- the United States, France and Japan -- and nine others that qualified for the finals after winning national and intercontinental competitions.
Apart from Taiwan, the other competing teams were Turkey, Mexico, Argentina, Poland, Sweden, Spain, Italy and Netherlands.
During an award ceremony Wednesday, the event organizers announced that the next competition will be held in 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Talks on Alitalia-Air France deal collapsed.
Talks on Air France's bid to take over the Italian money-losing carrier Alitalia collapsed Wednesday. Alitalia chairman Maurizio quit as the talks ended and the state-controlled company risked going bankrupt.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sony plans to increase procurement in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The president of the electronics giant Sony Corporation promised during a meeting with President-elect Ma Ying-jeou Thursday to increase procurement in Taiwan.

Ryoji Chubachi, president and electronics CEO of Sony Corp., said that Sony plans not only to increase procurement and expand its investment in Taiwan, but also to engage in research and development of advanced products with its counterparts in Taiwan.

Chubachi, who is in Taipei to officiate at the opening of a promotion function dubbed "Sony Fair, " related to the media that during his meeting with Ma he had referred to the close cooperative links between electronic manufacturers in Japan and Taiwan, and had expressed the hope that these ties would expand.

Chubachi, who holds a Ph. D. in Engineering from Tohoku University, was named president of Sony Corp. and CEO of Sony's Global Electronics Business in June 2005. This is his second visit to Taiwan since then.

Speaking to members of the local media, Chubachi said Sony Corp.'s revenues usually shrink by 6 billion yen (US$58.377 million) whenever the Japanese currency appreciates against the U.S. dollar by one yen.

Chubachi said the global economic slowdown has already affected the world's manufacturing sector. He quoted leading world economic forecast organizations as predicting that economies in industrially advanced countries will grow about 3-4 percent for 2008, while rising economies like Brazil, Russia, India and China, will record growth ranging from 6 to 9 percent for the year.

He predicted that there will be no major impact on Sony Corp. should the U.S. economy start to bottom out at the end of 2008. However, if the U.S. slowdown continues, he said, the global economy will take a turn for the worse.

Also speaking at the news conference, vice president of Sony Corp. Naofumi Hara said that in the face of the slowdown, Sony will increase incoming orders as a short-term remedy, but its long-term strategy is to cut production overheads and choose its production bases more carefully.

Headquartered in Tokyo, Sony Corporation is a leading manufacturer of audio, video, communications and information technology products for the consumer and professional markets. Its music, motion pictures, computer entertainment operations, and online businesses make Sony one of the most comprehensive entertainment companies in the world.
Sony recorded consolidated annual sales of approximately US$70.3 billion for the fiscal year that ended March 31, 2007, and it employs 163,000 people worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: U.S. Cites Planning Gaps in Iraqi Assault on Basra
Ambassador Ryan C. Crocker first learned of the Iraqi plan on Friday, March 21: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki would be heading to Basra with Iraqi troops to bring order to the city.
The Wall Street Journal:U.S. Slump Takes Toll Across Globe
Here's a big lesson of the first international financial crisis of the 21st century: Some old- fashioned economies are weathering the storm better than those that borrowed big to spur growth or those that bet heavily on debt- strapped American consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Congratulatory telegrams not sent due to administrative delay: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) downplayed Thursday reports that diplomatic relations with several of Taiwan's allies are fragile as the ministry has not yet received official congratulatory telegrams from two of the country's 23 diplomatic allies following its recent presidential election, blaming the silence on administrative delay.

"Congratulatory messages of two allies are delayed due to administrational procedures but shall be arriving in the next few days, " said MOFA's spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh, without elaborating on the issue.
It is believed that the two countries are Burkina Faso in western Africa and the Caribbean country Federation of Saint Kitts and Nevis. However, the ministry refused to confirm this.
Yeh said "sending congratulatory telegrams is a good gesture which has no direct link to diplomatic relations, " stressing that relations between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies remain stable.
She specifically dismissed reports that diplomatic ties with Saint Kitts and Nevis are shaky, describing bilateral relations as "friendly and normal."

Prime Minister Denzil Douglas of the Caribbean country paid a visit to Taiwan in February to attend the opening ceremony of its first embassy in Asia, and bilateral cooperative projects are under steady progress, which all indicate that diplomatic links between the two countries remain unchanged, the diplomat said.

However, Taiwan's Vice President Annette Lu said in an interview with the Apple Daily Wednesday that the delay was a "diplomatic warning" for the incoming government as several allies have not yet sent out official congratulatory telegrams.
Lu explained Thursday that she made the remarks out of "good intention" to caution President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and his incoming administration.
The embassies of the two countries in question, on the other hand, declined to make any comment Thursday.

Ma's decisive victory on March 22 was so welcomed by the international community that many countries, even without diplomatic relations with Taiwan, congratulated Ma because many expected and welcomed the prospect of improvement in cross-Taiwan Strait relations between Taiwan and China.

U.S. President George W. Bush also sent a statement right after the election to congratulate Ma, praising Taiwan as a beacon of democracy in Asia, a contrast from the letter sent by his secretary to President Chen Shui-bian, a week after his election in 2004.
However, Yeh noted that the ministry is paying close attention to China for any maneuver to sway Taiwan's allies before the new government takes office on May 20.
China has been trying to shrink Taiwan's international space by using financial and political clout to lure Taiwan's diplomatic allies to switch their allegiance to Beijing.

The Foreign Ministry warned there would be no diplomatic honeymoon for the new government as there were signs that China was not easing its campaign to suppress Taiwan's diplomatic ties with other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to decide whether to move up party chairmanship election date

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Central Executive Committee will decide next Monday whether it would move up the date of the party's chairmanship election and whether the poll should be held alongside two other DPP elections, party sources said Thursday.
DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh suggested Wednesday that the election of the new party head be moved up one week to avoid a leadership vacuum when his term expires on May 20, according to the sources.

Hsieh, who stayed on at the post after he was defeated by Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang in the March 22 presidential election, suggested that the DPP chairmanship election be held on May 18 instead of May 25 as previously scheduled.
Hsieh said that this will allow for a "seamless transition" and will avoid a situation of the party being without a leader in the period between May 20 and May 25.
Under the DPP charter, the party chairman, delegates and local chapter chiefs may serve two-year terms and elections are due on the fourth Sunday of May, or May 25 this year.

Party sources said that given the party's dire financial situation, it will face difficulties if it does not combine the elections. The three-in-one election will save money and help boost turnout rates, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post:Alliance Invites In Croatia, Albania
NATO's political leaders agreed Wednesday night to admit Croatia and Albania into the military alliance, but after a vigorous debate they effectively rejected President Bush's bid to put two former Soviet republics on the path to membership.
The Washington Times:Bernanke sees 'recession' signs
Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke said yesterday that the economy may be in a mild recession, and he defended the Fed"s rescue of Bear, Stearns & Co. as a one-time move needed to keep the economy from worsening.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect pushes for Taiwan-Japan cooperation in tapping China

TEXT.P: High-tech companies in Taiwan and Japan could forge strategic alliances to jointly tap the Chinese market, President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday.

Taiwanese and Japanese companies have maintained close cooperation over recent decades and such strategic alliances could further bilateral cooperation in the field, Ma said after a 30-minute meeting with Ryoji Chubachi, president of Sony Corp.
Chubachi, head of the world's second-largest maker of consumer electronics, is the first foreign business executive of a leading global company to visit Ma after his election victory on March 22.

Ma said the meeting focused on Sony's future procurement in Taiwan. Sony is the third largest foreign buyer of Taiwan's high-tech products after Hewlett-Packard Co. and Dell Inc., with the annual procurement amount reaching US$10 billion, said Ma. Chubachi said that Sony has plans to increase its procurement in Taiwan, according to Ma.
During the meeting, Ma said he told Chubachi that he hoped Sony could also increase investment in its research and development in Taiwan.
In addition, Ma said that they discussed investment and procurement on thin film transistor (TFT) panels, something of which Taiwan is a leading maker.

Ma added that Chubachi assured him Sony's cooperation with South Korean companies or Sharp Corp. -- Japan's largest maker of liquid-crystal display televisions -- will not affect its investment in Taiwan in this field.

During the meeting, Chubachi also learned about Ma's promise to push for the opening of direct air links between Taiwan and China soon after Ma assumes office on May 20, information that could help Sony in deciding whether to expand the size of its logistics center in central Taiwan.

In another development, Ma said at a ceremony marking the 63rd anniversary of Taipei Fuhsing Private School that he will "value morals over talent" in appointing public agency heads in his administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rice price hikes more critical than oil price rises: V.P.

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that she thinks the upward swing of rice prices is more critical than gasoline price hikes.

Lu said the country should pay closer attention to fluctuations in rice prices, given that people could drive less when petroleum prices surge but cannot avoid feeding themselves when the price of the important and popular staple, rice, soars.
Lu made the remarks during her speech at a ceremony held at National Chia Tung Vocational School in the southernmost county of Pingtung to mark the school's 71st founding anniversary.
The vice president encouraged students to devote their energy and time to agricultural development after graduation, saying that agriculture is by no means a low status industry.
Rather, she said, agriculture is a strategic industry during war time and an important driving force of a nation's economy during peace time.

The vice president made a whirlwind trip to Pingtung County Thursday. In addition to visiting the vocational school, Lu also toured the famous Known-You Seed Co. and an aluminum processing company as well as a nursing home.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA willing to help president-elect arrange U.S. visit

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is very willing to help President-elect Ma Ying-jeou arrange a visit to the United States prior to his May 20 inauguration if Ma's office raises such a request, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Thursday.
Huang made the comments during a legislative committee meeting while fielding questions from Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator John Chiang, who questioned whether MOFA was sitting idle and not helping Ma.

Brushing aside Chiang's concern on the grounds that MOFA has not received any such request from Ma's office, Huang stressed that his ministry would definitely do its best to help the president-elect arrange a visit to the United States if he needs assistance in this regard.

According to Huang, communications channels between Ma's office and MOFA have been set up after Ma's election victory on March 22 to prepare for and arrange the May 20 presidential inauguration ceremony, but Ma's team has not mentioned his hopes for a U.S. visit.

"MOFA is not in a position to make any move regarding the issue without permission from Ma, " Huang said, adding that "it would be good if Ma could realize a U. S. visit to boost two-way relations before his inauguration on May 20."
The minister, however, said that he could not judge whether or not Ma could make a visit to the United States, because the U.S. side has to weigh several factors.
During a meeting last week with visiting American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond Burghardt, Huang said that they did not touch on Ma's plan to visit the United States.
Ma's aides said Wednesday that the president-elect's office is still negotiating with the U.S. side over his U.S. visit request.

Ma, of the main opposition KMT, beat his ruling Democratic Progressive Party rival, Frank Hiseh, in the presidential race by a wide margin of more than 2.21 million votes, taking a record high of 7.65 million votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: New legislature has low attendance rate: monitoring group

TEXT.P: A legislature monitoring group called the public's attention Thursday to the poor attendance at the new legislature, noting that even the best-performing lawmakers were absent from 50 percent of the meetings held over the past two months.

According to a survey conducted by Citizen Congress Watch (CCW) based on the attendances at 34 floor or committee meetings held between Feb. 1 and March 26, the legislators with the lowest attendance rate were absent from 27 meetings, while those with the highest attendance rate were absent from 17.
The survey revealed that the lowest attendance were recorded for opposition Kuomintang Legislators Liu Chuan-chung and Yang Jen-fu, both of whom were absent from 27 meetings.
Coming in second were KMT Legislator Fu Kun-chi and Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei, who were both absent from 24 meetings.

The third-lowest attendance were jointly recorded by seven legislators who were absent from 22 meetings: Chen Chieh, Hsu Yao-chang, Tsao Erh-chung and Chung Shao-ho of the KMT; Yen Chin-piao and Lin Pin-kun of the NPSU; and Ker Chien- ming of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Lin Feng-cheng, a leading member of the legislative watchdog CCW, pointed out that with each legislator receiving NT$184,960 in salary per month, the legislators mentioned above each wasted between NT$160,000 and NT$130,000 in taxpayers' money during the period.

The legislators with the highest attendance -- attending 17 of the 34 meetings -- were Liu Shen-liang, Lin Yu-fang, Shuai Hua-ming, John Chiang, Chang Hsien- yao, Cheng Li-wun and Justin Chou of the KMT and the DPP's Twu Shiing-jer, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese-language teachers to pass on skills in Philippines

TEXT.P: A team of instructors is slated to depart for the Philippines April 7 to embark on a project to train teachers of the Mandarin-language at schools there, Chang Liang-min, an official of the Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission, said Thursday.

The commission had mandated the Kaohsiung county government for the first time to select trainers in the area of Chinese-language teaching to travel to the Philippines for the purpose of promoting education among Taiwanese expatriates residing in the Southeast Asian country, Chang said.

Liu Ming-che, an official of the Kaohsiung county government, encouraged the trainers to help the potential Mandarin-language teachers to get a better understanding of Taiwan's history, culture, geography, tourist attractions and high technology development.
Chang presented a flag to Tsui Chun-ling, leader of the seven-member team, during a ceremony held at the Kaohsiung County Hall Thursday.
The seven trainers include five incumbent and two retired teachers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Children in care need more psychological counselors: CCSA

TEXT.P: Children living in orphanages and shelters in Taiwan are generally in good material condition but have an urgent need of professional psychological counseling to increase their sense of security, social workers and orphanage directors said Thursday, citing the results of a recent survey.

In order to understand the daily lives and needs of these disadvantaged children, the Chinese Childrenhome and Shelter Association (CCSA) conducted the survey in February and March, based on Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs, among children aged between 10 and 15 in children's shelters nationwide.
They survey results show that more than half of the children questioned are satisfied with their physiological needs such as food, clothes and living environment.

However, in the area of psychological safety, about 50 percent described themselves as victims of verbal or physical violence, said they sometimes feel crowded out by other children and do not know how to turn to social workers or shelter staff for help.

"The need for psychological counselors in children's shelters is urgent, " said Wu Xiao-ping, the CCSA's office manager, adding that only five shelters out of the country's 44 have full-time psychological counselors.
In 2007, the CCSA raised funds to hire part-time counselors who serve four hours a week in 11 shelters and this year, they plan to hire more professionals who will work in another 4.
"But this leaves half of the children's homes still in need, " Wu said.

As to the need for love and a sense of belonging, about 40 percent of the children surveyed said they consider the staff and social workers as their families but still have a strong desire to be reunited with their real parents, the CCSA said, urging the parents to stay in close contact with their children.

In the field of self-actualization, the CCSA expects children's shelters to provide more opportunities to help them manage their finances and plan their futures, by encouraging them to express themselves and participate in group activities.

The sheltered children include not only orphans (representing only 5 percent of all sheltered children) as most people believe, but also children who have been abandoned, maltreated by their parents or sexually abused (38 percent), or who come from single-parent families unable to care for them (33 percent), the CCSA noted.

Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs is a psychological theory according to which five levels of basic human needs -- physiological needs, safety, love and a sense of belonging, self-esteem and self-actualization -- are ranked.

DOC.HEADLINE: Crew of stricken fishing boat return to Taiwan: SEF

TEXT.P: The captain and four crew of a Keelung-registered fishing boat that sank in waters off Hong Kong last month returned to Taiwan Thursday, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) announced later that day.
SEF officials said the vessel, the Man Chin Shun No. 6, sank March 31 about 45 nautical miles east of Hong Kong after being hit by another ship.

The captain, Chang Cheng-shan, and crewmen Lin chin-li, Lee Ah-chou, Cheng Wan- teh and Hsu Chin-tu boarded a life raft and were picked up by a passing Hong Kong commercial vessel, which took them to Guangzhou, in China's Guangdong Province, for temporary shelter.
Upon learning the news, the SEF immediately contacted its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, and other related agencies, to provide assistance.

The SEF, a semi-official agency set up by Taipei to handle civilian exchanges with China in the absence of official ties, noted that to strengthen assistance for Taiwan nationals in distress, it set up an emergency service center March 12 for Taiwanese people in trouble on the other side of the Taiwan Strait.
The center's 24-hour hotline is (02) -27129292, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hotline set up to help victims of domestic violence

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Coalition Against Violence announced Thursday that it has set up a hotline to help victims of domestic violence obtain timely assistance.

Kao Feng-hsien, chairwoman of the coalition, told reporters that last year more than 70,000 domestic violence cases were reported in Taiwan, but law enforcement agencies investigated only half of them.
There were also 7,000 sexual violence cases reported in 2007, but less than 20 percent of the cases were investigated, she said.
The figures show that many victims of domestic and sexual violence did not get appropriate assistance, Kao said.

According to Kao, although Taiwan passed the Sexual Assault Crime Prevention Act in 1997, followed by the implementation of the Domestic Violence Prevention Act in 1998 and the Sexual Harassment Prevention Act in 2006, there is insufficient coordination among different parts of government or society that can help victims -- including law enforcement agencies, hospitals, the judiciary, educational and social welfare institutions.

Doctors and nurses, for example, often fail to report injuries from victims to the police. Social welfare groups, wanting to protect the privacy of victims, also are sometimes reluctant to notify the police when victims come to them for help. Even when police officers investigate cases they know about, they often do not arrest the perpetrators, thus many cases are not prosecuted.
Kao said that with the new toll-free hotline (0800-434-434, ) her coalition will "act like the government's eyes and arms" to help domestic violence victims find protection against their abusers.

In addition to setting up the hotline, Kao said, her coalition has formed an advisory committee to supervise the government's domestic violence prevention network and help refer domestic violence cases and appeals for help from victims to related government agencies or private organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Crowds mark 33rd anniversary of Chiang Kai-shek's death

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Vincent Siew, former Premier Hau Pei-tsun, retired government officials and soldiers, as well as friends and family of the late president Chiang Kai-shek on Thursday showed their profound respect and appreciation of Chiang by commemorating the 33rd anniversary of his death.

Chiang died at the age of 87 from kidney failure and advanced cardiac malfunction in Taipei on April 5, 1975, 26 years after he withdrew from mainland China to Taiwan, after losing a civil war with the Communists.

Expressing respect for Chiang's achievement in fighting against the Japanese invasion and occupation of China during World War II and reclaiming Taiwan from Japanese control, Tsai Kong Ming-ru, executive director of the National Women's League of the Republic of China (NWL), which organized the event, said "he (Chiang) is a good example for us to learn from."

Tsai said that Chiang and his wife Soong May-ling, also known as Madame Chiang, were devoted to the implementation of the "New Life Movement," a campaign to educate people with the right attitude toward life.
"Hopefully the spirit of the New Life Movement can last and bring our nation a bright future," Tsai said.

Discounting recent actions by the current administration of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to downplay the legacy of Chiang, Reverend Chou Lian-hua, the Chiangs' family-priest, said "we, the younger generation, cannot deny the contributions of our forefather (Chiang) to the country."
Naming Chiang as "the grandfather of everyone," Chou said that "Chiang's efforts indeed helped Taiwan to be stabilized socially and economically after the war."
In defense of criticism over Chiang's dictatorship, Chou said "his (Chiang's) personality as well as moral quality is what people have to take as an example which is undeniable."

From 1928 until his death, Chiang served as Generalissimo of the national government of the Republic of China (ROC). In 1925, he took control of the Kuomintang (KMT) after the death of Sun Yat-sen and led the KMT until his death in 1975.

Critics, including current President Chen Shui-bian have blamed Chiang for the 228 Incident in Taiwan in 1947 and the subsequent period of "White Terror" in which thousands of people were killed or arrested for opposing or for suspicions of being opposed to the KMT's authoritarian rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese tourists allowed to re-enter Tibet from May: tour agency

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tourists will be allowed to visit Tibet again from May after tourism to the strife-torn region was restricted by Beijing when riots against Chinese rule broke out there in mid-March, an executive of a Taipei-based tour agency said Thursday.

K.H. Liu, general manager of Pug Tours International Travel Co., Ltd., said that her tour agency had received an urgent notification earlier in the day from China's National Tourism Administration announcing that from May 1, Tibet will be re-opened to tourists from around the world.

According to Liu, Pug Tours, which organizes group travel to Tibet exclusively, stopped sending package tour groups to Tibet March 15 after the rioting by Tibetans against Chinese oppression erupted in the capital of Lhasa.

Now that the situation in Tibet has stabilized and because Tibet will be re- opened to the outside world from the start of the next month, Pug Tours will organize a group of more than 20 tourists that is slated to depart for Tibet May 8, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSEC encourages local brokers to trade in Abu Dhabi

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stock brokers could begin trading in the Abu Dhabi Securities Market (ADSM) in June and capitalize on the new market, Wu Rong-I, chairman of the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSEC), said Thursday following a roundtable discussion with the ADSM's CEO, Tom Healy and other ADSM officials.

The TSEC, which signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the ADSM last December, discussed with the Mideast partner the future of the global stock market and the details of bilateral cooperation in areas such as reciprocal stock market listings of Exchange Traded Funds (ETF).
Local brokers, securities investment trust enterprises and financial officials also joined the roundtable talks held at Taipei 101.

"Following the signing of the MOU that regulates stock investment, Taiwan's public companies will be able to capitalize on the new Abu Dhabi market in the United Arab Emirates (UAE)," said Wu, adding that the oil-rich Islamic country has shown interest in Taiwan's world-leading electronic sectors.
Wu noted that under the MOU framework, the three key areas of cooperation are bilateral investment, strategic alliances -- including information sharing -- and the development of financial products.
Wu said that in order to accommodate the MOU, the UAE is working on legislation to allow foreign stock trading of ETFs, and that the process is expected to be completed by June.
Taiwan brokers are also ready to enter the new market, he indicated.
"Taiwan's Polaris Securities has shown interest in trading in Abu Dhabi with stocks that would not violate Islamic taboos such as the ban on pork trading," Wu said.

Touching on global trends in stock exchange alliances, Wu said some of the world's largest stock exchanges, like the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) , are seeking partners in the Asian stock market, with Taiwan among the top choices.
The TSEC is also scheduled to sign an MOU with Poland's Warsaw Stock Exchange (WSE) on April 7.

"Eastern Europe is a virgin market waiting to be explored by Taiwan brokers and investors," Wu said, referring to it as an "emerging market" in what was known as the Iron Curtain region in the post-World War II period.

He added that the WSE had already indicated its willingness to deal with some Taiwanese companies that have established scores of businesses in Poland's market, and that further discussions will be held at the MOU signing.

An ETF is an investment vehicle traded on primary exchanges, similar to major stocks or bonds but with the advantages of low exchange costs and a more diverse stock portfolio that could minimize investment risks. ETFs provide an easier access for foreign investors to evaluate the local stocks, facilitating the foregin capital to flow into local bourse and companies.

Michael Lin, TSEC's senior executive vice president, said that according to a report by the management consulting firm McKinsey's, global investors see stocks in Taiwan and Singapore as hot cakes in the Asian market.
"Many foreign stock exchanges are attracted by the diversity of the industry sector listings on Taiwan's stock market," Lin said.
"Taiwan's stock market is a fully-developed market, " he said, drawing a comparison with the Abu Dhabi exchange which lists mostly real estate and financial stocks.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT raises question of Ma serving as party chairman

TEXT.P: The question of whether President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang (KMT) should serve concurrently as the chairman of his party is one that can be put up for discussion, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih said Thursday.

The secretary-general's remarks came one day after KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung raised the issue in a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting. The chairman said Wednesday that the possibility of amending the party's charter prior to the next chairmanship election in August 2009 to allow for the president to serve concurrently as party head can be further contemplated.

Wu Den-yih, on the sidelines of a memorial service to mark the 33rd anniversary of the death of President Chiang Kai-shek, said Thursday that the KMT chairman had discussed the matter with him previously.

Noting that a party's charter "has to progress with time," and that the KMT had recently added "Taiwan-centric advocacy" to its charter, Wu Den-yih said "this issue can indeed be put up for discussion without a pre-determined stance."

The current KMT charter stipulates that the chairman of the party should be chosen by its members by means of direct election, Wu noted. However when the popularly elected president is from the KMT, the question arises of whether the party should be headed by a national leader who has a broader support base, Wu Den-yih added.

Meanwhile, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, noting that Wu Poh-hsiung had led the party to victory in the Jan. 12 legislative election and the March 22 presidential election, said that if the incumbent chairman decides to serve another term after August 2009, he is sure to "lead the KMT to another win in the city and county chief elections late that year."
Commenting on the question of whether the president should also hold the party chairmanship, Wang said that "this will largely depend on Ma's wishes."
There are advantages and disadvantages to such an arrangement, he added.

The advantages are that the president will find it easier to promote his policies or ideals via the party as the KMT has a firm grip on both the executive and legislative branches of government, he said. However, one of he disadvantages will be a retrogression to the government being led by the party, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA welcomes Sony's expansion in local investment

TEXT.P: Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials expressed warm welcome Thursday at Sony's commitment to expand its investment and procurement in Taiwan, and said the ministry will offer its assistance to facilitate Sony's plans.

Ryoji Chubachi, president of Japanese electronics giant Sony Corp., promised during a meeting with President-elect Ma Ying- jeou that same day to increase procurement and expand investment in Taiwan, casting a vote of confidence in the new Cabinet.
He also committed Sony to engaging in research and development of advanced products with Taiwanese companies.

"The ministry has been making efforts to attract more foreign investors, especially from Japan, whose manufacturing is among the world's top, " said Berton B.C. Chiu, director-general of the Department of Investment Services under the MOEA.
Chiu said the department will do everything possible to assist Sony in its investment and procurement plans, including help with land acquisition and customs regulations.

"In addition to investment in local manufacturers, Sony's procurement of local electronic parts could also help Taiwan's export business, " he added, citing Sony as an important partner in the development of Taiwan's electronic sector.

Touching on the outlook for foreign investment, Chiu said the most likely industry sectors to set up in Taiwan in the future are wireless broadband, digital life, healthcare and green industries, "because the MOEA has been improving manufacturing in those areas."
Sony has already been working with the MOEA on scores of projects involving local industries.

"Sony has transferred technology to Taiwanese electronics makers to help develop products such as game software for PlayStation 3, Sony's 2006 hit in the gaming market," said Leu Jang-Hwa, director of the Information Technology Industries Division of the Industrial Development Bureau under the MOEA.

Leu also referred to another Sony-assisted project -- Taiwan Green Environmental Partner (TGEP) -- which pushed local electronic component makers to reach the Sony Green Partner Standard (GP) a high-quality eco-friendly identification among global makers.
"Once a company is qualified to GP standards, it can obtain business orders from Sony to expand its clients around the world, " Leu said.
The increasing amount of procurement in Taiwan from Sony -- US$6.5 billion (NT$195 billion) last year -- Leu noted, shows the company's ambition to further base its business in Taiwan.
"Following a logistics center Sony launched in Taichung in 2007, the company is planning to open another one in southern Taiwan, " he added.
Sony recorded consolidated annual sales of approximately US$70.3 billion for the fiscal year that ended March 31, 2007. The company employs 163,000 people worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA urges public to turn out lights for one hour on Earth Day

TEXT.P: The head of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) urged the public Thursday to make an effort to observe Earth Day on April 22, to help reduce carbon emission.

Wearing a necktie of tissue made from recycled plastic bottles, Winston Dang called for people to turn off their lights and elevators for one hour on Earth Day to show Taiwan's ambition to participate in the international event.

For every person who does so, 0.25 kg of CO2 emission can be reduced, so that if 1 million people do so, the CO2 emission reduction would reach 250,000 kg, which is the quantity of CO2 absorbed by more than 20,000 trees in one year, according to Dang.
"We hope to make the one-day activity more frequent in the future," he said.

"It is necessary to begin the movement with public institutions, " he went on, adding that the EPA has already begun to save natural resources by turning out its lights for an hour each day, banning the use of paper cups and limiting the use of elevators.

He also encouraged people to buy food produced locally instead of imported produce, to open the window rather than turn on the air conditioner, to stop using disposable tableware and to avoid purchasing goods with too much packaging.
Displaying a pedometer he was wearing, Dang also promoted walking and using public transportation rather than driving private vehicles.
The minister went on foot from the EPA building to the press conference, which took place in an elementary school 500 meters away, while some EPA officials went by car.
Also that day, the EPA launched a Web site on Earth Day, providing information and activities about the event, as well as suggestions on saving energy.

"Although Taiwan is not a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol, we can still do our best to reduce the effects of global warming, " said Dang, adding that Taiwan "might be the first country to enact regulations concerning the reduction of greenhouse gases."
A draft of greenhouse gas reduction regulations, approved by the Cabinet in 2006, is still being revised by legislators.

Earth Day was initiated in the United States in the 1970s, the period during which the consumption of leaded fuel was at its peak, with the aim of enhancing awareness of environmental protection. It became an international event in 1990 with the participation of 141 countries worldwide, including Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20,000 light bulbs and tubes to light up remote schools

TEXT.P: A total of 20,000 light bulbs and tubes will be sent to 100 elementary schools in rural Taiwan, in a campaign to improve underprivileged students' study environment, the campaign organizers announced Thursday.

"The lights will change the lives of those underprivileged children," said Gordon Yeh, chairman of Fubon Securities who is also a member of Fubon Charity Foundation(Fubon), one of the event organizers.
People living in cities or developed areas can not understand how basic resources, such as light bulbs, can be so scarce in rural Taiwan, Yeh said.
"I hope this campaign -- Light Up Hope, Sketching Future, Delivering Love -- will generate more love and concern from the public for the children," Yeh said at the launching ceremony.

Under the program, 20,000 light bulbs and tubes will be donated by Royal Philips Electronics of the Netherlands, Taiwan (Philips Taiwan) and be delivered by FedEx Corp. (FedEx) to 100 poor schools in remote areas of Taiwan.
The program is cosponsored by Fubon, Philips Taiwan, and FedEx.

The bulbs and tubes are energy saving and are expected to help the schools reduce their electricity usage by 10 percent, resulting in a savings of NT$ 190,000 (US$ 12,459) on energy costs a year for 100 schools, Edward Po, general manager of the Philips Taiwan's Lighting Division, said.

Chin Bin-cheng, principal of Wan-fu Elementary School located in the northeast county of Yilan said that a small school like hers needs to pay NT$160, 000 (US$ 5,245) on electricity and water bills each year, but the local government only allocates a budget of NT$ 80,000 (US$2,623) for those utilities.
"This has forced us to turn off some lights in the classrooms, and the optical health of the children are also hampered," Chin said.
She added that the donations "indeed helps solve our budget shortfall problem to pay electricity bills in many remote schools."
Edward Po also expressed a willingness to continue helping the schools in the future.
"We hope to use our resources to promote sustainability and give back to society," said Po.

Michael Chu, managing director of FedEx, Taiwan, said: "the campaign allows us to use our extensive logistic network and expertise to make a real difference in the lives of thousands of underprivileged children."

DOC.HEADLINE: Fubon Holding approved to invest in Xiamen Bank

TEXT.P: The government gave a green light to Taipei-based Fubon Financial Holding Co. Thursday, allowing it to invest in a bank in Xiamen City, in China's southeastern province of Fujian.

The Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) granted approval to a proposal submitted by Fubon Hong Kong to invest US$34 million to acquire a reported 20 percent stake in Xiamen City Commercial Bank.
The approval makes Fubon Financial Holding the first Taiwanese banking group to obtain governmental permission to invest in a bank in China via an overseas subsidiary.

Susan Chang, an FSC vice chairwoman and spokeswoman, said Fubon Financial Holding's total assets amounted to US$7.78 billion as of the end of 2007, with a BIS (bank of international settlement ratio) of 14.42 percent.
In addition, Chang said, Fubon Financial Holding has not committed any major irregularities in its business operations over the last three years.
With the approval, Fubon Financial Holding can now apply to the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs for formal permission to start the investment plan.

The investment plan is poised to increase Taiwanese banks' cooperation with their Chinese counterparts and most importantly, it could serve as a platform for Taiwanese banking institutions to improve their services to China-based Taiwanese businessmen and companies.

Meanwhile, Gong Tien-hsing, president of Fubon Financial Holding, said the company is expected to forge a contract with Xiamen City Commercial Bank in the middle of the year if everything goes smoothly.
However, Gong declined to say any more about the investment plan, pointing out that it would be inappropriate for him to express an opinion before an agreement is inked.
Xiamen City Commercial Bank was established in 1996 with investment by the Xiamen local government, as well as by several private companies and individuals.
Now with 31 branches around the city, the bank touts itself as "the Xiamenese' own bank." Its total assets totaled 15.05 billion yuan and net assets stood at 440 million yuan as of the end of 2006.

Xiamen, the Chinese city located closest to Taiwan, has been designated as one of the two Chinese coastal cities allowed to engage in the "mini three links" with the Taiwan-held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu since 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves at US$286.86 billion

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves amounted to US$286.86 billion as of the end of March, an increase of US$9.022 billion from the month-earlier level, the Taiwan-based Central Bank of China (CBC) said Thursday.
The figure represented the second-highest monthly increase after an increase of US$9.877 billion in February 2004, CBC officials said.

They attributed the dramatic increase to the appreciation of the euro and other major currencies against the U.S. dollar. Foreign exchange reserves denominated in these currencies were thus worth more in terms of the base currency -- the greenback -- they added.
Net foreign capital inflow and returns from foreign exchange reserve management also contributed to the increase, they continued.

Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves remained the world's fifth-largest after those of China (US$1.52 trillion as of last December, the latest figure available), Japan (US$979.2 billion as of February) , Russia (US$383.6 billion as of February) and India (US$294.6 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: Hospital to begin testing on target drug for head, neck cancers

TEXT.P: Taichung Veterans General Hospital (TVGH) is to begin clinical testing of a target drug for head and neck cancers, providing 17-week courses of free treatment for 20 volunteers, hospital sources said Thursday.

Cetuximab -- marketed under the brand name Erbitux -- is a target drug developed by U.S.-based pharmaceutical company ImClone Systems and approved for use in colon cancer by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in 2004.
Lin Jin-ching, an oncologist at the hospital, explained that the reason for the testing program is because the drug might also be helpful for treating patients with head and neck cancer.

TVGH physicians said that a 56-year-old male patient came to the hospital two years ago and was diagnosed with tongue and neck cancer. The patient, who underwent various therapies for a long period, finally settled on cetuximab and was cured in only four months.

However, they went on, a single dose of cetuximab costs NT$10,000 (approximately US$329), while a full course of three months would cost up to NT$300,000 -- which put many patients who are in financial difficulties off the idea of the testing.

"Therefore, we asked Merck KGaA for financial assistance to carry out the project, " Lin said, adding that Merck KGaA, the global distributor of cetuximab, decided to provide some NT$10 million for the program.
According to the hospital, the project will begin as soon as 20 suitable volunteers are recruited.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cash settlement talks needed before exchanges allowed: FSC

TEXT.P: Taiwan must engage in cash settlement talks with China before it gives a go- ahead for allowing Chinese yuan exchange services on Taiwan proper, the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Thursday.

FSC officials said that if the signing of a formal agreement on free currency exchanges between the Chinese yuan and the new Taiwan dollar is not possible in the near future, the government should at least seek to build a mechanism to facilitate the cross-strait currency exchange business.
The FSC will listen to advice from the Taiwan-based Central Bank of China (CBC) for any moves in this regard, they said.
At present, Taiwanese citizens are only allowed to take up to 20,000 yuan in or out of the country when they travel via the Taiwan-held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

However, in an exclusive interview with the British news agency Reuters the day before, President-elect Ma Ying-jeou reportedly said he will see to it that Chinese yuan-NT dollar exchanges will be opened at the end of this year at the latest.

FSC officials said the CBC could borrow from the experiences in conducting exchanges between the NT dollar and other foreign currencies to work out a pragmatic mechanism for regulating the opening, even in the absence of a formal cross-strait cash settlement agreement.
In March 2004, the central bank began to allow local citizens to bring in up to 6,000 yuan per homecoming visit and increased the limit to 20,000 yuan in October 2005.
Unconfirmed reports have said that Taiwanese people might have amassed a total of more than 100 billion Chinese yuan (US$14.25 billion) over the past several years.

The accumulation of Chinese currency in Taiwan can be attributed to a combination of factors, including China's chronic trade deficit with Taiwan and the inclination of Taiwanese businessmen operating in China to bring home Chinese yuan.
According to an estimate by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, local people have made a total of more than 12 million visits to China over the past three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Toko University coeds killed by drunken driver

TEXT.P: A drunken driver who killed two coeds of Toko University in Puzih City in the southern county of Chiayi late Wednesday has been identified as the university's director of general affairs, local police said Thursday.

According to police officers and public prosecutors investigating the incident, Lin Chi-cheng, 35, admitted that he had dozed off at the wheel when the sport utility vehicle he was driving hit the two female students, who were riding bicycles.
Chen Yi-chen, 20, and Wu Hao-shu, 21, were pronounced dead after they were rushed to a hospital.
Police found Lin still in his immobilized car 300 meters from the scene of the accident. The car had hit a wall and a tree, busting a tire before coming to a halt.
Officers who gave Lin a breathalyzer test found that his blood alcohol concentration measured 0.99 percent, almost four times the maximum allowed limit of 0.25 percent.
At a meeting Thursday, the teachers' advisory committee of Toko University decided to suspend Lin from his duties pending completion of the due process of law.

The university authorities said faculty members and students are not allowed to consume alcohol on campus and that they will be expelled from the university if they commit drunken driving offenses off campus.
Toko University President Huang Shao-yen expressed his condolences to the families of the two students and presented NT$100,000 to each family as a token gesture of solace.
Lin also apologized to the two families and promised to shoulder all the responsibility. He was released by the Chiayi District Public Prosecutors Office on bail of NT$100,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor to visit Shanghai to sign pact for 2010 World Expo

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-pin announced Thursday that he will travel to China to sign an agreement on showcasing the city's achievements in wireless broadband development and resource recycling at the 2010 Shanghai World Expo.

"It is a major honor that Taipei will be able to show off its progress in these two advanced fields along with such world metropolises as Geneva, London, Paris and Osaka at the Shanghai World Expo's `best practice' area," a jubilant Hau told a news conference.
According to Hau, it will mark the first time that Taiwan has been offered an opportunity to operate a pavilion at a world exposition since the country was forced out of the United Nations in 1971.

Noting that the city government has received confirmation that its application has been successful, Hau said he will travel to Shanghai to strike a final deal on the event and inspect the exhibition site.
"The itinerary will be worked out after we receive the event organizers' formal invitation letter, " Hau said, adding that it was too early to give an exact date for his visit.
If his travel plans come to fruition, Hau will be the first mayor of Taiwan's capital city ever to visit China.

Hau said the city government will need to seek financial aid from the central government and the private sector to realize its plan to showcase its wireless broadband and resource recycling models at the Shanghai World Expo, which will be held in an area between the Nanpu and Lupu bridges on both banks of the Huangpu River in Shanghai from May 1-Oct. 31, 2010.
The exposition will be divided into four main areas to accommodate national pavilions, city pavilions, thematic pavilions and the "Best Practice" area.

Asked whether Taipei will be downgraded to a city under China and incorporated into China's national pavilion, Hau said Taipei will only be showcased in the "Best Practice" area. Even if China opens a Taiwan pavilion at the exhibition, it will have nothing to do with the Taipei city government, he added.

Noting that more than 200 countries and international organizations are expected to take part in the Shanghai World Expo, Hau said he believes Taipei's participation in the event will be conducive to its city-to-city diplomacy and its international image and profile.

Taipei has won worldwide recognition for its wireless Internet infrastructure, including receiving the 2006 Intelligent Community Award conferred by the Intelligent Community Forum, which is an affiliated organization of the World Teleport Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 4, or the 28th day of the second month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1581: Sir Francis Drake, who in 1580 became the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe, is knighted in London by Queen Elizabeth I. The English naval hero later became vice admiral of the fleet that destroyed the Spanish Armada in 1588.
1617: John Napier, the Scottish mathematician who invented logarithms and introduced the use of the decimal point in writing numbers, dies at the age of 67.
1841: William Henry Harrison, the ninth president of the United States, dies of pneumonia at the age of 68 after only one month in office.
1900: Prince Edward, heir to the throne of England, narrowly escapes death when a teenage anarchist fires two shots at the prince who is on a train in a Brussels station.
1905: An earthquake rocks Lahore, then part of British India, killing some 19,000 people.
1932: The Republic of China observes its first Children's Day. Children have the day off from school.
1942: Japanese forces sink three British warships in the Bay of Bengal.
1949: The foreign ministers of Belgium, Britain, Canada, France, Holland, Luxembourg, Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Italy, Portugal and the United States sign the North Atlantic Treaty in Washington to protect Western nations from Soviet aggression.
1950: The Chinese Refugees Relief Association is inaugurated.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold E. Holt arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1968: Dr. Martin Luther King, the American civil rights leader who won the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize, is assassinated at a motel in Memphis, Tennessee. His eloquence and commitment to nonviolent tactics formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's.
1973: The Republic of China and the Khmer Republic conclude a temporary air transport agreement with an exchange of notes in Phnom Penh.
1974: The 21-member women's national basketball team returns after a tour of the United States and Brazil. The team won 24 games and lost six.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Botswana.
1974: U.S. Ambassador Walter P. McConaughy and his wife leave Taipei for retirement. He is succeeded by Ambassador Leonard Unger.
1976: Chinese at home and abroad mark the first anniversary of the passing of President Chiang Kai-shek with solemn ceremonies, tributes and prayers.
1979: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Pakistan's former president who was deposed by Gen. Zia ul-Haq in 1977, is hanged in Rawalpindi for the alleged murder of a political opponent.
1980: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo presides over a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1983: The United States grants political asylum to Hu Na, a noted tennis player from mainland China.
1989: The Ministry of Education approves the applications of three mainlanders to visit Taiwan.
1990: Communist China's legislature approves the Basic Law, the constitution that will govern Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.
1990: Britain publishes a bill to grant citizenship to up to 225,000 Hong Kong residents in the run-up to the colony's handover to mainland China in 1997.
1994: A communist Chinese court sentences Si Yang, a reporter at Hong Kong's Ming Pao newspaper, to 12 years in prison for "stealing and probing national secrets."
1999: At the conclusion of a weeklong visit to Taiwan, prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan urges Beijing to abandon threatening Taiwan with military aggression.
2000: Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi reiterates that his country's stance of supporting the Republic of China in international forums will never change.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, meets with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong in Taipei to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman must be sympathetic, obliging and affectionate: sympathetic and obliging to his friends and affectionate to the members of his family."

La Repubblica: Trade unions concede on Air France-Alitalia deal.
The trade unions in the Italian money-losing carrier Alitalia conceded and expressed their willingness to resume talks with Air France on its bid to take over Alitalia. The talks collapsed Wednesday after the trade unions presented a proposal which was described by Air France chairman Jean Cyril Spinetta as unacceptable.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disaster relief warehouse donated by Taiwan opens in Philippines
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, the Philippines, April 3 (CNA) 04/04/08 17:08:33 (By Emerson T.Lim and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A warehouse built with funds from Taiwan's government that will be used to store disaster relief supplies opened Thursday in Pasay City in the Philippines.

Taiwan donated US$300,000 to the Philippines at the end of 2006 to purchase supplies and help rebuild areas devastated by Typhoon Durian. The National Resource Operations Center Warehouse was also built with the funds to leave the Philippines in better position to cope with natural disasters in the future.

The warehouse, featuring two temperature-controlled rooms for storing perishable goods and a heat-insulating roof, is located near Manila International Airport and was completed after two years of construction.
Before the establishment of the new warehouse, all donations and goods were stored in an old warehouse at the Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD), department officials said.
Space often ran out in the warehouse, and the department had to set up a temporary enclosure nearby to store goods that were vulnerable to exposure to the sun and rain.
The DSWD plans to establish a second warehouse and peripheral facilities with the remainder of the funds provided by Taiwan, according to the officials.

To mark the inauguration of the 800-square-meter warehouse, Taiwan's representative to the Philippines Wu Hsin-hsing and Philippine Social Welfare and Development Secretary Esperanza I. Cabral presided over a ribbon-cutting ceremony on Thursday.

At the ceremony, Wu said Taiwan, with its close geographical proximity to the Philippines and its solid friendship with its southern neighbor, has always felt Filipino's suffering when disasters hit and the donation of the warehouse was an expression of that compassion.

Meanwhile, Cabral expressed her country's gratitude for Taiwan's humanitarian aid and expressed her hope that the governments of the two countries could push forward further cooperative relations in every field between the two countries.
Cabral later presented Wu with a plaque as a gesture of thanks to Taiwan's government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative Yuan to hold public hearing Monday on gasoline prices

TEXT.P: A legislative committee will hold a public hearing Monday to debate a controversial freeze on local gasoline prices that has temporarily reduced inflationary pressures but led to huge losses at state-owned oil refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan.

The Legislature's Economics and Energy Committee has invited representatives from academia, the government and industry to offer their views on increasing domestic fuel and electricity prices, resuming a price adjustment mechanism, and providing subsidies for disadvantaged groups if gas prices are raised.
On Friday, Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Wong Chung-chun urged the Executive Yuan to keep politics out of its handling of the fuel price issue and focus instead on economic considerations.
The questions that needed to be addressed, Wong said, were whether or not gas prices should be increased, and, if so, when and by how much.

Wong said officials from CPC Corp., Formosa Petrochemical Corp. (FPCC) -- Taiwan's only private refinery, the state-owned Taiwan Power Company, and other related government bodies such as the Council for Economic Planning and Development and the Fair Trade Commission would attend the hearing.

CPC, Taiwan's biggest oil refiner, said Tuesday it would maintain its freeze on gasoline and diesel prices in April in line with government policy, after Formosa Petrochemical hiked its prices at the pump by just under 10 percent in late March.

CPC has suffered substantial losses since the freeze was first imposed in November and is expected to post a deficit of NT$30 billion (US$984.25 million) in the first four months of 2008, said KMT Legislator Lu Shiow-yen.

Warning of a possible loss of more than NT$100 billion from national coffers from CPC deficits this year if the price cap is maintained, Lu urged the Executive Yuan to resume its use of the floating oil price mechanism that set gasoline prices based on international crude oil prices.

CPC adopted a floating pricing mechanism in January 2007 under which it adjusted its fuel prices on a weekly basis in response to crude oil price fluctuations. The system was then replaced by a monthly adjustment mechanism last September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tax office holding prize draw to encourage online filing

TEXT.P: The National Tax Administration of Northern Taiwan Province under the Ministry of Finance (MOF) is holding a special prize draw to encourage individuals and businesses to file their tax returns online.

Residents in the counties of Taipei, Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Yilan, Hualien, Kinmen and Lienchiang and in the cities of Keelung and Hsinchu will have their names entered into the draw for a chance to win one of several prizes up for grabs if they file their returns online between May 1 and June 2.
The prizes include a new car valued at NT$500,000 (US$16,400) , five motorcycles, each valued at NT$30,000, ten cash prizes of NT$10,000, and 30 cash prizes of NT$2,000.
Meanwhile, the MOF's Taipei National Tax Administration is holding its own draw for residents of Taiwan's capital who file their tax returns via the Internet.
In addition, the Taipei tax office is also offering free IC card readers to the first 1,400 residents of the city who file their returns online.

DOC.HEADLINE: Incoming, outgoing administration reps meet to discuss handover

TEXT.P: The convener of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) ad hoc presidential handover committee visited Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen for the first time Thursday to discuss matters related to the transfer of power to the new administration.

Chen, accompanied by Presidential Office deputy secretaries-general Chen Chi-mai and Lin Chia-lung, met with committee convener Chan Chun-po, KMT Deputy Secretary-General Chan Chi-hsien, and Feng Chi-tai, director of the international affairs department of the KMT's presidential election campaign headquarters, to exchange views on the matter in an atmosphere described later as very cordial.

During the one-hour meeting, the two sides agreed to set a date for a visit to the KMT's presidential handover committee by the Presidential Office secretary- general and deputy secretaries-general, as well as the heads of relevant Presidential Office units, for a briefing on the details of plans surrounding the May 20 presidential inauguration ceremony and related events.

According to a Presidential Office statement released after the meeting, Chen told the visitors that detailed preparations for the handover have already been drawn up and he expressed willingness to assist the committee and make arrangements according to their requirements.

At the same time, he went on, preparations have been made in line with President Chen Shui-bian's guidelines set forth March 28 on handling the transfer of power to ensure that political and social stability are maintained.

For his part, Chan expressed appreciation for his group's warm reception, as well as the efforts made by the Presidential Office to map out the arrangements for the handover, adding that he hopes the two sides can set up a mechanism and cooperate fully in handling the transfer of power so that the new administration can assume office smoothly.

Later that evening, Luo Chih-chiang, spokesman for the office of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew, said that as it was the initial meeting, the two sides only discussed the principles of the handover plans and established a "dialogue window, " adding that the details will be handled at future meetings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chen reflects on role as Taiwan protector at clan geneology unveiling

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reflected on his family history as well as his presidency Friday at a ceremony in his home county of Tainan marking the unveiling of the complete geneology of the Chen clan in the county's Hsichuang Village.
Prior to the ceremony, Chen visited the tomb of the first member of his clan to arrive in Taiwan from China centuries ago to pay homage in a traditional ceremony of ancestral and religious worship.

Speaking at the ceremony, Chen said his ancestors came to Taiwan from Shaoan County in the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian 300 years ago in search of peace and stability. Although following generations of the clan always remembered where they originally came from, they also knew that Taiwan was their home country, he stressed.
"They knew Taiwan was their country and that it was their duty and mission to protect it," he said.

During his eight years as president, Chen said, he has continuously striven to uphold this principle by working to protect Taiwan's interests, and he willfully accepted the responsibility of insisting on Taiwan-centric values and upholding Taiwan's sovereignty in the face of external pressure.
He added that history will judge him as a protector of Taiwan and that his compatriots will eventually come to understand his motivations and principles in this regard.
Meanwhile, Chen's updated geneology records clarified a misperception that he was of Hakka ancestry.
"According to the Chen clan geneology, my ancestors came from Shaoan County's Ciyao Village, which is a Hoklo community, not a Hakka community," he explained.
