DOC.HEADLINE: EPA offers tips on reducing air pollution on Tomb-sweeping Day

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) suggested Thursday that people should not burn incense and "ghost money" during Friday's Tomb-sweeping Day if they want to help reduce air pollution.

The traditional burning of incense and "ghost money" as offerings to the dead produce carcinogenic benzene and methylbenzene, as well as small suspended particles harmful to people suffering from respiratory disease, the official went on.
People should also be careful when burning "ghost money" at tombs in rural areas to avoid setting off grassfires, according to the official.

The EPA, the official said, has instructed environmental protection departments in the country's 25 cities and counties to set up free programs in which tomb sweepers can gather their "ghost money" together and have it burned in incinerators.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan children's film festival offers feast of creativity, fun

TEXT.P: Children in Taiwan will once again have a chance to step into a magic world of fun and creativity, with the opening of the third Taiwan International Children's TV and Film Festival (TICTFF), the event organizers said Friday in Taipei.

Educating children through television and film has always been one of our important services and we sincerely hope that audiences of all ages will enjoy an entertaining and educational feast of creativity at this year's film festival,said Cheng Tung-liao, chairman of the Public Television Service (PTS), one of the organizers of the TICTFF.

The event was ceremoniously opened by official guests, including Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey and PTS Chairman Cheng, who were dressed as magicians and waved their "wands" to unveil the mascot, in keeping with TICTFF's "Magic Garden" theme this year.
Eight-year-old Chiou Hsien-song, who has been playing the guitar for just one year, gave a solo performance that won the hearts of the audience.
Shieh, in his opening speech, explained to the overseas guests the significance of the Chinese characterwhich stands for "children."

He said the character is constructed of two parts -- a big head and two small feet -- which he said is similar to the appearance of an infant. The top part of the character signifies that a child's head is open to the world and that everything is possible, he added.
Shieh also pointed to the unlimited scope of the imagination as one of humanity's greatest assets.

"The biggest nation in the world is not the United States, nor is it China or India, but rather the imagination, which is the children's and our domain," Shieh said, drawing laughter and a big round of applause.

The third TICTFF, launched on April 4 Childrens Day in Taiwan, is organized by the PTS and Fubon Cultural & Educational Foundation, under the supervision of the Government Information Office. It brings film and TV productions, with their colorful dreams and lifestyles, from all over the world to children in Taiwan.

We believe that the Taiwan International Children's TV and Film Festival provides a new way for audiences to see the world," said Robert Chen, one of the film festival jurors. "It also encourages us to open our hearts and to experience the world."

Nicole Elena Dreiske, founder and artistic director of the Chicago International Children's Film Festival said that what is most valuable about the festival is that it induces children to think about what they watch.

"Media education is one of the most important common issues in global culture,she said, adding that children will become "passive consumers and uninformed voters" if they do not digest, discuss and and reflect on what they are watching.
Irene Chen, president of the Fubon Cultural & Educational Foundation, said that as a mother of four children, aged 13 to 19, she found the TICTFF very educational.

"Through the festival's marvelous efforts, its productions and films, our children have a chance to grasp and embrace the true notion of a global village, to become better, more broad-minded people with an appreciation for different cultures,she said.

This years TICTFF features four exhibitions and ten workshops at Eslite Bookstores on Xinyi and Dunhua South roads, Taipei City. The biennial will also screen 105 films from 31 countries, until it closes on April 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mysterious side of Cihhu soon to be opened to public

TEXT.P: The temporary burial place of Taiwan's late President Chiang Kai-shek in Taoyuan County, once a prime tourist attraction, lost some of its luster in recent decades as democratization gripped Taiwan and the authoritarian figure fell out of favor.

But interest in the Cihhu Presidential Burial Place was actually revived in the past two years as it became embroiled in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) campaign to remove public vestiges of the man many see as a brutal dictator.

Chiang statues from around Taiwan were relocated to the hillside park near the mausoleum, and the DPP then further raised the site's profile when it closed down access to Chiang's marble sarcophagus late last December by pulling funding for the military detail guarding the grounds.

With the election of Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Ma Ying-jeou in the March 22 presidential election, Taoyuan County officials hope the mausoleum will be reopened and plan to give the public a glimpse of a previously restricted section of the park.
The forbidden area, which sits to the rear of Chiang's temporary burial place, has been closely guarded by the military since the late president built a residence on the grounds in 1962.

Cihhu, also spelled Cihu or Tzuhu, refers to the lake located near the tomb site. Originally called "Horn South Pond" because of its shape, " the lake was renamed by Chiang in memory of his mother because the scenery in the area reminded him of his hometown of Sikou in Zhejiang province's Fenghua County in eastern China.
Chiang's favorite residence was converted into his temporary resting site after his death on April 5, 1975 and opened to visitors.

But the mysterious grounds behind the mausoleum remained under the control of the Ministry of National Defense (MND) , making it impossible for the public to appreciate the beauty of the location or Chiang's security precautions.

The trail into the lush woodlands of the restricted area is punctuated with blockhouses, stone-walled sentry posts and bomb shelters, reflecting the tensions between Chiang's government and its Chinese communist rival and his concern for his own safety.

The Taoyuan county government plans to turn the scenic spot, with its hilly woods and quiet pond, into a site for concerts or other public events. The few buildings in the area dubbed "rear Cihhu" have been renovated into exhibition halls, awaiting visitors to witness relics from the Chiang era.

Su Wen-shen, the supervisor of Dasi Township where Cihhu is located, hopes that after President-elect Ma takes office on May 20, areas closed to the public, including "rear Cihhu, " will be open to everybody.

The stakes for Dasi and the county are high. They hope Chiang's resting place and the opening of the restricted area will boost local tourism and increase the NT$400 million to NT$500 million (US$13.11 million to US$16.39 million) in an annual revenues Cihhu tourism is estimated to have injected into the area in recent years.

In anticipation of the new opening, the Taoyuan Tourism Marketing Department has also created a Chiang Family Culture Park, which integrates period pieces and buildings related to Chiang and his son Chiang Ching-kuo, who was entombed in Dasi's Touliao in 1988.
Taoyuan County officials acknowledge that the area behind the elder Chiang's mausoleum, which remains off-limits to visitors to this day, lacks any eye- catching landmarks.
But, the officials say, this site that was, in effect, Chiang's back yard, offers a rare combination of historical tradition and natural beauty that they hope will spark new prosperity in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign Christian missionaries help locals clean cemetery

TEXT.P: A group of foreign Christian missionaries drew attention Friday at a public cemetery in Taichung City, central Taiwan, when they assisted locals in weeding their family tombs and cleaning the cemetery.
The missionaries were volunteering at the cemetery to mark Tomb-Sweeping Day, a national holiday in Taiwan where families remember deceased relatives by sprucing up their tombs.

More than 50 missionaries of the U.S.-based Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints -- commonly called the Mormon Church -- appeared at the No. 32 cemetery to help with the tomb-sweeping activities.

The missionaries said they were happy to make the effort because it was a good way to engage in cultural exchanges with local residents and an opportunity to become more familiar with traditional Taiwanese culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opening of weekend cross-strait charter flights requires talks: MAC

TEXT.P: The opening of weekend charter flights will require consultations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and cannot be decided by Taiwan unilaterally, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) spokesman said Friday.
Liu Teh-hsun was responding to media reports that president-elect Ma Ying-jeou has met with his staff on the plan for direct cross-strait flights, one of his key campaign promises.
The reports indicated that if everything progresses as expected, the weekend charter flight services will begin July 4.

Liu noted, however, that according to an agreement reached between Taipei and Beijing on cross-strait charter flights in 2006, there are only four kinds of charter flight service -- special charter cargo flights, regular charter passenger flights for special holidays and the operation of charter services for emergency medical needs or humanitarian purposes.

Regular charter flight services are available during the Chinese New Year, Tombsweeping Day, Dragon Boat Festival and Mid-Autumn Festival holidays between Taoyuan and Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou and Xiamen in China.
"Weekend charter flight service does not fall into the four categories," Liu said.

Liu noted that the original agreement says any adjustment in the plan requires consultations by related agencies, even if it just involves an increase in the number of flights or flight destinations, "not to mention the addition of cross- strait charters on weekends."
"Even if the MAC looks forward to the realization of weekend cross-strait charter flight service, consultations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be essential, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stray cat protection group urges cat owners to be responsible

TEXT.P: The Taipei Stray Cats Protection Association (SCPA) held a parade in Taipei Friday to celebrate Taiwan Cat Day and called on local residents to show more compassion for stray cats.

"We hope to raise awareness of the existence of Taiwan Cat Day on April 4, as it is generally known as Women and Children's Day here in Taiwan, " said Hsiao Chun, a member of the nonprofit organization.
The goal of the event, which was the first of its kind in Taiwan, was to familiarize those who do not have cats with the animals' behavior and compel cat owners to act more responsibly, Hsiao said.
"We hope whoever decides to keep a cat will think twice before actually adopting one because it is a lifetime responsibility, " she added.
At the parade, some cat lovers dressed as catwomen while others brought their cats to play with passers-by and promote the idea of adoption.
Ren Shan-shan, who adopted a stray cat with feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV or feline AIDS) , said her two-year-old cat Morphine was no different from normal healthy cats.
"Cats with FIV will not pass it on to human beings or other kinds of animal. It is just difficult for them to recover from the illness,"she said.
She added that Morphine was her second cat with FIV, but she became fond of it from the first moment she saw it.
Many people prefer kittens because they are cuter but grown-up cats are more independent and can take care of themselves,she said.
SCPA was founded in 2006 by a group of volunteers and cat lovers and was recognized by the Taipei City Government aiming to promote awareness and respect of animal rights.

Stray animals are a serious problem in Taiwan. Only 36 percent of the strays in Taipei City are neutered, far less than the 70 percent in the United States, according to the Taipei Municipal Institute for Animal Health.

Due to the limited number of shelters available to hold stray cats, animal protection groups have advocated more aggressively encouraging adoption and urged the government to increase its budget for animal contraception and its trap, neuter, release (TNR) project, while reducing the amount spent on slaughtering unwanted animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma pledges to visit Chiang mausoleums annually

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Friday that he will visit the mausoleums of two late presidents from his party -- Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo -- on April 5 to observe the 33rd anniversary of Chiang Kai-shek's death, adding that he will continue to do so each year after he takes office on May 20.

Chiang Kai-shek's remains were entombed at the Cihhu presidential burial place in the northern county of Taoyuan after his death on April 5, 1975. The body of his elder son, Chiang Ching-kuo, who was president of Taiwan between 1978 and 1988, was laid to rest in Touliao, also in Taoyuan, after he passed away on Jan.13, 1988.

The Cihhu and Toulaio sites were closed to public access on Dec. 24, 2007 by the current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration as part of its efforts to downplay the legacy of the Chiangs.

Noting that judgment on the Chiangs is open to discussion, Ma told CNA reporters that the purpose of his visit to the mausoleums was to "commemorate the deaths of the former Kuomintang (KMT) leaders," and should not be branded as an act of "worship."
Ma said that he was not very concerned about any controversy over his visit to the tombs, stressing that "everyone can hold different views on history."

Commenting on the DPP's renaming on May 19, 2007 of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei as the National Taiwan Democracy Hall, Ma said he was concerned about the "legitimacy" of the change.
"Your views may be different from mine, but you cannot coerce me into adhering to your opinions," said Ma, adding that divergent opinions within the society should be tolerated.

"Taiwan is already a mature democracy, " he said, citing as proof the recently concluded presidential election in which he and his running mate Vincent Siew won over 7.6 million votes, or 58.45 percent of the ballots cast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Donation program for 10,000 children to end in September: GIO

TEXT.P: A sponsorship program launched in 2005 by the Government Information Office (GIO) to support 10,000 children in Southeast Asian countries affected by a devastating tsunami in late 2004 will come to an end on Sept. 30, GIO Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said Thursday.

The three-year program, which raised more than NT$407.5 million (US$13.4 million) from local residents, has benefited children in Sri Lanka, Indonesia's Aceh province and Nias Island, and those suffering from poverty and domestic violence in Taiwan.
Some interest earned on the funds will also be used to help local disadvantaged children, he said.
Shieh's statement came after the program's supervisory committee approved the final donation project totaling NT$36 million.

Shieh said the GIO commissioned four local charities -- including the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families, World Vision Taiwan, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and the Child Welfare League Foundation -- to implement the program, which the GIO chief said has raised Taiwan's international profile.
The undersea earthquake-sparked tsunami killed at least 225,000 people in the region on Dec. 26, 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma: Taiwan to join international organizations under 'Chinese Taipei'

TEXT.P: Taiwan's President-elect Ma Ying-jeou signaled his intention Friday to employ pragmatism and flexibility in his foreign policy, stating that "Chinese Taipei" is an acceptable name for Taiwan to use in international organizations, a suggestion that represented a significant departure from the position of the current administration.

In an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency Friday, Ma, when asked about the sensitive name issue, said, "Has there been any success (in joining international organizations) by using any names other than 'Chinese Taipei'? Except for the even worse 'Taipei, China,' is there a more acceptable name than'Chinese Taipei?'"

Following Ma's landslide victory in the March 22 presidential election, Taiwan's foreign policy is expected to undergo a fundamental shift from a pro- independence approach under the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government to a policy of what Ma called "modus vivendi," within which dignity, pragmatism and flexibility are the fundamental principles.

The upcoming World Health Assembly (WHA) , the WHO's governing body that is scheduled to open May 19 in Geneva, one day before Ma's inauguration, is seen likely to be the first crucial test of the relationship between China and Ma's new administration.

Ma indicated that Taiwan should continue to apply for WHO observer status, but he strongly opposed the idea of application for full membership under the name Taiwan, a strategy the DPP government adopted last year. Ma referred to the DPP's approach as a "total embarrassment, " that resulted in a WHO delegate of an allied country avoiding the vote on Taiwan's application under the pretext of having diarrhea.

Referring to the title Taiwan uses in the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and the World Trade Organization (WTO) , Ma said he believes that "Chinese Taipei" is workable, noting that even China has not objected to that name.

Since Taiwan's expulsion from the United Nations and affiliated organizations in 1971, it has been isolated from major international activities, managing to retain only 23 allies, to date. Taiwan's efforts to participate in international organizations has met with strong opposition from China. One rare exception is the WTO which allowed Taiwan to join under the name "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matzu," and also refers to the country as "Chinese Taipei."

Emphasizing the principles of his policy of modus vivendi, Ma also called for reconciliation in the international arena between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, saying that even China has gradually accepted Taiwan's de facto existence, a situation that he said makes peaceful co-existence possible.

The president-elect however warned Beijing that if it continues to suppress Taiwan, the Taiwanese people, if stripped of dignity, would choose to fight back, a consequence that would not serve the interests of either side, he added.
Ma also strongly criticized President Chen Shui-bian for having already issued order to apply for WHO membership using last year's formula, a move that Ma said was "very unfair to us."

"President Chen is about to step down, but the new government will bear the consequences of possible failure (of the application)," Ma said. "President Chen can certainly claim that he is consistent... but we object to the legacy he is leaving us."

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma continues to define China as "mainland area"

TEXT.P: Taiwan's president-elect Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Friday his "mutual non-denial" position in dealing with Beijing and said China will continue to be defined as the "mainland area" in the law governing relations across the Taiwan Strait.

In an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency in which he outlined his stance toward China, Ma indicated that at present, "mutual recognition (between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait) is not possible, while mutual denial is unnecessary. Therefore only mutual non-denial can provide space for interaction."

He said that China once refused to face the reality of Taiwan's existence but now only emphasized its objection to Taiwan's "de jure independence, " a clear indication that Taiwan and China can find a way to co-exist peacefully.
According to Ma, mutual non-denial implies that "we will not deny their (China's) existence but we cannot recognize their sovereignty."
With the Kuomintang-supported Ma emerging victorious in the March 22 presidential election, a sea change in Taiwan's China policy and cross-strait relationship appears imminent.

Ma publicly announced during and after the election campaign that he would launch regular weekend charter flights, open Taiwan to Chinese tourists, relax restrictions on investment in China, and negotiate the three direct links, a more open approach to ties with Beijing that marks a reversal of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) policy over the past eight years.

To cope with the new situation, Ma admitted that "the Act Governing Relations between Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area" will have to be amended, but stressed that under the framework of the Constitution of the Republic of China, "China can not be addressed as the People's Republic of China."

Although critics have argued that Ma has oversimplified complex cross-strait issues and made comments that were not well thought out, the president-elect said he was fully aware that nothing could be accomplished in a single step.

Ma stressed he would exert great caution in pursuing ties with China and favored a gradual approach, but he also emphasized that issues like weekend charter flights had been sufficiently discussed in past years but were simply not acted on by the DPP government.
Noting that China is only part of the KMT's "global-linkage" strategy, Ma contended that the DPP totally ignored the importance of China and took a hands- off position instead.
"The fundamental difference between Ma and the current government will be to face issues pragmatically, rather than putting them off or facing them blindly, which is key," he said.

To normalize economic relations with China, the optimistic Ma said he would look to sign agreements on protecting investments by Taiwanese businesses in China and avoiding double taxation, which he did not feel would encounter any resistance.
Ma also defended his support for recognizing diplomas issued by Chinese universities in Taiwan, which critics have said would cost local residents job opportunities at home.
He said he supported the policy to facilitate exchanges of students and professors rather than to enable them to acquire professional licenses in Taiwan.

Asked if he would mention the "1992 Consensus, " in which the KMT says Taiwan and China acknowledged "one China" but with different interpretations, in his May 20 inauguration address, Ma said only that the speech is being drafted and would not elaborate.
As for plans for him to visit the U.S. before May 20 and for the U.S. to send a special envoy to his inauguration, Ma said no decision has been made on either issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmaker urges immediate security briefing of president-elect

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chang Hsien-yao called on government agencies Friday to apprise KMT President-elect Ma Ying-jeou early of the nation's current security situation and the challenges it faces in that regard.

Chang, a former official of the National Security Council (NSC), noted that Ma will not take office until May 20, and expressed concern that Ma "might not have firsthand information on national security or cross-strait issues."
Chang's remarks came after former NSC secretary-general Ting Yu-chou criticized Ma as "not being ready to take up his post."
Ting said that Ma, since his election on March 22, has been talking a lot on matters with which he's not very familiar, which could have created the impression that he is "too complacent."

Ting said that Ma's remarks on issues on which he is not well versed, showed a "lack of prudence and careful consideration." In making the point, Ting cited Ma's July timetable for implementing cross-strait charter flights, implying that it was improper to give a definite date.

Chang said that Ting's remarks should be seen as "a helpful suggestion, rather than criticism." Ting served as the head of the National Security Bureau between 1999 and 2001 and the NSC secretary-general between 2001 and 2002 and has rich experience in matters of "cross-strait relations and national security," Chang added.

Chang said that Ting probably thought that national security authorities had failed to provide Ma with thorough and detailed briefings, which Chang said are crucial in preparing the president-elect for the job.

Chang urged that the relevant government agencies, including the NSC, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of National Defense, National Security Bureau and Mainland Affairs Council arrange a briefing for Ma soon.
"The briefing should be arranged immediately, instead of waiting until after May 20," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Caribbean ally sends congratulatory message, vows no change in ties

TEXT.P: The eastern Caribbean nation of Saint Kitts and Nevis has sent a congratulatory telegram on the election of Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang as Taiwan's next president, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Friday.

"St. Kitts and Nevis Prime Minister Denzil Douglas sent a congratulatory message on behalf of his country earlier in the day, " MOFA spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said, adding that the ministry will forward the telegram to Ma's office next Monday when all public offices reopen after the tomb-sweeping holiday.

In his message, Yeh said, Douglas also reassured the foreign ministry that the 25-year-old diplomatic relations between his country and Taiwan will remain intact in the wake of transition of power between different political parties in Taiwan.
"Douglas also expressed hopes that bilateral relations will be further deepened and expanded during Ma's term of office," Yeh said.

Douglas' congratulatory message came after Vice President Annette Lu said in a media interview earlier this week that the failure of three allies -- Guatemala, Burkina Faso and St. Kitts -- to send congratulatory messages on Ma's victory in the March 22 presidential poll was a warning that ties with those countries could be tenuous.

Yeh on Thursday acknowledged that the foreign ministry had yet to receive congratulatory messages from Burkina Faso and St. Kitts, also known as Saint Christopher and Nevis, but she said the oversight was due to administrative delays in those two countries.

She did not mention the situation with Guatemala, but Foreign Minister James Huang indicated that the Central American country already said soon after Ma was elected that it would send its vice president to Ma's inauguration ceremony, signaling the strong ties between the two countries.

Meanwhile, Yeh said Thursday that St. Kitts and Nevis Gov. Cuthbert Sebastian will head a delegation to attend Ma's May 20 inauguration, which she said is proof of stable ties bwteen the two countries. The Caribbean ally opened its first embassy in Asia in Taipei in January this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect vows to prevent influx of 'hot money' from China

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that he will propose anti-speculation legislation that will prevent Chinese investors from trying to make quick profits in the local real estate market.

Ma said in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency (CNA) that his government will seek to normalize economic relations between Taiwan and China while maintaining Taiwan's national security and dignity.

As an example, Ma said his government would allow Chinese investors to invest in Taiwan's real estate market but also pass supplementary measures to prevent speculators from manipulating the market to make quick gains.
Under the measure, Chinese investors will not be allowed to resell the properties they buy in Taiwan within five years after making the purchase, he said.
Ma also warned that speculative capital might come not just from China but also from Southeast Asian countries and said the new government will take action against any speculative moves.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'I will not run for KMT chairmanship': President-elect

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Friday that he will not run for his party's chairmanship next year.
"I resigned as the KMT chairman last year, and I feel that that way is fine, " Ma said in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency.

A debate over whether Ma should lead the party while serving as president emerged after KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung suggested on Wednesday that he was open to the idea of having Ma hold the two posts concurrently.
Some party insiders believe such an arrangement would make it easier to coordinate policy between the party and the government.

Should Ma want to run for the post, however, the party's charter would have to be amended prior to the chairmanship election slated for August 2009 to allow the president to act as party chairman, Wu said at a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting.

KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih said that if Ma wanted to become party chairman, whether he would still have to be directly elected by party members or could become chairman by virtue of having been elected president by a broader base of voters could also be discussed.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT member, said an advantage of serving as both the president and the party chairman is that the president could have his policies implemented by the legislature through the party.
The KMT holds 80 seats, or nearly three-fourths, of the 113-seat legislature.
Wang cautioned, however, that a downside to dual leadership would be that it could lead to the KMT repeating its past mistake of having the government follow the party line.

Ma was elected KMT chairman on Aug. 19, 2005, but resigned from the post on Feb. 23, 2007 immediately after he was indicted for allegedly misusing his special allowance funds during his eight-year term as mayor of Taipei City between 1998 and 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to promote Matsu culture as intangible cultural heritage

TEXT.P: Followers of the folk deity Matsu from both sides of the Taiwan Strait are planning to seek United Nations approval to have the Matsu culture declared an intangible world cultural heritage, a promoter said Friday.

The idea was proposed Friday at a Taiwan Matsu cultural forum at the Jenn Lann Temple in Dajia in the central county of Taichung, which is a historical site of worship of Matsu, also known as Chinese goddess of sea. The event was part of the 2008 Taichung County Matsu International Festival, which began Feb. 21 and is scheduled to end April 28.
During the forum, Matsu believers from Japan, South Korea, Australia and Singapore shared their views on various ways of worshipping the goddess.

Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, who also attended the forum, said that the Matsu culture, which is interwoven with a series of original worship and pilgrimage ceremonies, is not just a traditional folk religion. According to Huang, belief in Matsu and her power to bless believers has spread and gained depth through an increasing number of religious and cultural activities, including the annual round-the-island pilgrimage of the Dajia Matsu statue.

For over 200 years, the Jenn Nann Temple in Dajia township has been a religious mecca for Matsu worshipers in dozens of local villages, and has also drawn huge numbers of followers from all over the island. The Dajia Matsu pilgrimage in Spring is an internationally renowned event that draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims every year to worship and honor the goddess of the sea.

The complex and creative Matsu-worshipping ceremonies and activities have been listed by the Discovery Channel as one of three major religious festivals in the world, according to the 18th-century Jenn Nann Temple.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's intellectuals impressed by Taiwan's election: Beijing scholar

TEXT.P: Liberal intellectuals in China are highly impressed by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Ma Ying-jeou's victory in Taiwan's March 22 presidential election, a visiting Beijing scholar said Friday.

"This election has reversed some of the long-held negative impressions of Taiwan's democratic development," said Li Fan, who has promoted grassroots elections in China for years and has visited Taiwan several times to observe its elections.

Li, in an interview with CNA before he left Taipei for home, said that even as Taiwan is switching its attention from the poll to the possible lineup of Ma's administration, intellectuals in China are still earnestly discussing the election.
He noted that, based on ideology, some liberal intellectuals in China have not had good opinions regarding Taiwan's democratic development, and could even be said to have been "rather negative."

But the KMT's victory has changed all that, mainly because many intellectuals in China have perceived that the difference between the "pan-blue" camp, headed by the KMT, and the "pan-green" parties, led by the incumbent Democratic Progressive Party administration, lies in one favoring cross-strait unification and the other insisting on Taiwan independence.
But with Taiwan's second peaceful transition of power through democratic election, "the liberal intellectuals in China have gone wild," Li said.
The average Chinese citizen, on the subject of Taiwan's election, has also expressed the view that "democracy on the other side has borne fruit, while ours is still under the icy ground."
Li said that Taiwan also has a high degree of freedom, which he described as "an inspiration to China."
He said that democracy needs gradual fermentation, but under Taiwan's influence, "China's democracy is imminent and unstoppable."

DOC.HEADLINE: 8,200-plus in Taiwan waiting for organ transplant

TEXT.P: As of Friday, more than 8,200 people in Taiwan were still waiting for organ transplants, more than 50 times as many people who have been given transplants this year, the Taiwan Organ Registry Sharing Center said.
Liu Chia-chi, deputy executive director of the center, said that only 148 people have had their wishes fulfilled this year, based on the number of organs donated.

Liu said hospitals in Taiwan only register the number of organs donated by people who had died and not live organ donations, so it was difficult for the center to know if patients had already received organs from their relatives and had already been excluded from the waiting list.
She said that the Department of Health estimated two years ago that around 450 Taiwanese patients travel to China each year to have organ transplants, with about 300 getting kidney transplants.

But she said that now that China has banned the sale of organs, organ transactions have moved to the black market. The impact of this change on Taiwanese traveling to China to have their kidney and liver transplanted is "unclear."

Although organ transplant patients have to take anti-rejection drugs all their lives, those who take the drug are not necessarily organ transplant patients, Liu said, citing as an example lupus (SLE) patients.

"Therefore, it is hard to determine the number of patients who received organ transplants overseas and returned to Taiwan to take the anti-rejection drug based simply on data on anti-rejection drugs given under the national health insurance program," she said.
The two blind spots in the present registry system are live organ transplants and organ transplants overseas, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 5, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect vows to review bans on technology exports to China

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who has pledged closer economic ties with China, said Friday his government will first assess which technologies can be exported to China before determining whether local high-tech firms can establish bigger presences there.

The new government will listen to experts' opinions on the matter, Ma told the Central News Agency in an interview, promising that he will "respect professionalism and there will not many political considerations."

Supporting the removal of a restriction that limits Taiwanese companies' investment in China to up to 40 percent of their net worth, Ma said that government controls should focus only on technologies, not capital.
Ma pointed out that if Taiwan is not the sole source of some technologies for China, the government's restrictions will only hinder the development of Taiwanese companies in that market.
He explained that the U.S. government, which adheres to the Wassenaar Arrangement on export controls of technologies, had allowed Intel Corp., the world's biggest chipmaker, to invest in China.
This obviously shows that 12-inch wafer manufacturing technology is no longer considered as a key technology, he went on, referring to Intel's construction of a 12-inch wafer fab in China.
Ma added that although Taiwan is not a signatory of the Wassenaar Arrangement, his government will still adopt the convention by 40 countries as a standard.

The agreement -- which was first signed by 33 countries, including the United States, in Wassenaar, the Netherlands, in mid-1996 -- is aimed at controlling the exports of conventional arms and dual-use goods and technologies to countries perceived as threats to peace.
At present, Taiwan allows local firms to invest in 8-inch wafer plants in China, which Ma said is no longer an advanced technology there.
Executives of local semiconductor companies told him that if Taiwan had lifted the ban on technology transfers two years ago, their market shares would have grown substantially, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect's possible attendance at Boao Forum attracts attention

TEXT.P: Many observers will be watching closely to see if Vice President-elect Vincent Siew attends next week's Boao Forum in Hainan, China, in what could be a sign of the potential for closer ties between Taipei and Beijing under the incoming Kuomintang (KMT) administration.

Siew, a seed member of the Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) , has attended the Boao Forum every year since its inception in 2001, but with Chinese President Hu Jintao also scheduled to attend, whether Siew will be able to make the trip remains uncertain.
The BFA is a non-governmental, not-for-profit international organization modelled after the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.
During an interview with CNA Friday, President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said he is unaware whether Siew will attend this year's BFA meeting.
"I need to ask Siew about his intention before answering your question in this regard," Ma told CNA interviewers.
Asked whether it would be strange if Siew is absent from this year's meeting scheduled for April 10-13, Ma simply answered: "Yes."

Sources familiar with the Boao Forum for Asia said Siew has consistently thrown his full support to its activities over the past year, but following the March 22 presidential election, the situation may have changed.

"With his election as Taiwan's next vice president, his status has changed and it has become very sensitive as to whether he will attend the forum's upcoming conference, " said a source who spoke on condition of anonymity.
It was said that former Council of Labor Affairs Minister Chan Hou-shen, a close Siew friend, will attend the upcoming Boao Forum meeting.

China frowns at the appearance of any high-ranking Taiwanese government official at international conferences or forums, even in organizations such as the Asia- Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in which Taiwan is a full-fledged member.
Siew, a former premier and economics minister, has attended the annual Boao Forum in his capacity as chairman of the Cross-Strait Common Market in the past few years.

During the 2007 forum, Siew met with Wu Bangguo, chairman of the National People's Congress, China's rubber-stamp parliament, and asked Wu to help push Beijing authorities to allow Chinese citizens to make sighseeing trips to Taiwan as soon as possible.
Siew also proposed at that time that the two sides strengthen cooperation in mutually beneficial financial, agricultural and energy resource development.

The founding of the forum was driven by the People's Republic of China and founded by 26 Australasian states on Feb.27, 2001. It has its fixed address in Boao, Hainan, China, although the Secretariat is based in Beijing.
The BFA holds a high-level annual forum for representatives from government, business, and academia with the focus on economics, integration, cooperation, social issues, and the environment.
In addition to its annual meeting, the organization also sponsors other forums and meetings related to Asian issues.
Besides Hu, Australian Prime Minister Kein Rudd, Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf and top leaders of 10-plus other countries will also attend this year's forum, acording to BFA sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 5, or the 29th day of the second month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1725: Giovanni Casanova, Italian adventurer famous for his amorous conquests, is born.
1793: President George Washington approves plans for new public buildings and roads in the American capital city.
1827: Joseph Lister, British surgeon and discoverer of antiseptic agents, is born. He demonstrated in 1865 that carbolic acid was an effective antiseptic.
1895: Oscar Wilde, the author of the highly successful plays "The Importance of Being Earnest" and "Lady Windemere's Fan," sues the Marquess of Queensberry for libel.
1896: The first modern Olympic Games begin in Athens.
1900: Spencer Tracy, American actor who won an Oscar two years in a row for "Captain Courageous" (1937) and "Boys Town" (1938), is born.
1915: Jack Johnson, the first black world heavyweight boxing champion, losses his title to the "Great White Hope" Jess Willard.
1916: Gregory Peck, American actor noted for both his fine film performances and his work for humanitarian causes, is born.
1941: Allied forces recapture Addis Ababa in Ethiopia during World War II.
1949: The Chinese national government begins talks with Chinese Communists.
1950: The Executive Yuan grants Taiwan authority to carry out self-government by popular elections in counties and cities within two months.
1951: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are sentenced to death in the United States for giving away atomic weapons secrets to the Soviet Union.
1954: More than 14,000 Chinese Communist POW's in Korea who refused to return to the Chinese mainland take their oath to join the ROC armed forces.
1955: British Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill announces his resignation. He is succeeded by Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden.
1960: The film "Ben Hur" wins 10 Oscars.
1964: Douglas MacArthur, American general who served as U.S. chief of staff and commanded the Allied forces in the South Pacific during World War II, dies at the age of 84. He commanded U.N. forces in Korea until a conflict over strategy led to his dismissal by President Harry S. Truman.
1975: President Chiang Kai-shek passes away in Taiwan at the age of 89.
1976: Howard Robard Hughes, American film producer, aviator, and multimillionaire, dies at the age of 71. He founded Hughes Aircraft Corporation, broke the air speed record in 1935, and flew around the world in record time in 1938.
1976: The National Youth Commission reports helping some 31,000 youths find jobs since its establishment 10 years earlier.
1982: The British task force to oust Argentinian forces from the Falkland Islands sets sail.
1988: Arab gunmen seize a Kuwait Airways Boeing 747 flying from Bangkok to Kuwait. The 111 hostages aboard were freed on April 20 when the hijackers surrendered in Algiers.
1989: A political pact between the independent trade union federation Solidarity and the government of Wojciech Jaruzelski ends Communist rule in Poland.
1990: The Republic of China reestablishes diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Lesotho. Peking (Beijing) severs ties with Lesotho two days later.
1991: President George Bush orders U.S. Air Force transport planes to begin dropping supplies to Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq.
1994: Israel begins to withdraw from the Gaza Strip.
1998: Japan's 3,911 meter-long Akashi Kaikyo Bridge, the world's longest suspension bridge linking the main islands of Honshu and Shikoku, is opened to traffic.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin I-hsiung pays a visit to James Soong, chairman of the newly founded People First Party, to seek PFP support for the abolition of the upcoming National Assembly election.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian holds amiable talks with the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, in a landmark encounter at the Presidential Office.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A good honest man, after educating the people for seven years, will be able to lead them to war."

DOC.HEADLINE: Caribbean ally sends congratulatory message, vows no change in ties

TEXT.P: The eastern Caribbean nation of Saint Kitts and Nevis has sent a congratulatory telegram on the election of Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang as Taiwan's next president, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Friday.

"St. Kitts and Nevis Prime Minister Denzil Douglas sent a congratulatory message on behalf of his country earlier in the day, " MOFA spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said, adding that the ministry will forward the telegram to Ma's office next Monday when all public offices reopen after the tomb-sweeping holiday.

In his message, Yeh said, Douglas also reassured the foreign ministry that the 25-year-old diplomatic relations between his country and Taiwan will remain intact in the wake of transition of power between different political parties in Taiwan.
"Douglas also expressed hopes that bilateral relations will be further deepened and expanded during Ma's term of office," Yeh said.

Douglas' congratulatory message came after Vice President Annette Lu said in a media interview earlier this week that the failure of three allies -- Guatemala, Burkina Faso and St. Kitts -- to send congratulatory messages on Ma's victory in the March 22 presidential poll was a warning that ties with those countries could be tenuous.

Yeh on Thursday acknowledged that the foreign ministry had yet to receive congratulatory messages from Burkina Faso and St. Kitts, also known as Saint Christopher and Nevis, but she said the oversight was due to administrative delays in those two countries.

She did not mention the situation with Guatemala, but Foreign Minister James Huang indicated that the Central American country already said soon after Ma was elected that it would send its vice president to Ma's inauguration ceremony, signaling the strong ties between the two countries.

Meanwhile, Yeh said Thursday that St. Kitts and Nevis Gov. Cuthbert Sebastian will head a delegation to attend Ma's May 20 inauguration, which she said is proof of stable ties bwteen the two countries. The Caribbean ally opened its first embassy in Asia in Taipei in January this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to promote Matsu culture as intangible cultural heritage

TEXT.P: Followers of the folk deity Matsu from both sides of the Taiwan Strait are planning to seek United Nations approval to have the Matsu culture declared an intangible world cultural heritage, a promoter said Friday.

The idea was proposed Friday at a Taiwan Matsu cultural forum at the Jenn Lann Temple in Dajia in the central county of Taichung, which is a historical site of worship of Matsu, also known as Chinese goddess of sea. The event was part of the 2008 Taichung County Matsu International Festival, which began Feb. 21 and is scheduled to end April 28.
During the forum, Matsu believers from Japan, South Korea, Australia and Singapore shared their views on various ways of worshipping the goddess.

Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, who also attended the forum, said that the Matsu culture, which is interwoven with a series of original worship and pilgrimage ceremonies, is not just a traditional folk religion. According to Huang, belief in Matsu and her power to bless believers has spread and gained depth through an increasing number of religious and cultural activities, including the annual round-the-island pilgrimage of the Dajia Matsu statue.

For over 200 years, the Jenn Nann Temple in Dajia township has been a religious mecca for Matsu worshipers in dozens of local villages, and has also drawn huge numbers of followers from all over the island. The Dajia Matsu pilgrimage in Spring is an internationally renowned event that draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims every year to worship and honor the goddess of the sea.

The complex and creative Matsu-worshipping ceremonies and activities have been listed by the Discovery Channel as one of three major religious festivals in the world, according to the 18th-century Jenn Nann Temple.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's intellectuals impressed by Taiwan's election: Beijing scholar

TEXT.P: Liberal intellectuals in China are highly impressed by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Ma Ying-jeou's victory in Taiwan's March 22 presidential election, a visiting Beijing scholar said Friday.

"This election has reversed some of the long-held negative impressions of Taiwan's democratic development," said Li Fan, who has promoted grassroots elections in China for years and has visited Taiwan several times to observe its elections.

Li, in an interview with CNA before he left Taipei for home, said that even as Taiwan is switching its attention from the poll to the possible lineup of Ma's administration, intellectuals in China are still earnestly discussing the election.
He noted that, based on ideology, some liberal intellectuals in China have not had good opinions regarding Taiwan's democratic development, and could even be said to have been "rather negative."

But the KMT's victory has changed all that, mainly because many intellectuals in China have perceived that the difference between the "pan-blue" camp, headed by the KMT, and the "pan-green" parties, led by the incumbent Democratic Progressive Party administration, lies in one favoring cross-strait unification and the other insisting on Taiwan independence.
But with Taiwan's second peaceful transition of power through democratic election, "the liberal intellectuals in China have gone wild," Li said.
The average Chinese citizen, on the subject of Taiwan's election, has also expressed the view that "democracy on the other side has borne fruit, while ours is still under the icy ground."
Li said that Taiwan also has a high degree of freedom, which he described as "an inspiration to China."
He said that democracy needs gradual fermentation, but under Taiwan's influence, "China's democracy is imminent and unstoppable."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'I will not run for KMT chairmanship': President-elect

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Friday that he will not run for his party's chairmanship next year.
"I resigned as the KMT chairman last year, and I feel that that way is fine, " Ma said in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency.

A debate over whether Ma should lead the party while serving as president emerged after KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung suggested on Wednesday that he was open to the idea of having Ma hold the two posts concurrently.
Some party insiders believe such an arrangement would make it easier to coordinate policy between the party and the government.

Should Ma want to run for the post, however, the party's charter would have to be amended prior to the chairmanship election slated for August 2009 to allow the president to act as party chairman, Wu said at a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting.

KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih said that if Ma wanted to become party chairman, whether he would still have to be directly elected by party members or could become chairman by virtue of having been elected president by a broader base of voters could also be discussed.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT member, said an advantage of serving as both the president and the party chairman is that the president could have his policies implemented by the legislature through the party.
The KMT holds 80 seats, or nearly three-fourths, of the 113-seat legislature.
Wang cautioned, however, that a downside to dual leadership would be that it could lead to the KMT repeating its past mistake of having the government follow the party line.

Ma was elected KMT chairman on Aug. 19, 2005, but resigned from the post on Feb. 23, 2007 immediately after he was indicted for allegedly misusing his special allowance funds during his eight-year term as mayor of Taipei City between 1998 and 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8,200-plus in Taiwan waiting for organ transplant

TEXT.P: As of Friday, more than 8,200 people in Taiwan were still waiting for organ transplants, more than 50 times as many people who have been given transplants this year, the Taiwan Organ Registry Sharing Center said.
Liu Chia-chi, deputy executive director of the center, said that only 148 people have had their wishes fulfilled this year, based on the number of organs donated.

Liu said hospitals in Taiwan only register the number of organs donated by people who had died and not live organ donations, so it was difficult for the center to know if patients had already received organs from their relatives and had already been excluded from the waiting list.
She said that the Department of Health estimated two years ago that around 450 Taiwanese patients travel to China each year to have organ transplants, with about 300 getting kidney transplants.

But she said that now that China has banned the sale of organs, organ transactions have moved to the black market. The impact of this change on Taiwanese traveling to China to have their kidney and liver transplanted is "unclear."

Although organ transplant patients have to take anti-rejection drugs all their lives, those who take the drug are not necessarily organ transplant patients, Liu said, citing as an example lupus (SLE) patients.

"Therefore, it is hard to determine the number of patients who received organ transplants overseas and returned to Taiwan to take the anti-rejection drug based simply on data on anti-rejection drugs given under the national health insurance program," she said.
The two blind spots in the present registry system are live organ transplants and organ transplants overseas, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 50 U.S. congress members congratulate ROC president-elect
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 4 (CNA) 04/05/08 14:27:25 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: More than 50 members of the U.S. Congress have extended their congratulations to President-elect Ma Ying-jeou on his March 22 election win, Taiwan's representative to the United States said Friday.

According to Joseph Wu during an informal gathering with Taiwanese reporters in Washington, D.C., the maturity and rationality demonstrated by the Taiwanese people and the democratic manner in which the outcome of the election was accepted by Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties have won the praise of Congress leaders, including House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) , Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) , Senate Republican Whip Jon Kyl (R-Ariz.), and House Republican Whip Roy Blunt (R-Mo.).

They believe the Taiwanese people should be proud of their democratic system and that Taiwan's experience in pursuing democracy can become a model for other countries in the Asia-Pacific region and even around the world, Wu said.

Other Congress leaders who have sent their congratulations to Ma include Senate Committee on Foreign Relations Chairman Joseph Biden (D-Del.) and ranking minority member Richard Lugar (R-Ind.), as well as House Committee on Foreign Affairs Chairman Howard Berman (D-Calif.) , according to data provided by Taiwan's representative office in the United States.
Members of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus and Senate Taiwan Caucus, who have been working to promote U.S.-Taiwan relations, have also congratulated Ma.

In their congratulatory messages, the Congress members emphasize the importance of U.S.-Taiwan relations in light of the many common interests between the two sides, including democracy, human rights, the rule of law, trade, and peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, Wu said.
They also express the wish to continue to cooperate with Taiwan to strengthen bilateral ties, Wu went on.

He expressed appreciation for the firm support and deep friendship displayed by the Congress members for Taiwan, adding that he believes Taiwan's cooperation and exchanges with Congress will grow even stronger in the future based on the existing foundation.
Also Friday, Wu said he wrote to Pelosi a day earlier to express Taiwan's support for the attention paid by Congress to the Tibet issue in the wake of China's recent crackdown on Tibetan protesters.

In addition to offering firm support for the Tibetans and people in other regions of China, Wu also said in the letter that Taiwan must resist the threats posed by China against the country's democracy and freedom, which include the more-than 1,400 missiles deployed by China targeting Taiwan and Beijing's continued efforts to isolate Taiwan in the international arena.

Noting that the long-standing support provided by the United States for Taiwan has been a major reason why Taiwan has been able to establish a democratic and prosperous society, Wu said China's recent crackdown in Tibet demonstrates that it is very important for the United States to continue to support Taiwan as a beacon of democracy and freedom in East Asia.

Wu said Taiwan looks forward to continuing a strong partnership with the United States to face the numerous challenges that are threatening security, freedom and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region.

: The Straits Times: Jurong's massive makeover.
Extreme makeovers do not come more dramatic than this. In an ambitious plan unveiled yesterday, a large swathe of Jurong will be redeveloped and rebranded the Jurong Lake District.

DOC.HEADLINE: Incoming administration to decide on salary hikes: DGBAS

TEXT.P: A decision on whether salaries for military personnel, civil servants and public school teachers should be raised in 2009 will be left for the incoming administration of president-elect Ma Ying-jeou to make, Directorate General of Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) Minister Hsu Chang-yao said Saturday.
Hsu said it would be inappropriate for him to comment on "whether salaries should be raised or not and what the adjustment level should be."

He made the remarks one day after Ma said that in the face of import-induced inflation, Taiwan's short-term strategy will be to expand domestic demand, while the middle- and long-term strategies will be to increase incomes, with salary hikes for military personnel, civil servants and public school teachers one of the options in an overall review.

Hsu noted that when Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's Cabinet mulled raising salaries for military personnel, civil servants and teachers last year, it considered consumer prices and the financial situation, as well as the two major elections of 2008.

"To avoid giving the impression that the salary hikes were aimed at wooing ballots from those groups, Chang's Cabinet decided against them, " he said, adding that "the Cabinet also thought that 2009 would be a suitable time to make the adjustment."
Hsu said that if the salaries were raised by 3 percent, the central government would have to shoulder the additional costs of around NT$18.5 billion (US$612.17 million).

Central Personnel Administration Director Chou Hung-hsien also noted that the Executive Yuan usually decides in July or August whether to raise salaries prior to working out its general budget for the following year.

Chou said the Executive Yuan's decision against salary hikes in 2008 took into consideration the relatively stable consumer prices and the government's financial situation, as well as the fact that salaries in the private sector had not seen any dramatic increases.
The Democratic Progressive Party administration raised salaries for military personnel, civil servants and school teachers in 2001 and 2005 during its eight- year rule, each time by 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's democracy will shine in cross-strait interactions

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that he does not advocate "directly exporting democracy" to China, adding that through greater cross-Taiwan Strait interaction, the merits of Taiwan's democracy will "naturally" lead to positive change in China over time.
In an exclusive interview with CNA, Ma said that because of ideology, Taiwan in the past only looked at China as a threat, ignoring the opportunities it presented.
He said Taiwan should adjust its policies and use its own "soft strengths" to influence China by engaging in greater cross-strait interaction.

During and after the election campaign, Ma announced that he would launch regular direct cross-strait weekend charter flights, open Taiwan to Chinese tourists, relax restrictions on investment in China, and negotiate the "three direct links" -- a more open approach to ties with Beijing that marks a reversal of the incumbent Democratic Progressive Party administration's policy over its past eight years in power.

Ma told CNA that through greater non-political exchanges between the two sides, the attraction of Taiwan's democratic values will inevitably exert their influence on China, with the resulting benefits to Taiwan's national defense being greater than by simply increasing defense spending.

He claimed that Taiwan's democratic process on display for Chinese people in countries around the world to see in the recent presidential election, in which the losing candidate gracefully accepted defeat after the hotly contested race and the winner declared victory in a humble manner, "shook China like nothing else could."

On whether Taiwan should try to export democracy to China, the president-elect said this is not necessary, as the development of modern communications, including the Internet and satellite television, means that many people have access to information and can see the merits of Taiwan's democracy directly.
To back up his point, Ma recalled a message he read on the China-based People's Daily Web site following Taiwan's "three in one" elections in 2005.

According to Ma, the citizen who posted the message asked: "Why can the Taiwanese people go to their neighborhood elementary school and cast ballots in an election and we cannot? Is it possible that we really are second-class citizens?"

Ma said that he was greatly moved by the message and felt that this sort of reflection -- spurred by Taiwan's democratic process -- demonstrates the immense power and usefulness of Taiwan's "soft strengths."

Ma pointed to his support for Taiwanese recognition of diplomas issued by Chinese universities as an example of how his policies will help utilize Taiwan's "soft strengths." He said it is hoped that recognizing Chinese degrees will lead to a greater number of Chinese students opting to study in Taiwan, who will in turn learn more about Taiwan's lifestyle.
"When these young people who receive their education in Taiwan return home, they will become some of Taiwan's best friends, " he said.

"Allowing more young Chinese to understand that Taiwan is a model worth learning from instead of a place that should be attacked is probably a better way of ensuring Taiwan's security than boosting the nation's defense spending," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese agro-tourism attracts Singaporeans

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agro-tourism in the form of leisure farms is attracting increasing numbers of foreign visitors, especially from Singapore, and has won much praise in the area of service, an official of the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Saturday.

To help transform the farming sector into a service industry, the government is trying to develop agro-tourism, which gives tourists a taste of life in the Taiwanese countryside and its produce, along with human interest in the form of the farmers themselves, the official said.
The COA began promoting Taiwan's agro-tourism in Singapore in 2005, participating in travel exhibitions, organizing press conferences and collaborating with local tour operators.

The official said Southeast Asia and Hong Kong are the target areas for the promotion plan as they have in general similar languages, diet preferences and cultural backgrounds to Taiwan. He added that Singapore, with a population that is 75 percent of Chinese descent, is one of the countries from which Taiwanese leisure farm operators are particularly keen to attract tourists.

According to the official, the Singapore promotion led to a growth rate of 50.68 percent in the number of Singaporean tourists visiting leisure farms in Taiwan, representing an increase from 10,139 people in 2006 to 15,278 in 2007.
Analyzing the success of agro-tourism in attracting Singaporeans, the official said it might be because the city state lacks its own land, agricultural production, rural ecosystem and rural culture.
Statistics compiled by the Taiwan Leisure Farming Development Association show that there are more than 100 establishments involved in the leisure agricultural industry around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Guatemala ties stable: MOFA

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official reaffirmed Saturday that Taiwan's diplomatic relations with Guatemala remain stable in the wake of a report that the recent formation of a China-Guatemala chamber of commerce signifies increased uncertainty in Taiwan-Guatemala ties.

MOFA spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said the ministry is aware of the growing economic and trade relations between Guatemala and China, but pointed out that the chamber of commerce is a private organization promoted by a group of Guatemalan businessmen to support their economic interests in China.
Yeh said similar organizations also exist in other allies of Taiwan in Central America and that the ministry will keep close watch on the situation.
According to Yeh, despite a decrease in trade volume between Taiwan and Guatemala, bilateral relations have continued to grow stably.

For example, Taiwan has continued to support various infrastructure construction projects in Guatemala, while agricultural and information technology cooperation between the two countries is also underway, Yeh said.

During a summit of business leaders from Taiwan and its Central American allies held last month, Taiwanese businessmen were encouraged to set up operations in Central America to promote economic and trade ties with the region, she noted.

According to a China Times report, following the inauguration of the China- Guatemala chamber of commerce earlier this week, a large Chinese investment delegation will visit Guatemala in June and the first Guatemalan trade show will take place September in Shanghai.

The report said that in light of Guatemala's economic interests in China, Guatemalan President Alvaro Colom has turned down Taiwan's invitation for him to attend the May 20 inauguration of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou.
The report also said Colom and two other leaders of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America will take part in the opening ceremony of the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games in August.

On Colom's expected absence from Ma's inaugural ceremony, Yeh noted that during a visit by President Chen Shui-bian to Guatemala in January to attend Colom's inauguration, Colom told Chen he would not be able to attend the inauguration of Taiwan's new president and would instead assign his deputy to come on his behalf because operations of the new administration were expected to keep him occupied.
Meanwhile, Yeh said the ministry had not received any information indicating that leaders of Taiwan's Central American allies have any plans to take part in the Olympics opening ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO entry details undecided: foreign minister

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has not yet come to a conclusion on how to handle Taiwan's bid for its access to the World Health Organization (WHO) this year, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Saturday.

Huang made the remarks after President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said in an exclusive interview with CNA a day earlier that he thinks Taiwan should continue to apply for the observer status in the World Health Assembly (WHA), the WHO's decision- making body.
As to the proper designation for the bid, Ma said he thinks that there is no more acceptable name than "Chinese Taipei" for Taiwan to use in international organizations at present.

In the interview, Ma said it was learned that President Chen Shui-bian has instructed the MOFA to follow the 2007 formula in applying for the country's WHO membership under the name "Taiwan" during this year's WHA conference, scheduled to open in Geneva May 19, one day before Ma's inauguration. Should that be the case, Ma said, the application could end up a failure again just like last year's bid.

Responding to Ma's remarks, Huang said the MOFA is still pondering the strategy and the country's designation for this year's WHO bid. "Before May 20, the MOFA will still follow the incumbent government's policy in addressing the issue," he explained.

"Up until now, no definite proposal has been outlined, " Huang said, noting that the issue is pending discussions among relevant authorities and that the MOFA will communicate with Ma's office on any possible proposal through proper channels.

MOFA spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh also stated that the ministry is still working on strategies and designation for the WHO bid and that relevant government agencies are scheduled to discuss the issue in the coming week. Ma won the March 22 presidential election by a decisive margin, a victory that means Taiwan's foreign policy under the Kuomintang is expected to undergo a fundamental shift from the pro-independence approach of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government to a policy of what Ma called "modus vivendi" within which dignity, pragmatism and flexibility are the fundamental principles.

Speaking of Ma's plans for seeking membership of the WHO -- an organization that has rejected Taiwan's application for its membership for over 10 years due to China's opposition -- a foreign affairs official well versed in international organization operations said diplomatic circles were surprised by Ma's disclosure of his strategies when there is still more than a month to go before the May 19 opening of the World Health Assembly in Geneva.

They expect the disclosure to have a mixed effect, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. On the positive side, he said, Ma's goodwill signals toward China and the international community shows his intention of employing pragmatism in his foreign policy, which is different from that of the DPP administration.

Ma has also revealed that he will attempt to persuade Beijing to relax its suppression of Taiwan and will seek support from the United States, Japan and the European Union in the country's bids for membership in international organizations.
The president-elect is being seen as trying to handle diplomatic issues within the framework of general exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the official analyzed.

On the possible negative side, the official went on, local diplomats regard the name "Chinese Taipei" as more of a step backward than other possible names such as "the Republic of China (Taiwan) " and "Taiwan (the Republic of China) , " and more of a backward step, even, than the idea of using the term "health entity" to designate Taiwan in its WHO bid.
If "Chinese Taipei" is accepted, there might be no more acceptable name than that for Taiwan's other international membership applications in the future, he said.
