DOC.HEADLINE: Heavy traffic, pollution mar Chingming Festival

TEXT.P: The Chinese tradition of Chingming, or Tomb Sweeping, a time for people to pay their respects to their ancestors and clean their graves, began in the Chou Dynasty some 2,500 years ago and was later set as a festival during the Sui and Tang Dynasties

Usually falling on April 5 of the Gregorian calendar, the Chingming Festival this year occurred a day earlier -- on April 4 -- due to 2008 being a leap year and giving people in Chinese societies such as Taiwan, China, Hong Kong and Macau a three-day vacation.

To observe the holiday, as well as to pay respects to the ancestors and tidy up their graves, returning home is an essential task for most people prior to the beginning of the festival, leading to soaring demand for transport.

According to Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau (TANFB) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), loading on the three national freeways April 3, the day before the festival, was up 16 percent compared to normal days. On April 4, 2.55 million cars were also reported using the freeways, breaking the record of the previous Chingming Festival.

Passenger numbers recorded by the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corporation (THSRC) on the high-speed railway linking Taipei in the north and the southern port city of Kaohsiung, also broke its record with 120,000 passengers April 3, forcing the THSRC to lay on extra trains to accommodate the crowds.

Freeways, stations and piers in Hong Kong and Macau, as well as in China where the Chingming Festival was officially being celebrated as a holiday for the first time, also saw multitudes of passengers traveling home for the festival.

An estimate released by the Shanghai Civil Affairs Bureau indicated that graveyards around the city saw 2.37 million tomb sweepers during the three-day vacation, a 56 percent increase over last year, with roads leading to graveyards and around Shanghai's neighboring cities or towns packed with cars, causing tailbacks that stretched for kilometers.
Queues were to be seen on the piers in Hong Kong and Macau as well, as many Hong Kong citizens visited the tombs of their ancestors buried in Macau.
Tomb sweepers not only had to brave the heavy traffic but also had to suffer from the air pollution caused by the burning of piles of "ghost money."

According to Chinese tradition, people must prepare food, drinks, "ghost money" and incense as offerings to the gods or their ancestors. After a ceremony, the money is burned for use by the gods or the dead.

In order to prevent fire, the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department (AFCD) under the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administration Region, warned the public to take care not to start fires while burning "ghost money" or setting off firecrackers.
A maximum fine of HK$25,000 (US$3,278) was also introduced as part of the AFCD's effort to prevent fire.

In Taiwan, meanwhile, fire brigades were geared up for emergencies. In Kaohsiung County, some 350 km south of the capital Taipei City, 42 fires were reported, while many other minor fires were started by careless citizens elsewhere in the country.

Based on the findings of recent research on "ghost money, " the Taiwan based Consumers' Foundation, Chinese Taipei (CFCT) noted that 20 percent of "ghost money" tested contains lead, making it extremely hazardous for those forced to breathe the fumes when it is burned.

CFCT Chairman Cheng Jen-hung pointed out that "exposure to excessive amounts of lead can cause brain damage, learning difficulties and slow growth among children... adults suffering from lead poisoning will feel pain in the muscles and joints, and their blood pressure will also rise."

In order to reduce air pollution and safeguard public heath, the authorities in Taiwan have been promoting the burning of "ghost credit cards" or "ghost cheques" instead of large amounts of "cash, " but these moves have proved unpopular.

The three day vacation of the Chingming Festival this year ends Sunday. Even though the Chinese tradition will surely continue in Chinese populations around the world, finding ways to make future festivals more travel-friendly and environmentally friendly will need to be considered.

DOC.HEADLINE: No plans for missile base on Kinmen: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has formally informed the Kinmen county government that the military has no plans to establish a missile base on the outlying island.

The information was provided after the county government raised concerns about such a possibility following media reports ahead of the January legislative elections that the government was building a missile base on the outlying island of Matsu.

During the legislative election campaign, Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng of the pro-unification opposition New Party expressed his support for opposition Kuomintang candidate Wu Cheng-dien because of his strong opposition to establishing a missile base there.
In the letter, the MND said that the military's long-term combat readiness plans do not at this stage include the building of a missile base on Kinmen.

Kinmen County Council Speaker Hsieh Yi-chang expressed welcome to the MND's letter and said Kinmen had experienced much suffering during artillery battles between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the past and that as a result, Kinmen residents' hopes for peace are the strongest.
"The Kinmen people do not want to once again become the point of a battle because of the establishment of a missile base on the island," he said.

Since the launch of the "mini three links" at the start of 2001, he continued, Kinmen has become a bridge for cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges and the people of Kinmen "hope to continue in this role, with war remaining nothing but a distant memory."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA urges diversification of sources to ensure coal supply

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Saturday that since Taiwan relies entirely on imports for its coal supply, it has to diversify its import sources to ensure smooth operations.
Taiwan also needs to sign long-term purchase contracts to stabilize its coal supplies, MOEA officials said.

Taiwan has in recent years encouraged users to diversify its import sources, the officials said, noting that total coal imports amounted to around 65 million tons last year, mainly from Australia, Indonesia and China, accounting for 39 percent, 37 percent and 20 percent, respectively of the total imports.
The ministry has instructed Taiwan Power Co. to step up coal exploration overseas so as to ensure a steady supply, the officials went on.
They noted that world coal prices have continued to surge since 2003, mainly because of the rise of China and India, which has led to massive demand and tight supply.
The officials noted that major coal producers such as Australia have seen coal prices rise by 46 percent since early this year.

China announced Jan. 24 a suspension of coal exports for two months because of its own urgent need for coal and electricity due to heavy snowstorms that wreaked havoc in some areas of the country, while production in South Africa's coal mines has been affected by electricity shortages during the same period, prompting it to also suspend coal exports.
"World coal supplies over the past year have been the tightest since the second energy crisis of 1979," the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Music fans flock to southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: The opening of several music festivals in southern Taiwan attracted tens of thousands of music fans who crowded into the township of Kenting over the weekend to enjoy different kinds of music, while the authorities questioned the impact of the events on the ecosystem of the Kenting National Park.
April used to be an off-season for tourism in Kenting, a popular scenic spot famed for its beaches, good weather and the richness of its sub-tropical ecosystem.

Since the "Spring Scream" music and art festival took place for the first time in Kenting in April 1995, the annual event has attracted tens of thousands of tourists and brought great benefits to businesses in the township, said Shi Jin- fang, director of the Kenting National Park Administration Office (KNPAO).

With the success of Spring Scream, more and more outdoor concerts and music festivals are now organized in Kenting in April. "Today, the profits made from the music festivals can match those of the Chinese New Year period, " she said.

While the event does boost the economy, however, it harms the environment of the national park, the KNPAO said, indicating that about 200,000 people crowded into the Henchun peninsula over several days in the 2007 festivals, which means not only a great opportunity for business operators but also eventual environmental degradation in the township.

In order to avoid developing the economy at the expense of nature, the KNPAO will ask academics and experts to discuss the issue in the coming year, the public institution said, adding that it will assess the impact caused by the festivals on the environment, to see whether the event should continue to be held in the national park in the future, or whether its scale should be limited.
"Spring Scream" was founded in Taiwan by two foreign musicians who decided to create the festival in 1995 to encourage the development of independent bands and original creations.
In 2008, about 250 mostly local bands have been invited to perform in this year's three-day program.

Besides "Spring Scream, " seven other music festivals have been organized on the Henchun peninsula this year, with an estimated 100,000 people expected to arrive in Kenting to enjoy the music on Saturday night, according to local police.

Designated as a national park in 1984, the Kenting National Park was the first of seven in Taiwan. Located in the southernmost region of the island, it features coral reef cliffs and rich sub-tropical biodiversity.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect unlikely to visit U.S. before taking office
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 4 (CNA) 04/05/08 19:04:01 (By Jorge Liu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A former high-ranking U.S. official expressed doubt Friday that President-elect Ma Ying-jeou will be invited to visit Washington D.C. prior to his May 20 inauguration.

Randy Schriver, a former deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, made the comment at a workshop held by the Heritage Foundation, a Washington think tank, for discussions on Taiwan's just-concluded presidential election.
Schriver, however, said he himself fully supports the president-elect making a trip to Washington before taking office.
Asked to explain his doubt, Schriver, an expert in cross-Taiwan Strait affairs, said he made the comment based purely on his personal judgment rather than from "inside sources."

He said the U.S. government will refrain from inviting the president-elect to visit Washington before his inauguration out of concern that such an invitation might set a precedent that could present unwanted consequences in the future.

The U.S. government will think that a more appropriate time for Ma to come to the United States will be when he goes abroad after assuming office and can use the foreign trip to conduct a transit stop on U.S. soil, Schriver said.

The former U.S. official suggested that Ma should engage in dialogue with Washington through phone calls or video conferences if he cannot come to the U.S. before his inauguration, or even use a trip to other country to make a stopover in the U.S. possible.

At the workshop, Deputy Representative Chang Ta-tung of the U.S. office of the opposition Kuomintang and its political ally, the People First Party, said they are still working to organize a trip for Ma to Washington D.C. before his inauguration.
Mentioning that the U.S. side has told the media it is pondering what to do about Ma's desire to visit, Chang expressed optimism, saying that "anything could happen."
Asked whether there are discussions on replacing Washington with other U.S. cities, Chang said that "all I can say is that everyone is talking about the issue with delight."

Top-ranking official exchanges between Taiwan and the United States have been a sensitive issue amid the absence of formal diplomatic relations and opposition from China, which claims Taiwan as part of its territory.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect calls for using Chiang's legacy for tourism

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou called Saturday for leaving the historical roles of the two late presidents -- Chiang Kai-shek and his son Chiang Ching-kuo -- to the historians, but said their legacies should be used to help develop tourism.
Ma noted that the Chiangs dominated Taiwan's political scene from the 1950s until 1988 and said that "their merits and shortcomings should be left for the historians to decide."
But he added that the two late presidents have left great legacies, which he said could be used as historical and cultural assets and for tourism development.

Ma made the remarks while taking part in a creative doll festival that included figurines of the late Chiangs and the unveiling of a renovated Chiang Kai-shek statute -- the largest in the country -- in Cihhu, also spelled as Tzuhu, in the northern county of Taoyuan.

Ma noted that Taoyuan has an international airport which is Taiwan's main gateway to the world, and also hosts the two late presidents' mausoleums, which could be valuable assets in developing tourism.

Ma said that a Chiang cultural park beside Cihhu has 141 statutes of Chiang Kai- shek, many of which were collected from cities and counties around the nation in a campaign launched by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to remove statutes of Chiang in a bid to get rid of the last vestiges of his authoritarian rule.
"With the incoming administration's plan to open up Taiwan to Chinese tourists in July, the cultural heritage of the Chiangs and their residences will become popular tourist attractions," he said.

Ma also pledged that after he assumes office May 20, he will appropriate NT$30 billion for a tourism development fund and NT$30 billion for a local industrial development fund in a bid to boost the tourism and cultural development of Taiwan's cities and counties.
Ma, who began his political career serving as English secretary to Chiang Ching- kuo, earlier visited the two mausoleums, a ritual he practices every year.
He was emotional and teary-eyed when paying his respects at Chiang Ching-kuo's mausoleum in Touliao, also in Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO bid hindered by 'one China' framework, not name: spokesman

TEXT.P: Taiwan's quest for World Health Organization (WHO) entry has been obstructed by Beijing's "one China" stance, not by the issue of how Taiwan should be designated, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Saturday.

Shieh issued the clarification at a news conference held a day after president- elect Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said in an interview with CNA that he was informed that President Chen Shui-bian has directed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) to follow last year's formula in applying for WHO membership when this year's World Health Assembly (WHA) convenes in Geneva May 19. The WHA is the WHO's decision-making body.
The government applied to join the WHO in the name of Taiwan for the first time last year, which was rejected due to China's opposition.
"If such a formula is employed again this year, the result would be the same, " Ma said, adding that it would be unfair to have his administration bear the blame for such a consequence.
During the interview, Ma further said he feels that there is no more acceptable name that "Chinese Taipei" for Taiwan to use in applying for membership in international organizations.

Commenting on Ma's remarks, Shieh said the country began to apply for WHO entry under its official title "Republic of China" in 1997 when the KMT was in power. The formula was followed by the Democratic Progressive Party administration after President Chen assumed office in 2000.
As none of those bids were successful, Shieh said the DPP administration adopted a new strategy last year by using the name Taiwan.

"We all know that the only reason behind our failure over the past decade lies in China's uncompromising insistence on its 'one China' principle which claims Taiwan is part of Chinese territory, " Shieh argued, adding that both Ma and his party are fully aware of this crucial problem.

Stressing that President Chen and the DPP government have been striving hard to shun Beijing's "one China" framework, Shieh said it is regrettable that Ma and the KMT have publicly embraced the "one China" concept.

Shieh also criticized Ma for "singing duet with Beijing" in blaming the DPP- ruled Taiwan as a "troublemaker, " referring to Ma's promise in a recent interview with the London-based international news agency Reuters that his administration will lead Taiwan to play the role of a responsible stakeholder and peacemaker in cross-Taiwan Strait affairs instead of being a troublemaker as it was in the past few years.

During his two-year stint as Taiwan's representative to Germany, Shieh said he had discussed with European Union officials China's opposition to Taiwan's participation in major international organizations. "We all agree that the root cause of their opposition is their 'one China' notion, not the designation issue, " he explained.

Recalling that Ma often chanted Taiwan-themed or Taiwan-centric campaign slogans in the run-up to the March 22 presidential poll, Shieh said it is sad for him to hear Ma's acceptance of the so-called "1992 consensus" between then-KMT government and Beijing authorities.

According to the KMT, the "1992 consensus" refers to a tacit understanding between it and Beijing authorities that both sides of the Taiwan Strait belong to "one China," but each side is eligible to define what "one china" means. For the KMT, "one China" refers to the Republic of China, Taiwan's official national title.

"Should that be the case, Taiwan should be able to join the international organizations under its official title Republic of China, " Shieh said, adding that Ma should not have just mentioned "Chinese Taipei" as an acceptable title for Taiwan's designation in world organizations.

Noting that the incumbent DPP government has not yet decided on its strategy and formula for applying WHO access this year, Shieh said that if the application fails again, the only reason should still be same. "That is Beijing's 'one China' stance, nothing else," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 6, or the 1st day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1199: Richard I, king of England known as "The Lion-Hearted," dies at the age of 42 from an infected wound received while besieging Chaluz Castle during the Crusades. He was captured in Austria in 1192 and held as a prisoner by Holy Roman Emperor Henry VI until England ransomed him in 1194.
1789: George Washington is unanimously elected the first president of the United States.
1814: French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte is forced to abdicate unconditionally.
1868: Japanese Emperor Meiji establishes the Charter Oath, which was to change the form of government. He also promises an assembly.
1890: Anthony Fokker, Dutch-born American aircraft designer and manufacturer who revolutionized aerial warfare by synchronizing a front-mounted machine gun with the rotations of a propeller, is born.
1896: A modern version of the ancient Olympic Games is opened in Athens, initiated by French aristocrat Baron Pierre de Coubertin, whose goal was to stimulate interest in physical fitness and promote understanding between nations.
1913: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China is dissolved.
1917: President Woodrow Wilson signs a resolution entering the United States into World War I on the side of Great Britain and France.
1933: The Ministry of Finance of the Republic of China orders the implementation of a yuan currency system instead of the tael currency system.
1935: Emperor Henry Pu Yi of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed by the Japanese, visits Japan.
1938: The ROC armed forces score a major victory over Japan in the battle of Taierchuang, killing more than 30,000 Japanese troops.
1941: German bombers raid Belgrade, killing some 2,500 people. Hundreds of buildings were destroyed during the attack, including the National Library with its countless medieval manuscripts.
1945: U.S. naval forces score a major victory against the Japanese at Kyushu.
1953: Scrap bombs explode on a hillside in Nanshihchiao, Taipei County, killing or injuring more than 300 people.
1963: The Executive Yuan proclaims December 25 "Constitution Day" and a national holiday.
1965: The United States launches Early Bird I, the first commercial communications satellite, from Cape Kennedy, Florida.
1968: Pierre Trudeau becomes prime minister of Canada, succeeding Lester B. Pearson.
1975: Yen Chia-kan, vice president of the Republic of China since 1966, takes the oath of office as the nation's second constitutional president.
1976: Millionaire recluse Howard Hughes dies in a plane while being flown to a hospital, leaving a fortune of US$2 billion.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo renews his call to communist cadres and mainland China military personnel to rise up against the Maoist regime following the April 5 riots at Tienanmen Square in Beijing.
1993: Two mainland Chinese youths, Liu Bao-zai and Huang Shu-kang, hijack a Southern Airlines' Boeing 757 passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: A missile hits a plane as it attempts to land in Rwanda, killing all people onboard, including President Cyprien Ntaryamira of Burundi and President Jubenal Habyarimana of Rwanda.
1998 Citicorp merges with Travelers Group Inc., becoming the largest corporation in the world in terms of assets. The new firm is worth more than US$70 billion.
1999: Indonesian President B.J. Habibie assures visiting ROC Economics Minister Wang Shih-kang that his administration will take all necessary measures to protect Taiwan investors in Indonesia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bien says that the administration under his leadership will honor all accords and commitments that have already been inked with foreign countries.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, calls on former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and expresses his gratitude for Lee's promotion of increased Taiwan-Tibet exchanges during his term in office.
2004: Lithuanian President Rolandas Paksas is impeached by the Parliament, making him the first European popularly elected president to step down due to impeachment.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To allow people to go to battle without first instructing them is to betray them."

The support rate for the Cabinet of Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda plunged 6.8 percentage points from mid-March to 26.6 percent, the lowest level since the start of his administration last September, according to a new poll by Kyodo News.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Presidential Office decries use of name other than Taiwan in WHO bid

TEXT.P: Using names other than Taiwan in the country's bid to enter the World Health Organization (WHO) will backfire seriously, a high-ranking official from the Presidential Office said Sunday.

The official, who spoke to CNA on condition of anonymity, said that if the nation uses a title other than Taiwan in its WHO bid, the negative impact will be greater than using Taiwan if the bid fails again this year.
He noted that Taiwan's quest for WHO entry has been obstructed by Beijing's "one China" policy rather than by the issue of how Taiwan should be designated.

He made the remarks in response to President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang, who said in an interview with CNA last week that following last year's formula in applying for WHO membership in the name of Taiwan "would be another foreseeable failure."

Ma said he had been informed that President Chen Shui-bian has directed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) to follow last year's formula in applying for WHO membership when this year's World Health Assembly (WHA) convenes in Geneva May 19. The WHA is the WHO's decision-making body.
The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration applied to join the WHO in the name of Taiwan for the first time last year, which was rejected due to China's opposition.
"If such a formula is employed again this year, the result will be the same, " Ma said.
During the interview, Ma further said he feels that at present, there is no more acceptable name than "Chinese Taipei" for Taiwan to use in applying for membership in international organizations.

Discounting Ma's remarks, the official said that no decision has been made on this year's designation for Taiwan's WHO bid, adding that officials from the MOFA, the National Security Council and other relevant agencies will exchange views on the issue before referring a decision to Chen for final approval.

Taiwan began to apply for WHO entry under its official title Republic of China in 1997 when the KMT was in power. The formula was continued by the DPP administration after Chen assumed office in 2000.
However, since none of those bids were successful, the official said, the DPP administration adopted a new strategy in 2007, using the name Taiwan for its bid, which also failed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese masterpieces being displayed in Beijing

TEXT.P: A total of 70 ceramic and earthenware masterpieces made by 16 contemporary artists from Taiwan are currently on display at a museum in Beijing as part of the cultural activities marking the 2008 Olympic Games.
The display -- opened at the National Art Museum of China April 3 -- marks the first large-scale exhibition in China of work by contemporary artists in ceramics and earthenware from Taiwan.

The exhibition is set to run at the leading fine art museum for six months, according to You Ran-chi, director of the Taipei County Yingge Ceramics Museum, one of the Taiwanese and Chinese organizations sponsoring the exhibition.

The masterpieces -- telling stories about nature, people, obsession and illusion -- reflect that Taiwanese ceramics and earthenware artists have surpassed the level of designing only practical ware and utensils, You said.
Rather, You said, the artists represent their artistic thinking and deliver their cultural attainments via their designs.
The display is also poised to serve as a new platform to help bolster exchanges in ceramics, earthenware and related arts across the Taiwan Strait, You added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese students stun world with outstanding AMC results

TEXT.P: Taiwanese students once again stunned the world with outstanding mathematical ability as 28 students scored full marks in the American Mathematics Competition (AMC) this year, the best performance ever, the sponsor said Sunday in Taipei.

26 out of 6,328 Taiwanese students got perfect scores in the AMC 10 competition for grade 10, representing 55.32 percent of the total perfect scores from the whole world compared to 12.8 percent last year.
In addition, two of 6,075 Taiwanese contestants scored full marks in the AMC 12, representing 18.18 percent of the total full marks received, compared to 10.5 percent in 2007.

"It is such a great achievement and again proves that many students in Taiwan have exceptional talent in math, " said Ho Yien -ming, chairman of the Nine-Nine Cultural and Educational Foundation, which sponsored the contest in the Taiwan area, at the award ceremony.

The AMC, which was established in 1950 and is the first of a series of competitions for high school mathematics, includes three levels -- AMC 8, AMC 10 and AMC 12 -- for students in grades 8, 10 and 12. The annual event is held by the American Mathematics Competitions organization.

Major universities such as the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) are beginning to take AMC scores as important references in student applications, since the AMC tests a deeper level of math than the SAT and can help identify students who are ready for a rigorous undergraduate curriculum.

Mark Chen from the National Experimental High School at Hsinchu Science Park, who got perfect scores both in the AMC 12 and the American Invitational Mathematics Examination, is the first person in Taiwan to get full marks in both contests.

Chen, who was born in the United States and came back to continue his senior high school study in Taiwan three years ago, has already been admitted by MIT and will enroll this August. The 17-year-old said he is interested in math.

"You have to pick up the best, the most beautiful parts in math," he said, adding that he can spend up to 10 hours a day doing math on weekends and can even spend several days thinking how to solve a math problem.
"Math helps me think in a more creative way and to analyze things more deeply, " said Chen, who also finds interest in other subjects such as science and English literature.
He said that although the education system in Taiwan is more "strict and stringent" while it is more "lenient" in the U.S., both are equally good.
"Both have their own advantages -- leniency will let you have a lot of time to do what you want to do while strictness gives you discipline," he said.

Ho said there is a long way to go, as this is only the 7th year in which Taiwan has competed in the AMC. Although Taiwan's performance is one of the top in the world, China and Singapore should not be neglected, as students there are doing better and better, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,500 auto, parts makers represented at Taipei exhibitions

TEXT.P: Automobile parts, auto electronics products and motorcycles will be shown in Taipei from April 9-12, with 1,500 local and foreign manufacturers occupying 3,500 booths that are expected to draw 57,850 visitors.
Visitors will have the chance to take a good look at the latest innovations in the industry, including devices that interact with drivers through voice, as well as customized motorcycles.

Organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , the Taipei International Auto Parts & Accessories Show (AMPA) will be held along with the Taipei International Automobile Electronics Show (AutoTronics Taipei) and the Taipei International Motorcycle Industry Show (Motorcycle Taiwan).

The AMPA is the largest of the three exhibitions with 2,400 booths and 1,000 manufacturers, which will fill the newly opened Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) Nangang Exhibition Hall. The other two will take place at the TWTC Exhibition Hall 1.

Following the success of the Taipei International Cycle Show in March -- the Nangang Exhibition Hall's debut that attracted 86,000 visitors, a record for the cycle show -- the TAITRA hopes to attract more buyers with its 46,000 square meters of space and rich array of show features.

In addition to displays of the latest innovative auto parts and accessories, the AMPA will highlight the integration of car and information technology (IT) with a pavilion serving as a business platform for local auto part makers and IT service providers to trade with foreign buyers.
Another spotlight of the AMPA, the Taiwan Automotive International Forum, will discuss the future of interrelation between humans, vehicles and the environment.
AutoTronics Taipei, with 300 manufacturers occupying 600 booths, will open with the AutoTronics Innovation Awards to showcase applications of advanced electronics in the field of automobiles.
The fair will also feature an AutoTronics Forum to discuss the future of auto electronics.
The smallest of the shows, with 200 manufacturers occupying 500 booths, Motorcycle Taiwan will show off the latest motorcycles from world-renowned companies such as Yamaha, BMW and SYM.

To catch the "green industry wave, " the fair is promoting the concept of "the new century on the green planet" to the local market, featuring a 5th-Stage Emission Standard Pavilion to underscore the importance of air pollution control.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pilgrimage tour gets modern twist of environmental protection

TEXT.P: An annual pilgrimage tour of Matsu, goddess of the sea, that kicked off Saturday from a popular central Taiwan temple, got a green twist of environmental protection, thanks to the participation of a team of environmental workers who vowed to maintain community cleanliness during the religious procession.

The environmental protection team, composed of volunteers from business corporations and social groups, was organized by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) and environmental bureaus of four counties through which the pilgrimage passes.

Led by EPA Deputy Minister Chang Tzu-ching, the environmental team took part in a religious ritual at the renowned Jenn Lann Temple in Taichung County's Dajia township Saturday in preparation for the eight-day pilgrimage tour that commenced at around midnight that same day.

The annual parade is part of celebrations of Matsu's birthday, which falls on the 23rd day of the third lunar month, but is usually celebrated earlier with a pilgrimage to sister Matsu temples in neighboring Changhua, Yunlin and Chiayi counties.

The tradition has been observed for more than a century and has bloomed into what Discovery Channel describes as one of the three major religious festivals in the world in recent years thanks to Jenn Lann Temple management's introduction of modern marketing and advertising strategies into the program of festivities.

Over the past decade, the traditional eight-day religious walking event has been evolved into a month-long carnival that incorporates religious, cultural, fashion and tourism activities better known as the Taichung County Matsu International Festival.

Since the late 1990s, the annual pilgrimage tour has consistently attracted nearly 1 million Matsu worshipers who follow the Matsu journey on foot. Along the route, huge quantities of garbage are produced, creating a burden on the environment.
According to environmental officials, most of the waste consists of food packaging, such as empty drink bottles and lunch boxes.

"For the first time this year, an environmental team will head the procession, and along the route 6,000 garbage and recycling bins made of recycled paper will be placed for trash collection and resource recycling to ensure environmental cleanliness," Chang said.

Individual team members, including teachers and professionals from various fields, will also promote the concept of resource recycling and garbage classification to the townships they will visit, and will remind pilgrims to maintain environmental cleanliness and good hygiene during the 330-km journey.
A Jenn Lann Temple manager said the marathon walking event is not only aimed at inspiring mental purification but also at providing a cleansing experience for local communities.

"By combining traditional religious rituals like the Matsu pilgrimage tour with modern trends like environmental protection, we hope to imbue locals with more updated notions of what is good for society and the next generation," he added.

This year's Dajia Matsu festival began Feb. 20 and is scheduled to end April 28. In addition to the climatic Matsu pilgrimage procession, there are also exhibitions related to Matsu, who watches over fishermen, as well as folk cultural performances and fashion shows in and around the 276-year-old Jenn Lann Temple. To emphasize its global nature, organizers have also invited musical groups from around the world to perform.

DOC.HEADLINE: Singers eat with fans to raise money for disadvantaged children

TEXT.P: Singers from a popular televised singing competition had lunch with fans Sunday at a tea house in Taipei to raise money to allow disadvantaged children to go to school.

Lin Pei-yiao, Wu Chung-ming, Yeh Wei-ting and Tzeng Pei-tsi from the second season of the program titled One Million Stars, met 16 fans who bid on the Internet for the chance to have lunch with their idols. The highest bid went up to NT$4,000 (US$131).
Some NT$30,000 that was raised from the luncheon will be used as tuition fees for disadvantaged children, said Shi Tu Chien-ming of the Red Heart Association in Taiwan, which organized the event.

"These artists have taken part in many charity activities and we hope that by setting a good example, their fans and the general public will also join efforts to help the disadvantaged children so that they can go to school, " he said, adding that anyone can join the charity by donating NT$500 to the Red Heart Association.
To express their appreciation for the fans, the four singers first acted as receptionists and waiters, taking their lunch orders and serving them drinks before joining them for lunch.
A flight attendant in "real life, " Lin's professional service made her fans feel like they were on a first class flight, one of them said afterward.

"Only by actually going to care centers and orphanages can we really understand how much help they need and how little we have done, " said Tzeng, urging everyone to help children from single-parent and low-income families, or those without parents, to go to school.
Wu said that as long as there is a need, they are very willing to take part in charity activities, as it is also their job to educate the public and fans on how to help the disadvantaged.
"It is so meaningful to be part of charity affairs, especially when you can do it with your own idols, " said Lucy Liu, a fan of Yeh Wei-ting.

The Red Heart Association, established in 1988, is a non- government social service organization that focuses on disadvantaged households rather than individuals and is responsible for taking care of over 2,000 underprivileged families in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese tourists continue to head to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 6 (CNA) 04/06/08 17:45:53 (By Mike Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of Japanese tourists making bookings to visit Taiwan during the upcoming "golden holiday" between late April and early May remains at the same level as that posted in 2007, a leading travel agency reported Sunday.

According to a survey conducted by the JTB Tourist Agency, 33,000 Japanese citizens have made reservations to travel to Taiwan for the "golden holiday" between April 25 and May 5 -- the same number as last year.
In comparison, the number of Japanese tourists heading to China during the same period declined by 20 percent -- to 75,000 people from last year's 94,000, according to the JTB survey.

JTB, which is Japan's largest travel agency, attributed the sharp decline mainly to the poisonous Chinese dumplings incident that occurred in Japan late last year and the ongoing Chinese military crackdown on Tibetan protesters.
JTB conducted the annual survey among Japanese citizens aged between 15 and 79 recently and obtained 1,200 valid responses.
The agency also found that 458,000 Japanese citizens have made bookings to travel overseas during the holiday, representing a year-on-year decline of 14.6 percent from 2007's 536,000.
According to the agency, the decline is mainly because of difficulty getting vacation time off work and prohibitively expensive air tickets as a result of skyrocketing international oil prices.
China is the top destination, followed by South Korea, which has attracted 74,000 people, and Hawaii, which has attracted 34,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Award-winning baker sets up foundation to aid young people

TEXT.P: A local baker who won joint second place with other two Taiwanese bakers at the 2008 Bakery World Cup in Paris April 2, returned to the store where he works as a pastry chef in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Saturday with a silver cup and a vow to set up a foundation to aid apprentices in financial plight.
Wu Pao-chun said his idea of founding the organization was inspired by his late mother, Chen Wu-hsien, who raised him and her seven other children single- handed.

Wu, 39, born in Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, is the youngest in the family and lost his father when he was a child. Unwilling to see his mother working so hard to raise her family, Wu dropped out of senior high school and traveled to Taipei to learn how to be a baker.

Since then, Wu has moved from one city to another, from northern to southern Taiwan, absorbing various experiences and baking skills. Last year, Wu defeated the champion Chinese team at the World Cup Asian qualifying rounds last May, winning the title of "King of the Asian Bakers."

On March 31 at the World Cup finals in Paris, Wu used his "secret weapon" -- smoked dried longan -- to make artisan bread with a flavor of his homeland. The dried longan bread made with sweet fermented rice wine was a hit with the judges.
Wu said he created the bread because he missed his late mother. When he was young, Wu recalled, his mother used to cook longan soup with sweet fermented rice in winter to keep out the cold.
"Maybe it was the `flavor of mother' that touched the judges' hearts," he said.

Wu said he will contribute his money, knowledge and skills to the Chen Wu-hsien Foundation, to help apprentice bakers suffering from financial problems and train more world champion bakers for Taiwan.
Wu, Tsao Chih-hsiung and Wen Shih-cheng represented Taiwan in the Bakery World Cup held March 31-April 2 in Paris and also won a ticket for the next competition, scheduled for 2012.

The triennial baking competition, the seventh of its kind, brought together 12 national teams, including the top three winners of the 2005 competition -- the United States, France and Japan -- and nine others that qualified for the finals.
The other teams were from Turkey, Mexico, Argentina, Poland, Sweden, Spain, Italy and the Netherlands.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president-elect to attend Boao Forum in China

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Vincent Siew of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will attend the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia to be held April 11-13 in Hainan, China, a spokesman for the Taiwan delegation to the forum said Sunday.

Wang Yu-chi said Siew, who has attended the forum in five of the last six years since the forum started meeting in 2002, will attend the gathering in his capacity as chairman of the private Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation that he founded in 2003 to promote the establishment of a common market across the strait.
Wang told a news conference at the KMT headquarters that Taiwan's delegation will host a round-table meeting on Taiwan's economy and on the cross-strait economic outlook April 13 at the forum.

Hung Tu, executive director of the Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation, and Chan Hou-sheng, an advisor to the foundation and a former Council of Labor Affairs chairman, will accompany Siew to Boao, he added.

As to whether Siew, who is set to assume his new post as vice president May 20, will meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao, who will preside over the opening of the three-day conference, Wang said the matter remains uncertain and that he will give a briefing to the public once the issue is confirmed.
According to Wang, the two sides will not touch on political issues even if they meet, because the forum serves solely as a platform on which members exchange views and opinions on economic topics.
Siew shrugged off the question of whether he would attend the forum earlier that day in the central city of Taichung, saying only that the answer will be given at a news conference in two days.

Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, who met Siew earlier in the day at a closed-door meeting, said Siew's participation in the Boao Forum meeting would be conducive to Taiwan's economy. But he added that he believes Siew will also thoroughly assess possible negative ripples that could arise from the matter on the political front.
If Siew attends the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia next week, he would be Taiwan's first vice president-elect to land on Chinese soil in history.

Should Siew meet Chinese President Hu Jintao on the occasion, a Siew-Hu meeting would mark a new page in cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges after a meeting between Hu and KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan in Beijing in 2005.
A Siew-Hu meeting would also serve as an indicator as to whether major breakthroughs can be made in Taiwan-China ties, analysts said.

The non-government, non-profit Boao Forum for Asia was set up in 2001, with China, Japan and the Philippines among its 26 members. From 2002, the forum has held an annual conference in Boao, and Siew has participated in the meeting every year since 2003.

KMT Legislator Lee Chi-chu said it would be good if Taiwan and China can enhance two-way exchanges, although she suggested that concrete conclusions might not be reached in such high-ranking meetings as a result of a stalemate between the two sides over the past eight years.

"It would be good enough if the two sides could forge a good climate for greater cross-strait trade and economic exchanges on the financial front and in the area of direct trade and transportation links," she said.

Ker Chien-ming, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's legislative caucus whip, urged Siew to use the opportunity to underscore Taiwan's desire to join international organizations such as the World Health Organization, while fully safeguarding Taiwan's independent sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group urges president-elect to pay closer attention to environment

TEXT.P: A civic group called on President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Sunday to pay closer attention to matters regarding the environment and environmental protection once he assumes office.

The Taiwan Environmental Protection Union (TEPU) said the KMT, which held power for decades until 2000, is well-known for its economic policies and related achievements but paid regrettably little attention to affairs pertaining to the environment.

Hsu Kuang-jung, a TEPU leader and a professor at National Taiwan University, said TEPU is concerned that Ma, who is set to be inaugurated May 20, will follow the KMT's old policies regarding the environment after he takes the helm of a new administration.

Noting that in the past, Taiwan's economic development was built on highly polluting and high energy- and water-consuming manufacturing industries, Hsu called on Ma to see to it that Taiwan shifts to knowledge-based economy and "green" manufacturing industries that are environmentally friendly.

Hsu also said that Taiwan has been accused of being a major culprit in terms of carbon dioxide emissions and suggested that Ma should keep in his mind efforts to cut the country's carbon dioxide emissions and make "concrete schedules" for such reductions.

Hsu also suggested that the KMT, which now holds an absolute majority in the 113-seat legislature, should seek to lower the vote threshold for referendums on major issues concerning environmental protection, such as whether or not new nuclear power plants should be built.

DOC.HEADLINE: No conclusion over president-elect's U.S. visit: KMT official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 5 (CNA) 04/06/08 19:21:27 (By Jorge Liu and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government has not yet decided on whether it will allow President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to visit Washington ahead of his inauguration May 20, a KMT official said Saturday.

Deputy Representative Chang Ta-tung of the U.S. office of the KMT and its political ally, the People First Party, told CNA that "we are still negotiating with the U.S. government over the matter. The atmosphere is very good and our main purpose focuses on how to further Taiwan-U.S. relations."

Chang rebutted an April 4 story in the Nelson Report, a Washington insider daily newsletter, quoting Christopher Hill, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, as having apparently told a journalist during a visit to Indonesia that Bush had already denied Ma's visa request.

The story also said that "no-one involved will be surprised when this is formally announced. So attention has already turned to how the White House plans to compensate for so obviously catering to Beijing's concerns."
"Most likely by sending a much higher-level official U.S. delegation to the inauguration than has been seen before, " the story went on.

In addition, the story wrote that "Taiwan journalist sources say they've been told that Chris Hill himself will lead the U.S. delegation, but former Administration officials here say they think that unlikely, given the self- imposed U.S. ban on such a high-ranking State Department official visiting Taiwan in any capacity."
Casting doubt on the correctness of the story, Chang said that he had read the story, and as it did not directly quote Hill, was thus "not necessarily reliable."
On the same day in Taipei, Ma's spokesman, Lo Chih-chiang, declined to confirm or deny whether Ma's U.S. visit has been denied.
Commenting on the story, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Shieh Jhy- wey said that if the story is true, then "we will feel very sorry" for Ma and Taiwan's people.
Shieh further attributed the cause to Beijing's "one China" principle, which Taiwan refuses to accept on the grounds that the principle downgrades Taiwan into a part of China's territory.

At a workshop held a day earlier by the Heritage Foundation, a Washington think tank, Randy Schriver, a former deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, said that he fully supports Ma visiting Washington before taking office.
Schriver, however, doubted if Ma's trip would come about.

He explained that the U.S. government will refrain from allowing the president- elect to visit Washington before his inauguration in fear of setting a precedent that could invite undesired consequences.

The U.S. government might feel that it would be more appropriate for Ma to come to the United States when he makes a transit stop on U.S. soil during an overseas trip after assuming office, Schriver said.

He suggested that Ma should hold a dialogue with Washington through phone calls or video conferences if he fails to visit the U.S. ahead of his inauguration, or even use a trip to another country to make a stopover in the U.S. possible.
Top-ranking official exchanges between Taiwan and the United States have been a sensitive issue amid the absence of formal diplomatic relations and opposition from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Climate change theme of World Health Day 2008

TEXT.P: To mark World Health Day 2008 April 7, the World Health Organization (WHO) has designated "protecting health from climate change" as the theme for the year in order to raise public awareness of the issue and generate action by government and non government institutions, according to the WHO Web site.

Climate change has caused negative effects in Taiwan, such as poor crops and the spread of infectious diseases. Dengue fever, which used to be recorded only in southern Taiwan, has spread into the central and northern part of the island since 1995 as a result of the global warming effect, according to the Web site of the Taiwan Environmental Information Center, a non-government organization.
In addition, Taiwan suffered a severe water shortage in 2002 because of poor rainfall that year, which was a consequence of irregular weather patterns caused by climate change.
According to the WHO, health is one of the areas most affected by climate change, especially in the poorest regions of the world, which actually contribute least to greenhouse gas emissions.

A WHO assessment shows that approximately 600,000 deaths occurred worldwide as a result of weather-related natural disasters in the 1990s, some 95 percent of which were in poor countries, a tendency is likely to worsen in the future, according to the WHO.

Climate change can effect health because of increasing frequency of heatwaves and cold spells, more variable precipitation patterns that are likely to compromise the supply of drinking water and increase the risk of disease.

With sea levels rising, the risk of coastal flooding is also increased, which will lead to population displacement, the WHO says, enumerating other natural disasters stemming from climate change such as extreme temperatures, droughts and bushfires.

To illustrate the increasing impact of climate change, the WHO noted that in the 1980s, 1,848 extreme climate events affected 1.3 billion people around the world, while in the 1990s, about 1.8 billion were affected by 2,078 disaster events.

With the aim of stabilizing the effects of climate change on health, the WHO suggested cross-sector collaboration among government agencies, non-government organizations, industrial and professional groups and local communities, on decisions related to urban planning, transport, energy supply, food production, land use and water resources.
World Health Day, established in 1950, is celebrated every April 7 under the sponsorship of the WHO with the aim of promoting awareness of a specific health theme.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to raise exporters' awareness of strategic high-tech goods

TEXT.P: The government will hold a series of presentations from April 8 to raise local companies' awareness of regulations on the export of strategic high-tech commodities to help the companies avoid breaking the law and hurting the country's international image.

Although the Bureau of Foreign Trade established a mechanism with the U.S. government in June 2006 for screening applications for exporting strategic high- tech commodities to North Korea and Iran, there has been an increase in the number of local companies violating the regulations over the years, the bureau said in a recent statement.
Some of the violators have been indicted by local prosecutors on charges of violating the Foreign Trade Act, the statement went on.
As part of efforts to solve this problem, the bureau also plans to amend the control list to exclude less sensitive items, the statement said.
In addition, the bureau will work with the U.S. government to help Taiwanese companies set up an internal control system, the statement continued.

According to the statement, the Taiwan government formulated the regulations to join a global effort to control the transport of strategic high-tech products and technology to prevent weapons and equipment from spreading illegally.

The statement explained that it is very easy for Taiwan to become a source for terrorists seeking to obtain sensitive goods because Taiwan has a well-developed high-tech industry and it is a transport hub for goods in Southeast Asia.
As a consequence, the results of these control measures have attracted the world's attention, according to the statement.

The presentations will take place at the bureau's office April 8, and at the offices of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) in the southern port city of Kaohsiung and in the central city of Taichung April 10 and 15, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier worries about VP-elect's possible meeting with Chinese leader

TEXT.P: As Vice President-elect Vincent Siew of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is likely to meet Chinese President Hu Jintao at the 2008 Boao Forum next week in China's Hainan Province, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Sunday that he is concerned that such a meeting would lack a basis of parity and national dignity.

Speaking to a TV reporter, Chang said that "it may be an exaggeration to speculate that Siew will sell out Taiwan, but I do believe that such contact between Siew and Hu would lack the principles of dignity, self-determination and parity. "
The premier argued that "cross-Taiwan Strait contacts must not be made at the cost of Taiwan's overall interests, " although he said he has "the greatest expectations for them." He did not elaborate.

Wang Yu-chi, who will serve as the spokesman for Taiwan's delegation at the 2008 Boao Forum meeting, confirmed the same day at KMT headquarters that Siew, in his capacity as chairman of the Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation, will lead a delegation to the annual international conference April 11-13, as he has done for the last several years.
Siew established the foundation in 2003 to promote the formation of a cross- strait common market, and has taken part in the annual Boao Forum conference every year since then.
Taiwan's delegation, according to the conference agenda, will host a round-table meeting on Taiwan's economy and on the cross-strait economic outlook April 13, Wang said.

Hung Tu, executive director of the Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation, and Chan Hou-sheng, an advisor to the foundation and a former Council of Labor Affairs chairman, will accompany Siew to Boao, he added.
As to whether there will be a Siew-Hu meeting during the three-day conference, Wang said the matter remains uncertain and that he will give a briefing to the public after it is fixed.

According to Wang, the two sides will not touch on political issues even if they do meet at the forum, because the forum serves solely as a platform on which members exchange views and opinions on economic topics.

However, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey urged Siew to use the Forum to demand Hu in public to allow Taiwan to enter the World Health Organization (WHO) as a full member or to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer.

As the KMT has repeatedly said that Taiwan's security and international space will be better guaranteed if it returns to power, the issue is set to become the first major task facing the KMT in terms of cross-strait relations, with the WHA annual conference slated to be held from May 19-24 in Geneva, Shieh said.
Siew and President-elect Ma Ying-jeou will be inaugurated May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mainstream PC makers eyeing low-price laptop market

TEXT.P: Eager to replicate the success of Taiwanese PC maker ASUSTek Computer (ASUS) , which dominated the market for low-priced laptop computers with its Eee PC in 2007, big-name PC vendors including Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) , Acer and Dell are all gearing up to bring their own small laptops to market.
Last October, ASUS launched and sold 350,000 Eee PCs -- a mini notebook that weighs less than 1 kilogram and has a 17.78 cm screen.
According to a ASUS official, the US$400 computer helped boost company sales at the recent Taipei Software Show to 4,800 notebooks.
ASUS estimates that worldwide sales of the Eee PC throughout 2008 will reach 5 million.

The Eee PC has spurred many companies to follow ASUS's lead, with local company Acer among the first to enter the low-price notebook market with its own ultra- compact, 22.6 cm screen laptop that is scheduled to go on sale this June.
Acer's mini notebook will be manufactured by Taiwanese PC maker Quanta Computer in a run of 2 million units, which will be the manufacturer's major notebook order in the second quarter of 2008.

Leading PC maker Intel and LCD maker AU Optronics are also beneficiaries of Acer's bid, receiving orders from Acer to make Central Processing Units (CPUs) and LCD monitors, respectively, for the low-price notebook.

Another potential competitor for the Eee PC -- HPQ's Compaq 2133 -- will enter the market in April. The mini computer will weigh 1.13 kilograms and will be manufactured by Inventec Corp., market analysts said.

Intel, following the collaboration with ASUS in creating the Eee PC, developed a similar product of its own -- the Netbook, or 2go PC. The little laptop, manufactured by Computer Technology Link (CTL), will be aimed at the education market.

Although one step slower than its competitors, Dell's low-price notebook, which is scheduled to be launched in July, is expected to have a first order of about 1 million units, manufactured by Compal Electronics.
Dell's move into the market indicates that the world's mainstream PC vendors are all targeting the low-price market.
An industry insider said that apart from the low price advantage, another major factor for the popularity of mini laptops in the local market is their lightweight portability.

"Many parents, for example, have bought Eee PCs for their children for educational use, because small children can easily bring the book-sized little laptop to school with them, " said the industry insider, who referred to the Eee PC as an electronic book.

The mini laptop market is expected to grow at a faster speed than that of home PCs and regular-sized notebooks, and will help boost notebook market sales to 200 million units by 2010, according to Intel.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 7, or the second day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1348: Charles IV, king of Bohemia, founds Prague University, the first university in central Europe.
1827: John Waller, a chemist in northern England, sells the first matches, which he invented.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek resumes the Northward Expedition at the order of the National Government.
1932: A National Emergency Conference in Loyang decides on continued resistance against Japanese aggression.
1934: Mahatma Gandhi suspends his campaign of civil disobedience against British rule in India.
1945: The Yamato, Japan's largest battleship, is sunk by U.S. aircraft carrier warplanes.
1947: Henry Ford, American car manufacturer, dies at the age of 84. He developed a gasoline-powered automobile in 1893, founded the Ford Motor Company in 1903, and mass-produced the Model T from 1908 to 1927.
1948: The World Health Organization (WHO) is founded in Geneva.
1953: Dag Hammarskjold, Swedish diplomat and political leader who won the 1961 Nobel Peace Prize posthumously, succeeds Trygve Lie as secretary-general of the United Nations.
1954: Jackie Chan, Hong Kong movie star who is noted for his action films, is born.
1963: The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia is set up with Marshal Tito as president for life.
1969: Traffic courts are set up in Taipei City and other locations around Taiwan to begin handling traffic violation cases.
1976: Simon Kuznets, 1971 Nobel Prize winner for economics, arrives in Taipei for a three-week-visit.
1976: The Communist Party of China's Political Bureau decides at a meeting to appoint Hua Guofeng as premier and to depose Deng Xiaoping as deputy premier after riots in Beijing.
1976: Hishan M. Nazer, Saudi Arabian minister of planning, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter backpedals on building the Neutron bomb.
1979: The International Olympic Committee decides the ROC can retain its membership while admitting Communist China as a new member.
1981: Voters in the Philippines approve a new constitution, giving President Ferdinand Marcos sweeping powers.
1987: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces that American diplomats will not occupy the new embassy in Moscow until he is sure that it is secure against Soviet eavesdropping.
1989: Cheng Nan-jong, the person in charge of the "Era of Freedom" magazine, immolates himself after refusing arrest for involvement in an insurrection case.
1989: The Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee announces that ROC athletic teams and organizations will participate in international sports events held on the mainland under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1990: Communist China launches a U.S.-made telecommunications satellite into orbit.
1998: Indonesia and the International Monetary Fund agree on a package of measures to get a US$43 billion bailout package on track.
1999: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho urges the government to step up its international publicity drive to buttress global awareness of the Republic of China.
2000: Almost two-dozen founding members of the hard-line Independence Party announce their decision to drop out of the party because they say that the party has completed its mission.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, receives a set of CNA file photos, including one showing he in the arms of his mother along with his father and his elder brother.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is dishonorable. When there is no justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is also dishonorable."

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect confirms his plan to attend forum in China

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Vincent Siew of the Kuomintang confirmed Sunday that he will attend the Boao Forum to be held April 11-13 in Hainan, southern China.

In an interview with TVBS, Siew said he is a founding member of the forum and will attend the annual gathering in his capacity as chairman of the Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation, as he has done in the last five years.
The organization was founded by Siew in 2001 to promote the establishment of a common market across the Taiwan Straits.
Siew related that he had informed President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of his intention, and that Ma said he respected his decision since it had to do with the Common Market Foundation.

Siew said he had missed the March 13 deadline for applying to participate in the forum as he was busy with his election campaign during that time, and that he had explored the possibility of joining the event only after the March 22 election in which he and Ma beat their Democratic Progressive Party rivals Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang.
Fortunately, Siew said, the organizers of the forum welcomed his participation, and the paperwork for his participation in the event was almost all set for Saturday.
"Barring any unexpected incidents, I will attend the forum." said Siew, who will be sworn in as vice president on May 20.

He said that the forum's organizers must have gotten a green light from Beijing before accepting his application, in light of his sensitive new position as Taiwan's vice president elect. But "I do not understand the reasons" behind Beijing's decision, he added.
The forum will be formally opened by China President Hu Jintao and there is a possibility that he will meet Siew for the first time since the Taiwan election.
Siew and Hu have met previously at the forum in 2004.
Siew refused to predict what results his attendance at the forum might achieve, saying only that the forum was dedicated to discussing economic issues that Taiwan would face in the future.
"I will join the forum as a member and if there are any positive results from my participation, I would let the people know after I return," Siew said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT urges respect for VP-elect's professionalism

TEXT.P: An official of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) called on the Taiwan people Monday to respect the professionalism of KMT Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and to trust in his ability.

Lin Yi-shih, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, urged the public to trust Siew's ability to uphold Taiwan's dignity and rights at the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia, which he will attend April 11-13 in Hainan, China.

Wang Yu-chi, a spokesman for the Taiwan delegation to the forum, confirmed Sunday that Siew, who was at the forum for five of the last six annual meetings since it was launched in 2002, will participate this year in his capacity as chairman of the private Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation.
The foundation was founded by Siew in 2001 to promote the establishment of a common market across the Taiwan Strait.

Lin noted that some people in Taiwan have been making noises about Siew's attendance at the forum on grounds that Siew is now the Republic of China vice president-elect, and that his presence at the international forum -- which is expected to bring together 11 heads of state -- may provide Beijing with a chance to further belittle Taiwan in the international arena.

Noting that Siew and his team are trying hard to score a breakthrough for Taiwan in the global diplomatic community, Lin said that the KMT will spare no efforts and will make every possible attempt to assist them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fugitive arms broker, family still absent from Taipei court

TEXT.P: A fugitive arms broker and his family, indicted on charges related to the high- profile Lafayette kickback case, were still absent from their trial at a Taipei court Monday, legal sources said.

Neither Andrew Wang, the French arms supplier Thompson-CSF's agent in Taiwan, nor his wife and their four children were present at Monday's trial. The six were indicted by a special judicial panel in September 2006 on charges of collecting kickbacks from Taiwan's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates from France in 1991.
At the court, Wang's lawyer said Wang temporarily has no plans to return to Taiwan as he is ill and is also worried that his personal safety may be jeopardized if returns.
As to Wang's wife and their four children, the lawyer said, they were absent because none of them were involved in the kickback case.

Wang fled the country after Navy Capt. Yin Ching-feng died under suspicious circumstances in late 1993. Yin is believed to have been poised to blow the whistle on his colleagues who had allegedly received kickbacks from the Lafayette deal.
Wang has been listed by Taiwan authorities as wanted on murder charges since September 2000.

Concluding a second-phase investigation into the arms procurement scandal in September 2006, the Taipei special judicial panel indicted Wang, his wife, and their four children, as well as Kuo Li-heng, a former naval officer in charge of arms procurement, and his brother Kuo Wen-tien on charges of collecting kickbacks from the Lafayette deal.
The judicial panel also asked for a life sentence for Wang.
According to the 2006 indictment, the Wangs opened more than 60 bank accounts in Europe and Asia to launder US$520 million in illicit gains from the deal.
Wang had also transferred more than US$10 million in kickbacks to Kuo via several overseas banking accounts, the indictment stated.

Swiss authorities in June 2007 returned to Taiwan US$34 million in frozen bank deposits believed to be kickbacks connected to Taiwan's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates from France in 1991. Officials at the Swiss Department of Justice said the funds returned belonged to two different holders, but declined to identify the holders.
The funds were handed over to Taiwanese authorities on condition that the legal proceedings against the two persons comply with human rights principles, the Swiss officials stipulated.
Taiwan began to seek legal assistance from the Swiss government in 2001 in an attempt to retrieve the funds frozen in several Swiss banks.

Through a judicial aid agreement with Switzerland, Taiwan prosecutors managed to obtain a collection of bank files from a Swiss federal judge in November 2005. After nearly 10 months of close examination of the files, Taiwan petitioned in September 2006 for the return of US$520 million from a total of US$730 million frozen in the Swiss banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Boosted by surging global stock market, Taiwan share prices rose Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 133.45 points, or 1.55 percent, to close at 8,729.79.

The bourse opened at 8,638.63 and fluctuated between 8,729.79 and 8,619.99 during the day's session. A total of 4.74 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$134.52 billion (US$4.41 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction shares moving up the most at 5.1 percent, followed by textile stocks at 3.8 percent, banking and financial shares at 2.1 percent, foodstuff issues at 2 percent, paper and pulp stocks at 1.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.2 percent, and machinery and electronics issues at 1.1 percent.
Only one stock category lost ground, cement stocks, which moved down 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,517 to 627, with 340 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$3.40 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Saint Kitts and Nevis rebuts reports of fragile ties

TEXT.P: The charge d'affaires to Taiwan of Saint Kitts and Nevis rebutted Monday a warning by Vice President Annette Lu that diplomatic relations are fragile because the Caribbean country did not immediately send a congratulatory message to President-elect Ma Ying-jeou on his poll victory, blaming the delay on "unfortunate circumstances."

"We were not able to respond to the result of the election as we normally do due to a series of unfortunate circumstances, " Saint Kitts and Nevis Charge d'Affaires Jasmine Huggins told CNA to clarify the issue.

Lu said in a media interview April 2 that the failure of three Republic of China allies -- Guatemala, Burkina Faso and St. Kitts and Nevis -- to send congratulatory messages on Ma's victory was a warning that ties with those countries could be tenuous.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) acknowledged April 3 that the Foreign Ministry had yet to receive congratulatory messages from two diplomatic allies but downplayed the issue, saying that the oversight was due to administrative delays.

Huggins noted that she had to hasten home upon the death of her father the day after the March 22 presidential election and did not come back until last Thursday. Also, she went on, she had been very sick since her return.
The charge d'affaires said the embassy did not intend to delay the congratulatory message and that relations between Taiwan and Saint Kitts and Nevis remain stable.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's landslide victory March 22 was so welcomed by the international community that many countries, even some without diplomatic relations with Taiwan, congratulated Ma because many welcome the prospect of improvement in cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

U.S. President George W. Bush also sent a statement right after the election to congratulate Ma, praising Taiwan as a beacon of democracy in Asia -- a contrast from the letter sent by his secretary to President Chen Shui-bian which was not delivered until a week after his re-election in 2004.
A congratulatory message sent by St. Kitts and Nevis Prime Minister Denzil Douglas arrived April 4, according to the MOFA.

Douglas said in his message that the 25-year-old bilateral relations will remain intact in the wake of the transition of power in Taiwan and that he hopes bilateral relations will be further deepened and expanded during Ma's term in office, the MOFA said.

Taiwan became the first diplomatic ally of Saint Kitts and Nevis after its independence and the two forged diplomatic ties in 1983. Douglas visited Taiwan in February to attend the opening ceremony of the country's first embassy in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up 137 points to close at 8,709, with 45,697 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May rose 139 points to finish at 8,688, with 816 contracts traded, while June futures gained 138 points to close at 8,675, with 45 contract transactions.
September futures increased 158 points to finish at 8,459, with 44 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 160 points to close at 8,450, with 26 contracts traded.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 133.45 points Monday to finish at 8,729.79, with a market turnover of NT$134.52 billion (US$4.41 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 8,572 for April; 8,549 for May; 8,537 for June; 8,301 for September and 8,290 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
April TE futures moved up 3.55 points to close at 331.1, with 3,626 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 4.05 points to finish at 330.3, with 88 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.
April TF futures rose 23.4 points to close at 1,142.6, with 4,154 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures increased 23.8 points to finish at 1,140, with 91 contracts traded.
June TF futures moved up 6.4 points to close at 1,125, with one contract traded, while September TF futures gained 11.8 points to finish at 1,120, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health club ordered to pay compensation for wet floor accident

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court recently ordered the Alexander Health Club to pay over NT$245,000 (US$8,060) in compensation to a university professor who broke his arm after he slipped on a wet floor at one of the fitness centers.

The National Taiwan University of Science and Technology professor, surnamed Lin, broke his right forearm at the health club's Songshou Road branch Dec. 17, 2005. Lin ended up spending four days in hospital for treatment of his broken forearm, which took over two months to heal.

Lin decided to sue the health club for compensation six months after the accident, stating in the lawsuit that the health club had not placed any warning signs to let people know that the floor was wet.

In the lawsuit, Lin claimed that the muscles in his right forearm were still weak and that full mobility had not been restored after over six months of rehabilitation, and that he was seeking NT$1.44 million in compensation for medical and transportation expenses, loss of income due to his injury, and emotional suffering.
The court said in its ruling that the Alexander Health Club was responsible for the accident and should compensate the plaintiff.

The health club was ordered to pay Lin over NT$14,000 for medical expenses, more than NT$80,000 for transportation expenses, NT$42,000 for loss of income, and NT$100,000 for emotional suffering -- a total of over NT$245,000 in compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Builders to launch one-day strike

TEXT.P: Local construction companies engaged in public works projects decided Monday to launch a one-day strike later this week to protest against what they described as the outgoing government's lack of action in dealing with their difficulties stemming from surging costs of building materials.
The Taiwan Regional Engineering Contractors Association (TRECA) , which is comprised of 11,743 realtors and contractors, plans to launch the strike April 10, TRECA officials said.

Meanwhile, they added, some 3,000 people connected to the organization are expected to launch an appeal on that day to the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission for a solid and immediate response to a subsidy request they made last month.

They said that TRECA Chairman Pan Chun-jung and executives of various contractor companies paid a courtesy call on Premier Chang Chun-hsung in mid-March in an attempt to ask the administration to raise the levels of subsidies to help them overcome the financial difficulties brought on by the surging building material costs.
At that meeting, they said, Chang promised that the administration would make a decision in a week on how and when increased subsidies should be granted.
