However, they went on, the Public Construction Commission announced after the March 22 presidential election that such a decision should be made by the incoming new administration, on the grounds that the amounts involved in the subsidy plans are too large and that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration will be leaving office.
DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh lost to his rival from the main opposition Kuomintang, Ma Ying-jeou, in the March 22 election by some 2.21 million votes.
TRECA lashed out at the DPP administration, accusing it of eating its words, and decided to launch the one-day strike in protest.
The association asked the DPP government in March for NT$6 billion (US$197.37 million) in subsidies to help them cover the rising cost of building materials that have plagued them over the past year.

The government currently offers subsidies to contractors when building materials in general categories rise by 5 percent and in specific categories by 10 percent. The Public Construction Commission in early March tentatively approved the lowering of both thresholds to 2.5 percent.

Pan said TRECA had no opinion on the commission's move but hopes that the subsidies will be applied retroactively from January 2007 -- when the price hikes actually began -- and continue to the end of 2008.

Developers and contractors have been hit especially hard by the soaring cost of steel products used in building. The cost of rebar had surged from NT$8,000 (US$263.16) per ton some four months ago to over NT$28,000 per ton as of Monday -- an all time high.

Under pressure from local builders to take action to stem the rise, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Feb. 20 a ban on the export of rebar and steel billets -- the main material used to produce rebar.

But even the MOEA acknowledged that the ban, which is expected to last for three months after it takes effect in two weeks, will not have much of an impact on local prices because Taiwan does not export big volumes of those products.
The ministry said it will also closely monitor exports of steel H-beams and steel scrap for three months to see if action on those items is warranted.
As of Monday, the average price for steel H-beams had surged to NT$29,300 per ton, while the average price for steel scrap had soared to NT$16,900 per ton -- both representing record highs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan human rights group urges China to free jailed dissident

TEXT.P: Human rights activists in Taiwan urged Chinese authorities Monday to release jailed dissident Hu Jia and called for condemnation of China's deteriorating human right record and a boycott of the Beijing Olympics.

"This Olympics absolutely does not reflect justice or human rights, " said Sun Yu-lien, an executive member of Taiwan International Human Rights Solidarity Center. "We strongly urge leaders of the Chinese government to fulfill the promise that China made in order to win the right to host the Olympic Games -- to improve its human rights record."

Several human rights activists, including a lawyer, a journalist and a university professor, held a press conference in Taipei to call for China to release the prominent Chinese human rights dissident Hu Jia on bail for medical treatment, based on humanitarian concerns.

Hu, who suffers from cirrhosis of the liver, was sentenced on April 2 to three and a half years in prison and banned from political activism for one year for "inciting subversion of state power" by posting articles on the Internet and giving interviews to foreign journalists. The 34-year-old activist, one of the most vocal in China, rose to prominence as a campaigner for the rights of AIDS patients.

Amid growing criticism worldwide of China's crackdown in Tibet, Hu's case has drawn much international attention, with critics saying that his detention and conviction were part of a campaign to silence dissents ahead of the Beijing Olympics.
Hu's wife, Zeng Jinyan, who has a newborn baby, has been under house arrest since her husband was arrested in December last year.

Yang Chunlin, another human rights activist, was given a maximum sentence of five years in jail last month on subversion charges after he organized a campaign to collect 40,000 signatures for a petition that stated: "We want human rights, not the Olympics."

Huang Mou, director of the Chang Fo-Chuan Center for the Study of Human Rights at Soochow University, said that it is incomprehensible why the Chinese government would expend so much effort on two completely harmless people whose only concerns are the truth and human rights.

"What China did has violated every moral standard, " Huang said. "China cannot expect to be seen as a great civilized country when it is showing disregard for the universal values of freedom of speech and human rights."
Chow Fu-mei, an executive member of the Association of Taiwan Journalists, said that Hu Jia's case is "a trial of the conscience of the 1.3 billion Chinese people."
"Taiwan will never shrink from any effort to rescue Hu Jia because we believe that justice will be restored if we try hard enough," she said

Lin Feng-jeng, executive director of the Judicial Reform Foundation, said the foundation hoped that the press conference would be just a start in a series of efforts to support those detained and jailed in China.
"Let's hope today's Taiwan will be tomorrow's China," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Women warned about cervical cancer even if their womb is removed

TEXT.P: Officials of the health department in Taichung County in central Taiwan urged local women not to loosen their alertness against cervical cancer even if their wombs have been taken out.

The officials pointed to a case of a woman who was more than 60 years old, who got cervical cancer even though she had her womb and ovaries taken out 10 years ago in the hope that she would never have to worry about getting the cancer.
As the woman has skipped getting Pap smear examinations since then, she was shocked to find out that she got cervical cancer early this year, according to the officials.
They believe that cancer cells might develop even in remaining womb tissue, but officials said the good news is cervical cancer is one of the most curable types of cancers.
"Cervical cancer is not as terrible as women think. On the contrary, it has the highest cure rate among various cancers if discovered early," the official said.
Pap smear has been one of the medical checkups that the government has not spared efforts in promoting during the last few years.

According to the officials, Taichung County's Department of Health has offered free Pap smear for women aged more than 30, and free tests in blood pressure, blood sugar and cholesterol for women aged more than 40 years old.
Meanwhile, women older than 30 who have had a Pap smear will be offered a free ultrasound breast exam, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Bush and Putin find limits to personal diplomacy
Seven years ago, President Bush famously said after his first private meetings with Russian President Vladimir Putin, "I was able to get a sense of his soul." Even after seven years, and private meeting in settings as varied as Bush's rain-soaked ranch in late autumn and Putin's woodsy dacha amid the McMansions on Moscow's outskirts, the message on the eve of their work session today was:Personal diplomacy can go only so far, and in a crunch, national interests certainly trump all. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Bush, Putin fail to resolve missile row
U.S. President George W. Bush and Russia's Vladimir Putin ended their last face- to-face meeting as heads of state Sunday with warm words for each other but no resolution to their row over missile defense.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:Top Clinton Aide Leaving His Post Under Pressure
Mark Penn stepped down as Hillary Rodham Clinton's chief strategist after his business arrangements again clashed with her campaign positions.
The Wall Street Journal: WaMu to Get $5 Billion Infusion
WaMu's Killinger Private-equity firm TPG and other investors are near a deal to invest $5 billion in WaMu in return for stock. That could allow the U.S.'s largest thrift to meet all its capital requirements amid deep losses from the mortgage crisis, but would dilute current holders' stakes. 12:18 a.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post:Focus of Iraq Hearings May Be on Candidates
This week's sessions in the Senate promise to be as much about presidential politics in the U. S. as about the past six months of progress in Iraq.
The Washington Times: Sri Lankan rebels set up U.S. branch
The Tamil Tigers, a terrorist organization whose suicide bombings and political assassinations have killed 4,000 people in the past two years, have quietly established a U.S. presence to help bankroll and equip its brutal secessionist campaign in Sri Lanka, authorities said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu draws many visitors on first weekend of sea festival

TEXT.P: Many residents and non-locals took advantage of the sunny weather on the first weekend of Hsinchu City's month-long sea festival to enjoy outdoor activities along the city's coastline.

The sea festival, launched by the local government to introduce Hsinchu's marine attractions, is showcasing the city's 17-kilometer coastline through various activities, including a biking event, rollerblading competition, and a mass wedding to be held near the end of April.
The municipal government has spent the last several years upgrading the natural attractions and leisure facilities along the coastline to draw more tourists to the city.
The coastline now features eight main attractions, including a Sea Park, a recreational boating wharf, a mangrove forest, a sea-viewing area, a canal, and a bird-watching area.
Over the past weekend, many locals and visitors to the city could be seen taking in the various sights along the coastline.

Others engaged in outdoor activities such cycling along the scenic bike trails, trying out the pedal boats, flying kites on the wide lawn area around the tourism center, or just relaxing on the white sandy beaches and enjoying the spectacular views.
Hsinchu's new tourism area also drew many visitors who wished to sample the fresh local delicacies at the many seafood restaurants along the coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: $1m set aside to help needy with food costs.
The first step in a joint effort to help needy Singaporeans cope with the rising cost of food items has come in the form of a kitty with at least S$1 million in it. The money will come from MCYS' ComCare fund and details would come ' very soon'.
The Lianhe Zaobao: ComCare fund will give S$1m to to help Singapore's needy with rising food costs.
The Ministry of Community Development Youth and Sports (MCYS) will allocate S$1 million at least from it's ComCare fund to help needy to deal with rising food costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Bossi threatens to take arms.
The right-wing Northern League party leader Umberto Bossi threatened to take arms if the government refuses to reprint ballots for the April 13-14 general elections. Bossi issued the threat after former premier Silvio Berlusconi asserted that the list of contenders on the ballots should be printed vertically, not horizontally such as what the government is planning to do. Interior Minister Giuliano Amato argued that the typography of ballots follows the decree issued by Berlusconi's administration two year s ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Registration for computer writing competition for foreigners opens

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education and the Steering Committee for the Test of Proficiency-Huaya opened registration Monday for a computer writing contest for foreigners.
Registration for the contest for non-native Chinese high-intermediate Mandarin students will run until April 30. The contest will be held May 27.
The steering committee said the contest will consist of two parts -- an applied essay, for which 50 minutes will be allotted and a discussion essay, for which 70 minutes will be allotted.
The top five winners in the contest will receive awards and cash prizes ranging from NT$2,000 to NT$10,000, according to the steering committee.

In addition, as the contest will only be held in two locations -- National Taiwan Normal University in Taipei City and National Cheng Kung University in Tainan City -- the committee is offering transport subsidies of up to NT$1,000 in order to encourage students from around Taiwan to take part.
The steering committee said it is hoped the contest will encourage more foreigners to improve their computer writing and Mandarin skills.
Those interested in taking part in the contest can visit the committee's Web site at http: //www.sc-top.org.tw or call (02) 3343-3900 for more information.

DOC.HEADLINE: High speed rail daily passenger volume hits new high

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Speed Rail system transported 132,000 passengers and operated a total of 130 trains Sunday, the last day of Taiwan's Tomb Sweeping holiday, marking two new highs, an executive of the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) said Monday.

Sunday's passenger volume broke the record of 123,000 set on the eve of the traditional holiday when local people travel to their family homes to pay tribute to their ancestors and clean up their graves, the executive said.

Some 460,000 passengers traveled on the system during the four-day holiday, a figure that exceeded the volume recorded over the Chinese New Year holiday in February this year, according to the executive.

The official attributed the increased volume to the THSRC's decision to provide additional trains and some free seats, a service that drew a lot of impromptu passengers, adding that during the Chinese New Year holiday most travelers had reserved seats for planned tours.

On the last day of the Tomb Sweeping holiday, the THSRC allowed free seating on some train cars and dispatched an additional four non-reserved trains to carry people from Kaohsiung to Taipei and one from Taichung to Taipei, but many passengers still had to stand all the way, the executive said.

He added that on average, a train with 989 seats was at some points carrying about 1,500 passengers during peak hours on Sunday, but added that the trains were not too crowded all the way as many passengers disembarked along the route.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, losing NT$0.012 to close at NT$30.418.
A total of US$992 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$30.450 and hit a low of NT$30.370.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei streamlines procedure for applying for elderly services

TEXT.P: Taipei City has established a new center to streamline applications for long- term care for elderly people living in the capital, the city government announced Monday, as the proportion of seniors in Taipei is expected to grow.
The Taipei City Long-Term Care Management Center (LTCMC) has been established with an aim of simplifying the process for the elderly to apply for medical and social care services, officials said.

In the past, elderly people in need of services had to file one application to the Department of Health for medical assessment and another to the Department of Social Welfare for social services, a welfare department official said at press conference.

"The integration of the resources of the two departments is like a wedding," joked Allen W. Chiu, the DOH's director, saying that with the establishment of the center, senior citizens needing long-term care have only one application to file.
"Through the collaboration of the two departments, a more efficient service will benefit elderly citizens in Taipei, " Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin told the news conference.
The center also provides services such as assessment of individual conditions and needs, home care, home rehabilitation treatment, and low cost respite care.

Residents in Taipei aged over 65 -- 55 for indigenous people and 50 for disabled people -- who are deemed unable to take care of themselves, can file applications for aid at the center, according to a statement issued by the center.
Other people of all ages who are unable to take care of themselves can also apply for aid, but will receive less governmental subsidies, the center said.
According to the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), in 2007, about 2.3 million people in Taiwan were aged over 65, representing 10.2 percent of the total population.
A survey by the Taipei city government showed that in Taipei, 315,618 people, accounting for 12 percent of the city's population, are aged over 65, and the growth rate is expected to increase.
About 30,000 of Taipei's elderly people currently need long-term care services, the center noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGBeijing Olympics: hopes swiftly extinguished by violence and farce
The Beijing 2008 Olympic Games torch relay was reduced to farce and ignominy yesterday as ugly scenes of protest disrupted the London leg of the tour that was billed as a journey of harmony and peace. More than 35 protesters were arrested in a series of clashes with the police, who had to reroute part of the procession to protect the 80 runners.

DOC.HEADLINE: No law bans VP-elect from attending forum in China: MAC

TEXT.P: There are no laws or regulations that would ban Vice President-elect Vincent Siew of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) from attending the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia in Hainan, China, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun said Monday.

He was responding to concerns raised in recent days about the appropriateness of Siew's planned trip to the mainland to attend the forum from April 11-13, especially because he might have a chance to meet Chinese President Hu Jintao.
Siew and president-elect Ma Ying-jeou won the presidential election on March 22, but will not take up the posts until they are inaugurated on May 20.
They have pledged to build closer economic ties with China to stimulate growth in Taiwan's economy and have proposed setting up a "common market" with China.
The non-government, non-profit Boao Forum, whose 26 members include China, Japan and the Philippines, aims to promote economic and trade cooperation.
Siew has attended the forum every year since 2003. The forum, which was set up in 2001, held its first annual conference in 2002.
If Siew attends the Boao Forum in his private capacity as chairman of the Cross- Strait Common Market Foundation before the inauguration, there should be no legal problem, Liu told reporters.
As to the question of whether Siew has asked the MAC to brief him on the latest situation across the Taiwan Strait, Liu said the council has not received such a request from relevant authorities.

Siew confirmed a media report Sunday that he will take part in the forum as the chairman of the Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation. He founded the foundation in 2001 to promote the idea of setting up a common market between Taiwan and China.

Siew's attendance at this year's Boao Forum annual conference, however, has stirred up widespread attention from the domestic political spectrum, due to his status as Taiwan's vice president-elect and in part because Siew is likely to meet Hu at the forum.
Siew's visit will be the first time that a vice president-elect from Taiwan will land on Chinese soil before his or her inauguration.

Wang Yu-chi, the spokesman of Siew's delegation to the Boao Forum for Asia, told a news conference Sunday at the KMT headquarters that Hung Tu, executive director of the Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation, and Chan Hou-sheng, an adviser to the foundation and a former Council of Labor Affairs chairman, will accompany Siew to Boao.
Wang said that the delegation will host a round-table meeting on Taiwan's economy and on cross-Strait economic outlook on April 13 at the forum.

According to Wang, Taiwan's and China's delegations will not touch on political issues even if Siew and Hu meet at the forum, because the forum serves solely as a platform for member countries and areas to exchange views and opinions on economic topics.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC, Taipower welcome `lump sum' price hike plans

TEXT.P: Executives of both state-owned oil refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan and grid operator Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) expressed welcome Monday to the idea that fuel and electricity prices will be hiked in June in a "lump sum" way.

Vice President-elect Vincent Siew is reported to have said recently that after the Kuomintang (KMT) administration is inaugurated May 20, he will make sure the floating oil price system is reviewed and that if necessary, fuel and electricity prices will be hiked at one time, rather than in several smaller increments.

CPC President Pan Wenent and Taipower Chairman Edward Chen expressed welcome to the "lump sum" price hikes in June, given that it seems impossible for the two state-owned enterprises to raise their prices any earlier as the outgoing Democratic Progressive Party administration has decided that prices of gasoline, electricity and water will not be adjusted before President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's administration takes the reins of power May 20.
Pan said that under the "lump sum" price hike formula, the CPC will increase the average price of its oil products by NT$2.5 per liter.
He lamented that even if gasoline prices are raised "in one shot" in June, the hikes will not help CPC's balance sheet look any better for this year.
He added that as of Monday, CPC had suffered an average loss of NT$330 million (US$10.86 million) each day, or NT$13 million per hour.
Meanwhile, Chen said that if electricity prices are raised in June, he hopes that the hikes will average about 30 percent.
He said Taipower would have to implement a price hike averaging 48 percent if the country's major grid operator wants its costs and revenues to balance by the end of this year.

However, he went on, Taipower will not opt for a 48 percent price hike in consideration that such a drastic increase would cause a negative impact so big that the country would be "unable to take it."
He added that when adjusting electricity prices, Taipower will raise prices by smaller margins for smaller utility users and by larger margins for bigger users.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan establishes cooperation with Poland on stock exchanges

TEXT.P: The stock exchanges of Taiwan and Poland have signed a Memorandum of Cooperation (MoC) to allow for reciprocal investment and market operations, Wu Rong-I, chairman of Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp. (TSEC) announced Monday.

Following the signing of MoCs with Vietnam, Thailand and Abu Dhabi earlier this year, the TSEC has continued to expand its foreign alliances by inking a cooperation deal with Poland's Warsaw Stock Exchange (WSE) , in a bid to explore the East and Central Europe market, Wu said.
TSEC, Taiwan Future Exchange (TAIFEX), GreTai Securities Market (GTSM) each signed a separate agreement with the WSE, he added.
"The TSEC will take the opportunity to pursue market cooperation to expand its internationalization," Wu explained.
He said the TSEC and WSE will hold regular meetings and exchange information on market operation to prepare for brokerage trade and company listings in both markets.

He urged that Taiwan companies invest in the Poland market, following the example of local brokerage firms Yuanta Securities and Polaris Securities after the signing last year of the MoC between Taiwan and Singapore. The two securities, testing the Singapore market, have listed stock warrants and exchange traded funds (ETF).

Wu also said that the inking of the MoC between Taiwan and Poland indicated that European investors are seeking a more lucrative market, adding that a more diverse range of financial products are to be developed in the future to accommodate cooperation with the WSE.

Following the signing, WSE vice president Adam Maciejewski noted that the Polish stock market has been growing quite rapidly over the last few years and that it is seeking global opportunities for investment of its capital.
Through our stock exchange, Taiwan companies are able to expand their businesses in Europe, especially in Poland,he said.

He was referring to the exchange model of the Polish initiative, the New Connect that was launched last October to allow for a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) that helps small companies to list their stocks.
Maciejewski also said the WSE would like to list Taiwanese companies.
It (the listing of those companies) would be of great interest to the Polish capital market,he noted.
According to Michael Lin, TSEC's senior executive vice president, high-tech companies like resin maker Chi Mei and PC vendor ASUS are among the targets that the WSE would like to attract.

MoC between stock exchanges often provide new business opportunities for both markets, said Wu Tang-chieh, Director-General of the Securities and Futures Bureau under the Financial Supervisory Commission, citing the market alliance of Taiwan and Poland as a part of a global trend.
The new relationship between the two countries will benefit both market operators and all the participants in the financial markets," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Meeting with Chinese leader depends on Boao organizer: VP-elect

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Vincent Siew confirmed Monday his plan to participate in the upcoming Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) in China in his capacity as chairman of the Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation (CSCMF), but he refused to elaborate on whether he will meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao.
Siew's participation in the BFA annual meeting and the possibility that he might meet with Hu are considered by the media as an indicator of the prospects for future cross-strait relations.
At a crowded press conference, Siew avoided directly responding to repeated questions as to whether he will meet with Hu, saying only that "we respect the arrangements of the organizer."

Noting that the CSCMF, a founding member of the Boao Forum, has routinely taken part in the BFA's annual conference since 2003, Siew said that "we will attend this year's forum from April 11 as usual."

However, he rebutted concerns that China might use the opportunity to describe Siew "the vice leader of the Taiwan area" to belittle Taiwan, saying that "nothing will be belittled within the Boao Forum."
He said that what matters in the forum are the discussions and the suggestions from participants.
"The Boao Forum serves as a platform for international and cross- strait exchanges under which everyone is on an equal footing, " he added.

"We must bear in mind the interest of our nation with a positive attitude," said Siew, adding that "Taiwan's economy must be connected with the world. With this positive attitude, we can better understand global issues."
"We have to be open-minded and focus on the forum itself, and on what will benefit Taiwan in the future," Siew noted.

Saying that his plan to take part in the forum was sanctioned by President- elect Ma Ying-jeou, Siew reaffirmed that "we should never give up any opportunity that enables Taiwan to be heard by the world."

In addition to the scheduled forum activities, Siew said he will also preside over an April 13 roundtable in which the forum participants will exchange views on Taiwan's economy and cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
"We hope to bring a new beginning to this new era through cross-strait relations as well as economic exchanges," he said.

The BFA is a non-government, non-profit international organization set up with the aim of giving leaders in government, business and academia in Asia and elsewhere an opportunity to share their visions on the most pressing issues in the region and in the world at large.
According to the event organizer, participants in this year's conference include Siew and Hu, as well as the presidents of Chile, Mongolia, Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Tanzania.

Donald Tseng, chief executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (SAR) and Edmund Ho Hau Wah, chief executive of the Macao SAR, are also expected to attend, along with the premiers of Australia, Kazakhstan, Qatar and Sweden.

DOC.HEADLINE: Siew cannot be stopped from participating in Boao Forum: MAC

TEXT.P: Despite concerns over Vice President-elect Vincent Siew's participation in the upcoming Boao Forum for Asia (BFA), there are no regulations that would prevent him from going, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) spokesman said Monday.

High-ranking Taiwanese government officials are banned from traveling to China under Taiwan law, but MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said that Siew will participate in the non-governmental conference in an "unofficial capacity" and stressed that "there is no restriction on his (Siew's) visit."
Siew said Monday that he will attend the forum in China's Hainan province in his capacity as chairman of the Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation (CSCMF).
His trip will take on added significance, however, because of his status as vice president-elect and the possibility that he could meet Chinese President Hu Jintao at the forum.

Critics from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party have raised concerns that China would try to belittle Taiwan and Siew during the April 11-13 event, although few have argued that he should be stopped from going.
In keeping with Siew's private status in attending the forum, Liu said the DPP government would not get involved in the details of the vice president-elect's trip.

"His (Siew's) participation in the annual meeting kicking off April 11 will not be arranged through the government, " Liu said. "We have not received any order yet to brief Siew on the most up-to- date intelligence on China before his departure."

The Boao Forum for Asia, a non-government and non-profit international organization founded in 2001, serves as a platform for high-level interaction between Asian and global leaders and aims to promote development goals in Asia through greater regional economic integration.

According to the forum's organizers, participants will also include Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd, Chile's President Michelle Bachelet, Pakistan President Pervez Musharraf as well as the presidents of Mongolia, Sri Lanka and Tanzania.
Donald Tseng, chief executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (SAR) and Edmund Ho Hau Wah, chief executive of Macau SAR, are also expected to be present at the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan looks forward to purchasing F-16 C/D fighters from U.S.

TEXT.P: Taiwan's lawmakers and the military are looking forward to purchasing 66 F-16 C/D fighters from the United States for the Republic of China Air Force, despite their disagreement over why the proposed deal, reportedly approved by Washington in 2006, has failed to materialize.

Deputy Defense Minister Ko Cheng-heng told a meeting of the legislature's Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee that premature exposure of the deal and pressure from Beijing are the most likely reasons why the U.S. government has hesitated in giving the go-ahead for the sale.
Ko said that an answer obtained from the U.S. State Department about the proposed armed deal is that the decision is now up to the U.S. president.
Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang, a co-convener of the committee, disagreed with Ko's explanation.

He said the U.S. government was having second thoughts on the deal mainly because it was displeased with President Chen Shui-bian's obstinacy in pushing a national referendum on using the name of "Taiwan" to enter the United Nations.

The legislative committee later unanimously approved a proposal to defreeze a NT$29.64 million (US$974,140) budget designated for the training of personnel and other related purposes in preparation for the purchase of the F-16 fighters.
Last year, the legislature approved an initial conditional budget of NT$20 billion for the F-16 deal, with the funding only allowed to be used when the U.S. side has agreed to proceed with the sale.

Taiwan currently has some 140 F-16 A/B jet fighters, which it bought from the United States in the 1990s. The Air Force is hoping to acquire 66 F-16 C/D aircraft --- a more advanced multipurpose jet fighter -- to replace its aging F-5E fighters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign delegates visit Taiwan for Matsu festivities

TEXT.P: More than 100 representatives from five countries are visiting Taiwan to attend a forum on the culture of Matsu, the Chinese goddess of the sea, as well as a variety of activities celebrating the goddess' birthday, which falls on April 28 this year.
The representatives are from 17 temples that worship Matsu from China, Hong Kong, Macao, Thailand, Singapore, Japan and Australia.

The Matsu cultural groups, which arrived April 3, attended a international forum on Matsu culture held April 5 at the Jenn Lann Temple in Dajia, in central Taiwan's Taichung County. The temple has organized an eight-day pilgrimage in which devotees carry a Matsu statue around four counties in the region.
Matsu, who watches over fishermen, is mostly worshipped by people in Taiwan and in China's coastal areas.
Matsu's birthday falls on the 23rd day of the third month in the lunar calendar, and various festival activities are held around this date, although the pilgrimage of the goddess is the most popular.
The Matsu cultural delegations also visited the Fusing Temple in Yunlin, southern Taiwan, Monday, where the Matsu statue stayed twice during its pilgrimage.
Yang Wen-chung, president of the Fusing Temple, noted that Matsu followers are scattered around the world and expressed hope that they can "propagate Matsu's mercy" wherever they live.

Meanwhile, Lin Guoliang, vice chairman of Chinese Mazu (Matsu) Cultural Exchange Association, headquartered in China's Fujian Province, hailed the activities organized by Taiwanese temples and praised the close cultural exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
Some Chinese representatives said they had come specifically to see the Matsu pilgrimage and were impressed by the good cheer and devotion of the Taiwanese followers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Korean women rights activists to visit Taiwan's old comfort station

TEXT.P: Two representatives of Korean organizations advocating the rights of World War II comfort women are in Taiwan to collect information for South Korea's second museum dedicated to women's rights, which is expected to open in the spring of 2009.
As part of their visit, the two will visit a cave in Hualien County that served as a comfort station during World War II, the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation (TWRF) announced Monday.

The abandoned cave, which was once a military depot, has already been confirmed to have been a comfort station, where indigenous Taiwanese women were treated as sex slaves by Japanese soldiers during the war, the foundation said.
The organization is trying to register the cave as a historical landmark to spotlight the rights of comfort women, but the process has not been easy.

"We have encountered some problems, as the residents want to keep the outside world from knowing that there was a comfort station in their village, "said Graceia Lai, the foundation's director of International Affairs.
She said her group is still making efforts to communicate with the local residents.
The Korean visitors said they hope their new museum, to be located in downtown Seoul, would effectively raise awareness of the comfort women's rights.
"It will be dedicated to all women who were deprived of their rights during the war in all countries, " said Song Hanna, the future curator of the new War and Women's Human Rights Museum.

Korea's first museum dedicated to women's rights, located one and a half hours by car outside the capital, only has a collection of documents related to the comfort women, said Song, who will be in Taiwan until Wednesday.
Lai said that before her foundation builds a real museum in Taiwan, it plans to first build a virtual museum on the Internet that will expose the crimes committed against comfort women.
The foundation estimates that some 1,000 to 1,200 Taiwanese women served as sex slaves to the Japanese army during World War II, but it said that fewer than 60 have been confirmed as comfort women.

Two comfort women passed away in March, leaving only 22 in Taiwan to continue their fight against the Japanese government for compensation and an acknowledgement of their status, while in South Korea, 105 comfort women remain alive.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aircraft deal legal, money-saver: CAL chairman

TEXT.P: China Airlines' (CAL's) recent purchase deal for 20 Airbus A350-00 planes is legal and has saved a great deal of money for the company, CAL Chairman Ringo Chao said Monday.
Chao said that "instead of paying NT$10 billion (US$330.9 million) more for the purchase, I have actually saved around NT$16 billion for the company."
Chao made the remarks when he was invited to report on CAL's purchase of the aircraft for around NT$130 billion (US$4.3 billion) to a transportation committee at the legislature.

The deal raised concerns that the decision was made in haste, with some critics noting that former CAL Chairman Philip Wei thought the deal was more expensive than the highest price CAL would pay and suggested putting the deal on hold when he was replaced late last year.

There was also criticism that the down payment on the deal was unreasonably high when compared with general practice and an investigation unit under the Supreme Prosecutors Office has conducted a probe into suspected irregularities in the purchase deal.

Legislator Yang Li-huan of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , questioned during the committee meeting why CAL, Taiwan's largest air carrier, paid a down payment of 3 percent instead of the more usual 1 percent.
"Even if it is 3 percent, the money should only be paid one year before the delivery of the aircraft," Wang said, adding that "this is tantamount to a capitulation in the purchase negotiation."
In response, Chao said that the higher down payment had solicited more preferential payment conditions.

Yang's colleague Huang Chao-hsun also said the Civil Aeronautics Administration under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications approved the deal Jan. 22 and that CAL signed the deal with Airbus that same afternoon, questioning if the Presidential Office was pulling the strings behind the deal.
However, Chao said the company signed the deal Jan. 22 because it wanted to meet the deadline for Airbus to offer a preferential deal.

Under the deal, CAL will place an order for the new aircraft to phase out the six A340-300 passenger jets it currently operates and will maintain an option to buy an additional six new Airbus aircraft. The planes are still being developed and will not be delivered until 2015.

DOC.HEADLINE: March CPI up 3.96% year-on-year

TEXT.P: Led by a 9.33 percent hike in food prices, Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) rose to 103.12 in March, representing a 3.96 percent rise compared to the same month last year, the statistics bureau announced Monday.

"Although March's CPI was 1.07 percent lower than in February, the CPI for the first quarter still recorded an average increase of 3.59 percent," said Chao- Ming Wu, a section chief of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The month-on-month decline in inflation reflected a fall in prices from highs set during the Chinese New Year holiday, when the prices of overseas travel, caretakers, and fruits and vegetables usually spike.
Wu also warned of the 3.07 percent rise year- on-year of core CPI, which excludes the prices of fruits, vegetables, fish and shellfish.
"The rise in core CPI was the highest since March 1999, when it went up 3.28 percent, " he said, noting that core CPI's upward climb began accelerating in the second half of 2007.

Wu attributed the surge in prices primarily to soaring international commodity prices, citing the 7.15 percent increase in the wholesale price index (WPI) for March as a reflection of imported inflation.

"Excluding the impact of the Taiwan dollar's appreciation, the WPI for imported commodities valued in U.S. dollars soared by 20.66 percent in March, the highest since August 1980, when the index rose 27.72 percent because of the second oil crisis.
Global increases in prices crude oil, coal, corn, soybeans, wheat and steel were the main causes of higher wholesale prices, Wu said.
From early 2006 to March 2008, global wheat prices rose 1.7 times, soybean prices doubled, and corn prices surged 1.6 times, according to the Chicago Board of Trade.
From January 2007 to March 2008, the price of oil exported by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) increased by 95 percent, from US$50.80 to US$99.03 per barrel.

The DGBAS monthly report on price indexes also revealed that fruit, meat, and cereals and grains, with year-on-year price increases of 13.45 percent, 12.86 percent and 11.57 percent, rose the most of any food commodities in March.

Wu said Taiwan is not the only country suffering under the burden of rising international prices, as in the first two months of 2008 the CPI in the U.S., China, Japan, South Korea, and Singapore climbed by 4.2 percent, 7.9 percent, 0.9 percent, 3.7 percent and 6.6 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP urges public to begin scrutinizing Ma-Siew team

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged Taiwan's people Monday to begin keeping a close eye on President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew, even though they will not take office for another six weeks.

Lu called on the public to immediately begin monitoring the Ma-Siew team -- which will be sworn in on May 20 -- regardless of whether they voted for the Ma-Siew ticket of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) or for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) ticket on March 22.

The vice president asserted that Ma and Siew simply used "Taiwan" as a tool to solicit votes, but now that they had won the presidential election, they were ready to push Taiwan under China's wing without hesitation.

Lu asked people to ponder whether Ma's offer to use "Chinese Taipei" to apply for Taiwan's membership at the World Health Organization was a sign that he was ready to accept Beijing's "one country, two systems" unification scheme.
"Taiwan risks becoming a special administrative region of China in that case," she warned.
Lu issued the call after attending a memorial service for Cheng Nan-jung, who self-immolated in 1989 as a protest against KMT rule and its abuse of human rights in Taiwan.

The vice president made her comments a day after that Siew confirmed he would attend the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia in China's Hainan province from April 11-13 in his private capacity as the chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation.

Siew's visit, which will mark the first time a vice president-elect from Taiwan has set foot on Chinese soil, has drawn widespread attention because he could meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao, who will also be in attendance.

Like Vice President Lu, DPP legislators appear skeptical over the future KMT administration's efforts to reach out to China and contended Monday that Siew's trip could also negatively impact Taiwan's sovereingty.

At a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, DPP legislative caucus whip William Lai argued that China would definitely use the Boao Forum to suppress Taiwan and downgrade it to the status of a province of China and said he doubted Siew would chalk up any concrete gains at the meeting.

DPP lawmaker Tsai Huang-liang prodded Siew to ask Hu to clarify China's stance on the existence of the contentious "1992 Consensus, " a formula in which China and Taiwan accept that there is only one China, but with different interpretations of what that China is.
The DPP has denied the existence of the so-called "1992 consensus" and sees it as trap that will allow Beijing to swallow up Taiwan.
But the KMT maintains that the "1992 consensus" can help set aside the dispute over Taiwan's sovereignty and pave the way for negotiations on economic and political issues between the two sides.
Siew said at a press conference Monday that economic rather than political issues would be the focus of attention at the forum, which aims to promote trade and economic cooperation in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect urged to bring up Taiwan, Chinese dissidents with Hu

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Vincent Siew should express concern over China's suppression of Taiwan's international space and jailed Chinese dissidents when he meets Chinese President Hu Jintao at an economic forum later this week, local human rights groups said in a statement Monday.
The statement was issued one day after Siew confirmed that he will attend the Boao Forum for Asia to be held in Hainan province in southern China April 11-13.
Siew stressed that he will take part in the annual gathering in his capacity as chairman of the Taipei-based Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation, as he has done the past five years.

In the joint statement, Lin Feng-jeng, executive director of the Judicial Reform Foundation, said that Taiwan "should not be absent" from the growing support in the United States and Europe for Hu Jia, an environmentalist and a campaigner for AIDS patients' rights who began serving a three-and-a-half year sentence for subversion on April 3.
Lin said that a greater wave of opposition will force Beijing to soften its hardline stance in cracking down on Chinese dissidents.
The groups also blasted the Chinese government for failing to keep its promise to improve its human rights record when it bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games in 2001.

The group cited Yang Chunlin, a farmers' rights activist who was sentenced to five years in prison March 24 on the same charge as Hu Jia's, as another example of China's failure to improve its human rights situation since winning the Olympic bid.
The statement called on the world to boycott the Games to be held in Beijing in August to force China to realize that protecting human rights is the government's responsibility.
The rights groups also said in the statement that the two jailed activists' criticism of the Communist Party of China should not constitute a crime and supported their court appeals.
They strongly urged Beijing to allow Hu Jia, who suffers from cirrhosis of the liver, to be released for medical treatment based on humanitarian concerns.

Joining in issuing the statement were representatives from the Chang Fo-Chuan Center for the Study of Human Rights at Soochow University, the Deng Liberty Foundation, the Taipei Bar Association's Human Rights Protection Committee, the Association of Taiwan Journalists, the Taiwan Association for Human Rights, and the Taiwan Labor Front.

DOC.HEADLINE: Winners of bakery competition hope to help newcomers

TEXT.P: Three Taiwanese bakers who won a silver medal at the 2008 Bakery World Cup in Paris said Monday they are eager to share their experience with newcomers in the field.

Participating in the competition for the first time, Taiwan sent a team composed of Wu Chun-pao, Tsao Chin-hsiung and Wen Shih-cheng to Paris for the March 31-April 2 event, and the threesome finished second to France after defeating teams from 10 other countries.

In addition, Wu and Tsao each won individual prizes in the European style and artistic baking categories, which qualifies them for the first international competition for individual bakers to be held in 2010.

During a reception held by the Taiwan Flour Mills Association Monday, the trio said they were especially excited when they won the silver medal because they were the first Taiwanese to have ever competed in the event.
"We were very touched when our national flag waved at the venue of the competition, and we hope that more Taiwanese will follow suit," Wen said.

Wu said he wants to serve as a baking instructor to help Taiwan's baking industry surpass the levels of the United States and Japan within five or 10 years and hope that more seminars will be held in which they can hand down their experience to newcomers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD suggests incremental price hikes for fuel and electricity

TEXT.P: Fuel and electricity prices should be hiked incrementally instead of in one lump sum, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Monday.

"We didn't advocate that gasoline and electricity prices should not be adjusted. We favored a hike after consumer prices become more stable, " said CEPD Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh at a hearing held by the Legislative Yuan's Economics and Energy Committee on fuel and electricity price increases and their impact on the economy.
Price increases should be discussed after inflation in April eases, she said, adding that "those hikes should be phased in separately and incrementally instead of in one lump sum."
She indicated that the council has estimated that if both fuel and electricity prices rose in May, the consumer price index (CPI) would increase by more than 1 percentage point.

Ho also argued that gasoline prices should be adjusted before electricity rates because a higher cost of electricity would have wider repercussions and could easily spur across-the-board increases in consumer prices.

She backed the establishment of an open and transparent price adjustment mechanism and suggested price hikes should only take effect three months after they have been announced to allow businesses time to adjust their production structure and operational performance.
The CEPD also suggested that if fuel and electricity prices are raised, complementary measures should be adopted to take care of the underprivileged.

Options for such measures include adjusting rates for basic electricity consumption, offering preferential gasoline and electricity rates to public transportation operators, and providing preferential fuel rates for middle- and low-income households, Ho said.

Vice Economics Minister Hsieh Fa-ta said that according to an analysis by Taiwan's statistics bureau and Academia Sinica, Taiwan's leading academic institution, a 10 percent increase in gasoline prices would lead to increases in the wholesale and consumer price indexes of 0.46 percentage points and 0.33 percentage points, respectively, as well as a 0.27 percentage point decline in gross domestic product.
The same study found that a 10 percent rise in electricity rates would boost inflation by 0.22 percentage points and cause economic growth to fall by 0.14 percentage points.
Both state-owned CPC Corp., Taiwan, and Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) welcomed Monday the idea that fuel and electricity prices would be increased in June in one go.

Vice President-elect Vincent Siew said that after the new administration is inaugurated, fuel and electricity pricing will revert to a market mechanism, instead of remaining subject to existing price controls.

DOC.HEADLINE: Another indigenous dengue fever case confirmed in Tainan City

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) confirmed on Monday a new indigenous dengue fever case reported four days ago in the southern city of Tainan, according to the top local health official.

Hu Shu-chen, director of the Tainan City government's Bureau of Public Health, cited a laboratory test report by the Centers of Disease Control under the DOH in confirming that the virus causing the new dengue fever case was the same as the one that triggered the dengue epidemic last year -- the worst outbreak the city has ever experienced.

Tainan recorded over 1,500 confirmed dengue fever cases between mid-June 2007 and late January this year. The epidemic became so bad in August last year that Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair sacked Su Chun-jen, then director of the city government's Bureau of Public Health, and appointed Hu, an associate professor at National Cheng Kung University, to take his place.

Hu obtained the assistance of servicemen in launching a chemical spray campaign to kill mosquito larva within the city, but the campaign apparently has failed to exterminate all virus-carrying mosquitoes.
The new dengue patient is a 52-year-old woman who showed dengue symptoms in late March. The case was reported to health authorities April 3.
She is the third confirmed dengue case this year, following two previous cases confirmed in late January.

Dengue fever is an acute viral disease transmitted by mosquitoes. Its incubation period is three to 14 days. Typical symptoms include high fever, severe headache, skin rashes and muscle and joint pain, accompanied by nausea, vomiting and loss of appetite.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan prosecutors appeal court ruling on sexual assault case

TEXT.P: The Tainan Public Prosecutors Office on Monday appealed a Tainan District Court ruling handed down last month to acquit a 72-year-old man charged with sexually assaulting four foreign foreign workers between 2003 and 2005.

The prosecutors asked for a 15-year sentence for Hung Ching-chang for coercing four Vietnamese women into having sex with him. But in a ruling on March 5, the Tainan District Court found the defendant not guilty on grounds of insufficient evidence because the alleged victims, who had all returned to their native country, were not able to testify in court.

The court, however, sentenced his 50-year-old son Hung Ming-yu, an employment broker, to 20 years in prison for sexually assaulting 18 Vietnamese women who came to Taiwan to work as caretakers. The court ordered that the son must also receive mandatory treatment for three years before serving his sentence.
According to prosecutors, the father and son coerced the Vietnamese women into having sex with them by threatening to send them back to their home country if they dared to disobey.

The Hungs offered money to coax some of the victims into out-of-court settlements afterwards and used threats to obtain written agreements from other victims to prove that the women had settled all questions with them voluntarily.
The prosecutors' office in Tainan said it found the lower court ruling unacceptable and thus decided to appeal the case to the Taiwan High Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two DPP members plan to seek chairmanship: chairman

TEXT.P: Acting Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh said Monday that two party members have told him they want to contend for the leadership of the party in a May 18 election but did not say who they were.

One of the candidates is believed to be 73-year-old DPP Legislator Trong Chai, who failed in a previous bid to chair the party after the DPP suffered a major defeat in the 2005 city and county elections, according to party sources.

Hsieh also said after a Central Standing Committee meeting held Monday that he did not oppose the idea of choosing the party's chairman through a coordination process but indicated there needed to be candidates first.

During the meeting, the committee decided to hold the election for chairman May 18, rather than May 25 as originally planned, to coincide with other elections to select party representatives and heads of the party's local chapters.
In addition, the committee approved Hsieh's proposal to allow party members who are under the age of 35 and those who became DPP members prior to April 25 to vote in the election.

Hsieh explained at the meeting that the proposal was aimed at winning young people's support of the ruling DPP, which suffered a humiliating 17-percentage- point defeat to the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the March 22 presidential poll.

Hsieh -- the DPP's standard bearer in the election, who first resigned as chairman but later agreed to stay on to promote party reforms ahead of the upcoming chairman election -- predicted that only 3,000 or 4,000 young people would join the party, a number not large enough to influence the election to favor a certain candidate.
The DPP currently has some 256,000 valid members, according to Hsieh.
Vice President Annette Lu said at the meeting, however, that handing young people the right to vote would not make them like the DPP.

The party should carefully reconsider the proposal because if the party changed the rules just for young members, it would be unfair for senior party members, she said, while stressing at the same time that she did not oppose the proposal.
Other members, including Kuan Bi-ling, Wu Ping-jui and Lin Si-yao, backed Hsieh and described opening up the party to young people as the right path of development.
Wu, however, called for a strict screening of membership applications due to concerns about "nominal" party members who might influence the result of the election.
Nominal members serve as proxies for factional bosses or individual politicians who want to boost their vote counts or increase their influence within the party.
The registration period for the election will be from April 14 to April 18. The new DPP head will be sworn in May 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to invite president, former chairs to discuss election defeat

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will invite President Chen Shui- bian, Vice President Annette Lu and former party heads to attend the last of the eight meetings designed to review its decisive defeat in the March 22 presidential poll, party sources said Monday.
The DPP lost the election to the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) by 17 percentage points or 2.2 million votes.

At the first four meetings, to be held at the party's headquarters every evening from Monday, the DPP will listen to scholars, social activists and media representatives for their ideas on whether the party followed its values when it ran the government, the sources noted.
At the meetings, the DPP will also learn about how the party should chart its development and the local and foreign challenges it faces, the sources said.
In addition, the DPP will organize another three meetings with its party members in Kaohsiung, Taichung and Taipei in southern, central and northern Taiwan, April 12-13, the sources said.
The final meeting, slated to take place in Taipei City April 19, will be attended mainly by DPP members who also hold posts in the government.

Any conclusion reached at the meetings that will require an amendment to the party's charter will be sent to the Central Standing Committee and a representative party congress for approval, which the sources said will formally put the reforms in motion.
The DPP plans to call a provisional representative party congress May 4, according to the sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma solicits support from business leaders

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew paid a visit to business leaders Monday as part of their campaign to solicit views from leading enterprises on charting Taiwan's future course.

Ma paid visits to Hon Hai Group leader Terry Gou and Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) founder Wang Yung-ching in the afternoon and then had dinner with them, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) Chairman Morris Chang and Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung.
"Between now and the inauguration on May 20, I hope to make good use of the time to learn more about the problems and expectations of businesses," Ma said.

He pledged to adopt a more pragmatic policy, more liberalized cross-strait trade and economic relations, and better cooperation between government and private sectors to make Taiwan a design and innovation center.
He also said he hoped to see Taiwan turn into the linchpin of Asian and Pacific trade and the business headquarters of Taiwanese businesses.

Ma earlier promised that FPG's Mailiao harbor in western Taiwan will serve as a port for direct cross-strait shipping links and that Anping Harbor in Tainan could also be included as a direct cross-strait shipping port to give local businesses better access to sources of raw materials and markets.
"This will not only benefit industrial production, but will also help agricultural product exports to China," Ma continued.
Asked if he needed any assistance in setting up a steel plant or naphtha cracker complex in China, Wang said there was no need to go to China now.

FPG officials said Wang meant that if direct cross-strait transportation links are established, there will be room for development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, meaning there is no longer an urgent need to invest in China.
Hon Hai's Gou said that Ma knows he has made software investments in India and Nanjing, China, and indicated the president-elect urged him to invest in a software industrial park in Kaohsiung.
Noting that Ma asked him "to take action before the May 20 inauguration, " Gou said that he would be happy to comply with Ma's wishes.
Kaohsiung has the potential to become the creative center of digital content in Asia, as the city has quick access to world information, Gou said.

The Hon Hai head also said that some of the products in his Vietnamese plants are currently shipped to the United States through Singapore or Hong Kong, and he disclosed that he would also take Ma's advice to tranship it via Kaohsiung to help balance development between northern and southern Taiwan.

CNFI head Chen suggested to Ma that clear guidelines should be set up for environmental assessment studies so that if businesses were willing to abide by the rules, "environmental concerns would not hinder economic development."
Chen also called for a leaner government, improvement of the investment environment, tax cuts, and reasonable conditions for Chinese capital coming to Taiwan.
He said he was sure that under those circumstances, many Taiwanese businesses would be willing to return to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP urges public to begin scrutinizing Ma-Siew team

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged Taiwan's people Monday to begin keeping a close eye on President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew, even though they will not take office for another six weeks.

Lu called on the public to immediately begin monitoring the Ma-Siew team -- which will be sworn in on May 20 -- regardless of whether they voted for the Ma-Siew ticket of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) or for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) ticket on March 22.

The vice president asserted that Ma and Siew simply used "Taiwan" as a tool to solicit votes, but now that they had won the presidential election, they were ready to push Taiwan under China's wing without hesitation.

Lu asked people to ponder whether Ma's offer to use "Chinese Taipei" to apply for Taiwan's membership at the World Health Organization was a sign that he was ready to accept Beijing's "one country, two systems" unification scheme.
"Taiwan risks becoming a special administrative region of China in that case," she warned.
Lu issued the call after attending a memorial service for Cheng Nan-jung, who self-immolated in 1989 as a protest against KMT rule and its abuse of human rights in Taiwan.

The vice president made her comments a day after that Siew confirmed he would attend the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia in China's Hainan province from April 11-13 in his private capacity as the chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation.

Siew's visit, which will mark the first time a vice president-elect from Taiwan has set foot on Chinese soil, has drawn widespread attention because he could meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao, who will also be in attendance.

Like Vice President Lu, DPP legislators appear skeptical over the future KMT administration's efforts to reach out to China and contended Monday that Siew's trip could also negatively impact Taiwan's sovereingty.

At a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, DPP legislative caucus whip William Lai argued that China would definitely use the Boao Forum to suppress Taiwan and downgrade it to the status of a province of China and said he doubted Siew would chalk up any concrete gains at the meeting.

DPP lawmaker Tsai Huang-liang prodded Siew to ask Hu to clarify China's stance on the existence of the contentious "1992 Consensus, " a formula in which China and Taiwan accept that there is only one China, but with different interpretations of what that China is.
The DPP has denied the existence of the so-called "1992 consensus" and sees it as trap that will allow Beijing to swallow up Taiwan.
But the KMT maintains that the "1992 consensus" can help set aside the dispute over Taiwan's sovereignty and pave the way for negotiations on economic and political issues between the two sides.
Siew said at a press conference Monday that economic rather than political issues would be the focus of attention at the forum, which aims to promote trade and economic cooperation in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two DPP members plan to seek chairmanship: chairman

TEXT.P: Acting Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh said Monday that two party members have told him they want to contend for the leadership of the party in a May 18 election but did not say who they were.

One of the candidates is believed to be 73-year-old DPP Legislator Trong Chai, who failed in a previous bid to chair the party after the DPP suffered a major defeat in the 2005 city and county elections, according to party sources.

Hsieh also said after a Central Standing Committee meeting held Monday that he did not oppose the idea of choosing the party's chairman through a coordination process but indicated there needed to be candidates first.

During the meeting, the committee decided to hold the election for chairman May 18, rather than May 25 as originally planned, to coincide with other elections to select party representatives and heads of the party's local chapters.
In addition, the committee approved Hsieh's proposal to allow party members who are under the age of 35 and those who became DPP members prior to April 25 to vote in the election.

Hsieh explained at the meeting that the proposal was aimed at winning young people's support of the ruling DPP, which suffered a humiliating 17-percentage- point defeat to the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the March 22 presidential poll.

Hsieh -- the DPP's standard bearer in the election, who first resigned as chairman but later agreed to stay on to promote party reforms ahead of the upcoming chairman election -- predicted that only 3,000 or 4,000 young people would join the party, a number not large enough to influence the election to favor a certain candidate.
The DPP currently has some 256,000 valid members, according to Hsieh.
Vice President Annette Lu said at the meeting, however, that handing young people the right to vote would not make them like the DPP.

The party should carefully reconsider the proposal because if the party changed the rules just for young members, it would be unfair for senior party members, she said, while stressing at the same time that she did not oppose the proposal.
Other members, including Kuan Bi-ling, Wu Ping-jui and Lin Si-yao, backed Hsieh and described opening up the party to young people as the right path of development.
Wu, however, called for a strict screening of membership applications due to concerns about "nominal" party members who might influence the result of the election.
Nominal members serve as proxies for factional bosses or individual politicians who want to boost their vote counts or increase their influence within the party.
The registration period for the election will be from April 14 to April 18. The new DPP head will be sworn in May 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to invite president, former chairs to discuss election defeat

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will invite President Chen Shui- bian, Vice President Annette Lu and former party heads to attend the last of the eight meetings designed to review its decisive defeat in the March 22 presidential poll, party sources said Monday.
The DPP lost the election to the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) by 17 percentage points or 2.2 million votes.

At the first four meetings, to be held at the party's headquarters every evening from Monday, the DPP will listen to scholars, social activists and media representatives for their ideas on whether the party followed its values when it ran the government, the sources noted.
At the meetings, the DPP will also learn about how the party should chart its development and the local and foreign challenges it faces, the sources said.
In addition, the DPP will organize another three meetings with its party members in Kaohsiung, Taichung and Taipei in southern, central and northern Taiwan, April 12-13, the sources said.
The final meeting, slated to take place in Taipei City April 19, will be attended mainly by DPP members who also hold posts in the government.

Any conclusion reached at the meetings that will require an amendment to the party's charter will be sent to the Central Standing Committee and a representative party congress for approval, which the sources said will formally put the reforms in motion.
The DPP plans to call a provisional representative party congress May 4, according to the sources.
