DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 8, or the third day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
217 AD: Caracalla, or Marcus Aurelius Antonius, the Roman emperor who was obsessed with and sought to imitate Alexander the Great, is assassinated after a bloody reign.
1513: Juan Ponce de Leon, the Spanish explorer who completed the conquest of Puerto Rico, discovers Florida and claims it for the Spanish throne.
1861: Elisha Graves Otis, the American inventor of the passenger elevator which was first installed in 1857, dies at the age of 50.
1902: China's Ching court and Russia reach agreement on the evacuation of Manchuria. After the Boxer Uprising in 1900, Russia took the opportunity to occupy Manchuria. When the troops of the other foreign powers withdrew from Chinese territory, Russia refused to leave Manchuria.
1907: France and Britain sign a convention confirming the independence of Siam (now Thailand).
1914: The Republic of China's first Congress is organized in Beijing.
1913: Brazil officially recognizes the Republic of China, which was founded on Jan. 1, 1912, becoming the first country in the world to do so.
1925: The Australian government and the British Colonial Office offer low- interest loans to encourage 500,000 Britons to emigrate to Australia.
1946: The League of Nations holds its final session in Geneva. It was later replaced by the United Nations.
1958: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower proposes mutual inspection as a means of enforcing the nuclear test ban.
1965: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with the Republic of Dahomey.
1966: Leonid Brezhnev is elected general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party. He later became president of the USSR in 1977.
1973: Dr. Mohammed Abder Rahman Basbeer, minister of communications of Jordan, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Pablo Picasso, the Spanish artist who was one of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, dies in his chateau at Mougins at the age of 92. He excelled in painting, sculpture, etching, stage design, and ceramics.
1979: Lee Pao-chen, a noted Chinese musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 73.
1981: Omar Nelson Bradley, the American general who played a major part in the Allied victory in World War II, dies at the age of 88. He commanded the U.S. forces in the Normandy invasion and later led the 12th Army Group as France was liberated.
1986: Clint Eastwood, the screen tough guy famed for his portrayal of "Dirty Harry," is elected mayor of Carmel, a Californian resort town.
1989: More than 60 Soviet submariners die after a nuclear-powered Mike-class submarine refuses assistance from nearby Western merchant ships after catching fire off the coast of Norway.
1990: ROC Economics Minister Chen Li-an and Singaporean Minister of Trade and Industries Lee Hsien Loong preside over the first ministerial-level conference on economic cooperation between the two countries.
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly is convened in Taipei to discuss constitutional reforms.
1992: Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat is found alive 12 hours after his plane crashes in the Sahara desert.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa resigns over a loan scandal.
1995: At a meeting of the National Unification Council, ROC President Lee Teng-hui offers a six-point proposal for Taiwan-mainland China relations.
1999: NATO continues airstrikes against Yugoslavia while the eastern European country says its 14-month war against ethnic Albanian separatists is over.
2000: Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa tells U.S. President Bill Clinton that granting mainland China permanent normal trade relations status would give Hong Kong's recovering economy a further boost.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says while attending the inauguration of Taiwan's Anti-Cancer Federation that a heart full of pleasure is the best medicine against cancer.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A gentleman who only thinks of the comforts of life cannot be a true gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
President-elect declines to attend simulated war games

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office on Tuesday said it regretted that President-elect Ma Ying-jeou couldn't take part in this year's computerized warfare simulation to learn more about the operation of the nation's security system.

The officials were responding to Ma's decision, announced through spokesman Lo Chih-chiang, to decline an invitation from the Presidential Office to observe the computer war games because of a "tight schedule. "
Ma has been busy traveling around Taiwan to thank supporters and visit business leaders and political figures after winning the March 22 election.

The president-elect has "missed an opportunity to learn the comprehensive operations of the national security system, " a Presidential Office official said, but added, "the computerized war games won't be affected by Ma's absence, it will continue as scheduled."
Media reports said recently that the National Security Council has mapped out the annual computerized warfare simulation.

Under the plan, President Chen Shui-bian will go to a command center in suburban Taipei, while Vice President Annette Lu will go to another command center and conduct the simulated war games via videoconference between April 25-27.

The officials noted that the office has begun the process of handing over power to Ma, starting with a meeting between President Chen and the president-elect on April 1 to brief him on classified information related to national defense, cross-strait relations and diplomatic issues.
On April 3, Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen also met with Chan Chuen-po, convener of Ma's transition team.

The officials said that during the first transition of power between the two parties in 2000, most of the contact between incoming and outgoing officials were largely ceremonial and concerned primarily with the presidential inauguration.

But the transition in 2008 has involved briefings in a wide range of areas, with not only President Chen briefing Ma on diplomatic secrets, but also Tan Sun Chen meeting with officials from Ma's camp.
The Presidential Office will work with Ma's team to "provide the necessary assistance should needs arise," the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Work restrictions on Chinese spouses eased

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) officially announced on Tuesday that Chinese spouses of Taiwanese citizens with children below age 20 will be allowed to work even if they have not obtained long-term residence status.
The new measure, made possible by an amendment to existing regulations, will take effect April 10.

The CLA said in a statement that the change was made to give Chinese spouses more of an opportunity to contribute to their family's finances, in light of the increased financial burdens of couples with underage children.
In filing their applications, eligible Chinese spouses should provide household registration records issued within the last three months and other related documents, the CLA said.
Those with non-adult children from previous marriages are eligible to apply if the children have been adopted by their present Taiwanese spouses and are living in Taiwan, the CLA said.
This group of applicants should present the exit and entry permits of the children in addition to the documents mentioned above.

The regulations will continue to forbid Chinese spouses who do not have non- adult children from working in Taiwan during the six years it usually takes them to obtain a long-term residence permit here, unless they meet certain other conditions.
Those include that their Taiwanese spouse is over 65 years of age, is physically or mentally disabled, or is suffering from serious illness or injury.
The exception also applies to those found by a court to have been victims of domestic violence and those determined to be part of a low-income household.

DOC.HEADLINE: Internet shoppers face a lack of information: survey

TEXT.P: The lack of company and product information found on online shopping sites violates the Consumer Protection Law and could jeopardize the interests of buyers, said Cheng Jen-hung, the chairman of the Consumers' Foundation, Chinese Taipei (CFCT) , Tuesday.

According to a recent foundation survey of 15 Internet stores, 93 percent of the online vendors failed to provide basic company information, such as the company's address or customer service contact information, making it difficult for consumers to get in touch with the company for after-sales services such as product returns.

"Article 19 of the Consumer Protection Law (CPL) empowers online buyers to return products within seven days without having to state the reason or pay any extra charges, including shipping costs, for the return," Cheng said.
But 33 percent of the shops surveyed required buyers to pay for shipping when returning goods, a clear violation of the law, he said.

"The foundation calls on the authorities concerned, including the Consumer Protection Commission and the Ministry of Economic Affairs, to take prompt action to protect the rights of online consumers," Cheng said.
He suggested that the commission could order stores to fulfill their legal obligations and regularly monitor online retailers.
Cheng also said consumers needed to gain greater awareness of their rights before making purchases over the Internet.
"Consumers should make sure of the validity of contract terms before rushing through a deal," Cheng said.
The foundation warned that lingering suspicions over the transparency of online shopping sites could eventually affect their ability to survive.

"The survey showed that 100 percent of shops fail to abide by clauses in Article 19 that require them to clearly inform consumers about the right to cancel contracts and demand product returns, " foundation vice chairman Hsieh Tien-jen said, noting that such inaction could backfire.
Compared with TV shopping networks, which offer 10-day unconditional return periods, online stores would face greater challenge if they did not handle service issues properly, Hsieh said.
Another area where service could be improved, he said, is dropping the requirement that consumers pay for merchandise before it's delivered, as was the case at nine of the 15 stores surveyed.
Hsieh believed the shops should deliver the goods before making their customers pay, even if it was not mandated by law.
The need for better service would only accentuate the advantages of online shopping, which offers greater variety than TV shopping networks that can only showcase one product at a time.
"With such an advantage, a more complete information system would help boost the business of online commerce even more," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND has followed precedents in arranging trip for outgoing president

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Tuesday that it has "followed precedents" in arranging for Taiwan's outgoing president to pay a visit to the military before leaving office.

MND spokeswoman Lisa Chi made the remarks after the Apple Daily, a local tabloid, reported the same day that the ministry has arranged for President Chen Shui-bian to visit military installations in his capacity as the nation's commander-in-chief prior to stepping down on May 20 at a cost of up to NT$100 million (US$3.29 million).
Some military officials said it would cost NT$10 million alone for the fuel costs to have military vessels return to Zuoying Naval Base from where they are stationed to be reviewed.
Added to that would be expenses for fuel and equipment for the army, air, logistics, military police and reserve command, according to reports.
Chi said the ministry has followed precedent in arranging Chen's visit and that the president went out of his way to ask that there be "no pomp" in arranging the trip.

"The ministry has made the trip into a visit of the troops and the expenses will be funded from their training costs, " Chi said, denying that the ministry has arranged for any type of ceremonial review or squandered a large amount of money.
Chi stressed that the president is the commander-in-chief under the Constitution, and his review of military forces is a routine and normal operation.
The visit will follow military protocol and be conducted in a simple and warm manner with "etiquette and decorum" befitting a president but will not interrupt normal military operations.
Meanwhile, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged parties across the political spectrum and the public to show the "necessary respect for the outgoing and incoming presidents."

Legislator Sun Ta-chien of the opposition Kuomintang said that in view of the dire financial straits of the nation, he hopes the visit will be conducted in a "simple but solemn way to lessen the burden on the MND and national coffers."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to help Kenya develop emergency medical mechanism

TEXT.P: A National Cheng Kung University Hospital (NCKUH) delegation will leave Thursday for Kisumu, Kenya's third largest city, to assist that country in building a model mechanism for disaster prevention and emergency medical care, a hospital spokesman said Tuesday.

During its planned four-week stay in Kisumu, the group will help local Great Lakes University Kisumu (GLUK) organize and train second- and third-degree health care units, introducing the training methods used by Taiwan's own national disaster medical assistance team to the university, the spokesman noted.
The group of medical experts from the Tainan City-based hospital will hold two different training courses in Kisumu.
A week-long program will train local medical and health care personnel on how to command a national disaster medical assistance team, while six day-long training workshops will cover other topics.

The group will also donate NT$1 million (US$32,700) worth of disaster rescue equipment to the Kenyan university, assistance that will include large-sized tents for emergency medical treatment, first-aid kits, communication devices and computers, the university spokesman said.

According to the university, Taiwan began medical and health care exchanges with Kenya two years ago when that country was affected by an outbreak of rift valley fever, an acute, fever-causing viral disease that affects domestic animals and humans.

In April 2007, GLUK Deputy President Dan Kaseje visited Taiwan, and three months later, Tsai Ming-che, head of the NCKUH Department of Emergency Medicine, visited the Kenyan university, where he helped set up the program to establish the model disaster prevention mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect has plenty to gain, and lose, at Boao Forum for Asia

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Vincent Siew will be walking a fine line when he attends an economic forum in China this weekend, an occasion many believe could set the stage for improved ties between Taiwan and China.

Siew's every move will be watched under a microscope at the April 11-13 Boao Forum for Asia. If he proves adept at personal diplomacy and skillfully navigates meetings with Chinese officials, including with Chinese President Hu Jintao, he could score a breakthrough in the lingering cross-Taiwan Strait impasse.

But should Siew appear to be marginalized or find himself unable to defend the country if China attempts to belittle Taiwan, then he will have fallen prey to what critics call Beijing's "unification trap," political analysts said Tuesday.
Siew announced at a news conference Monday that he will attend the forum in southern China's Hainan province in a private capacity as the chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation.

Noting that the forum is a platform for exchanges of visions on international and cross-strait trade and economic development, Siew said he will convey Taiwan's good will and sincerity to China in hopes of enhancing mutual trust.
He insisted that economic issues will dominate the forum and ruled out any possibility of touching on politically sensitive questions in discussions with Chinese officials.
The vice president-elect's focus dovetails with President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's campaign promises of working for closer cross-strait economic ties and faster domestic economic growth.
But it remains to be seen what, if anything, Siew can really accomplish in three days, or if he even needs to bring home any tangible results for his mission to be proclaimed a success.

More optimistic observers believe that the man known as "smiling Siew, " who showed a knack for diplomacy and was a skilled trade negotiator while serving as economics minister and premier under the previous Kuomintang (KMT) administration, will be in a strong position so long as he can successfully foster an impression of "ice-breaking" by reaching out to Hu during the conference.

But skeptical lawmakers and officials from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration are worried that the presence of Taiwan's vice president- elect at an international meeting in China might lead to an undesirable outcome.

They are particularly wary that China could manipulate the event to claim its sovereignty over Taiwan and belittle Siew by portraying him as the deputy leader of the Taiwan area under China's jurisdiction.

"Siew should bear in mind that his status as vice president-elect is far more important than his capacity as chairman of the private Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation and should not let China use the occasion to downgrade Taiwan to a local government under its control, " Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy- wey warned Monday at a news conference.

Like many in the DPP, Shieh urged Siew to go beyond economic issues at the Boao forum and seize the opportunity to persuade China not to impede Taiwan's bid for observer status in the World Health Assembly -- the decision-making body of the World Health Organization.

Commenting on Shieh's proposal, political analysts said Shieh is setting the bar too high, given the fact that the Boao forum is just a non-governmental conduit for discussion on economic issues. Moreover, they said, the DPP administration has not authorized Siew to negotiate such a politically sensitive issue.

Meanwhile, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun contended that Siew's emphasis on his private capacity in attending the forum could make him a "laughing stock" in the international community.
"Siew should not ignore the fact that his status has changed significantly following his election as our country's next vice president," Chen cautioned.

While stressing that the government supports participation in international conferences and activities, Chen said three principles -- dignity, parity and reciprocity -- could not be compromised at these occasions.

"As the vice president-elect, Siew should bear in mind Taiwan-centric identity and the common well-being of Taiwan's people as his guiding principles and keep the content of the upcoming forum transparent and open for media supervision," Chen said.

Some political analysts believe the most important thing Siew can do at the forum is to help Chinese President Hu Jintao better understand President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who will be sworn in as president May 20.
According to them, Chinese leaders are now sizing up Ma, who advocated "no independence," "no unification, " and "no use of force" in the Taiwan Strait during his election campaign.

At the same time, however, he did not reiterate that the KMT's ultimate goal for Taiwan was "eventual unification" with China, which analysts said has made Beijing suspect that Ma has abandoned the concept as a pillar of his China policy.
Should China confirm that suspicion, they said, the prospects for substantial improvement in cross-strait ties could be dimmed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved down 71 points to close at 8,635, with 43,622 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May lost 73 points to finish at 8,610, with 1,662 contracts traded, while June futures moved down 75 points to close at 8,600, with 43 contract transactions.
September futures moved down 99 points to finish at 8,360, with 32 contract transactions, while December futures dropped 71 points to close at 8,379, with seven contracts traded.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index slid 56.94 points Tuesday to finish at 8,672.85, with a market turnover of NT$133.48 billion (US$4.38 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 8,706 for April; 8,683 for May; 8,675 for June; 8,459 for September and 8,450 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
April TE futures dropped 3.05 points to close at 328.25, with 3,237 contracts traded, while May TE futures lost 3.05 points to finish at 327.05, with 62 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.
April TF futures dropped 17.6 points to end at 1,125.2, with 3,002 contract changing hands, while May TF futures decreased 18 points to finish at 1,122, with 189 contracts traded.
June TF futures slid 14.4 points to close at 1,123.2, with one contract traded, while September TF futures were down 13 points to close at 1,118, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Shirakawa tipped as BOJ chief:No. 2 iffy
The government nominated Bank of Japan Deputy Gov. Masaaki Shirakawa as BOJ chief and former Finance Ministry bureaucrat Hiroshi Watanabe as deputy governor despite widespread speculation the latter will be rejected by the Democratic Party of Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jhonghe City to stage Burmese New Year's celebration

TEXT.P: Jhonghe Mayor Chiu Chuei-yi on Tuesday invited people around the country to come enjoy the Burmese New Year's festival to be staged in his city in Taipei County on April 20.
Chiu issued the invitation while paying a visit to Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi- wei at the county government.

Burma's New Year's festival, called Thingyan, is celebrated over a period of three or four days according to the Burmese calendar. The highlight of the festival is people throwing water on themselves and others to get relief from the heat and to wash away the sins of the past year.
Chiu welcomed everyone to come enjoy an exotic experience and "get wet" at Jhonghe's celebration to be held in the city's suburban district of Nanshihjiao.
Nanshihjiao has a significant Burmese minority, with many signs of the Southeast Asian nation's culture on display, including a number of restaurants featuring Burmese delicacies.
Chiu said the celebrations within the designated festival area on Huahsin Street will feature a series of fun-filled activities, including afloat parade.
Water facilities, including large scale tanks to let revelers "reload, " will also be set up so that everyone can enjoy splashing and spraying one another to their heart's content, he said.
One of the main features will be a "spray tunnel, " borrowed from organizers of the Yilan International Children's Folklore and Folkgame Festival.
Anyone wanting to enter the festival area will have to "undergo a baptism" by walking through the spray tunnel, after which, "anything goes," Chiu said.

During his visit to the county government, Chiu also invited Chou to attend the celebrations, jokingly challenging him to a water fight. A smiling Chou accepted the challenge and invitation to attend the festival, with both men wishing all Burmese people in Taiwan a happy and prosperous new year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vatican might send ambassador close to Taiwan for inauguration: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Vatican, Taiwan's only diplomatic ally in Europe, might send one of its ambassadors posted in a nearby country rather than a high-level delegation to attend President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's inauguration ceremony May 20, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Anne Hung, director-general of MOFA's Department of European Affairs, said at a regular press briefing that the Republic of China's embassy in Vatican City has not yet received any information on the issue.

However, since the Holy See has remained "low-key" recently regarding political contacts with Taiwan, the MOFA "does not expect the Vatican to dispatch a high- ranking delegation to attend the inauguration," she said.
Hung suggested instead that the Holy See might send an ambassador stationed close to Taiwan on May 20 instead.
The Republic of China established diplomatic ties with the Vatican in 1942 and the Holy See remains Taiwan's only ally in Europe.
In May 2004, the Vatican sent Archbishop Patrick Coveney, who was the papal nuncio, or ambassador, to New Zealand, to attend the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian in 2004.

The Vatican's low-key approach to Taiwan reflects its recent efforts to improve relations with Communist China, which has not recognized the Holy See since Chairman Mao Zedong drove out the papal nuncio more than half a century ago.
Last November, a Vatican delegation visited China and met with representatives of the government. It has also recently hinted at the possibility of moving its embassy in Taiwan back to Beijing.
China, however, has imposed two preconditions for the normalization of relations that have stalled the resumption of diplomatic ties.

It insists that the Vatican break diplomatic relations with Taiwan and refrain from interfering in China's internal affairs, especially in the area of religion, conditions that the Vatican cannot accept.
There are around 300,000 Catholics in Taiwan compared to over 10 million in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Singapore braces itself for worst dengue epidemic.
Singapore is spending $200,000 a day in an effort to stave off what might be its worst dengue fever epidemic.
Unless the trend of infections is halted, the number of sick people could hit record levels in three years' time.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Five new ERP gantries effective.
Five Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) gantries in residential areas enabled yesterday morning, and traffic was smooth right away.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ranks 4th in machine tool exports for 2007

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked the world's fourth largest machine tool exporter in 2007, exporting US$3.41 billion worth of the products last year, according to a report released Tuesday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
The value represented an increase of 15 percent over 2006 and accounted for 8.7 percent of the world's total, the report said.

The amount was behind only Germany's US$9.17 billion, Japan's US$7.61 billion and Italy's US$4.21 billion, said the report, referring to the results of the 2008 World Machine Tool Output and Consumption Survey conducted by the U.S.-based Gardner Publication Inc.

The survey, which looked at exports from 29 countries around the world, revealed that the world's machine tool output amounted to a record US$71 billion for 2007, marking an 18 percent increase from the year-earlier level.
Taiwan's machine tool production was valued at US$4.38 billion for 2007, a 14 percent increase from the previous year.
In terms of per capita production, Taiwan's machine tool production amounted to US$190, ranking second in the world after Switzerland.
The CEPD predicted that Taiwan's machine tool output will continue to increase, with the production value expected to reach NT$350 billion (US$11.2 billion) by 2015.

DOC.HEADLINE: Secrecy of war games is reason for Ma not attending: spokesman

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou has declined an invitation to attend this year's computerized warfare simulation because he believes it should be top secrets and open exclusively to the president and his subordinates, Ma's spokesman Lo Chih- chiang said Tuesday.
Lo said that "it is not appropriate" for Ma, who will only assume office on May 20, to be part of the secret operations scheduled for April 25-27.

The Presidential Office said earlier in the day that it regretted that Ma could not take part in this year's war games because of his "tight schedule," saying that Ma "has missed an opportunity to learn the comprehensive operations of the national security system."
Ma has been busy traveling around Taiwan to thank supporters and visit business leaders and political figures after winning the March 22 election.

Lo noted that sources at the Presidential Office said that after Ma won the March 22 presidential election, President Chen had instructed the National Security Council to invite Ma to observe the simulated war games to highlight his determination to push for an institutionalized mechanism for a "peaceful transfer of power."

This year's war games will have President Chen go to a command center in suburban Taipei, while Vice President Annette Lu will go to another command center, with the two communicating via video conference a warfare response.
Lo said that since the war-preparation exercises will be a top secret within the government and the Presidential Office, Ma's camp concluded that it is not appropriate for him to participate.

The simulated war games, which will have administrative, national security officials and government heads converging in the command center in suburban Taipei, have been carried out each year since 2005.

The purpose is to provide a reference to national leaders and department heads in their decision making so as to help them familiarize themselves with how to react to crises and to upgrade their capacity in handling crises when the government is on the verge of wars.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, DPP compete for new members in Kaohsiung City

TEXT.P: Both the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are seeking to recruit new members in Kaohsiung City, following a shift in support in Taiwan's second-largest city evident from the March 22 presidential election, said sources from the two camps Tuesday.

Hsu Fu-ming, chief of the KMT's Kaohsiung City chapter, confirmed that many people in the southern port city have applied to join the party or to renew their membership after the presidential race, in which the KMT ticket of Ma Ying-jeou and Vincent Siew stunningly defeated their DPP rivals by a broad margin of more than 2.21 million votes.

The Ma-Siew ticket also beat the DPP ticket in Kaohsiung City, a traditional DPP stronghold, grabbing some 468,000 votes, which exceeded the DPP ticket's 440,000 -- the first KMT electoral victory in the city.

In conjunction with Ma's and Siew's inauguration on May 20, Hsu told reporters his division is organizing to recruit more fresh blood before that date to further cement the party's power base in Kaohsiung City.
The KMT has about 53,000 party members in Kaohsiung City -- Taiwan's second- largest city after Taipei and the largest city in southern Taiwan, Hsu noted.

At the same time, Chang Chih-ming, head of the DPP's Kaohsiung City branch, said his party is also doing its best to attract young new members in Kaohsiung City as part of its efforts to overhaul the party following its presidential election defeat.

According to Chang, the DPP's branch in Kaohsiung City will organize a 100-member recruitment drive on April 20 in the hope of injecting a new lease on life to the party after its consecutive defeat in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the recent presidential contest.
The DPP has little time to waste as it needs to gear up to lift party morale and strengthen its power base in Kaohsiung City ahead of the 2010 city mayor elections, Chang explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, appreciating NT$0.106 to close at NT$30.524.
A total of US$1.727 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.445 and fluctuated between NT$30.415 and NT$30.524.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 56.94 points, or 0.65 percent, to close at 8,672.85.

Giving back some of the gains of the previous day, the bourse opened at 8,717.06 and fluctuated between 8,725.69 and 8,672.85 during the day's session. A total of 4.82 billion shares changed hands on turnover of NT$133.48 billion (US$4.38 billion).

Three of eight major stock categories gained ground. Plastics and chemicals shares moved up 0.5 percent, the most of any sector. Foodstuff issues advanced 0.4 percent and construction issues rose 0.3 percent.

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground. Cement stocks led all sectors with a decline of 2.3 percent. Banking and financial shares fell 1.7 percent, paper and pulp issues lost 1.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares shed 0.8 percent, and textile stocks were down 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,478 to 698, with 320 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$9.95 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to impose inspection of sunglasses after U.S. recall

TEXT.P: Following a recent recall by U.S. authorities of a particular brand of children's sunglasses imported from China, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced in a press release Tuesday that all children's sunglasses will be inspected before they go on the market.

The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) on April 3 announced the voluntary recall of 144,000 units of children's sunglasses imported from China by American retailer StyleMark, after it was found that the surface paint on the temples of the sunglasses contained levels of lead in excess of the federal lead paint standards.

While there have been no reports to date of illness among children wearing the glasses, the CPSC urged consumers to immediately take the sunglasses away from children and contact StyleMark for instructions on returning the product for a free replacement pair.

The Taiwan Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection under the MOEA reacted to the U.S. recall by imposing a compulsory inspection of children's sunglasses before the products go on the market, a measure that will take effect April 15.
The bureau said it will follow current toy safety standards and add a new category to inspect children sunglasses for lead paint.
To help trace the suspect products, the bureau has issued a description of the sunglasses and is urging local consumers to report the purchase of any such product, according to the press release.

The sunglasses are described as having Main Street Drag characters on the bottom of one lens and dark metallic blue or dark metallic red frames with gray checkered sides. "Main Street Drag" is printed in orange at the temples.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mechanism of immunoprotein AMP revealed by microbiologists

TEXT.P: Several Taiwanese microbiologists have unraveled the mechanism of an immunoprotein -- antimicrobial peptide, or AMP-- which was found to kill pathogenic bacteria by penetrating their cell membranes, a local newspaper reported Tuesday.

According to the China Times newspaper, researchers said antimicrobial peptide -- a natural antibiotic agent in the human immune system -- will first punch a hole on the bacterium's membrane and then inhibit the subject from healing itself by continuously expanding the aperture.

"In the end, the microbe dies as the in-cell equilibrium is destroyed, " said Lee Ming-Tao, an assistant research fellow at the Hsinchu-based National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center and a co-author of the paper published by the U.S. science journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS).

Antimicrobial peptide, first found by scientists in the 1980s, exists in many species, including the shiitake mushroom, African clawed toad, and humans. Although antimicrobial peptide has been used in some drugs -- including magainin, an antibiotic named after the African clawed toad -- its mechanism is still little known.

Lee and three other team members -- Hung Wei-chin of the Kaohsiung- based Chinese Military Academy, Chen Fang-yu of National Central University in Taoyuan, and Huey W. Huang of Rice University in Houston -- worked for six years on the project to better understand the mechanism of antimicrobial peptide and submitted their research paper to PNAS in late 2007.
Describing their findings as fundamental, Lee said he hopes the results can be a springboard for anti-microbial or anti-cancer drug development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Deputy Kaohsiung mayor welcomes Hon Hai's planned investment

TEXT.P: Deputy Kaohsiung Mayor Chiu Tai-san said Tuesday he welcomed the plan by a local tycoon to invest in the port city, while another city official expressed the hope that the move would serve as an incentive to attract downstream manufacturers.

Chiu's comments came in the wake of a statement by Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Guo that he is willing to comply with President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's wishes to invest in the Kaohsiung Software Park to help achieve the balanced development of northern and southern Taiwan. Guo, whose company is the world's leading electronics contract manufacturer, made the proposal during a meeting with Ma on Monday.

Chiu said that after learning more about Hon Hai's investment plan, the city government will brief Guo on the operations of software park and also on the Kaohsiung Multifunctional Commerce and Trade Park.

He noted that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has attached great importance to the development of the Kaohsiung Software Park, and that it allocated NT$150 million (US$4.93 million) last year to finance the development of the park.
A development fund for small- and medium- businesses under the MOEA will provide NT$10 million to organize an incubation center at the software park.
Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chuang Chi-wan said Tuesday that he hoped Hon Hai would invest in the park "immediately" and would serve as an engine to bring more investment to the city.

Chuang said that although Kaohsiung has an airport, a harbor and a convenient transportation network that includes high speed rail and mass rapid transit systems, the country's "closed-door" policy and the lack of direct cross-strait transportation over the past eight years had made it difficult for the city to develop its high-tech industry.
"The Hon Hai investment project would provide a much needed shot in the arm to Kaohsiung's high-tech industry," he said.
He expressed confidence that if leading manufacturers such as Hon Hai or Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. invest in Kaohsiung, downstream businesses would follow.
Chuang suggested that the Kaohsiung Multifunctional Commerce and Trade Park be renamed the "Kaohsiung Multifunctional High-tech Commerce and Trade Park," to attract high-tech manufacturers.
He said that the city's priority will be to develop its high-tech industry as a means of boosting its economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Korean animal rights groups seek Taiwan's assistance

TEXT.P: Korean animal rights groups appealed to their Taiwan counterparts and Taiwan lawmakers Tuesday to help stop the South Korean government from amending the law to classify dogs as livestock for consumption.

Representatives of several groups, including the Korean Association for Animal Protection (KAAP) and Coexistence of Animal Rights on Earth (CARE), made their case at a news conference in Taipei Tuesday.

CARE representative Park So-yeon noted that the South Korean government had passed a law banning the sale of dog meat and strictly enforced it ahead of the 1988 Seoul Olympics to improve the country's image. However, shortly after the games ended, the government relaxed enforcement, and dog meat restaurants were soon back in business, he said.
Nowadays, because the government is not enforcing its animal welfare laws, many Koreans assume it is legal to raise dogs for the cooking pot, to slaughter them and sell the meat, he said.
Park said that about 2 million dogs are consumed in South Korea each year.

On March 24, the Seoul municipal government said it planned to propose to the central government that the law be amended to classify dogs as livestock in order to set food safety standards for South Korean lovers of dog meat.

Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Wang Hsing-nan, who played an instrumental role in the passage of legislation to outlaw the killing of dogs for food and the sale of dog meat in Taiwan, said at the press conference that there is no need today for dog meat to be used as food.

Wang said that respect for life is a universal value and that the protection of animal rights is a sign of a civilized society. He added that because there are so many other sources of protein today, there is no need to eat dog meat, and questioned why the Seoul government wants to legalize such a practice.

Chu Tseng-hung, director of the Environment and Animal Society of Taiwan, supported Wang's statement, saying that long ago, many humans depended on animal meat for survival but that in this modern age, this is no longer the case as there are so many other alternatives.

He claimed that people today have become excessively reliant on meat, adding that the raising of livestock poses a threat to human health by providing a channel for the spread of many serious diseases.

KAAP representatives displayed several photos at the news conference to illustrate the terrible treatment of dogs in South Korea and the appalling conditions in which they are raised for their meat. Some of the photos showed dogs crammed into small metal cages with no room to move.
Park said that the environment in which the dogs are raised is very unsanitary, and that they are usually fed old food scraps, such as moldy bread.
Representatives of a Taiwan animal rights group brought several healthy and active dogs to the news conference to demonstrate the stark contrast to the abused animals shown in the KAAP's photos.

Soon after the Seoul government's announcement of its plan to classify dogs as livestock for consumption, Korean animal rights groups voiced their strong protest and urgently began soliciting assistance from other countries around Asia to convince the South Korean central government to reject the proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unemployed groups opposed to fuel price hikes

TEXT.P: Several advocates for the unemployed publicly backed current freezes on gasoline, electricity and water prices Wednesday and urged the incoming Kuomintang administration to devise measures to help the country's 420,000 jobless and their families.

Two groups promoting the rights of workers -- one that lobbies for the rights of the unemployed and another that promotes the hiring of older workers -- urged the new KMT government in a statement to adopt a package of relief measures for the unemployed.

They suggested increasing unemployment benefits paid to qualified claimants from 60 percent to 70 percent of their previous average monthly salary and extending the benefit period from six months to one year.

They also advocated extending the age employed workers and Taiwanese citizens could join the employment insurance program from 60 to 65 and called on the new government to remove the six-month cap on national health insurance premium subsidies for those without work.
They also urged the government to provide a fixed monthly subsidy for food, fuel, water and electricity for those who have been jobless for more than one year.

In the statement, Su Cheng, head of the advocacy group for the unemployed, dismissed a public hearing held Monday by the legislature's Economics and Energy Committee on fuel, electricity and water prices, branding it as nothing but an attempt to push price hikes.

The groups warned that increases in prices in any of the three categories would carry over to other commodity prices and said the unemployed and their families would be forced to bear a disproportionate burden of the price rises.

DOC.HEADLINE: Violinist Lu Siqing to perform with Evergreen Symphony Orchestra

TEXT.P: Award-winning Chinese violinist Lu Siqing will perform with the Evergreen Symphony Orchestra in a concert at the National Concert Hall on Thursday.

The performance will be Lu's second in Taiwan. In September last year, he played with Taiwan's National Chinese Orchestra to a full house on The Butterfly Lovers' Violin Concerto, a musical adaptation of a Chinese legend about a tragic romance between two lovers, Liang Shanbo and Zhu Yingtai.
Thursday's concert will begin at 7:30 p.m., with the orchestra's music director and chief conductor Gernot Schmalfuss at the helm.

In addition to playing several Taiwanese folk songs, including "The Torment Of A Flower" and "Tide Over With Romance," Lu will collaborate with the Evergreen Symphony Orchestra to play Chen Gang's "Sunshine on Taxkorgan" -- a fantasy originally composed for the erhu, a traditional Chinese musical instrument -- and Dmitri Kabalevsky's "Violin Concerto," a technically demanding composition that is rarely performed in Taiwan.

The orchestra will also perform Gioacchino Rossini's "The Barber of Serville: Overture" and Czech composer Dvorak's "Symphony No. 7," a Bohemian number passionately acclaimed by the German composer Brahms.
Lu is hailed as the most celebrated violinist of China. He was born in 1969 in Qingdao, Shandong province, and began studying the violin with his father at age 4.

He was accepted by the Central Conservatory of Music in Beijing as a special student when he was only 8. Three years later, he studied with Lord Yehudi Menuhin in London. In 1984 he returned to China for advanced studies at the Conservatory in Beijing. Five years later, he studied at the Juilliard School of Music in New York City.

Lu, who now lives in New York, was the first Asian violinist to win the gold prize at the Paganini International Violin Competition in Italy in 1987 when he was only 17. He has also won numerous international competitions in China, the United Kingdom and the United States, and has performed in more than 30 countries in Asia, Europe, as well as North and South America.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8.2% of part-timers underpaid: survey

TEXT.P: Although many part-time workers have seen their pay increase since a raise in minimum wage last year, a minority of the workers remain underpaid, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).
The survey, conducted by the council in November 2007 among 3,112 part-timers, was aimed at evaluating the work status, labor conditions and the effect of the minimum wage hike on such workers.
On July 1, 2007, the government raised the minimum hourly pay for part-time workers from NT$66 to NT$95.

The survey revealed that while only 44.3 percent of the respondents received over NT$95 per hour before the adjustment, the percentage climbed to 92.8 percent after the change, meaning that 8.2 percent of the respondents were still paid less than the minimum wage.

Among workers who saw their hourly wage increase to over NT$95, 13 percent said their employers decreased hiring after the wage hike, 81 percent said their employers made no change in staff numbers, and 6 percent said their employers increased hiring.
After the minimum wage hike, 7.5 percent more part-timers were paid hourly, 6.8 percent more were paid monthly, and 4.1 percent more were paid daily.
The survey found that 49 percent of part-timers were students, and 18.1 percent were housewives.
In terms of the jobs undertaken by the respondents, the largest group -- 19.9 percent -- were working as cashiers.
Waiters formed the second-largest group at 12.8 percent, followed by miscellaneous workers who accounted for 12.2 percent.
Compared with 71 percent of respondents who were paid hourly, 21 percent were paid monthly.
On average, the respondents worked 28 hours per week, equal to 60 percent of the weekly work hours of full-time workers.
The flexible work hours of part-time work was mentioned by the largest number of respondents -- 48 percent -- as the reason for them to choose that type of jobs.
While 23 percent of part-time workers surveyed said they picked the jobs because they were interested in them, 20 percent did so because the jobs were simpler.

Another 15 percent of the respondents said they could not manage a full-time job because of family-related reasons, while 10 percent wanted to shorten their work hours, and 9.7 percent could not find a full-time job.

According to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, if all workers who work less than 35 hours per week are defined as part-timers, there would be more than 366,000 part-timers in Taiwan, accounting for 3.6 percent of the country's work force.
The percentage is lower than South Korea's 8.8 percent, Japan's 24.5 percent and the United States' 12.6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Orientation course for foreign spouses opens in Kaohsiung County

TEXT.P: A Kaohsiung County service center opened a program Tuesday for foreign spouses of Taiwanese nationals to help them adapt to life in Taiwan, an official said Tuesday.
The two-hour course is the first of its kind in the southern county, according to the official.

In light of the fact that scores of foreign wives do not know their rights and legal obligations, as specified in the residence law enacted by the Ministry of the Interior, the service center under the National Immigration Agency has decided to offer the orientation program so that these women can have a better understanding of the terms of the residence law, the official said.
The course also offers social welfare information and tips on how to lead a better life in Taiwan, the official stated.
Similar programs will be offered in the county three times a month, according to a service center plan.

Currently, there are more than 6,000 foreign spouses in Kaohsiung County, with Vietnamese women accounting for the highest percentage. Foreign spouses from Indonesia, Cambodia, Thailand and the Philippines are also among that number, according the official.
It is estimated that between 35 to 40 new foreign spouses settle in Kaohsiung County each month.

According the residence law, new foreign spouses should apply for residence permits after they arrive in Taiwan, said the official, adding that they are eligible to apply for ID cards after they have lived in the country for three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should develop people-oriented tourism: renowned hotelier

TEXT.P: Taiwan should develop a people-oriented type of tourism that would integrate various aspects of the country's culture to create a fine and modern product that would be attractive to the rest of the world, a hotelier said Tuesday in Taipei.
Speaking at the launch of his latest book, "The Future I See, " CEO of the Landis Hotel Group Stanley Yen, said that Taiwan's cultural attributes are its best assets in developing its tourism.
"Culture and tourism not only are inseparable but also complement each other, and visitors bring vitality to a culture, which also adds depth and meaning to tourism," he said.

He suggested that to market Taiwan as a desirable destination for international tourists, the country has to be aware of its advantages, must make detailed plans and effectively execute them, and needs to envision what would be essential to its sustained competitiveness.
Yen said that the proposal to open up to more tourists from China would prove to be only a short-term solution.

"The idea of making money from an influx of Chinese tourists is ill-conceived, " he said. "Although this plan may help to boost the stagnant economy in the short term, it is actually the people and culture here that can make this business sustainable."
Yen said that he would like to refer every decision maker in the government to his book because it records his 37 years of experience in the travel and tourism industry.

"I hope that this book, which includes all my experience and knowledge in the field of tourism promotion, will serve as reference for decision-makers and anyone else who loves and cares about Taiwan," he said. He described the book as his "final report before graduating from the industry, " in a reference to his imminent retirement from the chairmanship of the Taiwan Visitors Association.

Yen, who is dubbed "Hotel Godfather, " said that when he retires from the tourism industry, he will continue his work in the areas of culture and philanthropy, and will also play the role of a good adviser -- though hard on the ears -- to the new government.

His first piece of advice to President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who will take office May 20, would be to first find the best team, one that shares his views and goals, then let its members use their talents to the fullest, he said.

He also suggested that tourism could be a good diplomatic tool for Taiwan to raise its profile in the international community, adding that he always believed the main purpose of the industry is not to make money but to make friends in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei city government to follow law over nationality probe: mayor

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Tuesday that the city government will comply with the law over a proposal by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) councilors to investigate whether he, chief city administrative heads and city councilors hold dual nationality or U.S. green cards.
Hau said before giving an administrative report at the city council that his green card, giving him U.S. permanent residency status, expired a long time ago.
He explained that his green card became invalid because he has used his Republic of China passport and U.S. visas for his visits to the United States since he began serving as a lawmaker in 1996.
Taiwan law bars anyone with foreign nationality from holding public office, although there is no law preventing civil servants, councilors or lawmakers from holding a green card.
Hau's remarks came in response to a motion proposed by several DPP city councilors at the council to ask the city government to launch the investigation.

DPP City Councilor Hsu Chia-chin said that when President Chen Shui-bian served as Taipei mayor from 1994-1998, Deputy Mayor Chen Shih-meng and David Ta-wei Poo, head of the city's Department of Transportation, renounced their U.S. nationality after coming under harsh criticism.
Hsu said that former Taipei City Councilor Tim Chang also renounced his U.S. nationality before being sworn in.

Noting that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Ching-an also once held U.S. nationality despite serving as a Taipei city councilor, Hsu said the city council should be fair in handling such cases, take back the salary Lee has been paid in public office and investigate her responsibility.

For her part, DPP Taipei City Councilor Wu Su-yao said that after Lee admitted that she once had foreign nationality, the KMT legislative caucus also raised a proposal to ask the central government to investigate the nationality of government agency heads.
Wu added that the Taipei city government should also conduct an investigation.
City Council Speaker Wu Bi-chu said she will respect the mayor's decision on whether the city government should launch the investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA approves proposals for US$86.7 million in China investment

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Tuesday that it has approved four China investment proposals from local manufacturers, which have a total investment amount of US$86. 7 million (NT$ 2.64 billion).

The four companies which sought MOEA approval to invest in China -- Lingsen Precision Industries, King Yuan Electronics, IC assembly company Sigurd Corp. and Siliconware Precision Industries, will invest in integrated circuit packaging (ICP) and testing.
The companies will invest US$10 million, US$20 million, US$6.7 million, and US$50 million, respectively.

In a meeting Tuesday, the MOEA decided that the investment proposals met the clauses in the China investment procedure issued by the ministry's Investment Commission. The procedure aims to make sure Taiwan's investments in China will do no harm to Taiwan's industries and economy, such as by leaking key technologies to the mainland, said Fan Liang-tung, the commission's executive secretary.

Under the procedure, investment plans require approval from the MOEA if they involve a single investment that exceeds US$100 million, the company's total investment in China that reaches US$200 million, or the investment that could transfer core local industries' technologies to China.
Fan said the core industries mainly involve the manufacturing of 8- inch wafers and 4-inch TFT panels, and IC packaging.

After today's meeting, what the commission will need from each of the companies is a written document containing their commitments on the terms of their investment, including the financial plan, information on any technology transfers, information on the company's domestic investment, as well as employment information, to further assess the plans thoroughly.
Fan noted one of the terms the commission is concerned about the most is future investment in Taiwan.

Within the next three years, Lingsen Precision Industries, King Yuan Electronics, IC assembly company Sigurd Corp. and Siliconware Precision Industries have all made commitments to return their capital to Taiwan, in the amounts of NT$2 billion, NT$19.2 billion, NT$3 billion and NT$23 billion, respectively, Fan said.
He added that the commission will make sure the promises are delivered once these investments are under way.

"In a bid to keep high-end technologies in Taiwan, the procedure would push China investment from Taiwan to focus on down scale manufacturers rather than technology-concentrated makers, " Fan stressed.
The commission will hold a second round of meetings to decide if those proposals are to take effect, adding that the final decision will be made no later than the end of April, Fan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan county chief urges ex-DPP head to assume chairmanship

TEXT.P: Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih on Tuesday called on former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Lin I-hsiung to assume chairmanship of the party again so as to help end infighting.

Su made the comments to reporters following a meeting with former Premier Su Tseng-chang, who paired up with former Premier Frank Hsieh to compete against their rivals from the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) but lost in the March 22 presidential election.

The election defeat and an earlier one for the party in the Jan. 12 legislative elections have caused a lot of finger pointing within the ruling DPP, especially as top members vie for the chairmanship. A decision on who will be next chairman is expected to be announced in May.

The Hsieh-Su ticket lost the presidential election to the KMT ticket of Ma Ying- jeou and Vincent Siew by a wide margin of more than 2.21 million votes. Hsieh, who concurrently served as DPP chairman, quit the chairmanship quickly following the election defeat. Hsieh later agreed to stay on the post until May 20 when the country's new president will be sworn in.

Su Huan-chih on Tuesday voiced his hope that the party's next chairman should be produced through negotiations instead of a direct vote by party members to avoid already fierce infighting intensifying further.

He urged Lin, who voluntarily stepped down from the party's top post in May 2000 following the DPP took over the presidency from the KMT for the first time in Taiwan's poltiical history, to assume the chairmanship again so as to bring an end to the party's power struggle and effectively reinforce its support base to better prepare for future elections.

Lin has long been viewed by many DPP supporters as a "puritan." His mother and twin daughters were murdered in 1980, when the KMT was the governing party and the DPP was still considered illegal. The murders remain unsolved.

The DPP did relatively well in Tainan County -- the home county of President Chen. Traditionally the party has done well in southern Taiwan, but in the recent presidential and legislative races, it lost many votes in the south to the KMT.

Echoing Su Huan-chih's remarks, Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tian-tsair contended that the DPP should produce its next chairman through negotiations or hold a direct vote within the party without any restrictions to avoid a fiercer power struggle or fresh complications at an already extremely difficult time for the party.
The chairmanship issue has become a thorn on the side of the DPP as a result of the party's stunning defeat in the presidential race -- the worst since its establishment some 20 years ago.
The party's Central Advisory Committee decided Monday to advance the vote for the party chairman to May 18, two days ahead of the May 20 chairmanship takeover ceremony.

Meanwhile, the DPP plans to hold a major meeting on April 19 aimed at reviewing the party's performance in the March 22 presidential election. President Chen, Vice President Annette Lu and all former party chairs will be invited to take part.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect to attend forum with corporate heads

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Vincent Siew will head a nine-member delegation that will include just three local corporate heads at an economic forum in southern China later this week, a spokesman for the delegation said Tuesday.

The three corporate heads are Morris Chang, founder and chairman of the world's largest contract chip maker, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) , Walsin Lihwa Corp. Chairman Chiao You-lun and Taiwan Cement Corp. Chairman Leslie Koo.

The announcement came two days after Siew confirmed that he will take part in the Boao Forum for Asia slated to be held in China's Hainan Province April 11-13 in his capacity as chairman of the Taipei-based Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation.

Spokesman Wang Yu-chi explained that Siew filed an application after the deadline for registration for the annual gathering, and that with little time left, the foundation could only invite the foundation's board members or consultants.
He offered a public apology to other business leaders who had wanted to take part in the forum.

Wang said the delegation members will take the opportunity to offer Taiwan's goodwill and sincerity to China in the hope of starting a new beginning for cross-Taiwan Strait relations after the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) won the presidential election in March and will return to power in May after eight years of Democratic Progressive Party rule.

In addition, the delegation believes that if the government wants to raise Taiwan's international profile, it should try to take part in as many international gatherings -- such as the Boao Forum -- as possible, remaining pragmatic about which name the country should use, Wang went on.

Wang noted that as security at the forum will be very tight to protect participating state leaders and prime ministers from Australia, Chile, Kazakhstan, Mongolia, Pakistan, Qatar, Sri Lanka, Sweden, Tanzania and Tonga, Siew will only be accompanied by one security guard.
He did not confirm whether or not Siew will meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao at the forum, saying that Siew's schedule will only be confirmed after he arrives in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: City government blamed for incompetence in protecting historic site

TEXT.P: A Taipei city councilor accused the city government Tuesday of incompetence in failing to protect one of the capital city's historic sites after discovering that old wisteria vines at the Wisteria House, a local teahouse, are dying.
The Wisteria House, a 1920-built two-story Japanese-style wooden building, is named after three wisteria vines in its courtyard, one of which is nearly 90 years old.

The house has been a teahouse since 1981, serving traditional tea and snacks, and is a favorite spot for local artists and intellectuals due to its simple yet elegant and quiet atmosphere that harks back to a bygone age.

The Taipei City Department of Cultural Affairs began work in 2005 to renovate the old house and the renovations were scheduled to be completed in January to allow the facility to be re-opened in March. However, the schedule has been delayed.

City Councilor Li Keng Kuei-fang inspected the site earlier in the day along with several city officials and executives of the Wisteria Cultural Association (WCA), which is contracted by the city to manage and operate the teahouse.
According to Li, it is the repair work that has damaged the old vines which, according to the Cultural Heritage Preservation Law, are part of the protected historic site.
However, teahouse manager Chou Yu's wife Lin Huei-feng said it was because high buildings surrounding the house block the sunlight -- essential to the plants in the house's courtyard.
One of the three vines has also been sick for years due to termites and experts from the Forestry Bureau are assisting to control the damage, the WCA said.
Lin said one of the other two vines is thriving and is now blossoming, but the other died before the beginning of the renovation.
The Wisteria House, located on Xingsheng South Road, was a residence of top- ranking Japanese officials until 1945.

In 1950, it was taken over by the Ministry of Finance and was then used as the residence of the then-customs agency chief, Chou Teh-wei. After his death in 1975, his son Chou Yu continued to occupy the house and turned it into a teahouse six years later.

In 1997 the ministry tried to take back the house, but the move triggered an outcry among artists, scholars and ancient monument protection activists. That same year, the city government designated Wisteria House as a historic site.

In 2000, Lung Ying-tai, the then-city director of cultural affairs who is also a famous writer and political commentator, expressed willingness to take over the management of the teahouse and asked the National Property Bureau to voluntarily give the property and the plot of land on which it sits to the city government for public use.

The Wisteria House now belongs to the city government, which has turned the property into a space for cultural exchanges, exhibitions, workshops and performances, as well as a place where authentic Chinese tea drinks and traditional Taiwanese tea culture can still be experienced.

DOC.HEADLINE: Volunteer service intensity increases

TEXT.P: Taiwan's volunteers working with local governments provided services to 14.6 million people in 2007, up 18 percent from the year-earlier level, according to a press statement released by the Ministry of the Interior Tuesday.
Total volunteer service time in the same year reached 12.14 million hours, an increase of 40 percent from the 2006 figure.
The statement said Taiwan had 108,869 volunteers in 1,880 teams working under local governments' social bureaus or departments last year.
Services provided by these teams benefited various different groups of people, including the mentally and physically disabled, the elderly, women and children.

On average, each volunteer provided service to 2.58 people for 2.14 hours per week, the statement said, adding that about 68.27 percent of last year's volunteer workers were women, while only 31. 73 percent were men.
Most of the volunteer workers were housewives, people who work in industrial and commercial circles and students.
Taipei County in northern Taiwan topped other local governments, with 12,500 volunteers, followed by Taipei City, which had more than 12,400 volunteers, the statement said.

In terms of participation rate, Taitung County in eastern Taiwan ranked top, with 223 per 10,000 people doing government-organized volunteer work, followed by Hualien County in eastern Taiwan and offshore Kinmen County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Uganda's Watoto Children's Choir to perform in Taichung

TEXT.P: The Watoto Children's Choir from Uganda, East Africa, will perform two concerts in the central city of Taichung April 20 as part of a performance tour of Taiwan that began late last month.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu received the choir and its leader and introduced them at a press conference Tuesday.

The two concerts in Taichung, sponsored by a local community service association, will take place at 2:30 p.m. and 7:30 p.m. in he city's Chungshan Hall. Tickets are free, with a maximum allocation of four tickets per person.

The Watoto Children's Choir has already given eight "Concerts of Hope" in major cities since its arrival March 28, including three in Taipei and one each in Changhua, Hsinchu, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Yila under the sponsorship of World Vision Taiwan, a Christian relief organization dedicated to helping underprivileged children and families.

This is the choir's second visit to Taiwan. During its last visit in 2006, the children moved the hearts of their audiences with their songs and the tour was a resounding success, with considerable funds raised.

The choir's 18 members are all orphans aged between 6 and 13, each of whom has a sad story to tell. Their tour of Taiwan is intended to increase awareness about the AIDS crisis in Africa and raise funds for a missionary program -- the Watoto Child Care Ministries -- that helps AIDS orphans in Uganda.
About 2 million in Uganda are afflicted with AIDS and most of the 1,600 children in the care of the ministries have lost their parents to the disease.
Watoto, the name of the village in Uganda from which the choir takes its name and from where the children come, means "children" in Swahili, one of the most widely spoken languages in East Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Customs Office seizes illegally imported slipper orchids

TEXT.P: The Taipei Customs Office announced Tuesday that it had seized 558 paphiopedilums, better known as slipper orchids, that had been imported illegally from China via express delivery March 28.

The office said in a news release that agricultural experts at the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture had established that the plants belong to a species protected under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES).
The treaty, signed in 1973, has more than 150 signatory countries who have agreed to regulate global commerce in endangered animals and plants.
The Taipei Customs Office impounded the rare plants and is following leads to trace those responsible for the shipment, the news release said.

Since November 1980, CITES has banned all commercial trade in paphiopedilum species, except in the case of certain slipper orchids that can be proved to have been cultivated. The measure is intended to protect the rare species in the wild from the depredations of collectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's foreign trade hits record high in March

TEXT.P: Amid a slowdown in global trade, Taiwan's foreign trade value in March posted a 29.6 percent rise year-on-year to reach a record US$48.34 billion (NT$1. 47 trillion), the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) announced Tuesday.

Led by the precision instrument sector, which rose 69.3 percent year-on-year in March, Taiwan recorded an export value of US$24.35 billion, the highest in history and an increase of 22.8 percent compared with the same month last year.

The BOFT said because of the soaring price of raw materials and fuel internationally, Taiwan's import value was also the highest ever recorded -- US$24.08 billion -- with a 37.3 percent rise year-on-year.
Agricultural and industrial materials accounted for 80 percent of total imports, with crude oil and wheat in high demand, rising 114.3 percent and 243.2 percent year-on-year, respectively.
The foreign trade surplus was therefore down 92.4 percent year-on-year to US$170 million, a sharp decline compared with US$3.24 billion in February this year, according to the BOFT.

Given the decline in the U.S. economy and its weaker currency, Asian exporting countries like Taiwan and South Korea would not able to rely on the U.S. market, the BOFT forecast. Taiwan's exports to the U.S. in the first three months of 2008 accounted for only 11.9 percent of the total export value, the lowest percentage ever recorded, it stated.
In light of the shrinking U.S market, exporters should explore emerging economies such as Indonesia, India, Brazil, and Malaysia, the bureau advised.

Touching on the impact on exporters due to the recent appreciation of the local currency, the BOFT called for the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) to make an effort to ensure that the fluctuations in New Taiwan dollar are kept in line with those of other major currencies, including the euro and the Japanese yen.

Concerns over domestic inflation should not undermine the importance of maintaining export competitiveness, the BOFT stated, referring to the recent Central Bank increase in key interest rates by 12.5 basis points that was aimed at cooling inflation.

DOC.HEADLINE: American nurse serving Taiwanese leprosy patients dies at 89

TEXT.P: Marjorie I. Bly, a nurse from the United States who has served Taiwanese leprosy sufferers on Penghu Island for 54 years, died Tuesday of heart failure at the age of 89.
Bly's heart failure was the result of pneumonia brought on by a bout of flu, said Wu Fang-tsan, Bly's doctor.

Paying his last respects to Bly at the hospital, Penghu Magistrate Wang Chien- fa described Bly as "Penghu's angel" and said that her death would bring sorrow for many, adding that the county government will issue a public statement to recognize her long-term devotion to the island.
Wu Wen-chung, a local priest, said local residents will follow Bly's instructions and decorate her funeral ceremony with her favorite sunflowers.
Wu also said that at the funeral, there will not be too much talk or hymns. Bly herself requested this, Wu went on, because "she did not pass away. She is just sleeping."
Bly, nicknamed by local residents as "Aunty White, " was assigned by her church to come to Taiwan in 1952. She arrived in Penghu two years after that.
President Chen Shui-bian bestowed a state medal upon Bly April 1, 2007, in recognition of her contributions and of the sacrifices she has made for the people of Penghu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City Government berated for allowing fish to die

TEXT.P: Animal protection activists denounced the Kaohsiung city government Tuesday for killing off the fish in the Lotus Lake, which is being drained in preparation for the 2009 World Games.

The Animal Rescue Team Taiwan (ARTT), a Taichung-based non-profit group, urged the public to rescue some of the fish in a small area of the lake that has not yet been drained, as the southern port city prepares to dredge the lake in the Zuoying district, which will be one of 24 venues of the World Games.

Ni Ching-tai of the ARTT criticized the city government as putting its own interests before the protection of living creatures. There should be a well- planned means of dredging the lake, he said, adding that there is no worse way than to just drain the water and leave the fish to die in the sun.
The city government's lack of respect for life shows that it is not qualified to host the sports event, Ni said.

According to a TV report, the Kaohsiung City water management office, which is responsible for the dredging project, said that 93 percent of the fish were not endemic to Lotus Lake. The office said that the 7 percent of endemic species had been released into nearby rives, while the rest had been used to make animal feed, the report stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP administration claims substantial economic gains

TEXT.P: The outgoing Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration has achieved almost all of its policy goals with regard to boosting economic growth while keeping inflation and unemployment at bay over the past eight years, an Executive Yuan official said Tuesday.

According to the official, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will deliver a report reviewing the country's economic progress over the past eight years at the Executive Yuan's weekly meeting Wednesday.

Quoting from the report, the official said the DPP administration has managed to realize all of the targets it set for the country's economic growth, inflation and unemployment rates during the eight years of its rule.

Especially encouraging was the fact that the average economic growth rate for President Chen Shui-bian's second term has reached 5.23 percent, higher than South Korea's 4.7 percent, the official went on.
Because of the time required to compile accurate economic records, figures quoted in the report are based on data that had been compiled as of the end of last year, the official said.

According to the report, Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) registered an average growth of 0.89 percent for the period from 2000 to 2007, compared to an inflation rate of 3 percent in South Korea, a 1 percent CPI growth in Singapore and a decline of 0.8 percent in CPI in Hong Kong.

"The figures indicate that Taiwan's consumer prices have been relatively stable since the DPP grabbed the reins of power, " the official said, adding that the CPI even registered negative growth for three consecutive years from 2001 through 2003.

On the economic growth rate, the official said Taiwan recorded an average 4.1 percent growth in gross domestic product (GDP) for 2000 through 2007, higher than the world's average of 3.2 percent, America's 2.6 percent and the euro zone's 2.1 percent. But Taiwan fell behind South Korea which registered an average of 5.2 percent GDP growth for the seven-year period.

On the job front, Taiwan's unemployment rate dropped to 3.9 percent for 2006 and 2007, a new low in recent memory, the official said, adding that about 910,000 new job openings have been created during the past eight years. At the end of 2007, the number of employed persons reached 10.29 million.

Wednesday's report on economic achievements will be the second of a series of such reports on the accomplishments of the various ministries and agencies under the Executive Yuan to be issued over the coming weeks before the inauguration of new President Ma Ying-jeou from the opposition Kuomintang on May 20.
The first of the series was delivered last Wednesday, which focused on the accomplishments in infrastructure and transportation construction voer the past eight years.

Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open marginally higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened marginally higher Wednesday.
The weighted price index was up 11.81 points at 8,684.66 on a turnover of NT$2.63 billion (US$86.23 million) at the open. The index lost 56.94 points, or 0.65 percent, to close at 8,672.85 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$30.521 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.03 from Tuesday.
