DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 9, or the fourth day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1241: Batu Khan, grandson of Genghis Khan, leads his Mongol horsemen to victory over the Teutonic Knights at Liegniz, Silesia.
1626: Sir Francis Bacon, English philosopher, essayist, courtier, jurist, and statesman, dies at the age of 65. His writings include "The Advancement of Learning," and the "Novum Organum," in which he proposed a theory of scientific knowledge based on observation and experiment that came to be known as the inductive method.
1667: The world's first art exhibition opens in Paris, and lasts for 15 days.
1682: La Salle, the title of Robert Cavelier, the French explorer of North America who claimed Louisiana for France in 1682, reaches the Gulf of Mexico after traveling down the Mississippi River.
1865: Confederation Gen. Robert E. Lee surrenders to Union Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at the Appomattox Courthouse in Virginia, ending the U.S. Civil War.
1926: Tuan Chi-jui resigns as provisional chief executive of the Republic of China.
1928: Islam is no longer recognized as the state religion of Turkey.
1940: German troops invade Norway and Denmark.
1942: American and Filipino forces on Bataan surrender to the Japanese after a four-month siege.
1957: Egypt announces the opening of the Suez Canal after the withdrawal of invading troops from Great Britain and France from Port Said.
1961: The Republic of Vietnam holds its first presidential elections with Ngo Dinh Diem elected as president.
1963: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill is proclaimed an honorary U.S. citizen at the White House.
1965: The ROC and the United States conclude in Taipei an accord to establish a Sino-American fund for economic and social development in Taiwan.
1969: The Concorde, the supersonic passenger jet, makes its maiden flight from Bristol to Fairford in England.
1973: Hedley Donavan, editor-in-chief of Time magazine, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1973: Lt. Gen. Thomas K. McGebee, commander of the U.S. Aerospace Defense Command, arrives in Taipei from Bangkok for a three-day visit.
1974: Nguyen Van Kieu, newly elevated Vietnamese ambassador-extraordinary and plenipotentiary, presents a copy of his credentials to ROC Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan.
1976: The fifth congress of the Federation of Asian Photographic Arts opens with 200 representatives from South Korea, the Philippines, India, Indonesia, Sabah and the ROC attending.
1976: Bernard B. Matawali, permanent secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture of Malawi, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1988: Mainland China's National Peoples Congress names Li Peng as premier.
1990: The Democratic Forum of Hungary sweeps to power in elections, after 40 years of communism.
1991: Georgia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1998: More than 100 Muslim pilgrims are crushed to death in a stampede at the Haj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.
2000: Paraguay's first flower exhibition center is inaugurated in the Central Province city of Caacupe, with Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi and Republic of China Ambassador to Asuncion Liu Ting-tsu cutting the ribbon.
2001: Former Republic of China Vice President Shieh Tung-min passes away at the age of 95 at his home in a suburb of Taipei from cardial infarction.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country a man may be bold and lofty in the expression of his opinions as well as in his actions. When, however, there is no justice and order in the government of the country, a man may be bold and lofty in his actions, but should be reserved in the expression of his opinion."

Taiwan official named chairman of WTO committee
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 8 (CNA) 04/09/08 12:23:34 (By Jou Ying-cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan trade official was named chairman of a World Trade Organization (WTO) committee Tuesday, the first time any Taiwanese official has been appointed to head a WTO subsidiary body.

Henry Liu, a first secretary in Taiwan's representative office at the WTO, was elected chairman of the Committee on the Trade-Related Investment Measures (TRIMs) , which is one of the subsidiary bodies under the WTO Council for Trade in Goods.
The committee monitors the operation and implementation of commitments by members to remove trade-restrictive or distorting investment measures, such as local content or trade balancing requirements.
Commenting on the appointment, Taiwan's WTO representative Lin Yi-fu said it represents another way for Taiwan to make a more significant and active contribution to the world trade regulatory body.
"It is also an obvious benefit for Taiwan in terms of talent cultivation and gaining experience," Lin said.

Taiwan did not encounter any political interference during the election process, Lin said, pointing out that Taiwan is a full member of the WTO and has exercized its rights and duties there on an equal footing with all other WTO member countries.
For his part, Liu told CNA that the election of chairpersons of Goods Council subsidiary bodies had nothing to do with Taiwan's interests in affairs pertaining to any particular committees.
He said the leadership of the council conducted the election simply based on the principle of fairness.
The WTO Council for Trade in Goods elected by acclamation Amb. Karen Tan (Singapore) to succeed Amb. Karsten Vagn Nielsen (Denmark) as its new chairperson March 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan university develops revolutionary wire inspection device

TEXT.P: A Tainan-based university has developed a low-cost, compact wire inspection device that will revolutionize the way construction constractors and machine makers check their wiring assemblies, a local newspaper reported Wednesday.

According to the Liberty Times, Southern Taiwan University of Technology (STUT) has arranged to have a local manufacturer mass produce the device, which saves time and manpower by checking the status of a group of wires simultaneously rather than wire by wire as normally occurs at present.
Researchers at the university said the gadget, dubbed the "digital wiring inspector, " is comprised of a signal transmitting unit and a signal analyzing unit.

The transmitter, placed at one end of the wires, sends individual signals through each wire to the analyzer at the other end. The analyzer indicates which lines are functional and which are faulty by decoding the signals received.
"It's like putting a yellow, a green and a red pellet into pipelines one, two, and three, " explained Wei Chao-huang, an assistant professor in the university's Department of Electrical Engineering.
"If only the yellow and red pellet go out through the other end, then it can be determined that pipeline two is broken."
The new device can be operated by a single person, a huge advantage in today's market.

Wei said the most commonly used methods of wiring inspection require multiple workers at a site to check each wire individually, usually by using an additional common wire -- a reference wire designated by inspectors -- to short-circuit the wire being inspected.

"When the workload is only a cable or two, it's not a problem using the conventional ways, " Wei said, "but at a construction site, for example, where there might be tens of rooms with hundreds of electrical cables, one-by-one inspection would be extremely time-consuming."

Researchers said the prototype device, awarded a gold medal at the 2008 Thailand International Invention Exhibition, cost less than NT$200 (about US$6.56) and estimated that the price of the commercial version would be no more than NT$99.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academic widely tipped as future premier

TEXT.P: Soochow University President Liu Chao-shiuan has been widely tipped by the media to become premier in the incoming Kuomintang (KMT) administration, but the former vice premier refused to address the speculation.

"I will not answer any questions like that at the moment, " Liu said Wednesday when asked whether he had been offered the job by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and whether he was interested in taking it.

"The final decision on this matter will be made and announced by President-elect Ma, " said Liu, who has been president of Soochow University, located in Taipei City's northern suburb of Shihlin, since July 2004.
Liu's four-year term as president of the school expires at the end of July.

A technocrat with an educational background in chemistry, Liu held many important governmental posts in the 1990s when the KMT last held power, including serving as vice premier from 1997-2000, when Vice President-elect Vincent Siew was premier.

The United Daily News and China Times reported Wednesday that Ma has visited Liu at his home three times since late March to persuade him to head the KMT administration slated to be inaugurated May 20.
Meanwhile, Ma spokesman Lo Chih-chiang would not comment on the media's speculation, saying that President-elect Ma will make a formal announcement when the Executive Yuan lineup is finalized.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Matsu culture' stabilizing force in Taiwanese society: VP-elect

TEXT.P: The culture surrounding Matsu, goddess of the sea, is not only one of the most representative religious activities in Taiwan, it is a stabilizing force in Taiwanese society, Vice President-elect Vincent Siew said Wednesday.

Siew, who traveled to the southern county of Chiayi to lead a ceremony marking an important stop on the eight-day annual pilgrimage tour of Matsu, said that the parade is not only an important religious event locally, it is now a high- profile religious activity among Chinese communities around the world.

The pilgrimage is part of celebrations for Matsu's birthday, which falls on the 23rd day of the third lunar month but is usually celebrated earlier with a pilgrimage that starts from the renowned Jenn Lann Temple located in Dajia township in the central county of Taichung and then proceeds through the counties of Changhua, Yunlin and Chiayi.

Matsu -- who legend has it was a young woman from China's Fujian Province who was turned into a goddess after she sacrificed her life to rescue her fishermen father and older brothers -- has been worshipped for more than one thousand years by Chinese mainly living in coastal areas.

At Wednesday's ceremony held at Feng Tien Temple in Chiayi County's Hsinkang township, Siew was joined by Yen Ching-piao, chairman of Jenn Lann Temple, Feng Tien Temple Chairman Lu Ming-sen and Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, as well as Taichung Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, in a worship ritual containing 28 lengthy rites that have been handed down through the ages.

The tradition has been observed for more than a century and has bloomed into what Discovery Channel describes as one of the world's three major religious festivals, thanks to the Jenn Lann Temple management's introduction of modern marketing and advertising strategies into the program of festivities.

Over the past decade, the traditional eight-day religious walking pilgrimage has evolved into a month-long carnival that incorporates religious, cultural, fashion and tourism activities better known as the Taichung County Matsu International Festival.
Since the late 1990s, the annual pilgrimage has consistently attracted nearly 1 million Matsu worshipers who follow an image of Matsu borne on a palanquin along the route.
This year's Dajia Matsu festival began Feb. 20 and is scheduled to end April 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices marginally lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed marginally lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 4.92 points, or 0.05 percent, to close at 8,667.93.

Finishing lower for the second consecutive day, the bourse opened at 8,684.66 and fluctuated between 8,759.75 and 8,628.62 during the day's session. A total of 5.17 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$135.03 billion (US$4.42 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground. Foodstuff issues moved up 2.9 percent, the most of any sector. Construction issues advanced 2.1 percent, paper and pulp issues rose 1.5 percent, cement stocks were up 1.2 percent, textile stocks increased 1.1 percent, and banking and financial shares gained 0.7 percent.
Two of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares dropping 0.6 percent and plastics and chemicals shares falling 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,126 to 1,018, with 348 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5.36 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Steel posts record revenues in March

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp. (CSC), Taiwan's largest steel producer, posted a record monthly high for sales in March at NT$20.447 billion (US$669.8 million) , the company announced Wednesday.

The figure represented a jump of 21.05 percent over the March 2007 level of NT$16.892 billion and a 21.23 percent increase over February's sales of NT$16.866 billion, the steel maker said in a statement.

CSC's monthly sales first broke the NT$20 billion barrier in January this year, boosted by rising prices for its products in both local and foreign markets, the company said. The monthly figure again exceeded the NT$20 billion mark in March thanks to increased output.
According to rough estimates by the steel maker, in which the government remains the largest shareholder, combined Q1 revenues totaled NT$57.353 billion, up by 16.74 percent year on year.

Meanwhile, analysts predicted that CSC's earnings growth in the first half of this year would outpace that registered in the same period of 2007. They said the company's business in the second half of the year would depend on world market conditions during that period. By Flor Wang)

TAIEX Index futures for May gained 36 points to finish at 8,648, with 2,975 contracts traded, while June futures rose 34 points to close at 8,634, with 54 contract transactions.
September futures increased 38 points to finish at 8,398, with 58 contract transactions, while December futures dropped two points to close at 8,377, with 16 contracts traded.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index slid 4.92 points Wednesday to finish at 8,667.93, with a market turnover of NT$135.02 billion (US$4.43 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 8,637 for April; 8,612 for May; 8,600 for June; 8,360 for September and 8,379 for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP rebuts report on massive debt from presidential campaigning

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Deputy Secretary-General Lan Shih-tsung said Wednesday that the party owes about NT$70 million (US$2.3 million) for its advertising in the recent presidential election, and not NT$400 million as reported in a local weekly.
Lan said that the DPP headquarters spent about NT$160 million on campaign ads and publicity materials for the party's presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and his running mate Su Tseng-chang.
Of that total, about NT$90 million has already been paid by the DPP headquarters, with the remaining NT$70 million to be paid off in monthly installments by the end of this year.

Lan was responding to an article in the most recent edition of the weekly Next magazine that claimed the ruling party owed more than NT$400 million for televised campaign ads during the presidential race.

DPP Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan, who concurrently served as chief executive of the Hsieh campaign, said that the party ran up debts during the campaign for January's legislative elections, and that consequently, the DPP headquarters lacked the resources to provide anything more than only very limited funds for the presidential campaign.

He added that as one-third of the central government subsidies provided to Hsieh for his election campaign had already been handed over by Hsieh to the DPP headquarters -- as required by DPP regulations -- and as Hsieh's own fund- raising targets were nearly met, the Hsieh-Su campaign came close to breaking even.

Meanwhile, Lan said that the DPP has already negotiated with relevant companies and TV stations on a repayment schedule for the money it owes for presidential campaign advertising and promotional materials.
About NT$11 million will be payed back each month, he said, adding that if the DPP were to pay the entire amount in one lump sum, it would have no money left over for its day to day operations.

Meanwhile, a high-ranking DPP official said that the party has in recent years been borrowing money to pay off its debts, claiming that if the DPP's annual operating budget remains at NT$300 million to NT$400 million, the party's deficit will continue to balloon.

He said that the DPP has already mapped out a two-stage personnel streamlining plan to bring spending under control, with the goal of reducing the party's annual operating budget to levels at the beginning of the decade when the figure stood at about NT$200 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan declines in 2008 global information technology report

TEXT.P: Taiwan fell four places to 17th place among 127 economies worldwide and ranked last among the "Four Asian Dragons" in the "networked readiness index (NRI) , " a measure of competitiveness in the information, communication and technology (ICT) industry, according to a just released report.

The Geneva-based World Economic Forum on Wednesday released The Global Information Technology Report 2007-2008, which is considered the world's most comprehensive and authoritative international assessment of the impact of ICT on the development process and competitiveness of nations.

In the ranking of the index, which is designed to examine how prepared countries are to use ICT effectively, Taiwan dropped to 17th place among the countries covered by the report, while Korea impressively rose 10 places to rank 9th, overtaking Taiwan for the first time.
Taiwan also was placed last among the "Four Asian Dragons," after Singapore, which ranked 5th, South Korea and Hong Kong, which ranked 11th.

"Korea offers a textbook example of how to quickly and advantageously join the knowledge economy, by adopting an integrated public-private strategy focused on Information & Communications Technology (ICT), innovation and education, " said Irene Mia, Senior Economist of the forum's Global Competitiveness Network, in a press release.

Despite losing some ground this year, the report said, Taiwan is still ranked at a "satisfactory" place overall, showing its resilience as one of the world's largest ICT exporters and producers and a leading innovator.
It ranked 1st place for high-tech exports and 3rd for the number of registered utility patents, according to the report.

"Taiwan's development story is a textbook example of how a resource- poor rural economy can transform itself in the short span of three decades into a ICT powerhouse, thanks to coherent e-leadership from the government," it added.
Denmark is the most networked economy, followed by Sweden, Switzerland, the United States, Singapore, Finland, the Netherlands, Iceland, Korea and Norway.
China slightly improved two places to 57th this year, showing weaknesses in its underdeveloped ICT infrastructure and scarce individual usage rate.

The index featured in the report covers three dimensions: general business as well as the regulatory and infrastructure environment for ICT; the readiness of the three key stakeholder groups -- individuals, businesses and governments -- to use and benefit from ICT; and their actual usage of the latest information and communication technologies available.
Under the theme "Fostering Innovation through Networked Readiness, " this year's report places a particular focus on the role of networked readiness in spurring innovation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung resident indicted for intimidation of Taipei city mayor

TEXT.P: A man from Kaohsiung City was indicted Wednesday on charges of intimidation and hindering public security for sending threatening letters to Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin late last year.

According to the indictment issued by the Taipei District Prosecutors Office, suspect Chuang Shun-kui allegedly sent a threatening letter containing a pair of sheep testicles to Hau in protest of the Taipei Election Commission's stance on the voting method used in the Jan. 12 legislative elections.

Chuang, who mailed the letter to Hau by private courier on Nov. 29, 2007, was angry because the city insisted that voters cast ballots in the legislative polls and on concurrently held referendums in two separate steps, in defiance of Central Election Commission (CEC) orders that all ballots be picked up in one single step.

The procedural issue became one of the major points of debate in the run-up to the elections and further stoked divisions between supporters of rival political camps led by Hau's Kuomintang (KMT) and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

In the letter, Chuang blasted Hau for balking at the CEC's decision and accused Hau of "trampling on the civil rights of Taiwan's people" by advocating the "two-step" voting method. At the end of the letter, he signed the name of a civic rights group that he coined.
After investigation and questioning by Taipei prosecutors, Chuang admitted to the act and was indicted for violating Article 305 of Taiwan's Criminal Code.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSB briefs VP-elect prior to Boao Forum in China

TEXT.P: National Security Bureau (NSB) officials have briefed Vice President-elect Vincent Siew on the latest cross- Taiwan Strait situation and on security measures prior to his departure for a forum in China, NSB Deputy Director- General Tsai Te-sheng said Wednesday.

Tsai said the NSB officials reported to the vice president-elect upon his request, although the vice president-elect will take part in the Boao Forum for Asia, to be held April 11-13 in China's Hainan Province, in his capacity as chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation.
Tsai made the remarks while fielding questions from main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers at a legislative committee meeting.

According to Tsai, the NSB must provide adequate protection to the incumbent president and vice president as well as the president-elect and vice president-elect wherever they are, whether at home or abroad, according to the law.

The NSB also will offer full security to Siew at the Boao Forum in line with his requirement, Tsai said, adding that Siew's office has also contacted the forum's authorities to ask for security protection.

Siew's attendance at the Boao Forum is set to carry historical significance to cross-strait ties due to his status as vice president-elect. Relevant issues, including Siew's personal safety, have aroused widespread attention from across the domestic political spectrum.
His entourage will include entrepreneurs and aides from the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation that he founded in 2001 to promote the idea of setting up a common market between Taiwan and China.
Siew's visit will be the first time that a vice president-elect from Taiwan will have landed on Chinese soil.
Siew has attended the Boao Forum -- started in 2002 -- every year since 2003 and there has been widespread press speculation that he will meet Chinese President Hu Jintao at this year's forum.
The non-government, non-profit Boao Forum for Asia, whose 26 members include China, Japan and the Philippines, aims to promote economic and trade cooperation in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan motorcycle show focuses on environmental protection

TEXT.P: The Third Taiwan International Motorcycle Industry Show opened Wednesday, emphasizing environmental protection, with a special pavilion devoted to featuring the most advanced equipment that incorporates green concepts and technology, organizers said.

"This year's show has introduced a new slogan--'New Era for a Green Planet', to show Taiwanese motorcycle manufacturers' commitment to environmental protection, " Donald Lu, Executive vice president of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), the main organizer of the exhibition, said in the opening ceremony.
A pavilion has also been set up at the exhibition to showcase Taiwan's fuel- injection (FI) jet engine, which uses less fuel and reduces emission.

"The FI jet engine makes the fuel consumption of the motorcycle more efficient, so that reduces exhaust gas emission, " said a staff of the pavilion who declined to be named, adding that an FI jet engine can reduce fuel consumption by 10 percent compared to a combustion engine, the kind generally used at present in Taiwan.
But consumers have to pay about NT$5,000-NT$8,000 more for the high tech engine, he said.
Taiwan's government stipulated that all new motorcycles on the market must be equipped with FI engines from 2009, to adapt to the fifth stage motorcycle emission standard.
The fifth stage emission standard, which was put into effect in July 2007 in Taiwan, is one of the strictest motorcycle exhaust standards in the world, according to the organizers.

"In Taiwan's motorcycle industry, the supply chain is complete to include the upper, middle and lower-stream business, from motorcycle components to finished products, all of which are full of international market development potential, " Eric S. H. Chiang, the deputy director of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, told foreign and local buyers in his opening remarks.

Taiwan's motorcycle show is the second largest one of its kind in Asia, after only Tokyo's. The scale of the Taiwan show has been expanding year by year, with an annual growth rate of 13 percent for manufacturers participating and 30 percent for the number of booths set up, organizers said.

About 20,000 visitors are expected at the four-day show staged in the Taipei World Trade Center this year, from April 9-12, with the first two days reserved for buyers and the last two open to the general public.
Taiwan is the 6th largest motorcycle manufacturer in the world, according to Chiang, after China, India, Indonesia, Thailand and Japan.
A total of 481 booths in the exhibition are exhibiting motorcycles, scooters, engines, noise and emission inspection equipment, as well as maintenance equipment and accessories.

DOC.HEADLINE: Generation Y tends to climb to managerial posts earlier: survey

TEXT.P: Generation Y people born after 1981 tend to climb to managerial posts in companies at a relatively much younger age than their older counterparts, a job placement service center said Wednesday.

Employees born after 1980 tend to first become managers at an average age of 25.3, compared to 31.8 for their counterparts who were born in the 50s, according to the 104 Job Bank, one of the country's largest human resource service companies.

In comparison, employees who were born in the 60s used to climb to managerial positions at an average age of 29.5 and those who were born in the 70s usually entered management for the first time at an average age of 27.4, according to the results of a survey conducted by the job bank.
The Y-generation people seem to climb the career ladder faster as they tend to have stronger ability to learn and a stronger work ethic, according to the poll.
Most of the business executives said they do not particularly consider employees' ages when they are choosing new leaders within their corporations, the poll found.
Negotiation and coordination ability, the ability to solve problems and professional abilities are more important factors when they are considering promotions, according to the poll.
The Y-generation people, nevertheless, do not necessarily perform well in management terms, the poll found.

According to company executives who responded to the poll, managers aged 39-48 were the best performers, with an average score of 77.4 points, compared to 74.0 points for managers aged between 49-58 and 72.3 points for managers aged between 29 and 38.
The Y-generation people -- aged under 28 -- got the lowest average score of 58.7 points, the poll found.

The poll, conducted on-line last month, obtained 480 valid responses from corporate executives, with a margin of error of 4.5 percent, and 4,073 valid responses from individual office workers, with a margin of error of 1.54 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Hakka Tung Blossom Festival to begin April 10

TEXT.P: The 2008 Hakka Tung Blossom Festival will begin Thursday, with seven counties in northern and central Taiwan presenting a variety of activities to celebrate the annual flower season through the end of May.

According to the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs, Lee Yung-teh, who heads the council, will hold a news conference Thursday to release detailed information on where visitors can go to see the spectacular drifts of snow-white flowers, as well the many activities reflecting Hakka culture in the counties of Taipei, Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Miaoli, Taichung, Changhua and Nantou.

April and May are the months when tung flowers, also known as paulownia flowers, are in full bloom in central and northern Taiwan. The white flowers have become a symbol of the Hakka people and the flowering season is celebrated in Hakka villages every year with traditional music and song, coupled with the consumption of Hakka delicacies.

According to the Council for Hakka Affairs, 44 community groups in 25 cities and townships will present over 100 artistic and cultural activities, while 92 outlets will market some 400 tung flower-related products and 78 designated restaurants will provide Hakka dishes.
The 2008 Tung Blossom Festival has been designated by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications as one of the eight major events of Tour Taiwan 2008-2009.

The Hakka are a unique ethnic group of Han Chinese, who originally lived in central China but gradually migrated south during different dynasties and settled in Jiangxi, Fujian and Guangdong provinces, as well as in Taiwan, after fleeing from war and famine. They were called Hakka, which literally means "guest families," by the locals when they first settled in.

The Hakka people are considered to be careful about maintaining their cultural traditions and one of their outstanding characteristics is that they are willing to venture into other parts of the world to establish themselves.
During the 100 years, the Hakka have migrated to Southeast Asia, East Africa, Europe and North and South America.

Taiwan has about 4.5 million Hakka people, accounting for 13.2 percent of the population. The first wave of Hakka migrants came from China to Taiwan in the 1690s, when China was under the rule of the Ching Dynasty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan County to hold expo to woo new residents

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first exposition on residential assets will start Sunday in the northeastern county of Yilan to woo new residents to the area, Yilan County Deputy Magistrate Lin Hsin-hua said at a news conference Wednesday.
The exposition will take place at the Wu Lao Keng Mountain Stream Park in Yilan County, and will run until May 18, Lin said.
Participants will be able to obtain housing information and learn about the different choices in Yilan County, including upscale residential areas and suburban farm houses.
The county government has designed outdoor exposition areas that would allow participants to get a first hand experience of living in Yilan County.
Deputy Magistrate Lin said Yilan is an attractive place to live because of its natural environment, reasonable cost of housing, convenient transportation, and high-quality medical center.
It is also a good place to work, Lin said, adding that about 15,000 job opportunities have been created in the last two years since the county attracted 95 investment projects.

Chen Jung-sheng, chairman of the opto-electronics company Abon Touchsystems Co., encouraged young people, especially those from Yilan, to seek jobs in the county to sustain the local economy. According to Chen, his company opened a plant in Yilan in 2005 to provide jobs for young residents there.

At the news conference, Lin conferred honorary county residency on Matthew Lien -- a Canada-based musician known for his musical tributes to nature -- citing Lien's musical exploration of Yilan County.
"I am glad to become an honorary resident of the county which gave me a lot of inspiration," Lien said.
Lien spent more than two years, from 2002 to 2004, visiting Yilan's mountains, rivers, and plains, and recording the natural sounds in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan achieves steady economic growth under DPP: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday that Taiwan has achieved steady economic growth over the last eight years under the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration.
The premier made the remarks during a meeting of the Executive Yuan to review the overall economic performance of the DPP during the two terms of its administration.
Chang said that Taiwan's economic growth averaged 4.1 percent between 2000 and 2007, and reached 5.23 percent in the last four years, higher than the 4.7 percent recorded by neighboring South Korea.

The premier said that a series of economic development programs promoted by the government, such as the 10 new major economic development projects and "mega- investment and mega-warmth" plan, have borne fruit.
He noted that annual private investment also increased to an average NT$1.63 trillion between 2000 and 2007, up NT$540.9 billion from the average NT$1.09 trillion between 1992 and 1999.
"Private investment in 2007 surpassed the NT$2 trillion threshold to reach NT$2.04 billion," he added.
Chang said that approved inbound investment averaged NT$7.14 billion between 2000 and 2007, or 2.6 times the figure of NT$2.74 billion recorded between 1992 and 1994.
Approved inbound investment totaled NT$15.36 billion in 2007, setting a historic record, Chang said.

On the country's foreign trade performance, the premier said that imports and exports increased to NT$219.3 billion and NT$246.7 billion, respectively, in 2007 from the NT$111.2 billion and NT$123.7 billion recorded respectively in 1999.

Chang also noted that Taiwan's consumer price index registered an average growth rate of only 0.89 percent between 2000 and 2007, and that growth was around 1.8 percent in 2007, comparatively lower than that registered in China, the United States, South Korea and Singapore.

He also pointed out that the unemployment rate dropped to 3.9 percent in 2007 -- the lowest in seven years. An additional 909,000 jobs were created between 1999 and 2007, among them 665,000 for women, while women's labor participation rate was as high as 49.4 percent, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local banks back fund to facilitate corporate loans

TEXT.P: Five Taiwanese banks will join with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to establish a fund to build a platform that would streamline the assessment of small and medium enterprises (SME) seeking financing, the ministry announced Wednesday.

Chinatrust Commercial Bank, Taiwan Corporate Bank, First Commercial Bank, E. Sun Bank, and Taipei Fubon Bank have agreed to contribute NT$5 million each, to match the MOEA's input of NT$5 million, for the construction a NT$30-million information facility that would provide all-in-one credit assessment for commercial financing.

The facility, an electronic financial service platform planned in 2004, will compile financial reports on SMEs by using the e-Government Services Hub, a state-run virtual platform to access the data of the business status and credit status of Taiwan's private companies.

The requirements for corporate loans are often stricter than for personal loans, as the banks usually have to review a range of financial information such as income tax and sales tax records, to determine a company's ability to repay a loan.

Greater transparency of companies' financial status will help lower the risk of bad debts and subrogation costs incurred by the MOEA, which in some cases serves as a guarantor, said a section chief of the Small and Medium Enterprise Administration (SMEA) under the MOEA.

"Once the banks are convinced that a company has the ability to repay a loan, they would be more willing to offer financing, which in turn would help upgrade the company's businesses," the official said. Financially stronger SMEs would mean reduced tax levying by the Ministry of Finance, she added.
The new mechanism will also make it easier and quicker for the country's SMEs to obtain loans, as conventional procedures require a lot of paperwork and extra time and costs.

The new platform will incorporate hardware infrastructure and a software system. The former will focus on a firewall to protect the companies' information, while the latter will be an application to systemize the information required by the banks.
The MOEA section chief said no decision has yet been made regarding the sourcing of the components.

Referring to another MOEA project, the SME Credit Guarantee Fund, the official said the ministry is offering a total of NT$5 billion in loan guarantees in 2008, and that some NT$37 billion had already been spent in credit guarantees and subrogation fees to the banks since 2003.
"The new platform and the credit guarantee fund could together help to improve the financial capacity of Taiwan's SMEs, " she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei international auto parts show opens

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taipei International Auto Parts and Accessories Show kicked off Wednesday morning, with a record high number of manufacturers setting up booths at the event.

A total of 937 automobile parts and accessories makers are taking part in the four-day exhibition being held at the Taipei World Trade Center Nangang Exhibition Hall. The figure represents a 13.6 percent increase over the previous year.
Meanwhile, 2,494 booths have been set up at the show, also a record high, marking a 30 percent increase over the number at last year's event.

Speaking at the opening of the show, Hsieh Fa-da, deputy minister of economic affairs, said that the record-high figures illustrate the Taiwan auto parts and accessories industry's "unyielding strength."
Hsieh said that "Made in Taiwan" auto parts and accessories have become famous around the world and "synonymous with innovative technology and high quality."

"By means of a complete supply chain and their efforts at adding value to their products, Taiwan's auto parts and accessories manufacturers have been successful in expanding their overseas markets," he said.

Hsieh noted that the production value of Taiwan's auto parts and accessories industry reached NT$153.9 billion (US$5.04 billion) in 2007, a year-on-year increase of 2.7 percent, while the country's auto parts and accessories exports amounted to NT$4.771 billion, up 11.3 percent from the previous year.
He said these figures illustrate the competitiveness of Taiwan's auto parts and accessories makers.

Hsieh further said that if Taiwan's auto parts and accessories manufacturers can maintain their distinct advantages as flexible and diversified suppliers and continue investing in innovation, they will be able to preserve their competitiveness in overseas markets.

The 2008 Taipei International Auto Parts and Accessories Show was organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council. Aside from Taiwanese suppliers, manufacturers from 13 countries, including the United States, Japan, the United Kingdom, India and Singapore, are taking part in the show.
In addition, Thailand, South Korea and Malaysia have each set up booths to showcase their respective auto parts and accessories industries at the exhibition, which will run through April 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: One more enterovirus-71 case confirmed in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) confirmed Tuesday another serious case of enterovirus -- Type 71 (EV 71) -- in southern Taiwan, bringing the number of confirmed severe cases of enterovirus to 27 so far this year, with one casualty.
The newest case is a one-year-old boy in the southern County of Pingtung, where most of Taiwan's enterovirus cases were recorded in recent months.
The boy developed a fever and pain in his throat March 27, and by March 29 was vomiting and having spasms.
He was sent to the intensive care unit of a medical center March 31 after he developed pneumonia and muscle weakness.
The boy, who has since been moved to an ordinary ward, is expected to be discharged from the hospital soon.

Chou Chih-hao, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control under the DOH, said that two confirmed cases of serious enterovirus are still being treated in the pediatric intensive care unit -- an 8-month-old boy from Hsinchu City and a 21-month-old girl from Kaohsiung County.

Chou said the enterovirus cases occurred earlier than expected this year, with three-fourths of them recorded in the southern areas of Taiwan. According to Chou, the epidemic usually reaches its peak between May and June, and between September and October.

Enterovirus usually enters the body through the gastrointestinal tract and thrives there, and then moves on to attack the nervous system. It can be found in the respiratory secretions and stool of an infected person.
Chou reminded parents and teachers that frequent hand-washing is still the most effective way to avoid contracting enterovirus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Philippine governor visits Taiwan to deepen medical exchanges

TEXT.P: A Philippine governor on Tuesday called on the Chiayi city government and visited the Chiayi Christian Hospital (CYCH) in an effort to enhance the exchange of information on providing medical care.

Sally Lee, governor of Sorsorgon Province in the southernmost Philippines, was warmly welcomed by Chiayi Deputy Mayor Lee Hsi-chin and CYCH superintendent Chen Cheng-ren, a CYCH spokesman said Wednesday.

Lee shared her views with Deputy Mayor Lee Hsi-chin and Chen on issues related to upgrading the quality of health management and enhancing local infrastructure development, according to the spokesman.
The visits came three years after Sorsogon Provincial Hospital and CYCH forged sisterhood ties and a CYCH overseas medical team undertook a medical mission to the Philippine hospital.

Under the sponsorship of the Cabinet-level Department of Health and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, in 2005, CYCH put together an overseas medical team, led by its former superintendent Wong Juei-heng, to provide free medical services at Sorsogon Provincial Hospital, the spokesman said.
Due to a severe shortage of medical equipment and health care professionals in the Philippines, most seniors in the country suffer from rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes and gout, the spokesman noted.

Thus, one of the main goals of the medical mission is to provide Filipinos with information on dental, gastrointestinal and diabetic health care, and other types of relevant information, the spokesman said.
"Through the exchanges between the two sister hospitals, Filipinos have greatly benefited from Taiwan's medical technologies," the spokesman said.

Medical personnel from Sorsogon Provincial Hospital have also attended seminars and surgery demonstrations in Taiwan as part of the efforts to boost the quality of medical care in the Philippines, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: State-run enterprises to be allowed to issue corporate bonds

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has approved a draft amendment to the Administrative Law of State-Run Enterprise to allow state-run businesses to issue corporate bonds, beyond the confines of the Company Act, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced Wednesday.
The proposed amendment will go into effect only after it has been passed by the Legislative Yuan, Chang noted, urging the legislature to pass the bill as soon as possible.

According to Article 247 of the Company Act, the total amount of corporate bonds cannot exceed the net value of all assets possessed by a company after deducting all liabilities and intangible assets, and the total amount of unsecured corporate bonds should not exceed one-half of the net remainder.

As state-run enterprises may be vulnerable because of their role in helping the government stabilize the prices of commodities without raising the prices of their own products, Chang said, "this has impeded the ability of the state-run enterprises to raise funds."

In recent months, state-run enterprises in Taiwan, such as oil refiner CPC Corp. Taiwan and grid operator Taiwan Power Co., have frozen the prices of petroleum and electricity in accordance with government policies, making it difficult for them to raise funds under the terms of the current Administrative Law of State- Run Enterprise.
"The proposed amendment to the law would help the state-run enterprises to raise funds and would also boost the nation's economic development on the whole," Chang said.
Meanwhile, Chang said that personnel recruitment in state-run enterprises should be done openly and transparently and should include the required "written test."
"Matters pertaining to personnel employment, assessment, retirement, and management within state-run enterprises should be drafted by each company and approved by the Executive Yuan, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seminar to be held on Taiwan's sovereign status

TEXT.P: An international seminar on Taiwan's sovereign status will be held April 18-19 in Taipei to solicit opinions from world experts on the issue.

The seminar will be organized jointly by Taiwan Thinktank and Taiwanese Society of International Law, with participation by several internationally prominent experts in law, including Ando Nisuke, former chairperson of the United Nations Human Rights Committee and Stephen Yates, former adviser to U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney on national security affairs.
The organizers said the seminar will focus on discussions on Taiwan's sovereign status from the perspective of international law, history and international politics.
Other foreign participants will include Rhee Sang-Myon, a professor at the College of Law at Seoul National University and Asada Masahiko, a law professor at Japan's Kyoto University.

Taiwanese experts, including Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Ling Chia-lung, Taiwanese Society of International Law President Hwang Tzong- leh, and Michael Hsiao, executive director of the Center for Asia Pacific Area Studies under Academia Sinica, will also attend the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: New government will continue cooperation projects with allies: Ma

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou has made assurance that none of the country's ongoing cooperation projects with its diplomatic allies will be changed after his assumed office May 20, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.

Ma made the remarks in two separate telephone conversations with El Salvadoran President Elias Antoni Saca and Honduras President Jose Manuel Zelaya March 27 and April 2, respectively, during which the two Central American leaders congratulated Ma on his election as Taiwan's next president, the MOFA said in a press release.
During the conversations, Saca and Zelaya hailed the democratic maturity that they said the Taiwan people demonstrated during the March 22 presidential election, the MOFA statement said.

In addition to reaffirming that his new government will continue all the cooperation projects that the current Democratic Progressive Party administration signed with or promised its diplomatic allies, Ma also invited Saca and Zelaya to attend his inauguration on May 20, an invitation that the two leaders have accepted.

Meanwhile, the MOFA said Saca and Zelaya also sent congratulatory messages to President Chen Shui-bian on March 27 and April 2, respectively, praising the democratic maturity that the people of Taiwan had demonstrated during the March 22 presidential election.

Saca and Zelaya told Chen they will travel to Taipei to attend the inauguration of Taiwan's new president, the MOFA statement said, adding that the two leaders also said they look forward to meeting with Chen during their visit to Taiwan.
For his part, the MOFA said, Chen conveyed his gratitude to Saca and Zelaya for their long-term support of Taiwan's efforts to enter the United Nations and World Health Organization.

Chen was quoted as saying that the transfer of power is a normal process in a democratic country, and that the new government will definitely fulfill all the cooperation programs the outgoing government had agreed to with its diplomatic allies.
Chen also expressed optimism that Taiwan's economic and trade ties with El Salvador and Honduras will be further strengthened in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung city exterminating rats to prevent epidemic

TEXT.P: The southern port city of Kaohsiung is on the alert for a possible outbreak of a rodent-borne disease after the first case of native Hantavirus hemorrhagic fever this year was reported.

The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health confirmed Tuesday that a 26-year-old man who worked at a fish processing factory in Kaohsiung's Cianjhen district was diagnosed with Hantavirus hemorrhagic fever on March 38 after he complained of having a stomach ache, fever and diarrhea.
The patient has recovered and was discharged from hospital three days after he was admitted, according to a CDC statement.

CDC Deputy Director General Chou Chih-hau said a rat had been caught on the grounds near the factory in Cianjhen where the man worked and that laboratory tests were being conducted to determine whether the rat was carrying the virus..

Hantavirus is found in the urine, saliva and droppings of infected city or field rats and some other rodents. The diseases caused by the virus, including hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) , are listed in Taiwan as second- degree infectious diseases that pose a moderate public health risk.
Taiwan has reported 10 cases of Hantavirus since 2001, according to CDC data.

The CDC said extermination of rats is the best way to prevent the disease since people could become ill by inhaling virus-carrying dust, being bitten by rats, or touching objects polluted by the droppings or urine of infected rodents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Appointments at state-run firms follow strict procedures: Official

TEXT.P: Personnel appointments and promotions at state-run enterprises strictly follow standard procedures, and such appointments were based mainly on internal evaluations at each company, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Wednesday.

Shieh made the remarks at a press conference, on behalf of Chen Chin-jun, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan who is reportedly involved in a scandal concerning the proposed appointment of Huang Fu-yuan, manager of the Taipei North Branch under the Taiwan Power Co.(Taipower), as the company's vice chairman.

The proposed appointment of Huang, reportedly on the recommendation of Chen Chin-jun, has sparked criticism after opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Ching-hua claimed that Huang had paid a bribe of NT$20 million (US$655,737) to secure the position.

Edward K. M. Chen, president of Taipower, said that it was likely he would be forced to resign from his post because he did not endorse Huang's appointment. The Ministry of Economic Affairs on Wednesday admonished him for opposing Huang's appointment.
Earlier in the day, Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen revealed during an interpellation at the Legislative Yuan that "he had been asked by Chen Chin-jun to handle (Huang's appointment)."
Rebutting the accusations that the vice chairmanship of Taiwpower could be bought, the minister nonetheless ordered an investigation into the matter.

Meanwhile, Shieh insisted that Chen Chin-jun's recommendation of Huang was "normal, " stressing that Chen Chin-jun did not know Huang personally and that the government often receives recommendations from various sources whenever a position is available.
"As long as the person is competent, the Executive Yuan would consider the recommendation," he added.
Shieh, however, failed to elaborate on why Chen Chin-jun would recommend someone he did not know for the Taipower post.
"Decisions regarding recruitment lie with the personnel departments in the state-run companies... and no one can manipulate the employment process," Shieh said.
Discounting Lee's accusations, Shieh said the lawmaker "should provide further evidence in this matter instead of making indiscriminate statements."

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH warns travelers to Vietnam to beware of cholera outbreak

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) on Wednesday urged people to be on the alert during any trips to Vietnam, as 85 confirmed cases of cholera have been reported in that country.

Chou Chih-hao, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said that with the increasing exchanges between Taiwan and Vietnam, people visiting the Southeast Asian country should wash their hands frequently and refrain from eating uncooked food.
Chou said the cases of cholera, including fatalities, had been reported mainly in 10 areas in northern Vietnam, including Hanoi and Hai Phong.

Among the 85 confirmed cases, 44 people lived in Hanoi, all of whom reported that they had eaten uncooked food or vegetables, Chou said, noting that Vietnamese authorities had found vibrio cholerae, the bacteria that causes the disease, in rivers, ponds and vegetables.
He said that there have been no reported cases of cholera in Taiwan for two consecutive years, and that there have been only chronic cases in the country over the past decade.
Since Taiwan business people are major investors in Vietnam and Vietnamese nationals are the biggest group of foreign spouses in Taiwan, the DOH had to issue the warning, Chou added.

Cholera is an acute type of gastroenteritis caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. The bacterial infection of the small intestines can be mild with no symptoms, but in severe cases it can cause massive diarrhea, vomiting and leg cramps. Approximately one in 20 infected persons develop the severe form of the disease and the rapid loss of body fluids leads to dehydration and shock. Without treatment, death can occur within hours, as cholera is one of the most rapidly fatal illnesses known.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker questions justification of U.S. container security program

TEXT.P: A legislator of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) asked the Ministry of Justice Wednesday to investigate why a container security program at the southern seaport of Kaohsiung, aimed at preventing weapons of mass destruction from reaching U.S. territory, should be carried out at Taiwan's expense.

Legislator Lu Hsiu-yen reminded Chien Liang-chi, head of the Directorate General of Customs under the Ministry of Finance, at a legislative session that the container security program at Kaohsiung harbor is not based on the principal of reciprocity, nor on mutual respect for sovereignty.

Chien admitted earlier to another KMT legislator, Liao Cheng-ching, that about 10 U.S. officials are currently stationed in the port city for the anti- terrorism program, and that the Directorate General of Customs had paid for the container X-ray facilities.

Chien said the two large imaging machines purchased in 2005 for NT$180 million (US$5.9 million) turned out to be unusable, and that two other advanced machines acquired in October 2007 for NT$240 million are still not in use after undergoing test runs.

Lu criticized the Ministry of Finance for wasting public funds and allowing the nation's sovereignty to be infringed upon by another country. She urged the Ministry of Justice to investigate the inappropriate spending.

In 2002 after the 9-11 terrorist attacks, the U.S. Customs and Border Protection proposed the Container Security Initiative aimed at ensuring that all containers that could pose a potential risk of terrorism are identified and inspected at foreign ports before they are destined for the Unite States.

The program has stationed multidisciplinary teams of officers to work with host foreign government counterparts to target and prescreen containers, using automated facilities and radiation detection devices at major seaports around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Imported dengue fever reported in one family: DOH

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) confirmed the first imported cluster cases of dengue fever discovered in a family Wednesday.
Chou Chih-hao, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said the patients were four children born to a Tongese mother who was married to a Taiwanese man living in Taipei County.
Chou said the mother took her four children to visit Tonga, a South Pacific island nation near New Zealand, and brought the children back to Taiwan on March 24.
Her 4-year-old son was detected to have fever at the airport and was confirmed to have been infected with the mosquito-borne disease.
Taipei County health authorities then took specimen from the mother and her three daughters aged 8, 10, 13. Tests confirmed that the three sisters were also infected, although the mother was not.
But "only one sister showed the symptom of fever on March 28, and the two others had no symptoms," Chou said, adding that all four children recovered after taking medicine.
The centers estimated that there have been 24 imported dengue fever cases so far this year, compared with only 15 imported cases during the same period last year.
Among the 24 cases, 10 were from Indonesia, four each were from the Philippines and Tonga, three from Vietnam, one each from India and Malaysia and the source of another case was unclear.

Chou said that dengue fever outbreaks were reported in Southeast Asia and the South Pacific with fatalities this year, urging the public to take precautionary measures against mosquito bites when traveling to those countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: University signs cooperative pacts with Vietnamese schools

TEXT.P: Taipei-based Tatung University (TTU) has recently signed agreements with four Vietnamese educational institutions to boost cooperation in manpower cultivation, a TTU official said Wednesday.

The four Vietnamese institutions are the Ho Chi Minh City University of Pedagogy (HCMCUP), the International Business and Law Academy, the Hanoi University of Business and Technology (HUBT) and the Hanoi National University of Education, the official stated.

TTU -- affiliated with Tatung Co., a long-established manufacturer of electrical and digital consumer products -- has collaborated with the company in designing projects to train TTU students in various occupational skills, the official went on.

TTU has decided to seek talent using the projects to cultivate students from the Vietnamese educational institutions in the hope that the talent can serve as new blood for the company's Vietnamese operations, according to the official.

Meanwhile, the HUBT has decided to recommend 15 students to the TTU in the next semester to study for master's and doctoral degrees, while the HCMCUP has not only decided to send six graduates to the company's Vietnam offices in the near future, but will also launch a project in which 30 HCMCUP students per semester will work as interns there.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 Taiwan eateries to exhibit Taiwanese delicacies in Hong Kong

TEXT.P: Ten Taiwanese eateries will show off their culinary arts at a three-day "Taiwan night market festival" in Hong Kong April 11-13, according to the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
The festival will be held as part of the bureau's Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009. The event will take place in the East Point City Shopping Arcade at Tseung Kwan O in Hong Kong's New Territory.

Nine eateries from the southern city of Tainan will present a wide range of typical Taiwanese delicacies, usually found at night markets around Taiwan, while another exhibitor from Hsinchu will present a special kind of pork meatballs known as gung wan.

According to tourism officials, in addition to a Taiwanese night market street, the 7,000 square-meter exhibition ground will also feature a Taiwan food square, an area for a Taiwan travel expo and two areas designated for stage performances and a photo exhibition of Taiwan scenery.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 10, 2008

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairman urges younger generation to run for chairmanship

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh is encouraging younger party members to run for the party chairmanship in the election scheduled for May 18, a DPP official said Wednesday.

DPP Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan, quoting Hsieh's remarks during a regular meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee, said the chairman encouraged the young people to "take up the responsibility, as whoever takes over the post will face a tough task ahead."
According to Lee, the party has been in disarray since it suffered two major setbacks in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the March 22 presidential poll.
Hsieh has invited more members, especially those under 50, to register for the party chairmanship election, Lee said.

Lee said that, in accordance with DPP election guidelines, consultations will be held among the hopefuls after the registration process, and if a leader is not selected, then an election will be held.
The DPP will hold an event May 10 for hopefuls to present their platforms, and will invite young people to raise questions, in an effort to involve younger party members in the process, Lee said.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, one of the seven local DPP heads in southern Taiwan, said that it is best to produce a party chairman through consultation, and suggested that former Presidential Office Secretary-General Chen Shih-meng is one of the best candidates.
"An election is likely to lead to protracted squabbling and that could extend the time it would take the DPP to regain power," Yang said.
To date, no one within the DPP has openly expressed an intention to run for the chairmanship.

Hsieh said during a meeting with the media Tuesday night that the party should pass the baton to the younger generation, suggesting that Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung and former DPP legislator Lo Wen-jia should throw their hats into the ring.
"Those city and county chiefs who will step down at the end of next year are also potential candidates," Hsieh said.

On the future of the party, Hsieh said that the incoming Kuomintang (KMT) administration would be happy to see the DPP and other parties splinter into three or four equally weak groups so that it could maintain its grip on the power for a long time.
But he also said that after the KMT takes over, it will face problems as the electorate in the urban areas will become discontented and will complain.

The city and county chief election in late 2009 is a major poll, but it is not expected to result in much change, he said, adding that the more crucial elections will be the presidential and legislative polls in four years' time.
As for his future plans, Hsieh, 62, said that he has been dedicated to the democratic movement since he was in his 30s, and that the younger generation should now lead the party.
Having served as premier and Kaohsiung mayor, Hsieh said, he is very familiar with government operations and budgets.
"I will use my experience to help monitor the government via the Internet," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Offenders of high-tech export law to face harsher penalties

TEXT.P: Violators of the strategic high-tech export control regulations will face harsher penalties under the revised trade law, Executive Yuan officials said Wednesday.

According to a draft package of amendments to the trade law approved by the Executive Yuan at its weekly meeting held earlier in the day, those who violate the relevant regulations by exporting banned strategic technologies and products to certain rogue countries may face amaximum five-year prison sentence plus a maximum fine of NT$1.5 million, the officials said.
Under the existing regulations, the maximum penalty for offenders is a two-year prison term plus a fine of NT$300,000.

The more stringent punishments are aimed at more effectively preventing some sensitive technologies and products from falling into the hands of terrorist groups or rogue countries and prevent proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, the officials said, adding that the draft package will take effect after being approved by the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open marginally higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened marginally higher Thursday.
The weighted price index was up 14.17 points at 8,682.10 on a turnover of NT$2.92 billion (US$95.85 million) at the open. The index lost 4.92 points, or 0.05 percent, to close at 8,667.93 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Thursday.
The greenback was trading at NT$30.377 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.088 from Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 10, or the fifth day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: James V of Scotland, who became king at the age of 17 months, is born. He allied Scotland with France against the English.
1810: Pirate chieftainess "Dragon Lady" Cheng Yi-sao surrenders herself and the 1,800 junks under her command to China's Ching court.
1814: British and Spanish forces defeat Napoleon's army at the Battle of Toulouse, leading to his abdication and exile to the island of Elba the next day.
1829: William Booth, the British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army with his wife Catherine Mumford Booth and who served as its first general, is born.
1847: Hungarian-born American journalist Joseph Pulitzer is born. The newspaper publisher owned newspapers in St. Louis and New York City and established and endowed the Pulitzer Prizes for achievements in journalism and literature.
1858: Chinese Governor-General Ye Ming-chen of Canton and a prisoner of Britain, dies in Calcutta during an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing in 1858.
1898: France obtains concessions from China's Ching court.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected president of the Republic of China.
1932: German general and politician Paul von Hindenburg is re-elected president of the Weimar Republic with 19 million votes to Adolf Hitler's 13 million. He appoints Hitler chancellor in 1933.
1938: More than 99 percent of Austrian voters in a referendum cast their ballots in favor of a merger with Germany.
1944: Brigadier General Charles de Gaulle, who is number one on the hit list of the collaborationist Vichy government of Marshal Petain, becomes commander-in- chief of all the Free French forces.
1946: Japan holds general elections with women voting for the first time.
1953: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the resignation of Taiwan Governor Wu Kuo- chen and names Yu Hung-chun as his replacement.
1958: Dr. Hu Shih assumes office as president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1960: The U.S. Senate passes the Civil Rights Bill.
1963: The USS Thresher, an American atomic submarine, sinks in the northern Atlantic, killing all 290 aboard.
1971: Ethnic Chinese hold a mass rally in Washington, D.C., to show their support for the protection of a disputed territory known to the Chinese as the Tiaoyutai Islands.
1972: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Tonga.
1972: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty banning biological warfare.
1976: Miguel Urrutia Montoya, director of the national planning department of the Republic of Colombia, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs legislation permitting continued commercial and cultural relations between the American government and the ROC following the break in their diplomatic ties.
1980: Mainland China and the Soviet Union end a friendship pact they signed in 1950.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan's Middle East peace plan collapses when King Hussein of Jordan fails to reach an accord with the Palestine Liberation Organization on the terms of the deal.
1986: The United States conducts a nuclear test in the Nevada desert.
1991: Georgia becomes the latest of the Soviet republics wishing to break away from central control.
1996: Mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng's visit to France is marred by a diplomatic wrangle with his French counterpart Alain Juppe over human rights in Beijing.
2000: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on David Dean, former Taipei director of the American Institute in Taiwan.
2001: The 13th annual convention of the Overseas Chinese Council in Asia opens in Osaka, Japan, with more than 400 delegates from the Asia-Pacific region participating.
2002: Vice President Annette Lu wins a civil suit against the Taipei-based Journalist weekly, for damage to her image arising from a false report carried by the magazine.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who possesses moral worth will always have something to say worth listening to, but a man who has something to say is not necessarily a man of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker questions justification of U.S. container security program

TEXT.P: A legislator of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) asked the Ministry of Justice Wednesday to investigate why a container security program at the southern seaport of Kaohsiung, aimed at preventing weapons of mass destruction from reaching U.S. territory, should be carried out at Taiwan's expense.

Legislator Lu Hsiu-yen reminded Chien Liang-chi, head of the Directorate General of Customs under the Ministry of Finance, at a legislative session that the container security program at Kaohsiung harbor is not based on the principal of reciprocity, nor on mutual respect for sovereignty.

Chien admitted earlier to another KMT legislator, Liao Cheng-ching, that about 10 U.S. officials are currently stationed in the port city for the anti- terrorism program, and that the Directorate General of Customs had paid for the container X-ray facilities.

Chien said the two large imaging machines purchased in 2005 for NT$180 million (US$5.9 million) turned out to be unusable, and that two other advanced machines acquired in October 2007 for NT$240 million are still not in use after undergoing test runs.

Lu criticized the Ministry of Finance for wasting public funds and allowing the nation's sovereignty to be infringed upon by another country. She urged the Ministry of Justice to investigate the inappropriate spending.

In 2002 after the 9-11 terrorist attacks, the U.S. Customs and Border Protection proposed the Container Security Initiative aimed at ensuring that all containers that could pose a potential risk of terrorism are identified and inspected at foreign ports before they are destined for the Unite States.

The program has stationed multidisciplinary teams of officers to work with host foreign government counterparts to target and prescreen containers, using automated facilities and radiation detection devices at major seaports around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH warns travelers to Vietnam to beware of cholera outbreak

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) on Wednesday urged people to be on the alert during any trips to Vietnam, as 85 confirmed cases of cholera have been reported in that country.

Chou Chih-hao, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said that with the increasing exchanges between Taiwan and Vietnam, people visiting the Southeast Asian country should wash their hands frequently and refrain from eating uncooked food.
Chou said the cases of cholera, including fatalities, had been reported mainly in 10 areas in northern Vietnam, including Hanoi and Hai Phong.

Among the 85 confirmed cases, 44 people lived in Hanoi, all of whom reported that they had eaten uncooked food or vegetables, Chou said, noting that Vietnamese authorities had found vibrio cholerae, the bacteria that causes the disease, in rivers, ponds and vegetables.
He said that there have been no reported cases of cholera in Taiwan for two consecutive years, and that there have been only chronic cases in the country over the past decade.
Since Taiwan business people are major investors in Vietnam and Vietnamese nationals are the biggest group of foreign spouses in Taiwan, the DOH had to issue the warning, Chou added.

Cholera is an acute type of gastroenteritis caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. The bacterial infection of the small intestines can be mild with no symptoms, but in severe cases it can cause massive diarrhea, vomiting and leg cramps. Approximately one in 20 infected persons develop the severe form of the disease and the rapid loss of body fluids leads to dehydration and shock. Without treatment, death can occur within hours, as cholera is one of the most rapidly fatal illnesses known.

DOC.HEADLINE: President wants to make cycling national sport

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian proposed Thursday that the government work with the private sector to map out a bicycle path network around Taiwan to help make cycling a national sport.
Chen raised the issue in an article published in the latest issue of his online newsletter, in which he commented on Earth Day, which falls on April 22.
Chen noted that the world is paying increasing attention to Earth Day, as global warming has adversely impacted on the environment and the earth's ecological system in recent years.
Against this backdrop, bicycles, which do not produce carbon dioxide, has become a popular means of transport in many European countries, such as the Netherlands, Chen pointed out.

Although there is an increasing number of people in Taiwan who ride bicycles to work and enjoy cycling as a pastime on weekends, cycling is still not as popular in Taiwan as in Europe, the United States and Japan, he said.
"Cycling would become more popular if the government and the private sector could be more creative," he said.

Pointing out that some people in Taiwan recently completed a cycling tour around the island, the president suggested that senior high school students be encouraged to make a round-the-island cycling trip before they graduate.

According to Chen, such a tour will not only provide an opportunity for the students to test their patience and willpower, but will also allow them to become more familiar with the land in which they live and to recognize the importance of protecting the environment and the ecological system.

DOC.HEADLINE: FTC fines architectural firm NT$5.5 million for misleading ad

TEXT.P: The Fair Trade Commission fined the local construction company RSL Architecture NT$5.5 million (US$180,328) Thursday for misleading consumers with an advertisement for real estate showing residential buildings on land specified for industrial use.

The RSL commercial advertisement shows spaces such as living rooms and kitchens superimposed on a blueprint of the land, an image that could lead potential buyers to think that the property could be used for residential purposes, according to FTC Commissioner Chou Ya-shu.

This advertisement could cost buyers considerable trouble because the construction of any residential buildings on the property would be illegal and the owners may be forced to redesign or even demolish the buildings,said Chou at a press conference.
The FTC will also order the company to revise the advertisement, which is in violation of the Fair Trade Law, she indicated.

The FTC cautioned that investors should ensure that any land they purchase can be legally developed as intended, especially as Taiwan's real estate is likely to become more popular thanks to the incoming government's promise to allow Chinese buyers to purchase property in Taiwan.
Buyers need to watch out for potential risks in case some companies try to take (illegal) advantage of the anticipated higher demand,said Brain Chang, an FTC section chief.
The FTC said there had been no response from RSL to the fine, to date, but that the company might appeal for a reversal of the FTC ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices surged Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 161.47 points, or 1.86 percent, to close at 8,829.4.

The bourse opened at 8,682.1 and fluctuated between 8,829.4 and 8,681.89 during the day's session. A total of 4.98 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$130.94 billion (US$4.32 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues gaining the most at 3.2 percent. Paper and pulp issues advanced 2.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and machinery and electronics shares both rose 2 percent, banking and financial shares increased 1.7 percent, cement stocks and textile stocks both gained 1.4 percent, and foodstuff issues rose 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,581 to 601, with 339 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$5.86 billion.
