Former premier and leader of the center-right People of Liberty Party Silvio Berlusconi criticized President Giorgio Napolitano for being in support of the nation's left-wing forces. He said that Napolitano was elected by the leftist.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua magistrate visits Japanese mayor to promote exchanges
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 9 (CNA) 04/10/08 16:02:02 (By Mike Chang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan promoted the central Taiwan county's long-stay tourism initiative during ameeting Wednesday with Katsuhiko Umehara, mayor of Sendai City in Japan, and shared his views on issues of mutual concern.
Cho, who is leading a delegation of county officials and councilors on the visit, also reached an agreement with Umehara, during their one-hour meeting, on enhancing bilateral exchanges.
Umehara said that both Sendai and Changhua are middle-size municipalities and one of the main goals of the two governments is to press forward with local development.
The mayor also expressed the hope that the meeting between the two sides would help promote mutual understanding and further exchanges in the future.
Cho, in turn, noted that Changhua County has engaged in frequent interactions with Japan over the past few years, and cited the example of the county government's visit to Hokkaido, Japan last year.

The magistrate touted the attractions of his county's newly developed long-stay tourism plan to the Japanese mayor, urging that Japanese visitors, especially those from the colder regions, should travel to Taiwan and enjoy Changhua's fine weather.

Cho said that on its current trip, his delegation will call on Sendai City's Finland Wellbeing Center to draw on the Japanese experience for Changhua County's plan to establish a health park, and will visit a business center and an international conference center in the city.

Noting that Changhua County and Tainan City in southern Taiwan were among the first areas in the country to be developed, and that Tainan has forged sisterhood ties with Sendai City, Cho expressed hope that his county would also form closer links with the Japanese city.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former finance minister indicted for violating revolving-door ban

TEXT.P: Former Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang, who became chairman of Fuhwa Financial Holding Co. soon after his retirement from public service in 2005, was indicted Thursday for violating a revolving-door ban.

Under the terms of the Civil Service Act, former civil servants are banned from taking top positions in any company they supervised during the five-year period before their retirement from the service.
Violators of the law may be subject to a maximum sentence of two years in jail plus a fine of up to NT$1 million, and could also have their earnings from the jobs confiscated, according to the law.
The banned positions listed under the law are chairman, supervisor, manager, shareholder and consultant.

The Taipei District Prosecutors Office noted in its indictment that Yen served as Minister of Finance from Oct. 6, 2000 to Jan. 31, 2002 before being appointed as Taiwan's representative to the World Trade Organization on Feb. 1, 2002, a position he held until March 23, 2005.

However, less than three months after retiring from the public service, Yen in June 2005 assumed chairmanship of Fuhwa Financial Holding Co., an enterprise that was given approval for establishment by the Ministry of Finance on Dec. 31, 2001 when Yen was head of the MOF, the indictment stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Debt-ridden airline regrets flop of liquor firm's investment offer

TEXT.P: Far Eastern Air Transport (FAT) , one of the local airlines that have been hard hit by a downturn in domestic air travel, said Thursday it regretted that a proposal by a potential investor to give it a much needed shot in the arm had not taken off.

Shih Chien-hua, an FAT planning manager, made the remarks after learning that the Kinmen County Council had voted earlier in the day -- 10-6, with two abstentions -- to turn down a proposal by county government-owned Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor Inc. (KKL) to invest in FAT.

Shih however added that an FAT shareholders' meeting will take place as scheduled Friday and that the meeting is expected to pass a proposal to increase the airline's capital to ease its dire financial situation.
Shih said that two vacant board director seats are also expected to be filled during the meeting. The board will then contact interested parties on the possibility of investment, he said.
He declined to identify the potential investors, saying only that "they are from home and abroad."

KKL's new chairwoman, former legislator Joanna Lei, contacted FAT last month with a proposal to inject between NT$2.2 billion (US$66.58 million) and NT$2.75 billion into the company in exchange for a 40 percent stake.
Lei said she was hoping that the investment would benefit Kinmen, which lies closer to China than to Taiwan, and help to provide its residents with more convenient transportation options.
Upon learning that the KKL investment proposal had been rejected, both Lei and Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng said they "respect the majority decision by the county council."

KKL, which is run by the Kinmen local government, enjoys an annual turnover of more than NT$11 billion, with its famous sorghum liquor enjoying the largest domestic market share in the white rum business.

FAT, Taiwan's oldest privately owned airline, celebrated its 50th anniversary in November 2007. Its financial crisis first came to light in February when a fuel payment check for NT$151 million bounced and it was disclosed that FAT was also unable to pay its landing fees.
The airline filed for bankruptcy protection Feb. 15 after reporting debts of NT$9.99 billion at the end of September 2007.
It won a 90-day stay in bankruptcy from the Taipei District Court Feb. 22. Since then the airline has been seeking investors willing to take over its huge debts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up 143 points to close at 8,819, with 69,420 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May rose 128 points to finish at 8,778, with 3,942 contracts traded, while June futures increased 128 points to close at 8,762, with 51 contract transactions.
September futures gained 136 points to finish at 8,534, with 67 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 98 points to close at 8,473, with 41 contracts traded.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 161.47 points Thursday to finish at 8,829.4, with a market turnover of NT$130.94 billion (US$4.32 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 8,676 for April; 8,650 for May; 8,634 for June; 8,398 for September and 8,375 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were both higher.
April TE futures gained 5.25 points to close at 333.25, with 4,158 contracts traded, while May TE futures rose five points to finish at 332, with 282 contract transactions.

June TE futures moved up 3.15 points to close at 331.15, with four contracts traded, while September TE futures rose 6.55 points to finish at 328.4, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December.
April TF futures increased 22.4 points to close at 1,158.4, with 4,457 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures moved up 17.8 points to finish at 1,151, with 938 contracts traded.
June TF futures rose 5.4 points to close at 1,136.2, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Record number of diplomatic allies to attend inauguration: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that, so far, 17 of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies had confirmed that they would be represented at President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's inauguration ceremony May 20, setting a new record.

"It is a very good sign that 17 heads of state and vice presidents have already committed to attending the inauguration ceremony, which shows a high degree of goodwill and is a very positive development, " Foreign Minister James Huang said after briefing President-elect Ma and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew on Taiwan's current diplomatic circumstances.

Speaking at a meeting of the Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee of the Legislative Yuan, MOFA's Deputy Minister Yang Tzu-pao also said that one king, eight presidents, three governor-generals, two prime ministers and three vice presidents had confirmed that they would attend the ceremony.

The leaders are the king of Swaziland; the presidents of Palau, Kiribati, the Marshall Islands, Burkina Faso, Sao Tome and Principe, Honduras, El Salvador, and Paraguay; the governor-generals of the Solomon Islands, Saint Kitts and Nevis, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines; the prime ministers of Tuvalu and Belize; and the vice presidents of the Gambia, Guatemala and Nicaragua.
"The ceremony will be simple and solemn and will be held in accordance with diplomatic protocol," Yang said.

He told the CNA that the number of foreign dignitaries scheduled to attend President-elect Ma's inauguration is "more than at previous inaugurations, setting a historic record," and that many other countries that do not have diplomatic ties with Taiwan will also send envoys and delegates to the ceremony.

Regarding speculations that the United States might send a high- ranking official to attend the ceremony as a salve following its rejection of Ma's request to visit the U.S. before taking office, Yang did not respond directly, saying only that the MOFA hopes countries, with or without diplomatic relations with Taiwan, would send high-ranking officials.

Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-pao said he hoped the MOFA would do its best to invite dignitaries like former U.S. President Bill Clinton and former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to the May 20 inauguration. Yang said anything is possible and the MOFA will do all that it can.

Ma's decisive victory on March 22 was welcomed by the international community, and many countries, even those without diplomatic ties to Taiwan, have congratulated Ma with high hopes that relations between Taiwan and China will improve.
U.S. President George W. Bush also issued a statement right after the election to congratulate Ma, and praised Taiwan as a beacon of democracy in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Subsidies to builders should be decided by incoming government: PCC

TEXT.P: A high-ranking official in charge of public construction said Thursday that the planned government subsidies to contractors of public construction project should be decided by the incoming government to be inaugurated May 20.

Lee Wu-hsiung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission (PCC) , made the remarks at a meeting with a group of petitioners led by Pan Chun-jung, chairman of the Taiwan Regional Engineering Contractors Association (TRECA) , who mobilized thousands of builders to protest against the government's failure to offer them subsidies amid soaring construction material prices.
Lee said that as the issue will involve huge sums of money, the PCC will leave the decision to the incoming government of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou.

The TRECA also launched a one-day strike Thursday demanding that the government fulfill a promise it made before the March 22 presidential election to subsidize builders of public construction projects in light of the increasing prices of building materials.

Many builders complained that they can hardly survive at a time when the cost of almost all construction materials has risen, and some even claimed that they were losing money even though business had increased.
According to the builders' estimates, Thursday's strike will cost them some 2 billion (US$65.8 million).

Pan claimed that the PCC and TRECA had reached a consensus before the presidential election that the government would lower the subsidy threshold from 2.5 percent of construction material price hikes, and had agreed that the subsidies would be granted if the price increases exceeded 1.5 percent.
For some specific items, the PCC promised to lower the threshold from 10 percent to 2.5 percent, according to Pan.

Pan described as ridiculous and irresponsible the PCC's decision to leave the matter to the incoming government at a time when many public construction projects remained idle as builders do not want to bid for them and the construction firms can hardly survive.
TRECA members urged the government to fulfill its promise to the builders, otherwise, they would mobilize more people, trucks and bulldozers to stage a street protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: Heightened alert urged against Kawasaki disease

TEXT.P: Pediatricians called Thursday for a heightened alert in Taiwan this season against the occurrence of Kawasaki disease, an illness that often strikes young children under the age of five.

Kawasaki disease, also known as lymph node syndrome or Kawasaki syndrome, is a leading cause of acquired heart disease in children in Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan, as well as in children in the rest of the world of oriental extraction, said Lu Hung-chi, executive director of the Cardiac Children's Foundation Taiwan.

Children, particularly those under five living in Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, are prone to Kawasaki disease in the months between April and June every year, Lu said in a speech delivered at the Ninth International Kawasaki Disease Symposium that opened at the Grand Hotel in Taipei Thursday.

First described in 1967 by Dr. Tomisaku Kawasaki in Japan, the disease is a poorly understood self-limited vasculitis that affects many organs, including the skin and mucous membranes, lymph nodes, blood vessel walls, and the heart.

Lu said that parents and pediatricians should pay extra attention if children in their care have a fever for more than five days and show other symptoms such as a rash, swollen hands and feet, red eyes, swollen lymph glands in the neck, and irritation and inflammation of the mouth, lips and throat.
In Taiwan, about 66 out of every 100,000 children under five have been affected by Kawasaki disease, compared to 188 in Japan and 105 in South Korea, Lu said.
He said that the number of Kawasaki disease cases in Taiwan has gradually increased over the past 10 years, with 800 to 1,000 cases being diagnosed annually in the last two years.

"In the absence of proper treatment, as many as 20-30 percent of the children with Kawasaki disease could suffer complications that affect the heart, " Lu said. "Their coronary arteries and heart muscles could be damaged."

Doctors still do not know what causes Kawasaki disease, but it appears not to be hereditary or contagious. Researchers who have studied the illness think evidence strongly suggests that is caused by an infectious agent such as a virus. It is very rare for more than one child in a family to develop Kawasaki disease and less than 2 percent of children have a repeat attack.
Wu Mei-huan, a leading pediatrician at National Taiwan University Hospital, said at the symposium that Kawasaki disease is not easily diagnosed, as many of its symptoms are similar to those of flu.
"Doctors are encouraged to use endocardiography to diagnose the little patient, if a child presents with four to five symptoms of typical Kawasaki disease," Wu added.

Even though the cause of Kawasaki disease is unknown, certain medicines are known to help, according to members of the Cardiac Children's Foundation Taiwan. Aspirin is often used to reduce fever, rash, joint inflammation and pain, and to help prevent blood clots. Another treatment, intravenous gamma globulin, can help decrease the risk of developing coronary artery abnormalities if administered during the early stages of the illness, they said.
Dr. Tomisaku Kawasaki was at the opening of the symposium Thursday, which also brought together 27 leading pediatricians from around the world.
A total of 274 research papers by specialists from 20 countries are expected to be read or presented during the three-day symposium.

DOC.HEADLINE: All four commercial harbors ready for direct cross-strait links

TEXT.P: The heads of Taiwan's four commercial ports said unanimously Thursday that they are ready for direct cross-strait transportation links between Taiwan and China.
They were responding to questions by Legislator Yang Chiung-ying of the Kuomintang at a legislative committee meeting regarding whether they have made adequate preparations for the links.
President-elect Ma Ying-jeou declared recently that he would open full direct cross-strait transportation links between Taiwan and mainland China after he assumes office on May 20.
Keelung Harbor Bureau Director-General Hsiao Ting-hsun said there will be no difficulty for the harbor in northern Taiwan to deal with cross-strait transportation, noting that "all is set."
Taichung Harbor Bureau Director-General Lee Lung-wen said that the harbor in central Taiwan was ready nine years ago, and "is waiting for the government to give the green light."

Lee also said that the harbor has conducted a test, which showed that four vessels could navigate the harbor within two hours. He ADDED THAT an estimated 4,000 passengers can travel through the port each day.

Taichung currently allows direct cross-strait transportation links during religious festivals to ease travel, such as for followers of Matsu, a revered sea goddess in Taiwan and China, so they can directly travel through the harbor to China without having to go through a third destination.
Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau Director-General Hsieh Ming-hui said that as an international harbor, the harbor in southern Taiwan is ready to accept passengers and cargoes from all corners of the world.
Hualien Harbor Bureau Director-General Wang Chung-hsiung said with confidence that the harbor in eastern Taiwan is "all ready."
President-elect Ma has said that he would open Taiwan to direct cross-strait transportation links and allow 3,000 Chinese tourists to come to Taiwan daily after July 1.

Currently, due to sour relations between China and the current Taiwanese administration, only direct "mini" links are allowed between Taiwan's outlying islands and a few cities in China's Fujian province and only certain people qualify to take those convenient routes.
Direct chartered flights between Taiwan and China are allowed only on special holidays to enable Taiwanese business people and their families to easily return to Taiwan.
Most others who want to travel from Taiwan to China and back must go through a third destination - usually Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: Israeli mayor's wife commends trip to Taiwan as 'remarkable'

TEXT.P: Yael Huldai, the wife of the mayor of the Israeli city of Tel Aviv-Yafo said in a written statement issued Thursday that her April 1-7 visit to Taiwan was "remarkable."
Huldai made the remarks in response to a written interview by CNA following her first-ever visit to Taiwan.

She accompanied the troupes Habimah National Theatre of Israel and Cameri Theatre of Tel Aviv, which performed at Taiwan's National Theater in downtown Taipei as part of its International Theater Festival.
In the statement, Huldai said she enjoyed every moment she has spent in Taiwan.
"The warm welcome of local people and the beauty of your national treasures displayed at the National Palace Museum all make my visit remarkable," she said.

Huldai further commended Taiwan'sscultural achievements after visiting the Contemporary Legend Theater, the Legend Lin Dance Theater and the U-Theatre, saying that she was touched by the great culture and creativity of Taiwan while viewing works at these theaters.
Huldai's husband Yael Huldai, mayor of the City of Tel Aviv - Yafo, hosted Taiwan's President-elect Ma Ying-jeou in 1999, when Ma was Taipei's mayor.
Huldai expressed her wish for Taiwan'ssparticipation in the Centennial Celebration of City of Tel Aviv - Yafo in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. presidential candidates congratulate ROC president-elect

TEXT.P: All three U.S. presidential candidates have extended congratulations to President-elect Ma Ying-jeou on his March 22 election win, a ranking official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

Presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama of the Democratic Party and Republican John McCain have all offered congratulations to Ma and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew in public statements made on the campaign trail, said Christine Hsueh, deputy director-general of the MOFA Department of North American Affairs.
In a speech delivered in Chicago March 22, Obama said that he offered his congratulations to Ma and best wishes for his presidency.

"The people of Taiwan deserve our respect and admiration for this free and fair election, which is just the latest step in consolidating a democracy that has advanced over the last two decades," Obama said.

"I hope the People's Republic of China responds to this election in a positive, constructive and forward-leaning way. It is important for Beijing to demonstrate to the people of Taiwan that the practical and non-confrontational approach that President-elect Ma promises to take toward the Mainland will be met with good faith and progress, " he said.
Obama said the PRC should reduce the military threat to Taiwan by drawing back the missiles it has deployed in southeast China and by other security confidence-building measures.
He said on issues such as Taiwan's observer status in the World Health Organization, where the health of all Chinese people is at stake, it should allow Taiwan greater international space.

"The United States should respond to Ma Ying-jeou's election by rebuilding a relationship of trust and support for Taiwan's democracy. The U.S. should reopen blocked channels of communication with Taiwan officials. We should continue to provide the arms necessary for Taiwan to deter possible aggression," he said.

At a regular press conference Thursday, Hsueh said the White House and the U.S. Department of State had offered congratulations to Ma and Siew almost immediately after the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) ticket won the poll.
A total of 56 members of the U.S. Congress have also extended congratulations to Ma and Siew, either by sending congratulatory letters or in open statements, Hsueh added.

She noted that the 56 members included leaders of the Congress such as Speaker of the House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) , Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) , Senate Republican Whip Jon Kyl (R-Ariz.) , and House Republican Whip Roy Blunt (R-Mo.).
In addition, she said, three state governors and three deputy governors, as well as speakers of many state assemblies have also sent congratulatory messages to Ma and Siew on the KMT's victory.
On the question of who might represent Washington at Ma's inauguration on May 20, Hsueh said the U.S. government has yet to make a final decision.
The United States sent a delegation to Taiwan to attend the presidential inauguration ceremonies in 2000 and 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect's visit a formality: MAC chairman

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Thursday that a visit by the president-elect and vice president-elect to the MAC earlier that day was a formality.
Chen, the country's top China policy planner, did not elaborate on the details of the closed-door meeting with the two incoming leaders, saying only that it went smoothly.
Chen made the remarks after briefing President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew on the current state of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Chen said that the briefing session was held at the instruction of President Chen Shui-bian and that the MAC had done its best to give Ma and Siew a detailed report on cross-strait matters.
The briefing was a formality established after the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) came to power in 2000, the MAC chief added.

Ma and Siew were accompanied by Kao Lang, a professor of political science at National Taiwan University who is tipped to take over as chairman of the MAC, and by Su Chi who served in that position between 1999 and 2000 when the Kuomintang was in power. Su is tipped to be the National Security Council secretary-general of Ma's administration.
Ma and Siew, who won the March 22 presidential election with 7,658,724 votes, or 58.45 percent of the ballots cast, will take office on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Thai New Year to be celebrated with carnivals

TEXT.P: A carnival celebrating Songkran Festival--or the Thai New Year--will take place this weekend in Kaohsiung County to help foreign workers from Thailand ease homesickness, an activity organizer said at a news conference Thursday.

The carnival, to be jointly organized by governments of Kaohsiung County, Kaohsiung City, and Pingtung County in southern Taiwan, will be held at the Kaohsiung County's Labor Recreation Center from April 13-15. It will mark the first time for the the three local governments to hold such an activity. Kaohsiung County held its first such carnival last year alone, drawing 1,000 participants.
According to Sung Ting-tung, director of Kaohsiung County's Labor Affairs Bureau, the Songkran Festival is celebrated every year in Thailand from April 13-15.

To celebrate Thailand's most joyful holiday, Thai people splash water and put scented powder on each other to express hopes of ridding bad luck and praying for blessings, Sung said, adding that the festival is also celebrated in many other Southeast Asian countries, such as Laos, Cambodia and Myanmar, as well as by the Dai people in Yunnan, China.
Activities designed for the carnival in Kaohsiung include water splashing, a band performance, traditional Thai dance, and traditional dance from the Philippines, Sung said.
Nearly 5,000 people have signed up for the carnival, he added.
Sung noted that Taiwan has more than 9,800 temporary workers from Thailand, and most of Kaohsiung County's more than 1,300 foreign workers are from Thailand.
"Taiwan is the top choice in terms of working destination for workers from Thailand, " said Sung.
Directors of the three government's labor affairs bureaus Thursday invited all foreign workers and local residents to join the carnival to gain a better understanding of the traditional Thai culture.
A similar activity will take place in Taipei City in northern Taiwan on April 12, according to an official of Taipei City government's Department of Labor.

In addition to water splashing, there will be dance performances by a group from Thailand-based Faculty of Fine Art, Srinakharinwirot University, as well as performances by popular bands formed by Thai workers in Taiwan.
Muay Thai--Thai boxing, singing contests, lottery drawing, and delicacies presentation will also be featured at the carnival.
The official added that the one-day carnival is the beginning of the whole year's activities to introduce Southeast Asian cultures to Taipei City residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: NGOs call for more comprehensive policy on Chinese spouses

TEXT.P: Two non-governmental organizations are urging the incoming government to adopt more comprehensive policies regarding Chinese spouses in Taiwan, to augment the immigrants right to work and streamline the process of applying for residence.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who won a decisive victory in the March 22 presidential election, campaigned on a platform of more open and closer relations between Taiwan and China, a significant departure from the position of the current Democratic Progressive Party government.

"We hope that the incoming government will pay greater attention to the rights of Chinese spouses, " said Ke Yu-ling, executive director of the Pearl S. Buck Foundation, a non-governmental organization that helps foreign spouses and their children to adapt to life in Taiwan.

"The government should take into consideration the immediate needs of Chinese spouses, and give attention to issues such as the right to work and a simpler process of obtaining a Taiwan identity card, " Ke told the Central News Agency. She further called for the Immigration Act and the regulations on resident permit applications to be amended.

Chinese spouses, in most cases, have to wait five to eight years to obtain Taiwan nationality, longer than spouses from other countries, who can apply for resident status after about three years and are allowed to work almost as soon as they arrive in Taiwan.
She suggested that Chinese spouses should at least be treated the same as other foreign spouses.

The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) officially announced in early April that Chinese spouses of Taiwanese citizens who have minor children will be allowed to work even if they do not yet have residence status.
About 10,000 Chinese spouses will benefit under the new regulation, according to the CLA.

Describing the new measure as "a step forward," Lin Ying-zhen, the director of the section of aid and service of the Chinese Association for Relief and Ensuring Services, said that the government has been paying increasingly greater attention to the voices of new immigrants.

She added, however, that the government should provide alternative access to information for Chinese people who are marrying Taiwanese citizens, as most official Taiwan Web sites are blocked in China.
Of the 400,000 foreign spouses living in Taiwan, some 250,000 are from China, according to the Ministry of the Interior.

DOC.HEADLINE: Campaign to `spread love' in Taiwanese society kicks off

TEXT.P: A campaign to "deliver love to every corner of Taiwan" kicked off Thursday in Taipei with the participation of dignitaries and officials, including Chu Shu- hsian, the wife of Vice President-elect Vincent Siew, and Taipei Mayor Hau Lung- bin.

The program invites the public to contribute articles to express their love in an attempt to "influence society with people's love." The best articles will be chosen by experts and the winning writers awarded prizes of between NT$100,000 (US$3,278) and NT$1,000.

Pai Hsueh-hua, better known by her stage name Pai Ping-ping, who is founder and chairwoman of the event's organizer -- the Pai Hsieh-yen Cultural and Educational Foundation (PCEF) -- said at the launch ceremony that even though social order in Taiwan is unsatisfactory, "love is still observed in many places."
She urged the public "to treasure what they have, to write stories about love and to spread their love to others."
The PCEF was founded in 1997 by Pai, a well-known local singer and actress, after her only daughter, Pai Hsieh-yen, was abducted and murdered.

Following the establishment of the PCEF, the foundation has devoted itself to creating a society in which people can live in peace and enjoy their work, as well as helping children in Taiwan grow up safely.
Commending Pai as a brave woman in overcoming tragedy and throwing herself to social work, Chu said that "only love can let us live happily."
"Let's do good things, say good words and make our society a peaceful one," Chu said.
Hau praised Pai for her achievements in helping the underprivileged and urged the public "to work together and use love to solve the obstacles around us."
The PCEF started accepting entries April 10 and will continue to accept them until June 30, with the winners expected to be announced Sept. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bears forage based on acorn production: study

TEXT.P: Formosan black bears, the only bear species endemic to Taiwan, forage around the areas near Jade Mountain following the fruit bearing season of a specific kind of oak tree, according to a recent study conducted by local zoologists.

Formosan black bear, or ursus thibetanus formosanus, is a subspecies of the Asiatic black bear. The species, the largest mammal in Taiwan, usually inhabits forest areas at elevations between 1,000 meters and 3,500 meters.
Scientists believe that the bears leave their domain only when the food supply becomes scarce.

The zoologists, who have closely observed the black bear's activities for nearly a decade, reported Wednesday that the number of bears in the region laced with ring-cupped oaks always rises sharply from October to January, corresponding with the period when acorns are produced.

Hwang Mei-hsiu, assistant professor at National Pingtung University of Science and Technology and leader of the project, said the average bear population in the neighborhood between October and January is around 1.5 times that in February to September.

"Bears usually begin to arrive by late-October, and leave gradually after acorns become scarce; when there is no nuts at all, the bears disappear entirely as well, " said Hwang during a thesis presentation organized by the Yushan National Park Administration, the supervising agency for the areas neighboring Jade Mountain (Yushan in Chinese).

Hwang, nicknamed "Mother Black Bear" for her contribution to the understanding and conservation of the endangered species, said during the years when ring- cupped oaks produce less fruits, the bears would more likely invade human territories to seek food supply.
Animal researchers suggested that the acorn production volume can be recognized as an index of the aggressiveness of wild black bears in October-January.

They also suggested that when the nut supply is expected to decrease in the year, an advanced warning could be issued to caution residents or tourists in the area of the danger of bears prowling activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Withdrawing missiles not good enough: defense minister

TEXT.P: Just withdrawing, instead of destroying, half of the missiles that China has deployed along its coastal provinces aimed at Taiwan is not good enough, Defense Minister Tsai Ming-hsien said Thursday.

Speaking to members of the print media, Tsai said he has no idea about the veracity of speculations circulating in the local stock market that Chinese President Hu Jintao plans to give President-elect Ma Ying-jeou an impressive gift on his May 20 inauguration by announcing that China will withdraw half of the missiles.
Whether the speculation is true or not, the United Evening News said it caused the TAIEX weighted index to surge 161.47 points, or 1.86 percent, to close at 8,829.4, a record high in 11 trading days.
Tsai said that since most of China's missiles are mobile, withdrawing them would make little sense, as they could very easily be moved back into place at a later date.
"If China truly wants to demonstrate its goodwill toward Taiwan, it should first destroy some of the missiles targeting Taiwan and work out a timetable for such destruction," Tsai said.
Meanwhile, Lo Chih-chiang, a spokesman for Ma's campaign office, said the office has received no information on the issue and therefore refused to speculate on the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bid for WHA as Chinese Taipei is step backward: DPP legislator

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) criticized Thursday President-elect Ma Ying- jeou's remarks that Taiwan should continue to apply for observer status in the World Health Assembly (WHA) under the name Chinese Taipei, describing it as a backward-moving strategy, the result of which will be the responsibility of the outgoing government.

"I strongly oppose applying for observer status in the WHA under the name Chinese Taipei, as it would be a step backward, " DPP Legislator Yeh Yi-jin said during a session of the legislature's Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee.

Yeh said Taiwan does not have to deceive itself, as the membership application is doomed to fail again this year. She added that "we cannot make concessions in advance, as the incumbent government will have to take the blame for the result of the bid."

The upcoming WHA -- the World Health Organization's (WHO's) decision-making body -- which is scheduled to open May 19 in Geneva, one day before Ma's inauguration, is seen in some political quarters as likely to be the first crucial test of the relationship between China and Ma's new administration.

Foreign Minister James Huang reiterated Thursday that no conclusion has been reached on how to handle Taiwan's bid for its participation in the WHO this year but said the Foreign Ministry will continue to communicate with Ma's office.

"The issue is pending discussions among relevant agencies and the government will communicate with Ma's office on the basis of mutual respect, " he said after briefing Ma and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew on Taiwan's present diplomatic circumstances.

Ma signaled his intention April 4 to employ pragmatism and flexibility in his foreign policy -- which he described as "modus vivendi " -- saying that Chinese Taipei is an acceptable name for Taiwan to use in international organizations, a suggestion that represents a significant departure from the position of the outgoing DPP administration.

Since it began seeking representation at the WHA in 1997, Taiwan's annual attempts have been thwarted by Beijing. Last year, it applied for membership of the WHO for the first time under the name Taiwan but failed due to opposition from China, which claims Taiwan as its territory.

Since Taiwan's expulsion from the United Nations and affiliated organizations in 1971, it has been isolated from major international activities and at present has formal diplomatic relations with only 23 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA to promote vegetarianism: EPA minister

TEXT.P: Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Minister Chen Chung-hsin said Thursday that his agency will promote vegetarianism in an effort to counter global warming.
Chen made the remarks at a meeting of the Health, Environment and Social Welfare Committee of the legislature, where he explained the government's policy on reducing carbon dioxide emissions.
Legislator Lin Hung-chih of the opposition Kuomintang, who was also present at the interpellation session, asked why the EPA has not promoted vegetarianism as a way to fight global warming.

According to information collected by Lin, producing one kilo of beef (from breeding to selling) will produce 76.4 kg of carbon dioxide, as the transport process requires refrigerated planes and trucks.
Lin noted that the livestock industry depends heavily on pastures, the creation of which causes shrinkage of forests worldwide and thus accelerates global warming.

While producing animal products consumes large amounts of energy, the cultivation of plants consumes little, Lin went on, adding that the CO2 emissions produced by cultivating plants are only 3 percent of those produced by animal products.
"The CO2 emissions of the world's agriculture and livestock industries account for nearly 20 percent of global CO2 emissions, " Lin said, adding that this poses a very serious problem for the world.
Lin suggested that each person could reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 7 kg per day if he or she adopts a vegetarian diet, and urged Chen to promote this kind of diet.

For his part, Chen said he is aware that vegetarianism has become a world trend in fighting global warming and admitted that it is a pity the EPA has failed to promote it in its pamphlets promoting a "green lifestyle."
He promised that the EPA will follow this route and that he will not eat meat on Earth Day, which falls on April 22, and will encourage his colleagues to follow suit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City welcomes Hon Hai investment

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Government officials were reluctant to confirm media reports Thursday that Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Kuo will travel to Kaohsiung Friday to discuss his investment plans with the local government, but voiced welcome for possible investment by the major company.

Chen Kai-ling, acting director of Kaohsiung's Department of Economic Development, would only say that the Kaohsiung city government has contacted Hon Hai Group, and expressed warm welcome and full willingness to cooperate for any potential investment by the company.
Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu will be briefed on a software park on the eve of Kuo's reported visit, Chen added.

Meanwhile, Kaohsiung City Councilor Hung Ping-lang confirmed that Kuo will visit the city Friday, where he will inspect the sites conserved for the establishment of a software park and multifunctional trade and economic park.
Hon Hai Group is reportedly planning to invest in the southern city's software park and use the city's port as a key shipping point for its exports to other countries.

According to local media reports, authorities in Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second- largest city, are gearing up for possible investment by Hon Hai in the hope of creating more job opportunities for local residents.

Local media cited Kuo as saying that in response to a request by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, his group will launch investments in Kaohsiung City's software park and will use the Kaohsiung Port, instead of Singapore or Hong Kong, to re- ship export items produced by Hon Hai's plant in Vietnam to the United States or European countries.
Ma visited Kuo Monday to exchange views on Taiwan's industrial development at Hon Hai's headquarters in Tucheng, Taipei County.
Media reports cited Kuo as saying that his group has begun assessing the feasibility of several investment projects in Kaohsiung and concrete plans could be made before Ma's inauguration on May 20.
In the past, Hon Hai's investment in the domestic market mainly focused on Taipei County and the Miaoli area, Kuo noted.

It was reported that during the Monday meeting, Ma asked Kuo to increase investment in Taiwan, particularly in southern regions, upgrade Hon Hai's headquarters in Tucheng and turn it into the company's global business operations center, and play a leadership role in advocating companies donate to charity.

On Monday, Ma and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew also met with Formosa Petrochemical Group (FPG) Chairman Y. C. Wang at the group's headquarters in Taipei City. Also present at the meeting were Kuo, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. Chairman Morris Chang and Chinese National Federation of Industries Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung.

Kuo, Wang and Chang are leading moguls from Taiwan's high-tech and traditional businesses. Combined assets of their groups total more than NT$6 trillion (US$196.72 billion) in market value, accounting for over 20 percent of the Taiwan's stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-finance minister dismayed over indictment

TEXT.P: Former Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang said Thursday that he was both "surprised" and "regretful" that prosecution authorities have indicated him for violating a "revolving-door" ban.

Yen made the remarks after learning that the Taipei Prosecutors Office had indicted him for violating a code of ethics by assuming the chairmanship of Fuhwa Financial Holding Co. less than three months after retiring from public office.
"The prosecution has distorted the spirit of the revolving door ban, " Yen claimed.
He noted that he served as finance minister between Oct. 5, 2000 and Jan. 31, 2002 and that at the time of his leaving the post, Fuhwa Financial Holding was not even established.

Yen then served as Taiwan's representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) from Feb. 1, 2002 until March 23, 2005, but said the job had nothing to do with financial holdings or financial supervision operations.

Moreover, Yen said that opposition Legislator Sun Ta-chien asked the Ministry of Civil Service (MCS) in 2005 to explain his situation and the MCS replied that his serving as chairman of a financial holding did not contravene the revolving- door ban.
The Civil Service Act states that former civil servants are banned from taking top positions in any company they supervised during a five-year period before their retirement from the service.

Violators of the law can be subject to a maximum sentence of two years in jail plus a fine of up to NT$1 million, and could also have their earnings from such positions confiscated, according to the law.
The banned positions listed under the law are chairman, supervisor, manager, major shareholder and consultant.

The prosecutors said that Fuhwa Financial Holding Co. was approved by the Ministry of Finance Dec. 31, 2001, when Yeh was still finance minister, although the company was not established until Feb. 4, 2002.
Yen assumed the chairmanship of Fuhwa Financial Holding in June 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hakka Tung Blossom Festival to kick off April 12

TEXT.P: The Hakka Tung Blossom Festival will be celebrated April 12-May 18 with over 100 artistic and cultural activities in northern, central and southern Taiwan, organizers said Thursday.

The Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs, which sponsors the annual flower season, now in its seventh year, will work with eight county governments and 44 social groups to organize the activities, Council Chairman Lee Yung-teh said.
The public can see spectacular drifts of the snow-white flowers in the counties of Taipei, Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Miaoli, Taichung, Changhua, Yunlin and Nantou.
To make the festival more eco-friendly, Lee said the council has also asked the county governments to launch hiking, biking and jogging events, and he urged visitors to use public transport.

In addition, stores in these counties have designed 400 tung flower-related products, including porcelain works and accessories, as part of the council's efforts to promote the development of industries featuring Hakka culture, Lee told a news conference heralding the opening of the festival.
The products will be sold at 92 outlets and 78 designated restaurants will lay on Hakka dishes, according to Lee.
The council will also collaborate with local companies to launch a photography exhibition highlighting the past 100 years of Hakka culture in Taiwan, as well as organizing package tours, he went on.
It will also offer 100,000 free copies of tour brochures after April 16, providing information about the events.

Lee added that for this first time this year, the council has followed Japan's suit by working with local TV stations to give up-to-date information in their weather forecasts about the blossoming of the tung flowers from April 11-May 10.
The council has also set up a Web site at http: //tung.hakka.gov.tw to provide details about the festival and maps.
April and May are the months when tung flowers, also known as paulownia flowers, are in full bloom in central and northern Taiwan.

The white flowers have become a symbol of the Hakka people and the flowering season is celebrated in Hakka villages every year with traditional music and song, coupled with the consumption of Hakka delicacies.
The Tung Blossom Festival has been designated by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications as one of the eight major events of Tour Taiwan 2008-2009.

The Hakka are a unique ethnic group of Han Chinese, who originally lived in central China but gradually migrated south during different dynasties and settled in Jiangxi, Fujian and Guangdong provinces, as well as in Taiwan, after fleeing from war and famine.
They were called Hakka, which literally means "guest families" in Chinese, by the locals when they first settled in.

The Hakka people are considered to be careful about maintaining their cultural traditions and one of their outstanding characteristics is that they are willing to venture into other parts of the world to establish themselves.
The Hakka have migrated to Southeast Asia, East Africa, Europe and North and South America in the past century.

Taiwan has some 4.5 million Hakka people, accounting for 13.2 percent of the population. The first wave of Hakka migrants came from China to Taiwan in the 1690s, when China was under the rule of the Qing Dynasty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Journalist group protests over China's barring of Taiwanese media

TEXT.P: The Association of Taiwan Journalists (ATJ) lodged a protest Thursday against Beijing for barring a Taiwan-based daily from covering news regarding the Boao Forum set to take place in China this weekend.

In a written statement, the ATJ protested against Beijing's barring of journalists and camera crew from Apple Daily from covering news regarding Vice President-elect Vincent Siew's attendance at the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia, slated to be held in China's Hainan Province April 11-13.
Siew is set to depart from Taiwan for Hainan Friday to attend the forum in his capacity as chairman of the private Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation.
ATJ asked Siew to defend Taiwan reporters' rights to cover the news during his visit.
The group also said it wants Siew to meet the media, in private or public, on a daily basis during his stay in China to allow Taiwanese media outlets to keep fully abreast of the forum proceedings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Competition for Galileo applications extended to Taiwan

TEXT.P: The European Satellite Navigation Competition (ESNC) , held to promote applications related to the Galileo satellite navigation system, will include Taiwanese participants for the first time, the regional organizer announced Thursday.

Galileo, based on concepts similar to that of the U.S. Global Positioning System, is being built by the European Union and the European Space Agency. The system is expected to be fully operational by 2013.

In preparation for the commencement of Galileo, two German organizations launched the ESNC in 2004 to encourage satellite navigation application services using the Galileo system, including initially only Germany, France and Sweden.
Over the past four years, the ESNC has expanded to include 11 regions, with 900 participants vying for the grand title of Galileo Master.
For the 2008 competition, the organizers have decided to extend coverage to Taiwan, and have chosen the Hsinchu-based Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) as a regional organizer.

During a press conference, ITRI President Johnsee Lee said that in addition to the Galileo Master prize, the ITRI has also established two special awards for Taiwanese participants -- the ITRI Special Topic Prize and the Taiwan Region Prize.
According to the ITRI, the winner of the Galileo Master title will be rewarded with 20,000 euros and free project incubation services for six months.

The winner of the ITRI Special Topic Prize will receive 20,000 euros and free ITRI incubation services for one year, while the winner of the Taiwan Region Prize will get 10,000 euros, one round-trip air ticket to Europe and free ITRI incubation services for one year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan academic team sets up seismic network in Vietnam

TEXT.P: An academic team from Taiwan has deployed a temporary seismological network in northern Vietnam to monitor earthquakes in the South China Sea area, the National Science Council under the Cabinet learned Thursday.

Members of the council were briefed about the research work of the team by Huang Bor-shouh, a research fellow at the Institute of Earth Sciences of Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's leading research institute -- and Chen Yue-gau, a professor with the Department of Geosciences of National Taiwan University.
Huang and Chen said the network can send instant first-hand information about seismic activity in the South China Sea back to Taiwan through either the Internet or satellite.
They said the team will expand the seismic network to cover southern Vietnam during a trip later this year, followed by cooperation with the Philippines to set up a seismic network in that country.

According to the two academics, the team chose Vietnam to deploy the network because Vietnam has high seismic action and the information received about earthquakes in the South China Sea can be used to keep countries in the area informed about the threat of tsunami, which are often caused by undersea quakes.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2nd Taiwan Culture Week held in France

TEXT.P: The second-ever Taiwan Culture Week was launched Tuesday in Lyon, France's second largest city, as part of efforts to promote cultural exchanges between the two countries.

The five-day event is organized by the France Taiwan Society with the help of the Institute of East Asian Studies in Lyon and the Institute of Political Science in Lyon, in an effort to allow the French public to get a better understanding of Taiwan's culture.

Michel C.L. Lu, the Republic of China's Representative to France, and Chen Chi- cheng, director of the Taiwan Cultural Center in Paris under Taiwan's Council for Cultural Affairs, spoke during a ceremony to mark the opening of the cultural event.

In his speech, Lu commended Lyon for its excellent development of science and education and expressed hope that Taiwan and Lyon will boost cultural exchanges, especially with Taiwan's holding of the cultural event in collaboration with local educational institutions.

A series of activities are being held for the Taiwan Culture Week -- including a calligraphy exhibition, traditional Taiwanese hand puppet shows, a Taiwan photo exhibition, Taiwanese documentaries screening events and lecture courses on Taiwan's history and culture.
A one-day symposium on Taiwan's identity will also be held by France's National Center for Scientific Research, alongside the cultural event. The first Taiwan Culture Week took place last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Businesses welcome to invest in Philippines' economic zones

TEXT.P: The Philippine government will provide Taiwanese investors with incentives, such as lower taxes and special visas, to attract them to its special economic zones, a visiting Philippine delegation of government officials and businessmen, said Thursday.

The delegation, named the RP Investment Mission to Taiwan, made the appeal at a press conference aimed at promoting investment in the Philippines through cooperation between the government and private sectors.

Noting that Taiwan is a competitive market with advanced technology and hard- working people, Lilia Lima, director-general of the Philippine Economic Zone Authority (PEZA) , expressed hope that more Taiwanese businesses will invest in her nation's 134 economic zones.
"Through the investment, Taiwan and the Philippines can strengthen bilateral cooperation, which also helps boost the economic development of both sides," said Lima.

She further said that the Philippine government is willing to set up other economic zones -- areas especially developed for foreign investors to set up companies or factories -- to accommodate Taiwanese businesses' specific needs.

Saying that the Philippines has a good investment environment with sound public security, Lima said the PEZA, an investment promotion agency attached to the Department of Trade and Industry, will provide the incentives to Taiwanese investors.
According to Lima, developers and operators in economic zones pay only a 5 percent Gross Income Tax in lieu of all other national and local taxes.
"The government will also issue special visas for foreign investors and their immediate family," Lima went on, adding that many other benefits await Taiwanese businessmen.

Lolito Lopez, president of the Philippines Footwear Federation, said the Philippines is an ideal place for footwear making, adding that if Taiwanese shoe manufacturers invest in the Philippines, "the government will do everything to support the industry."

Delegates of the RP Investment Mission to Taiwan, sponsored by Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and Taiwan External Trade Development Council, also include Tomas Alcantara, chairman of the Manila Economic and Cultural office, and representatives of the Philippines private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese panda offer should be city-to-city: municipal official

TEXT.P: China's offer to give Taiwan two pandas would be better achieved based on a city-to-city framework, Taipei City Education Department Director Wu Ching-ji said Thursday.

As Taipei City and Chengdu City in China's Sichuan Province also maintain sports exchanges, it would be more appropriate for China to give the two pandas under a city-to-city framework to better safeguard Taiwan's national dignity, Wu said while fielding questions during an interpellation session at the Taipei City Council.

Responding to a question from Councilor Lee Shiou-yen as to how much animal conservation fees Taiwan should pay China if it takes the pandas, Wu said the two sides should hold talks in a way acceptable to both to settle the issue.

According to Lee, China charges the United States as much as US$1 million per year in animal conservation fees for pandas that it has received from China, but asks Hong Kong to pay a minimum sum for the same purpose.

If China applies the Hong Kong model to Taiwan, it would undermine Taiwan's independent sovereignty, but if China charges Taiwan the same fee as the United States, it would be too expensive, Lee pointed out, adding that pre-entry quarantine and breeding are other major concerns.

The panda issue again sparked public attention after Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) won the March 22 presidential election, fanning hope that the pandas could come to Taiwan after he assumes office May 20.
Taipei City and Hsinchu City in northern Taiwan and Taichung City in central Taiwan are competing to take charge of the rare animals.
The Democratic Progressive Party administration rejected the offer of the pandas when Beijing first made the offer in May 2005 following a visit to China by KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan.

Some DPP government officials described the panda offer as a "Trojan Horse" designed to dampen Taiwan's sovereignty. Beijing has named the animals "Yuan- Yuan" and "Tuan-Tuan, " which together mean "unite" in Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1.45 million environmental pledges bring prize for Taiwan

TEXT.P: A total of 1.45 million pledges made by Taiwanese people in an international competition for environmental protection brought a US$350,000 prize to Taiwan, according to a press statement released Thursday by Standard Chartered Bank Taiwan.
The statement said the prize will be used to support vital environmental protection projects in Taiwan.
The competition, organized by the Standard Chartered Group and the World Wildlife Fund, ran from last October to March 17 this year, attracting more than 3.4 million participants.

The competition, titled The Greatest Race on Earth 2007/08, required participants to choose up to eight personal energy-saving actions listed on an activity Web site that they then pledged to stick to in their daily lives.

The three countries or areas with the highest percentages calculated on the basis of dividing the pledge number with the national population shared a US$1 million prize. Brunei ranked before Taiwan and won US$500,000, while Hong Kong took third place and won US$150,000, the statement said.

The eight pledges included not leaving tap water running while cleaning teeth, turning lights out when leaving the room, spending a minute less in the shower each day and reusing or refusing plastic bags at least three times a week.

The statement pointed out that 14,600 liters of water can be saved every year simply by making sure the faucet is fully closed every day, while another 2,920 liters can be saved if one spends a minute less in the shower each day and turning off lights when leaving the room can reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 68 kg every year.

Complete realization of the 1.45 million pledges made by Taiwanese people will reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 48,000 tons, prevent 28.5 million plastic bags from being dumped and save 3.2 billion tons of water, according to the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hotel tempts Taiwanese gourmets with organic Canadian food

TEXT.P: The Landis Taipei Hotel launched a Canadian Food Festival Thursday to promote Canadian cuisine that features the original flavors of nature, according to Stephanie Liang, director of public relations at the hotel.

During the festival, which will be held from April 11 to May 4, the hotel will present a series of dishes prepared from ingredients imported from Canada, such as beef, lobster, salmon, blueberries, wild rice, icewine and maple syrup, all grown or produced naturally, Liang said.

"A clean environment does not come automatically -- we've tried hard to work for it," said Hugh Moeser, deputy director of the Canada Trade Office in Taipei which is one of the sponsors of the festival.
He said that his country has made efforts to enhance the quality of its food by establishing, for example, a system of traceability of beef to ensure the safety of meat from the farm to dining table.
He also noted that Taiwan is an important market for Canada, as it represents Canada's fourth largest trading partner in Asia and its 11th in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi Hospital successful in treating Parkinson's with new method
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/08 22:45:05 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital in Hualien has been highly successful using deep brain stimulation (DBS) surgery to treat Parkinson's disease, a doctor at the hospital said Thursday.

Chen Hsin-yuan, director of the hospital's Parkinson's Disease Treatment and Research Center, made the remarks while meeting a group of his patients on the eve of World Parkinson's Disease Day. The patients have all benefited from the new method over the past few years.

Chen pointed out that the Tzu Chi hospital has treated 110 patients with Parkinson's disease or other movement disorders with DBS surgery, with a 100 percent success rate and accounting for 44 percent of all DBS operations performed in Taiwan.

As a result, the hospital has now become a center in Asia for teaching the DBS method, which offers the best hope for patients with Parkinson's disease whose symptoms are not sufficiently controlled by medication, Chen went on.

The treatment involves the use of electrodes that are implanted in the patient's brain at the precise location where nerve signals generate the tremors. The electrodes are then connected to a neurostimulator, which sends tiny electrical impulses through a wire into the brain to block the abnormal activity that causes the tremors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to approve new inaugural stamp design for Ma

TEXT.P: The government will approve a set of commemorative postage stamps to mark the inauguration of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou May 20, ending a controversial dispute over how the stamps should be named, a Cabinet source said Thursday.
"The Executive Yuan respects their decision, " the source said, referring to the conclusion reached by Ma's office and the state-run Taiwan Post Co.

The announcement came after the office agreed to accept the new design, which will carry the imprint "the Republic of China (Taiwan), " as a solution proposed by the postal company to solve the dispute of how the country's name should appear.

Earlier, the office had suggested postponing the launch of the stamps because the original design was controversial as it was printed with only the name Taiwan rather than the country's national title -- the Republic of China.

The office's move was considered a move to question the legitimacy of a government decision to change the postal company's name from Chunghwa Post Co. to Taiwan Post Co. last year as part of its name change campaign supposed to highlight Taiwanese identity.
Soon after the name change last February, the company also replaced the Republic of China on its stamps with Taiwan.

However, the legislature dominated by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Ma's party, did not pass an amendment to an act governing the establishment of the postal company last year, leaving the company's legal name as Chunghwa Post Co.

Prior to Thursday's announcement, the Cabinet had insisted that the name Taiwan should appear on the stamps, but it decided to soften its stance because it does want to "politicize" the launch of the new stamps, the source noted.
This year will be the fourth time that the postal company has launched inaugural stamps since 1996, when the company sold 4.2 million stamps to mark former President Lee Teng-hui's inauguration.
In 2000, the company also sold 3 million commemorative stamps for President Chen Shui-bian when his party, the Democratic Progressive Party, first came to power, ending 55 years of KMT rule.
However, 1.5 million of the 3.5 million stamps launched in 2004 to mark the start of Chen's second term remain unsold.

TEXT.P: The Landis Taipei Hotel launched a Canadian Food Festival Thursday to promote Canadian cuisine that features the original flavors of nature, according to Stephanie Liang, director of public relations at the hotel.

During the festival, which will be held from April 11 to May 4, the hotel will present a series of dishes prepared from ingredients imported from Canada, such as beef, lobster, salmon, blueberries, wild rice, icewine and maple syrup, all grown or produced naturally, Liang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi Hospital successful in treating Parkinson's with new method
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, April 10 (CNA) 04/11/08 11:27:58 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital in Hualien has been highly successful using deep brain stimulation (DBS) surgery to treat Parkinson's disease, a doctor at the hospital said Thursday.

Chen Hsin-yuan, director of the hospital's Parkinson's Disease Treatment and Research Center, made the remarks while meeting a group of his patients on the eve of World Parkinson's Disease Day. The patients have all benefited from the new method over the past few years.

Chen pointed out that the Tzu Chi hospital has treated 110 patients with Parkinson's disease or other movement disorders with DBS surgery, with a 100 percent success rate and accounting for 44 percent of all DBS operations performed in Taiwan.

As a result, the hospital has now become a center in Asia for teaching the DBS method, which offers the best hope for patients with Parkinson's disease whose symptoms are not sufficiently controlled by medication, Chen went on.

The treatment involves the use of electrodes that are implanted in the patient's brain at the precise location where nerve signals generate the tremors. The electrodes are then connected to a neurostimulator, which sends tiny electrical impulses through a wire into the brain to block the abnormal activity that causes the tremors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 11, or the sixth day of the March of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1713: France cedes Newfoundland and Gibraltar to Britain.
1775: James Parkinson, the British physician who defined Parkinson's disease, a progressive disease of the nervous system also called paralysis agitans or shaking palsy, is born.
1814: Louis XVIII accedes to the throne as Napoleon Bonaparte abdicates and is banished to the island of Elba under the Treaty of Fontainebleau.
1893: Dean Acheson, the U.S. politician and secretary of state who helped to formulate the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan and who promoted the setting up of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), is born.
1899: Spain transfers control of the Philippines to the United States.
1919: The International Labor Organization is founded in Geneva in affiliation with the League of Nations to improve living standards and working conditions.
1926: American horticulturist Luther Burbank dies at the age of 77. He developed countless new varieties of fruits, vegetables and flowers, including the Burbank potato and the Shasta daisy.
1935: Dust storms wreak havoc in the so-called "Dust Bowl" states of Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming, Oklahoma, Texas and New Mexico in the United States.
1945: U.S. forces capture the German towns of Essen and Weimar and liberate the Buchenwald concentration camp near the end of World War II.
1950: The Bank of Taiwan issues its first lottery.
1950: China lodges a complaint with the United Nations against Soviet aid to the Chinese communists, the Soviet invasion of China and Soviet violation of the U.N. Charter.
1951: U.S. President Harry Truman relieves Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the World War II hero who accepted the Japanese surrender in Tokyo Bay in 1945, of all his command, including that of U.N. forces in Korea.
1957: Singapore is granted self-government by the United Kingdom.
1969: Taiwan's Executive Yuan approves the "Guidelines for the Population Policy of the Republic of China."
1970: The government of Prime Minister Lon Nol announces abolishment of the monarchy and proclaims Cambodia a republic.
1974: U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, leading a party of 19, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the Sino-Honduran Fishery Technical Cooperation Agreement.
1976: An ROC education mission headed by Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang leaves for the Middle East on a visit.
1976: Col. Carlos Humberto Romero, secretary of defense and pacific security of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: The Taiwan Province Black Foot Disease Control Center is inaugurated in Peimen Village, Tainan County.
1979: A combined force of Ugandan exiles and Tanzanian troops captures the Ugandan capital of Kampala, ending the eight-year rule of Idi Amin.
1981: Chen Ta, a noted singer of Taiwanese folk songs, dies at the age of 76.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton orders trade sanctions against Taiwan in accordance with the Pelly Act.
1995: Chen Yun, one of Communist China's leading veteran hardliners and one of its leading economic planners, dies in Beijing at the age of 90.
1997: Turin Cathedral is engulfed by flames, but firefighters manage to save the famous Turin Shroud.
2000: Foreign ministers of the 113-member Non-Aligned Movement endorse the Philippine-led regional code of conduct in the South China Sea to promote peace and stability in the region.
2001: The Executive Yuan signs an agreement with the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office (NTIO) in Taipei to enact regulations to prevent double taxation on Dutch people working in Taiwan as well as those from Taiwan in the Netherlands.
2002: The European Parliament passes a pro-Taiwan resolution urging mainland China to dismantle missile deployment against Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A moral character always has courage; but a man of courage is not necessarily a moral character."

TEXT.P: Former Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan confirmed Friday that he has accepted President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's offer to appoint him premier.

Liu, who is president of Soochow University and served as vice premier 1997-2000, said he has discussed the issue with Ma on many occasions and will complete the Cabinet lineup by the end of the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect leaves for Boao Forum in China

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Vincent Siew departed Friday for the southern Chinese island of Hainan via Hong Kong to attend the annual conference of the Boao Forum for Asia (BFA).

Siew, who is taking part in the meeting in his capacity as chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation, was scheduled to arrive later that day at Meilan International Airport in Haikou, Hainan, where he was to be received by Chen Yunlin, chief of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council.

There has been speculation that Siew will have talks with Chinese President Hu Jintao, who will address the conference's opening ceremony Saturday, but Siew has declined to confirm the meeting, although he said he hopes his participation in the conference will help extend Taiwan's goodwill to China and increase cross-Taiwan Strait mutual trust.
On Sunday, Siew will host a roundtable discussion titled "Prospects for Taiwan's Economy and Cross-Strait Economic Cooperation and Trade" before returning to Taiwan.

The leaders of 11 countries and more than 2,000 Chinese and foreign guests are expected to participate in this year's BFA conference, which focuses on the theme "Green Asia: Moving Towards Win-Win Through Change."
The BFA is a non-government international organization committed to promoting regional economic integration and bringing Asian countries closer to their development goals.

The forum was initiated in 1998 by then-Philippine President Fidel Ramos, then-Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke and then-Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa. It was formally inaugurated in February 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: Full marathon to take place in Hsinchu

TEXT.P: A full 42.195-km marathon conforming to international standards will take place in the northern county of Hsinchu Sunday, an organizer said Friday.

The 2008 UMC International Marathon is sponsored by the United Microelectronics Corp. with assistance from Hsinchu county and city, as the route will go through both administrative areas, said UMC Chairman Jackson Hu.
In addition to the full marathon with a time limit of five-and-a-half hours for completion, the race also has divisions for a half-marathon, as well as for 10-km, 5.6-km and 1.6-km runs.

Enrollment had ended as of Friday, with nearly 13,000 people signing up, including 1,400 UMC personnel and their families, and 2,500 police officers -- 500 of whom are females -- led by National Police Agency Director-General Hou Yu-ih, said Hu.

Hu said the UMC started holding annual runs in 2004, but this year's was upgraded for the first time by adopting the international standards for full- and half-marathons. The previous runs were only 10 km.

Hu said UMC sponsors the runs to promote sports in Taiwan, and he expressed hope that Taiwanese people will develop good daily exercise habits, like President- elect Ma Ying-jeou, who jogs almost every day.
Hu also reminded the public that certain roads, including parts of Highway 68, will have traffic controls on race day.

26 draft bills expected to be reviewed in one week: lawmakers

TEXT.P: At least 26 draft bills regarding the people's livelihoods and welfare are expected to be reviewed in the space of a week, a spokesman for the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus said Friday.

Hsieh Kuo-liang, an acting KMT caucus whip, said that in the coming week, various committees under the KMT-dominated legislature will review the draft bills that have already passed their first readings in the legislature.

According to Hsieh, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng called a meeting April 8 to seek consensus among legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the KMT on a decision that committee meetings, instead of meetings of the whole legislature, will be held throughout the following week to review draft bills so that the Legislative Yuan will have "some bills" processed in the days to come.

During the meeting, it was decided that April 11, 15 and 18 -- originally reserved for whole-legislature meetings -- will be used for committee meetings because there are no bills left over from the previous legislature, which ended late last year, for review.

According to Hsieh, the 26 bills will include a central government general budget bill and several related bills, a bill on labor insurance, an amendment on lowering taxes on rice wine and related products, as well as an amendment to statutes regarding the welfare of youths and children.
