DOC.HEADLINE: New WHO strategy litmus test for China's sincerity: official

TEXT.P: The government's new strategy of seeking both membership of and observer status in the World Health Organization (WHO) can serve as a litmus test to gauge China's sincerity in wishing to improve bilateral ties, an official of the Presidential Office said Friday.

"Our new strategy can not only show the world our resolve to secure representation in the world health regulatory body but can also serve as a litmus test for China's sincerity in seeking to foster a better relationship across the Taiwan Strait, " said Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung.

According to the new strategy, President Chen Shui-bian will write to WHO Director-General Margaret Chan to express the country's intention to join the organization as a full member under the name Taiwan or at least as an observer in its decision-making body -- the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- also in the name of Taiwan.

In addition, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will ask the country's diplomatic allies who are also WHO members to present the application at this year's WHA conference scheduled to take place in Geneva May 19-24.

Taiwan has been unsuccessfully trying to become an observer in the WHA under its official title Republic of China since 1997. Last year, it applied for full WHO membership as Taiwan for the first time, which failed again due to same reason as before -- China's opposition on the grounds that Taiwan is part of its territory.
"This year around, we'll continue seeking full WHO membership while also pursuing WHA observer status should the membership bid be doomed again," Lin said.

The new strategy was adopted at a national security meeting presided over by Chen a day earlier. Those present at the meeting included Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Foreign Minister James Huang.

As the country's new government will take over the reins of power just a day after the opening of the WHA conference, Lin said Chen has also asked President- elect Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to express his opinion about the issue.

"Ma responded April 4 with a written statement addressed to Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen, in which he said the country should refrain from using the name Taiwan in the membership application, " Lin said, adding that Ma did not propose another title under which to apply.

Noting that the country's designation has never been a point at issue or a major hindrance to Taiwan's quest for WHO representation, Lin said the real obstacle lies in the trammels of Beijing's "one China" policy and its merciless obstruction of Taiwan.

"Against this backdrop, all those present at the meeting agreed that we should continue to use the name Taiwan in applying for WHO membership or WHA observer status to uphold policy continuity and consistency," Lin said.

The decision came after Ma said in a recent interview with CNA that his government will seek WHO participation as an observer, rather than as a full member. He also expressed his support for Taiwan seeking membership in international organizations under the name Chinese Taipei, in line with his cross-Taiwan Strait policy of "modus vivendi" based on "dignity, pragmatism and flexibility."

Upon learning of the incumbent Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's decision to stick to its guns and apply again for WHO membership as Taiwan, Ma's spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said Ma had reminded the caretaker government of the possible grim results this strategy might bring.
"As the DPP is still the party in power, we have no say in the matter and can just be prepared to suffer the consequences," Lo said.
Meanwhile, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said the ministry does not want to see the WHO issue spark discord or confrontation between the outgoing and incoming governments.
Early in March, Yeh said, China sent a letter to all WHO member countries asking them to promise to shut Taiwan out of any forthcoming WHA activities.

"Faced with enormous diplomatic woes, parties of different political persuasions should bear in mind that our battlefield is in Geneva, not on the domestic front, " Yeh said, adding that both the ruling and opposition camps should work hand-in-hand in the pursuit of their shared goals of safeguarding the public's health rights and preventing Taiwan from becoming the only gap in the global epidemic control network.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP urges VP-elect to defend Taiwan's interests during Boao forum

TEXT.P: Members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus urged Vice President-elect Vincent Siew Friday to defend Taiwan's interests during the Boao Forum set to take place in China this weekend.

Siew departed from Taipei earlier that day for China's Hainan Province, where he will attend the April 11-13 2008 Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) in his capacity as chairman of the private Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation.
William Lai, the DPP caucus whip, said that Siew's name was not included on the official BFA namelist of delegates. Hence, he is attending the international forum as a "business leader," Lai added.

Lai said he hopes that Siew's attendance at the forum is aimed at speaking for the rights and interests of the Taiwanese people rather than seeking profits for himself, his party or other individuals.

"I hope Siew will stand tall and defend the Taiwan people's interests so as to live up to the strong mandate that the voters gave him and President-elect Ma Ying-jeou in the just-concluded presidential election," Lai added.

Siew has attended the Boao Forum every year since 2003 in his capacity as chairman of the cross-strait foundation and this year's attendance at the purely non-political forum has nothing to do with his election victory.

According to Kuan Pi-ling, a deputy DPP caucus whip, the DPP chose not to press Siew too much on the issue "because the DPP is a party of virtue and kindness" and because the DPP is willing to give Siew an opportunity to defend Taiwan at an international event.
Kuan expressed hope that Siew will play the role of a Republic of China vice president-elect who will not jeopardize Taiwan's interests on the world stage.

"As an ROC vice president-elect with legal status and obligations, Siew should strive to disseminate messages that will benefit Taiwan at the Boao Forum and not let the international community misunderstand the true relations between Taiwan and China, " she continued.
Meanwhile, Hung Chi-chang, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, said Siew's attendance at the forum arouses both "expectation and worry."

Hung said he attaches great expectations on Siew's ability to conduct substantive negotiations with Chinese officials on cross-strait business and trade issues on an equal footing, but added that he is also worried that chances for the two sides to enter practical engagement will be lost should he fail to deliver on these expectations.

Lin Cho-shui, a former DPP legislator, said Siew, who will be sworn in as vice president May 20, owes the country an explanation on whether he is visiting China with an invitation issued to international VIPs or with a taibaozheng -- a travel document issued by the PRC government for people from Taiwan that apparently downgrades Taiwan to a province of China.

"If Siew uses a taibaozheng to enter China, can we respect him as a vice president-elect any longer? " Lin asked, adding that "if Siew enters China with an invitation, he should show it to the accompanying media and not prevaricate on his status."

TEXT.P: The Cloud Gate 2 dance troupe, an offshoot of the world renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theatre composed of Cloud Gate's younger dancers, kicked off an islandwide "Spring in the Hospital" tour Friday with a performance at Taichung Hospital in central Taiwan.
The dancers performed selected parts of the troupe's productions "Tantalus, " "Love Story" and "Body, Sound, " in the hospital's lobby, to the delight of patients and staff.

An 82-year-old male patient surnamed Chen and a 91-year-old female patient surnamed Lin who were taken to the lobby in wheelchairs by hospital staff said they had heard about the troupe but had never had the opportunity to see any of its performances before.
Both said that seeing the troupe perform live was a wonderful experience that filled them with joy.
