DOC.HEADLINE: Hospital urges people eating out to be on guard against hepatitis A

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Tzu Chi Hospital in Chiayi County's Dalin township said Friday that with the approach of warmer weather, people who often eat out should take precautions against acute hepatitis A infection.

Chou An-liang, a doctor in the hospital's Gastroenterology and Hepatology Department, said that the hepatitis A virus is most commonly transmitted by the fecal-oral route via contaminated food or drinking water, and he urged people who eat out to make sure to choose restaurants that are sanitary.

Noting that early symptoms of hepatitis A infection can be mistaken for influenza, Chou said that people who experience fatigue or loss of appetite should immediately have a blood test to see if they have been infected, as the disease can lead to liver damage and even death if not treated properly.

Chou noted that according to the latest Department of Health tallies, 82 cases of hepatitis A infection had been reported this year in Taiwan as of the end of March, or nearly double the amount for the same period of the previous year.

He also pointed out that as the weather gets warmer, frozen snacks and desserts tend to become more popular and he urged those who enjoy such treats to make sure they purchase sanitary products, as the hepatitis A virus can survive in temperatures as low as minus 20 degrees Celsius.
Chou also said that people with hepatitis B or C or cirrhosis of the liver should get tested for the presence of hepatitis A antibodies.
If hepatitis A antibodies are not present, these individuals should consider being vaccinated against the disease, he added.
Chou also advised people who traveling to Southeast Asia, China or other areas where hepatitis A is prevalent to get vaccinated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seminars to be held to forge consensus: president-elect

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that large seminars will be held in northern, central and southern Taiwan between late April and early May to forge a public consensus on key issues related to Taiwan's development.
The themes of the seminars will be the economy and education, the president- elect noted.
"This is the time to put election bickering behind and join hands to develop the nation," Ma said while attending a changeover ceremony of an influential civic group in Tainan, southern Taiwan.
The March 22 presidential election was "significant" in many ways, Ma suggested.

It indicated that Taiwan's people wanted a change because it will bring opportunity and hope, that they don't want a "closed-door" policy, and that they want clean government, a harmonious society without confrontation, and peaceful cross-Taiwan Strait relations without tensions.
He also said that he will address the nation's problems with "openness and pragmatism" and will not favor big business.

Citing public polls showing that 80 percent of the public were satisfied with the result of the election, Ma said he would have a broader mandate to govern, but he stressed that his KMT government would listen carefully to public opinion.
Ma won the presidency on March 22 with 58.45 percent of the vote, the highest of any candidate in Taiwan's four direct presidential elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hakka proficiency test to be held Sunday

TEXT.P: The Council for Hakka Affairs Commission under the Executive Yuan will hold nationwide intermediate and high-intermediate Hakka proficiency tests Sunday afternoon.

A total of 11,252 people, including 38 disabled citizens, have registered to take one of the two tests, more than for any previous Hakka proficiency test, including basic-level tests, according to the commission.
To meet the needs of the examinees islandwide, the commission has arranged a total of 24 test-taking locations in areas in the north, south, east and west of Taiwan.

The test will be comprised of an oral and written section. The written section will include testing on vocabulary, phonetic symbols and the structure of literary compositions, while the oral section will include testing on translation from Chinese, reading, and telling a story from pictures, according to the commission.
The proficiency test will begin at 1 p.m. at all locations around the island, commission officials said, reminding examinees to bring along proper identification to gain entry.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, appreciating NT$0.011 to close at NT$30.319.
A total of US$1.342 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.355 and fluctuated between NT$30.226 and NT$30.360.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGConsumer crunch bites despite cut in base rate
Millions of struggling families will be hit by higher mortgage payments after banks raised their charges last nightVdespite the Bank of Englandsquarter-point cut in the base rate to 5 per cent.
The rate cut would normally bring the cost of mortgages down. Instead, four of the biggest banks ignored it and increased charges on a range of loans, adding aboutG150 a month to a typical mortgage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records one new cancer case every seven minutes

TEXT.P: Taiwan recorded 67,896 new cancer cases in 2004 and another 68,907 new cases in 2005, meaning one person was being diagnosed with cancer every seven minutes in the country, according to a report released Friday by the Department of Health (DOH).

Among the new cases recorded in 2004, 39,075 cases involved men and 28,821 cases involved women, with the sex-specific crude incidence rates standing at 339 in every 100,000 men and 259 in every 100,000 women, the report said.
For the new cases recorded in 2005, 39,431 involved men and 29,476 involved women, with the sex-specific crude incidence rate standing at 341 in every 100,000 men and 263 in every 100,000 women.

During those two years, the top 10 most prevalent types of cancer among men were liver cancer, colorectal cancer, cancer of the tranchea, bronchus and lungs, oral cancer, prostate cancer, stomach cancer, esophagus cancer, bladder cancer, skin cancer and nasopharyngeal cancer, in that order.

Among women, the top 10 most prevalent types of cancer were breast cancer, colorectal cancer, liver cancer, cancer of the trachea, bronchus and lungs, cervical cancer, stomach cancer, thyroid cancer, skin cancer, uterine cancer, and cancer of the ovary, fallopian tube and broad ligament.

During the 2001-2005 period, the cancer incidence rate for men jumped by 3.7 percent, with oral cancer, colorectal cancer, prostate cancer and esophagus cancer registering the largest increase at 18 percent, 16 percent, 13 percent and 8 percent, respectively, according to the report.

The cancer incidence rate for women rose by 2.1 percent during the same period, with breast cancer, uterine cancer, and colorectal cancer seeing the largest increase at 22 percent, 21 percent and 8 percent, respectively. The incidence rate of cervical cancer, however, declined significantly by 31 percent, the report said.

Chao Kun-yu, deputy director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion, attributed the increase in the number of men suffering from oral cancer and esophagus cancer to the popularity of unhealthy habits such as betel-nut chewing, smoking and drinking.
Chao ascribed the sharp decrease in the number of women suffering from cervical cancer to the rising number of women receiving screening for the disease.

Chao noted that the likelihood of men surviving five years after being diagnosed with cancer stands at only 40 percent -- lower than the 63 percent for women, mainly because men suffering from lung cancer, liver cancer and esophagus cancer enjoy a five-year survival rate of only 10-20 percent.
The DOH report also revealed that the average age at the time of cancer diagnosis was 65 among men and 59 among women during the 2004-2005 period.

For men aged 25-44, the top five types of cancer recording the highest incidence rates were oral cancer, liver cancer, nasopharyngeal cancer, colorectal cancer, and cancer of the trachea, bronchus and lungs.
For women in the same age group, the top five most common types of cancer were breast cancer, thyroid cancer, cervical cancer, colorectal cancer and ovarian cancer, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan VP-elect expected to meet World Bank president at forum
DOC.DATELINE: Boao, Hainan, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/08 18:06:45 (By Lin Yi-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Vice President-elect Vincent Siew is expected to meet with World Bank Group President Robert Zoellick during the Boao Forum for Asia.

Siew, set to take part in the forum in his capacity as chairman of the private Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation, is also expected to meet a great number of world political leaders and former heads of states, including Chinese President Hu Jintao, former U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell, former Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke and former Philippine President Fidel Ramos, for bilateral talks on the sidelines of the forum slated to take place this weekend.

Siew and his entourage, including Morris Chang, founder and chairman of the world's largest contract chip maker, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC); Walsin Lihwa Corp.'s Chairman Chiao You-lun; Taiwan Cement Corp.'s Chairman Leslie Koo; and Su Chi, a professor with Tamkang University, were met at Hainan's Haikou International Airport by Chen Yunlin, China's top official in charge of Taiwan affairs.
The vice president-elect is expected to be honored with a dinner Friday hosted jointly by Chen's office -- China's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs -- and the Hainan provincial government.
Siew will be attending the forum scheduled to open at 5:30 p.m. Saturday, and will be accompanied by Chan Huo-sheng, an adviser to Siew's delegation to the forum.
The most "expected" and high-profile meeting between Siew and Hu is slated for Saturday, although Siew and his team members were still reluctant to confirm it.
Siew is scheduled to preside over a roundtable meeting on Taiwan economy and the prospects of cross-strait business and trade development Sunday before concluding his three-day visit to Hainan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Fleet of Friendship visiting Guatemala
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 10 (CNA) 04/11/08 18:18:57 (By Ramon Huang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two warships carrying 850 military cadets is berthing at Guatemala's Puerto Quetzal Port, for a friendship visit and exchanges in military education, according to a Thursday report by EFE, Spain's leading news agency.
The reports pointed out that the two warships--a Kangding-class frigate and Chenggong-class vessel, plus acombat support ship, composed Taiwan's Fleet of Friendship.
The fleet takes a voyage abroad every year as a shipboard training program for students at the Naval Academy and the National Defense University prior to their graduation.

Citing Guatemala's Vice President Rafael Espada, the reports said the visit of the fleet, which arrived at the port April 8, is aimed at strengthening bilateral relations through exchanges in military education.
An official of Taiwan's embassy in Guatemala told a CNA reporter that the students will perform military music and karate at the Plaza of Constitution in Guatemala City Thursday.

Another official at Taiwan's embassy in El Salvador said the three ships will arrive at the Acajutla Port in the country's Sonsonate Province Friday and will be open for local people to tour for two days.
Students from the ship will visit El Salvadore's important military sites and scenic spots, the official said.
Before setting out on the voyage in mid-March, the fleet made stops at seven domestic harbors to let Taiwanese people acquire a better understanding of the naval force's armaments.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most disposable chopsticks have bleaching agent traces: CF

TEXT.P: The Consumer's Foundation warned Friday that most disposable chopsticks provided by restaurants in Taiwan contain toxic bleaching agents that pose considerable health risks.

In a random survey of disposable chopsticks from 40 restaurants nationwide collected between December 2007 and January 2008, the foundation found that 68 percent of the samples had traces of sulfur dioxide, with one pair having an amount of the chemical that exceeded accepted norms, said foundation Chairman Cheng Jen-hung.
"Even though the chopsticks are not produced by the restaurants, they are still responsible for consumers' safety," Cheng said.
The sulfur dioxide, a colorless chemical used in bleaching and preserving foods, helps restrain microbes from proliferating and prevents the chopsticks from becoming moldy and change color.
According to local regulations, the sulfur dioxide found on chopsticks should be below 500 parts per million (ppm).

People who are sulfite-sensitive can develop asthma, breathing difficulties, diarrhea and vomiting when eating with disposable chopsticks, Cheng said, and he advised consumers to smell the chopsticks before using them.
If they smell sour, he said, they may contain sulfur dioxide.
In addition, consumers should break the chopsticks after eating with them "to prevent some manufacturers from reusing them, " Cheng suggested.
"But the best solution is to use your own pair of reusable chopsticks to protect the environment and your health, " Cheng stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post:A Weekend to Start Fixing the World
Financial markets are tumbling. The world economy is starting to sputter. Food prices have shot up so far, so fast, that there are riots in the streets of many poor nations.
The Washington Times:McCain advisers tied to foreign lobbying
Two of Sen. John McCain's top advisers and fundraisers are among several Republican and Democratic presidential campaign officials whose lobbying firms have been paid more than $15 million by foreign governments since 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:Fight for Sadr City a Proving Ground for Iraq Military
The Iraqi soldiers pushed their way up a main thoroughfare in Sadr City over the past week, but the militias that still prowl the Shiite enclave were sniping at them from the alleyways.
The Wall Street Journal: Microsoft Remains Favorite In Crowded Battle for Yahoo
Yahoo Inc.'s directors meet Friday to discuss alternatives to a Microsoft Corp. takeover, with many insiders still seeing a Microsoft deal -- without the participation of News Corp. -- as the most likely outcome.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Zoo management criticized for unfair treatment of animals

TEXT.P: Taipei City councilors criticized the city zoo management Friday for treating animals with two different standards under its plan to house a pair of long- expected star guests -- two pandas from China -- in a "luxurious mansion" while keeping other animals in small, shabby cages.

City Councilors Hsu Chia-ching and Wu Si-yiao of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed that an "M-shaped" society is forming in the Taipei City Zoo, after the management spent more than NT$300 million (US$9.9 million) in building a special exhibition hall to accommodate the Chinese giant pandas.

The "M-shaped" society generally refers to the widening gap between the rich and poor in Taiwan and the island's dwindling middle class as more people cannot keep up with the rising cost of living, especially under stagnating wages.
In the case of the zoo, however, the Shin Kong Group, which owns some 18 affiliated companies in Taiwan, donated NT$250 million for the exhibition hall.
Construction of the hall began in 2003 and it is scheduled to be completed this June.

According to the city councilors, the facility occupies a plot of land that measures more than 1,400 square meters, and each of the pandas, if they could come to Taipei for a long stay, would occupy a room that measures some 689 square meters - as big as a "presidential suite" in a five-star hotel.

In comparison, a Burmese python only lives in a 6.6 square-meter glass exhibition box, while the Asian yellow pond turtle, a protected amphibian native to Taiwan, is kept together with many other kinds of turtles in one glass tank, Hsu said at a press conference which she and her colleague held at the City Council.

Hsu said she suspected the dormitory-like living environment was the cause of death of 10 Asian yellow pond turtles in 2006. She said the turtles were attacked or died from disease transmitted by other species living with them.
Wu criticized the zoo for attaching much greater importance to boosting tourism than to animal conservation and educational affairs.
She also doubted new Taipei Zoo Director Yeh Chie-sheng is the right person for the post which requires professional knowledge of animal caring and conservation.
Yeh assumed the office April 2 after his predecessor Wu Pao-chung retired. He was promoted from the position of deputy director general of the city Bureau of Civil Affairs.

In response to the criticisms, Yeh said he takes the job with an open mind, and noted that the zoo, under the management of a group of professionals, has been listed as one of the world's top 10 zoos.

Chang Ming-chie, head of the animal division, said the zoo is not only commissioned to display animals but also to shelter those seized in agriculture authorities' raids against illegal animal smuggling.
He also explained that in the wild, different species live together in one place, and that if the species share similar genes they would mate with each other to produce hybrids.

Beijing offered the pandas to Taiwan in 2005 following then-opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China in May that year, but the pandas were then rejected by the current DPP government. The government and the DPP criticized the offer as a publicity ploy by China, which wants to eventually reunify with Taiwan.
The panda issue returned to the media spotlight after President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the KMT said he welcomed them after Ma won the presidential election last month.
The Taipei Zoo has been actively seeking to host the celebrities, which the city government regards as a way to boost tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's bullet train ready to welcome 23 millionth passenger

TEXT.P: Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) said Friday that with passenger volume continuing to rise, it is now expecting the 23 millionth passenger, or the number of the nation's total population.
THSRC officials said that as of Thursday, the company has sold 22,873,331 high speed rail tickets, and they think that it will see the 23 millionth passenger in the next few days.

To celebrate yet another milestone in the system, the officials said they are preparing to present the 23 millionth passenger with 23 business-class tickets as well as high speed rail system memorabilia.
Since the north-south high speed rail system was inaugurated on Jan. 5, 2007, it has continued to see new records in passenger volume and revenues, officials said.
The passenger volume and revenues reached 2.31 million and NT$1.903 billion (US$62.59 million), respectively, in March, both setting records in a single month.
The passenger volume broke the threshold of 1 million on Jan. 22, 2007; 10 million on Sept. 18, 2007, and 20 million on March 7.
The bullet train helps reduce the travel time between Taipei and Kaohsiung to 90 minutes from the original four-and-a-half-hours.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Thinktank blasts VP-elect's visit to China

TEXT.P: Speakers at a Taiwan Thinktank forum on Friday branded Vice President-elect Vincent Siew's appearance at an economic forum in China "irresponsible and impetuous conduct" and suggested that the entry permit he used for the trip belittled Taiwan.

"Siew's visit to the forum is completely impetuous and lacks a plan, " said Lai Yi-chung, deputy-director of the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Department of International Affairs, at a seminar organized by the pro-DPP think tank discussing expectations for Siew's trip.
Siew left for China early Friday to take part in the Boao Forum for Asia being held in China's southern Hainan province from April 11 to 13.
He will be making his sixth consecutive appearance at the annual conference in his capacity as chairman of the private Taipei-based Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation.

Siew's trip marks the first time a Taiwanese vice president-elect has set foot on Chinese soil and will be the first public encounter between Chinese officials and a member of the future Kuomintang administration since the party's Ma Ying- jeou was elected president on March 22.
The seminar's participants blasted Siew for the possibility that he might hold a closed-door meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao.
Lai said Siew should not talk to Chinese leaders as no consensus has been reached yet in Taiwan on cross-strait issues.
Ma, who won the presidency by a 17 percentage point margin, campaigned on the promise of forging closer and more open economic ties with China.

Many have attached significance to Siew's trip as a possible new beginning for more harmonious cross-Taiwan Strait relations, although it was unclear how much contact Siew would have with Chinese officials at the forum.

Lai said, however, that it would be a severe test of the potential future use of "the 1992 consensus" -- which has both Taiwan and China recognizing there is only one China but agreeing to differ on its definition.
If Siew is using a standard "re-entry permit for Taiwan compatriots," it would be a serious issue, Lai contended.

The requirement of such a permit might be an indication that China refuses to accept President- elect Ma Ying-jeou's "mutual non-denial (of each other's existence) " stance, or even worse, that Ma's "1992 consensus" would be interpreted as accepting the "one-China" policy," Lai argued.
Former DPP legislator Lin Cho-shui said Siew should immediately make clear how he entered China.

"How could Siew brag that this is a 'diplomatic breakthrough' if he uses a Taiwan compatriot entry permit? It would be a head of state (Hu Jintao) meeting with a citizen of the People's Republic of China," Lin said.

Lin questioned how Siew would lead his subordinates after being inaugurated on May 20, arguing that officials of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation or those attending Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forums, have not needed Taiwan compatriot permits when visiting China in the past.
A "tacit" face-saving agreement has existed in the past to facilitate the entry of Taiwanese officials into China.

At APEC forums, for example, the officials would present their invitation to enter the country, and the Chinese government would unilaterly process their "re-entry permit for Taiwan compatriots" without actually giving it to them.
Lin urged Siew, if he used the permit to go to Boao, to relinquish it, apologize and withdraw from the forum immediately.

As to speculation that China intends to use this meeting between Hu and Siew to divert attention in the international community on the Tibet issue, Lai said "Taiwan should not become China's accomplice in suppressing Tibet."

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision launches new campaign to sponsor indigenous children

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan and Starbucks Coffee Company Taiwan began their 10th year of cooperation on charitable projects by launching Friday another campaign to help indigenous children stay in school and attend after-school tutorial programs.
"Contributing to society and the environment is an important mission of our company, " said Hsu Kwang-yu, general manager of Starbucks in Taiwan.
The campaign, called "Bringing Hope to Indigenous Children" will kick off April 17 and last for three months.

All 215 Starbucks coffee shops in Taiwan will have fundraising boxes and will sell products like notebooks and reusable chopsticks to raise money to sponsor 961 indigenous children in central Taiwan's Nantou County, Hsu said.
World Vision Taiwan National Director Hank Du said that the two organizations hoped to raise greater public awareness of the predicament of indigenous children.

Being one of the first group of children who benefited from the program, a boy who went by the alias Hsiao Chun said he used to blame God for his misfortune until he received support from the charity.
"I learned to look at poverty and illness with a positive attitude, " said Chun, suffering from polio. "I wish to help other underprivileged indigenous children after graduating from university."
Well-known Taiwanese designer Jamei Chen is also taking part in the event, designing a limited edition T-shirt.
"The black bear print on the T-shirt represents the forests where many indigenous people live," she said.

Starbucks launched the aid program with World Vision in 1999, the same year the global company set up its first branch in Taiwan, to help those who lost their homes in the September 21 earthquake that claimed over 2,000 lives, injured more than 8,500 people, and destroyed 6,000 buildings.
Some NT$ 31 million (US$ 1 million) has been raised in the past 10 years to sponsor 10,544 indigenous children to get their educations and organize over 100 after-class tutorial sessions for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-dumping duties on coated art paper imports should continue: MOEA

TEXT.P: The International Trade Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has reached consensus that it is still necessary for Taiwan to levy anti-dumping duties on coated art paper imported from Japan to protect domestic products from unfair competition.

The commission announced its findings Thursday after conducting a review on behalf of the Ministry of Finance in accordance with a ruling by the Supreme Administrative Court in June 2008 that called for a re-evaluation of the impact of imported coated art paper from Japan on local manufacturers of the same type of product.

The Supreme Administrative Court ruling was made after the finance ministry appealed a decision by the Taipei High Administrative Court in favor of an importer of paper products, requiring the ministry to cease levying anti-dumping duties on imported coated art paper from Japan.

The MOEA commission said its members reached the conclusion that lifting the anti-dumping duties would again cause harm to locally produced coated art paper products, and that the commission will submit its observation for the finance ministry to make its final decision.
Taiwan has imposed anti-dumping duties on coated art paper imported from Japan since July 2000 at rates varying between 8 percent and 44 percent.

Because China has also imposed anti-dumping duties up to 71 percent on the same product from Japan since August 2003, members of the commission said they fear that lifting the anti-dumping duties now would turn Taiwan into a major dumping ground for Japanese overproduction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Direct links will push Chinese companies to Taiwan: job bank
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/08 20:00:30 (By H. H. Chiou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The anticipated establishment of direct transportation and trade links across the Taiwan Strait will push Chinese companies to recruit professional talent in Taiwan, an executive of a Taipei-based head hunting company said here Friday.

Alex Huang, CEO in charge of the Chinese market for www.104.com. tw, one of the largest Web sites providing human resource services in Taiwan, said opening direct transportation routes will further boost cross-strait economic and political exchanges and attract Chinese and foreign enterprises to set up strongholds in Taiwan, creating more job opportunities for Taiwanese people.
According to Huang, his division in Shanghai has recently received many inquiries for Taiwanese professionals from Chinese corporations.
One of them, an electronics company, has offered to pay from 600,000-700,000 Chinese yuan (US$85,817) per year for a sales representative position in Taiwan, he said.
The Chinese company is offering the Taiwan-based post in the hope of receiving more orders directly from Taiwan, he explained.
Due to the lack of direct air travel and shipping services across the strait in the past, Chinese businesses were passive about exploring means to bolster two- way contacts, he pointed out.

Huang, however, said that with direct transportation and trade links hopefully to be put in place between the two sides in the short term, Chinese companies are set to take concrete measures to reduce transportation and other operating costs.

Against such a backdrop, more Chinese and foreign corporations will certainly open offices or shops in Taiwan, creating a larger number of jobs in Taiwan and boosting local people's willingness to work in China, he forecast.

According to a survey conducted by Huang's company after Taiwan's March 22 presidential election, more than 17,000 Taiwan job seekers were trying to land a job in China in March -- the highest number for a single month in more than two years.
For the whole of last month, the number of full-time job seekers in the domestic market had reached nearly 300,000, the survey showed.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang, who adopts a more pragmatic approach to China, has repeatedly promised to implement direct air and shipping services between Taiwan and China as soon as possible after his May 20 inauguration.
Such links currently do not exist due to a political stalemate across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elementary school students to set off on trip to Singapore

TEXT.P: A group of elementary school students from northeastern Taiwan's Yilan County is preparing to go on a trip to Singapore with money they earned in the past year from selling home-made specialty foods.
It's a dream come true for the group of 37 fifth-graders from Hsin Nan Elementary School in Yilan's Chuangwei Township, who will depart from Yilan for Singapore on April 15 for the five-day trip.

At a function dubbed "Here we come, Singapore!" held at the school, County Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua presented the banner representing the northeastern county, wishing the children a happy and safe tour of Singapore.

The fifth-graders have worked under the assistance and guidance of their parents and teachers over the past year to produce and market home-made specialty foods, such as Amerille melon marmalade, sweet preserved roselle, fermented soybean curds and peanut candy, in a bid to earn enough money for their air tickets to Singapore.
The fifth-graders' primary activities in Singapore will be visits to Singapore's Hong Wen Primary School, said Hsin Nan Elementary School Principal Liu Hsi-hsin.
During the visits to the Singaporean elementary school, the students will show off their talent and skills in riding unicycles, diabolo juggling and exercising martial arts and gymnastics.
Hsin Nan Elementary School has also prepared four brand new unicycles to give to the Singaporean school as a token of friendship, Liu said.

After the news of the fifth-graders' wishes to tour Singapore with their own money was reported last month via foreign wire services, some Singaporean residents of Taiwanese descent have sent letters to Hsin Nan Elementary School, offering to provide hospitality to the students when they arrive in Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: HP to help improve southern county's development

TEXT.P: The Taiwan branch of Hewlett-Packard (HP) Co., the world's largest personal computer maker, has promised to help enhance the southern county of Kaohsiung's development and education, a top county official said Thursday.

The announcement came a day after HP Taiwan obtained approval from the central government to set up a facility in the southern county's 570-hectare science park, said County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing.

HP, which purchases NT$800 billion (US$26.3 billion) in goods from Taiwan last year, has promised to help transform Kaohsiung into a WiMAX county that offers a wide range of broadband wireless service, Yang said.
The county government has been working hard to attract major high-tech companies to the science park in recent years to narrow the development gap between northern and southern Taiwan.

HP Taiwan will encourage its Taiwanese subcontractors -- including Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., the world's largest contract electronics maker, and Quanta Computer Inc., the largest contract manufacturer of notebook computers -- to set up operations in the science park, Yang noted.
HP Taiwan will also collaborate with local universities on various projects, Yang said.

In a separate project, the computer maker has promised to assist the county government to build a village that gives visitors an opportunity to practice English with native speakers who dress as people from different walks of life, Yang noted.
Some local governments in Taiwan have set up or planned to build such a village to improve local schoolchildren's English ability.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA to keep ban on 800 Chinese agricultural products after May 20

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will continue to ban more than 800 Chinese agricultural products from entering Taiwan after May 20 when president-elect Ma Ying-jeou will assume office, a COA official said Friday.

Deputy COA Minister Hu Hu-hsiung noted that the COA currently imposes a ban on more than 800 Chinese agricultural products, which he said is allowed under the framework of the World Trade Organization based on the principles of protecting a country's domestic agricultural products and quarantine necessity.
Both Taiwan and China are WTO members.
Hu also said that Taiwan currently allows the imports of more than 1,000 Chinese agricultural products.
Hu was responding to questions by Legislator Twu Shiing-jer of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party who wanted to know how the COA will execute Ma's cross-strait policy.

Ma advocated during his presidential campaign that Taiwan should export its agricultural products to China to help Taiwanese farmers earn money but he pledged to at the same time restrict Chinese agricultural products from flooding into Taiwan.
On cross-strait agricultural product exchanges, Hu said "the most urgent thing is to help Taiwan farmers get intellectual property rights protection when their products are exported to China."
The move is aimed at "preventing agricultural know-how from flowing to China," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Drivers faced heavy fine for misuse of ETC toll lane

TEXT.P: Freeway authorities warned motorists Friday they will face a steep fine if they back up in the electronic toll collection (ETC) lane after discovering they drove through the wrong toll booth.

Motorists not equipped to use the ETC toll lane will be fined NT$3,000 to NT$6,000 (US$99 to US$198) if they drive through the toll booth and then back up, hoping to correct their mistake, or if they change lanes as they approach the automatic toll booth, the Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau (TANFB) said in a statement.
Under the statute governing road traffic, drivers are fined NT$600 to NT$1,200 if they mistakenly drive through an ETC toll booth but then continue on their way.
One lane is usually reserved at toll stations on Taiwan's No. 1 and No. 3 freeways for cars equipped for the ETC system, which collects tolls electronically.

The system was embroiled in controversy when first installed, saddled with disputes over its accuracy, the cost of the on-board unit, and suspicions that Far Eastern Electronic Toll Collection bribed officials to win the contract to operate the BOT (build, operate, transfer) project.

But the freeway bureau announced Friday that it was now permitted Far Eastern to open another ETC lane at the Taishan Toll Collection Station in Taipei County, northern Taiwan, to ease heavy back-ups during peak hours.

Traffic flow at the Taishan toll station is heavier than at other toll stations on the freeway, with freeway bureau statistics showing that as many as 1,837 vehicles have poured through the station in an hour.

DOC.HEADLINE: American artist exposes human wastefulness in exhibition in Taipei

TEXT.P: An environmental art exhibit featuring the enormity of waste produced in contemporary America opened at Liberty Square in Taipei Friday to celebrate Earth Day and to raise people's awareness about the environmental crisis.

The exhibition, named "Running the Numbers -- An American self- portrait", presents photographs by an American photographer, Chris Jordan, whose aim is to visualize the enormity of the waste that people produce everyday.
For example, people can see in his photos 106,000 cans that are dumped by Americans in 30 seconds, two million plastic bags used by them every five minutes, or 410,000 paper cups used in 15 minutes.

Some images are synthesized by the photographer. People will see a picture of woman's breast, made up of 32,000 Barbie dolls, which is also the number of elective breast augmentation surgeries performed monthly in the U.S. in 2006.

Visitors will also see a skull, with a cigarette between the teeth. The skull is composed of 200,000 packs of cigarettes, equal to the number of Americans who die from cigarette smoking every six months.

"Through my work, I'd like to convey a message that collectivity is made of many individuals, " said Jordan in the opening ceremony of the exibition, adding that each individual is responsible for wastefulness, which is causing an environmental crisis.

Asked about the origin of his idea, the photographer, whose work has been exhibited worldwide, explained that most people reading the huge numbers of the waste on pages of newspapers or reports do not feel anything, and he wanted to "translate the cold language to a visual one."
Stressing the importance of every individual's effort, he urged people to reduce daily waste, saying that "one thing we can control is our behavior."
Jordan was once a lawyer, enjoying high social status and material wealth, but he decided to dedicate himself to showing his care for the world through his photos several years ago.

The exhibition is organized by the National Geographic Channels International to celebrate Earth Day on April 22. This year is the 10th anniversary of the channel's presence in Taiwan and the 120th anniversary of the National Geographic Society.
The images are exhibited outdoor at Liberty Square from April 11-27.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect arrives in China for Boao Forum
DOC.DATELINE: Boao, China, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/08 21:25:33 (By I. F. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Vincent Siew arrived in southern China's Hainan province Friday to attend the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia, a visit that could represent a watershed in cross-Taiwan Strait ties.

Although Siew is attending the economic conference in a private capacity, he hoped that his attendance at the forum will help thaw relations between Taiwan- China, which have been stalled for more than a decade because of a political impasse over Taiwan's sovereignty.
Chinese President Hu Jintao and other Chinese officials will be present at the annually held conference from April 11-13 and are expected to meet with Siew.
"With this trip, I hope I can help the two sides build mutual trust and enhance bilateral understanding through the forum's platform," Siew said upon his arrival.

There had been speculation that Siew would meet Hu in a one-on-one meeting at the forum, but a Siew spokesman said on Friday that Hu would instead meet with Siew together with other members of Taiwan's 14-member delegation for 20 minutes Saturday afternoon.
According to the spokesman, Siew has not brought any message from President- elect Ma Ying-jeou for Hu.
Ma and Siew of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) won Taiwan's March 22 presidential election. The pair has vowed to set up closer economic ties with China
Siew's delegation will host a round-table forum on the cross-strait economic outlook on Saturday at the conference.

"I would like to take the opportunity to exchange opinions on Asian and international economic development and also share Taiwan's standpoint with the rest of the world, " the vice president-elect said.

Siew is the first vice president-elect from Taiwan to set foot on Chinese soil, although he has repeatedly stressed that he is taking part in this year's Boao Forum in his capacity as chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation as he has done over the past five years.
The Boao Forum is a private organization dedicated to economic cooperation in the region, with members including China, Japan and the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County Council speaker begins to serve five-month sentence

TEXT.P: Tainan County Council Speaker Wu Chien-bao was sent to prison to serve a five- month sentence Thursday on an illegal gambling conviction after a prosecutor exercised her right of discretion and refused to allow him to pay a fine instead.
The Taiwan High Court's Tainan branch had sentenced Wu to five months in prison for operating and illegal gambling parlor in 2004 but commuted the sentence to an NT$137,000 fine.

When Wu appeared at the Tainan Public Prosecutors Office to settle the case, prosecutor Chang Wan-ning decided that the fine would not serve justice because Wu's illegal gambling operation netted huge profits, with daily proceeds amounting to millions of NT dollars.
Citing one example, Chang said Wu's deputy, Kuo Hsiu-chu, admitted to losing NT$80 million (US$2.64 million) within 10 days at Wu's underground casino during the 2004 Lunar New Year holiday.

The prosecutor decided on the spot to have Wu serve his five-month sentence without delay, based on Article 41 of the Code of Criminal Procedure of the Republic of China, which gives prosecutors the power to enforce a prison sentence if they deem a fine instead as an insufficient remedy.
Wu appeared stunned, as he was obviously unprepared for the prosecutor's decision. His family said they will ask lawyers to file a petition within one month to seek redress for his imprisonment.
If unsuccessful, Wu, as an inmate serving a criminal sentence, could be deprived of his qualification as an elected Tainan County councilor.

The 57-year-old Tainan County Council speaker has been a controversial figure. A member of the opposition Kuomintang, he was elected as a county councilor in 1998 and was re-elected in 2002 and became the speaker in the same year.

Wu failed in his bid for a seat in the legislature when Li Chun-yi, his opponent from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, defeated him in the Jan. 12 legislative election by a margin of 8,000 votes.
He was connected to a game-fixing ring in Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League last year. The case is still pending in the Tainan District Court.

According to prosecutors, he paid five Chinatrust Whales players NT$300,000 each through the head of a gambling ring in exchange for their cooperation in fixing the games. The team is one of six professional baseball teams in Taiwan,

The gambling ring leader also helped Wu to profit by using dummy accounts to place large bets at six gambling outlets. The prosecutors said that at one of the outlets, the weekly turnover amounted to a staggering NT$1.4 billion (US$46.2 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairman would probably attend presidential inauguration

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh said Thursday that he "would probably attend" the May 20 inaugural ceremony of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang.

In an interview with cable television network SET TV, the defeated former presidential candidate said that he was considering attending the ceremony, adding that he was also present at the inauguration of former president Lee Teng-hui.
Meanwhile, Hsieh dismissed speculation that the DPP was mired in infighting ahead of the party's election of a new chairman to replace him in May. Hsieh has decided to step down.
Media reports of infighting grew after Hsieh recently accused President Chen Shui-bian of applying double standards in the handling of corruption charges.

According to media reports, Hsieh criticized Chen for demanding that DPP members who were merely suspected of corruption be expelled from the party, but for being lenient when it came to Chen's family.
Chen's wife has been indicted for embezzlement and his son-in-law has been convicted of insider trading.
"It is incorrect to call our self-examination a power struggle, " Hsieh said, adding that his remarks about Chen were made in connection with self-reflection by the party.
Hsieh stressed that "there isn't any need for infighting, " even though the DPP lost the presidential election. He said he will never run for president or party chairman again.
To win the city and county chief elections in late 2009, Hsieh said the DPP must first engage in reflection and reform, while cementing party unity.

The DPP chairman also encouraged those interested in running for the DPP chairmanship to throw their hats in the ring. He expressed hope that the next chairman will be a reformer and will be able to reach out to the grassroots communities.

With regard to his turning down a visit request by Ma, Hsieh explained that considering that Ma was quite busy and the meeting served as a mere formality, he decided not to meet with Ma and that it was not a "boycott".
He added he will continue to keep a close eye on the government after Ma takes office May 20.

On his plans after stepping down as party chairman, Hsieh said he hopes to share his experience in political and public affairs with the general public, particularly young people, to enable them to develop the capabilities of supervising the government.
Hsieh also floated an idea of running a "shadow government" to monitor the government, which would be based on the DPP's basic values and concept of a "wellbeing economy."

Meanwhile, he plans to modify his campaign Web site into an "Internet Radio" to allow experienced politicians and young talents to work together to upgrade grassroots people's ability to supervise government operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of private companies in Taiwan down slightly in 2007

TEXT.P: A total of 1.18 million for-profit businesses were operating in Taiwan at the end of 2007, down 0.2 percent from a year earlier, according to a report by the country's statistics bureau profiling Taiwan's economic activity.
As of the end of February 2008, there were 596,000 "existing companies" officially registered with the Ministry of Economic Affairs, down 3.6 percent from a year earlier.

But to get a more accurate look at overall economic activity in Taiwan, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics (DGBAS) relied on tax bureau figures to assess the number of businesses and in the country and the size of their turnover.
Sole proprietorships, like small retail stores, and partnerships are not included among the MOEA's registered companies but do file taxes and account for a substantial amount of economic activity.

Over half, or 612,052, of the businesses in the DGBAS report were involved in the wholesale and retail sectors, down 0.7 percent from the end of 2006, while the cultural, sports and leisure category had the fewest number of companies at 25,546, down 9.3 percent from the end of 2006, the report, released Thursday, indicated.

Despite the growing demand for leisure activities in Taiwan, the decline registered in the leisure sector was the largest of any sector, followed by the 1.3 percent decline in the number of manufacturers to 128,761, the statistics showed.

Some sectors showed increases in the number of companies, with the accommodations and food-services sector growing 3 percent with 97,758 businesses and the real estate and rental sector growing 2.5 percent with 26,552 businesses.

The total sales of the businesses in the DGBAS study rose 4.2 percent year on year to NT$36.32 trillion (US$1.19 trillion), with sales by manufacturers growing 10.4 percent in 2007 to NT$13.29 trillion, the highest of any business category. Sales in the wholesale and retail sector totaled NT$12.5 trillion for the year, 4.1 percent higher than in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan City reports 44 suspected enterovirus cases in last month

TEXT.P: The Tainan city government reported Friday that 44 suspected enterovirus cases were discovered in the city between mid-March and April 10, with the case load likely to grow as the peak period for the virus quickly approaches.
Four of the suspected cases were serious ones, the southern Taiwan city said in a statement.

A 20-month-old boy in the southern county of Kaohsiung died from the enterovirus on March 5, the first reported fatality in Taiwan this year caused by the virus that is highly infectious in young children.

Of the enterovirus cases that have hit children in Taiwan so far this year, 85 percent of the infected children were under the age of five and 73 percent were under the age of three, the city's health bureau said, citing figures released by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health as of April 3.
The epidemic usually emerges in late March before reaching its peak between May and June. It often reappears in September when schools open.
Outbreaks of the virus in Taiwan have been centered in the southern part of the island, with Tainan City particularly hard hit in recent years.
In its statement, the city's health bureau urged local parents not to ignore the virus and stressed frequent hand-washing was still the most effective way to avoid contracting enterovirus.
The bureau said the practice was not as widespread as it needed to be, citing a recent survey conducted among people who take care of children under five years old.
Only 20.2 percent of the respondents in the survey said they wash their hands before coming in contact with children, which poses a serious health concern, the bureau said.
Bureau officials have also discovered from their visits to local schools to raise awareness of the epidemic that about 40 percent of the city's children did not wash their hands cleanly enough.
Those infected with the virus can develop blisters on their hands, feet or in the mouth, or a flu-like illness with fever and muscle aches.
Taiwan had not reported any deaths from enterovirus in the past two years.

In 1998, Taiwan experienced a severe outbreak of E71 -- the deadliest type of the virus -- with 405 children infected, 78 of whom died. Another E71 outbreak in 2005 infected 145 children, 15 of whom died.

DOC.HEADLINE: Students hike to raise funds for charity

TEXT.P: Students and their teachers from a private senior high school in Taitung City went on a 14-kilometer hike Friday during an annual fund-raising activity.

In its renewal of a unique charity activity their school has held for years, students at Kung Tung Technical Senior High School promised to walk one kilometer in exchange for a donation of NT$1 to raise money for underprivileged children and groups in the city.
This year, the students decided to walk 14 kilometers, meaning they had to get donations of at least NT$14, said Lan Chen-fan, principal of the school located in southeastern Taiwan.
Kung said the students raised NT$200,000 (US$6,599) this year, far more than they had expected.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pro-independence lawmaker to run for party chairmanship

TEXT.P: Legislator Trong Chai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) announced Friday that he will register next Monday to run in the May 18 party chairman election.
The stalwart pro-Taiwan independence lawmaker was the first potential candidate to make his intention to run for the post publicly known.

Chai said his platform will include a reform of the party's nominating mechanism as well as appointing members from the younger generation to serve as the party's vice chairmen so that they will have the opportunity to groom themselves for leadership.
"In this way, the party can achieve generational change, " he said.

DPP Legislator Wang Sing-nan, who is also a staunch advocate of Taiwan independence, said that no individual who takes the helm of the party can reform the party alone and that he would suggest to Chai that he set up a collective leadership after being elected.

He also suggested that 200,000 DPP members take part in community service as volunteers, so that they will "touch the hearts of the public" like members of Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, the largest charity organization in Taiwan.
Chai's announcement drew mixed reactions from colleagues within the party.

DPP Legislator Lee Chun-yi said that he couldn't dismiss anyone who wants to contribute to the party, but if only Tsai registers, then there will be no other choice, which he said was bad for the DPP.
Lee expressed the hope that "more will register with the party," and that "the younger generation display passion."
DPP Legislator Su Cheng-ching said he believes an election would further splinter the party, already thrown into disarray after severe setbacks in the March 22 and the Jan. 12 legislative elections.
He also suggested that Council of Agriculture Minister Su Jia-chyuan would be a suitable candidate.
The legislator, who represents a district in the southern county of Pingtung that Su Jia-chyuan once headed, noted that a party chairman "should have abroad base of support."
He noted that Su Jia-chyuan has served as a legislator, county magistrate and interior minister, giving him ample experience in a variety of major posts.
There are also reports that the now-defunct New Tide Faction within the party could field former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen for the post.
On the other hand, former Council for Hakka Affairs Chairman Luo Wen-jia said Friday that he believes he is not up to the challenge of serving as party chairman.
"There are others who are more suitable to serve in the post, " Luo said.
But the outspoken young Turk also said frankly that he believes the "heavyweights" within the party are no longer suitable to take part in the race.

DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh recently suggested that members of the party's younger generation, including Luo and former Government Information Office head Lin Chia-lung, both in their 40s, run in the election.

The DPP will invite hopefuls to register with the party April 14-18 and organize a platform presentation for the candidates May 10. After the registration, the party will try to reach a consensus on one candidate through coordination, and, if that fails, then the party chairman election will be held May 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: Life sentence sought for former prosecutor on corruption charges

TEXT.P: Taipei prosecutors are seeking a life sentence for a former colleague whom they indicted Thursday for taking bribes totaling NT$6.2 million (US$204,620) in 2002 and 2003 while investigating two criminal cases.
If the Taipei District Court hands down a life sentence as requested, it will be the harshest punishment for an offense by a prosecutor in Taiwan's judicial history.

According to the indictment submitted to the court Thursday, Ko Chin-chu, 60, received NT$5.5 million in 2002 from Hong-En Hospital in Taipei through a lawyer friend while he was investigating the hospital's involvement in health insurance fraud.
The hospital allegedly paid the bribe in return for his promise not to prosecute its executives.

In 2003, Ko again worked with his lawyer friend, Lu Ching-nan, to solicit NT$700,000 from Chung Hua Hospital while investigating allegations that questioned the legality of the hospital's operations, in exchange for a promise that none of the defendants would be indicted.
This was not Ko's first brush with the law. In September last year, the Taipei District Court sentenced him to 12 years in prison on corruption charges.

The court found him guilty for taking a NT$1.2 million bribe in 2003 in return for promising not to indict Huang Ju-yi during an investigation into the gangster's alleged criminal activities. Ko has appealed the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan group calls on vice president-elect to push Hu on Tibet

TEXT.P: A human rights group on Friday urged Vice President-elect Vincent Siew to ask China's president to stop suppressing Tibet and hold dialogue with the Tibetan government- in-exile led by the Dalai Lama during their Saturday meeting at an economic forum in China.

The Taipei-based group, Taiwan Friends of Tibet, issued the call in a press release asking Siew to relay its concern over human rights conditions in Tibet after riots against Chinese rule erupted in mid-March in Lhasa.
Siew and other members of Taiwan's delegation are expected to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao Saturday afternoon for 20 minutes in a private meeting.
The group appealed to Beijing to immediately halt all acts of suppression in Tibet and begin peace talks quickly with the Dalai Lama.
"Beijing would win the highest respect from Taiwan's people and others across the world if it does so, " the group said in the statement.

Despite its impressive economic development over the past two decades, China will be still be seen as an authoritarian and feudal state if it continues to adopt oppressive policies against its people, who are keen for progress, modernization and human rights, the group said.

China should seize its hosting of this weekend's Boao Forum for Asia to display its leadership role and prove to the entire world its claim that its rise will be peaceful, especially as it will also host the 2008 Olympic Games in August, the group asseted.
"Now is the best time for China to change its image and improve its international status before the entire world," it argued.

Siew departed earlier in the day for the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia annual conference being held in Hainan province in southern China through April 13. The forum's main goal is to step up economic and trade cooperation in Asia.

Siew's participation at this year's conference has sparked widespread attention from across Taiwan's political spectrum because of his status as president- elect. The visit could be an early test of the newly elected government's hope for closer ties with Beijing.

Although Siew has stressed that he is attending the forum in his private capacity as chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation, he is the first vice president-elect from Taiwan ever to set foot on Chinese soil.

DOC.HEADLINE: President lauds military neutrality in Penghu

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lauded Taiwan's military Friday for remaining neutral in all local and central elections since he first took office in 2000.

The military neutrality demonstrated over the years is "a sign of progress", Chen told troops based on Penghu Island, adding that no member of the military can campaign for any specific political party or candidate.
Chen had been pushing for political neutrality and loyalty to the country rather than a party within the military and intelligence agencies since he came to power.
Taiwan's defense establishment had long been seen as being loyal to the Kuomintang (KMT) , which ruled Taiwan for the second half of the 20th century, before Chen was elected president in 2000.
In his speech, Chen also praised the Penghu-based troops for working hard to protect the country.
Chen's remarks came after he inspected a navy base and an army battalion on the island, 50 kilometers off Taiwan's west coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan even with Kazakhstan after first day of Davis Cup tie

TEXT.P: Kazakhstan used a mystery player to pull even with Taiwan Friday in the first day of their Davis Cup Asia/Oceania Group I playoff tie being played in Almaty this weekend.

After Taiwan's top singles player, Lu Yen-hsun, dispatched Kazakh veteran Alexey Kedryuk without much drama, 6-3, 7-5, 6-2, Chen Ti was called on to face world no. 127 Yuriy Schukin, the center of attention at this weekend's event.

On the ATP (Association of Tennis Professionals) Web site, Schukin is listed as a Russian and local media reported that even Kazakh journalists were wondering about his legitimacy as a member of the home Davis Cup team.

But Schukin recently obtained a Kazakhstan passport, and because he had never competed for Russia in the sport's premier international team event, he was eligible to compete for the central Asian nation.
The timing could not have been worse for Taiwan, which was likely to cruise to victory if Kazakhstan did not have its Russian import.
Instead Chen Ti, currently ranked 284th in the world, found out the hard way that Schukin is a potential threat, losing in five sets after taking two of the first three.

Schukin's 3-6, 6-3, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory gave his adopted country a 1-1 tie after the first day's singles, putting the pressure on Taiwan in Saturday's doubles, in which Chen and Lu are likely to team up, although Yang Tsung-hua, the Australian Open Junior Doubles champion, could also get the nod.
Taiwan lost its opening round match against Lleyton Hewitt-led Australia 4-1 in February in Kaohsiung and is now trying to avoid what would be a painful relegation.
A victory over Kazakhstan this weekend would keep Taiwan in Group I and conclude its Davis Cup campaign for the year.

But a defeat would send it into another playoff against the loser of the Uzbekistan-Philippines tie in September, with the loser being relegated to Asia/Oceania Zone Group II, where Taiwan has not played since 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 12, 2008

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP legislative caucus comes up with internal reform initiatives

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday that a controversial public polling method should be scrapped and that the party should step up efforts to recruit young members, following a meeting Friday held to review the party's latest election setbacks.
The DPP legislative caucus reached the consensus at the meeting aimed at bringing the demoralized party back to its feet.
DPP lawmakers present at the meeting suggested that polls that exclude "pro- blue" voters should no longer be used in nominating party candidates for local or national elections.
In choosing candidates to represent the party in the Jan. 12 legislative elections, the party held a primary and an opinion poll to decide the winner.

The opinion polls attempted to weed out respondents who were likely to support rival Kuomintang (KMT) candidates so that only the sentiment of hard-core DPP supporters was gauged, which many believe resulted in nominees who were less attractive to independent voters.
The participants also agreed that the party should produce its nominees through consultation rather than primaries because the latter have often led to irreparable divides within the DPP.

A consensus was also reached on the need to increase the number of the party's central and local officials and young members serving as party standing committee members to give them more opportunities to take part in the party's operations.
They also advised that the DPP plan early for the city and county chief elections scheduled for late 2009.

DPP Legislator Lin Shu-fen, who said that the party has been criticized for being estranged from the public during its eight years in power, suggested that it should "listen to the views of the people."
She also said the party needed to continue its tradition of debating different paths for the country's future and "to enrich its discourse on the core values of the party."

The participants argued that the DPP, which was founded on the ideals of cleanness and integrity, has seen its image tainted during the past eight years, especially in the latter part of President Chen Shui-bian's second-term when a series of scandals surrounding his family members and close aides came to light.

"The party failed to review the problems in time," Lin said, and after the impression of corruption took root, the party couldn't buck the trend and had suffered three major election setbacks since 2005, including the 2005 city and county chief elections and the Jan. 12 legislative elections this year.

They also said that the reforms that the party promoted, such as reform of the judicial, electoral and financial systems and a revamping of preferential saving rates for retired civil servants, military personnel and public school teachers, had failed to meet their goals.
The DPP also failed to force the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to return its ill- gotten assets to national coffers, they said.
On the campaign strategy of the presidential election, they believed that the DPP's slogans of "Taiwan reformation" and "happy economy" were too abstract for Taiwan's voters.

Although the DPP's warning against the KMT's "one-party dominance" of both the legislative and executive arms of the nation, as well as challenges to KMT candidate Ma Ying-jeou's loyalty and integrity over his alleged U.S. permanent resident status, did have some effect, the tactics failed to keep the voters.
The rude language leveled against Ma by some DPP members also turned the election into a negative campaign, which they said ran counter to the party's theme of "bringing happiness" to the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: Inflation to approach 3% if fuel, power rates rise: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's inflation rate will approach 3 percent if the new government simultaneously raises gasoline and electricity prices, the country's top economic planner cautioned Friday.

"The domestic consumer price index (CPI) could register nearly 3 percent annual growth this year if the new government to be sworn in May 20 opts to raise electricity and fuel prices in one 'lump sum' move, " said Ho Mei-yueh, chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Speaking in an interview with several local media outlets, Ho said the incumbent Democratic Progressive Party administration has consistently followed several principles in addressing fuel and utility pricing issues, including operating costs, corporate finances, market mechanisms and rate segmentation depending on the customer.

Nevertheless, Ho said that in the wake of recent sharp spikes in international commodity prices, the adjustment of domestic fuel and electricity prices could no longer be set simply based on raw material cost.

"Both the domestic and global macroeconomic situations should be factored in while formulating fuel and utility pricing policy, " Ho argued, adding that finding an opportune time and drafting complementary measures were extremely important in deciding whether to adjust gasoline and electricity prices.

State-run oil refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan has proposed raising its product prices by NT$2.8 per liter from May and another state-run enterprise Taiwan Power Co. also plans to raise electricity prices by NT$0.65 per kilowatt hour from May.

Should the two price hike plans be adopted and the local currency's exchange rate against the greenback stay at NT$30 to the dollar until the end of the year, inflation would rise more than 1 percentage point to around 3 percent, Ho warned.
She also said economic growth would drop by at least 1 percent from last year's level to about 3.3 percent.

Noting that small- and medium-size enterprises tend to bear the brunt of rising inflation, Ho said the incoming Kumointang government should take multiple factors into account in addressing fuel and electricity pricing issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 12, or the seventh day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1606: The Union Jack becomes the United Kingdom's official flag.
1860: Vajirananavarorasa, prince and patriarch of Buddhism in Siam, is born. He institutionalized Thai Buddhism.
1861: The U.S. Civil War breaks out as Confederate forces under Gen. Pierre Beauregarde take Fort Sumter in Charlestown harbor, South Carolina.
1927: The Kuomintang starts a "purification" movement by expelling communist members.
1945: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt dies in office at the age of 63. Vice President Harry S. Truman is sworn in as his successor.
1949: The 37.5 Per Cent Farm Rental Reduction Program goes into effect in Taiwan.
1953: The Legislative Yuan passes a bill submitted by President Chiang Kai-shek, extending the term of office for legislators by an additional year, to May 7, 1954.
1958: The first national meeting for commending "Good Men and Good Deeds" is held at Chung Shan Hall in Taipei.
1961: The Russians put the first man into space when cosmonaut Yauri Gargarin is launched in the Vostok I space vehicle for a single orbit of the earth.
1963: Indonesian forces launch an armed attack against Malaysia as part of a new policy of confrontation.
1966: Cheng Wan-fu, former chairman of the "Taiwan Democratic Party" and a leader of the "Taiwan Independence Movement" in Tokyo, returns to Taipei after 20 years of self-imposed exile in Japan.
1973: Deng Xiaoping, who was purged during the Cultural Revolution, resumes his position as the vice premier of Communist China.
1973: Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: Economic Affairs Vice Minister K.S. Chang, leading a group of government officials and businessmen, depart for San Francisco to attend a Sino-U.S. conference on economic relations.
1974: Tsinghwa University completes the installation of its second nuclear reactor for research purposes. This is the fourth research reactor installed in Taiwan.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan calls on the people to carry out the Last Testament of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1975: Taipei building contractors pledge NT$1 million to start a fund-raising campaign for the proposed Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1979: Taiwan's first geothermal power plant formally begins operations.
1981: Joe Louis, American prize fighter, dies at the age of 67. He held the heavyweight title for nearly 12 years (1937-1949), successfully defending it a record 25 times.
1981: Columbia, the world's first reusable space shuttle, is launched at Cape Canaveral.
1983: China Airlines inaugurates its regular flight service to Amsterdam as the first step toward establishing worldwide commercial air services.
1989: Honduran President Jose Azcona Hoyo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1994: The Mainland Affairs Council decides to suspend all cultural and educational exchanges with the mainland until Beijing provides reasonable and satisfactory explanations for the Qiandao Lake tragedy of March 31 in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed.
1996: The Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, are declared the world's tallest buildings.
2000: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew meets with Guenter Rexrodt, a former German economics minister, to exchange views on bilateral relations between the two countries.
2001: an IBM-Linux Development Center is inaugurated in Taiwan. The center will provide local individual and group users with system testing, technical exchanges, experience sharing and training on using the Linux operating system.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are wise men who are not moral characters; but a fool is never a moral character."

Siew's participation at this year's conference has sparked widespread attention from across Taiwan's political spectrum because of his status as president- elect. The visit could be an early test of the newly elected government's hope for closer ties with Beijing.

Although Siew has stressed that he is attending the forum in his private capacity as chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation, he is the first vice president-elect from Taiwan ever to set foot on Chinese soil.

DOC.HEADLINE: Life sentence sought for former prosecutor on corruption charges

TEXT.P: Taipei prosecutors are seeking a life sentence for a former colleague whom they indicted Thursday for taking bribes totaling NT$6.2 million (US$204,620) in 2002 and 2003 while investigating two criminal cases.
If the Taipei District Court hands down a life sentence as requested, it will be the harshest punishment for an offense by a prosecutor in Taiwan's judicial history.

According to the indictment submitted to the court Thursday, Ko Chin-chu, 60, received NT$5.5 million in 2002 from Hong-En Hospital in Taipei through a lawyer friend while he was investigating the hospital's involvement in health insurance fraud.
The hospital allegedly paid the bribe in return for his promise not to prosecute its executives.

In 2003, Ko again worked with his lawyer friend, Lu Ching-nan, to solicit NT$700,000 from Chung Hua Hospital while investigating allegations that questioned the legality of the hospital's operations, in exchange for a promise that none of the defendants would be indicted.
This was not Ko's first brush with the law. In September last year, the Taipei District Court sentenced him to 12 years in prison on corruption charges.

The court found him guilty for taking a NT$1.2 million bribe in 2003 in return for promising not to indict Huang Ju-yi during an investigation into the gangster's alleged criminal activities. Ko has appealed the case.

Los Angeles TimesG County medical crisis deepens.
Los Angeles County's profoundly troubled public healthcare system fell into further crisis Thursday when its embattled director abruptly quit, and negotiations with a private entity to reopen King-Harbor hospital fell apart. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

The United States will immediately notify Japan if a service member in the country deserts or otherwise goes absent without leave and will authorize police to take that person into custody if found, Foreign Minister Masahiko Komura said Friday.

: The Straits Times: Why torch protests are a bad move.
Protesters disrupting the Olympic torch relay have made an impact worldwide, but have missed the effect they are having on China's young people, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said yesterday.
They have aroused intense anti- foreigner feelings in young Chinese, who feel humiliated and have taken to venting their anger on the Internet.
