DOC.HEADLINE: Cluster infection of German measles reported in central Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) reported Saturday a cluster infection of German measles among Chinese-Malaysian students studying at a central Taiwan university.
Chou Chih-hao, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said that seven students were confirmed to have contracted German measles.

Chou said that the matter first came to light when two male Chinese-Malaysian students at the university sought treatment at the same clinic April 3 and April 4, respectively, after developing the symptoms of coughing, running noses and rashes.
As the two students were from abroad and had similar symptoms, the doctors treating them alerted the DOH April 6.

Chou said that health officials were dispatched to the school to collect specimens for testing. Among the seven male Chinese-Malaysians and one female Taiwanese student who had had contact with the two infected men, five were confirmed to have measles, including the Taiwanese student.

Further investigation found that one of the infected students had returned to Taiwan from Malaysia in late February, and developed obvious symptoms of the disease March 13. The DOH thus suspected that the cluster infection had originated overseas.
Chou said that the DOH has vaccinated 59 other foreign students against measles, mumps and rubella (MMR).
He said that as the rate of MMR vaccination in Taiwan is as high as 95 percent, and the vaccine is 95 percent effective, the DOH estimates that "the disease is unlikely to spread further."

Asked why the Taiwanese student was also infected, Chou said that she should have had 95 percent protection with the MMR vaccine, but that less than five percent of vaccinated people, because of individual factors, could still get the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public health care project takes root among indigenous people

TEXT.P: A pilot project aimed at delivering better health care to senior indigenous people has proved fruitful after several months of work, volunteers said Saturday at a press conference.

The project, launched in late 2007, was introduced by the Department of Public Health (DPH) of National Cheng Kung University and the National Association for the Promotion of Community University (NAPCU) to establish a complete system of public health care among indigenous tribes, most of which live in remote mountain areas.

Under the project, volunteers are focusing on providing health education to elderly people, and on establishing a team of health workers in each clan, said Chen Mei-xia, a DPH professor and volunteer on the project.

"Indigenous people need a public health system that would take into consideration factors such as their particular values, cultures, and autonomy, " the professor said, referring to the basis of the pilot project.

She said that "indigenous people are at a disadvantage in the area of public health because they have long been neglected by the society, " adding that the public health system in Taiwan is not very well developed.
In general, indigenous people lack medical resources and life expectancy is about an average of 10 years shorter compared to the wider population in Taiwan, Chen added.
In 2007 the average life expectancy in Taiwan was 77.5 years, according to the Department of Health under the Executive Yuan.

The DPH and NAPCU have recruited 188 volunteers, including 80 who are themselves indigenous, to work among 15 clans of the many tribes nationwide, and those numbers are expected to increase, Chen said.

"Young people have a chance to not only help care for the elderly, but also to contribute to the continuity of the indigenous culture," said Li Hui-lan, a religious worker in a clan in southern Taiwan who is also one of the volunteers on the project.
Li also said that the communication between the volunteers and senior members of the tribes could serve the purpose of recording oral history.

"We hope that the project will continue. Elderly people are very happy to know that others care about them," said Zhou Jin-mei, who has served at a health center in southern Taiwan for 23 years and is participating in the project.
"Now we particularly need more funding for disease prevention, " she added.
In Taiwan, the government officially recognizes 13 indigenous tribes that represent 484,000 people, or about 2.1 percent of the total population of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Youth Policy White Paper symposium held

TEXT.P: The "2008 Symposium on the Results of the Youth Policy White Paper Guidelines" was held Saturday, with government leaders, scholars and youth representatives discussing topics related to youth development, participation, health and protection.

The symposium, sponsored by the National Youth Commission, the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Education and the Department of Health, was held at the Civil Service Development Institute in Taipei City.

Speaking at the opening of the symposium, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung expressed the hope that the conclusions reached at the gathering will help the government in formulating and implementing policies that are more in line with the needs of the nation's youth.

"By promoting such policies, it is hoped that an environment where all Taiwan's young people have an equal opportunity to develop will be created, and the competitiveness of the nation's youth will increase with each generation," he said.

A National Youth Commission official said at the symposium that as youth affairs and policies cannot be handled by a single department, the commission in 2002 invited a group of scholars and representatives of various ministries and agencies to establish the "Youth Affairs Advancement Committee."

He added that the Youth Policy White Paper Guidelines were put forward in 2005 to provide a foundation for the government's general plan for youth affairs, in the areas of youth development, participation, health and protection.

The official further said that youth representatives have been invited to the symposium to give them an opportunity to have their voices heard in order to allow the government to gain a better understanding of the real needs of Taiwan's young people.

Among the many proposals made by youth representatives at the symposium was one related to Internet crime put, forward by Wu Pei-chi, a student at Beitou Junior High School in Changhua County, who took part in the discussion on youth protection.

Wu noted that although Internet crime involving youth, including online dating scams and online fraud, has become more serious in Taiwan, the government has yet to come up with adequate measures to deal with the problem.
She suggested that the government give greater priority to formulating policies and laws to prevent online crime involving young people.

Meanwhile, Liou Hsin-hsiang, a high school student in Hualien County who took part in the discussion on youth health, complained about the lack of literature and fine arts resources in eastern Taiwan and the fact that schools there do not place much importance on the cultural development of students.

She suggested that the government take measures to address these inadequacies in order to create an environment where youth around the country may have the opportunity to develop into well-rounded individuals.

Cameras will be used to track down and fine motorists and their passengers who throw litter from cars, The Times has learnt.

The electoral campaigns for the April 13-14 general elections came to an end Friday with candidates calling supporters to vote both in political rallies and television programs. DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD warns against overreliance on Chinese tourists to boost economy

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairwoman Ho Mei-yue warned Saturday against relying too heavily on Chinese tourists to boost the economy, calling this a "passive" approach that could prove dangerous.

Ho made the remarks ahead of a planned meeting between Chinese President Hu Jintao and Taiwan's vice president-elect, Vincent Siew, Saturday afternoon on the sidelines of the Boao Forum Asia being held in southern China's Hainan province.

There has been a lot of speculation about whether Hu and Siew would discuss cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economic issues, such as the proposed direct air links and the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists, and whether the meeting would lead to a thawing of relations between the two sides.

Siew said ahead of the meeting that the Boao Forum provides a platform for cross-strait economic exchanges and he expressed the hope that mutual understanding between the two sides could be enhanced and that they would "break the ice" via this platform.

Commenting on the much anticipated Hu-Siew meeting, Ho said that an increase in tourist numbers would indeed bring many economic benefits to Taiwan, including helping to boost development in the more remote regions.

However, she expressed the hope that the incoming administration would not rely solely on an increased number of Chinese tourists to stimulate the local economy, as such a policy carries inherent risks.

Noting that the tourism industry is usually one of the first casualties during a global economic downturn, Ho said the impact of such a downturn on Taiwan would be massive if the government were to follow such an approach.

She therefore urged the next administration to adopt an "active" approach to stimulating Taiwan's economy. She cited the example of Taiwan's high-tech industry which enjoys many competitive advantages, saying that the government must actively work to maintain the industry's international competitiveness for the good of the wider economy.

Parents will have to navigate unfamiliar and difficult terrain when it comes time to pay for college this year, with student loan companies in turmoil and banks tightening their standards and raising rates on other types of borrowing.

The world's major economic powers issued a warning to financial markets Friday that they won't sit by and watch the dollar continue to slide against other big currencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect meets Chinese president for watershed talks

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Vice President-elect Vincent Siew met with Chinese President Hu Jintao Saturday for the highest-level contact across the Taiwan Strait after a nine- year hiatus.

During the 20-minute talks, Hu said he looks forward to seeing the two sides pursue a consensus amid changing social and economic situations, according to footage shown on cable television station TVBS.
For his part, Siew expressed hopes that Taiwan and China would set aside their disputes with pragmatism and work together to create a bright future that will see a win-win scenario.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect meets Chinese president for historic talks

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Vice President-elect Vincent Siew met with Chinese President Hu Jintao Saturday for the highest-level political contact across the Taiwan Strait in more than five decades.
On the sidelines of the Boao Forum for Asia, Hu sat down with Siew for a low- profile but historic meeting that is expected to mark a watershed for long- stalled cross-strait relations.

During the 20-minute talks, Hu said he looks forward to seeing the two sides pursue a consensus amid changing social and economic situations on both sides, according to footage shown on cable television station TVBS.
For his part, Siew expressed hopes that Taiwan and China would set aside their disputes with pragmatism and work together to create a bright future that will see a win-win scenario.

Siew arrived in Boao in southern China's Hainan province Friday to attend the Boao forum in his capacity as chairman of the private Taipei-based Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation. Siew headed a 12-member delegation composed of academics and business executives. Among the members is Morris Chang, chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp.-- the world's largest contract chip maker.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei's Labor Affairs Department holds 'Thailand Day' celebrations

TEXT.P: The Taipei municipal government's Department of Labor Affairs held a "Thailand Day" event with a series of activities Saturday, including a Songkran Festival or "water spraying" ceremony, in celebration of the upcoming Thai New Year.

The event, held at the Shin Kong Mitsukoshi building, was attended by several ranking officials, including the head of Thailand's Economic and Cultural Office in Taiwan, and Chen Chi-yung, deputy director of Taipei's Department of Civil Affairs.
The celebrations drew the participation of over 100 Thai laborers and their spouses.
Labor Affairs Director Su Ying-kuei expressed the hope that the staging of such traditional events will help local citizens understand the beauty of other cultures.
Thai New Year celebrations usually start April 13 and last through April 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP begins journey of self-reflection

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which suffered major setbacks with the loss of the legislative and presidential elections this year, is attempting to pick itself up and move forward by engaging in self-examination and internal reforms.
The DPP legislative caucus announced Saturday that it will begin a series of public regional meetings Monday to discuss legislative reforms.

Caucus whip William Lai said the DPP will not be able to perform its duty of providing checks and balances on the incoming Kuomintang government without public support and a party caucus that is 100 percent dedicated to its work in the legislature.

The victory by the KMT's Ma Ying-jeou in the March 22 presidential election will put the party in control of both the executive and legislative branches of government following its landslide win earlier in the year of 81 seats to the DPP's 27 in the 113-seat legislature.

Lai said that a healthy legislative system is crucial to the DPP's role of monitoring the incoming KMT government. Lawmakers should have integrity and be professional, should not hold dual citizenship and should refrain from physical and verbal attacks during question-and-answer sections, he said, adding that the DPP will seek to adhere to these standards.

Meanwhile, during a DPP self-examination meeting in the southern city of Kaohsiung to review its poor performance in the recent elections, grassroots members harshly criticized the party's leaders, and claimed that factional conflicts had destroyed the party's spirit and cohesion.

Similar meeting are being held in other major cities in central and northern Taiwan, with DPP members spelling out the flaws and missteps of the party that first came to power when it defeated the KMT in the presidential election in 2000. Since then the DPP and some of its leaders have faced a string of corruption allegations, which many see as largely responsible for the sharp decline in the party's popularity.

The party members at the meetings argued that the DPP, which was founded on ideals of integrity, has seen its image deteriorate over the past eight years, especially in the latter part of President Chen Shui-bian's second-term when a series of scandals surrounding his family members and close aides come to light.
The party has also failed to fulfill its long-standing goal of forcing the KMT to return its ill-gotten assets to the national coffers, the critics said.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, who is one of the founding members of the DPP, said Saturday that he had suggested to President Chen on the day of the recent presidential election that the leadership of the party should be taken over by younger party members.

The DPP will begin registration April 14 of party members who wish to run for the chairmanship position. Veteran DPP member and Legislator Trong Chai announced Friday that he will register to stand in the May 18 election for the post, making him the only member to date openly express an interest in the party leadership.

Chang said he believes the "Formosa generation, " which refers to a generation of pro-democracy activists during the martial law era, should pass the baton of the party to the younger generation, having completed its mission of pushing democratic reforms of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Traditional Japanese tea ceremony staged in Beitou

TEXT.P: A traditional Japanese Urasenke tea ceremony was held at one of the most typical Japanese-style buildings in Taiwan Saturday, marking the first time that such a tea ceremony has been presented here.
The tea ceremony at the Taiwan Folk Arts Museum (TFAM) building in Taipei City's Beitou district attracted the attendance of many local scholars, tea lovers and Japanese culture enthusiasts.
The ceremony was hosted by Seki Souki of the Urasenke Tradition of Tea, a prestigious sect of Chado (Japanese Way of Tea) in Japan, in a room that fully recreated an atmosphere of Japanese culture.
Because Chado engages the body, mind, and soul, Souki said, "practicing Chado leads to perfection of speech and behavior."

Noting that the 1921 Japanese-style wooden structure that houses the TFAM is a valuable cultural asset, Cecile Wu, director of the museum, said she hopedthe program would help locals better understand the essence of Japanese culture."

According to Wu, through learning and practicing Chado, the tradition of making Japanese tea, doing ikebana (flower arrangements), aesthetics, the protocol of tea making and aesthetics are all observed.
"Each move in Japanese tea making has a specific meaning that is worth learning and is worthy of appreciation by the Taiwanese people," Wu said.
Hsu Shi-nung, an assistant professor of Japanese language and law at Ming Chuan University, said "experiencing Japanese Chado indeed promotes the publics sense of propriety."

Hsu, who began to learn Chado when he was studying for his doctoral degree in Japan, further explained that because good manners is essential in Japanese tea- making ceremonies, "practicing Chado helps individuals learn how to use utensils carefully at home and how to relate well to other people in the society."

In an attempt to promote the museum and its historical background and to provide the the public with an opportunity to experience Japanese culture, the TFAM also launched a special program starting Saturday as a basis for learning Japanese tea making, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Quit smoking' campaign with high prizes launched

TEXT.P: A contest aimed at encouraging smokers to quit was officially launched Saturday, with organizers announcing that the contestants who succeed in kicking the habit within the specified time will qualify to draw for a top prize of NT$600,000 (US$19,672).

The "Quit and Win" campaign was organized jointly by the John Tung Foundation (JTF) and the Bureau of Health Promotion under the ministerial-level Department of Health, as part of its effort to promote public health.

Chen Ying-chun, JTFs vice director of the Tobacco Control Division, said "many smokers are actually willing to quit this bad habit, " and that "some 20,000 smokers are expected to enroll in the contest."

Noting that there are an estimated of 4.5 million smokers in Taiwan, which represents one fifth of the nations population, Hsueh Kuang-chieh, Head of Tobacco Cessation Clinic, Kaohsiung Veterans General Hospital, said he hoped "the campaign would help them to stop smoking completely."

Hsueh said that smoking-related problems cost the government some NT$30 billion each year to provide treatment, and suggested that deep breathing, drinking cold water and doing body stretches will help to reduce the desire to smoke."
I am eager to quit smoking in order to fulfill the promise I made to myself and my family, " said Liu Chou-hong, one of the contestants who has been smoking for 28 years.

Lu, who recalled that he lit his first cigarette at the age of 15, said "quitting smoking would not only make me healthier, but would help me to set a good example for my 18-year-old son who is also a smoker."
Andy Chu, a taxi driver who had been a smoker for 30 years before he quit in 2007, told the participants in the campaign that "a strong will and self- discipline are both crucial."
Since I quit smoking, neither my clients nor family members, and my daughter in particular, have complained about the bad smell, " Chu said happily. "I also feel much healthier than before."

According to the rules of the contest, competitors must stop smoking for the period May 2 to May 29. After a medical evaluation and an assessment by the person supervising the contestants, the successful ones will qualify for a lucky draw to win top prize of NT$600,000.
"Come and join us and help to create a better and healthier life, " said Chen Ying-chun, adding that the closing date for entries is May 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Boao Forum 'ice-melting' journey: former official

TEXT.P: The Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) being held in southern China's Hainan province is an "ice-melting journey" for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, said a former Taiwan official in charge of mainland affairs Saturday.
Hours before the opening of the meeting, Su Chi, a former chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said the forum will be a place where the two sides can make friends with each other.

After the BFA, it will be time to activate a new round of interactions between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) in Beijing, Su said at a lunch meeting with the media in the Hainan resort of Boao.

Su is part of Vice President-elect Vincent Siew's BFA delegation, which also includes Morris Chang, founder and chairman of the world's largest contract chip maker Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.; Walsin Lihwa Corp. Chiao You-lun; and Taiwan Cement Corp. Chairman Leslie Koo.

Su said that in the 1990s when the two sides each established a quasi-official intermediary body to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official links, technical issues were given priority over political matters.
However, in the near future, if SEF-ARATS talks resume, the discussions will touch on every possible issue, including technical and political matters, he said.
Asked when the two associations are likely to resume contact, Su said "at least within one year."
Siew and his entourage met with Chinese President Hu Jintao Saturday afternoon soon after the opening ceremony of the two-day forum.

Siew, who is taking part in the meeting in his capacity as chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation, will host a roundtable discussion entitled "Prospects for Taiwan's Economy and Cross-Strait Economic Cooperation and Trade" Sunday, before returning to Taiwan.

The leaders of 11 countries and more than 2,000 Chinese and foreign guests are participating in the 2008 BFA conference, which is focused on the theme "Green Asia: Moving Towards Win-Win Through Change."
The BFA is a non-government international organization committed to promoting regional economic integration and bringing Asian countries closer to their development goals.

The forum was initiated in 1998 by then-Philippine President Fidel Ramos, then-Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke and then-Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa. It was formally inaugurated in February 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan on brink of Davis Cup defeat after losing doubles

TEXT.P: Taiwan's worst Davis Cup nightmare may be coming true.

Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun and Chen Ti lost the pivotal doubles Saturday to Kazakhstan's Alexey Kedryuk and Yuriy Schukin 6-2, 6-3, 6-7 (2) , 7-5 in a match that lasted over three hours to fall behind 2-1 in the best-of-five Asia/Oceania Zone Group I tie in Almaty.

Playing in a hostile atmosphere in which the home fans were happy to do what they could to disrupt the visitors, including making noises as Taiwan's players served, Chen and Lu were unable to cope with the hard serving Kazakhs, and especially some brilliant serving and returning of serve from Kedryuk that belied his 522 ranking.

Taiwan's players and team captain repeatedly complained to the Iranian chair umpire to restrain the crowd, but that only further encouraged unruly behavior, according to members of the Chinese Taipei Tennis Association who are attending the match. Lu and Chen recovered from two poor sets and seemed to have righted themselves by taking the third set in a tiebreaker, but a tiring Chen Ti, coming off a 3-hour 45-minute marathon singles defeat on Friday, was unable to hold his serve late in the fourth set, ending Taiwan's hopes of a comeback.

Lu and Chen will have to win both of Sunday's reverse singles if Taiwan is to avoid facing a relegation battle in September against the loser of the Uzbekistan-Philippines tie, not an impossible task since they will be ranked higher than their opponents.
But for a team that has long had the potential to be one of Asia's best, struggling in the relegation playoff round of the eight-country Group I is not where Taiwan might have expected to be.

Clearly, the addition of the 127th-ranked Schukin, a Russian who recently obtained a Kazakhstan passport to become eligible for its Davis Cup team, has made Taiwan's task much more difficult than expected.
He defeated Chen in a five-set marathon Friday to even the tie at 1-1, and will face Lu, ranked 114th, in the first match Sunday.

If Lu, who has had trouble getting used to what he described as a court that wasfaster than fast, can overcome the pesky Schukin, the world no. 284 Chen would have to top the veteran Kedryuk, ranked more than 200 places lowers but clearly a threat at home on the slick hardcourts.

Chen was being treated for a sore right shoulder after the doubles, and it was unclear how healthy he would be if he has to play for the decisive point on Sunday. Taiwan was last in Asia/Oceania Group II in 2003 and had seemed more likely in recent years to contend for a spot in the World Group playoffs, the entry point to the Davis Cup's elite 16-country World Group, than face relegation.
But with one singles defeat in Almaty on Sunday, a relegation battle is exactly what Taiwan will face.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic cooperation focus of VP-elect talks with Chinese leader
DOC.DATELINE: Boao, Hainan, April 11 (CNA) 04/12/08 21:19:03 (By Lin Yi-feng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The issue of economic exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait dominated the historic meeting between Taiwan's Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines of the 2008 Boao Asian Forum (BFA) in Hainan, southern China, Saturday.
The high-profile meeting began 35 minutes later than scheduled as it was delayed by the opening ceremony of the BFA that was attended by many world political leaders and former heads of states.

Television footage showed that Hu shook hands and exchanged greetings with Siew upon his arrival at the Sofitel hotel where the meeting between Chinese officials in charge of Taiwan affairs and members of Siew-headed Taiwanese delegation to the forum took place.

During the brief greeting, Hu said he was delighted to meet Siew, whom he lauded as an expert in economic affairs, and expressed the hope of exchanging opinions with Siew on cross-strait economic cooperation.
Hu told Siew that the two sides needed to make joint efforts to promote cross- strait economic cooperation and exchanges.

Calling himself a "veteran soldier" in Taiwan's fight for economic development, Siew told the Chinese leader that he thought that Taiwan's economy is an integral part of the economy of Asia, and the global economy as well.

Over the past two decades, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait has grown ever closer economically, Siew said, adding that "the cross-strait economic development is a common expectation of the people of the two sides, " which is believed to be able to improve their lives and promote regional peace.

It is the sixth time that Siew is attending the Boao Forum. He is heading a delegation comprised of 12 members, including Morris Chang, founder and chairman of the world's largest contract chip maker -- Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.

Siew, attending the forum in his capacity as chairman of the private Cross- Strait Common Market Foundation, will preside over a roundtable meeting on Taiwan's economy and the prospects of cross-strait business and trade development Sunday, before concluding his three-day visit to Hainan.
While the first seven-minute part of the high-profile 20-minute meeting between Siew and the Chinese president was open to the media, the rest of the talks was held behind closed doors.

Su Chi, a member of Siew's delegation, said afterwards that the Siew-Hu talks focused on future cross-strait engagements, including opening of direct air links and opening of Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: First World Summit of Indigenous Cultures opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: The 2008 World Summit of Indigenous Cultures, the first of its kind in Taiwan, will open Sunday, focusing on the prominent issue of climate change from the perspective of the indigenous peoples of the world, the organizers said at Saturday's opening ceremony.

Indigenous peoples from a dozen countries as well scientific researchers and scholars have been invited to share their knowledge at the summit, which is being held under the theme, "Cherishing the Earth, Respecting Ancient Wisdom, " said the Taiwan Indigenous Cultural Enterprise Development Association (TICEDA), the main organizer.

"Global warming is a reality that we are going to have to confront, and the way that indigenous people live, which means in harmony with nature, can be an example for modern society," said Alice Takiwatan, director-general of TICEDA.

Urging people to pay closer attention to the environment and to respect nature, Takiwatan related a piece of wisdom passed on from her mother, saying that "human beings cannot joke with the Earth, because it winks its eyes," implying that nature reacts to human behavior.
"And now, it's that moment when the Earth winks, " she said.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who was unable to attend the opening ceremony, conveyed his support for the summit via indigenous Legislator Kung Wen-chi, stating that the idea of sustainable development has always been a part of indigenous peoples' lives, and that one of the priorities of his incoming administration would be to work on environmental protection.
Ma's and his administration are scheduled to take office on May 20.

Asked to give an example of indigenous peoples' means of preventing global warming, Takiwatan said that "leveling the mound and raising that which is low is not part of indigenous peoples' logic," alluding to their respect for the order of nature.

Scholars, followers of different religions and sects, along with indigenous peoples from countries such as the Philippines, United States, England, Singapore and Myanmar, will also discuss during the two-day summit topics like development of indigenous enterprise and their contemporary belief system, according to TICEDA.
In Taiwan, the government officially recognizes 13 indigenous tribes that represent 484,000 people, or about 2.1 percent of the total population of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition on folk worship in Taiwan opens

TEXT.P: The Taipei Story House (TSH) on Saturday opened a special exhibition on Taiwan's folk worship traditions, with President-elect Ma Ying-jeou praising the show as a channel for cultural understanding as well as for tourism promotion.
"The Story of Folk Worship" exhibition is showcasing various forms of worship observed on special dates or during festivals, through pictures and handicraft.
"The historical and cultural meanings of folk worship in Taiwan are equally important as the religious significance and cannot be ignored," Ma said at the opening ceremony.
"Through this exhibition we can fully understand that Taiwanese virtues of goodness, diligence, loyalty, and filial piety are deeply associated with folk worship," he added.

Noting that his incoming administration, which is to take office on May 20, will lift the ban on Chinese tourists to Taiwan soon, Ma stressed thatthe exhibition will not only help to educate Chinese visitors, but will also serve to promote tourism.

Commending the TSH as one of Ma's achievements in culture during during his tenure as Taipei City mayor from 1998 to 2006, the incumbent mayor Hau Lung-bin said he hoped the exhibition will attract not only locals, but also foreigners, to learn about Taiwan's traditions.
The TSH, a European-style villa, was completed during the Japanese colonial period in 1914 by a tea merchant and used as a meeting place for local gentry, Japanese officials and foreign guests.
It was renovated and transformed into a gallery in 2003 in accordance with Ma's policy on culture revitalization.
Hau said that helping foreigners to understand Taiwanese customs is a positive effort."Let us be proud of our own culture," he added.
Chen Kuo-tsi, the founder of the TSH, said at the ceremony that folk worship is an important part of family activities, regardless of age, gender, or generation, andsymbolizes family reunions."

Chen invited the public to also join the associated programs organized jointly by the TSH and the Department of Cultural Affairs under the Taipei City Government, such as the Dragon Boat Festival Deities Costume Show, the Children Summer Camp, and various lectures on folk worship in the coming months at the TSH.
The Story of Folk Worshipexhibition is being held from April 12 to September 7, between the hours of 10: 00 a.m. and 6: 00 p.m., Tuesday to Sunday.

TEXT.P: The 2008 Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) opened Saturday in Boao, a resort city on the southern Chinese island of Hainan, with Taiwan Vice President-elect Vincent Siew joining business leaders and many other international political figures, including former U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell, to discuss, among other topics, economics and the environment.

It was Siew's sixth time at the annual forum, but his first time seated in the front row reserved for VIPs. Siew was seated between Volvo Group Chief Executive Officer Leif Johnansson, on his left, and Chen Jinhua, vice chairman of the ninth National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, on his right.
Powell sat next to Chen at the opening, while Chinese President Hu Jintao was seated center stage between 10 other heads of state.

The forum is being attended by over 1,000 world political and business leaders, as well as former heads of states. However, Siew, who is participating in the meeting in his capacity as chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation, was the focus of attention for the Taiwanese reporters covering the event, who appeared to be anticipating some interaction between him and Hu.
The theme of the BFA conference this year is "Green Asia: Moving Towards Win-Win Through Change."
The BFA is a non-government international organization committed to promoting regional economic integration and bringing Asian countries closer to their development goals.

The forum was initiated in 1998 by then-Philippine President Fidel Ramos, then-Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke and then-Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa. It was formally inaugurated in February 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect brings up 4 requests in historic talks with Chinese leader

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Vice President-elect Vincent Siew brought up four requests in his historic talks with Chinese President Hu Jintao Saturday, with improving economic relations as main focus, according to Siew's spokesman.

Su Chi, a top China policy planner in Taiwan's former Kuomintang (KMT) government who is accompanying Siew on his current visit to China, told reporters that Siew had called for normalization of cross-Taiwan Strait trade exchanges and resumption of bilateral dialogue mechanism in his talks with the top Chinese leader.

Siew also requested that China allow its citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan as early as possible and open direct cross-strait charter flights on weekends as a prelude to the establishment of direct air links, Su said.
The historic Siew-Hu meeting took place on the sidelines of the Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) which opened Saturday with regional economic cooperation as its top theme.

The meeting was the highest-level cross-strait political contact since the Republic of China government moved its seat to Taiwan in 1949. Never before has an ROC president-elect or vice president-elect set foot on mainland China soil.

According to Su, the 20-minute Siew-Hu meeting focused on improving economic relations, a key plank in the platform that boosted incoming Vice President Vincent Siew and President-elect Ma Ying-jeou to victory in the March 22 presidential poll.

"The 20-minute talks started with Hu making brief welcoming remarks, which were followed by Siew's presentation in detail and then Hu's response, " explained Su, who is now a professor and widely tipped to be the new KMT government's top national security adviser.
The first seven minutes of the Siew-Hu meeting was open to the media but the rest of talks proceeded behind closed doors.

According to China's official Xinhua news agency, Hu met with Siew in his capacity as the general secretary of the Communist Party of China. He was accompanied by Chinese officials in charge of Taiwan affairs during the meeting.

In contrast, Siew, who will take office May 20, is visiting China in his capacity as chairman of the private Taipei-based Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation (CSCMF) . The 12-member CSCMF delegation headed by Siew is composed of academics and business executives.

The Siew-Hu meeting is expected to mark a watershed for cross-strait relations that have been stalled since 1999 when then-President Lee Teng-hui declared cross-strait relations as a special state-to-state relationship. The Ma-Siew ticket campaigned on a platform of better economy and closer cross-strait ties.
After exchanging pleasantries with the Siew-headed CSCMF delegation, Hu said improving relations between the two sides requires efforts from both parties.

"On this occasion, I'm happy to exchange opinions on the cross-strait economic cooperation with Siew," Hu said, adding that he looks forward to seeing the two sides forge consensus amid changes in regional and global situations.

Hu further said the enthusiastic participation of delegates from around the world to the Boao forum reflects a strong desire of Asian countries and areas to strengthen exchanges and cooperation and create mutual benefits.
"This common aspiration has provided an important inspiration for our two sides in considering how to boost bilateral economic exchanges," Hu said.
For his part, Siew said reality has proved that cross-strait economic development is the common wish of people on both sides of the strait.
He expressed hopes that Taiwan and China would set aside their disputes with pragmatism and work together to create a bright future that will see a win-win scenario.
"I hope our two sides will face reality, set sights on the future, put aside disputes and pursue a win-win scenario for all parties concerned," Siew said.

Noting that it's not easy for him to attend the Boao forum this time around, Siew said he keenly hopes the two sides can from now on adopt a pragmatic and open-minded attitude in dealing with bilateral affairs to turn a new page for cross-strait relations that are based on "mutual trust, mutual understanding, mutual help and mutual benefits."

Responding to Siew's proposals, Hu was quoted by Xinhua news agency as having promised to continue promoting bilateral negotiations on opening of weekend cross-strait charter flights and on issues regarding Chinese tourists to Taiwan.
At the end of the meeting, Hu also asked Siew to convey his regards to Taiwan's president-elect Ma Ying-jeou, KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung and KMT honorary chairman Lien Chan.

Hu was further quoted as having stressed that in the face of ever more ferrous global economic competition, the two sides should seized the current hard-won opportunities to create a win-win scenario for both sides.
The Boao Forum is a non-government, not-profit organization aimed to promote regional economic cooperation. Founded in 2001, it is headquartered in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect satisfied with China's treatment at Boao forum

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Vice President-elect Vincent Siew said late Saturday that he was satisfied with courteous reception that China has accorded him at an economic forum being held in the southern Chinese resort of Boao in Hainan province.

Siew, the running mate of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , made the remarks after attending a dinner hosted by Chinese President Hu Jintao in honor of all participants to the Boao Forum for Asia (BFA).
"I'm satisfied with all the warm hospitality and courteous treatment extended to me by forum organizers, " Siew told Taiwanese reporters covering his current landmark visit.

Siew is the first Taiwanese vice president-elect ever to set foot on Chinese soil. Although he is attending the forum in his capacity as chairman of the private Taipei-based Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation (CSCMF) , China sent a charter plane to Hong Kong to take him and his 12-member entourage to Boao, a lavish treatment befitting his status as a country's incoming vice president.
On Saturday afternoon, Siew met Hu in the highest-level political contact across the Taiwan Strait in nearly 60 years.

Siew, who, along with Ma, will take office May 20, said he keenly hopes his 20-minute talks with Hu will contribute to peaceful development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait which separates Taiwan from China.
During the meeting, Siew said he proposed that the two sides "face reality, set sights on the future, shelve disputes and pursue a win-win scenario."

"The essence of my suggestion is that cross-strait affairs should be addressed with pragmatism and openness, " Siew said, adding that all his opinions expressed during the meeting have received Hu's positive response.
Siew recalled that when he bade farewell to Hu at the end of the dinner, Hu told him that their meeting in the afternoon was "very meaningful."

Describing Hu's comments as offering a "historic opportunity" for improving cross-strait ties, which have been stalled for eight years due to China's unwillingness to hold dialogue with Taiwan's incumbent pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party administration, Siew said the two sides should start with tackling economic issues while putting political disputes on the back burner.
Meanwhile, Su Chi, a former Mainland Affairs Council chairman who was also present at the Siew-Hu meeting, portrayed the talks as "candid and friendly" with "harmonious chemistry."

According to Su, Siew brought up four requests during the talks, including resumption of cross-strait dialogue, normalization of bilateral trade and economic ties, launch of weekend cross-strait charter flights and opening of Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

"My observation is that cross-strait negotiation will resume soon and weekend cross-strait charter flights could take off in early July, " Su forecast optimistically, adding that it is almost sure that spring is in sight.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 13, or the eighth day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1732: Frederick North, the English prime minister who introduced the Tea Act that led to the "Boston Tea Party," is born. His policies finally led to Britain's loss of America.
1743: Thomas Jefferson, the third president of the United States, is born. He drafted the Declaration of Independence in 1776. His presidency was marked by the purchase of the Louisiana Territory from France in 1803 and the Tripolitan War from 1801 to 1805.
1862: France and Annam (now Vietnam) sign the Treaty of Shanghai, annexing the province of Cochin China to France.
1898: Prompted by the success of the Meiji Reformation in Japan, Kang Yu-wei initiates a reform movement and submits a report to Emperor Kuang Hsu of China's Ching dynasty, requesting government reformation.
1904: In the Russo-Japanese War, a mine sinks the flagship of the Russian fleet at Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China, killing 600.
1906: Samuel Beckett, Irish dramatist and winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1969, is born.
1919: British troops under the command of Brig. Gen. Dyer open fire on some 380 followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi in an incident known as the Amritsar massacre.
1939: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini's forces invade Albania.
1941: Japan and the Soviet Union sign the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact in Moscow.
1945: Allied bombers launch massive bombing raids over Japan, destroying a large part of Tokyo.
1960: The construction of an atomic reactor at Taiwan's National Tsinghwa University in Hsinchu, the first of its kind in Southeast Asia, is completed.
1964: Sidney Poitier wins an Oscar for his performance in Ralph Nelson's "The Lilies of the Field," becoming the first black actor to receive the award.
1966: Iraq's President Abdul Salam Arif is killed in a helicopter crash.
1978: Communist China and Portugal formally sign a "joint statement" that clears the way for the return of Macao to Beijing on Dec. 20, 1999.
1980: Twenty-three-year-old Spanish golfer Severiano Ballesteros becomes the first European and also the youngest person ever to win the U.S. Masters in Augusta, Georgia.
1982: U.S. Secretary of State Alexander Haig returns to Washington following failed attempts in London and Buenos Aires to settle the Falkland Islands dispute.
1988: Hainan Island becomes the 23rd province and the fourth "special economic region" of mainland China under communist rule.
1990: The Soviet Union admits that its secret police was responsible for the 1940 systematic murder of 1,500 Polish army officers at Katyn, Poland.
1995: The Ukraine agrees to close the Chernobyl nuclear reactor by 2000.
1995: Lang Chin-shan, known as "China's father of photography," dies at the age of 104.
1999: Willi Stoph, chairman of the Council of Ministers of the former German Democratic Republic, dies at the age of 84.
2000: The World Trade Organization ranks Taiwan as the world's 14th-largest exporting country and the 15th largest importing country in terms of merchandise in 1999.
2000: The International Monetary Fund ranks the people of Taiwan as the 18th richest people in the world, with the nation's annual per capita income based on purchasing power parity expected to reach US$16,854 in 2000.
2001: U.S. Congressman David Wu (D-OR) arrives in the Republic of China at the head of a four-member delegation making a five-day visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is affection, exertion is made easy; where there is disinterest, instruction will be neglected."
