DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect meets former U.S. secretary of state
DOC.DATELINE: Boao, China, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/08 15:40:53 (By Lin Yi-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Vincent Siew met with former U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell for a brief talk Sunday on the sidelines of the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia, which opened in the southern Chinese resort city a day earlier.

Powell met Siew for a meeting that lasted about 20 minutes. After the talk, Powell praised Siew's landmark meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao Saturday, saying it was "very good news for the region."
Powell told reporters that "the two sides have begun down a new path.... I think we are at the beginning of a new phase in relations between the parties in Asia."

He said that Siew has been one of his Asian friends for years, adding that he had also offered his congratulations to Ma Ying-jeou and Siew on their election as the president and vice president in the Taiwan presidential poll held March 22. Ma and Siew are slated to take office May 20.

For his part, Siew told the reporters that he had extended an invitation, on behalf of President-elect Ma, to Powell to attend their inauguration May 20 in Taiwan. Powell responded that "he would love to attend the inauguration ceremony if time permits, " according to Siew.
Siew said Powell had visited Taiwan before and that he has a great impression of the country.
Siew added that Powell values the friendship between them and would like to visit Taiwan again to meet with him.
According to Siew, he wrote a preface for the Chinese version of Powell's autobiography that was published several years ago.

At the historic Hu-Siew meeting Saturday, Siew reportedly made four proposals, namely the normalization of cross-Taiwan Strait trade exchanges, the resumption of bilateral dialogue mechanism, permission by China for its citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan and the opening direct cross-strait charter flights on weekends as a prelude to the establishment of direct air links.

Hu reportedly responded to Siew at the meeting by endorsing two of Siew's proposals -- opening up Taiwan to more Chinese tourists and allowing weekend charter flights. Direct air travel across the Taiwan Strait has been banned since the two sides split amid civil war in 1949.
Many hoped the Hu-Siew meeting would mark a thawing in cross-strait relations that have been in the deep freeze during the eight-year administration of President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City Government holds healthy baby competition

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government held a healthy baby competition featuring over 300 children under five years of age Sunday to promote public awareness of the importance of breast-feeding and regular monitoring of child development.
The2008 Healthy Baby Competition" was the second of its kind organized by Wyeth Taiwan Corporation and BabyHome Web site, under the supervision of the Taipei City Government's Department of Health.

These young participants were divided into four groups to compete in various activities, including crawling, rolling balls and matching color balls. The categories were chosen to highlight parent-child interaction and to assess muscle and cognitive development.

"Healthy babies are those who receive their vaccinations on time, have regular physical and child development examinations and are breast fed," said Lin Hsiu- liang, deputy director of the department.
She advised that parents should make sure their children have
regular check-ups so that the babies can be treated if there is
any sign of developmental delay.

Developmental delay is defined as a child lagging behind in areas such as motor, language, social, or thinking skills, which means he or she is not reaching developmental landmarks at the expected age.

According to the World Health Organization, 6-8 percent of children aged zero to six years old suffer developmental delay, and in Taiwan the number is at least 100,000 children under the age of six, Lin said.
Lin called on all new parents to breast feed their babies, saying it is the best first food for infants.
Research has shown that breast milk is perfectly suited to nourish infants, protect them from illness and promote the development of intelligence," she said.

In the baby crawling competition, the parents were even busier than their six- month to one-year-old babies, using pacifiers, stuffed toys, keys or even cell phones to get the attention of the children and encourage them to move to the finish line.
" Being part of this competition can create great memories between our baby and us," said Yao Shin-yi, the mother of an eight-month-old competitor wearing a camouflage head scarf.
The organizers of the competition also set up counseling booths to provide a wide range of health information to parents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Long beloved Kapok trees cause headaches in Taiwan

TEXT.P: CNA Staff Reporter

Taipei, April 13 (CNA) Spring has arrived in Taiwan and with it the dilemma over what to do with the island's many kapok trees, whose beautiful flowers are inspiring some local governments to plant them to promote tourism, while irritating motorists and others to no end.

The problem involving the trees -- known for their large, beautiful, lily-like flowers -- is turning out to be a battle between nature and modernization. It also reveals the changes in Taiwanese society over the decades.

In April, the large trees, which grow to about 60 meters tall, enter their blooming season. Palm size blossoms in colors of red, pink or orange make picture perfect backdrops for photos, but they are a headache as the pedals fall to the ground, causing scooter drivers as well as pedestrians to slip and fall.

Fallen flowers also get stuck on windshields and the flying cotton-like fillings of the large seed pods that form on the trees a month after the flowers bloom irritate people with respiratory problems. Ripe pods, the size of big mangoes, open up to release cotton-like fillings with little seeds, which are carried by the wind and fly around in the air. Some people also complain that the flowers stink after being crushed by cars on the roads.

City, county and township governments in many parts of Taiwan are torn over what to do about the problem after getting frequent complaints by local residents about problems innocently caused by the trees.

Many local governments of where the kapok trees are found are faced with having to decide whether to spend lots of time and effort maintaining the trees where they are or removing them and risk harming the roots and killing them in the process.
Those who despise the trees and those who love them are in a tug of war.

A dispute over whether or not to remove the trees in Tungshih township in central Taiwan's Taichung County still has not been resolved after festering for three years. Six village heads complained about the trees on behalf of local residents and appealed to the township office to cut down about 900 kapok trees in 2005.

Thanks to increasing awareness of the importance of ecological protection, tourism promotion, as well as consideration of public's affection for the trees, the government chose transplantation, said Chen Ching-tung, the township office's construction section chief.

The Taichung County-based Ecological Conservation and Environmental Protection Association of Ta-Chia Stream urged the local government to leave the trees where they are, arguing that not that many people are bothered by them and that transplantation might still jeopardize the life of these trees as they had stood where they were for three decades.
"The roots of the trees could be impaired during the transplantation process, which will lead to them dying, " said an executive of the association.

Kapoks, also known as Ceiba or Silk Cotton trees, were once a star on Taiwan's floral list, voted as the official flower of Taiwan's second largest city, Kaohsiung, as well as Taichung County by local residents in the 1980s.
The local governments of Kaohsiung and Taichung began planting the trees in wide areas following the vote, aiming to formulate people's identity with the places where they live.

The tree rose in people's heart in 1978, when Taiwan was riding the wave of a folk song era. A song titled "Kapok Tree Road" that relates the red kapok blossoms with nostalgic love impressed the old and young.

As the song, sung by then famous singer Wang Mung-lin, goes, "the long road burns with blooming blossoms and that passionate love vanishes quickly as flaming red kapok blossoms wither and fall after its season passes."

The tree also had practical uses in people's lives at a time when many Taiwanese were poor. Its flowers, pods, and "silk cotton" pod fillings served as children's toys decades ago, when Taiwan had not yet seen so much economic and modern development and children did not have expensive hand-held computer games and other toys as they do now.

Housewives would make food or teas with the kapok petals, and use its silk- cotton as filling material for pillows, but such use is no longer seen as imported cotton can be easily purchased in stores.
As trees were widely planted and Taiwanese society became more modern, people started to notice how the tree got in the way of their daily life during the blooming season from March until May.

However, as the kapok, introduced from India to Taiwan in the 17th century, is deeply connected with many people's childhood memories and recollections of a bygone era, many people do not want to see the trees uprooted from where they had survived for hundreds of years, existing alongside humans with few problems.

In Tatu, another township in Taichung County, transplantation has not been enough to iron out the dispute between those who love the trees and those who wish they were gone. The township had 960 kapok trees in schools and main roads removed to a park last year, but complaints about the same problems still exist, with some county councilors pointing out that the park is not far enough away from densely populated areas for the petals and silk cotton to not be a nuisance.
Another place in Taichung County, Fengyuan City, chose to send fire brigade wagons to "shoot down" ripe seeds with water hoses to prevent the silk-cotton from flying around once the seed pods open.
"Taichung County now has less than 3,000 kapok trees remaining on main roads, not including the 960 already transplanted, " said Lin Hung-wen, chief of the county's road maintenance section.
While the issue of finding a home for kapok trees remains a debate in Taichung County, central Taiwan's Changhua County is trying to use the trees to promote tourism, seeing them as an attraction.
Changhua County's Pitou township kicked off its first campaign last week to promote tourism during the Kapok tree flowering season along a 4.5-km riverside road, which has about 670 kapok trees.
They timed the campaign during Taiwan's Tomb Sweeping Festival in hopes of drawing more tourists and boosting local economic development.
A series of activities were held to celebrate the flower season, with local schools performing music and dance and presenting sweet broths and cakes made of kapok blossoms.

"We are hoping that the flower season will help create business opportunities for local industries, " said Pitou township head Chen Tsang-chiung, adding that since the flower season appears to be attracting a lot of visitors, the township office has decided to plant more kapok trees on the other side of the same road to create a grander view.

Taiwan had 3.71 million visitors, including tourists, in 2007, up 5.58 percent from 2006's figure, but the number is considered low. The Tourism Bureau plans to increase visitor numbers to 4.25 million in 2009.
Domestic travel by Taiwanese people is also increasing, showing a promising future in tourism promotion.
Many local governments now actively plan activities related to local cultural or natural resources, with the aim of attracting more visitors to boost the local economy.
Advocates of keeping the kapok trees said they hope the awareness of tourism promotion will create a way out for the kapok. The fate of the trees in many other areas, however, remains unknown.
Regardless of whether it is decided that the trees should remain or be transplanted, efforts are needed to take care of the trees to ensure they are in good health.

An executive of the Ecological Conservation and Environmental Protection Association of Ta-Chia Stream pointed out that without proper care and a good place for transplantation, the trees, even if they are removed to a new place, would still cause the same problems, especially as those areas develop and become more densely populated.
"When the problems happen again after removal, where should the trees be moved to?" said the executive.

Tungshih Township, which still has not decided whether or not to transplant the trees, now that the community has cleaning teams to clean fallen flowers everyday and will prune the pods to prevent the silk-cotton from flying and dancing with the wind.
Chen added that the township office will hold a public hearing next month inviting representatives from different sectors to decide whether to move the trees or not.
"No big complaints have been made recently, but the problem still has to be solved, " said Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect's meeting with Chinese leader helpful: KMT lawmaker

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus leader said Sunday that although it was yet unclear what results the meeting between Taiwan's vice President-elect and the Chinese president would produce, the exchange was definitely conducive to the development of cross-strait ties in the future.

Hsieh Kuo-liang, an acting KMT legislative caucus whip, said he welcomed the meeting between Taiwan's Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and Chinese President Hu Jintao Saturday, which took place on the sidelines of the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia in Hainan, China.

Hsieh said although the KMT caucus would not be able to determine the tone of Siew's "ice thawing" participation in the Boao Forum until the vice-president elect returns to Taiwan, it views the amicable Hu-Siew meeting as a historic event that would significantly contribute to the development of cross-strait relations.

Meanwhile, Hsieh blasted Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong for adhering to what he called the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's approach of shutting off Taiwan from the international community by refusing to engage in any kind of exchanges with China.
"It would be pathetic if Chen chose to stick to the DPP's closed-door policy until the last day, May 20, when the incoming KMT government takes over," Hsieh said.

If Chen is indeed a responsible official in charge of formulating Taiwan's China policy, he should take the time to obtain a better understanding of the incoming government's cross-strait policies and its needs so that he could help the MAC administer the measures that would be introduced by the KMT, Hsieh added.

Also commenting on the historic Hu-Siew meeting, Vice President Annette Lu said the meeting could help ease cross-strait tensions, which had intensified since Taiwan launched referendums on the country's bid to enter the United Nations under the name "Taiwan."

Lu also called for the country not to fuss too much over how Siew was treated at the meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao, saying that she thinks Siew was met with proper etiquette in his capacity as a leading KMT figure, while Hu met with him in Hu's capacity as general secretary of the Communist Party of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA to elevate 17 km section of railway in northern Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) will elevate a 17.15 km section of railway in northern Taiwan to improve transport efficiency and services as part of its strategy to cope with competition from the Taiwan High Speed Rail.

According to TRA executives, the project to elevate the railway section between Yingge township in Taipei County and Chungli City in Taoyuan County will eliminate 17 grade crossings, and the three current stations at Taoyuan, Neili and Chungli will be replaced by new elevated stations.

The project will also add five new stations between Yingge and Chungli at an interval of about two kilometers between every two stations to facilitate commuters. The decision was made in accordance with the TRA's policy to operate the railway more like a metro system.
The entire project will carry a price tag of NT$30.8 billion (US$1.02 billion) and will take seven and a half years to complete.

The 120-year-old railway network in Taiwan's west corridor has lost 33 percent of its long-distance passengers since the High Speed Rail became operational in January 2007. The 345-km high speed rail linking Taipei and Kaohsiung has reduced travel time between Taiwan's two largest cities from four-and-a-half hours to 90 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Italy to face electoral challenge.
Italians are to vote for their new parliament. A total of 61,212 polling stations across the nation will be open from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. on Sunday April 13 and from 7 a.m. to 3 p.m. on Monday April 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect's China visit should benefit all: spokesman

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Vincent Siew is expected to return home bearing the fruits of his China visit, which should benefit all fellow citizens, not just his own party or any specific individual, an official said Sunday.

Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey made the remarks a day after Siew, the running mate of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), had a historic meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines of an annual global economic forum being held in the southern Chinese resort of Boao in Hainan province.

"As a vice president-elect, Siew represents Taiwan. We would like to see substantial results from his current China trip. Nevertheless, any fruitful outcome should be beneficial to all compatriots, not just the KMT or the Ma-Siew ticket," Shieh said.

The KMT once ruled all of China before fleeing to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to the Chinese communists, and Siew is the first Republic of China vice president-elect ever to set foot on Chinese soil since then.

Shieh reminded Siew not to take any steps or make any statements during his stay in China that could mislead the world into perceiving his visit as the "beginning of reconciliation" between the two civil war rivals -- the KMT and the Communist Party of China.

Since the KMT lost power to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in 2000, Shieh said, the KMT has often sung a duet with the Beijing government, accusing the pro-independence DPP government of being a troublemaker.

"This time around, if the Chinese leaders criticize the DPP government, Siew should remain silent or just respond with his trademark smile because he is no longer a private citizen but instead is representing Taiwan," Shieh urged.

Shieh also derided as "too self-deprecating" some media reports that interpreted Siew's seating in the front row along with the top leaders from several participating countries at the opening ceremony of the Boao Forum for Asia Saturday as a sign of China's "tacit recognition" of his status as Taiwan's incoming vice president.

"Seating arrangements at such an occasion mean little. We should never forget that it is China that has spared no effort to suppress and belittle Taiwan in the international arena since 1971 when the People's Republic of China took over the 'China' seat in the United Nations at the expense of the R.O.C.," Shieh noted.
The incoming KMT government should push China not to block Taiwan's bid to obtain seats in major world organizations, including the U.N. and the World Health Organization, he added.

Siew left for Boao Friday to attend the annual Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) in his capacity as chairman of the private Taipei-based Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation. The three-day forum brought together some 2,000 dignitaries from major countries around the world, including political leaders, academics and business executives, to discuss matters related to Asia regional economic integration and cooperation.
Saturday's Siew-Hu meeting was the highest-level political contact across the Taiwan Strait in nearly 60 decades. It was also widely seen as a watershed in the long-stalled cross-strait relations.

Despite a thaw in the early 1990s, cross-strait engagements have sunk to a low ebb since 1999 when then-President Lee Teng-hui declared cross-strait ties as special state-to-state relations. Because of Beijing's unwillingness to negotiate with the pro-independence DPP administration, cross-strait ties have remained deep-frozen over the past eight years.

Against this backdrop, Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday she would recognize Siew's contribution if his historic meeting with Hu could truly help defuse cross-strait tensions and usher in a new era of peaceful cross-strait development and co-existence.

On Siew's proposal to Hu that the two sides shelve disputes with pragmatism and work together to create a win-win scenario, Lu said it is "easier said than done" and that the success of such an initiative depends on China's sincerity to take concrete action.

"We should keep close watch on the development," Lu said, adding that she hopes the incoming KMT government would listen to different opinions from various quarters, including political parties, in dealing with cross-strait affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor calls attention to importance of organ donation

TEXT.P: The rate of organ donation in Taiwan is not as good as it could be due to cultural obstacles, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Saturday at a commemoration ceremony to honor those who had decided before they died to donate their organs.

Hu presided over the unveiling of a plaque that commemorated organ donors, while recipients presented bouquets of flowers to the families of donors, at ceremony held at China Medical University in the central city of Taichung.

Hu expressed gratitude to the families of the organ donors, and noted that there was still ample room for improvement in organ donation rates and in overcoming the psychological barriers to organ donation.
"Taiwan faces various obstacles to promoting organ donation, " Hu said, citing the example of the cultural belief in keeping body intact after death so that the deceased could enter the spirit world.
Hu said that it is also a common view that requesting organ donation immediately after the death of a potential donor deepens the surviving family's grief.
He noted, however, that some people are reluctant to have organ transplants as they fear transplant failure.

Even though it is difficult to change the public mindset against organ donation, government agencies and the private sector has a responsibility to help raise awareness of the importance of organ donation in saving lives, Hu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. press corps impressed by Danshui's historic, scenic charm

TEXT.P: Nineteen members from various U.S. print media outlets expressed amazement at the high concentration of heritage sites and the spectacular coastal scenery in Danshui, during a tour of the township in the northern county Saturday.

The press corps from some 10 prominent American outlets, including the New York Times and the Washington Post, were accompanied by Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei on the second day of their Taiwan trip.

Chou, in the dual role of tour guide and head of the host county, spared no effort to pitch the many scenic attractions of the area to the foreign guests, who had been given a tour of Taipei City a day before.

Speaking in English, Chou detailed the history of Danshui, beginning with the shore on which George Leslie Mackay -- a Canadian missionary well known and remembered in Taiwan for his work in the fields of religion, education -- disembarked in Danshui in 1872.

Chou mentioned many other sites of historical significance and also talked about the county's achievements in infrastructure construction. He exchanged views with the media professionals on travel experiences and solicited their opinions on Taiwan's future development.
He said he hoped that "Taipei County will become better known to the world" through the introduction of the American journalists from various influential media establishments.
During the two-hour tour, the delegation visited Mackay Mission Hospital, Danshui Church, Little White House, Oxford College, Danshui High School's "eight-cornered tower" and Fort San Domingo.

Members of the press corps praised Danshui as an attractive destination, with its great number of historic sites, diversified transportation system and variety of local delicacies. They promised to develop a series of reports that would feature the township.

Kurt Wisner, a senior National Geographic Explorer reporter, described the Taipei County tour as an amazing experience, adding that he never thought the metro link between Taipei City and Danshui was so convenient or the natural scenery along the Danshui River so breathtaking.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to turn off lights for one hour June 21

TEXT.P: Taiwan is poised to join a regional action to turn off the lights in some cities for one hour June 21 in an effort to raise environmental awareness, an environmental group announced Sunday.

The Society of Wilderness, Taiwan (SOW) announced that it had reached an agreement with its counterparts in Hong Kong and Guangdong, China Sunday on an energy conservation plan that would see Hong Kong, Taipei, Taichung, Kaohsiung and Guangdong cities extinguish household lights and the exterior lights on public buildings for an hour on the night of June 21.

"More than 1 million people are expected to join this significant lights-out plan June 21, as other civil groups, from Beijing and Japan, that champion environmental protection have also promised to participate," said SOW officials.

According to the SOW, some 650,000 people around Taiwan joined a lights-out campaign last June 21, with more than 100 public buildings of local governments, high-tech companies at Hsinchu-based Science Park, high-speed railway stations, Taipei 101 building and Kaohsiung's Love River turning off unnecessary exterior lighting.

The 2007 lights-out campaign, which lasted about 70 minutes, saved a total of 300,000 kwh of electricity, roughly equivalent to a reduction of 187 tons of carbon dioxide emissions at the time, according to the SOW officials.

In addition to helping to save energy and reduce global warming, the lights-out campaign is also aimed at encouraging consumers to support corporations and public organizations that demonstrate a greater willingness to save energy, SOW officials said.
This year's campaign, which marks summer solstice and is the fourth in a row, is also inviting ordinary households to join the effort by turning off their lights that night, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan motor show expected to bring US$55 million in business

TEXT.P: The four-day Taiwan International Motorcycle Industry Show, which closed Saturday, attracted a total of 20,000 visitors and buyers, with exhibitors seen likely to gain an estimated US$55 million (NT$1.67 billion) from potential trade contacts made during the show.

This year's motor show was 30 percent bigger than the last year's, as the space at the Taipei World Trade Center (WTC) Exhibition Hall 1 allowed for 200 exhibitors to display the latest motor vehicles, engines and other products at 500 booths.
The show was held alongside the Taipei International Automobile Electronics Show and the Taiwan International Auto Parts & Accessories Show from April 9 to 12.

Over 1,000 foreign buyers, mostly from the U.S., England, Japan, South Korea, China, attended the show and many of them have expressed interest in coming back next year, according to the show organizer Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

World-renowned motor brands like Italy's Plaggio exchanged business ideas with 30 local manufacturers at the show's 83 procurement meetings, TAITRA stated, adding that local companies are anticipating the business opportunity of some US$55 million from deals made at procurement meetings at the exhibition.

There was also an increased number of new buyers from Latin America, the Middle East and Africa, some of whom visited the factories of local manufacturers and expressed interest in placing orders, according to Taiwan's Dinli Metal Industrial Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: China using Siew to divert attention from Tibet suppression: President

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that China had invited Vice President-elect Vincent Siew to attend a regional economic forum in southern China as a diversion in the face of international pressure over its suppression of Tibet.

Chen said he had received reports that claimed Siew originally did not want to take part in the forum, but later changed his mind and submitted an application after the deadline because China had extended an invitation to him.

Siew, the first Taiwan vice president-elect ever to set foot on Chinese soil, said prior to his visit that he planned to attend the annual forum April 11-13 in his capacity as chairman of the private Taipei-based Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation (CSCMF) , as he had done in the past five years.

However, Chen said at an alumni meeting of the Taipei-based Ketagalan Institute that Siew's visit to China was an attempt by Beijing to divert the attention of the international community, in much the same way that it did three years ago when it passed an anti-secession law.
The anti-secession law authorized Beijing to use force against Taiwan if it declares formal independence from China.

In 2005, two leaders of Taiwan's opposition parties -- Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong -- were invited to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao in China.

On the sidelines of the Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) held in the southern Chinese resort of Boao in Hainan province, Siew and Hu discussed issues such as enhanced trade and other cross-strait exchanges, during a 20-minute meeting.
The historic meeting was the highest-level of political contact between Taiwan and China in nearly six decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate dancers to entertain hospital patients with 19 shows

TEXT.P: The world-renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theater and its younger sister troupe, Cloud Gate 2, will take turns to entertain patients at Taiwan's hospitals with 19 performances this year as part of Cloud Gate's 35th anniversary celebrations.

According to Lin Hwai-min, founder and artistic director of Taiwan's first contemporary dance troupe, during the islandwide tour called "Spring in Hospitals, " dancers of the two troupes will stage some of Cloud Gate's classic shows in the lobbies of 18 hospitals in Taipei, Hsinchu, Chiayi, Tainan and Kaohsiung between April 11 and Oct. 24.

One of the shows is Moon Water, which Lin created in 1998 on inspiration from a Buddhist proverb: "Flowers in a mirror and moon on the water are both illusive." The dance has been integrated with Tai Chi moves and is performed to the music of Bach's Suites for Solo Cello.
Other shows to be staged include parts of the troupe's productions "Tantalus," "Love Story" and "Body, Sound."
Cloud Gate Dance Troupe 1, founded in 1973, now focuses more on international touring while Cloud Gate 2, founded in 1999 to cultivate young choreographers, performs mainly in local communities.

Lin said that although the two troupes are extremely busy with domestic and overseas performance tours this year, they have managed to find time for the meaningful cause to bring joy to patients in hospitals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City Government urges use of non-disposable chopsticks

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government, along with a television channel and a department store, launched an event in Taipei Sunday, in recognition of Earth Day April 22, at which they called on the general public to use non-disposable chopsticks to help save the earth.

The earth is not just in high fever it's also suffering from lung disease," said Taipei City governments Bureau of Environment Protection Director Stephen Shen, referring to the effects of global warming and deforestation.
One thousand trees are cut down to make the 2.8 million chopsticks used in Taiwan each day, said Shen, urging the public to start using non-disposable chopsticks as a way to save the earth.
He said that the Taipei City Government might introduce a law to restrict some businesses, such as convenience stores, from dispensing disposable chopsticks.

If the six billion people on earth could all stop using disposable dining utensils, we would becomegood bacteriaon the earth and help it to get better much faster, " he added, sticking to the analogy of a sick person.

Shen also read a "statement from a dying tree" in Hsinyi New Life Square that urged the use of non-disposable chopsticks, which he said represented the "views" of all those trees that had been hewn down to make disposable chopsticks.

Shen, along with Home Box Office (HBO) Singapore Senior Director Caroline Wong and Yang Tsung-rong, store manager of the Shin Kong Mitsukoshi Department Store Xinyi Branch, wrote on tree leaves their commitments to save the earth. The leaves will be hung on the four-meter tall dying tree as symbol of its restoration to life.
Because we are going to show the film -- An Inconvenient Truth -- on Earth Day, this is a great time for us to try to get the Taiwanese people involved in doing something to save the earth,said Wong.
Since disposable chopsticks are used a lot in Taiwan, we feel that it would be appropriate for everyone to switch to chopsticks that can be reused," she added.

Yang said that the campaign, dubbed "One pair of reusable chopsticks -- together we can save the earth," will last from April 10 to 22, and anyone who spends NT$200 (US$7) in the department store's food court can get a free pair of reusable chopsticks and contribute the protection of the environment.
Earth Day was founded by environmental activist John McConnell in 1969 to inspire awareness of and appreciation for the Earths environment. It is celebrated in many countries each year on April 22.
Cutting carbon dioxide emissions is a matter of great urgency in Taiwan, with the country's per capita carbon dioxide emissions amounting to three times the global average.

Each Taiwan citizen produces about 12 metric tons of carbon dioxide each year, much higher than the global average of 4 tons. Taiwan is responsible for about one percent of the entire global greenhouse gas emissions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan pulls off Davis Cup comeback to upend Kazakhstan

TEXT.P: Fighting fatigue and a sore serving shoulder, Taiwan's Chen Ti saved his Davis Cup team from a painful defeat Sunday in its Asia/ Oceania Zone Group I playoff encounter against upstart Kazakhstan in Almaty.

Chen' s clutch play in two tiebreakers proved the difference as he outlasted Kazakh veterain Almaty n Alexey Kedryuk 7-6 (8), 4-6, 6-1, 7-6 (4) to give Taiwan a 3-2 comeback win in the best-of-five tie and avoid a relegation battle against the Philippines in September.

With Taiwan having to win both reverse singles Sunday to claim victory after losing the doubles on Saturday, Taiwan's No. 1 Lu Yen-hsun launched the comeback with a relatively routine 6-3, 6-4, 6-2 triumph over Kazakhstan's Russian import Yuriy Schukin.
Although Lu is only ranked 13 places higher than Schukin, the gulf seemed far wider as the world no. 114 rarely was pressured on his serve and returned well on the lightning fast court in Almaty.

It was then up to Chen to clinch the final point, and for the second time in three years, the mild-mannered 24-year-old overcame the pressure, and fatigue from having been on the court more than seven hours the previous two days, to pull through.

Although Chen is ranked 238 places higher than Kedryuk, he needed three sets to overcome the 27-year-old Kazakh in a Futures event in Uzbekistan last year and was likely to have an even tougher task in front of a highly partisan crowd.

Chen was playing this weekend in place of Taiwan's No. 2-ranked player Wang Yeu- tzuoo, who was left off the team because he has yet to recover his form after battling illness and injuries in recent months.

Wang's absence almost proved costly after the 127th-ranked Schukin, listed as a Russian on the ATP site, was added to the Kazakhstan team recently when he was granted a passport from the Central Asia country.
He outlasted Chen in a five-setter on Friday and partnered with Kedryuk on Saturday to win the doubles and give the hosts a 2-1 lead.
But fortunately for the visitors, Chen replicated his decisive victory of February 2006 when he beat Aqeel Khan in four sets in Taipei to give Taiwan a 3-2 Group 1 opening round win against Pakistan.
With the victory, Taiwan's Davis Cup campaign for the year ends, and it will open the competition as one of the eight teams in Asia/ Oceania Zone Group 1 next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Thai workers in southern Taiwan celebrate Songkran Festival

TEXT.P: Residents of southern Taiwan joined nearly 1,000 Thai workers in that part of the country Sunday to celebrate the Songkran Festival, which is regarded in Thailand as the traditional New Year.

The Thai nationals are employed in Kaohsiung City and the counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung. The Kaohsiung County Government used several fire-trucks and water-carrying vehicles to provide logistic support at what is also known as the "Thai water festival."

The festival formally began at the plaza in front of the Kaohsiung County Labor Recreation Center with a representative of the Thai workers pouring flower- scented water into the hands of the guests of honor seated on a platform.

Kaohsiung County Deputy Magistrate Yeh Nan-ming, Pingtung County Deputy Magistrate Chung Chia-bin, and Damrongsak Engsriswasdi, director of the Thailand Trade and Economic Office in Taiwan, each threw a bucket of water into the crowd, marking the beginning of a hilarious water fight symbolizing mutual well-wishing.

The Songkran Festival, by far the most important event of the year for the Thai people, will last until 15. It is a time of fun and a special time to pay tribute to water, the most important element in the agricultural culture of Southeast Asia.

Taiwan is the first choice of Thai nationals seeking employment abroad. It has hired about 100,000 Thai workers, the largest concentration of Thai nationals outside Thailand, with Singapore's 8,000 Thai workers being a distant second.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect's meeting with Chinese leader sets tone for ties: lawmaker

TEXT.P: A historic meeting between Taiwan's Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and Chinese President Hu Jintao at a regional economic forum in China has set the tone for cross-strait relations in the next four years, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker said Saturday.
Hu mentioned cross-strait trade exchanges twice in his short opening remarks during the meeting with Hu, which clearly focused the 20-minute discussion on trade, said KMT Legislator Lin Yu-fang.
The meeting marked the highest-level political contact across the Taiwan Strait in nearly 60 years.

Siew, who took part in the forum in his capacity as chairman of the private Taipei-based Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation (CSCMF), is the first Taiwanese vice president-elect ever to set foot on Chinese soil.

Offering his views on the meeting between Hu and the KMT's Siew on the sidelines of the Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) at the southern Chinese resort of Boao in Hainan province, Lin said that Hu will not raise any highly sensitive political issues concerning Taiwan, such as the "1992 consensus," at the forum.

Lin expressed the view that Hu will try to avoid "internationalizing" China's problem with Taiwan at a forum of many state leaders, senior officials and business leaders from Asia, the U.S., Europe and Australia.

It has been widely speculated that the "1992 consensus"-- a formula that the KMT said would allow the two sides to skirt the issue of Taiwan' s sovereignty in any official talks -- could serve as platform for the restoration of cross- strait dialogue after President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the KMT starts his four- year term May 20.

According to the KMT, under the "1992 consensus," each side would agree that there is one China, but with different definitions of that one China, with Beijing referring to "one China" as "the People's Republic of China" and Taipei as "the Republic of China, " Taiwan's official title.
In addition, Lin said, China wanted to show the foreign delegates at the economic forum it hosted from April 11-13 that it now has a harmonious, improved relationship with Taiwan.
Otherwise, China's inability to handle the cross-strait issue well will prompt other countries to doubt Beijing's ability to play a leading role in economic integration in Asia, he added.

Lin nevertheless described the Siew-Hu meeting as having more of a symbolic significance, but added that he believes the meeting will have a major impact on the policies of state leaders on both sides of the strait in the next four years.

Cross-strait relations have been frozen in the past eight years due to China's unwillingness to hold dialogue with Taiwan's incumbent Democratic Progressive Party administration, which favors independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect's meeting with Chinese leader seen as ice-breaker: scholar

TEXT.P: An unprecedented meeting between Taiwan's Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and Chinese President Hu Jintao at a Beijing-hosted economic forum reflects a thawing of relations between Taiwan and China, according to a Taiwanese scholar.

Beijing did not say much after the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , which advocates closer ties with China, won the March 22 presidential poll, Lin Chong-Pin, a professor of Taipei-based Tamkang University, said Saturday.

Hu's remarks at the 20-minute meeting with Siew Saturday on the sidelines of the Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) in China's southern Hainan province was the first official response from Beijing since the Taiwan election, Lin noted.

Although he did not go into any details regarding trade exchanges and cooperation between China and Taiwan, Hu responded positively to Siew's four requests to resume cross-strait dialogue, normalize bilateral trade and economic ties, launch weekend cross-strait charter flights and open Chinese tourists to Taiwan, Lin claimed.
It is now left to be seen how the two sides will work out the details, said Lin, a former vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council and a former vice defence minister.

Lin pointed out that the meeting also marked another new development, as Beijing did not insist on asking Taiwan to accept its "one-China" policy, but rather Hu put aside political issues and focused on economic matters.

Meanwhile, neither side mentioned the "1992 consensus" -- a formula that the KMT said would allow the two sides to skirt the issue of Taiwan' s sovereignty in any official talks -- after the meeting, Lin noted.
The decision by both sides to set aside political issues "is sort of in line with the spirit of the 1992 consensus," Lin said.

Siew, who attended the forum in his capacity as chairman of the private Taipei- based Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation (CSCMF) , is the first Taiwanese vice president-elect ever to set foot on Chinese soil.
The meeting marked the highest-level political contact across the Taiwan Strait in nearly six decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: Demand of large-size LCD panel will meet the supply in Q2 : analysis

TEXT.P: Despite a 17 percent oversupply of large-size LCD panels in the first quarter of 2008, the balance is expected to level out starting in the second quarter if the demand remains largely the same, IDC Taiwan stated in a recent press release.

IDC Taiwan is the Taiwan branch of IDC, which provides data, market intelligence, advisory services, and tracks trends in information technology, telecommunications, and consumer technology markets globally.
Despite the falling demand in the first quarter for LCD panels, 14-inch and bigger, the prices of such products did not record a significant decline, the IDC stated.
The prices of personal computer monitors and notebook panels dropped 3 percent to 10 percent, while LCD-TV panels were 4 percent cheaper thanks to strong demand, according to the press release.

"What stabilized the prices was mainly the LCD panel makers move to strategically increase inventory instead of selling the panels on the market," said Hsu Mei-wen, IDC Taiwan's panel research manager.
This strategy will help panel makers to deal with a crisis such as the one of last year when demand outstripped supply, due to the snow crisis in China said Hsu.

Expecting a growth in LCD-TV panel demand that could compensate for the weak demand for desktop computers, the IDC forecasted that starting in the second quarter, the demand for LCD panels will begin to top supply, sending prices up.
"In the third quarter prices will reach a peak, " the press release stated.

The IDC said the world's leading LCD manufacturers, including Taiwan's Chi Mei and AU Optronics, are expanding their production capacity, which will increase total supply 25 percent to 30 percent year-on-year. However, the IDC noted that the increase might not be enough to cope with the soaring demand.

The LCD makers are evaluating to what extent demand could rise in the latter half of 2008, as the U.S. subprime mortgage crisis is still affecting the global market, said the IDC, adding that the makers would likely decide on the level of production expansion in the second quarter.

Citing the recent decline of the U.S. currency against the New Taiwan dollar, the IDC advised LCD makers to take appropriate hedge positions to avoid potential losses as result of a higher Taiwan dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairman takes lead in self-reflection

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party no longer has a monopoly on the Taiwan identity issue, and if the party continues to focus solely on that concern, it would be hard pressed to regain majority support in Taiwan, DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh has said.

In an article published Saturday in the Chinese-language China Times, Hsieh wrote that the Taiwan identity advocated by the DPP has become a consensus in Taiwan's society and has also been accepted by the newly elected Kuomintang.
Hsieh said he believed that the party could soon stage a comeback if its members at all levels engaged in a self-reflection and reform.
In the article titled, "My Reflections and Future Prospects,", Hsieh took the self-examination lead by stating four areas in which he thought he could have done better.
Hsieh said that he had served in a number of important posts during the eight years of the DPP administration but had failed to fulfill the desire of Taiwan's people for a more harmonious society.
The DPP chairman also offered an apology for disappointing the Taiwan people because he was unable to spur the party to deliver on its promises of integrity and procedural justice.

Since the DPP came to power in 2000, it has become increasingly alienated from the grassroots communities and has been motivated largely by a desire to remain in office, Hsieh said. He said the party sometimes sacrificed the values of progress and democracy to maintain political power, and he pegged the reasons for its recent crushing election defeats firmly to those problems.
Hsieh also apologized to party members and supporters for having failed to help deter factional fighting within the party while he DPP chairman and a member of the DPP Central Standing Committee.

The DPP, which will go into opposition when the KMT takes office May 20, should monitor the incoming KMT government, particularly on its handling of cross- Taiwan Strait issues, and will not allow the KMT to compromise Taiwan's sovereignty or national security, or to hurt the democratic movement, Hsieh wrote.
Hsieh, urging the public not to speculate on his reasons, reiterated that he will not run for president in 2012 and will not endorse anyone to run in the presidential election at that time.

Also on Saturday at a reception, The DPP chairman floated the idea of running a "shadow government" to monitor the incoming KMT government, which he said would be based on the DPP's basic values and concept of a "wellbeing economy."
Hsieh said he would use the administrative experience he gained as the country's premier and as mayor of Kaohsiung to help young people develop skills in supervising the government.

At the reception, which he attended by taking the MRT, Hsieh said that he had nothing to complain about and respected the voters' choice, in response to a question on why he had lost by a margin of more than 20,000 votes in the southern port city where he had served as mayor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice President-elect returns to Taiwan from China

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew returned to Taipei late Sunday from a three-day forum in Hainan province, southern China.
On his arrival at the Taoyuan International Airport, Siew waved to waiting jounalists but didn't answer their questions.

Before leaving Boao, Hainan province, Siew described his attendance at the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia as a successful "ice-breaking" trip that not only helped to ease tensions across the Taiwan Strait, but also served to enhance Taiwan's international image.

Siew told Taiwan journalists accompanied him on the trip that he hoped his 20-minute meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines of the forum will lead to a better understanding between Taipei and Beijing and contribute to the trust-building process across the strait.

The Hu-Siew meeting, the highest political contact between Taipei and Beijing during the last six decades, was the highlight of Siew's activities in Boao and was considered a breakthrough in the political impasse between China and Taiwan.

Beijing, which considers Taiwan part of its territory had ceased all contact with Taiwan since 1999 when then-Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui described the relations between his country and China as "special state to state, " had hardened its no-contact stance after the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party came to power in Taiwan in 2000.
During his talks with Hu, Siew called for the launch of weekend charter flights between Taiwan and the mainland, and urged China to allow its people to visit Taiwan for sightseeing purposes.
Stopping short of agreeing with Siew's requests immediately, Hu said Beijing will keep negotiating with Taipei on these issues.

Siew, who will be inaugurated on May 20, took part in the forum in his private capacity as chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation which he founded in 2001 to promote the establishment of a common market between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect briefs forum attendees on Taiwan economic blueprint

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Vice President-elect Vincent Siew said Sunday that while striving to bolster its economic growth, Taiwan will pay attention to social justice and sustainable development.
To achieve that goal, Siew said, Taiwan should seek to increase domestic demand and consumption, as well as to expand public investment, which will eventually lead to infrastructure upgrades.

Governmental policies that would contribute to rejuvenating Taiwan's industrial structure so as to rev up innovation in the private sector are also imperative, added Siew, who is slated to take office on May 20..
Siew made the remarks during a roundtable meeting at which he outlined the prospects of Taiwan's economic development after the incoming Kuomintang administration is sworn on May 20.

A number of people, including academics and business leaders from both China and Taiwan, attended the roundtable meeting on Taiwan's economic situation and cross-strait economic and trade prospects, which took place on the sidelines of the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia in Hainan, China April 11-13.
Siew met with Chen Deming, China's minister of Commerce for a brief talk before they jointly presided over the opening of the roundtable meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairman takes lead in self-reflection

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party no longer has a monopoly on the Taiwan identity issue, and if the party continues to focus solely on that concern, it would be hard pressed to regain majority support in Taiwan, DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh has said.

In an article published Saturday in the Chinese-language China Times, Hsieh wrote that the Taiwan identity advocated by the DPP has become a consensus in Taiwan's society and has also been accepted by the newly elected Kuomintang.
Hsieh said he believed that the party could soon stage a comeback if its members at all levels engaged in a self-reflection and reform.
In the article titled, "My Reflections and Future Prospects,", Hsieh took the self-examination lead by stating four areas in which he thought he could have done better.
Hsieh said that he had served in a number of important posts during the eight years of the DPP administration but had failed to fulfill the desire of Taiwan's people for a more harmonious society.
The DPP chairman also offered an apology for disappointing the Taiwan people because he was unable to spur the party to deliver on its promises of integrity and procedural justice.

Since the DPP came to power in 2000, it has become increasingly alienated from the grassroots communities and has been motivated largely by a desire to remain in office, Hsieh said. He said the party sometimes sacrificed the values of progress and democracy to maintain political power, and he pegged the reasons for its recent crushing election defeats firmly to those problems.
Hsieh also apologized to party members and supporters for having failed to help deter factional fighting within the party while he DPP chairman and a member of the DPP Central Standing Committee.

The DPP, which will go into opposition when the KMT takes office May 20, should monitor the incoming KMT government, particularly on its handling of cross- Taiwan Strait issues, and will not allow the KMT to compromise Taiwan's sovereignty or national security, or to hurt the democratic movement, Hsieh wrote.
Hsieh, urging the public not to speculate on his reasons, reiterated that he will not run for president in 2012 and will not endorse anyone to run in the presidential election at that time.

Also on Saturday at a reception, The DPP chairman floated the idea of running a "shadow government" to monitor the incoming KMT government, which he said would be based on the DPP's basic values and concept of a "wellbeing economy."
Hsieh said he would use the administrative experience he gained as the country's premier and as mayor of Kaohsiung to help young people develop skills in supervising the government.

At the reception, which he attended by taking the MRT, Hsieh said that he had nothing to complain about and respected the voters' choice, in response to a question on why he had lost by a margin of more than 20,000 votes in the southern port city where he had served as mayor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Thai workers in southern Taiwan celebrate Songkran Festival

TEXT.P: Residents of southern Taiwan joined nearly 1,000 Thai workers in that part of the country Sunday to celebrate the Songkran Festival, which is regarded in Thailand as the traditional New Year.

The Thai nationals are employed in Kaohsiung City and the counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung. The Kaohsiung County Government used several fire-trucks and water-carrying vehicles to provide logistic support at what is also known as the "Thai water festival."

The festival formally began at the plaza in front of the Kaohsiung County Labor Recreation Center with a representative of the Thai workers pouring flower- scented water into the hands of the guests of honor seated on a platform.

Kaohsiung County Deputy Magistrate Yeh Nan-ming, Pingtung County Deputy Magistrate Chung Chia-bin, and Damrongsak Engsriswasdi, director of the Thailand Trade and Economic Office in Taiwan, each threw a bucket of water into the crowd, marking the beginning of a hilarious water fight symbolizing mutual well-wishing.

The Songkran Festival, by far the most important event of the year for the Thai people, will last until 15. It is a time of fun and a special time to pay tribute to water, the most important element in the agricultural culture of Southeast Asia.

Taiwan is the first choice of Thai nationals seeking employment abroad. It has hired about 100,000 Thai workers, the largest concentration of Thai nationals outside Thailand, with Singapore's 8,000 Thai workers being a distant second.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan pulls off Davis Cup comeback to upend Kazakhstan

TEXT.P: Fighting fatigue and a sore serving shoulder, Taiwan's Chen Ti saved his Davis Cup team from a painful defeat Sunday in its Asia/ Oceania Zone Group I playoff encounter against upstart Kazakhstan in Almaty.

Chen' s clutch play in two tiebreakers proved the difference as he outlasted Kazakh veterain Almaty n Alexey Kedryuk 7-6 (8), 4-6, 6-1, 7-6 (4) to give Taiwan a 3-2 comeback win in the best-of-five tie and avoid a relegation battle against the Philippines in September.

With Taiwan having to win both reverse singles Sunday to claim victory after losing the doubles on Saturday, Taiwan's No. 1 Lu Yen-hsun launched the comeback with a relatively routine 6-3, 6-4, 6-2 triumph over Kazakhstan's Russian import Yuriy Schukin.
Although Lu is only ranked 13 places higher than Schukin, the gulf seemed far wider as the world no. 114 rarely was pressured on his serve and returned well on the lightning fast court in Almaty.

It was then up to Chen to clinch the final point, and for the second time in three years, the mild-mannered 24-year-old overcame the pressure, and fatigue from having been on the court more than seven hours the previous two days, to pull through.

Although Chen is ranked 238 places higher than Kedryuk, he needed three sets to overcome the 27-year-old Kazakh in a Futures event in Uzbekistan last year and was likely to have an even tougher task in front of a highly partisan crowd.

Chen was playing this weekend in place of Taiwan's No. 2-ranked player Wang Yeu- tzuoo, who was left off the team because he has yet to recover his form after battling illness and injuries in recent months.

Wang's absence almost proved costly after the 127th-ranked Schukin, listed as a Russian on the ATP site, was added to the Kazakhstan team recently when he was granted a passport from the Central Asia country.
He outlasted Chen in a five-setter on Friday and partnered with Kedryuk on Saturday to win the doubles and give the hosts a 2-1 lead.
But fortunately for the visitors, Chen replicated his decisive victory of February 2006 when he beat Aqeel Khan in four sets in Taipei to give Taiwan a 3-2 Group 1 opening round win against Pakistan.
With the victory, Taiwan's Davis Cup campaign for the year ends, and it will open the competition as one of the eight teams in Asia/ Oceania Zone Group 1 next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 14, or the ninth day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1629: Christiaan Huygens, the Dutch physicist and astronomer, is born. He discovered Saturn's rings in 1655, pioneered the use of pendulum in clocks in 1657, and formulated Huygens' principle.
1865: US President Abraham Lincoln is failing fast after being shot in the back of the head at point-blank range by actor John Wilkes Booth, a Confederate fanatic, at the Ford Theater in Washington, D.C. He died the next day and was succeeded by Andrew Johnson.
1889: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and author of a 12-volume work entitled "A Study of History," is born.
1903: The typhus vaccine is discovered by Dr. Harry Plotz in New York.
1912: The Titanic strikes an iceberg and sinks in the North Atlantic, killing 1,500 people.
1941: Condemning the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact, Foreign Minister Wang Chung-hui of the Republic of China declares that Outer Mongolia and the northeastern provinces are Chinese territory and that the Soviet-Japanese statement is not binding on China.
1945: US bombers pound Japan's Imperial Palace during World War II.
1949: The Taiwan provincial administration announces a decision to carry out the "37.5 Percent Farm Rental Reduction" and the "Land-to-the-Tiller" policies.
1956: USS Saratoga, a US Navy aircraft carrier which joined the fleet in 1927 as the largest warship in the world, is formally decommissioned.
1956: The first videotape is demonstrated in Chicago.
1962: French Prime Minister Michel Debre resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1971: The new Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1972: The first satellite observation station in the Republic of China is inaugurated at National Cheng Kung University.
1973: President Nguyen Van Thieu of the Republic of Vietnam leaves Taipei for home after a three-day visit.
1973: Dr. Jesus Soto Amesty, chairman of the Venezuela Senate Foreign Policy Committee, arrives in Taipei for a ten-day visit.
1975: Sikkim abolishes its monarchy and seeks full Indian statehood.
1976: A total of 3,460 students from 642 middle schools compete in the Taiwan Area Games.
1977: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.
1982: Armed bandit Lee Shih-khe robs the Land Bank of Taiwan's Kuting Branch in Taipei City of more than NT$5 million, a major criminal case at that time.
1988: The Soviet Union ends its intervention in Afghanistan and allows its troops to withdraw.
1993: On International Women's Day, a Chinese newspaper asks 100 women what they would most like to be. Sixty say that they want to be men.
1994: Two US F-15 fighters shoot down two American helicopters over northern Iraq killing 26 people.
1999: Pakistan test-fires a 2,000-km range ballistic missile.
2000: Ovidio Manuel Barbosa Pequeno, the new Sao Tome and Principe ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
2001: A four-member U.S. Senate delegation led by Sen. Phil Gramm (R-TX) arrives in Taipei to begin a three-day visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To be poor without complaining is not easy; but it is easy to be rich without being proud."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Incoming presidential team to meet press on Boao forum

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew of the main opposition Kuomintang are slated to meet the press Monday afternoon, mainly to discuss Siew's recent attendance at the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia which took place in Hainan, China April 11-13.

Siew, who attended the annual Boao forum in his capacity as chairman of the private Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation, is expected to be showered with questions about China's unilateral adding of the "one China" term to a news release that was issued after Siew and Chinese Commerce Minister Chen Deming jointly presided over a roundtable meeting Sunday on the sidelines of the forum.

On that issue, Siew said after the forum that he and his team members had no idea about it and that the news release, issued by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, had not been approved by the Taiwan delegation before it was released.

China released a statement Saturday that read in part, "Both sides will build up a bilateral communication platform, the sooner the better, under the "one-China" policy." The statement was posted on the official Web site of the Chinese Ministry of Commerce.
It was learned Monday that the words "one China" have since been deleted from the statement.

Siew and the Taiwan delegation returned to Taiwan late Sunday night. Before leaving Boao, Hainan province, Siew described his attendance at the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia as a successful "ice-breaking" trip that not only helped to ease tensions across the Taiwan Strait, but also served as a platform for economic exchanges between Taiwan and the rest of the world.

Siew told Taiwan journalists accompanying him on the trip that he hoped his 20-minute meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines of the forum will lead to a better understanding between Taipei and Beijing and contribute to the trust-building process across the strait.

The Hu-Siew meeting, the highest political contact between Taipei and Beijing during the last six decades, was the highlight of Siew's activities in Boao and was considered a breakthrough in the political impasse between China and Taiwan.
During his talks with Hu, Siew called for the launch of weekend charter flights between Taiwan and the mainland and urged China to allow its people to visit Taiwan for sightseeing purposes.
Stopping short of agreeing with Siew's requests immediately, Hu said Beijing will keep negotiating with Taipei on these issues.
Ma and Siew are scheduled to take office May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan forecast to win seven golds at Olympics

TEXT.P: Taiwan is forecast to win seven gold medals at the 2008 Olympic Games slated to open in Beijing Aug. 8, the country's top official in charge of sports affairs said Monday.

Yang Jong-her, chairman of the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council, said 37 male and 24 female Taiwan athletes have qualified to compete in nine events at the Beijing Olympics and these athletes are expected to win seven gold and many other medals at the games.
Taiwan athletes are seen as having the best chances of winning gold in the taekwondo, weightlifting, archery and tennis competitions, Yang said during a session at the Legislative Yuan.
Taiwan athletes have registered to compete in other events, including women's softball, table tennis, track and field, swimming and baseball, according to Yang.

At the session, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Kuan Pi-ling suggested that the Sports Affairs Council emulate the United States and plan to boycott the opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympics to express Taiwan's indignation over China's military crackdown on Tibetan protesters.
Responding to Kuan's suggestion, Yang said that his council has "resolved to adhere to the principle of separating politics from sports."

Yang added that the Sports Affairs Council will consult other Cabinet-level agencies on issues pertaining to Taiwan's participation in international competitions and the country's hosting of international sporting events, such as the World Games set to take place in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan next year.

Taiwan athletes won two gold medals, both in taekwondo competitions, as well as two silvers and one bronze at the last Olympic Games held in Athens in 2004, taking 31st spot in the overall medal standings that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT deputy chairman to be Taiwan's chief negotiator with China

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou confirmed Monday that he will name Kuomintang (KMT) Deputy Chairman Chiang Pin-kung as head of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and that efforts to push for talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will begin after his inauguration May 20.

Ma made the announcement at a joint press conference with Vice President-elect Vincent Siew Monday to talk about the latter's recent attendance at the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia that took place in the southern Chinese province of Hainan April 11-13.

Siew had a high-profile meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao Saturday on the sidelines of the forum, after which China urged that the two sides "build a bilateral communication platform, the sooner the better."
At Monday's press conference, Ma described the Siew-Hu meeting as "successful," and promised to pragmatically promote the resumption of cross-strait dialogue, which had stopped since 1999.

Taiwan established the SEF in 1991 to serve as an intermediary body to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official links. Its Chinese counterpart is the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.
During the press conference, Ma also confirmed that he will appoint Taipei-based Soochow University President Liu Chao-shiuan to serve as premier.
Siew, who attended the annual Boao forum in his capacity as chairman of the private Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation, returned to Taiwan late Sunday night.

Siew told Taiwan journalists accompanying him on the trip that he hoped his 20-minute meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines of the forum will lead to a better understanding between Taipei and Beijing and contribute to the trust-building process across the strait.

The Hu-Siew meeting, the highest political contact between Taipei and Beijing during the last six decades, was the highlight of Siew's activities in Boao and was considered a breakthrough in the political impasse between China and Taiwan.
