DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high but ended slightly lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 16.9 points, or 0.18 percent, to close at 8,892.68.

The local bourse opened at 8,877.47 and fluctuated between 8,928.87 and 8,839.12 during the day's session. A total of 6.67 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$173.94 billion (US$5.74 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction shares moving up the most at 4.1 percent. Cement stocks rose 2.3 percent, paper and pulp issues advanced 1.7 percent, plastics and chemical shares moved up 0.7 percent, textile stocks increased 0.6 percent, banking and financial shares rose 0.5 percent, and foodstuff issues gained 0.4 percent.
Only one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares dropping 1.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,329 to 988, with 232 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5.5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to overhaul minimum wage policy

TEXT.P: Labor rights activists groups urged the government Monday to honor its promise to review the minimum wage annually and take steps to have all wage earners covered by the Labor Standards Act.

Members of several social activist groups, including the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions (TCTU) , filed an appeal with the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Monday for a national meeting to review the existing minimum wage structure, a meeting that the CLA had earlier promised.

TCTU Chairman Shih Chao-hsien called for the CLA to convene the meeting as soon as possible to decide whether or not the minimum wage is at a reasonable level, as prices of commodities and daily necessities have soared over the past year.

Shih said that although inflation has surged by an average of 6.46 percent over the past four years and the country's economy has advanced between 4 percent-6 percent annually, blue-collar workers have not enjoyed any positive results of this growths.
He pointed out that Taiwan's minimum wage has not been adjusted over the last 10 years except for once in 2007.
"Even though the minimum wage was adjusted last year, the payment adjustment did not efficiently reflect the real growth in inflation," Shih said.
He further noted that the country's civil servants enjoyed salary hikes in 1999, 2000, 2001 and 2005.
"I hope President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and his new administration will pay closer attention to the issue of salaries for the working class," Shih added.

Meanwhile, Sun You-lien, secretary-general of the Taiwan Labor Front, said that according to official statistics released by the CLA, about 310,000 blue-collar workers have yet to be protected under the Labor Standards Act.
However, he disputed this figure, saying that according to his group's estimation, at least around 600,000 salaried workers are not entitled to the benefits of the Labor Standards Act.
Sun called for the CLA to make a commitment that measures will be taken to gradually allow all these disadvantaged workers to enjoy the benefits stipulated in the law.

The minimum wage was raised to NT$17,280 (US$568) per month and the minimum hourly wage was hiked to NT$95 July 1, 2007. About 1.41 million "marginal" members of the country's workforce -- including foreign laborers, part-time workers, senior citizens who have returned to the employment market after retirement and female workers -- reportedly benefited from the wage hike.

In response to the groups' calls, CLA officials said Monday that a review of the issue of including more employees under the protection of the Labor Standards Act is expected to be completed by the end of 2009 and that a national meeting on the minimum wage issue will be held as scheduled -- probably after May 20, when the new Kuomintang administration will take office.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA identifies new 'white-blossomed' subgroup of Taiwan Cherry tree

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture's (COA's) Agricultural Research Institute recently identified a previously unrecorded type of cherry tree with white blossoms, found at high elevations in Taiwan, as a subgroup of the Taiwan Cherry tree.

The institute has since registered the "white blossomed Taiwan cherry" with the International Union of Biologicial Science's Commission for the Nomenclature of Cultivated Plants under the name "prunus campanulata Maxim F. Alba I.C. Wen."

Huang Sheng-chung, director of the institute's National Plant Genetic Resources Center, said Monday that he recently decided to research the background of the special white-blossomed cherry tree and discovered that there was no record in Taiwan of this type of tree.

Huang said that he initially suspected that the tree might have been an imported Japanese variety. However, after doing a thorough search, he found that the tree did not match any on record in Japan's plant databases.
He therefore decided to carry out a Random Amplified Polymorphic DNA analysis on a specimen of the tree and determined it to be a member of the Taiwan Cherry tree family.
The white-blossomed variety of cherry tree shares most of the same characteristics as the Taiwan Cherry, or prunus campanulata Maxim, including excellent soil adaptability.
The main difference is the color of the blossoms, with the Taiwan Cherry having deep, rosy-pink, bell-shaped flowers about an inch wide.
The Taiwan Cherry is native to southern China, Taiwan and Japan's Ryukyu Islands, and is usually found at elevations of between 500 meters and 2,000 meters.
The Taiwan Cherry has been hybridized with other cherry species to produce several important ornamental trees, including the highly treasured "Okame."

Throughout Taiwan's sightseeing areas, there are some 100,000 Taiwan Cherry trees that each year attract thousands of tourists who flock to see the spectacular display of color when the trees are in bloom.

Huang said that the presence of the white-blossomed variety of cherry tree adds another element to Taiwan's natural scenery during the spring months and provides an additional reason for nature lovers to visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: 779,000 passengers use `mini three links' in 2007

TEXT.P: A total of 779,000 passengers used the "mini three links" across the Taiwan Strait during 2007, according to tallies released Monday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
The figure marks an increase of 16.4 percent over the level for the previous year, according to the tallies.
Of the total, 672,000 were Taiwanese nationals, marking an increase of 14.8 percent over the year-earlier figure.
Meanwhile, 107,000 Chinese citizens used the "mini three links" routes in 2007, up 27.8 percent.
It was the first time that Chinese passenger numbers had broken the 100,000-mark since the implementation of the links at the start of 2001, the MOTC said.

The "mini three links" refers to direct postal, transport and trade links between the Chinese cities of Xiamen, Mawei and Quanzhou in Fujian Province and Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu.
As of the end of 2007, 2.681 million passengers had used the routes, with an average annual increase of 75 percent, according to the MOTC statistics.
Of that total, 263,000 of the passengers were Chinese citizens, with the average annual increase standing at about 93 percent, the tallies show.

Analyzing the figures, MOTC officials noted the large difference between Taiwanese passenger and Chinese passenger numbers, resulting in part from the differences in policies between the two sides of the strait.
Given the fact that passengers using these routes are mainly Taiwanese, the officials said that the mini three links have not contributed much to boosting bilateral cross-strait exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu sets up bike police unit to patrol scenic coastline

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu City Police Department has set up a special bicycle unit over the weekend to patrol the city's 17-km scenic coastline.
The unit was inaugurated in conjunction with the northern Taiwan city's ongoing "Sea Viewing Festival" being held during the month of April.
The festival, launched by the local government to introduce Hsinchu's marine attractions, is showcasing the city's coastline through various activities.

The bicycle patrol unit was formally launched in a ceremony hosted by Hsinchu Deputy Mayor Chen Chuan-kuei on Saturday. Several ranking local government officials, including Hsinchu City Council Deputy Speaker Hsieh Wen-chin, also attended.
Speaking at the ceremony, Hsinchu police chief Chiou Feng-guang said that Hsinchu's 17-km coastline is a scenic area with many attractions, including bicycle paths.
The municipal government has spent the last several years upgrading the natural attractions and leisure facilities along the coastline to draw more tourists to the city.
The coastline now features eight main attractions, including a Sea Park, a recreational boating wharf, a mangrove forest, a sea-viewing area, a canal, and a bird-watching area.
Chiou said that the 46-member bicycle unit has been set up to maintain law and order in the scenic area and offer services to tourists in order to maximize the enjoyment of their visit to the city.

DOC.HEADLINE: Siew's trip to BFA `total failure': Taiwan Thinktank

TEXT.P: As opposition Kuomintang (KMT) President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew celebrated the fruits of Siew's appearance at the Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) over the weekend, speakers at a forum organized by a pro-independence think tank Monday described his trip as a "total failure."

Participants in the Taiwan Thinktank forum also claimed that instead of achieving substantive results, Siew's visit served only to divert international attention from the Chinese authorities' crackdown on Tibet and caused confusion over Taiwan's cross-strait policy.

Saturday's meeting between Chinese President Hu Jintao and Siew on the sidelines of the three-day BFA in China's Hainan Province was the highest-level contact ever between the two sides since Taiwan and China split in 1949 after a civil war, and is being viewed as the first step of a thaw in long-frozen political exchanges.
Cross-strait relations have been stalled over the past eight years, with outgoing President Chen Shui-bian -- who has been branded a separatist by China -- restricting closer Taiwan ties with China.

However, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and pro- independence groups blasted Siew's visit, describing it as impetuous conduct that belittles Taiwan's sovereignty, as Siew applied for a "re-entry permit for Taiwan compatriots " from China -- though without actually using it -- for the trip.

"From every aspect, the Hu-Siew meeting was no doubt a total failure, " said Lai Yi-chung, deputy director of the DPP's Department of International Affairs, at the seminar organized by the think tank to discuss and evaluate Siew's trip.

Noting that the Hu-Siew meeting was more of a formality rather than anything of substance, Lai said the facts that Hu did not respond to four requests Siew proposed and that no further meetings were arranged all indicate that the gambit was a failure.
In his meeting with Hu, Siew said Taiwan's position is that the two sides should "face reality, envision the future, put aside differences and pursue a win-win situation."

Responding to Siew's proposals, Hu said China will continue promoting bilateral economic and cultural exchanges, negotiating on the opening of weekend cross- strait charter flights and on issues regarding Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan, caring for the rights and welfare of the Taiwanese people, and seeking a resumption of cross-strait negotiations.
According to Lai, Hu only touched on the substantive issues lightly.

"Hu only said `continue promoting' rather than making it clear if and when talks will be resumed, " he said. "As to the normalization of cross-strait economic and trade exchanges, Hu did not mention this at all," he noted.

Lai said that despite everyone focusing on Siew's landmark meeting with Hu and interpreting of it as "breaking the ice, " the real indicators will be whether China will ease its suppression of Taiwan at the upcoming May 19 World Health Assembly, or whether China will really reduce the number missiles aimed at Taiwan.

Tsai Horng-ming, deputy general-secretary of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, also said that another indicator would be whether Taiwan can send a higher-ranking official to attend this year's Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit meeting, or whether China and Taiwan -- both of which are members of the World Trade Organization -- can have better interaction under the organization's framework.

As to DPP accusations that Siew "fell into China's trap by attending the BFA" -- a meeting he has attended every year since 2003 -- and that China made use of his visit to deflect criticism over its crackdown in Tibet, Lai claimed that the Kuomintang (KMT), which will take office May 20, "falls for China's plots every time."

He also said former KMT Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China in 2005 helped China to divert attention from the international community, which was criticizing it for passing its anti-session law targeting Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM declines to comment on possible impact of Siew-Hu meeting

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang declined Monday to comment on the possible impact on Taiwan's diplomatic situation that could be the result of the historic meeting between Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and Chinese President Hu Jintao over the weekend.

Huang said he could not tell whether the meeting, which took place on the sidelines of the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia in China's Hainan Province, "will affect or have anything to do with Taiwan's diplomatic situation."
Huang made the remarks while answering reporters' questions in the southern city of Tainan on whether the Siew-Hu meeting represented a diplomatic breakthrough for Taiwan.

Noting that diplomacy is a symbol of national sovereignty, Huang said he believes that the incoming Kuomintang administration will handle cross-Taiwan Strait issues cautiously as President-elect Ma Ying-jeou has reaffirmed that he will attach great importance to Taiwan's diplomatic ties with other countries.

Speaking of Taiwan's renewed bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) under the name Taiwan, the minister of the outgoing government led by the Democratic Progressive Party said that Beijing has made public its decision to boycott any Taiwanese proposal for WHO access.
Huang said that "designation is not the key problem, rather it is China's attitude" toward Taiwan.

"China fears that any concession to allow Taiwan to join (the WHO) will trigger a domino effect" on Taiwan's other attempts to obtain membership of international organizations, he said, adding that China will still try to shut out Taiwan even if it uses other names for the bid.

Asked about China's use of the "one-China" term in a public statement released after the Siew-Hu meeting that was regarded as an "ice-melting" moment in the long-frozen cross-strait direct talks, before deleting it after Taiwan protested, Huang said he has never seen China's "one China" stance waver.
Beijing has never altered its stance of claiming that "there is only one China in the world, and that Taiwan is part of China, whose only legal government is the People's Republic of China," he said.
The "one China" principle is like "a magic spell that China has cast on Taiwan, " which binds Taiwan whenever it tries to join international activities, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait economic prospects keep Taiwan stocks stable: analysts

TEXT.P: High anticipation of better economic ties between China and Taiwan has allowed Taiwan's share prices to remain unshaken by last Friday's huge setback in the U.S. stock market, with the local bourse only dropping 16.90 points, or 0.18 percent, even as other Asian stock markets suffered a blow from the 256-point drop in the U.S. market.
The Kuomintang's (KMT) win in the March 22 presidential election has given local investors and industries the expectation of prosperous economic relation across the Taiwan Strait.

The anticipation was further enhanced by the recent Boao Forum for Asia, in which Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and Chinese President Hu Jintao held a landmark meeting over the weekend discussing issues including direct chartered flights on weekends and bilateral investment in real estate and banks.

Compared with other major Asian stock markets such as Japan and Hong Kong, which dropped Monday by 3.10 percent and 3.47 percent, respectively, analysts said the fruitful results of the Boao Forum have made Taiwan stocks immune from outside influence, especially in such sectors as tourism, shipping and aviation, construction, and finance. All of them rose by 5.38 percent, 1.46 percent, 4.07 percent, and 0.51 percent, respectively.
Analysts attributed the potential boost in domestic consumers' confidence as the main factor strengthening those sectors.
With a more prosperous economic exchange between Taiwan and China, the domestic demands are likely to rise, said Andy Chang, senior vice-president of Cathay Securities Investment Trust Co.

Chang said the revival of business activities could lift the confidence of both consumers and investors, predicting that the promising outlook of cross-strait trades could attract customers as well as lure back the countrys outflow of capital, which is estimated to be NT$6.7 trillion over the last eight years. The return of the foreign-based Taiwanese, along with Chinese tourists and investors, could spur local industry sectors including airlines, real estate and construction, and retail commodities, he said, referring to the one million China-based Taiwanese businessmen.
Taiwan stocksprice-earning ratio, a measure of how a company s earnings relate to its stock price, could also be gaining ground due to the increase in investorsconfidence,Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.006 to close at NT$30.325.
A total of US$898 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.340 and fluctuated between NT$30.260 and NT$30.439.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wet weather predicted for Taiwan area from April 16

TEXT.P: An approaching cold front is expected to bring drenching rain to Taiwan from Wednesday until next week, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) predicted Monday.

Meteorologists at the CWB said Taiwan will see relatively stable weather conditions for two more days before the cold front sets in Wednesday, bringing thunderstorms to northern Taiwan and showers to the northeastern, eastern and southeastern parts of Taiwan.
The weather experts added that from Thursday, the entire Taiwan area will be affected by very wet weather, which is likely to continue into the next week.

The cold front will cause temperatures to drop slightly, with daytime highs between 25 and 30 degrees Celsius and nighttime lows between 18 and 22 degrees Celsius in most parts of Taiwan, according to the forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect honored in Jerusalem's Forest of Peace

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou received the rare honor Monday of having nine trees planted in Jerusalem's Forest of Peace in his name, representing the hope of peace and prosperity in Taiwan under Ma's presidency.

In a private meeting, Israeli Representative to Taiwan Raphael Gamzou, on behalf of the Forest of Peace, presented the certificate of tree-planting to Ma at the headquarters of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
"Since both of us (Israel and Taiwan) are pursuing peace, I decided to plant nine trees on Ma's behalf," Gamzou told the CNA.

Explaining that the number nine is synonymous with the Chinese word "jeou" and symbolizes "a new beginning" in Hebrew, Gamzou said the tree-planting project is "to wish him success and regional peace and prosperity."
In August 2007, Gamzou also planted 18 trees in honor of Master Chen Yen, founder of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation.
On behalf of his wife Michal Gamzou, Gamzou also presented Ma's wife Chou Mei- ching with a CD of Israeli vocalist David D'Or, who creates works based on the teachings of Master Chen Yen.
Gamzou congratulated Ma for his landslide victory in the March 22 presidential election and commended the Taiwanese people's achievements in establishing democracy.

Recalling a visit he made to Israel in 1999 as Taipei mayor, Ma said he was really impressed by the country, the Weitzman Institute of Science -- Israel's top research organization -- and his meeting with then-Jerusalem Mayor Ehud Olmert, who is now Israel's Prime Minister.
Ma, an enthusiastic jogger, also recalled jogging on the long beach at Tel Aviv, saying that the experience "was great fun."

Although issues on Taiwan's domestic politics were only slightly touched upon during the meeting, Ma, however, restated his wish to Gamzou that he hopes direct chartered flights between Taiwan and China will start very soon and that increasing tourism from China will help boost Taiwan's economy.
Characterizing his meeting with Ma as "fruitful, " Gamzou said he and Ma share a common wish for peace in the Middle East and across the Taiwan Strait.
"We both wish that Taiwanese and Israelis can work together in various fields for the benefit and prosperity of both," Gamzou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP stalwart registers to run for party chairmanship

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Trong Chai registered Monday to run for the chairmanship of the party in an election slated for May 18.
The stalwart pro-Taiwan independence lawmaker was the first potential candidate to register with the DPP Central Committee to run for the post, which will be vacated by Frank Hsieh next month.
Hsieh, who was the DPP's standard bearer in the March 22 presidential election, offered to resign as DPP chairman March 26 to take responsibility for the party's crushing defeat in the poll.
Hsieh, nevertheless, agreed to stay on in the chairmanship post until a new leader is chosen.
According to DPP election guidelines, consultations will be held among candidates for the position after the registration process, and if a leader is not selected, then an election will be held.

The DPP will invite hopefuls to register April 14-18 and will organize a platform presentation for the candidates May 10. After the registration, the party will try to reach a consensus on one candidate through consultations and, if that fails, then a chairmanship election will be held May 18.

Upon his registration as a candidate, Chai said that he supports "collective leadership, " and suggested that several DPP members of the younger generation be appointed to serve as the party's vice chairmen so that they could have an opportunity to be groomed for leadership.
"In this way, the party would be able to achieve generational change," he said.

Apparently not daunted by the voices of younger party members, who have said that the new DPP chairman should be "young and inclined towards reform," Chai said he is "resolute in his decision to run for the chairmanship" because he is "determined to safeguard the Taiwan-centric political line and continue the efforts to seek Taiwan independence -- ideals that are not necessarily central to the views of the younger generation of DPP members."
Chai, however, said that he would not oppose the proposal that the party should try to reach a consensus on one candidate through consultations.

"I see it as my duty to serve the DPP as the party is facing unprecedented challenges -- challenges that are even tougher than those 20 years ago when the DPP was founded as a small opposition party -- and in the wake of two humiliating election defeats this year," Chai asserted.

He also suggested that 200,000 DPP members engage in community service as volunteers, so that they can "touch the hearts of the public," like members of the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, the largest charity organization in Taiwan.

Frank Hsieh took the helm of the DPP Jan. 16 this year, replacing President Chen Shui-bian, who resigned from the party chairmanship soon after the DPP was soundly defeated in the Jan. 12 legislative elections.
Chen was widely blamed for the party's drubbing in the legislative polls which left the DPP with only 27 seats in the new 113-seat legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP-elect's trip to China could hinder diplomatic work: MOFA official

TEXT.P: A senior Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official turned a cold shoulder to Vice President-elect Vincent Siew's trip to an economic forum in China, criticizing at a seminar Monday in Taipei that it has created an illusion that will severely hinder Taiwan's diplomatic efforts and strategies.

"The incoming administration, which prioritized cross-straits policies over diplomatic policies, or thought of using cross-straits policies as the guidelines for all diplomatic policies, will severely impact Taiwan's overall diplomatic strategy, " said Liu Shih-chung, vice chairman of the MOFA's Research and Planning Committee.

Saturday's meeting of Chinese President Hu Jintao and Siew on the sidelines of the three-day economic conference Boao Forum for Asia in China's Hainan Province was the highest-level contact ever between the two sides since Taiwan and China split in 1949 after a civil war, and is being viewed as the first step of thawing the long- stalled political exchanges between the two sides.

Cross-strait relations between Taiwan and China have been stalled over the past eight years, with Beijing reluctant to deal with the outgoing administration of President Chen Shui- bian -- who has been branded a separatist by China.

Describing the incoming government as "over enthusiastic with overly high expectations, " Liu said "it fell right into China's carrot-and- stick trap -- feeding with more economic and trade exchanges without giving up diplomatic suppression of Taiwan's participation in the international community."
In addition, the trip could also bring trouble to future diplomatic efforts, Liu said.

"When we ask our diplomatic allies to speak for us in international organizations or urge them not to make contact with China, they might question: your vice president-elect also shook hands with President Hu Jintao," Liu said.
It will be an important and difficult task for President-elect Ma Ying-jeou to find an equilibrium between the cross-strait policies and diplomatic policies, he added.
"The so-called ice-melting trip is, in reality, just the tip of an iceberg, underneath which lies much bigger troubles," Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to cover losses in helping Honduras build power plant

TEXT.P: State-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) President Edward K.M. Chen said Monday that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will be responsible for any losses in the firm's investment in a power plant in Honduras.
Chen made the remarks in response to questions from several opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers during a legislative interpellation session.

During the session, the legislators asked Chen why Taipower is still insisting on investing in a hydroelectric power plant in Honduras, one of Taiwan diplomatic allies in Central America, after MOFA classified the politics and social order in that country as unstable and after Taipower has incurred massive losses due to a government ban on lifting a freeze on electricity prices.

According to Taipower statistics, the firm is expected to have an income of NT$443.8 billion (US$14.64 billion) and spending of NT$488.6 billion this year, which will leave a pre-tax loss of NT$44.8 billion.
Taipower officials have attributed the losses mainly to continuing soaring fuel prices and increasing demand for electricity.
The lawmakers asked why Taipower is still evaluating a project that would help the Honduran government build a power plant, at projected losses of more than US$35 million.
The power plant project forms part of a package of foreign aid that President Chen Shui-bian promised to several Central American countries during a trip he made there last August.
"As this project is a response to government policy, the government has promised that MOFA will be responsible for any losses the project incurs, " K.M. Chen said.
He also claimed that the company might face a loss of up to NT$130 billion a year if the government decides not to increase electricity prices to cope with continually increasing oil prices.

"If Taipower hopes to balance its books, it should increase electricity prices by 50 percent, " the Taipower head said, adding that he favors an upward readjustment in several stages, with 30 percent increases in the first stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor wants her city to be gateway for Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said Monday that she will hold President-elect Ma Ying- jeou to his campaign promise to spur development in the southern Taiwan port city, in part by asking to channel Chinese tourists there.

Ma has pledged that an agreement would be reached to allow Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan beginning in July, and Chen said that from the standpoint of Kaohsiung, she hoped her city would be the point of entry and departure for the visitors to boost local tourism revenues.
"If that is not possible, we hope that they could at least enter Taiwan through Taipei and leave from Kaohsiung," she said.
The mayor also said that she hoped to institutionalize the distribution of tax revenues allocated by the central government.

The central government allocated NT$11.9 billion (US$391.44 million) to Kaohsiung last year in addition to a special subsidy of NT$10 billion, Chen said, but she worried that if funding guidelines were not institutionalized, her city would face a funding shortfall on an annual basis.
She urged the central government to enact a law on allocations to local governments as soon as possible to ensure the city's financial future.
Chen wasn't the only Democratic Progressive Party administrative head Monday who felt closer economic ties with China would help her constituents.

With frosty cross-Taiwan Strait relations perhaps thawing after a meeting between Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and Chinese President Hu Jintao at an economic forum in China over the weekend, Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen is reportedly eyeing a share of the vast Chinese market for farmers from her county.
The United Evening News said that Su will lead representatives from 24 farmers' groups to Macau this week on a four-day visit, during which she will promote the county's agricultural produce.

She is expected to sign a long-term marketing agreement with a supermarket chain there to supply it with premium vegetables, fruits and flowers as well as county's specialities such as its rice, soy sauce, coffee and black peanuts.
Hoping to use Macau as a springboard to tap the Chinese market. Su will visit Beijing in mid-July on another promotional mission.
Reports quoted Su as saying, "I will go anywhere that will be helpful to farmers."

Both Chen and Su are from the Democratic Progressive Party that lost power in the March 22 presidential election. Kaohsiung City and Yunlin County are among seven of Taiwan's 25 cities and counties that are run by the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect does not expect to visit China, Hong Kong soon

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou indicated Monday that he has no plans at present to visit China or Hong Kong, saying "it's too early" to talk about the matter.
Ma was speaking at a news conference held jointly with Vice President-elect Vincent Siew on Siew's just-concluded trip to Hainan province in southern China to attend the Boao Forum for Asia.
Siew met with Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines of the forum Saturday, a meeting that Ma described as "successful" and took place in a "natural, friendly and constructive atmosphere."
But the visit wasn't one that Ma was looking to copy in the near future.
The president-elect has been more interested in trying to visit the United States, Japan and other countries before taking office May 20, a desire he made public soon after being elected on March 22.

Ma explained that he wanted to deliver a message of friendship to the countries and brief them on his cross-Taiwan Strait and diplomatic policies but seemed resigned Monday that his hopes would not be fulfilled.
"It doesn't matter if I can't go, " Ma said, adding that the ball was now in the "court of others." He reiterated Taiwan's sincerity in improving international and cross-strait relations.

Facing local and foreign reporters' questions over when Taiwan and China will resume long-stalled direct talks, Ma said efforts to promote the resumption of contacts between Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- will begin soon after May 20.

He said a number of problems, including personnel changes and talks on technical issues, needed to be addressed before the long-anticipated resumption of direct talks between the two bodies, which were founded in the early 1990s to handle cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges in the absence of official links.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exchange of Chinese yuan to be allowed in Taiwan from July

TEXT.P: A task force of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has worked out measures to allow some convertibility between the Chinese yuan and the Taiwan dollar in Taiwan proper beginning in July, a KMT lawmaker said Monday.

Legislator Lu Shiow-yen, co-convener of the Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee, told reporters after a committee meeting that the legislature only needs to make minor amendments to an existing law to allow individuals to exchange yuan and Taiwan dollars at any designated bank.
Lu is a member of the KMT task force in charge of preparations for policy implementation after president-elect Ma Ying-jeou assumes his office as chief of state on May 20.
Other members of the task force include KMT Vice Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Legislator Wu Den-yih, who is also secretary-general of the KMT.
Lu said the new measures will still cap the amount that can be exchanged, with the details to be worked out by the incoming KMT government.

The yuan and Taiwan dollar have been convertible on the Taiwan-controlled islands of Kinmen and Matsu since October 2005. Individuals from either China or Taiwan with valid travel documents are allowed to exchange up to 20,000 yuan at designated banks on the islands.

Individuals may also bring up to 20,000 yuan into Taiwan but cannot exchange it on Taiwan proper, according to existing clauses in the Statute Governing the Relations Between the Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area,

Lu said the law and regulations will be amended in time to allow the exchange of a limited amount of the yuan everywhere in Taiwan to coincide with the implementation of new measures allowing 3,000 Chinese tourists into Taiwan each day and direct charter flights between Taiwan and the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese expatriates to solicit support for country's WHO bid
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/08 21:28:08 (By Jennifer Huang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Several Taiwanese expatriate groups will hold a series of activities in London April 20 to solicit support for Taiwan's bid to enter the World Health Organization (WHO).

Lord Faulkner, co-chairman of the British-Taiwan Parliamentary Group, a sub- group in Britain's Parliament, will be among those attending the activities, which will be held at Speaker's Corner in London's Hyde Park.
Faulkner and his parliamentary group have consistently supported Taiwan's bid to enter international organizations, including the United Nations and WHO.
Lee Hung-yao, secretary-general of the European Federation of Taiwan Health Alliance, said Taiwan's membership in the world health body was long overdue.

"The fact that the WHO has excluded Taiwan from the organization for a long time has violated the WHO's commitment to safeguarding health rights of the world's people regardless of sex or race, " Lee told the Central News Agency.

Taiwan has attempted to become an observer in the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the decision-making body of the WHO -- under its official title Republic of China every year since 1997 but has been rejected due to the opposition of China, which sees Taiwan as a part of its territory.
Last year, Taiwan decided to apply for full membership for the first time under the name Taiwan, which China also successfully rebuffed.
This year, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will ask the country's diplomatic allies to file both membership and observer status applications at this year's annual WHA meeting, which opens May 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA warns of hazardous bedding accessories

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) warned consumers Monday that they may be vulnerable in their own beds, after a survey by Taiwan's standards bureau found excessive amounts of chemicals in local bedding accessories that could harm people's health.

The MOEA's Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection tested 11 randomly selected accessories, including sheets and pillow cases, and found that three contained excessive amounts of formaldehyde and five had high levels of fluorescent substances.

Formaldehyde is a toxic and flammable substance that is listed by the World Health Organization (WHO) as a carcinogen and by Taiwan's Environmental Protection Administration as a kind of toxic chemical.
Products containing formaldehyde can cause skin allergies, respiratory problems or even life threatening pulmonary edema and cancer, the bureau warned in a statement released Monday.
Fluorescents also pose a threat of skin allergies.
In addition, 10 of the 11 samples were found to be lacking basic product information, including the material used and the name of the manufacturer, in violation of the Commodity Labeling Law.
The bureau will order the manufacturers and retailers of the substandard products to recall and destroy their goods and will conduct more tests on similar products, the statement said.
To further prevent potential harm, the bureau advised local consumers to examine product information before purchasing bedding accessories and check for any unpleasant smell before use.
The bureau suggested that washing the fabrics with warm water could eliminate the formaldehyde and fluorescent substances adhering to their surfaces.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teacher convicted of sexual assault must be dismissed: group

TEXT.P: The Modern Women's Foundation (MWF) on Monday urged a university in Central Taiwan to dismiss one of its faculties who was convicted of sexually assaulting one of his students, stressing that this kind of teacher should be "kicked out of campus."
The women's group made the appeal as the controversial scandal which happened in National Chi Nan University (NCNU) in the central county of Nantou, surfaced.
Lee Wen-chih, an associate professor at the Department of Public Policy and Administration, was accused by one of his female students of sexual assault in July 2006.
Lee was convicted of sexual assault by a court in March and sentenced to one year and two months in prison.

However, according to Amy Chang, chief executive of the women's foundation, the university did not dismiss Lee, only suspending him from his job for six months after the incident became public. In early 2007, he resumed teaching at the university, Chang said.
"Because Lee was only suspended from duties instead of being dismissed, he could return to campus to continue teaching," said Chang.

"It is really incredible that the NCNU only suspended Lee's duties, which can only deepen the mental trauma of the victim," Chang said, urging the university to dismiss Lee in the university administration's upcoming meeting to be held next week.

In response to the criticism, Chiang Ta-shu, secretary-general of the NCNU, said the university allowed Lee to resume teaching because at that time he had not been sentenced yet, stressing that the NCNU has already suspended Lee following the announcement of the sentence in March.
Chiang further said that in the university administration's meeting next week, the school will reexamine the case and decide whether to dismiss Lee.

Commenting on the scandal as one of possibly many cases of sexual assault on campus, Pan Wei-kang, the foundation's president and an incumbent legislator, said that "I hope that through this case, everyone in society can face such a task seriously."
Pan stressed that "to force the teachers like Lee to leave the campus is fundamental to preventing such cases from happening again and again."
"The legislature should also regulate laws to supervise the teachers," Pan said.

Noting that the victim of the scandal even attempted suicide and was hospitalized for several times, Lai Fang-yu, an attorney for the victim, urged the university to dismiss the teacher Lee immediately, to prevent him from returning to campus and to help the student.

Agreeing with the attorney Lai, Sandy Lai, president of the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, said "if the university doesn't tackle this problem well, teachers like Lee will become common on campuses."
"We hope that justice still exists. ... We also hope that the victim in this case will be the last one who has to hide herself and cry alone without help," added Lai.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vegetable Center in Taiwan an asset of the world: President

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that a world vegetable center headquartered in southern Taiwan is a precious asset for both the country and the international community, as it helps innumerable farmers in the world with important farming technologies.
Chen made the remarks at a ceremony marking the change of the center's name from the Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center (AVRDC) to the AVRDC-the World Vegetable Center.
Addressing the re-designation recemony, Chen said the new name is better suited to the center's current global role.

The non-profit center was co-founded in 1971 by the Asian Development Bank, as well as Taiwan, Japan, Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam, with the aim of working towards reducing malnutrition and alleviating poverty in East Asia's developing countries through improved yields and development of strains adaptable to tropical climates.
Located in Tainan County's Shanhua township, the center has emerged as the world's leading organization in vegetable research and development.
The center has eight regional offices in Asia and Africa and is the only international organization headquartered in Taiwan.

Over the past three decades of its operation, Chen said the center has helped developing countries in Asia, Africa, and Central America to improve their agricultural, Chen pointed out in a speech at the center.

Chen said the center has proposed many initiatives to help alleviate poverty through improved agricultural yields for poor countries. He added that Taiwan, as a founder, increased its donation amounts in 2006 to support these initiatives, including one involving setting up a global research network on tropical fruits and vegetables.
Scientists from around the world will be able to work together to attain food security, poverty alleviation, and sustainable agriculture, through the research network.

Chen said the center has made great contributions to Taiwan's agricultural development by improving techniques and increasing production value through a variety of bilateral cooperation projects with both the government and private sectors.

Taiwan's overseas agricultural aid teams also cooperated with the center in providing agricultural aid to developing countries, Chen said, adding that agricultural technology aid is an important link for Taiwan in carrying out its foreign aid policies.
He also expressed the hope that the center would draw more international scientists to join its ranks and generate more attention and awareness of agriculture's importance among developing countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: No sabotage found in derailed train incident: prosecutors

TEXT.P: No signs of sabotage were discovered at the site where a small tourist train derailed Sunday in one of Taiwan's most famous national scenic areas, local prosecutors said Monday.
The investigation was launched soon after the Chiayi Forest District Office, which manages the mountainous railway network on Alishan, reported a derailment for the third time in just two weeks.
The office decided to suspend operations of the railway's main line beginning Monday for a comprehensive inspection and investigation, said office head Yeh Hsien-liang.

Service will not be restored until all safety concerns are resolved, Yeh said, with the only exception an early morning train on a spur line that will continue to take travelers to see Alishan's famous sunrise.

Never in the history of the nearly 100-year-old railway, which was inaugurated in 1912 by the Japanese to transport logs down the mountain, have so many derailments occurred so closely together, leading some to suspect human sabotage may have been involved.
Yeh described the first derailment that occurred on March 30 as an accident and attributed the cause to mud and rocks that happened to fall on the track.
The second derailment on April 1 at the same site as the first one was also an accident because it took place on a rainy day and the track was slippery, Yeh said.

He was at a loss, however, to explain the latest derailment, which occurred at a different point on the line. He said his office inspected the locomotive and the five carriages prior to the accident and found no problems.

In addition, the railroad ties in the section where the derailment occurred -- about 30 minutes after the train departed from the station -- had been replaced several months ago, Yeh said, and no other problems were detected.
Yeh said none of the 125 passengers on board panicked or were hurt because the train was operating at a slower-than-usual speed.
The third accident was different from the previous two in that it was the locomotive, not the carriages, that derailed.

Liu Tong-ti, the 57-year-old driver of the train, said that just as the front carriages of the train were entering a tunnel, he heard unusual sounds coming from the back of the train where the locomotive was located and put on the brakes.

After stepping out of the train to check out what was causing the noises, he found the locomotive had derailed, Liu said, who noted that the weather and the track's condition at the time were both fine.
Lin Shan-ben, an office official, said the only unusual signs found by the agency's inspection were two three-meter-long markings on the rails that may indicate the train ran over something.

The investigation also came amid speculation that the derailment was caused by sabotage to protest a build-operate-transfer (BOT) project passed in 2006 to privatize the management of the railway network for the next 30 years.

One rumor suggested that Chiayi-based Hungtu Construction Co., which won the BOT bid, did not want to take over the network, which generates NT$100 million (US$3.3 million) in revenues annually but has cost NT$300 million a year to operate.

According to another rumor, low-level train employees were said to be outraged that the office enriched the construction company by purchasing hundreds of millions of Taiwan dollars worth of equipment for the railway before Hungtu took over its operations.

Yeh dismissed the speculation and insisted the derailments will would not halt the privatization project because the company has agreed in the contract that it would unconditionally take over the train network in June.
The Alishan mountain resort area, known for cherry blossoms and trees that are thousands of years old, has attracted nearly 900,000 local and foreign visitors annually in recent years.
The area's cherry blossom season, which began on March 15, has attracted over 100,000 visitors, many of whom come from China.

A Chinese tourist surnamed Zheng said Monday that she felt very disappointed by the suspension of the rail line because she traveled all the way to Taiwan from China via Thailand in order to take a ride on the forest train, which can take tourists as high as 2,316 meters above sea level.
The office now provides shuttle buses to transport tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: No substantial gains from Boao Forum: DPP legislative caucus

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Vincent Siew has not obtained any substantial gains from the 2008 Boao Forum on Asia, but his attendance at the forum has in fact upset Taiwan's status, legislative caucus members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday.
DPP legislative caucus whip Yeh Yi-jin and other DPP lawmakers made the remarks at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan

Siew of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) returned to Taiwan Sunday with his 13-member delegation after the Boao Forum for Asia Annual Conference 2008 was held from April 11-13 in the southern Chinese province of Hainan. He will be sworn into office May 20 along with President-elect Ma Ying-jeou.

His attendance at this year's forum made him the first vice president-elect from Taiwan ever to set foot on Chinese soil -- a milestone in cross-Taiwan Strait relations since the two sides split in 1949 after a civil war in China.

Although Siew attended the 2008 Boao Forum in his private capacity as chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation, as he has done over the past five years, the event sparked grave concern in the pro-independence DPP out of fears that his presence would undermine Taiwan's international status or benefits due to the KMT's pro-China stance.
The Boao Forum for Asia is a non-government, non-profit organization dedicated to trade and economic integration in the region.
DPP legislative caucus whip Yeh Yi-jin accused Siew of making Taiwan into a Chinese province by entering China on a special travel document designed by Beijing for use by Taiwanese citizens.

Furthermore, she went on, the protocol accorded by Beijing to Siew at Haikou Airport, as well as the seating arrangements made for him -- in the same row as the executive chiefs from Hong Kong and Macau -- at the forum's annual conference Sunday were apparently all attempts by Beijing to downgrade Taiwan's status to that of a Chinese province and make it an inseparable part of Beijing's so-called "one China."

Although Chinese President Hu Jintao responded positively to four requests raised by Siew during a Saturday meeting on the sidelines of the conference, Yeh said the four issues -- a resumption of cross-strait dialogue, normalization of bilateral trade and economic ties, the launch of weekend cross-strait charter flights and allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan -- were already initiated in a meeting between Hu and KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan in 2005 in Beijing.
"The Siew-Hu meeting has actually not brought about any concrete progress in Taiwan-China ties," Yeh said.

According to DPP lawmaker Kuan Pi-ling, Taiwan was classified as a "special administrative region" -- like Hong Kong and Macau -- under China's jurisdiction in all documents relating to the Boao Forum.
This will not only mislead the international community to believe that Taiwan is part of China in line with Beijing's "one China" principle, but will also deeply hurt Taiwan's interests, she warned.

In response to the attacks from their DPP counterparts, KMT legislators said that their party, which will take the reins of power after Ma and Siew take office, is capable of implementing the agreements reached in the Siew-Hu meeting.

Legislator Lee Chi-chu, speaking on behalf of the KMT's legislative caucus, said at a news conference that the meeting helped lay a key foundation in cross- strait ties -- that two-way relations should be handled through negotiations in an institutionalized and transparent way by the semiofficial Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Beijing-based counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Lee urged the DPP lawmakers to adopt a positive attitude toward the Siew-Hu meeting and help push through law amendment proposals regarding issues of major public concern, such as a quick opening of direct transport links across the strait and free exchanges of China's currency in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Forum on religious heritage conservation to be held

TEXT.P: A forum on religious heritage conservation opened Monday, marking the International Day for Monuments and Sites, to bring attention to Taiwan's religious heritage and generate ideas for policies on heritage conservation, a cultural official said Monday.

The two-day forum, organized by the Council for Cultural Affairs, is being held in Tainan City in southern Taiwan, with experts and scholars invited to exchange views and share their professional knowledge on tangible and intangible assets of Taiwan's religious cultures with forum participants.

According to the official involved in cultural properties management, the day was created in 1982 by the International Council on Monument and Sites (ICOMOS) under the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), and was later approved at the 22nd UNESCO General Conference in 1983.
The ICOMOS selects a topic to be highlighted every year, and this year's topic is Religious Heritage and Sacred Places.

The first day of the forum will focus on March's celebration of Matsu, Taiwan's "Goddess of the Sea" and most important folk deity, with discussions ranging from the cultural aspects of folk religion to issues related to religious culture conservation.

The second day's discussions will center on different dimensions of Taiwan's religious cultures, and forum participants will go on field trips to certain religious heritage sites to grow better understanding of local religious monuments, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor skirts question on travel to China

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said Monday she would welcome Chinese tourists to visit her port city in southern Taiwan but would not say if she would travel to China to solicit investment using a special travel document issued by Beijing for Taiwanese people.
Fielding questions from Kuomintang (KMT) councilors at a Kaohsiung City Council session, Chen said the Kaohsiung City government was ready to make full preparations for the entry of Chinese tourists.

Chen is a member of the ruling pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, which has long opposed a full range of exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and restricted Taiwan businesses from investing in China.

DPP politicians criticized Vice President-elect Vincent Siew for traveling to China for this past weekend's Boao Forum for Asia on a "Taiwanese Compatriot Entry Permit, " which they said belittled Taiwan.
But the mayor failed to elaborate on whether she would travel to China to woo Chinese investment to Kaohsiung using the special travel document.
"As long as the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) gives its go-ahead for Chinese to invest in Taiwan, Kaohsiung also will welcome Chinese capital," Chen said in sidestepping the question.
"I would study the possibility of (visiting China) on a case-by-case basis for the sake of Kaohsiung's development, " she added.

The KMT councilors also asked Chen to push municipal authorities to get ready for potential investment projects from major Taiwanese companies such as the Hon Hai Group and Quanta Computer, which are reportedly preparing to invest in Kaohsiung City.
KMT President-elect Ma Ying-jeou has promised to allow the entry of Chinese tourists to Taiwan and the opening of weekend direct cross-strait charters beginning in early July.
Siew obtained a positive response from Chinese President Hu Jintao on the two issues at the three-day Boao Forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business center under planning in Kaohsiung will be green building

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Computer Association will spend NT$3 billion (about US$100 million) to construct an international business center with green technologies, Chuang Lien-hao, chairman of the association, said Monday.

Chuang, who is also chief executive of the Kaohsiung-based Winner Group, said the business center is expected to create NT$60 billion worth of new business opportunities each year, and that some 300 companies involved in the computer and information industries have already applied to set up shop in the center.

The center's building, to be located in the Kaohsiung Software Park, will be shaped like a flying saucer, with the construction materials and architectural design aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions and minimizing any environmental impact, Chuang said.

Citing a few examples, Chuang said that to conserve energy, the roof of the building will be equipped with a high-efficiency solar energy collection system, while the design will allow sufficient sunlight to penetrate the structure so that electric lighting during the daytime will not be needed.

Other features of the smart building include an automatic rainwater collection system for watering plants, good ventilation for all rooms on all floors, and a digital environment for the new generation of wireless Internet users.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF Chairman-designate to travel to China for talks

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said Monday that he would soon travel to China for talks on major cross-strait issues.
Chiang made the remarks after president-elect Ma Ying-jeou earlier announced that he would be appointed as chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Chiang said that before he formerly assumes the post after the incoming KMT government takes office May 20, he would travel to China in his capacity as SEF chairman-designate to discuss direct cross-strait transportation links, Chinese yuan and Taiwan dollar convertibility, and the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists.

The 76-year-old former economic affairs minister and vice Legislative Yuan speaker said his family was not very supportive of his heading the SEF, a semi- official body set up by Taiwan's government to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal relations.

But Chiang said he gladly accepted the offer to serve as the top negotiator with China, especially after KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan expressed his support the previous night for Chiang to serve in the post.
KMT Legislator Lee Chia-chin disclosed earlier the same day that Chiang hopes to reach an agreement or "tacit understanding" with China on major cross-strait issues during the upcoming visit.
"But the signing of a formal agreement will have to wait until after May 20," Lee said.

Chiang's upcoming visit is expected to revive long-stalled cross-strait talks after nearly a decade of inactivities. A window of opportunity for improved cross-strait ties emerged after a goodwill meeting between Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and Chinese President Hu Jintao at an economic forum in China over the weekend.

Reports have said that Chen Yunlin, director of Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, will be designated as the chairman of the Beijing-based Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), the SEF's Chinese counterpart.

A meeting between former SEF Chairman Ku Cheng-fu and former ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan in Singapore in 1993 brought a series of systematic exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait following nearly five decades without official contacts.
But the communications were disrupted after former President Lee Teng-hui described the cross-strait relationship as a "special state-to-state" one in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: Iceberg to become flood if it melts too fast: Vice president-elect

TEXT.P: "Time and wisdom" will be needed to melt long-frozen cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Vice President-elect Vincent Siew said Monday.

Although his just-concluded visit to southern China's Hainan province was a "journey of melting the ice" in the frosty relationship between Taiwan and China, Siew said he hopes the iceberg will not melt too fast.

"It will become a flood if it melts too fast, " Siew said, noting that time and wisdom are needed to develop contacts between Taipei and Beijing and, therefore, there was no timetable for the resumption of direct cross-strait talks.

The vice president-elect made the remarks in answering questions from Hong Kong reporters at a news conference held jointly with President-elect Ma Ying-jeou a day after Siew returned from a historic visit in Hainan province.
Siew was there to attend the 2008 Boao Forum for Asia and met with Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines of the event.
Siew said he discovered during the meeting that Hu held a pragmatic and friendly attitude on cross-strait relations.

Speaking of the Boao Forum, Siew described the annual event as a platform for international and cross-strait exchanges and lauded the inclusion of a roundtable forum on the agenda to discus issues related to Taiwan's economy.
Siew saw the discussion as a channel for the two sides to conduct dialogue and reduce misunderstandings.
The Monday press conference was divided into two sessions, with the first attended by reporters from 14 Hong Kong media outlets to interview Taiwan's new leaders.
The second part of the conference was opened for local and foreign reporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Books on homeland study curriculum published

TEXT.P: The National Cultural Association launched two books Monday on special features of southern Taiwan as part of an ongoing program to document Taiwan's local cultures and history and develop materials for a homeland study curriculum.

Tchen Yu-chiou, secretary general of the association, said the two books -- one about Kaohsiung County and one on Pingtung County -- took scholars, elementary and junior high school teachers, and people who work in the field, three years to research and write.
"The book is aimed at representing Taiwan's cultures with insights from local perspectives," Tchen said.

The publishing of the two books is part of a program called Window on Taiwan that started in 2004. The program hopes to construct a library that introduces history, culture, geography, special events, and the heritages of Taiwan's 319 townships, in both digital and written forms.
The program was organized by the association at the instruction of the Ministry of Educaiton and with the assistance of local governments, Tchen said.
Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng said the program helps strengthen students' understanding of Taiwan and its regional characteristics, which will help them identify with the land they live on.
"Identity formulation" is an important part of school education, Tu said, adding that this formulation would allow the next generation to know where they are standing when they face the world.

Tchen said books about Taipei County and Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan and Yunlin County in southern Taiwan have already been published, and books about Chiayi County and Kaohsiung City in northern Taiwan, Hualien County in eastern Taiwan and offshore Kinmen County will be published in June.
Books about Taichung City, Taichung County, Changhua County, and Nantou County in central Taiwan, and Taitung County in eastern Taiwan are scheduled to be published next year.
Tchen said all the books will be sent to elementary and junior high schools around the nation to be used as references by teachers.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect to remember 1989 protests in different ways

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that he will still attend events in memory of a massacre in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in 1989 after he takes office, but in different ways.

Ma said he has attended similar events every year since 1989 when Chinese troops killed hundreds of people, most of them students who had occupied Tiananmen Square in a demonstration for freedom and democracy in China.
Ma did not elaborate on what he would do, however, saying only that he "will tell everybody when the time approaches."

The president-elect was speaking at a news conference for reporters from Hong Kong one day after Vice President-elect Vincent Siew returned from a three-day trip to southern China, during which he met Chinese President Hu Jintao for 20 minutes on the sidelines of a China-hosted economic forum.
The meeting was generally seen as a positive first step in developing improved relations between Taiwan and China.
Asked if both sides would again choose Hong Kong as a venue for cross-strait talks, Ma replied that there will be no restriction on where to hold the talks as long as it was acceptable to both sides.

In the past, some of the talks were held in Taiwan and some in China, Ma said, adding that Hong Kong's status is now different than it was in 1992 when high- level representatives from Taiwan and China reached what Ma's KMT, describes as the "1992 consensus" at a historic meeting there.

According to the KMT, the "1992 consensus, " a term coined by former Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi of the KMT in 2000, was a formula to help the two sides to skirt the issue of Taiwan' s sovereignty in official talks.
Under the formula, that China has yet to accept, both sides agree that there is "one China, " but with different interpretations of how it is defined.
When the 1992 meeting took place, Hong Kong was still a British colony. The United Kingdom handed over Hong Kong to China in 1997.

In addition, Ma told the reporters that Hong Kong will not be affected if direct transport links are opened between Taiwan and China because he said that Hong Kong will remain as a transit point between Taiwan and Southeast Asian countries.
In addition, he said that Taiwanese tourists outperform other foreign visitors to Hong Kong in terms of personal consumption.
Ma, who was born in Hong Kong, said he hopes that private and official exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong will be intensified in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC to adopt two-stage approach on convertibility of Chinese yuan

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) said Monday that it plans to adopt a two-stage approach in introducing full convertibility between the Chinese yuan and the New Taiwan dollar in Taiwan proper.

CBC officials said the exchange of Chinese yuan, which has been allowed since October 2005 in the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, will require a revision of the law, referring to an amendment of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.
After both sides sign an agreement on a currency clearance and settlement mechanism, the yuan and Taiwan dollar will become convertible in Taiwan proper, the officials said.
But before the signing of such an agreement, the central bank will follow a two- stage approach, they said.

Because of the uncertainty of the supply of Chinese yuan at local banks, the central bank in the initial stage will only allow financial institutions to buy Chinese yuan in exchange for Taiwan dollars, they added.

In the second stage, if the central bank is confident of a stable supply of yuan, which could be provided by inbound tourists from China, it will permit financial institutions to both buy and sell the Chinese currency.
In anticipation that the yuan will soon be traded in local banks, the central bank has sponsored seven seminars on how to identify counterfeit yuan.
Starting this month, it will open more classes to familiarize banking clerks with techniques to detect forged yuan.
Central bank Governor Perng Fai-nan is expected to report on the exchange of yuan and the Taiwan dollar in front of a legislative committee Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Tuesday.
The weighted price index was up 38.40 points at 8,931.08 on a turnover of NT$4.96 billion (US$163.56 million) at the open. The index lost 16.9 points, or 0.18 percent, to close at 8,892.68 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 15, or the 10th day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1865: Andrew Johnson is sworn in as the 17th president of the United States following the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
1912: The British luxury liner the Titanic sinks after hitting an iceberg during its maiden voyage to New York. More than 1,500 people are feared drowned in the icy waters of the North Atlantic.
1923: Insulin is made available for general use by diabetics when Canadian physiologist Sir Frederick Grant Banting shares a 1923 Nobel Prize for the discovery of insulin.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces, organizes the Republic of China government in Nanjing.
1942: Japanese artillery blasts U.S. positions on Corregidor in the Philippines.
1945: Art treasures looted by the Nazis, including paintings by Rubens, Goya, Raphael, and Leonardo da Vinci, are found in an Austrian mine shaft.
1949: The Chinese communists demand ROC government acceptance of their eight- point proposal by April 20, following talks which began in Beijing on April 5.
1952: U.S. President Harry S. Truman signs a peace treaty between the United States and Japan.
1958: The first meeting of independent African nations is held in Accra, Ghana.
1959: U.S. Secretary of State John Dulles resigns due to illness. The American diplomat and politician pursued a policy of opposition to the USSR largely through military and economic aid to American allies.
1966: A team of American virologists develops a vaccine for German measles, known medically as rubella.
1971: President Joseph Desire Mobutu of Congo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1971: London and Beijing agree to the reopening of a telephone link between London and Shanghai which had been closed for 22 years.
1975: Praising the late ROC President Chiang Kai-shek as "an old friend and a great leader," Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller of the United States arrives in Taipei to attend the National Memorial Services for the generalissimo.
1975: ROC Premier Chiang Ching-kuo reveals President Chiang's last written instruction to him. The late leader told his eldest son to assume full responsibility for the fate of the nation without regard to his personal fate.
1976: India and Communist China resume diplomatic relations.
1976: Dr. Alfredo Lamaison, a member of the State Council of Uruguay, and Arg Gustave Nicolich, president of National University, arrive in Taipei for a nine- day visit.
1980: Jean-Paul Sartre, the French writer and philosopher who declined the 1957 Nobel Prize for literature, dies in Paris at the age of 74. A leading existentialist, he wrote literary works such as the autobiographical novel "Nausea" and the play "No Exit," as well as philosophical volumes that include "Being and Nothingness."
1988: President Kim Il Sung receives 43,000 gifts as he celebrates his 76th birthday in style. The North Korean dictator died in 1994.
1989: Hu Yaobang, former general secretary of China's Communist Party, dies of a heart attack in Beijing at the age of 73. A democracy movement is launched by Beijing University students following his death.
1989: Ninety-five soccer fans are crushed to death and 200 injured at Sheffield's Hillsborough Stadium in Britain's worst-ever sports disaster.
1994: The Uruguay Round of talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) concludes with ministers from more than 100 of the world's trading nations signing the GATT pact, the biggest market-opening treaty in history, and also with the announcement of the setting up of the World Trade Organization (WTO).
1996: The United States and Japan announce the closure of six more U.S. military facilities on Okinawa.
1997: The first locally-developed Ching Kuo tactical combat aircraft wing, a second generation ROC Air Force warplane, is founded at the Chingchuankang air force base in Taichung.
1998: Pol Pot, former Khmer Rouge leader, dies of a heart attack.
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei, who has been designated as the next premier by President-elect Chen Shui-bian, checks into Veterans General Hospital to undergo a thymoma operation.
2001: At least four persons are killed and more than 40 injure in an accident involving two buses near Encore Garden in Taichung, central Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man looks upwards in his aspirations; a fool looks downwards."
