DOC.HEADLINE: World Vegetable Center in Taiwan an asset of the world: President

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that a world vegetable center headquartered in southern Taiwan is a precious asset for both the country and the international community, as it helps innumerable farmers in the world with important farming technologies.
Chen made the remarks at a ceremony marking the change of the center's name from the Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center (AVRDC) to the AVRDC-the World Vegetable Center.
Addressing the re-designation recemony, Chen said the new name is better suited to the center's current global role.

The non-profit center was co-founded in 1971 by the Asian Development Bank, as well as Taiwan, Japan, Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam, with the aim of working towards reducing malnutrition and alleviating poverty in East Asia's developing countries through improved yields and development of strains adaptable to tropical climates.
Located in Tainan County's Shanhua township, the center has emerged as the world's leading organization in vegetable research and development.
The center has eight regional offices in Asia and Africa and is the only international organization headquartered in Taiwan.

Over the past three decades of its operation, Chen said the center has helped developing countries in Asia, Africa, and Central America to improve their agricultural, Chen pointed out in a speech at the center.

Chen said the center has proposed many initiatives to help alleviate poverty through improved agricultural yields for poor countries. He added that Taiwan, as a founder, increased its donation amounts in 2006 to support these initiatives, including one involving setting up a global research network on tropical fruits and vegetables.
Scientists from around the world will be able to work together to attain food security, poverty alleviation, and sustainable agriculture, through the research network.

Chen said the center has made great contributions to Taiwan's agricultural development by improving techniques and increasing production value through a variety of bilateral cooperation projects with both the government and private sectors.

Taiwan's overseas agricultural aid teams also cooperated with the center in providing agricultural aid to developing countries, Chen said, adding that agricultural technology aid is an important link for Taiwan in carrying out its foreign aid policies.
He also expressed the hope that the center would draw more international scientists to join its ranks and generate more attention and awareness of agriculture's importance among developing countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: No sabotage found in derailed train incident: prosecutors

TEXT.P: No signs of sabotage were discovered at the site where a small tourist train derailed Sunday in one of Taiwan's most famous national scenic areas, local prosecutors said Monday.
The investigation was launched soon after the Chiayi Forest District Office, which manages the mountainous railway network on Alishan, reported a derailment for the third time in just two weeks.
The office decided to suspend operations of the railway's main line beginning Monday for a comprehensive inspection and investigation, said office head Yeh Hsien-liang.

Service will not be restored until all safety concerns are resolved, Yeh said, with the only exception an early morning train on a spur line that will continue to take travelers to see Alishan's famous sunrise.

Never in the history of the nearly 100-year-old railway, which was inaugurated in 1912 by the Japanese to transport logs down the mountain, have so many derailments occurred so closely together, leading some to suspect human sabotage may have been involved.
Yeh described the first derailment that occurred on March 30 as an accident and attributed the cause to mud and rocks that happened to fall on the track.
The second derailment on April 1 at the same site as the first one was also an accident because it took place on a rainy day and the track was slippery, Yeh said.

He was at a loss, however, to explain the latest derailment, which occurred at a different point on the line. He said his office inspected the locomotive and the five carriages prior to the accident and found no problems.

In addition, the railroad ties in the section where the derailment occurred -- about 30 minutes after the train departed from the station -- had been replaced several months ago, Yeh said, and no other problems were detected.
Yeh said none of the 125 passengers on board panicked or were hurt because the train was operating at a slower-than-usual speed.
The third accident was different from the previous two in that it was the locomotive, not the carriages, that derailed.

Liu Tong-ti, the 57-year-old driver of the train, said that just as the front carriages of the train were entering a tunnel, he heard unusual sounds coming from the back of the train where the locomotive was located and put on the brakes.

After stepping out of the train to check out what was causing the noises, he found the locomotive had derailed, Liu said, who noted that the weather and the track's condition at the time were both fine.
Lin Shan-ben, an office official, said the only unusual signs found by the agency's inspection were two three-meter-long markings on the rails that may indicate the train ran over something.

The investigation also came amid speculation that the derailment was caused by sabotage to protest a build-operate-transfer (BOT) project passed in 2006 to privatize the management of the railway network for the next 30 years.

One rumor suggested that Chiayi-based Hungtu Construction Co., which won the BOT bid, did not want to take over the network, which generates NT$100 million (US$3.3 million) in revenues annually but has cost NT$300 million a year to operate.

According to another rumor, low-level train employees were said to be outraged that the office enriched the construction company by purchasing hundreds of millions of Taiwan dollars worth of equipment for the railway before Hungtu took over its operations.

Yeh dismissed the speculation and insisted the derailments will would not halt the privatization project because the company has agreed in the contract that it would unconditionally take over the train network in June.
The Alishan mountain resort area, known for cherry blossoms and trees that are thousands of years old, has attracted nearly 900,000 local and foreign visitors annually in recent years.
The area's cherry blossom season, which began on March 15, has attracted over 100,000 visitors, many of whom come from China.

A Chinese tourist surnamed Zheng said Monday that she felt very disappointed by the suspension of the rail line because she traveled all the way to Taiwan from China via Thailand in order to take a ride on the forest train, which can take tourists as high as 2,316 meters above sea level.
The office now provides shuttle buses to transport tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business center under planning in Kaohsiung will be green building

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Computer Association will spend NT$3 billion (about US$100 million) to construct an international business center with green technologies, Chuang Lien-hao, chairman of the association, said Monday.

Chuang, who is also chief executive of the Kaohsiung-based Winner Group, said the business center is expected to create NT$60 billion worth of new business opportunities each year, and that some 300 companies involved in the computer and information industries have already applied to set up shop in the center.

The center's building, to be located in the Kaohsiung Software Park, will be shaped like a flying saucer, with the construction materials and architectural design aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions and minimizing any environmental impact, Chuang said.

Citing a few examples, Chuang said that to conserve energy, the roof of the building will be equipped with a high-efficiency solar energy collection system, while the design will allow sufficient sunlight to penetrate the structure so that electric lighting during the daytime will not be needed.

Other features of the smart building include an automatic rainwater collection system for watering plants, good ventilation for all rooms on all floors, and a digital environment for the new generation of wireless Internet users.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF Chairman-designate to travel to China for talks

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said Monday that he would soon travel to China for talks on major cross-strait issues.
Chiang made the remarks after president-elect Ma Ying-jeou earlier announced that he would be appointed as chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Chiang said that before he formerly assumes the post after the incoming KMT government takes office May 20, he would travel to China in his capacity as SEF chairman-designate to discuss direct cross-strait transportation links, Chinese yuan and Taiwan dollar convertibility, and the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists.

The 76-year-old former economic affairs minister and vice Legislative Yuan speaker said his family was not very supportive of his heading the SEF, a semi- official body set up by Taiwan's government to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal relations.

But Chiang said he gladly accepted the offer to serve as the top negotiator with China, especially after KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan expressed his support the previous night for Chiang to serve in the post.
KMT Legislator Lee Chia-chin disclosed earlier the same day that Chiang hopes to reach an agreement or "tacit understanding" with China on major cross-strait issues during the upcoming visit.
"But the signing of a formal agreement will have to wait until after May 20," Lee said.

Chiang's upcoming visit is expected to revive long-stalled cross-strait talks after nearly a decade of inactivities. A window of opportunity for improved cross-strait ties emerged after a goodwill meeting between Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and Chinese President Hu Jintao at an economic forum in China over the weekend.

Reports have said that Chen Yunlin, director of Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, will be designated as the chairman of the Beijing-based Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), the SEF's Chinese counterpart.

A meeting between former SEF Chairman Ku Cheng-fu and former ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan in Singapore in 1993 brought a series of systematic exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait following nearly five decades without official contacts.
But the communications were disrupted after former President Lee Teng-hui described the cross-strait relationship as a "special state-to-state" one in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. welcomes Siew-Hu talks
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 14 (CNA) 04/15/08 11:37:59 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States welcomed the recent meeting between Taiwan's Vice President- elect Vincent Siew and Chinese President Hu Jintao, a U.S. State Department official said Monday.

"We have long called on both Taiwan and the PRC to find a constructive path for dialogue to address cross-strait issues, " said the official from the department's Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"It has been a consistent U.S. policy to support a peaceful resolution of cross- strait differences acceptable to people on both sides of the strait," he added.

Siew met Hu over the weekend on the sidelines of the annual Boao Forum for Asia held on the southern Chinese island of Hainan, marking the highest-level cross- Taiwan Strait political contact since 1949.

During the meeting, Siew called for normalization of cross-strait trade exchanges and resumption of cross-strait dialogue. He also requested that China allow its citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan as early as possible and open direct cross-strait charter flights on weekends as a prelude to the launch of direct air links.

DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Coal at heart of climate battle.
Every time a new coal-fired power plant is proposed anywhere in the United States, a lawyer from the Sierra Club or an allied environmental group is assigned to stop it, by any bureaucratic or legal means necessary. They might frame the battle as a matter of zoning or water use, but the larger war is over global warning:Coal puts twice as much temperature raising carbon dioxide into the atmosphere as natural gas, second to coal as the most common power plant fuel. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: World Bank takes aim at rising cost of food

DOC.HEADLINE: Education Ministry planning to integrate preschool and kindergarten

TEXT.P: The Education Ministry plans to combine preschools and kindergartens to create an integrated day care system for children aged 2-6 years old, the Deputy Minister of Education Wu Tsai-shung said Tuesday.

Briefing the Legislative Yuan's Education and Culture Committee on the plan, Wu said the ministry also plans to provide day care facilities for infants up to the age of two as well as after school day care services for elementary school children over the age of 6.
Wu noted that at present, standards vary greatly among kindergartens and preschools in terms of facilities, organization and staff.

He said that the ministry is planning the measure to offer the best education and day care services for all children from the time they are born until after they enter elementary school so as to meet the needs of parents.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA flight delayed after tires burst on takeoff and landing

TEXT.P: The tires of an EVA Airways-operated aircraft burst soon after taking off and during landing Tuesday, causing a flight delay of 35 minutes and the Kaohsiung International Airport to be closed for four hours.
No casualties were reported. Officials at the Civil Aeronautics Administration and the Aviation Safety Council said they are investigating the cause behind the accident.
The MD-90 aircraft carrying 36 passengers and six crew members was flying from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to Kaohsiung when the accident occurred, the airline said.

Detecting abnormalities in the tire pressure and cabin doors soon after the plane took off from Taoyuan International Airport at 8: 45 a.m., the pilot immediately notified controllers at Kaohsiung International Airport of the situation, the carrier said.

As the plane approached, airport controllers saw that one of the aircraft's tires had burst and instructed the pilot to keep the aircraft hovering to burn most of its remaining fuel and prevent a potential explosion during landing, the airline said.
Because of pressure imbalances, two other tires of the aircraft burst during landing at 9:55 a.m., causing the plane to veer off the runway.
The aircraft, owned by EVA Air subsidiary Uni Air, flew back safely to Taoyuan in the afternoon after having the damaged tires replaced.
Kaohsiung International Airport, forced to close temporarily because of the accident, was reopened at 2: 20 p.m., according to airport officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet lineup to be publicized as soon as possible: premier-designate

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan said Tuesday he will make public the lineup of the incoming Cabinet early if his discussions with potential Cabinet members proceed smoothly.
Liu, who previously said he would try to hammer out the Cabinet lineup by the end of this month, made the remarks while paying a visit to opposition Kuomintang Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung.

There has been speculation that Liu will meet with President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and his deputy Vincent Siew to finalize the lineup within this week, and Liu's visit with Wu was also believed to be related to the matter.
Liu denied, however, that the new Cabinet's personnel arrangements were raised during his meeting with Wu.

The premier-designate said the main purpose of his visit was to ask Wu for his advice on the current political situation, noting that he has been out of politics for quite some time and feels a bit disconnected.
Liu, who served as vice premier between 1997 and 2000, is currently president of Soochow University.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGBanks are told to cut rates and ease pressure on borrowers
Gordon Brown will hold talks today with mortgage lenders amid growing evidence that the downturn in the housing market could be worse than that of the early 1990s.
The Prime Minister is expected to urge banks to help to shore up the housing market by easing loan costs, passing on cuts in base rates by the Bank of England to borrowers and being less tough on buyers in distress.

A much-awaited ratings system for video games will kick in here from April 28, giving adults a wider choice of games, including ones that would have been banned in the past.
