Some 2.4 million Singaporeans will receive $3 billion in Government benefits this year, as part of the $1.8 billion of surplus sharing from the 2008 Budget and other measures such as Goods and Services Tax (GST) Credits announced last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to continue providing bins for furniture disposal: Mayor Hau

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Tuesday that the municipal government will continue providing furniture disposal bins around the city despite the actions of a minority of citizens who lack "civic spirit."

Speaking with reporters after a municipal government meeting, Taipei City Government spokesman Yang Hsiao-tung said that there are currently 3,400 bins for collecting old furniture at locations around the city.

Yang quoted Hau as having said during the meeting that the city government will continue with the policy even though some citizens have taken advantage of the situation by dumping their regular garbage in the bins.

"We shouldn't cause an inconvenience for the majority of the citizens by withdrawing the bins just because of a lack of civic spirit on the part of a small minority of the people, " Yang quoted Hau as having said.

According to Yang, Hau suggested that a better approach would be to educate this small group of individuals about the importance of civic spirit and to encourage them not to recklessly dump their garbage.
The mayor also suggested during the meeting that the municipal government's Department of Education launch a program at schools around the city to teach students the values of civic mindedness.

Yang said that the problem of people abusing the furniture disposal bins is serious and suggested that related municipal departments come up with measures to deal with the problem before it gets worse.

He also noted that damaged lids on public trash cans are another problem, with between 10 percent and 15 percent of them requiring repair. He said relevant agencies will set to work repairing the damaged public trash cans and keeping them clean.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central bank ready for yuan convertibility but wants laws changed

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bank said Tuesday that it is fully prepared for full convertibility between the Taiwan dollar and Chinese yuan but insisted that regulations needed to be revised before any currency exchange system could take effect.

"The central bank is fully prepared for the new measure, " Central Bank of the Republic of China Vice-Governor George Chou said at a legislative hearing, but he said his bank did not have any yuan to sell to local buyers.
"Chinese yuan will have to be obtained from Chinese tourists to Taiwan," he said.
Chou insisted, however, that a plan by Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers to launch exchange facilities for the two currencies without amending existing regulations was not feasible.

He said that as the yuan is not a fully-convertible currency, Taiwan and China needed to reach agreement on a currency clearance and settlement mechanism, which would inevitably require a revision of applicable statutes.
Some countries, including China, restrict fluctuations in their currency's exchange rates and require permits to exchange large sums, limiting the currency's convertibility.
President-elect Ma Ying-jeou recently committed to opening the free exchange of the Chinese yuan in Taiwan, and the central bank said Monday it would follow a two-step approach to achieve the goal.
Individuals have been allowed to exchange up to 20,000 yuan on the Taiwan- controlled islands of Kinmen and Matsu, which lie just off China's southeastern coast, since October 2005.
But with an agreement on the arrival of Chinese tourists in Taiwan expected to be reached after the new government takes office, yuan convertibility on Taiwan proper has become a pressing issue.
Chou urged the Mainland Affairs Council to continue negotiating a clearance and settlement mechanism with China to cement the plan.

Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman-designate Chiang Pin-kung is expected to visit China in the near future to lay the groundwork for agreements on a number of issues, including the arrival of Chinese tourists and yuan convertibility.
Chou said one benefit of a legalized exchange mechanism would be to clamp down on black market yuan-Taiwan dollar trading, which was estimated at NT$77.78 billion between 2002 and 2006.

Meanwhile, Chou also said the central bank is working on ways to promote easier ways to arrange direct transfers involving Taiwan dollars and the yuan, especially with so many Taiwanese businesses operating in China.
"Direct fund transfer reduces costs and time, and could also earn banks more business," Chou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ball pools in Taipei are filthy: Consumers' Foundation

TEXT.P: Ball pools affiliated with playgrounds in the Taipei area are mostly filthy, containing a high concentration of germs that pose a health risk to children, the Consumers' Foundation (CF) said Tuesday, urging the relevant authorities, playground operators and parents to pay attention to the problem.

The CF officials made the statement on completion of its inspection of eight ball pools, including those at IKEA, the Y-17, Kid's Park, Tom Dragon Castle, Hsin-Yi Foundation, and Taipei Wanhua Sports Center.

The findings indicate that high concentrations of colony forming unit (CFU) were commonly found on the surfaces of the balls tested, and two of the 24 samples recorded 10,000 to 100,000 CFUs, Cheng Jen-hung, chairman of the CF, claimed.
Chen said that colon bacilli and other germs were also found on the balls.
"The ball pools are polluted K and Staphylococcus aureus which causes nausea, vomiting, and food poisoning was also found," Chen said.

Meanwhile, the results of the investigation also showed that most of the operators failed to provide detailed information on how often they clean the ball pools and how they disinfect the balls and the facilities, said CF's deputy director Lee Cherh-yu.
"We sincerely hope that the operators will provide consumers with that information," Lee said. "The consumers need to put pressure on the operators to achieve better management of the pools."

Hsieh Tien-jen, vice chairman of the CF, stressed that "the operators must clean not only the balls but also the pools thoroughly," noting that some items such as pencils and hair grips that could be hazardous to children were also seen in the pools.

In order to safeguard customers' right to information as well as public health, the ball pool operators should improve thieir efforts at cleaning and disinfecting the pools, and should post clearly written rule for the users to follow, Chen urged.
"The authorities also need to regulate the operations" to make every ball pool a pleasant, clean, and safe place for children to play, Chen suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Int'l journalists' group opposes U.N. ban on Taiwanese reporters
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Belgium, April 14 (CNA) 04/15/08 17:35:47 (By P.C. Tang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The International Federation of Journalists (IFJ) condemned the United Nations Monday for barring Taiwanese journalists from covering the upcoming World Health Assembly (WHA), the World Health Organization's (WHO's) policy-making body.

The IFJ, which represents more than 600,000 journalists in 120 countries, said it issued a statement on April 11 urging the United Nations to lift the ban that has been imposed for the last four years.
It accused the United Nations of diminishing journalists' role in covering international public health activities.

In the statement, the IFJ said Taiwanese reporters should be granted the right to cover the WHA conference, slated to open in Geneva May 19, as was the case for hundreds of journalists from many other countries.

The statement noted that since 2004, the United Nations Department of Public Information has refused to issue press passes to Taiwanese journalists to cover WHA-related activities on the grounds that Taiwan is not a U.N. member.
The IFJ also expressed its support for a demand by its branch in Taiwan -- the Association of Taiwan Journalists -- that the U.N. lift the ban.
The federation argued that the U.N. should allow Taiwanese reporters access to the WHA meeting in accordance with Article 19 of the U.N. Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

It stipulates that everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression, and that this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive, and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers.

Noting that the controversy over China's national sovereignty and territory should not affect reporters' right to gather information, the IFJ requested that the U.N. and WHO protect the right of Taiwanese journalists to cover the conference.
IFJ Deputy Secretary-General Paco Audije said he could not understand the U.N.'s denial of the rights of Taiwanese journalists.
"Those reporters just want to fulfill their responsibility, and since they have nothing to do with politics, they should not be subject to such discrimination," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese top list of those bringing prohibited items into Macau, HK

TEXT.P: More Taiwanese nationals have been caught attempting to bring prohibited items into or out of Macau and Hong Kong than citizens of any other country in the region so far this year, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Tuesday.
Many of the Taiwanese nationals caught with prohibited items, including pepper spray, stun guns and tasers, were detained or charged according to local laws, the SEF said.
The SEF made the announcement to urge Taiwan citizens to familiarize themselves with the customs laws and regulations of the two Chinese special administrative regions before traveling there.

The foundation said that passengers entering or leaving Macau or Hong Kong can be arrested and detained if they are discovered to be carrying banned items on their person or in their carry-on luggage.
The SEF is a semi-official organization set up by Taiwan's government to handle technical and business matters with China in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kong tourism sector welcomes visa-free proposal
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/08 17:46:51 (By C. H. Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's tourism sector Tuesday
welcomed a proposal to grant Hong Kong visitors to Taiwan visa-free privileges and predicted that such a move would boost arrivals in Taiwan of tourists from the former British colony.

Taiwan's president-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who will take office May 20, said Monday at a news conference with Hong Kong reporters that his incoming administration will consider offering the special treatment to Hong Kong tourists as part of a package of measures aimed at stepping up bilateral ties between Taiwan and Hong Kong.

Wang Chun-bao, the director of the non-profit, tourism-promotion Taiwan Visitors Association Hong Kong Office, told the Central News Agency that the measure, if really implemented, will bolster Taiwan-Hong Kong exchanges and help lure Hong Kong tourists to Taiwan.
"The number of Hong Kong visitors to Taiwan will grow by 10 percent or more after the implementation of the measure, " Wang predicted.
A ranking Hong Kong Tourism Board official surnamed Liu agreed that the number of Hong Kong tourists to Taiwan would increase if Hong Kong residents were given visa-free privileges.
But he believed that passenger volume between the two sides would not be markedly affected in the short term.
Hong Kong also is a major transshipment hub for China-bound Taiwanese passengers.

A general manager at a Hong Kong travel agency said the visa-free status would save Hong Kong visitors to Taiwan the HK$100 visa fee. He also expected the move would lead to a 10 percent rise in the number of Hong Kong tourists visiting Taiwan.
According to statistics compiled by Taiwan's Tourism Bureau, there were 3.72 million foreign visitor arrivals in Taiwan in 2007.
Of that total, 13.2 percent, or 491,437 visitors, came from Hong Kong and Macau -- 13.79 percent more than arrived in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA paying close attention to Paraguay, Dominican Republic elections

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that it is closely watching the upcoming presidential elections in Paraguay and the Dominican Republic, two of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in South America and the Caribbean, especially as one of the candidates in Paraguay is known to be pro-China.

Paraguay and the Dominican Republic will hold their presidential elections on April 20 and May 16, respectively, at a sensitive time for Taiwan, just before the May 20 inauguration of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou.

Simon Ko, director-general of the MOFA's Central and South American Affairs said at a regular press briefing that, among the four candidates in Paraguay, the front-runners are former Catholic Bishop Fernando Lugo of the opposition Patriotic Alliance for Change (APC), retired army general Lino Oviedo of the opposition National Union of Ethical Citizens (UNACE), and Blanca Ovelar of the ruling National Republican Association -- Colorado Party.
"The latest polls showed that the election was too close to call, but the MOFA is paying close attention to it," Ko said.

Former education minister Ovelar is seeking to become the first female leader in Paraguay. The center-right Colorado Party has been in power in the South American country for more than six decades but the party is facing a big challenge in next Sunday's presidential election.
According to the latest poll in Paraguay, Lugo is leading the field with 34.5 percent of the potential vote, followed by Oviedo with 28.9 percent and Ovelar with 28.5 percent.

Ko said Lugo has stated during his campaign that he would like to establish relations with China if he is elected, giving rise to speculation on whether Taiwan will lose its only diplomatic ally in South American to China.
In comparison, the outcome of the presidential race in the Caribbean country of the Dominican Republic appears to be less uncertain.

Ko said incumbent President Leonel Fernandez, who is seeking a third consecutive term with his Dominican Liberation Party, is the front-runner. According to a Bloomberg report, Fernandez has widened his lead over his closest rival to 24 percentage points, with less than two months to go before the country's presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: New test to speed up detection of dengue fever in inbound travelers

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday it will begin using a fast-reacting blood serum test beginning next month to determine if inbound passengers have been infected with dengue fever more quickly than in the past.

Huang Chih-hsiung, a researcher at the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said the blood serum reagent kits will reveal if inbound passengers at ports or airports with high temperatures have been infected with dengue fever between five and 30 minutes after collecting drops of their blood.
Health officials will advise passengers who test positive to go to contracted hospitals for further examination, Huang said.

Three-fourths of more than 170 travelers who entered Taiwan with dengue fever last year were found to have had high temperatures at ports or airports and had their blood tested, but it took too long for the results to come back.
"Those people would only be notified of their infection two or three days after entering Taiwan, " Huang said. "They could have infected others during the period."

Wu Ho-sheng, director of the Centers for Disease Control Research and Diagnostic Center, said that because it is difficult to take blood samples from the elderly and children, the centers will also use saliva screening to test for the virus.

The drawback is that saliva testing is even less accurate than the blood serum tests, which are said to be 60 percent accurate. Of six dengue fever patients who tested positive through serum tests, only three were found positive in saliva screening, Wu said.
This is why the CDC is planning to expand saliva collection from the elderly, children or volunteers, in the second half of the year, hoping to collect 20 positive cases for further assessment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up 47 points to close at 8,918, with 50,619 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May rose 39 points to finish at 8,879, with 18,967 contracts traded, while June futures gained 34 points to close at 8,859, with 71 contract transactions.
September futures increased 30 points to finish at 8,620, with 31 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 20 points to close at 8,585, with 86 contracts traded.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 32.1 points Tuesday to finish at 8,924.78, with a market turnover of NT$168.34 billion (US$5.56 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 8,871 for April; 8,840 for May; 8,825 for June; 8,590 for September and 8,565 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both increased.
April TE futures rose 2.45 points to close at 333.3, with 3,716 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 1.75 points to finish at 331.2, with 2,581 contract transactions.

June TE futures moved up 0.7 points to close at 329.95, with 10 contracts traded, while September TE futures increased 2.9 points to finish at 326.1, with four contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December.
April TF futures gained 10 points to close at 1,197.2, with 4,956 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures increased 7.8 points to finish at 1,191, with 2.930 contracts traded.
June TF futures dropped three points to close at 1,184, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.059 to close at NT$30.266.
A total of US$1.13 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.350 and fluctuated between NT$30.244 and NT$30.360.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two algae extracts prove helpful to patients with metabolic syndrome

TEXT.P: A government-run aquaculture laboratory has developed two food ingredients based on algae extracts that proved effective in mitigating metabolic syndrome by controlling blood pressure levels and blood fat, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) reported Tuesday.

The ingredients developed by the COA's Fisheries Research Institute (FRI) are Fuso-trehalose -- a sugar that exists in algae, mushroom, bean, shrimp and bread -- and "instant kanten" -- the Japanese name for agar.

Wu Chun-heng, director of the FRI's Seafood Technology Division, said that in addition to the effect in moderating blood pressure and lipid level, Fuso- trehalose is also capable of enhancing the defensive mechanism against pathogenic viruses and bacteria in the human immune system.
"Japan physicians have long experience in using trehalose compounds as a supplementary treatment for cancer patients," Wu said.

Wu said Fuso-trehalose can be used as food ingredient because its chemical structure can sustain environments of 121 Celsius degrees for 30 minutes or 100 Celsius degrees for one hour -- the temperatures and times usually used for food sterilization.

Besides, the trehalose made by Japanese companies has only 80-percent purity, while the FRI's Fuso-trehalose has a purity of 90 percent or higher, which makes the refined ingredient very competitive in the market, Wu said, adding that the relevant technologies have been passed on to a local company.

In the case of instant kanten, Wu said the products currently available on the market are neither easy to cook nor easy to carry, thus the FRI came up with the idea of making instant noodle-like kanten products, which contain kanten powder that can be brewed with hot water at 85 Celsius degrees.
FRI Researchers said that dietary fiber-laced kanten can be used as meal replacements for patients with metabolic syndrome or persons who wish to control their body weight.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public urged to help combat global warming by not overeating

TEXT.P: With April 22 World Earth Day approaching, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing urged the public Monday to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions by not overeating.

Yang issued the call while leading a group of Kaohsiung County government high- ranking officials at County Hall's dining room to use non-disposable chopsticks. Also present was Wang Mao-song, director of Kaohsiung County's Environmental Protection Bureau.

If people do not overeat on a daily basis, less gas and electricity will be consumed and lower levels of greenhouse gas emissions will be produced, which will help minimize global warming, according to Yang.
Statistics show that the level of carbon dioxide emissions in Taiwan averages 12 tons per person per year, some three times higher than the average global figure, Wang said.

Figures also show that 2.8 million pairs of disposable chopsticks are used in Taiwan every year, which is equivalent to the deforestation of 540 hectares of bamboo, said Wang. He suggested that people should use reusable chopsticks instead of disposable ones, which are proven to contain bleaching agents detrimental to human health.

Wang also urged members of public to replace incandescent light bulbs with other energy-saving and high-efficiency lighting devices and share vehicles or walk when commuting between work and home in order to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high and closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 32.1 points, or 0.36 percent, to close at 8,924.78.

Rebounding from losses on the previous day, the local bourse opened at 8,931.08 and fluctuated between 8,951.56 and 8,885.32 during the day's session. A total of 6.23 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$168.35 billion (US$5.56 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 2.8 percent. Banking and financial shares advanced 0.8 percent, construction issues increased 0.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares were up 0.4 percent, and textile stocks gained 0.2 percent.
Two of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares dropping 0.4 percent and foodstuff issues falling 0.5 percent.
Paper and pulp issues remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,195 to 1,027, with 341 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$1.11 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD approves nature conservation budget

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) approved a four-year project worth NT$14.88 billion (US$491 million) Monday to improve conservation systems in national parks.

The project, presented by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) , aims to improve the functioning of national parks, establish an ecological corridor through Taiwan's Central Mountain area and establish guidelines for the conservation of maritime resources.

"In the long term, the MOI hopes that the areas in the country designated for nature conservation will be increased to 20 percent of the island's total area, and that 8 percent of the coastline will gradually be dedicated to maritime national parks, " an MOI official said.

The MOI will also work to strengthen environmental education, establish cooperation links with other organizations around the world and dedicate more effort to nature conservation, the official added.
An official of the Cabinet-level CEPD said the council also supports the idea of establishing a national park administration in the future to facilitate conservation efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign caretakers benefit from new CLA policy

TEXT.P: A young Filipina, Judith Miguel Pascual, may be among the big beneficiaries of the newly established Direct Hiring Service Center (DHSC), as she is now free from brokerage fees and can save money to buy a house in her home country.
When Pascual came to work in Taiwan for the first time more than three years ago, she had to pay a considerable sum of money to employment agencies both in the Philippines and in Taiwan.
But when her employer recently renewed her contract through the DHSC, Pascual did not have to pay any brokerage fees or placement fees.

She said that throughout the three years of her first contract, an agency in Taiwan deducted about NT$1,500-NT$1,800 in brokerage fees from her monthly wage of about NT$16,000 -- deductions that amounted to almost NT$20,000 per year.
"Without those additional charges, I can now save enough money to buy my family a house in the Philippines," said Pascual.

The DHSC, established in late December 2007 with the main objective of streamlining the process of hiring foreign caretakers, has proved effective, said Tsao Ai-lan, the deputy chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).
"Through the DHSC, both hirers and foreign employees can save time and money, and the application process is much more efficient, " Tsao said at a press conference.

Before the DHSC was established, caretakers who wished to renew their contract with the same employers had to first return to their home countries and wait at least two or three weeks -- in some cases up to three months -- for the relevant documents to be processed before they could re-enter Taiwan.

But through the DHSC, Taiwanese employers can now apply to renew the work permit of the same caretaker about four months before the contract expires, which can cut the waiting period for re-entry to Taiwan to a minimum of one day, in express cases, Tsao said.
The process is convenient for busy employers or those in urgent need of a helper, she added.
"Under this new measure system, I saved about NT$5,000-NT$10,000 in agency fees when I renewed Judith's contract," said Pascual's employer Yang Zi-hua.
"We hope that employers will make good use of the DHSC, which also benefits foreign workers," said Tsao.
The DHSC will allow employers to hire caretakers directly from the Philippines, Vietnam, Thailand, Indonesia and Mongolia.

About 160,000 foreign caretakers work in Taiwan, accounting for almost half of the 360,000 foreign laborers from primarily Indonesia, Thailand and the Philippines, according to the Ministry of the Interior.
More information on the DHSC application process is available at the DHSC and local employment services centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU graduates remain employers' top hiring choices: survey

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) graduates, for the second consecutive year, have been named as the top hiring choices for local businesses, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by Cheers magazine.
In second and third places were graduates of National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) and National Chiao Tung University, respectively, according to the survey of the country's top 1,000 businesses.

NTU graduates, who replaced NCKU graduates for the first time in 2007 to climb to the leading position, showed significant progress this year in terms of their stability and ability to withstand stress, with their ranking on these attributes leaping from eighth last year to second this year, the results indicated.
Also this year, National Chung Cheng University graduates made the top-15 list for the first time, squeezing out Soochow University graduates.

The survey found that the percentage of businesses planning to recruit fresh graduates dropped to a three-year low of 70 percent this year, and that the starting salary offered by businesses for new graduates ranged from NT$25,000 to NT$30,000.

Sixty percent of businesses said that in screening the resumes of job applicants, they attach the greatest importance to the university from which the applicants graduated, whether the applicants expressed strong ambitions and whether they had any professional licenses, according to the results.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't might restore rice cultivation on fallow farmland

TEXT.P: The government will consider a call by lawmakers to resume cultivation of fallow rice paddy to curb an increased food shortage across the globe, a government official said Tuesday.

Huang You-tsai, director of the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture (COA) , made the remarks after legislative caucus members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) issued the proposal at a news conference earlier in the day.

According to Huang, the government could allow rice paddies that have lain fallow to be plowed under at any time, although it has adjusted its rice production policy after Taiwan entered the World Trade Organization.
Compared to other Asian countries, Taiwan's rice prices remain relatively stable, having increased by only 13 percent this year, Huang said.
To cope with possible food shortages, the government has always maintained a safe level of rice stocks -- some 310,000 tons at present -- which can be released in emergencies, Huang said.

The central government has since January this year been offering free rice to low income families across Taiwan -- 0.4 kg per person per day distributed by local governments -- he said, adding that as much as nearly 1,000 metric tons has been given away.

Speaking at a Legislative Yuan news conference earlier in the day, DPP legislative caucus whip William Lai proposed that the Executive Yuan study the feasibility of replanting rice on some 220,000 hectares of farmland that has been lying fallow, in light of a growing food scarcity across the globe that has led to riots in several countries.

Although rice prices in Taiwan have increased only slightly compared to some other countries, Lai contended that the government must take precautions against possible incidents amid the fast-changing global situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City starts school tour on enterovirus prevention

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan has started a tour of schools to promote awareness of enterovirus prevention, aimed at developing correct hand-washing habits among elementary and preschool children, a local official said Tuesday.

Su Chuan-chuan, deputy director-general of the city's Department of Health, said the Kaohsiung city government has co-operated with the Ronald McDonald House Charities in Taiwan -- a charity organization founded by the McDonald Corp. -- to present promotional activities at seven local elementary schools, the first of which was held at the Lung Hua Elementary School a day earlier.

According to Su, Kaohsiung City has had four serious cases of enterovirus infection reported to date this year, a relatively high number compared to the one serious case reported during the same period of last year.
Summer and early fall are usually peak seasons for enterovirus infection, but in Taiwan, a subtropical country, infection can occur throughout the whole year, Su said.

Enterovirus, a common cause of diseases such as meningitis and myocarditis, can be contracted through direct contact with contaminated sources such as respiratory secretions. The virus enters the body through the gastrointestinal tract, where it thrives, and can move on to attack the central nervous system.
An infected person usually develops either a rash or a flu-like illness with fever and muscle aches.

Children are more susceptible to the infection than healthy adults, Su went on, adding that 85 percent of infections in children occur in those aged under 5, with 73 percent of those reported in children aged under 3.
No vaccine is available to curb the virus and frequent hand-washing and regular exercise are the most effective ways of preventing infection, Su said.

The school tour will promote correct hand washing among school children, who will be reminded to wash their hands on at least five occasions -- before eating, before playing with babies, after using the toilet, after blowing the nose and before and after visiting hospitals, Su said.
She also called on parents to change their clothes and wash their hands before cuddling or feeding infants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Russian parliament forms pro-Taiwan group

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that the Russian parliament, which was elected at the end of last year, has established for a second time a Taiwan amity group to consolidate exchanges between Taiwan and Russia.

Ali Yang, the newly designated deputy director-general of the MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs, said at a regular press briefing that the State Duma -- Russia's lower house of parliament -- on April 9 established the Russian Parliamentary Group of the State Duma for the Relations with Taiwan.
"The establishment of the group represents the development of bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and Russia," Yang said.

The group was first established in 2004 by parliamentarians of the State Duma to promote bilateral exchanges in the fields of economy, trade, technology and education -- areas in which the two countries have cooperated over the past years although there are no diplomatic relations between them.
However, the group was dissolved when a new parliament was re-elected last December.

Yang quoted the group's new chairman Oleg Korgunov as saying that Taiwan's economic achievement and democratic development are well- known in the world and that he will continue to promote bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and Russia.

Yang said the Russian Academy of Engineering Sciences' selection of Taiwanese Professor Liou Yuei-an of National Central University's Center for Space and Remote Sensing Research as a foreign member in mid-Feb was a reflection of the close bilateral links.

Liou's appointment marked the second time that a Taiwanese scholar was awarded such a prestigious title by the 900-member Russian academy. Tsai Chen-shui, a member of Taiwan's Academia Sinica and a professor at National Taiwan University, in 2001 became the first Taiwanese member of the group.

As to whether Russia will send an envoy to attend President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's inauguration May 20, Yang said Taiwan's representative office in Russia had notified its Russian counterpart of the event but had not yet received a response.
He said Russia adheres to the one-China policy and therefore there are no official exchanges between Taiwan and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: World's wealthiest Chinese person might invest in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/08 21:12:35 (By Mandy Wong and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Li Ka Shing, the richest Chinese person in the world, said Tuesday that his conglomerate might invest in Taiwan with the prospects of improved ties between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Li, chairman of Hong Kong-based Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd., made the remarks while attending the inauguration ceremony of the Hong Kong-Changzhou Trading Association, which is composed of businessmen from Hong Kong and Changzhou, in China's Jiangsu Province.

Asked by journalists if his conglomerate will consider investing in Taiwan as relations between the two sides of the strait seem to have relaxed following a historic meeting between Taiwan's Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and Chinese President Hu Jintao at an economic forum in China, Li said he will not rule out the possibility.

As to the question of whether the series of policies the Chinese government has adopted to curb its overheated economy has affected his business in China, Li said that "there has been only limited impact" as his business dealings are diverse and his employees perform well.

Li, who has an estimated fortune of some US$26.5 billion, tops Forbes' list of richest people of Chinese descent this year. His conglomerate covers a wide variety of business, including real estate, electricity, telecommunications, shipping and the Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: Film featuring legendary figure's life published as tourism ad

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu county government published a tourism promotion documentary Tuesday featuring the life of a legendary warlord who played a historic role in the turbulent China of the 1930s and who was kept under house arrest in this northern Taiwan county for over a decade.

The film, titled The Ching Chuan Dream, was screened during a regular meeting of county officials at the county government headquarters. Hsinchu Magistrate Chen Yung-chin said the film will be shown at Chang's home on Chingchuan in Wufeng township, which is now being reconstructed.

After Beijing displayed a positive attitude toward Taiwan's proposals on weekend cross Taiwan-Strait charter flights and further opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists, Chen instructed that the reconstruction of Chang's former residence be stepped up. The residence of the "Young Marshall, " as Chang was known, was swept away by a typhoon in 1962.

The film records Chang's life in Chingchuan from 1946 to 1960, including the love story of the legendary figure and his mistress, who later became his wife. Chen said the film will be broadcast at Chang's home as an attraction to visitors from China.
Chen said he expects the house and the story will be one of the county's unique tourism resources in attracting Chinese visitors.

Chang, the son of Chinese warlord Chang Tso-lin, was born in 1901. He played a key role in the kidnapping of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in 1936 in an attempt to persuade the latter to go all-out against Japanese aggression.

He was persuaded by Chiang to give up his attempt and submit himself to the Nanjing-based Nationalist government for discipline. Chang escorted Chiang to Nanjing two weeks later, ending the so-called Xian Incident.
He was then put under house arrest for nearly half a century after moving to Taiwan along with the ROC government in 1949.
He was granted relative freedom of movement in Taiwan in 1988 by then-President Lee Teng-hui and was finally allowed to move to Honolulu in 1993, where he died in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: Industry leaders ready to work with incoming Cabinet

TEXT.P: Local industries are looking forward to the incoming administration, whose commitment toward closer ties with China could help Taiwanese industries' efforts to compete in the global market, Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung said Tuesday.

Addressing industry leaders at a CNFI conference, Chen expressed confidence in the policies promised by the new Cabinet, citing the incoming government's 12 major construction projects, industry renovation and global connection as key measures that could make a difference to local industries.

"Improvements in cross-Taiwan Strait relations -- including direct cross-strait chartered flights, the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists, and relaxing restrictions that currently limit local investment in China to 40 percent of a company's total capital -- will be sure to help boost Taiwan's private sector in the face of the highly competitive global market," he said.

Chen said the association will steer the 149 industry associations under its umbrella to collaborate with the new government in order to further develop the domestic economy, while urging the incoming Cabinet to keep President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's campaign promises.

He also urged the country to join the East Asian Free Trade Agreement (EAFTA) and to form economic zones with China to facilitate the relocation of local businesses to other parts of the world's economies.

Speaking to reporters prior to his opening speech at the conference, Chen praised the Boao Forum for Asia, on the sidelines of which Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and Chinese President Hu Jintao held a landmark meeting to discuss bilateral economic issues.
"The meeting is a great start for a revival of cross-strait business development, " he said, adding that it shows the new government's determination to improve China-based Taiwanese businesses.

Chen also welcomed a recent plan by the Central Bank of the Republic of China to open currency exchanges between the Chinese yuan and the new Taiwan dollar, saying it is something that should have been done many years ago.
"Now, currency exchanges across the strait will no longer have to rely on underground trading," he noted.

Chen, a former vice commissioner of the Council of Agriculture, recently attended a meeting with Ma and various top industry leaders, and there has been speculation that he is a possible candidate to join the new Cabinet as head of the COA.
He declined to comment on the rumor, but pointed out two things the new administration hopes to achieve to improve the domestic business environment.

"Major construction projects must be undertaken in a timely fashion so that industry can seize business opportunities, " he said, adding that to encourage local investment, the government should reduce the tax burden on enterprises.
"It is not a policy with an aim of catering to the rich but an action that would improve the wealth of the country overall, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA to launch special train service for Bocelli fans

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) will provide a special train service to transport music fans between Taipei and Taichung for an April 19 concert by Italian singer Andrea Bocelli, TRA officials said Tuesday.

The decision not only shows the popularity in Taiwan of Bocelli -- a renowned blind vocalist born in Lajatico near the Italian city of Pisa -- it has also earned the TRA a reputation as a supporter of culture, according to Wang Hu-chen of the TRA's Department of Transport.

Two express trains will depart from the Taipei Railway Station at 3: 08 p.m. and 3: 40 p.m., respectively, on the day of the concert, while passengers wishing to return from the central city to the north after the concert can catch trains at 11:21 p.m. and 11:40 p.m.
The concert, which will be staged in the Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium (TIBS) in Taichung City, some 150 km south of Taipei, is Bocelli's first in Taiwan.
Noting that half of the tickets have been bought in Taipei, Wang said that "the TRA therefore decided to provide the Taipei fans with the special services so they can return home more conveniently."
"This is the first time the TRA has offered such a program for music fans," Wang noted, promising that "the TRA will introduce other additional services to meet the special needs of the public."

DOC.HEADLINE: New York-based Battery Dance Company to perform in Taichung

TEXT.P: The Battery Dance Company, a renowned modern dance troupe based in New York City, will stage a performance in the central city of Taichung May 1, the Cultural Affairs Bureau of the Taichung city government announced Tuesday.

The performance, titled Moving Spirit, will take place in Taichung City's Chung Shan Hall at 7:30 p.m. From April 17, the bureau will distribute free tickets, with each applicant limited to a maximum of four tickets.
The performance is sponsored by the Taichung city government and the American Institute (AIT) in Taiwan -- the de facto U.S. Embassy in Taiwan.

In addition to staging its own dance pieces, the troupe will help an 18-member aboriginal dance troupe of Taichung County's Szu Chen Junior High School present a 10-minute work created by the students themselves.
The troupe will also conduct four master classes April 29-30 to connect with young dancers in Taichung and Pingtung counties.

This will be the Battery Dance Company's second visit to Taiwan. The troupe had a six-day stay in Taiwan in October 2006, during which its founder and artistic director, Jonathan Hollander, along with his dancers, conducted 11 master classes and workshops and worked with dancers from the Cloud Gate Dance Theater, Taiwan's most prestigious dance troupe.

Taiwan is one of six legs of the Battery Dance Company's tour of Asia, which began in South Korea April 12 and will take the troupe to Laos, Myanmar and Mongolia before finishing up in Beijing May 10.

According to a news release posted on the company's Web site, the Asian tour will see six dancers presenting four pieces: I'll take you there (2006) , Shell Games (2005) , Notebooks (2003) and Moonbeam (1992) -- all choreographed by Hollander, who founded the troupe in 1976. Moonbeam, a work of unusual peace, serenity and austere romanticism, was originally premiered as a duet in India in 1992, but has been expanded into a piece for six dancers.
The company has produced nearly 100 original works, characterized by choreography and music inspired by worldwide sources, with the musical accompaniment often performed live.

Over the past decade, the troupe has developed extensive cultural exchange programs with dancers and musicians in East and South Asia, Eastern and Central Europe, Scandinavia, North Africa, the Middle East, Australia and the Caribbean.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators seek to include greenhouse gas reduction target in law

TEXT.P: Some legislators suggested Tuesday to Winston Dang, minister of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) , that the target for greenhouse gas reduction should be included in the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Act (GGRA) draft rather than in separate regulations, to clearly establish Taiwan's goal of reducing global warming.

"If Taiwan's target for reducing greenhouse gases is made part of the law, it would help to enhance the country's image in the international community, " said Kuomintang Legislator Wu Chih-yang during a review of the GGRA draft.
In response, Dang said that he will respect the legislators' decision, adding that Taiwan's actual target is to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions to the 2000 level by 2025.
Another KMT legislator, Yang Li-hung, also suggested that the GGRA should be enacted in line with other relevant legislation, such as the energy-related laws.
The GGRA was approved by the Executive Yuan in 2006 to create a legal basis for the control of greenhouse gas emissions.
Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions account for 1 percent of the global volume, while its population is only 0.3 percent of the world's, according to the EPA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan county chief pushes for passage of airport bill

TEXT.P: Taoyuan Magistrate Chu Li-lun called Tuesday for quick passage through the legislature of a bill that would allow an upgrading of the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, saying that Taiwan will suffer dwindling competitiveness if the bill fails to pass soon.

Chu made the call as the transportation and home affairs committees under the Legislative Yuan held a joint meeting to screen the bill, which is aimed at upgrading the status and functions of the country's main gateway.
The bill would allow Taiwan to catch up with Japan and experience booming development, and the whole country -- not just Taoyuan County -- would benefit from it, according to Chu.
In the future, development in such special zones as Taichung Port and Chingchuankang Airport in central Taiwan's Taichung City will also take off, he said.

According to Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Oliver F.L. Yu, the bill also involves a project by the Taoyuan county government to establish a Taoyuan aviation park on land adjacent to the airport that could house different areas for eight businesses, including a special airport zone and a free trade zone, among other foreign trade, taxation and customs operations.

Chu told a news conference at the Legislative Yuan in October last year that the 30-year-old airport, formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, needs to sharpen its competitiveness, as its ranking has dropped to 85th place among the world's 136 major airports.

The airport must be made into a legally and professionally incorporated compound comprising a multinational business operations hub, a free trade zone, warehousing and distribution facilities, exhibition centers, tourism hotels, shopping malls and a high-tech science park, so as to avoid being shunted aside and so that it can again become globally competitive, Chu said.

Driven by that goal, Chu said, he crafted a program to create the aviation park, to be located on a 6,150-hectare plot, that could attract over NT$1.2 trillion (US$37 billion) -worth of investment, creating an annual business revenue of at least NT$600 billion and more than 80,000 jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 90% of plastic bags not recycled: official

TEXT.P: Taiwan recycled 2.66 billion, or 9,319 tons, of plastic bags via the garbage collection system from May 2006 to March this year, but the performance still has room for improvement as the annual recycling rate is less than 10 percent, an Environmental Protection Administration (EAP) official said Tuesday.

Ho Shun-chin, director-general of the Department of Waste Management under the EPA, said Taiwanese people consume about 18 billion plastic bags every year, with each person using more than two plastic bags every day on average.
"Taiwan is the first country to collect plastic bags through the national garbage collection system," Ho added.

The plastic bag recycling service started two years ago on a trial basis in 14 counties and cities, with the recycling volume reaching about 3,000 tons before the service was formalized in all 25 counties and cities last April.
About 80 percent of Taiwan's 319 townships now provide a plastic bag recycling service, Ho went on.

Taiwan implemented a partial ban in 2003 that prohibits department stores, supermarkets, convenience stores and wholesalers from providing free plastic bags to customers, Ho said, adding that the annual national consumption of plastic bags was about 20 billion before the ban.

However, she added that the ban does not apply to all plastic bag sources, as sellers at traditional markets and street vendors that provide free plastic bags often are not included on the control list.
Moreover, she pointed out that because plastic bag recycling is not yet a mandated regulation, there are no penalties for those who dump recyclable plastic bags along with their garbage.

The public is encouraged to recycle bags made of materials such as polypropylene (PP) and polyethylene (PE) , which are both non-degradable and can be reprocessed into such items as plant pots or new bags, Ho said.

Some townships accept both clean and stained plastic bags for recycling, while some only accept clean ones because they do not have the equipment for cleaning dirty bags before reprocessing, Ho went on.
Other plastic bags, such as those made of complex materials including foil and anti-static bags for protecting computers or monitors, cannot be recycled and have to be dumped, Ho continued.
She further pointed out that some packaging manufacturers put recycling labels on non-recyclable products, causing misunderstandings between the public and garbage-sorting teams.
Once again, though, the Waste Disposable Act fails to stipulate any penalties for violators, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: America Online launches portal site in Taiwan

TEXT.P: AOL, a U.S.-based Web services provider formerly known as America Online, launched a Chinese-language portal site in Taiwan Monday, the company said in a news release.

The new site, the second in Asia after one in India, is part of the company's efforts to expand its global presence from the current 18 portals to an estimated 30 by the end of 2008, the statement said.
"People in Taiwan are among the world's most sophisticated Internet users, " said Maneesh Dhir, executive vice president of AOL International, in the statement.
Prior to the launch of the site, AOL conducted a two-year assessment of the Taiwan market, said Norman Koo, vice president and general manager for Greater China of AOL.
"The launch of AOL.tw is just the beginning of an ongoing effort to provide consumers in Taiwan with the services and content they want," he added.
Like other major portal sites in Taiwan provided by Google and Yahoo, AOL.tw offers a wide range of free content and services, including free e-mail with unlimited storage and an instant messenger.

To offer Chinese-language news updates, AOL.tw has joined forces with udn.com, a news Web site operated by United Daily News, a major Chinese-language daily based in Taipei, and Hong Kong-based Phoenix New Media.

In addition, AOL is working with Hewlett-Packard Co., the world's biggest PC maker, to deliver a co-branded local language portal and search solution for HP users in Taiwan in the coming weeks, according to the statement.

However, industry watchers have been quoted in the DIGITIMES -- a bilingual information technology news provider -- as saying that AOL entered the Taiwan market "too late and is expected to face intense competition."
But Koo said he believes there is still room for AOL in Taiwan because local Internet users have diverse demands.
As of February, Yahoo! Kimo was the largest Web portal in Taiwan, followed by HiNet, Google, Microsoft MSN, PChome Online and Yam, according to survey statistics cited by DIGITIMES.

In the United States, AOL has a market share of 4 percent, a far smaller percentage compared with other search engines -- Google with 50 percent and Yahoo with 20 percent, according to statistics released by the Virginia-based researcher ComScore Inc. in February.
The launch of the Taiwan portal also came at a time when AOL is reportedly negotiating with Yahoo over a possible merger after Yahoo rejected a US$44.6 billion takeover offer from Microsoft Corp.
AOL is a majority-owned subsidiary of Time Warner Inc. AOL and its subsidiaries have operations in the U.S., Europe, Canada and Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIV-positive woman from Vietnam evades medical re-examination

TEXT.P: The Public Health Center of Sijhih City in Taipei County is trying to trace a woman from Vietnam who has been found to be HIV-positive through an initial blood test.

Health workers told a news conference Tuesday that they located the woman through one of her friends and took her to the center for a second blood test to double-check whether she had really contracted HIV.
However, while medical personnel were preparing to administer the test, the unidentified woman fled.

According to the public health center, the woman used a health insurance card belonging to her friend, a 30-year-old Vietnamese woman living in the northeastern city of Keelung, to pay for the initial blood test.

When informed of the test result, the card owner was shocked, but soon recalled that she had not visited the hospital and that it was probably her friend who had used her card to avoid paying for medical expenses.

Through the help of the card owner, health officials tracked down the suspected HIV-positive patient, who acknowledged that she used her friends's health insurance card to visit the hospital but denied that she took a blood test.
Officials at the Sijhih City Public Health Center said they are anxious to find the woman because she is like "a viral time bomb."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei ready to be Asia-Pacific operation hub: officials

TEXT.P: Taipei city government officials said Tuesday that the city is prepared to serve as an Asia-Pacific operations center if its Sungshan Airport can be used to accommodate charter flights between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Since Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang was elected president March 22, many cities around Taiwan have been eager to promote their airports as possible stops for the cross-strait charter flights Ma has promised to promote after he assumes his post.

According to the officials, the promotion of Songshan Airport as a direct air- link hub will not only lure Taiwanese businessmen operating in China to relocate their headquarters to Taipei, but will also boost Taipei's potential as a regional operations hub.

In addition to promoting Songshan Airport as a stop on cross-strait charter routes, "the Taipei city government will also give priority to strengthening the information, medical care, conferencing, culture and gourmet food industries in order to create an excellent investment environment," the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Watoto Children's Choir from Uganda enjoy shopping in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The 28 members of Uganda's Watoto Children's Choir currently touring Taiwan spent a half-day Tuesday shopping in a hypermarket in the central city of Taichung, and apparently enjoyed the experience.

The children and their adult leaders, each armed with NT$1,000 (US$33) -- a gift from the Tatun Chapter of the Rotary Club -- roamed the store, buying mostly clothing, socks and sports shoes. They also received a variety of gifts from the hypermarket management.
The choir was treated to a steak lunch at a restaurant before spending the afternoon at the National Museum of Natural Science in Taichung.
The Ugandan children will perform two concerts in Taichung April 20 as part of the choir's Taiwan tour that began late last month.

The two Taichung concerts, sponsored by a local community service association, will take place at 2:30 p.m. and 7:30 p.m. in the city's Chungshan Hall. Tickets are free, with a maximum allocation of four tickets per person.

The Watoto Children's Choir has already given eight "Concerts of Hope" in major cities since its arrival March 28, including three in Taipei and one each in Changhua, Hsinchu, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Yilan under the sponsorship of World Vision Taiwan, a Christian relief organization dedicated to helping underprivileged children and families.
This is the choir's second visit to Taiwan. During its last visit in 2006, the children moved audiences with their songs and the tour was a resounding success, with considerable funds raised.

The choir's members are all orphans aged between 6 and 13. Their tour of Taiwan is intended to increase awareness about the AIDS crisis in Africa and raise funds for a missionary program -- the Watoto Child Care Ministries -- that helps AIDS orphans in Uganda.
About 2 million in Uganda are afflicted with AIDS and most of the 1,600 children in the care of the ministries have lost their parents to the disease.
Watoto, the name of the village in Uganda from which the choir takes its name and from where the children come, means "children" in Swahili, one of the most widely spoken languages in East Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's chief negotiator with China to visit mainland soon

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Deputy Chairman Chiang Pin-kung , who has been named by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou to lead the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) under his incoming administration, confirmed Tuesday that he is planning to visit China some time between late April and early May.

The main goal of the trip is to convey the party's appreciation to Taiwanese businessmen operating there for their support in the just-concluded presidential election that saw the KMT regain the presidency it lost eight years ago to the Democratic Progressive Party, Chiang told reporters.
Chiang made the confirmation while answering reporters' questions about a recent news report about the visit.

The report said Chiang will visit China on April 20 and if he has the chance, he will meet with his possible counterpart Chen Yunlin, who has been reported to take over the post of chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.
However, Chiang said Tuesday that he is not eager to meet Chen now. Chen currently heads China's Taiwan Affairs Office.

Chiang said that many important issues need to be addressed through talks between the two sides, such as allowing direct flights and currency exchanges, but they won't be put on the negotiaions table before the new government's inauguration on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indoor air quality is three times worse than outdoor: German expert

TEXT.P: The air quality of a non-smoking office is three times worse than the quality of outdoor air, a Taipei-based German environmental expert said Tuesday.
Many modern construction materials contain chemicals that are harmful to human health and so do many office equipment, said Andreas Gursch, deputy director of the Germany Trade Office in Taipei.

Gursch, an expert on waste management and resource recycling, made the remarks after posing the question -- "Is your office killing you? " -- to employees of the Taipei county government in a keynote speech on German green buildings and renewable energies.
Citing survey results, Gursch said that a TV set contains more than 4,000 types of chemicals.
He suggested the county government rent, rather than buy, durable office goods so that it can return the goods to the company for upgrading or replacement when they are too old.
By doing this, waste could be minimized, Gursch said.

On Taipei county's government building, a fully enclosed one that was recently criticized by Deputy County Magistrate Lee Hung-yuan as very environmentally unfriendly, Gursch said that a building should be designed or built as eco- friendly as a tree.

In addition, Gursch said that only products that can always be recycled are called "renewable resources, " not those that can be recycled just once, which he stressed is a concept that needs to be established in Taiwan.
As an example of the concept, Gursch said that people should recycle daily and to also recycle kitchen waste.

Meanwhile, Gursch praised Taiwan for doing a good job in recycling and said young Taiwanese children have a keen sense of environmental awareness. But he added that Taiwan's adults need to work harder.

In 2006, Taiwan's Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) kicked off a countrywide recycling campaign requiring local residents to sort household waste into three categories: recyclable resources, kitchen waste and garbage.
Taiwan's total recycling rate has reached some 36 percent, a percentage that the EPA said is higher than that of the United States and Japan.
Gursch further predicted that agriculture will be the focus of the next eco- revolution, saying that local farmers' associations should start to increase local farmers's eco-friendly awareness.

Gursch, who has dedicated himself to protecting the environment in Taiwan over the last 16 years, said that Taiwan has the responsibility to cut carbon dioxide emissions even though it is not a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol.

DOC.HEADLINE: 40 bus lines to remote areas suspended

TEXT.P: Forty bus lines serving remote areas of Taiwan have been suspended from the beginning of this year due to their unprofitability, an official of the Directorate General of Highways (DGH) under the Executive Yuan said Tuesday.

Deputy Director-General Chen Chun-hsiung said the DGH has encouraged bus companies to design new lines with integrated routes and more effective operations with the aim of reducing the inconvenience caused by the suspension to residents living in remote areas.
He added that local governments and motor vehicle offices in the affected areas have provided a total of 250 possible new lines to be examined by a bus company committee April 25.

Earlier, a suggestion by the DGH to run smaller buses on existing lines to save on fuel costs was rejected when the bus companies said the ceiling of government subsidies for buying the buses -- 45 percent of the purchase amount -- means the companies would fail to cover their operating costs, Chen said.
He pointed out that 570 of the 1,199 bus lines under DGH jurisdiction are operated with government subsidies, including the 40 suspended lines.
The companies involved include the Hsinchu Transportation Co., Hsingnan Bus, Miaoli Bus, Kaohsiung Transportation Co., Taichung Bus and Kuokuang Motor Transport Co.

The government provides about NT$720 million (US$23.68 million) in subsidies, which is equal to 80 percent of the amount applied for by the industry, to help cover their losses, Chen said, adding that the DGH will seek additional budget to make up the remaining 20 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 90% of plastic bags not recycled: official

TEXT.P: Taiwan recycled 2.66 billion, or 9,319 tons, of plastic bags via the garbage collection system from May 2006 to March this year, but the performance still has room for improvement as the annual recycling rate is less than 10 percent, an Environmental Protection Administration (EAP) official said Tuesday.

Ho Shun-chin, director-general of the Department of Waste Management under the EPA, said Taiwanese people consume about 18 billion plastic bags every year, with each person using more than two plastic bags every day on average.
"Taiwan is the first country to collect plastic bags through the national garbage collection system," Ho added.

The plastic bag recycling service started two years ago on a trial basis in 14 counties and cities, with the recycling volume reaching about 3,000 tons before the service was formalized in all 25 counties and cities last April.
About 80 percent of Taiwan's 319 townships now provide a plastic bag recycling service, Ho went on.

Taiwan implemented a partial ban in 2003 that prohibits department stores, supermarkets, convenience stores and wholesalers from providing free plastic bags to customers, Ho said, adding that the annual national consumption of plastic bags was about 20 billion before the ban.

However, she added that the ban does not apply to all plastic bag sources, as sellers at traditional markets and street vendors that provide free plastic bags often are not included on the control list.
Moreover, she pointed out that because plastic bag recycling is not yet a mandated regulation, there are no penalties for those who dump recyclable plastic bags along with their garbage.

The public is encouraged to recycle bags made of materials such as polypropylene (PP) and polyethylene (PE) , which are both non-degradable and can be reprocessed into such items as plant pots or new bags, Ho said.

Some townships accept both clean and stained plastic bags for recycling, while some only accept clean ones because they do not have the equipment for cleaning dirty bags before reprocessing, Ho went on.
Other plastic bags, such as those made of complex materials including foil and anti-static bags for protecting computers or monitors, cannot be recycled and have to be dumped, Ho continued.
She further pointed out that some packaging manufacturers put recycling labels on non-recyclable products, causing misunderstandings between the public and garbage-sorting teams.
Once again, though, the Waste Disposable Act fails to stipulate any penalties for violators, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: America Online launches portal site in Taiwan

TEXT.P: AOL, a U.S.-based Web services provider formerly known as America Online, launched a Chinese-language portal site in Taiwan Monday, the company said in a news release.

The new site, the second in Asia after one in India, is part of the company's efforts to expand its global presence from the current 18 portals to an estimated 30 by the end of 2008, the statement said.
"People in Taiwan are among the world's most sophisticated Internet users, " said Maneesh Dhir, executive vice president of AOL International, in the statement.
Prior to the launch of the site, AOL conducted a two-year assessment of the Taiwan market, said Norman Koo, vice president and general manager for Greater China of AOL.
"The launch of AOL.tw is just the beginning of an ongoing effort to provide consumers in Taiwan with the services and content they want," he added.
Like other major portal sites in Taiwan provided by Google and Yahoo, AOL.tw offers a wide range of free content and services, including free e-mail with unlimited storage and an instant messenger.

To offer Chinese-language news updates, AOL.tw has joined forces with udn.com, a news Web site operated by United Daily News, a major Chinese-language daily based in Taipei, and Hong Kong-based Phoenix New Media.

In addition, AOL is working with Hewlett-Packard Co., the world's biggest PC maker, to deliver a co-branded local language portal and search solution for HP users in Taiwan in the coming weeks, according to the statement.

However, industry watchers have been quoted in the DIGITIMES -- a bilingual information technology news provider -- as saying that AOL entered the Taiwan market "too late and is expected to face intense competition."
But Koo said he believes there is still room for AOL in Taiwan because local Internet users have diverse demands.
As of February, Yahoo! Kimo was the largest Web portal in Taiwan, followed by HiNet, Google, Microsoft MSN, PChome Online and Yam, according to survey statistics cited by DIGITIMES.

In the United States, AOL has a market share of 4 percent, a far smaller percentage compared with other search engines -- Google with 50 percent and Yahoo with 20 percent, according to statistics released by the Virginia-based researcher ComScore Inc. in February.
The launch of the Taiwan portal also came at a time when AOL is reportedly negotiating with Yahoo over a possible merger after Yahoo rejected a US$44.6 billion takeover offer from Microsoft Corp.
AOL is a majority-owned subsidiary of Time Warner Inc. AOL and its subsidiaries have operations in the U.S., Europe, Canada and Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Watoto Children's Choir from Uganda enjoy shopping in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The 28 members of Uganda's Watoto Children's Choir currently touring Taiwan spent a half-day Tuesday shopping in a hypermarket in the central city of Taichung, and apparently enjoyed the experience.

The children and their adult leaders, each armed with NT$1,000 (US$33) -- a gift from the Tatun Chapter of the Rotary Club -- roamed the store, buying mostly clothing, socks and sports shoes. They also received a variety of gifts from the hypermarket management.
The choir was treated to a steak lunch at a restaurant before spending the afternoon at the National Museum of Natural Science in Taichung.
The Ugandan children will perform two concerts in Taichung April 20 as part of the choir's Taiwan tour that began late last month.

The two Taichung concerts, sponsored by a local community service association, will take place at 2:30 p.m. and 7:30 p.m. in the city's Chungshan Hall. Tickets are free, with a maximum allocation of four tickets per person.

The Watoto Children's Choir has already given eight "Concerts of Hope" in major cities since its arrival March 28, including three in Taipei and one each in Changhua, Hsinchu, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Yilan under the sponsorship of World Vision Taiwan, a Christian relief organization dedicated to helping underprivileged children and families.
This is the choir's second visit to Taiwan. During its last visit in 2006, the children moved audiences with their songs and the tour was a resounding success, with considerable funds raised.

The choir's members are all orphans aged between 6 and 13. Their tour of Taiwan is intended to increase awareness about the AIDS crisis in Africa and raise funds for a missionary program -- the Watoto Child Care Ministries -- that helps AIDS orphans in Uganda.
About 2 million in Uganda are afflicted with AIDS and most of the 1,600 children in the care of the ministries have lost their parents to the disease.
Watoto, the name of the village in Uganda from which the choir takes its name and from where the children come, means "children" in Swahili, one of the most widely spoken languages in East Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indoor air quality is three times worse than outdoor: German expert

TEXT.P: The air quality of a non-smoking office is three times worse than the quality of outdoor air, a Taipei-based German environmental expert said Tuesday.
Many modern construction materials contain chemicals that are harmful to human health and so do many office equipment, said Andreas Gursch, deputy director of the Germany Trade Office in Taipei.

Gursch, an expert on waste management and resource recycling, made the remarks after posing the question -- "Is your office killing you? " -- to employees of the Taipei county government in a keynote speech on German green buildings and renewable energies.
Citing survey results, Gursch said that a TV set contains more than 4,000 types of chemicals.
He suggested the county government rent, rather than buy, durable office goods so that it can return the goods to the company for upgrading or replacement when they are too old.
By doing this, waste could be minimized, Gursch said.

On Taipei county's government building, a fully enclosed one that was recently criticized by Deputy County Magistrate Lee Hung-yuan as very environmentally unfriendly, Gursch said that a building should be designed or built as eco- friendly as a tree.

In addition, Gursch said that only products that can always be recycled are called "renewable resources, " not those that can be recycled just once, which he stressed is a concept that needs to be established in Taiwan.
As an example of the concept, Gursch said that people should recycle daily and to also recycle kitchen waste.

Meanwhile, Gursch praised Taiwan for doing a good job in recycling and said young Taiwanese children have a keen sense of environmental awareness. But he added that Taiwan's adults need to work harder.

In 2006, Taiwan's Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) kicked off a countrywide recycling campaign requiring local residents to sort household waste into three categories: recyclable resources, kitchen waste and garbage.
Taiwan's total recycling rate has reached some 36 percent, a percentage that the EPA said is higher than that of the United States and Japan.
Gursch further predicted that agriculture will be the focus of the next eco- revolution, saying that local farmers' associations should start to increase local farmers's eco-friendly awareness.

Gursch, who has dedicated himself to protecting the environment in Taiwan over the last 16 years, said that Taiwan has the responsibility to cut carbon dioxide emissions even though it is not a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol.
