DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 16, or the 11th day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1828: Francisco Jose de Goya, Spanish artist whose paintings and etchings reflected the political and social turmoil of his time, dies at the age of 82.
1850: Madame Marie Tussaud, Swiss founder of the famous waxworks museum in London, dies at the age of 89.
1889: Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin, known as "Charlie," film actor and comedian much loved for his portrayal of a tramp in baggy pants and bowler hat, is born in Britain. His productions include "The Kid," "The Gold Rush," and "The Great Dictator."
1912: American pilot Harriet Quimby becomes the first woman to fly the English Channel.
1917: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin returns to Russia after three years of exile in Zurich.
1923: Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito arrives in Keelung for an inspection tour of Taiwan, which is under Japanese rule.
1925: In honor of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who died in Peking on March 12, 1925 at the age of 59, the Kwangtung Provincial Government changes the name of Hsiangshan County, the place of birth of Dr. Sun, to Chungshan County.
1941: German troops enter Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, and the main synagogue is destroyed.
1948: The Organization for European Economic Co-operation (OEEC) is established in Paris by Western European nations in accordance with the Marshall Plan.
1960: The Taiwan Provincial Government begins the implementation of labor insurance regulations by establishing the Labor Insurance Bureau.
1972: Yasunari Kawabata, Japanese writer who won the 1968 Nobel Prize for literature, commits suicide at the age of 73. His novels, including "Thousand Cranes," often concern alienated, lonely individuals in search of beauty and purity.
1972: The Apollo 16 mission is launched from Cape Kennedy, Florida, to make the fifth manned moon landing.
1975: The communist Khmer Rouge seize Phnom Penh, capital of Cambodia.
1978: A tornado strikes the eastern state of Orissa in India, killing some 180 people.
1981: The Kaohsiung C.K.S. Cultural Center is inaugurated.
1982: Queen Elizabeth proclaims Canada's new constitution, severing the colonial links with Britain.
1985: The first test tube baby in the Republic of China is born at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei.
1990: In London, Freed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela publicly thanks the world for its support during his 26-year imprisonment by the South African government.
1998: Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot is reported dead of a heart attack in his Cambodian jungle stronghold at the age of 73. During his four-year reign of terror some two million Cambodians died.
1999: Former opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang is blasted by other DPP members for his recent remarks on plebiscites and Taiwan independence.
1999: A field hospital donated by Taiwan opens at the Stenkovee refugee camp outside Skopje, Macedonia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that "maintaining peace and stability and safeguarding the interests of Taiwan are the highest goals and moral obligations" for him as president.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men in old times educated themselves for their own sakes. Men now educate themselves to impress others."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records nine more severe enteroviral infections

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) confirmed Tuesday nine more cases of severe enteroviral infection, bringing to 36 the total number of such incidents so far this year.

Of these 36 children who developed severe complications from the infection, 16 contracted the virus from their elder siblings who often show only mild symptoms from the infection, according to CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Chih-hao.

In one of the latest of these cases, a three-year-old boy in the southern city of Tainan was diagnosed early this month with severe enteroviral infection, and the source of infection was traced to his six-year-old brother and five-year-old sister, who were first infected but had only mild illness, Chou said.
Experts have said that those who contract the virus from other patients and those under the age of 4 are particularly vulnerable to developing serious enteroviral symptoms.

Referring to data collected from the Department of Health's "sentinel physician active reporting system," Chou said 2.26 in every 1,000 persons making medical visits last week were infected with enterovirus, up significantly from 1.97 in every 1,000 persons in the previous week.

Over the past month, Chou continued, as many as 39 percent of enterovirus cases tested by CDC-contracted laboratories have been identified as enterovirus type 71 (E71) -- the deadliest type of enterovirus.
While 43 percent of children aged 5 and under in Taiwan are not immune to E71, as many as 90 of those aged 4 and under lack any immunity to E71, according to the CDC.
Enteroviruses are the most common cause of aseptic meningitis and can be serious, especially in infants.
In 1988, Taiwan experienced a severe outbreak of E71, with 405 children infected, 78 of whom died.
Another E71 outbreak in 2005 saw 145 children infected, 15 of whom died.

DOC.HEADLINE: Better ties with China could spur progress on FTAs: president-elect
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/08 13:41:56 (By Charles Kang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will pursue a comprehensive economic cooperation pact with China and at the same time try to seal free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries, including Singapore, President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said in interviews published here Wednesday.

In the interview in Taipei Tuesday with The Straits Times and Lianhe Zaobao, Ma, who is slated to be inaugurated May 20, said Taiwan will seek to enter into a comprehensive economic cooperation pact with China and seal FTAs with other countries around Asia.

Ma said that he hoped FTA talks between Taiwan and the city state will be restarted as soon as possible to pave the way for Taiwan to seal similar agreements with other Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) members.
"As long as Singapore agrees, we should start as soon as possible, " Ma said in interviews that were published on prominent pages of the two dailies.

Talks started soon after President Chen Shui-bian was elected in 2000, but broke off soon after, partly under pressure from China and partly because of a dispute over how to refer to Taiwan, Ma told the The Straits Times.
Ma said eased cross-Taiwan Strait relations were critical to the resumption of Taiwan-Singapore FTA talks.

"We certainly hope we can achieve some results in our relations with the mainland so that Singapore can rest assured that our FTA negotiations will not hurt its relations with the mainland, " Ma said.
The president-elect asserted that so long as Taiwan is flexible and pragmatic on the title issue when engaging in talks with Singapore, obstructions will be minimized.
"We can accept any other names as long as they are feasible and won't undermine Taiwan's dignity. Substance is more important than formality," Ma told The Straits Times.
For years, Ma has advocated that Taiwan should be accepted as the the fourth partner of dialogue in the ASEAN Plus Three (China, Japan and South Korea) group.
Responding to Ma's call, Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry issue a statement Wednesday, saying that Singapore has yet to be approached officially by the Ma administration on the FTA

Also in a statement, Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said there will be many opportunities for Taiwan and Singapore to enhance bilateral economic cooperation if cross-Strait relations improve and economic affairs are not politicized.
In the interview, Ma also mentioned that Taiwan hopes to accelerate progress on FTA talks with the United States.
"I won't say I'm optimistic about sealing FTAs with other countries. But I think all nations will welcome a peaceful and not troublemaking Taiwan," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Supreme Investigation panel mum on Chen's no-exit report

TEXT.P: Prosecutors of the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office would not comment Wednesday on a magazine report that they are considering restricting President Chen Shui-bian from leaving Taiwan over his alleged misuse of a special fund.

Chen Yun-nan, chief of the division, would not confirm anything pertaining to their investigation into President Chen's handling of the special "state affairs fund" budgeted for his discretionary use.

Next Magazine, a tabloid weekly published by Apple Daily, reported Wednesday that prosecutors are planning to restrict President Chen from leaving the country in relation to a case in which he and his wife allegedly pocketed cash from the fund drawn with receipts provided by people other than the first family.
His wife, Wu Shu-chen, was indicted on corruption charges and prosecutors said they had enough evidence to charge Chen but could not because he enjoyed immunity as a sitting president.
Prosecutors said at the time they would charge Chen when his immunity ran out. His tenure ends May 20.

The Taiwan High Prosecutors Office formed a special task force in June 2006 to investigate the "state affairs fund" controversy after receiving suspicious financial reports related to the president's special fund from the Ministry of Audit under the Control Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan's tourism industry prepared for opening to Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: Taiwan's travel agencies are capable of providing safe, quality tours to 10,000 Chinese tourists a day, Yao Ta-kuang, chairman of the Travel Agent Association of R.O.C., Taiwan (TAA), asserted Wednesday.

"Since 2002, the industry has accommodated 800,000 tourists from China, who came to visit or were transiting to other destinations, and is well-aware of the potential risks and safety issues involved," Yao said at a public hearing at the Legislative Yuan.

Yao said the association, which is responsible for tour group registration to protect the rights of inbound tourists, imposes strict conditions on details like charter bus standards and restaurant reservations before handing out permission to an agency to lead an inbound group.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou campaigned on opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists. Under the incumbent Democratic Progressive Party administration, arrivals were to be limited to 1,000 visitors a day, but Ma has suggested that number could increase to between 3,000 to 10,000 per day once an agreement with China has been ironed out.

Officials of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) and the Tourism Bureau raised concerns that admitting too many Chinese tourists too quickly could strain their operations and lead the potential inflow of illegal immigrants.

But Yao was confident that the travel association's screening system could prevent some of the problems, and he insisted tourism could be amajor force in reviving cross-Taiwan Strait economic exchanges and spurring economic growth at home.
He estimated Chinese tourists could directly inject NT$66 billion into Taiwan's economy, which would generate 2.7 times that amount in terms of overall social and economic benefit.

Taiwan's biggest airline, China Airlines Ltd. (CAL), also said it was ready for the opening, expected to be launched in July, saying it would fly to more destinations in both Taiwan and China once the policy was in place.

"CAL has more than 10 years of experience transporting passengers across the Taiwan Strait, and we plan to establish more destinations to cater to the increasing number of cross-strait passengers, " said CAL President Ringo Chao.

He said the carrier hopes to connect Taipei Taoyuan, Taichung and Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou and Xiamen in China, which Chao saw as the cities that attract the most Taiwanese businessmen.
He also said CAL is full-prepared for cross-strait direct chartered flights on weekends that are expected to begin prior in July.
Concerned about a large influx of Chinese tourists, the Ministry of the Interior's National Immigration Agency said it had measures in place to deter illegal immigration.
"The bureau imposes a NT$200,000 fine on tour agencies for every tourist that does not leave the country with the rest of the group as scheduled, " said Wu Shen-yan, a senior official with the NIA.

According to the agency, 119 Chinese tourists have failed to abide by the restriction since 2002, when the government withdrew the ban on inbound Chinese tourists on a limited basis. Ninety-four of them have been caught and returned to China.

Wu also suggested that the Travel Agency Association hire subcontractors to handle inbound tourism services on behalf of his agency, saying the government may not have enough manpower to handle the projected 3,000 tourists per day.
The hearing also included voices from local scholars, who generally backed the new policy but warned that quantity could not undermine the quality of the tours.
"The tour should provide symbolic values such as cultural diversity to impress the visitors, "said Jimmy C. Yung, the president of Kaohsiung Hospitality College.

Yung called for an in-depth cultural exchange between Taiwan and China and advised the local tour industry to arrange a variety of sights around the island to showcase Taiwan's multidimensional faces.

Lawmakers who chaired the hearing said the discussion, by forging a consensus among local industry, academia and the government, could help the incoming cabinet negotiate with China regarding on tourism issues.
