DOC.HEADLINE: Fugitive former Hsinchu County Council speaker returns to Taiwan

TEXT.P: Former Hsinchu County Council Speaker Huang Huan-chi returned to Taiwan and was taken into custody Tuesday after fleeing to China two years ago following his sentencing to eight years in prison on corruption charges, judicial sources said Wednesday.
Following unsuccessful kidney transplant surgery in China, Huang recently informed Hsinchu County police that he would be returning to the Taiwan.
Shortly after Huang's plane landed in Taiwan, he was escorted away by police, who later turned him over to the Hsinchu District Prosecutors Office.
Huang served two terms as Hsinchu County Council speaker before running in the legislative elections in December 2001 as a candidate of the Taiwan Solidarity Union. He ended up losing the election.
In that race, Huang was accused of vote-buying violations for allegedly using the county council's budget to purchase tea and moon cakes for voters. He was later released on bail.

Two years ago, after being convicted on corruption charges related to an incinerator scandal in the county, Huang decided to flee to China to avoid serving his prison sentence. He was then placed on the Hsinchu District Prosecutors Office's wanted list.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipower to report to lawmakers on investment plan in Honduras

TEXT.P: State-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) will make a confidential report to a legislative committee on its investment in a power plant in Honduras, Taipower officials said Wednesday.

The officials were responding to a request by legislators who expressed worries that Taipower could incur severe losses on its investment plan in Patuca hydroelectric project in the Central American country.

The legislators said that Taipower's finances have been weakened by a government freeze on electricity rate, and that it would have to shoulder heavy interest payments if it needed to borrow money for the investment.

According to the legislators, Taipower passed the NT$345.88 million (US$11.57 million) investment plan in an internal meeting March 5 and the plan will begin this year, with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) initially footing the bill.
As Taipower has not appropriated funds for the investment project and legislators were unable to screen the budgets, they had asked for a closed-door report by the Taipower.
Taipower Chairman Edward K. M. Chen said recently that the MOFA will be responsible for any losses in the firm's investment plan.
The investment plan forms part of a package of foreign aid that President Chen Shui-bian promised to several Central American countries during a trip he made there last August.
"As this project is a response to government policy, the government has promised that MOFA will be responsible for any losses the project incurs," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese yuan exchanges to be adopted in two stages: Cabinet

TEXT.P: Taiwanese financial institutions will be allowed only to buy Chinese yuan in exchange for new Taiwan dollars as a "first stage" measure if exchange services between the currencies of Taiwan and China are launched in Taiwan proper in July, a government spokesman said Wednesday.

Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey quoted Perng Fai-nan, governor of the Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) , as saying that the central bank plans to adopt a two-stage approach in introducing full exchange services between the Chinese yuan and the new Taiwan dollar in Taiwan proper, in accordance with requests by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators.

In the initial stage, the central bank will only allow financial institutions to buy Chinese yuan in exchange for new Taiwan dollars, as local banks will have zero or little stock of the Chinese currency available when Taiwan first allows such exchanges, Shieh quoted Perng as saying.

In the second stage, if the central bank is confident of a stable supply of yuan -- which could be provided by inbound tourists from China -- it will permit financial institutions to both buy and sell the Chinese currency, Shieh added.
Between the two stages, he noted, banking institutions on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will consult each other on how to tackle other technical issues related to the opening.

Shieh did not exclude the possibility that the first stage could take place prior to the inauguration of the new Kuomintang (KMT) administration May 20, although he pointed out that regulations will need to be revised before any currency exchange system can take effect.

Since the Chinese yuan will have to be obtained mainly from Chinese tourists coming to Taiwan, the two-stage opening measure is necessary as Taiwanese citizens make some 4 million visits to China each year, compared to only some 1 million Chinese tourists who will be allowed to visit Taiwan each year if Taiwan decides to allow entry to a maximum of 3,000 Chinese tourists a day after the KMT administration takes office, Shieh added.

The KMT legislative caucus proposed recently that Taiwan should launch exchange facilities for the two currencies even before relevant regulations are amended and a cross-strait clearance and settlement mechanism is established.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou has committed to allowing free exchange of the Chinese yuan in Taiwan. Individuals have been allowed to exchange up to 20,000 yuan on the Taiwan-controlled islands of Kinmen and Matsu, which lie just off China's southeastern coast, since October 2005.

But with an agreement on allowing entry of Chinese tourists to Taiwan expected to be struck after the new government takes office, the issue of exchange services on Taiwan proper has become more pressing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 141.26 points, or 1.58 percent, to close at 9,066.04.

Rising for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 9,007.63 and fluctuated between 9,068.97 and 8,981.91 during the day's session. A total of 7.49 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$210.29 billion (US$6.95 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 4.7 percent. Textile stocks advanced 4 percent, banking and financial shares rose 3.2 percent, cement stocks and foodstuff issues both increased 2 percent, machinery and electronics shares gained 1.4 percent, plastics and chemical shares grew 0.4 percent, and construction issues were up 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,491 to 783, with 288 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$6.39 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: All three burst tires on EVA plane installed in last two weeks: CAA

TEXT.P: All three of the tires that burst on an EVA Air MD-90 aircraft that was forced to make an emergency landing the day before were new, while the one tire that did not burst had recently been repaired, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Wednesday.

The aircraft was taking off from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in the north for Kaohsiung in the south Tuesday morning when the accident occurred. The pilot detected abnormalities shortly after takeoff and informed air traffic controllers, who in turn informed the pilot that tire fragments had been discovered on the runway.

While the plane was preparing for landing in Kaohsiung, air traffic controllers there noticed that one of the tires had burst. During landing, two more of the tires burst due to pressure imbalances caused by the blown tire.

CAA Deputy Director Lin Hsin-teh said Wednesday that investigations revealed that besides fragments of the plane's outer skin and tire fragments, no other debris was found on the runway at Taoyuan International Airport.
Noting that the three tires that burst on the plane were installed after March 31, Lin said the CAA is investigating how an almost brand new tire could have burst upon takeoff.
Investigators also discovered during the initial examination of the plane that besides the burst tire, the left wheel door was damaged and the right wheel door was missing.
None of the 36 passengers or six crew members aboard the B-17913 flight were hurt in the accident.
The MD-90 aircraft, which was manufactured in December 1996, was rented from Uni Air, a regional domestic subsidiary of EVA Airways.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up 171 points to close at 9,086, with 30,628 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May rose 168 points to finish at 9,045, with 37,212 contracts traded, while June futures gained 151 points to close at 9,010, with 75 contract transactions.
September futures increased 140 points to finish at 8,760, with 49 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 135 points to close at 8,720, with 67 contracts traded.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 141.26 points Wednesday to finish at 9,066.04, on turnover of NT$210.28 billion (US$6.94 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 8,915 for April; 8,877 for May; 8,859 for June; 8,620 for September and 8,585 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both increased.
April TE futures rose 5.55 points to close at 339, with 2,363 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 6.95 points to finish at 338, with 3,552 contract transactions.

June TE futures moved up 4.55 points to close at 334.5, with 14 contracts traded, while September TE futures increased 5.5 points to finish at 331.6, with one contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December.
April TF futures gained 42.2 points to close at 1,240, with 5,661 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures increased 45.2 points to finish at 1,236, with 7,660 contracts traded.

June TF futures rose 45.4 points to close 1,234, with eight contract transactions, while September TF futures gained 33.8 points to finish at 1,220, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ferry ticket prices on mini three links route to increase

TEXT.P: Ferry companies offering services on the "mini three links" route are set to raise their ticket prices from Friday by nearly 10 percent due to increasing fuel costs.

Representatives of the ferry companies Chinhsia, Darong and Chinan said they have received approval from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to increase their ticket prices from NT$600 (US$20) for a one-way trip to NT$650.

The one exception is the "Eastern Star" ferry, whose ticket prices will remain unchanged for the time being. The operator of the ferry said it was holding fares steady to "celebrate Ma Ying-jeou and Vincent Siew's election as president and vice president."
The ferry operators said they are increasing their ticket prices to deal with rising operating costs resulting from surging fuel prices.
They also noted that with the recent appreciation of the Chinese yuan, ticket prices on Chinese-operated ferries are now equivalent to about NT$650 for a one- way trip.

The "mini three links" refers to direct postal, transportation and trade links between the Chinese cities of Xiamn, Mawei and Quanzhou in Fujian province and the Taiwan-controlled islands of Kinmen and Matsu that lie just off the Chinese coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady of Panama thanks Taiwan for social welfare aid
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 15 (CNA) 04/16/08 16:45:45 (By Ramon Huang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Panama's first lady Vivian Fernandez de Torrijos extended her gratitude Tuesday to Taiwan for its contributions to several social welfare programs in Panama, including the construction of elementary schools and water conduits.

The Panamanian first lady expressed her thanks at a ceremony at the Presidential Office during which Republic of China Ambassador Hou Ping-fu pledged funding for the projects on behalf of the ROC government.
Hou noted that the projects, which also include the construction of highways and the expansion of a football stadium, are all examples of bilateral cooperation.

Once the highways are completed, Hou said, the agricultural produce grown in rural villages can be easily transported and sold in urban areas, while the hospital that Taiwan promised to help build in eastern Panama Province will greatly benefit the poor in that area.

According to the first lady, President Martin Torrijos will have constructed 108 elementary schools in rural areas before he steps down in August next year, which have improved significantly the level of education in poorer regions.

As to the football stadium Rommel Fernandez in Panama City, which Taiwan has helped to expand, First Vice President Samuel Lewis said that it will be able to accommodate some 40,000 people, double the original 20,000 capacity, once the construction work is completed and be suitable for international matches.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi: House tax to be abolished soon.
After winning the just concluded general elections, Italian former premier and leader of the center-right People of Liberty Party Silvio Berlusconi said that the abolition of house tax is ready and will be discussed in his future government's first Cabinet meeeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Railway companies gear up services for Bocelli concert

TEXT.P: Both the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) and Taiwan High Speed Rail (THSR) announced Wednesday that they will provide special train services between Taipei and Taichung April 19 to serve Taipei fans of Italian tenor Andrea Bocelli, who is set to perform in Taichung that evening.

The TRA will run an additional two express trains on the afternoon prior to the concert -- departing from the Taipei Railway Station at 3:08 p.m. and 3:40 p.m., respectively for Taichung -- and returning from the central city to Taipei after the concert from 11:21 p.m. and 11:40 p.m., a TRA official said.
The concert, which will be staged in the Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium in Taichung City, some 150 km south of Taipei, will be Bocelli's first in Taiwan.
The TRA decided to offer the special services as half of the concert tickets have been bought in Taipei, the TRA official said.

Meanwhile, the THSR will offer a special train Saturday night -- departing at 11 p.m. from Taichung for Taipei, with open-seat economy-class tickets available for all passengers at 80 percent of the original price, THSR officials said.
Passengers can book TRA or THSR train tickets online or at the Taipei Railway Station.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post:Democrats Willing to Let Battle Continue
Sen. Barack Obama holds a 10-point lead over Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton when Democrats are asked whom they would prefer to see emerge as the party's presidential nominee, but there is little public pressure to bring the long and increasingly heated contest to an end, according to a new Washington Post-ABC News poll.
The Washington Times:Pope 'ashamed' of sex scandal
Pope Benedict XVI commanded the American stage for the first time yesterday, welcomed by thunderous cheers and a rare presidential airport greeting after declaring that he was "deeply ashamed" by the sex-abuse scandal that rocked the church. The pontiff vowed to do all he can to ensure that priests never harm children again.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Big Tax Breaks for Businesses in Housing Bill
The Senate proclaimed a fierce bipartisan resolve two weeks ago to help American homeowners in danger of foreclosure. But while a bill that senators approved last week would take modest steps toward that goal, it would also provide billions of dollars in tax breaksX for automakers, airlines, alternative energy producers and other struggling industries, as well as home builders.
The Wall Street Journal: Merrill Upped Ante as Boom In Mortgage Bonds Fizzled
Some 10 months after the mortgage hurricane made landfall, Merrill Lynch & Co. is still trying to dig out.
On Thursday Merrill will report $6 billion to $8 billion in new write-downs, according to a person familiar with the matter. The latest would bring its total since October to more than $30 billion and mean that Merrill reports a third straight quarterly net loss, the longest losing streak in its 94-year history.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature demands inter-party talks are recorded

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed Wednesday the first reading of a draft amendment demanding that the whole course of any closed-door inter-party negotiations within the legislature be video- and audio-recorded, and archived.
The amendment was proposed to prevent possible under-the-table deals during inter-party negotiations, said Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the opposition Kuomintang, who put forth the amendment bill.
Under the existing law governing the Legislative Yuan's operations, inter- party negotiations at the legislature take place in private, with only the conclusion required to be gazetted.

Ting argued that it is common for proposals adopted at special legislative committee meetings to be revised or overthrown in closed-door inter-party talks. As the public has no way of knowing how or why the changes are made, they often suspect that is the result of inter-party horse-trading, he said.
To facilitate legislative efficiency, the draft bill also requests a shortening of the term of inter-party negotiations on a controversial bill from four months to one month.
Ting's proposal won the support of Legislator Wong Chin-chu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the draft bill will now be sent for review by the plenary session.

DPP legislative caucus whip William Lai said the party, which only controls 27 of the 113 seats at the legislature, is delighted to see the bill adopted, which is part of efforts to push for more openness and transparency in legislative operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Singapore's new home-grown legal team.
A new generation of leaders is taking the helm in the legal field, and they have one thing in common: they went to the law school here. They are: incoming Law Minister K. Shanmugam, Chief Justice Chan Sek Keong, Attorney-General Walter Woon and Solicitor- General Koh Kuat Jong.
The Lianhe Zaobao: ISD opens detention center's mystery.
The Internal Security Department (ISD) provided operation way of the Whitley Road Detention Center to Lianhe Zaobao first time, and this detention center is not running like other prisons and detention centres because it is for political prisoners' detention, intelligence sets asked and ideological transformation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.011 to close at NT$30.255.
A total of US$1.04 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.296 and fluctuated between NT$30.230 and NT$30.297.

DOC.HEADLINE: New stands of rare trees found in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Two more groves of a rare endemic beech tree species, known as Fagus hayatae, were found in the northern part of the island, a natural resources professor has said.
The new stands of the relic-like trees were discovered in Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan at the lowest altitude recorded on the island of the plant species.

One of the two stands was discovered on a 34-hectare area in the mountainous Dabaishan area, at an altitude of 1,369 meters, while the other was found in the mountainous Lancan area at 1,477 meters, occupying an area of 0. 34 hectares, said Chen. Previous to the latest discovery, the trees had only been found in Taiwan at altitudes of about 1,900 meters.

According to Chen Tze-ying, professor of the Department of National Resources of the I-Lan University, who discovered the forest in October 2006, the rare plants can be traced back to the glacial age.

The Fagus hayatae was first found in Taiwan in 1906 in Taipei County by Japanese botanist Nariaki Konishi, and since 1992 has been listed in the Cultural Heritage Preservation Law as a rare and precious plant.

"By observing these beeches, we can see the effects of the global warming, " said Chen, adding that the trees were originally found at low altitudes during the last glacial period in Taiwan -- about 15,000-20,000 years ago-- but with the rise in global temperatures due to climate change, the species was later found only in high-altitude areas.
"If global warming continues, several groves of the beech trees in Taiwan, which are already on the mountaintops, will have no more room for retreat, " Chen warned.
He noted that the biggest beech forest in the Tongshan areas in Yilan County, which occupies 1,154 hectares, is under the threat.
In order to protect the rare tree species, the Forestry Bureau launched a three- year plan aimed at monitoring the biological diversity in beech forests and preserving their genes.

Asked how extinction of the beeches on th island could be prevented, Chen said that "designating forest reserves is only one of ways -- the best solution, of course, is to slow down the effects of global warming."

The 12 existing species of beeches worldwide are usually found in temperate zones in the Northern Hemisphere -- Taiwan is at present the southernmost habitat of the plant, a Forestry Bureau official said.
A relic-like plant does not evolve, as most organisms do, with environmental change over tens of million of years -- it moves to a more hospitable environment when its habitat changes.
The Forestry Bureau has made a beech pathway in the mountainous Taipingshan areas in Yilan county, from which people can view the beech forest.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmental group launches coastal cleanup movement for Earth Day

TEXT.P: To mark the approach of Earth Day on April 22, the Society of Wilderness (SOW) , a local environmental group, launched a coastal cleanup movement nationwide Wednesday, urging people to take better care of Taiwan's polluted beaches.

Of Taiwan's 1,316 km of coastline, about 724 km, or 55 percent, are occupied by breakwaters, cement dikes or harbors, while the remainder is polluted to varying degrees, SOW Secretary-General Shi Chun-rong warned at a press conference.
The SOW called for people to join the organization's eight branches on a cleanup of 13 areas of coastline and beaches April 20, he added.

"But the cleanup movement alone is not enough; finding ways to reduce man-made waste and leave nothing on the beaches are the real solutions, " said Zheng Ming-xiu, a scholar of the Research Center for Biodiversity at Academia Sinica.
Zheng also urged the public and the government to re-examine the policy on coastal construction such as harbors and breakwaters, which he said are excessive.
According to the SOW, Taiwan has about 240 harbors, amounting to a harbor every six kilometers on average.

"We have to change the deep-rooted concept that `man's determination will conquer nature, '" he said, adding that breakwaters, for example, destroy not only the natural coastline, but also the ecological system.
He noted as an example the finding that crabs living among breakwaters rather than along natural coastlines lose their ability to reproduce.

Earth Day was initiated in the United States in the 1970s with the aim of enhancing awareness of environmental protection. It became an international event in 1990 with the participation of 141 countries worldwide, including Taiwan

DOC.HEADLINE: Cakes with too much trans-fats endanger health: officials

TEXT.P: Cakes containing excessive amounts of trans fatty acids (TFAs) pose a health risk to the public, officials warned Wednesday amid increasing cake purchases in celebration of Mother's Day, which falls on the second Sunday of May -- May 11 this year.

According to Lin Hsiu-lian, deputy commissioner of the Department of Health (DOH) under the Taipei city government, TFAs are unsaturated fats with trans- isomer fatty acids that are manufactured by partially hydrogenating plant oils.

Noting that consumption of TFAs increases the risk of coronary disease, Liu said at an event promoting healthy diets for Mother's Day that "the DOH would like to recommend high quality bakeries to consumers."

The event, which attracted the participation of officials and bakeries from the Taipei area, was organized by the DOH and the Taipei Bakery Association (TBA) with the purpose of not only promoting healthy cakes but also showcasing the creativity of Taiwanese bakers.

"Mothers should enjoy cakes that are healthy and TFA-free, " Lin said, adding that "the public can purchase cakes that meet TFA safety standards from bakeries displaying an "OK" sign designed by the DOH."

Following the suit of the European Union and the United States, both of which regulate the use of TFA, Chiang Yu-mei, chief of the DOH's Food and Drug Division, said that "since 2008, Taiwan has also requested that bakeries limit the amount of TFA used in cakes to less than 2 percent."
Chiang further expressed hope that the bakeries, as well as consumers, can both better understand the drawbacks of excessive consumption of TFAs through the event.

Ellen Yin, chairman of the TBA, said that cakes made in Taiwan are very creative with fantastic presentation and a fusion of European, Japanese and U.S. flavors, adding that "choosing a good cake for mother is essential."

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Labour is warned of May Day humiliation in the local elections Labour is heading for its worst results in local elections for 30 years and could be forced into third place on May 1, local government experts predicted yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC express regret over news reports on simulated war games

TEXT.P: The National Security Council (NSC) on Wednesday described as regrettable reports that alleged this year's computerized warfare simulation revolves around a scenario of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou being assassinated before his May 20 inauguration.
NSC officials said the reports by "Next" weekly magazine were "regrettable, " and "irresponsible," adding that they were "distorted because they were politically-motivated."

The reports stated that the war games simulated a situation in which Taiwan was thrown into turmoil after Ma's assassination and the Chinese government took the opportunity to launch a blitz attack on Taiwan.
This year's war games are actually simulating a senario of China acquiring its first aircraft carrier in 2020 and launching an all-out attack from off the east coast of Taiwan, the officials said.
The officials said the war games are aimed at strengthening the capacity of government agencies to deal with military crises and the ability to protect the nation's infrastructure in a crisis.
The simulation exercise is also aimed at testing decision-making among the heads of relevant government agencies and verifying mechanisms for dealing with crises, and related plans, they added.

The officials said that this year's war games, scheduled for April 25-27, will be held in three stages -- the first stage being a drill to open command centers to station personnel, the second a drill to protect the nation's infrastructure, and the third computerized war games.

Meanwhile, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus said Wednesday that the media has "stretched its imagination too far" by reporting on Ma's assassination as the war games scenario.
DPP Legislator Tsai Huang-liang said that it is not appropriate for the media to issue false reports that could cause public unease.

Tsai's colleague Kuan Pi-ling called for Ma to take part in the war games, saying that Ma's team had already contacted a transitional team assigned by President Chen Shui-bian, and that Ma's absence from this year's war games was "irresponsible."
Ma declined an invitation last week to observe the computer war games, citing the reason of a "tight schedule."
A spokesman for Ma's office declined Wednesday to comment on the magazine's reports, saying it is the Presidential Office that should elaborate on the matter.

Vice President Annette Lu called for Ma to attend the war games Wednesday, urging that the nation's affairs, especially national security, should be run without interruption as the two political parties prepare to make the transition.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect promises to continue cooperation projects with allies

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that his incoming government will continue all the existing cooperation projects that the current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration has signed with the country's diplomatic allies.
Ma made the assurance during a tea gathering with 18 ambassadors and representatives of Taiwan's diplomatic allies at a hotel in Taipei. The country now maintains diplomatic ties with 23 countries.

Greeting his guests with English, Spanish and French at the beginning of the meeting, Ma told these foreign diplomats that he has invited diplomatic allies to send representatives to attend his inauguration on May 20, with most of them responding by promising to send high-level delegations, for which Ma said he was grateful.

Noting that the transfer of power only changes the government, and not the country, Ma said he will continue all the existing cooperation projects with Taiwan's diplomatic allies to share with them Taiwan's experiences in economic development and to strengthen bilateral ties in diverse fields.

Ma, who has visited several of Taiwan's diplomatic allies, including Panama, Guatemala, Honduras and the Solomon Island, expressed hope that ties between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies can thrive forever, and welcomed its allies to invest in Taiwan.

Ma was elected president of the Republic of China on the March 22 presidential election, after wining 58.45 percent of the 13.1 million votes cast, defeating his rival Frank Hsieh from the ruling DPP by a margin of 17 percent, or 2.21 million votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Leading food maker recalls milk allegedly from diseased cows

TEXT.P: Taiwan's leading food manufacturer, AGV Products Corp., decided Wednesday to recall two brands of fresh milk that it markets, in the wake of a report that the products are contaminated by milk from diseased cows.
The affected brands are Highland and Ching Chun, both of which are processed by an AGV-contracted dairy operated by the Miaoli County Farmers' Association.

According to an investigative report published that day by Apple Daily, one of the plant's suppliers in Yunlin County has provided it with diseased milk that was collected from neighboring dairy farms. Such milk -- which refers to milk produced by cows during and immediately after the period when they are receiving medication -- is forbidden to be processed for human consumption.

The report said the milk, which was bought at a low price of approximately NT$8 per kilogram, was sold to the dairy at NT$18 per kilogram, bringing in profits estimated at NT$1 million per month to the unscrupulous supplier.

AGV said in a statement that it will investigate the extent of the dairy's responsibility and pointed out that according to the terms of their contract, the dairy is responsible for ensuring the quality of the ingredients used in production.
However, officials at the Miaoli County Farmers' Association dismissed the Apple Daily report as totally false.
The officials said the milk is required to undergo drug residue screening tests upon delivery to the dairy, which includes tests for tetracycline, penicillin, sulfonamides and chloramphenicol.
Any milk detected with traces of these antibiotics is immediately rejected, they said.

In light of the wide attention the incident has drawn, the Yunlin District Prosecutors Office later that same day raided the dairy farm that allegedly sold the diseased milk and seized 4,000 kg of milk for testing.
Also Wednesday, the Miaoli county health and agricultural authorities visited the dairy to collect milk products for testing.
Chen Chi-ying, chief of the county's Animal Health Inspection and Quarantine Institute, noted that there are 25 dairy farms with a combined total of 2,000 head in the county.
Of the total of 175 milk samples tested by the institute last year, none were found to contain traces of antibiotics, Chen said.

Meanwhile, Consumers' Foundation Chairman Cheng Jen-hung called on AGV to provide free health examinations and other remedial measures to consumers who might have consumed the questionable milk and said that any consumers who feel physically uncomfortable after consuming the products can ask the foundation to help seek compensation from AGV.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor reiterates intention to remain in city government

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu reiterated Wednesday his intention to remain in his current post, amid reports of an offer to serve as secretary-general in the office of the incoming president, Ma Ying-jeou.

There has been wide speculation that Hu, whose local administration in the central Taiwan city won a four-star public rating in a poll conducted by the Taipei-based Global Views Monthly Magazine in 2007, has been tapped for the post of presidential secretary-general when Ma takes office.

Citing Hu, Deputy Taichung Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi reiterated that no one from Ma's camp had directly made such an offer to the mayor, and that Hu had not changed his mind about wanting to remain in his current post to fulfill the promises he made to Taichung residents in his 2005 re-election campaign.
Hu's second mayoral term will end in December 2009 after which he would be ineligible to run for the position again.
In the 2007 survey, Hu was evaluated as having the cleanest image among the 23 local government chiefs in Taiwan, and a spotless anti-corruption record.

Hu, born in 1948, holds a doctoral degree in International Relations from Oxford University in Britain. He has served as head of the Government Information Office, as an envoy at Taiwan's representative office in Washington, United States, and as minister of foreign affairs under the previous Kuomintang government. He was first elected as Taichung mayor in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese restaurant chain to open 50 new eateries

TEXT.P: The owner of the only Taiwanese outlet of a popular Chinese hot pot restaurant chain announced Wednesday an ambitious plan to open 50 new restaurants here over the next three years, in anticipation of an influx of Chinese tourists promised by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou.

Tony Huang, owner of the only Little Sheep restaurant that currently exists in Taiwan, told a news conference that the chain intends to open restaurants throughout Taiwan, with the aim not only of introducing typical Mongolian hot pot cuisine to locals but also of catering to the taste buds of an increasing number of Chinese visitors.
Huang predicted that the sluggish economy in Taiwan during the past few years will be revitalized soon and that cross-strait exchanges between mainland China and Taiwan are expected to increase.

"Opening more chain restaurants will give rise to greater competitiveness for our restaurant, " Huang told CNA on the sidelines of the news conference. "Through this expansion, we also hope to set up a model for other chain restaurants from China that want to invest in Taiwan."

Ma, slated to take office on May 20, has pledged to allow more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan, raising the hopes of the Taiwanese restaurant industry for a higher volume of visitors from mainland China and their attendant consumption of Taiwanese goods and services.

The Little Sheep chain -- known in Chinese as the Xiao Fei Yang chain -- specializes in lamb hot pot, serving up plates of thinly sliced raw lamb strips that are dunked into pots of boiling broth and cook within seconds. The meat, which can be substituted with beef, chicken, fish and vegetables, is then dipped in various sauces.
Speaking at the press conference, Yu-fu, a host of TV food programs, said that opening more Chinese chain restaurants will "help upgrade the diversity of cuisine found in Taiwan."
However, Huang said the chain, which is popular in mainland China, has seen a lot of copycats in Taiwan, which use almost identical trademarks.
To deal with the problem, Huang said, he will launch a campaign to battle piracy and safeguard the rights of both Little Sheep and its customers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Industry group urges Cabinet to handle price-rise issue

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) urged the Cabinet Wednesday to guide Taiwan through the challenge of continuing price hikes of raw materials in the international market.

As the impact of rising prices has continued to increase, CNFI Chairman Chen Wu- hsiung urged the outgoing Democratic Progressive Party government not to leave the problem to the Kuomintang administration that will take office following President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's May 20 inauguration.

According to Chen, if the issue is left until after May 20, "it will be too late" to handle the problem that he described as posing a far greater threat to Taiwan than the first and second crude oil price crises of the 1970s and 1980s.

At a press conference held by the CNFI, Chen pointed out that not only have international oil prices been increasing steadily, but prices of rice, wheat, soy beans, corn, steel rebar, cement, gravel and various petrochemical raw materials have also continued to rise unabated.
The CNFI urged the government to take measures that include lowering the business tax on petroleum products, prohibiting exports of vital materials and expanding imported raw material sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: More gene mutation found related to Parkinsonism in Han Chinese

TEXT.P: An international cooperative project has spotted a Parkinsonism-related gene mutation that only develops in Han Chinese, and these who carry this mutation are twice more likely to develop Parkinson's disease.

The mutation, known as R1628P is found in gene LRRK2 which codes for protein Leucine-rich repeat kinase 2, according to a paper produced from the project partially funded by the cabinet-level National Science Council and published in the science journal, Annals of Neurology.
Parkinsonism, also known as Parkinson syndrome, is a degenerative disorder of the central nervous system that often impairs the patient's speech and movement.

The group of experts from Taiwan, Singapore, Japan and the United States has already reported other Parkinsonism-related mutations linked to LRRK2 and has found correlations between different ethnic groups and individual mutations.
For example, the experts found that LRRK2-G2019S is a common cause of Parkinsonism among Berber Arabs and Ashkenazi Jews.
In 2004, the group reported that a mutation, G2385R in LRRK2, was linked to Parkinsonism in Asians, especially Han Chinese.
Individuals carrying the mutation were more than twice more likely to develop the disease than non-carriers, it was reported.
The LRRK2-G2385R mutation does not appear to play a role in Parkinson's disease within other racial groups, according to the research results published in 2005.
Their analysis concluded that the G2385R mutation occurred approximately 4,800 years ago, corresponding with the rise of Chinese civilization.
The study of LRRK2-G2385R is mainly conducted by subgroups of the project based in National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) in Taipei and the Mayo Clinic in Jacksonville, Florida.

On the newly found R1628P, Wu Ruey-meei, director of NTUH's Center for Parkinsonism and Movement Disorder and a participant in the study, noted that LRRK2-R1628P mutation could also double the risk of Han Chinese developing Parkinson's syndrome. However, Japanese, who were also a target group in the research of 2007-2008, showed no indication for such a mutation, he said.
The incidence rate of R1628P mutation is estimated to be three in 100 among Han Chinese, Wu said, adding that this mutation might be have been passed down some 2,500 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Randonneurs Taiwan's 200-km endurance cycling to take place April 19
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/08 20:22:34 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Some 250 cyclists will take part in a 200-km ride in Taiwan's southernmost county of Pintung April 19 in the spirit of challenging their own physical limits and trying to go farther and farther on a single ride.
The non-competitive event is being held by Randonneurs Taiwan and the Taiwan Super Triathlon Association.

Cyclists will set off at 6 a.m. from the visitors' center of the Dapeng Bay National Scenic Area and ride along a scenic route all the way to Eluanbi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, before returning via a much different route to finish at the visitors' center.
Riders who complete the course within 13 hours 30 minutes will receive a Randonneurs pin and will qualify to participate in the next level of the event.
Randonneur cycling originated in France in the 1890s. The sport has become popular in other parts of the world, including Italy, the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada and Asian countries.

There are two kinds of rides in a randonneurs event: brevets and populaires. A populaire is intended to introduce new riders to the club. In a brevet, a French word meaning suffering, cyclists follow a set route in their desired distance, moving up to longer rides.
A rider must complete the four races in the basic series -- 200 km, 300 km, 400 km, and 600 km -- in order to qualify for the 1,200-km Paris-Brest-Paris race, which takes place every four years.

The 1,200-km Paris event, a grueling test of human endurance and cycling ability, begins on the southern side of the French capital, travels 600 kilometers west to the port city of Brest on the Atlantic Ocean and returns along the same route.

Randonneurs gain international recognition from Audax Club Parisien, creator of the sport, by riding 5,000 km in official randonneur events within four years. The 1,200 km Paris-Brest-Paris is one of the most prestigious rides that must be completed to fulfill the requirements for the 5,000 km award.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's technology exports not sufficient: academic

TEXT.P: Taiwan's technology exports are not sufficient, with the value amounting to only about a quarter of the island's technology imports, the head of the nation's highest academic research institute said Wednesday.
Academia Sinica President Chi-Huey Wong made the remarks when he reported on technology transfer records in recent years to a legislative committee.

Legislator Kuan Pi-ling from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said the value of Taiwan's technology exports only amounts to several billions of Taiwan dollars a year although the value of imports reaches NT$40 billion, showing that "exports are only one quarter of the imports."
She said that in technologically advanced countries such as the United States and Britain, technology exports could be as high as two folds of imports of technological products.

Taiwan is not even on par with South Korea, Kuan said, noting that technology exports are between 23 percent and 25 percent of its imports in South Korea, while in Taiwan, the ratio is usually between 13 percent and 17 percent.
"Taiwan's performance is indeed not satisfying," Wong admitted.

In terms of patents, Wong said that Academia Sinica has applied for 598 patents at home and overseas over the past nine years, and acquired 207 patents, among them 108 were acquired from the United States, especially in the areas of biotechnology and new drugs.

Wong also noted that Academia Sinica has signed 321 agreements with domestic and foreign companies since early this year to transfer technology, but whether the companies can successfully develop products after the technology transfers will largely depend on the relations between the inventors, research institutes and the industries.

Wong suggested an amendment to the Civil Servant Service Act, noting that many civil servants are barred from serving the posts of advisers, directors and supervisors of companies under the law, so that there is still a gap between research and the development of a product.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity calls for 'one-day salary' donation for children's safety

TEXT.P: A foundation devoted to improving children's safety Wednesday invited the public to donate at least one day's salary to help children injured in accidents, as part of Taiwan's first National Children's Safety Day.
The Jing Chuan Child Safety Foundation said money raised will be used by the non-profit group to help enhance its ability to provide aftermath care to children injured in accidents.

According to Lin Yue-chin, the foundation's chief executive officer, accidents are the main cause of death for children in both Taiwan and in the world. Every year, around 300,000 children in Taiwan are injured or killed in accidents which happen in many places, including at home, on roads, in classrooms, and on playgrounds.

The foundation provides aftermath care because many families do not know how to deal with children's injuries. They need to know how to respond to injuries with proper medical treatment as well as a healthy mental state, Lin said, adding that families also should know how to protect themselves through the legal process.
"Hopefully the donation will allow us to set up a center to integrate resources in providing better aftermath care to injured children and their families, " Lin told a CNA reporter.

Half of the donations will be used to integrate current resources of aftermath care for children hurt in accidents. The care includes medical counselling, psychologic counselling, legal counselling, and support for parents who undergo self-blame and social condemnation, Lin said.
The other half of the donations will be used to sponsor the foundation's work in preventing children's accidents, Lin added.
This year's donation amount is projected to reach NT$10 million (US$328,950), Lin said.

Taiwan's government has designated May 15 as National Children's Safety Day in memory of Lin Jing-chuan, a Taipei City kindergarten teacher who died in a school bus fire while trying to rescue children in her care May 15, 1992.
The foundation was established one year after the accident in the hope of raising awareness from the public and the government about providing a safer environment for children.

Lin said that designating a special day to highlight the importance of children's safety is a consolation for families of those who died in the accident as it increases people's awareness of child safety.
According to Lin, officials at both the central and local governments, as well as their friends and families, have donated to the fundraising drive after it was officially launched in April.
The whole police staff at Taoyuan County's Gueishan division in northern Taiwan even actively made donations before the drive's official launch, Lin said.
Lin pointed out that MasterLink Securities Corp. Chairman Wang Pei-chih, and Scania Taiwan, a large vehicle manufacturer, have made donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Salvadoran ambassador foresees no change in Taiwan's foreign policy

TEXT.P: El Salvador Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana said Wednesday that he does not think Taiwan's foreign policy will change with the election of Ma Ying-jeou as the country's new president.
Santana made the remarks after attending a tea party organized by Ma for ambassadors and representatives of Taiwan's diplomatic allies.

According to Ma's spokesman Lo Chih-chiang, ambassadors and representatives of 18 of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies attended the gathering, the first formal contact between the diplomatic corps in Taiwan and Ma since he was elected on March 22.

During the meeting, Ma assured the foreign diplomats that he will continue all the cooperation projects that the current Democratic Progressive Party administration signed with Taiwan's diplomatic allies, and he invited the allies to send representatives to attend his inauguration on May 20.
In addition to promising continued support for Taiwan's bid to enter international organizations, several foreign diplomats also invited Ma to visit their respective countries after he takes office.

Asked by journalists whether he saw any difference between the foreign policies of President Chen Shui-bian and Ma, Santana said it is natural that two leaders would have different working styles. However, he said he foresees no fundamental change in Taiwan's foreign policy under a new leader.

Regarding reports that Ma was planning to economize on his inauguration ceremony and had thus decided that visiting foreign leaders would not be accommodated in presidential suites, Santana said he and other diplomats do not think such an arrangement would be a discourtesy or an inconvenience to the foreign dignitaries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sony includes Taiwan in its green partner program

TEXT.P: Sony Taiwan signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) Wednesday to include Taiwan in its program to encourage the production of eco-friendly electronic products, with the program expected to help local high-tech manufacturers boost their business by being considered top global green-product suppliers.

The Taiwan branch of the Japanese electronic giant signed the agreement with the Taiwan Green Environmental Partner (TGEP) Promotion Center, which will create a certification system to help local electronic component makers meet Sony's Green Partner Standards (GP).
Once they obtain the certificate, Taiwanese manufacturers will be considered high-quality, eco-friendly electronics makers -- a status that is expected to help them gain more production orders.
In order to qualify for the certificate, manufacturers must meet Sony's set of standards, which involves limiting the amount of toxic substances used to make the products.

"By jointly establishing a system controlling the products' toxic chemicals while enhancing production capacity, Sony will help Taiwan's industry to boost its business in the global green industry market, " said Itoh Masashi, Sony's General Manager of Supplier Relations Department of its Procurement Center.

Citing the rising global awareness of the importance of using eco-friendly electronic products, Itoh, who was speaking at a news conference of the signing, indicated that companies which meet Sony's standards can obtain business orders from the Japanese electronics giant and expand their clients around the world.
The agreement was signed days after Sony president Ryoji Chubachi made a commitment to increase procurement and investment in Taiwan during a meeting with President-elect Ma Ying-jeou.

Asked whether the MOU is part of Sony's future procurement plan for Taiwan, Sony Taiwan's Chairman Kenji Sakai did not give a direct answer, saying only that an upgraded Taiwanese green industry would naturally receive more procurement from Sony.
"The GP program will compose a win-win situation for both Sony and Taiwan industries," Sakai said.
The TGEP center, which signed the agreement with Sony, is run by two local organizations -- the Institute for Information Industry and the Corporate Synergy Development Center.
Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), which sponsored the TGEP center, welcomed Sony's plan, pointing out the potential boost in production value for local companies.

"The MOEA expects NT$3 billion (US$98 million) in production value from 400 local manufacturers applying for the program this year, " said Lo Ta-sheng, a section chief of the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau.
Lo added that the ministry will push Taiwanese electronics makers to meet Sony's standards and obtain the certificate before the end of 2008.

With the certificate, which will help Taiwan's electronic makers qualify as global makers of green products, Taiwan's industry could access a market that reaches US$81.2 billion per year, according to Lo.
"Taiwan's industry would expand its edge over other electronic suppliers of the world," Lo noted.

The project could allow more local makers to enter the global supplier chain by assisting them to meet the green product standards in developed countries, including the U.S., Japan and European countries, Lo added.
Sony recorded consolidated annual sales of approximately US$70.3 billion for the fiscal year that ended March 31, 2007. The company employs 163,000 people worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan donates aerators to Salvadoran fishermen
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/08 21:19:15 (By Ramon Huang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has donated to Salvadoran fishermen 50 paddle wheel aerators, which increase the oxygen level in water, with the aim of helping to improve the production of mouthbreeder fish, Taiwan's Ambassador to El Salvador Carlos Liao told a CNA reporter Wednesday.
Taiwan's agricultural aid team began to provide technical assistance to the central American ally in 1999, and has since helped Salvadoran fishermen to increase fish production volume.

El Salvador now has an annual production of 1,200 tons of mouthbreeder fish, which is 25 times the 2000 figure, Liao said, adding that the donation of aerators will now help to improve production quality.

Officials at Taiwan's embassy in El Salvador and Salvadoran officials exchanged views Tuesday on the progress of a Taiwan-sponsored project on the early examination and treatment of newborns with congenital diseases such as hypothyroidism -- reduced levels of thyroid hormone -- Liao said.

El Salvador's public hospitals do not have the techniques or service to offer such treatment, and charges at private hospitals are too high for the poor, Liao said. He expressed the hope that the health project will give more of a chance to babies with congenital diseases born to poor families.

Liao also presented a donation Wednesday to the Regional Organization for Plant Protection and Animal Health based in El Salvador to help facilitate the integration of fishing and aquaculture in central America.
The integration project was officially launched by Taiwan's embassy in El Salvador and the organization April 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investigation bureau burns 285 kg of illegal drugs

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice destroyed over 285 kilograms of illicit drugs Wednesday, the bulk of which was heroine.

According to a press release issued by the bureau later the same day, 257 of the 285 kilograms of illegal drugs seized by investigation bureau agents in raids over the past year was heroin, with the reset being mainly amphetamines and ketamine.
It is clear that those three types of narcotics were the most heavily abused illegal drugs in Taiwan, the bureau said, pointing out that they also topped on the list in the three previous years.

To ensure that all the confiscated illegal drugs were taken to the incinerator in Mucha, suburban Taipei, the substances were transported to the site in armored cash carrier vehicles, with tight air and ground escort all the way, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung County chief welcomes Chinese tourists, investment

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing said Wednesday he would welcome Chinese investment and tourists to his county, but fretted about possible speculation in the local housing sector.

Yang, a senior member of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), made the comments to reporters while talking about a planned wider opening to China by the incoming government of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou from the DPP's rival party, the Kuomintang (KMT). Ma will assume the presidency May 20.
He has pledged to build closer economic and trade links with China by easing Taiwan investment in China while also allowing Chinese investment in Taiwan.

Vice President-elect Vincent Siew also has advocated establishing a cross-Taiwan Strait common market and helping Taiwanese farmers, mostly in central and southern regions, sell their produce to China.
Yang said he is particularly keen on attracting Chinese investment in tourism- related businesses, such as hotels and resort facilities.

According to the Kaohsiung County magistrate, the county could use Chinese capital for a five-star hotel contained in a project to construct a resort island on a 240-hectare plot of reclaimed land in Yungan township.
Yang said the Kaohsiung county government is currently seeking private investment to jointly develop the resort island, adding that Chinese capital is also welcome.
However, he expressed concerns that some Chinese property investors might enter the Taiwanese market merely to speculate.
Yang added that he is not in favor of exporting Taiwan's fruits to China out of grave concern over rampant counterfeit and piracy in the Chinese market.

He argued that Taiwan's fruit exporters should focus their sights on the Japanese, South Korean and Hong Kong markets, which have a great interest in Taiwan's vegetables and fruits and offer better protection for industry expertise.

Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan has long been a stronghold of the pro- independence DPP. The DPP presidential ticket scored more ballots than the KMT's Ma-Siew ticket in the southern Taiwan county during the March 22 presidential election, despite the KMT's big gains in most of the other constituencies. enditem/cs
But he expressed opposition to Chinese capital speculating in the housing market out of fears that it would push up private house prices beyond local residents' means.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmental groups want timetable for greenhouse gas reduction

TEXT.P: Three environmental activist groups in Taiwan expressed their opposition Wednesday to the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Bill being deliberated in the legislature, on grounds that the legislation provides no target or timetable for its implementation.

At a joint press conference held in front of the Legislative Yuan, the Green Party Taiwan, the Green Citizens' Action Alliance and the Taiwan Environmental Action Network urged the legislature not to pass the bill.
They made their positions known after the legislature's Sanitation, Environment and Labor Committee met a day earlier to deliberate on the language of the bill.

The executives of the three civic organizations contended that the nation is now in a period of confusion right before the transition of power from the outgoing Democratic Progressive Party government to the Kuomintang, and that it is an inappropriate time to consider the draft bill submitted by the incumbent Cabinet.

Pan Han-chiang, secretary-general of the Taiwan Environmental Action Network, noted that the current version of the bill is similar to the one introduced in May last year, except that the current version has deleted the clauses committing to an overall reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, as well as reductions by individual sectors.

"The legislation can no longer be called a Greenhouse Gas Reduction Bill, " Pan said. "If a person wants to lose weight, the first step is to find out how much he weighs, and the next step is to set a target and timetable for losing weight."

Pan added that his organization and the other environmental groups are not happy with a proposal floated by some legislators that an article should be added to the draft bill to stipulate that Taiwan's carbon dioxide emission level should be maintained at the 2007 level.
"We hope Taiwan's greenhouse gas emissions would be reduced to the 1990 level," he said.

Pan urged the legislature to shelve the bill and re-examine the issue carefully and, at the same time, to prepare a supplementary law and regulations to encourage the development of renewable energy and to levy additional taxes on producers of carbon dioxide.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative committee demands postal company resume original name

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's transportation affairs committee approved Wednesday the 2008 budget plan for Taiwan Post Co. but on condition that the state-owned postal company change its name back to Chunghwa Post within six months.

The proviso was proposed by Legislator Chen Ken-te of the main opposition Kuomintang, who argued that the change of the company's name to "Taiwan Post" in February 2007 did not follow the due process of law.
The committee agreed on the six-month deadline so as to avoid politicizing the decision on the name change ahead of the handover of government on May 20, the lawmaker said.

The incumbent pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party government, in line with its "Taiwan identity" ideology, launched a movement last year to change the designation of state-run enterprises whose titles included the word "China" or "Chinese."
However, the change of the postal company's name triggered protests among its workers who denounced it as a politically expedient move.

Some detractors also argued that the removal of the word Chunghwa, which means China in Chinese, was problematic because an amendment to the law regulating postal operations had not been passed in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: Swedish couple adopts Taiwanese boy with congenital deformity

TEXT.P: A Swedish couple met for the first time Wednesday a two-year-old Taiwanese boy with congenital bone disease whom they have adopted, in the central county of Taichung.

The couple, known by the surname Nordholm, will remain in Taichung for two weeks to get to know Hauhau, as the child is called, before flying back to Sweden with him, said Pai Li-fang, supervisor of the Child Welfare League Foundation.
During this time, the foster parents who had been taking care of the abandoned boy, will have time to adjust to the idea of him leaving, Pai added.

Hauhau was found abandoned in the county's Shenkang township in September 2006, not long after he was born, and was diagnosed with congenital funnel chest, or pectus excavatum, which is caused when the breast bone is pushed abnormally inward, according to Pai.

She said it is more difficult to find homes for children like Hauhau who have deformities than for healthy children. Such children are usually adopted by foreigners if there are no local prospects, Pai added.
After an unsuccessful six-month search by Taichung County police for Hauhau's biological parents, he was made a legal ward of Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng and put into foster care.

The foster parents, known by the last name Li, did their best to take care of Hauhau, Pai said, adding that there were times when an ambulance siren was often heard between the Li's home and hospitals.
Hauhau's health is now stable, thanks to the care given by the Lis, and he will now likely be in the good hands, as his adoptive mother is in the medical profession, she said.
The Swedish couple said they are ready to welcome Hauhau as their first child after six years of longing for a baby.
Taichung County Deputy Magistrate Chang Chuang-hsi said he believed that Hauhau's future will be a happy one with the love of his new parents.

Chang said Taichung Count has an annual budget to help find future homes for abandoned children. He called on people who wish to adopt children to contact the Child Welfare League Foundation, which has regional offices around the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Angler struck by lightening might lose his manhood
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, eastern Taiwan, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/08 23:23:47 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: A man fishing on a rock on Green Island off the coast of eastern Taiwan suffered serious burns to his abdomen, groin and thighs when he was struck by lightening Wednesday.
Firemen on the island rushed Chen Ming-wen, 47, to the Taitung branch of Mackay Memorial Hospital, where he was treated for second degree burns.
Doctors said that although Chen was lucky to be alive, it is still unclear whether his sexual functions will be impaired.

The angler was having a good time fishing on the edge of a rock near a sea wall, with the blunt end of the fishing rod touching his abdomen, when a bolt of lightning struck him, causing burns to 20 percent of his body.
Fishing experts said Chen's fishing rod, made of carbon fiber, served as a conductor, causing him to be struck by the lightening bolt.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipower to phase out preferential billing of servicemen

TEXT.P: The state-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) will phase out preferential household electricity billing for military servicemen over a three-year period, Vice Economics Minister Hsieh Fa-ta said Wednesday.
Hsieh said that, starting next year, Taipower will start to cut preferential billing by one third for active servicemen and approved families of deceased servicemen.
"Taipower will scrap the preferential treatment by 2012, " Hsieh said.

He said that under an agreement between the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Ministry of National Defense (MND) , the MND will appropriate funds for electricity subsides to servicemen starting next year.
He said that the ministry has adopted the measures at the suggestion of the legislators, who said the move was a fair one and will help conserve energy.

The lawmakers noted that Taipower has had to appropriate NT$640 million (US$21.05 million) per year in subsidies for the preferential billing of servicemen, although the company is in the red because of soaring world fuel prices.

Moreover, because of the preferential treatment, military servicemen were found to have been using 20 percent more electricity than the average household, which the lawmakers said was "tantamount to encouraging waste."

Under the current preferential system, Taipower gives 50 percent discount for the consumption of less than 500 kilowatt/hour of electricity per month, 30 percent for between 501 kw/h and 1,000 kw/h, and charges full price for consumption of more than 1,000 kw/h.
Meanwhile, Taipower Chairman Edward Chen said Wednesday that if the company cannot raise electricity rates, its losses will increase.

Speaking at a meeting of a legislative committee that was reviewing Taipower's annual budget, Chen noted that the government has frozen fuel prices since late last year for fear of triggering inflationary pressure on consumer prices, despite soaring world crude oil prices.
He said that if the state-run petroleum company CPC Co. Taiwan maintains its gasoline price, then Taipower will lose between NT$130 billion and NT$150 billion a year.

But if CPC hikes its gasoline price and Taipower cannot raise its fees, then the power company's losses will amount to NT$200 billion annually, Chen said, adding that this could lead to Taipower gradually depleting its financial resources in 2009 and going bankrupt in 2010.

The question of when President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's incoming government, which has said that it would respect the market mechanism, will adjust the gasoline and electricity rates remains uncertain, Chen said. Ma will assume the presidency May 20.
If CPC raises its gasoline prices June 1, and Taipower could follow suit one month later, then Taipower "will have to raise electricity rates by 50 percent to break even this year," Chen said.

As such an increase could impact heavily on the daily lives of consumers, Chen said, he is suggesting a hike of 30 percent in the first stage, which would translate into an increase of NT$0.65 to NT$2.8 from an average of NT$2.15 per kilowatt/hour last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Thursday.

The weighted price index was up 119.54 points at 9,185.58 on a turnover of NT$10.88 billion (US$359.6 million) at the open. The index gained 141.26 points, or 1.58 percent, to close at 9,066.04 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Thursday.
The greenback was trading at NT$30.220 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.035 from Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history \
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 17, or the 12th day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1421: More than 100,000 people drown when the sea breaks through a dike in Dort, Holland.
1790: American public official, writer, scientist, and printer Benjamin Franklin dies at the age of 84. He played a major part in the American Revolution, negotiated French support for the colonies, signed the Treaty of Paris and helped draft the US Constitution.
1824: The United States and Russia define respective rights in the Pacific Ocean and on the northwest coast of America.
1894: Nikita S. Krushchev, Soviet politician, is born. As Soviet leader he denounced Stalin and thwarted the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. He was deposed in 1964 for his failure to improve the Soviet economy.
1895: The Treaty of Shimonoseki is signed, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaoning Peninsula, Taiwan and the Pescadores to Japan.
1897: During a revolt in Ottoman-held Crete, war breaks out between Greece and the Ottoman Empire.
1906: A Pacific cable between China and the United States is completed.
1938: Chang Kuo-dao, governor of the Chinese communist government that controls the region comprising Shensi, Kansu and Ningsia issues a statement in Hankou distancing himself from the Chinese Communist Party.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt approves initial military aid US$45 million for China.
1946: Communist troops enter Changchun, Kirin Province, in northeastern China.
1950: The Chinese Women's Anti-Aggression League is formally inaugurated.
1964: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with The Congo.
1968: U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson meets with South Korean President Park Chung Hee in Honolulu, pledging U.S. protection for noncommunist Asia.
1971: Egypt, Syria and Libya sign an agreement to form a confederation.
1971: East Pakistanis declare their homeland an independent nation which they rename Bangladesh. Sheik Mujibur Rahman serves as the nation's first prime minister.
1973: President Lon Nol of Cambodia announces the resignation of his Cabinet.
1980: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) accepts mainland China as a member, and the Republic of China is forced to pull out of the organization.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council passes a proposal to allow teachers and staff of public schools to travel to the Chinese mainland for family visits.
1992: Legislative proceedings are completed for the National Employment Act, which is to serve as the basis for employment of foreign nationals in the Republic of China.
1994: Mainland China's public security unit announces it has solved a criminal case in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed at Qiandao Lake on March 31, 1994.
1995: Fire breaks out at a KTV on Hankou Street in Taipei, killing 12 people and seriously injuring 14 others.
1996: U.S. President Bill Clinton signs a joint declaration on security cooperation with Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto pledging to maintain American military levels in Japan and elsewhere in Asia.
1999: An ROC humanitarian relief delegation returns to Taipei after a visit to Macedonia to express concern and offer assistance to ethnic Albanian refugees from neighboring war-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
2000: The Year 2000 Trend Setting & Technology Conference is held in Taipei with more than 100 experts and industrialists from home and abroad participating.
2000: The Republic of China Finance Ministry allows two local insurance companies to set up offices in mainland China, marking the first mainland foray for the island's insurance industry.
2001: The Taipei Bank is chosen over four other hopefuls by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to issue both traditional and computerized charity lotteries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is ashamed to say much; he prefers to do more."

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Pope's U.S. visit begins with remarks on abuse.
Pope Benedict XVI, beginning his first U.S. visit as pontiff Tuesday, wasted no time in confronting the sexual abuse scandal that has shaken the Roman Catholic Church in this country. DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei ranks 18th among world's most popular host cities for 2007

TEXT.P: Taipei was rated the world's 18th most popular host city for international meetings in 2007, as a total of 67 such events took place in the city during that year, according to rankings released recently by the Dutch-based International Congress and Convention Association (ICCA).
The result marks a remarkable leap for Taipei, which was rated 40th in 2006 when only 29 meetings were held in the city, the ICCA's top 20 country and city rankings for 2007 revealed.

The rankings consider meetings organized by international associations, which take place on a regular basis and which rotate among a minimum of three countries. ICCA data shows that more than 6,500 such events took place worldwide in 2007, representing an increase of approximately 800 from 2006.

Topping the city rankings for 2007 was Vienna, which hosted 154 meetings during the year. Berlin, Singapore, Paris and Barcelona rounded out the top five by hosting 123, 120, 115 and 106 meetings, respectively.
Among Asian cities, Taipei's ranking advanced from ninth in 2006 to sixth in 2007, behind Singapore, Beijing, Hong Kong, Seoul and Bangkok.
Taiwan, however, did not make the top 20 country rankings for 2007, which were topped by the United States as host to a total of 467 meetings during the year.
Rounding out the top 10 were Germany (429) , Spain (303) , the United Kingdom (281), France (255), Italy (250), Japan (215), Brazil (209), Austria (204), and Canada (197).
In addition to Japan, other Asian countries making the top 20 list were China, South Korea and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to participate in Global Greens conference in Brazil

TEXT.P: A 25-member Taiwanese delegation will participate in the second meeting of the Global Greens Coordination and Network, to try to integrate Taiwan's environmental efforts against global warming with those in other countries, Pan Han-shen, secretary-general of the Green Party Taiwan, said Thursday.

The conference, which will be held in early May in Sao Paulo, Brazil, will focus on topics such as biomass energy, sustainable cities, climate change and post- Kyoto proposals, Pan said at a press conference.

"By participating in the conference, we hope to introduce the latest ideas on environmental protection and to network with different groups in Taiwan, " said Robin Winkler, an American friend of Global Greens who has been living in Taiwan for about 30 years.

Even if Taiwan is not among the countries that ratified the Kyoto Protocol, its environmental movements need help from the international community, and its bid to reduce carbon emission is part of the global effort, Pan said, adding that Taiwan's per capita CO2 emissions are three times the world average.
The Global Greens, of which Taiwan is a full member, is a network of Green parties and political movements active in more than 70 countries on the five continents.
The last conference of the Global Greens was held in Canberra, Australia, in 2001, with about 800 people from 70 countries participating.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE to step up campaign against betel nut chewing in schools

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will try to learn more about the phenomenon of junior high school students chewing betel nuts, a ministry official said Thursday.
Vice Education Minister Chou Tsan-der made the remarks in response to a question in the legislature on the high percentage of junior high school students who chew betel nuts.

Legislator Yang Chiung-ying of the opposition Kuomintang, who raised the question at a committee meeting, cited a survey conducted by the Bureau of Health Promotion which revealed that 7.5 percent of the junior high school students said that they usually chew betel nuts, and among them, 2.5 percent of female junior high school students who said that they had chewed betel nuts before.
In southern Taiwan the percentage of junior high school students who said they had chewed betel nuts was even higher, at 11.2 percent, Yang noted.

"The incidence is too high, " Chou said, noting that the ministry will try to learn more about the situation and at the same time ask schools to step up public awareness campaigns on the health risks associated with chewing betel nuts.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 economic growth forecast upward to 4.67%

TEXT.P: The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) adjusted Thursday its forecast upward for Taiwan's economic growth for 2008 from 4.16 percent to 4.67 percent.
Wang Lee-rong, director of the CIER's Center for Economic Forecasting, said the CIER's revised economic projections were based on high demand from China in the first quarter of this year.

Wang said although the U.S. economy is expected to slow due to subprime mortgage woes, the Chinese economy performed better than expected in light of the brisk international trade in the first quarter of this year, and is expected to grow at 10 percent for the whole year.

With the high demand for Taiwan's optical equipment, electrical and electronic products, machineries and telecommunication products from China, Taiwan's economic growth in the first quarter is likely to top 6.28 percent, 1.8 percent higher than originally predicted.

The CIER, a government-funded economic think tank, predicted that Taiwan's economic growth will reach 4.42 percent for the second quarter, 4.15 percent for the third quarter and 3.93 percent for the fourth quarter, with the growth for the whole year registering 4.67 percent. It forecast that the economic growth will further expand to 5.43 percent in 2009.
The CIER also predicted the country's private consumption for the whole year will rise by 3.29 percent, with private investment to increase by 5.11 percent.

On the country's inflation rate, the CIER revised upward its prediction for the consumer price index (CPI) for the whole of 2008 from 2 percent to 2.64 percent, with fuel and electricity price hikes being excluded from the calculation.

Wang said it is difficult to take fuel and electricity prices into the CPI measure at the moment as the government's fuel pricing mechanism and complementary measures are still unclear. But Wang admitted that commodity price hikes will have great effect on the country's economic growth.

Wang cited the evaluation by the Council of Economic Planning and Development as noting that if the government's plan to hike petroleum prices by NT$2.8 per liter and increase power rates by NT$0.65 per unit after May is implemented and the exchange rate of the Taiwan Dollar against the U.S. Dollar remains at 30 by the end of this year, the CPI will increase by more than 1 percent. This means that the CPI for the whole year will approach 3 percent, while economic growth will drop by 1 percent, representing 3.3 percent for the entire year. Wang said.
