DOC.HEADLINE: Higher education widening in Taiwan: MOI

TEXT.P: Taiwan citizens with tertiary education levels of training outnumbered those with senior high school levels for the first time in 2007, as higher education continues to widen in the country, according to a report released Thursday by the Ministry of the Interior.

The report showed that the number of Taiwan citizens with tertiary education levels of training accounted for 33.85 percent of the population aged 15 and over at the end of 2007, while those with senior high school levels accounted for 33.21 percent, and those with elementary school levels accounted for 15.69 percent.
The number of people in the population age group 15 and over who have received higher education has increased by 17.9 percentage points over the past 10 years, the report said.
At the end of 2007, there were 18.928 million people aged 15 and over, accounting for 82.44 percent of the country's total population, the report noted.
The literacy rate among this population group stood at 97.6 percent at the end of 2007, meaning that 2.4 in every 100 persons in the age group could not read or write.

In terms of gender, the literacy rate was 3.5 percentage points lower among women than among men, with the difference being especially obvious among those aged 65 and over where the literacy rate among men was 22.6 percentage points higher than among women.
In the 15-40 age group, however, the literacy rates between men and women were comparable, the report said.

The number of Taiwan citizens with tertiary education levels totaled 6.408 million at the end of 2007, up 4.47 percent from the previous year. Among this number, 3.38 million, or 52.75 percent, were men, and 3.027 million, or 47.25 percent, were women.
Noticeably, more women than men had received higher education in the under-35 age group, but the opposite was true among older people.

Of those with higher education levels, 3.282 million either had studied in or graduated from universities, 2.404 million either had studied in or graduated from colleges, and 722,000 either had studied in or graduated from graduate schools, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 24.39 points, or 0.26 percent, to close at 9,090.43.

Rising for the third consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 9,185.58 and fluctuated between 9,194.86 and 9,063.69 during the day's session. A total of 8.11 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$238.96 billion (US$7.91 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 1 percent. Paper and pulp issues advanced 0.5 percent and plastics and chemicals shares increased 0.1 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 2.7 percent. Cement stocks dropped 1.9 percent, foodstuff issues fell 1.2 percent, construction issues lost 0.7 percent, and banking and financial shares were down 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,344 to 981, with 277 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$21.1 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's letter for WHO bid to be submitted in coming days: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that the government is communicating with its diplomatic allies and other major countries in the World Health Organization (WHO) on how to approach Taiwan's bid to join the health regulatory body this year, and that it will submit President Chen Shui-bian's letter to the WHO in the coming days.

In accordance with Taiwan's new strategy of seeking WHO representation, President Chen will write to WHO Director-General Margaret Chan to express the country's intention to join the organization as a full member under the name Taiwan, or at least as an observer in its decision-making body -- the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- also under the name of Taiwan.
In addition, the MOFA will ask Taiwan's diplomatic allies that are also WHO members to submit its application at this year's WHA conference scheduled to take place in Geneva May 19-24.

"We hope that such a flexible and pragmatic approach will gain more support from the members of the WHO," Lily Hsu, deputy director-general of MOFA's Department of International Organizations, said at a regular press briefing.
She added that the government is communicating with its diplomatic allies and major countries such as the United States, Japan and the nations of the European Union, on how to execute the bid.
"Only by obtaining at least observer status in the WHA can Taiwan really enjoy the so called 'meaningful participation'," Hsu said.
The U.S. and Japan have openly expressed their support for Taiwan to have "meaningful participation, " meaning that Taiwan should be allowed to join WHO technical meetings and activities.
As to the views of Taiwan's diplomatic allies regarding this year's WHO bid, Hsu said they are all well aware of Taiwan's stance.

"Our diplomatic allies understand our requests clearly and know that we do not intend to change the official name of our nation or the status quo across the Taiwan Strait with the use of the name Taiwan," she stressed. "The name has been chosen because it is what is commonly used in the international community when referring to us."

Hsu said President Chen's letter to the WHO will be submitted in the coming days, since application for membership has to be submitted one month in advance. But she declined to elaborate on the exact date and contents of the letter.

Taiwan has been trying, unsuccessfully, to become an observer in the WHA under its official title, the Republic of China, since 1997. Last year, it applied for full WHO membership as "Taiwan" for the first time, but the bid failed again for the same reason as before -- China's opposition on the grounds that Taiwan is part of its territory.

As the country's new government is due to take office one day after the opening of the WHA this year, Taiwan's bid to join the world health regulatory body has attracted even more attention than usual.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic group condemns wage plan as discriminatory

TEXT.P: A civic group condemned legislators of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Thursday for instigating a plan calling for the delinking of wages for migrant blue-collar workers from the Labor Standards Act that also governs minimum wages for workers in the country.

The Taiwan Labor Front (TLF) lashed out at four KMT legislators for having proposed an amendment to a statute governing free trade harbors and relevant affairs, which called for a separation of wages for migrant workers employed at free trade harbors from the minimum wage stipulated in the Labor Standards Act.

The KMT-initiated amendment proposes that wages for migrant workers at Taiwan's free trade harbors should be decided by the employers and employees and should not be governed by the Labor Standards Act, according to TLF Secretary-General Sun You-lien.
The proposed amendment also calls for a lower hiring percentage of aboriginal workers at free trade harbors.
Sun said the proposed amendment would be an unfair law that would discriminate against migrant workers and would allow local employers to exploit their foreign employees.
Sun urged the KMT lawmakers to withdraw what he called the discriminatory draft amendment.
The TLF leaders also urged KMT President-elect Ma Ying-jeou to restrain his party's lawmakers from further infringing on the basic human rights of migrant workers in Taiwan.
Sun threatened to seek international sanctions should the KMT do nothing to stop the progress of the draft bill.

Taiwan was host to more than 360,000 migrant laborers at the end of February, with those from Indonesia forming the largest group, according to figures released Tuesday by the Council of Labor Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tests on allegedly tainted milk to be completed on April 21: COA

TEXT.P: Authorities are expected to release on April 21 the results of tests on milk reportedly contaminated by the milk of diseased cows, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Thursday.

Huang Ing-haur, director of the COA's Department of Animal Industry, said health and agricultural authorities collected samples of both raw and processed milk for tests immediately after news about the possible contamination broke a day earlier.
Huang said the council will make sure the tests are completed as soon as possible.

He made the remarks during a news conference held by the opposition Kuomintang legislative caucus, during which Huang and several other officials were invited to brief the media on their handling of the incident.

At issue are two brands of fresh milk -- Highland and Chiang Chun -- which are marketed by the leading food manufacturer, AGV Products Corp., and processed by an AGV-contracted dairy processing plant in Miaoli County.

According to an investigative report published Wednesday by Apple Daily, one of the plant's suppliers in Yunlin County has provided it with milk from diseased cows that was purchased at low prices from neighboring dairy farms. Such milk -- which were produced by cows during and immediately after the period when they are receiving medication -- is forbidden to be processed for human consumption.
The revelation prompted food manufacturer AGV to recall the two brands of milk, and health and agricultural authorities to launch an investigation into the situation.

Huang said the situation described in the Apple Daily report is quite unlikely to have happened because according to guidelines set down by the council on the procurement of raw milk by dairy processing plants, any milk tested with drug residues upon delivery to the plants will be dyed and rejected.
Of the more than 40,000 raw milk samples tested by the COA last year, 99.73 percent passed the tests, Huang said.

Cheng Hui-wen, director of the Department of Health's (DOH's) Bureau of Food Safety, told the same meeting that fresh milk currently sold on the Taiwan market should be safe, noting that all 243 products tested by the DOH last year met the department's criteria.

Meanwhile, Consumer-Protection Official Wang Teh-ming said major retailers have removed the allegedly contaminated products from their store shelves and that if consumers discover any of the products still on the market, they can inform the Consumer Protection Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Several global organizations to attend May 20 inauguration: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has been sending out invitations to international organizations for President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's inauguration ceremony May 20 in accordance with its usual practice, an official said Thursday.

"International organizations will not be absent from the May 20 inauguration ceremony, " Lily Hsu, deputy director-general of MOFA's Department of International Organizations, said at a regular press briefing.
She added that the ministry had invited presidents and chairmen of several international organizations that have close relations with Taiwan to attend the event.

Executive President of the Central American Bank for Economic Integration Harry Brautigam and Paul Sun, Director-General of the World Vegetable Center, have confirmed that they will attend, Hsu said. However, Asian Productivity Organization's Secretary General Takashi Tajima will be unable to attend the ceremony, she added.

Hsu noted that the ministry did not send out too many invitations but had invited those who were on the list of attendees at the inauguration ceremonies in 2000 and 2004, because President-elect Ma had asked his aides to limit spending on the ceremony and avoid waste.

To hold down costs, Ma's camp has decided to ask Taiwan's diplomatic allies to limit the number of visiting representatives they send to the ceremony, and foreign dignitaries will generally not be put up in presidential suites.

So far, 14 heads of state and 3 vice presidents of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies have confirmed that they will be present at the May 20 ceremony, setting a historic record. Other countries without diplomatic ties with Taiwan have also expressed great interest in sending special envoys and delegations to Taiwan, Hsu said.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Ma and his running mate, Vincent Siew, won a landslide victory March 22 over the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's ticket of Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang. The victory returned the KMT to power eight years after its loss to the DPP in 2000, which ended more than five decades of uninterrupted rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan lags behind East Asian nations in services export: WTO

TEXT.P: Taiwan remained the world's 16th largest merchandise exporter in 2007, but showed slower growth in commercial services export, according to a report released Thursday by the World Trade Organization (WTO) , raising concern among some local analysts over the strength of Taiwan's services industry.
The data was listed in an annual world statistics report issued by the Geneva- based WTO, entitled "World Trade 2007, Prospects for 2008."

Taiwan's 2007 merchandise export reached US$246 billion, capping a 10 percent annual growth and earning the 16th rank in the world, while import increased to US$220 billion with an 8 percent growth year-on-year, maintaining the 17th place from 2006.

The total value of US$464 billion in merchandise trade made Taiwan the 17th world trading power, behind its major competitors in the three newly industrialized economies of South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore, which ranked 11th, 13th, and 14th, respectively.

Taiwan's commercial services export maintained 26th place in the world, with a value of US$30 billion, but with a lackluster 5 percent growth, Taiwan was outperformed by Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea which registered annual growth of 13, 13 and 28 percent and ranked 12th, 14th and 15th, respectively.
Taiwan also lagged far behind two of the BRIC (Brazil, Russia, India, and China) economies -- China (7) and India (11), and slightly behind Russian (25).
"Somewhat weak export and import growth in dollar terms was reported for Japan and Chinese Taipei (Taiwan), while growth remained moderate for Hong Kong and Singapore," the report stated.

Experts in Taiwan warned about the weakness in Taiwan's commercial service export, saying the local industries had failed to develop export capacity in major service sectors such as tourism, financial and transportation sectors.

"The small growth in the number of inbound tourists is probably the biggest problem in the commercial service sector, " said Cheng-Mount Cheng, chief economist of Citibank Taiwan, adding that the regulation limiting the number of Chinese tourists to Taiwan was one of the major obstacles.
He said opening Taiwan to more Chinese tourists, which was part of the President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's campaign platform, could help to improve the situation.
"Three thousand or more (Chinese) tourists per day could boost both the country's GDP and local market demands, which in turn would spur more business and investment," he estimated.

Touching on financial service exports, Cheng said local banks should provide foreign tourists and businessmen with more services, such as direct fund transfer and currency exchange, alluding to the restrictions on such exchanges with China -- the biggest foreign capital magnet in Asia.

"With a more open policy toward China (by the incoming administration), local banks could locate their business and service destinations in China to take advantage of those opportunities, " he stressed, adding that Taiwanese would also rely less on foreign financial institutions for banking businesses.
Chen said the relevant regulations also need to be relaxed in order to boost the transportation sector, which he however noted was more competitive than the tourism and financial service industries.

"Taiwanese shipping companies sometimes register their vessels under foreign flags in order to access business in China because there are strict bans on cross-Taiwan Strait trading and shipping, " he said, indicating that the income made by those companies could not be included in Taiwan's export value.

The WTO reported stated that due to the sharp economic deceleration in key developed countries, 2007's world trade growth slid to 5.5 percent last year from 8.5 percent in 2006, adding that the figure is likely to decline further to 4.5 percent in 2008.

The continuing strong growth in emerging economies, such as China and India that increased their merchandise exports by 26 percent and 20 percent, respectively, could only partly offset the decline, the WTO report stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: China must face up to Taiwan's democracy: MAC official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 16 (CNA) 04/17/08 19:00:30 (By C. Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's democracy is very valuable in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, and Beijing has to adjust its policy in view of Taiwan's achievements in democratization, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Tung Chen-yuan said Wednesday.
Tung made the remarks while giving a speech on post-election ties between Taiwan and mainland China during a seminar at a cultural center in the U.S. state of Maryland.
The seminar was sponsored by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States and attended by more than 100 Taiwanese expatriates living in the greater Washington area.

Although Beijing seems willing to give Taiwan's incoming Kuomintang (KMT) government greater space by not mentioning its "one China" principle in recent days, Tung said, the Chinese government still has to face up to the existence of the RepublIc of China (Taiwan) if it wants to make substantial progress in bilateral negotiations.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the KMT beat the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) rival, Frank Hsieh, in Taiwan's March 22 presidential election, helping the KMT return to power after eight years of DPP rule.
As Ma will assume the presidency on May 20, Tung said, Beijing needs to gear its approach toward Taipei because of the new situation emerging in Taiwan.

Since 2000 when the DPP swept to power, it has been doing its best to build Taiwan's distinguished identity as a sovereignty independent from China and to make eventual unification with China no longer the sole choice for Taiwan's people, Tung said.
The DPP's efforts have made Beijing shift from its previous goal of unifying with Taiwan to a now anti-independence stance in its dealings with Taiwan, Tung said.

At a time when Taiwan will soon inaugurate its third democratically elected president, he contended that Beijing must take new steps in settling its relations with Taiwan due to the island's democratic advancement.

Tung voiced his hope that the newly-elected Ma and his administration will fare smoothly in inking accords with China to allow more Chinese tourists to Taiwan and to open direct cargo and passenger transportation services between the two sides.

Tung suggested Taiwan and China start bilateral negotiations on undisputed issues. He pointed to new signs on the Chinese side after Taiwan's recent presidential election indicating Beijing appears to be willing to re-open two- way dialogue by putting aside disputes.
Nevertheless, Tung pointed out, no Beijing official has so far publicly recognized the "one China, separate interpretations" stance upheld by Taiwan.

Under the "one China" policy, China defines Taiwan as a part of its territory. Ma and his party the KMT, however, prefers the concept of there being only one China, with Taiwan and the mainland free to interpret on their own what that China is.

Giving his best wishes to the new government to be led by Ma, Tung said that the DPP, which will soon become the opposition party, has to fully check and balance the policies and decisions of the incoming new administration.

He urged the KMT, which also controls nearly three quarters of the Legislative Yuan's 113 seats, to forge a common ground with the opposition in enhancing cross-strait ties and building foreign relations, so as to lead Taiwan into new horizons.

DOC.HEADLINE: Speaker to attend Marshall Islands' National Day celebrations

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has appointed Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to attend the Marshall Islands' May 1 National Day celebrations on his behalf, legislative sources said Thursday.
The Marshall Islands, located in the South Pacific, is one of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies.
Marshall Islands President Litokwa Tomeing visited Taiwan in March, during which he delivered a speech at the Legislative Yuan.
In his speech, Tomeing reaffirmed support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and other major international organizations.

Following Tomeing's speech, Wang expressed hopes that Taiwan and the Marshall Islands will work together to boost exchanges in various fields. He also promised that the legislature will do more to contribute to the realization of bilateral cooperation projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: Many people buy medicines promoted by illegal radio stations: poll

TEXT.P: The results of a recent survey showed that some 340,000 Taiwanese over the age of 40 have bought medicines or health foods promoted by unlicensed radio stations.

The poll, conducted by the monthly magazine Global Views and commissioned by the Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs (BPA) under the Department of Health, surveyed 1,100 residents over 40 years old islandwide.
According to the results of the poll, 14.6 percent of the respondents had bought unapproved medicines or health foods advertised by unauthorized radio stations.
Among those buyers of unapproved medicines, some had made single purchases amounting to NT$60,000 (US$1,980).
As a result, it is estimated that the total sales of these unapproved medicines, especially Chinese herbal cures, or health foods amounted to NT$680 million a year.
Asked why they wanted to buy medicine advertised on unauthorized radio stations, most of the respondents said "it sounded good" for their health.
Liao Chi-chou, director of BPA, said that most of people buy these unapproved Chinese herbal products or health foods believing that "they have fewer side effects" than chemical medicines.

As middle-aged and elderly people constitute the majority of buyers of unapproved medicines -- many of whom already have some chronic illness -- Liao warned that procuring medicines from unidentified sources poses a great threat, especially to the health of the liver and kidneys, with dialysis being required in some serious cases.
Liao stressed that the it is illegal to advertise medicines on any radio station, and urged members of the public to seek help from medical doctors if they are ill.

DOC.HEADLINE: French trade fair opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: A trade fair featuring French fashion, foodstuffs and other consumer items opened at Far Eastern department stores in major cities around Taiwan Thursday as part of efforts to promote cultural and commercial exchanges between Taiwan and France.

The trade fair -- dubbed "La Provence -- Colors & Tradition" -- is being sponsored by the French Institute in Taipei, which represents French interests in Taiwan in the absence of official ties, and the Far Eastern Group to allow the Taiwanese public to gain a better understanding of French culture, organizers said.
The exhibit items featured in the trade fair include French cars, perfume, tea and fashion accessories. Workshops on French wine and delicacies making were also organized alongside the fair.
The exhibition is simultaneously held at Far Eastern department stores in Taipei, Hsinchu and Kaohsiung.
The fair's opening ceremony took place at the Mall, a shopping center attached to the Far Eastern Plaza in Taipei City, with Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang presiding over the ceremony.

Also present were Emmanuel Ly-Batallan, an official of the French Institute in Taipei; Far Eastern Group Chairman Douglas Tong Hsu; Far Eastern Department Store General Manager Hsu Hsueh-fang; and United Daily News publisher Wang Shaw- lan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to ease visa procedures for professionals visiting Taiwan

TEXT.P: The government has tentatively decided to ease restrictions on foreign professionals applying to work in Taiwan and will introduce new categories of visas and work permits to accommodate them, an economic planner said Thursday.

But Thomas Yeh, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said the introduction of some new measures will involve a revision of administrative regulations so that there is no definite timetable for implementation.

According to the measures passed by the Economics and Finance Committee under the Executive Yuan Wednesday, the government will streamline the complicated application process for foreign professionals and academics coming to Taiwan to work or for scholarly exchanges.
Under the new measures, the government will allow multiple entries over a period of up to three years for prominent academics and business leaders of international stature.

Presently, Taiwan only issues courtesy visas based on diplomatic considerations. People of international standing who visit Taiwan to give lectures or to provide technological expertise are usually given single-entry visas. If they wish to remain in Taiwan for more than 14 days, they have to apply to the Council of Labor Affairs for a work permit, a regulation that is said to have caused trouble for some foreign professionals.
The Economics and Finance Committee said it has therefore adopted the new measures proposed by the CEPD to attract more foreign professionals to Taiwan.
But whether Chinese professionals would also be included under the new plan is yet to be determined, the committee said.
Yeh said that the council has invited relevant government agencies to discuss the issue and has examined similar regulations in the United States, the European Union, Singapore and South Korea.

"It is hoped that the National Immigration Agency under the Ministry of the Interior will serve as a one-stop service center for foreign professionals intending to come to Taiwan for work or visit," Yeh added.

He noted that the government will issue non-employment "academic or business travel cards" to prominent academics, such as Nobel laureates and to business leaders recommended by foreign trade associations in Taiwan.

In the case of foreign professionals who have been recruited by the government to work in Taiwan, they will be issued "work visa cards," which will be a combination of work permit, alien resident certificate and reentry permit, Yeh explained.
The government will also issue "permanent alien residence cards" to those foreign investors and professionals, he said.

Yeh said that except for the "permanent alien residence card," which should be ready by the end of June, the introduction of the academic, business travel and work visa cards will involve a revision of administrative regulations, and that there is no timetable for implementation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi Foundation urges reduction of carbon dioxide emission

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation (TCF) reaffirmed Thursday its determination to continue tackling the effects of greenhouse gasses, and urged that all Taiwan people work to reduce carbon emissions.

The TCF, which has some 4,500 recycling stations around Taiwan, made the appeal with the aim of encouraging the public to reduce carbon emissions through everyday practices, in recognition of April 22 Earth Day.

Noting that the soaring food prices, severe climate changes, and rising sea level are the results of commercial activities, Hsieh Ching-kuei, director of the Religious Cultural and Humanitarian Department at the TCF, said "this is an urgent task that we must face and deal with immediately."

Based on the teachings of Master Cheng Yen who founded the TCF in 1966 and has been devoted to environmental protection for more than 20 years, Hsieh suggested that through consumption of vegetarian food and energy saving measures, "carbon emissions can be easily reduced."

Speaking exclusively to the CNA, Hsieh said he was proud of his achievement of reducing carbon emissions by at least 1 ton a year by cycling and taking public transportation instead of driving his own car.

"We also need to reduce our consumption of unnecessary items, to reuse materials, and to recycle resources and make our life simpler, which indeed would help to reduce carbon emissions," Hsieh stressed.

Amid concern that Taiwan's carbon emissions are increasing rapidly compared to Japan and the European countries, Shaw Liu, director of the Research Center for Environmental Changes at Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institution, said "if we don't act to reduce carbon emissions, a massive extinction of species may occur soon."

In line with Master Cheng Yen's teachings, Wei Chuan Foods Corporation (WCFC), one of Taiwan's main food manufacturers and processors, also launched an internal campaign to reduce carbon emissions, WCFC Chairman Wei Ying-chung said.

According to Wei, the WCFC has cut carbon emissions by 2,500 tons over the past six months through the use of environmental friendly materials and by asking its employees and their families to save energy.
"We hope that other corporations nationwide can practice energy saving measures to help save the earth," Wei said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect open to relocating Presidential Office: aides

TEXT.P: The campaign office of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that Ma and his campaign team are open to the notion that the Presidential Office be relocated to Guandu, a plain to the west of Taipei City near the foot of Yangmingshan that has been undeveloped for many years.
Lo Chih-chiang, spokesman for Ma's campaign office, said that after Ma is inaugurated May 20, he will solicit opinions from the public via open debate on the relocation issue.

Ma reportedly said Thursday during a visit to Chen Fang-ming, director of the Graduate Institute for Taiwanese Literature at National Chengchi University, that he intends to relocate the Presidential Office -- a facility of Renaissance-style architecture built during Japan's occupation of Taiwan -- and other Cabinet agencies to the Guandu Plain after he takes office.

Ma told Chen about his intention after the academic proposed to the president- elect that when he seeks to address "transitional justice" issue after he becomes head of state, he should also address the historical issues that have been left in Taiwan since the end of the Japanese colonial rules.
Meanwhile, main opposition Kuomintang Legislator Ting Shou-chung welcomed the notion that the Presidential Office and other government agencies could be relocated.

Ting, whose constituencies include Guandu and the nearby Beitou, said the relocation plan could start a "turnaround of Taipei's axis," under which the Guandu Plain could be developed into a second Taipei downtown area, giving the city a completely new face.

Ting said development of the Guandu plain would not be an ecological nightmare and quoted Hsia Chu-joe, director of the Graduate Institute of Building and Planning of National Taiwan University, as having said that the plain could not only be developed into the "lungs" of Taipei, but could also be developed into the "backyard" of Taipei, should proper environmentally friendly procedures be adopted during development.
The development would also benefit farmers living on the plain, Ting added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City becomes second in Taiwan to ban vehicle engine idling

TEXT.P: Following in the footsteps of Tainan City, Taichung City in central Taiwan has decided to ban engine idling beginning in July to cut down on pollution from vehicle emissions.
Southern Taiwan's Tainan city is the first city in Taiwan to adopt such a measure when it put its anti-idling policy into effect on Jan. 1, 2008.

Under Tainan's policy, motorists of cars and other vehicles, including motorcycles, must turn off their engine when they stop for more than three minutes, otherwise the drivers will be fined NT$500 to NT$2,000.
Taichung City's policy will be similar, but the fines will be much higher.

If a driver in Taichung does not turn off his engine when he has stopped for three minutes or longer, he will be fined NT$5,000 to NT$10,000, according to a Taichung City Environmental Protection Bureau official who declined to be named.

Under the first stage of Taichung's program, which will begin in July 2008, only vehicles involved in for-profit business will be required to follow the rule, but by the second stage of the program which will begin in October, all vehicles will have to comply with the regulation.
The bureau began trying to raise public awareness about the new policy in April and up to now, it has heard no complaints from the public, said the official to CNA reporter in a phone interview.

While authorities in local governments make efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emission by banning engine idling, Taiwan's Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has no plan to ban vehicle idling nationwide, said on the phone Hsiao Hui-chuan, director of the EPA's air quality protection and noise control section.

"The EPA's actual objective is to enhance education for people, " Hsiao said, adding that it is possible to integrate the anti-idling policy into national law in the future if the two cities' pilot measures prove successful.

In Tainan, where the policy has been implemented for more than four months, no violations have been recorded so far, said the an official from the city's environmental protection bureau, who declined to be named.

"Even though some people complain that the three-minute time limit is too short, and that in the summer it is too hot to stay in a car without turning on the air conditioner, more than 90 percent of the citizens understand and support the policy, " said the official on the phone.

Asked why the bureau set the time limit to three minutes, she said the bureau took into consideration policies in other countries and regions, including Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan and the United States, adding that the time limit in Taiwan is reasonable.
According to the Tainan bureau, a vehicle emits more air pollutants when idling than running, and the CO2 emission of 100 idling vehicles equals to that of 10,000 running ones.

To encourage people to follow the regulation, the Tainan bureau also noted that they can save about 640 litres of gasoline per year by reducing 30 minutes of idling per day. That is about NT$18,000 per year saved and 1.4 tons of CO2 emission reduced, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP recruiting young members with technology

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) launched a recruitment campaign Thursday using Internet technology such as YouTube to attract younger people to join the party.
YouTube is a video-sharing Web site that enables users to upload, view and share video clips, and has gained massive popularity worldwide since its creation in 2005.

The DPP project, titled "We Want You," allows the public not only to view video commercials presented by young DPP officials on YouTube but also to receive the party's profile, as well as to register with the party online.

Chou Yung-hong, director of the DPP's Department of Youth Development, said that promoting the DPP through the Internet "helps inspire the `geeks' who rarely stay in touch with politics but would nevertheless like the opportunity to participate."

Noting that only about 16 percent of some the party's 400,000 members are aged under 35, DPP acting Chairman Frank Hsieh said at the launch ceremony that "we look forward to greater support from young people" to make the DPP more diversified.

Hsieh added that while a political party popular among younger generations will not necessarily win the support of the majority, "young people bring the party a better and more promising perspective."
"We hope young people who are adventurous and eager for innovation will join us ... and that the DPP can serve as a platform from which they can speak out," Hsieh noted.

Although the DPP lost the March 22 presidential election and will become the opposition after President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, representing the Kuomintang, takes office May 20, Hsieh encouraged new blood wanting to join the DPP "to surprise the government and make changes in Taiwanese society together."

Chou further urged people aged between 18 and 35 to watch the DPP's commercials on the Internet to learn more about the party and to complete the online application online, adding that the party hopes to recruit 2,000 to 3,000 new members through the campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA to launch nationwide toll-free number

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) has announced a new toll-free telephone number that will go live on Friday to provide passengers with better services, TRA officials said Thursday in a press release.

According to Lin Chun-yao, section chief of the TRA's Department of Transportation, passengers can make inquiries through the number 0800-765-888 about train information, as well as lost items, at any time.
In the past, people seeking train information would have to call various different numbers according to the caller's location.
"We hope the new service will satisfy people around the nation, making their inquiries easier and more efficient," said Lin.
"Passengers can also use the number to make complaints to the TRA, which will also help the TRA to improve," Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Inauguration ceremony held for Kaohsiung MRT Red Line

TEXT.P: A grand inauguration ceremony was held Thursday for the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) system's Red Line which has been in commercial operation since April 7 following a one-month test run.
Vice President Annette Lu, who presided over the ceremony, said at the occasion that the Kaohsiung MRT system plays a crucial role in ensuring a promising future for the southern port city.
Lu said she is proud of Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu for eventually putting into operation the Red Line, which initially saw many setbacks.

Chen said the system has brought revolutionary changes to the city, was providing a more convenient form of transportation, boosting real estate market, and contributing to improved air quality as it offers an alternative to cars and buses.
Chen expressed the hope that the central government will support an extension of the city's MRT system into the neighboring Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties.

Speaking on the same occasion, Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. Chairman Lin Wen- yuan apologized to the residents living near the line for the inconveniences they had to endure during its construction, and thanked all those who were involved in the construction and had made great contributions to the project.

The system's Red Line started operation with a test run March 9 this year. Nearly 8 million passengers were able to ride the trains free of cost during the test period, prior to April 7 when charges went into effect.
The 28.3-km Red Line extends north-south and some of its 24 stations feature public installation art designed to present specific aspects of the city's culture and history.
Chairman Lin also announced at the ceremony that the other main line -- the Orange Line -- is slated to begin operation in August this year.
Construction of the 14.4-km Orange Line, which runs east to west and has 14 stations, will be completed ahead of schedule in August instead of October, Lin said.
Kaohsiung City is the second metropolis in Taiwan to build an MRT system after Taipei City.

The KRTC is being constructed under a build-operate-transfer (BOT) contract signed with the Kaohsiung City government, at a total cost of NT$181.3 billion (US$5.89 billion) . The project was approved by the Kaohsiung city council in 1999, but was rocked by number of construction accidents and corruption scandals after work began in October 2001.
A number of minor lines are also planned -- blue, brown, yellow, green -- as well as a light rail, with the completion of the entire MRT network scheduled for 2021.

DOC.HEADLINE: Museum offers free entry for two days to celebrate anniversary

TEXT.P: The Shihsanhang Museum of Archaeology in Bali Township, Taipei County, will offer free entry to the public April 19-20 as part of the activities to celebrate its fifth anniversary, the management of the museum said Thursday.

The museum will also invite the public, including local schoolchildren, to "roam the streets" of Bali on the afternoon of April 20 to demonstrate their support for the museum as a treasured cultural heritage.
According to the museum's management, the first 150 visitors on April 19 and 20 will each receive a gift donated by the Giant Bicycle Co.

The museum, housed in an award-winning building, opened April 24, 2003 at an archaeological site that dates back 500 to 1,800 years. It is located at the foot of the Guanyin Mountain near the Danshui River.
The museum's name, Shihsanhang, refers to the 13 stores that existed in the area. About 400 artifacts excavated from the area are on display.

The relics show that the ancient dwellers in the area had the know-how to make iron tools and ceramics, and used silver and gold jewelry, as well as coins, for economic exchanges with other people, including ancestors of the Ketegalan people of the Pingpu aboriginal tribe and people from China and Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nobel Prize winner says his theory applies to cross-strait relations

TEXT.P: The 2007 Economics Nobel Prize laureate, Eric S. Maskin, said Thursday his theory on how to predict the outcome of a situation involving different players is applicable to the cross-strait situation between Taiwan and China.

While giving a speech in Taipei, the mathematician from Princeton University in the United States focused on his lifelong work -Evolution and Repeated Games - a theory which explains how a player within a game situation could break the ice.
Citing his theory, Maskin said any of the two parties in a game, who fail to cooperate with each other, could evolve in a way that leads to a change in the situation.

Responding to media inquiries about how his theory can be applied to help solve the situation between Taiwan and China, Maskin said as a mathematician, he could only explain the theoretical mechanism instead of predicting actual results, but ensured that his theory is applicable to still unresolved disputes across the Taiwan Strait.
"You can use the theory to predict the result or outcome of any game situation that involves more than one player,he noted.

The 57-year-old American scholar, who recently attended the Boao Forum for Asia, arrived in Taipei Thursday and is scheduled to share his theory and inspirations at a roundtable seminar Friday on solving the cross-strait stalemate. The forum will be attended by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou.
Maskin's speeches are part of a two-day forum co-organized by the global investment company Allianz, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research and the Economic Daily News local paper.
He will also be exchanging ideas with Udo Frank, CEO of Allianz RCM Global Advisors; Douglas Hsu, chairman of Far Eastern Group; and Daigee Shaw, the president of Chung-Hua Institution.

Maskin won the 2007 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences along with Leonid Hurwicz and Roger Myerson, for establishing the foundations ofmechanism design theory, a study of designing rules of a game or system to achieve a specific outcome.

Initiated in the 1960s by Hurwicz, the mechanism design theory combines the application of game theories and social choice theory, and is considered the most notable economic theory on the study of information asymmetry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government enterprises post looses of over NT$6 billion in 2006

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Hsieh Fa-ta promised Thursday to overhaul state-run companies after lawmakers found in a screening session that they posted combined business losses of some NT$6.02 billion (US$198.84 million) in 2006.

Hsieh made the remarks after lawmakers discovered the extent to which government enterprises were in the red when reviewing the central government's income and expenditure in 2006 at a meeting in the Legislative Yuan.
The state-run companies under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) include CPC Corp. Taiwan, Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. and Taiwan Power Company (Taipower), among others.

CPC -- Taiwan's largest oil and fuel refiner -- registered the largest deficit of NT$13.9 billion. Of all the state-owned MOEA-affiliated businesses, Taiwan Water Corp., was the sole profitable company for that year.

Apart from taking cost-effective measures, Hsieh ascribed the CPC Corp. and Taipower deficits to a government order freezing a cap on their product prices amid rising production costs due to surging prices of raw materials.

Although the Executive Yuan has insisted that water and electricity fees be maintained at their current levels prior to May 20, when President-elect Ma Ying-jeou will be sworn in, it has been reported that some state-owned companies have nevertheless been studying the feasibility of price hikes in the near term to reflect their increased operating costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan County confirms first local enterovirus case this year

TEXT.P: The Public Health Bureau of northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County on Thursday confirmed the county's first enterovirus case this year, saying that the patient, an 18-month-old child, is out of danger after undergoing treatment in the past week.

Lin Hsueh-jung, a staff member of the bureau, said the boy developed a fever on April 6, coupled with a rash and high blood pressure, and that his condition did not improve despite treatment in a clinic near his home.
The boy was then referred to a hospital on April 9 and stayed in an intensive care unit, where his condition stabilized several days later.

The Center for Disease Control has confirmed that the child contracted Enterovirus Type 71 (EV 71) , a fatal enterovirus strain that has spread to Taiwan from other Southeast Asian countries, according to Lin.
With the new enterovirus case, the accumulated total number of confirmed cases in Taiwan this year has increased to 37, of which most were EV 71 cases, Lin said.

Hou Sheng-mou, head of the Cabinet-level Department of Health, warned last month that children in Taiwan have a relatively low degree of immunity against the disease because Taiwan has not suffered an enterovirus epidemic for the past two years.
Enterovirus is a common cause of diseases such as meningitis and myocarditis. The flu-like illness is usually contracted through direct contact with contaminated sources.
The virus enters the body through the gastrointestinal tract, where it thrives, and can move on to attack the nervous system. Children are more susceptible to the infection than healthy adults.
No vaccine is available to curb the virus and frequent hand-washing is still the most effective way to prevent infection.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disadvantaged students make dream visit to Singapore
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 16 (CNA) 04/17/08 20:46:09 (By Charles Kang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: A group of primary school students from disadvantaged families in the northeastern county of Yilan have had a dream come true with a visit to Singapore, funded by money they earned selling home-made specialty foods over the past six months.

"We are so happy that we have finally traveled overseas to Singapore," said 37 fifth-graders from the Hsin Nan Elementary School in Yilan's Chuangwei township during a Wednesday meeting with Kuo Shih-nan, Taiwan's representative to Singapore.

The children were scheduled to visit Singapore's Hong Wen Primary School, where they were to demonstrate their talents and skills in riding unicycles, diabolo juggling and martial arts and gymnastics the next day.
The children also took with them four unicycles to give to the Singaporean school as a token of friendship.
Kuo, himself an Yilan native, said he was moved by the students' efforts to realize their dreams.

The students wanted to visit other countries after meeting with their peers from Singapore and Hong Kong during school exchange events a few years ago, said Hsu Pao-yin, a teacher in charge of the group.

Hsu said that most of the students come from either single-parent families or financially disadvantaged ones and that it was a "mission impossible" for each student to raise the more-than NT$20,000 (about US$661) cost of the four-day trip.

To make their dreams come true, the school and parents helped the students launch a drive to raise funds for the trip by selling home-made preserves, candies and cookies on weekends and holidays, Hsu went on.
The students raised nearly NT$300,000 in six months, with the shortfall made up by the students, the Yilan county government, county councilors and from public donations, said Hsu.
Hsu said the fund-raising has taught the students the importance of working hard to achieve their dreams and she added that the students have vowed to help others when they grow up.

To help other students travel overseas in the future, the school's principal, Liu Hsi-hsin, said the school will require students to save money from first grade and will also teach them the importance of saving.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity organization develops odorless compost

TEXT.P: Volunteers of Taiwan's largest charity organization are overjoyed to have developed an environmentally friendly product -- an odorless compost.

The volunteers at a Taichung facility of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation said they first came up with the idea of the compost to overcome the nagging problem of how to deal with kitchen waste.
They noted that the a medical building is being constructed at the facility and that the hundreds of construction workers and Tzu Chi volunteers produce a stunning amount of kitchen waste.
The volunteers begun a long process of collecting composting information and conducting experiments with the goal of handling the kitchen waste.

Lin Shu-chiao, one of the volunteers, said they place plastic netting at the bottom of kitchen waste collection bins upon which they spread layers of rice chaff, culture and kitchen waste before topping everything off with chaff to absorb the moisture.
Lin said the layers are kept loose and the collection bins left for natural fermentation to take place.
"Using this method, there are no maggots and no odors, " Lin added.

After more than a month, the solid parts of the compost can be used for growing vegetables, while the liquefied parts can be used as fertilizer and as a cleaning agent for toilets and plumbing systems to good effect, according to Lin.
Tzu Chi, founded in 1966, is dedicated to providing charity, medical services and education, and to the promotion of culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: NIA is revising rules on residency permits of foreign spouses

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency (NIA) is revising laws to deal with the problem of foreign spouses of Taiwanese nationals who overstay their residency permits, an official said Thursday.
NIA Director-General Wu Chen-chi made the remarks at the Home and Nations Committee of the legislature in response to questions by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Chao Erh-chung.

Chao criticized as inhumane the immigration laws that stipulate that foreign spouses of Taiwan citizens should return to their home countries before they apply for re-entry to Taiwan when they overstay their residency permits.

Chao cited a case of a foreign spouse living in the offshore island of Kinmen, who was ordered to return to her home country for one year before she can apply for re-entry to Taiwan because she overstayed her residency permit for one year.

Another case occurred on the outlying island of Matsu, involving a spouse who was "relatively luckier" than the first case as the NIA asked her to leave Taiwan for a short period time before she applied for re-entry as she only overstayed her residency permit for three months.
Chao noted that demanding foreign spouses of Taiwanese citizens to leave Taiwan before they apply for re-entry is a practice that dates back to the period when Taiwan was still under martial law.
"Such a formality is inhumane and has caused so much inconvenience to the foreign spouses of Taiwanese as some of them just forgot to apply for the extension of their residency permits, " Chao said.

In response, Wu noted that there are indeed many foreign spouses of local citizens who do not know they should apply for an extension of their residency permits or who do not know when their permits expire.

"The NIA has been trying to revise the immigration rules to impose a fine on foreign spouses who overstay their permits or allow an afterward application instead of asking them to leave the country before they apply for a re-entry," Wu said.
However, he did not elaborate when the new immigration rules will be in place.

DOC.HEADLINE: Campaign manager says he will not join KMT administration

TEXT.P: A campaign manager of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou declared Thursday that he will not be part of Ma's administration and will instead join Taiwan's largest charity group after Ma is inaugurated May 20.

Chan Chi-shean, a former head of the Cabinet-level Department of Health and president of the private Chi Mei Foundation Medical Center, said in a written statement that after May 20 he will join the Buddhist Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Foundation, answering an invitation extended prior to the March 22 presidential election by Tzu Chi founder Master Cheng Yen, who called for Chan to devote his later years to charity.

In the statement, Chan, 59, who also worked as a surgeon at several leading medical centers in the United States between 1975 and 1989, said he is glad to have made some trivial contribution to Ma's campaign and that the country will soon be under the leadership of an able man who has personal integrity and compassion.
"I will soon return to the grassroots community to continue my services to Taiwanese society," Chan said in his statement.
Chan said he issued the statement in an attempt to calm widespread speculation that he will be appointed by Ma as a vice premier or a deputy Presidential Office secretary-general.
Chan turned off his cell phone after issuing the statement, signalling that he would answer no further questions on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: New association of biomedical electronics established

TEXT.P: A new association of biomedical engineering and electronics was established Thursday at Hsinchu-based National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) as a cooperative platform upon which experts from different fields can promote the development of Taiwan's biomedical industry.

NCTU President Wu Chung-yu, who first broached the idea of the association, said the biomedical industry is a relatively new sector in Taiwan and needs more efforts to foster it as the next "trillion dollar industry" -- a term used to describe those industries that are capable of achieving annual revenues of NT$1 trillion or above.

Describing the establishment of the association as "a first step and a good start, " Wu expressed hope that the organization can become an interdisciplinary platform for biomedicine, engineering, electronics, technology-related legislation and venture capital for the industry.
He also said the association will help strengthen the local biomedical industry through international cooperation and collaborative research projects on technology and application.

Liu Wen-tai, honorary director of NCTU's Intelligent Prosthesis Research Center, said the biomedical industry can be separated into three sub-sectors -- biomedical pharmaceuticals, biomedical components and diagnostic instruments.

Liu explained that Taiwan has encountered difficulties developing the biomedical pharmaceutical industry because domestic companies lack key genetic engineering technology and because ethnic distribution in Taiwan is relatively less diversified, which makes it difficult to conduct cross-racial experiments.

"However, " Wu said, "Taiwan still has potential in developing biomedical components and diagnostic instruments based on the fact that the country has a strong electronics sector and a world-class information industry."

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kong eyeing Taiwan tourists prior to direct cross-strait links

TEXT.P: In an effort to seize as many business opportunities as possible prior to the planned opening of direct weekend charter flights between Taiwan and China, Hong Kong tourism operators will be represented at a travel fair next week in the central city of Taichung, offering economy package tours to lure Taiwanese visitors.

The Hong Kong Tourism Board will showcase their products -- joint ventures with Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd., Dragonair Hong Kong and a dozen Taichung-based tour agencies -- to lure Taiwanese visitors at four booths in the Taichung International Travel Fair 2008, to be inaugurated April 25 at the World Trade Center Taichung.

According to a Hong Kong Tourism Board manager, there are currently 39 direct flights from Chingchuankang Airport in suburban Taichung to Hong Kong every week. The drive from Taichung to the airport is 90 minutes shorter than the drive from Taichung to Taipei.

In addition, the manager said, prices of the various three-day trips to Hong Kong to be offered at the fair for individual travelers are even cheaper than domestic travel in Taiwan -- ranging from NT$4,999 (US$165) to NT$16,888.
For parents and children on group tours to Hong Kong Disney Land Magic World, a three-day package tour costs between NT$13,888 and NT$15,888, she went on.

Hong Kong has long been the major transshipment hub for cross-Taiwan Strait flights due to the lack of direct air links between Taiwan and China, but the former British colony might soon lose this key advantage after direct transport services are set up between the two sides of the strait, hopefully starting in early July with weekend charter flights.
President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who will assume the presidency May 20, vowed to implement the measure throughout his election campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: Preferential-rate life insurance policy for non-smokers approved

TEXT.P: A life insurance policy offering a preferential rate for people who are healthy non-smokers was approved Thursday by the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC).
FSC officials said the term life insurance policy offered by Nan Shan Life -- the Taiwan operation of insurance giant AIG -- is the first of its kind on the island.
Under the program, non-smoking policy holders are entitled to lower premiums than those who smoke, even if they are of the same age and gender.

The commission's approval was aimed at encouraging insurance companies to provide more life insurance policies that champion health awareness and encourage smokers to kick their habit, FSC officials said.
Similar policies offered by three other insurance companies, namely Prudential, Mass Mutual Mercuries Life and Shin Kong Life, are presently in the process of being screened, the officials added.
There are an estimated of 4.5 million smokers in Taiwan, which represents one- fifth of the nation's population.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public invited to hike, bike to see river clean-ups

TEXT.P: The Water Resources Agency on Thursday invited the public to hike in northern Taiwan and bike in southern Taiwan this weekend to appreciate the island's rivers and see the government's efforts in river dredging.

Hiking excursions will take place along the Keelung River in northern Taiwan's Keelung City on April 19, and biking activities will be held along the Puzih River in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County on April 20, according to an official at the agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The two activities, co-organized by the agency and the two local governments, are being planned to celebrate World Earth Day, which falls on April 22.
They are also part of a series of annual activities arranged by the government to arouse the public's awareness about Taiwan's river ecology, the official said in a statement.
Participants will be able to see beautiful scenery along the two rivers and learn more about the rivers' ecology and dredging projects from experts in the field, said the official.

There will also be lessons on how to make organic soaps to encourage participants to use organic cleaning products, instead of synthetic ones in daily life, to protect rivers, the official said, adding that the public's participation is an important link in river ecology protection.
Since 2002, the central government has spent seven years dredging the 59-km Keelung River, which used to cause serious floods during the typhoon season.
Channelizing and tree planting in the past seven years has brought a totally new look to the river, which runs through Taipei City, Taipei County, and Keelung City, the official said.
Dredging in the Puzih river is another success story, according to the official.

The government spent the past seven years cleaning the 75-km river that had serious pollution problems. Major efforts were carried out to find sources of waste water, cut off pollutants, and evaluate water quality.
Now the river has turned into a clean and beautiful one, and it is no longer referred to by its former title -- "black river, " said an official at the Chiayi County government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sports lottery to kick off in May: issuing bank

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first sports lottery will kick off May 2, yielding an estimated NT$1.07 billion (US$354 million) in revenue for this year, a spokesman for the issuing bank said Thursday.

The annual revenue will have grown to NT$30 billion by the start of 2009, predicted Richard Yang, vice president of Taipei Fubon Bank, which also operated the country's public welfare lottery for five years until 2006.
Half of the bank's 200 designated retailers will begin selling sports lottery tickets on the first day, Yang said, adding that the number of designated retailers will have increased to 1,000 by June.
In addition, the bank will inaugurate an online betting system in mid-June, Yang said.

Citing the examples of Hong Kong and Singapore, Yang noted that the online system is expected to contribute 40 percent of the total revenue when people know how to place bets on the Internet or via telephone.
In the first year, however, retailers will still account for the bulk of the revenue, he went on.

Saying that the online system will not eat into retailers' profits, Yang explained that each of the 1,000 retailers is expected to generate some NT$18 million on average, which is higher than the average profit of NT$11 million posted by the bank's previous public lottery ticket retailers.
In the initial stage, the sports lottery will focus on NBA basketball and Major League Baseball in the United States, as well as on the Union of European Football Associations, according to Yang.
The sports lottery will also cover local baseball and basketball, Yang continued, adding that local residents will be allowed to bet on local baseball games from mid-August.

The Taipei Fubon Bank -- a subsidiary of Fubon Financial Holding Co., Taiwan's second-largest financial service company by market value -- won the right last September to operate the sports lottery from 2008 to 2013.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu City to hold beach cleanup

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu city government in northern Taiwan will hold a beach cleanup April 19 as part of a festival it has organized titled Month of Sea Festival, Hsinchu City Deputy Mayor Chen Chuan-kuei said at a news conference Thursday.
The cleanup will kick off at 1: 30 p.m. at the Hsinchu Harbor Sports Park and everyone is welcome to participate, Chen said.
The festival started April 1 and will run through April 30, featuring a variety of activities taking place along the city's coastline.

The city's Environmental Protection Bureau has designed the activities in line with April 22 Earth Day, including a quiz on Taiwan's garbage sorting measures, according to the bureau's director-general, Chang Chien-tsung.

Chang also invited the public to take part in an online activity in which people make pledges that they can relate to their daily lives to help reduce carbon dioxide emissions, such as using energy-saving light bulbs, turning off lights when leaving the house and reducing private vehicle use.
Both the mayor and his deputy set out their pledges on the Web site at www.earthday.com.tw at the news conference, in the hope of drawing more people's participation in efforts to protect the earth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors seeking 10-year sentence for former investigator

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Prosecutors Office indicted a former special agent of the Bureau of Investigation and his girlfriend Thursday on charges of making death threats to more than 20 people last year.
Prosecutors are seeking a 10-year sentence for Yang Ching-hai, 54, and six years in prison for his girlfriend, Ting Yi-chih, 59.
According to the indictment, Yang and Ting mailed 28 letters in 2007 to government officials, legislators, journalists and television pundits, with a bullet enclosed in each letter.

Among those who received the threatening letters were Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, former Premier Frank Hsieh, and 13 legislators of both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party.

After a seven-month investigation, police arrested Yang at his Taipei County home in December last year. They also seized two pistols and 52 bullets from his residence. Yang is facing an additional charge of violating the Statute Regulating Firearms, Ammunitions, Knives and Other Deadly Weapons.
Yang's girlfriend, who allegedly assisted him in writing the letters, was also arrested, but both were later released on NT$100,000 bail.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural export subsidies focus on world markets: COA

TEXT.P: The government offers subsidies to help local governments export farm produce to the world, not just China, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said in a press release Thursday.

The statement was issued soon after a local newspaper reported that the council recently shifted its stance to offer a maximum of NT$16 million (US$528,160) to subsidize local governments to sell agricultural products to China.

However, the statement said the council began providing the subsidies last year and that most of the eight subsidized counties -- Taipei, Miaoli, Taichung, Yunlin, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Hualien -- have focused on exporting to Japan, Singapore and Canada.
Only a few of them targeted China, the statement added.
In addition, the council explained in the statement that it did not specifically exclude any market from its subsidy list.

This year, the council will subsidize another eight counties -- Taipei, Taoyuan, Taichung, Yunlin, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Hualien -- and only Taipei and Yunlin have selected China as their export market in their applications, the statement went on.

In assisting agricultural exports to China, the council attaches greater importance to protecting the know-how, brand image and trademark of Taiwan's quality farm produce because Taiwanese agricultural products are often counterfeited in China, according to the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: President says Taiwan's future should be decided by residents
DOC.DATELINE: Tapei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/08 23:41:30 (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Restating that China and Taiwan are two separate countries, President Chen Shui- bian said Thursday that only the 23 million inhabitants of Taiwan have the right to decide the future of their island.

In a clear rejection of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's recent overture to China, Chen also said that shelving the dispute over Taiwan's sovereignty amounts to "a de facto shelving of (Taiwan's) sovereignty" itself.

Speaking to foreign participants in a conference on Taiwan's sovereign status, the outgoing president denied the efficacy of both the 1943 Cairo Declaration and the 1945 Potsdam Declaration, which have been interpreted by some as acknowledging China's sovereignty over Taiwan.
"These declarations were merely... unilateral policy statements," Chen said. The president will hand over power to Ma May 20 after serving two four-year terms.

The San Francisco Peace Treaty, which took effect in 1952, takes precedence over both the earlier declarations, said Chen, adding that the treaty does not mention which country can claim sovereignty over Taiwan.
Rounding off his remarks, Chen summed up his stance regarding Taiwan's sovereign status with the following four main points:

First, Taiwan's sovereignty should be based on self-determination by its populace and on the principle of popular sovereignty, while neither the Cairo Declaration nor the Potsdam Declaration should be employed to constrain the destiny of the Taiwanese people.

Second, Taiwan, regardless of its title -- no matter whether it is called "Taiwan" or the "Republic of China" -- is a sovereign state, with its sovereignty held in the hands of its people and only by them. Nobody else is entitled to determine the country's future.

Third, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are two separate countries -- Taiwan and China, or the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China -- which are independent of each other and do not belong to each other. They are not part of a divided, separately ruled China.

Fourth, any normalization of cross-strait relations should be carried out under the tenets of the four principles of "sovereignty, democracy, peace and parity." As far as the sovereignty dispute is concerned, self-restraint and self- deprecation are not tolerable because adopting such stances would eventually lead to the shelving and abandonment of sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect said mulling relocation of Presidential Office

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou will evaluate the feasibility of relocating the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei to the Guandu plain in the city's northern area after he assumes office May 20, a local academic said Thursday.
Chen Fang-ming, head of the Graduate Institute for Taiwanese Literature at National Chengchi University, made the revelation after an 80-minute meeting with Ma at his office.

During their talks, Chen said, he mentioned that the pursuit of transitional justice should include a review of the legacies of Taiwan's colonial era, not just setting the record straight on the Kuomintang's authoritarian past as pursued by the incumbent Democratic Progressive Party administration over the past few years.

When it comes to historical issues regarding Japanese colonial rule, Chen went on, the fate of the building that has housed the Republic of China's Presidential Office since 1950 should not be overlooked.
The Baroque-style building in downtown Taipei was completed in 1919 to house the then-Japanese colonial government.

It became a target of U.S. bombing in the latter years of World War II and was partially destroyed in 1945, with repair work not completed until 1948. After the ROC government moved its seat from China to Taiwan in 1949, the building became the Presidential Office in 1950.

Responding to Chen's suggestion, Ma was quoted as having said that during his tenure as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006, he had tried to sort out the most appropriate way to transform the Presidential Office building in tandem with Taiwan's progress into a democratic era.
"Ma told me that after he takes office, he is likely to come up with a plan to relocate the Presidential Office to Guandu Plain," Chen told reporters after his closed-door meeting with Ma.

Ma visited Chen to show his determination to promote social reconciliation and harmony in the wake of the bitterly contested presidential election. Chen supported Ma's rival, Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, in the March 22 poll.

Thanks to a good chemistry between them, the Ma-Chen meeting lasted much longer than originally scheduled. Ma told reporters after the meeting that he admires Chen's dedication to study of Taiwanese culture and literature as well as his achievements in Taiwan's localization discourse.
