DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 18, or the 13th day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1480: Lucrezia Borgia, the illegitimate daughter of Pope Alexander VI, is born in Italy. She was married three times by the age of 18 to further her father's political ambitions.
1906: An earthquake devastates San Francisco, killing more than 1,000 people and making 300,000 others homeless.
1925: The first world women's exposition is opened in Chicago.
1927: The national government is established in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1933: Fighting spreads in northern China as several strategic passes along the Great Wall fall to the Japanese.
1942: Planes from a U.S. aircraft carrier bomb Tokyo for the first time. They were commanded by Lt. Gen. James Doolittle.
1943: Isoroku Yamamoto, a Japanese naval officer, is killed when his plane is shot down by U.S. warplanes over the Solomon Islands. He planned Japan's naval strategies during World War II, including the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941.
1946: The League of Nations is formally dissolved.
1948: By a two-thirds majority, the first National Assembly approves temporary provisions granting emergency powers to the president during the ongoing anti- Communist campaign.
1949: The Republic of Ireland is formally proclaimed in Dublin.
1954: Gamal Abdel Nasser becomes prime minister of Egypt.
1955: Albert Einstein, the German-born American theoretical physicist who won a Nobel Prize in 1921 for his explanation of the photoelectric effect, dies at the age of 76. His specific and general theories of relativity revolutionized modern thought on the nature of space and time and formed a theoretical basis for the exploitation of atomic energy.
1968: Army officers in western Africa's Sierra Leone take over the government, dissolve the Legislature and suspend the constitution.
1977: A boat capsizes near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan, killing 32 college students and teachers on board and injuring 16 others.
1980: The former Rhodesia becomes independent Zimbabwe under President Canaan Banana.
1982: Monaco's Prince Rainier III and his wife, Princess Grace Kelly, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1988: The Republic of China Red Cross Society begins forwarding mail from Taiwan residents to mainland China.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council under the Executive Yuan decides to permit Taiwan citizens to gather news and make films in mainland China.
1998: Official talks between South and North Korea end with the two sides failing to resolve a dispute over aid to the starving North and the reunion of separated families.
1999: A GIO-produced documentary featuring the relationship between the year of one's birth and the 12 animals in the 12-year cycle of the Chinese calendar wins a gold medal at the Houston International Film Festival.
2000: Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University signs an academic cooperation contract with Japan's Kanazawa Industrial University.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on U.S. Senator Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska) for his contributions to promoting bilateral relations between the ROC and the United States.
2001: The Tainan District Court approves a prosecution request to hold Tainan City Mayor George Chang incommunicado over his alleged involvement in a governmental land-requisition scam.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man may be known in three ways which I am not able to show in my own person. As a moral man he is free from anxiety; as a man of understanding he is free from doubt; and as a man of courage he is free from fear."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Text message volume soars 26% year-on-year in Q4 2007

TEXT.P: The volume of text messages sent by Taiwan mobile phone users posted a year-on- year increase of 26 percent to reach 1.256 billion in the fourth quarter of 2007 as mobile phone subscriptions continued to rise, according to a report released Friday by the Institute for Information Industry (III).
The volume, representing a growth of 9 percent compared with the previous quarter, translated into each person sending an average 54.7 text messages per quarter and 18.2 text messages per month.

For the fourth quarter of 2007, the monthly text message volume averaged 419 million, while in December alone, the volume hit a record single-month high of 460 million, thanks to the increasingly popular practice of sending Christmas or New Year greetings via text messaging, the report said.
The number of mobile phone subscriptions jumped 1.3 percent quarter-on-quarter to hit 24.3 million for the period, with the mobile phone subscriptions per 100 inhabitants standing at 105.8.

Mobile Internet subscriptions climbed 7.8 percent quarter-on-quarter to reach 11.86 million -- equal to half the number of Taiwan's population, meaning that 48.8 percent of mobile phone subscriptions were registered with mobile Internet services.
The report also noted that mobile phone users in Taiwan were gradually dumping 2G networks for 3G networks.

While 2G network subscriptions declined 4.2 percent quarter-on-quarter to 15.9 million, 3G network subscriptions rose 16.5 percent to 6.91 million, accounting for 28.5 percent of total mobile phone subscriptions.

With 3G network subscriptions having increased at a rate of 3.2-3.8 percent per quarter, the III predicted that the number will top 10 million by the end of 2008 to account for 40 percent of total mobile phone subscriptions.

In terms of mobile Internet technologies, 55.1 percent of mobile Internet users went online through a 3G network, compared with 32 percent who accessed the Internet through general packet radio services (GPRS) , indicating that 3G was replacing GPRS as the mainstream technology for mobile Internet connection.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT's win does not represent loss of Taiwan-centric line: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 17 (CNA) 04/18/08 13:40:30 (By Jaw-pyng Hwang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The decisive victory of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the March 22 presidential election represented a victory for everyone in Taiwan but not a defeat of the Taiwan-centric political line, a high-ranking Taiwanese official said Thursday at the Taiwanese American Center in New York.

"Taiwanese identity and Taiwan-centric consciousness have become a consensus and common language in the country since the election, " said Tung Chen-yuan, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , who is currently on a speaking tour of the United States.
"The KMT owed its victory partly to its tilting toward the Taiwan-centric advocacy that has been championed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)," Tung said.
Tung said the contributions that outgoing President Chen Shui-bian has made in deepening Taiwan's democratization and consolidating the Taiwanese identity are historically undeniable.
"Chen's efforts have altered the mode of cross-strait relations development and have also created strategic maneuvering space between the two sides," he went on.

Meanwhile, Tung said, the Beijing leadership has ceaselessly adjusted its Taiwan policies and is "still adjusting, " which he said indicates that Beijing has also been unable to free itself from the impact of Taiwan's democratic development.

Noting that Taiwan's democracy is a core asset in cross-strait relations and the bottom line of cross-strait negotiations, Tung said Beijing has had no other options but to adjust its stance in the face of Taiwan's democratic progress.

He said that although Beijing has never openly acknowledged the notion that "there is only one China but both sides could interpret the meaning separately, " its stance seems to have changed, according to a March 26 telephone dialogue between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao.

According to a Beijing-based Xinhua News Agency English-language report on Hu's conversation with Bush, Hu said "it is China's consistent stand that the Chinese mainland and Taiwan should restore consultation and talks on the basis of `the 1992 consensus, ' under which "both sides recognize that there is only one China, but agree to differ on its definition."

Hu's remarks show that China in a sense will change and will accept the "One China, differing definitions" notion, Tung said, adding that should China anticipate any progress in political engagement across the strait, it must face squarely the fact of the Republic of China's existence on Taiwan.
He also said that Taiwan cannot afford not to know China better, given that China is an enemy and Taiwan's closest neighbor.

Tung suggested that cross-strait relations should be developed under a "triangular, two-tier" framework -- taking opinions of both Taiwan, China and the rest of the world into account, while heeding the wills of the people on either side of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mandatory retirement age could be raised to 65

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yaun completed a preliminary review Friday of a bill that would raise the mandatory retirement age prescribed in the Labor Standards Act from the present 60 to 65.
The draft amendment, which cleared the legislature's Health, Environment and Labor Affairs Committee, is still pending second and third readings before it can be signed into law.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Yang Chiung-ying, a lead sponsor of the bill, said it is necessary to put off the mandatory retirement age of workers to strengthen the use of middle-aged and elderly human resources because the average life expectancy in Taiwan has increased to 76 and more older workers are staying in the labor force rather than retiring.
The measure is also crucial to cope with the possible impact of the declining birth rate on the labor force, Yang said.

Legislators Hsu Shao-ping and Chung Shao-ho, also of the KMT, said the measure would extend the work rights of local workers, while those who wish to retire early could still do so voluntarily even after the law is passed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Council of Agriculture develops organic bactericides

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has developed organic bactericides made of natural plant extracts, with germicidal efficiency reaching 99.9 percent, no reported drug resistance in bacteria or negative effects on humans, an agriculture official said Friday.

Chen Kuo-hsiung, director-general of the council's Taiwan Seed Improvement and Propagation Station in Taichung County, central Taiwan, said the center has applied for patent rights for the development to facilitate future technology transfers to the private sector.

The complex organic bactericides were developed after years of research and contain many plant extracts with secondary metabolites, which are organic compounds indirectly generated from normal growth, development or reproduction of organisms.
These compounds, such as alkaloids, glycosides, phenols, sterols, and essential oils, are used by plants as defenses against predators, parasites and diseases, Chen explained.

The organic bactericides are effective in combating more than 10 types of fungus and bacteria, such as rice blast fungus, bacillus cereus and colon bacillus, the latter of which is used as an indicator in evaluating food sanitation.

According to Chen, due to Taiwan's humidity and high temperatures, crops are often invaded by bacteria or fungus, both of which also exist in water, air and food, causing environmental pollution and health risks, Chen said.
Farmers tend to use chemical ingredients or antibiotics to protect their crops, but the high frequency and intensive use have caused bacteria and fungi to develop resistance.
The development of the organic bactericides is part of the COA's measures to meet its projected goal of reducing use of chemical germicides by half by 2015.

Chen said the organic bactericides are qualified to be labeled as environmental sanitation ingredients for sterilizing public facilities such as hospitals and schools, as organic biopesticides to support organic agriculture and as alternative medicine for medical use.

The center has the world's leading technology in making the organic bactericides and will transfer the expertise to the industry after acquiring patent rights, in the hope of developing more antibacterial products such as pesticides, soaps, detergents and paper towels, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier-designate expresses respect for departing campaign manager

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan said Friday that he respects the decision by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's campaign manager to not seek a post in Ma's administration.

Liu, who is set to be the next premier when Ma is inaugurated May 20, said he respects Chan's decision not to be part of the incoming KMT administration and to instead return to his medical career working at a research hospital run by Taiwan's largest charity group, the Buddhist Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Foundation.

Liu, however, would not comment on whether Chan's decision to leave after making commendable contributions to Ma's campaign was the result of behind-the-scenes struggles involving people who have tried to "position" themselves for a posting in Ma's new administration.

The premier-designate noted that he talked with Chan over the telephone Thursday and told Chan that he will certainly invite him to serve in public offices in the future if Chan is not opposed to the idea.
Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Chan, a veteran medical professional, is capable of serving the country in many ways.
"We should respect his decision if Chan decides to leave the political arena and return to his medical career," Wang said.
Chan declared Thursday that he will not be part of Ma's administration and will instead join the Tzu Chi charity group after Ma is inaugurated.

Chan, a former head of the Cabinet-level Department of Health and president of the private Chi Mei Foundation Medical Center, said in a written statement that after May 20 he will join the Buddhist Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Foundation, answering an invitation extended prior to the March 22 presidential election by Tzu Chi founder Master Cheng Yen, who called for Chan to devote his later years to charity.

In the statement, Chan, 59, who also worked as a surgeon at several leading medical centers in the United States between 1975 and 1989, said he is glad to have made some contributions to Ma's campaign and that the country will soon be under the leadership of an able man who has personal integrity and compassion.
"I will soon return to the grassroots community to continue my services to Taiwanese society," Chan said in his statement.
Chan said he issued the statement in an attempt to calm widespread speculation that he will be appointed by Ma as a vice premier or a deputy Presidential Office secretary-general.
