DOC.HEADLINE: Delegation promotes Taiwan tourism in New York City

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese delegation organized by the Tourism Visitors Association held an exchange activity and banquet Thursday at a New York hotel to promote Taiwan's tourism.

Members of the delegation, including representatives of various Taiwanese airlines, hotels, travel agencies and hospitals, discussed cooperation with American tourism industry representatives at the gathering. Chang Lee Cheng- chin, an official from the Tourism Visitors Association, said at the event that Taiwan offers both tropical and sub-tropical scenery, as well as wonderful mountain and forest views and kind and friendly people.
She said these assets should attract American citizens traveling to Asia to visit Taiwan.

Although world oil prices and the depreciating U.S. dollar have had a negative impact on Asian countries' tourism industries, Lee said Taiwan's geography and culture have special qualities that should draw more tourists from the United States.

Meanwhile, Steven T.Y. Kuo-Su, deputy director of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, introduced a variety of promotional packages being offered by the bureau under the "Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009." These include special seasonal packages for first-time arrivals with the theme of dining and recreational activities.

Various incentive measures are also being offered to foreign tourists under the program, including hotel room rates of just US$79 per night for transit passengers and free gifts for members of tour groups, he went on.

The members of the delegation, including representatives of various travel agencies, the Howard Plaza Hotel and China Airlines and EVA Air set up booths at the gathering to introduce their tour packages and specials.

Members of various Taiwan medical facilities and hospitals, including Tung's Taichung Metro Harbor Hospital, also took part in the event to promote Taiwan's competitive advantages in the area of medical tourism, including high-quality and inexpensive cosmetic surgery, dialysis, health exams and dental services.

The tourism office of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York also invited many U.S. tourism industry representative to take part in the event to learn more about Taiwan's attractions, tourist packages and special offers.

One of the representatives said that more than half of the American tourists who travel to Asia do so during the summer vacation months of July and August and she suggested that if Taiwan tourism officials want to attract more U.S. visitors, they should take seasonal factors into consideration when formulating incentive packages and special offers.
The Taiwan delegation held similar tourism promotion events in Los Angeles April 13 and in Vancouver, Canada April 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: High court: ASDF mission to Iraq illegal
The Air Self- Defense Forces's airlifting of multinational combat troops into the war zone of Baghdad is unconstitutional because it is an act integral to other countries' use of force, the Nagoya High Court ruled in a suit Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: $70m plan to beef up cyber defences.
It seems innocuous, but among the biggest threats to cyber security is the movie you have just downloaded to watch on your office computer, or the e-mail message with the sexily named attachment you just have to open.
Now, a new effort to drive it home will be kick-started by Government as part of a S$70 million Infocomm Security Masterplan 2.
The Lianhe Zaobao: S$70m to promote six strategies to beef up S'pore's cyber security.
Singapore government will invest S$70 million to promote Infocomm Security Masterplan 2 to protect the security of Singapore's information and communication environment and enhance business and individual users' recognizing about the threat from Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Bossi against proposed cabinet line-up.
Italian Northern League Party leader Umberto Bossi expressed his opposition to a proposed Cabinet line-up and said that he would only negotiate with would-be premier Silvio Berlusconi on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Workers Get Fewer Hours, Deepening the Downturn
Not long ago, overtime was a regular feature at the Ludowici Roof Tile factory in eastern Ohio. Not anymore. With orders scarce and crates of unsold tiles piling up across the yard, the company has slowed production and cut working hours, sowing worry and thrift among its workers.
The Wall Street Journal:Economic Split Seen In Corporate Earnings
As first-quarter corporate earnings reports begin to roll in, a stark picture is emerging of an economy on two tracks.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Public's View of Economy Takes Fast Turn Downward
The public's ratings of the national economy continue to sour, with assessments deteriorating faster than at any point in Washington Post-ABC News polling. Views on the Iraq war have also turned more negative, with six in 10 now rejecting the notion that the United States needs to win there to effectively battle terrorism.
The Washington Times:Pope celebrates jubilant Mass
Pope Benedict XVI ministered yesterday to the many and the few, celebrating Mass with 46,000 joyful Catholics in a sun-bathed Nationals Park before meeting privately with a handful of the sex-abuse victims at the center of the church's darkest scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: New administration to limit display of head of state's portrait

TEXT.P: The incoming administration to be led by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou will limit the number of portraits of the head of state hung at public offices to cut costs, a spokesman for Ma said Friday.

Under the measure, the portraits will no longer be hung in public schools and state-owned enterprises, but they will still be required in government offices, military agencies and the country's embassies and representative offices overseas, said Lo Chih-chiang.
The move is expected to help save one-third of the expected cost of preparing the portraits, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st employment center for recovering drug addicts inaugurated

TEXT.P: The nation's first employment service center for drug addicts who have undergone methadone treatment was inaugurated in National Cheng Kung University Hospital in southern Taiwan's Tainan City Friday.
Cheng Kung University Hospital officials said society is usually reluctant to accept drug addicts and the center will help them find jobs to facilitate their return to normal life.
The center will be jointly run by the hospital, Tainan City government, and Tainan Prosecutors Office.
Similar employment service centers will be set up at Chi Mei Foundation Medical Center in Tainan County and Tainan Hospital in Tainan City in the future, the officials added.

The Tainan Prosecutors Office first promoted the methadone treatment program in 2006 to kick their reliance on heroin with good effect, and the program has since spread to other parts of the country. Taiwan's Legislative Yuan passed a law on April 8 to give the treatment a legal basis.

Cheng Kung University Hospital officials said that between 20 and 30 percent of drug addicts in Taiwan who have taken part in the alternative treatment program foot their own bills. In Tainan city, the percentage is about 45 percent.
For the outpatients in the hospital, the ratio is as high as 70 percent, far higher than in other cities and counties, officials said.

There are around 400 drug outpatients in the hospital who have taken part in the alternative treatment program, and the number is increasing at a speed of between 10 and 15 per week, hospital officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT victory does not mean Taiwan wants to unify with China: scholar

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's decisive victory in the presidential election does not mean Taiwan's people are gradually moving toward unification with China, and such an interpretation is "malicious, " a pro-independence scholar said at an international conference Friday in Taipei.

"Some pro-China media and people have intentionally played up the election result, saying that the majority of Taiwanese people have given up seeking independence and will gradually move toward unification with China, " said Ketagalan Institute Chairman Lee Hong-hsi, without providing any examples.
"Such an interpretation is malicious, misleading and completely wrong, " he said at the opening of the International Conference on Taiwan's Sovereign Status.
KMT candidate Ma Ying-jeou defeated the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Frank Hsieh by a bigger-than-expected margin of 2.21 million votes in the March 22 presidential poll.
The victory returned the KMT to power eight years after its five decades of uninterrupted rule in Taiwan ended in 2000.
Ma vowed during his campaign to build closer ties with China, especially in the economic realm, an approach that marks a reversal of the DPP's policy over the past eight years.

The president-elect has publicly pledged to launch regular weekend charter flights, open Taiwan to Chinese tourists, relax restrictions on investment in China, and negotiate direct transportation links.

But majority support for this more open approach does not equate to wanting unification, Lee said, citing a recent survey in which 84 percent of the people said they did not concur that Ma's victory meant a majority of Taiwan's people agree the island country should unify with China.
The survey showed that nearly 80 percent of KMT supporters said they voted for Ma to be president for reasons other than his support for "eventual unification."

As to Taiwan's status, Lee contended that Taiwan is a "de facto state" because it has its own territory, inhabitants, government and courts and also exercises sovereign rights and fulfills responsibilities in the international community.
He said it was not imperative for Taiwan to seek international recognition because it is already a sovereign country based on the 1933 Montevideo Convention on Rights and Duties of States.
The convention defines a sovereign state as having a permanent population, a defined territory, a government, and the capacity to enter into relations with other states.
Lee added that Taiwanese people have no intention of unifying with China and insisted that the future of a country has to be determined by its people.
The two-day conference, which opened on Friday, was organized by the nonprofit Taiwan Thinktank, an independence-leaning public policy research organization.

Among the scholars attending are Nisuke Ando, former chairperson of the United NationsHuman Rights Committee, Thomas Grant, senior research fellow of Wolfson College under the University of Cambridge, and Stephen Yates, former deputy assistant for national security affairs to U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney and now president of DC Asia Advisory.

The conference featured keynote speeches and four discussion sessions on topics such as "Taiwans Sovereign Status from the Perspective of International Law, " "Historical Perspectives of Taiwan's Sovereign Status, " "International Political Perspective on Taiwan's Sovereign Status, " and "The Prospect and Future of Taiwan's Sovereign Status.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung city government launches 24-hour service hot line

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung municipal government launched a new 24-hour telephone line Friday to provide comprehensive services and information on its various departments and agencies.
In a ceremony marking the launch of the "1999" hotline, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, accompanied by Chunghwa Telecom Chairman Tan Ho Chen, received the first call to the new service line.
The hot line will be manned by 18 operators working in three shifts to provide 24-hour service.
Ten physically challenged individuals will serve as operators on the day shift.

Chen said the move is in line with her policy of taking care of disadvantaged groups in the city, as well as an extension of a similar policy during her term as head of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) between 2000-2005.
The mayor said that physically and mentally challenged individuals were employed as operators to man the CLA's customer service lines when she served as head of the council.

Also speaking at the ceremony, Ho Chen said that a survey of the telephone company's 3,000-plus operators conducted last year revealed that disabled operators displayed several characteristics, including patience, consideration and attentiveness, that made them better suited than others for this line of work.

Noting that the telephone company's disabled operators showed "a high EQ and level of tolerance in dealing with customer complaints, " Ho Chen said he believes the decision to select such individuals to man the Kaohsiung municipal government's hot line will increase the quality of service.
The new "1999" hot line, linking customer service for all of the city government's units, will operate around the clock 365 days a year, without interruption.

The city government's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission will keep a record of complaints and requests made via the hot line as well as the various government ministries' and agencies' responses as a reference in evaluating their level of service to citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved up 17 points to close at 9,081, with 50,482 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June gained 13 points to finish at 9,048, with 184 contracts traded, while September futures rose 22 points to close at 8,812, with 45 contract transactions.
December futures dropped 20 points to finish at 8,735, with 39 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index slid 16.09 points Friday to finish at 9,074.34, with a market turnover of NT$180.61 billion (US$5.96 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 9,064 for May; 9,035 for June; 8,790 for September: 8,755 for December and 8,715 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
May TE futures lost 1.95 points to close at 338.4, with 4,667 contracts traded, while June TE futures dropped two points to finish at 337.25, with 32 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved down 4.85 points to close at 332.5, with five contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December and March.
May TF futures gained six points to close at 1,233.2, with 6,029 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures dropped one point to finish at 1,229, with 15 contract transactions.
September TF futures lost 1.8 points to close at 1,212.2, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 16.09 points, or 0.17 percent, to close at 9,074.34.

The local bourse opened at 9,092.93 and fluctuated between 9,123.07 and 9,025.01 during the day's session. A total of 6.3 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$180.61 billion (US$5.96 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.9 percent. Textile and construction shares both advanced 1.5 percent, while foodstuff and plastics and chemical shares both increased 0.2 percent.

The three other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks falling the most at 1.2 percent. Machinery and electronics issues dropped 0.7 percent, and banking and financial shares fell 0.1 percent.
Loser outnumbered gainers 1,262 to 1,034, with 299 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$6.41 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Taiwan-Japan higher education agreement signed

TEXT.P: Two higher education organizations of Taiwan and Japan signed an agreement Friday to promote bilateral academic cooperation through a series of exchanges.

Under the agreement, the Foundation for International Cooperation in Higher Education of Taiwan (FICHET) and Japan's Consortium of Universities in Osaka (CUOSA) will launch bilateral research projects, exchange programs for students and mutual visits of educational personnel, said Lee Si-chen, the FICHET chairperson and the president of Taiwan's prestigious National Taiwan University.
"This is a further step we've made toward academic exchanges between Taiwan and Japan, " said Lee at the signing ceremony, adding that the agreement will provide a platform for future exchanges.
Eighty tertiary education institutions in Taiwan and 46 in Japan will be involved in the exchanges, said Lee.

"The agreement will make the relationship between Japanese universities and those of Taiwan as close as its relationship with China, " said Kawata Teiichi, the CUOSA chairperson, noting that Japanese universities attached great importance to the cooperation.
The accord, following the one with Australian Exchange Service, is the second of its kind signed by the FICHET with an overseas academic institution.
The FICHET was established in 2000, with an aim of integrating resources of higher education institutions and promoting Taiwan's academic performance in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.009 to close at NT$30.284.
A total of US$973 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.310 and fluctuated between NT$30.255 and NT$30.348.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier attends groundbreaking for Sun Moon Lake gondola

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung officiated Friday at a groundbreaking ceremony for a cable car system that will link Sun Moon Lake and the Formosan Aboriginal Culture Village, two popular tourist attractions in central Taiwan's Nantou County.

Chang said the planned 1,825-meter-long cable car system will help make Sun Moon Lake, long known as "the pearl in the mountains, " even brighter and help rejuvenate Taiwan's overall tourism development.
"The Sun Moon Lake Gondola will also certainly help rev up the travel industry in the central county of Nantou," Chang said.

The Sun Moon Lake Gondola, to be developed and operated by the Formosan Aboriginal Culture Village under a build-own-operate (BOO) project, is scheduled to be built in 18 months at a cost of NT$720 million (US$23.76 million).

But Village Chairman Chang Jung-yi said he hoped the gondola would be completed ahead of schedule to come on line at the end of this year when the new No. 6 Freeway that will connect the Formosan (North-South) Freeway to Puli is expected to open.
Puli, about 12 kilometers from Sun Moon Lake, is a gateway to many attractions in Nantou County and the new central cross-island highway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to help Central American allies develop vocational education

TEXT.P: A Taiwan government fund has recently offered a loan of US$10 million to the Central American Bank for Economic Integration (CABEI) with the aim of helping Taiwan's Central American allies fight poverty through education.

Lee Hsin-ying, deputy secretary-general of the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) under the supervision of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, signed a memorandum April 11 in the Dominican Republic with CABEI President Harry E. Brautigam for the establishment of the fund to offer preferential academic loans for vocational studies to students from underprivileged families in the region.

In addition, Lee said, the ICDF has also donated US$200,000 to the CABEI for the establishment of a fund to help strengthen educational exchanges between vocational schools in Taiwan and Central American countries, through which Taiwanese vocational schools can share their development experiences with their Central American counterparts.
"The program will help poor students gain access to vocational education and fight poverty through strengthening educational levels in the region," Lee went on.
The CABEI, funded in 1960 by five Central American countries -- Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica -- aims to transform Central America into a prosperous and united region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Evergreen head hopes regular flights to China soon become reality

TEXT.P: Chang Yung-fa, founder and chairman of the Evergreen Group, told President-elect Ma Ying-jeou Friday that he hoped Ma's new government could make regularly scheduled cross-Taiwan Strait passenger and cargo flights a reality as soon as possible.

In a half-hour meeting between the two at Evergreen headquarters -- one of Ma's many encounters with business leaders as he prepares to take office May 20 -- Chang hoped for direct cross-strait charters in July as scheduled and regular service to follow at the earliest possible opportunity.

At a news conference after the meeting, Ma reiterated his plan to open flight service between Taiwan and China with charters on weekends by July and then on weekdays by the end of the year before launching regular flight service.
He said he told Chang that the schedule could be moved up if negotiations went smoothly and travelers responded favorably to the services.
"Eventually, there have to be regular flights between the two sides and also rights allowing connecting flights to other countries, " Ma said.
Under the president-elect's plan, both Taiwanese and Chinese carriers would enjoy connecting flight rights, which would create additional opportunities for them to expand their businesses, Ma said.
Chang, whose EVA Airways is Taiwan's second largest carrier, also suggested opening cross-strait charter flights to cargo at the same time that passenger charters begin, Ma told reporters.

During their meeting, the two individuals also discussed education issues, with Chang suggesting that the education reform program that has been in place for the last decade be reviewed and made more inclusive, with a greater emphasis on moral education.
"People's hearts have changed in recent years, " Chang said, attributing deteriorating social order to problems in education.
The businessman is the founder of the nonprofit Chang Yung-fa Foundation, which is devoted to charity and public welfare activities.

The Evergreen Group encompasses Evergreen Marine Corp., Evergreen International Corp., EVA Airways, Evergreen Aviation Technologies Corp., Evergreen Air Services Corp., Evergreen Air Cargo Services Corp., and Evergreen International Storage and Services Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGSchoolsuperheadsto earnG 200,000 a year in rewards and incentives system
Head teachers from grammar schools could see their pay double to G200,000 a year in return for also taking over the management of failing schools in their area, under plans to bring private sector-style leadership and pay rates into state schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: Resuming cross-strait talks remains a government goal: MAC

TEXT.P: Restoring the semi-official negotiation mechanism between Taiwan and China remains one of the government's long-standing goals, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Friday.
However, the government insists that such negotiations must be conducted on principles of equality and dignity, and with no preconditions, said MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun.

Liu was referring to the talks that ground to a halt in 1999 between the Taipei- based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), the two semi-official intermediary bodies set up by each side to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties.
Liu made the comment in response to recent remarks by SEF Chairman-designate Chiang Ping-kung that he will work to resume dialogue between SEF and ARATS, after he assumes his post.

On Chiang's plan to invite to Taiwan Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council who is likely to be appointed chairman of ARATS, Liu said the MAC would welcome whoever is appointed ARATS chairman to visit Taiwan.
Liu said he believes exchange visits between SEF and ARATS will help enhance mutual trust and understanding.

A meeting between the late SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and the late ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan in Singapore in 1993 brought a series of systematic exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait after nearly five decades without any official contact.
But the exchanges have been stalled since 1999 when then-President Lee Teng-hui described cross-strait ties as a special state-to-state relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: High school girls not to be outperformed in 'Good Samaritan' efforts

TEXT.P: Students from 27 classes of the prestigious Taipei Municipal Zhongshan Girls High School have jointly sponsored 30 needy children from 16 developing countries.

Starting early this year, the students have been learning to be "good Samaritans" to sponsor needy children from poor families in less developed countries, including nations as far away as Paraguay, Ethiopia and Uganda, using their limited daily allowance or hard-earned scholarship funds.

Zhongshan Girls High Superintendent Huang Yu-yi welcomed the enthusiasm displayed by the students in joining the Foreign Sponsorship Program initiated by the Christian charity organization, Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF), saying that the activity would allow the students to practice the Biblical Good Samaritan principle of helping and loving other people and showing compassion.

Students from 10th Class Yi have jointly sponsored a seven-year-old boy, known as Obrian, from the Caribbean island country of St. Vincent and Grenadines. Their sponsorship has helped pay for Obrian's lunch at school and buy him stationery, which the subsisting family of the seven-year-old could not afford. Obrian's father deserted the family years ago, and neither his mother nor grandmother has been able to work outside the home, according to Chen Mei- chun, a TFCF director.
Hsu Wen-yu, a 12th grader, donated the full amount of an NT$3,000 scholarship she received last month for outstanding academic performance.
Chen called for all people in Taiwan who are financially capable, regardless of gender or age, to join the TFCF Foreign Sponsorship Program and the great cause of helping others.
"We hope to be good Samaritans (Luke 10: 25-36) and do the right thing regardless of religion or status. Where there is a child in need, there is TFCF," Chen added.

According to Hsieh Pi-jung, a TFCF volunteer, the charity organization was established in the 50s as an orphanage to help local needy children. It launched the Foreign Sponsorship Program in 1987 to allow the people of Taiwan to help needy children abroad.

So far, a total of 23,314 foreign children have benefited from the TFCF sponsorship program, while 38,000 others from scores of third world countries are currently receiving donations, according to Hsieh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mutual non-denial the best solution to cross-strait dispute: Ma

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Friday that "mutual non-denial" is the best approach the dispute with Beijing over Taiwan's sovereignty and said the two sides should first deal with issues more urgent than their political differences.

While China sees Taiwan as a renegade province, Taiwan's constitution treats China as part of the Republic of China's territory, Ma said. To solve the stalemate, the two can either recognize each other or deny each other's existence, but that would be "either unnecessary or impossible.

"The best solution is something in between -- mutual non-denial," he said during a discussion with 2007 Economics Nobel Laureate Eric S. Maskin, who is on a three-day visit to Taiwan to attend a forum co-organized by the global investment company Allianz, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research and a local newspaper, the Economic Daily News.
Ma added that it was better to shelve issues which could not be solved at the moment and first deal with other more urgent ones that could generate more good will and friendship.
Maskin described such an approach as "clever and constructive."
The incoming president, who is to take office May 20, also said that he does not want to continue arguing with China over the legitimacy of Taiwan's status.

"Our idea is to combine security, prosperity and dignity. In other words, if they continue to squeeze us, obviously it is not a friendly signal to Taiwan's people, " Ma said, referring to China's past use of of its political and economic clout to suppress Taiwan in the international community.

During his campaign, Ma set out the "three noes" -- no unification, no independence and no use of force -- and "three yeses" -- prosperity, security and dignity -- to be the guiding principles for cross-strait relations.
However, he admitted that it is not known whether Chinese authorities are ready to think about his proposals and whether they have such perception.

Asked whether his world-renowned "mechanism design theory" can be applied to solve the cross-strait dilemma, Maskin said that while he is not an expert on cross-strait issues, he is confident that the theory is applicable to the still unresolved dispute between Taiwan and China.

"I think mechanism design can definitely be used to help us to think about the relationship between Taiwan and mainland China," the mathematician from Princeton University said. "But again, that all depends on the particular circumstances and details."
The 57-year-old American scholar, who recently attended the Boao Forum for Asia, arrived in Taipei Thursday.

Maskin won the 2007 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences along with Leonid Hurwicz and Roger Myerson, for establishing the foundations of "mechanism design theory, " a study of designing incentives or institutions to achieve specific outcomes.

Initiated in the 1960s by Hurwicz, the theory combines the application of game theories and social choice theory and is considered the most notable economic theory on the study of information asymmetry.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA to tighten inspection of farm exports to Japan: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/08 19:44:59 (By Yang Ming-chu and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will step up its inspection of farm produce to be exported to Japan to ensure that levels of pesticide residue do not exceed the limits set by Japan, an agricultural official said Friday.

Chen Wen-to, director-general of the COA's Department of International Affairs, made the remark after Japan said in a statement Thursday that it was tightening inspection of carrots from Taiwan to check every shipment since excessive levels of pesticide residue, for the second time in April, had been found on these imports.

According to a statement by the Japan government, carrots from Taiwan were found April 15 to contain residues of methamidophos -- a highly dangerous pesticide -- of over 0.02 parts per million (ppm), using a level of monitoring that meant there was a 30-50 percent chance the produce would be inspected.

The case involved a shipment of 49 tons of carrots from Taiwan, 23 tons of which was in a warehouse, while 26 tons was already on the market, according to Japan's Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare.
Japan's limit for methamidophos residue is 0.01 ppm, while Taiwan's, as regulated by the Department of Health, is 0.1 ppm.
Chen said the COA will find the origin of the contaminated batch of carrots in order to provide guidelines for future exports.
In its statement, Japan said that in the future, carrots that fail to pass its inspections will not be allowed into the country.

Japan tightened its inspection from random checks to stricter monitoring of carrots from Taiwan after excessive pesticide residues were found for the first time on a shipment April 1, according to the statement.

Chen said that after the first report of the problem, the COA had asked members of the Taiwan Vegetables and Fruits Exporters Association to step up their own monitoring of pesticide residues on produce for export.
The COA's Agriculture and Food Agency provides subsidies to help farmers to check for pesticide residues in line with the standards set by the destination countries, Chen noted.

All Taiwan's carrot exports to Japan will now be subject to tighter inspections, which is not favorable to either the export or import firms, as the carrots would lose their freshness if the shipment has to be delayed for two to three weeks before entering the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT to promote healthier diet

TEXT.P: The Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) and a Taiwanese cancer-prevention foundation will hold a press conference April 22 to promote a healthy diet of "five servings of fruit and vegetables a day."
According to an AIT official, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and AIT spokesman Thomas Hodges will be invited to deliver speeches at the press conference.

In 2007, the AIT, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties, developed a cooperative nutrition program with Formosa Cancer Foundation (FCF) and since then has been promoting the diet.

Through the efforts of the AIT, the U.S. Department of Agriculture and several American agricultural associations have funded FCF studies on the nutritional content of elementary school lunches in Taiwan. The AIT and FCF have also been encouraging school children and their parents to switch to more healthy eating habits.
"The program has seen fruitful results and gained widespread coverage by the media," the official said.

The official explained that this year's program will offer discounts to customers who buy American fruits and vegetables at supermarkets, and will include a lucky draw for two United Airlines tickets to San Francisco and several other prizes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asia Pacific girl scouts meet in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The second general assembly of an Asia Pacific girl scout organization kicked off at Taipei City's Grand Hotel Friday, drawing a total of 221 girl scouts from around Asia to discuss regional girl scout issues.
The organization, called the Friends of Asia Pacific, is governed by the World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts (WAGGGS) , a global association supporting female-oriented scouting affairs.
The regional organization was established three years ago with the objective of raising funds to promote and arrange girl scout activities in the Asia Pacific area.
Addressing the assembly's opening ceremony, Vice President Annette Lu said that Taiwan boast considerable achievements in improving the opportunities for women in leadership positions.
She cited the one-third of Taiwan's legislators who are women, higher than the average 18 percent seen in Asian countries and 17 percent averaged in parliaments around the world.

The organization's members meet every three years, and this year's assembly is hosted by the Girls Scouts of Taiwan (GST) at the request of WAGGGS, according to GST executive Chou Yun-chiou. She said the world association made the request after being impressed by the performance of Taiwan's girl scouts.
A member from the Philippines told a Central News Agency reporter that she was glad to come to Taiwan for the exchange opportunity.

During their four-day stay here, the visiting girl scouts were expected to see some of Taipei's most popular attractions, including the National Place Museum, Taipei 101, and the Shihlin night market.
They are also scheduled to meet with Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin and Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun.
GST President Kao Chang Ming-luan said that in ably introducing Taiwan's cultures to their guests, Taiwan's girl scouts would hopefully contribute to the country's diplomacy.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP lawmakers oppose rushing through airport bill

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators objected Friday to rushing passage of a bill that would upgrade Taiwan's main international airport, arguing that it would create a "state within a state" and undermine national security.

DPP caucus whip William Lai urged the Kuomintang (KMT) , which will take power when President-elect Ma Ying-jeou assumes the presidency May 20, to work on the special airport bill after the new government lineup is in place.

"The KMT must not rashly ram the bill through the Legislative Yuan before the current caretaker DPP government's departure, " he said at a news conference after he and his DPP colleagues met with officials from the Transportation and Communications, Interior, and Finance ministries to discuss the proposal after it was screened in committee earlier in the day.

Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-luan called Tuesday for quick passage of the bill to upgrade the airport, saying that Taiwan would suffer a decline in competitiveness if the bill failed to pass soon.

The measure, which would turn the airport into a legally incorporated business, includes provisions for the county's proposed development of a "Taoyuan Aviation Park" on a 6,150-hectare lot adjacent to the airport.

The park, to be positioned as a multinational business hub with a special airport zone and free trade zone, could attract over NT$1.2 trillion (US$37 billion) worth of investment, creating annual business revenue of at least NT$600 billion and more than 80,000 jobs, Chu contended.

Lai said he agreed with the idea of turning airports into incorporated businesses but insisted that the bill be professionally assessed by relevant agencies after the new government takes power May 20.
"Various proposals contained in the bill are unworkable because they would create irreversible and serious consequences if they pass through the legislature without detailed screening," he said.

Should the bill submitted by Taoyuan County clear the legislature in its present form, the Taoyuan Aviation Park would become a "state within a state, " Lai said, that would involve the authority of 16 government agencies and be exempt from 33 laws.
It would also give corporate groups special privileges, such as allowing them to import Chinese and foreign workers or allowing Chinese nationals to enter Taiwan without a visa.
"An influx of Chinese workers would put Taiwan's national security at risk, " he warned.
Lai said he is particularly concerned that other local governments might follow suit if the legislature rashly approves the Taoyuan County bill.

DPP lawmaker Kuan Pi-ling said that out of Taiwan's 18 airports, the Taoyuan airport is the only profitable one and is required by law to turn over its annual NT$6 billion (US$198.7 million) in earnings to a national aviation fund.
Kuan asked what would happen if it only had to give back NT$1.8 billion per year as would be the case after becoming an incorporated entity.

Chu told a news conference at the Legislative Yuan in October last year that the 30-year-old airport, formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, needs to sharpen its competitiveness, as its ranking has dropped to 85th place among the world's 136 major airports.

He argued at the time that the airport needed to be turned into a legally and professionally incorporated compound comprising a multinational business operations hub, a free trade zone, warehousing and distribution facilities, exhibition centers, tourism hotels, shopping malls and a high-tech science park.
Without such a project, Chu said, the airport would no longer be globally competitive and end up being shunted aside.
The Taoyuan County magistrate said Tuesday that the bill would allow Taiwan to catch up with Japan and experience booming growth, and would benefit not only Taoyuan County but the whole country.
It would pave the way for development in other special zones such as Taichung Port and Chingchuankang Airport in central Taiwan's Taichung City, Chu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Petrol bootleggers rampant on Taipei streets: city councilor

TEXT.P: Illegal petrol traders are rampant on the streets of Taipei City as domestic gasoline prices are at the highest in history due to skyrocketing international crude oil prices, a Taipei City councilor claimed Friday.

"Bootleggers are selling 98 unleaded gasoline at NT$25 (US$0.8) per liter, while at the gas stations NT$32.2 of the state-run petroleum company CPC. Corp., Taiwan (CPC) the price is NT$32.2 per liter, " said Chuang Ruei-hsiung of the Democratic Progressive Party at a press conference held at the city council.

With the petrol coming from unknown sources, Chuang warned that the bootlegged product could cause air pollution which is a health threat. He added that the low cost of the bootlegged fuel, which is being sold with a free add-on car-wash service, is drawing taxi drivers, despite the risk of damage to their vehicle engines.
Chuang urged the Taipei City authorities to take steps to stop the illegal trade.

In response, city officials said a special team has been organized to crack down on illegal petrol sales, and that offenders may be subject to a fine of NT$1 million under the law governing petroleum management.
However, to date, the city's law-enforcement officers have not caught any underground petrol vendors, who are said to operate mostly at night and drive pickup trucks to evade police checks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Italian tenor Bocelli arrives in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Renowned Italian tenor Andrea Bocelli arrived in Taiwan Friday to a warm welcome from local fans.
Soon after his arrival, Bocelli was driven to the central city of Taichung, where he will hold his first and only concert in Taiwan, Saturday.
At a press conference held upon his arrival in Taichung City, the blind vocalist said he felt Taiwan's friendship and passion, and that he will sing in the country with his best voice ever.

Some 20,000 people, including President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, are expected to attend the concert which will be held Saturday at the Intercontinental Baseball Stadium starting at 7:00 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan Green International Film Festival to kick off Saturday

TEXT.P: The eight-day Green International Film Festival in Taiwan (GIFT) will kick off Saturday in Yilan, northeastern Taiwan, to raise awareness of global climate change.
Yilan County Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua said the festival, now in its fifth year, presented during the last four years many films from around the world that showed concern over the ecological environment.
"The festival has become the pride of Yilan residents, " Lu said, as he invited more people to participate in the festival.

This year's festival will present, in addition to local films, several award- winning productions from Germany, Netherlands, United States, United Kingdom, China, South Korea, Japan, Belgium and Mexico, Yilan County government officials said.
Among the local films, is one produced by Lai Hui-lung on the great variety of rare birds found in Yilan County.

Lai, who has shot many films about birds, noted that there are many areas in Yilan County suitable for bird-watching, but reminded the public not to make noises or wear colorful clothes as this would scare the birds.
As a sideline to the festival, the Yilan County government will also organize a two-day exhibition of organic agricultural produce and eco-friendly products, at the Yilan Sport Park.

The products on display will include organic radical batteries (ORBs) , solar- powered model cars, dissoluble packaging and energy-saving electrical appliances, which will give the public a look at different aspects of a "green lifestyle."

DOC.HEADLINE: Former vice premier could be first female DPP party chairperson

TEXT.P: Former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen registered with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Friday to compete for the job of reviving a struggling party badly bruised by two election setbacks this year.

Tsai was the last of three members to register for the party chairman race. The other two aspirants are pro-independence diehards -- DPP Legislator Trong Chai and Koo Kuan-min, a former adviser to President Chen Shui-bian.

The DPP will try and pick a leader through a coordination process that would eliminate the rancor of a competitive election. Asked whether she is willing to coordinate with the other two aspirants, Tsai said that she "has no answer" to the question
"Both are revered predecessors, and it is difficult and also an honor for me to compete with them," she said.
If coordination among the trio fails, the 52-year-old Tsai is expected to face 73-year-old Chai and 82-year-old Koo in the May 18 party chairman election.
Tsai, a usually low-profile academic and technocrat, said she "only made the decision this morning," adding that she "couldn't stop herself" and that an impossible thing has taken place.
She noted that a lot of friends urged her to run but many also tried to persuade her against the idea.

Tsai, who had said that she probably would never become involved in politics again after stepping down as vice premier on May 20, 2007, is currently the chairwoman of TaiMed Biologics, a biotechnology company based in Taiwan.
She said that after eight years in power, the party's operations have become "bureaucratic, " and she hopes to bring the party back to its "simple" nature, and make it a party of "tolerance."
The DPP will "transform into an opposition party with ruling experience," she added.
Asked if she will resign from her role with TaiMed, she said that she will "handle the issue properly" in due time.

She also expressed her views on how to deal with the party's divisive factions and nominal members -- members who are controlled by party leaders to create internal personal power bases -- two of the DPP's more intractable problems.
Tsai said factions were simply groups of people, and she hoped they could be oriented toward political views or different ways of thinking rather than traditional mutually dependent blocks.
On nominal members, Tsai said she would invite scholars to recommend a new set of rules that would help eradicate the practice.

She stressed, however, that first determining how to define nominal members and what they represented, and understanding how they hold back party development were the questions that really needed to be answered.
Tsai also acknowledged the party's indebtedness, but she said that if the DPP could convince the public to support the party, the problem would be more easily solved.

She stressed that the DPP, founded in 1987, is still a fledgling party and has many possibilities in the future. Although it fared dismally in two major elections this year, she said they should be considered part of a process rather than the final gauge of the party's success or failure.

Reports have said that with the DPP facing its biggest challenge after its defeats in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the March 22 presidential election, many DPP members are pinning their hopes on a leader with a fresh image to help the floundering party back to its feet.

A DPP young turk likened the situation to the opposition Kuomintang, arguing that the KMT has changed little from what it was eight years ago but was transformed by presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou, whose image of integrity was entrenched in the mind of the public.

DPP heavyweights, including DPP Central Standing Committee member Ker Chien- ming, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing and even former Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh have recently urged Tsai to join the race.
Former Council for Hakka Affairs Chairman Luo Wen-jia reportedly said that a party chairman should be the brand of the party.
"Even if the party head can't fully help the party regain its image, it should at least be a major start, " Luo was quoted as saying.

Tsai graduated from the department of law at National Taiwan University in 1978, and then obtained a Master's degree in Legal Science from Cornell University Law School in 1980 and then a Ph.D. from the London School of Economics (1984).

Upon her return to Taiwan, she held professorial positions at several universities until 1993 before being appointed to a succession of bodies, including chief legal adviser on International Economic Organizations for the Ministry of Economic Affairs as well as head of the Mainland Affairs Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: President lauds production of Taiwan-made armored vehicle

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lauded military personnel Friday for successfully producing Taiwan's first locally developed armored vehicles during a 40-minute visit to a production facility center in the central county of Nantou.

Chen said before inspecting the production line at the factory in Jiji Township that the Cloud Leopard armored vehicle was the result of a collaborative project between the Ministry of National Defense (MND) and local industries.
Chen added that such a collaboration was conducive to both the ministry and the private sector because it has created business opportunities and helped upgrade local industries' capabilities.

Describing the eight-wheeled vehicle that can reach speeds of 100 kilometers per hour as "fast, " "light, " "powerful" and "maneuverable, " Chen said that it was specifically designed to be adaptable to Taiwan's diverse terrain.
He encouraged the ministry to continue to develop various armored vehicles to enhance Taiwan's defense capabilities.
It took the ministry three years from 2002 to 2005 to develop the vehicle and small-scale production began last year.

The armored personnel carrier was named after the Formosan clouded leopard, a subspecies of the clouded leopard indigenous to Taiwan that is now thought to be extinct. The name was given to the vehicle because it is, like the animal, agile and swift.

DOC.HEADLINE: Large oil slick spotted off northern Taiwan coast

TEXT.P: A large oil slick, covering an area of about 30 square kilometers, has been detected off the northern Taiwan coast, the National Central University's Center for Space and Remote Sensing Research said Friday.

The center, which has been commissioned by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) to help monitor shipwrecks, collisions and other marine disasters in the country's coastal regions since 2001, spotted the oil spills floating off Jinshan, Taipei County for the first time Wednesday.
"Multiple ENVISAT satellite radar images show that the oil slick spans 30 kilometers in length and some 500 meters to 1,000 meters in width," said Liu Shou-an, director of the space research center.

The oil slick, located some 20 kilometers off Jinshan, have been traced to a point 25 degrees 39 minutes north latitude and 121 degrees 28 minutes east longitude, Liu said, almost directly north of Taiwan's northernmost point.
The spill is suspected of having leaked from a merchant ship sailing in a north- northwest direction.
Liu said the center has alerted the EPA and the National Space Center for continued monitoring in order to determine the source of pollution.
"We'll also inform neighboring countries of the discovery and ask them to assist in tracking the movement of the vessel," Liu said.

Chen Chi-fan, a professor and senior researcher at the center, said major cases of oceanic pollution are often reported in Taiwan's coastal regions because Taiwan is a marine transport center in East Asia with a thriving shipping industry.
Vessels sailing in waters off Taiwan's coast are also vulnerable to volatile weather and undersea reefs and atolls have.

Worse still, he said, human sabotage, such as the release of waste oil and waste water from merchant vessels that navigate through Taiwan's waters have aggravated marine pollution and affected the ecological situation in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex vice premier to redefine 'Taiwan identity' if elected DPP chair

TEXT.P: Former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen said Friday that if elected as the chairwoman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) she will seek to redefine "Taiwan identity."

Tsai said she will also help the party expand its international profile, including cooperation with nongovernmental organizations, and help solicit international support, so as to gain a niche for the party and make up for the deficiency of the Kuomintang (KMT) in the international community.
The 52-year-old former chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) gave her views after registering for the party chairman race by Friday's deadline.

Tsai, echoing a belief held by many in the party that the DPP no longer has a monopoly on "Taiwan identity, " said that she will seek to redefine the concept and incorporate a wide array of interpretations of what it means to be "Taiwanese."

Tsai, who was the main architect of the "special state-to-state" cross-strait relation theory espoused by former President Lee Teng-hui in 1999, also said that she will seek to build the party's new theoretical framework on China.

Under the premise of not interfering with cross-strait trade and business exchanges, Tsai said that she "will seek to strike a balance between safeguarding Taiwan's sovereignty and the development of a new theoretical framework on China."

The former vice premier said that for the past two decades, Taiwan and China and the whole of Asia have undergone many changes, and the situation the Kuomintang faced in its over five decades of rule until 2000 was quite different than that faced by the DPP in its eight years in power.
A lot of people may think that the DPP's China policy is different from that of the KMT, but they fail to see the different contexts in which the two parties formulated their policies, she said.

Tsai said that in the next 10 to 20 years, the situation in Asia will be completely different, and "how we view Asia and the world outside Asia will affect the orientation of ourselves and our relations with China."

Many DPP supporters have expressed concern about the party chairman election, believing it will be crucial to bring the floundering party back to its feet after its two major election setbacks this year -- the Jan. 12 legislative elections and March 22 presidential election, party sources said.

A lot of DPP heavyweights have been tapped as suitable to head the party, including Council of Agriculture Chairman Su Jia-chyuan; Chen Shih-meng, former secretary-general to President Chen Shui-bian; and former Legislator Luo Wen- jia.
You Ying-lung, MAC vice chairman and Straits Exchange Foundation secretary- general, even picked up a registration form Thursday, but all of the above contenders decided not to register for the race.
Tsai's competition will be two pro-independence diehards -- DPP Legislator Trong Chai and Koo Kuan-min, a former adviser to President Chen.
The election is scheduled to take place May 18 if coordination among the trio fails to produce a consensus candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei city government urged to introduce taxi quota system

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government should impose a quota on the total number of taxis operating in the northern city to resolve the problem of low occupancy rates, a Taipei city councilor said Friday.
Taipei City Councilor Chen Yung-te said during a question-and- answer session at the council that seven in 10 cabs in the city are often unoccupied.
Citing statistics for the period 2004 to 2006, Chen said that local taxi drivers picked up passengers 14.53 times a day on average, and that the drivers worked about 24 days per month.
Chen also said that 1,984 cases involving unregistered taxi drivers were reported last year and that many of the traffic violations by taxi drivers were speeding, illegal parking and drunk driving.

Many cab drivers enter the business after losing their jobs or if they are between jobs and they often rush around dangerously competing for customers, Chen said, stressing that it was necessary to introduce a quota for the number of cabs in the city.

In response, Luo Shiaw-shyan, head of the city's Department of Transportation, attributed the city's oversupply of cabs to an inflow of taxis from the neighboring Taipei County, Keelung City and Yilan County.
There are more than 60,000 taxis in the four cities and counties, according to Luo.
The Taipei city government has suspended issuing business licenses to cab drivers because the number of registered taxi drivers grew by 20 percent to more than 30,000 over the last decade, Luo said.
Meanwhile, Luo urged the central government to enact a law or provide other support to help impose a taxi quota system that would resolve the oversupply problem.

Many of the city's approximately 2.63 million residents, the second largest metropolitan population in Taiwan, rely on scooters and a convenient public transportation network, comprised of a mass rapid transit system and buses, to get around.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to keep tap on Chinese leader's visit to Japan: envoy

TEXT.P: Taiwan will closely monitor developments when China President Hu Jintao visits Japan next month, Taiwan's representative to Japan Ko Se-kai said Friday.

Ko said that his office will carefully follow Hu's visit May 6 during which he is expected to meet with Japanese Emperor Akihito and Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda and sign a "fourth political document" that will complement the three -- a 1972 Sino- Japanese Joint Statement, the 1978 Peace and Friendship Treaty, and the 1998 Sino-Japanese Joint Declaration -- that form the foundation for Sino- Japanese ties.

Ko said that if the document mentions Taiwan, he hopes Japan will not deviate from its previous stance, which is that Japan acknowledges but does not recognize China's claim that Taiwan is a part of the People's Republic of China.
The envoy made the remarks when he reported on bilateral relations between Taiwan and Japan at a legislative committee hearing.
He would not comment when asked about the possibility of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou visiting Japan prior to his inauguration May 20.
Ko noted that Japan was concerned about whether the incoming Kuomintang administration, which is considered to be more pro-China than the DPP administration, will change its policy toward Japan.
"Both Taiwan and Japan should brief the other side on its exchanges with China to avoid misunderstandings," he continued.

Ko also said that Taiwan and Japan have seen some breakthroughs in their relations in recent years mainly because of the ascension of several prime ministers and cabinet members who are friendly to Taiwan.
Looking to the future of bilateral relations, Ko said that his office will dedicate itself to promoting the opening of new air routes between Japan's Haneda Airport and Taiwan's airports.
Haneda Airport, which handles both domestic and international traffic, is only 10 kilometers from central Tokyo, far more conveniently located than Narita International Airport.

The signing of a free trade agreement between the two countries will be still difficult, Ko said, adding that his office will focus instead on talks on specific issues such as intellectual property rights, trade facilitation and the signing of a bilateral investment agreements.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor may visit Beijing to promote tourism

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu may lead a delegation to attend an international travel expo in Beijing in June to promote the southern port city as a tourist destination, a city official said Friday.
However, Chen will only make the visit under the principles of equal treatment and mutual respect, said Liu Hsin-cheng, head of the city's Economic Affairs Bureau.
Liu's remarks came one day after Chen expressed willingness to visit Beijing as long as China will not downgrade her position to a local head of the Chinese government.
China claims sovereignty over Taiwan, although they split after a civil war in 1949.
Chen said that since she was elected as Kaohsiung mayor in 2006, China has twice denied her a visa, once to visit Beijing last May, and again to visit Hong Kong earlier this year.

Chen also expressed doubts about the sincerity of a statement made by Li Weiyi, spokesman for China's Taiwan Affairs Office, April 16 that he would welcome ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) heads of local governments on visits to China in their "proper capacities."
Chen reiterated that her current unalterable position is mayor of Kaohsiung.
The DPP is generally considered as favoring formal independence for Taiwan, a stance that China says is unacceptable.
On Friday, Liu also met with representatives from the city's hotels, travel agencies and associations to discuss how to attract Chinese tourists to Kaohsiung once they are allowed to visit Taiwan.

The representatives suggested that city officials should lead delegations on visits to China to raise Kaohsiung's profile, and should print brochures in simplified Chinese for potential tourists from China.
In addition, they also asked the city government to open Kaohsiung Harbor to Chinese visitors.

In response, Liu said that the city government will set up a pavilion of 12 booths -- which he said will outnumber those planned by Taipei County, Yilan County, Hualien County and Yunlin County -- at Beijing's travel expo June 19-21 to feature the city's tourist attractions.
Liu added that Chen will also lead a delegation to visit Japan in May and others to South Korea and Singapore in September to try to lure more visitors to Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: New presidential chief of staff named

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vice chairman will serve as the incoming president's chief of staff, President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's office announced late Friday in a statement.
Chan Chuen-po, who has been a KMT vice chairman since 2007, will serve as secretary-general of the Presidential Office after Ma is sworn in on May 20, the statement said.
Former Taipei Deputy Mayor Yeh Chin-chuan will serve as Chan's deputy, the statement added.

Chan, 67, is a veteran KMT official who has held many important party posts, including secretary-general. He was the party's secretary-general during Ma's tenure as KMT chairman from August 2005 to early 2007. Chan also played a leading role in Ma's presidential campaign.

Yeh, 58, a high school classmate of Ma, served as health chief of Taipei for two years after Ma became mayor of the city in 1998. He then left that post and became a public health professor at Tzu Chi University. He returned to the front line during the outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) in the country in 2003. His role was important in boosting the morale of the staff at Taipei's Hoping Hospital during the SARS crisis.
Yeh became Taipei's deputy mayor in August 2004, but quit the post in April 2006 to seek KMT nomination to run for Taipei mayor, a bid he lost.

The new appointments came a day after Chan Chi-shean, one of Ma's key campaign strategists, issued a public statement said he had decided not to be part of the new government or the Presidential Office.

Chan Chi-shean, a noted surgeon who once served as Department of Health minister in the previous KMT administration, had been widely tipped to be the new president's deputy chief of staff or vice premier.
In a statement that caught many by surprise, Chan Chi-shean said he will join Taiwan's largest charity group -- Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- after Ma takes office May 20.
Chan Chi-shean was the superintendent of Chi Mei Medical Center in Tainan City, one of the most prestigious medical institutions in southern Taiwan, before he joined Ma's campaign team last July.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 19, 2008

TEXT.P: 2. Event: News conference on signature campaign for legislative transparency. Date and Time: 10:00 a.m., Saturday, April 19, 2008. Place: Legislative Yuan front gate, No. 1, Zhongshan S. Road, Taipei City. Organizers: Citizens Congress Watch. Press Contact: Tel.2358-5858. 3. Event: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou attending Andrea Bocelli's concert. Date and Time: 07:00 p.m., Saturday, April 19, 2008. Place: Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium in Taichung City. Press Contact: Tel.2343-4567.
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 19, or the 14th day of the third month of the Year of Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Jose Echegaray y Eizaguirre, Spanish dramatist, mathematician, statesman and Nobel laureate, is born.
1853: Russia claims to be the protectorate of Turkey in a prelude to the Crimean War.
1882: British naturalist Charles Darwin dies at the age of 73. He revolutionized the study of biology with his theory of evolution based on natural selection. His most famous works include "Origin of Species" and "The Descent of Man."
1906: French chemist and physicist Pierre Curie is run over and killed in Paris at the age of 47. He and his wife Marie shared the 1903 Nobel Prize for fundamental research into radioactivity.
1928: Japanese troops occupy Shantung Province in northern China.
1942: Chinese Expeditionary Forces led by Gen. Sun Li-jen capture Yenangyuang in northern Burma, rescuing more than 7,000 British and Burmese troops from Japanese encirclement.
1948: The first National Assembly elects Chiang Kai-shek as the Republic of China's first president under the new ROC Constitution, garnering 2,430 out of 2,704 votes.
1956: Prince Rainier of Monaco marries American screen actress Grace Kelly in Monte Carlo. Over 1,200 guests attend the televised Catholic wedding ceremony.
1959: The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan leader fleeing a Communist Chinese invasion of his country, finds sanctuary in India.
1960: South Korean President Syngman Rhee is toppled in a nationwide pro- democracy student uprising that was protesting election fraud.
1966: Australian troops leave Sydney to join American forces in Vietnam.
1974: The Blood Donation Association of the Republic of China is inaugurated.
1975: India's first satellite is launched by a Soviet rocket.
1977: ROC Education Minister Tsiang Yien-si resigns to take responsibility for an incident in which 32 college students and teachers were killed when their boat capsized near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan. Tsiang was succeeded by Li Yuan- zu.
1992: Dutch Minister of Foreign Trade Yvonne van Rooy visits Taipei to seek stronger bilateral relations.
1993: A total of 87 Branch Davidian cult members, including their leader David Koresh, are killed when federal agents storm their compound in Waco, Texas, after a 51-day standoff. Nine other members are freed.
1995: A huge truck bomb destroys the Alfred P. Murrah government building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring more than 400 others.
1995: Malawi President Bakili Muluzi pays a state visit to Taipei.
1997: The S.S. Sheng Da, a mainland China container freighter, steams into Kaohsiung Port on its maiden voyage, becoming the first ship to sail directly to Taiwan from the mainland in 48 years, and completing a historic crossing of one of the world's great political divides.
1999: Tsai Shun-fa, 52, known as "Bean Curd Papa," is honored by Premier Vincent Siew for donating blood 495 times over 20 years.
1999: The Republic of China-Swaziland Conference on Economical and Technological Cooperation opens in Taipei.
2000: Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, says that if Beijing bullies Taiwanese doing business in mainland China, it will hurt both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian promises that his administration will help the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau transform itself into a "National Bureau of Investigation."
2001: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew says that he will file an application with the government for a visit to mainland China to pitch for the formation of a "common market" across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be not concerned that men do not know you; be concerned that you have no ability."

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government should impose a quota on the total number of taxis operating in the northern city to resolve the problem of low occupancy rates, a Taipei city councilor said Friday.
Taipei City Councilor Chen Yung-te said during a question-and- answer session at the council that seven in 10 cabs in the city are often unoccupied.
Citing statistics for the period 2004 to 2006, Chen said that local taxi drivers picked up passengers 14.53 times a day on average, and that the drivers worked about 24 days per month.
Chen also said that 1,984 cases involving unregistered taxi drivers were reported last year and that many of the traffic violations by taxi drivers were speeding, illegal parking and drunk driving.

Many cab drivers enter the business after losing their jobs or if they are between jobs and they often rush around dangerously competing for customers, Chen said, stressing that it was necessary to introduce a quota for the number of cabs in the city.

In response, Luo Shiaw-shyan, head of the city's Department of Transportation, attributed the city's oversupply of cabs to an inflow of taxis from the neighboring Taipei County, Keelung City and Yilan County.
There are more than 60,000 taxis in the four cities and counties, according to Luo.
The Taipei city government has suspended issuing business licenses to cab drivers because the number of registered taxi drivers grew by 20 percent to more than 30,000 over the last decade, Luo said.
Meanwhile, Luo urged the central government to enact a law or provide other support to help impose a taxi quota system that would resolve the oversupply problem.

Many of the city's approximately 2.63 million residents, the second largest metropolitan population in Taiwan, rely on scooters and a convenient public transportation network, comprised of a mass rapid transit system and buses, to get around.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times Citing Tibet, temple spurns Olympic torch Zenkoji, the city of Nagano's main temple, declined Friday to serve as the starting point of the Japan leg of the torch relay for the Beijing Olympics, citing safety concerns and the crackdown on Buddhists in Tibet.

Pope Benedict XVI celebrated a colorful, open- air Mass with thousands of eager faithful at Washington's just-opened baseball stadium Thursday and later urged church educators to work to strengthen Roman Catholic identity in their schools and universities or risk "confusion" for the young. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

: The Straits Times: New China visa rules cause confusion.
Beijing has slapped new visa rules on travellers to China ahead of the Olympic Games, causing confusion and delay for many around the world.

Deputy Prime Minister Wong Kan Seng will deliver a ministerial statement in Parliament Monday, the report is about how the Jemaah Islamiah (JI) leader Mas Selamat escaped from the Whitley Road Detention Center in almost two months ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q1 inward FDI down 21% year-on-year

TEXT.P: Inward foreign direct investment (FDI) approved by the government in the first quarter of 2008 amounted to US$1.19 billion, a decrease of 21.19 percent compared with the same period last year, according to a report released Saturday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

During the first three months of this year, approved outward FDI posted a year- on-year increase of 129.1 percent to reach US$1.16 billion, statistics from the ministry's Investment Commission showed.
In March alone, approved inward FDI amounted to US$427 million, while outward FDI totaled US$437 million.

According to data from the Securities and Futures Bureau under the Financial Supervisory Commission, in the first quarter of this year, new securities issued overseas by Taiwan-based listed companies amounted to US$318 million, and foreign investors remitted a net amount of US$15.98 billion into Taiwan for investment in the stock market.
In terms of China-bound investment, a total of 184 projects worth a total of US$1.98 billion were approved by the commission in the first quarter of this year.
The amount, which represented a declince of 4.61 percent year-on-year, included US$832 million for March.
During the three months to March, Taiwan businesses registered 74 new China- bound investment projects worth no more than US$200,000 with the commission, with total value of US$9.23 million.

Of the investment approved in the first quarter, 32.4 percent targeted Jiangsu province, 17.84 percent targeted Shanghai, 13.68 percent targeted Guangdong province, 10.48 percent targeted Fujian province and 7.79 percent targeted Zhejiang province.

By industry, 14.3 percent of the approved investments were for electronic part and component manufacturing, 11.81 percent for base metal manufacturing, 10.96 percent for the manufacturing of computers, electronics and optical products, 8.92 percent for power equipment manufacturing, and 8.32 percent for machinery manufacturing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City real estate transactions up 11 percent in Q1

TEXT.P: Real estate transactions in Taipei City were up by 11 percent in the first quarter compared to the last three months of 2007, a sign of rebounding confidence in the local housing market.
The figures released by the city government show that the number of properties bought and sold in January reached its highest level since the second month of last year.
Real estate brokers said the figures show that Taipei City residents' confidence in the local housing market has recovered and that this trend should continue.

Yeh Ling-chi, general manager of Yungching Real Estate Co., said that online surveys conducted by his company after the January legislative elections and the March presidential election clearly indicate that a growing number of residents are optimistic about Taiwan's housing market over the coming months.

He said the surveys revealed that confidence in Taipei's housing market has reached its highest level since the fourth quarter of 2006 and rebounded significantly from a low in the latter half of last year.

Although the number of real estate transactions in Taipei City in the first three months of this year rose 11 percent quarter-on-quarter, the figure was still down 6 percent from the level for the first quarter of 2007, according to city government figures.

The nation's top transportation official yesterday announced steps that she said will improve oversight of airlines' compliance with safety mandates and ensure that last week's mass groundings and flight cancellations do not recur.

After three days in which Pope Benedict XVI has persistently addressed the scandal of child sexual abuse by priests, a top Vatican official said on Friday that the church was considering changes to the canon laws that govern how it handles such cases.
