DOC.HEADLINE: Mobile Internet subscriptions up 30% year-on-year in Q4 2007

TEXT.P: The number of mobile phone subscriptions registered for mobile Internet services soared 30 percent year-on-year in the fourth quarter of 2007 to 11.86 million, but actual usage of the function lagged behind, an industry report has revealed.

The increase of 2.71 million mobile Internet subscriptions in Taiwan meant that 48.8 percent of all cell phone subscriptions had access to Internet service functions, according to a report released recently by the Foreseeing Innovative New Digiservices (FIND), a Web site run by the Institute for Information Industry to provide professional information on Internet demographics and trends.

It said the growth was mainly attributable to a sharp rise in 3G data service subscriptions, which nearly doubled from 3.29 million in the fourth quarter of 2006 to 6.53 million in the fourth quarter of 2007 and accounted for 51.1 percent of all mobile Internet subscriptions.

That share outpaced the 32 percent subscribed for the Internet through general packet radio services (GPRS), a clear indication that 3G is replacing GPRS as the mainstream technology for mobile Internet access.
The rise in mobile Internet subscriptions, however, has not necessarily led to an increase in mobile Internet users.

According to a survey conducted by FIND in August 2007 and released in January 2008, only 9.7 percent of Taiwan's population, or 2.22 million people, had gone online using mobile devices, only 1.6 percentage points higher than in 2006.

The results indicate that mobile Internet use may not be as popular as it appears to be, FIND analysts said, adding that promoting its use reamins a major issue to be addressed by mobile network operators.

DOC.HEADLINE: President joins with Pope in calling for PRC dialogue with Tibet

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Friday condemned China's military crackdown on Tibet and said he supports the pope's message of encouraging "dialogue and tolerance" in solving the problem.

At a ceremony celebrating the third anniversary of Pope Benedict XVI's ascension to the papacy at the Holy See's embassy in Taipei, Chen called on the Beijing government to solve the problem peacefully, improve its human rights practices, and guarantee religious freedom to China's people.

During a weekly audience in late March after the suppression occurred, the pontiff appealed for an end to the violence in Tibet and neighboring areas in China, and urged Beijing and Lhasa to find "solutions that will safeguard peace and the common good" in Tibet.
Protests in the Tibetan capital by Buddhist monks demanding greater cultural freedom and automony turned violent on March 14 and were suppressed militarily by China in a bloody crackdown.
Chen said that China should allow interaction between missionaries and the Chinese people and should end its oppression of individuals' rights to choose the food that nourishes their souls.
He also urged China to abandon its military threat against Taiwan by removing and destroying missiles aimed at the country to ensure regional peace.
At Friday's celebration, Chen also extended his congratulations on behalf of Taiwan's people and the government to the pope on his third anniversary in office.

Taiwan is a faithful partner in carrying out charity missions that reflect the Holy See's values, Chen said, citing humanitarian aid provided by Taiwan's government and people to areas that have experienced natural disasters or man- made calamities.
He said Taiwan will continue its exchanges and interaction with the Vatican as part of its efforts to improve human rights, democracy, freedom, and peace in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's advantages as springboard to China showcased in U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/08 16:57:37 (By Lillian Lin and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association and the U.S. Department of Commerce jointly held symposiums in two major U.S. East Coast cities in recent days to introduce Taiwan's advantages as a springboard for U.S. businesses wanting to make inroads into China.
The first symposium on "Taiwan and Hong Kong as Gateways to Asia" was held in Philadelphia on Thursday, with more than 100 business management academics from around Pennsylvania attending.
The second gathering took place Friday at the Manhattan headquarters of the international package delivery company UPS, with 100-plus U.S. businesspeople based in the New York area taking part.
The U.S. Department of Commerce invited Gregory M. Wong, head of the American Institute in Taiwan's Commecial Section, to deliver a speech on "Taiwan: Asia's Strategic Market" at the two seminars.

In his speech, Wong said that Taiwan is a society of friendly and hospitable people where English is one of the languages of business. He further said Taiwan's people are very familiar with "the American lifestyle" and have incorporated many elements of it into their own lives, adding that U.S. products have enjoyed strong popularity in the country.

Wong also said that with the recent election of Ma Ying-jeou and Vincent Siew as the new president and vice president, respectively, Taiwan's new administration is expected to follow a more open policy on links with China, including allowing convertibility of the Chinese yuan and Taiwan dollar in Taiwan and launching regular direct cross-strait flight services.
He noted that this more liberalized approach will make Taiwan even more attractive in terms of serving as a platform for U.S. businesses looking to make inroads into the Chinese market.

Wang cited several sets of statistics to stress the importance of business ties between Taiwan and the U.S., noting that Taiwan is the United States' ninth largest trading partner and the 10th largest market for U.S. exports.
He also said that the United States is the second largest destination for overseas investment by Taiwanese businesses.

Noting that the U.S. Department of Commerce places importance on Taiwan's trade and economic position in the world, Wong said that of the department's 20-plus overseas units, its presence in Taiwan ranks ninth in the world in terms of staff numbers.
He added that Taiwan ranks third in terms of the amount of information and statistics provided to U.S. businesses on export opportunities.

Participants in the symposiums raised many questions following Wong's speech, including queries related to the future direction of Taiwan's industrial development policies as well as the climate for foreigners doing business in the country.

Wong invited Mr. V.C. Chu, director of the Investment and Trade Office of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States (TECRO) , to assist in answering the participants' questions.
Chu said that Mandarin is the main language used in business and daily life in Taiwan but that the use of English is also quite prevalent in doing business.

Chu also introduced various aspects of the Taiwan government's industrial development policies, including the elements and achievements of its "Two Trillion Twin Stars" policy, as well as the next administration's planned projects on infrastructure development and boosting trade and investment.
After Friday's symposium in New York City, the participants paid a visit to TECRO's Investment and Trade Office to discuss cooperation on boosting Taiwan-U.S. economic and trade ties in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Convenience store in Taipei 101 goes high-end and reaps the rewards

TEXT.P: A convenience chain operator has recently succeeded in boosting revenues of its outlet in Taipei 101 by abandoning the standard convenience store look and creating a deluxe ambiance catering to the building's higher-end customers.

Taiwan FamilyMart Co.'s renovation of its store on the 35th floor of the skyscraper has boosted spending per customer by 30 percent and sales revenues by 35 percent since the outlet was reopened on April 7, according to FamilyMart manager Lin Tsuei-chuan.
The renovation is part of the chain's plan to customize its stores to the communities or neighborhoods in which they are located to reflect the changing tastes of consumers.

FamilyMart President Chang Ren-dun said his company believes that today's consumers want the convenience store to deliver "lifestyle satisfaction" rather than simply time savings as has been the case in the past, leading to the concept of a "new-style" outlet found in Taipei 101.
Lin, who said a number of the chain's 2,259 stores are undergoing similar renovations, indicated that these new outlets will vary the products they sell based on location.

She pointed out, for example, that the company's first new-style chain store in a hospital district, inaugurated last year, offers more products related to medical care and fruits and gift baskets people can offer as gifts when visiting patients than one would find at a typical FamilyMart shop.

Lin said the product mix in the chain's Taipei 101 store, which is only accessible by workers and tenants in the building, is 30 percent different from regular outlets, with fresh fruit, low-fat, low-sugar snacks, 300 imported items, and cosmetic products that are popular among young female consumers on offer.
A large portion of people working in the building are foreign businessmen and female employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: '3D virtual guinea pig' to be developed for new drug development

TEXT.P: A government-run laboratory is close to developing an imagery database of guinea pigs that will allow "virtual animal testing, " reducing the cost of drug development and the demand for live laboratory animals, sources at the National Applied Research Laboratories (NARL) said Saturday.
The 3D-virtual guinea pig system was developed by NARL's National Laboratory Animal Center (NLAC) , which used true-color image algorithms to reconstruct guinea pigs in a digitized environment.
NLAR researchers said they have finished establishing the imagery data and will have the system ready for practical applications after some final adjustments are made.

Explaining how the system functions, NLAR researchers said that after parameters have been entered, the system projects the interaction between a drug and the animal based on given settings and the guinea pigs' sectional images, physical information, and biological characteristics entered in the database.
Researchers said such a process would be able to replace some live animal experiments, saving the lives of laboratory animals and the cost of acquiring guinea pigs.

Taking drug experiments as an example, researchers noted that a series of experiments require hundreds to thousands of rodents, and that a "specific pathogen free" (SPF) mouse can cost up to several thousand Taiwan dollars.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Montezemolo: It's enough with trade unions' veto.
Italian industrial leader Luca Cordero Montezemolo said Friday that the results of the April 13-14 general elections showed a defeat of the anti-business forces and that the workers are more close to enterprises than to trade unions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition to raise awareness of global warming opens

TEXT.P: A special exhibition aiming at raising the public's awareness of global warming and reduction of carbon dioxide emissions opened Saturday, with some 100 activists pledging to save energy resources on a daily basis to save the earth.

Visitors of the exhibition can calculate how many tons of carbon dioxide they produce per day by answering a quiz, and they will also become acquainted with the impact of global warming and the ways people can conserve energy to make the earth healthier.

"I hope people can really understand that our earth is sick, " said Josephine Lee, a spokeswoman of the event organizer - - the Da-an Branch of the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation (TCF).
Saying that knowing about global warming is not enough, Lee emphasized that "we must learn what to do and how to do it to save energy on a daily basis, thus helping save our environment."
One fifth grader who visited the exhibition with her mother, vowed to invite her friends to save energy after attending the show.
"Through the exhibition, I now understand the importance of environmental protection," said Wu Chi-ning.

Seven-year-old boy Chang Ching-hsiang said he learned that "the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions will also reduce flooding " and encouraged people to get into the habit of garbage sorting and recycling.

Kim Cassidy, the only foreign Tzu Chi commissioner in Taiwan, suggested at the opening ceremony that everyone should use public transportation more often and switch off lights when they aren't needed.

"It saves not only the earth but also our money, Cassidy said, who was born in New York and learned about the foundation when it solicited help for victims of a major earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999 that battered central Taiwan and left 2,145 dead.

Based on the teachings of Master Cheng Yen, who founded the foundation in 1996 and has been devoted to environmental protection for more than 20 years, the foundation's Da-an Branch will also launch a campaign to show its determination to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, Lee said.
More than 300 shops on Zhongxiao East Road, one of Taipei's most popular shopping areas, will switch off their store signboards simultaneously for 10 minutes Sunday evening, Lee said.
"It wont affect the businesses at all, " she said. "On the contrary, it not only serves the shops but also shoppers as a reminder to conserve energy."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese charity NGO to 'send love to America'

TEXT.P: The Chou Ta-kuan Cultural and Educational Foundation (CTKF) , a local charity dedicated to caring for children with cancer and other serious diseases, said Saturday it will donate the proceeds from sales of a book of poems in the United States to an American cancer society to benefit poor child cancer patients.

Titled "I Still Have a Leg", the selection of the poems to be sold in the U.S. was created by Chou Ta-kuan, a 10-year old boy who died in 1997 of cancer but retained a passion for life until his final days.
After Chou's death, his parents founded the foundation in 1997 to provide medical services and financial aid to children afflicted with serious diseases.
In the foundation's "Send Love to America" activity, "I Still Have a Leg" will be released in the United States in early May, the 12th country where the book has been published.
To date, 4 million copies have been sold in different languages around the world, with the more than NT$16 million in royalties earned used to help the poorest among ailing children in 11 countries.
Besides making a donation to the cancer society, the foundation will also present "Love for Life Awards" to three lovers of life living in the U.S.
"This is a most beautiful and touching diplomatic mission, " said Foreign Minister James Huang, who was invited to the event by the foundation.

At Saturday's news conference, Huang and Chou Jin-hua, the founder of the foundation and Chou Ta-kuan's father, awarded two Taiwanese young girls with the "Love For Life" award, affirming their passion and perseverance in striving for life.

One of the recipients, Lin Mu-ching, had her left leg amputated at the age of 16 because of cancer. Encouraged by Chou's poems, she decided later to overcome her physical disability and has traveled to 15 countries, taken up rock-climbing, and is now the host of a TV show.

"The imperfection of one's body cannot hinder life from reaching perfection, " said Wang Shu-chiao, the other prize recipient, who lost her left arm when she was a child after getting her arm caught in a meat mincer at a restaurant, owned by the family's neighbors.
The two girls formed a "three-arm, three-legged dance pairing" to prove that "without arms and legs, we can still dance."
The "Love For Life" award is given by the foundation every year to about 20 people worldwide who fight for life with courage, compassion and perseverance, the foundation said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic inflation could top 3% if oil prices keep rising: CIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's inflation rate could rise to 3.23 percent if the average price of West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude oil averages US$115.84 per barrel this year, a local economic think tank has forecast.

If crude oil prices maintain levels in that range, Taiwan's projected economic growth would shrink to 4.6 percent, while private consumption growth would fall slightly from a projected 3.29 percent to 3.23 percent, according to a report released this week by the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER).

With the WTI oil prices projected to average US$100.61 per barrel this year, the CIER has predicted a 2.64 percent increase in Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) for this year, and 4.67 percent growth in the country's gross domestic product.

Both numbers exceed estimates by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, which predicted in February that inflation would rise only moderately by 1.98 percent this year and economic growth would reach 4.32 percent.

However, if the average WTI oil price declines to US$93 per barrel, the CIER predicted that economic growth would expand slightly to 4.71 percent and private consumption would rise to 3.33 percent. The inflation rate, meanwhile, would fall to 2.3 percent.
Oil prices may drop if supply increases or if a worldwide economic slowdown causes global demand to decrease, the research body said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan a creative country in culture: Taipei mayor

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the most democratic country among Chinese-speaking nations, which enables writers or artists to fully unleash their creativity, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Saturday at an event honoring authors of children's picture books.

"Taiwan should be proud of its creativity in cultural activities" spawned by its democracy, Hau said at an award ceremony organized by the Hsin-Yi Foundation (HYF) to honor picture books for children aged between 0 and 8.

The foundation was established in 1971 to promote early childhood education, and the award was created 20 years ago to introduce good picture books that parents and their children could share together.

At Saturday's ceremony, six winning titles chosen from 191 entries were honored, including one telling a story about a toad and an anole (a small lizard) that won its two authors the top prize of NT$200,000 (US$6,557).
Hau said that children's books were rarely published in Taiwan decades ago and stressed that the foundation's achievements in creating a good reading environment for children were admirable.
"Reading good children's books helps not only create better relations between parents and their children, it also helps Taiwan cultivate future talents," Hau said

Commending the winning titles as "the most valuable treasure of Taiwan, " foundation chairman Ho Shou-chuan promised that "the foundation will continue its efforts to bring Taiwanese society more reading materials of good quality for young children.
"Through the winning titles, we can see cultural diversity, creativity, and confidence within Taiwanese society," Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sixty tons of garbage collected at beach cleanup in northern Taiwan

TEXT.P: More than 3,000 volunteers collected 60 tons of garbage from an 18.5-kilometer stretch of Taipei County beaches in northern Taiwan Saturday, in an activity held to mark April 22 World Earth Day.

Some 3,091 volunteers scoured Taiwan's northern beaches for two hours looking for trash ahead of the environmental cleanup day observed around the globe on April 22, and from the 60 tons of garbage collected recovered 14 tons of recyclable resources.

The activity was co-organized by the central government's Environmental Protection Administration, the Taipei County government, and the county's eight townships locating on the northern coast, including Jinshan, Bali, and Danshuei.

The local activity drew foreign guests, such as Ambassador of Panama Julio Mock Cardenas, Charge d'Affairs of Saint Christopher and Nevis Jasmine Elise Huggins, American Institute in Taipei (AIT) Taipei Office Deputy Director Robert Wang, and German Trade Office Deputy Director Andy Gursch, exemplifying concern for the earth not bounded by borders.
Over 600 employers of the Taiwan-based Hotai Motor Co., a vehicle manufacturer, and more than 20 family members of AIT staff, also participated in Saturday's activity.

In addition to daily cleaning efforts, Taipei County's Environmental Protection Bureau holds a united cleanup activity once a year and asks townships along the coast to hold cleanups in spring and fall every year, said the bureau's director Teng Chia-chi.

DOC.HEADLINE: Theme design contest for Design Alliance Congress launched

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Design Center launched a promotional theme design contest Saturday for the 2011 International Design Alliance Congress to be held in Taipei City.
The promotional theme design should reflect Taiwan's uniqueness and culture as well as be representative of the times, the center said.
The first, second and third place finishers will receive NT$30,000 (US$986.40), NT$20,000 and NT$10,000, respectively, i tn cash prize, the center said.
The International Design Alliance Congress is being organized by iF International Forum Design, the Taiwan Design Center and UNIPLAN Taiwan Corporation.
The theme of the congress will be "Fusion, " blending East and West as well as technology and traditional culture, the organizers said.

The world's three largest international design organizations -- the International Council of Societies of Industrial Design, the International Council of Graphic Design and the International Federation of Interior Architects/Designers -- established the International Design Alliance in early 2007.
The International Design Alliance Congress to be held in Taipei will be the first of its kind since the alliance's establishment.
The promotional theme design contest for the congress will run through April 25, the center said.
Those interested in participating in the contest can e-mail fusion_2011tdc@yahoo.com, fusion2011tdc@gmail.com, or tracyhuang@tdc.org.tw for more information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fresh start for DPP after registration: party chairman

TEXT.P: The absence of past party heavyweights from this year's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman election registration marks a fresh start for the party, DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh said Saturday.

Hsieh was referring to himself and the three other contenders for the DPP's presidential nomination last year -- former premiers Su Tseng-chang and Yu Shyi- kun and Vice President Annette Lu. None of them came forward to register for the race by Friday's deadline.

Hsieh, who lost to his rival Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang by 2.21 million votes in the March 22 presidential election, said that "I have said that I wouldn't run, but the others could have of course joined the race."
"This means that the people want a change for the party and that the newcomers will have a free hand in bringing thorough change, " he said.

Hsieh made the remarks in the last of a series of meetings held to review the DPP's latest election setback. Nearly 200 party officials, including Su and Lu, attended the meeting at the Taipei International Convention Center.

Conspicuously absent from the meeting was President Chen Shui-bian, who said on the sidelines of a fundraiser held Saturday afternoon that he "took leave" because he himself is the target of review and his absence would allow others to "speak their minds more freely." The other absentee was Yu.

Hsieh noted that "the party's fate lies in its name -- democracy and progress." The people have high expectations for the party to continue to progress, he said, and criticism will be heaped on the party if it doesn't pursue the path of progress.

He said the DPP suffered major setbacks for a multitude of reasons, and this is why it held a series of meetings to listen to the views of people from all walks of life, and not just from party members.

Three DPP members registered for the chairmanship election -- former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen, DPP Legislator Trong Chai and Koo Kuan-min, a former adviser to President Chen -- and Hsieh hoped a new party leader could be produced as soon as possible.
The DPP's party chairman election will be held May 18 and the winner inaugurated May 21, much earlier than in the past when a new chairman would not have assumed the post until July, Hsieh said.
The schedule has been moved up, he said, to create a "seamless transition" so that there will be no vacuum in the party's check-and-balance of the new president, who will be sworn in on May 20.
Hsieh, who left the meeting after speaking for about 10 minutes, urged all participants to freely express their views on party reform to help it regain its feet.
Chai and Koo attended Saturday's gathering, but Tsai was absent because of a previously scheduled overseas visit.

On suggestions by some DPP members, including Su, that it would be better to come up with a chairman through a consultative process, Chai said an important trait for a party chairman would be the ability to solve the party's problems.
"If Tsai has the capacity and the determination, then it will be all right for her to serve in the post," Chai said.
But he argued that party and administrative affairs are different, which would make it difficult for Tsai, whose political career has been spent mostly as an administrator.
The major function of a party chairman is to "help win elections, " Chai said, but his rival, he contended, is "not familiar with party affairs."
Chai contended he is more capable than Tsai in many key areas, such as election affairs, party affairs, Taiwan identity and reform of the DPP.
He stressed the first crucial test for the DPP will be the city and county head elections in late 2009, saying that if the DPP continued its losing streak, it will be wiped out.
Koo, a pro-independence diehard like Chai, was all praise for Tsai but said, "I wouldn't know how the chair issue can be coordinated."
On suggestions that coordination was necessary for the sake of party unity, Koo said, "it's easier said than done."

Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu gave her blessing to all three contenders, expressing the hope that the race can end peacefully and that no one gets bruised because of the heated competition as the party could not afford more infighting.

Chen also laid out the qualifications that an ideal chairperson would have -- being able to unify the party's factions and live up to the high expectations of society, and having ideals and regaining the public's trust of the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-born, Oscar-winning director working on comedy
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 18 (CNA) 04/19/08 20:01:01 (By Chu Lu-sheng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-born Oscar-wining film director Ang Lee disclosed Friday that he is currently working on a comedy, tentatively named A Little Game.
He said the film, a Hollywood-style picture on a modest budget, will not have any Chinese actors or actresses, and he hoped it could be completed and released next year.

Lee, whose credits include Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, which won the Academy Award for Best Foreign Picture in 2000, and Brokeback Mountain, which won the Academy Award for Best Director in 2005, said the purpose of making a movie is neither to please the audience nor to ask them to completely accept it.
He said the hope that he can convey ideas and communicate with moviegoers is what inspires him to produce films.
Lee made the remarks in a seminar with actress/director Joan Chen at a three-day annual meeting organized by the Committee of 100 (C100) in Los Angeles.
Both Lee and Chen were honored for their achievement in the film industry.

The C100 is a prominent nonprofit organization based in New York City that was founded in 1990 by a group of Chinese Americans who are leaders in their respective fields. Committee members include noted AIDS researcher David Ho and Yahoo! co-founder Jerry Yang.

Lee last came to Taiwan in September 2007 to promote his latest work "Lust, Caution, " a spy thriller adapted from a short novel by the late Chinese author Eileen Chang, which was loosely based on an actual event that took place in 1939-1940 in Japanese occupied Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential chief of staff-designate confident of meeting challenge

TEXT.P: The incoming presidential chief of staff said Saturday he is confident of fulfilling his duty as the Presidential Office's top day-to-day affairs manager after President-elect Ma Ying-jeou is sworn in on May 20.

Chan Chuen-po, a vice chairman of the soon-to-be-ruling Kuomintang (KMT) who concurrently serves as convener of Ma's transition team, was tapped Friday to serve as secretary-general of the Presidential Office following Ma's inauguration.

Chan, 67, is a veteran KMT official who had held many important party posts before becoming one of the party's six vice chairmen last year. He is known for his knack for subtle political negotiations.
He served as the party's secretary-general during Ma's tenure as KMT chairman from August 2005 to early 2007 and also played a leading role in Ma's presidential campaign.

Noting that he has established a good rapport with Ma after more than 10 years of interaction, Chan said he was fully confident of meeting the requirements of being the incoming president's chief of staff.

"At the moment, my most important work is to ensure an orderly transition from the outgoing Democrtic Progressive Party administration to the incoming KMT administration as well as to help guarantee that the presidential inauguration proceeds smoothly," Chan said.

Although Ma named Chan as the convener of the transition team immediately after his decisive victory in the March 22 presidential poll, Ma didn't formally offer him the post in the incoming government until late Friday, amid speculation of a fierce power struggle within KMT ranks.

According to Chan, Ma twice discussed with him on April 5 and 13 the possibility of working in the Presidential Office, but didn't mention any specific post for him in the new government until Friday.

A short list of candidates for the presidential chief of staff post was widely circulated in the past few weeks and included incumbent Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih. Both men were later ruled out for various reasons.

Chan Chuen-po's appointment came only a day after Chan Chi-shean, another of Ma's key campaign strategists, issued a public statement declaring his decision of not to be part of the new government or the Presidential Office.

Chan Chi-shean, a noted surgeon who once served as Department of Health (DOH) chief in the previous KMT administration, had been widely tipped to be the new president's chief of staff, deputy chief of staff or vice premier.
In the statement that caught many by surprise, Chan Chi-shean said he will join Taiwan's largest charity group -- Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- after Ma takes office May 20.
Chan Chi-shean was the superintendent of Chi Mei Medical Center in Tainan City, one of the most prestigious medical institutions in southern Taiwan, before he joined Ma's campaign team last July.
Also on Friday, Ma named Yeh Ching-chuan, a former deputy mayor of Taipei, as deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office.

Yeh, 58, a high school classmate of Ma, served as health chief of Taipei for two years after Ma became mayor of the city in 1998. He then left that post and became a public health professor at Tzu Chi University. He returned to the front line during the outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) in the country in 2003. His role was important in boosting the morale of the staff at Taipei's Hoping Hospital during the SARS crisis.
Yeh became Taipei's deputy mayor in August 2004, but quit the post in April 2006 to seek KMT nomination to run for Taipei mayor, a bid he lost.

Yeh said Saturday that Ma originally offered him the post of DOH chief. "I rejected that offer as I don't like to be in the limelight, " Yeh said, adding that Ma asked him to serve as Chan Chuen-po's deputy only two days ago.

"I'll take delight in teaming up with Chan in running the Presidential Office's day-to-day affairs after the inauguration of the new administration, " Yeh told reproters after a meeting with Chan at the KMT headquarters Saturday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alien lizard threatens ecological balance, local animals

TEXT.P: A type of lizard native to Southeast Asia, South Asia and southern China is invading Taiwan, threatening the local ecological balance and the survival of native lizards and its cousin living along Taiwan's coastline, researchers warned.

The lined lizards, known simply as skinks or by the species name mabuya multifasciata, are spreading to the central and eastern parts of the island from the south where they were first discovered in 1992, according to studies released recently by the Endemic Species Research Institutes (ESRI) under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture.

In 2001, ESRI researchers discovered during field surveys that the intruder had spread to Pingtung and Tainan counties after being first spotted in Kaohsiung nine years earlier, ESRI researcher Lin Teh-en said.

Five years later, the alien skinks were found building their colonies in Tainan, Chiayi and Yunlin counties, Lin said, warning that the species may soon spread to other parts of the island and even to Orchid and Green islands off Taiwan's southeastern coast because of their unique adaptability.
Lin pointed out that unlike native lizards, the lined skinks do not need to hibernate because of their stronger resistance to cold weather.

That allows the reptile to breed in every season, and once they intrude into places inhabited by native lizards and skinks, such as the Formosa smooth skink and Formosa grass lizard, they are able to expel or wipe out the locals, Lin said.

The institute recently discovered a possible victim of the alien skinks' invasion. An ESRI report noted that it is getting difficult to spot the coastal skink, known as emoia atrocostata, in its normal habitat, the rocky shorelines of southern and eastern Taiwan.
Instead, there are many signs of the alien skinks' presence in the coastal areas, the ESRI said.

It warned that the local species is facing a threat from the outsiders, but said it was not clear what could be done to help the coastal skink because not much is known about its biological characteristics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Mobile adopts 10,000 trees

TEXT.P: Taiwan Mobile Co., the nation's second largest telecom service carrier, adopted 10,000 trees to help build the forest in central Taiwan as part of its efforts to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and slow down global warming.

Taiwan Mobile Vice Chairman Daniel Tsai then donated the adopted 10,000 tree seedlings to National Taiwan University (NTU) Vice President Chen Tai-jan at the Sitou Recreational Area in Nantou County's Luku Township.
The NTU Experimental Forest Administration based in Luku will create 6.5 hectares of forest within 10 years with the donated seedlings.

Tree planting is the most direct way to slow down global warming as it helps adjust temperatures, and the adopted 10,000 are expected to absorb 250 tons of carbon dioxide and generate 190 tons of oxygen every year, Tsai said.
As part of Saturday's activity, over 1,300 employees of Taiwan Mobile and their families planted 1,000 tree seedlings in Sitou to show their support for environmental protection.

They pledged to develop habits that help reduce carbon dioxide emissions in daily life, including walking more and driving less, in line with global efforts for environmental protection as part of World Earth Day which falls on April 22.
The company also held ecological tours and an outdoor concert along with the tree planting activity and donation ceremony for participants to appreciate the beauty of nature.
Taiwan Mobile President Harvey Chang said the planted saplings, including ring cupped oak and soapberry trees, are all strains beneficial to a balanced ecosystem.

The recreational area suffered devastating mudflows and landslides during Typhoon Toraji in 2001 in areas where land and rock had already been loosened by the 7.3 magnitude Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake centered in central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pets, bikes can be brought in high-speed rail trains if 'packed'

TEXT.P: Pets and bicycles can be taken on high-speed rail trains, but there are certain rules to be followed, said the Taiwan High Speed Rail Co. (THSR) Saturday in an attempt to answer frequently asked questions brought up by passengers.

Under the rules, the size of each bicycle that passengers intend to carry with them during the trip has to be under 150 cm in length, and the net weight must be under 40 kilograms, the company said in a statement.
The bike must also be well packed in a bag and placed in either the front or back end of carriages reserved for large-sized baggage, the statement said.

As to pets, the statement said that in principle, animals, excluding on-duty police dogs, guide dogs or young guide dogs accompanied by their trainers, are banned from entering high-speed rail stations and trains.

If there's a need, however, passengers are allowed to travel with pets that are confined in a case no bigger than 55 cm by 45 cm by 38 cm. The container must be safely placed under their seats and be built so that no feces can leak out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait dialogue to resume in June: SEF chairman-designate
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/08 21:39:22 (By Yang Ming-chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman-designate Chiang Pin-kung foresees the resumption of stalled cross-strait dialogue in June, soon after the new administration of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou takes the reins of power May 20, a Japanese paper reported Saturday.

Speaking in an interview with the Japanese daily, Asahi Shimbun, Chiang said that once he assumes his post atop the SEF, a semi-official body that handles cross-strait exchanges in the absence of diplomatic ties, he will visit China as soon as possible.

Ranking Chinese officials could also visit Taiwan, Chiang said, noting that "this will be the first step toward improving cross-strait relations, and I'm sure that China would be favorable to the move."
Cross-strait dialogue has been suspended since 1999 after then- President Lee Teng-hui described the cross-strait relationship as a "special state-to-state" one.

Chiang also expressed the hope of early consultations with China on such issues as weekend cross-strait charter flights, opening Taiwan up to Chinese tourists and allowing the full convertibility of the Taiwan dollar and Chinese yuan on Taiwan proper, all of which were Ma's campaign promises.
Chiang said he hoped to deliver Ma's campaign promises, saying that cross-strait consultations could be handled initially through party-to-party channels.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier-designate to announce first wave of Cabinet lineup

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan may announce the first wave of the Cabinet lineup by Monday at the earliest, a spokesman of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's office said Saturday.

Lo Chih-chiang said the announcement will cover the posts of vice premier, secretary-general and deputy secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, as well as heads of the financial, education and interior ministries.

But the heads of the defense, foreign affairs ministries and those dealing with cross-strait and national security affairs, ase president under Taiwan's Constitution, as well as the heads of some independent government agencies, such as the Financial Supervisory Commission and the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, will be announced at a later date.
Tsai Hsung-hsiung, executive officer of the National Policy Foundation, a Kuomintang think tank, who has close contacts with Liu, is expected to serve as vice premier, KMT sources said.
Former Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Chan Hou-sheng is expected to serve as the secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, the sources said.

Former Vice Economic Affairs Minister Yiin Chii-ming is expected to head the Economics Ministry, while former Vice Finance Minister Sean Chen is set to head the Ministry of Finance, the sources added.
Former Vice Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Schive Chi is expected to head the council.

Lee Jih-chu, a legislator and a financial adviser to Ma's office. is expected to serve as minister without portfolio. Chu Yun-han, another adviser and National Taiwan University professor, and former Fair Trade Commission Chairman Chao Yang-ching could also be included in the Cabinet lineup.

Former Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Mao Chih-kuo could head the ministry, while Taipei City Department of Education Director Wu Ching-kee could head the Ministry of Education.
Liao Feng-teh, director of the KMT's Department of Organization and Development, is widely tapped to head the Ministry of the Interior, sources also said.

To deliver Ma's campaign promise to increase female Cabinet members, former Sports Affairs Council Chairwoman Chao Li-yun, former Legislator Wang Yi-ting, and former head of health department under Taipei City Government Chiu Shu-ti could fill the posts of Council for Hakka Affairs, National Youth Commission and the Department of Health.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP calls for continued support for free tutoring program

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called Saturday for continued support for a free after-school tutoring program for schoolchildren from disadvantaged families that she launched around the country in March 2007.
Lu made the appeal at a luncheon aimed at raising funds for the "Little Scholar School" program that was initiated by her along with a group of like-minded social activists.
Addressing the fund raiser at the National Taiwan University Hospital's International Convention Center, Lu said she looks forward to seeing the program continue after her imminent retirement.

"Every child is our baby. Even though the program requires a large sum of money, I don't want to see it suspended because of my retirement next month, " said Lu whose second four-year term expires May 20.
With the "new poor" issue getting ever more serious, the number of young schoolchildren who need assistance in schooling is also increasing, Lu said.

Since the inauguration of the "Little Scholar School" program, it has helped more than 9,000 schoolchildren, including those born to foreign mothers or aboriginal parents as well as those from low-income families and single-parent familes or those who are raised by grandparents.
"But I believe that the actual number of schoolchildren who need help with their homework after school is much higher and could be as many as 200,000," Lu said with tears welling up in her eyes.
Lu said she hopes local philanthropists will not cut off their contributions to the program after her retirement but will instead continue financial support to maintain its continuity.
"We can fund the program simply by drinking one less bottle of luxury wine and buying one less brand-name handbag," she added.

President Chen Shui-bian, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and many other politicians also attended the fund raiser and contributed funds to the program. Wang donated a wooden sculpture created by a South American artist for charity sales for NT$900,000 (about US$30,000).

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT mum on reports about posting Marine guards at new Taipei office

TEXT.P: The Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) refrained Saturday from making any comments on a foreign wire service report that the United States may post Marine guards at its new office complex in Taipei's Neihu district.

The Associated Press reported Saturday that the U.S. Department of State has published an adertisement in the English-language Taipei Times newspaper calling for contractors to construct quarters for Marine security guards at a new U.S. compound in capital Taipei.

Responding to the report, Thomas Hodges, spokesman for the AIT Taipei Office, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, said he had no immediate comment on the possible dispatch of the Marines to Taipei.
The AP report quoted Alexander Huang of Taipei's Tamkang University as saying that if it goes through, sending the Marines would signify an improvement in Taiwan-U.S. relations.
"With the Marine guards in place, the U.S. would be treating its Taipei facility just like its other embassies and consulates despite the lack of diplomatic relations," Huang said.

The new U.S. compound in Taipei is a part of a large-scale State Department overseas construction program. The facility, to be built in the city's Neihu district, will replace the AIT's aging downtown compound.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said the ministry has played an intermediary role in helping with the AIT's land acquisition for its relocation plan. In the process, Yeh said, the ministry has learned a bit about its plan to build security guard quarters.

As the new AIT compound covers a large area, Yeh said it is understandable that the AIT needs to build security guard quarters to ensure safety. As to whether the quarters will be staffed by U.S. Marines, Yeh said the MOFA is not in a position to give any comments.
Since the U.S. switched its recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, there have been no marine guards at its Taipei facility in keeping with its deliberately low political profile.
Despite the absence of diplomatic relations, the two countries have maintained close substantive ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 20, or the 15th day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1526: Baber, or Zahir ud-Din Mohammed, leads 2,000 Moguls to victory over 10,000 Muslims and 100 elephants under Ibrahim at the battle of Panipat. The conqueror of India later captured Delhi and Agra and founded the Mogul dynasty.
1657: Jews in New Amsterdam (now New York City) are granted equal rights and privileges as citizens.
1836: The U.S. Congress officially separates the western part of the Michigan Territory, creating a new zone known as the Wisconsin Territory.
1859: Holland concludes a treaty granting Portugal the right to govern the eastern part of Timor as well as Atauro Island and Oecussi.
1889: Adolf Hitler, house painter and subsequently German dictator who founded the National Socialist (Nazi) Party and was the architect of World War II, is born in Austria.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung, with a total length of 405 kilometers, is opened to traffic.
1916: The Taipei Yuanshan Zoo is inaugurated.
1933: President Franklin D. Roosevelt removes the United States from the gold standard.
1944: Britain's Royal Air Force drops a record 4,500 tons of bombs on Germany in a single raid.
1945: Soviet troops penetrate Berlin defenses.
1950: The Taiwan Garrison Command Headquarters is established, with Gen. Sun Li- jen serving at its first commander.
1957: Japan protests against nuclear testing by the Soviet Union.
1968: Pierre Elliot Trudeau of the Liberal Party becomes the 15th prime minister of Canada.
1970: President Richard M. Nixon announces the withdrawal of 150,000 U.S. military personnel from South Vietnam.
1974: The Republic of China announces the termination of Taiwan-Japan flights by China Airlines and Japan Airlines after Japan and mainland China sign an air pact in Beijing.
1978: Soviet warplanes force an off-course South Korean airliner down in the Soviet Union near the Arctic Circle, killing two passengers aboard and injuring 13 others.
1984: Britain announces that its administration of Hong Kong will cease in 1997 when the colony is returned to mainland China.
1986: A reservoir bursts and floods a Sri Lankan town, killing 100 people and making some 20,000 families homeless.
1990: Soviet troops storm Lithuania's state printing works after Mikhail Gorbachev cuts off 85 percent of gas supplies to the rebellious republic.
1996: World leaders meeting in Moscow agree to cooperate on increasing nuclear safety.
1999: Taiwan's Council of Agriculture rejects a call from South Korea for a resumption of reciprocal trade in fruit between the two countries.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei denies a U.S. media report that the Republic of China plans to develop medium range missiles.
2000: Central News Agency President Bill Wang says that CNA will shortly add a commercial information databank to its Internet services.
2000: National Yang Ming University President Tseng Chih-lang announces that he has decided to accept President-elect Chen Shui-bian's offer of the post of education minister in the new administration.
2001: Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono announces that Japan will issue a visa to former ROC President Lee Teng-hui to seek medical treatment for his heart condition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who does not anticipate deceit nor imagine untrustworthiness, but who can readily detect their presence, must be a very superior man."

DOC.HEADLINE: New Kaohsiung MRT cutting into taxi drivers' incomes

TEXT.P: For many, the inauguration of the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit system was a day worth celebrating.
But for Kaohsiung taxi drivers, already jolted by the high price of gasoline that may soon climb higher, the opening of the subway system was another blow that has them worried about their futures.

The Kaohsiung Red Line, which began service on March 9, passes through many key spots in the southern port city, including the train station, the high speed rail station, the airport and a key shopping district, and will certainly satisfy some of the transportation needs of Kaohsiung residents.
But their convenience could come at the expense of the taxi drivers' incomes.

"The impact (of the metro) has been huge. Sometimes a taxi driver can only earn a little more than NT$1,000 per day, while before, we made an average of NT$2,000 a day, " said Ye Guo-bin, a taxi dispatcher.
He said that after deducting gasoline costs and the rental fee for the car, drivers are left with only several hundred Taiwan dollars as their daily wage.

"It is now so difficult to pick up fares that taxi drivers in Kaohsiung are killing themselves because of the economic pressure, " he said in a telephone interview with Central News Agency, citing one of his colleagues who committed suicide by charcoal burning last week and two similar tragedies in March.
According to Ye, more than 6,000 taxis are operating in the city of about 1.5 million people, and "the competition is very fierce."
"To maintain their wage levels, taxi drivers can do nothing but operate their cars for longer, " he said, with many of them spending nights in their vehicles.

Asked how taxi drivers could improve their situations, one taxi driver named Mr. Wu, who declined to give his full name, said in a phone interview that adopting their vehicles to natural gas would help taxi drivers overcome the high price of gasoline.
He also expected that the situation would stabilize once metro fares were normalized.

During the Red Line's trial period from March 9 to April 6, all passengers were allowed to ride the metro for free and in the three months starting from April 7, passengers owning an "I pass card", similar to the Easycard in Taipei, only pay NT$12 for a one-way journey.
Normal fares on the Red Line range from NT$20 to NT$60 depending on the distance traveled.
The taxi drivers suggested another possible source of new revenue, one that may in fact be nothing more than a false hope.

"We are also looking forward to the coming of the Chinese tourists, " Ye and Wu said in unison, but Chinese tourists are currently required by law to stay in their groups and travel on tour buses around the country, leaving few opportunities to take taxis.

DOC.HEADLINE: 47 academics nominated for Academia Sinica laurels

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica, the country's top research institution, announced its 2008 list of academician candidates Saturday, with 47 outstanding scholars nominated for the prestigious honor.
A maximum of 30 candidates will be elected by incumbent academicians in a vote scheduled for early July, the academy said in a statement.
Twenty-six of the candidates, or 55 percent of the total, are foreign-based and the remaining 21 are based in Taiwan, according to the statement.
Only five of the nominees are female, and 14 were previously nominated but failed to be elected.

Academia Sinica academicians are grouped into three divisions -- mathematics and physical sciences, life sciences and humanities, and social sciences. A maximum of 10 new academicians can be elected to each of the three divisions at each biennial election.
Of this year's candidates, 27 are in the mathematics and physical sciences division, 14 are in the life sciences division and six are in the humanities and social sciences division.
The academicians are full members of the academy and make up the Convocation of Academia Sinica, which formulates academic research policies.
The academy now has 231 academicians. The title of academician is an honorary lifetime privilege.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chairmanship candidate has high expectations for DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 19 (CNA) 04/20/08 16:15:22 (By Lu-sheng Chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen, who is vying to become chairwoman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said here Saturday that she hopes the DPP will completely transform itself and become a party of integrity.

Tsai, visiting Los Angeles at the invitation of the North America Taiwanese Women's Association, said the DPP should return to its down-to-earth simplicity and strive to free itself from the bureaucratization and formalism that have overtaken the party in recent years.

She said the DPP, which suffered bruising defeats in the Jan. 12 legislative polls and March 22 presidential election, should seek to operate more efficiently and pragmatically and demonstrate that it is a party of inclusiveness that can execute power.
Noting that the DPP is a young party with a history of only 20 years, Tsai said "the party should aim higher and strive to achieve greater goals."
She said the party should also show greater magnanimity by tolerating people from differing ethnic groups or with differing ideologies and points of view.

The 52-year-old former chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council was the main architect of the "special state-to-state" cross-Taiwan Strait relations theory espoused by former President Lee Teng-hui in 1999.
Tsai, in Los Angeles to take part in activities marking the 20th anniversary of the founding of the North America Taiwanese Women's Association, is scheduled to return to Taiwan April 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Taiwan employees take English, Japanese for promotions: poll

TEXT.P: A large share of Taiwan's white-collar employees study English or Japanese as their foreign languages of choice to pursue promotions or pay raises in the workplace, according to the results of a survey by a job bank.

The survey conducted by the 1111 Job Bank -- one of Taiwan's largest online human resources companies -- showed that 45.3 percent of local enterprises polled felt that foreign language ability, and especially English, was the skill Taiwan's office workers needed to improve the most to meet companies' job requirements.

These 1111 Job Bank said that in the second half of 2007, 34.4 percent of visitors to its Web site who sought information on continuing education opted for language courses, or 2.6 percentage points more than in the second half of 2006. Of those, 64 percent opted for English and 27 percent for Japanese, job bank officials said.

Only 8 percent searched for information on Korean courses, an indication that Taiwan's white-collar employees choose to learn a foreign language mainly to meet their needs in school examinations, at work, and on international occasions, job bank officials said.

Citing a study by the U.S.-based Thunderbird School of Global Management of over 500 graduates who received foreign language training, the job bank said 82 percent of respondents indicated that good foreign language skills made them more marketable, while 39 percent and 32 percent said they were often asked to make overseas trips or to be stationed abroad, respectively.

Some 32 percent said they were frequently praised for their foreign language abilities, and 18 percent and 12 percent admitted that they received promotions and pay raises, respectively, because of their language skills.
