JOHN PRESCOTT, who as deputy prime minister punched a protester in the face, has confessed to suffering from bulimia, the eating disorder usually associated with anxious young women.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-Chairman Yu Shyi-kun should apologize: former DPP lawmaker

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun should apologize for adopting "blue-excluding opinion polls, " and the party should focus on actually rooting out corruption rather than taling about it, a former DPP legislator said Sunday in Taipei.

"It is a shame that a person who hurt the DPP so much is not willing to apologize for his own mistake, " said former DPP legislator Lee Wen-chung, referring to Yu's remarks at the end of a meeting held Saturday to review the DPP's latest election setback.

Yu refused to accept suggestions that the controversial polling method should be abolished, arguing that "the DPP might as well give up conducting opinion polls, should those excluding blue-leaning voters be eliminated."

The polls, used to help determine party nominees for the Jan. 12 legislative elections and March 22 presidential election, attempted to identify and exclude supporters of the rival Kuomintang (KMT) from participating for fear that they would manipulate the results in the KMT's favor.

Following the DPP's drubbing in the legislative elections, however, many party members criticized the polls for political labeling respondents and encouraging the nomination of more extreme candidates.
The polls, they said, not only excluded pan-KMT, or "blue, " supporters but also independent voters.

"Any system adopted by a party should be able to make the party even more competitive. I think former chairman Yu, rather than objecting to review the measure, should apologize publicly for adopting the opinion poll method," Lee said.
Lee contended that the main reason why the DPP lost decisively in the presidential election was its failure to actually put its anti-corruption campaign into practice.
"We have seen so many meetings reviewing the problem of corruption within the party, but instead of talking the talk, you must walk the walk," he said.

Lee added that the party's Central Review Committee and anti- corruption council should immediately deal with the corruption cases. Committee members should resign right away if they are not capable of doing so, he said.
The former lawmaker, however, also gave the DPP credit for holding a series of meetings to review their setbacks.
"These face-to-face meetings between party members and heavyweights showed that the DPP would not turn its back to problems even there are some conflicts and sparks," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU graduate student wins top mystery writer award

TEXT.P: Chih Yen, a National Taiwan University (NTU) graduate student, has won first prize for mystery writing for her novel "Absinthe" in a competition sponsored by the Mystery Writers of Taiwan, the first time a female writer has taken top honors.
Chih was awarded NT$50,000 and a trophy Saturday at the seventh annual conference of the Mystery Writers of Taiwan after defeating three other competitors from Hong Kong in the final round.
The contest, organized by the private mystery writers' group to encourage authors to write mystery novels, received a total of 36 submissions from domestic and overseas competitors.

After the award ceremony, Chih expressed delight at capturing the title in her second attempt, after making an unsuccessful bid two years ago, and thanked her family for supporting her efforts since she took up writing in her first year of high school.
She admitted, however, that her success in the competition did not mean she would make a living from her talent.
"Winning the award will not lead me to become a professional writer, " said Chih, who explained that she enjoys writing when inspiration strikes but hates to write under pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Some 100 environmentalists sign declaration for sustainability

TEXT.P: Nearly 100 academics and experts from home and abroad signed a declaration vowing to commit themselves to environmental conservation at an environmental forum in the southern city of Tainan.

The declaration, signed by participants to the two-day "2008 Jade Mountain Forum on Sustainable Environment, " will be read on World Earth Day on April 22 at the summit of Yushan (Jade Mountain) by staff members of the Sustainable Environment Research Center of National Cheng Kung University, which is hosting the forum.
Yushan, which stands at 3,952 meters in altitude, is the highest peak in Taiwan.

The declaration, written in Chinese, English, and Japanese, says that environmental sustainability is a global challenge faced by all nations and that the signees, environmental protection advocates from the Pacific region, are duty-bound to promote through actions environmental protection.

The environmentalists -- from Canada, Australia, Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong, and Taiwan -- also vowed in the declaration to meet the goals of "low carbon emissions and improved safety and waste elimination, " in an effort to create a sustainable environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Patience is needed to achieve transitional justice: civic group

TEXT.P: Civic groups and a former legislator said Sunday transitional justice takes time and patience to achieve but should no longer be manipulated as a political tool in elections and create conflicts.

"It takes a lot of patience to deal with the tortured past and to achieve transitional justice, " Lee Wen-chung, a former Democratic Progressive Party legislator said at a seminar titled "Forgiveness and Mutual-trust: A Trans-party List for Transitional Justice."

The seminar was organized by the nongovernmental Mainlander Association, a group founded to promote harmony between ethnic groups by second-generation members of families who came to Taiwan around 1949 with the Kuomintang after it lost the Chinese Civil War to the communists.

Lee said he thought the incoming Kuomintang (KMT) administration was more suitable than the outgoing Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to deal with the issue as the KMT is considered to be responsible for the human rights abuses of the white terror era.
"It is probably not possible to deal with the past from a legal perspective as many documents are gone. But in terms of history, it is necessary to confront the painful legacy of the past," he said.
The "White Terror" refers to the suppression of political dissidents and Taiwanese elite under martial law from May 19, 1949 to July 15, 1987.

The "White Terror" left many Taiwanese with a deep-seated bitterness toward the KMT, Chiang Kai-shek and, to a lesser extent, his son Chiang Ching-kuo, who served as president from 1978 until his death in 1988.
Chien Hsi-chieh, executive director of the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan, said several items in the Trans-party List for Transitional Justice are things the incoming government can do.

He said the government should realize that transitional justice is unrelated to the issue of independence from or unification with China but rather deeply reflects the legacy of widespread or systematic human rights abuse in the past.
The government, according to the list, should disclose information related to the White Terror era and launch investigations as needed, he said.

Chien said that transitional justice should be achieved through a series of citizen's forums and that civil society in Taiwan should play the role of supervising and helping national leaders to bring about justice.
"Politicians should not abuse transitional justice and use it to increase their own political clout or as an Automatic Teller Machine for votes, "he said.
Tsai Shih-ping, a prominent author and former campaign spokesman of President- elect Ma Ying-jeou, said that he personally agreed with the list and thought that Ma should accept it.
"The government needs patience when dealing with historic events. If not, such events will be manipulated by political opportunists, "he said.
Tsai suggested that President-elect Ma release all documents from KMT archives for the general public to review.
"The government should call on civil groups and society to examine the past and achieve a holistic sense of justice for all citizens, to establish or renew civil trust, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Annual Gueishan whale watching kicks off

TEXT.P: The annual whale watching season off Gueishan Island officially kicked off Sunday, with hundreds of tourists and foreign media workers packing onto boats to get a glimpse of whales and dolphins off Taiwan's northeastern coast.

In addition to attracting numerous local tourists, the launch of the 2008 Gueishan Island Whale Watching campaign also attracted more than 100 tourists from Malaysia, Singapore, Japan, Hong Kong, Germany and the United States.

The tourists, including reporters and camera crews from three Japanese media outlets, set off from Yilan's Wushih port in the morning, cruised around Gueishan Island -- located about 10 kilometers off the coast of Yilan County -- to watch whales.

Their ships then docked at the volcanic islet, known literally as "Turtle Mountain Island" because of its resemblance to a turtle, giving visitors a chance to explore the island's well-preserved environment.

According to officials from the Northeast and Yilan Coast National Scenic Area Administration, one of the sponsors of the activity, the Gueishan Island area is one of the areas around Taiwan with the richest populations of cetaceans, with some 17 species appearing on a regular basis.
Most of the 17 species -- including bottlenose dolphins and false killer whales -- appear in waters near the Gueishan Island between April and September, the officials said.

During the spring, they said, tourists are welcome to land on Gueishan Island to enjoy its rich flora in the island's southernmost section, where wild flowers, cultivated flowers and other natural botanical species are now flourishing around a small lake there.

A former military base, Gueishan used to be out of bounds to civilians and remained closed to tourists until 2001, when the government designated it as a tourist spot. With a strict quota system in place limiting the number of tourists allowed to visit the island, advance registration to go there is required.
Gueishan Island, which is known as an "ecological park on the sea, " is also known as a paradise for underwater geological exploration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese yuan exchange to be launched at certain locations

TEXT.P: The exchange of Chinese yuan will be permitted at specific locations in Taiwan, including airports and harbors, regardless of whether a currency clearance and settlement mechanism is established, central bank sources indicated this week.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou pledged to allow full convertibility of the Chinese currency in Taiwan during his election campaign, and the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) has drawn up plans to meet the goal.

Central Bank Vice-Governor George Chou recently said the plan involved a two- step approach, but he insisted that before any exchange of the yuan could take place, Taiwan and China needed to agree on a currency clearance and settlement mechanism.
Central bank sources suggested recently, however, that limited currency exchanges could be allowed before such a mechanism was established.

"The central bank in the initial stage will impose restrictions on the amount of currency exchanged and those who can apply for the exchanges, " said a central bank official speaking on condition of anonymity.

"Trading locations will be limited to harbors, airports, tourist attractions and certain financial institutions, " the official said, describing the bank's draft of an administrative procedure that will skirt the clauses on yuan convertibility in the Act Governing Relations Between Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.
The act requires that a clearence mechanism exists before allowing yuan to be exchanged in Taiwan proper.
But with the legislature seemingly unwilling to amend the law and the negotiations on a clearance mechanism expected to take time, the central bank seems set to establish an interim system.

The central bank suggested that under its plan for this initial stage, local banks could only buy Chinese yuan, which is likely to disappoint the 4 million Taiwanese who travel to China and 1 million China-based Taiwanese businessmen who have a strong demand for the Chinese currency.

"These restrictions in the first stage could also prevent the potential risk of insufficient stock of yuan available in local banks, " said the official, who stressed that these modest openings could be achieved without an agreement on a currency clearance and settlement mechanism.
Once provided with a stable supply of yuan, the central bank will permit local banks to both buy and sell the Chinese currency in the second stage, the official added.

The central bank expects the demand for the exchange of the Chinese yuan and Taiwan dollar to grow, as the incoming Kuomintang (KMT) administration has promised to open Taiwan to more Chinese tourists, up to 3,000 to 10,000 per day.

The only place where yuan can be legally exchanged at present are on the Taiwan- controlled islands of Kinmen and Matsu, which lie just off China's southeastern coast. Individuals have been allowed to exchange up to 20,000 yuan since the act was revised in October 2005.

KMT lawmakers, eager to promote greater convertibility of the yuan in Taiwan, has proposed its own revision of the act based on Hong Kong's approach, which allowed the Chinese yuan to be exchanged there starting in 1995 without the establishment of a clearence mechanism.
"As long as local banks can balance their currency reserves, there is no urgent need to establish the clearence mechanism, " KMT lawmaker Lee Jih-chu said.
Hong Kong did not set up a clearence mechanism with China until 2003, six years after it come under Chinese rule.
Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers also showed their support for the opening of yuan convertibility.
"We will assist in the revision of the act in full force," said DPP lawmaker Ker Chien-ming.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to invest in tap water facilities

TEXT.P: The government should make a massive investment to improve Taiwan's tap water infrastructure, even if the country's rate of access to potable water has reached 91 percent, the level of developed countries, a local scholar said Saturday.

Speaking on the challenges faced by Taiwan in public water supplies at a forum organized by National Cheng Kung University in the southern city of Tainan, Yeh Hsuan-hsien, an environmental engineering professor at the university, warned that Taiwan's potable water system had serious problems.

Yeh said that Taiwan needs to find ways to store more rainwater because while the island's average annual rainfall is as high as 2,500 millimeters, 75 percent of the rainfall occurs between May and October, particularly during the typhoon season from July and September.
If the government cannot build large reservoirs due to strong opposition from local environmental groups, it should still try to build small flatland reservoirs and ponds, he suggested.

Yeh also noted that water quality issues exist. He said algae in some reservoirs produce odors and worsen water quality and that farm fertilizers often pollute ground water, resulting in high concentrations of nitrate nitrogen that can pose health threats.
Strong heavy rains sometimes also worsen the water quality of reservoirs in northern, central and southern Taiwan, which he said would cause water shortages.

He cited the example of a 19-day water shortage in 2004 in the greater Taoyuan area in northern Taiwan after a typhoon caused heavy silt run-off into Shihmen Reservoir that resulted in a sudden deterioration of its water quality.
A big problem, Yeh said, is that water prices in Taiwan are extremely low and thus the government does not have enough funds to replace water pipelines and equipment.
This has prompted many to buy bottled water or water filters at home because they are suspicious of tap water quality, he observed.
Yeh suggested that the government set up a special research and development agency to work with advanced countries to carry out the large investment projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's once dark village becomes example of illumination renovation

TEXT.P: Once called the "dark village, " the Smangus Tribe in Hsinchu County has become a shining example of Taiwan's illumination renovation, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Saturday.
Ahead of World Earth Day on April 22, the Smangus demonstrated advanced illumination concepts and equipment such as LED lighting devices that are eco- friendly and conserve energy.
One of the last areas in Taiwan to be connected to electricity, the Smangus village relied on standard, high power-consumption fixtures, like T9 fluorescent lamps, that caused occasional blackouts.

The Bureau of Energy, Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) and Industrial Technology Research Institute recently decided, however, to turn the remote village into a model for illumination, replacing the old devices with electricity-saving bulbs.

The heads of the tribe stressed that the renovation could improve both the stability of electricity supply and energy conservation and said the change was in line with the philosophy of their ancestors, who lived in tune with nature.

The bureau noted that the new fixtures lowered electricity bills, and saved on the costs of building infrastructure for the neighborhood, while maintaining the original landscape by integrating the high-tech lighting with the natural environment.

Adopting similar energy-saving lighting devices around Taiwan could potentially save between 30 percent to 80 percent of the 26 billion kilowatt/hours of electricity used for illumination annually, which represents about 12 percent of Taiwan's total electricity consumption of 221.4 billion kilowatt/hours, according to the bureau.
"The energy saving lighting could also help reduce carbon dioxide emissions, " the bureau noted.

To realize such savings, the ministry has worked to promote both the energy efficiency and standards for energy-saving products, while launching a green revolution in illumination this year, the bureau said.
These efforts include assisting local public and private organizations to replace incandescent lamps, which are high energy consuming, and promoting the use of energy saving LED products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Direct Taiwan-China flights' designation unclear: KMT vice chairman

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman and Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman- designate Chiang Pin-kung denied Sunday a Japanese newspaper report quoting him as saying that direct flights between Taiwan and China will be designated as "direct route flights."

According to Chiang, he did not mention to Asahi Shimbun during a recent interview that future direct flights across the Taiwan Strait will be designated as "direct route flights, " and suggested the term may have come from a misunderstanding of his words.

To his knowledge, Chiang said, "cross-strait flights" was the designation agreed upon by both Taiwan and China in previous rounds of two-way talks on the issue to avoid the political complications of calling them either "international" or "domestic" flights.
Chiang has been appointed by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou to lead the semi- official SEF, which is responsible for cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Ma has pledged to implement direct flights and shipping links across the strait as soon as possible after he assumes presidency on May 20, beginning with direct weekend charter flights from July 4, then daily charter flights and eventually daily regularly scheduled flights.

Hsieh Kuo-liang, the KMT's acting legislative caucus whip, said earlier Sunday that Taiwan's people are more concerned about whether direct cross-strait charters every weekend begin as planned in early July than how they should be designated.

As Taiwan's public has high expectations for a quick establishment of direct air links between the two sides, the new administration's failure to achieve the aim of opening weekend charter flights from July would disappoint many people, he said.

In an exclusive interview broadcast Saturday by Taipei-based TVBS, Chiang said that he would visit China as soon as possible after taking over as SEF chairman. He asserted that regularly scheduled daily cross-strait flights will be implemented some time within the next year.

The SEF chairman-designate said he would resume institutionalized dialogue with his Chinese counterpart, the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) in June or July on a wide range of issues, including pushing for the opening of SEF offices in China.

Talks between the SEF and ARATS ground to a halt in 1999 after former President Lee Teng-hui described the reslationship between Taiwan and China as a "special state-to-state relationship" earlier that same year.

Kuan Pi-ling, a lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which will become the main opposition party after May 20, contended that Taiwan- China flights should be named in an impartial way to technically put aside the dispute surrounding the sovereignty dispute between the two sides.
"The key point concerning the issue is that both sides must be treated on an equal footing and with parity," Kuan stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interviews, exhibition planned to honor Father of Blackfoot Disease

TEXT.P: Taiwan Historica and the National Taiwan Museum plan to honor Wang Chin-ho, a 93 -year-old doctor who has devoted most of his life to patients with blackfoot disease in southwestern Taiwan since the 1960s, with an interview and a photo exhibition.

Taiwan Historica in the central city of Nantou will conduct oral history interviews with Wang to collect information about the history of blackfoot disease in Taiwan, with interview transcripts to be published at the end of this year.

To allow more people in Taiwan to acquire knowledge about the outbreak and treatment of blackfoot disease, the Taipei-based National Taiwan Museum will hold a retrospective photo exhibition featuring Wang's medical achievements in March 2009 to mark the museum's 100th anniversary.

Wang signed an agreement Sunday at a ceremony in Taipei with Taiwan Historica Director Hsieh Chia-liang and National Taiwan Museum Curator Hsiao Chung-huang in which he promised to participate in the projects.

Wang, who has being respectfully called the Father of Blackfoot Disease for his contributions to the treatment of the disease, was born in 1916 and studied medical science in Japan before returning to his hometown in Beimen township in the southern county of Tainan in 1943 to practice medicine.
Blackfoot disease, an endemic peripheral vascular disease caused by drinking arsenic-contaminated water, appeared in the southwestern coast of Taiwan in the 1960s.

Sponsored by Lilian Dickson, founder of Mustard Seed Inc., an international evangelical Christian missions organization, Wang soon began to provide free medical services to patients with the disease at the Beimen Free Clinic of Christian Mustard Seed, Hsieh said.

During the period, Wang went beyond the call of duty in caring for blackfoot disease patients. He was known to carry those who couldn't walk on his back to the clinic for treatment, make coffins for families of the deceased who couldn't afford them, and set up a handicraft training center to help those who became disabled because of the disease to gain practical skills, Hsieh said.
For those reasons, Hsieh said he visited Wang and decided to send people to interview him and record oral history to make more people aware of his achievements and have them emulate his good deeds.

Wang retired in 1996 at the age of 81 and closed his clinic. It was later converted into the Taiwan Blackfoot Disease Memorial and has attracted more than 60,000 people to visit since it was opened at the end of last September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor to visit Switzerland to lobby for Olympic baseball

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu is scheduled to depart for Switzerland April 23 to lobby the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to retain baseball as an officially- recognized Olympic event.
The sport's appearance at the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing in August may be its last after the sport was voted out as an Olympic event three years ago, beginning with the London Games in 2012.

Hu has developed good relations with officials from the International Baseball Federation (IBF) after Taichung City hosted several international baseball championships over the past year, and he was invited by the group to lobby the IOC to reinstate baseball as part of the Summer Games.

Aside from visiting the Lausanne-based IOC, Hu will also visit the headquarters of the Switzerland-based IBF to further consolidate Taichung's relations with the world's baseball governing body and seek more opportunties to host international baseball tournaments in the future.
Hu has endeavored to turn Taichung City into Taiwan's "capital of baseball" since he became mayor of he city in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: President visits child with rare disease in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian traveled to the southern port city of Kaohsiung Sunday to visit a seven-year-old girl who has bravely battled a genetic disease called tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) since birth.

Chen arrived at the house of the seven-year-old named Lee Pei on Kaohsiung City's Min Sheng 1st Road around noon and gave the child a red envelope as a token of his best wishes and encouragement. They also exchanged a "high-five" in a warm atmosphere.
Lee has suffered from the rare, multi-system genetic disease
since she was born. She was diagnosed at birth with tumors in her brain, heart and kidneys.
Doctors operated on her when she was one month old to remove a life-threatening tumor -- hence saving her life and allowing her to live on to the present date.
Due to the tumors in her brain, Lee often has seizures and her mental development has been stifled, with her intellectual level equal to that of an average two-year-old.
She is scheduled to attend a special school for the mentally challenged in September this year.

Lee's mother, a high school nursing teacher, offered her gratitude to the Chen administration's efforts over the past several years to help families of patients of rare diseases, major illnesses and injuries.
The mother also asked Chen about the condition of the wheelchair-bound first lady Wu Shu-jen.
"The best condition for her is to maintain the 'status quo, '" Chen answered.

Lee's mother was given a "Great Love" award by the Ministry of the Interior in August 2006 for her unselfish devotion to her daughter. She visited the Presidential Office in 2007 to meet with Chen to promote the cause of patients, and Chen at the time promised to visit the child in person.

TSC causes benign tumors to grow in the brain and on other vital organs such as the kidneys, heart, eyes, lungs, and skin. A combination of symptoms may include seizures, developmental delay, behavioral problems, skin abnormalities, and lung and kidney disease.

TSC is caused by mutations on either of two genes, TSC1 and TSC2, which encode the proteins hamartin and tuberin respectively and prevent them from fulfilling their roles as tumor growth suppressors and regulators of cell proliferation and differentiation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT vice chairman to thank Taiwanese businessmen in China for votes

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman Chiang Pin-kung will travel to China via Hong Kong next week to thank Taiwan businessmen based there for their votes for the KMT ticket in the March 22 presidential election, a KMT official said Sunday.
KMT Mainland Affairs Department Director Chang Jung-kung made the announcement in a press release.

According to Chang, Chiang will leave for China next Thursday and visit Shanghai, Kunshan, Xiamen and Shenzhen, where a large number of Taiwan businessmen are clustered, to thank them for their support of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew.

The Ma-Siew ticket beat their ruling Democratic Progressive Party rivals by more than 2.21 million votes, seizing a record high 7.65 million votes, or 58 percent of the total, in the presidential race.

Chang said that more than 200,000 China-based Taiwan businessmen returned to Taiwan to cast their ballots for the Ma-Siew ticket on March 22, and that the KMT fully appreciated their firm backing for the pair and for their deep interest in Taiwan's political development.

Chiang, who doubles as convener of the KMT's Taiwan businessmen center, has been appointed to take over as chief of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) when the Ma administration takes office on May 20.

Ma and Siew touted closer trade and economic ties between Taiwan and China throughout the campaign and are expected to implement direct cross-strait air links and shipping services, which would be advantageous for the many Taiwanese businessmen with operations in China.

The SEF, responsible for cross-strait exchanges in its dealings with the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), is expected to play a prominent role after the inauguration of Ma's administration.

Two-way SEF-ARATS talks have been stalled since 1999 when former President Lee Teng-hui angered Beijing by terming Taiwan-China ties as a "special state-to- state relationship" earlier that same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan cleans up shores to observe Earth Day

TEXT.P: More than 3,000 people in nine counties around Taiwan joined together to clean up shores Sunday to observe the April 22 Earth Day.

The Society of Wildness, which organized the shore-cleaning campaign said in a press release that the activities were held simultaneous at shores in the counties of Taipei, Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Taichung, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Yilan and Hualien.
Beside picking up garbage, the participants were guided by volunteers to learn the flora on the shores, birds and fish living in the tidal zones and the delicate ecosystem of the shores.
Lin Yao-kuo, president of the society, said in Taipei that the theme of this year's Earth Day is to enhance people's awareness about the problems facing the country's shores.

Besides littering with garbage, Lin said Taiwan's shores are lined with concrete wave breakers, man-made harbors, while the natural shores are disappearing, not least the coral reefs which house many fish.

Lin said the conservation of the shore couldn't be done by an one-day cleaning- up campaign, but it can help people to realize that they can help protect the island's shores by not littering, not taking any natural object away from the shore and leading an environmentally friendly lifestyle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier-designate reveals lineup of Cabinet

TEXT.P: Liu Chao-shiuan, who was asked by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou to form a Cabinet, on Monday announced 17 members of the new lineup.
The 17 members are:
-- Vice Premier: Paul Chiu, a former minister of finance.
Secretary-General of the Executive Yuan: Steve Hsieh, a former
vice chairman of the National Science Council.
-- Minister without Portfolio: Tsai Hsung-hsiung, a former chief of the Environmental Protection Administration.
-- Minister without Portfolio: Chu Yun-peng, an economics professor at National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County.
-- Minister of the Interior: Liao Feng-te, chief of the Kuomintang Department of Organization Affairs.
-- Minister of Foreign Affairs: Francisco H.L. Ou, ambassador to Guatemala.
-- Minister of Justice: Wang Ching-feng, a female lawyer and a former member of the Control Yuan.
-- Minister of Economic Affairs: Yiin Chii-ming, a former vice minister of economic affairs.
-- Minister of Transportation and Communications: Mao Chi-kuo, dean of the college of Management, National Chiao Tung University in Hsinchu.
-- Minister in charge of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics: Shih Su-mei, chief of the Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Taipei City government.
-- Minister in charge of the Department of Health: Lin Fang-yue, dean of the College of Medicine, National Taiwan University.
-- Minister in charge of the Environmental Protection Administration: Shen Shih-hung, chief of the Environmental Protection Bureau under the Taipei City Government.
