-- Minister in charge of Council of Indigenous Peoples: Chang Jen-hsiang, a Kuomintang legislator.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 21, or the 16th day of the third month of the Year of Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1634: Jan van Riebeeck, Dutch naval surgeon and founder of Cape Town, South Africa, is born.
1898: The United States declares war on Spain.
1910: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, dies at the age of 74. He drew on his childhood along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1926: Elizabeth II, Queen of England since 1952, is born.
1930: Fire breaks out at the Ohio state penitentiary, killing 355 people.
1935: An earthquake hits central and northern Taiwan, killing some 3,000 people.
1937: Steamships formally begin plying a regular weekly route between Shanghai and San Francisco.
1946: British economist John Maynard Keynes dies at the age of 63. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, can be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1948: Republic of China troops evacuate Yenan.
1949: The Chinese communists resume an all-out offensive and cross the Yangtze River.
1954: The United States flies a French battalion to Indochina to defend Dien Bien Phu, which is overrun by Vietnamese forces three weeks later.
1957: Taiwan voters go to the polls for the third time to elect county magistrates, city mayors and provincial assemblymen.
1958: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly building in Wufeng, Taichung County, is inaugurated.
1960: Brazil moves its capital from Rio de Janeiro to Brazilia, the brain-child of President Juselino Kubitschek.
1966: The ROC and Dahomey resume diplomatic relations.
1971: Haitian dictator Francois Duvalier, known as "Papa Doc," dies at the age of 64. Elected president in 1957, he declared himself president for life in 1964 and ruled in an authoritarian manner until his death. He was succeeded by his son Jean-Claude, who fled the country in 1986 after widespread civil unrest.
1975: South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu resigns after denouncing the United States as untrustworthy.
1987: Terrorists detonate a bomb near the main bus station in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing and injuring more than 400 people.
1989: More than 10,000 workers and students clamoring for democracy and human rights march from campuses to converge on Tiananmen Square in Beijing in defiance of official warnings against anti-government protests.
1997: An advance contingent of communist Chinese troops enter Hong Kong in preparation for the July 1 handover of the British crown colony to communist China.
1998: Seoul drops efforts to receive Japanese compensation for women held as sex slaves during World War II and says it will pay the surviving women.
1999: A survey conducted by the Switzerland-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence ranks Taiwan as the least risky area for investment in the world.
1999: Renowned local writer Su Hsueh-lin, winner of the Chungshan Literature Prize and the National Literature Prize, dies at the age of 104.
2000: Taiwanese "Go" player Wang Li-cheng wins the title of "Go Sage," the highest title and honor for any Go professional in Japan.
2000: Tsai Ying-wen, an advisor to the National Security Council and a professor at National Chengchi University, is confirmed chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.
2001: A pro-unification organization urges Taiwan's three main opposition parties to monitor the Democratic Progressive Party-led government to prevent Taiwan from "marching toward independence."
Confucius lesson of the day: "A good horse is considered so not because of its mere brute strength but because of its moral qualities."

DOC.HEADLINE: Experience counts the most: speaker

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng welcomed the first part of the new Cabinet lineup that was announced by Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan Monday, saying that experience is what counts the most when starting a new administration.

Discounting doubts that Liu was forming an administrative team made up of "old bureaucrats, " Wang said the new appointees were all academics or technocrats with rich administrative experience, adding that these Cabinet members should live up to the expectations of the country.

Noting that experience is most valuable during the transitional period when political stability is vital, Wang said the incoming administration, set to be inaugurated May 20, should of course also strive to reform the governmental structure in the coming months.

Meanwhile, Chang Hsien-yao, a deputy whip of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus, also defended Liu's Cabinet appointments, saying that although they were "old faces, " those former officials were ready to immediately begin work by bringing their invaluable administrative experience to bear particularly on the efforts to rev up the domestic economy.
The majority of the 17 ministers-designate announced by Liu Monday had previously served as vice ministers under the former KMT government prior to 2000.
The 17 new appointees are:

Vice Premier Paul Chiu, Secretary General of the Executive Yuan Steve Hsieh, Minister of the Interior Liao Feng-te, Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco H.L. Ou, Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo, Minister in charge of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics Shih Su-mei, Minister in charge of the Department of Health Lin Fang- yue, Minister in charge of the Environmental Protection Administration Shen Shih-hung, Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development Chen Tain-jy, Chairwoman of the National Youth Commission Wang Yu-ting, Chairman of the Council of Agriculture Chen Wu-hsiung, Minister in charge of Council of Labor Affairs Jennifer Ju-hsuan Wang, Minister in charge of the Council of Indigenous Peoples Chang Jen-hsiang, and Ministers without Portfolio Tsai Hsung- hsiung and Chu Yun-peng.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: China calls for calm as protests spread
China urged its citizens to be "calm" and "rational" as nationalistic protests against French supermarket Carrefour spread Sunday to more cities across the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Anti-West protests go beyond China.
The Olympic torch passed through Britain, France and the United States - amid much protest over China's handling of the unrest in Tibet. Over the weekend, the tables were turned when their cities became sites of anti-Western demonstrations.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore development model is facing internal and external problems: Dr. Yaacob.
Singapore was successful in balance of industrialization, economic development and environmental protection, but now this development model is facing internal and external problems, Minister for the Environment and Water Resources Yaacob Ibrahim said in a interview of Lianhe Zaobao.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Palestinian militants attack a key Gaza border crossing.
Palestinian militants besieged a crucial Israel-Gaza border crossing Saturday, wounding 16 Israeli soldiers in a barrage of mortar fire and car bombs. Three Palestinian gunmen died in the attack on the Kerem Shalom crossing, which followed a string of smaller militant raids on the other entry points through which vital humanitarian supplies and fuel pass to Gaza. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: Former youngest KMT lawmaker named to lead youth affairs council

TEXT.P: Wang Yu-ting, formerly the youngest legislator of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , was named chairwoman of the Cabinet-level National Youth Commission by Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan Monday.

Wang, who was elected a legislator representing the constituency of Tainan City, southern Taiwan in 1999 at the age of 26, said she was approached by Liu early last week on the possibility of taking up the post. Wang said that after discussing the offer with her mother, with whom she lives, she decided to accept the challenge.

"Now I'll have to put aside my plans to travel around the world," said Wang, who lost her re-election bid in the Jan. 12 legislative poll that elected half the original number of members for the newly revamped 113-seat legislature. Wang served three terms as a KMT legislator from 1999-2007.

Wang said she made a sightseeing trip to the historical Angkor Wat, Cambodia in March and had planned to tour Europe, starting April, as part of her objective to slow down and reflect after having worked non-stop for nearly 10 years.

Wang, a graduate of the Department of Law of Catholic Fu Jen University, said she will try her utmost to implement President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's youth policies after the incoming KMT administration takes office May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 9% of foreign laborers in Taipei fail physical examination

TEXT.P: Nearly 9 percent of foreign laborers in Taipei City failed their physical examinations in 2007 and among them, 30 have been repatriated, a Taipei City Government health official said Monday.

Wang Yung-wei, director of disease control under the Department of Health, said that of the 33,799 foreign laborers who underwent physical examinations in 2007, 8.76 percent, or 2,962 of them, failed the health checks.

Most of them failed because they had intestinal parasites, he said. In the screening for 10 types of parasites, 2,814 workers were found to have blastocystis hominis, a single-cell parasite that infects the gastrointestinal tract of human and animals, he disclosed. Symptoms associated with the infection include diarrhea, abdominal pain, anorexia and vomiting.

Wang noted that people infected with blastocystis hominis are usually prone to anemia, but that foreign laborers employed in construction who are infected with the parasite pose no risks to their employers. However if they are working as domestic helpers or caretakers, then their employers should be careful not to contract the infection and the foreign workers should wash their hands frequently, he added.
Wang said that 30 foreign laborers, on X-ray examination, were found to have tuberculosis, a communicable disease. Those workers were repatriated, he said.
Foreign laborers who fail their health checks are allowed to remain in Taiwan if their health problems can be treated and cured, he added.

According to the relevant regulations, foreign laborers are required to take physical examinations six, 18 and 30 months after their arrival in Taiwan. The health checks include chest X-ray examination, tests for the AIDS virus, syphilis, parasites, and leprosy, and a general condition appraisal.

DOC.HEADLINE: EasyCard a hit in Matsu

TEXT.P: The EasyCard has been a hit in Matsu since it was introduced on the outlying island at the end of last month, the Taipei Smart Card Corp. (TSCC) said Sunday.
The TSCC, which issues the card, said that it has been used about 252 times a day on average in Matsu since it was made valid for use there on March 28.

Almost 25 percent of those using the EasyCard on Matsu have been visitors to the island, which illustrates the effectiveness of integrating the electronic transportation fee collection system, the TSCC said.
To date, more than 2,300 of the multi-purpose cards have been issued -- mostly to students -- on Matsu Island, according to the company.
In the first phase, the EasyCard will be valid for use on public buses in certain parts of Matsu, and will then extend to all ferry services on the outlying island from September.

From that date, Matsu residents will also be able to use their EasyCards in Taipei City on public buses, the MRT and the Maokong Gondola, the TSCC said, adding that visitors to Taiwan's capital will even be able to use the card at public libraries and to gain entry to the Taipei Zoo.
Persons interested in purchasing EasyCards can visit the TSCC's Web site at www.tscc.com.tw or call its toll-free customer service line at 0800-028880-970420 for more information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taipei stores turn off signs in Tzu Chi Earth Day activity

TEXT.P: Hundreds of businesses in Taipei City turned off their neon store signs Sunday evening at the Tzu Chi Foundation's behest to mark the upcoming Earth Day.
The foundation's Taipei office decided to hold the activity to promote efforts to counter global warming through energy conservation and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.
More than 500 businesses in the eastern part of the city took part in the activity by turning off their neon store signs for ten minutes at 8:00 p.m.
Tzu Chi staff also joined the effort by cleaning up streets, promoting measures to reduce carbon emissions, and collecting recyclables in the vicinity of the foundation's Taipei office.
Tzu Chi members will also observe Earth Day on April 22 by not using any electricity in their homes for one hour in the evening and urging others to do the same to help save the planet.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier-designate announces partial Cabinet lineup

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan announced Monday 17 members of his Cabinet, the selections based on their "integrity, competence, past record and the spirit of teamwork," and gave his assurance that the new administration will be in full cooperation upon taking office May 20 without a grace period.
Liu told a press conference that in addition to these qualities, "they also share a common consensus on the policies of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and his running mate Vincent Siew."

Liu first announced that Paul Chiu, a former finance minister, will be his deputy, commending Chiu as "the ideal candidate" for the vice premiership. Liu said he believes that Chiu will help make Taiwan's financial sector more vigorous and efficient.

Among the 17 designates, five of the new Cabinet members, including Hsieh Hsiang-chuan (secretary-general of the Executive Yuan), Tsai Hsun-hsiung (minister without portfolio), Yiin Chii-ming (minister of economic affairs), Mao Chi-kuo (minister of transportation and communications) and Chen Wu-hsiung (minister of the Council of Agriculture) were deputy ministers in the Kuomintang administration before 2000.
"No matter if the Cabinet members are old or new in the government, they must be ready for the task on the first day of their inauguration," Liu said.

Discounting media reports that many people have been soliciting positions, Liu emphasized that "the names of the new Cabinet members were initially proposed by me and have been decided following discussions with and approval from Ma and Siew."
"No one has come to me seeking any position," Liu went on, adding that the selections were made by the new administration through his invitation only.

Saying that the public has high expectations of the new government and hopes it will provide measures to solve the problems facing the country, Liu stressed that "we need talent with experience and qualifications because there is no time for the Cabinet to fine-tune."

He said he will complete the appointment of the entire Cabinet, including the ministers of national defense, finance, education and the Mainland Affairs Council by April 30, adding that "the new Cabinet will then immediately formulate its policies so that it can implement them after May 20."
"We want a 'seamless transition' from the current Democratic Progressive Party administration," Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign minister-designate Ou is the best choice: ex-FMs

TEXT.P: The selection of Francisco Ou as the next foreign minister has gained overwhelming approval, with two former foreign ministers praising him Monday as the best qualified candidate for the job given his solid experience in the diplomatic arena.

"Without any doubt, he is the best person to be foreign minister as he is a highly experienced and skilled diplomat," said former Foreign Minister John Chiang, who now serves as a Kuomintang legislator.

Describing Ou as a "technocrat, " Chiang said he was ideal for the job as it is a profession-oriented position and Ou's diplomatic skills are well known within the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Chiang was foreign minister from 1996 to 1997, during which period Ou served as his deputy.
Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu, also a former foreign minister, agreed with Chiang, saying that Ou is the most suitable candidate for the job.
"I am extremely delighted to see such a talented person appointed as foreign minister," Hu said.

Hu recalled that during his two-year stint as foreign minister from 1997 to 1999, Ou made a remarkable contribution to building friendships with countries that had no diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
Ou was best known for his sacrifice and dedication to diplomatic work, Hu said, noting that the senior diplomat was once trapped by a flood in Fiji and could not be contacted for over 24 hours.

The 68-year-old diplomat, who graduated from the National Chengchi University's Department of Diplomacy, speaks perfect Spanish and has served in various important posts, including representative to Spain and director-general of the MOFA's Department of Central and South American Affairs. He is now Taiwan's ambassador to Guatemala.

Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan announced 17 members of the Cabinet lineup Monday. He stressed that experience is what counts the most when starting a new administration. The new cabinet is to be inaugurated May 20.

The 17 new appointees include Vice Premier Paul Chiu, Secretary General of the Executive Yuan Steve Hsieh, Minister of the Interior Liao Feng-te, Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco Ou, Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii- ming, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Lega Nord to have one vice premier and three ministers.
Italian incoming premier Silvio Berlusconi's future government will have one vice premier and three ministers from his allied Lega Nord party. Former reform minister Roberto Calderoli will be vice premier. Former justice minister Roberto Maroni will take over the Interior Ministry. Lega Nord leader Umberto Bossi will heads the Ministry of Institutional Reforms and Luca Zaia will be minister of agriculture.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor vows to entice Chinese tourists with quality services

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said Monday that she will ask restaurants, hotels and shops to provide quality services to entice more Chinese tourists to visit the southern port city.
Chen made the remarks after President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said he hopes that at least 33 percent of Chinese tourists who visit Taiwan once opening measures are in place will arrive via Kaohsiung.

Ma said he hopes for "balanced development of northern and southern Taiwan" and that "everyone will have an opportunity, " noting that Kaohsiung's international airport could play the role of a gateway to southern Taiwan.
Chen said she has asked the city's Department of Redevelopment to meet with restaurant and hotel operators to discuss how to upgrade their service quality.
She said shops should also follow stringent requirements in terms of setting prices and quality.
The Kaohsiung city government has set this year as "tourism year" and there will be a series of activities and souvenir promotions targeting tourists, officials said.
Chen will also lead various delegations overseas to promote tourism, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Increase in grain cultivation to help deter price hikes: academic

TEXT.P: An academic said Sunday that international cereal price hikes might slow as more countries work to increase grain production.

Lin Kuo-ching, a professor of the Department of Agricultural Economics at National Taiwan University, noted that the recent international cereal crisis is due mainly to the fact that more and more farmers around the world have switched to corn cultivation in order to produce ethanol as biomass energy amid soaring oil prices, which has affected the production of other cereals.

"The other main reason is climate change, which has resulted in the reduction of cereal crops in several countries," Lin said, citing the example of Australia, which has suffered a drought for the last few years.
"Since many countries are boosting their grain production, the future prices of cereals will largely depend on the extent of climate change," Lin went on.

According to the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations, global rice production is expected to increase by 12 million tons this year, or 1.8 percent, if weather patterns remain normal for the rest of the year.

The FAO has estimated that the world's major rice producers, including Bangladesh, China, India, Indonesia, Myanmar, the Philippines and Thailand will see their rice production rise significantly this year, with many other parts of the world also increasing production, including Africa, Latin America and Europe.

Chen Ming-chien, a professor of finance at Hsuan Chuang University, said many poor countries are blaming the subsidy policy that rich countries are adopting to boost production of biomass energy, which encourages farmers to grow corn on land normally used for cereal cultivation, a policy that has also been blamed for the hikes in cereal prices.
However, Chen noted that the cereal crisis might mean a comeback for genetic modification, as this can produce bigger harvests from limited land to feed the global population.
Noting that genetically modified crops can resist insects and can produce more returns, Chen estimated that more biotechnology companies will dedicate their efforts in this field.

Meanwhile, You Sheng-feng, deputy director of Agriculture and Food Agency under the Council of Agriculture, noted that there is limited space for rice price hikes, as the country's rice production will reach 800,000 tons in its first crop of the year, due in May.

"In addition, the government has been releasing stored rice onto the market and is discussing the future of the 220,000 hectares of fallow land around Taiwan to cope with the rising prices, " You said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 8.98 points, or 0.09 percent, to close at 9,083.32.

The local bourse opened at 9,156.77 and fluctuated between 9,160.10 and 9,047.66 during the day's session. A total of 6.14 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$164.75 billion (US$5.4 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up 1.2 percent.

The other seven lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 5.4 percent, followed by paper and pulp shares at 2.5 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.4 percent, and cement stocks at 0.5 percent. Textile and plastics and chemical stocks both slid 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,259 to 1,084, with 267 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$5.64 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Telecare solution to Taiwan's aging society: health minister

TEXT.P: The minister of the Department of Health said Monday that telecare is the solution to Taiwan's fast-aging society, as the crisis of the aging population is imminent and the government has to adopt counter-measures sooner rather than later.

Speaking at an international conference on policy and service delivery models for telecare, Department of Health Minister Hou Sheng-mou said that "crisis is inevitable if a country cannot tackle in advance problems that are set to happen, " referring to the tendency of the falling birthrate and the aging population in Taiwan.
He noted that the telecare project proposed by the Department of Health in 2007 is an initiative aimed at solving this problem, at least in part.

"The telecare project is the first functional network in Taiwan that provides integrated and ubiquitous care services 24 hours a day by combining community care, home care and institution care, " Hou said.
In a keynote speech at the conference, Department of Health Deputy Minister Chen Tzay-jinn said that "care services are not the responsibility of the medical system alone."

The whole of society should move toward shared care and integrated service as well as improved accessibility and cost-effectiveness of health services in order to achieve the goal of healthy aging and fulfill demands for long-term care, he added.

However, Chen admitted that there are several limitations for Taiwan's telecare pilot program, which include the lack of reliable financing support for long- term care, insufficient capacity for care devices and health electronics development, and the language or digital access barrier for migrant caregivers and the disabled.

Wanfang Hospital Superintendent Chiu Wen-ta, who introduced the current situation of Taiwan's Telecare Pilot Project in his presentation, said that although the promotion of telecare in Taiwan is in its primary stage, there is no doubt that it is the best solution for the needs of a fast-aging society.
Council for Economic Planning and Development Minister Ho Mei-yueh noted that the speed of the aging of the population in Taiwan is so rapid that it is creating a very serious problem.
In 2007, 10 percent of Taiwan's 23 million people were aged over 65 years, Ho said, a number that will have doubled in just 20 years. By 2050, 33 percent of the population will be over 65, she added.
"It is not only a serious problem but also a great business opportunity," Ho said.

She noted that if Taiwan can deal with the problem as soon as possible by developing a well-organized telecare system, the implementation of such a system will facilitate the development of the health 3C industry -- health- implemented computers, health-implemented communication technology and health care electronics -- and Taiwan will then be able to export its technology and experience to other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Certain Cabinet appointments get mixed reviews from NGOs

TEXT.P: Non-governmental agencies responded favorably Monday to the choice of new heads of the Department of Health (DOH) and the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), but were less enthusiastic about the candidate to lead the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).

Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan on Monday named Dean of National Taiwan University College of Medicine Lin Fang-yue as minister in charge of the DOH, and Jennifer Ju-hsuan Wang, a lawyer and chief of the Awakening Foundation, as head of the CLA. Shen Shih-hung, the current Taipei City Environmental Protection Bureau director, was selected as minister of the Environmental Protection Administration, on a list of 17 new cabinet members announced by Liu to date.

"I have a great expectation for Lin Fang-yue, as he is considered a methodical and perseverant person who has high work standards," said Lin Ching-li, the director of the public affairs section of the John Tang Foundation, which has been promoting the public health since its inception in 1984.
"We hope that he will make the DOH more vibrant," she said in a telephone interview with the Central News Agency.
Another non-governmental organization, which focuses on labor rights, expressed similar sentiments regarding Wang's appointment.

"We expect much from Wang, as she has a progressive image," said Gu Yu-ling, the secretary-general of the Taiwan International Workers' Association. Wang has long been involved in advocacy for the rights of minority groups such as homosexuals and female workers, Gu noted.
"We will observe the approach to the rights of foreign caregivers as a key indicator to Wang's policies," Gu added.
In Taiwan, about 160,000 caretakers, mostly from Southeast Asian countries, have scant protection under the Labor Standards Law.
The response to the appointment of the 59-year-old Shen to head the EPA was cooler, with a Green Party official expressing reservations about Shen's past work record.

"I don't recall any important achievements by Shen during his stint in the Taipei City environmental bureau and I"m not optimistic about his appointment," Pan Han-shen, the secretary-general of the Green Party Taiwan, told the CNA.
"If the central government's focus is on boosting the economy, the environment will be a difficult issue, " Pan added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved up one point to close at 9,082, with 49,851 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June gained seven points to finish at 9,055, with 292 contracts traded, while September futures dropped eight points to close at 8,804, with 48 contract transactions.
December futures increased 30 points to finish at 8,765, with 18 contract transactions, while March futures moved up one point to close at 8,733, with two contracts traded.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 8.98 points Monday to finish at 9,083.32, with a market turnover of NT$164.75 billion (US$5.4 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 9,081 for May; 9,048 for June; 8,812 for September: 8,735 for December and 8,732 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
May TE futures rose five points to close at 343.4, with 4,925 contracts traded, while June TE futures gained 4.9 points to finish at 342.15, with 39 contract transactions.
September TE futures increased 2.7 points to close at 338, with seven contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December and March.
May TF futures dropped 19.6 points to close at 1,214, with 5,864 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures decreased 17.8 points to finish at 1,211.2, with 31 contract transactions.
September TF futures gained 0.8 points to close at 1,213, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.004 to close at NT$30.288.
A total of US$912 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.315 and fluctuated between NT$30.265 and NT$30.348.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 Taipei County high school students injured in car accident

TEXT.P: Fifteen students of the National Taishan Senior High School were injured early Monday when the bus carrying them to school crashed into a combination truck on the Dahan Bridge, which links the two neighboring cities of Banciao and Hsinchuang.

Firemen and other emergency workers sent the 15 students, including four girls, to three hospitals for treatment. Most of the students suffered lacerations to the face, chest and knee. Several of them had to have stitches to close the wounds.

According to police, a city bus owned by Sanchung Bus Co. was carrying more than 30 students from Banciao city to their school, Taishan Senior Hish School in Taishan township, when the accident occurred.
Kung Chun-min, the 38-year-old bus driver, said that as he drove onto the Dahan Bridge, he found that the roadway was covered with a film of grease.
"I was driving at 40 kilometers per hour when I noticed that the truck ahead of me had stopped. I started to brake from 100 meters away, but still could not stop the bus," he said.

Chiu Ching-han, 33, the driver of the combination truck, said he also noticed the film of grease on the bridge and had stopped the truck in order to caution traffic policemen on the other side of the road about the potential hazard.
"The accident would not have occurred if I had minded my own business," he said.

Police said the grease on the bridge was probably the main cause of the accident, but they could not be certain whether it had been left by a construction team or was the result of a previous vehicular accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawyer/activist named minister of labor affairs

TEXT.P: A longtime advocate of women's rights and gender equality has been appointed Taiwan's new minister of labor affairs, one of four females who will comprise President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's new cabinet.
Jennifer Ju-hsuan Wang, 45, was appointed minister in charge of the Cabinet- level Council of Labor Affairs by Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan Monday.

She and other Cabinet members under the incoming Kuomintang (KMT) administration of Ma will take office on May 20. The other three women minister-designate named Monday will serve in the positions of minister of justice, chairwoman of the National Youth Commission and chief of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

Wang, who has been a women's rights lawyer and an activist with several organizations championing gender equality, including in the workplace, said she accepted the appointment because she believes the post will allow her greater opportunity to take care of the less advantaged people in Taiwan.
Expressing she had mixed feelings about joining the government, Wang said she nevertheless realizes that the tasks entrusted upon her will be heavy and the road ahead is a long one.
Meanwhile, Wang's appointment was met favorably in general by labor activist groups in the country.

Hsieh Chuang-chih, secretary-general of the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions, said Wang's expertise and experience in handling issues pertaining to women's rights could be a plus to governmental efforts to address labor issues, such as career women's work time, maternity leave and wages.
Hsieh pointed out, however, that gender equality is not the only issue involved in the country's labor affairs.

Considering that Wang is more or less a stranger to the labor sector, Hsieh suggested that Wang meet with representatives of various labor groups prior to the May 20 inauguration to hear views from the grass-roots labor sector so as to help her shape her policies once taking office.

Sun You-lien, secretary-general of the Taiwan Labor Front, urged Wang to pay closer attention to issues pertaining to the implementation of labor retirement pension, the enactment of laws governing labor unions and settlement of disputes between employers and employees.

Sun said that some KMT legislators have submitted a number of draft bills, aimed at helping rev up the flagging domestic economy, that would instead hurt the rights and interests of the working class.
He urged Wang to bear in mind, once she takes office, workers' rights and interests.
Ku Yu-ling, chairwoman of the Taiwan International Workers Association (TIWA) , said her group attaches great expectations to Wang's performance in coming years.

"Nevertheless, TIWA, which serves more than 300,000 migrant workers working in Taiwan, will not relent in checking and monitoring the performances of the Council of Labor Affairs in the future, " Ku added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20% of first-graders nearsighted

TEXT.P: The results of a survey of Taiwanese students' eyesight in 2006 show that 19.6 percent of first-graders suffer from myopia, according to a statement released by the Department of Health (DOH) Monday.
The survey was conducted among students aged between 6 and 18 every two or three years by the Bureau of Health Promotion under the DOH.

The results of the survey and of the previous ones show that nearsightedness in Taiwan has three special features: occurring at a young age, with high prevalence and of a high degree of nearsightedness.
However, a different survey carried out a year earlier shows that Taiwanese people do not have enough common sense to cope with this common eye problem, according to the statement.

The results of a survey on the public's knowledge of myopia, conducted via telephone interviews in 2007, show that only 8.3 percent of the 4,026 respondents answered correctly to three test questions on myopia. Among the respondents, females, older people and people with lower education levels showed less common sense on myopia than the other respondents.
Some 29.9 percent knew that corrective surgery for high-degree nearsightedness, which is a popular treatment in Taiwan, cannot prevent complications of existing high degree myopia.

Only 35.7 percent knew that people with nearsightedness of over 600 degrees have the chance of getting retinal degeneration or detachment, while 46.6 percent knew that a high degree of myopia is more likely to happen to children who become nearsighted at a younger age than those who do not suffer until later in life.

According to the statement, most nearsightedness in Taiwanese students is axial myopia, which is due to eye axis elongation. Corrective surgery can make changes to only corneal curves, not to the elongated axis.

People with high-degree nearsightedness, even if they have corrective surgery, are still likely to get complications related to elongated and degenerated axis, such as retinal detachment, glaucoma, cataract and macular degeneration.

The statement reminded the public to pay more attention to the eye health of their children, many of whom over-strain their eyes at school, surfing the Internet, watching television and playing computer games.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF chairman-designate to visit five Chinese cities

TEXT.P: Chiang Pin-kung, a vice chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT) and chairman-designate of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), will visit five cities in southeastern China later this week, a KMT official said Monday.

Chiang will visit Shanghai and Kunshan in Jiangsu Province, and Xiamen in Fujian Province, Shenzhen and Tungguan in Guangdong Province, where most of the Taiwan businessmen operating in China converge, according to Chang Jung-kung, deputy executive director of the KMT's Policy Committee and director of the party's Department of Chinese Affairs.

Chang noted that more than 200,000 Taiwanese businessmen operating in China returned to Taiwan to vote in the March 22 presidential election, which saw KMT candidate Ma Ying-jeou score a decisive victory by a margin of 2.21 million votes against his ruling Democratic Progressive Party rival, Frank Hsieh.

"Their concerns for Taiwan's political development are admirable," Chang said, adding that Chiang will express appreciation on behalf of Ma to the Taiwan businessmen during his five-city visit April 24-28.

Observers said they are watching whether Chiang, SEF chairman-designate, will meet with high-ranking Chinese officials. The SEF is a semi-official body set up by Taiwan to handle civic exchanges with China in the absence of official ties.

Chiang has said he hopes the stalled cross-strait dialogue, which was suspended in 1999 after then-President Lee Teng-hui described cross-strait ties as "special state-to-state relations," can be resumed as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to make fire alarms mandatory

TEXT.P: The Taipei municipal government is planning to put forward a draft amendment to the fire prevention and control law that would require all residential buildings in the city to be equipped with fire alarms.
According to current regulations, only residential buildings over six storeys tall and more than a certain area in size are required to be equipped with fire alarms.
If the amendment is passed, the requirement will apply to all residential buildings, the Taipei City Fire Department said.
Under the amendment, violators could be fined up to NT$3,000 (US$100).
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said the amendment is needed as a tool in efforts to stem the number of fire disasters in the city.
The fire department said that its disaster prevention department held a hearing on March 20 to get the public's input on the proposed amendment.
The department added that the amendment has already been sent to the Taipei City Secretariat for review.
It expressed the hope that the process of legislating the amendment to the fire prevention and control law can be completed by the end of this year.

The fire alarms will have to comply with the standards set forth in the city's fire regulations, the department said, adding that the alarms will have to be checked by a certified professional at least once a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: University to hold World Earth Day activities

TEXT.P: A local university plans to hold a series of activities Tuesday aimed at urging the public to change its diet from meat-based to vegetarian in observance of World Earth Day.

National Chi Nan University in the central county of Nantou said in a statement Sunday that the activities, to be held in collaboration with the Nantou county government from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m., will begin with a documentary entitled "Devour the Earth, " which shows the environmental impact of human activities and meat-based diets on the planet.
The documentary will be followed by three speeches on the impact of global warming, green consumption, and a healthy diet, respectively, according to the statement.

The activities will end with a vegetarian lunch provided to all participants as part of the university's efforts to encourage local residents to eat more fruits and vegetables rather than meat, on the basis of the argument that the meat production process generates a high volume of carbon dioxide emissions.

The production of one kilogram of beef results in 36.4 kilograms of carbon dioxide, the most common greenhouse gas, a Japanese study showed. One kilogram of beef also requires the same amount of energy as it takes to light a 100-watt bulb for nearly three weeks, the study indicated.
The university's statement cited a United Nations report that said Taiwan is located in an area that is at high risk because of global warming.
The Earth's average temperature has risen 0.6 degrees in the past 100 years, while Taiwan's average temperature has climbed 1.3 degrees Celsius over the same period, according to the report.

The organizers of Tuesday's activities are also urging the public to follow the recent advice offered by Rajendra Pachauri, head of the U.N.'s scientific panel on climate change -- "don't eat meat, ride a bike, and be a frugal shopper" -- to help "brake global warming."

On Tuesday, the university also plans to launch a signature drive to recruit one million people to join its anti-global warming efforts, and will give away 200 cups and chopsticks for people to carry around rather than use disposable eating utensils.
Meanwhile, the university will turn off its lights for one hour on Earth Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan signs MOC with Intel to promote WiMAX application

TEXT.P: Global chipmaker giant Intel signed a Memorandum of Cooperation (MOC) with Taiwan Monday to jointly develop WiMAX service applications for the telecommunication sector in Taiwan, with a portion of the funding coming from a separate but complementary US$500 million investment and procurement program from 2008 to 2013.

Sean Maloney, Intel's executive vice president and chief sales and marketing officer, who met with President-elect Ma Ying-jeou earlier the day, signed the agreement with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on behalf of the U.S. microchip maker.

He noted that Intel plans to spend US$500 million on procurement and investment in Taiwan from 2008-2013 to promote the local WiMAX industry, citing Taiwan as an important strategic partner of Intel in the advancement of the development of the global WiMAX industry.

"Intel and its Taiwanese partners have produced global standards that make technology more affordable," Maloney said, pointing out the hundreds of millions of people around the world who can enjoy such technology, much of which is designed and manufactured in Taiwan.
He also referred to system integration and the compatibility of chip standards as major technical challenges that need to be solved as part of the cooperation between the two sides.

The MOC will be carried out both to advance Taiwan's technology to new frontiers and to strengthen the relationship between Taiwanese manufacturers and the global WiMAX industry, the MOEA announced at the signing.

By forming the partnership with the global leader in microchip design, the ministry went on, the alliance will help create a business entity established by the MOEA, Intel and the domestic private sectors to develop and test innovative applications, mobile devices and system integration frameworks based upon WiMAX technology, and to offer consulting services for WiMAX Network Infrastructure.

Taiwan ranks second in the world for investment in this particular technology, with a potential investment value of US$664 million (NT$20.25 billion) by 2010. WiMAX is a telecommunications technology that provides wireless data over long distances in a variety of ways, from point-to-point links to full mobile cellular-type access.

"Since 2005, Taiwan and Intel have worked in partnership to promote the WiMAX industry, said Shih Yen-shiang, MOEA administrative deputy minister, referring to a memorandum of understanding (MOU) signed between the MOEA and Intel in 2005, since which time Intel has helped local makers to develop WiMAX equipment while organizing expositions and conferences on the technology.
Shih said the domestic private sector's achievements boosted by the MOU, such as the latest innovations and devices, will be showcased in the "2008 WiMAX Expo, Taipei" set to take place June 2-6.
"Those devices will ensure that consumers are able to buy high-quality and reasonably-priced WiMAX products, Shih said.
Diverse applications and broadband networks, Shih added, are the keys to the global WiMAX market shares in the technical- application industry.

Intel established Intel Innovation Center in 2003 to work with the Taiwanese telecommunication and information technology sectors to develop a range of applications including mobile computing, industry networks and home digital services.

Taiwanese technology companies have been collaborating with Intel since the 1980s, dating back to the very establishment of the Internet to as recently as the Wi-Fi broadband services launched five years ago, according to Maloney.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA chairman-designate outlines vision for agriculture

TEXT.P: The chairman-designate of the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Monday that the main goal of the council will be ensuring the "health, efficiency and sustainable growth" of Taiwan's agricultural production after he assumes office.

Chen Wu-hsiung made the remarks to CNA in an interview after it was confirmed earlier Monday that he will be the new COA chairman of the incoming administration led by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou. Ma will be sworn in on May 20.

Chen, 64, earned a doctoral degree in agricultural economics from Illinois University and once served as the council's vice chairman until January 2002. He is currently a committee member of the National Policy Foundation -- a non- profit think tank.
As a veteran expert in Taiwan's agricultural sector, Chen also was the mastermind who crafted Ma's agricultural policy white paper prior to the presidential campaign.

Chen said that under his leadership, the COA will aim to "build public health, boost agricultural competitiveness and enhance sustainable growth" as a means of injecting a new lease on life for Taiwan's agricultural industry.
Increasing Taiwan's food output in view of a deteriorating food shortage around the globe will be his short-term objective, Chen said.
Some 220,000 hectares of farmland that has been lying fallow across Taiwan should be restored to planting crops that the country currently imports from other countries, Chen said.

Boosting the quality of Taiwan's farm products is another major goal of the COA, according to Chen. Taiwan's farm products must be good enough and free from pesticides and other toxic substances to fully protect consumers' health, he said. Only such good produce can break into the international market and help build up Taiwanese brands of farm goods, he said.
To increase competitiveness, Taiwan's agricultural sector also must possess unique technology, such as biotech, management and production expertise, Chen said.

Turning to the major task of "sustainable growth, " Chen said, the government must iron out visionary policies to preserve its natural resources, and that every member of the public has to do his or her share to help reduce the emission of greenhouse gas.
Chen pledged to implement an 80,000-hectare forestation program in the coming eight years and build three large world-class forest recreational parks.

In addition, he said, the COA will help Taiwan's farmers sell their goods to China and set up a long-term mutually beneficial cooperation system with China. The vast Chinese market is a good outlet for Taiwan's farm products, Chen noted.

Along the lines of what Chen is promoting, Huang You-tsai, director of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, said last week that the government would consider resuming cultivation of fallow rice paddies to curb an increased food shortage around the world.

According to Huang, the government could allow rice paddies that have lain fallow to be plowed at any time, although it has adjusted its rice production policy after Taiwan entered the World Trade Organization.
Compared to other Asian countries, Taiwan's rice prices remain relatively stable, having increased by only 13 percent this year, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier to go vegetarian for Earth Day

TEXT.P: High ranking government officials, including Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, will go vegetarian Tuesday to mark Earth Day, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Monday.
Apart from Chang, Vice Premier Chiou I-jen and Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun will also forego meat to lend their support to mark Earth Day, said Shieh.
The Executive Yuan issued notification to the agencies under its auspices, urging their staff to either walk, cycle or take public transport to work on the day.
The Executive Yuan also called on its agencies to switch off lights and turn off elevators for one hour during the midday break as part of their efforts to reduce CO2 emissions in observing the day.
According to Shieh, Environmental Protection Administration Minister Chen Chung-hsing, Fair Trade Commission Chairman Tang Jinn-chuan and he himself will walk to their offices Tuesday morning.
Only one car will escort the premier to his office, rather than the usual three, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: New government to review financial reforms: vice premier-designate

TEXT.P: The incoming Kuomintang (KMT) administration will review the second phase of financial reforms initiated by the incumbent government and present measures to expand the financial services market, Vice Premier-designate Paul Chiu said Monday.

Chiu, a finance minister when the KMT was in power prior to 2000, made the remarks at a press conference presided over by Premier-designate Liu Chao- shiuan to announce several members of his new Cabinet, who Liu said meet the qualifications of "integrity and competence."

Asked by reporters if the new government will continue the financial reforms initiated by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration, Chiu said the direction of the existing reforms, which is focused on mergers and acquisitions to boost the competitiveness of local financial institutions, is generally correct.
However, he added that "the process of the mergers and acquisitions should be fair and transparent and should follow market mechanisms."

Noting that sound financial structure is pivotal to a country's economic development, Chiu stressed that the KMT administration will put more efforts on expanding the scale of the domestic financial service market and boosting the effectiveness of domestic financial institutions.

Although Liu stressed that the lineup of the new Cabinet will recruit talent from diverse fields, he added that his selection of a financially skilled hand such as Chiu to serve as his deputy will help resolve the country's financial and economic problems, which he described as a very important sphere.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA lifts alarm over alleged tainted milk

TEXT.P: Milk reported to have been contaminated by the milk of diseased cows has passed drug residue tests, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Monday.

Huang Ing-haur, director of the COA's Department of Animal Industry, said health and agricultural authorities collected samples of the raw and processed milk in question for tests and the results "were either negative or showed no drug residue."

The allegedly tainted milk was sold under two fresh milk brands -- Highland and Chiang Chun -- that are both marketed by leading food manufacturer, AGV Products Corp. The milk was processed by an AGV-contracted dairy processing plant in Miaoli County.

According to a report published April 16 by Apple Daily, one of the plant's suppliers in Yunlin County supplied it with milk from diseased cows that was purchased at low prices from neighboring dairy farms.
Because the milk was produced by cows during and immediately after a period when they were receiving medication, by law it could not be processed for human consumption.
The revelation prompted AGV to recall the two brands of milk, and led health and agricultural authorities to launch an investigation into the situation.
Huang said that the drug test screened for antibiotics, such as tetracycline, penicillin, sulfonamides and chloramphenicol, but found no traces of any of them.

He suggested that the situation described in the Apple Daily report, in fact, was quite unlikely to have happened because according to council guidelines for dairy processors' procurement of raw milk, any milk found to have drug residues after arriving at their plants should be dyed and rejected.
Of the more than 40,000 raw milk samples tested by the COA last year, 99.74 percent passed the tests, Huang said.
Despite the false alarm, the COA said it will step up random checks to ensure dairy farmers rigorously follow proper procedures in medicating their animals.
In the meantime, the agency insisted domestic fresh milk and dairy products were "safe," and urged local residents to consume them freely.
Although health and agricultural authorities cleared Chiang Chun's name, its plant in Miaoli said Monday that the credibility of both Chiang Chun and AGV Products had been "irreparably damaged."
Chiang Chun said the market for all dairy products on the island were hit hard by Apple Daily's report last week, with sales falling by between 30 and 40 percent.
The company indicated that, along with AGV, it had borne the brunt of the incident, losing an estimated NT$10 million (US$328,950) daily since the report was published.
Chiang Chun said it reserved the right to file suit against the Apple Daily and would also devise measures to regain the trust of consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung Mayor to promote Taichung City tourism in Hong Kong

TEXT.P: Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu will head for Hong Kong Wednesday to promote tourism in the central city at a seminar for travel agents of the former British colony.

Hu and Taiwan's Landis Hotel and Resorts President Stanley Yen will exchange views on tourism promotion in Taichung and Hong Kong and issues related to future direct charter flights between Taiwan and China at the April 25 seminar, the Taichung mayor told the Central News Agency.

Regular direct charter flights between Taiwan and China, a key plank in President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's program, are expected to begin sometime this year, and Hu is worried about the impact they could have on Taichung Airport.

He told CNA that opening charter flights at other airports in Taiwan could hurt existing charters between Taichung and Hong Kong and Macau, but suggested the drops in passenger load factors could be offset by offering arrival visas to Hong Kong and Macau residents.
Hu said he had made the suggestion to the central government many times but had yet to receive any concrete response, but Ma may even take the Taichung mayor's idea one step further.

In a news conference with Hong Kong reporters on April 14, Ma said he would consider granting Hong Kong visitors to Taiwan visa-free status, which some travel agents estimated would boost arrivals from the "special administrative region" by 10 percent.

Following the seminar in Hong Kong, Hu will head to Britain to solicit investment and then visit the International Baseball Federation in Switzerland in a bid to persuade baseball's world governing body to hold more international baseball events in his city.
The Taichung mayor will also visit the International Olympic Committee in Lausanne to lobby the organization to reinstate baseball as an Olympic event.

At an IOC meeting in 2005, baseball was voted out of the Olympics beginning with the 2012 London Games. Eight teams, including Taiwan, have qualified to play in what might be the sport's farewall appearance at the Olympics in Beijing in August.

Eager to bring the sport's standard in Taichung to international levels, Hu built the 15,000-seat Intercontinental Baseball Stadium to have an acceptable venue in the city to host international tournaments.
Since its completion in 2007, the stadium has hosted the Asian Baseball Championship, the Baseball World Cup, and the 2008 Final Olympic Qualifying Tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign minister-designate hopes for truce in diplomatic tug-of-war

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister-designate Francisco Ou expressed the hope Monday of a "truce" in the diplomatic tug-of-war between Taiwan and China.
Ou, a seasoned diplomat who is currently the Republic of China (Taiwan) 's ambassador to Guatemala, made the remarks at a news conference held at the headquarters of the soon-to-be-ruling Kuomintang.

Ou dismissed reports that Taiwan is engaging in "dollar diplomacy" as "improper, " saying that all developed countries will assist developing countries, and that Taiwan, as a developed country, is simply doing the same thing.

Moreover, Taiwan has developed close and friendly relations with its allies over a long period of time, and the allies have continued to speak up for Taiwan in the international community, so it was "only natural for both sides to continue cooperation and reciprocity," the 68-year-old diplomat said.
But he also acknowledged that some allies had done their best to exploit the rivalry between the two sides for their own gains.
"This is why a truce in diplomatic tug-of-war is important, " Ou said, explaining that if both sides could reach an agreement on a truce, it would benefit the two sides immensely.
"The question now is to find an approach that can be accepted by both sides, " Ou said.

If Taipei and Beijing could cease their vicious competition, they could then engage in rational cross-strait cooperation and avoid "irrational acts" to undermine each other and squander valuable resources, he contended.

Ou, a senior diplomat with 44 years of experience who said he was caught off guard at being recruited for the post, said Taiwan's plight in the international community is different from that of most other countries, and that diplomacy cannot be conducted in a conventional way.
Noting that diplomacy is an extension of a nation's domestic affairs, he said that he has to learn more about the path of the new administration before he can map out a new diplomatic approach.
But he also said that "dignity" and "pragmatism" will remain key diplomatic principles necessary to safeguard national interests.
The choice of Ou is a departure from the tradition of selecting foreign ministers from among diplomats stationed in English-speaking countries.
Ou, who served as Spanish interpreter for the late President Chiang Kai-shek, will be the first diplomat serving in a Spanish-speaking country to fill the post.
Twelve of 23 of the country's allies are located in Central and South America and in the Caribbean.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's GDP growth for 2008 predicted at 4 percent: Citibank Taiwan

TEXT.P: Citibank Taiwan has lowered its forecast for Taiwan's gross domestic product growth for 2008 to 4.0 percent, lagging even further behind the 5.7 percent growth recorded in 2007.

Cheng Cheng-mount, chief economist of Citibank Taiwan, said the growth forecast was scaled down from 4.5 percent predicted earlier this year to 4.0 percent mainly because of the impact of the subprime mortgage financial crisis in the United States.
Cheng said both private sector consumption and capital investment in Taiwan are showing stronger growth momentum than last year, but export growth is expected to slow.
Taiwan is also expected to maintain its unemployment rate at 3.9 percent in 2008, with the inflation rising from 1.8 in 2007 to 2.3 percent this year, according to Cheng.
The economist remained pessimistic about the performance of the U.S. economy.
"The worst of the subprime mortgage crisis may be over, but the best times have not yet arrived," he said, adding that the impact of the crisis might be felt for another six months to one year.

According to Cheng's analysis, the U.S. economy is expected to post negative growth of minus 1.32 percent in the second quarter this year, followed by a 0.1 percent growth in the third quarter, with overall economic growth for 2008 forecast at 0.8 percent.
Citibank Taiwan has forecast 1.3 percent economic growth for the euro area in 2008, 1.7 percent growth for Japan, 9.8 percent growth for China and 7.7 percent growth for India.

DOC.HEADLINE: More women than men vote in presidential polls: CEC

TEXT.P: Some 210,000 more eligible female voters cast ballots than their male counterparts in the March 22 presidential polls, Taiwan's election authority said Monday.

This year marked the first time that the Central Election Commission (CEC) had ever conducted a gender analysis of elections in Taiwan, making it impossible to know if the results deviated from past practice.

The CEC, which said the analysis was done at the request of the Cabinet-level Commission on Women's Rights Promotion, analyzed data for both the presidential election and the Jan. 12 legislative polls.

In the presidential election, 6.71 million of the 8.65 million eligible female voters, or 77.65 percent, turned out to vote, while 6.5 million of the 8.67 million male voters, or 75.02 percent, exercised their rights, according to a CEC statement released Monday.

Female voter turnout surpassed male voter turnout in all but one of Taiwan's 25 cities and counties, with Taoyuan County the only exception. There, male turnout was 78.75 percent compared to 76.41 percent turnout for female voters.

Although no data exist on gender breakdowns for past elections, CEC officials said that it is generally agreed that a higher percentage of male voters than female voters have taken part in previous polls.

That was still the case for the 2008 legislative elections, in which 5.06 million of the 8.65 million eligible male voters, or 58.5 percent, cast ballots, edging out the 5.01 million of the 8.63 million eligible female voters, or 58.09 percent, who voted.

Liao Da-chi, a political scientist with National Chungshan University, was quoted by the Chinese-language United Daily News as having said that the higher turnout of female voters in the presidential race should not be attributed to the personal charisma of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who is seen as popular among female voters.
Rather, Liao said that more women turned out to vote because they attached greater importance than men to rebuilding ethics and values in the government.
Ma, who campaigned on a platform of rooting out corruption at the central government level, defeated his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rival Frank Hsieh by more than 2.2 million votes.

Liao also argued that female voters were more willing to take part in the presidential election than in the legislative polls because the latter is smaller-scale and did not create enough energy and excitement to draw women voters to the polls.
The overall turnout rates for the presidential and legislative polls were 76.33 percent and 58.28 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese real estate tycoons arrive for 'trip of discovery'

TEXT.P: A group of nine Chinese real estate developers arrived in Taiwan Monday for a four-day visit which they described as a trip to explore the local property market and study Taiwan's laws and experiences in real estate marketing and development.

Taiwan's real estate market has the most potential of any in the Asia-Pacific region, said delegation leader Lin Changle, the chairman of the Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite Television Co., upon the group's arrival at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.

Taiwan's "mature" experience in property management and regulatory framework are worth learning, added the businessman, who also operates the Beijing-based Zhong Chen Le Tian Real Estate Development Co. Ltd.

Taiwan currently allows investment by Chinese nationals in the local property market, but the barriers, including security checks, proof of the source of funding, and strict limits on borrowing, have discouraged potential investors.

As a result, fewer than a handful of Chinese have successfully bought property here, but that may change under President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who pledged to open up investment in the local real estate market to Chinese developers.

Asked whether their trip was connected to Ma's election victory, Liu said he thinks now is an opportune moment for the two sides to begin implementing their long-discussed plans to boost bilateral economic and trade exchanges.
Members of the Chinese group include Lin Silian, chairman of Guangzhou R&F Properties Co., and SOHO China Ltd. Chairman Pan Shiyi.

From the airport, the group of business tycoons went directly to the Neihu Science Park in Taipei's Dazhi District to begin their tour of the island. At the park, they received a briefing by Taipei Deputy Mayor Lin Chung-yi on Taipei's political and economic development.
The group will head to the central Taiwan city of Taichung Tuesday, where they will be received by Mayor Jason Hu, according to the Taichung city government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two security guards injured in daylight robbery in Taipei

TEXT.P: Two armed robbers escaped with NT$4.3 (US$141,870) million on a motorcycle Monday after firing 10 shots and injuring two security guards in a daylight cash-in-transit heist in front of a post office in Taipei's Wanhua district.
The two security guards were walking toward their cash-in-transit delivery vehicle with a bag of cash collected from the post office on Guoxing Road when fired upon by the two robbers.
Wang Ching-ling, director of the Wanhua Police Precinct, said the robbery was well-planned, with the two criminals wearing raincoats, motorcycle helmets and face masks during the attack.

According to Wang, one of the security guards, surnamed Chou, was hit four times and received penetrating wounds in both legs and his pelvis. Doctors at the Hoping branch of the Taipei Municipal Hospital said he was not out of danger yet and still remained in an intensive care unit.
The other security guard, surnamed Hsieh, suffered two gunshot wounds on his right knee. He was also operated on at the same hospital.

Wang said police has found the silver-colored motorcycle and the empty money bag discarded by the two robbers on a road near a river bank, and that a task force consisting of police officers from his precinct, the Taipei Police Bureau and the Criminal Investigation Bureau has been formed to investigate the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: New interior minister KMT's election hero

TEXT.P: The architect of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) stunning run of election victories in recent years was given a new challenge Monday when appointed as interior minister-designate, a post in which the new government hopes he will have a similar run of success.
Liao Fung-te, the KMT's deputy secretary-general and organization and development committee director, has been the party's election coordinator since late 2004.
Under Liao's direction, the KMT won 81 of the 113 seats in a scaled-down Legislative Yuan in elections in January and then scored a decisive victory in the presidential election in March.

The KMT's string of electoral success under Liao began with the legislative elections in December 2004, when the KMT-led alliance with the People First Party upset the predictions of most prognosticators by retaining its majority in the lawmaking body.
The unexpected success led President Chen Shui-bian to step down as chairman of the party.

The KMT then won the 2005 city and county head elections and by-elections, further expanding its political dominance, and in late 2006 gained victories in the Taipei City mayoral election and Taipei City and Kaohsiung City council elections.
The only electoral setback suffered by the party in recent years was when it narrowly lost the race for Kaohsiung City mayor that same year.

Liao's political career began when he served as election campaign spokesman for former President Lee Tung-hui in 1996. He then failed in his bid to become Yilan County magistrate in 1997 and was named a KMT legislator-at-large.

Before starting his political career, the 57-year-old Liao, who has a doctoral degree in history, was a newspaper reporter and accomplished writer who won a major literary award. One of his novels, titled "Neighbors, " was adapted into a popular television soap opera series.

DOC.HEADLINE: Feisty female lawyer to head Ministry of Justice

TEXT.P: An articulate and feisty female lawyer who has been active in helping disadvantaged women secure their rights was named minister of justice of the incoming administration of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou Monday.
Wang Ching-feng, 56, said she accepted the job offer with both trepidation and a sense of awe as she has never before been involved in prosecutorial work.

Wang, a former member of the Control Yuan, responsible for monitoring the behavior of government officials and civil servants, said both Ma and Premier- designate Liu Chao-shiuan had twice approached her to agree to take the helm at the Ministry of Justice.
"I agreed to take up the job only after giving it a lot of thought, " Wang said, adding that she is determined to do her best to live up to public expectations.

On her policy vision and future work agenda, Wang said she intends to upgrade prosecutorial efficiency, wipe out official corruption, establish clean politics and further improve the protection of human rights.

The appointment of Wang marked a deviation from the tradition of picking a justice minister from the ranks of prosecutors. Asked whether her "outsider" status would draw a backlash from prosecutors, Wang said she is confident of addressing such issues as she has always dealt with people courteously and sincerely.

An outspoken advocate of clean politics, Wang said that after she takes office May 20, she will push for the establishment of a special commission in each city and county around the country to promote good governance and fight official corruption.
Wang has built a thriving legal career since obtaining a master's degree from National Cheng Chi University's Graduate Institute of Law.

In 1987, she founded the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, which is dedicated to rescuing child prostitutes and helping women who are victims of domestic violence. The foundation has also spoken out for aging Taiwanese women, known as "comfort women," who were forced into providing sex services for Japanese troops during Wolrd War II.

Wang gained national attention in 1996 when she agreed to serve as then-Control Yuan President Chen Li-an's running mate in the country's first-ever direct presidential election. Their ticket finished last among four candidates.

Following the 2004 presidential election, Wang was named by the opposition- controlled Legislative Yuan to serve as convener of the "319 Truth Commission" to investigate an election-eve shooting case in which President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu were slightly wounded on the campaign trail in the southern city of Tainan.

The "pan-blue" alliance of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) claimed that the incident was staged to help the Chen-Lu ticket win sympathy votes in the presidential poll.
The incumbent president and vice president won re-election the following day, beating the ticket comprising then-KMT Chairman Lien Chan and then-PFP Chairman James Soong by a slim margin.
Wang's appointment has drawn mixed reaction in judicial and political circles. The country's two major prosecutor associations recognized Wang's clean image and professionalism.
Chen Wen-chi, president of the Prosecutors Association, said all association members welcomed Wang's appointment as the new justice minister.

Noting that local media and members of the public have voiced high expectations for prosecutorial reforms over the past few years, Chen said her colleagues are hopeful that prosecutorial reforms can be accelerated following Wang's assumption of the office.

Chen Chih-ming, convener of the Prosecutors Reform Association, said Wang's lack of experience in prosecutorial work is not expected to greatly hinder her new role so long as she can strengthen dialogue and communications with rank-and- file prosecutors.

"Wang's 'outsider status' will give her a freer hand to promote reform, but the disadvantage lies in her unfamiliarity with the ministry's day-to-day operations. She needs appropriate assistance," Chen Chih-ming said.

Reaction from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was more reserved. Yeh Yi-jin, a DPP legislative whip, said that during Wang's stint as spokeswoman for the "319 Truth Commission, " Wang denied investigative results of all law enforcement officers, including policemen, Investigative Bureau agents and prosecutors.

"Wang should endeavor to repair the damage caused by her attitude (in pursuing the case) after assuming her new post, " said Yeh, who also hoped that Wang would not be obsessed with investigating the March 19, 2004 shooting case and should follow proper procedure if she does further pursue the investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGAlistair Darling tries to buy off 10p tax rate rebels withhelp for poor later
Alistair Darling will call Labour rebels to a series of private meetings today over the 10p tax issue as he begins a week-long operation to spare Labour its most embarrassing Commons defeat since it came to power in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Trailing in Pennsylvania, Obama Sharpens Tone
Senator Barack Obama sharpened his tone against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday as the six-week Pennsylvania primary contest raced to a close, with the rivals marshaling extensive resources in a battle for undecided voters and delegates that could determine whether the Democratic nominating fight carries on.
The Wall Street Journal:NatCity Close To $6 Billion Cash Infusion
