DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 22, or the 17th day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: On his way to India with 13 ships, Portuguese navigator Pedro Alvarez Cabral discovers Brazil and claims it for Portugal.
1724: Immanuel Kant, German idealist philosopher and one of history's greatest thinkers, is born. He argued that reason is the means by which the phenomena of experience is translated into understanding. His classic works include "Critique of Pure Reason" and "Critique of Practical Reason."
1870: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian leader of the Bolshevik Revolution and first leader of Communist Russia, is born.
1904: Robert Oppenheimer, American nuclear scientist who developed the atom bomb, is born.
1915: The Germans use poison gas for the first time on British troops on the Western Front during World War I.
1944: Allied forces land on Dutch New Guinea.
1947: Wei Tao-ming becomes governor of the newly established Taiwan Provincial Government.
1951: The first contingent of officers from the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group (MAAG) in Taiwan, arrives in Taipei. Maj. Gen. William C. Chase, the first MAAG chief, would arrive in Taipei later.
1956: Beijing appoints the Dalai Lama as chairman of a committee to prepare Tibet for regional autonomy within Communist China.
1961: The construction of the Taipei Chunghua Bazaar is completed with Gov. Chow Chih-jou of Taiwan Provincial Government presiding over the inauguration ceremony.
1969: American surgeons conduct the first human eye transplant.
1973: President Hammer de Roburt of the Republic of Nauru and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: A Pan American Airlines passenger plane crashes in Bali, Indonesia, killing 107 people.
1975: The first batch of Vietnamese refugees arrive on the western coast of the United States, as South Vietnam falls to the communists.
1980: S.S. Don Juan, a vehicle ferry, collides with a car float and sinks near Mindoro Island in the Philippines, killing some 1,000 people.
1984: Medical researchers working in the United States and France identify a type of human cancer virus that may be the causative agent in the killer disease Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly passes, at its sixth plenary meeting, the Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China and approves the abolishment of the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: Gasoline that leaked from a nearby refinery explodes in the sewer system of Guadalajara, Mexico, killing more than 200 people and injuring over 600 others.
1993: The Legislative Yuan ratifies a 1989 ROC-U.S. copyright agreement and passes amendments to the ROC's copyright law that go into effect April 26.
1993: Tongan Prime Minister Baron Vaea and Madame Vaea visit the Republic of China.
1994: Former U.S. President Richard M. Nixon dies of a stroke at the age of 81. He visited mainland China in 1972 and established detente with the USSR. When Congress recommended three articles of impeachment for Nixon's involvement in the Watergate scandal, he resigned from office Aug. 9, 1974.
1999: Visiting President Kirsan Nikolayevich Ilyumzhinov of the Kalmykia Republic meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and expresses interest in creating sisterhood ties between the Russian state and Taipei.
2000: The newly founded People First Party calls for a halt in revamping the ROC Constitution by the National Assembly, branding the draft amendments unconstitutional.
2000: The ROC Foreign Ministry formally approves the appointment of Chen Kuo- huang, director of the Foreign Ministry's Western Asian Affairs Department, as ambassador to Palau.
2001: Nobel laureate Yang Chen-ning is honored as the outstanding alumnus of the century in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, by his alma mater National Tsinghua University.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When the rulers encourage education and good manner, the people are easily amenable to government."

DOC.HEADLINE: More women than men vote in presidential polls: CEC

TEXT.P: Some 210,000 more eligible female voters cast ballots than their male counterparts in the March 22 presidential polls, Taiwan's election authority said Monday.

This year marked the first time that the Central Election Commission (CEC) had ever conducted a gender analysis of elections in Taiwan, making it impossible to know if the results deviated from past practice.

The CEC, which said the analysis was done at the request of the Cabinet-level Commission on Women's Rights Promotion, analyzed data for both the presidential election and the Jan. 12 legislative polls.

In the presidential election, 6.71 million of the 8.65 million eligible female voters, or 77.65 percent, turned out to vote, while 6.5 million of the 8.67 million male voters, or 75.02 percent, exercised their rights, according to a CEC statement released Monday.

Female voter turnout surpassed male voter turnout in all but one of Taiwan's 25 cities and counties, with Taoyuan County the only exception. There, male turnout was 78.75 percent compared to 76.41 percent turnout for female voters.

Although no data exist on gender breakdowns for past elections, CEC officials said that it is generally agreed that a higher percentage of male voters than female voters have taken part in previous polls.

That was still the case for the 2008 legislative elections, in which 5.06 million of the 8.65 million eligible male voters, or 58.5 percent, cast ballots, edging out the 5.01 million of the 8.63 million eligible female voters, or 58.09 percent, who voted.

Liao Da-chi, a political scientist with National Chungshan University, was quoted by the Chinese-language United Daily News as having said that the higher turnout of female voters in the presidential race should not be attributed to the personal charisma of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who is seen as popular among female voters.
Rather, Liao said that more women turned out to vote because they attached greater importance than men to rebuilding ethics and values in the government.
Ma, who campaigned on a platform of rooting out corruption at the central government level, defeated his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rival Frank Hsieh by more than 2.2 million votes.

Liao also argued that female voters were more willing to take part in the presidential election than in the legislative polls because the latter is smaller-scale and did not create enough energy and excitement to draw women voters to the polls.
The overall turnout rates for the presidential and legislative polls were 76.33 percent and 58.28 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two security guards injured in daylight robbery in Taipei

TEXT.P: Two armed robbers escaped with NT$4.3 (US$141,870) million on a motorcycle Monday after firing 10 shots and injuring two security guards in a daylight cash-in-transit heist in front of a post office in Taipei's Wanhua district.
The two security guards were walking toward their cash-in-transit delivery vehicle with a bag of cash collected from the post office on Guoxing Road when fired upon by the two robbers.
Wang Ching-ling, director of the Wanhua Police Precinct, said the robbery was well-planned, with the two criminals wearing raincoats, motorcycle helmets and face masks during the attack.

According to Wang, one of the security guards, surnamed Chou, was hit four times and received penetrating wounds in both legs and his pelvis. Doctors at the Hoping branch of the Taipei Municipal Hospital said he was not out of danger yet and still remained in an intensive care unit.
The other security guard, surnamed Hsieh, suffered two gunshot wounds on his right knee. He was also operated on at the same hospital.

Wang said police has found the silver-colored motorcycle and the empty money bag discarded by the two robbers on a road near a river bank, and that a task force consisting of police officers from his precinct, the Taipei Police Bureau and the Criminal Investigation Bureau has been formed to investigate the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: New interior minister KMT's election hero

TEXT.P: The architect of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) stunning run of election victories in recent years was given a new challenge Monday when appointed as interior minister-designate, a post in which the new government hopes he will have a similar run of success.
Liao Fung-te, the KMT's deputy secretary-general and organization and development committee director, has been the party's election coordinator since late 2004.
Under Liao's direction, the KMT won 81 of the 113 seats in a scaled-down Legislative Yuan in elections in January and then scored a decisive victory in the presidential election in March.

The KMT's string of electoral success under Liao began with the legislative elections in December 2004, when the KMT-led alliance with the People First Party upset the predictions of most prognosticators by retaining its majority in the lawmaking body.
The unexpected success led President Chen Shui-bian to step down as chairman of the party.

The KMT then won the 2005 city and county head elections and by-elections, further expanding its political dominance, and in late 2006 gained victories in the Taipei City mayoral election and Taipei City and Kaohsiung City council elections.
The only electoral setback suffered by the party in recent years was when it narrowly lost the race for Kaohsiung City mayor that same year.

Liao's political career began when he served as election campaign spokesman for former President Lee Tung-hui in 1996. He then failed in his bid to become Yilan County magistrate in 1997 and was named a KMT legislator-at-large.

Before starting his political career, the 57-year-old Liao, who has a doctoral degree in history, was a newspaper reporter and accomplished writer who won a major literary award. One of his novels, titled "Neighbors, " was adapted into a popular television soap opera series.

DOC.HEADLINE: Feisty female lawyer to head Ministry of Justice

TEXT.P: An articulate and feisty female lawyer who has been active in helping disadvantaged women secure their rights was named minister of justice of the incoming administration of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou Monday.
Wang Ching-feng, 56, said she accepted the job offer with both trepidation and a sense of awe as she has never before been involved in prosecutorial work.

Wang, a former member of the Control Yuan, responsible for monitoring the behavior of government officials and civil servants, said both Ma and Premier- designate Liu Chao-shiuan had twice approached her to agree to take the helm at the Ministry of Justice.
"I agreed to take up the job only after giving it a lot of thought, " Wang said, adding that she is determined to do her best to live up to public expectations.

On her policy vision and future work agenda, Wang said she intends to upgrade prosecutorial efficiency, wipe out official corruption, establish clean politics and further improve the protection of human rights.
Wang also expressed her hope that the MOJ becomes a "ministry of the people" and prosecutors under its jurisdiction become "servants of justice."

The appointment of Wang marked a deviation from the tradition of picking a justice minister from the ranks of prosecutors. Asked whether her "outsider" status would draw a backlash from prosecutors, Wang said she is confident of addressing such issues as she has always dealt with people courteously and sincerely.

An outspoken advocate of clean politics, Wang said that after she takes office May 20, she will push for the establishment of a special commission in each city and county around the country to promote good governance and fight official corruption.
Wang has built a thriving legal career since obtaining a master's degree from National Cheng Chi University's Graduate Institute of Law.

In 1987, she founded the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, which is dedicated to rescuing child prostitutes and helping women who are victims of domestic violence. The foundation has also spoken out for aging Taiwanese women, known as "comfort women," who were forced into providing sex services for Japanese troops during Wolrd War II.

Wang gained national attention in 1996 when she agreed to serve as then-Control Yuan President Chen Li-an's running mate in the country's first-ever direct presidential election. Their ticket finished last among four candidates.

Following the 2004 presidential election, Wang was named by the opposition- controlled Legislative Yuan to serve as convener of the "319 Truth Commission" to investigate an election-eve shooting case in which President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu were slightly wounded on the campaign trail in the southern city of Tainan.

The "pan-blue" alliance of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) claimed that the incident was staged to help the Chen-Lu ticket win sympathy votes in the presidential poll.
The incumbent president and vice president won re-election the following day, beating the ticket comprising then-KMT Chairman Lien Chan and then-PFP Chairman James Soong by a slim margin.

Wang's appointment has drawn mixed reaction in judicial and political circles. The country's two major prosecutor associations recognized Wang's integrity, no-nonsense working attitude and professionalism.
Chen Wen-chi, president of the Prosecutors Association, said all association members welcomed Wang's appointment as the new justice minister.

Noting that local media and members of the public have voiced high expectations for prosecutorial reforms over the past few years, Chen said her colleagues are hopeful that prosecutorial reforms can be accelerated following Wang's assumption of the office.

Chen Chih-ming, convener of the Prosecutors Reform Association, said Wang's lack of experience in prosecutorial work is not expected to greatly hinder her new role so long as she can strengthen dialogue and communications with rank-and- file prosecutors.

"Wang's 'outsider status' will give her a freer hand to promote reform, but the disadvantage lies in her unfamiliarity with the ministry's day-to-day operations. She needs appropriate assistance," Chen Chih-ming said.

Reaction from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was more reserved. Yeh Yi-jin, a DPP legislative whip, said that during Wang's stint as spokeswoman for the "319 Truth Commission, " Wang denied investigative results of all law enforcement officers, including policemen, Investigative Bureau agents and prosecutors.

"Wang should endeavor to repair the damage caused by her attitude (in pursuing the case) after assuming her new post, " said Yeh, who also hoped that Wang would not be obsessed with investigating the March 19, 2004 shooting case and should follow proper procedure if she does further pursue the investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: First legislative session to be extended until at least late June

TEXT.P: The first session of this legislature, scheduled to run to the end of May, will be extended to at least the end of June, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin -pyng said Tuesday.

Wang noted that the budget proposals for state-run businesses will only be sent to the legislature in mid-May, which will take until late May or early June to review. That will be followed by an interpellation session for new premier Liu Chao-shiuan and his Cabinet, which take office May 20.
"It may be necessary for the legislature to be in session until the end of June," Wang said.
According to the Law Governing the Legislative Yuan's Power, Liu is required to give an administrative report to the legislature within two weeks of his inauguration May 20.
Legislators can ask questions in person or in writing on the content of the reports given by Liu and his Cabinet members, according to the law.

The ROC's Constitution stipulates that there are two legislative sessions every year. The first session is from February to the end of May, and the second session goes from September to the end of December. Each session can be extended if necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer group warns of food coloring's link to hyperactivity

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation recommended Tuesday that food containing artificial colorings and preservatives be labeled with warnings of their possible harmful effects, after a British study found a link between the consumption of certain food colorings and hyperactive behavior in children.

The study investigated the effect of six food colorings -- sunset yellow, quinoline yellow, carmoisine, allura red, tartrazine and ponceau -- and the presevative sodium benzoate on 153 3-year-old and 144 8- and 9-year-olds drawn from the general population.
The researchers from the University of Southampton who conducted the study concluded in results published in September 2007 that the additives increased hyperactive behavior in the children tested.
The findings prompted the European Food Standards Agency to recommend earlier this month that the six colorings be phased out from food and beverages in the European Union.

According to Consumers' Foundation Chairman Cheng Jen-hung, a survey conducted by the foundation March 20-24 on 21 brands of ice pops and preserved fruits sold in Taiwan found that they all contained sodium benzoate and either tartrazine, sunset yellow or allura red.

Given the common use of the additives in food manufacturing, consumers should be warned of their possible harmful effects on their children, especially those already diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), Cheng said.
The Naivety ADHD Education Foundation has estimated that there are more than 137,000 elementary and junior high school students in Taiwan with the disorder.
Cheng advised parents to feed their children natural instead of processed foods to protect their health.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature passes amendment allowing decrease in rice wine tax

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Tobacco and Wine Law Tuesday to lower the tax on rice cooking wine.
Under the amendment, the tax on rice cooking wine will be reduced from NT$22 (US$0.72) per liter to NT$9 per liter.
The cooking wine is considered to be an essential ingredient in Chinese cuisine.
The legislature also passed a complementary resolution requiring the Ministry of Finance and the Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. to ensure that the final price of the wine reflect the tax reduction.
Martin Tsai, chairman of the Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp., said recently that if the amendment were passed, the retail price of the company's rice cooking wine would drop.

If the company adheres to its promise following the amendment's passage, the price of 20-proof rice cooking wine will drop from NT$48 per bottle to NT$40 per bottle, while that of a 40-proof bottle of rice cooking wine will decrease from NT$64 to NT$56, and that of an 80-proof bottle from NT$90 to NT$82.

DOC.HEADLINE: IDU lauds Taiwan's presidential election as example for Asia

TEXT.P: The International Democrat Union (IDU) expressed high hopes for the stability of the Asia-Pacific region and better relations across the Taiwan Strait with President-elect Ma Ying-jeou soon to take office, according to a statement approved by the IDU's Executive Committee Monday.

The IDU Executive Committee, meeting in Sydney with 50 participants from 27 countries, unanimously approved the statement drafted by the IDU Secretariat to congratulate the Kuomintang's (KMT's) Ma on his victory in the March 22 presidential election.
Describing the election as the second peaceful and democratic transition of power in Taiwan, the statement was hopeful that it would serve as an example for the Asia-Pacific region as a whole.
"The KMT victory is a positive for the stability of the Asia-Pacific region, and is a fresh opportunity to develop relations with Mainland China," the statement added.

IDU representatives, together with a delegation from the international Young Democrat Union, were the first international representatives to meet President- elect Ma after his election victory was known.

Former Australian Prime Minister John Howard currently serves as the chairman of the IDU. Lin Cheng-chi, a former deputy chairwoman of the KMT, which joined the organization in 1992, is the only female among the 12 vice chairmen of the international body.

The IDU is an international grouping of conservative, nationalist, classical liberal, and anti-Communist political parties. It was founded in 1983 by former Prime Minister of the Untied Kingdom Margaret Thatcher, then Vice President of the United States George H.W. Bush, Chancellor of Germany Helmut Kohl and then mayor of Paris Jacques Chirac.

The international organization, which has over 80 member parties from over 60 countries, provides a forum in which political parties holding similar beliefs can come together and exchange views on matters of policy and organizational interest, to present a unified voice toward the promotion of center-right policies across the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA imposes inspection of Chinese toys after U.S. recalls

TEXT.P: Following U.S. authorities' recent recall of children's fake teeth and push toys imported from China, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has launched a six-month inspection campaign to check if any of the recalled products are being sold in Taiwan.

The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission announced two separate voluntary recalls on April 10 and April 16 of 26,000 packs of fake teeth and 9,000 push toys imported by two American retailers, FUNTASTIC, and Santa Toy Corp., respectively.
The commission found that the surface paint on the products contained excessive levels of lead, violating the U.S. federal lead paint standard.
The "Hillbilly teeth" feature teeth painted yellow unevenly spaced across brown- painted gums.
The push toy is a plastic horse with a rider and a 20-inch long pole/handle. The rider is wearing red pants and a green shirt, while the horse comes in various colors.

While there have been no reports to date of illness among children playing with these toys, the commission urged U.S. consumers to immediately take these toys away from children and return them to retailers for a refund.

The Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection under the MOEA said it had no knowledge of any of the recalled products being imported into Taiwan but said it has launched a series of measures, including a six-month import inspection and monitoring program that began April 17, to ensure Taiwan is free from these potentially threatening products.
"If the same products were found in local market, the bureau will inspect them to determine if they violate local lead paint standards," an bureau official said.

To help track down the toys, the bureau issued a description of the suspected goods and encouraged local consumers to report to the bureau if they have purchased the toys, according to a MOEA press release.
Locally sold toys have long been subject to inspections for safety reasons and are banned from the domestic market if found to be substandard, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect's plan to impose energy tax is campaign platform

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's announcement of imposing an energy tax was a plank of his campaign platform and is nothing new, Ma's spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said Tuesday.
Lo also said, however, that the substantive measures will have to be worked out by related government agencies after Ma's inauguration May 20.

Ma announced Monday that he would impose an energy tax, with the revenues being channeled into the development of renewable energy. He also promised to promote greater energy efficiency, and formulate measures to cut greenhouse gas emissions, at an event held to mark Earth Day, which falls on April 22.
Lo welcomed opinions on the energy tax policy from all corners of society and said they would be taken into consideration in crafting the measure.

On Economic Affairs Minister-designate Yiin Chii-ming's remarks that he will hike gasoline prices in one step after assuming his post May 20, Lo said such an approach was that of a responsible administration.
But he also said the incoming administration will consider subsidies for low- income and undperpriviledged groups to help them absorb the burden of higher gasoline prices.

Despite the soaring price of crude oil on world markets, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party administration has imposed a freeze on gasoline prices since last November in a bid to keep a lid on inflationary pressures caused by rising commodity prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Encouraging youth online to commit suicide now subject to fine

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Children and Juveniles Welfare Law Tuesday to make forcing, encouraging, inducing or accommodating suicidal behavior among youths via the Internet subject to a fine of up to NT$300,000 (US$9,900).
Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the Kuomintang, who proposed the amendment, said that the number of online suicide pact cases among young people has been growing in Taiwan in recent years.
He said that some people have been using online chat rooms and other discussion forums to try to seek out vulnerable youth to tempt them into committing suicide.
To counter this trend, Lai said he came up with the amendment to clearly define in law that any actions aimed at luring young people into killing themselves is punishable.
Under the amendment, anyone found guilty of this behavior will also have their name made public.

The Legislative Yuan passed another amendment to an article of the Children and Juveniles Welfare Law the same day raising the fine for abandoning or abusing children or adolescents or using or tricking them into engaging in activities that are harmful to their health.
The fine was increased from NT$60,000 to NT$300,000, and those found guilty will have their name made public.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA vows to maintain diplomatic ties with Paraguay after poll

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that it will endeavor to maintain diplomatic relations with Paraguay despite Sunday's election victory by a presidential candidate known to favor establishing ties with China.

MOFA spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said the agency has congratulated Paraguay's newly elected president Fernando Lugo and that there is no change to the diplomatic relations or bilateral cooperative projects between Paraguay and Taiwan.
Lugo, a former Roman Catholic bishop, won a historic victory in Paraguay's presidential election, ending more than six decades of rule by the center-right Colorado Party.

Dubbed the "bishop of the poor, " the 56-year-old Lugo vowed to improve the economy of the poor South American nation and clean up practices that have given Paraguay the reputation as being a corrupt country and a safe haven for smuggling.
Lugo resigned the post of bishop in December 2006 to sidestep Paraguay's constitutional ban on clergy seeking office.
Lugo said during his campaign that he would like to establish relations with China if elected, giving rise to speculation that Taiwan might lose its only diplomatic ally in South America to China.

"There are different opinions on Paraguay's diplomatic relations to other countries, and, rather than being decided by the president alone, it is an issue to be carefully discussed within the nation itself," Yeh noted.
Yeh said Lugo, in an interview with the Central News Agency before the election, stressed that he understands that Taiwan and Paraguay have a long-lasting and good relationship.
Taiwan's Ambassador to Paraguay David Hu also paid a visit to Lugo before the election and exchanged views on bilateral relations, she added.
Yeh said the MOFA will maintain close contact with Lugo and make plans on sending a delegation to his inauguration ceremony Aug. 15.
It is uncertain whether or not President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who is to take office May 20, will attend the inauguration ceremony.
Paraguay and Taiwan forged diplomatic relations in 1957.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Book Day marked around Taiwan

TEXT.P: National Central University (NCU) began a series of activities Tuesday to mark World Book and Copyright Day, launched by the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) to encourage reading and held every April 23.
The NCU opened an eight-day book exhibition in the lobby of its library Tuesday to mark the day, with more than 100 books on display that focused on the concept of life education.

The university is also encouraging people to donate books for children living in remote and poor areas, and will present a lecture by professor Daisy Hung, founder of the university's Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, on the "relations between the brain and reading" on May 6.
The school will also hold a movie festival on its campus themed around life education, including award-winning and popular movies such as Children of Heaven, Marvin's Room and Good Will Hunting.

Chen Su-lan, a section chief of the university's library, noted that with the popularity of the Internet, the reading population is shrinking worldwide. But the librarian hoped that the activities organized by the university would plant the seeds of reading around the island.

Meanwhile, many elementary schools around the country are also encouraging students to donate books for children from underprivileged families or who live in remote areas to encourage more young people to read.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened low and closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 46.07 points, or 0.5 percent, to close at 9,037.25.

The local bourse opened at 9,067.9 and fluctuated between 9,081.29 and 8,997.02 during the day's session. A total of 5.24 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$137.68 billion (US$4.54 billion).
Only construction and foodstuff issues of the eight major stock categories gained ground, both moving up at 0.6 percent, while paper and pulp shares remained unchanged.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with textile and cement stocks both dropping 1.7 percent, plastics and chemical shares falling 1.2 percent, machinery and electronics stocks sliding 0.4 percent, and banking and financial shares decreasing 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,322 to 967, with 346 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved down 54 points to close at 9,030, with 49,134 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June lost 53 points to finish at 8,998, with 228 contracts traded, while September futures dropped 62 points to close at 8,742, with 98 contract transactions.
December futures decreased 63 points to finish at 8,702, with 75 contract transactions, while March futures moved down 66 points to close at 8,667, with one contract traded.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index slid 46.07 points Tuesday to finish at 9,037.25, with a market turnover of NT$137.68 billion (US$4.54 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 9,084 for May; 9,051 for June; 8,804 for September; 8,765 for December and 8,733 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both dropped.
May TE futures dropped 1.7 points to close at 341.5, with 4,602 contracts traded, while June TE futures lost 1.65 points to finish at 340.5, with 20 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved down one point to close at 337, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for December and March.
May TF futures dropped seven points to close at 1,207, with 4,807 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures decreased 5.6 points to finish at 1,205.6, with 24 contracts traded.
September TF futures lost 1.8 points to close at 1,190, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar remains unchanged on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar remained unchanged against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, closing at NT$30.288.
A total of US$829 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.340 and fluctuated between NT$30.235 and NT$30.360.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung magistrate wary of Chinese speculating in housing market

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing said Tuesday that he is open to the idea of Chinese investment in Taiwan, including in his county, but voiced objections to any plans for Chinese investors to speculate in the housing market.

Yang made the remarks to reporters while answering questions related to a four- day visit by a group of Chinese real estate moguls who arrived a day earlier in Taiwan to study the country's investment climate and business opportunities in the local tourism resort and real estate sectors.
Yang said he has accepted an invitation from the Fokuangshan Temple to attend a welcome party for the Chinese group, which is slated to visit the Kaohsiung County-based temple Thursday.
Reiterating that he welcomes Chinese investment in Taiwan, Yang, however, made it clear that he is firmly opposed to any speculating in the domestic housing market by Chinese investors.
Yang is a senior member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which lost the March 22 presidential election to the Kuomintang (KMT).
President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who will assume the presidency on May 20, has vowed to build closer trade and economic ties with China and to open Taiwan to Chinese investment.

Vice President-elect Vincent Siew also has advocated establishing a cross-Taiwan Strait common market and helping Taiwanese farmers, mostly in central and southern regions, sell their produce to China.

Yang said he is particularly keen on attracting Chinese investment in tourism- related businesses, such as hotels and resort facilities which are capable of creating more job opportunities than hi-tech businesses.

According to Yang, the county could use Chinese capital for a project to build a resort on a 240-hectare artificial land in Yungan township. The Kaohsiung County magistrate said the Chinese group is welcome to conduct an on-the-spot inspection.
Yang said last week that the Kaohsiung County government is currently seeking private investment to jointly develop the island into a resort, adding that Chinese capital is also welcome.
However, he expressed concerns that some Chinese property investors might enter the Taiwanese market merely to speculate.

Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan has long been a stronghold of the pro- independence DPP. The DPP presidential ticket won more votes than the KMT's Ma- Siew ticket in the southern Taiwan county in the March 22 presidential election, despite the KMT's big gains in most of the other constituencies.

Meanwhile, the Chinese real estate developer group attended an investment seminar hosted Tuesday by Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun after touring Cihu -- the site of late President Chiang Kai-shek's tomb in the county in northern Taiwan.

Clarifying rampant allegations that the group's visit might drive up Taiwan's private house prices, Liu Changle, chairman of the Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite Television Co. who led the delegation, said that the aim of the group's visit is to explore Taiwan's urban development.
"The group has set its sights on tourism-related facilities in Taiwan, rather than on general residential properties, " Liu explained.

At a news conference held earlier the same day at the Legislative Yuan, members of the DPP's legislative caucus warned that an influx of Chinese capital into Taiwan's housing market might further diverge Taiwan's economic development into an increasingly M-shaped society.
DPP lawmaker Wong Chin-chu called it a futile attempt to pin the hopes of boosting Taiwan's urban development on Chinese real estate businessmen.
"Such an approach only would benefit construction companies and would put Taiwan's people at a great disadvantage," she said.
DPP lawmaker Pan Meng-an cautioned the incoming KMT government against deteriorating public order if Taiwan is opened to Chinese tourists rashly without the introduction of complementary measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: University faculty cuts one meal to mark Earth Day

TEXT.P: As Taiwan marks Earth Day Tuesday with a variety of activities to conserve energy and cut greenhouse gas emission, National Kaohsiung Normal University took an unusual approach -- the school's faculty skipped one meal.

University President Tai Chia-nan, and school professors and students converged in front of the student activity center shortly before noon. Dressed in blue to mark Earth Day, they declared that they would skip lunch.
School faculty noted that cutting a meal will allow the human body the opportunity to digest properly and recover.

Greenhouse gas emitted during the stages of food planting, raising, transportation, storage, manufacturing as well as distribution will also be cut as a result of people eating one fewer meal, faculty members said.

According to a study by the school, preparing a lunchbox in Taiwan results in the emission of half a kilogram of carbon dioxide. If 200 members of the faculty skip lunch, it will help save 100 kg of dioxide emission.
Tai also urged the faculty to encourage others to join the "cut meal, cut noise and cut carbon dioxide emission" campaign.

The school stressed that "noise cut" will also allow people to live in a quiet and tranquil environment, which it said will not only help conserve electricity, but will allow the public to learn the benefits of living a simple and quiet life.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ushers in 'carbon reduction era'

TEXT.P: Taiwan staged an islandwide campaign Tuesday to reduce carbon emissions, in an Earth Day event led by president-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who pledged to introduce a policy to save energy and reduce carbon emissions.
Ma said on Monday that when he takes office he will enact a Greenhouse Gas Reduction Act and impose an energy tax that would be used to fund renewable energy research.

EPA Minister-designate Shen Shih-hung said Tuesday that the proposed energy tax is one of Ma's most important policies, and that the new administration will implement it step by step to minimize the economic impact.

In response, Winston Dang, the incumbent EPA minister, said that an energy tax and regulations related to renewable energy can only be implemented after the enactment of the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Act, which is under review in the Legislative Yuan.

Dang, who has less than a month left in office, has been very vocal in his efforts to raise awareness of the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. He had asked that government officials turn off office lights from noon to 1 p.m., to go to office on foot and eat vegetarian meals made with local ingredients, in observance of Earth Day.

"Sustainability is a simple notion -- to leave behind clean water and pure air for future generations, " said Dang at a press conference. Small actions taken now in daily life can be fruitful later on, he added.
People in Taiwan especially should make an effort, as Taiwan, with 0.35 percent of the world's population, produces almost 1 percent of the world's carbon dioxide emissions, he said.
In response to Dang's call, Shieh Jhy-wey, minister of the Government Information Office (GIO), walked to work Tuesday morning, saying that he was reminded of his school days.
"We can put this one-day effort into regular practice, " said Shieh, in response to a question on whether people can really help save the Earth by walking to work only on Earth Day.
To help make it easier for people to choose vegetarian meals on Earth Day, the GIO cafeteria offered a mostly vegetarian menu, which was generally met with approval by the GIO staff.
"In fact, a vegetarian meal is not enough for a man -- I will be hungry soon. But I am glad to be a part of the movement, " a GIO official said.
Several workshops were also held all day Tuesday under the theme, "The first year of the carbon reduction era."

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu delegation attends int'l rice noodle forum in China

TEXT.P: An association of Hsinchu City rice-noodle businesses held a news conference Tuesday to announce the results of a recent international rice-noodle forum held in Guangxi Province, China.
The forum was held in the county of Xingan in Guilin City in the southern Chinese province from April 17-21.

The representatives of the association said they discussed with other participants in the forum the differences in rice noodle cuisine and uses in various regions and learned from one another's experiences in the rice-noodle business.

At the news conference, members of the Hsinchu delegation to the forum presented Hsinchu Mayor Lin Jung-tzer with an invitation from Xingan County head Wang Jianyi to attend Guilin's rice-noodle festival to be held from April 28 to May 2.

Lin said he was moved to receive the invitation which was written in traditional Chinese characters used in Taiwan, noting that Hsinchu City and Xingan County have atraditional rice-noodle culture in common.
Others attending the forum in Xingan included experts from Germany and England as well as scholars from other parts of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA silent about whether FTA talks with Singapore have resumed

TEXT.P: Amid speculation that talks to ink a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and Singapore might restart soon, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday refused to comment on whether there is any progress in resuming negotiations on this sensitive issue.

When asked to comment on reports that Singapore and Taiwan will reopen discussions of an FTA soon, Weber Shih, director-general of the MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs told a regular press briefing that to strengthen co-operations, especially in the economic realm, with member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) has always been one of the main tasks of the government.
"The Free Trade Agreement (FTA) is of course among our major tasks. However, we cannot give details on any particular case, " Shih said.

Reports said prospects seemed to have brightened that the Southeast Asian city- state might be more willing to negotiate with Taiwan on a free trade deal after the Kuomintang, which favors closer trade ties with China and easing cross- strait tensions, won a decisive victory in the March 22 presidential election in Taiwan.

In his meeting with international media after his election victory, President- elect Ma Ying-jeou said he would push to revive talks for an FTA with Singapore, based on the "WTO formula, " meaning using Taiwan's name in the World Trade Organization - "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu".

This name was used by the island to join the World Trade Organization in 2002, as China, which considers Taiwan part of its territory, objects to Taiwan joining international organizations as a nation.
Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement recently that "FTAs with customs territories such as Taiwan are permissible under WTO rules, " according to a report by the China Post.
The city-state, however, set up preconditions to an FTA deal, such as that issues involving trade should not be politicized.
Shih said he believed that building up a full-scale economic trade partnership with countries in the Southeast Asian region will be the priority of the incoming government.

According to an unofficial account, the free trade discussions between Taiwan and Singapore, which started in 2000, stagnated after the outgoing President Chen Shui-bian's government insisted on signing the FTA using the name "Taiwan" or its official title the "Republic of China".
So far, Taiwan has no FTA with any leading trade nations due to such political obstacles.

DOC.HEADLINE: Five local governments commended for reducing carbon emissions

TEXT.P: As part of the activities to mark Earth Day Tuesday, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) commended five local governments for their achievements in carbon emission reduction.
The five areas named were Taipei City, Taipei County, Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan, and Tainan City and Kaohsiung City in the south.

"While people can refuse to eat polluted food or drink contaminated water, they cannot refuse to breathe polluted air and cannot escape the impact of global warming, " said EPA Minister Winston Dang at the award ceremony. He encouraged local governments to play a more active role in protecting the health of their residents.
Taipei city was commended for its diverse efforts to reduce carbon emissions.

For example, the city reduced its volume of garbage from 1,600,000 tons in 1998 to about 600,000 tons in 2006. Also, the city hall building is recycling rain water to flush its toilets, and the city was the first local government to adopt hybrid cars for official use, according to the EPA.

Apart for the five local governments that received commendations, Miaoli County in northern Taiwan, Tainan County in the south and Hualien County in the eastern part of the island were also cited by the EPA as setting good examples.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lights out event saves 28,800 kwh of electricity in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A total of 28,800 kilowatt-hours (kwh) of electricity was saved in a one-hour lights out event held from noon Tuesday in Taiwan to mark Earth Day, officials at the state-owned Taiwan Power Company said.

The amount conserved has in effect reduced carbon dioxide emissions by 18,374 kilograms and represents a great improvement compared with the 17,500 kwh that was saved in a similar activity held last year, the officials said.
The activity was mainly held among government agencies and public schools, while the private sector was encouraged to follow suit.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tien Chiu-chin, the initiator of the campaign, said the lights out event was intended simply as a demonstration and that it is more important for people to make energy conservation a habit in their daily life in order to save the Earth.

According to the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, turning off for one hour a fluorescent lighting fixture with four 20-watt lamps, as commonly seen in offices, can save 0.08 kwh of electricity and decrease carbon dioxide emissions by 53 grams.

As 26 percent of the total of 4.7 billion kwh of electricity consumed by government agencies every year are used on lighting, it can save 500,000 kwh of electricity if all these agencies have their lights turned off for one hour, the bureau said in a statement.

The amount of electricity conserved will increase to 1.88 million kwh if the commercial sector joins the action and further to 5.09 million kwh if all households around the country also take part, the bureau said.
As part of the government's energy conservation efforts, the public is also encouraged to replace traditional lighting with high-performance, energy- efficient ones, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Renowned Israeli actress, director invited to Taipei Film Festival

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taipei Film Festival will be graced with the presence of leading Israeli actress Gila Almagor and Israeli heavyweight documentary filmmaker Ron Havilio, organizers of the event disclosed Tuesday.

The annual festival, now in its 10th year, will take place June 20-July 6, screening some 200 films in four categories. The event is sponsored by the Taipei city government and organized by the Taipei Cultural Foundation.
The organizers said they will hold a special film exhibition and seminar during the festival for Almagor and Havilio, while Havilio will also put a selection of his photographic works on display.

Almagor has starred in some 40 movies and numerous TV programs. She has also hosted her own radio show for many years and is involved in voluntary work with children suffering from cancer. A winner of the Israel Prize for lifetime contribution to the culture of Israel in 2004, she is acclaimed as a symbol of Israeli culture.

Havilio is an award-winning documentary filmmaker. His "Fragments Jerusalem," a six-hour documentary, personal diary and family saga interwoven with the history of Jerusalem, captured the Grand Prize in the Yamagata International Documentary Film Festival of Japan in 1997. He now teaches art history, photography and film at the Jerusalem Film and Television School and at the Jerusalem Cinematheque.

The 2008 Taipei Film Festival offers 22 awards in four categories: the New Talent Competition; the Golden Lion International Student Film Competition; the Taipei Award; and the Taipei Image Award, with cash prizes ranging from NT$1 million (US$33,020) to NT$30,000, plus trophies.
The entries include feature films longer than 70 minutes and documentaries, animated shorts, experimental and independent films limited to 10 minutes in length.
The entries from around the world will be screened by a panel of judges at several venues in Taipei City and Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: PC manufacturers, distributors promote recycling

TEXT.P: To mark Earth Day, manufacturers and distributors of information technology (IT) products launched a campaign Tuesday aimed at saving energy resources and recycling and reusing computers.

The event was organized jointly by Taiwan ASUSTek Computer Inc. (ASUS), the global chipmaker giant Intel's Taiwan office (Intel), and Tsann Kuen Enterprise Co., Ltd. (TK), which has some 250 electronic appliance outlets around Taiwan.

Under the program that will start May 1, the public will be able to recycle PCs and laptops at TK shops in exchange for coupons worth NT$2,000 (US$65) each, which in turn could be used to purchase environmentally friendly products supplied by ASUS and Intel. TK will clean up and fix the used computers and then donate them to rural schools or underprivileged children.
"The cooperation among ASUS, Intel and TK in recycling and reusing products indeed shows our appreciation for the earth," Johnny Shih, chairman of ASUS, said at a launch ceremony.

Noting that ASUS is dedicated to environmental protection through its manufacture of energy-saving products, Shih promised that the company "will continue its efforts to give something back to the society and to humanity, which is also a core value of ASUS."

"We (at ASUS) will commit to environmental protection by using 'green' designs and 'green' methods of procurement, manufacture, and marketing," Shih said, adding that he hopes "the Earth will be better tomorrow with our efforts."

Jason Chen, country manager of Intel, said the company has being using recycled energy and water resources in manufacturing." He pledged that "for our Earth, we will make our products more energy efficient and our operations more productive."
"Giving recycled computers to schools in remote areas will allow the students to have better access to information and narrow the 'digital gap' between urban and rural communities," Chen added.
Jerry Yen, TK's general manager, said it is also crucial to "buy environmentally friendly products and to recycle and reuse materials."
Yen commended the campaign as helping to save energy and enhancing education among underprivileged students, and he encouraged the wider public to join the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Octogenarian to be commended for sponsoring poor Sri Lankan kids

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Fund for Children and Families will commend an octogenarian in a ceremony to be held in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan on Sunday for his long-term financial support of impoverished children in Sri Lanka.

Fund officials said Tuesday that Weng Hsin-mao, 83, who lives in Taichung, central Taiwan, has sponsored two Sri Lankan children for 20 years, paying around NT$10,000 (US$330) annually for their living expenses.

Weng began sending money to the children after he became deeply touched in 1988 upon learning that the South Asian country donated corneas to Taiwan to help more than 1,000 people regain their eyesight.
Weng wanted to do something in return and asked the fund to arrange for him to join its sponsorship program, the officials said.
They said that in addition to two Sri Lankan children, Weng has also sponsored three impoverished children living in India and Vietnam.
"As long as I'm alive, I will not stop the sponsoring, "Weng said, adding that good deeds help others and make him happy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Miaoli county chief promotes milk after false alarm

TEXT.P: Miaoli County Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung drank and gave away milk at the county hall Tuesday to help restore consumer confidence in the products of a local dairy plant that was accused of selling tainted milk.

Liu bought 161 bottles of fresh milk and 48 boxes of sterilized milk from the plant in the northern county one day after the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced that the plant's products had passed drug residue tests.

According to a report published April 16 by the Chinese-language Apple Daily, one of the plant's suppliers in the southern county of Yunlin had been purchasing milk from diseased cows at low prices from neighboring dairy farms.
The allegedly tainted milk was sold under two fresh milk brands -- Highland and General Milk -- that are both marketed by leading food manufacturer, AGV Products Corp.
The news report prompted AGV to recall the two brands of milk.
Despite the release of the COA test results, the plant said, the false alarm dealt it a huge blow because all its orders were canceled after the newspaper report.
The plant said that having received no orders, it now faces the problem of how to pay its 110 employees.
The plant also stated Monday that the credibility of both General Milk and AGV Products had been "irreparably damaged."
General Milk said the market for all dairy products on the island were hit hard by Apple Daily's report last week, with sales falling by 30 to 40 percent.
The company indicated that, along with AGV, it had borne the brunt of the problem, losing an estimated NT$10 million (US$330,250) daily since the report was published.
General Milk said it reserved the right to file suit against the Apple Daily and would also devise measures to regain the trust of consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Campaign to encourage balanced diet for children launched

TEXT.P: Health activists launched a campaign Tuesday to promote a balanced diet for elementary school children, encouraging the daily consumption of adequate amounts of fruit and vegetables.

The campaign was organized by the Formosa Cancer Foundation (FCF) and the Ministry of Education (MOE) with the sponsorship of Yuanta Foundation, the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei Office, 13 U.S. agricultural producer associations and the Wellcome Taiwan Company, Ltd.

According to a recent survey conducted online by the FCF, 54 percent of the 5,172 respondents aged under 12 had inaccurate knowledge about the "5-a-day" concept of fruit and vegetable consumption, which is the theme of the campaign.

Referring to the "5-a-day" idea that everyone should eat at least three portions of vegetables and two of fruit per day, Lai Gi-ming, executive chief officer of the FCF, said that "even though more than 50 percent of the students have heard about `5-a-day,' there is still room for us to make more effort" to increase awareness.

Admitting at the ceremony that he himself is not particularly fond of certain fruits and vegetables, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng who is also chairman of the FCF, said that "through this campaign, I hope we can find solutions that will help persuade both adults and children to eat more fruit and vegetables."
"A balanced diet not only makes school children healthier but also helps prevent cancer," Wang said.
The survey results also indicate that although 99 percent of the students polled understand the advantages of eating sufficient fruit and vegetables, only 60 percent are in the habit of doing so.

Attributing the unwillingness to eat fruit and vegetables to parents who do not prepare enough fruit and vegetables at home, Fuh Wei-wei, a section chief at the MOE, said that "the public, parents and teachers must pay more attention to children's nutrition."
Fuh further promised that "the MOE will suggest that elementary schools throughout Taiwan be aware of balanced diet when preparing lunches for school children."

Commending the partnership with the FCF as a "truly win-win situation" not only for children's health but also for the U.S. agricultural producers involved in the project, AIT spokesman Thomas Hodges said that "a healthy diet that includes at least five full servings of fruit and vegetables is a widely recognized and easy-to-implement way to maintain health and prevent disease."

"In 2008, the Agricultural Trade Office under the AIT and its agricultural producer associations will provide funding to develop and print new interactive nutrition education materials that will be distributed to over 50,000 school children and their families around Taiwan," Hodges said.

In support of the campaign, Piano Chia, group marketing manager of the Wellcome chain, which operates some 200 supermarkets around Taiwan, also announced special discounts for school children who purchase fruit or vegetables from its outlets.

"By offering coupons that enable children and their parents to enjoy savings on fruit and vegetables at Wellcome, I hope everyone will take part in this meaningful activity for better health, " Chai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County magistrate may visit China in May

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei said Tuesday that the county plans to open offices in China to lure Chinese investment and that he may visit Beijing in May or June to explore such possibilities.

Chou made the remarks while answering reporters' questions regarding an ongoing four-day visit by a group of nine Chinese real estate moguls who arrived in Taipei Monday to study Taiwan's investment climate and business opportunities.
The Taipei county magistrate met the Chinese visitors Monday evening.

According to Chou, he is considering attending an architectural seminar in Beijing in May or an international travel fair to be held in the Chinese capital in June, to gain access to Chinese entrepreneurs and exchange views with them on investing in Taipei County and on opening offices in China.

The county government has rented a big booth in Beijing's upcoming international travel fair to try to promote the northern Taiwan county to the Chinese public and woo potential tourists to the county.
Chou did not say where in China the county will open its representative offices.

Turning to the visiting group of Chinese real estate moguls, Chou said they came to Taiwan in search of fresh investment opportunities outside China, where investment environments have undergone noticeable changes in recent years.
The group's visit has sparked a high degree of attention in Taiwan after the Kuomintang's Ma Ying-jeou won the March 22 presidential election.

Ma, who will assume the presidency on May 20, favors wider trade and economic exchanges between Taiwan and China after eight years of the rule by the pro- independence Democratic Progressive Party, which has been passive in exploring business opportunities with China.
Ma has promised to allow Chinese investment as well as more Chinese tourists in Taiwan as a way to boost the island's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City advocates planting trees to mark Earth Day

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin and municipal education department chief Wu Ching-chi planted a "tree of hope" and signed a carbon dioxide emission reduction pledge Tuesday at a primary school in the city to mark Earth Day.

Stressing that concrete action must be taken to save the Earth from the destructive effects of escalating global warming, Hau encouraged Gongkuan Elementary School children to plant more trees to protect the Earth, all animals and the human race.

Wu expressed the hope that each of the city's 287 elementary schools would plant at least one arbor on its campus. These trees are expected to generate more than 140 tons of oxygen for the Earth over some 40 years, he explained.

Over the past year, schools of all levels in Taipei City saved as much as NT$50 million (US$1.65 million) in electricity fees, Wu said, adding that more can be done made to save the Earth through collective effort, and that everyone must do their share to achieve the objective.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yulin succeeds in promoting agricultural products in Macau

TEXT.P: The Yunlin County Government recently succeeded in gaining access to the Macau market for the central county's agricultural goods, county chief Su Chih-fen said Tuesday.

A group of 40 farmers and farmers' representatives of Yunlin, led by the county's Director of Agriculture Lu Chen-chang, visited the special administrative region of China April 17-20 to promote and sell their products.
At a press conference at the county office, Su lauded the attempt to expand the overseas markets for locally grown products, including rice, fruits and vegetables, pork, chicken and goose.
During its visit to Macau, the delegation organized a trade fair, at which the three cargo containers of agricultural products it took there were sold out.
The promotion effort generated an income of NT$9 million (US$297,200), Su said.
Following the success of that venture, Su said, the county government has plans to access other Chinese and regional markets based on the "Macau model."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung promotes Chinese investment in the city's motel industry

TEXT.P: Taichung Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi touted the motel industry in the central Taiwanese city Tuesday during a meeting with nine visiting Chinese real estate developers.
The high-profile group traveled from Taipei in northern Taiwan earlier in the day to Taichung to continue their four-day "fact-finding" trip in Taiwan which began Monday.

The Chinese entrepreneurs' arrival triggered attention from the local media, with some calling them "persons of great wealth" as each of the real estate tycoons is said to hold multibillion NT dollars in wealth, and is poised to invest in Taiwan as soon as President-elect Ma Ying-jeou takes office on May 20.
At the city hall, Hsiao told reporters that the property developers want to know the market for premium motels and high-quality residential buildings in the city.
In Taichung, Hsiao said, the motel industry is a "unique, quality emerging business, " with many "six-star" and "seven-star" motels.

"The living environment offered by those motels cast a shadow on many international hotels, " Hsiao said, noting that the city government's office has arranged for the Chinese guests to visit different motels to experience different lodging services during their one-day stay in Taichung.

Taiwan currently allows investment by Chinese nationals in the local property market, but the barriers, including security checks, proof of the source of funding, and strict limits on borrowing, have discouraged potential investors.

As a result, fewer than a handful of Chinese have successfully bought property here, but that may change under Ma, who pledged to open up investment in the local real estate market to Chinese developers as a way to boost the local economy.

Hsiao said he expects Taichung will have a bright future in economic and trade development because after direct air links between Taiwan and China are set up, as Ma has also pledged to do, Taichung's Chingchuankang airport is expected to become one of the key ports of entry for Chinese visitors.

The visiting Chinese business tycoons, headed by Lin Changle, chairman of the Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite Television Co. who also operates the Beijing- based Zhong Chen Le Tian Real Estate Development Co. Ltd., arrived in Taiwan Monday.

Group members include Li Silian, chairman of Guangzhou-based R&F Properties; Zeng Wei, chairman of Beijing-based Palm Springs Holdings Co.; Hu Baosen, chairman of Henan-based Jianye Group; Feng Lun, chairman of the Beijing-based Vantone Real Estate; Chen Zhuolin, chairman of the Agile Property Holdings Limited; and Pan Shiyi, chairman of SOHO China Ltd.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Keelung Fairy Tale Art Festival to culminate with parade

TEXT.P: The month-long 2008 Keelung Fairy Tale Art Festival will culminate April 26 with an Ocean Dream Carnival Parade before coming to an end the following day.
Organizers said 60 teams with a total of more than 5,000 people will participate in the 1.8 km parade through the city of Keelung between 2 p.m. and 5 p.m.

There will be a variety of floats featuring different motifs, such as marine life, Aladdin -- hero of one of the best-known stories in The Thousand and One Nights -- and Cinderella's Pumpkin Carriage.
The floats will lead more than 2,000 children dressed like fairy tale characters, as well as teams of Samba dancers.

The Keelung Fairy Tale Art Festival is organized by the Keelung city government and the Yangming Marine Transport Corp. Cultural Foundation, with the assistance of 23 of the city's government agencies and civic organizations.

Over the past month, the event has presented a wide range of art activities for parents and children at the Yangming Oceanic Culture and Art Museum, including games, garden parties, story telling sessions, dancing and painting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's negative real wage growth overshadows rising labor capacity

TEXT.P: Taiwan's real wage growth from January to February recorded its worst level since 1981, with negative growth of 1.52 percent that overshadowed the rise in regular wages during the same period, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Tuesday.

In tune with the monthly unemployment rate of 3.86 percent in March -- the lowest in eight years -- the employed population recorded 1.28 percent growth year-on-year to reach a monthly average of 10.37 million during the first three months of 2008, indicating a growing labor market, said Huang Jiann-jong, deputy director of the Bureau of Census under the DGBAS.
The unemployment rate in this year's first three months marked 3.87 percent, Huang added.

The overall regular wage, which is calculated one month behind the employment statistics, also showed steady growth, marking an eight-year high at 1.84 percent year-on-year in the first two months of 2008.

But the global inflation affected the local consumer price index (CPI), causing it to grow 3.41 percent during the same period, which undermined the real wage growth to minus 1.52 percent, the worst level in 27 years, said Huang.
"The rising pace of regular wages has been relatively slow compared to that of consumer prices," Huang went on.
He cited the low profitability of local companies and part-time employment as the major factors of the gradual increase, a result of fiercer competition in the increasingly globalized economy.

Touching on the country's overall economy, Huang said the domestic labor market remained healthy, as the structure of the employment market has not changed despite the ongoing problem of an increasing unemployed population of people with tertiary education, which jumped to 282,000 in 2007 from 89,000 in 1997.

"The high salary demands of these young people has led them to accept only either voluntary or short-term unemployment, " said Huang, noting this so-called "frictional unemployment" affects the local economy very little.
The March unemployment rate for college graduates stood at 3.88 percent, just 0.02 percent higher than the overall rate of 3.86 percent, according to the DGBAS.

"Compared with unemployment rates in other Asian countries like Japan and Hong Kong, which stood at 3.9 percent and 3.4 percent, respectively, the rate in Taiwan is nothing out of ordinary," he went on.
Scholars are more concerned by both the slow pace of salary growth and unemployment among college graduates, as global inflation continues to eat away at the lukewarm economic rise.

"The small wage growth indicates a slow-growing local economy, in which the capacity and profitability of local industries are not performing at their best, " said Lee-rong Wang, director of the Center for Economic Forecasting under the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research.

To cope with the import inflation caused by the skyrocketing commodity prices around the world, Wang said a prosperous local economy, or micro-economy, could help increase the nominal wage standard to compensate for the effects of the international situation.

Individuals also need to play a part to boost earnings, she added, saying that college students should upgrade their employability by developing skills that are unique compared to those of their peers.

"Taiwan's economic outlook -- and accordingly the wage standard -- in recent years have not been as good as those of neighboring countries, which has driven many of our high-quality employees to seek work overseas," she added.
Another way to tackle the low earnings, Wang suggested, would be to increase wages in the government sector.
"Labor history in Taiwan tells us that every time the government gets a raise, the private sector follows, as a result of labor market competition," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to hold first International Robot Exhibition in May

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taiwan International Robot Exhibition, the first trade show of its kind to be held in Taiwan, will take place May 1-5 at Hall 1 of the Taipei World Trade Center.

The event, held by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and the Taiwan Association of Machinery Industry, is aimed at trade buyers from the United States, Canada, Mexico, Germany, Italy, France, the United Kingdom, Spain, Sweden, Japan and South Korea.
Twenty-six robotic manufacturing companies will display their latest products, including industrial robots, service robots, robot parts, accessories and peripherals.
The exhibition will be held concurrently with the Taipei Computer Numerical Control Machine Tools and Manufacturing Technology Show.
A forum will be held May 2, with the participation of major producers of robots from around the world, to discuss market prospects for the robotics industry.

TAITRA officials quoted official statistics as saying that the overall value of robots produced by Taiwan in 2007 totaled NT$20 billion (US$ 660.4 million), accounting for 5.56 percent of the world's robotics production.
The officials estimated that by 2012, the total world demand for "smart" robots could have reached between US$80 billion and US$250 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lighting revolution takes place in remote village

TEXT.P: A remote village housing 150 Atayal tribe members in the mountains of Hsinchu County, northern Taiwan, recently started a "lighting revolution" by replacing all the electric lamps in the village with high-performance and energy-saving bulbs, a county official said Tuesday as the world marked Earth Day.

Lin Hsien-sheng, county head of the area, related the story of the village Smangus, known as "the Tribe of God, " during a "one-hour lights off" exercise at the county office. The action was aimed at calling for a public consensus on actions to cut carbon dioxide emissions.

Smangus, situated in Jianshih township, was the last area in Taiwan to be supplied with electricity, Lin said. Up to 1997, the village was called he "tribe of darkness," he said, adding that now, Smangus has become the country's model for energy efficient lighting.
The village is equipped with 874 lamps that have all been changed from incandescent lighting to the use of energy saving bulbs and high-performance LEDs, according to Lin.
Lin said that because of the changeover, electricity consumption in the village is expected to drop by 60 percent a year, which would make Smangus Taiwan's most energy efficient village.
The Atayal is one of 13 major aboriginal tribes in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Energy tax will be imposed gradually: EPA head-designate

TEXT.P: Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) chief-designate Shen Shih-hung said Tuesday that the imposition of an energy tax will be done gradually.
Shen said that in the initial stage, the government will target those who import energy "to avoid too much of an impact, " before also imposing the tax on average consumers.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Monday at an event to promote Earth Day the following day that he will impose the energy tax, with the revenues to be channeled into the development of renewable energy. He also promised to promote greater energy efficiency and to formulate measures to cut greenhouse gas emissions.
Shen noted that Ma spoke of a carbon dioxide tax during his presidential campaign and that the volume of carbon dioxide emissions will be given consideration when imposing the energy tax.

He cited as an example that while imported coal is cheap, it will produce more carbon dioxide than petroleum and natural gas when burnt which will be taken into consideration when the tax levy is determined.

Shen said that a lot of countries in Europe have levied taxes on carbon dioxide emissions and that Taiwan will have to have further discussions about thermal heat, carbon dioxide emissions and related issues before mapping out the complementary measures for imposing energy tax.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect vows to cut taxes

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that he will cut taxes and simplify taxation procedures after he takes office May 20.
Ma said he will ask the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to establish a tax reform committee to review current tax policies to achieve his goal.

Speaking to reporters after a 100-minute meeting with the heads of eight local high-tech companies at the Neihu Technology Park in Taipei, Ma said the new government will also ease the restriction on China-bound investment by Taiwan businesses under which their investment cannot exceed 40 percent of their net assets.
In addition, the new government will encourage overseas Taiwanese businessmen to return to invest in Taiwan and will work to attract more foreign capital to Taiwan, he went on.
Ma said he wants to build Taiwan into a global operations headquarters for Taiwanese companies and an operations hub in the Asia-Pacific region for foreign companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reader's Digest announces list of top brand names in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Chinese-language edition of Reader's Digest monthly announced Tuesday its 2008 list of most trusted brand names in Taiwan, naming 42 local trademarks that won golden awards among 78 brands worldwide, accounting for 53 percent of the total.

The list was based on mail and telephone surveys conducted by the regional office of the magazine in Singapore between October and November 2007 among its readers and other members of the public across Asia. In Taiwan, the magazine received mail responses from 1,890 readers and telephone responses from 500 adults around the island.

According to executives of Reader's Digest, Japanese brand names on a wide variety of products gained long-term popularity among Taiwanese consumers, while Taiwanese manufacturers excelled especially in the food sphere, with Uni-President Group, Kuangchuan and Kimlan Foods. Co. Ltd winning golden awards in the categories of cooking oil, milk, and soy sauce.
Among the various brand names in the information sector, the personal computers (desktop notebook) of Taiwan's Acer Inc. won the trusted brand name award both in Taiwan and across the Asian region.

Reader's Digest also released a list of 15 brand names, selected by consumers in Taiwan, that received platinum awards in their various categories. Among them were seven domestic trademarks and the rest were international brands.

The 15 platinum brand names are EVA Air, Franklin Templeton Investments, Chunghwa Telecom, Nokia, Taiwan's state-run oil company CPC Corporation, Taiwan, Sinyi Real Estate Inc., National Taiwan University, Starbucks, Toyota, HP, Sony, Hitachi, sanitary ware manufacturer Hocheng Corp. (HCG), Taiwan Beer, and CentrumVitamins.
Chai Sung-lin, founder of Taiwan's Consumer's Foundation, said that the award- winning trademarks will not always remain the best unless the manufacturers work hard to please the consumers.
"Only those trademarks that pay attention to the quality of their products and after-sales services will gain the long-term trust of consumers," Chai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two DPP chairmanship candidates vow to stay in race

TEXT.P: Two of the candidates for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairmanship, Trong Chai and Koo Kuan-min, both vowed Tuesday to stay in the race, acting DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh said later that day.

Speaking after meetings with both candidates, Hsieh said they agreed to accept a coordination meeting on election and debate procedures but would not accept coordination aimed at asking either of them to quit the race.
The decisions made by DPP Legislator Chai and Koo, a former adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, mean that a general vote among party members slated for May 18 is now inevitable.
Another candidate, former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen, who is seen as a front- runner, was expected to meet with Hsieh soon after returning from an overseas trip Wednesday.

Tuesday's announcement followed speculation that Chai and Koo would be asked to drop out of the race after Tsai registered for the chairmanship election on the last day of registration, to create an image of party unity.

However, Hsieh was quoted by party sources as saying that while producing the party leader through coordination might prevent an election process in which candidates will harshly criticize one another, anyone who is persuaded to quit the race will feel they have been unfairly treated.
Hsieh said he also believes a general vote will give the new party leader a mandate from the party membership, giving him or her more legitimacy to push for party reforms, the sources went on.

Both Chai and Koo proposed to Hsieh that all candidates should reach a consensus on establishing a chairmanship election model that is free of negative attacks on the other candidates, the sources said.
Chai also suggested that the party organize more debates between the candidates, rather than just the one already scheduled for May 10, according to the sources.
The new party chief will be sworn in May 21.
Hsieh tendered his resignation as chairman after he lost the March 22 presidential poll to his rival, Ma Ying-jeou of opposition Kuomintang (KMT), by a wide margin of more than 2.2 million votes.
