DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 23, or the 18th day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1616: William Shakespeare, English playwright and poet whose body of works is considered by most as the greatest in English literature, dies at New Place at the age of 52.
1616: Miguel de Cervantes, Spanish writer best known for his classic satirical novel "Don Quixote," dies at the age of 69.
1873: The Dutch war against the Sultan of Achin begins in northwest Sumatra, Indonesia.
1895: Russia, Germany and France protest the ceding of Chinese territory to Japan.
1897: Lester Pearson, Canadian prime minister from 1963-1968, is born. He won the 1957 Nobel Peace Prize for his part in settling the Suez crisis.
1919: Peking Teachers High School for Girls is formally established.
1928: Shirley Temple Black, American child star who went on to become the U.S. ambassador to Ghana, is born. As Shirley Temple, she was an immensely popular child actress of the 1930s, starring in films such as "Wee Willie Winkie" and "Bright Eyes."
1935: Joseph Stalin officially opens the Moscow underground rail system.
1945: U.S. and Soviet forces meet at Torgau in eastern Germany.
1946: Hsia Kai-chun, noted writer of modern Chinese literature, dies in Shanghai at the age of 63.
1949: Government forces of the Republic of China evacuate Nanking.
1962: In the biggest-ever "ban the bomb" demonstration, some 150,000 people rally in London's Hyde Park.
1965: The Soviet Union launches its first communications satellite.
1965: President Charles de Gaulle of France emphasizes his opposition to the United States' Asian policies by withdrawing French units from naval maneuvers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.
1969: A Los Angeles jury decides that Sirhan B. Sirhan should be sent to the gas chamber for the murder of Sen. Robert Kennedy in June 1968.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford declares the Vietnam War is over as panic grips Saigon after the South Vietnamese regime's Cabinet resigns.
1985: The Industrial Technology Research Institute successfully develops an amorphous-silicon solar battery of high commercial value.
1986: National Taiwan University Hospital separates a pair of 14-day-old Siamese twins, saving the life of one of the girls. The twins set a record for being the youngest to be separated.
1990: Li Peng, premier of mainland China, arrives in Moscow for a visit, becoming the most senior Beijing leader to tour the Soviet Union in 26 years.
1991: Tens of thousands of striking Soviet workers fill the streets in Minsk on the eve of the Communist Party plenum.
1997: After 26 days of occupation by rebels, Peru's government launches a sudden attack on the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima, freeing 71 hostages. Three soldiers, one hostage and all 14 guerrillas die in the attack.
1999: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. inaugurates a phalaenopsis plant in Costa Rica, with scores of ranking Costa Rican government officials attending the ceremony.
2000: Former U.S. Assistant Secretary for East Asia and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord visits People First Party Chairman James Soong to exchange opinions on the Taiwan Strait situation.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Vice President-elect Annette Lu kick off an island-wide tour to express thanks to their supporters in the March 18 presidential election.
2001: Computer chip giant Intel signs a memorandum of cooperation with the Industrial Development Bureau and the Technology Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is one who sets himself seriously to order his conversation aright."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan president-elect should be invited to visit U.S.: expert
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 22 (CNA) 04/23/08 13:02:35 (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A U.S. expert on cross-Taiwan Strait affairs has urged the Bush administration to reconsider its decision not to invite Taiwan's president-elect Ma Ying-jeou to visit Washington before his inauguration.

Alan D. Romberg, senior associate and director of East Asian Studies at the Washington-based Henry L. Stimson Center, argued that the Bush administration should invite Ma to the U.S. for a pre-inauguration visit, saying that if Ma's intention to visit the U.S. prior to taking office was fulfilled, it would serve U.S. interests.
He also said strong U.S. support could help Ma ease the suspicions of critics who worry he will sell out Taiwan and forge a broad-based consensus for his China policy.

"Ma is committed to lowering tensions with Beijing, a long-standing U.S. objective. But his success requires strong domestic consensus, which, in turn, depends on open American support, " Romberg wrote in an article published on the think tank's Web site Monday.
"Inviting Ma to Washington before his inauguration would signify such critical backing. Instead, President Bush seems determined to miss this unique opportunity to promote U.S. interests," he said.

The Bush administration seems to have fallen into the realm of former Israeli Foreign Minister Abba Eban's quip that the Arabs' "never miss an oppotunity to miss an opportunity" with Israel, Romberg said.

The scholar said the decision was apparently made hastily and without serious reflection, perhaps based partly on assumptions about PRC objections and partly on pique that yet another Taiwan leader was springing surprises on Washington.
Ma "announced" his hope to visit Washington in answering a question from a reporter the night of his election victory.

Romberg argued the White House's decision badly misses the difference between inviting a sitting Taiwan president and an elected one, a difference quite evident in PRC President Hu Jintao's willingness to meet recently with Ma's vice president-elect, Vincent Siew, at an economic conference in Hainan, southern China.
"It also ignores the fact that Ma's avowed intention is to restore trust, not take steps that undermine it," Romberg wrote.

"One assumes Ma can get beyond his disappointment, but that will not make up for the U.S. having squandered an opportunity to establish a relationship of trust with him -- and to convey that to the Taiwan public -- that would manifestly serve U.S. interests, " he wrote.
"It is highly unlikely this decision will be reversed. But in light of the Hu- Siew meeting it should be, and it would serve U.S. interests if it were," Romberg said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sediq the 14th indigenous tribe recognized in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Cabinet officially recognized the Sediq Wednesday, the 14th indigenous tribe in Taiwan to gain formal status.

Commenting on the issue during a weekly Cabinet meeting in which the recognition was granted, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung noted that the Sediq had been previously grouped by the government as a member of the Atayal, although the Sediq considers itself a different tribe from the Atayal.
"The recognition of the Sediq as an individual tribe is a show of respect for the will of the ethnic group and is consistent with the principle of fairness underlying our ethnic policy," Chang said.

To honor the self-identities of indigenous peoples, the government has since 2001 recognized four other indigenous tribes, namely the Thao, Kavalan, Truku and Sakizaya, in addition to the Sediq, the premier pointed out.
According to data from the Council of Indigenous Peoples, the Sediq population totals 6,000 to 7,000 people and is mainly distributed in areas along the border separating Nantou and Hualien counties.

Taiwan's indigenous people -- the native groups that predate all other communal groups in Taiwan -- could have originated either from the southern part of China or from the vast Austronesian-language region.

In addition to the five tribes mentioned above, the other nine tribal groups recognized as having their own dialect and distinct culture are the Amis, Atayal, Bunun, Paiwan, Pinuyumayan, Rukai, Saisiyat, Tsou and Yami.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor prepares to lobby for Olympic baseball

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu departed Wednesday on a trip that will take him to Hong Kong and then to Europe, with his visit to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to lobby to restore baseball as an Olympic event one of the highlights of the trip.
The sport's appearance at the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing in August may be its last after the sport was voted out as an Olympic event three years ago, beginning with the London Games in 2012.

Hu has developed good relations with officials from the International Baseball Federation (IBF) after Taichung City hosted several international baseball championships over the past year, and he was invited by the group to lobby the IOC to reinstate baseball as part of the Summer Games.

During his stay in Switzerland, Hu will also visit the headquarters of the Switzerland-based IBF to further consolidate Taichung's relations with the world's baseball governing body and seek more opportunties to host international baseball tournaments in the future.
Hu has endeavored to turn Taichung City into Taiwan's "baseball capital" since he became mayor of he city in 2001.

Eager to bring the sport's standard in Taichung to international levels, Hu built the 15,000-seat Intercontinental Baseball Stadium to have an acceptable venue in the city to host international tournaments.
Since its completion in 2007, the stadium has hosted the Asian Baseball Championship, the Baseball World Cup, and the 2008 Final Olympic Qualifying Tournament.
Prior to heading to Switzerland, the Taichung mayor will first visit Hong Kong, where he will attend a seminar Friday to promote tourism in the central Taiwan city.

At the seminar, Hu is expected to join Stanley Yen, president of Taiwan's Landis Hotel and Resorts, to exchange views with Hong Kong travel agency operators on tourism promotion in Taichung and issues related to future direct charter flights between Taiwan and China.

Regular direct charter flights between Taiwan and China, a key plank in President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's program, are expected to begin sometime this year, and Hu is worried about the impact they could have on Taichung Airport.

He told the Central News Agency recently that opening charter flights at other airports in Taiwan could hurt existing charters between Taichung and Hong Kong and Macau, but suggested the drops in passenger load factors could be offset by offering arrival visas to Hong Kong and Macau residents.
Following the seminar in Hong Kong, Hu will first head to Britain to solicit investment before heading to Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers worry about quality of service for Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: Legislators said Wednesday that they are worried about service quality and quarantine control if an influx of Chinese tourists visit Taiwan later this year, but officials assured them that everything is ready.

The lawmakers expressed their concerns at a legislative committee during which officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) were invited to brief lawmakers on preparations for hosting Chinese tourists.
President-elect Ma Ying-jeou has pledged to open Taiwan fully to Chinese tourists in July.

Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Hung-chun said he worried about the quality of service offered to Chinese tourists, noting that some Chinese visitors have described their trips in Taiwan as getting up early, going to bed late, eating poorly and rushing around all day.

If Ma's pledge is put into practice and up to 3,000 Chinese tourists come to Taiwan per day, Lee said there might not be enough international-standard hotels to accommodate them, and the interests of local tourists could be undermined on weekends.

Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the MOTC, responded that there are 190 hotels in Taiwan rated three stars or higher with a total of 26,000 rooms and 600 other standard hotels with 50,000 rooms.
"There will be no problem for the hotels to accommodate 3,000 Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan daily," Lai said.

Legislator Yeh Yi-jin pointed out that China has never been "transparent about its quarantine control, " and she questioned how the government is going to conduct effective quarantine if Taiwan opens up fully to Chinese tourists.
Vice Transportation and Communications Minister Ho Nuan-hsien said quarantine control will definitely be included in cross-strait negotiations.

On possible price gouging by local vendors, Lai said the bureau will ask travel agencies to arrange for Chinese tourists to visit shops recognized by the bureau, establish a monitoring mechanism and guarantee tourists full refunds if they return items they find unsatisfactory.

DOC.HEADLINE: Drug-related crime on the rise in Taipei

TEXT.P: A total of 1,670 drug-related criminal cases were uncovered in Taipei City in the first quarter of this year, marking an increase of 7.95 percent compared with the same period of 2007, according to a report released Wednesday by the Taipei City Government.
A total of 1,792 suspects were arrested in the cases, with 10.51 kilograms of illicit drugs seized, said the report compiled by the city's Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

For the whole of 2007, the number of drug-related criminal cases uncovered in the city rose 18.39 percent over the previous year to 5,660, with 6,194 suspected arrested and 253.54 kilograms of illicit drugs seized.
Of these suspects, 5,304, or 85.63 percent, were men.
More than 71 percent of those arrested were taken into custody for using illicit drugs, while 15.79 were suspected of drug possession and another 8.78 percent were suspected of selling drugs.

By educational background, those with a high school education formed the largest group at 49.48 percent, followed by those with a junior high school education at 38.51 percent and those with an elementary school education at 6.64 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unemployment among university grads reaches record high of 4.48%

TEXT.P: The unemployment rate among university graduates reached 4.48 percent in March, marking a record high, according to the latest statistics released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Speaking at a news conference held to present the figures, Huang Chien-chung, the deputy director of the DGBAS' Fourth Department, said that although the figure marks a new high, much of it is "voluntary or short-term unemployment that isn't expected to have an impact on the overall job market."

Huang said that as higher education has become more universal in Taiwan over the past several years, the number of college graduates has increased significantly from about 89,000 in 1997 to 282,000 last year.
The March unemployment rate among college graduates has gradually increased each year from 2.37 percent in 2001 to 4.48 percent this year, according to the DGBAS tallies.
The figure was the highest among all groups classified by education level, the statistics show.
A total of 109,000 college graduates were unemployed in March, according to the tallies.

Huang said that one of the reasons the figure is particularly high is that a significant percentage of those unemployed were recent graduates and relatively young, adding that college graduates tend to change jobs more frequently and have higher standards in searching for employment.
He noted that the DGBAS tallies also show that 2.303 million college graduates were employed in March, up by 222,000 over the figure for the same month last year.
He said this figure illustrates the fruitful results of efforts to increase the quality of the talent pool in the local job market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened low and closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 28.76 points, or 0.31 percent, to close at 9,008.49.

Finishing lower for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 9,032.61 and fluctuated between 9,079.43 and 8,951.53 during the day's session. A total of 5.81 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$183.13 billion (US$6.05 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 2.7 percent. Textile stocks dropped 1.3 percent, cement stocks fell 0.7 percent, foodstuff issues and plastics and chemicals shares both lost 0.4 percent, while machinery and electronics shares and paper and pulp issues were both down 0.3 percent.
Banking and financial shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,199 to 1,087, with 347 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5.51 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's new lawsuit rules belittle Taiwan: MAC

TEXT.P: China's new rules covering civil lawsuits downgrade Taiwan's status and jeopardize the interests and rights of Taiwanese people if they are involved in lawsuits there, a Taiwanese official said Tuesday.

The remarks came after China's supreme court announced new provisions earlier in the day that Chinese courts can deliver civil lawsuit documents to Taiwanese people involved in Chinese lawsuits via mail, fax or e-mail.

In addition, under the new provisions, if Chinese courts cannot deliver the documents or do not know the whereabouts of Taiwanese citizens involved in the cases, they can make a public announcement for three months in newspapers or authoritative Web sites inside or outside China.

Liu Te-shun, vice chairman of the Taipei-based Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , said that if foreign countries want to deliver legal documents to Taiwan, they must respect Taiwan's judicial sovereignty by going through diplomatic channels to reach the interested parties.

Prior to the announcement of the new rules, Chinese courts often delivered documents in civil lawsuits to courts in Taiwan, and the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) would help verify them, Liu explained.
After verification, local courts will help deliver the documents to Taiwanese citizens and then the SEF would send a notice to courts in China, Liu said.
The new rules, however, signal that China has extended its jurisdiction over Taiwan and considers Taiwan as a part of China, Liu pointed out.

Liu said that the delivery of judicial documents between Hong Kong and China or between Macau and China was decided by bilateral negotiations and that it was therefore "inappropriate" for China to unilaterally decide that its domestic rules can apply to Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Liu also pointed out that courts in China do not deliver legal documents to Chinese citizens via e-mail. "Why should Taiwan alone accept such an e-mail? This is very ill-considered."
Using public announcements as a way of valid delivery will jeopardize the rights and interests of Taiwanese citizens, he asserted.

If Taiwanese citizens are named as defendants in a case but do not learn about Chinese court announcements and miss hearings, the courts can rule against them, contending they did not want to appear in court.
The new rules on lawsuit document delivery also were symbolic of the "one-China" principle, which is unacceptable to Taiwan as the principle regards Taiwan as a Chinese province, Liu noted.

Liu said that Taiwan and China should soon authorize the SEF and the Beijing- based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , respectively, to hold talks on the delivery of legal documents to protect individual rights on either side of the Taiwan Strait.
The council will soon call meetings with the SEF and other agencies to discuss how to deal with the impact of the new Chinese rules, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aboriginal college students suffer high drop-out rate: lawmaker

TEXT.P: Aboriginal college students tend to drop out during their academic years due to economic reasons, failure to keep up with their non-aboriginal peers and various other factors, a legislator claimed Wednesday.

Speaking at a session of the Legislative Yuan Education and Culture Committee, Kao Chin Su-mei, a member of the legislative caucus of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, said indigenous young men and women can enter universities and colleges under a preferential entrance program.
Many of them, however, drop out of school in the middle of their courses due to lack of special academic assistance, according to Kao Chin.
Some of the students find themselves being left behind their non-aboriginal peers after studying for a period of time, prompting them to leave school without finishing their studies, Kao Chin said.
Some drop out as a result of financial difficulties as they usually have to leave their remote hometowns to attend colleges or universities located in cities, she noted.
Kao Chin said the trend of aboriginal students dropping out of school "seems" to have risen steadily in recent years.
However, Vice Education Minister Chou Tsan-deh disagreed with her point of view, pointing out that the number of aboriginal college students quitting school has in fact not risen.
According to Chou, 171 aboriginal students were admitted to colleges and universities in 2002. The number nearly doubled to 332 in 2003 and jumped to 714 in 2007.
Chou said the average aboriginal student is unlikely to flunk, since most colleges and universities operate resource grouping classes to help them adapt better academically.

As to their financial difficulties, Chou said the Ministry of Education could coordinate with the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) or the Ministry of the Interior in the future to work out subsidy plans for aboriginal students under a social welfare program.

Meanwhile, Lin Chiang-yi, a vice chairman of the CIP, said that the situation of aboriginal students dropping out has improved in recent years as a result of the implementation of various support programs.
Lin said most aboriginal students who quit their studies do so for financial reasons.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.005 to close at NT$30.293.
A total of US$838 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.320 and fluctuated between NT$30.265 and NT$30.340.

DOC.HEADLINE: Attorney-at-law re-elected chairman of ROC Red Cross Society

TEXT.P: Renowned Attorney-at-Law C.V. Chen was re-elected chairman of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China Wednesday, enabling him to continue to lead the organization for an eighth year.

Chen, 63, an LL.D. holder from Harvard Law School and a senior partner of Lee and Li Attorneys-at-Law, has been chairman of the ROC Red Cross Society since 2000. He was the organization's secretary-general from 1988-1992.

Chen was re-elected Wednesday at a meeting of the board of directors. During the meeting, Justice Minister-designate Wang Ching-feng, who has been a standing director of the society for four years, was elected a vice chairwoman of the non-profit organization.
Two other incumbent vice chairmen -- Chen Feng-yi and Shih Chun-jen -- were also re-elected.
A total of 31 directors and six supervisors were elected or re-elected to new four-year terms, all of which are unpaid.

DOC.HEADLINE: Listing vitamin products as drugs `international trend': DOH

TEXT.P: Responding to an outcry over the high price of vitamin products in Taiwan, an official of the Department of Health (DOH) explained Wednesday that it is because most vitamins are marketed in Taiwan as drugs.

Out of concern that some vitamins, such as vitamins A, D and E, can accumulate in the body and can cause harm, the government has categorized certain vitamins as drug products in an effort to prevent overdoses, said Liao Chi-chou, director of pharmaceutical affairs under the DOH, who said the move is "meeting an international trend."

Liao offered the explanation in response to questions from reporters on a news report carried that day by the United Daily News, which described local consumers as "fatheads" for paying a much higher price for the brand-named multi vitamin Centrum in Taiwan than it costs in the United States.

Citing a recent ruling by the Taipei District Court, the report said that unlike more than 100 other countries, Taiwan lists vitamins as drugs. As a result, imported vitamins have to receive DOH permission before entering the local market, which is why vitamins sold in Taiwan cost several times more than the prices charged elsewhere, according to the ruling.

While ruling a pharmacy owner innocent on the charge of selling banned drugs, the court suggested that the government review and amend the laws governing pharmaceutical affairs in an effort to defend consumers' rights, according to the report.

Hsieh Su-yi of the Luck Star Pharmacy in downtown Taipei was indicted after she was found reselling Centrum that her friends had brought in from the United States. She was freed after the court ruled that the product was not a banned drug.
In Taiwan, Liao pointed out, vitamins whose levels surpass three-fold the advised daily dose are categorized as drugs, while those under that level are regarded as food supplements.

Liao also stated that a much larger production amount in the U.S. is also the factor that leads to Centrum being cheaper there, even though the product is manufactured in Hsinchu by the Wyeth Taiwan Corp.

The Wyeth Taiwan-produced Centrum is priced at around NT$600 (US$19.8) per 120 tablets -- NT$5 per tablet -- while Centrum made by Wyeth's mother company in the U.S. costs only US$17.67 per 523 tablets -- NT$1.6 per tablet.

Several lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan expressed concern Wednesday over the issue, with Legislator Ho Tsai-feng of the opposition Kuomintang accusing the DOH of attempting to profit from pharmaceutical factories.
In response, the DOH promised to invite experts within 10 days to discuss the issue in order to outline proper measures for vitamin trading management within one month, Liao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier vows full efforts in flood prevention

TEXT.P: Despite having less than a month left in office, the caretaker government will spare no efforts to prevent problems from flooding as the annual monsoon season approaches in May, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday.
Chang made the remarks at an Executive Yuan session after listening to a briefing of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' (MOEA) Water Resources Agency on the prevention of floods and inundation.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which has held the presidency for the past eight years, will transfer power to the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) when the KMT's Ma Ying-jeou is inaugurated as president May 20.

Chang asked the MOEA to instruct local governments in cleaning drainage systems, dredging rivers, and checking water gates, so as to work toward the goal of "zero-damage" during the rainy period from May through November.
In Taiwan, floods are usually caused by heavy rains during the plum rain season, or the East Asian rainy season, from May to June and the typhoon season from July to November.

Heavy rainfalls during the period can also cause high turbidity, leading to water supply problems, which have affected the Shihsmen Reservoir in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan and the Kao-Ping River Weir in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan.
The MOEA will strengthen emergency measures for these two places to prevent the same problems from occurring this year, Chang said.

According to Chang, the central government has implemented an eight-year program with a budget of NT$116 billion (US$3.83 billion) since June 2006, to solve flood problems in the nation's flood-prone areas.
Chang expressed the hope that with the MOEA's active promotion, 90 percent of the first phase of the project will be completed by June this year.

Chen Shen-hsien, director-general of the MOEA's Water Resources Agency, said the government's flood prevention work has improved from experience and training during past two years, and the MOEA will make full efforts in preventing and reducing damages by floods.

DOC.HEADLINE: Science administration to propose carbon dioxide reduction guidelines

TEXT.P: The cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) is working on guidelines to further cut carbon dioxide emissions nationwide by 140 million tons by 2025, as part of efforts to reduce Taiwan's greenhouse gas emissions to the 2000 level, NSC officials said Wednesday.

Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions in 2000 was 214 million tons, and is forecast to top 531 million tons by 2005. The cabinet has set a goal of reducing the country's carbon dioxide emissions to the 2000 level by 2025.

"This means that carbon dioxide levels have to be cut by 317 million tons, " said NSC Deputy Minister Yang Hung-duen. He added that the guidelines already established would lead to a reduction of 177 million tons of carbon dioxide emissions, but the NSC has yet finalize a plan for cutting another 140 million tons of carbon dioxide emissions to meet the goal.

Yang said the council is now considering a combination of methods, such as imposing a carbon emission tax, joining global carbon trading networks, encouraging eco-friendly economic development, regulating industry proportion of emissions, seeking alternative energy sources, and developing green technology.
NSC officials said that after the council has drafted the guidelines, they would still be subject to inter-agency reviews and cabinet approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: Paraguay urged not to develop ties with China at Taiwan's expense

TEXT.P: Ambassador to Paraguay David Hu has urged Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo not to forge closer relations with China at the expense of its diplomatic ties with Taiwan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.

Lugo said at a news conference after he won Sunday's election that Paraguay is the only country in the region that does not have ties with China and that "if other countries have established relations with China... we will not be left behind."

Lugo, whose victory ended more than six decades of rule by the center-right Colorado Party, had said during his campaign that he would like to establish ties with China if he won the election, which gave rise to speculations that Taiwan might lose its only diplomatic ally in South America to China.

MOFA spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh related that Hu, in meetings with Lugo before and after the election, had said that "Taiwan hopes to strengthen its diplomatic relations with Paraguay. If Paraguay can expand its links with China without compromising its ties with Taiwan, I think it will be all right."
Yeh noted that Hu has repeatedly urged Paraguay not to develop relations with other countries at Taiwan's expense.

Simon Ko, director-general of MOFA's Department of Central and South American Affairs, said that Taiwan must respect the sovereignty of the South American nation and therefore cannot oppose any plans it might have to establish ties with China, but can only hope that Taiwan-Paraguay relations would not be compromised.

"We are, of course, open to diplomatic ties between our allies and China, if relations with Taiwan are not compromised, " Ko said, "but the point is that China does not accept dual recognition -- at least, not at present, " he added.
Paraguay and Taiwan established diplomatic relations in 1957.

DOC.HEADLINE: Training vessel embarks on fishing-monitoring mission

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) dispatched an official Taiwan fishery training ship to the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Occean Tuesday to police Taiwan fishing vessels operating on the high seas there.
Law enforcement authorities deployed by the Coast Guard Administration are sailing aboard the Yuhsun No. 2 for the duration of its 183-day mission, the COA's Fisheries Administration said.

The officials aboard the vessel -- which is equipped with advanced monitoring equipment -- will report any irregularities committed by Taiwanese fishing vessels to the relevant organizations, the Fisheries Administration said.
This marks the third year that the Yuhsun No. 2 has been dispatched to monitor fishing operations in international waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan delegation attends world expo under national title

TEXT.P: A delegation of Hsinchu city government officials successfully took part recently in a world high-tech exposition under Taiwan's national title, rather than as "China" as has been the case at previous events, according to a city government statement.

The delegation from the northern county in Taiwan attended the fifth WTA Techno Mart of the World Technopolis Association (WTA) -- hosted by Dubai April 14-16 -- under the name, "Taiwan, Republic of China" for the first time, the statement issued Wednesday read.

This was a result of Hsinchu City Mayor Lin Junq-tzer's protest at the last expo two years ago against the organizers' move to identify the Taiwanese delegation as being from China, in brochures designed to introduce member cities, the statement noted.
It also marked the first time that the organizers recognized Taiwan's national status, Lin said in the statement.
Lin, who led the delegation, added that at past events, delegations from Taiwan had lodged strong protests with the organizers on grounds that Taiwan's sovereignty was being denigrated.
For example, when the event was first held, a delegation comprised of Tainan city officials refused to take part, in protest over the name issue, Lin recalled.
At this year's event, however, the association and the host city apparently attached great importance to Hsinchu City's statement of protest last time, he added.
Meanwhile, the delegations from the Chinese cities of Nanjing and Hefei were also respectful of Taiwan's designation this time, he said.
At many other international forums, Chinese delegates often reacted strongly over the name issue, in light of China's claim of sovereignty over Taiwan.
Lin said that the Hsinchu City delegation also displayed Taiwan's national flag on a banner on its booth at the event.
The association praised Hsinchu City's high-tech development and negotiated to have the city host the event in 2010, according to Lin.
The city will submit an application at the annual meeting of the association to be held in South Korea later this year, according to the statement.

The WTA, which was established in 1997 in South Korea, is a multilateral cooperative international organization comprised mainly of city governments from around the world, with the aim of linking science and technology advancement with local development.

DOC.HEADLINE: 500 breakfasts donated to underprivileged children

TEXT.P: The Super Mill Group (SMG), a breakfast restaurant chain, on Wednesday donated 500 breakfasts to the Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF) to offer underprivileged children a nutritious meal.

CWLF, established in Taipei in 1991, is a non-profit organization devoted to child welfare, and provides both direct and indirect services. It also advocates children's rights and strives to raise awareness of child welfare issues.
SMG Vice President Yeh Song-ji said at a press conference Wednesday that he hopes the gesture will serve to generate greater concern for children in need.

"We hope that the donation will help raise public awareness of the plight of underprivileged children and generate more love and concern for them, " said Yeh, whose chain operates more than a thousand breakfast eateries around Taiwan under the name "My Warm Day."

Noting that the CWLF is committed to assisting some 2,000 children from 1,300 underprivileged families, Alicia Wang, chief executive officer of the CWLF, expressed appreciation to the breakfast chain on behalf of the children.
"SMG has indeed given our children a very good gift," she said.

According to Wang, about 40 percent of the children who receive assistance from the CWLF are not covered under the national health insurance scheme. She urged the general public and enterprises "to help those children who really need financial assistance."
"There is still room for the public to assist the children in various ways, such as helping to pay their daily expenses, tuition fees, and medical bills," Wang told a Central News Agency reporter.
Wang further suggested that the government adjust its standards for defining "low income families" so that more families would become eligible for assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fallow land to be used for corn, not biofuel: new agriculture chief

TEXT.P: Taiwan's incoming agricultural czar said Tuesday that as the country is unable to achieve an economy of scale in the production of crops for biofuel, its 220,000 hectares of fallow land should be used to grow corn for feed instead.
Such a plan could help the nation reduce its reliance on imports of animal feed as well as help Taiwan maintain meat prices at a stable level even as global food prices skyrocket, said Chen Wu-chung.

Chen, who has been designated as the new minsiter of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) in the new administration of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, said in an interview with the Central News Agency that utilizing fallow land in this way will also help revitalize rural villages.
He argued that there is currently not enough land to make the growing of crops for biofuel in Taiwan practical.

As the ongoing international food crisis has led to steep price increases, Chen said, making use of Taiwan's fallow land to grow corn for feed and to build up the nation's corn supply is a good policy.
Corn can be stored for long periods, with no threat that possible overproduction will lead to a glut.
Commenting on current COA Minister Su Jia-chyuan's goal of encouraging production of crops for biofuel, Chen said the policy has proven to be unfeasible.
He noted that according to the COA's own tallies, it costs at least NT$51 (US$1.70) to produce one liter of biofuel from soya in Taiwan, which is much more expensive than abroad.

Using other crops, such as rapeseed and sunflower, to try to create economies of scale for the production of biofuel also have proven unsuccessful in Taiwan for a variety of reasons, including damage by pests and limited land, Chen said.
Taiwan uses about 5 million tons of corn for feed annually, according to Fang Ching-chuan, head of the National Animal Industry Foundation's livestock division.

As one hectare of land can produce about 5 tons of corn for feed, Fang said that if the 220,000 hectares of fallow land in Taiwan are used to grow corn for one season, then 20 percent of the nation's annual demand can be met.

Shipping corn from the United States to Taiwan costs about US$70-80 per ton, Fand said. Using 1.1 million tons of corn grown in Taiwan could therefore save the country about US$88 million in shipping fees alone, he said. The savings are even higher if one includes fees for customs, storage, insurance and internal transportation, he added.
The savings would be passed on to the main users of corn feed in Taiwan, namely livestock and poultry farmers, which in turn would help keep meat prices in the country under control, Fang said.
Having a stable domestic supply of corn for feed would also be beneficial in terms of national security considerations, Fang said.

Meanwhile, Su Tzung-chen, head of the COA's foodstuffs division, agreed that corn is a suitable choice because it is resistant to drought and can be harvested twice a year. He added that technological advances in Taiwan's agricultural industry have made it possible to produce six to seven tons of corn on one hectare of land.

Furthermore, Su said, the COA launched a program at the start of this year to encourage farmers to grow corn for feed on fallow land. Under the program, the council is offering up to NT$45,000 per harvest on a contract basis to farmers for each hectare of corn that they plant.
The program is aimed at lowering Taiwan's reliance on foreign feed grains and at reducing livestock and poultry farmers' costs, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGBoston's population swell's 25% as Eastern Europeans head for Fens
Thescale and paceof change caused by migration has been so fast that Eastern European migrants now make up a quarter of one British townspopulation, a minister disclosed yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier touts DPP's promotion of social welfare

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration has funneled an average of NT$290.9 billion per year into the promotion of social welfare over the past eight years, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday.
The amount is 1.75 times as much as the average of NT$166 billion per year that was spent by the former Kuomintang (KMT) administration during the 1993-1999 period, Chang said.
The premier was speaking during a weekly Cabinet meeting in which he reviewed the DPP administration's achievements in promoting social welfare programs.

In terms of economic security, the programs introduced during the DPP administration included the provision of an allowance of NT$3,000 per month to citizens aged 65 and over, the launch of a new retirement program for workers and an increase of the monthly allowance for elderly farmers to NT$6,000.

Measures to reduce the burden on local households included the establishment of an after-school care system for elementary school children and a community babysitting system and long-term care program for the disabled, children and patients suffering from chronic disease, as well as free kindergarten enrollment for disadvantaged five-year-olds, Chang went on.

Turning to programs targeting minority groups, he said the DPP administration established a NT$3 billion fund aimed at helping foreign spouses assimilate into Taiwanese society, enacted a basic law on indigenous rights, launched an indigenous television channel, allowed indigenous citizens to start receiving a pension at 55 and lowered the unemployment rate among the indigenous population from 9.24 percent in 2001 to 4.36 percent at present.
On steps to enhance the status of women, Chang noted that Taiwan has now seen its first female vice president and vice premier.

In terms of efforts to promote public health, Chang said the satisfaction rating for medical visits in Taiwan has now increased to 77 percent, while Taiwan's successful National Health Insurance program has also received media coverage in the United States.

Meanwhile, thanks to the government's efforts to improve the social security network, the disparity between the rich and the poor has narrowed from 6.39-fold to 6.01-fold, while the unemployment rate has declined from a high of 4.6 percent to 3.9 percent, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP members abroad worried about party's future: former vice premier

TEXT.P: Former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen said Wednesday that overseas members of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are worried about the DPP's future after the party's two election defeats in January and March.

Tsai, who has entered the DPP chairmanship race, made the remarks after returning from a visit to Los Angeles, where she attended the 2008 annual convention of the North America Taiwanese Women's Association last weekend and gave a keynote speech on Taiwan's economic development over the past eight years.

Tsai said the DPP members and supporters she met during her trip had expressed extreme worry about the party's future after the party lost both the legislative election on Jan. 12 and the presidential election on March 22 to the opposition Kuomintang.

"They expressed the hope that the DPP can get back on its feet as soon as possible and that a capable leader will guide the party out of the shadow of defeat and bring it back to its heyday," she said.

Asked whether she will coordinate with the other two candidates for the DPP chairmanship position before the party makes a final decision on whether a May 18 election is really necessary, Tsai said the matter is up to incumbent DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh.

Some DPP members have proposed that the next DPP chair should be produced through intra-party coordination rather than through an election, but a May 18 election appears inevitable because although Tsai, 52, is the front runner in the race, her two rivals -- former senior presidential adviser Koo Kwan-min, 82, and DPP Legislator Trong Chai, 73 -- have both told Hsieh they will not take part in any coordination that has a predetermined purpose of persuading them to yield to Tsai.

Chai has expressed doubt about Tsai's suitability for the role, describing her as a "rookie " as far as party affairs are concerned, while Koo, a staunch Taiwan Independence advocate, has said he feels duty-bound to run so that he can "try to restore the party's faith in itself."

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st confirmed chikungunya fever case in Taoyuan County reported

TEXT.P: Taoyuan county health officials confirmed Wednesday the first chikungunya fever case this year in the northern county.
The officials said the victim is a 58-year-old Taiwanese businessman who traveled to Shanghai March 26-April 9 and then proceeded to Jakarta, Indonesia April 9-19.
He was found to have a fever when he passed through the screening station at the airport and further tests confirmed that he had been infected with chikungunya fever.
His condition improved after treatment, the officials added.

Lin Hsueh-jung, health chief of Taoyuan County, said the chikungunya virus (CHIKV) is transmitted to humans through the bite of the aedes mosquito and causes an illness with symptoms similar to those of dengue fever. The acute febrile phase of the illness lasts only two to five days, but the pain associated with CHIKV infection of the joints persists for weeks or months.

In addition to tropical countries where dengue fever is prevalent, such as Indonesia, Vietnam, Thailand, Singapore, the Philippines, Malaysia and Cambodia, chikungunya fever is also common in southern Africa and South America.

DOC.HEADLINE: Production glut causes slump in carnation prices

TEXT.P: Mother's Day is around the corner, but the price of carnations, the floral symbol of the occasion, has remained unusually weak because of a production glut, agricultural sources said Wednesday.

Wang Chih-hsiung, a flower farmer in Changhua County's Tienwei township in central Taiwan, said the price of locally produced carnations rose to a high of NT$70 to NT$80 per 10-stem bunch around Mother's Day last year.
Encouraged by such profitability, many Changhua farmers switched to carnation plantation this season, with total acreage exceeding last year's level by more than 50 percent.
"Expanded plantation has let to an oversupply and a resulting severe price slump," Wang lamented.
At the moment, Wang said, wholesale prices are hovering around NT$20 a bunch or have fallen as low as NT$15 at the country's five flower auction markets.
"Such prices can hardly cover production costs, not to mention any profits for growers," Wang said.
With just two weeks to go before Mother's Day, which falls on May 11 this year, many blooming carnations are left untended on farms in Tienwei, one of Taiwan's major floral production hubs.
The plight of "the more flowers plucked, the more money lost," coupled with a manpower shortage, has discouraged flower farmers from cutting mature carnations, Wang noted.

With a number of unsold carnations in his inventory, Wang said he doesn't expect prices to rebound to last year's level in the coming two weeks. "The wholesale prices will fluctuate between NT$50 and NT$60 at most," he predicted.

To help promote carnation sales, Liu Shu-fang, a Changhua County councilor, launched a campaign Tuesday, urging government agencies, corporations and social groups to buy more locally grown carnations to celebrate Mother's Day.
The Tienwei township government will also organize a promotional program this weekend to boost carnation sales.

Wang and many flower farmers in the county, however, said they would like the government to assist them in transforming their farms into tourist gardens, with visitors allowed to pick fresh carnations on their own as a form of recreation and an inexpensive way to enjoy the beauty of fresh carnations.
"We believe that is the best way to help us cut labor costs and lower our losses," Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect Ma to join a campaign to promote tranquility

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and his running mate Vincent Siew will participate in a campaign namedPeace Movementto promote tranquility in society and in people's minds, a Buddhist master who initiated the event said Wednesday.

The Peace Movement, which will kick off Saturday afternoon, is co-organized by the Ling Jiou Mountain Buddhist Society (LJMB) and the Museum of World Religion (MWR) , with the aim of promoting tranquility in society and people's minds. Both of the organizations were founded by the master, Hsin Tao.

According to the program, an estimated 10,000 people, including Ma, Siew, and representatives from various communities, are expected to gather at Taipei's Daan Forest Park in central Taipei to meditate and promote peaceful living.
Hsin Tao invited members of the public regardless of race, gender, religion, and political belief to participate in thePeace Movement to create a peaceful society.
Mankind's avarice has not only hindered social order but also harmed the world, Hsin Tao said, expressing hope thatthe movement will help reduce tensions or conflicts within our society."

He added that a harmonious society will emerge when everyone has a calm mind, stressing thatwe hope individuals can practice tranquility, love, and dialogue in our daily life to show appreciation for the globe.
"Through everyone's participation, we also hope to achieve our goal of creating a 'Global Family for Love and Peace,'Hsin Tao noted.

Commending the activity asthe most meaningful cultural event involving participation from politicians and celebrities in recent years,Pao Teh Han, director of the museum said he hoped that the campaign can also promote "life education" for the public.
We really need a tranquil society because the social order in Taiwan is too chaotic," said Han, stressing thatpeople can have clear thoughts only when they live in tranquility.

Speaking on behalf of businesses, Vincent Yen, chairman of the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development R.O.C., urged enterprises to join the campaign in order to show respect to the Earth and life.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmental assessment system deficient:environmentalists

TEXT.P: Taiwan's official environmental impact assessment (EIA) system was denounced Wednesday by a group of scholars and students as a "rubber stamp" for construction interests.

The group of more than 20 students from three prestigious universities in Taiwan, along with some scholars, made the accusation at a press conference under the slogan, "impact assessment that fails to find impact."

According to the results of the students' research, which was conducted by reviewing 350 EA reports and interviewing several EIA committee members, 70 to 80 percent of EIA reports usually conclude that planned construction projects would have little or no impact on Taiwan's environment.
"If all these construction projects, including those of the Formosa Plastics Group, are seen as having no impact on Taiwan, it means that the EIA system cannot find the impact," said Li Jia-da.

The student researchers also disclosed that EIA committee members usually have on average 9 days to read a report before a review meeting is held, and that they are usually assigned a new report about every 2.06 days.

In addition, many EIA committee members have received telephone calls from Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) officials, "who expressed concerns (about the construction plans under review)," and one committee member was even replaced because of his differences with the nation's top environmental agency, the group said.

"EIA members are interfering with the administration, and their professionalism is not respected, " said Li. "The EIA's reports are influenced by construction interests, and under such circumstances, its assessment system is nothing more than a rubber stamp."

Urging that the incoming government under president-elect Ma Ying-jeou to improve the EIA system, Yu Yue-hwa, a professor at the Graduate Institute of Environmental Engineering, National Taiwan University (NTU), suggested that serving on the EIA committee should be a full-time job.
Most of the members are professors or experts who serve on an ad hoc basis on the EIA committee.

Liou Ming-lone, chairman of Environmental Quality Protection Foundation and a professor at NTU, suggested further that the report on the controversial Suao- Hualien Expressway, which is slated to reviewed by the EIA committee Friday, should be returned to the Ministry of the Transportation and Communications and that the new government should decide whether or not to implement the project.

"The role of the EPA should not be limited to reducing water and electricity usage or cleaning the streets -- it has a mission to protect Taiwan's environment," said Liou. He further encouraged EPA Minister-designate Shen Shih- hung to play a more active role in the incoming government, which sees the economy as its top priority.

The 86-km Suao-Hualien Expressway project, which was designed mainly to boost the economy in eastern Taiwan, has drawn repeated fire from environmentalists who have questioned its necessity and have expressed grave concerns over its potential negative impact on the ecological system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Food price rise drives COA to gear policy on fallow farmland

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (C0A) has been working on a program to restore cultivation of Taiwan's fallow farmland to tackle surging food prices, COA Deputy Chairman Lee Jen-chyuan said Wednesday.

While giving a special report at a legislative committee meeting on the government's plan to deal with a looming global food crisis, Lee told lawmakers that the cabinet-level COA has decided to slash subsidies for the 220,000 hectares of farmland that has been lying fallow across Taiwan.
The subsidies, aimed at discouraging overproduction, were imposed after Taiwan joined the World Trade Organization and began allowing imports of rice from abroad.
As global food prices skyrocket in recent weeks, Lee said the COA is now evaluating measures to encourage farmers to resume cultivation on some of the land.
It is planning to urge farmers to grow corn for corn feed on 12,000 hectares of the fallow farmland this year and on 30,000 hectares next year, Lee said.
Taiwan imports 5 million metric tons of corn feed every year at a high price, which has caused a heavy burden on animal and crop farmers.
As the price of corn feed has jumped recently, prices for meat have also risen.

In addition to using up to 30,000 hectares of the fallow farmland to grow corn in 2008, the COA plans to use another 20,000 hectares and 16,000 hectares for cultivating rice and for forestation, respectively, Lee said.
The remaining fallow farmland will be used to produce other kinds of grains that will not cause a glut in the domestic market, Lee said.
After cultivation is resumed on the farmland, the land's use will not be changed to "non-agricultural" purposes, Lee assured lawmakers.

In line with the COA's measures, Taiwan's rice paddies are expected to increase by 20,000 hectares per year from the current 260,000 hectares and its rice production will rise by around 100,000 metric tons annually, Lee said.

At the same time, Lee said, the COA will largely reduce its subsidies for fallow farmland -- currently at NT$45,000 (US$1,485) per hectare for each harvest -- to push farmers to restore cultivation. The new level of subsidy is being studied and has not yet been determined, he added.

According to Huang Yu-tsai, director of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, the government's policy of subsidizing fallow farmland has had a negative effect on the local agricultural sector's competitiveness.
Compared to other Asian countries, however, Taiwan's rice prices remain relatively stable, having increased by only 13 percent this year, Huang pointed out last week.
And to cope with possible food shortages, the government has always maintained a safe level of rice stocks -- some 310,000 tons at present -- which can be released in emergencies, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Simple life, less consumption can save Earth: activists

TEXT.P: A recent TV commercial in Taiwan showing a family being advised to replace their old air conditioner to save on electricity bills so they can buy a new computer for their child has been blasted by local activists as touting a consumption concept that will only accelerate global warming.
Pan Han-chiang, a member of the Taiwan Environmental Action Network, said it was a typical advertisement in Taiwan that capitalizes on consumer concerns about global warming.
However, while it might appear to focus on environmental protection, the ad is essentially encouraging yet more consumption, Pan said.
He also added that in the ad, "the money saved from electricity bills is used to buy a new computer, but in the end, the electricity bills will still increase."
He described the "production-to-advertisement-to- consumption-to- production" commercial model as the main cause of accelerating global warming.

Robin Winkler, a local lawyer and long-term environmental activist, said that overconsumption and the globalization of products have expanded the scale of many economies but have driven environmental protection out of control.

"If governments do not change their thinking on GDP-based economy, the situation will only get worse," warned Winkler, also a former member of the environmental impact evaluation committee of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
"Reducing consumption and returning to a simple life are the only solutions," he went on.

Products that are over-consumed in Taiwan include not just electronics but also disposable items such as chopsticks, bottled water and drinks, paper diapers, toilet paper and tissues, and plastic bags.

Citing disposable chopsticks as an example, Liu Ming-long, chairman of the Environmental Quality Protection Foundation (EQPF) , said that Taiwan consumes some 3 billion pairs of disposable chopsticks every year.

The chopsticks in turn produce nearly 70,000 tonnes of garbage and 92,700 tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions, Liu said, adding that the carbon dioxide emissions do not include those released during the importing process.
Although polyethylene terephthalate (PET) bottles can be recycled, many of them are still thrown into the regular garbage after use, the EPA said.

The EPA suggested that the public should continue to use PET bottles after finishing the drink they originally contained, saying that using the bottle 20 times saves the equivalent amount of CO2 required to produce a new PET bottle.

To help save the Earth, environmental protection advocates urged, the public can also use air conditioners less often, drive less often, wear cotton or linen clothes rather than man-made fiber garments, eat locally grown fruit more often and reject using disposable goods.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County takes no smoking campaign to the streets

TEXT.P: Staff of Changhua County's Public Health Bureau went on the streets Wednesday to urge people to quit smoking, hoping that an upfront and personal approach might raise public awareness about the dangers of cigarettes.

The 12 staff members, led by bureau director-general Yeh Yen-poh, showed posters containing information about the dangers of smoking to pedestrians and shop owners along the streets in the county's Changhua City.

They also encouraged smokers on the streets to join the national "Quit and Win" campaign, which was organized jointly by the John Tung Foundation and health departments and bureaus in Taiwan's local governments.

Participants in the campaign must stop smoking from May 2-29, and after a medical evaluation and an assessment by the person supervising the contestants, the successful candidates will qualify for a lucky draw to win a top prize of NT$600,000 (US$19,800).
Those who are over 18 and have smoked for at least one year can sign up for the competition, Yeh said, adding that smokers may also seek professional help from doctors on how to give up smoking.
Smoking is a serious public health problem that causes many diseases such as heart diseases, lung diseases, eye problems, as well as risks for women and babies.
Statistics compiled by the World Health Organization showed that about 5 million people died of diseases related to tobacco hazards around the world every year.
Giving up smoking will reduce people's chances of getting diseases in their respiratory and circulatory systems, and also lower risks for getting stroke and cancer, Yeh said.

He offered four tips to help those who want to quit smoking stay off cigarettes and live a nicotine-free life, including: taking deep breaths, drinking cold water, jumping after stretching, and brushing one's teeth or washing one's face to refresh oneself.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's diversification of markets pays off: CEPD

TEXT.P: Shrinking exports to the United States, one of Taiwan's major trading partners, has not caused as great an impact as expected, thanks to Taiwan's strategy of diversifying its overseas markets, officials of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.

CEPD statistics showed that Taiwan's exports to the U.S. recorded a year-on-year decline of 0.4 percent in the first quarter of 2008, but that in the same period exports to Asian countries, excluding Japan, registered a growth of 24.8 percent.
The figures indicate that Taiwan's exports have not been heavily affected by the U.S. subprime mortgage crisis that began in the third quarter of 2007 and has since battered the U.S. economy.

Over the past year, some scholars had predicted an economic recession in the U.S. and other industrial countries would hit exports and economic growth in emerging and developing economies in East Asia, including the "four Asian Dragons" of Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea, as well as China and members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

Citing the biannual East Asia Update issued by the World Bank in April, the CEPD said although the economic slowdown in the U.S. had impacted on exports of emerging and developing East Asian economies, the effect was less than expected because of an increasing demand in other emerging economies around the world.

Analyzing the changes in Taiwan's export market, the CEPD pointed out that Taiwan's exports to the U.S. dropped to 13 percent of the total in 2007, from 23.4 percent in 2000. However exports to other Asian countries, excluding Japan, increased to 60.1 percent from 41 percent during the same period, the CEPD said.

DOC.HEADLINE: New drug for liver cancer to hit Taiwan market

TEXT.P: The drug Nexavar has proved effective in preventing the growth and spread of liver cancer, the most deadly type of malignancy in Taiwan, two gastroenterology specialists announced at a press conference Wednesday.

Nexavar was first used to treat kidney cancer in 2005 and has been approved in more than 50 countries since then, said Wang Chung-kwe, the deputy superintendent of the Ren-ai branch of the Taipei City Hospital.

In international clinical research, Nexavar was found effective in prolonging the lives of liver-cancer patients in the terminal stages by about 4 to 6 months, said Wang. The drug works by reducing the blood supply to the cancer cells and by blocking tumor cell signals so that the cancer cells cannot grow and divide, he explained. It has few side effects, one of which is diarrhea, he added.
The drug is now under review by the Department of Health, and "we believe it will soon be approved," Wang said.
In Taiwan, about 9,800 new cases of liver cancer are recorded each year, and only 15 to 20 percent of the patients are suitable for surgical treatment, according to Wang.
Most liver cancer patients cannot undergo surgery because the tumors are often detected in the terminal phase, and are often accompanied by liver sclerosis.
At the press conference, Wang also announced that the Taiwan Liver Cancer Association (TLCA) , the first of its kind in the country, was established in January.
"With the TLCA, we hope to provide a platform for medical professionals nationwide to exchange their clinical experiences regarding liver cancer treatment," said Wang.
He added that one of the association's goals is to establish liver cancer departments in hospitals.

"Research on liver cancer in Taiwan is more advanced than in Europe, the United States and Japan, because Taiwan has more cases of the disease," Wang said, stressing the necessity of an organization like the TCLA.

Cancer is the number one cause of death in Taiwan, with liver cancer being the most deadly. The high mortality rate from liver cancer compared to other countries is due to the fact that 15 to 20 percent of Taiwan people are hepatitis B or C carriers, according to Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shops will be penalized for trading in Chinese yuan: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) warned local shops Wednesday not to trade in Chinese yuan, or they will face fines and their Chinese currency cash will be confiscated.

MAC officials made the statement after it was reported the same day that a popular computer and hi-tech product store had posted an advertisement welcoming the use Chinese yuan to make purchases. According to the report, a well-known coffee shop chain has also listed its prices in Chinese yuan.
According to the MAC officials, these two business practices are in breach of the law, and the central bank has the right to impose penalties on the two enterprises.

Before a currency clearance and settlement mechanism is established between Taiwan and China, local businesses are prohibited, under the relevant regulations, from trading in Chinese yuan, the officials warned.

It is expected that the exchange of Chinese yuan will be permitted at specific locations in Taiwan, including airports, harbors and financial institutions, after the Taipei-based Central Bank of Republic of China (CBC) has implemented the measures, in line with an election promise made by President-elect Ma Ying- jeou of the Kuomintang.

Ma vowed, throughout his campaign, to build closer trade and economic ties with China after he assumes office on May 20, promising measures such as full convertibility of the Chinese currency in Taiwan on an incremental basis.

The CBC has forecast that the demand for the exchange of the Chinese yuan and Taiwan dollar will grow in Taiwan, as the incoming KMT administration is set to allow the entry of Chinese tourists from early July -- up to 3,000 per day in the initial stages and increasing to 10,000 per day eventually.
Currently, Taiwan residents are allowed to exchange Chinese yuan only on the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu, in amounts of less than 20,000 yuan.

Kinmen and Matsu maintain direct two-way ferry services to three ports in China's Fujian provinces, via the mini links which allow many China-based Taiwan businessmen to travel frequently between the two sides.
