DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan High Speed Rail increases prize for 23 millionth passenger

TEXT.P: Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) has increased the prize for its 23 millionth passenger in hopes that the lucky person would come forward, a THSRC executive said Wednesday.

The THSRC has been looking for the ticket holder for about two weeks, but to date no one has shown up to claim the prize. The number 23 million was selected by the THSRC because it is linked to Taiwan's total population.

The 23 millionth THSRC ticket, bearing the number 11-2-01-0-103-0365, was a non-reserved adult ticket and was bought at Tainan Station in southern Taiwan at 11: 41 a.m. April 12 for travel to Taichung Station in central Taiwan, according to the THSRC.

The THSRC is now offering an additional prize of 23 tickets for standard trains, valid for one year and usable at any time during its daily schedule. The original prize was 23 tickets for business class, valued at NT$56,120 (US$1,852), and a 700T model train set valued at NT$6,000, the executive said.

The THSRC began operation last January and since then has seen continuous growth in performance. Its trains travel between Taipei and Kaohsiung in 90 minutes at a competitive cost that has forced several domestic air carriers to discontinue their flights on that route.
The THSRC also gave prizes to its 5 millionth and 10 millionth passengers.
The executive said if the 23 millionth passenger does not show up by May 22 to claim the prize, the THSRC will donate the tickets or an equivalent sum of money to charity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Spending on fireworks display to be limited to NT$5 million

TEXT.P: The spending for the fireworks display during the May 20 presidential inauguration celebration in southern Taiwan will be limited to NT$5 million (US$164,500), or one fourth of the original allocation budgeted by the government, a spokesman for President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday.

John Feng, convener of Ma's inauguration celebration organizing team, said Ma has given instructions that the inauguration celebrations be held in line with the principles of "economy and simplicity."

Although the sum of NT$20 million had originally been budgeted for the fireworks display along the Love River in the port city of Kaohsiung, Ma said that based on his experience as two-term Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006, "there is no need to spend that much."
The budget for the fireworks display will be NT$5 million at most, and any unused funds may be transferred to other development projects or returned to the national coffers, Feng quoted Ma as saying.

To ensure that the quality of the display would not be compromised due to the lower spending, Ma's staff has also decided to take a cue from the United States' Fourth of July celebrations in Boston and have a symphony orchestra play Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky's "1812 Overture."
The piece is best known for its climatic volley of cannon fire and ringing chimes, which is expected to uplift the spectators, the staff said.
Feng said he has contacted the Kaohsiung City Symphony Orchestra and the Ministry of National Defense (MND) to discuss their roles in the fireworks display.

The Kaohsiung City Symphony Orchestra was "elated" and "is now preparing for its performance, " Feng said. The MND also said that the volley of cannon fire will synchronize perfectly with the fireworks display "to create a spectacular show worth more than NT$20 million."
Feng said that the fireworks display will last 30 minutes, and all vacant areas close to the Love Rive will be open to the public on May 20, once the authorities give security clearance.

DOC.HEADLINE: First bluefin tuna caught this season sold for NT$1.72 million
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/08 22:26:19 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The first bluefin tuna caught this season was sold for NT$1.73 million (US$57,055) in an auction at Donggang harbor Wednesday.
The auction, presided over by Council of Agriculture head Su Jia-chyuan and Pintung County Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung, marked the beginning of the 2008 annual Pingtung Bluefin Tuna Cultural Festival.
The giant tuna fish, weighing 247 kilograms, was caught by a fishing boat named Wan Yi Tsai which is registered with the Liouciou Islet off Pingtung County.

To qualify as the first tuna caught for the season, the fish must be a northern bluefin tuna -- a species native to both the western and eastern Atlantic Ocean. Its weight must exceed 180 kilograms, and the fish must have been alive when it was removed from the water.
The catch must be reported immediately to the nearest fishery radio station and must be shipped back to Donggong harbor by boat.

Three restaurants bid for the fish in the auction. Hung Shih-yang, owner of the Hong Hai Sea Food Restaurant near the Kaohsiung International Airport, said he was happy to win the bid for his four-month old business by offering a price of NT$7,000 per kilogram.
The Pingtung County Government has hosted the annual Bluefin Tuna Cultural Festival since 2001, with the aim of stimulating the local economy.

Owners of fishing boats operating out of Donggang used to export most of their tuna catch to Japan, but since the county government launched the Bluefin Tuna Cultural Festival, they now prefer to sell their fish on the domestic market for better prices, netting a total profit of over NT$600 million per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cost of Centrum will not be lowered: Wyeth

TEXT.P: Following questions about the high price of its multivitamin, Centrum, the manufacturer Wyeth Taiwan Corp. said Wednesday that it does not plan to lower the price.
According to a local newspaper Wednesday, people in Taiwan pay a much higher price for Centrum than in other countries, although it is manufactured locally.

Wyeth's Taiwan-manufactured Centrum is priced at around NT$600 (US$19.8) for 120 tablets -- NT$5 per tablet -- while Centrum made by Wyeth's parent company in the U.S. costs only US$17.67 for 523 tablets, or NT$1.6 per tablet.
In response to the report, Ye Man-qing, director of the consumer healthcare department of Wyeth, said that the high price is a consequence of different manufacturing processes and regulations.
She indicated that Taiwan's humid climate has to be taken into consideration in the manufacturing process, and that the multivitamin is classified as a drug under Department of Health regulations.
In order to lower the unit price, Wyeth Taiwan, which is based in Hsinchu County in northern Taiwan, is presenting the multivitamin in packages of 310 tablets, Ye added.
"Although the U.S. dollar has depreciated, the cost of raw materials on the international market have continued to rise, " she said. "So far, we have no plans to slash the price (of the product)."

DOC.HEADLINE: Certification system for vegetarian food to be announced in July

TEXT.P: The Food Sanitation Bureau of the Department of Health (DOH) announced Wednesday that it will present a certification system for vegetarian food in mid-May for promulgation in July, if there are no objections from the public.

The bureau's planned move is in response to a call by Kuomintang Legislator Lin Hong-chi, who urged DOH head Hou Sheng-mao to develop a certification system to protect the rights of Taiwan's more than 2 million vegetarians.

Officials at the Food Sanitation Bureau said that after consulting more than 100 civic organizations, including religious groups and food production companies, the bureau has decided to group vegetarian foods into five classes -- purely vegetarian, vegetarian with eggs, vegetarian with dairy products, vegetarian with eggs and dairy products, and vegetarian without animal content.

The system will be implemented in July if there are no objections from the public, and law enforcement agencies will begin to impose fines for violations with effect from July 2009, they said, adding that those who infringe on the regulations by mislabeling their products could face fines of between NT$40,000 and NT$200,000.

A package marked "purely vegetarian" means that its does not contain animal products or any of the five spices that are considered as non-vegetarian -- onion, garlic, Chinese chives, shallot and leek -- because, according to Buddhist scriptures, they excite the senses.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 hopefuls to draw lots for DPP chairmanship election Thursday

TEXT.P: The three candidates running for the chairmanship of the soon-to-be-opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will draw lots Thursday to determine the order in which their names will appear on the ballots, party sources said Wednesday.

Outgoing DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh made the announcement after the party's Central Executive Committee (CEC) approved the candidacy of the three hopefuls -- Trong Chai, a veteran legislator, Koo Kuang-min, a former presidential adviser, and former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen -- for the race.
According to Hsieh, consultations for the three hopefuls to avoid a showdown in the vote slated for May 18 have not yet broken off.
"I have met with all three candidates and have come to a fair understanding of their views on the party chairman race, " Hsieh told reporters after a CEC meeting.

"While all three are willing to negotiate a way out, none of them are willing to accept the proposal that two of them withdraw from the race voluntarily right now," Hsieh said, adding that all of them agreed to take part in a policy debate or a televised platform presentation.

Hsieh said the party has tentatively decided to organize a televised debate May 10 for the three candidates to present their policy visions. A changeover ceremony for outgoing and incoming chairman will take place May 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: All three party head hopefuls to stay in the race: DPP chairman

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that he has talked with all three hopefuls for the party leadership and they have agreed to debates but none of them were willing to bow out of the race.

Hsieh said the three -- former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen, and two other pro- independence diehards, DPP Legislator Trong Chai and former presidential adviser Koo Kuan-min -- have "a strong sense of mission in running for the post, and none of them can be persuaded to quit."

Hsieh, who was urged by DPP members to mediate among the hopefuls to produce one candidate and avoid further splintering within the floundering party after its latest setback in the March 22 presidential election, said he will follow the party system to start the coordination process.
"It will start with debates and a presentation of platforms, " Hsieh said, adding that if this fails, then there will be a vote by party members on May 18.

DPP Central Standing Committee member Wu Ping-jeo said "the result of the election is already sealed." Although he did not elaborate, it is widely believed that Tsai, with her clean image, has the broadest support within the party.

Wu's colleague Yang Chiu-hsin, who also serves as Kaohsiung magistrate, supported this view, saying that "an election is unnecessary, " and that Hsieh should start the coordination process immediately.
Chai has vowed to "stick to his guns to the last."

During a meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee, members also passed a proposal to scrap the controversial DPP polls that exclude "pan-blue" voters, meaning supporters of the soon-to-be-ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and its allies.
Although the proposal will not have to be sent to a DPP provisional congress May 4 for approval, the congress could still overturn the decision if it disagrees with the idea.

The DPP's national election primaries are comprised of two parts -- a party member vote and public opinion polls, with the vote accounting for 30 percent, while the polls account for the remaining 70 percent. The DPP, under then-party chairman Yu Shyi-kun, changed the format of its polls by screening out the "pan- blue" voters in October 2006, and the new poll format has been only used once since then -- during the DPP legislative primary in May 2007.

Many within the DPP have cited the controversial poll as the main reason for the party's drubbing in the Jan. 12 legislative elections in which the DPP garnered only 27 seats compared to the KMT's 81 seats in the 113-seat legislature.
The recent "China fever" whipped up by the ongoing visit of Chinese real estate tycoons was also a topic at Wednesday's meeting.
Hsieh said that he will meet with seven chiefs of local governments run by the DPP next week to discuss the party's stance on the matter.

Hsieh said that he favors investments by the tycoons in factory and other manufacturing sectors, but would oppose any speculating by the Chinese in real estate, as this would hurt the public, the wage-earners and the youths.

He said that the DPP will respect the incoming KMT administration's pursuit of high economic growth figures, but added that he thinks it should also address the issues of inflation, bubble economy and over reliance on China, and especially social justice and fair distribution of resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. wants discussion with Taiwan after Ma's inauguration: official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 23 (CNA) 04/24/08 11:10:22 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States is looking forward to discussing with the authorities in Taiwan issues concerning relations between the two countries after the inauguration of Taiwan's President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, U.S. Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte said Wednesday.
Negroponte made the remarks in response to a question by Taiwanese media regarding the possibility of Washington approving Ma's request to visit the United States before his May 20 inauguration.
Negroponte extended his congratulations to Ma on his election and said the U.S. government looks forward to sending a delegation to Taiwan to attend Ma's inauguration ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 24, or the 19th day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1731: Daniel Defoe, British journalist, novelist and economist, dies at the age of 71. His works include "Robinson Crusoe" and "Moll Flanders."
1800: The U.S. Congress votes to set up a congressional library.
1898: Spain declares war on the United States after receiving a U.S. ultimatum to pull out of Cuba.
1919: Chan Tien-yu, a railway pioneer in China, dies in Hankou at the age of 59.
1941: Hsieh Chin-yuan, a Chinese hero in the War of Resistance Against Japan, is assassinated at the age of 37. The ROC Army regimental commander led his "800 Brave Fighters" in a heroic battle against invading Japanese troops at a warehouse in Shanghai. Shanghai was captured by the Japanese on Nov. 11, 1937, after three months of fierce fighting.
1946: The ROC government postpones the convention of the National Assembly set for May 6, 1946.
1948: Lin Hsien-tang is appointed head of the Historical Research Commission of Taiwan Province.
1955: The Bandung Conference ends with five Asian states condemning colonialism by both the West and the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: All three party head hopefuls to stay in the race: DPP chairman

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that he has talked with all three hopefuls for the party leadership and they have agreed to debates but none of them were willing to bow out of the race.

Hsieh said the three -- former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen, and two other pro- independence diehards, DPP Legislator Trong Chai and former presidential adviser Koo Kuan-min -- have "a strong sense of mission in running for the post, and none of them can be persuaded to quit."

Hsieh, who was urged by DPP members to mediate among the hopefuls to produce one candidate and avoid further splintering within the floundering party after its latest setback in the March 22 presidential election, said he will follow the party system to start the coordination process.
"It will start with debates and a presentation of platforms, " Hsieh said, adding that if this fails, then there will be a vote by party members on May 18.

DPP Central Standing Committee member Wu Ping-jeo said "the result of the election is already sealed." Although he did not elaborate, it is widely believed that Tsai, with her clean image, has the broadest support within the party.

Wu's colleague Yang Chiu-hsin, who also serves as Kaohsiung magistrate, supported this view, saying that "an election is unnecessary, " and that Hsieh should start the coordination process immediately.
Chai has vowed to "stick to his guns to the last."

During a meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee, members also passed a proposal to scrap the controversial DPP polls that exclude "pan-blue" voters, meaning supporters of the soon-to-be-ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and its allies.
Although the proposal will not have to be sent to a DPP provisional congress May 4 for approval, the congress could still overturn the decision if it disagrees with the idea.

The DPP's national election primaries are comprised of two parts -- a party member vote and public opinion polls, with the vote accounting for 30 percent, while the polls account for the remaining 70 percent. The DPP, under then-party chairman Yu Shyi-kun, changed the format of its polls by screening out the "pan- blue" voters in October 2006, and the new poll format has been only used once since then -- during the DPP legislative primary in May 2007.

Many within the DPP have cited the controversial poll as the main reason for the party's drubbing in the Jan. 12 legislative elections in which the DPP garnered only 27 seats compared to the KMT's 81 seats in the 113-seat legislature.
The recent "China fever" whipped up by the ongoing visit of Chinese real estate tycoons was also a topic at Wednesday's meeting.
Hsieh said that he will meet with seven chiefs of local governments run by the DPP next week to discuss the party's stance on the matter.

Hsieh said that he favors investments by the tycoons in factory and other manufacturing sectors, but would oppose any speculating by the Chinese in real estate, as this would hurt the public, the wage-earners and the youths.

He said that the DPP will respect the incoming KMT administration's pursuit of high economic growth figures, but added that he thinks it should also address the issues of inflation, bubble economy and over reliance on China, and especially social justice and fair distribution of resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Certification system for vegetarian food to be announced in July

TEXT.P: The Food Sanitation Bureau of the Department of Health (DOH) announced Wednesday that it will present a certification system for vegetarian food in mid-May for promulgation in July, if there are no objections from the public.

The bureau's planned move is in response to a call by Kuomintang Legislator Lin Hong-chi, who urged DOH head Hou Sheng-mao to develop a certification system to protect the rights of Taiwan's more than 2 million vegetarians.

Officials at the Food Sanitation Bureau said that after consulting more than 100 civic organizations, including religious groups and food production companies, the bureau has decided to group vegetarian foods into five classes -- purely vegetarian, vegetarian with eggs, vegetarian with dairy products, vegetarian with eggs and dairy products, and vegetarian without animal content.

The system will be implemented in July if there are no objections from the public, and law enforcement agencies will begin to impose fines for violations with effect from July 2009, they said, adding that those who infringe on the regulations by mislabeling their products could face fines of between NT$40,000 and NT$200,000.

A package marked "purely vegetarian" means that its does not contain animal products or any of the five spices that are considered as non-vegetarian -- onion, garlic, Chinese chives, shallot and leek -- because, according to Buddhist scriptures, they excite the senses.

DOC.HEADLINE: First bluefin tuna caught this season sold for NT$1.72 million
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, April 23 (CNA) 04/24/08 12:54:26 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The first bluefin tuna caught this season was sold for NT$1.73 million (US$57,055) in an auction at Donggang harbor Wednesday.
The auction, presided over by Council of Agriculture head Su Jia-chyuan and Pintung County Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung, marked the beginning of the 2008 annual Pingtung Bluefin Tuna Cultural Festival.
The giant tuna fish, weighing 247 kilograms, was caught by a fishing boat named Wan Yi Tsai which is registered with the Liouciou Islet off Pingtung County.

To qualify as the first tuna caught for the season, the fish must be a northern bluefin tuna -- a species native to both the western and eastern Atlantic Ocean. Its weight must exceed 180 kilograms, and the fish must have been alive when it was removed from the water.
The catch must be reported immediately to the nearest fishery radio station and must be shipped back to Donggong harbor by boat.

Three restaurants bid for the fish in the auction. Hung Shih-yang, owner of the Hong Hai Sea Food Restaurant near the Kaohsiung International Airport, said he was happy to win the bid for his four-month old business by offering a price of NT$7,000 per kilogram.
The Pingtung County Government has hosted the annual Bluefin Tuna Cultural Festival since 2001, with the aim of stimulating the local economy.

Owners of fishing boats operating out of Donggang used to export most of their tuna catch to Japan, but since the county government launched the Bluefin Tuna Cultural Festival, they now prefer to sell their fish on the domestic market for better prices, netting a total profit of over NT$600 million per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: President commends Taiwanese winners of Bakery World Cup

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has paid tribute to the Taiwanese winners of the 2008 Bakery World Cup, saying they are Taiwan's glory in an alternative way, as they have put Taiwan on the world stage in a new field of endeavor.
Chen congratulated the winners on behalf of the government and people of Taiwan during a meeting with them at the Presidential Office Wednesday.
Chen said the three bakers had won the prizes because of their creativity, intelligence, efforts and persistence, and that they serve as inspiration for other Taiwanese people seeking success.
The three-member Taiwanese team won second place in the competition, behind the French team and ahead of Italy which placed the third.

Like Taiwan-born New York Yankees pitcher Chien-ming Wang, Taiwanese ultra- marathon runner Lin Yi-chieh, and female tennis players Chuang Chia-jung and Chan Yung-jan, Chen said they had made Taiwan shine in the world.

The bakers, Wu Pao-chun, Tsao Chih-hsiung and Wen Shih-cheng, presented the panel of judges with home-style bread of a special flavor. They spent eight hours making the bread from mainly flour, dried longan and rum, and shaping them to feature the traditional Chinese lion and dragon dance motif.
In addition, Wu and Tsao each won an individual prize in the European style and artistic baking categories.
The triennial competition was held in Paris from March 30-April 1, drawing a total of 12 national teams.

Chen praised Wu for striving to achieve his goals despite the fact that he grew up in a poor family and suffered many setbacks in life. The president said that, following Wu's example, each person can find his or her own stage and seize the opportunity to make a name for himself or herself in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumers' group warns of safety problems at libraries, museums

TEXT.P: Sixty-percent of public libraries and museums inspected recently by the Consumers' Foundation had at least four safety problems, including, in one case, fire extinguishers that had expired seven years ago, according to the results of the evaluation released Thursday.

The inspection was conducted March 10-31 of 90 public libraries and museums around Taiwan -- 19 in northern Taiwan, 23 in central Taiwan, 24 in southern Taiwan's Tainan region, 13 in the Kaohsiung and Pingtung areas and 11 in the eastern areas of Hualien and Taitung. A total of 14 safety criteria were evaluated.
The Juesui Township Library in Hualien County was rated as the most unsafe library, failing in nine of the areas examined.
Also at the bottom of the list were the Kaohsiung Municipal Library's Hsinhsing branch and the Shoufeng Township Library in Hualien County, both having failed to meet seven of the safety criteria.
The Old Fort of An-Ping Museum in Tainan City, which failed six of the foundation's safety standards, was rated as the third-most unsafe building on the list.
It was found that 40 percent of the libraries and museums inspected were either not equipped with any emergency escape mechanisms or had failed to make such equipment easily identifiable.
Also, 38 percent of libraries and museums failed to display emergency escape maps on every floor, and in 19 percent of the buildings, the fire hydrants were blocked by other objects.

At 9 percent of libraries and museums, the pressure setting on the fire extinguishers was incorrect, while at 10 percent of the buildings, the fire extinguishers had passed their expiry date. In one case, at the Juesui Township Library, fire extinguishers that had expired on June 1, 2001 had not been replaced.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high but closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 18.16 points, or 0.2 percent, to close at 8,990.33.

Finishing lower for the third consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 9,025.47 and fluctuated between 9,064.15 and 8,974.79 during the day's session. A total of 5.2 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$149.6 billion (US$4.94 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 2 percent. Cement stocks increased 1.6 percent, banking and financial shares rose 0.7 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares were up 0.1 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1.1 percent. Machinery and electronics shares dropped 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues fell 0.6 percent, and construction issues shed 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,395 to 906, with 335 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$11.12 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT director's presence at war games harms national dignity: KMT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers blasted the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government Thursday over the appearance of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei Office Director Stephen Young at the "Yushan war games, " saying that Taiwan's national dignity had been compromised.

"Our national dignity was harmed with the appearance of the American representative in Taiwan and officials from the U.S. State Department at the military exercises," said KMT Legislator Lin Yu-fang after an interpellation session held by the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee.
"It is extremely disturbing. I have never seen anything like that," he said.

According to a China Times' report, AIT Director Stephen Young and several officials from the U.S. State Department were invited to observe the Yushan war games, which simulated a strike by the Chinese military on the east coast of Taiwan.

During Tuesday's exercise, Young and several U.S. officials arrived at the Hengshan Command Center -- a top-secret war command and control center -- and left with President Chen Shui-bian and other high-ranking officials on a military personnel carrier, simulating evacuation under attack, the report stated. It also noted that it was an unprecedented decision to allow foreign representatives to take part in national war games.

The government, however, stressed that the U.S. officials "did not directly take part in the exercise, but rather closely observed the simulated evacuation of foreign civilians under Chinese missile fire."

In response to KMT Legislator Lin's question on whether the MOFA knew in advance that Young would be at the war games, MOFA's Deputy Minister Yang Tzu-pao said he did not know about it beforehand as the MOFA is not in charge of the exercise.

Hsueh Mei-yu, deputy director-general of the MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, said that she had not received any notification that.U.S. State Department officials would be part of the military exercises.

But she disclosed that in response to a MOFA inquiry, the National Security Council had said that based on the principles of reciprocity and bilateral cooperation, the U.S. officials were granted "limited observation" status by the government and they did not participate in any meetings related to dealing with national crises.

Lin contended that there was no rationale for Young's presence at the military exercise, as Taiwan is neither a vassal state nor a colony of the U.S. He also noted that Taiwan's representative to the U.S. will never be invited to participate in any U.S. war games.

"No matter how close the two countries are, boundaries should be set when national secrets are involved, " Lin said. He however conceded that the issue could be viewed in the light of the U.S. highly valuing its relations with Taiwan and wishing to have more substantial contact with high-level officials.
Asked about the U.S. officials' participation in the military exercises, the AIT on Thursday declined to comment on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Supreme Court acquits president-elect of embezzlement charge

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Supreme Court upheld Thursday a high court ruling that acquitted President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of a graft charge.
The latest acquittal was a final decision, with no chance of appeals, and came a month after Ma scored a decisive victory in the March 22 presidential election.

Ma of the opposition Kuomintang was first indicted in February 2007 for allegedly diverting NT$11.18 million (US$372,666) from his special allowance fund into his private account while serving as Taipei mayor between 1998 and 2006.
The Taiwan High Court acquitted him last December on the grounds that it was a common practice for officials to use their discretionary funds without providing detailed accounting.
However, prosecutors appealed the ruling in the Supreme Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: Physical punishment decreasing in Taiwan schools: MOE

TEXT.P: Fewer students are being physically punished in schools since the government legally banned corporal punishment in December 2006, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Thursday.

The change was reflected in the results of a survey conducted among junior high students every two months by the ministry, which revealed that the percentage of students physically punished in schools dropped from 42.5 percent in 2006 to 29.2 percent in 2007, said Jenny Ko of the MOE's Student Affairs Committee. She noted that this means 70.8 percent of students had not been physically punished in 2007.

During the first two months of 2008, the percentage of students who received physical punishment in schools declined further to 15.8 percent, marking a decrease of 12 percentage points compared with the 27.7 percent recorded during the same period in 2007, Ko said.
The results mean 84.2 percent of students had not been physically punished at school during the January-February 2008 period, compared to 72.3 percent during the same period in 2007, she pointed out.

By region, Chiayi City, Changhua County and Pingtung County are the three localities where physical punishment is the most prevalent, with approximately 30 percent of junior high school students being physically punished at school during the first two months of 2008, according to the results.
Hsichu City had the best record at 5.2 percent, followed by Kaohsiung County at 5.6 percent and Taipei City at 5.8 percent, the survey indicated.
The latest survey was carried out in January and February, with responses from 109,171 junior high school students around Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: China-based Taiwanese firms need help: experts

TEXT.P: Facing a tougher investment environment in China and fiercer competition globally, Taiwanese manufacturers in mainland China need the Taiwanese and Chinese government to work together to help them cope with the changes, said a panel of experts Thursday.
The experts were speaking at a seminar held by the Institution for National Policy Research (INPR) to discuss the future of Taiwanese companies that are based in China.

Many of them called for local policy makers from both sides to take measures, including helping the businesses relocate from China's coastal cities to inland provinces where the cost of labor and production is cheaper. Experts also urged the governments to help the businesses upgrade their operations to switch to value-added and brand productions.

The institution's president Tien Hung-mao, while addressing the seminar, and noted that President-elect Ma Ying-joeus pledge to form closer ties with China could create a mechanism for normalized cross-strait economic relations.
The era of more open cross-strait negotiations is about to come,said Tien, a former foreign minister of Taiwan.
However, he cited the recent global economic slowdown and stricter China investment regulations as major obstacles Taiwanese enterprises need to tackle.

Following China's launch of a new labor contract law that favors workers and the takeaway of tax incentives for Taiwanese investments in the coastal cities in 2007, Taiwanese businesses fear that lower profitability could force them to relocate their businesses to Vietnam or inland China.

The U.S. subprime mortgage crisis, according to economists, could prolong its negative effect on the global economy in the next year, Tien added, noting that the international crisis is something the governments across the Taiwan Strait must work out hand-in-hand.
Experts also advised Taiwan's government to help re-position Taiwanese businesses in the global market.

Policy makers must find new roles for Taiwanese industries in China, said Wea Chi-lin, chairman of Top Taiwan VI Venture Capital Co., adding that the cross- strait political stalemate must not become the issue blocking bilateral economic exchanges. Wea said by allowing more cross-strait trade such as financial exchanges, local government could help Taiwan to find an alternative roleVas a logistics center for the worlds business people.
Taiwan should make amendments in regulations governing cross-strait trade to improve local logistics for Chinese businesses and tourists,said Wea.

He added that this could also help to boost the service export sector, in which Taiwan ranked 26 in the world, a relatively weak performance compared with its merchandise export sector, which ranked 16.

Touching on the recent visit to Taiwan by a group of wealthy property developers and business people from China, Wea said Chinese investment in the local real estate market at this early stage should be kept to commercial zones, instead of residential areas.
The prices for residential areas concern the welfare of the public; therefore the investment should be taken slowly, he explained.

Liu Cheng-tao, a Chinese scholar from Tsinghua University in Beijing, called for the establishment of a cross-strait negotiation mechanism to safeguard bilateral investment and trade, and to promote speedier transportation for high-skilled workers so they can easily travel between the two sides.
When cross-strait direct flights are established, Taiwans specialists could fly to China in the morning and back in the evening,he added.
Liu also said Taiwan's government should lift some of the bans on cross-strait trade, and provide support to help manufacturers upgrade their operations to raise their ability to compete.
The Chinese government meanwhile could also take on further measures to protect and boost Taiwanese business, experts said.
The Beijing government should give Taiwanese companies more time to adjust to the new regulations, said Kao Chang, a scholar of National Dong Hwa University,

He was referring to the new labor contract law and the cancelling of tax incentives, the latter of which hikes Taiwanese enterprises' income tax from the average 12 percent to 25 percent in the coastal cities.
He added that China should also improve its service efficiency to better support the manufacturers to base and maintain their business operations in the mainland.

Many Taiwanese companies are worrying about the change in China sinvestment environment,Kao said, indicating fears of a trend of potential shutdowns in operations by Taiwanese manufacturers in the following year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education ministry to earmark NT$3.7 billion to promote reading

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education plans to provide NT$3.7 billion (US$122 million) in three years to help improve the reading environment at public libraries around the country, according to a ministry official.

The project to help the country's public libraries upgrade their facilities, replenish their stocks of books and hold readings is aimed at creating a more friendly reading environment nationwide, according to Chu Nan-hsien, director of the ministry's Department of Social Education.
"We hope children would enjoy going to libraries as much as going to McDonald's," Chu said.

Chu made the announcement Wednesday at a ceremony during which the ministry signed an agreement with the National Central Library and representatives from every city and county around the island to promote reading.
The ceremony was held to coincide with World Book and Copyright Day, April 23, designated by the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) to encourage reading.
Meanwhile, representatives of various sectors of Taiwan's society also presented the ministry with a statement expressing their hope that the country's reading environment would be improved.

To mark the day, the Taipei City Government called a news conference Wednesday to promote a four-year reading program for students at elementary schools around the country with the objective of helping children to develop early reading habits.

At the event, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin told a story to school children and donated to National Education Radio a collection of selected stories created by students, for broadcast on the station's bedtime programs.

Kang Tzung-hu, deputy director of the city's Department of Education, said that according to a survey, on average, each student in the city had read more than 30 books per year since the city government launched a reading program in 2003.

The city government has been holding a series of activities, including story- telling and reading contests, to promote reading among school children, Kang said. The activities complement an exhibition that is being held until April 27 at the Taipei Public Library to showcase students' stories, plays, and other types of creative writing, he said.
