DOC.HEADLINE: 20,000 migrant workers per year waiting for new jobs: civic group

TEXT.P: A civic group criticized the government Thursday over what it called a misguided policy that has resulted in 20,000 migrant workers per year waiting in Taiwan for new jobs.

The Migrants Empowerment Network in Taiwan (MENT) denounced the Council of Labor Affairs' (CLA) decision to allow the so-called "3D (dirty, dangerous, difficult) industries" to hire workers directly from abroad.

According to the MENT, since the policy was put into effect in October 2007, about 13,600 new workers have been recruited from abroad, leaving thousands of migrant workers already in Taiwan in financial straits.

Most of these migrant workers, who live in hospices operated by the government or non-governmental organizations, were forced to leave their original jobs either because they were ill treated by previous employers, or the factories they worked for were shut down, the MENT stated in a press release.

If these workers, most of whom are from Southeast Asian countries, do not find employment within two months, they will be repatriated, according to the statement. Some of them may run away and try to find new jobs, illegal in most cases, before they could be sent back to their countries, as have no money to repay their debts, it added.
Most migrant workers in Taiwan start out with debts, on average, of US$7,000 to US$8,000 in employment brokerage fees, the MENT stated.

"If these workers cannot find new employers, they would have no choice but run away or return to their home countries heavily in debt," said Wang Wen-shiou, director of the Labor Concern Center of the Presbyterian Church in Taiwan, in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Asked in a telephone interview why Taiwan employers prefer to import new workers rather than hire those already in Taiwan, Ku Yu-ling, chairperson of the Taiwan International Workers' Association, explained that "brokers make more profit by bringing in new workers from abroad than by placing those already in Taiwan."

"I would never be able to repay my debts if I do not find a job in Taiwan," said a 25-year-old Vietnamese woman, who first came to Taiwan to work in a factory. When the factory closed down, she was transferred to a Catholic center where she is now awaiting new employment.
Another Vietnamese immigrant said he was fired from his job because he refused to work 16 hours a day for an eight-hour wage.

"We are asking the CLA to change the regulations on hiring foreign workers, and to encourage Taiwanese employers to give priority to people who are already in the country and waiting for new jobs," Wang said.
According to the Ministry of the Interior, about 358,000 foreigners work in Taiwan, most of whom are from Indonesia, Thailand and the Philippines.
The MENT is an umbrella organization of about a dozen of non-governmental organizations nationwide that advocate migrant worker rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA cautious but optimistic over diplomatic ties with Paraguay

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it remains "cautious but optimistic" over diplomatic relations with Paraguay, despite the recent election to power of President Fernando Lugo, who is known to favor ties with China.

The diplomatic ties between Taiwan and the South American country were the focus at Thursday's interpellation session of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee, in light of the newly elected Paraguayan President Fernando Lugo's statement, before and after the election, that he wants to establish closer relations with China.

MOFA's Deputy Minister Yang Tzu-pao said that Lugo will have to take into consideration the long lasting Taiwan-Paraguay friendship, as well matters such as national development and international cooperation now that Lugo is to lead Paraguay..

"The ministry is cautious but optimistic about the bilateral relations between Taiwan and Paraguay," Yang said, stressing that the ministry remains in close contact with Paraguay and is optimistic that bilateral relations will remain in place.
Lugo, a former Roman Catholic bishop, won a historic victory in Paraguay's presidential election, ending more than six decades of rule by the central-right Colorado Party.

After his meeting with Lugo Monday, Taiwan's ambassador to Paraguay David Hu told the Paraguayan media that Taiwan will not mind Paraguay developing relations with any country, as long as the diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Paraguay are not jeopardized.

Describing "dual recognition" of Taiwan and China as a degradation of bilateral relations, Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Huang-liang contended that it will be a "cul-de-sac" situation for Taiwan.
He added that Taiwan-Paraguay relations will serve as barometer for relations between Taiwan and China.
"It would be a huge slap in the face for Taiwan if diplomatic ties with Paraguay are severed after President-elect Ma Ying-jeou takes office May 20," Tsai said.

"China will never allow dual recognition, " said DPP Legislator Twu Shiing-jer. "Even if dual recognition is an option, Taiwan should try it out first with countries with which it has no diplomatic relations," he added.

In response, Yang said "I would prefer to call such links 'parallel relationships' rather than 'double recognition, '" meaning that Taiwan is happy to see Paraguay establish relations with other countries but hopes that such relations will not put the existing bilateral relations between Taiwan and Paraguay at risk.
Paraguay and Taiwan forged diplomatic relations in 1957 and Paraguay is Taiwan's only remaining diplomatic ally in South America.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.004 to close at NT$30.297.
A total of US$1.328 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$30.323 and closed the day's low of NT$30.268.

DOC.HEADLINE: Koo Chen-fu a model, an institution and a legend: President-elect

TEXT.P: The discussions, known as the "Koo-Wang Talks," were held in Singapore and Shanghai in 1993 and 1998, respectively, between Ku, then chairman of Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Wang, then director of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

The timing of the film's screening, just before Ma's inauguration, is widely seen as significant, as Ma has promised to improve cross-strait relations which have been frozen since the Democratic Progress Party came to power in 2000.

Koo played a "rare role" in Taiwan's history, from the time of Japanese colonialism to cross-strait negotiations, Ma said at the the film premiere and commemoration ceremony which was organized by the Koo Foundation.

Ma noted that during the two Koo-Wang talks, the discussions focused not only on important cross-strait issues, but also on cultural topics such as Chinese opera, which he said had made the dialogue even more meaningful.
"I hope the screening of the documentary on Koo will help give rise to more figures (like him) in our society," Ma said.
Vice President-elect Vincent Siew said that considering Koo's achievements in business, diplomacy, and cross-strait negotiations, his passing was indeed a big loss to all Taiwanese people.
"Koo will live forever in the memory of people around the world," Siew said, expressing the view that Koo had devoted his life and contributed all that he could to the welfare of the nation.

Chiang Pin-kung, the chairman-designate of the SEF, pledged to follow in Koo's footsteps and said that his work will not only impact on Taiwan's future development but also on the welfare of all Taiwan's people.
"Taiwan's national interests and the welfare of the Taiwanese people will be my priorities," he pledged.

According to Vivien Koo, Koo's eldest daughter and the producer of the 150-minute documentary, the commemorative piece portrays her father's life through photographs, video clips, and interviews with the people with whom he had contact, including former Singapore President Lee Kuan Yew, and former U.S. President George H. W. Bush.
She said the documentary will be broadcast from Friday to Sunday between 9:00 p.m. and 10:00 p.m. on Channel 52.

Koo's widow, Cecilia, disclosed that up to the time he died he was still worrying about Taiwan's future. With tears in her eyes, she related that Koo kept emphasizing that "our country must never be split up."

Koo, a respected leader in business circles in Taiwan and founder of Taiwan's Economic Council offices in the United States, Japan, Korea, and most of those in Europe, was born on Jan. 6 1917 in Taipei. He died of renal cancer on Jan 3, 2005 at the age of 87.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmakers call for cancellation of aboriginal envoy assignment

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators expressed strong opposition Thursday to the outgoing Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's assignment of a new representative, an indigenous official, to Fiji less than one month before it hands over the reins of power.
Yohani Isqaqavut, formerly minister in charge of the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples, has been appointed as Taiwan's top representative in the South Pacific nation since late March.
He is the first aboriginal official to be appointed by Taiwan to serve as the country's top representative in another nation.
Yohani is poised to fill the vacancy left by Kuo Shih-nan, who was re-assigned to Singapore as Taiwan's representative in that city state in September 2007.
Yohani is reportedly scheduled to assume his post on May 5.

Expressing opposition to the assignment, KMT Legislators Ting Shou-chung and Kung Wen-chi, who is himself an aborigine, said at a session at the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Defense Affairs Committee that Yohani's assignment during a governmental transition period is unacceptable to the KMT administration, which is set to take office May 20.
Ting said that since Yohani has yet to assume his post, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs should halt his assignment.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, from the KMT, and the KMT administration are slated to be inaugurated on May 20. If Yohani were to assume his new post in Fiji on May 5, he would probably be recalled after May 20, making him a Taiwan representative in Fiji for only 15 days, Kung said.

The foreign ministry had announced plans to appoint an indigenous representative to Fiji before the presidential election and had previously said the move was aimed at helping Taiwan strengthen ties with Pacific Island nations, many of which have aboriginal populations which share a common heritage, language and customs with Taiwan's indigenous tribes.

Kung, however, described Yohani's assignment as a joke. He said it is ridiculous that President Chen Shui-bian appointed the first aboriginal envoy a month before his second term is about to expire, despite having been in the office for nearly eight years.

Noting that there are many capable aboriginal talent who could be assigned abroad to represent Taiwan, Kung added that "I hope President Ma will see to it that a more trustworthy and representative aboriginal envoy will be assigned abroad soon after he is inaugurated."

DOC.HEADLINE: 5.9 magnitude earthquake strikes off Taiwan's east coast
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, eastern Taiwan, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/08 18:46:30 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 5.9 on the Richter scale struck off Taiwan's east coast early Thursday, sending people scrambling from their beds, but no injuries have been reported.

According to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) , the moderate earthquake occurred at 2:28 a.m., with the epicenter located at 37.7 kilometers southeast of the CWB's Chengkung seismic station in Taitung at a depth of 10.1 km under the ocean.
The tremor could be felt across Taiwan, registering magnitude 4 on Green Island off Taitung, magnitude 3 in Taitung city, and magnitude 2 or less in other cities and counties.
The earthquake was followed by 11 aftershocks of magnitude 4.3 to 5.4 in a six- hour period between 2:52 a.m. and 9:04 a.m, with some of them lasting more than 10 seconds, according to the CWB.
Chen Jung-hua, an senior officer on duty at the Fire Bureau of Taitung County, told the CNA via telephone that the bureau has received no reports of damage or injuries as a result of the earthquakes.

DOC.HEADLINE: President has not yet received invitation to Ma's inauguration

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has not yet received an invitation to attend President- elect Ma Ying-jeou's inauguration on May 20, the Presidential Office said Thursday in a statement.

The statement was issued to discount a cable TV report earlier in the day that Chen will not attend Ma's inaugural ceremony because he has been scheduled to take part in a volunteer service on May 20.
"The report was not factual as the president has not yet received an invitation," the statement said.
The statement didn't elaborate on whether Chen would attend Ma's inauguration ceremony at the Taipei Arena if he receives an invitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT mum on who will lead delegation to Ma's inauguration

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) declined Thursday to say whether former White House Chief of Staff Andrew Card would lead a U.S. delegation to attend President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's inauguration ceremony next month.

Speaking with Taiwanese media, U.S. Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte said Wednesday in Washington D.C. that the U.S. government looks forward to sending a delegation to Taiwan to attend Ma's inauguration ceremony. Local media in Taipei reported that Card has been designated to lead the delegation.
An AIT staff in Taipei told a Central News Agency reporter that "it will make an official announcement as soon as it (the envoy) is confirmed."

The status of the U.S. envoy, his relationship with the president in particular, is often seen as an important indicator of how Washington views bilateral relations between Taiwan and the United States. Since the U.S. reacted positively to Ma's election, Taipei has high hopes that the Bush administration would dispatch a high-level delegate to Ma's inauguration on May 20.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs also avoided making direct comments on the issue. Spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said at a regular press briefing that the ministry has a general idea about the list, but due to diplomatic practices, details will have to be announced by the U.S.

"The U.S. government probably will not send administration officials for the ceremony as there is no diplomatic relations between the two countries, " she said. "As to who will lead the delegation, I believe the U.S. government has its own position."

The AIT is a non-profit, private corporation established shortly after the U.S. government changed its diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China on Jan. 1, 1979. The AIT Taipei office, however, functions as a de facto embassy and its head is also treated as the de facto top U.S. representative to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Supreme Court clears President-elect of corruption charges

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou was acquitted Thursday by the Supreme Court of charges of corruption and breach of trust related to the use of a special allowance fund during his term as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.
Closing a case that had undergone two appellate proceedings, the highest-level of Taiwan's judiciary affirmed the Taiwan High Court's ruling that Ma was not guilty of the charges.

The Supreme Court said the appeal by the prosecution against the ruling was invalid because it failed to present any argument against claims by the Taiwan High Court that Ma had no intention of embezzling from the fund and did not obtain the money through "fraudulent means."

Ma was indicted on Feb. 13, 2007 on charges of embezzling NT$11.17 million from a special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use during his mayoral terms. The funds in question were set aside to cover the mayor's job-related expenses.

The prosecutor in charge of the case claimed that Ma transferred half of the public funds to his personal bank account every month, keeping that portion which was not used as his personal income, with the knowledge that they were public funds.

The prosecutor claimed that although the government's regulations allow the mayor to use half of the fund by simply signing a receipt instead of providing vouchers to account for his spending, the money should go towards job-related spending and that any remaining funds should be returned to the government's coffers.

However, the Taipei District Court acquitted Ma of the charges on Aug. 14, 2007, saying that half of the special allowance funds paid to executives holding public office are meant as salary subsidies and that as soon as the payment is made, the receivers are authorized to spend the money at their discretion, without having to provide proof of spending.
The practice is established by the Cabinet and should not be considered "fraudulent," according to the district court's verdict.
The prosecution appealed the ruling to the Taiwan High Court on Aug. 17, but the ruling was affirmed by the high court on Dec. 28.
Undeterred, the prosecution appealed the ruling to the Supreme Court on Jan. 9.

While the Supreme Court maintained the high court ruling that Ma was not guilty, it, however, expressed its disagreement with claims by the district court and high court that half of the special allowance funds are meant as some kind of "salary subsidies."
Although no proof of spending is required, this part of the funds must also be used on job-related expenses, according to the Supreme Court's verdict.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourists, charter flights to come on stream in July: VP-elect
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/08 19:45:48 (By M. C. Yang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Technical matters concerning Taiwan's opening to Chinese tourists and the launch of weekend charter flights across the Taiwan Strait will be put in place from July 4 as planned, Japan's Yomiuri Shimbun quoted Taiwan's president-elect Vicente Siew as saying Thursday.
Siew made the remarks to the Japanese newspaper in an exclusive interview Wednesday in Taipei.
Siew was cited as saying that technical details related to the two issues have all been settled, and that the only thing that is required now is "political judgment."

Asked why he was confident that such a step could be taken, Siew replied that he had obtained a "visionary answer" from Chinese President Hu Jintao on April 12 during the Boao Forum for Asia 2008 in China's Hainan Province.

Regarding the establishment of direct cross-strait charter flights on weekends, Siew said the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and the Kaohsiung International Airport will offer the charter service in the initial stages, and that a total of seven airports around Taiwan will be allowed to operate the business in the future.
Siew said that the Chinese side did not mention the sensitive "one-China" issue during the forum, according to the report.

Siew reiterated that Taiwan would welcome Chinese investment in large-scale development projects over the coming eight years, which will involve NT$4 trillion (US$132 million) worth of investment funds. He also said that in line with the decision to allow more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan, it is also necessary to allow exchange of the Chinese yuan.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and his running mate Siew of the Kuomintang (KMT) , throughout their campaign, vowed to build closer trade and economic ties with China after they assume office on May 20, promising measures such as permitting Chinese tourists to sightsee in Taiwan, implementing direct cross-strait charter flights and allowing full convertibility of the Chinese currency in Taiwan on an incremental basis.

The Taipei-based Central Bank of Republic of China has forecast that the demand for the exchange of the Chinese yuan and Taiwan dollar will grow at home, as the incoming KMT administration is set to allow the entry of Chinese tourists from early July -- up to 3,000 per day in the initial stages and increasing to 10,000 per day eventually.
Currently, Taiwan residents are allowed to exchange Chinese yuan only on the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu, in amounts of less than 20,000 yuan.

The Ma-Siew ticket gained a record high of 7.65 million votes, or 58 percent of the total, in the March 22 presidential election, beating the ruling Democratic Progressive Party ticket by a wide margin of 2.21 million votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to promote 'green technology' among large manufacturers

TEXT.P: The government plans to launch a new strategy to encourage local manufacturers to adopt "green technology" for mass production and waste recycling, in order to reduce cost and pollution, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials announced Thursday.
The strategy is part of an initiative -- dubbed "industrial pollution prevention and control services" -- which has been operated by the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) since 1983.
The initiative has helped hundreds of local small and medium size enterprises upgrade their technology and equipment to use less toxic materials and emit less pollutants.
According to the bureau, by using green technology under the new plan, the manufacturers will reduce both the cost of waste management and the expenditures of energy, water, and raw materials.

Yang Po-keng, deputy chief of the bureau's Sustainable Development Division, said that the bureau has redirected this year's strategy from focusing on individual companies to a group of core and satellite factories in an attempt to increase efficiency.

Yang said bureau staffers will first choose a core factory to help improve its production technology and equipment, and the factory will later become a "pilot factory" that encourages its satellite factories to establish their own eco- friendly measures in compliance with the central factory's.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF chairman vows to resign before May 20

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Hung Chi-chang said Thursday that he will submit his resignation before May 20, when the new government is slated to take office.

Hung made the announcement in a written statement following news reports that Chiang Pin-kung, who has been named by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to head the semi-official foundation, intends to invite Hung to serve as his deputy.

In his statement, Hung said he will bow out of government service along with his party, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which lost to the KMT in the March 22 presidential election after eight years in office.
Hung said he will resign in the interest of upholding the "spirit of party politics and defending political ethics and code of conduct."
The DPP candidate, Frank Hsieh, lost the March 22 presidential election to Ma by a margin of 17 percent.

Regarding the importance of cross-Taiwan Strait affairs, Hung said that he will continue to keep track of cross-strait exchanges in various fields following his departure from the SEF post, and will monitor the incoming KMT government's performance in implementing its planned policies.
On the issue of Chiang's reported offer, Hung said that he had not been contacted by Chiang regarding any position, and he expressed regret over what he called the false reports in the media.
The SEF was founded in 1990 to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Hong Kong residents arrested for smuggling heroin

TEXT.P: Two Hong Kong residents were arrested Thursday in the central city of Taichung for smuggling heroin into Taiwan, a spokesman for the Investigation Bureau's mobile unit in central Taiwan said.
The spokesman said the two men from Hong Kong, identified as Wong Ming-ho and Ren Pei-zhen, were referred to the Miaoli Prosecutors Office for prosecution.

According to the spokesman, the mobile unit received tips from abroad that two drug "mules" from Hong Kong who swallowed a considerable amount of heroin balls were hiding in a hotel in Taichung, waiting for instruction from their employer to deliver the drug.

Agents of the unit, supported by local military police and officers of the Coast Guard Administration, checked the guest lists of all hotels in Taichung and found that Wong and Ren matched the descriptions provided by the information source.
The law enforcement agents searched their hotel room and discovered 140 heroin balls wrapped in plastic, weighing 770 grams, with a street value of NT$15 million (US$495,375).

According to the spokesman, Wong confessed that he had smuggled heroin into Taiwan several times by swallowing the drug wrapped in little plastic balls, but he said he does not know who the recipient of the drug is this time.
The two suspects will face charges of violating the Narcotics Endangerment Prevention Act and the Act for the Control and Punishment of Smuggling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei deputy mayor steps down

TEXT.P: Taipei Deputy Mayor Wu Hsiu-kuang resigned Thursday after he was reported by a weekly magazine to be under suspicion of having taken bribes from an arms dealer.
Mayor Hau Lung-bin gave the nod to Wu's resignation earlier in the day, saying that he respects the decision.
Hau said he believes Wu is "not a greedy man" and that so far, he has not been found to have done anything illegal during his stint as deputy mayor of Taiwan's capital.
"Now that the media seem to have judged him unfavorably, Wu will probably have to clear his name via the judicial process, " the mayor added.

Confirming his resignation at a news conference, Wu denied any wrongdoing in taking "research fees" from an arms dealing company known by its Chinese name as Lai Fu Trading Co. for research that he did for the company between July 2005 and June 2006, when he was a professor teaching at a university in Taipei.

Nevertheless, Wu said, he decided to step down from the deputy mayorship as media reports -- following a Wednesday report by Next Magazine run by the tabloid Apple Daily -- have already damaged his reputation and tarnished the image of the Taipei city government.
"TV reports following the Next Magazine report have not only blurred the truth but are also poised to affect the operations of the city government," Wu said.

Wu said he was a professor at Shih Hsin University between August 2004 and July 2006 and that he did a research project for Lai Fu between July 2005 and June 2006, receiving a little more than NT$1 million (US$33,000) for his work that took less than one year.

Wu said the research he did for Lai Fu was related to his own field of research but had nothing to do with city government affairs, since he was not working in public office between July 2005 and June 2006.

Meanwhile, Hsu Chia-ching, a Taipei city councilor of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , went to the Taipei District Prosecutors Office Thursday to accuse Wu of having received bribes from an arms dealer.
Hsu accused Wu of "having continuously taken bribes from Lai Fu since November 2004" and asked prosecutors to launch a probe into the case.

Earlier that day, the DPP caucus in the Taipei City Council demanded that Wu be suspended from his job temporarily and that he explain himself to society to clear up doubts about the graft allegations.
Claiming that Wu has "probably violated" the "revolving door act" regulating public functionaries, the DPP caucus members said he should be investigated by the judiciary.

Lai Fu Trading Co. is believed to be the largest and oldest arms dealer in Taiwan. It is also carrying out work on the construction of the Taipei MRT Neihu Line as a subcontractor, among other projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fate of Suhua expressway depends on new administration: NEEB

TEXT.P: The Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) Committee for the Suao-Hualien expressway will meet Friday, but regardless of any conclusion reached at the meeting, the fate of the controversial expressway will be in the hands of the new administration, the National Expressway Engineering Bureau (NEEB) said Thursday.

The NEEB, which is responsible for the construction of the proposed expressway on Taiwan's east coast, admitted Thursday that "the meeting is just a legal procedure and will not deprive the new government of its right to make any decisions on the matter."

The EIA committee is scheduled to be convened Friday, probably for the last time before the opposition KMT assumes power May 20. During the last review meeting in early April, Chang Ching-sen, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development and one of the official EIA committee members, abruptly suggested that a final decision on the plan should be left to the new Cabinet.
The NEEB explained later that Chang was acting on his own and had not received any orders from the Executive Yuan to change the policy.

Trying to downplay the controversy over the expressway, the NEEB said in a statement that if the construction plan is passed, it will take about three or four months to amend the project in accordance with the changes of budget and members' suggestions before sending it to the Executive Yuan for final approval, so the new government's right to make a final decision will remain intact.

"For us, the worst case scenario would be having to supply more documentation, " said Chen Ze-ren, chief of the planning section of the NEEB, adding that an EIA report on the expressway was passed in 2000 and that the report to be reviewed Friday is only a differences analysis.
Asked about Friday's meeting, members of the committee declined to express their opinions before the outcome.

"Whether or not the plan is passed tomorrow, what really matters is the attitude of the new government and the new minister of the Environmental Protection Administration," said Li Han-lin, one of the heads of a student association that is against the expressway.

The 86-km expressway is designed to boost the economy of the eastern part of the island, one of the country's poorest regions. It was one of the campaign promises of President Chen Shui-bian in 2000. Approved in 2002 by the Executive Yuan, it was suspended in 2003 over environmental concerns.
Environmentalists say the construction, estimated to take about 10 years to complete, is not the best solution to improving the region's immediate transportation needs.
They also say the construction will have a negative impact on the ecology of the area and might be dangerous because of its proximity to geological fault lines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education ministry to help remote schools build swimming pools

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will subsidize remote schools in building swimming pools to teach students how to swim and to reduce the disparity in educational resources between urban and rural areas, an education official said Thursday.

Public junior high and elementary schools that have over 2,000 students and have a suitable space for building a swimming pool may submit their applications to the ministry before April 30 for subsidies up to NT$8 million (US$263,168), the official said.

The subsidy program started last year, and the MOE has provided assistance to 10 schools including those in offshore Lienchiang County, as well as Taipei, Taoyuan and Miaoli counties in northern Taiwan, said the official at the MOE's Department of Physical Education.
The official said the difference in the number of swimming pools in urban and rural areas exemplifies the uneven allocation of educational resources in Taiwan.

No junior high school in eastern Taiwan's Taitung County, northern Taiwan's Miaoli County and the offshore Penghu County has a swimming pool, according to a study conducted in 2005. On the other hand, there were 33 swimming pools in Taipei City's junior high schools, of which, 28 were indoor heated ones.
The statistics were compiled by the National Taiwan Normal University's Physical Education Research and Development Center.

As for elementary schools, a study by the university in the same year found that there was no swimming pool in elementary schools in Hsinchu County in northern Taiwan, Yunlin and Chiayi counties in southern Taiwan, and offshore Penghu and Kinmen counties. Meanwhile, there were 47 swimming pools in Taipei City's elementary schools, of which, 33 were indoor heated.

The number of swimming pools in Taipei City's elementary schools is about 40 percent of the total number of Taiwan's elementary schools, the official said, adding that some schools have already received subsidies.

One of the schools that have received the financial assistance, Luofu Elementary School, located in Taoyuan County's Fuhsing township will have its new swimming pool completed by the end of this year, the school's principal Bayes Lohsin said.

The township has no swimming pools, and the school's students, mostly aborigines, would play with water in brooks or streams, which is dangerous since they never had the opportunity to learn to swim, Bayes said.
He added that when the swimming pool is completed, not only students, but also township residents, will be able to benefit from the facility.

DOC.HEADLINE: `92 Consensus' remains controversial in Koo documentary

TEXT.P: One of the legacies of the late Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu is the so-called "92 Consensus" he is purported to have forged, but the existence of any such consensus remains controversial in Taiwanese society, according to a documentary released Thursday in commemoration of Koo and his achievements.

The definition of the so-called "92 Consensus" -- that "there is only one China with different interpretations as to the meaning of one China" -- is discussed in depth in the commemorative piece produced by the Koo Foundation on the politicians involved in the talks between Koo and his Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
The discussions were held in Singapore and Shanghai in 1993 and 1998, respectively.

According to the documentary, the conclusion of a meeting held in Hong Kong in October 1992 prior to the first Koo-Wang talks was defined as the "92 Consensus" by Su Chi, a former chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and a former Kuomintang legislator who has been widely tipped to take the position of secretary-general of the National Security Council after President-elect Ma Ying-jeou takes office May 20.
However, former President Lee Teng-hui says in an interview portrayed in the film that "this is a consensus without a real consensus... China wants us to accept one China."
"There is no `one China, '" Lee says, adding that "one is the People's Republic of China, and ours is the Republic China."

Shi Hwei-yow, then-secretary-general of the SEF, who participated in the Hong Kong meeting, also says in the film that no conclusion was reached at the Hong Kong meeting and that the "one China, different interpretations" idea was in fact dreamed up by the media.
The discrepancy between China and Taiwan on the meaning of "one China" later led to different interpretations by each side "which was accepted by China," said Shi.
Ma, a former vice chairman of the MAC also says in the documentary that "there is no need to further negotiate on how to interpret `one China.'"

The documentary, portraying Koo's life through photographs, video clips and interviews with the people with whom he had contact, including former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew and former U.S. President George H.W. Bush, will be broadcast from Friday to Sunday between 9 p.m. and 10 p.m.
Koo was born Jan. 6, 1917 in Taipei and died of renal cancer Jan. 3, 2005 at the age of 88.

DOC.HEADLINE: Enzyme related to liver cancer discovered

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwanese biologists have reported in a recent scientific paper that an enzyme that exists in both humans and rodents is closely related to the development of liver cancer, indicating a new pathway for drug and therapy development, academic sources said Thursday.

Activity of the enzyme -- glycine N-methyltransferase (GNMT) -- might also provide an explanation to why females have a lower incidence of liver cancer, or hepatocellular carcinoma, while the risk among males is sometimes three to eight times higher.

Chen Yi-ming, a professor at the Department of Microbiology of National Yang- Ming University, said that their study found that the expression of GNMT-related genes is suppressed in patients with liver cancer, indicating that the cancer is prone to develop when the enzyme and related genes fail to function normally.
Chen also noted that the GNMT-related gene expression is also found to be eight times stronger in females than in males, suggesting that males are more susceptible to liver cancer.

The findings have already been proved in experiments on rodents and published by medical journal Hepatology late last year. Another study published by the journal in its April issue reconfirms the correlation between the enzyme and liver cancer development.

During animal testing, the team used GNMT-knockout mice as subjects and found that at 11 weeks after birth, the mice developed syndromes of hepatomegaly and hypermethioninemia, and had significantly higher levels of both serum alanine aminotransferase and hepatic S- adenosylmethionine -- all of which can lead to the development of hepatocellular carcinoma.
The tests also found that 100 percent of the female mice without GNMT develop liver cancer, while the onset ratio is only 50 percent among male GNMT- knockout mice.
Chen said the figures suggest that GNMT does inhibit cancer development and indicate that females without GNMT protection are more susceptible to liver cancer.

DOC.HEADLINE: `After school cramming' top concern of youths: poll

TEXT.P: The results of a recent survey on youth policy conducted by the Cabinet-level National Youth Commission (NYC) reveal that most of the youths surveyed would prefer to have no after-school cram studies, the NYC reported Thursday.
The issue was chosen by the country's youths in an online poll authorized by the NYC in a bid to tap the thinking of the younger generation, their likes and dislikes.

The youths' choice of "no more after-school cramming" as their favorite policy indicates that the younger generation crave more leisure and relaxation time in addition to the time they spend studying, NYC officials said.
"My future is not just a dream" was another issue chosen as the No. 2 concern of the youths who responded to the survey, according to NYC officials.

Officials from the NYC, the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Education and the Cabinet-level Department of Health, as well as several civic groups championing youths rights and interests, met for a seminar recently aimed at gaining deeper understanding of young people so as to work out a more pragmatic youth policy.
Twenty issues were available in the survey for the youths to list in order of importance, with sex and relationship issues also close to the head of the list, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan industry leaders urge cooperation between cross-strait firms

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industry leaders Thursday called for closer cooperation between Taiwan's and China's technological and financial sectors, urging them to follow in the footsteps of manufacturing-based industries.

Leaders of Taiwan's industries were speaking at a one-day seminar held by the Institution for National Policy Research (INPR) , where they discussed the choices Taiwanese companies based in China have in face of a slowdown of major economies around the world and a potential strengthening of ties across the Taiwan Strait.

They called on Taiwan's government to take the initiative to relax current regulations on cross-strait trade, while urging the Beijing government to help Taiwanese companies maintain their business operations in China.

"The restrictions will only handicap China-based Taiwanese industries and slow their development, " said Preston W. Chen, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), who added that cross-strait industry collaboration is "inevitable."
Chen urged Taiwan's incoming administration to remove the 40 percent investment cap that restricts most companies from expanding investment in China.
"Investing in China does not mean selling our motherland, " he said, adding that he is confident that money earned in China would return to Taiwan.

Both sides' industries could work hand-in-hand to form stronger economic entities, Chen said, adding that local governments must not fight against the trend of integration among companies across the strait.
Chen added that more and more Taiwanese investment are upgrading into technology-concentrated sectors instead of labor-intensive, low-end manufacturers.

Schive Chi, a Shin Hsin University professor who is regarded as a potential cabinet member in the incoming administration of President-elect Ma Ying- jeou, echoed Chen by saying a win-win situation will be achieved at the establishment of cross-strait direct sea and air links.

"The speedier transportation will help build Taiwan as an Asia- Pacific Regional Operations Center that focuses on Taiwan's location advantage, manufacturing strength and rich cultural assets, " he explained.
Schive also said Taiwan, by being the more financially developed side, could become a regional financial center in the Asia Pacific.

This corresponded with what was said earlier in the seminar by the other panelists, who stressed closer financial cooperation might help form a shield for Taiwan and China to weather the current U.S. subprime mortgage crisis that has clamped global finance.
Chou Wu-tien, the chairman of the Taipei Foundation of Finance, encouraged Taiwanese investors to explore the Chinese market for financial services.

"By establishing cooperation between stock exchanges and opening bilateral investment in banking businesses, both sides could together form a healthier mechanism safeguarding investment and money transactions," Chou said.

He added that the Chinese government should also return the favor by giving Taiwan industries credit for helping it to become more modernized in the finance sector, while putting forward more incentives to attract Taiwanese investment.

Chang Bin-shi, the chief representative of Polaris Securities in Shanghai, said through setting up bank branches bilaterally, cross- strait financial markets could be integrated to create more financial services, such as capital financing across the strait.
"To integrate in a steady and gradual pace, these financial institutions could take the first step by holding seminars and forums to gain mutual understanding," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Merger of two major KTV chains fails due to FTC opposition

TEXT.P: The Fair Trade Commission (FTC) rejected again Thursday a planned merger of the two largest KTV chains in Taiwan, out of concern that the merger would damage the market competition mechanism.

The FTC imposed the ruling after the Holiday KTV and Cashbox KTV filed an appeal with the Executive Yuan's Petition and Appeals Committee against an earlier FTC ruling in 2007 prohibiting the two from merging with each other based on the reason that the combination would lead to a monopoly.
In February this year, the petition committee came up with a ruling that revoked the FTC's 2007 ruling and instructed the FTC to review the case once again.
In 2003, the two KTV operators filed the merger plan, which would have allowed the businesses to hold a joint market share of 41 percent at that time.
The FTC agreed to the merger, but with a proviso that banned the two from blocking emerging competitors through sheer market scale.
However, the merger did not go forward because they failed to reach an agreement on cooperation and the two operators withdrew the project in 2004.

Two years later, Holiday and Cashbox re-submitted the merger plan after settling the disagreement, but this time they failed to win the FTC's approval, which reasoned that the two businesses' combined market share had increased since their first merger attempt.

Holiday and Cashbox together not only control over half of the KTV service market in Taiwan, their combined market share has reached 90 percent in Taipei, the FTC said in its ruling against the merger last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 620,000 poor people to benefit from government rice program

TEXT.P: At least 620,000 underprivileged people will benefit from a government charity program aimed at giving rice to the poor to help them cope with rising food prices, government officials in charge of the program said Thursday.

Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang and Huang Yu-tsai, director-general of the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), made the announcement at a news conference held at the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).

In line with an instruction issued last month by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and a decision by an Executive Yuan product price stabilization task force, the MOI and the COA will launch the program that will run May 1-15, using government- stored rice, Lee said.

According to Lee, the program will target low income families, poor elderly people, disadvantaged women and mentally challenged citizens, with the combined number of eligible people estimated at more than 620,000.
Each member in the low-income families included in the program will be entitled to receive 10 kg of free rice, while members of medium-low-income families will receive 5 kg.
As much as 8,427 metric tons of rice will be distributed if two such charity operations are conducted this year, with the other distribution program slated for the end of this year, Lee said.

Non-profit welfare organizations, including Fokuangshan Temple and World Vision Taiwan, as well as city and county authorities, will join the efforts to transport the grain to local residents in need, he noted, adding that transportation fees will be shared by central and local governments.
According to Huang, the rice to be given away is from the newly harvested crop which has been quarantined within the last year.
Compared to the government's stockpiles of about 308,000 metric tons of rice, the amount to be used for the charity program is just a small portion, he said.
The government has always maintained a safe level of rice stocks -- some 310,000 tons at present -- to provide a buffer against shortages or emergencies.

Compared to other Asian countries, however, Taiwan's rice prices have remained relatively stable, having increased by only 13 percent this year, Huang said last week at a legislative committee meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public's IT competitiveness above average: poll

TEXT.P: The international information competitiveness of people in Taiwan is considered by many locals to be just above average, according to the results of a poll released Thursday.
Sixty eight was the average score given by 1,083 poll respondents on local people's computer competitiveness on a 100 point scale, the results show.
The respondents were aged over 20 and had at least a junior high school education.

At a press conference organized by the poll commissioner, Business Weekly, a major business magazine in Taiwan, Microsoft Taiwan Corp. General Manager David Tsai described the score as " not surprising."
Although Taiwan is a major producer of computer hardware, people's ability to use software and their creativity are the keys to competitiveness, Tsai said.
Unfortunately, Taiwan does less well on software than it does on hardware, he pointed out.

In addition, the poll shows a disparity in the computer skills of different age groups, with nearly 90 percent of the respondents in their 20s saying they know how to use computers but only 53 percent of the respondents in their 50s describing themselves as computer literate and 47 percent in the same age group saying they do not have computer skills.
In the age group of 60 and above, a mere 28 percent said they know how to use computers, the poll results show.
In general, 30 percent of the respondents who have received basic compulsory education were found to lack computer skills, which indicates a huge digital gap.
To bridge the gap, Ho Fei-peng, chief CEO of PC home Publication Group, suggested at the press conference that computer classes, already offered by many schools, should be made compulsory.

For his part, Lu Hsi-peng, a professor at National Taiwan University of Science and Technology's Department of Information Management, said that computer skills determine a person's competitiveness in the job market and called on young people to enhance their information abilities.

The poll also discovered that respondents with higher academic degrees are more likely to feel that women are less computer literate than men, while 35 percent of the women polled said that females do not know how to use computers, a view expressed by only 25 percent of the male respondents.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect calm over acquittal: spokesman

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou expressed no sentiment Thursday after learning that the Supreme Court had acquitted him of corruption charges, a spokesman for Ma said later that day.

Ma, who will be sworn in as president May 20, had no particular expectations over the outcome of his case as he had faith in his innocence and looked forward to justice being done, Lo Chih-chiang said.

The Supreme Court affirmed an earlier High Court ruling that Ma was not guilty of charges of corruption and breach of trust over his use of a special allowance fund during his term as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC hands out tree saplings to combat global warming

TEXT.P: CPC Corp., Taiwan (CPC) launched a campaign at its Zhonglun petrol station in Taipei City Thursday to hand out free tree saplings to people filling up their vehicle tanks, as part of efforts to help combat global warming, according to CPC President Wenent P. Pan.
CPC -- a state-owned oil refiner -- launched the campaign also with the aim of helping to promote environmental sustainability in Taiwan, Pan said.
The company also offered a limited number of free saplings Thursday to its customers at 200 of its petrol stations around the country, Pan said.

Pan, Miaoli County Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung and several Miaoli County councilors planted a total of 2,400 saplings at a CPC -owned natural gas treatment plant in the Tunghsiao area in the northern county of Miaoli a day earlier. The activity was part of the company's efforts to help fight global warming which has led climate change in recent years.
Under a CPC program of action, a total of 12,000 saplings will be planted at its refineries around the country before the end of May.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholar threatened for warning of housing bubble in Taipei

TEXT.P: An academic who warned of a property bubble in Taipei in a letter to a newspaper editor April 12 has received a threatening letter telling him to "shut up" or a contract killer will be sent to murder him.
The Wenshan police station in Taipei confirmed Thursday that its officers were investigating the intimidation case.

Chang Chin-oh, a professor of land economics at National Chengchi University, warned property hunters in his letter to the editor that the property market in Taipei is showing signs of a bubble and that although the market is no longer flourishing, housing prices are still being maintained at abnormally high levels.
After the letter was published, Chang received a computer-printed letter from the "Greater China Real Estate Alliance," warning him to keep his mouth shut or his life will be in danger.
Chang told reporters that the caution he set forth in his letter to the editor was well-intentioned, as he felt he has a duty to share the findings of his research with the public.
He added that 38 percent of the property prices offered on the Taipei market are bubble prices, although they have not yet reached bursting point.
"People should be careful when trying to buy property and the banks should avoid over-extending credit when granting mortgages," Chang said.
Benson Liao, president of Evertrust Rehouse Co., said that while there is a price bubble problem with presold housing units in Taipei, the property market in Taiwan otherwise appears normal.

Liao agreed that the abnormally high prices of presold housing units will have an impact on the overall property market because they tend to make buyers of second-hand houses believe that the prices they paid were relatively cheap while in actual fact the prices had already been jacked up.

DOC.HEADLINE: President invites Paraguay president-elect to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian congratulated Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo by telephone Thursday on his historic election victory and invited him to visit Taiwan at his convenience, according to a Presidential Office statement.
Lugo's victory made him the first opposition figure to capture Paraguay's presidency in more than six decades.

In their phone conversations, Chen lauded the Paraguayan people for their maturity in greeting their country's first transition of power between different political parties in more than 60 years with calm rationality, the Presidential Office statement said.
Noting that Taiwan and Paraguay have forged diplomatic ties for 51 years, Chen said both countries have benefited from their long-term cooperative projects in various fields.

"We look forward to further reinforcing bilateral exchanges and cooperation with the incoming Paraguayan government, " Chen said, adding that the two countries should begin negotiations on an expanded framework for future cooperation.
Chen, who will step down May 20 after ending his two four-year terms, told Lugo that he will continue assisting in boosting friendship between the two countries after his retirement.

For his part, Lugo, a former Roman Catholic bishop, expressed his gratitude for Taiwan's long-term financial aid and technological assistance to his country. He also expressed hopes that the two countries will further strengthen their cooperation.

Paraguay is Taiwan's sole remaining diplomatic ally in South America. As Lugo had said during his presidential campaign that he would like to establish ties with China if he won the election, speculations have been rife in recent days that the longstanding Taiwan-Paraguayan official ties may be at stake after Lugo's inauguration later this year.

Nevertheless, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Yang Tzu-pao said at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting earlier in the day that the ministry is "cautious but optimistic" about relations with Paraguay, stressing that the ministry has remained in close and extensive contact with various Paraguay quarters and will do its best to maintain bilateral ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Friday.
The weighted price index was up 62.97 points at 9,053.30 on a turnover of NT$3.79 billion (US$125.09 million) at the open. The index lost 18.16 points, or 0.2 percent, to close at 8,990.33 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$30.327 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.030 from Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 25, or the 20th day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1744: Anders Celsius, Swedish astronomer who devised the Celsius thermometer in 1742, dies at the age of 43.
1859: Under the direction of Ferdinand de Lesseps, the construction of the Suez Canal begins. It was opened 10 years later on Nov. 16, 1869.
1874: Gulielmo Marconi, Italian engineer and inventor who shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics, is born. He became the first person to transmit long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean, doing so in 1901.
1895: Lai Ho, a noted Chinese writer of anti-Japanese literature, is born in Changhua.
1898: The U.S. Congress passes a joint resolution declaring war on Spain over events in Cuba.
1912: The Chung Kuo Ke Ming Tung Meng Hui is reorganized as the Kuomintang.
1925: Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg becomes the second president of Germany's postwar Weimar Republic.
1927: After the national government in Nanking announces a purification movement that will entail the expulsion of Chinese communists, the communists meet in Wuhan and decide to set up a Soviet-style regime.
1930: Construction of the Chianan irrigation canal is completed.
1941: The United States and the United Kingdom sign in Washington separate but parallel agreements with China for stabilizing China's national currency. The United States provides US$50 million and the United Kingdom provides five million pounds.
1942: An accident at a coal mine in Benxi, located within Japanese-occupied China, kills 1,549 workers in the world's worst mining disaster.
1945: Delegates of 45 nations, including the Republic of China, meet in San Francisco, Calif., to organize the United Nations.
1946: The foreign ministers of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France meet in Paris to discuss the signing of a peace treaty with Germany.
1956: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with Haiti.
1962: The United States successfully launches its Saturn rocket, the largest in the world at the time.
1965: President Lyndon B. Johnson sends U.S. troops to the Dominican Republic to maintain order after rebel followers of Juan Bosch try to seize power.
1971: T.V. Soong, former president of the Executive Yuan, dies in San Francisco at the age of 77.
1971: Some 200,000 anti-Vietnam War protesters march on Washington, D.C.
1973: The Chinese National Baseball Team leaves Taipei for Manila to take part in the 10th Asian Cup Tournament.
1974: Portugal's dictator Marcelo Caetano is overthrown in a bloodless military coup. He surrenders to Gen. Antonio de Spinola, who becomes president the following month.
1982: The last Israeli soldier leaves Sinai, ending 15 years of Israeli occupation of the peninsula.
1989: Japanese Prime Minister Noburu Takeshita announces plans to resign over the "Recruit Affair," the country's biggest political scandal in decades.
1994: Tsutomu Hata becomes Japan's 51st prime minister.
1995 Ginger Rogers, American dancer and actress, dies at the age of 83. She is particularly noted for her partnership with Fred Astaire in several motion pictures, including "Swing Time," "Flying Down to Rio" and "Roberta."
2000: President Lee Teng-hui bestows a medal on Steve Forbes, president and CEO of U.S.-based Forbes Magazine, in recognition of his long-term contribution to the promotion of exchanges and coorperation between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that the ROC government will take steps to develop the island into a "competitive country with a knowledge-based economy" within five years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The ancient Emperor Shun was perhaps the one man who successfully carried out the principle of no-government. For what need is there really for what is called government? A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct, and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker welcomes possible U.S. choice for inauguration

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng expressed welcome Friday to the notion that U.S. President George W. Bush might send former White House Chief of Staff Andrew Card to attend President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's May 20 inauguration ceremony.

Wang said that if unconfirmed local media speculation that Card has been assigned to lead a U.S. delegation to attend Ma's inaugural ceremony proves to be true, it would indicate that Bush attaches great significance to the matter and that Ma's taking the helm of Taiwan is highly acceptable to the United States.

"It seems to me that the U.S. has not previously sent anyone of higher status than Card to Taiwan for official functions," Wang said, adding that "although Card is retired, it is widely known that he has maintained very close ties with Bush."

"Card's delegation to Taiwan would indicate that the Bush administration is highly positive toward Ma's election, particularly after both Taiwan and the U.S. have squandered years in the work of consolidating bilateral relations," Wang said.
"I'm sure the U.S. will keenly expect Taiwan's new government to show goodwill so as to help improve U.S.-Taiwan relations," he added.

Barbara J. Schrage, managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , declined a day earlier to confirm who will be appointed to lead the U.S. delegation to Taiwan for the presidential inauguration, adding that the AIT will not make an official announcement until the envoy is confirmed.

The AIT is a non-profit, private corporation established shortly after the U.S. government shifted its diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China Jan. 1, 1979. The AIT Taipei office, however, functions as a de facto embassy and its head is also treated as the de facto top U.S. representative to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Environmental committee nixes Suao-Hualien freeway

TEXT.P: A committee under the Environmental Protection Administration refused to approve Friday a plan for the construction of a freeway between Suao and Hualien in eastern Taiwan.
The Environmental Impact Assessment Committee decided after a meeting to turn back the controversial plan to its initiator -- the Ministry of Transportation and Communications -- for reconsideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislation needed to solve special allowance controversy: speaker

TEXT.P: Legislation is needed to solve once and for all controversy involving government officials' use of special allowance funds, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin- pyng said Friday.

Wang echoed remarks made by State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming a day earlier calling for the Legislative Yuan to amend relevant statutes so that the use of special allowance funds can be regulated more clearly and efficiently.
"Only by enacting legislation can the issue be addressed once and for all on a comprehensive basis," Wang said.
Wang called for the country not to waste any more time and resources on an issue that is part and parcel of the history of the Republic of China government.

Chen and Wang made the calls after President-elect Ma Ying-jeou was acquitted Thursday by the Supreme Court of charges of corruption and breach of trust related to his use of a special allowance fund during his term as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.
Closing a case that had undergone two appellate proceedings, the highest-level of Taiwan's judiciary upheld a Taiwan High Court ruling that Ma was not guilty of the charges.

"Basically, the judges believe that this case was the result of human error by Ma's secretary and had nothing to do with Ma, " said Chang Chun-tsung, a spokesman for the Supreme Court's Criminal Department, upon the final court ruling announcement.

The Supreme Court said an appeal by the prosecution against the ruling was invalid because it failed to present any argument against claims by the Taiwan High Court that Ma had no intention of embezzling from the fund and did not obtain the money through "fraudulent means."

Ma was indicted Feb. 13, 2007 on charges of embezzling NT$11.17 million from a special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use during his mayoral terms. The funds in question were set aside to cover the mayor's job- related expenses.

While the Supreme Court upheld the High Court ruling, it expressed its disagreement with claims by the District Court and High Court that half of the special allowance funds are meant to be some kind of "salary subsidy."
Although no proof of spending is required, this portion of the funds must also be used only for job-related expenses, according to the Supreme Court verdict.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate 2 puts on `Spring in the Hospital' show in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: The Cloud Gate 2 dance troupe put on a performance at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Friday as part of its ongoing round-the-island "Spring in the Hospital Tour."

The dance troupe, an offshoot of the world renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theatre composed of the group's younger dancers, performed selected parts of "Tantalus, " "Love Story, " and other of its famous productions, to the delight of patients and hospital staff.
The Chang Gung Hospital performance was the third on the troupe's tour which kicked off April 10 at Taichung Hospital in central Taiwan.
The tour, which will include 19 performances at 18 hospitals around the island, is being staged to mark the Cloud Gate Dance Theatre's 35th anniversary.

In addition to the tour, the troupe has also authorized those hospitals to show DVDs of some of its classic dance productions, including "Body, Sound" and "Water Moon, " to bring some joy into the lives of those less fortunate.
The Cloud Gate 2 dance troupe was established in 1999 to work with and help develop young dancers and choreographers.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP to donate computers, books to kindergarten on Lanyu

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu Thursday offered to donate books and two computers to a kindergarten in Taiwan's outlying Lanyu, or Orchid Island, to provide better educational resources to the island's children.
Lan An Kindergarten -- the island's only preschool, was a stop on a visit by Lu to the island.
Lu was making her third visit to Lanyu to acquire a better understanding of the island's development and its problems related to a shortage of resources.
The island, lying 45 km off the coast of the eastern county of Taitung, is home to the Tao aboriginal tribe. About 90 percent of the island's more-than 3,000 residents are Tao.
The tribe has an oceanic culture and is well-known for its flying fish festival in the spring, its unique houses of stone and wood, and the wooden boats used by the Tao for fishing and transport.
Lu visited a Tao boatyard, traditional Tao houses and a cultural museum, accompanied by Lanyu township office personnel.

In addition to discussing education, she also exchanged views about the township's development in terms of medical facilities, basic infrastructure and cultural conservation with the township office staff.
The visit could be Lu's last during her tenure, which will come to an end when opposition Kuomintang President-elect Ma Ying-jeou is inaugurated May 20.

She asked Lanyu residents to continue to pass their thoughts about township affairs and their needs to the Taitung county government and aboriginal legislators in order to let the central government hear their voices.
She also encouraged local residents to create more dishes or products with flying fish, the island's specialty, to make the area's produce more widely known.

Moreover, she expressed hope that the "Blue Highway" -- a project that promotes marine transport along Taiwan's coastline and outlying islands -- will have its route extend to Lanyu this September under a new government push to boost local tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mandatory retirement age raised to 65

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Labor Standards Act Friday that raises the mandatory retirement age from 60 to 65.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Yang Chiung-ying, a lead sponsor of the bill, said the amendment is aimed at protecting the work rights of elderly workers in light of the fact that the average life expectancy in Taiwan has increased to 76, with more older workers staying in the labor force rather than retiring.
Expected to benefit immediately from the amendment are workers aged between 60 and 65, who presently number approximately 94,000, Yang noted.
Meanwhile, there are approximately 30,000 workers aged above 65 in the labor force, Yang added.

On claims by critics that the amendment will mainly benefit elderly workers in state-owned enterprises, Yang said such claims are unfair because state-owned enterprise workers aged over 60 are usually allowed to continue working as long as they obtain the approval of the relevant authorities.
Under these circumstances, elderly workers in private businesses are those most in need of protection, she said, adding that those who wish to retire early can still do so voluntarily.

DOC.HEADLINE: Huge number of baby horseshoe crabs released on Kinmen

TEXT.P: Some 350,000 baby Asian horseshoe crabs bred in captivity were released into the wild off Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen Friday in an effort to conserve the "living fossil" species.

Kinmen County Deputy Magistrate Yang Chung-chuan led over 200 Kinmen residents and students in the activity held on the shore of the Chienkung islet and the mouth of the Wuchiang creek under the guidance of officials from the Kinmen Aquaculture Research Institute (KARI), which bred the crabs.
According to KARI researchers, the horseshoe crab is nearly extinct in waters surrounding Taiwan proper but is occasionally seen near the Penghu Island group and on the west coast of Taiwan proper.

The seas around Kinmen are among the horseshoe crab's major natural habitats, but even there, its numbers have declined in recent years as a result of industrial and urban development, the researchers said.

The sharp dwindling of the crab population prompted KARI to zone an 800-hectare coastal area near Kuningtou as Kinmen's horseshoe crab conservation district in 1999 in the hope that its population could be preserved.

In addition, since 2006 KARI has staged annual releases of baby horseshoe crabs to help accelerate the natural replenshiment of the species, known as a "living fossil" because it has evolved little in its 400 million years of existence.
With a distinctive domed carapace shaped like a horseshoe and a stiff pointed tail, the Asian horseshoe crab, or "tachypleus tridentatus, " is known as one of Taiwan's few "living fossil" species.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan kicks off Global Youth Service Day activities

TEXT.P: Taiwan, in concert with more than 100 other countries, kicked off a series of community improvement activities in support of Global Youth Service Day (GYSD) Friday, an annual international event that mobilizes young people to meet the needs of their communities through volunteerism.

This year, the event organizer for the local activities -- the National Youth Commission (NYC) -- has devised a number of events under the theme of "Young Volunteers Love the Globe, " in an attempt to promote awareness of issues related to global climate change, according to a NYC spokesman.
GYSD, launched in 1988 in the United States, mobilizes young people in more than 100 countries worldwide in service projects for a three-day run every April.

The 2008 GYSD, which will run through April 27, involves millions of young people who will address important community issues through service and service- learning projects. The goal of the event is to call on young people to change the world and build better lives for all.
As part of Taiwan's GYSD activities, the National Youth Commission plans to solicit 500 ideas and projects from the country's young people that could help deter global warming, the spokesman said.
The ideas and projects will be shared at a G8 work camp slated to be held in August in Hokkaido, Japan, the spokesman added.

Meanwhile, the commission's central, Nantou and eastern branches also rolled out various community service projects, while the Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission, the Ministry of Education, and a number of volunteer and youth groups have also been participating in related GYSD activities, the spokesman noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.043 to close at NT$30.340.
A total of US$1.24 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$30.347 and hit a low of NT$30.305.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Cabinet nominations to be announced next week

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan is expected to announce a second wave of Cabinet nominations next week as soon as they are finalized, an aide of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.
However, Lo Chih-chiang, a spokesman for Ma's office, declined to comment on speculation regarding the candidate nominations.
The next round of nominations will focus on ministers in charge of national defense, education, finance and cross-Taiwan Strait affairs.
According to local media reports, former Minister of Education Yung Chaur-shin remains Liu's top choice for education minister, but Yung has shown no intention of accepting the offer.

Chen Wei-jao, former president of National Taiwan University, is reportedly another possible choice for the position of education minister, while National Chi Nan University President Chang Jin-fu is tipped to head the National Science Council.

On the chairmanship of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , the possible candidates mentioned by the media include former MAC Vice Chairman Cheng An-kuo and Kao Lang, a professor of political science at National Taiwan University.

Speculation on possible choices for minister of national defense include incumbent Chief of the General Staff Huo Shou-yeh, former Army Commander-in- Chief Chen Chen-hsiang and Kuomintang Legislator Shuai Hua-min.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin sets Guinness record for largest meat tzung-tzu

TEXT.P: A new world record for the largest tzung-tzu -- a traditional treat of glutinous rice stuffed with meat, mushrooms and other delicacies and steamed in bamboo leaves -- was set in an activity held by the Yunlin county government at Jenwen Park in the southern county's Touliu City Friday.
More than 14,000 residents were on hand to witness the record-setting achievement and to get a taste of the 1,314-kg tzung-tzu made by a team of chefs from a Taichung City hotel.
Head chef Lee Ching-hua said it took 20 people about 24 hours to make the tzung- tzu.
All the ingredients were sourced in Yunlin County, including 210 kg of pork, 840 kg of rice, more than 30,000 bamboo leaves, 90 kg of locally grown peanuts, and 90 kg of mushrooms, Lee said.
A Guinness World Records representative witnessed the event and certified the new world record.
All the participants in the activity received commemorative certificates issued by the county government to mark the achievement.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: Speaking of doubts expressed by the European Union about a bridging loan of 300 million euros that the Italian government is to grant to the country's national carrier Alitalia, up-coming premier Silvio Berlusconi said that "the EU should not create difficulty for us, but giving a hand to us."

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Nation: Dusit to expand abroad.
The Bangkok Post: Samak confirms early election.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved up nine points to close at 8,988, with 54,703 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June gained six points to finish at 8,951, with 419 contracts traded, while September futures dropped 11 points to close at 8,674, with 35 contract transactions.
December futures lost 13 points to finish at 8,638, with 29 contract transactions, while March futures dropped 52 points to close at 8,599, with four contracts traded.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index slid 42.5 points Friday to finish at 8,947.83, with a market turnover of NT$149.52 billion (US$4.93 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 8,979 for May; 8,945 for June; 8,685 for September; 8,651 for December and 8,651 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
May TE futures gained 2.4 points to close at 339.5, with 4,496 contracts traded, while June TE futures increased 2.4 points to finish at 338.2, with 34 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved up 3.15 points to close at 335.4, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December and March.
May TF futures dropped six points to close at 1,213.8, with 4,200 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures decreased 5.2 points to finish at 1,208, with 51 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Rice price hits new high on global markets.
The prices of rice in Thailand, the world's top exporter, surged to a record high above US$1,000 (S$1,360) a tonne yesterday as fears of a global shortage spread as far as the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: Japan has stepped up random checks of U.S. beef imports after spinal columns were found in a shipment from California but is not planning another blanket ban, officials said Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high but closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 42.5 points to close at 8,947.83.

Finishing lower for the fourth consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 9,053.3 and fluctuated between 9,062.97 and 8,945.22 during the day's session. A total of 5.44 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$149.52 billion (US$4.93 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up at 0.1 percent.

The seven other major categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 4.2 percent. Cement stocks fell 1.4 percent, foodstuff issues lost 1.3 percent, paper and pulp issues shed 1.2 percent, banking and financial shares were down 1.1 percent, plastic and chemicals shares dropped 1 percent and textile stocks fell 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,669 to 671, with 321 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5.57 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Documentary festival to be held to underscore laborers' hardship

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Department of Labor is sponsoring a two-week documentary festival beginning April 27 to explore the hardship and suffering of laborers and the unfavorable legal and commercial environment they face.

Sixteen documentaries will be screened during the festival to be held at Spot- Taipei Film House, including 11 Taiwanese films and five foreign films from Japan, the United States, Israel and Canada, with admission free, said Labor Department Commissioner Su Yin-kuei.

These documentaries, Su said, cover a number of subjects related to workers, including laborers' lives, occupational cultures, labor-management disputes, occupational injuries, gender issues, foreign laborers, and the influence of privatizing state-run enterprises on workers.
