A short film competition for laborers will also be held alongside the festival, Su noted, adding that the film festival is part of May 1 Labor Day celebrations.
Two of the Taiwanese entries are "I Don't Want to Sleep Alone" and "Taipei, Looking up?"

The former was directed by Tsai Ming-liang, who has won awards at several international film festivals in recent years, and the latter was directed by Lin Jing-jie, who won the best film prize of the International Week of Film Critics of the 64th Venice Film Festival.
Lin directed his documentary at the invitation of Taipei City's Department of Labor to highlight occupational injuries among workers, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3M will continue to expand investments in Taiwan: corporate head

TEXT.P: 3M Taiwan, one of the oldest foreign companies in Taiwan, will continue to invest in the island so as to grow along with the country's economic progress, the head of the company said Friday.

3M, a multi-faceted technology company that produces more than 55,000 products, is based in St. Paul, Minnesota and has been in Taiwan for over 39 years. It will be celebrating its 40th founding anniversary next year, said 3M Taiwan President Chao Tai-sheng.
Chao made the remarks at a ceremony held at the Taipei County Government Building marking the opening of the 2008 3M Innovation Day in Northern Taiwan.

A diversified technology company which boasts that over half of the world's population use or come into contact with 3M products everyday, 3M -- with more than 55,000 products, 30-plus core technologies -- continues to provide innovative and practical solutions to meet the people's needs, said Chao.

At the exhibition for 3M Innovation Day, research and application achievements by 3M Taiwan were put on display, while business and industrial leaders were invited to exchange views with 3M staff on the company's eight business groups, including: tape and automotive; abrasives and chemicals; electro and telecommunications; health care; traffic and safety; office markets; imaging systems; and consumer markets.

Also addressing the opening ceremony, Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei said the Taipei County Government's management and operation concepts are in line with those of 3M in terms of environmental protection.
After years of strenuous efforts, Chou said, Taipei County now ranked first place in all cities and counties in Taiwan in efforts to prevent air and water pollution.
In addition, he said, the quality of the water in Danshui River is now the cleanest it has ever been in three decades.

"In the future, Taipei County will collaborate with 3M Taiwan and other corporations to jointly build Taipei County into a metropolis of culture, innovation, environmental protection and low carbon dioxide emissions," Chou vowed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Record number of prospective graduates searching for jobs online

TEXT.P: Approximately 60,000 students who are set to graduate this summer are already looking for jobs by having their resumes posted with online employment broker 104 Job Bank, the company said Friday.
The number marks an increase of 30 percent compared with the same time last year and reached its highest level in the last three years, the company said.

The numbers reflect the belief, proven in 2007, that those getting early starts have better chances at landing jobs. Last year, 80.2 of graduates who obtained employment within three months of graduation began their job search before graduation, according to a survey conducted by 104 Job Bank among member job seekers.
This year, 12,000 prospective graduates are looking for jobs in the category of administration and general affairs, while only around 2,000 openings are available, the company said.

Of the 110,000 vacancies open to fresh graduates that are currently posted with the job bank, 24.6 percent are in sales, 13. 1 percent in finance, 12.2 percent in operations and technical support, 10.4 percent in customer service and 8.3 percent in engineering research and development.

Meanwhile, there are approximately 6,000 openings for management trainees, with 24.4 percent in the wholesale and retail sectors, 19.6 percent in the financial and insurance industries, and 18.9 percent in the service industry, the company said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's foreign aid budget to reach NT$17.98 billion in 2008

TEXT.P: The budget for Taiwan's foreign aid will reach NT$17.979 billion (US$594 million) this year, with nearly all of it already committed to diplomatic allies and countries in need, Vice Foreign Minister Yang Tzu-pao said Thursday.

"Taiwan's foreign aid is used mainly to strengthen and expand its diplomatic relations and boost international cooperation, " said Yang at a Legislative Yuan session where he was briefing lawmakers on the allocation of the country's foreign aid.

He said Taiwan's aid projects focused mainly on helping its allies in infrastructure development, deploying agricultural and technical missions to allied countries, providing financial assistance and goods, and making loans.

According to Yang, aid to Central and South American countries (including the Caribbean) will reach NT$10.9 billion, accounting for the bulk of the total, followed by the NT$2.93 billion promised to countries in Africa.
The foreign ministry will also provide NT$2.43 billion in aid to Asian and Pacific region, NT$58.29 million to North America, NT$27.4 million to Europe, and NT$10.5 million to West Asia, Yang said.
Of the NT$17.966 billion in aid that has already been committed, some NT$4.38 billion has been spent up to now, Yang told the legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA celebrates World Intellectual Property Day with award ceremony

TEXT.P: The government held an award ceremony Friday as part of a series of events to mark World Intellectual Property Day, which an economics official said reflected Taiwan's commitment to improve both intellectual property protection and its capacity to innovate.

"Despite not being a member state of the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) , Taiwan has shown its determination to protect IP rights in recent years, " said Vice Economics Minister Fadah Hsieh.

To raise awareness of Saturday's World IP Day, the Intellectual Property Office (IPO) under the MOEA has collaborated with private institutions to hold a series of activities, including an essay competition, a drawing competition and a film festival between April 10 to May 30 to promote the importance of intellectual property (IP) rights.

Friday's award ceremony honored 10 of the office's 300 inspectors who were considered the best at examining patent and IP applications, and also awarded prizes to dozens of children who won the bureau's drawing competition.
Hsieh said the ceremony and a forum coinciding with the ceremony were held to recognize the contributions of the inspectors to intellectual property rights protection.
"The MOEA's campaigns echo what the WIPO wants to achieve throughout the world, " asserted Hsieh, who also said that intellectual property was an essential component of Taiwan's economic development.

Between 2001 and 2005, Taiwan ranked third in the world in the number of innovative patents registered, averaging 242 per million people, lagging only behind the U.S. and Japan, according to the Council of Economic Planning and Development.
"Taiwan focuses on innovation, research and intellectual development to spearhead our technology sector and integrate our economic and social capacities," Hsieh said.
Evolving from a labor-intensive to a knowledge-based economy is the only way to enter the new millennium and cope with globalization, Hsieh said.

He cited MOEA programs to help with patent management, finance small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) , and sponsor industry innovation and personal innovators, as helping with this transformation.
These all showed Taiwan's determination to play a role in the global trend of IP protection, he stressed.
Office director Wang Mei-hua stressed that innovation and IP protection were necessary to develop a knowledge-based economy.

"The possession of intellectual property is a key indicator of industrial capacity, regardless of whether it's in conventional or high-tech sectors, " Wang said, noting that innovative technologies help create boost corporate profitability.
She said the bureau needs to deal with about 80,000 patent and IP applications per year, but has only 300 inspectors to evaluate them, an indication of the inspectors' heavy workload.

April 26 was chosen to mark World Intellectual Property Day because it commemmorates the creation of the Convention Establishing the World Intellectual Property Organization, which took effect on April 26, 1970.

DOC.HEADLINE: Same standard should be applied to all special allowance cases: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that she believed President-elect Ma Ying- jeou deserved to be acquitted of corruption charges stemming from the use of his special allowance fund and hoped the same standard would be applied to all officials facing similar suspicions.
Lu, who has also been indicted for abuse of the discretionary fund during her tenure as vice president, said she thought Ma deserved the acquittal because the system was a "common burden of history."
"All cases related to the special allowance funds should be dealt with under the same standard instead of manipulating legal terms, " the outgoing vice president said.
She made the remarks after delivering a speech at an international forum for "International Images and Cultural Diplomacy of Taiwan."
Lu contended that the special allowance system was created by the Kuomintang (KMT) during the 1950s and has been passed on to the DPP government, which simply complied with standard practices.
"Our staff was told by accounting sections in different governmental departments to 'just do exactly the same as what they (previous administration) did before,'" she said.
Lu criticized judicial agencies for applying selective standards and holding only the DPP responsible for using special allowances.

"How come the Special Investigative Unit only targeted the four of us while it has so many (special allowance) cases to deal with," Lu said, referring to President Chen Shui-bian, Presidential Secretary General Chen Tan-sun, former DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and herself.

Taiwan's Supreme Court upheld Thursday a high court ruling that acquitted President-elect Ma of corruption charge. The latest acquittal was final, as prosecutors have exhausted opportunities to appeal.
The ruling came less than a month before Ma takes office on May 20.

Ma of the opposition KMT was first indicted in February 2007 for allegedly diverting NT$11.18 million (US$372,666) from his special allowance fund into his private account while serving as Taipei mayor between 1998 and 2006.
"The KMT, which is to take office again, should solve this historical common burden once and for all, " Lu said with a bit of emotion.
Asked how about whether the president should pardon those who have been indicted for alleged special allowance abuses, Lu said not to ask her for comment on the issue.
"As President-elect Ma has been acquitted, he should know how to handle the case as a national leader and as a person who knows the law well," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Red light timers to be installed at more intersections in Taipei

TEXT.P: Red light timers will be appearing at more intersections in Taipei City in the months ahead as the municipal government has decided to expand the scope of their use on a trial basis.

Chen Hsu-hsien, head of the municipal Department of Transportation's Traffic Engineering Office, said Friday that the countdown timers will be installed at 75 selected intersections around the city by August of this year.

The timers will be installed at intersections where the road width exceeds 20 meters, the red light signal's duration is over 60 seconds, and where a high number of traffic accidents occur, Chen said.
The transportation department installed red light timers at five intersections in the city last September, Chen pointed out.
She said that as the number of traffic accidents dropped measurably in the months following their introduction, the department has decided to expand the scope of the timers' use on a trial basis.
Green light timers on pedestrian traffic light signals have been used in Taipei City for a number of years.

But surveys by the transportation department shows that green light timers have not received a positive response in all the counties and cities around Taiwan where they have been introduced, Chen said.
The green light turns yellow when the timer stops, indicating the pedestrians and motorists to hurry up, but people on the cross street ofter go once the timer stops, ignoring the yellow light.

Red light timers, on the other hand, have proven "relatively less controversial" as well as effective in cutting the number of traffic problems, because when the timer stops at zero, the light will turn green and the pedestrians and motorists stopped on the cross street know they can cross.

DOC.HEADLINE: Citizens encouraged to apply for digital certificates

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) encouraged Taiwan citizens Friday to apply for electronic certificates to facilitate online personal income tax filing and other government services.

Citizens over the age of 18 can apply for the certificates at local household registration offices, an MOI official said, adding that they would be required to show their national ID cards and pay a service fee of NT$275.

The application process takes only 10 minutes, and the digital certificate would allow Internet access from anywhere to the government's round-the-clock electronic service, according to an official at the MOI's Information Center. The service includes annual personal income tax filing, which will begin May 1, the official said.

The digital certificate serves as "Internet ID" for people using online government services, ensures safe data transmission, offers the convenience of an online ID check, and allows for more efficient service, the official said.

The MOI issued 1.31 million digital certificates in the period from April 30, 2003 to April 23, 2008, which accounts for 15 percent of the 9 million people over 18 years who are frequent Internet users, according to the official.

The number of applications increased from 9,365 in 2003 to more than 115,000 in 2007, and the number of personal income tax filings through the use of the certificate increased from 1,122 in 2003 to 431,000 in 2007, the official said.
The MOI is hoping more people will apply for the digital certificate and that it will be more heavily used, as it is an important link to the electronic government service, the official added.

In support of the MOI's objective, the National Tax Administration of Northern Taiwan Province will hold a lottery June 17, in which citizens who file their personal income tax statements via the Internet using digital certificates will qualify for the draw. The first prize is a car valued at NT$500,000 (US$16,485).

Taiwan government agencies now provide 1,455 online services that may be accessed using the Citizen Digital Certificate. The most frequently used online services are labor insurance applications, which account for 39 percent usage, land administration, 29 percent, immigration information, 12 percent, and tax filing, 6 percent.

Citizens can apply for the digital certificates at household registration offices, as well as at the MOI's Information Center from 8: 30 a.m.-7: 30 p.m. on weekdays and from 9: 00 a.m.-5: 00 p.m. on weekends.
There is no charge for applications to extend the validity of digital certificates that are about to expire, the MOI official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visitor arrivals to Taiwan likely to hit 4.25 million in 2009: CEPD

TEXT.P: Visitor arrivals to Taiwan are expected to reach 4 million this year and rise to 4.25 million in 2009 thanks to several international sports events that will take place in Taiwan, according to a report released Friday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
The arrivals are likely to bring in NT$180 billion to NT$192.1 billion in revenue to the country, the report said.
In 2007, visitor arrivals reached a record high of 3.72 million, the report noted.
Of the number, 1.65 million visitors said the purpose of their visit was tourism, an increase of 89.49 percent compared with the 870,000 recorded in 2000, the report said.

The CEPD attributed the increase in visitor arrivals to the government's efforts to enhance visitor convenienc, such as setting up 80 tourist information service stations at major transportation points and establishing a travel information Web site that is available in both traditional and simplified Chinese characters, English, Japanese, Korean and German.
A 24-hour travel information hot line has also been launched, and can handle inquiries in Mandarin, English, Japanese and Korean, the report said.

To coincide with the 2008 Olympic Games being held in Beijing, the 2009 World Games to be held in Kaohsiung, and the 2009 Deaftlympics to be held in Taipei, the government is promoting Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009 to boost tourism, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA pondering whether to include depression as occupational disease

TEXT.P: A Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) official said Friday that it needs to conduct more studies and discussions on whether depression can be included on the list of occupational diseases which are covered by Taiwan's workers compensation system.

Wu Hung-hsiang, a session chief of CLA, made the remarks while meeting a group of labor representatives who went to the CLA office to protest against the CLA's excluding depression as one of the occupational diseases on its new list.
On Thursday, the CLA added 21 diseases, including 18 types of cancer, onto a new list of occupational diseases which will be covered by the agency's compensation system for laborers.

Huang Hsiao-ling, secretary-general of Taiwan Association for Victims of Occupational Injuries (TAVOI), who led the representatives to the CLA, said while the review of the occupational disease list has been overdue for 12 years, depression should not have been excluded.

"We are sorry to know that the CLA still excludes depression on its new list of occupation disease given the fact that the occurrence of depression is quite common in the workplace nowadays, " Huang noted.

Among the protesters was Chen Chao-lien, a former female worker of the Unitech Printed Circuit Board Corp., who said she began suffering from depression after being downgraded in her job without explanation and verbally insulted by her superintendents.
As her complaints were ignored by the company's management, Chen said she fell into chronic depression over the years, and was sent to the hospital twice for treatment of mental illness.

Now, in addition to losing her job, Chen said she cannot handle her daily life and often think of committing suicide. Chen's disease still has not been classified as an occupational disease and therefore she cannot receive any compensation from the insurance company.

As many cases of depression nowadays stem from the workplace, Huang said, the CLA should include mental disease on its list of occupational diseases as soon as possible to better protect employees' rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Coral polyps in Kenting soon to release eggs: expert

TEXT.P: The coral polyps living in the seas off the Kenting National Park in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, will release eggs in the next few days, a senior coral reef observer anticipated Friday.
Tsai Yung-teh said he believes the sea creatures will begin to produce eggs hours later in the day, and anticipated the upcoming spawning scale will be small.
Tsai is planning to take a dive tonight to observe the expected natural phenomenon, which the experienced diver said takes place once a year in Kenting.
Tsai said that after tonight, he would be able to figure out when the spawning will reach its height.
Full-moon nights in the lunar month of March have been the typical time for mass spawning in Kenting's corals.
Coral spawning is one of the world's most magnificent natural wonders, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Party consultations in legislature no longer 'closed-door' deals

TEXT.P: In a major step toward legislative reform, the Legislative Yuan passed a law amendment Friday which requires the recording and videotaping of consultations and negotiations among legislative caucuses of political parties.

The amended Law Governing the Legislative Yuan's Power stipulates that inter- party legislative consultations will be recorded, videotaped, and publicized on legislative gazette. The conclusions or agreements reached during negotiations should also be made public according to the amendment.

If the conclusions reached following consultations are starkly different from the original proposed version of a bill, then the legislators or party caucuses can have their proposed version and their reason for putting forward the proposals be also printed also on the gazette.
The amended law will go into effect after the president promulgates it.
Under the amended law, consultation periods for controversial bills will also be shortened from the current four months to only one month to facilitate legislative efficiency.

Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the Kuomintang who initiated the amendment, said that after the consultation process becomes "open and transparent," the public will know "the stance of every legislator clearly," and criticism about "under table dealings" will end.

Ting noted that currently the public is kept in the dark about the process of inter-party consultations and they can only see the results of the consultations after they are put on the legislative bulletin.

Due to the "secret" nature of the present inter-party consultations, the public could also question if there is any "under the table dealings" or "interest swapping" during the consultation process, Ting said.

"This is why the inter-party consultations have to be out in the open, especially because the new legislature has been streamlined by half to 113 seats and a few legislators could decide the fate of a bill that involves tens of billions of dollar," he added.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said that the legislature will act according to the amended law passed Friday, although he said the impact is still uncertain.

However, Wang disagreed that the current style of consultations as being "secret," saying that at least two representatives from each party's caucus are allowed to be present, and legislators and their aides can join freely. Only the media are "shut out of them."
A legislative watchdog group welcomed the increased transparency, saying that "the first ray of sunshine has come out."
Ku Chung-hua, president of the Citizen Congress Watch, expressed the hope that the legislature will also act quickly to allow live broadcast of legislative proceedings.
"The lawmakers should realize that they are themselves to be monitored, and that they should not turn the legislature into a closed-door meeting," Ku added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Renowned Aussie chef promotes seasonal organic food

TEXT.P: A renowned Australian chef on Friday urged people to eat local, seasonal and organic food as a way to save the environment since they are grown and produced using environmental -friendly methods and, unlike imported food, cause no greenhouse gas emissions with little transportation required.
"I really believe in organic food and I believe strongly in the environment, " said Curtis Stone, a famous chef from Melbourne, Australia and host of the television cooking show "Take Home Chef."

Stone said that it is good for the environment to eat organic food because they are grown without the use of pesticides or artificial fertilizers, which are harmful. Organic products also are healthier and taste better, he said.

"When you eat with the seasons, it becomes quite a celebration. Different seasons have different types of food that you can enjoy. It's exciting, " the 33 -year-old celebrity chef said, wearing his noted bloomy smile.

A big fan of outdoor life and a keen surfer, the environmental protection activist said that eating seasonal food is also a way of reducing greenhouse gas emissions as people would eat less imported food, which cause a great amount of carbon dioxide emission during transportation.

On a five-day visit to promote the latest season of his cooking program on Discovery's Travel & Living channel, Stone said he paid a visit to afamous night market in Taipei upon his arrival on Thursday night and tried the notorious "stinky tofu" and other bizarre local delicacies.
"The smell of stinky tofu did put me off a little bit but I came to like it after I tasted it," he said.
Stressing that he eats pretty much everything, the heartthrob food connoisseur said he particularly liked the glutinous rice balls filled with peanut powder and deep fried chicken with basil.
Chosen as one of People Magazine's Sexiest Men Alive, along with George Clooney and Brad Pitt, Stone revealed his secret on how to impress girls by cooking.

"When you cook for someone special, all you need to do is to get their favorite ingredients and you have to treat them really simply," he said philosophically. "The less you do to the food, the less chance that something will go wrong. Less is more."
As a chef, Stone said, he would like everybody to know that cooking is not only easy, but also fun.
"I try to encourage people to spend more time at the dinner table. I think if you are confident in the kitchen then you can bring happiness to the dinner table," he said.

Stone started studying for a Bachelor of Business degree, but quit half-way through when he realized his heart was in food instead. He began his cooking career at the tender age of 18 at the Savoy Hotel and worked at some top Australian restaurants before becoming head chef at the famous Marco's Quo Vadis in London.

DOC.HEADLINE: President praises Keelung River flood control project

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lauded the successful flood prevention project along the Keelung River in northern Taiwan as one of the achievements of his government during an inspection tour of the project Friday.
Chen's visit to the Yuanshantze flood diversion tunnel was part of the government's emergency preparation efforts against possible flooding as the typhoon season -- May to November -- approaches.

The Yuanshantze flood diversion tunnel, located in Taipei County's Jueifang township, was completed in 2005 at cost of NT$6 billion (US$198 million). It channels water from the Keeling River, as it rises, to the sea and thus prevents flooding, which was a serious problem along the course of the river, especially in Taipei County's Sijhih and Jueifang townships and neighboring Keelung City.

Water Resources Agency Director-General Chen Shen-hsien said the project has the passed the test of several typhoons and heavy rainfall and is a good example of river flood control in Taiwan. The two million people living close to the river can now be assured that their homes are safe from flooding, he added.
"Time and facts have proved the success of the Keelung River flood control project, and this was achieved by the current government," President Chen said.

The president said that unlike the ineffective measures, such as raising the river embankment and widening the watercourses, that were attempted by the previous Kuomintang government, the flood diversion tunnel has been effective and has allayed people's fear of flooding.

It was President Chen's seventh inspection of the Keelung River and his fifth of the flood diversion tunnel project, as his tenure nears its end. President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang is slated to take office May 20.

In June 2006, the central government launched an eight-year program, with a budget of NT$116 billion (US$3.83 billion) , to resolve problems of flooding in areas that were prone to such disasters, Chen Shen-hsien noted.
The flood prevention project will continue and the government will build entertainment facilities along the Keelung River as flooding is no longer a problem, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGNorth Sea oil pipeline set to close ahead of strike
The Forties pipeline system, which pumps crude oil from the North Sea, is set to shut down tonight, as 1,200 workers at the Grangemouth refinery in Scotland prepare to walk out in a dispute over pensions.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Democrats divided over lengthy race.
Hillary Rodham Clinton's Pennsylvania Win has bought her time--but not much--to make her case to the Democratic Party's superdelegates, many of whom expressed a strong desire Wednesday to end the nominating contest once the final voters are cast. Though few seem eager to use their power to call a halt to the presidential race-- and many said they welcomed the continued balloting. ]By Lu- sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: Export of solar products to Spain grow nearly fourfold Jan.-March

TEXT.P: The export of Taiwan's photovoltaic products to Spain grew 388.8 percent from the previous year to reach US$125 million in the first three months of 2008, according to a local trade promotion association.
Photovoltaic products also posted the largest growth in Taiwan's total exports to Spain, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said in a statement Thursday.
Total exports were recorded at US$520 million, up 49.14 percent from the same period the previous year, according to the statement.

TIATRA attributed the high export growth to its efforts to promote Taiwan products at a European photovoltaic solar energy exhibition in Spain last year. The council lead a delegation of representatives from five local companies to display their solar products at the exhibition last year.
The council said will lead another delegation of representatives of 15 companies to this year's solar product exhibition in Spain in September.

The council will also take representatives of local companies to similar exhibitions in Germany and the United States this year, and will explore new markets in France and Greece, according to the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIA committee puts Suhua Freeway in hands of new government

TEXT.P: An environmental review panel decided Friday to reject an environmental impact assessment of the controversial Suao-Hualien Freeway done by a Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) agency, in effect leaving it up to the incoming Kuomintang (KMT) government to decide the issue.

The Environmental Protection Administration's (EPA's) environmental review panel gave conditional approval to the project in March, pending a report by the MOTC agency responsible for planning the freeway.

But members of the EPA's Environmental Impact Assessment Review Committee were clearly unhappy that the agency, the National Expressway Engineering Bureau (NEEB), did not clarify in its report many controversial issues, such as the project's potential impact on indigenous peoples' villages and culture and on the area's groundwater.
The members also questioned the necessity of the freeway, saying it was designed 10 years ago and may no longer be suitable to meet the real needs of those who would use it.

Others on the panel argued that the NT$93 billion plan could conflict with the "Eastern Taiwan Sustainable Development Plan" approved in March 2008 by the Council for Economic Planning and Development under the outgoing Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration.
According to the sustainable development plan, the Suhua Freeway is neither the only nor the best solution for eastern Taiwan's transportation problems.

"Since the government's policy is not clear, I suggest that the committee reject the report and send it back to the MOTC, " said committee member Lin Su-zhen, a professor in the Department of Environmental Engineering of National Cheng Kung University in Tainan, at the end of the meeting.
Her suggestion was accepted without opposition by the panel's other members.
It will now be up to the administration of president-elect Ma Ying-jeou to determine the freeway's fate.

During the meeting, Huang Tai-hua, one of the representatives of environmentalists quoted Chen Tain-jy, the chairman-designate of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, as saying that "he will make a policy on top priority" and decide if the expressway should be constructed.

Designed to boost the economy in eastern Taiwan, the 86-kilometer expressway, which would be heavily composed of tunnels and bridges, would connect Suao in the northeastern county of Yilan and Jian, just south of Hualien city, the capital of Hualien County, to the south.

At present, the only road connecting the two cities in eastern Taiwan separated by mountainous terrain is a two-lane windy roadway cut into the side of mountains that is frequently plagued by landslides and considered dangerous.
Some living in the less-developed eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung, argue that the roadway effectively keeps away potential tourists from the densely populated western half of the island.

They see the proposed freeway as spurring potential growth in their counties in the same way that the 12.9-kilometer-long Hsuehshan Tunnel has boosted tourism and the property market in northeastern Yilan County, a proposition dismissed by environmentalists who oppose to the Suhua expressway plan.

They argue that more environmentally friendly alternative means of transportation can be arranged to spur tourism and that an influx of polluting cars would harm the pristine natural beauty that is among the counties' main selling points.
The expressway bureau's environmental impact assessment report has been discussed since 1999. It was approved in 2002 by the Executive Yuan, but was suspended in 2003 over environmental concerns.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU Hospital celebrates 40th anniversary of first organ transplant

TEXT.P: The hands that had wielded scalpels in surgery played the violin, while the patient who had suffered kidney failure moved her fingers deftly over the piano keys.
Together, the doctor and his former patient produced beautiful melodies in a canon.

The heart-warming scene was part of the celebrations that took place at National Taiwan University Hospital Friday to mark the 40th anniversary of its first organ transplant -- the first living-related renal transplant in both Taiwan and Asia by a team of four NTU doctors in 1968.

Tsai Meng-kun, a doctor at the NTU Hospital's Department of Surgery, said he had not played the violin for 20 years. But for the this special occasion, he and music worker Gao Pei-ling, a kidney recipient, had practiced together over the past month for the performance.
Other liver, kidney and heart recipients staged a sign language performance in front of their doctors to prove that they are very much alive and kicking.

Speaking as a guest of honor at the occasion, Hou Sheng-mou, head of the Cabinet-level Department of Health, recalled how he had worked on organ transplant experiments, using mice and other animals, while he was a medical school student at NTU.
Hou, who had taught at the NTU Medical School before becoming Taiwan's top health official, said he will rejoin the NTU Hospital's organ transplantation research after he retires May 20.
Chu Shu-hsun, president of the Far Eastern Memorial Hospital in Banciao city, Taipei County, was also invited to the celebrations.

Chu, who served as vice president of NTU Hospital from 1995 and 1999, said that some of the other first transplants performed in Taiwan included a live transplant by Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Taoyuan County in 1984, a heart transplant by NTU Hospital in 1987, the first successful pancreas transplant in Taiwan by NTU Hospital in 1995, and a small intestine transplant by Far Eastern Memorial Hospital in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scenic spots to get makeover in anticipation of Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: The government wants to upgrade the service environments of five scenic spots, including Alishan and the National Palace Museum, to make them more attractive to Chinese tourists, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday.
The council presented its plan in anticipation of an influx of Chinese tourists later in the year. President-elect Ma Ying-jeou has pledged to open Taiwan to tourists from China in early July.

To ensure the sustainable growth of Chinese tourists, the officials said the government has decided to renovate and upgrade service and safety at five scenic spots -- Sun Moon Lake, Alishan (also known as Mt. Ali), Taroko Gorge, the National Palace Museum and the skyscraper Taipei 101 -- favored by Chinese visitors.
The government plans to step up checks on facility safety, ensure environmental hygiene, promote honest pricing by retailers and guarantee the quality of purchased goods, the council said.

Tourism authorities also plan to classify scenic spots in Taiwan into "international, " "domestic, " and "local" categories, and devise different renovation plans to deal with each class of scenic area, the council noted.
The government has envisioned northern Taiwan and its northeastern coast, Sun Moon Lake, Alishan, the Hengchun Peninsula, and eastern Taiwan as international level tourist spots.

But it also hopes that Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan counties in southern Taiwan, Siraya National Scenic Area in Tainan County, Maolin National Scenic Area in Pingtung and the outlying island of Penghu can be developed into international level tourist spots.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker to visit Marshall Islands

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will attend national day celebrations in the Marshall Islands May 1 as a special envoy of President Chen Shui-bian, the foreign ministry said Friday.

Wang will lead a delegation to leave for the Marshall Islands, one of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies, Sunday and return home May 3, according to a statement released by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The delegation will also include three Taiwanese eco-tourism experts who will discuss with Marshall Islands officials how to develop eco-tourism on the islands in the western Pacific Ocean, the statement said.

During his stay on the islands, Wang will also meet with Marshall Islands President Litokwa Tomeing, senior officials and business leaders to discuss bilateral cooperation and issues of mutual concern, the statement went on.
Taiwan and the Marshall Islands have engaged in a series of exchanges and cooperated on development projects since they established ties in November 1998, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PVC dolls sold in convenience stores may pose health hazards

TEXT.P: Many of the PVC dolls and bobbleheads sold in convenience stores islandwide contain excessive levels of lead and plasticizers that are considered to be health hazards, a recent survey by the Ministry of Economic Affairs revealed.

According to officials of the MOEA's Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) , one of the 14 dolls tested -- sold at 7-Eleven and produced in China -- had a lead level of 585 mg/kg, more than six times the maximum permissible level of 90 mg/kg allowed for PVC dolls, while its chromium level reached 246 mg/kg, far above the maximum allowable 60 mg/kg.
The bureau has ordered the importer of the Chinese PVC dolls to recall their products.

The standards regulator also found that five of the 14 types of PVC dolls tested contain excessive levels (more than 0.1 percent) of plasticizers, additives which are typically used to soften finished PVC products and increase their flexibility.
Bureau officials noted that concerns exist over the potential negative effects of plasticizers on the human reproductive system and the functioning of hormones in the body.
They reminded parents that the health of their children could be affected if they put the PVC dolls containing plasticizers into their mouths.

The PVC dolls, which have been sold as merchandise or used by convenience stores as giveaways to boost sales, have experienced growing popularity around Taiwan as collectibles among the younger generation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City ready for Chinese tourists: Mayor

TEXT.P: The mayor of Taipei said Friday that the city is ready to accommodate 3,000 Chinese tourists per day, referring to plans by the incoming Kuomintang government to open Taiwan to more visitors from China and to introduce direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights.

In a meeting with foreign journalists based in Taipei, Mayor Hau Lung-bin expressed high hopes of economic benefits from an expected influx of Chinese tourists as well as from visitors to the 2010 Taipei International Gardening and Horticulture Exposition.

"The city is expecting that direct flights between Taipei Songshan Airport and Shanghai Hongqiao International Airport will get off the ground to provide quicker transportation for tourists and business people across the strait, " Hau said.

He made reference to President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's commitment to allow direct cross-strait flights and to initially permit the entry of 3,000 Chinese tourists to Taiwan daily, and increase that number over time to 10,000.
Hau said that with direct flights, the travel time from Taipei to Shanghai will be cut to 80 minutes from the present four hours, which includes a transfer in either Hong Kong or Jeju, South Korea.
The mayor said the Taipei City Government has already taken steps to provide services to the anticipated influx of Chinese visitors.
Hau also said that the world famous international flower expo to be hosted by Taipei in 2010 is expected to attract six million domestic visitors and 300,000 foreign tourists over a six-month period.

On the question of whether a recent visit to Taiwan by potential real estate investors from China would push up housing prices in Taipei, Hau said that the Chinese tycoons had expressed an interest in commercial real estate rather than residential properties.
Hau also dismissed the idea that housing properties in Taipei are be overpriced.
"Compared to Hong Kong and Shanghai, Taipei's housing prices are actually under- valued," he said.

Noting that Taipei has a rich cultural and historical heritage, he stressed that attracting Chinese tourists and investors is not just about making money, but also involves cultural and artistic exchanges.
Hau was upbeat about Taiwan participating in the World Expo in Shanghai in 2010, saying he will visit Shanghai to discuss the matter with the organizers of the exposition.
He also expressed a willingness to visit Hong Kong and other Chinese cities, but said he has no concrete plans to do so at the moment.

On the question of whether the city zoo is ready house two giant pandas to be donated by the Chinese authorities, Hau said the animals will receive the highest quality care as they will be accommodated in an NT$300 million panda house at the zoo and 17 panda experts will be on hand to help care for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi Hospital's Dalin branch to set up sleep center

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital in Dalin Township in the southern Taiwan County of Chiayi will set up a sleep center in May to provide inter-departmental clinical services to patients with sleep disorders.

The hospital's management said Friday the plan to set up the sleep center became necessary because an increasing number of patients -- averaging about 200 per month -- with sleep problems were confused about which department of the hospital they should seek medical help from.

Feng Shih-ching, director of the Department of Neurology, said the causes of sleep disorders are complicated, and that his department and other departments, including the Department of Psychiatry and the Department of Pulmonary Medicine, were all involved in treating patients who have trouble sleeping.

Feng said the factors that could contribute to sleep disorders include obesity, frequent urination during the night, sexual hypoactivity, snoring, uncontrollable hypertension, daytime sleepiness, addiction to alcohol, difficulty of concentration, the weakening of memory, personality change, anxiety and easy irritability.

He said people with sleep disorders should seek help from doctors as soon as possible, and that the new sleep center at Tzu Chi Hospital's Dalin branch will group medical experts from more than 10 departments to treat patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to subsidize solar-powered 'sunlight communities'

TEXT.P: Energy authorities launched a program Friday to encourage local governments to promote environment-friendly solar energy in "sunlight communities" under their administration.

Under the plan, solar-power driven generators will be installed within a certain district to supply electricity to nearly buildings or public facilities, according to a statement released Friday by the Bureau of Energy.

The governments are entitled to a subsidy of NT$300,000 (US$9,880) for each kilowatt peak (kWp) of power produced by the generators. A kilowatt peak is the output power achieved by a solar panel under full solar radiation.
The statement said the power-generating facility's total installed capacity should reach 40 kWp, and that the generator should at least cover the need of 15 buildings or 120 households.
A 1 kWp solar system is said to produce 750 kilowatt-hours to 1,600 kwh per year depending on the climate and solar conversion factors.

The program is being launched at a time when Taiwan may soon face increases in electricity prices because of soaring international raw material costs and is trying to develop viable alternatives to fossil-fuel based power generation.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for Japan to ink special visa agreement with Taiwan

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged Japan Friday to sign an agreement on working holiday visas with Taiwan to further upgrade bilateral relations.
President Chen noted that Japan has signed such agreements with South Korea, Canada and Australia, and that Taiwan also signed similar pacts with Australia and New Zealand.
"If Taiwan and Japan can sign a working holiday visa agreement, then it will definitely upgrade the substantive and cooperative relations between the two countries," Chen said.
President Chen made the remarks when he received a Japanese delegation led by Koichi Hagiuda, a Japanese parliamentarian.
Chen said that although Taiwan maintains no formal diplomatic ties with Japan, it has had closer exchanges with Japan in recent years than ever before.
Chen pointed out that the number of tourists visiting each other country exceeded 2.5 million last year, with 1.17 million Japanese tourists visiting Taiwan.
Working holiday visas are generally given to individuals under 30 years old who want to travel and work odd jobs to earn their expenses.
Under Taiwan's working holiday visa guidelines, visa holders cannot work for the same employer for more than three months and cannot work for the entire year of the visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rejection of Suhua expressway plan draws strong reactions

TEXT.P: Following the rejection of the environmental impact assessment report on the Suao-Hualien expressway, various groups have been expressing a range of views on the decision to effectively leave the matter up to the incoming Kuomintang government.

"The rejection of the project (by an environmental review panel) was really unexpected, " said Tsai Zhong-yue, a leader of one of the Hualien student groups that have been actively opposed to the project for years.
"We are happy about the decision, even though it did not totally focus on the environmental impact," he added.

The environmental review panel members rejected the construction plan due to several unresolved controversial issues, including the lack of a clear government policy on the development of eastern Taiwan.

"Our efforts have paid off, " said Lisin.haluwey, another student association leader who is of indigenous heritage. She said that her group will continue to pay close attention to developments on the issue.
But the Hualien County Council expressed disappointment over the decision, saying that the residents of the county will not be pleased.

"The expressway is necessary, in every way, for the people living in Hualien, " said Chen Tai-zhou, a member of the Hualien County Council, who had made a brief speech in favor of the plan during the review meeting.
"I think that the people will react strongly (to the decision)," he said, adding that proponents of the project will discuss in few days how to respond.

As the environmental impact assessment of the expressway designed to connect Suao and Hualien, eastern Taiwan was being reviewed Friday, many Hualien County residents came out to show their support for the project, while an estimated 200 students, each carrying a lily, traveled by train early from Hualien to Taipei and staged a guitar concert outside the meeting to demonstrate their concerns over the plan.

About two dozen Hualien County councilors also gathered some supporters outside the building of the Environmental Protection Administration, where they cried out for Hualien residents to be given a safe transportation option with the construction of the expressway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan protests Greenpeace shipboard check

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) issued a statement Friday that condemned Greenpeace activists for boarding a Taiwanese fishing boat in the South Pacific earlier this week to check for alleged illegal catch.

According to the statement, the Pingtung-based 98-ton "Niensheng No. 3" was on the open seas north of the Solomon Islands April 21 when Greenpeace activists interrupted its operations, using a 2,000-ton vessel equipped with a helicopter.

The Greenpeace activists, after circling the Taiwanese ship for nearly an hour aboard a yacht, demanded permission to board to check whether there was any illegal shark fin harvest or excessive tuna fishing.

"The Ninensheng skipper had no choice but to accede to the request by the Greenpeace activists," the statement said, adding that although the activists did not find any evidence of irregularities after a thorough inspection that included photographing, they continued to trail the Taiwanese ship for six to seven hours after they returned to their own yacht.
The activists did not stop the chase until after the Taiwanese ship entered the Solomon Islands' exclusive economic zone.

According to the International Marine Law, when a vessel is operating on the open seas, it is under the jurisdiction of the country with which it registered or the country to which its skipper belongs.
As the Niensheng No. 3 was fishing on the open seas, the statement said, its skipper could have legally rejected the Greenpeace activists' demand for shipboard inspection, inquiry or law enforcement.

Stressing that the Niensheng No. 3 is high on the list of vessels permitted to fish in the region by the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC) and the South Pacific Forum Fisheries Agency (FFA), the statement argued that Greenpeace activists' forced shipboard check, without the Taiwan government's approval, was in stark violation of Taiwan's legal jurisdiction and the International Law.
"We strongly protest the Greenpeace activists' action, " the statement read.
The incident marked the first time that a Taiwanese fishing vessel fell victim to Greenpeace's forced shipboard inspections on the open seas.

Fishery officials urged that Taiwanese deep-sea fishing vessels to immediately ask relevant government agencies to assist in grappling with the issues if they encounter a similar situation in the future.
The Niensheng No.3 left Taiwan Jan. 16 for operations in waters near the Solomon Islands which has issued a license to allow the ship to fish for tuna, sailfish and shark.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan County offers free entry to Dongshan River Water Park

TEXT.P: The Yilan County government has decided to allow free entry to the Dongshan River Water Park from May 1 to July 11 in an attempt to attract visitors to the county.

County government officials acknowledged Friday that the park, which attracted more than 1 million visitors each year from its inception in 1994 to 2004, has seen declining numbers in the past three years, probably because its facilities are no longer fresh and appealing.

The water park was selected as the venue of the annual Yilan International Collegiate Invitational Regatta between 1996 and 2005, and the annual Yilan International Children's Folklore and Folkgame Festival for 12 years between 1995 and 2006. Both events were terminated mainly because the county government could no longer afford the financial losses.
With the summer tourism season approaching, the county government decided to waive all entry fees -- NT$80 per adult, NT$60 per child, and NT$40 per senior citizen -- for 72 days from May 1.
Visitors, however, are still required to pay parking fees for their vehicles -- NT$100 each for buses, NT$50 for cars and NT$20 for motorcycles.
The Dongshan River Water Park opened to the public in 1994, with "water intimacy" as its theme. The park contains a boating area, a paddling area and a family area.
The main facilities in the park include an outdoor theater, paddling pools, a museum with exhibits of dragon boats, a swimming pool and a gym.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Philippines weather observation station opens
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, the Philippines, April 24 (CNA) 04/25/08 23:03:32 (By Emerson T. Lim and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: A weather observation station, established by Taiwan and the Philippines, was inaugurated in the Filipino province of Rizal Thursday to help both countries better predict typhoons and enhance the accuracy of weather forecasts.

The establishment of the weather station in the province 20 kilometers east of Manila is the result of one of two bilateral projects between Taiwan's National Science Council (NSC) and the Philippines' Department of Science and Technology (DOST).
Taiwan donated US$170,000 last November to fund the research projects, which are focused on weather disaster prevention and rainfall analysis technology.
The weather station will collect data on typhoons and general climatic information by releasing high-altitude weather balloons tied to a radio monitoring device on a daily basis.

The balloon and monitoring device cost a combined NT$14,500 (US$477) and cannot be reused. The device will send data back to the station's computers for analysis, and the data can then be sent to Taiwan.
NSC chief Chen Chien-jen said after presiding over the inauguration ceremony that the device can gather data on wind speed, wind direction, temperature, and ambient humidity.
The data, he said, would result in more accurate prediction of the formation and the paths of typhoons, and could help safeguard the lives and property of people in both countries.
He also said that Taiwan and the Philippines, which do not have official ties, will increase the training and exchange of personnel, and share satellite weather data.

Taiwan's representative to the Philippines Wu Hsin-hsing, who was also present at the ceremony, said that the two countries are geographically close and that many typhoons that hit Taiwan are formed off the coast of the Philippines.
The bilateral cooperation will expand the forecasting scope of Taiwan's central weather bureau to include its neighbor to the south, Wu continued.
The envoy also said he hopes that both sides can strengthen technological collaboration in other fields, which he believed will be conducive to bilateral relations.
For his part, DOST Secretary Estrella Alabastro said at the ceremony he hopes that Taiwan and the Philippines can maintain a long-term technological collaboration.

Antonio Basilio, Taipei-based representative of Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) , thanked Taiwan its cooperation on the project and for a previous donation of a school dormitory and relief supplies it made to help a village in the Philippines, which was hard hit by a huge mudslide recently.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor promotes his city in Hong Kong
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/08 23:17:53 (By Semy Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Taichung Mayor Jason Hu expressed hope Friday that Taiwan will grant landing visas to Hong Kong residents traveling to his central Taiwan city by October.

Hong Kong residents can obtain landing visas if they enter Taiwan via Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan or Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan, but they still have to apply for visas if they enter from Taichung Airport in central Taiwan.

Hu said that currently there are 39 regular flights between Taichung and Hong Kong per week, or around 160 flights per month serving between 30,000 and 40,000 passengers. He estimated that the ultimate destination of between 70 and 80 percent of the passengers on those flights is China.

The mayor is worried that if weekend cross-strait charter flights are established in July as pledged by President Ma Ying-jeou, Hong Kong's importance as a transit point to China will decline and exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong will be greatly reduced.
Hu hoped that reductions in traffic can be offset by an increase in tourism between residents of the two places.

At present, the number of Hong Kong residents visiting Taichung is limited, Hu said, but he believed there was room for growth, especially if the government granted Hong Kong residents landing visas, which would facilitate their travel to the city.
The Taichung City Government is also planning to coordinate with related agencies to provide discounts, necessary information and assistance to Hong Kong and Macau visitors, he said.
Hu hoped that Taichung could attract 60,000 Hong Kong tourists a month after allowing them to enter central Taiwan using landing visas.

Following the seminar in Hong Kong, Hu will first head to Britain to solicit investment before heading to Switzerland to lobby for the International Olympic Committee to reinstate baseball as an Olympic event.
The sport's appearance at the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing in August may be its last after the sport was voted out as an Olympic event three years ago, beginning with the London Games in 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP official regrets Ma's not-guilty verdict

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan expressed his regret Friday over the Supreme Court's decision to uphold lower court rulings that President-elect Ma Ying-jeou was not guilty of corruption.

Lee's remarks came a day after the Supreme Court finalized a ruling that Ma was not guilty of the charges related to his alleged misuse of special allowance funds during his term as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.

Noting that Ma once described special allowance funds as "public funds" to be used on government business, Lee, citing the indictment, said Ma used the money on his dog, utility bills and his daughters' tuition.

This was hard evidence of Ma's use of the public funds for private purposes, Lee said, adding that Ma, who will take office May 20, should still explain these matters or apologize even though he was found not guilty.

The Taipei District Court and Taiwan High Court ruled that the part of Ma's special allowance in question, the half that he did not need to justify with receipts, was a "substantive subsidy" that was for an official's discretionary use and not "public funds."

Although it was not a material part of its ruling, the Supreme Court disagreed with the lower courts' definition and said the special allowance was a "public fund" and had to be spent on job-related expenses.

The definition of the special allowance and its usage was the key issue in Ma's trials, and Lee urged judicial agencies to establish a uniform definition of the fund for central and local government officials and create an authoritative standard for similar cases.
Vice President Annette Lu and other central and local officials have also been indicted for their alleged misuse of their public funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 26, or the 21st day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1452: Leonardo da Vinci, Italian painter, engineer, scientist and one of the most versatile artists of the Renaissance, is born. As a painter, he is best known for "The Last Supper" and "Mona Lisa."
1885: Britain occupies Port Hamilton, Korea.
1925: Paul von Hinderburg, German general and politician, is elected president of the Weimar Republic. He appointed Adolf Hitler as chancellor in 1933.
1946: Chinese communist troops take over Harbin and Tsitsihar as Soviet forces evacuate.

1971: A White House commission recommends that Communist China be brought into the United Nations, with the Republic of China on Taiwan retaining its membership.
1972: The eleven-member Chinese track and field team returns from Manila after winning 11 gold, 2 silver and 4 bronze medals in the three-day Philippine National Open Track and Field Championships.
1975: The Embassy of the Republic of China in Saigon suspends operations.
1975: Shortly before the fall of Saigon, former South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a temporary stay before going into exile in the United States.
1976: The Fourth Asian Writers Conference of International P.E.N. opens with some 90 leading writers in Asia, Europe and America attending.
1976: The government of the Republic of China and the government of the Republic of South Africa announce the elevation of their consulates general to embassy status.
1976: Brig. Gen. Dan A. Brooksher of the U.S. Air Force arrives to replace Brig. Gen. David O. Williams Jr. as chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command.

Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Rejection of Suhua expressway plan draws strong reactions

TEXT.P: Following the rejection of the environmental impact assessment report on the Suao-Hualien expressway, various groups have been expressing a range of views on the decision to effectively leave the matter up to the incoming Kuomintang government.

"The rejection of the project (by an environmental review panel) was really unexpected, " said Tsai Zhong-yue, a leader of one of the Hualien student groups that have been actively opposed to the project for years.
"We are happy about the decision, even though it did not totally focus on the environmental impact," he added.

The environmental review panel members rejected the construction plan due to several unresolved controversial issues, including the lack of a clear government policy on the development of eastern Taiwan.

"Our efforts have paid off, " said Lisin.haluwey, another student association leader who is of indigenous heritage. She said that her group will continue to pay close attention to developments on the issue.
But the Hualien County Council expressed disappointment over the decision, saying that the residents of the county will not be pleased.

"The expressway is necessary, in every way, for the people living in Hualien, " said Chen Tai-zhou, a member of the Hualien County Council, who had made a brief speech in favor of the plan during the review meeting.
"I think that the people will react strongly (to the decision)," he said, adding that proponents of the project will discuss in few days how to respond.

As the environmental impact assessment of the expressway designed to connect Suao and Hualien, eastern Taiwan was being reviewed Friday, many Hualien County residents came out to show their support for the project, while an estimated 200 students, each carrying a lily, traveled by train early from Hualien to Taipei and staged a guitar concert outside the meeting to demonstrate their concerns over the plan.

About two dozen Hualien County councilors also gathered some supporters outside the building of the Environmental Protection Administration, where they cried out for Hualien residents to be given a safe transportation option with the construction of the expressway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan protests Greenpeace shipboard check

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) issued a statement Friday that condemned Greenpeace activists for boarding a Taiwanese fishing boat in the South Pacific earlier this week to check for alleged illegal catch.

According to the statement, the Pingtung-based 98-ton "Niensheng No. 3" was on the open seas north of the Solomon Islands April 21 when Greenpeace activists interrupted its operations, using a 2,000-ton vessel equipped with a helicopter.

The Greenpeace activists, after circling the Taiwanese ship for nearly an hour aboard a yacht, demanded permission to board to check whether there was any illegal shark fin harvest or excessive tuna fishing.

"The Ninensheng skipper had no choice but to accede to the request by the Greenpeace activists," the statement said, adding that although the activists did not find any evidence of irregularities after a thorough inspection that included photographing, they continued to trail the Taiwanese ship for six to seven hours after they returned to their own yacht.
The activists did not stop the chase until after the Taiwanese ship entered the Solomon Islands' exclusive economic zone.

According to the International Marine Law, when a vessel is operating on the open seas, it is under the jurisdiction of the country with which it registered or the country to which its skipper belongs.
As the Niensheng No. 3 was fishing on the open seas, the statement said, its skipper could have legally rejected the Greenpeace activists' demand for shipboard inspection, inquiry or law enforcement.

Stressing that the Niensheng No. 3 is high on the list of vessels permitted to fish in the region by the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC) and the South Pacific Forum Fisheries Agency (FFA), the statement argued that Greenpeace activists' forced shipboard check, without the Taiwan government's approval, was in stark violation of Taiwan's legal jurisdiction and the International Law.
"We strongly protest the Greenpeace activists' action, " the statement read.
The incident marked the first time that a Taiwanese fishing vessel fell victim to Greenpeace's forced shipboard inspections on the open seas.

Fishery officials urged that Taiwanese deep-sea fishing vessels to immediately ask relevant government agencies to assist in grappling with the issues if they encounter a similar situation in the future.
The Niensheng No.3 left Taiwan Jan. 16 for operations in waters near the Solomon Islands which has issued a license to allow the ship to fish for tuna, sailfish and shark.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan County offers free entry to Dongshan River Water Park

TEXT.P: The Yilan County government has decided to allow free entry to the Dongshan River Water Park from May 1 to July 11 in an attempt to attract visitors to the county.

County government officials acknowledged Friday that the park, which attracted more than 1 million visitors each year from its inception in 1994 to 2004, has seen declining numbers in the past three years, probably because its facilities are no longer fresh and appealing.

The water park was selected as the venue of the annual Yilan International Collegiate Invitational Regatta between 1996 and 2005, and the annual Yilan International Children's Folklore and Folkgame Festival for 12 years between 1995 and 2006. Both events were terminated mainly because the county government could no longer afford the financial losses.
With the summer tourism season approaching, the county government decided to waive all entry fees -- NT$80 per adult, NT$60 per child, and NT$40 per senior citizen -- for 72 days from May 1.
Visitors, however, are still required to pay parking fees for their vehicles -- NT$100 each for buses, NT$50 for cars and NT$20 for motorcycles.
The Dongshan River Water Park opened to the public in 1994, with "water intimacy" as its theme. The park contains a boating area, a paddling area and a family area.
The main facilities in the park include an outdoor theater, paddling pools, a museum with exhibits of dragon boats, a swimming pool and a gym.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Philippines weather observation station opens
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, the Philippines, April 24 (CNA) 04/26/08 10:55:21 (By Emerson T. Lim and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: A weather observation station, established by Taiwan and the Philippines, was inaugurated in the Filipino province of Rizal Thursday to help both countries better predict typhoons and enhance the accuracy of weather forecasts.

The establishment of the weather station in the province 20 kilometers east of Manila is the result of one of two bilateral projects between Taiwan's National Science Council (NSC) and the Philippines' Department of Science and Technology (DOST).
Taiwan donated US$170,000 last November to fund the research projects, which are focused on weather disaster prevention and rainfall analysis technology.
The weather station will collect data on typhoons and general climatic information by releasing high-altitude weather balloons tied to a radio monitoring device on a daily basis.

The balloon and monitoring device cost a combined NT$14,500 (US$477) and cannot be reused. The device will send data back to the station's computers for analysis, and the data can then be sent to Taiwan.
NSC chief Chen Chien-jen said after presiding over the inauguration ceremony that the device can gather data on wind speed, wind direction, temperature, and ambient humidity.
The data, he said, would result in more accurate prediction of the formation and the paths of typhoons, and could help safeguard the lives and property of people in both countries.
He also said that Taiwan and the Philippines, which do not have official ties, will increase the training and exchange of personnel, and share satellite weather data.

Taiwan's representative to the Philippines Wu Hsin-hsing, who was also present at the ceremony, said that the two countries are geographically close and that many typhoons that hit Taiwan are formed off the coast of the Philippines.
The bilateral cooperation will expand the forecasting scope of Taiwan's central weather bureau to include its neighbor to the south, Wu continued.
The envoy also said he hopes that both sides can strengthen technological collaboration in other fields, which he believed will be conducive to bilateral relations.
For his part, DOST Secretary Estrella Alabastro said at the ceremony he hopes that Taiwan and the Philippines can maintain a long-term technological collaboration.

Antonio Basilio, Taipei-based representative of Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) , thanked Taiwan its cooperation on the project and for a previous donation of a school dormitory and relief supplies it made to help a village in the Philippines, which was hard hit by a huge mudslide recently.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP official regrets Ma's not-guilty verdict

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan expressed his regret Friday over the Supreme Court's decision to uphold lower court rulings that President-elect Ma Ying-jeou was not guilty of corruption.

Lee's remarks came a day after the Supreme Court finalized a ruling that Ma was not guilty of the charges related to his alleged misuse of special allowance funds during his term as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.

Noting that Ma once described special allowance funds as "public funds" to be used on government business, Lee, citing the indictment, said Ma used the money on his dog, utility bills and his daughters' tuition.

This was hard evidence of Ma's use of the public funds for private purposes, Lee said, adding that Ma, who will take office May 20, should still explain these matters or apologize even though he was found not guilty.

The Taipei District Court and Taiwan High Court ruled that the part of Ma's special allowance in question, the half that he did not need to justify with receipts, was a "substantive subsidy" that was for an official's discretionary use and not "public funds."

Although it was not a material part of its ruling, the Supreme Court disagreed with the lower courts' definition and said the special allowance was a "public fund" and had to be spent on job-related expenses.

The definition of the special allowance and its usage was the key issue in Ma's trials, and Lee urged judicial agencies to establish a uniform definition of the fund for central and local government officials and create an authoritative standard for similar cases.
Vice President Annette Lu and other central and local officials have also been indicted for their alleged misuse of their public funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to join U.S. wind energy show

TEXT.P: Thirteen Taiwanese manufacturers are expected to take part for the first time in an annual wind energy exhibition slated for June in Texas, Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) officials said Saturday.
TAITRA will set up a Taiwan pavilion consisting of 18 booths at the show, the officials said.

Scheduled for June 1-4 in Houston, Windpower 2008 is North America's largest annual event for the wind energy industry. This year's participants are expected to include such leading manufacturers as GE Energy, Gamesa Wind US, Vestas, Repower Systems AG and Siemens Wind Power.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese Americans urge U.S. president to boycott Olympics opening
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 25 (CNA) 04/26/08 13:56:59 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The leaders of 21 Taiwanese American groups have urged U.S. President George W. Bush to boycott the opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympics slated for August over China's violent crackdown on Tibetan protesters and its military intimidation of Taiwan.
In a letter dated April 24, the leaders told Bush that if he were to attend the event, he "would be viewed as endorsing China's appalling policies toward Tibet and Taiwan."
"In the words of His Holiness the Dalai Lama, China is carrying out `cultural genocide' in Tibet. The United States must not be seen as colluding in committing this crime," they said.

Noting that Bush's repeated calls for China to enter into dialogue with the Dalai Lama "have all but fallen on deaf ears, " the leaders said China's brutal suppression of protesters in Tibet should not be tolerated as "business as usual."

They dismissed as "arrogant" and "imperialistic" a demand by Chinese President Hu Jintao that the Dalai Lama accept Tibet and Taiwan as "inalienable parts of China" as a precondition for Tibet-China dialogue.
"Hu is a dictator to be shunned, rather than an enlightened leader with whom you should share the stage in celebrating the Olympics, " they said.
The Taiwanese Americans pointed out that several European leaders have announced their intention to boycott the event and urged Bush to make a similar announcement immediately.

Those who signed the letter included Formosan Association for Public Affairs President Bob Yang, Taiwanese Association of America Ron Shieh, World Federation of Taiwanese Associations President Susan Chang, World Taiwanese Congress Coordinator C.K. Kuo, North America Taiwanese Women's Association President Darice Lee, Austin Institute of Taiwan Studies President Jack Chen, Chhong-Bi Memorial Fund President Adam Huang and Dr. Kang-Lu Wang Memorial Foundation President Kang-Hou Wang.
