DOC.HEADLINE: Japan urged to help have Taiwanese dam listed as world heritage site
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/08 14:30:33 (By Yang Ming-chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japan should help have the United Nations list a Taiwanese reservoir built by a Japanese engineer during Japan's colonial rule of Taiwan as a world heritage site, Taiwan's representative to Japan has suggested.

Koh Se-kai, head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan, made the call in a speech delivered Friday to a group of academics and business executives in Kanazawa, capital of Ishikawa Prefecture.
Noting that Taiwan and Ishikawa have a special historical link, Koh said the Wushantou reservoir in southern Taiwan's Tainan County was built by Yoichi Hatsuta, an Ishikawa-born engineer.

"Hatsuta built the reservoir, the greatest of its kind of that time in Southeast Asia, using the semi-hydraulic-filled-dam construction method," Koh said, adding that its 16,000 km-long canal and drainage system have made the Jia-Nan plain covering Tainan and neighboring Chiayi counties the rice basket of Taiwan.
"With its rich historical, cultual and technological significance, the reservoir deserves to be listed as a world heritage site," Koh said.

However, Taiwan cannot file an application with the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) on its own as it is no longer a member of the world body. "Against this backdrop, we need your assistance to realize the ambitious goal," Koh told his audience.

Filing an application for UNESCO world heritage listing on other's behalf is permissible, Koh went on, adding that France has, for instance, asked the U.N.-affiliated organization to list 23 historically important buildings scattered across seven countries around the globe as world heritage sites.

All 23 buildings were designed by the internationally renowned 20th Century French architect Le Corbusier (1887-1965). Among them is the National Museum of Western Art in Tokyo, which was completed in March 1959 as a symbol of the resumption of diplomatic ties between Japan and France after World War II.
"If you take pride in the construction of the Wushantou reservoir, you should not hesitate to lend a helping hand, " Koh urged.

The Republic of China -- Taiwan's official title -- was a founding member of the United Nations, but it was forced out of the organization in 1971 when the world body gave the "China seat" to the People's Republic of China at its expense.

In his Friday speech, Koh further said Taiwan-Japan exchanges will get another boost June 1 when scheduled flights between Ishikawa's Komatsu Airport and Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport will be inaugurated.
He also called for Japan to adhere to its policy toward Taiwan if it signs a fourth communique with China when Chinese President Hu Jintao visits Japan early next month.
"Japan should not waver on its stance of just `understand' and `respect, ' but not `recognize' China's claim that Taiwan is part of its territory," he urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan reps to UNPII gathering hold Taiwan aboriginal night activity

TEXT.P: Representatives of several Taiwan aboriginal tribes held a "Taiwan aboriginal night" activity at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York Friday.
The representatives are attending the seventh session of the U.N. Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues (UNPFII) being held in New York April 21-May 2.
They invited other participants in the forum from around the world to take part in the gathering, in which they gave a briefing on the current situation regarding Taiwan's aboriginal population.
The representatives, dressed in traditional costume, also put on several song and dance performances for the guests, and traditional aboriginal snacks and beverages were served.

Speaking at the gathering, Kenneth Liao, director of the New York TECO, thanked the aboriginal representatives from around the world for their assistance and support for Taiwan's efforts to take part in international organizations and activities.
Over 3,000 aboriginal representatives are taking part in this year's UNPFII gathering, which will include more than 300 forums and friendship-building activities.
The theme of the UNPFII's seventh session is "climate change, bio-cultural diversity and livelihoods: the stewardship role of indigenous peoples and new challenges."

Taiwan's representatives are scheduled to host a forum at the gathering April 29. The main topics of the forum will be handling land issues in a fair manner, and the controversy over aboriginal surnames in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan regrets continued placement on U.S. `Special 301' watch list

TEXT.P: Taiwanese officials expressed regret Saturday on a U.S. decision to keep the country on a watch list for intellectual property rights (IPR) protection.

The Intellectual Property Office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs noted that Taiwan has long been working to establish a friendly environment for IPR protection and urged the U.S. government to consider the efforts made by Taiwan in recent years.

The efforts have received recognition from the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, which recommended in March that the United States remove Taiwan from the "Special 301" watch list, the officials said.

In the annual Special 301 Report released Friday, the Office of the United States Trade Representative (USTR) said an out-of-cycle review will be initiated soon and completed this summer to monitor progress on "selected outstanding issues" to assess whether to remove Taiwan from the list.

On Taiwan's achievements in IPR protection over the past year, the report noted that the Legislative Yuan passed in June 2007 a new law aimed at ending illegal file-sharing over peer-to-peer platforms, which enabled officials to shut down some of the worst violators.

Other progress made by Taiwan includes continued efforts to establish an IP section at the Special Prosecutors Office, and the creation and issuance in October 2007 of the Action Plan for Protecting IP Rights on School Campuses, the report said.

However, the USTR urges Taiwan to make the specialized IPR Court operational as soon as possible, continue to implement the 2007 Campus Action Plan, continue its efforts to combat counterfeiting and Internet piracy, and work closely with the Legislative Yuan to pass pending IPR legislation regarding liability of Internet service providers for copyright infringements.

Also, Taiwan is asked to continue to take effective action against piracy on the Internet, especially on TANet -- the Internet service provider administered by Taiwan's Ministry of Education -- and against the unauthorized use of copyrighted material on or near universities.

The annual Special 301 Report, which reviews the adequacy and effectiveness of IPR protection by U.S. trade partners, placed nine countries on the Priority Watch List and 36 countries on the lower level Watch List for 2008.
After remaining on the Priority Watch List for four years, Taiwan was lowered to the Watch List at the end of 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins ice hockey Asia Challenge Cup

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei won the first ever IIHF Asia Challenge Cup Saturday, defeating Malaysia 5-2 in their last game in the round-robin tournament in Hong Kong.
Chinese Taipei's win, coupled with Hong Kong's 4-2 loss to Thailand earlier in the day, gave the Taiwan squad the championship.
Cho Yu-wei scored two goals, while Cheng Chung-yu, Deng Wen-fu and Chen Yen-chih added one each to help the Chinese Taipei side to victory.
Lin Tsung-han, who won the most valuable goalie award at the recent IIHF under-18 Division Three tournament held in Mexico City, played a solid game between the pipes Friday to keep Malaysia at bay.
The Taiwan squad was able to bounce back from a 2-1 loss to Hong Kong Thursday to defeat Singapore 2-1 and then thrash Macau 9-0 in their next two games.
A total of six teams took part in the tournament sponsored by the International Ice Hockey Federation -- Chinese Taipei, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Macau, Thailand and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung urban bike paths surpass 100 km in length

TEXT.P: The southern port city of Kaohsiung celebrated Saturday the breaking of the 100-km mark for the total length of its bicycle path system.

Mayor Chen Chu cycled on the Side Harbor Line of the urban bike system along with Public Works Bureau Director Wu Hung-mou and City Councilor Lin Yi-cheng of the opposition People First Party, as well as Kaohsiung citizens, to mark the event. Kaohsiung now has the longest urban bike path in Taiwan.

Comparing the city with London, Wu said the density of bike paths in Kaohsiung will catch up with London by the end of this year, by which time the total length of bike paths in the city will have reached 150 km.
London has 1,500 km of bike paths, but the city is also 10 times larger than Kaohsiung, Wu said.
According to Public Works Bureau data, as of April 20, the total length of Kaohsiung City's urban bike system had reached 105.68 km, and will have expanded to 167.05 km by September 2010.
Chen said the city government is also building bike paths around Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) stations to allow commuters to ride to the MRT before catching a train to their workplace.

The bike system is part of a strategy to save energy and reduce carbon emissions, the mayor said, noting that in the past, the air pollution rate in Kaohsiung City was recorded at 10 percent, but has dropped to 6.3 percent recently, according to tests by the Environmental Protection Administration.
The city government will be outlining more green projects, including a bike rental program that is already being carried out, Chen said.

The Kaohsiung urban bike system, covering prime city areas and key tourist attractions, is made up of five separate networks -- including the riverside bluebelt bike path, the boulevard bike path, the rapid transit commuting bike path, the landscape roadway bike path and the park bike path.
Detailed information of the system is available online at http://pwbgis.kcg.gov.tw/bicycle in both Chinese and English.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma should focus more on minority rights: minority groups

TEXT.P: Representatives of minority groups urged the incoming administration of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou Saturday to take more care of the rights of minorities, such as indigenous people, foreign spouses and foreign laborers.
They made the appeal at a forum organized by the Community Empowering Society, Taiwan, the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan and the Organization of Urban Re-s.

Sechin Yeong-Shyang Chien, an associate research fellow of Academia Sinica, Taiwan' s top research institute, said that while Taiwan is making more efforts toward reconciliation with various ethnic groups, "the rights of aborigines, foreign spouses and foreign laborers should also be emphasized."

Lan Ki-hue, a Vietnamese spouse fo a local man who represents the TransAsia Sisters Association, said local people are not familiar with alien cultures and that this has inflicted psychological wounds upon foreign spouses and their children.

"Inappropriate language and words used by locals to refer to foreign spouses and their children have caused misunderstandings and have hurt our children, " said Lan, adding that " the government should set up regulations to punish offenders."

On behalf of the estimated 365,000 foreign laborers in Taiwan, mainly from Southeast Asia, Ku Yu-ling, chairwoman of the Taiwan International Workers' Association, said the rights of foreign laborers are infringed upon in Taiwanese society for "they cannot be naturalized and possess no right to vote."
Ku lamented the lack of political rights that has "enslaved" foreign workers, depriving them of the right to choose their own employers and making them "slaves under feudalism."
"There will be no reconciliation within Taiwanese society if this inhumane situation is not improved," she added.

Paiwan aboriginal poet Monanung said that indigenous people have been treated as subhumans during past centuries, and urged the new administration to understand the real meaning of prioritizing ethnic groups.

A harmonious nation should be not only reconciliation among ethic groups but also between the people and nature, Monanung said, adding that the incoming administration should stop depredating the land for profit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins 4 golds at Asian culinary contest in Singapore
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/08 17:00:52 (By Charles Kang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese chefs and culinary students won four golds medals at an Asian culinary competition held in Singapore earlier this week, Taiwan's best performance in the past eight years in the biennial competition, a culinary professsional said Saturday.

According to Chen Hung-bin, secretary-general of the Taiwan Formosa Chefs Association, the Food and Hotel Asia Culinary Challenge (FCC) held at the Singapore Expo is Asia's most prestigious culinary competition, with winners receiving world recognition.

More than 50 Taiwanese participants from hotels, restaurants and culinary institutes, led by the Taiwan Formosa Chefs Association, took part in the international culinary event along with competitors from more than 20 countries and areas including Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, Arab, Australia, Mexico and America.
Among the four gold medals, three went to professional chefs Chiang Mei-chun, Wang Tsung-ming and Pan Juei-tzung.

The other gold was won by a two-member team from the Taipei Kai-ping Culinary School. Two students -- Chang Tzung-wen and Chen Lin-chieh won the Super Gold prize with their salmon appetizer and a mutton dish under the category "Hot Cooking -- Two to Tango."
The Taiwanese participants also won six silvers and five bronzes under a number of categories, both individually and as a team.

The FCC, supervised by the World Association of Cooks Societies -- a global network of chefs association -- is one of a series of culinary competitions of the Food and Hotel 2008, which is Asia's biggest exhibition and conference event of the industry.
Over 600 chefs and apprentices from the world took part in the internationally acclaimed competition, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8 divers missing off southern Taiwan coast

TEXT.P: Eight holidaymakers were reported missing Saturday while scuba diving in waters off Kenting National Park at the southernmost tip of Taiwan, according to coast guard sources.

The eight people -- six men and two women -- were diving in waters between Oluanbi and Chihsingyen with the assistance of a dive company when they lost contact with their dive boat, the coast guard officials said.

The Hengchun squad of the Coast Guard Administration in charge of coastal patrols off Kenting National Park launched a sea and aerial search as soon as they were informed of the case at 12: 10 p.m., the officials said.
The search was still going on as of press time.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC optimistic about project for manufacturing flu vaccine
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/08 17:39:39 (By Neil Lu and Emmanuelle Tzeng)

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan's first build-own-operate (BOO) project for manufacturing flu vaccine has been delayed for about three years, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) remains optimistic that the project will eventually proceed and that Taiwan will find itself in a superior position compared to developing countries.

The project, initiated in 2004, was officially launched by the CDC in late 2005 with the aim of establishing the capacity to manufacture enough flu vaccine, which can be transferred to produce pandemic trivalance flu vaccine, should an H5N1-like pandemic occur.
It would also make Taiwan the first developing country to manufacture flu vaccine using the second generation cell-based method.

But the ambitious project has met a variety of obstacles, both inside and outside of Taiwan. A deal between the CDC and the Dutch pharmaceutical company Akzo Nobel was put on hold, first due to opposition from domestic industries and then by the acquisition of Akzo Nobel by Schering-Plough.

A high-ranking CDC official, speaking on condition of anonymity, told CNA that both the CDC and Schering-Plough Corp. are still very hopeful of reaching consensus, saying that "the project is not dead, we just have not signed the contract yet."
Admitting that the negotiations have been at a standstill since the U.S.-based pharmaceutical company demanded "a looser schedule, " the CDC hopes not to reopen negotiations.
The official further indicated that Schering-Plough is still very interested in the project and that a senior official will soon visit Taiwan to discuss the matter.
Asked if the CDC is concerned by the fact that South Korea will begin to produce flu vaccine in 2010, the official said Taiwan can still take the lead in this area among developing countries.

"What we plan to produce is tissue-based vaccine, which means cell cultivation, " said the official, adding that the vaccine that South Korea plans to produce is egg-based, which is a first- generation technology.
He added that the company chose to cooperate with Taiwan rather than with China because it "considers Taiwan's intellectual property rights protection to be much better."

According to the original plan, the vaccine plant should have been completed in 2007 and operational in 2008, producing 2.5 million doses of trivalence flu vaccine on an annual basis, with the Department of Health promising to purchase the vaccine for NT$4 billion (US$1.3 billion).
Despite the CDC's optimism, however, the earliest possible target time for the project will be 2011, and then only if the two parties can reach an agreement this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two quakes rock eastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Two moderate earthquakes hit the eastern county of Taitung Saturday afternoon, seismologists at the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said, adding that no casualties were reported.

The first of the temblors, measuring 4.4 on the open-ended Richter scale, occurred at 1: 10 p.m., with the epicenter located 35.5 km southeast of the CWB Chengkung seismic station in Taitung at a depth of 6.2 km under the ocean floor, the seismologists said.
The second, measuring 4.1 on the Richter scale, struck at 3:44 p.m., with the epicenter located 12.2 km west of the CWB's Taitung seismic station at a depth of 8.1 km underground, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT honorary chairman to meet with Chinese president

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan is scheduled to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao during a planned visit to China, sources close to Lien said Saturday.

Lien, who will depart Monday for China, is slated to meet Hu in Beijing the following day, according to the sources. The Chinese head of state will also host a banquet in Lien's honor later that same day, they added.
If all goes as planned, it will mark the fourth meeting between Lien and Hu since April 29, 2005.
The sources said that Minister Without Portfolio-designate Tsai Hsun-hsiung, former Vice Premier Hsu Li-teh, KMT Vice Chairman Lin Feng-cheng and several entrepreneurs will accompany Lien.

During his two days in the Chinese capital, Lien will also attend a ceremony to mark the unveiling of a bronze sculpture by Taiwanese artist Yang Ying-feng at one of the venues for the Beijing Olympics. The sculpture was given to Hu by Lien during a 2006 visit to China.
Luo Chih-chiang, a spokesman for President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, said Ma and Lien have had smooth communications and share the same views on cross-Taiwan Strait matters.

Meanwhile, Lien's aides said that Lien has built foundations for closer cross- strait contact through his recent China visits and that these can be used as a supplementary platform by Taiwan's new administration in communicating with China in addition to the channels between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies -- Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police bust over 100 land-damage cases in four days

TEXT.P: The National Police Agency (NPA) cracked 104 criminal land damage actions April 21-24 in an effort to reduce the devastation that occur in the event of a natural disaster, according to a report released Saturday by the agency.
Over the four days, the NPA raided 33 illegal sand and gravel extraction operations and 71 illegal logging operations, arresting a total of 207 suspects, the report said.
Efforts have been strengthened to protect the land after earthquakes, typhoons and floods have taken many lives and destroyed numerous houses, buildings and public facilities over the years.

Illegal gravel extraction has been rampant in Taiwan since demand for gravel has surged in the construction industry, as many major government construction projects are underway and sales in the housing sector are growing, NPA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Melamine tableware most prone to microbe formation: study

TEXT.P: Scratches left on tableware can allow the formation of bacterial residue, with melamine dining ware the most prone to high amounts of microbial residue, a professor said Saturday.

Tsai Wen-cheng, a professor at National Yang Ming University, made the remarks when he unveiled the result of tests he conducted for bacterial residue on six types of tableware commonly found on the Taiwanese market.
The six types of dining ware are classed as three-fold strengthened glass, strengthened glass, strengthened porcelain, porcelain, aluminum and melamine.

Tsai said that after the tableware had been used for six months, he applied units of microbes such as e. coli, staphylococcus aureus, pseudomonas aeruginosa and salmonella enterica to their surfaces. He then left it to dry naturally before washing and assessing the microbial residue.
"The test results show that melamine tableware had the highest quantities of microbial residue," Tsai said.

The melamine plates had 7,600 colony-forming units (CFUs) , followed by the strengthened glass tableware at 1,875 CFUs, aluminum tableware at 1,572 CFUs, porcelain tableware at 1,450 CFUs, strengthened porcelain at 820 CFUs and three- fold strengthened glass at 740 CFUs.
Melamine tableware is very popular in kindergartens, eateries and some families because it is so difficult to break.
If scratched, however, large amounts of microbial residue will form on melamine tableware, especially e. coli, which can cause urinary tract infection, diarrhea, encephalitis and septicemia.

Of the staphylococcus aureus residue, aluminum tableware had the highest residue, followed by melamine. Strengthened glass, three-fold strengthened glass, porcelain and strengthened porcelain tableware had no residue.
Of the pseudomonas aeruginosa residue, melamine was the worst offender, followed by strengthened glass, strengthened porcelain and aluminum.
In terms of salmonella enterica residue, strengthened glass had the most residue, while the three-fold strengthened glass had the least.

Tsai suggested that consumers choose solid tableware that does not break easily and that has a glossy surface. The public should also avoid using scratched tableware, while dishes used for children and the elderly should undergo ultraviolet or high temperature disinfection after use.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins silver in Singapore cuisine competition
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/08 19:10:28 (By Charles Kang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese team won the silver medal with dishes with a Taiwanese flavor at a Chinese cuisine competition held in Singapore earlier this week, scoring lightly less than the host country, a team member said Saturday.
The Imperial Challenge competition, showing Chinese cuisine at its best, was one of a series of culinary events held along with the biennial Food and Hotel 2008 in the city state.

The five-member team, put together by the Taiwan Master Chef Academy and led by Chen Chao-lin, received training at Chen's restaurant for several months in Yilan County in northern Taiwan before the competition.

The team competed with eight others from China, Singapore and Malaysia in the three-day competition that ran from April 22-25, qualifying for the final round with a team from China and another from Singapore Thursday, Chen said.
In the final round, each team was tasked with making Chinese dishes with a list of designated materials and ingredients within a limited time.

The team won the silver medal with a meal of smoked chicken, soup made of dried Chinese carrots, a mutton dish with Taiwanese fruit, and Kao Cha -- deep fried meat cake, an Yilan County specialty, all served in Japanese and French display styles, Chen said.

He explained that the foreign display styles were used in the hope of winning higher scores from the judges, based on the consideration that a Singaporean team won the top prize at an international culinary contest held in Taiwan last year with entries displayed in a Western style.
He added that Taiwan was the only team to finish all its dishes within the one- hour time limit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Passengers to benefit most from Taiwan-China direct flights

TEXT.P: As airlines operating the Taiwan-Hong Kong and the Taiwan-Macau routes gear up for the opportunities and challenges brought by direct flights linking Taiwan and China, passengers without doubt will come out as the biggest winners.

The direct flight services, one of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's main election campaign policies, are slated to kick off in July, initially covering weekends before later expanding to daily flights by the end of this year, ending decades- long indirect flights in which passengers have to transfer via a third place, mostly Hong Kong.

According to unofficial counts, 4 million Taiwanese visit China annually, of which 70 percent travel through Hong Kong, making the route a "golden route" for carriers thanks to its high load rate and revenue.

In response to reports in the local media that China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's biggest carrier, is planning to reduce its services between Taipei and Hong Kong when daily direct flight services are implemented, Ringo Chao, chairman and president of CAL said optimistically that the company is ready for weekend direct flights.

Characterizing the direct services as a positive development, Chao said that "it not only lets passengers enjoy cheaper fares and save a lot of time, but also benefits CAL, " one of the largest carriers on the Taiwan-Hong Kong route second only to Cathy Pacific Airways.
"CAL will no longer need to share revenue with its Chinese counterpart," he noted.

Chao declined to comment in detail on how CAL will adjust its operations, saying only that "matters such as flight destinations and frequency can only be decided by the related authorities of Taiwan and China."
Eric Lin, manager of the Public Affairs Division at EVA Air, said that "EVA will deal with the changes after the new government issues directives on direct flights."
According to Lin, an estimated 1 million passengers fly with EVA to Hong Kong per year, and some 50 percent to 70 percent of them then transfer to China.
EVA operates eight daily flights between Taipei and Hong Kong, four flights between Taipei and Macau and another two between the southern port city of Kaohsiung and Macau.

Lin reiterated that "the direct services really benefit our airlines and also make it more convenient for passengers, " and added that that "we have been looking forward to this moment for a long time.

While CAL and EVA are seen as the major benefactors of the direct flights, the Hong Kong-based Cathay Pacific and Macau-based Air Macau seem set to lose some ground since they are excluded from the direct flights.
But an aviation expert disagreed, saying if direct flights are limited to a few destinations and frequencies, the impact on Cathay will be minimal.

He also noted that Cathay has been expecting the change since "day one, " implying that it is ready for the new challenge. As a major hub connecting Asia and Europe and America, many Taiwanese passengers heading for London and Paris still have to use Cathay.
Dragonair, an affiliate of Cathay that provides services to 21 destinations in China from Hong Kong, could be another factor keeping Cathay in the race.
Air Macau, which operates 10 flights between Taiwan and Macau and another three flights between Kaohsiung and Macau, could be in a much more difficult situation.

Noting that some 70 percent of its 400,000 passengers go to China through Macau annually and that Taiwan-China direct flights must eat into its profits from the Taiwan-Macau-China routes, Gary Yang, marketing and sales manager of Air Macau, Taiwan, remained optimistic.

"This (direct links between Taiwan and China) is already a trend that Air Macau has expected for a long time," Lin said, adding that " our company cannot solely rely on one route and needs to make changes accordingly."

Although Air Macau will not have a share of the direct flights, Yang said it will devote itself to providing passengers with more diverse services, adding that "Air Macau also has its advantages as it brings passengers to 12 destinations around China on a daily basis."
Another expert warned that the prospect for CAL and EVA might not be so rosy as expected, since airlines in China will join in the competition for the direct flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: 74 Thai students take Taiwan scholarship examination in Bangkok
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/08 19:35:09 (By Lin Ching-ping and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Seventy-four Thai students took a qualification examination Saturday at Dhonburi Rajabhat University in Bangkok to bid for a scholarship for study in Taiwan.
The Taiwan Scholarship examination was held by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Thailand for the third consecutive year.

There are 11 scholarships being offered this year, according to Chang Chun-chun, who is responsible for cultural affairs at the office, who added that each recipient will get NT$25,000 (US$824) a year for study at a Taiwanese university for four years.

As for scholarship recipients who want to study at graduate institutes in Taiwan for a master's or doctoral degree, the scholarship will be NT$30,000 per year for two years for a master's degree, or three years for a doctorate, Chang said.
Among the exam participants, a lecturer known as Nirote at Chiang Mai University in northern Thailand caught people's attention.
Nirote, 28, showed up at the TECO wearing a monk's robes. He said he was in the middle of a three-week practice program that is often adopted by Thai young people.
Nirote said he is looking forward to studying in Taiwan after meeting many professors from there at Chiang Mai, and he added that he wants to seek doctorate in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City to hold last legally binding group marriage

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government will hold the last legally binding group wedding Sunday on Yangmingshan, a mountain suburb of the city, to coincide with the mountain's calla lily season, a local official said Saturday.
According to the official, marriages will only be legal after marriage registration at local household registration offices after an amendment to the Civil Law is implemented May 23.

The current regulations stipulate that a marriage is considered binding if there is a public ceremony and at least two notaries. "Ceremonial marriages" such as group weddings, notary weddings, religious wedding ceremonies and wedding banquets will no longer have legal effect, as the amended law requires a marriage registration, the official said.

In order to promote the new law and provide convenience for newlyweds, Taipei city government household registration office personnel will provide registration services for couples who attend Sunday's group wedding.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin will be the notary for the city's last group marriage with legal effect, the official said, adding that the city has held 193 group weddings for 14,607 couples since May 20, 1973.

The official said each couple that attends Sunday's wedding have their own special love stories and that in order to create a unforgettable group wedding for them, the city government chose the romantic venue with blooming white calla lilies and will present each couple with a marriage certificate made of gold foil.

DOC.HEADLINE: Search for 8 missing divers yields no results

TEXT.P: An all-out search for eight missing divers in waters off Kenting National Park at the southernmost tip of Taiwan had not yielded any results as of Saturday evening, according to coast guard sources.

The eight holidaymakers -- six men and two women -- were reported missing while scuba diving in waters near Chihsingyen, located some 12 nautical miles southwest of Kenting in the southernmost county of Pingtung, the sources said.

They left for Chihsingyen along with four other holidaymakers aboard a yacht early in the morning. With the assistance of a dive company, the 12 began scuba diving in waters between Oluanbi and Chihsingyen at 10:30 a.m. and were supposed to return to the yacht at 11:30 a.m.

However, eight of them failed to return to the yacht on schedule. Strong winds and high currents in the region meant that the skipper of the yacht failed to find the missing divers. The skipper then reported the case to the Hengchun coast guard squad in charge of coastal patrols in the Kenting National Park region.
Coast guard teams from Pingtung and neighboring Kaohsiung County launched an all-out sea and aerial search as soon as they were informed of the case at around noon, the sources said.
The eight missing divers were identified as Hung Yu-sheng, 29; Ting Po-ling, 32; Wang Chih-yu, 25; Wang Shun-ping, 28; Tu Ting-chang, 38; Kuo Chun-hsien, 38; Lee Su-ling, 44; and Liu Hui-chun, 28.
The search was still going on as of press time.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to rent accommodation after stepping down

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will rent a place in Taipei as a temporary measure after he steps down and moves out of his current official residence May 20, the Presidential Office said in a news release Saturday.
The statement said that Chen's own apartment on Taipei's Ming Sheng East Road is infested with termites and that although pest experts have been working on them, the problem has yet to be resolved.
In addition, it is better for Chen to remain in Taipei for the time being considering the physical condition of first lady Wu Shu-jen, who has been wheelchair-bound since a car accident in 1985.

The statement further said Chen has purchased an apartment in Kaohsiung. The president said while campaigning for Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu in 2006 that he loves Kaohsiung and would like to live in the southern port city after his retirement May 20, 2008.
The president has not purchased any other property and might shuttle between Taipei and Kaohsiung for some time after he steps down, according to the news release.

His daughter Chen Hsin-yu lived in the Ming Sheng East Road apartment after her marriage in 2001 but moved out in 2006 after her husband, orthopedic surgeon Chao Chien-ming, came under the media spotlight in connection with insider trading.
The news release also said that after the termite problem and safety issues are resolved, the president will consider moving back in or selling it.

Some TV reports have said that Chen's son, Chen Chih-chung, has bought a house worth NT$200 million (US$6.58 million) in Taipei's posh Hsinyi district, suggesting that the president might move in with his son, daughter-in-law and their toddler daughter.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT chairman could visit China after May 20

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung said Saturday that he might visit China after the May 20 inauguration of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou.

Wu said that as head of the ruling party, he is willing to visit China "as long as it will be conducive to cross-Taiwan Strait peaceful development, contribute to the improvement of the cross-strait atmosphere and benefit the safety of Taiwan and the welfare of its people."

On reports that cited Chinese sources as saying that Beijing hopes to keep the party-to-party communication forum -- referring to the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) -- which was started by honorary KMT Chairman Lien Chan in 2005, to discuss guiding principles on cross-strait relations, Wu said that Ma has expressed his stance clearly.

Ma hopes that the stalled communications between the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), can resume after a nine-year hiatus, with the KMT-CPC contact serving in a complementary role, Wu said.
The SEF and ARATS were set up by Taipei and Beijing authorities, respectively, to discuss mainly technical issues related to civic exchanges in the absence of official ties.
Reports have said that Lien will soon visit China and that he is expected to meet with Chinese leader Hu Jintao for the fourth time since their first meeting in 2005.

Wu made the remarks when he attended the 20th anniversary of the establishment of the I-Kuan Tao headquarters in Shihkang, Taichung County. I-Kuan Tao, a new religious movement that originated in 20th-Century China, incorporates much older elements from Confucianism, Taoism and Chinese Buddhism, and recognizes the validity of non-Chinese religious traditions such as Christianity and Islam.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP lawmaker calls for better epidemic control

TEXT.P: The incoming Kuomintang (KMT) government should exercise prudence in opening the door wider to Chinese visitors in order to keep epidemics at bay, a lawmaker from the soon-to-be-opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged Saturday.

Legislator Kuan Bi-ling made the call amid reports that President-elect Ma Ying-jeou is determined to launch direct weekend charter flights across the Taiwan Strait in early July and simultaneously opens Taiwan's door wider to Chinese tourists.

Kuan said she is worried that hasty opening to Chinese tourists could adversely impact Taiwan's disease control and epidemic prevention as some contagious illnesses, such as tuberculosis (TB) , are prevalent in China.

Just recently, Kuan said, the KMT-controlled Legislative Yuan invited relevant government officials to report on preparations for further opening to Chinese tourists along with the much-anticipated inauguration of direct cross-strait weekends charter flights.

"Much to my regret, no public health officials were invited to report on needed preparations for better disease control and prevention following the implementation of such 'open-door' policies, " Kuan said, adding that their absence reflects flawed policy planning.

Stressing that imposing stricter epidemic prevention measures does not mean any discrimination against Chinese tourists, Kuan said both outgoing and incoming governments should step up disease prevention efforts lest increased cross- strait engagements become a new source of disease spreading.

DOC.HEADLINE: Search for 8 missing divers continues

TEXT.P: Coast guard officers continued an all-out search for eight missing divers in waters off Kenting National Park at the southernmost tip of Taiwan late Saturday as family members were anxiously waiting for updated news in a nearby coastal town.

The eight holidaymakers -- six men and two women -- were reported missing while scuba diving in waters near Chihsingyen, located some 12 nautical miles southwest of Kenting in the southernmost county of Pingtung, coast guard officials said.

They left Houpihu fishing port in Hengchun township for Chihsingyen along with four other diving lovers aboard a yacht early in the morning. With the assistance of a dive company, the 12 began scuba diving in waters between Oluanbi and Chihsingyen at 10: 30 a.m. and were supposed to return to the yacht at 11:30 a.m.

However, eight of them failed to return to the yacht on schedule. Strong winds and high currents in the region meant that the skipper of the yacht failed to find the missing divers. The skipper then reported the case to the Hengchun coast guard squad in charge of coastal patrols in the Kenting National Park region.

Coast guard teams from Pingtung and neighboring Kaohsiung County and a national airborne rescue squad launched sea and aerial search as soon as they were informed of the case at around noon, coast guard officials said.
According to Hsu Yung-kang, deputy head of the 14th Coast Guard Squad based in Henchun, five of the missing divers possessed diving licenses.
The eight missing divers were identified as Hung Yu-sheng, 29; Ting Po-ling, 32; Wang Chih-yu, 25; Wang Shun-ping, 28; Tu Ting-chang, 38; Kuo Chun-hsien, 38; Lee Su-ling, 44; and Liu Hui-chun, 28.
The search was still going on as of press time. Hsu said coast guard patrol boats will expand their search areas.

The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
