DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 27, or the 22nd day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1521: Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan is killed by the inhabitants on the island of Mactan in the Philippines.
1791: American painter and inventor Samuel F.B. Morse is born. A portraitist whose subjects included Lafayette, he refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name.
1822: Ulysses S. Grant, the 18th president of the United States, is born. After his victorious Vicksburg campaign, he was made commander in chief of the Union Army and accepted the surrender of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee at Appomattox in 1865, thus ending the Civil War.
1882: Ralph Waldo Emerson, the American essayist, philosopher, and a central figure of American transcendentalism, dies at the age of 78. His poems, orations and essays are regarded as landmarks in the development of American thought and literary expression.
1887: The world's first surgical removal of an appendix, an operation known as an appendectomy, is performed by American surgeon Dr. Thomas Morton in Philadelphia.
1911: An uprising in Canton, China, is foiled when revolutionaries led by Huang Shing are defeated by the local garrison. The battle in Canton is the 10th uprising directed by Dr. Sun Yat-sen after he launched a revolutionary movement against the Ching court in the late 19th century.
1937: The new Golden Gate suspension bridge linking the city of San Francisco with Marin County reaches completion after four years.
1945: The Allies reject peace offers by German S.S. chief Heinrich Himmler, insisting on unconditional German surrender.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek arrives in Shanghai and reiterates his determination to suppress the communist rebellion.
1950: The British government officially recognizes the state of Israel.
1956: Rocco Marciano, known as "Rocky," the American boxer who won the world heavyweight championship in 1952 and defended it six times, retires as undefeated world heavyweight boxing champion.
1959: Liu Shao-chi is elected "state chairman" of Communist China.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with the Republic of Togo.
1960: Syngman Rhee resigns as president of South Korea, ending his 12-year rule.
1962: Hsieh Chin wins the "best director" award in the first film festival to be held in mainland China.
1972: After a journey to the moon, U.S. Apollo 16 spacecraft carrying three astronauts makes a safe landing in the Pacific Ocean.
1972: Kwame Nkrumah, the Ghanaian president who was deposed in 1966 by a military coup while he was in mainland China, dies in Bucharest, Hungary.
1973: Jordanian Ambassador to the ROC Mutasim Bileisi returns to Amman after a two-year tour of duty in Taipei.
1974: The Academia Sinica Advisory Council votes on a list of candidates for academicians.
1974: The Taiwan Railway Administration and General Electric of the United States sign a contract for the electrification of Taiwan's western trunk line railway. GE will provide 74 locomotives and heavy trucks for the project.
1978: President Mohammed Daoud is killed in a bloody coup and replaced by Afghanistan's first communist ruler, Nur Mohammed Taraki, who proclaims the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.
1992: The International Monetary Fund and World Bank approve the membership of Russia and 12 other former Soviet republics.
1993: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, meet in Singapore in what is the first official contact between Taipei and Beijing since 1949.
1997: The world's longest road-rail suspension bridge, linking Hong Kong to its new offshore airport, is formally opened.
1998: Nguyen Van Linh, former general secretary of the Vietnam Communist Party, dies.
1999: Verka Modanu, the Republic of Macedonia's first resident envoy to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume her post.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that only mutual trust can bring real peace to the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: The first-ever civic group to promote private exchanges between Taiwan- controlled offshore island of Kinmen and mainland China' Xiamen is formally established following the implementation of the "mini three links" with mainland China at the beginning of the year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When you meet the proper person to speak to and do not speak out, you lose your opportunity; but when you meet one who is not a proper person to speak to and you speak to him, you waste your words. A man of intelligence never loses his opportunity, neither does he waste his words."

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Torch security smothers relay
Olympic torch bearers dashed past sporadic protests Saturday as heavy security shielded the Japanese leg of the world relay by lining streets with thousands of riot police and closely monitoring the event with helicopters.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Under pressure, China to meet Dalai Lama's envoy.
The Chinese government said Friday that it would meet with a representative of the Dalai Lama in "coming days, " apparently bowing to international pressure after weeks of anti- Beijing protests that have threatened to tarnish the Olympics. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
MOFA to offer legal aid to Tibetan activist detained in Japan

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will offer legal aid to a Tibetan activist of Republic of China nationality who was arrested in Japan Saturday for attempting to disrupt the Nagano leg of the Beijing Olympic torch relay, an official said Sunday.

Tashi Tsering, vice chairman of the Taiwan chapter of the Tibetan Youth Congress, was arrested after he attempted to seize the Olympic torch from Ai Fukuhara, a Japanese table tennis player, during the flame's relay in Nagano in central Japan.

MOFA spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said Tashi Tsering is from a Tibetan family that took refuge in India after China took control of Tibet in the 1950s. He came to Taiwan in the 1990s and has obtained Republic of China citizenship.
According to Yeh, Tashi Tsering was detained and was to be held incommunicado for 48 hours at Nagano's central police station.

Taiwan's representative office in Japan has been informed of the incident, Yeh said, adding that the representative office will keep close tabs on the situation and will send staff members to see Tashi Tsering as soon as he is allowed to receive visitors.
"The representative office will consult lawyers in order to figure out feasible ways to assist him," Yeh added.

Nagano was the 16th stop of the 2008 Beijing Olympic torch relay. Japanese police dispatched over 3,000 officers to safeguard the torch, but minor clashes still broke out several times between Tibetan activists and Chinese expatriates in Japan. Besides Tashi Tsering, four Japanese activists were also arrested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's incoming top negotiator with China visits Xiamen
DOC.DATELINE: Xiamen, China, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/08 16:10:19 (By Ni Kuo-yen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Chiang Pin-kung, a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and chairman-designate of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , arrived in China's southeastern coastal city of Xiamen Saturday for a short visit.

Chiang, who has been appointed by KMT President-elect Ma Ying-jeou as Taiwan's top negotiator with China, met with He Lifeng, secretary of the Communist Party of China's Xiamen Municipal Committee, for talks in Xiamen Sunday.

Chiang told He that as soon as President-elect Ma is inaugurated May 20, he will see to it that cross-Taiwan Strait weekend charter flights are opened, restrictions on people traveling across the strait via Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu are relaxed and Taiwan opens its doors to Chinese tourists.

"Among other immediate benefits, the opening of direct air links across the Taiwan Strait will help lower the costs of Taiwanese businesses operating in China, which will help raise their competitiveness, " Chiang told his host.

"Closer cross-strait business and trade exchanges, including allowing the Taiwanese financial service sector and hospitals to open branches in China, will also contribute to raising the quality of China's business operations and services," he added.

For his part, He, the top official in charge of political and business policies in Xiamen City, said Xiamen, which has accelerated bilateral ties with the islands of Kinmen and Matsu over the past several years, is now more actively expanding its own seaport, airport facilities and road development to prepare itself for engaging in closer trade and tourist exchanges with Taiwan.

He said Xiamen not only hopes to see the opening of direct cross-strait air links and the cancellation of all restrictions on the "mini three links, " but also looks forward to seeing the opening of direct shipping links between Xiamen and Taiwan proper.

It is Chiang's sixth visit to Fujian Province. The last time he was in Xiamen was in September 2007, when he attended a workshop on international investment in China sponsored by the Xiamen authorities.
Chiang flew from Shanghai to Xiamen a day earlier on an executive plane provided exclusively for him by the Shanghai-based Taiwanese firm Want Want China Holding.

The Xiamen visit was the third leg of a five-city tour of southern China, mainly to express appreciation on behalf of Ma to the Taiwanese businessmen there, many of whom showed avid support for Ma in the March 22 presidential election.
Chiang, who has visited Shanghai and Kunshan in Jiangsu Province since April 24, was scheduled to depart from Xiamen Sunday for Shenzhen and Dongguan in Guangdong Province.
The five southern Chinese cities are areas where most of the Taiwan businessmen operating in China converge.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Government, Lega stopped.
Italian incoming premier Silvio Berlusconi met Umberto Bossi, leader of the Lega Nord, Saturday at the Lega's headquarters in Milan. The meeting was aimed at discussions on the formation of the new government. Berlusconi said after the meeting that nothing had been confirmed and that "we were going ahead satisfactorily."

DOC.HEADLINE: Local holding company recruitment exam attracts 6,020 applicants

TEXT.P: In a bid to recruit high-quality employees, Taiwan's Hua Nan Financial Holdings (HNFH) brought together all seven of its subsidiaries to expand its first united recruitment exam which was held Sunday, attracting 6,020 applicants with a near-7 percent pass rate.

Facing the U.S. subprime mortgage crisis that has shaken the global financial market and the potential policies pledged by the incoming administration to intensify economic ties across the Taiwan Strait, HNFH Chairman Lin Ming-cheng said the company is targeting applicants that could become the backbone of the financial group currently among the top 10 of the country's financial holding companies.

"We have set high thresholds for the application qualifications, implementing a recruiting strategy that will help us to find the best people to cope with the challenges in the financial world," Lin said, pinpointing a potential relaxation of regulations governing cross-strait banking investment, which is one of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's campaign commitments.
The expanded exam opens 420 job vacancies within three major categories -- banking agents, counter staff and middle management.

Citing the higher-quality demand of the recruitment drive, Lin said that the subjects for the written exam for middle management include financial management, international business and economics, along with an oral exam requiring fluent English-language listening and speaking.

Lin further indicated that the company plans to send some of these qualifiers overseas for further training, saying that the international financial crisis has led to the need for globally trained bankers.

Unlike the past HNFH recruitment exams, which were held separately among its subsidiaries, including Hua Nan Commercial Bank and Hua Nan Securities, the group this year integrated its resources and conformed the test standards to increase transparency and fairness, Lin said.

"We made a groundbreaking change in the test formality in an attempt to lure the most professional employees in the financial business," Lin noted, adding that this new measure will be continued into future recruitment drives.

Touching on China's financial market, Lin said the company hopes to be among the first to make inroads into the 1.3 billion China market, but noted that this plan will not be implemented until Taiwan and China seal an agreement on financial regulations.
"We are waiting for the government to negotiate with China to allow local banks to upgrade their offices in China," Lin said.

HNFH President David J.Y. Lee said that if the bank has suffered losses incurred by the U.S. credit crunch, there has been a "slight impact, " but he added that company has taken hedge positions to ensure that the impact has been kept to a minimum.
He also said the early stage of the business in China will target China-based Taiwanese investors. "We will go wherever these people go," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travel-loving foreign couple settles in tranquil Penghu

TEXT.P: CNA Staff Reporter

Taipei, April 27 (CNA) A Canadian man and his Japanese wife, both avid travelers, have taken up residence in Taiwan's outlying island of Penghu, after falling in love with the tranquility found in Penghu's waters, mountains, and beaches.
Rod Harvey, who is from Canada' Quebec, and his wife Sayaki Kato, from Japan's Nagoya, have stayed in Penghu for three years after traveling around the world for many years.
Now they live a life enjoying unhurriedly Penghu's sunshine, sea waves, and lovely firewheel flowers.
Harvey teaches English at the Makung Elementary School in Penghu County's Makung City, and Kato makes her paintings and graphic designs at home, which is an old house that they rent near the beach.

Kato said Penghu has everything that they have hoped for: old houses, beaches, surfing, and diving. She said she usually swims at the beach when the sun is still strong and most Taiwanese girls do not like to go outside.
"It is really a luxury as if I own the whole beach, the sea, and sunshine," Kato said.
Harvey and Kato, both travel-loving people, took their own journeys around the world before they met in Egypt when Harvey was traveling by himself and Kato was working as a diving coach there.

They later traveled extensively around the world, including in Central America where they learned about the ancient Mayan civilization, as well as in Africa's Egypt, and Asia's Cambodia, Laos, and Indonesia.
The couple later visited Taiwan, where they came across the Penghu archipelago.
They thought it was just a midway station for them but it has turned out to be the place where they stayed the longest time so far on their journey.

Kato told CNA in an interview that the reason she and her husband decided to settle in Penghu was because they love Penghu's "Shanshuei Beach, " the famous white sandy beach that is over 200 meters long, located at Penghu's village of "Shanshuei."

Harvey said Penghu has many beautiful beaches, but the "Shanshuei Beach" is the quietest one and also the cleanest. The beach is a must-see for visitors to Penghu, known for its clean and white sand and bright sunshine.

Penghu County, consisting of 64 islands, is roughly located midway between Taiwan and China on the Taiwan Strait. The islands have a total land area of 127 square kilometers and a combined coastline of some 320 kilometers in length.

The couple live a quiet but joyful life. Every afternoon after Harvey is free from teaching, he goes home where Kato and the Japanese dishes she made are awaiting him. They would go for a walk with their black puppy on the beach under the sun or jog on the country roads filled with firewheel flowers.

While it's the first time the couple is living in Taiwan, Kato said she has some connection with the island nation. Her grandfather lived in southern Taiwan 64 years ago when he worked for the Japanese colonial government.

The connection comes in pairs as Harvey said Taiwan's political situation of striving for independence gives him a familiar feeling because his hometown Quebec Province also has long sought independence.
The couple plans to leave their home in Penghu for a while in the summer to travel to India, Nepal, and Tibet, for Kato has been learning Tibetan Buddhism.

"We will also visit Dharamsala where the Tibetan Government in Exile is based, and hopefully we'll get to see Dalai Lama, " Kato said, adding that if someday they decide it is time to leave Penghu, Tibet will be the next destination.
When they are too old to travel, the couple will return to Harvey's hometown and stay for the rest of their life, Kato said.
Asked if she misses her family in Nagoya, Kato said she seldom gets homesickness.
"Perhaps because it is my nature to live the traveling life or because the world outside my hometown is too beautiful," Kato said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to open its doors wider to students from abroad

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that the Ministry of Education will reserve 1 percent of its college enrollments to foreign students, to make it easier for students from abroad to pursue higher education in Taiwan.

"By reserving 1 percent of our college enrollments, presently numbering around 1.3 million, Taiwan will have a better chance of acquiring academic talent and people with higher intelligence from abroad, " Ma said during a colloquium with a group of educators from southern Taiwan held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Ma and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew traveled to Kaohsiung that day to meet with education representatives from southern Taiwan to gauge their opinions about the country's education policy, in a bid to allow the incoming Ma administration to craft better and more pragmatic education policies.
Speaking after talking with the educators, Ma said most of the officials, from schools of various levels, lamented about budget insufficiency.

In response to the educators' questions, Ma said his administration will increase the education budget by 0.2 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) annually, equalling about NT$24 billion (US$792.08 million) a year, or nearly NT$200 billion in eight years.

Answering questions about Taiwan's possible opening to Chinese students to study at local colleges and universities and allowing Chinese people with Chinese academic credentials to take part in local license accreditation tests, Ma said firmly that he will not allow such people to take part in local license accreditation tests.

"Chinese students will be welcome to study at local colleges and universities, but they will not be allowed to take part in local license accreditation tests, because such tests are open only to Taiwan citizens who are Republic of China passport holders, " Ma noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan might request WTO arbitration on EU import duty on LCDs

TEXT.P: Taiwan is considering requesting the World Trade Organization (WTO) to investigate and rule on a European Union tariff on imported liquid crystal displays (LCDs) , which Taiwan alleges is in contravention of the Information Technology Agreement (ITA), a high-ranking trade official said Sunday.

The EU has imposed a 14 percent import duty on LCDs of over 19 inches, claiming that they are electric appliances. However, the U.S. and Taiwan insist that the LCDs are IT products covered by the ITA and should enjoy "duty free" treatment.

U.S. Trade Representative Susan Schwab has threatened publicly to bring the case to the WTO and the U.S. also hopes that Taiwan, the world's no. 1 LCD producer, will join the legal battle against the EU.
Taiwan's LCD trade union also filed a complaint with the government that their exports are unjustly levied by the EU, and asked for assistance.

John Deng, chief representative of the Office of Trade Negotiations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), confirmed Sunday that Taiwan is conducting what he called "thorough and comprehensive evaluation" of the case and does not rule out the possibility of triggering the trade dispute settlement mechanism of the WTO.

But the top trade negotiator stressed that they would be "extremely careful" in the decision-making process, since the case could very well become Taiwan's first trade litigation in the WTO and involves huge commercial and trade interests.
According to official tallies, the EU collected as much as NT$19.6 billion (US$650 million) in import duty from Taiwanese LCD exports, valued at NT$140 billion.

Deng also noted that LCDs are one of Taiwan's most import IT products and said that "the government bears unavoidable responsibility to use all possible tools to protect our industry and trade interests."

The WTO's trade dispute settlement procedure, often regarded as "the world court of trade," is vital for enforcing the rules and therefore for ensuring that trade flows smoothly. But Taiwan has never been a party to any trade dispute, except for participating in other members' litigation as a third party.

"Bringing the case to the WTO is not a goal but a last resort, " explained Deng, expressing hope that the EU will abide by the ITA to avoid WTO proceedings, which takes at least a year for a preliminary ruling and another three months should the ruling be appealed. More often than not, however, cases drag on for years without any final settlement.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Chen to scale Taiwan's highest peak before bowing out

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to scale Jade Mountain in early May before his second term expires May 20, officials from the Presidential Office confirmed Sunday.
The president will "show his compassion" for Taiwan and pay his respects to Jade Mountain by scaling the island's highest peak, the officials said.
They added that the precise date of the climb had not been finalized.

The officials declined to comment on an Apple Daily report that day that Chen has been preparing to scale Jade Mountain between May 7-9 in the hope of become Taiwan's first president to set foot on the country's highest point.
At 3,952 meters, Jade Mountain is the highest mountain in East Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei city government urged to tackle pigeon pollution

TEXT.P: A Taipei city councilor urged the government Saturday to tackle the noise and environmental pollution caused by pigeons, which she said has "severely endangered" the health and living quality of the residents of the Daan Public Housing project.
"The seemingly-harmless pigeons, which come in flocks to nest on the eaves, have become a nightmare for the people living here, " according to opposition Kuomintang Taipei City Councilor Lin Yi-hua.

She said the pigeons nesting on the buildings come mainly from the nearby Daan Forest Park and that their droppings pose a great health hazard to the elderly and children. "Every pigeon produces 12 kg of droppings per year," she said.

"Research shows that pigeon feces contain crypotococcus, a kind of fungus that can cause pneumonia or meningitis, " said Wong Wing-wai, director of the Division for Disease Control and Prevention under the Taipei city government's Department of Health.
"People with weak immune systems, such as the elderly and children, are the most susceptible," he added.
Residents in the area said the problem has been there for over 20 years but nothing has been done by the government to help them get rid of the birds.
"Every day at around 5 a.m. we are wakened by the pigeons, which is really disturbing," said Chow Yin-hua, an elderly resident.
"Their feces are not only smelly but also impossible to clean, as they are on unreachable windowsill or eaves outside the house, " she added.
The residents said the city government should eradicate the pigeons.
"Strategies like spikes and nets have had little success and most of us can only passively clean up the mess created by the birds and tolerate them day after day," said Chow.
Lin said the government should begin by making feeding the pigeons illegal so that it might reduce the number of pigeons in the area.
She added that some cities in the United States, such as Los Angeles, have tried to cut their pigeon populations by lacing rooftop feeders with drugs that prevent the birds from breeding.

The contraceptive drug, OvoControl P, interferes with egg production and should therefore keep the population down without the need for poison or gates that give electric shocks, according to a report from the New York Times.

"Every big city, such as New York and London, has a pigeon problem like this. The Taipei city government should begin to take this issue seriously as currently there are no effective measures or restrictions," Lin said.
She said the government should refer to what has been done in other cities and draw up a comprehensive plan to tackle the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: Eight scuba divers still missing
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/08 18:42:10 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: An air and sea search for eight missing scuba divers continued for the second day Sunday in seas around Taiwan's southern tip, but failed to find any trace of survivors.

The search mission comprised seven cutters of the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) , six helicopters dispatched by the National Airborne Service Corps, and two sport fishing boats hired by the divers' families.

They searched the seas east of Taitung, as well as the seas west of Pingtung and Kaohsiung, but to no avail. Hsu Yung-kang, a deputy leader of the CGA detachment on the Hengchun peninsula, said the ocean currents were moving in a northeasterly direction between Saturday and Friday morning and that the search mission would continue, with the emphasis on the seas east of southern Taiwan.

The families of the holidaymaking divers were angry early Sunday when harbor security authorities at Houbihu, the largest fishing port in Hengchun, forbade them from going to sea on two hired fishing boats because they are not licensed crewmen. They then hired two sport fishing boats to join the search.

The eight missing divers -- six men and two women -- went missing a day earlier while scuba diving in waters near Chihsingyen (seven-star rocks) -- located 22 km southwest of Eluanbi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan.

CGA teams from Pingtung and neighboring Kaohsiung County, as well as an airborne rescue squad, launched a sea and air search after four of the divers' friends and the skipper of their dive boat reported that the eight divers had failed to return to the boat at 11:30 a.m. Saturday after an hour-long dive.

The sea around Seven Stars is loved by scuba divers because the coral reefs there are unpolluted and full of tropical marine life, but the site is also notoriously dangerous because of the strong currents due to the black tide, also known as the Kuroshio Current.
Experts in the diving trade said high winds and rough seas Saturday might have also contributed to the tidal action and they said a strong current could have swept them farther out to sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Songshan Tsuyou temple launches 2008 Sikou Culture Festival

TEXT.P: The Songshan Tsuyou temple launched the 2008 Sikou Culture Festival for the third consecutive year Sunday, featuring a series of events combining history, culture, the environment and Mother's Day to promote the unique and distinctive tradition of the riverside area.

"River, Mother and Love is the theme of this year's festival. We hope the two- week festival will increase the depth of local culture and awaken local residents' memories and love for the area, " said Yu Shu-yi, director of Taipei City's Songshan District Office.

"We also hope to promote the visibility of Songshan district to attract more tourists, " she said, adding that this is the perfect timing for the event as the Tsuyou temple is celebrating its 255th anniversary and Matzu's birthday. Matzu is the most important folk deity in Taiwan.

Yu noted that there are several meanings of this year's event, in which environmental protection plays an important part, as the Songshan area was developed because it is adjacent to the Keelung river.

Songshan was originally named Sikou, which is the Taiwanese-language pronunciation of a lowland aboriginal Ketagalan word meaning "where the river twists." In 1920, the area became known as Songshan village and later was merged with Taipei City in 1938.

"The Keelung river is the mother of Songshan, so as we celebrate the May 11 Mother's Day, we would like take the opportunity to remind everyone that it is important to keep the river clean so that we can enjoy ourselves along the riverside," she said.
Songshan Community College Director Tsai Su-chen said the event is more than an annual carnival.

"It has multiple meanings, such as education, culture and eco-conservation," Tsai said. "We hope bonding among residents will be cemented even further by the warm atmosphere and that people will be drawn to experience the distinctive cultural ambiance," she added.

Organized by the Songshan District Office, the Songshan Tsuyu temple, Songshan Community College and the Civil Affairs Bureau, the 2008 Sikou Culture Festival will feature a series of activities including traditional Chinese theatrical operas, concerts and food fairs before it ends May 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: Incoming leading negotiator with China pushing for cross-strait talks

TEXT.P: The chairman-designate of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) has promised to push for the SEF and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to serve as a negotiation platform to facilitate the peaceful development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Chiang Pin-kung, who is also a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), made the remarks Saturday at a reception in China's southeastern coastal city of Xiamen in Fujian Province to thank Taiwanese businessmen operating in the area on behalf of KMT President-elect Ma Ying-jeou for their support in the presidential election.

Chiang said the KMT will fulfill all the campaign promises made by the KMT ticket during the campaign period, particularly on cross-strait issues -- with which China-based Taiwanese businessmen are most concerned -- including the establishment of direct flights and the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists.

He pledged that if the SEF becomes the government's negotiation platform for the implementation of cross-strait affairs, it will first take into consideration the rights of Taiwanese businessmen in China, while seeking to promote cross- strait economic and trade exchanges, develop Taiwan's economy and boost cross- strait relations.

Once the negotiation mechanism is initiated, the agency will give priority to addressing issues concerning double taxation, investment protection for the interests of Taiwanese businessmen and investment in China by Taiwan's banking industry, Chiang noted.
The agency will also assist Taiwanese investors in industrial upgrading to increase their competitiveness in China.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties.

In 1993, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan met in Singapore for the first cross-strait talks in over four decades. They met again in October 1998 in Shanghai, but the negotiations were suspended by Beijing after then-President Lee Teng-hui described the cross-strait situation as a "special state-to-state relationship" in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan tourism ambassadors promote attractions in Singapore
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/08 18:52:26 (By Charles Kang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese pop singer Jolin Tsai and film director Wu Nien-jen, who are serving as Taiwanese tourism ambassadors for the Southeast Asian region, promoted Taiwan's wedding dress industry, night market culture and railway tourism at a shopping mall in Singapore Saturday.
It was the second time Tsai and Wu had traveled to Singapore to publicize Taiwan's major tourist attractions since they were named by the Tourism Bureau last year as tourism ambassadors.
Speaking at a publicity event organized by the Taiwan Visitors Association's Singapore Office, Tsai focused her efforts on introducing a July Taiwan Shopping Festival.
Wu joined Tsai in recommending a number of spots for couples, including Danshui Fisherman's Wharf and the Lengshuikeng area of Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei.
Wu also recommended Singaporeans to plan a trip by rail around Taiwan to experience the different style of the Taiwan High Speed Rail and the traditional Taiwan Railway System.
He also suggested a tea tasting journey to Maokong or Pinglin, two important tea-producing areas in the greater Taipei area.
The event also had a number of exhibition booths set up by Taiwanese wedding dress companies, manicurists and night market vendors.
Tsai also expressed her wish to get married by the seashore in spring and to go swimming after the wedding.

Taiwan's booming wedding industry is famous in Asia, and about 200 Singapore couples have their wedding photos taken in Taiwan each year by one of the major wedding companies, according to Chang Nien-chieh, a spokeswoman for one such company, who said the photos cost an average of NT$60,000 (US$2,000).
Taiwan has spent great efforts in promoting the country's wedding industry, as it has become one of Taiwan's tourist attractions, according to Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's first international trade legal team in full operation

TEXT.P: From scratch to a nearly full-fledged legal team, the Office of Trade Negotiations (OTN) has achieved in eight months something that has been requested, studied, and discussed for years.

In an interview with CNA, John Deng, chief representative of the OTN under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said Sunday that his team has already demonstrated its ability to fulfill the tasks of providing legal analysis and opinion, and eventually engaging in legal disputes under the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework in the very near future, although it might not be able to independently conduct a complete international trade legal proceeding just yet.

Legal counsel could be the weakest aspect in Taiwan's public institutions. Unlike developed countries, almost none of the ministries in Taiwan's central government have a competent and specialized legal office, except for the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) . The problem surfaced in 2002 when Taiwan joined the WTO, in which dispute settlement is a central pillar.
Even with the urgent demand, the legal team of the OTN was not established until August last year on an ad hoc basis with two legal experts on loan from the MOJ.

Aiming at promoting ability in international trade disputes and negotiations, such as free trade agreements (FTAs) , the country's first-ever international legal force has made impressive progress with limited resources, according to Deng.
The team is led by a negotiator in charge of legal affairs and rules, along with six members -- three middle-level officials and three legal assistants.

The backbone of the middle-level officials are two prosecutors-turned- legal advisors, tasked with providing analyses and advises on rights and obligations under the multilateral trading system and international trade agreements, and helping solve trade disputes under such agreements.
Deng said the prosecutors' legal and trial skills and expertise will ensure the quality of their work.

Although Taiwan has not been in the position of plaintiff or defendant in any trade dispute as a WTO member state -- partly due to lack of legal capacity -- the office is developing the team by submitting cases involving other countries as a third party.

To date, the team has accomplished five submissions in eight months, a massive jump against the seven submitted in the previous five years. In addition to quantity, Deng said the quality of those submissions is well-recognized.

Chen Chern-chyi, a negotiator in legal affairs and rules, praised the team, saying that the prosecutors have adapted to a lonelier job without the media spotlight -- something they were used to as criminal prosecutors.
"On top of that, they are very passionate toward the work, and have been learning about WTO issues from the ground up," Chen noted.
Citing the difficulties of the unprecedented tasks, Deng said the team still needs to consult with WTO experts to fully capture the complexity of international trade disputes.
He went on that in the long run, the team could be refined as a central force for Taiwan to independently solve the legal problems arising from external trade.
But the legal team faces an uncertain future as it is not a permanent office, and Deng expressed hope that it can become a regular unit in the government system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Senior citizen dies of exhaustion in long-distance swim

TEXT.P: A 70-year-old man died Sunday from exhaustion and drowning while taking part in a three-kilometer swim across South Bay in Kending, in Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung.

Chu Ching-hui and two other swimmers also suffering from exhaustion were rushed to a hospital after they swam for more than one hour. Chu was pronounced dead, while the other two were treated and released.
Some 3,500 people took part in the long-distance swim, including 56 disabled individuals and 65 elderly couples, with the oldest swimmer aged 82 and the youngest, 7.
The event was sponsored by the Pingtung county government and Taiwan Masters Swimming.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group reveals job plight of immigrant women in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Job discrimination, having to work multiple jobs, no labor insurance, no overtime pay and low wages are the five major plights faced by most working women who have immigrated from Southeast Asia to Taiwan, a local activist group said Sunday.

The findings are the result of a series of one-on-one interviews conducted by the Taiwan International Family Association (TIFA) between February and April with 75 Southeast Asian women married to Taiwanese citizens.

Although Southeast Asian spouses of Taiwanese citizens do not require a work permit, the association found that local employers often refuse to hire immigrant women on the grounds that they lack a work permit or national ID card, or that they speak poor Chinese.
"We speak Chinese with an accent, but we deserve an opportunity to demonstrate our working ability, " said Yeh Pei-chi, a Thai woman who married a Taiwanese citizen 13 years ago.
"If we are proven incapable, then don't hire us, but don't refuse to hire us simply because we are foreigners, " Yeh said.

She recalled that she was once rejected by a factory employer who told her that "we don't hire foreign spouses, " a common example of job discrimination experienced by many female immigrant workers in Taiwan.
For her part, Ruan Fan Chiu-hsiang from Vietnam said she has helped her Taiwanese husband to recycle metal since the day after she arrived in Taiwan.
She said she had no experience at the time, often made mistakes and got laughed at by others.

In addition, the association discovered that 72 percent of the women interviewed do not have the labor insurance to which they are entitled, while 68 percent work overtime without overtime pay, said Wang Shu-chuan, executive secretary of the association.
Among those who said they receive overtime pay, only 14 percent are paid an amount that meets the requirements of the Labor Standards Law, Wang said.

The association also observed that half of the immigrant women in the southern port city of Kaohsiung need to have multiple jobs to support their families, many of them working in restaurants or breakfast shops, she noted.
In northern Taiwan, most of the women work unusual shifts from 3 p.m. to 2 p.m., she continued.

Meanwhile, only 57 percent of the females surveyed earn a total monthly income higher than the basic monthly wage of NT$17,280 (about US$570) as required by the government, even though many of them work extra hours to earn higher salaries, Wang pointed out.

Calling for greater attention to job discrimination and the predicaments faced by immigrant women in Taiwan, Wang said the Council of Labor Affairs and local governments should raise the awareness of immigrants' working rights and related rules among local employers and immigrants.

Chang Yu-hua, executive director of the association, described female immigrants in Taiwan as "new low-level workers, " as many of them work as restaurant staff, household maids, or small factory workers.

Immigrant women need to learn local languages and adapt to a new environment but do not have strong emotional support as they do not have many family members and friends in Taiwan, Chang added, urging the public to offer care and help.
Taiwan has more than 123,000 foreign spouses from Vietnam, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines and Cambodia, as well as over 270,000 from China, Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lions group donates pap smear test vehicle to Kaohsiung county

TEXT.P: Lions Clubs International District 300-D2 donated Sunday a fully equipped pap smear screening vehicle to the Kaohsiung county government that will tour the southern county to provide women in remote areas with easy access to cervical cancer screening.
The vehicle, equipped with a full set of advanced and sophisticated medical instruments, is first in county to be equipped with an ultrasound breast screening device.
Yu Chien-chang, head of the Lions group, presented the vehicle to Kaohsiung Deputy Magistrate Yeh Nan-ming.

The vehicle, designed to perform breast, cervical and colerectal cancer screening and bone density measurements, will travel to remote areas in the county with the aim of increasing screening participation of local women, Yeh said.

Cervical cancer is one of the top causes of cancer death in women in Taiwan, causing the death of some 1,000 women each year, Yeh said, adding that women are strongly advised to get regular pap smears, as the test is the most effective cancer screening tool.

According to a survey released by the Department of Health, both the incidence and the death rate for cervical cancer could drop by 60 percent-90 percent for women who get pap smears every three years, Yeh added.

Even under Gordon Browns brief premiership their fortunes have soared by 15%, just as the financial squeeze and faltering house prices have hit ordinary people.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-CPC forum complementary to cross-strait contacts: KMT official

TEXT.P: Although the contacts between the Communist Party of China (CPC) and the Kuomintang (KMT) in Taiwan are different in nature to that between Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits and Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, they are complementary to each other, a KMT official said here Sunday.
Chang Jung-kung, deputy executive-director of KMT Policy Committee, said the two communication channels will exist together and help each other in cementing ties between Taiwan and mainland China.

Chang arrived here Sunday in company with KMT Vice Chairman Chiang Pin-kung to thank local Taiwan businesspeople for their support for the KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou and his running mate Vincent Siew in the March 20 election.

Chiang has been named by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou as chairman of the Strait Exchange Foundation with Chang as the vice chairman and secretary-general. They are expected to assume their new jobs after Ma's inauguration on May 20.
Chang said the Straits Exchange Foundation will deal with its Beijing counterparts on behalf of the Taiwan authorities.
It's an arm of the government, and its any agreement with Beijing have to be approved by the government and made into law before taking force, Chang said.

Meanwhile, the KMT-CPC forum, established in 2005 by CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao and then-KMT Chairman Lien Chan is a place for business leaders, academics, government officials even leaders of Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party to exchange views with their Chinese counterparts.
The forum will also help build consensus among its participants and these consensus may be translated into policies of Beijing and Taipei, Chang went on.

Although President-elect Ma Ying-jeou has said that contacts with China under his administration will be made mainly by the Straits Exchange Foundation, and his administration's policy won't be dictated by the KMT, the contacts between the KMT and CPC will continue, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier-designate reveals 2nd group of Cabinet members
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/08 12:07:32 (By Kao Yu-ling, Deborah Kuo and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan revealed the second group of 18 members of his Cabinet on Monday.
These members and their backgrounds are:
-- Minister without Portfolio: Chang Jin-fu, president of National Chi Nan University in Puli, Nantou County.
-- Minister without Portfolio: Ovid J. L. Tzeng, former minister of education.
-- Minister of Education: Cheng Jei-cheng, former president of National Chengchi University in Taipei.
-- Minister of Finance: Lee Sush-der, secretary-general of the Taipei City Government and former chief of the city's Bureau of Finance.
-- Chairwoman for Mainland Affairs Council: Lai Hsing-yuan, former legislator of the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
-- Minister of National Defense: Chen Chao-min, former deputy minister of national defense.
-- Minister in charge of the National Science Council: Lee Lou-chuang, president of National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County.
-- Minister in charge of the Government Information Office: Vanessa Yea-ping Shih, former deputy representative to Australia.
-- Minister in charge of the Sports Affairs Council: Tai Shia-ling, professor at Taipei Municipal University of Education.
-- Minister in charge of the Central Personnel Administration: Chen Ching-hsiou, associate professor of law at Soochow University.
-- Director General of the Finance Supervisory Commission: Gordon S. Chen, former vice minister of finance.
-- Director of the National Palace Museum: Chou Kung-shin, chair of the Graduate Institute of Museum Studies at Fu Jen Catholic University in Hsinchuang, Taipei County.
-- Minister in charge of the Veterans Affairs Commission: Kao Hua-chu, former minister of the Veterans Affairs Commission.
-- Minister and Chairman of the Automatic Energy Council: Tsai Chuen-horng, former dean of the College of Nuclear Science, National Tsing Hua University in Hsinchu City.
-- Minister in charge of Research, Development & Evaluation Commission: Jiang Yi-huah, professor of political science, National Taiwan University.
-- Chairperson of the Public Construction Commission: Frank L. S. Fan, deputy magistrate of Taoyuan County
-- Minister in charge of the Council for Cultural Affairs: Huang Pi-tuan, former president of Tainan National University of the Arts.
-- Minister in charge of the Council for Hakka Affairs: Huang Yu-cheng, director of the KMT Chairman's Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, May 28, or the 23rd day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1738: French physician and revolutionary Joseph Ignace Guillotin is born. He developed the execution device which was so heavily used during the "reign of terror" in the French revolution that it would later bear his name.
1754: George Washington, then in the service of the British Crown, destroys a French regiment under Jumonville near Uniontown, Penn., in the first battle of the French-Indian Wars.
1759: English statesman William Pitt the Younger is born. He became prime minister at the age of 24, the youngest-ever British prime minister.
1912: Patrick White, the Australian novelist who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1973, is born.
1934: Cecilie, Emilie, Marie, Annette and Yvonne Dionne are born to Olivia Dionne in Callender, Canada. They are the world's first surviving quintuplets.
1932: Dutch engineers complete the world's biggest dam, a major victory in their 900-year battle to push back the sea. The new dam, or dike, is 29 km long and turns the Zuider Zee into a vast freshwater lake, called the Ijsselmeer.
1933: Chinese Gen. Feng Yu-hsiang revolts at Kalgan Pass, near Changkiakow, capital of China's Chahar Province.
1956: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh informs Philippine Ambassador Narciso Ramos that the ROC has full sovereignty over the Nansha, or Spratly Islands.
1959: The United States launches its Jupiter rocket into space with two monkeys aboard. The monkeys return to earth safely, opening the way for manned space flight.
1966: Construction of Taiwan's Northern Cross-Island Highway is completed. An inauguration ceremony is held at Tahsi, Taoyuan County.
1966: The Cultural Revolution begins in mainland China after the central committee of the Chinese Communist Party sets up a "central cultural revolution group" to lead the movement.
1967: Francis Chichester, a 65-year-old British yachtsman, receives a hero's welcome when he arrives in Plymouth 119 days after setting out on a solo round- the-world trip.
1972: The Duke of Windsor, the British king who abdicated to marry American divorcee Wallis Simpson, dies in Paris at the age of 77.
1974: The Pacific-Asian Congress of Municipalities opens its third conference in Taipei.
1978: Chiang Ching-kuo, who was sworn in as the 6th president of the ROC on May 20, tells Reader's Digest that "our interests and those of America cannot be divided. If we stick together, both will benefit. If we go our separate ways, both will suffer. In any case, the Republic of China will persist."
1981: The ROC Executive Yuan approves Premier Sun Yun-suan's appointment of Konsin Shah as ambassador to the Republic of Uruguay and Loh I-cheng as ambassador to the Republic of Guatemala.
1982: Pope John Paul II arrives in Britain for the first papal visit to Britain since 1531.
1985: President Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez of the Republic of Costa Rica arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1986: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs protests an Argentine gunboat attack on an unarmed ROC trawler in the seas off the Falkland Islands that left one dead, one missing, and six injured.
1987: Mathias Rust, a West German teenager, flies his Cessna light plane from Helsinki to Moscow and lands in Red Square, evading the entire Soviet air defense system. Both the Soviet defense minister and the air defense commander were sacked as a result of the prank.
1989: The Ching Kuo, the first ROC-developed and manufactured indigenous defense fighter, successfully completes its first test flight.
1995: A strong earthquake rocks the Russian Far East oil-producing town of Neftegorsk on Sakhalin Island, killing more than 1,980 people.
1996: The ROC exchanges economic and trade representative offices with the Republic of Belarus. Belarus is the second (Russia being the first) member of the Commonwealth of Independent States to establish such a level of relations with the ROC.
1998: Pakistan conducts five nuclear test blasts and declares a state of emergency, triggering economic sanctions by Japan and the United States.
2000: Taiwan's Tseng Hsin-feng wins Japan's three-day Kosaido Ladies' Golf Tournament in the Tokyo suburb of Ichihara.
2001: The New Taiwan dollar plunges three percent, or 1.0005 against the U.S. dollar to close at 34.5 on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange market.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men of totally different principles can never act together."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-CPC forum complementary to cross-strait contacts: KMT official

TEXT.P: Although the contacts between the Communist Party of China (CPC) and the Kuomintang (KMT) in Taiwan are different in nature to those between Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits and Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, they are complementary to each other, a KMT official said here Sunday.

Chang Jung-kung, deputy executive-director of the KMT Policy Committee, said the two communication channels will exist in tandem and help each other in cementing ties between Taiwan and mainland China.

Chang and KMT Vice Chairman Chiang Pin-kung arrived here Sunday to thank local Taiwan businesspeople for their support for the KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou and his running mate Vincent Siew in the March 22 election.

Chiang has been named by President-elect Ma as chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, and Chang as vice chairman and secretary-general. They are expected to assume their new posts after Ma's inauguration on May 20.

Chang said the Straits Exchange Foundation will deal with its Beijing counterpart on behalf of the Taiwan authorities. It is an arm of the government, and any agreement it reaches with Beijing would have to be approved by the government and made into law before taking effect, Chang said.

Meanwhile, the KMT-CPC forum, established in 2005 by CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao and then-KMT Chairman Lien Chan, is a place for business leaders, academics, government officials, and even leaders of Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party to exchange views with their Chinese counterparts, Chang said.
The forum will also help build consensus among its participants and these decisions may be translated into policies for Beijing and Taipei, Chang added.

Although Ma has said that contacts with China under his administration will be made mainly by the Straits Exchange Foundation and that his administration's policy will not be dictated by the KMT, the contacts between the KMT and CPC will continue, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: All eight scuba divers rescued

TEXT.P: All eight scuba divers who had been missing since Saturday were rescued in the eastern county of Taitung Monday, after an extensive 47-hour search and rescue effort, the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) reported around noon.

The eight divers -- six men and two women -- were suffering from sun burn and dehydration after having drifted over 100 km at sea, CGA officials said. The divers were airlifted to Mackay Memorial Hospital in Taitung for treatment and recuperation, according to the officials.

The CGA had launched an air and sea search for the eight divers Saturday after they went missing in seas near Chihsingyen (seven-star rocks), 22 km southwest of Oluanbi on the southernmost tip of Taiwan, which is known for its turbulent ocean currents.
There was no sign of the divers until late Sunday night when dive coach Ting Po- ling swam ashore at 11: 50 p.m. Sunday to a beach in Taimali in the eastern county of Taitung.
Ting immediately alerted the rescue teams which began searching the nearby coastal area and soon scooped up four other divers from the waters off Taimali around midnight.
The four were spotted in pitch dark water because their flashed their torches, according to the crew of a helicopter mobilized by the Pingtung air base, who rescued the four divers.
At 5: 50 a.m. Monday, the rescuers spotted another missing diver on the beach.

Continuing the search, the rescuers found the last two divers -- Lee Su-ling and Wang Chih-yu -- near the Taitung coast at around 11 a.m. Monday, successfully wrapping up the daunting task of finding all eight divers alive 47 hours after the search began.

The search mission -- comprised of seven Coast Guard Administration (CGA) cutters, six National Airborne Service Corps helicopters, and two sport fishing boats hired by the divers' families -- did not spot any survivors until last Saturday night.

For several hours, they searched the seas east of Taitun and west of Pingtung and Kaohsiung -- two neighboring southern counties -- to no avail. Hsu Yung- kang, a deputy leader of the CGA detachment on the Hengchun peninsula, said Sunday that the ocean currents had been moving in a northeasterly direction since Friday morning and that the search mission would continue, focusing on the area east of southern Taiwan.
The eight divers were declared missing after they failed to return to their boat at 11:30 a.m. Saturday after an hour-long dive.

The waters around Chihsingyen are a favorite of scuba divers because of the coral reefs there that are unpolluted and full of tropical marine life. But the site is also notoriously dangerous because of the strong currents due to the black tide, also known as the Kuroshio Current.
Diving experts said high winds and rough seas Saturday might also have contributed to the tidal action and that a strong current could have swept the divers farther out to sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two universities in Hualien to be merged

TEXT.P: National Dong Hwa University (NDHU) and National Hualien University of Education (NHUE) , both located in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County, will be merged soon, NDHU President Hwang Wen-shu said Sunday.

After years of negotiations, Hwang said, both universities decided recently that the name of the merged university will be National Dong Hwa University, and that more than 3,000 faculty members and students of National Hualien University of Education will be relocated to the campus of NDHU.
Hwang estimated that the two universities will begin proceedings related to the merger in the second half of this year, as early as possible.

Wang Chun-chuan, deputy director of the Department of Higher Education under the Ministry of Education, said that the ministry will offer a total NT$2.5 billion in phased amounts for the merger of the two universities and the expansion of hardware facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former TSU lawmaker named top charter of mainland policy

TEXT.P: Former opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Legislator Lai Hsing-yuan was named chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) by Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan Monday.

Lai, 52, who holds a doctorate in research and development from the University of Sussex, UK, and was a TSU legislator between 2005-2007, was among 18 people named Monday by Liu in the second batch of members of the new Cabinet slated to be inaugurated May 20.
Some legislators of the incoming Kuomintang (KMT) expressed misgivings over Lai's inclusion in the Cabinet.

KMT Legislator Chiu Yi was obviously displeased with the appointment, saying that naming Lai, a protege of former President Lee Teng-hui, as Taiwan's top mainland policy planner indicated a reinstatement of the "Lee Teng-hui political line."

Lee, the spiritual leader of the TSU, was seen as aggravating cross-strait tensions in the late 1990s when he described cross Taiwan Strait relations as a special state-to-state relationship. His 1995 visit to the United States during his presidential tenure also was a source of ire to Beijing, which saw the trip as aimed at promoting Taiwan independence.
Chiu further said that the appointment of Lai, who to some extent represents the pro-independence influence, is tantamount to "eating pork in front of Muslims."

KMT Legislator Chang Hsien-yao argued that Lai's appointment is not conducive to the development of cross-strait relations, adding that he would not be optimistic about cross-strait relations after May 20 with Lai in charge of mainland affairs policy planning.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT honorary chairman heads for Beijing on private visit

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan departed Monday for Beijing on a private visit during which he will meet Chinese President Hu Jintao.

Asked whether he will exchange views with Hu on cross-Taiwan Strait activity, Lien refused to comment but said he will proceed from Beijing to Chongqing in Sichuan Province and on to Wuhan in Hubei Province.

He also declined to offer his opinion on the appointment of Lai Hsing-yuan, a former lawmaker of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , as chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council -- the government's top agency in planning Taiwan's China policy.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the KMT, who will be inaugurated May 20, is poised to take measures to bolster Taiwan-China trade and economic relations, as he promised throughout his election campaign.
Lai's appointment to the key post has sparked widespread concern across Taiwan's political spectrum because of her pro-independence stance.

Lien first visited China and met Hu in Beijing in 2005 -- the most prominent contact between Taiwan and China since 1949. During that trip, Lien and Hu signed an agreement to step up two-way exchanges between the KMT and the Communist Party of China.
Minister without Portfolio-designate Tsai Hsing-hsiung, KMT Vice Chairman Lin Feng-cheng, former Vice Premier Hsu Li-teh and Lien's wife are accompanying Lien on the trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high and closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 131.77 points, or 1.47 percent, to close at 9,079.6.

The local bourse opened at 8,965.73 and fluctuated between 9,079.6 and 8,953.95 during the day's session. A total of 5.14 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$145.24 billion (US$4.79 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction shares moving up the most at 3 percent, followed by banking and financial issues at 2.6 percent. Textile stocks rose 2.1 percent, plastic and chemical shares were up 2 percent, cement stocks advanced 1.8 percent, machinery and electronics shares increased 1.2 percent, paper and pulp issues gained 0.5 percent, and foodstuff shares moved up 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,321 to 1,037, with 288 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$6.36 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Complete list of financial, economic officials appointed

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan completed the assignment of Cabinet members for financial and economic affairs Monday, naming Lee Shu-te and Gordon Chen to lead the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC), respectively.

The incoming Kuomintang (KMT) government, which is set to take office May 20 from the Democratic Progressive Party, will face a number of financial and economic challenges, including inflation, a second phase of financial reforms, the government deficit and revitalization of cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade ties.

Along with last week's designations of Paul Chiu as vice premier, Yin Chi-ming as minister of economic affairs, and Chen Tain-jy as commissioner of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Liu's announcement completed the new administration's team of decision makers and executors for Taiwan's fractured economy.

Referring to the qualities of the finance minister-designate, Liu said that Lee, the incumbent secretary-general of the Taipei city government and a former commissioner of the city government's Department of Finance, has accomplished a score of tasks involving tax policies and the government deficit.

Lee, whose previous financial administration experience also includes a stint as director-general of the Kaohsiung National Tax Administration under the MOF, previously played a crucial role as a financial planner during President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's eight years as Taipei mayor.

An expert on tax policy with a complete record in financial administration and an MBA, Lee has helped Taipei to create tax income by attracting private investment in property in the city's Xinyi district.
Experts said the major challenges ahead of Lee in his MOF post are tax reforms and the reduction of the government deficit.

Upon hearing of Lee's appointment, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin of the opposition Kuomintang expressed welcome to the designation, saying that any city officials entering the central government is a good thing.
Former Taiwan Stock Exchange Chairman and vice Finance Minister Gordon Chen is at present chairman of the Taiwan Academy of Banking and Finance.
Also a very well-experienced financial expert, Chen, who Liu described as "strict and steadfast," has held several posts in public financial offices over the last decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: Selection of MAC chair sparks controversy

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan announced Monday another 18 members of his cabinet, including Lai Shin-yuan, a former legislator of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), as chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), a surprise appointment that sparked wide debates and some opposition.

The decision to name Lai as head of the cross-strait policy making governmental agency drew disparaging comments from some Kuomintang (KMT) legislators, while a group of Kuomintang (KMT) supporters gathered outside the venue of Monday's press conference shouting for Liu to step down.
The protestors argued that Lai is not a member of the KMT nor does she have the required experience in dealing directly with Beijing to hold such a post.

Liu, however, noted that the selection of the MAC chairperson was initiated by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and that Lai is "qualified for the position on the basis of her past experience in dealing with mainland affairs as well as her educational background."

Lai holds a master's degree in International Relations and a doctorate in Development Studies -- both earned in the United Kingdo m. She has served as Taiwan's negotiator for World Trade Organization accession, as a member of the National Security Council, a legislator, and a university research fellow.
Liu said that the protesters would be more accepting of Lai's appointment if they were aware of her qualifications and her support for Ma and Siew's mainland policy.
"Lai identifies with the mainland policy of Ma and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew, " Liu stressed. "She will no longer be involved in the administration of the TSU."

Lai later confirmed Liu's statement, saying that her approach to mainland affairs was "the same as Ma's." She gave the assurance that she will cooperate with Ma on issues that are in the interest of the Taiwanese people and will maintain Taiwan's dignity. Lai made the comments during a press conference held by the TSU via telephone following Liu's announcement.
"The priority of the MAC head is to coordinate various positions and opinions," Lai said, adding that a gradual development of cross-strait relations would be one of the components of her policy."
"The goal of Taiwan's mainland policy is to maintain cross-strait stability and promote peace in East Asia," Lai added.
Addressing concerns about her competence to hold the post, Lai said that "the job would be a challenge for me... and there are still many misunderstandings."
She however reaffirmed that she will safeguard Taiwan's integrity and dignity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government's promotion of knowledge clustering a success: CEPD

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning has said the Nankang Software Park's performance in a recent survey by the Economist Intelligence Unit shows that the government's efforts to promote innovation and the development of knowledge economy clusters has borne fruit.

The Economist Intelligence Unit survey looked at the effectiveness of four software parks in Asia -- including Cyberjaya in Malaysia, Dalian Software Park in China and Quang Trung Software City in Vietnam -- in promoting start-ups and domestic software firms, and the extent to which they foster innovation.
In the survey released in March, Nankang Software Park was found to have the highest survival rate for start-up businesses more than two years old, at 80 percent.

The CEPD said that promoting "knowledge clustering" is one of the major keys to success for industries and that Taiwan's efforts at cluster development and innovation have received affirmation from international organizations.
The council noted that Taiwan ranked first in the world in terms of the state of cluster development in the World Economic Forum's global competitiveness report for 2006 and 2007.

The performance of companies that have set up shop in Taiwan's Hsinchu Science Park, Central Taiwan Science Park and Southern Taiwan Science Park provide further proof that the government's cluster development policy has been successful, the CEDP said.
It pointed out that the total turnover of businesses located in the three parks amounted to NT$1.9664 trillion (US$64.69 billion) for 2007, up 12.3 percent over the previous year's figure.

Meanwhile, the three science parks' exports amounted to NT$1.2376 trillion for 2007, marking a steep year-on-year increase of 15.6 percent, the CEDP said. The science parks' exports for last year represented a whopping 15.3 percent of Taiwan's total exports, it added.

The Economist Intelligence Unit said in its survey that besides having a survival rate of 80 percent for start-ups less than two years old, the Nankang Software Park's occupancy rate stands at "an enviable 98 percent."

The Nankang Software Park, which opened in 1999 on the outskirts of Taipei City, is now in its third phase of expansion, focusing on specific market niches of integrated-circuit (IC) design, digital content and biotechnology. It is Taiwan's largest software park.

The software park, along with the nearby Neihu Science Park and Taipei Tech Park, forms part of Taiwan's high-tech corridor which extends to the Hsinchu Science Park located about 75 kilometers southeast of Taipei City.

The CEPD said that in order to boost Taiwan's industrial competitiveness in the international market, the government will continue cultivating and upgrading high-technology clusters to help create more job opportunities and to serve as an engine for economic growth.
