DOC.HEADLINE: Academic named head of Council of Cultural Affairs

TEXT.P: Huang Pi-tuan, a former president of the Tainan National University of the Arts in southern Taiwan, was named minister in charge of the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) Monday by Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan.

Huang, also a noted columnist and essayist who writes on education, culture and social phenomena, said upon the appointment that since culture is relevant to everyone and cultural development encompasses every aspect of society, she will endeavor to bolster progress in all cultural sectors, including education, media and tourism, after assuming office May 20.
Huang, 63, who graduated from National Taiwan University's Department of Political Science and its graduate school, also holds a doctorate in literature from the University of Wisconsin.
She was hired as a director of the Department of Foreign Language at National Sun Yat-sen University in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan soon after returning from the United States.
In 1992, she became deputy director in charge of management of the National Theater and the National Concert Hall.
Three years later, she was invited by National Chi Nan University in Nantou, central Taiwan to organize the establishment of a foreign language department there.

Huang became president of the Tainan National University of the Arts in 2004, eventually turning the university into a mecca for arts studies in southern Taiwan. Students at the university have often won prizes in international competitions relating to the arts and multimedia design.
In the meantime, Huang is also a renowned columnist for several major daily newspapers in Taiwan, impressing readers with her insightful and inspirational essays.

Talking to CNA after she was named CCA head, Huang said she supports the idea of expanding the CCA into a ministry of tourism and cultural affairs, as culture is one of the key elements of tourism, particularly in this day and age, when more and more people are making frequent sightseeing trips at home and abroad.
"Culture plays a key role in the efforts of a country or a place to allow its unique characteristics or beauty to be appreciated," she noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier-designate announces another 18 Cabinet members

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan announced Monday another 18 members of his cabinet, including the heads of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the ministries of education, national defense, and finance.

Liu, accompanied by Vice Premier-designate Paul Chiu at a press conference, named Lai Shin-yuan, a former Taiwan Solidarity Union(TSU) legislator, as MAC chairwoman; Cheng Jei-Cheng, former president of National Chengchi University, as education minister; Chen Chao-ming as minister of national defense; and Lee Sush-der, incumbent secretary-general of the Taipei City Government, as finance minister.

Despite protests over Lai's appointment among Kuomintang (KMT) supporters who gathered outside the venue of Monday's press conference, Liu stressed that Lai is qualified to hold the position, given her past experience in dealing with mainland affairs and her educational background.
"Lai identifies with the mainland policy of Ma and Vice President-elect Vincent Siew, " Liu said. "She will no longer be involved in the administration of the TSU."
Regarding his choice of education minister, Liu described Cheng as "a disciplined gentleman and a caring and patient educator."

"Cheng is concerned not only about higher education, but also about elementary and high school education, " Liu said, adding that he hoped Cheng will "set up a multi-dimensional education ministry with emphasis on humanism."

Noting that the lack of a communication channel between the government and parents has caused problems in education policy, Liu promised that Cheng will also build "a systematic, permanent, and open platform" for dialogue to improve the education system.

Liu also announced the new heads of the National Science Council, the Government Information Office, the Central Personnel Administration, the Sports Affairs Council, the Finance Supervisory Commission, and the National Palace Museum.
Rebutting criticisms that his Cabinet is comprised of too many former KMT government officials, Liu said the administration will be a "mixture of old hands and new blood."
"We will not have inexperienced people dealing with the many urgent issues -- there is no time for greenhorns to learn" on the job, Liu said.
He stressed that "old hands are the best," but gave the assurance that his administration will also continue its efforts to "groom rookies who are competent and honest."

So far, Liu has named 35 members of the KMT cabinet, with announcements yet to be made for the posts of one minister without portfolio, the head of the Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission, and the governors of the Taiwan and Fujian Provinces.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC head-designate to focus on development of specific academic areas

TEXT.P: National Science Council (NSC) Chairman-designate Lee Lou-chuang expressed the hope Monday that the governmental agency will focus on helping Taiwan develop expertise in specific science-related areas so that the nation can become a world leader in those fields.
"If Taiwan can expand its top-notched fields, it will help upgrade the overall academic environment," said Lee in an interview with CNA, citing Taiwan's development of biomedicine as an example.
"Education and high-tech are crucial to the development of Taiwan," said Lee, who is currently president of National Central University.
He said the NSC will continue to work on building up an excellent research environment.

He also said that science parks have helped Taiwan transform itself into a high- tech country, and the manufacturers in the science parks and the NSC will continue to work together to upgrade the island's high-tech industry.
Lee also vowed to have a balanced development of humanities and science, saying that the development of humanities will help contribute to a stronger overall spirit of innovation and professionalism.
With soaring crude oil prices and climate change, sustainable development of the environment is the unshirkable responsibility of every country, Lee noted.

He said that Taiwan has laid a solid foundation on the study of such issues as energy and environment, vowing to integrate resources to help contribute to the sustainable development of the environment.

Lee, 61, obtained his doctoral degree in physics from the California Institute of Technology in 1975. He has served as a research associate in NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland, taught in the University of Maryland, the University of Alaska, and National Cheng Kung University.

Specializing in space physics, he pioneered the FORMOSAT program during his term as the director of National Space Program Office 2001-2004. He also served as the president of National Applied Research Laboratories in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 international retail industry forum to be held in Taipei

TEXT.P: The President Chain Store Corp. is set to hold the 2008 International Retail Industry Trends Forum in Taipei City Wednesday to discuss ways of increasing added value in the retail sector.

The forum will focus on four main topics, namely "innovation in brand management, fashion lifestyle value, integration of online and traditional retail models, and green business opportunities, " according to the organizer.

Speakers at the forum will include Hsu Chung-jen, president of the President Chain Store Corp. which runs Taiwan's biggest convenience store chain with 4,600 7-11 stores, as well as Lin Tsang-sheng, CEO of the Uni-President Group.

Noting that Taiwan's retail industry production value reached NT$3.2735 trillion (US$107.5 billion) and the service industry employed 57.9 percent of the local workforce in 2007, Hsu said that it has become an economic model for the development of the country's service sector.

Taiwan's retail industry has matured and reached a stage of intense competition and the forum will discuss how to upgrade Taiwan's economy and innovation by means of strategies to boost added value in the retail sector, Hsu said.

Those invited to the forum include Hiroshi Mikitani, president of Rakuten Inc., Japan's largest Internet shopping mall; Tadamitsu Matsui, president of the Japanese retail company Ryohin Keikaku; Charles Brand, general manager of the food processing and packaging company Tetra Pak Taiwan Ltd.; and Rikuzo Suzuki of the Japan-based Sazaby League.

At the forum, Suzuki will talk about his company's experience in delving into various retail businesses, including restaurants, fashion, and daily necessities, while Matsui will discuss the growth of Ryohin Keikaku, also known as MUJI, in the Japanese market.

Meanwhile, Mikitani will relate his company's experience in facing the Internet bubble in Japan, and Brand will talk about measures to deal will global warming and strategies for grabbing green business opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Only MAC, SEF can hold official cross-strait talks: Ma

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) under its oversight are the only official agencies in charge of holding cross-Taiwan Strait talks, President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang (KMT) said Monday.

Ma made the remarks while answering reporters' questions at the KMT headquarters after KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan departed for Beijing on a private visit earlier the same day. Lien is slated to meet Chinese President Hu Jintao during the tour -- the fourth such meeting between the two men.

Asked whether any agreement reached in talks between Lien and Hu would influence policies of the incoming KMT government, to be inaugurated on May 20, Ma made it clear that only the MAC and SEF are authorized to represent the government in entering into negotiations with the Chinese side.
In line with the government system, the MAC is in charge of devising Taiwan's China policy, while the SEF is commissioned by the MAC to execute cross-strait technical issues, Ma explained.
However, Ma noted that regarding private exchanges between the two sides, the government is not entitled to impose any restrictions on such activities as long as they are lawful.
In essence, cross-strait policies must be made and carried out by the MAC and SEF, respectively, he stressed.

Accompanied by Minister without Portfolio-designate Tsai Hsung-hsiung, KMT Vice Chairman Lin Feng-cheng, former Vice Premier Hsu Li-teh, several entrepreneurs and his wife, Lien left for China via Hong Kong on Monday. He is scheduled to visit Beijing, as well as Chongqing in Sichuan Province and Wuhan in Hubei Province.
Asked whether he will exchange views with Hu on cross-Taiwan Strait activities, Lien refused to comment.

He also declined to offer his opinion on the appointment of Lai Hsing-yuan, a former lawmaker of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , as chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council -- the government's top agency in planning Taiwan's China policy.
Lai's appointment to the key post has sparked criticism across Taiwan's political spectrum because of her pro-independence stance in the past.

Lien first visited China and met Hu in Beijing in 2005 -- the most high profile and high level contact between the civil rivals, the KMT and the Communist Party of China, since 1949. During that trip, Lien and Hu signed an agreement to step up two-way exchanges between the two parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Forum on mother's art to celebrate Mother' s Day

TEXT.P: A forum to promote the "art of mother, " including embroidery, tailoring, cooking and floriculture, as well as the love and patience behind these skills, is slated to open in Taipei to celebrate the approach of Mother's Day, the organizers said Monday.
Mother's Day falls on the second Sunday of May, which this year will be May 11.

A charity sale will also to be held alongside the forum to preserve and promote mother's art, according to a press release from Fanny Chen, deputy director of the Marketing and Public Affairs Department of the Xue Xue Institute, one of the event organizers.

According to Chen, issues on the role of the mother in modern society, as well as on how to preserve mother's art, will be discussed by various female dignitaries, including Cecilia Koo, chairwoman of the National Women's League, and Lee Yong-ping, commissioner of the Department of Cultural Affairs under the Taipei city government.

In addition to the forum, a number of female singers will stage a concert, performing songs in various languages, including Chinese, Taiwanese, Hakka and the language of the Amis aboriginal tribe, Chen said.
The event will take place in Taipei's Neihu district May 2 between 2 p.m. and 3 p.m., Chen noted, adding that all are welcome.

DOC.HEADLINE: Woman arrested smuggling ivory seals

TEXT.P: A woman has been arrested for attempting to smuggle more than 100 ivory seals into Taiwan, customs officials reported Monday.

The officials said the woman, surnamed Huang, who has her household registration in Taipei City but resides in South Africa, arrived at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport via Hong Kong earlier in the day.
The X-ray machine at the airport detected secret compartments in wood carvings she had in her luggage, which contained 102 ivory seals weighing over 5.81 kg.
According to Huang, a friend had asked her to bring the wood carvings into Taiwan and she professed to have no idea that ivory seals were hidden within them.

Customs officials said Huang traveled from Malawi to South Africa before boarding a plane for Taiwan. She was turned over to the Taoyuan Prosecutors Office for violation of the Wildlife Conservation Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former university president named to head Education Ministry

TEXT.P: The newly named minister of education, Cheng Jei-cheng, said Monday that he will invite representatives of teachers' and parents' groups over the next few days for talks in an effort to find out what they expect for elementary and high school education.
Cheng, a former president of National Chengchi University in Taipei, is on a second namelist of incoming Cabinet members, which Premier-designate Liu Chao- shiuan announced earlier in the day.
Cheng, whom Liu described as "a self-disciplined gentleman and a caring educator with patience," told reporters he believes "education must be forward-looking."
He also expressed hope that the media will refrain from comparing him with other ministers of education.

The selection of incoming education minister has been a hot topic since President-elect Ma Ying-jeou named Liu to take the helm of the Executive Yuan in early April. Many people, parents and teachers in particular, have high expectations for new minister as educational reforms attempted over the past decade have been roundly criticized.
Cheng, born in Yilan, northeastern Taiwan, in 1946, graduated from Chengchi University's Department of Journalism in 1969.

With a doctoral degree in communications from Ohio State University, Cheng served as head of Chengchi University's Department of Journalism and College of Communications before being elected president of the university in 2000.

Chen held the post for five years and nine months until he quit in October 2006, three months before the end of his second term, a move he made to allow his successor to assume the office during the school vacation to minimize any disruption resulting from the handover.

Described as a "philosopher university president," Cheng is known for his gentle character and a "moderate" working style. In the days before he stepped down, he said jokingly that in his life, he has "never done what he wants to do, but instead has done what he doesn't want to do, "

In an interview published in 2006 in the Evaluation Bimonthly of the Higher Education Evaluation and Accreditation Council, Cheng recalled that he had wanted to work as a journalist after graduating from Chengchi University, but changed his career path shortly after taking a job as a reporter because "the media environment was not good" in those days.

In response to Liu's naming of Cheng as education minister, the National Teachers' Association (NTA) said it respects the designation, but it also expressed concern that Cheng might have little knowledge of elementary and middle school education.
In a statement, the NTA expressed hopes that Cheng will "make up his missing lessons" as soon as possible.

The organization also said Cheng's first task after taking office May 20 should be to select a deputy "in a cautious manner, " the statement said, adding that he should be willing to take advice from various education circles.

Speaking of his choice, Liu said Cheng "is concerned not only about higher education but also about elementary and high school education. " He added that he expects Cheng to set up a multi-dimensional ministry with an emphasis on humanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: VAC head-designate strong on defending veterans' interests

TEXT.P: Kao Hua-chu, a former minister in charge of the Cabinet-level Veterans Affairs Commission (VAC), was named by Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan Monday to return to the post.
Kao was among 18 people named Monday by Liu in the second round of appointments for the Cabinet which is slated to be inaugurated May 20.
Kao, 62, born in the Chinese province of Shandong, was the VAC head between May 2004 and February 2007.

A seasoned veteran and a graduate of the R.O.C. Military Academy, Kao has held many important military positions, including deputy commander of an Army group, director of the Combined Warfare Office under the Ministry of National Defense and head of the Combined Logistics Command.
Kao, a tall well-built man, is associated with many legendary stories, including one in which he survived a military helicopter crash on Dec. 22, 1974.

According to accounts, the helicopter carrying military commanders and Kao, who was then aide-de-camp to Army Commanding General Yu hao-chang, was on a war drill when it crashed in Lungtan, northern Taiwan. Kao, despite being severely injured in the crash, jumped from the aircraft and pulled Yu to safety seconds before the helicopter burst into flames, it was reported.

Kao is also known to have ordered the military kitchen to prepare hot chili dishes for his soldiers to give them a good dining experience in days after the devastation near ground zero when a 7.3-magnitude earthquake struck central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999. Kao led the soldiers in the post-disaster relief efforts following the deadly quake that killed some 2,000 people.

In 2006, when Kao was VAC minister, he threatened to quit if the VAC budget for the following year was cut by NT$5 billion as the Executive Yuan originally planned, on grounds that the Ministry of National Defense needed more funds for arms procurement. The VAC budget was eventually cut only by NT$40 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan students win two gold medals in Asian Physics Olympiad

TEXT.P: Taiwanese students won two gold, three silver and two bronze medals as well as an honorable mention in the just-concluded 2008 Asian Physics Olympiad (APhO), an official of the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Monday.
A total of 136 students from 18 countries participated in the event held April 20-28 in Ulaanbaatar, capital of Mongolia.
Taiwan sent eight senior high school students to this year's competition.

The two gold medalists are Ho Ying-you, a student at the National Experimental High School at Science-based Industrial Park in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, and Chu Po-yu from the Taipei Municipal Jianguo High School.
Ho, who has excelled in chemistry, physics and computer program design, also won a gold medal in the International Chemistry Olympiad last year.

The youngster said he hoped to pursue advanced studies at prominent international universities abroad after obtaining a bachelor's degree in Taiwan, promising to dedicate himself to the study of basic science and to contribute to Taiwan's scientific development.
Chu, who earned the bronze medal in the 2007 Asian Physics Olympiad, now studies at Jianguo High Schools' elite class. Chu is also a co-founder of the school's institute of robot study.
According to the MOE official, Taiwan has won 22 gold, 19 silver, 17 bronze medals, and six honorary mentions since the annual competition was first held in Indonesia in 2000.

The eight Taiwanese students in this year's competition will head to the Chinese cities of Beijing and Xian for educational exchanges after leaving Mongolia on April 30. They are scheduled to return home on May 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: Workplace injury rates close to advanced countries': CLA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's workplace death and injury rates are almost identical to that of advanced countries in Europe and America thanks to the government's efforts in reducing workplace injuries in the past eight years, an official at the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Monday.

Lin Yu-tang, a section chief of CLA's Department of Labor Safety and Health, said the government's efforts and measures in reducing occupational injuries has lowered the occupational death rate and disability rate by 55 percent and 42 percent respectively, during the current government's eight-year tenure.
Taiwan's occupational death rate of 2007 was 34 per million population, which is roughly the same as that recorded in the United States for the same year, Lin said.
Lin made the remarks in response to a labor group's accusation that the government has been ineffective in reducing occupational injuries.

Nearly 60 workers and their families, led by the Taiwan Association for Victims of Occupational Injuries, on Monday protested Monday at the Presidential Office against the government's performance in reducing occupational injuries, alleging that official statistics of occupational injuries and deaths do not match actual numbers.

The association, founded in 1992 by a group of workers with occupational injuries and their families, has long been active in trying to promote the public and the government's awareness about improving workplace safety.

The protest was held in conjunction with the April 28 International Workers' Memorial Day, a day of remembrance for workers who are killed, injured, or made ill by their work. The day was set by the United Nations in 1996 and since then has been recognized as a national day by many countries, including Taiwan.

The association's secretary-general Huang Hsiao-ling said the toll of workplace injuries and death released by the government are incorrect. He said many cases without insurance are not included and many others were not reported by employers who hoped to hide the facts to protect their company from lawsuits.
Hang said the actual numbers of occupational death and injuries could be three to five times that of the number released by the government.

Responding to Huang's accusation, Lin said the CLA's statistics of occupational injuries recognize a definition regulated in the Labor Safety and Health Law, and that many cases without labor insurance were also included in the statistics compilation as long as they are eligible for compensation under the law.

Lin added that there indeed are cases missed in statistics, but the CLA's statistics have been compiled according to international norms, and the statistics would not be three to five times actual numbers as claimed by Huang.

Lin insisted that the government has kept making efforts in improving workers' safety and work environments. He also said the government has designated this year as the workplace health promotion year to help create a more favorable working environment for workers.

In addition to calling for a reflection of the government's performance in reducing injuries at workplaces, Huang also called on the new government, which will take up its administration on May 20 when president-elect Ma Ying-jeou is inaugurated, to halt the rights of enterprises that had major occupational injury incidents in joining bids for public construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV debate for DPP chairman hopefuls to be held May 10

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will hold a TV debate May 10 in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan for its three party chairman hopefuls, a DPP official said Monday.
DPP Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan made the announcement after presiding over a party coordination meeting.

The three candidates -- Koo Kuan-min, a former senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, Legislator Trong Chai and former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen -- did not attend the meeting but sent representatives on their respective behalfs.

In a bid to widen the scope of the debate, the party has invited party members and the public to pose questions in the debate via fax on 02-2393-2158 or via email at chairperson@dpp.org.tw or dppyouth@hotmail.com.
Lee also said that to allow the public to learn more about the stances and ideals of the trio, a party provisional congress May 4 will invite them to present their platforms.
The DPP chairman election will be held May 18 and the newly elected chairman will be sworn in at a changeover ceremony May 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC chief-designate upbeat about opening of weekend charter flights

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman-designate Lai Shin-yuan said Monday she is confident that the launch of direct Taiwan-China charter flights on weekends will begin as planned on July 4.

Lai's confidence stemmed from her belief that the departing Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government has already laid much of the groundwork for the weekend charters and other cross-strait initiatives that the new Kuomintang (KMT) administration has pledged to implement soon after it takes office May 20.

The other measures include opening Taiwan wider to Chinese tourists and allowing Chinese yuan convertibility, but Lai stressed that the Chinese side needs to show good will and put complementary measures in place to turn these initiatives into reality.
"Cross-Taiwan Strait openings should be conducted in an orderly, pragmatic and step-by-step fashion, based on good faith, " she said.
Lai said she looks forward to Beijing adopting the same approach to deal with two-way exchanges.

Lai's appointment as MAC chief has sparked criticism from within the KMT because of her background as a legislator of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union and close ties to former president and TSU spiritual leader, Lee Teng-hui, known for his Taiwan-centric ideology.
President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang, who will take office on May 20, has long favored a wider opening to China by putting aside disputes concerning Taiwan's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: First suspected victim of birth control patch reported in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The controversial Ortho Evra birth control patch, marketed in Taiwan as the Evra Transdermal Patch, may have claimed its first victim on the island.

Three Taipei city councilors held a press conference Monday, calling on drug administration authorities to investigate a case involving a 33-year-old woman who suffered a stroke and lapsed into a coma after using Evra contraceptive patches.

According to councilor Huang Shan-shan, the victim, identified by the surname Li, was a product designer in Taipei's Neihu Technology Park who had no previous history of illness. She was rushed to the Armed Forces General Hospital Jan. 21 after suffering a stroke but has never regained consciousness.

From the contents and receipts in her handbag, Li's family members found that she was using Evra Transdermal Patches bought from Shanghai Union Dispensary Co. in Taipei. Her national health insurance record shows that the contraceptive patches were purchased without a doctor's prescription, in apparent violation of the law.
Huang asked Taipei City government officials in charge of drug administration to take action against the pharmacy.

Another councilor, Pan Hwai-tzong, said sales of the contraceptive patch should be banned in Taiwan because cases of blood clots, strokes and other serious side effects caused by Ortho Evra patches have already been reported in the United States and Canada.

Chiang Yu-mei, director of the Food and Drug Division of Taipei City's health department, said that according to the law, the pharmacy that sold Li the contraceptive patches without a prescription should be subjected to a fine of between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000.
She also said her division will recommend to the Cabinet-level Department of Health to re-evaluate the legality of the skin patch.
The Evra Transdermal contraceptive patch, introduced in Taiwan in 2004, is manufactured by Ortho McNeil Pharmaceuticals, a division of Johnson and Johnson.

The product was first introduced in the United States in 2002 under the trade name Ortho Evra as an alternative to birth control pills. Worn on the body once a week for less than two months, the patch delivers a steady flow of hormones through the skin into the bloodstream to inhibit ovulation and prevent pregnancy.
By November 2005, there were 23 deaths in the United States linked to the patches, of which 17 were directly related to blood clots.
Canadian health authorities have also reported that 17 people have suffered serious side effects linked to the patch since it was marketed there in early 2004, with two of the 17 dying.
Experts believe the increased estrogen level on the patch -- 60 percent more than an oral contraceptive -- is related to the higher risk of developing serious blood clots.

In 2006 alone, Johnson and Johnson faced 500 claimants in lawsuits seeking compensation for deaths and injuries caused by the Ortho Evra patch. Many of the victims were teenagers and young women of childbearing age who suffered strokes, heart attacks, pulmonary embolisms and deep vein thrombosis.

U.S. news media have reported that the manufacturer has adopted a strategy to settle as many lawsuits as quickly and quietly as possible and at the same time keep the mega-buck patch on the market for fear of losing billions of dollars in future sales.

DOC.HEADLINE: New GIO head vows to serve as communications channel

TEXT.P: The designated head of the Government Information Office (GIO) , Vanessa Yea- ping Shih, pledged Monday to communicate effectively with both the domestic media and the international community.

A career diplomat, Shih is now vice chairwoman of the NGO Affairs Committee under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) . She has rarely appeared in the limelight, but she caught the media's attention Monday when she was named as Executive Yuan spokeswoman on a partial list of Cabinet appointees presented by Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan at a news conference.

Shih, a former deputy representative to Australia, told reporters that the GIO plays the role of maintaining communications between government and the media, and between government and the people of the country.

Therefore, after assuming office, Shih said she will make every effort to faithfully report the government's policies and achievements through the media, while gathering views from the public that the government can refer to in outlining or carrying out its policies, Shih said.

Born in 1962, Shih is a mother of two children. She holds a master's degree in diplomacy of National Chengchi University and has served at the MOFA's Department of Information and Cultural Affairs and Department of North American Affairs, and also as a secretary to the representative to the United States.

Shih was also the secretary to Ting Mou-shih when the latter served as National Security Council secretary-general in 1994-1999. She was then transferred back to the MOFA to serve as deputy chief of the personnel department.

Before being promoted to the post of deputy representative to Australia, Shih had also served as deputy director general of MOFA's Department of Protocol. In late March this year, Shih was appointed to serve as vice chairman of MOFA's NGO Affairs Committee but has yet to be sworn in.

Asked to guess why she was invited to join the Cabinet, Shih said that while serving in Australia, she organized President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's itinerary in Australia in 2006 when Ma was Taipei mayor. Maybe it was her performance at that time that convinced Ma of her ability to do the job, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF and MAC will communicate well: SEF chairman-designate

TEXT.P: Chiang Pin-kung, the chairman-designate of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , said Monday he believes that SEF and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will communicate smoothly and cooperate well in the future.

Chiang, who is also a vice chairman of Kuomintang (KMT), made the remarks upon returning to Taiwan from a five-day visit to China Monday afternoon, after Lai Shin-yuan was named chairwoman-designate of the MAC, Taiwan's top China policy planner and coordinator.

The appointment of Lai, formerly a legislator with the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union known for her protests against substandard Chinese goods, raised speculation that the MAC would clash with the SEF, a semi-official body set up by Taiwan to handle cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Chiang's remarks were seen as an apparent attempt to dispel speculation that the two bodies would be at odds with each other in executing the more open China policy espoused by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou.

He may have also wanted to ease the doubts of Taiwanese businesses with operations in China worried about Lai's previous anti-China sentiment, and he hailed her as a hard-working legislator who could easily bring her talent into full play in the MAC.
Noting that cross-strait relations heavily influence Taiwan's economic development, Chiang said Ma presented many policies to expand cross-strait ties during his electoral campaign.

"The president-elect not only presented concrete plans, he had a timetable for them, " Chiang said, meaning it was important that both the MAC and SEF fully cooperate to get things done quickly and well after Ma takes office May 20.

But a blip in putting those policies into action may have emerged when Chiang confirmed that he will not be visiting Beijing on May 25 as expected on another trip to thank Ma supporters who returned to Taiwan to vote for him on March 22.

Local media speculated that he was also to meet Chen Yunlin, the head of China's Taiwan Affairs Office who is widely tipped to head the SEF's Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- on that trip, and attributed the trip's cancellation in part to Lai's appointment.
But Chiang explained that he wanted to complete the SEF's reshuffling of personnel under the new administration before deciding when to relaunch talks with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police officers awarded for losing weight

TEXT.P: National Police Agency Director-General Hou Yu-yih presented awards Monday to honor 35 police officers for losing significant amounts of weight.

Speaking at the awards ceremony, Hou said that he was very impressed with the result of local police officers' efforts to lose weight under a project launched by the agency Jan. 21 to promote physical fitness among local police.

Under the project, a total of 33,329 police officers lost a combined 45,279 kilograms, or 1.36 kg per person, through exercising, diet control and health counseling in the past three months, Hou pointed out.
The agency launched a series of campaigns recently to improve the health of local policemen after 36 police officers were suspected of dying on the job from stress and obesity.
Lien Chin-hsiu, a policewoman in the eastern city of Hualien, said at the awards ceremony that she lost 30 kilograms from swimming and biking.
Another award recipient, Wang Hsu-chong, a 42-year-old police officer in the southern city of Tainan, decreased his weight from 107.7 kg to 80 kg.
Wang explained that he lost 27.7 kg by strictly controlling his calorie intake and fast-walking five kilometers daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: New SAC Chairwoman prioritizes 2008 Olympics in tenure

TEXT.P: Sports Affairs Council (SAC) Chairwoman-designate Tai Hsia-ling said Monday that the performance of Taiwan's athletes in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games will be her top priority when she takes her post, with promoting exercise among local residents following closely behind.
Tai said she will do her best to provide Taiwanese athletes who have qualified to compete in the Games the resources necessary for them to perform at the highest level.

Tai was among the group of new Cabinet officials announced by Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan Monday. She will replace incumbent SAC Chairman Yang Chung-ho after President-elect Ma Ying-jeou is inaugurated May 20.

The new chairwoman, the second woman to head Taiwan's top sports agency, once competed on the national track team in the 400-meter hurdles and the 4 x 100 relay, and was at one point a national record holder in the 4 x 100 relay.

Tai also has a strong educational background. She received a PhD in management from Spalding University in Kentucky and has worked as dean of the Student Affairs Office at Taipei Municipal University of Education.
Tai said getting Taiwan's people to exercise will be her second priority, as she hopes to improve public health.

She will also increase funding for the promotion of mainstream sports like track and field, swimming, and gymnastics, explaining that emerging sports like archery and judo have taken funding away from the more common sports, which has led to their stagnation.

Asked about the direction of a new sports lottery that will be launched May 2, Tai said more evaluation is needed to select the sports that will be bet on, but she suggested that Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League needed to be included to promote the country's only professional sports league.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City councilors want city's juvenile crime rate reduced

TEXT.P: Three Kaohsiung City councilors criticized the high juvenile crime rate in the southern port city Monday and urged police authorities to do something about it.

Chen Li-chen, a city councilor of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), warned during an interpellation session that if Kaohsiung's crime rate is not reduced, Taiwan's second largest city will face an image problem when it hosts the 2009 World Games from July 16-26.
The event, held every four years, is expected to draw 4,600 athletes from some 100 countries.

Another KMT councilor, Tung Yen-chen, cited statistics as showing that Kaohsiung ranked first among Taiwan's cities and counties in terms of juvenile delinquency rates, with 2,303 cases reported in 2006, followed by 2,174 cases in Taichung and 1,976 cases in Taipei.

She urged the city's juvenile police squad to reduce the school dropout rate through interviews with parents and teachers, because the dropouts are likely to become repeat offenders in society when they grow up.

Councilor Huang Shao-ting, also a member of the KMT, said bluntly that Kaohsiung's police chiefs should devote more time and effort to boosting the morale of their police forces and spend less time on handling public relations. He also asked the police not to cut down the number of criminal cases through statistical gimmicks.

Local health officials said they didn't know if the coconuts "have been deliberately hidden somewhere or they have been sold to the public."

Carbendazim is used to control a broad range of diseases in arable crops, fruits, and vegetables. The use of the chemical is believed to affect hormone function.

DOC.HEADLINE: Index suggests Taiwan's economy set to slow down

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy flashed another green light in March, signaling steady growth for the fifth consecutive month, but the continuing decline of a leading index of business cycle indicators shows the economy faces an uncertain future, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Monday.
Taiwan uses a number of indicator indexes to track the economy. The monitoring indicators reflect the general economic outlook at present, with green a sign of steady growth.
The composite leading index indicates how the economic should perform in the coming months by using economic indicators that change well ahead of movements in the overall economy.
Average monthly overtime hours, building permits issued, changes in inventory, and stock price indexes, are all examples of such indicators.

The leading index's six-month rate of change -- which predicts turning points in economic activity some six months ahead -- fell 0.4 percentage points to 0.2 percent, and has fallen 5 percentage points since September 2007.

Hung Jui-bin, the head of the CEPD's Department of Economic Research, attributed the persistent decline to global inflationary pressures and financial turbulence following the U.S. subprime mortgage crisis that has added downside risks to domestic economic prospects.
But he downplayed the possibility of an economic contraction in the near future, saying the council needs more time to determine if the economic cycle is on a downward spiral.

"Despite the composite leading index's 5 percent downfall since September and its month-on-month decline of 0.1 percent in March to 149.1, it is still too early to say if the economy is heading toward a contraction," Hung said.

Hung said the fall in the index's six-month rate of change still had yet to match the rate's downward spiral in an eight-month span from 2000 to 2001, when the leading indicators plummeted 13.5 percent as a result of the Internet bubble.
Hung believed there were still some reasons for optimism.
"The country's productivity and exports are still in good shape," he said, and coincident indicators were also on the upswing.
Coincident indicators, which generally reflect the state of the economy as it exists today, went up for the third consecutive month in March, rising 0.1 percent to 157.2, Hung said.
Manufacturing sales and customs-cleared exports in March also had positive cyclical movements from the previous month.
"But the sales index of wholesale, retail and food services dropped 1.2 points to 123.3 month-on-month, " Hung added, saying the local consumer market is still underperforming.
Coincident indicators include nonagricultural employment and personal income, which generally move in stride with the overall economy.

Other positive economic signs cited by Hung included the recent recovery in the local bourse, which rose 1.9 percent in March, and Taiwan's economic growth forecast, which was recently adjusted upward by the World Bank to 4.3 percent from 3.8 percent.

Scholars also downplayed the negative composite leading indicators index, saying the local market might be merely adjusting from an overheated market last September, when a yellow-red light was recorded.

"The decline in leading indicators is the result of a seasonal downturn in business. Sales are usually slower now than in the latter half of the year, which usually regains vitality as manufacturers begin to deliver orders," said Chen Miao, a researcher at the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.
Citing the 17.6 percent rise in export value in the first quarter of 2008, Chen said Taiwan's manufacturers are still going strong in the face of decelerating global trade.

He attributed March declines in the wholesale and retail sectors to relatively high consumer spending in February, as local shoppers may have bought much of what they planned to buy during the month during which Chinese New Year was celebrated this year.
The negative growth of real wages in Taiwan, where inflation is outpacing rises in worker pay, could also be contributing to weak consumption.

Taiwan's real wage growth from January to February recorded its worst performance since 1981, with negative growth of 1.52 percent, as inflation more than wiped out any wage increases during the period, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Chen suggested that relaxing the constraints on credit could help spark revitalize consumption capacity by creating more economic transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese captain admits killing two Indonesian crewmen

TEXT.P: The captain of a Taiwanese ship which earlier reported a mutiny aboard the vessel has admitted that he killed two Indonesian crewmembers, the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) said Monday.

Captain Tsai Chih-chang confessed to the killings during the investigation into the bloodshed aboard the fishing ship, Wan Yi Chun, which is registered in Siaoliouchiou in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County.
CGA officials said that after the CGA cutter escorted the ship back to Kaohsiung Monday afternoon, they conducted separate interrogations of the captain and three surviving Indonesian members.
They said the incident could have been triggered by an Indonesian fisherman named Roid, who inadvertently let a tuna he caught slip back to the sea.
Tsai said that because his catch had been poor, he was in a bad mood, and when he saw Roid lose his hold on the fish, he pushed the Indonesian crewman into the sea, according to the officials.
The other two Indonesian crewmembers -- Rusdin and Driyantoro -- then apparently tried to avenge their colleague, and he killed them with a fishing knife.
Another Indonesian crewmember, Abidin Jenal, was stabbed in the hand and hip because Tsai suspected he was on the side of the trio.
The other three Indonesian crewmembers -- Mufitadi, Semsayor and Kamarudin -- told CGA officials during questioning that they saw Tsai push Roid into the sea.
The officials have turned Tsai over to the Pingtung Prosecutors Office.

The officials said Captain Tsai and four Indonesian crewmen were aboard the ship when it set sail from Donggang, Pingtung County, March 6, for waters in southeast of Lanyu (Orchid Island) to catch tuna and oriental sailfish.
The other three Indonesian fishermen joined the ship later at sea.

The CGA sent a cutter to the ship operating in waters off Hengchun, in southern Taiwan, after Captain Tsai solicited assistance via satellite phone Sunday morning, saying that Indonesian crewmembers on board threatened to kill him.

A CGA cutter, patrolling waters off Eluanbi, at Taiwan's southernmost tip, rushed to the scene of the ship Sunday afternoon. Only when the officials boarded the ship did they discover that two Indonesian fishermen had died, one had gone missing and another was injured in the incident.
A helicopter picked up Abidin Jenal for medical treatment at a Pingtung hospital later Sunday. His condition was stable.
The cutter escorted the ship back to Kaohsiung harbor Monday afternoon and conducted the investigation.
The CGA had originally suspected that wage disparities between the original crewmembers and the new arrivals and management problems had given rise to the discontent and caused the mutiny.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect honors promise of having more women appointees

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang has delivered on his campaign promise of naming at least a quarter of female Cabinet members, following the appointment of five more women department heads Monday.

Five of the 18 political appointees announced by Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan earlier in the day are female. Among them is Lai Shin-yuan, who was tapped to head the Mainland Affairs Council, the Cabinet-level body responsible for the country's China policy planning; and Huang Pi-tuan, who will head the Council for Cultural Affairs.

The female appointees named Monday also included Tai Shia-ling, chairwoman of the Sports Affairs Council; Vanessa Yea-ping Shih, a career diplomat who is tapped to head the Government Information Office; and Chou Kung-shin, director of the National Palace Museum, home to one of the world's largest ancient Chinese art collections.

The latest appointments followed a batch of 17 appointees announced a week ago, which also included five females -- Justice Minister-designate Wang Ching-feng; Council of Labor Affairs Minister-designate Jennifer Ju-hsuan Wang; Council of Indigenous Peoples Minister-designate Chang Jen-hsiang; National Youth Commission Minister-designate Wang Yu-ting; and Shih Su-mei, who is tapped to head the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 29, or the 24th day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1429: French military leader and heroine Joan of Arc enters Orleans, France, and defeats English forces. She was later tried for heresy and witchcraft and was burned at the stake in Rouen.
1661: Cheng Cheng-kung, also known as Koxinga, a national hero and one of the Ming loyalists and resistance fighters against foreign invasion, claims Taiwan from the Dutch and chooses Anping (present-day Tainan) as his capital, in the hope of returning to mainland China one day to restore the Ming dynasty.
1667: John Arbuthnot, Scottish physician and writer, is born. He was noted for his satirical anti-Whig pamphlets published in 1712 as "Law Is a Bottomless Pit" and later retitled "The History of John Bull."
1769: Arthur Wellesley, Duke of Wellington, English soldier and later the prime minister known as the Iron Duke, is born. He defeated Napoleon at Waterloo.
1818: Alexander II, the czar of Russia who emancipated the serfs in 1861, is born. He was assassinated in 1881 after severe repression of political opposition.
1863: William Randolph Hearst, American newspaper and magazine publisher, is born. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire, comprised of 28 major newspapers.
1901: Hirohito, the Japanese emperor who advocated the country's unconditional surrender that ended World War II, is born. He renounced his divine status in 1946.
1903: After Russia refuses to leave Manchuria when the troops of other foreign powers withdraw from Chinese territory, and prior to the outbreak of the Russo- Japanese War, Chinese students studying in Japan meet in Tokyo and set up a "Resist Russia" volunteer corps.
1937: American chemist Wallace Hume Carothers commits suicide just two months after he patented nylon.
1942: Japanese troops capture the Burmese town of Lashio, cutting off the Burma Road between China and India.
1945: U.S. forces in Germany liberate 32,000 victims of the Nazi death camp at Dachau, just northwest of Munich.
1946: Former Japanese leaders are indicted in Tokyo as war criminals.
1948: Li Tsung-jen is elected vice president of the Republic of China in the republic's fourth ballot.
1957: The first nuclear reactor goes into operation in the United States.
1969: Hsu Peh-yuen, governor of the Central Bank of China, is released from office and succeeded by Yu Kuo-hwa, the incumbent minister of finance.
1975: The last U.S. troops are evacuated from Saigon as thousands of foreigners and South Vietnamese are ferried out by helicopter from the roof of the American embassy.
1976: Edward Y. Kuan, ROC vice minister of foreign affairs, is named by the Executive Yuan as first ambassador to South Africa.
1976: The Sino-U.S. Seminar on Food Science and Nutrition opens in Taipei with 24 food scientists attending.
1980: Alfred Hitchcock, the British-born film director and the silver screen's master of suspense, dies in Los Angeles at the age of 80.
1985: The space shuttle Challenger is launched, and Dr. Wang Kan-chuen becomes the first Chinese American astronaut in space.
1992: Bolivian Vice President Luis Ossio Sanjines officiates at the inauguration of the Bolivian Commercial and Financial Representative Office in Taipei.
1993: Representatives of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, sign three agreements and a joint accord at a historic meeting in Singapore; the agreements and accord went into effect on May 29.
1996: On the third anniversary of the Koo-Wang cross-strait talks, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu appeals to mainland China not to postpone the second round of talks so that both sides can resume their pursuit of reunification.
1998: North Korea publishes an open letter by its leader Kim Jong-Il calling for unification with South Korea.
2000: Premier-designate Tang Fei checks out of Taipei Veterans General Hospital after fully recovering from surgery removing a benign thymoma on April 16.
2001: The Ministry of National Defense says that in accordance with relevant government laws, military generals on active service will not be allowed to travel to mainland China either for meetings or visits.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A workman who wants to perfect his work first sharpens his tools. When you are living in a country, you should serve those nobles and ministers in that country who are men of moral worth, and you should cultivate the friendship of the gentlemen of that country who are men of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
New SAC Chairwoman prioritizes 2008 Olympics in tenure

TEXT.P: Sports Affairs Council (SAC) Chairwoman-designate Tai Hsia-ling said Monday that the performance of Taiwan's athletes in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games will be her top priority when she takes her post, with promoting exercise among local residents following closely behind.
Tai said she will do her best to provide Taiwanese athletes who have qualified to compete in the Games the resources necessary for them to perform at the highest level.

Tai was among the group of new Cabinet officials announced by Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan Monday. She will replace incumbent SAC Chairman Yang Chung-ho after President-elect Ma Ying-jeou is inaugurated May 20.

The new chairwoman, the second woman to head Taiwan's top sports agency, once competed on the national track team in the 400-meter hurdles and the 4 x 100 relay, and was at one point a national record holder in the 4 x 100 relay.

Tai also has a strong educational background. She received a PhD in management from Spalding University in Kentucky and has worked as dean of the Student Affairs Office at Taipei Municipal University of Education.
Tai said getting Taiwan's people to exercise will be her second priority, as she hopes to improve public health.

She will also increase funding for the promotion of mainstream sports like track and field, swimming, and gymnastics, explaining that emerging sports like archery and judo have taken funding away from the more common sports, which has led to their stagnation.

Asked about the direction of a new sports lottery that will be launched May 2, Tai said more evaluation is needed to select the sports that will be bet on, but she suggested that Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League needed to be included to promote the country's only professional sports league.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City councilors want city's juvenile crime rate reduced

TEXT.P: Three Kaohsiung City councilors criticized the high juvenile crime rate in the southern port city Monday and urged police authorities to do something about it.

Chen Li-chen, a city councilor of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), warned during an interpellation session that if Kaohsiung's crime rate is not reduced, Taiwan's second largest city will face an image problem when it hosts the 2009 World Games from July 16-26.
The event, held every four years, is expected to draw 4,600 athletes from some 100 countries.

Another KMT councilor, Tung Yen-chen, cited statistics as showing that Kaohsiung ranked first among Taiwan's cities and counties in terms of juvenile delinquency rates, with 2,303 cases reported in 2006, followed by 2,174 cases in Taichung and 1,976 cases in Taipei.

She urged the city's juvenile police squad to reduce the school dropout rate through interviews with parents and teachers, because the dropouts are likely to become repeat offenders in society when they grow up.

Councilor Huang Shao-ting, also a member of the KMT, said bluntly that Kaohsiung's police chiefs should devote more time and effort to boosting the morale of their police forces and spend less time on handling public relations. He also asked the police not to cut down the number of criminal cases through statistical gimmicks.

Tsai Chun-chang, head of the Kaohsiung Police Bureau, promised that he will not tolerate any manipulation of the numbers in recording reported criminal cases, and that he will also have police officers patrol crime hot spots more frequently.

DOC.HEADLINE: Writer Bo Yang dies at 89

TEXT.P: Prominent writer and critic Bo Yang, jailed for his veiled criticism of Taiwan's top leader during the martial law era, died early Tuesday morning at age 89 at Cardinal Tien Hospital in Hsintien, Taipei County.

Bo Yang, who changed his real name to Kuo Yi-tung after being born Kuo Li-Pang, had been hospitalized since Feb. 24 for respiratory failure triggered by pneumonia. He is survived by five grown-up children.
Born in 1920 in Henan province, China, Bo Yang served as deputy editor-in-chief of the now-defunct Independence Evening Post and taught at the former National Taiwan College of Arts.

He was jailed for nine years from 1969 on charges of "spying for the Chinese communists" and "attacking the country's leadership" after allegedly criticizing then President Chiang Kai-shek through his translation of the U.S. comics Popeye the Sailor Man for publication in the China Daily News in 1968.
He became an advocate for human rights after his release and founded the Taiwan Section of Amnesty International in 1994 and served as its first president.
Among Bo Yang's best-known works are "The Ugly Chinaman" and "The Chinese: A Historical Summary."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's highest health official to speak on NHI system in D.C.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 28 (CNA) 04/29/08 13:27:50 (By Chiehyu Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH) Minister Hou Sheng-mou will attend a U.S. congressional hearing to introduce the island's national health insurance (NHI) system, a DOH official in the United States said Monday.

Juan Chuan-chuan said Hou has been invited by U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee Chairman John Conyers, Jr. (D-MI) to speak on the NHI, which offers wider and more convenient access to medical care at a cheaper premium than the U.S.' health care system.

Conyers, currently the U.S. House's second most senior lawmaker, is one of the leading advocates on Capitol Hill of a national health insurance system for the U.S. and has introduced a number of measures to improve the health care system.
He asked Taiwan's Representative Office in the U.S. to invite Hou to attend the hearing to see if there are merits in the system that Washington can learn from, Juan said.
She also said that Conyers will meet with Hou privately in the morning of May 22, and then have lunch with him and other scholars attending the hearing, which will be held in the afternoon.

Meanwhile, Hou will also attend the commencement ceremony of his alma mater, Johns Hopkins University, on May 21 and receive the Woodrow Wilson Award for Distinguished Government Service, Juan said. Hou obtained a master's degree in public health from the prestigious institution in 1998.

She said that William Brody, president of the school, wrote a letter to Hou March 31 to congratulate him for the award, which is given in recognition of his contribution to the academic field and public health service.

According to the information provided by the school, the award was established in 1990 in memory of U.S. President Woodrow Wilson, a Johns Hopkins alumni. Past recipients include former U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and Antonia C. Novello, former U.S. Surgeon General.
No one from Taiwan has received the award before.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA pushes for release of Tibetan activist detained in Japan

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday it will continue to push for the release of a Tibetan activist of Republic of China nationality arrested in Japan for attempting to disrupt the Olympic torch relay.
The agency hopes that staff members of Taipei's representative office in Japan will be able to meet the detainee, who has been held incommunicado for over 48 hours, by tomorrow.

Tashi Tsering, vice chairman of the Taiwan chapter of the Tibetan Youth Congress, was arrested Saturday after he attempted to seize the Olympic torch from Ai Fukuhara, a Japanese table tennis player, during the flame's relay in Nagano in central Japan.
The activist is from a Tibetan family that took refuge in India after China took control of Tibet in the 1950s. He came to Taiwan in the 1990s and has obtained Republic of China citizenship.

"We hope that the Japanese government will give proper care to Tashi Tsering and respect his human rights, " Peter Tsai, deputy executive director of MOFA's Committee on Japanese Affairs, said at a regular press briefing.
"Today is a public holiday in Japan, so we hope that our staff members in Japan will be able to see Tashi Tsering by tomorrow, " he added.

Taiwan's representative office in Japan was informed that Japanese police have applied to extend Tashi Tsering's detention at a police station in Nagano for 10 more days, said Tsai, who stressed that the ministry will keep close tabs on the situation and offer legal assistance.

Nagano was the 16th stop of the 2008 Beijing Olympic torch relay. Japanese police dispatched over 3,000 officers to safeguard the torch, but several minor clashes still broke out between Tibetan activists and Chinese expatriates in Japan.
Aside from Tashi Tsering, four Japanese activists were also arrested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local manufacturers upbeat over future

TEXT.P: Buoyed by a 17.6 percent jump in export value in the first quarter and recovering corporate profitability, Taiwan's manufacturers are regaining confidence in the future, an economic research unit said Tuesday.
In the Taiwan Institute for Economic Research's monthly business climate survey, the climate index for the manufacturing sector soared by 18.46 points to 120.42 in March, its largest jump since 1978.

The rise indicates that the country's continuing strong export performance has helped local producers regain confidence as international markets recover from the financial distress caused by the U.S. banking crisis.
"Despite suffering from the U.S. subprime mortgage crisis, global consumption showed signs of recovery in the first quarter, " said Dr. David Hong, the head of TIER.
Citing the expanding Asian economy, including China, Hong said local exports could remain strong.
"Facing the seasonal weakness in the first quarter, Taiwan's export value in March still grew 22.8 percent month-on-month, " he said.
The survey included a poll in which 39.7 percent of respondents from the manufacturing sector held a positive outlook for the next six months, up from 35.0 percent in February.
But Hong downplayed the influence of the potential for closer cross-strait economic ties, one of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's campaign pledges, on the more confident outlook.
"This poll did not include future policy factors, " Hong said, adding that once the new policies are implemented, the TIER will re-evaluate the potential changes to make new projections.
The March survey also showed a 3.42 rise in the business climate index for the service sector, reaching 119.02 from 115.6 in February.

"With the impact of the U.S. financial crisis on the wane, and the potential relaxation on cross-strait exchanges such as direct charter flights and bilateral banking investment, financial institutions are upbeat about the future, " explained Chen Miao, an associate research fellow of the TIER.

Touching on Taiwan's economic growth forecast, Chen said the private think tank projected 2008 gross domestic product (GDP) growth at 4.3 percent, considerably lower than the 5.7 percent growth registered in 2007.

"We are still seeing the continued impact of skyrocketing international commodity prices, which has also pushed TIER's annual projection for inflation to 2.32 percent, up from last year's 1.8 percent," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA urges Japan not to compromise Taiwan's rights during Hu's visit

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) urged the Japanese government Tuesday not to compromise Taiwan's rights and interests in a major communique it is likely to sign with China during President Hu Jintao's visit to Japan next week.

Peter Tsai, deputy executive director of the MOFA's Committee on Japanese Affairs, said at a regular press briefing that during his visit to Japan May 6 to May 10, Hu will meet Japanese Emperor Akihito and Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda.

Tsai said it is very likely that they will sign the fourth China-Japan communique on issues such as anti-terrorism, environmental protection, economic assistance and security cooperation based on mutual interests and reciprocity.
"However, such a communique is only a political commitment and has no legal effect," he noted.
Tsai said the Foreign Ministry will pay close attention to Hu's visit and hope that Taiwan's rights will not be compromised by any bilateral agreement between China and Japan.

Japan and China have previously signed three major communiques, the Sino- Japanese Statement in 1972, the Treaty of Peace and Friendship between China and Japan in 1978, and the Sino-Japanese Joint Declaration in 1998.
As to President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's inauguration ceremony May 20, Tsai disclosed that a cross-party group of 26 Japanese parliamentarians is scheduled to attend the ceremony.
This has not yet been confirmed, however, as the Japanese parliament might restrain its members from going abroad due to the tension among parties in the parliament, Tsai said.
Asked whether Taiwan's representative to Japan will be replaced after the new government takes office next month, MOFA's spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said there were no plans to do so.

"Based on the continuity of diplomacy, there is no such law or regulation that overseas representatives and ambassadors appointed by the outgoing government have to follow the old cabinet and resign by May 21," she noted.
She added that the new administration will have its own concerns and make arrangements after it takes office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma pledges to be a culture president

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou pledged Tuesday to be a "culture president" and said culture will help Taiwan promote itself in the international community, during a meeting with Lin Hwai-min, the founder and artistic director of the world-renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theatre.
"A city can be expanded and become bigger through public construction, but only the development of culture will make the city great, " Ma said after visiting Lin for about an hour.

The president-elect suggested that in addition to exporting computers or electronic devices abroad, culture is also an important product that Taiwan can use to enhance its image and reputation abroad.

"How to develop a cultural product into not only a creative work but also one that touches people is crucial, " Ma said, promising that "Taiwan will be a culture-based nation, and I will become a culture president."
He also noted that many Taiwanese artistic groups have looked for further development in China, but urged the culture industry to deepen its "roots in Taiwan" while developing overseas.
"This is also a task that our government must make efforts to tackle," he added.
Meanwhile, Ma vowed to raise the annual budget for cultural affairs from the current 1.3 percent to 4 percent of gross domestic product during his term to spur cultural development.

Expressing appreciation of Ma's determination to take action on culture-related issues, Lin hoped that "the minister-designate in charge of the Council for Cultural Affairs Huang Pi-tuan can gradually realize Ma's policies."

Lin further suggested that Ma's administration should first review the regulations governing art in Taiwan and then establish a clear blueprint for the country's cultural development in Taiwan before putting the revised guidelines into practice.
"We have to be concerned about how to create a better cultural environment within which all the artists are able to survive and grow," Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIER forecasts GDP growth of 4.3% for 2008

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is expected to grow by 4.3 percent for 2008, down from last year's growth of 5.7 percent, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research said Monday in its latest forecast.
Although growth will be lower than in 2007, the TIER said that growth of over 4 percent is "normal and stable" for a country whose economy and industrial development have matured.
The TIER said that Taiwan's export driven economy cannot avoid the impact of the slowdown in global economic growth.
However, the continued stable expansion of emerging economies in 2008 is expected to help Taiwan maintain steady export growth, according to the private economic think tank.

The institute forecast import and export growth of 13.61 percent and 11.16 percent, respectively. With growth in imports outpacing exports, Taiwan's trade surplus is expected to reach US$25.105 billion in 2008, or roughly the same as the figure for 2007, the TIER said.
Taiwan's trade surplus for 2007 was US$27.4 billion, according to Ministry of Finance statistics.

The TIER said that with the government's infrastructure projects and state-run enterprise reform plans, the growth rate for fixed public investment in 2008 will rebound into positive territory and reach 3.65 percent.

Although domestic industries continue to relocate overseas in large numbers, the TIER said, private investment growth in Taiwan is expected to reach 3.99 percent for the year as local businesses continue to invest in building new factories and industrial upgrading in an environment of stable economic expansion.

The TIER further said that although it expects oil prices to return to US$80 a barrel, rising agricultural and industrial raw material prices and rising inflationary pressures will result in wholesale prices increasing by 6.63 percent for 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Authorities track down importer of tainted coconuts

TEXT.P: Taipei County law enforcement and consumer rights authorities on Tuesday tracked down a businessman who illegally disposed of a 21-ton shipment of coconuts imported from Thailand that were found to contain the residue of a banned pesticide.
The businessman, Mo Yu-huei, was taken to the Criminal Investigation Bureau early Tuesday to be interrogated.
According to a cable TV news station, the trading company owner refused to disclose who bought the tainted coconuts but said his company had sold the goods to some street vendors.
Chain hypermarket outlets in the county, including RT-Mart, Carrefour and Welcome, also underwent inspections Tuesday, but none were selling the tainted coconuts.
They were asked, however, to take any coconuts from Thailand they were selling off their shelves until additional tests could be conducted.

Earlier in the day, county officials responsible for the protection of consumers' rights and health raided Mo's company -- named "Jih Chao" in Mandarin -- at its registered address in Tucheng, but only found a household there.
Meanwhile, police tracked the trader's actual operational base to Lujhou in the northern part of the county in the hope of finding the coconuts.

The Department of Health (DOH) reported the previous day that tests on samples from the shipment of over 30,000 Rungtawan coconuts detected 0.18 ppm of the fungicide Carbendazim in their juice and meat.
Although the volume of Carbendazim was minimal, any produce containing traces of the substance should be destroyed, said Hsieh Ting-hung, vice director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Safety.

When the government authorities asked to inspect the coconuts on April 18, the importer signed a letter of indemnity agreeing to store them in a special warehouse and selling them only after the test was completed.
But when Taipei County health officials went to the warehouse after the tests were completed to destroy the coconuts, they discovered the coconuts were gone.
Carbendazim is used to control a broad range of diseases in crops, fruits, and vegetables. The use of the chemical is believed to affect hormone function.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened low and closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 187.86 points, or 2.06 percent, to close at 8,891.74.

Suffering a drop from the gains of the previous day, the local bourse opened at 9,056.16 and fluctuated between 9,077.77 and 8,891.74 during the day's session. A total of 5.24 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$148.14 billion (US$4.87 billion).

All eight major categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 5.4 percent. Cement stocks dropped 4.5 percent, textile stocks and paper and pulp issues both fell 2.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and banking and financial shares both lost 2.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares shed 1.7 percent, and foodstuff issues were down 1.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,869 to 546, with 246 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$13.33 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF chairman-designate denies plan to visit China in May

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman-designate Chiang Pin-kung denied Tuesday he has had any plan to visit China in late May or meet with a high- ranking Chinese official in charge of Taiwan affairs.

Chiang, who returned to Taiwan from a trip to China Monday, made the clarification in response to a United Daily News report saying that he had canceled his travel plans after receiving a phone call from China.

Chiang reportedly had planned to visit China again next month to attend the annual conference of an organization formed by Taiwanese investors in China scheduled for May 25, during which he reportedly would meet with Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council.

The paper suggested that the change of heart was triggered by President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's decision announced Monday to appoint former Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Lai Shin-yuan -- known for her critical stance toward China -- to head the Mainland Affairs Council.
Issuing a statement through his office, Chiang dismissed the report as mere speculation.

Chiang said he has never had any plan to attend the May 25 event, which will take place soon after the inauguration of the new government on May 20, because he will be busy consolidating his new team at the foundation at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Incoming president's land restoration policy questioned

TEXT.P: Several environmental groups urged President-elect Ma Ying-jeou Tuesday to clearly articulate his policy on the environment, after a provisional resolution was passed in a legislative committee last week to suspend a government land restoration plan.

Kuomintang (KMT) legislators Kung Wen-chi, Lin Tsang-ming and Chiu Ching-chun argued during a committee meeting in the Legislative Yuan that the National Land Restoration Strategy and Action Plan should not be approved before the National Land Restoration Act was enacted.
They argued that the restoration plan did not provide a detailed assessment of people's rights and environmental protection and could have a serious impact on the country's development.

The National Land Restoration Act, approved by the Executive Yuan in 2005, aims to restore eroded land in coastal and mountainous regions, and would promote land conservation, limit the construction of new roads in mountainous areas and help indigenous people rebuild their homes.
The act was shelved in the Legislative Yuan, however, and has been seldom discussed since, drawing criticism from environmental groups.

Realizing that the proposed law had little chance of making its way through the legislature, the Executive Yuan in the same year introduced the National Land Restoration Strategy and Action Plan -- which did not require legislative approval -- to proceed with land restoration projects.
The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government implemented the plan, but the KMT legislators pushed through a resolution in committee to suspend the plan.

"Now that the plan may be suspended, Ma should make clear his position and policy on national lands, " said DPP legislator Lin Shu-fen, who noted that Ma touted national land restoration during his presidential campaign.

"Ma's plan to restore national lands is a kind of atonement for the KMT's enormous exploitation and development when it was in power." said Lee Ken-cheng, secretary-general of Mercy on the Earth, Taiwan, an environmental association.
He said that if Ma's policy views clashed with the stance of KMT lawmakers, then Ma should make public his opinion known on the opposition to the plan by his party's legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-vice premier's joining DPP chairman race 'good' thing: observer
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 28 (CNA) 04/29/08 16:53:24 (By Chiehyu Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen's participation in the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairmanship election has been a "good" thing, a noted Taiwan political observer said Sunday.
Antonio Chiang, who arrived in Washington D.C. last week to attend a seminar sponsored by a U.S. think tank, made the remarks when he was interviewed by the Voice of America Sunday.

Chiang, who has long been involved in opposition media and served as the deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC), was asked about how the floundering party can regain its feet after its latest setback in the March 22 presidential election.

Speaking on the three hopefuls in the May 18 DPP party chairmanship election, he noted that the participation of two pro-independence diehards -- Koo Kuan- min, former senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian and Legislator Trong Chai -- prompted the party's young turks to unite and persuade former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen to join the race, which he termed as a "good phenomenon."
Saying that the DPP has regressed to a "conservative" force, he said that it desperately "needs new faces and a new mind-set."

He suggested all those who were active in the 1978 "Kaohsiung Incident, " including Vice President Annette Lu, former DPP Chairmen Shih Ming-teh and Lin Yi-hsiung, and Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, as well as the lawyers who defended them --- President Chen Shui-bian and incumbent DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh -- will step back to allow the younger generation to take the helm of the party.

The Kaohsiung Incident refers to a peaceful commemorative activity marking Human Rights Day on Dec. 10, 1978 that turned violent. Many human rights activists directly or indirectly involved in the incident later formed the DPP and rose to political prominence.

Chiang pointed out that out of election considerations, the DPP has in recent years dwelled too much on playing up the ethnic divide and national identity issues, which has turned it into a "conservative" force.
He observed that even though the KMT has not undergone dramatic changes or reforms over the past few years, the DPP had let too many people down.
