Although the DPP is still young, signs of an "elder politics mentality" have emerged, which has led it to fall out of step with the changing times, he added.

Chiang also lauded the incoming KMT administration's choice of a former legislator from the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union to serve as the nation's top China policy planner, describing it as a "creative" arrangement.

He was referring to Lai Shin-yuan's designation as the chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , and he lauded her professionalism, international perspective and expertise in trade and economic issues.
But he also said how much room she'll have to maneuver in her post will hinge on how much authority President-elect Ma Ying-jeou gives her.
"This is because cross-Taiwan Strait relations fall under the realm of the president, and it will depend on how Ma is going to handle it," Chiang added.
Based on his experience in the NSC between 2000 and 2004, he observed that there is much to do and discuss in the area of cross-strait trade.

But the major challenge, he said, will come on the diplomatic front, which will decide whether there is a truce in the diplomatic tug-of-war and Taiwan has room to maneuver in the international community.
"The interests of the two sides often clash on this front," he noted.

He stressed that judging from China's current political structure, the policies of China's diplomatic and military systems are starkly different from those of the Taiwan Affairs Office under its State Council.
Even if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can resume stalled dialogues in a good atmosphere, the diplomatic and military forces in China will not necessarily toe the same line, he observed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Overseas volunteers serve as civilian diplomats for Taiwan: FM

TEXT.P: Taiwan's overseas volunteers, in their roles as civilian diplomats, can help Taiwan overcome its diplomatic plight and create unlimited possibilities for its diplomatic allies, Foreign Minister James Huang said Tuesday in Taipei.

"The service provided by Taiwan's overseas volunteers is highly influential in promoting Taiwan's diplomatic work, " Huang said. "These outstanding students who participate in the overseas volunteer program sponsored by the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) are the best publicity for Taiwan's national image."

Huang, in his role as chairman of the fund signed a letter of intent for cooperation with National Taiwan University (NTU) President Lee Si-chen, on ICDF's overseas volunteer program, marking the first ever cooperation between the organization and the top academic institution.
The ICDF was established as a foundation by the Republic of China government in 1996 in order to carry out international development projects.

The organization's purpose is to strengthen international cooperation and enhance foreign relations by promoting economic development, social progress and the welfare of the people in partner nations around the world.

Huang said volunteering is very meaningful as students not only can experience different cultures but can also become aware of the predicament of underdeveloped countries -- an experience that they will not be able to get in Taiwan.

He noted that in the United States, many distinguished youngsters, daughters and sons of celebrities, politicians and students of top universities volunteer in organizations such as the Peace Corps as their first job after graduation.

Citing an example, he said the daughter of former American Institute in Taiwan Director Douglas Paal chose to volunteer in Africa for a year instead of coming to spend Christmas with her father in Taiwan.

"Volunteering can develop young people's humanitarian concerns and international views, " Huang said. "The signature of a letter of intent between the ICDF and NTU provides a great opportunity for our students to test themselves and pursue their dreams."

NTU President Lee noted that all NTU students are required to take a three- year course called "serve and learn, " with students volunteering to provide social services in remote areas during winter and summer vacations.
"With the signing of cooperation with the ICDF, NTU students will have the chance to get involved in the societies of Taiwan's diplomatic allies and really grasp international trends," he said.
Since 1996, the ICDF has dispatched 312 volunteers to 30 countries around the world.

Services provided by Taiwan overseas volunteers include basic consulting services for small and medium enterprises, vocational and computer training, and instruction in Chinese language and other subjects.

This year, the ICDF extended its volunteer programs to recruit 115 long-term and short-term volunteers to serve as a new generation of Taiwan's "grass-roots diplomats, " said Chow Yen-shin, assistant secretary general of the ICDF.
He added that the organization hopes to work with industry unions in the near future to recruit talent from different fields and create a new force for Taiwan's diplomatic work.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung County favors halting fallow policy

TEXT.P: In anticipation of the central government's plan to halt its current fallow policy amid a looming food shortage across the globe, the Kaohsiung County said Tuesday that it favors such an adjustment to tackle rising food prices at home.
Huang Sheng-wei, head of the Kaohsiung County government's agricultural affairs department, made the remarks while reporting at a meeting with ranking county officials.

Huang said he will suggest the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency drop its fallow policy and slash subsidies for fallow farmland to encourage farmers to restart cultivation or to release their land plots for organic or competitive plantation.

Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan is a traditional agricultural area, with as much as 8,000 hectares of farmland. In recent years, some 4,200 hectares of the farmland were allowed to remain fallow for the first harvest, while 7,200 hectares were left unseeded for the second crop.

COA chairman-designate Chen Wu-hsiung told CNA in an exclusive interview early last week that under his leadership, the COA will aim to "build public health, boost agricultural competitiveness and enhance sustainable growth" to reinvigorate Taiwan's agricultural industry.
Chen said that increasing Taiwan's food output will be his short-term objective after he assumes office as part of the incoming Kuomintang government May 20.
According to the incoming COA chief, some 220,000 hectares of farmland across Taiwan have been lying fallow.

Echoing Chen's remarks, Huang Yu-tsai, director of the Agriculture and Food Agency, said last week that the government would consider resuming cultivation of fallow rice paddies to help curb an increasing food shortage around the world.

According to Huang, the government could allow rice paddies that have lain fallow to be plowed at any time, although it had adjusted its rice production policy by encouraging rice farmers not to plant after Taiwan entered the World Trade Organization and began allowing imports of rice from abroad.

According to COA Vice Chairman Lee Jen-chyuan, the COA projects the use of up to 30,000 hectares of the country's fallow farmland to grow corn in 2008, and another 20,000 hectares and 16,000 hectares will be used for cultivating rice and for forestation, respectively.
The COA is planning to urge farmers to grow corn for corn feed on 12,000 hectares of the fallow farmland this year and on 30,000 hectares next year, Lee said.
The rest of the fallow farmland will be used to produce other kinds of grains that will not cause a glut in the domestic market, Lee said.
Compared to other Asian countries, Taiwan's rice prices have remained relatively stable, having increased by some 13 percent this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM express regret over WHO's return of president's letter

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang expressed regret Tuesday over the World Health Organization's (WHO's) decision to return President Chen Shui-bian's letter seeking membership for Taiwan in the organization.

The letter, in which the president expressed the country's intention to join the world health body as a full member under the name Taiwan, or at least as an observer in its decision-making body -- the World Health Assembly -- was sent to WHO Director-General Margaret Chen on April 17, according Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh.
The letter was received by the WHO Secretariat on April 23 and then passed on to the WHO's Headquarters in Geneva before being sent back to Taiwan, she said.

Speaking with reporters Tuesday, Huang said the request for observer status in the organization illustrates Taiwan's "sincerity and flexibility" on the issue, and he expressed regret over the WHO's rejection of the letter.
He said that the Taiwan government has been communicating with its diplomatic allies and other major countries to support its WHO bid.
Huang said that the United States does not support Taiwan applying for full membership in the WHO but does support, in principle, the granting of observer status in the WHA.

He added that as Taiwan has adopted a two-pronged strategy regarding its WHO bid this year -- namely requesting observer status in the WHA while at the same time pushing for full membership -- the United States has yet to make a decision on whether to support Taiwan's efforts.

As for the European Union, Huang said that it supports "meaningful participation" by Taiwan in the WHO, but that it has so far maintained a reserved attitude on Taiwan's bid for observer status in the WHA.
The WHA's annual conference is slated to be held in Geneva May 19-24.

Huang said that the government is making an all out effort to gain the support of major countries for Taiwan's bid and that its diplomatic allies will submit a proposal at the WHA meeting for Taiwan to be granted observer status.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung County to establish first 'English village' in June

TEXT.P: An "English village" will be established at Tsai Wen Elementary School in Luchu Township, southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung county in June, aiming to offer students a unique, full-immersion experience, Kaohsiung Deputy Magistrate Yeh Nan-ming said Monday.
The village will be the first of its kind in the county, with several others to be set up in Kaohsiung in the near future. Few such schools exist in Taiwan.

The facility will enable students to practice real life English - including how to use English to order food in restaurants, mail a letter at the post office and shop for groceries in a supermarket, Yeh said.

The plan comes as public schools in Taiwan are facing pressure to improve English instruction. Many Taiwanese parents spend a lot of money to send their children to privately-run after school English tutorial centers, which employ foreigners, because they believe the standard of instruction in public schools is not up to par.
The "English villages" aims to offer students an overseas experience, without the high costs and problems of sending young children abroad to English-speaking countries.

The Tasi Wen Elementary School in Kaohsiung, for example, will have a one-day "English tour" that will include meals and boarding for the students, to give them a chance to experience what it would be like to study abroad.
Teachers will include foreigners as well as local instructors.
The language of instruction and communication will be English, unlike Taiwan's regular schools, where English is only spoken during English class in the classroom.
The establishment of the English village is aimed at sharpening not only students', but also teachers', English speaking and listening abilities, Yeh added.

Currently, Taiwanese English teachers get little opportunity to practice speaking English and it is hoped that by putting them in an environment with expatriate teachers, they will also have an opportunity to improve their English skills and therefore become better at teaching English.

Yeh's remarks came during a meeting at the Kaohsiung County Hall for directors of the county's agencies where he advised the county's education department to prepare local English teachers for teaching at the villages, especially their English conversation ability.

Following the opening of the first English village, the county government will also establish several English villages in the county's Fengshan, Gangshan and Chishan districts in the near future to offer English courses for more students, an official of the county's Education Department said at the meeting.

The English villages in Kangshan district, for example, will allow students to sharpen their spoken English in various contexts, including airport customs, in- flight, hotels, restaurants, bookstores, banks, post offices, on the MRT, buses, taxis, supermarkets, movie theaters and hospitals, Yeh noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Democracy Hall's fate up to public: incoming education minister

TEXT.P: Education Minister-designate Cheng Jei-cheng said Tuesday that the fate of the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall will be decided by public opinion after he assumes his post May 20.
Cheng, who was named minister of education by Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan Monday, made the remarks in response to questions by reporters.
Cheng said he will address the issue right after he takes office, but added that he does not expect a quick resolution and will leave the decisions up to the public.

The minister-designate was referring to the controversial renaming of the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, which was formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which sees the old name as a symbol of authoritarianism associated with the late President Chiang Kai-shek, renamed the complex last year amid protests by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its supporters.

Chiang is considered by many to be the mastermind behind the 228 Incident -- an uprising against what was called a corrupt KMT administration. The incident, which began Feb. 28, 1947 and resulted in the murder of thousands of civilians, led to four decades of martial law rule by the KMT.
Noting that the minister of education (MOE) should not be involved in politics and elections, Cheng said he will not make any decisions on his own in this regard.
"Many creative ideas can be obtained through dialogue within the society," Cheng said.

In response to questions regarding his views on rolling back the DPP government's desinicization campaign that included renaming many state-run enterprises, Cheng stressed that "culture and educational affairs should not be guided by politics. On the contrary, they should be guided by tolerance and diversity and should evolve in a natural way."

DOC.HEADLINE: Book featuring Hakka perspective launched

TEXT.P: The Council for Hakka Affairs released a new book "A Fast Read on Hakkas in Taiwan" Monday with the aim of helping Hakka people gain a better understanding of their homeland and establish their own identity, while spurring the development of Hakka communities.

The publication, comprised of some 600,000 words and more than 300 photos, is the country's first book that features Taiwan's history from the perspective of the Hakkas, the council's Chairman Lee Yung-te said at the book launch.
The council commissioned the book in view of the growing need for an easy reading account that would comprehensively and clearly introduce Hakka culture and affairs.
It was adapted from the book, "An Introduction to Taiwanese Hakka Studies," previously published by the council and the Association for Taiwan Hakka Studies.

The easy-to-read version, which focuses on the themes of history, economic life, society and culture, literature and arts, and contemporary Hakka developments, recounts the Hakka people's participation in various events in Taiwan's history. It also looks at their achievements in political, economic, business and artistic areas, as well as in the realms of literature, architecture and social movements.

"Although the Hakka people have never been excluded from the many important incidents and activities in Taiwan's history, they have been often overlooked," lamented the book's author Hsue Yun-fung, who is a lecturer at Hsuan Chuang University.
"Until recently, there were only a couple of research papers about Taiwanese Hakkas, but not many people read them," Hsue said.
For those reasons, the author said, he spent several months rewriting and compiling the book based on material written by academics who specialize in Hakka culture and affairs.

Tai Pao-tsun, a member of a book review committee who is also Hakka, said he hopes that the book will give more people better information about Hakkas -- the second largest ethnic group in Taiwan -- and help give visibility to the diversified aspects of Taiwan's history.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved down 170 points to close at 8,920, with 62,798 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June lost 159 points to finish at 8,898, with 704 contracts traded, while September futures dropped 164 points to close at 8,616, with 55 contract transactions.
December futures moved down 174 points to finish at 8,556, with 38 contract transactions, while March futures decreased 147 points to close at 8,575, with four contracts traded.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index slid 187.86 points Tuesday to finish at 8,891.74, with a market turnover of NT$148.14 billion (US$4.87 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 9,090 for May; 9,057 for June; 8,780 for September; 8,730 for December and 8,722 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both dropped.
May TE futures dropped 4.55 points to close at 337.5, with 4,579 contracts traded, while June TE futures lost 4.95 points to finish at 336, with 66 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved down 2.9 points to close at 334.4, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December and March.
May TF futures lost 22 points to close at 1,216, with 4,701 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures decreased 21.6 points to finish at 1,212.8, with 76 contracts traded.
September TF futures dropped 19.8 points to close at 1,206.6, with 12 contracts traded, while December TF futures gained 3.8 points to finish at 1,237.8, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.004 to close at NT$30.408.
A total of US$1.21 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$30.442 and hit a low of NT$30.392.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. troupe and Taiwan high school to present dance performance

TEXT.P: A renowned New York dance company will stage a modern dance performance that will include students dancers from a junior high school in Taiwan to showcase the traditional dance of the Taiwanese indigenous people, according to a press release by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Tuesday.

Working with dancers from New York's noted Battery Dance Company on April 28 and 29 in an international cultural exchange program called "Dancing to Connect, " the aboriginal student dancers of Szu Chen Junior High School of Taichung County in central Taiwan will create a new dance, with the help of Battery dancers. The dance will be presented as part of the New York company's May 1 performance at Chung Shan Hall in Taichung City.

"The AIT is pleased to bring Battery Dance to Taiwan again," said AIT Press Officer Lawrence Walker. "This time we are focusing on Taiwan's aboriginal dance traditions and engaging audiences in Taichung."

The performance, which is being organized by the AIT, the Council for indigenous Peoples of the Executive Yuan and Taichung City Cultural Affairs Bureau, will be open to the general public free of charge, according to the press release.

Jonathan Hollander, artistic director of the Battery Dance Company invited people in Taichung to attend the show with an open mind and to expect a variety of colors, moves and moods during the performance.

"Our job is to dance, to perform, to communicate, to teach and to facilitate the art of dance, and the lines of demarcation between cultures fall away as soon as the music and dance begins," he said. The Battery Dance Company, which visited Taiwan in 2006, will also present the premier of its new dance "Moving Spirit" on May 1. The company's style of modern dance, featuring uniquely eclectic and highly original choreography and music, is inspired by worldwide sources and reflects the diversity of cultures that make up American society, the press release stated.
The company's current tour includes South Korea, Laos, Burma, and Mongolia.

DOC.HEADLINE: I-Shou University holds gender equality activity

TEXT.P: I-Shou University is holding a gender equality activity on campus Monday and Tuesday with the aim of fostering an environment of respect between the two sexes.
The event, which was organized by the university's guidance counseling department, includes a gender equality book fair, film screening, writing contest and other activities.
In the writing contest, the organizers are soliciting stories or essays on dealing with and preventing sexual harassment and discrimination.
One of the films being screened at the event is the story of a girl who bravely battles sexual harassment and the patriarchal culture at her workplace.
Lee Ching-yan, a second year student in I-Shou's Information Engineering Department, expressed support for the university's efforts in holding the activity.
He said that many of the students at the school are recent high school graduates who are hoping to find romance during their college years.
"However, they often use the wrong approach in seeking a companion, which can cause other people emotional pain," Lee said.
"This activity helps teach these students how to interact with the opposite sex in an appropriate way and how to become refined and courteous gentlemen or elegant and charming gentlewomen," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-China trade volume up 19% for first two months

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade volume with China from January-February reached US$16.24 billion, up 18.9 percent from the same period a year earlier and accounted for 21.3 percent of Taiwan's total foreign trade amount for the same period, an official from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Tuesday.

The proportion of Taiwan's trade volume with China as a total of Taiwan's foreign trade during the same period increased 0.4 percent from last year's figure, the official said, citing statistics compiled by the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade.

Taiwan exported a total of US$11.7 billion-worth products to China during the first two months of this year, increasing 20.8 percent from the same period last year and accounting for 29.4 percent of Taiwan's total export volume, the official said.

Also during the same period, Taiwan imported US$4.54 billion-worth of Chinese products, growing 14.2 percent from last year's figure and accounting for 12.4 percent of Taiwan's total import volume from foreign countries.
According to the official, Taiwan enjoyed a trade surplus of US$7.16 billion with China from January to February, an increase of 25.3 percent from the level a year earlier.
China's customs statistics show that Taiwan was China's third largest origin of imports in terms of import volume during the first two months, ranking behind Japan and South Korea.
The official also pointed out that electronic equipment and components is the top category for both Taiwan's export to and import from China.

Moreover, Taiwan imported a total of US$330 million of mineral fuels -- coal or petroleum raw materials -- from China in the first two months, up 154.5 percent from the same period last year, as a result of rising oil prices, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Microsoft's Asia research arm to expand cooperation in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Marking the 10-year milestone of its launch, a team of leading scholars from the Beijing-based Microsoft Research Asia (MRA) held a forum in Taiwan Tuesday and pledged on behalf of the American software giant to expand academia-industry collaboration in Taiwan.

Lolan Song, a senior director of a unit of the Beijing-based institution, expressed her commitment to expand cooperation with Taiwan's academic institutions, noting the MRA has signed a Memorandum of Understanding with Taiwan's top research universities including National Taiwan University, National Tsing Hua University and National Chiao Tung University.
"We are looking forward to continuing and expanding the academic collaboration with Taiwan," she noted

"Our labs of experts have worked with a total of 59 universities in the Asia Pacific, " she added, noting research collaboration aims to build a long-term mutual benefit with Asia's academia and to serve as a bridge between the MRA's labs and Asian universities.

She was speaking at the "Globalization Forum" where Microsoft announced the winners of the Microsoft Research Fellowship Award. The award is given to scholars who stand out among the 350 MRA researchers in terms of their research.

"As the biggest and first outside-the-U.S. Microsoft Research (MSR) , an academic division established by Microsoft, the MRA has been working with institutions of academia, educational, and public sectors in Asia to streamline technology transfers, " said Hon Hsiao-wuen, the Asia research center's managing director.

Referring to the current 700 MSR researchers worldwide, Hon said these scholars' main task is to transform innovations into application, "in a bid to allow users around the globe to enjoy the newest software technologies with ease."
Following the first Microsoft lab established in 1991, Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft spent US$80 million during a six-year span starting in 1998 to create the branch in Beijing.

Hon said statistics-concentrated computing and killer applications, the latter of which refers to core computer programs with high market value, are the most competitive areas of the current software industry.
"Microsoft's latest launch, Microsoft Visual Studio 2008 is an example of the most advanced multimedia integration, Hon added.

He said the Beijing branch also promotes licensing of information technology, having offered 11 patents for private companies to facilitate the expansion the market, while accomplishing 200 application programs for the Microsoft products.
Other MRA programs of such cooperation also include curriculum innovation and talent development, the latter of which provides an internship program for international students.
"Between 2006 and 2007, eight Ph.D students and two college students have joined the internship programs in Beijing, learning and brainstorming with the scholars in our center, " Song added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's spectacle industry to develop high value-added products

TEXT.P: The Metal Industries Research and Development Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, together with local eyewear industry leaders, formed an alliance Tuesday for research and development of high value-added eyewear- related products.
Economic officials said the goal of the alliance is to reach self-sufficiency in terms of technology for the entire production process.

At least six optical companies in southern Taiwan have joined the alliance, pledging to develop new higher-value-added products within two years so that Taiwan's eyewear manufacturers will be less susceptible to competition from low- value products made in China and elsewhere.
Among the founding member companies are Jiann Lih Optical Co. and Hwa Meei Optical Co., both located in Tainan County.
In the initial stage, the alliance will concentrate on the development of high- valued industrial safety glasses to tackle the nearly NT$100 billion world market.

Taiwan used to be the world leader in the production of sunglasses in the 1970s, but many manufacturers moved overseas in the 1980s, with some 100 transferring their production bases to China. At present, Taiwan still has 123 companies involved in the production of a wide range of eyewear products.

DOC.HEADLINE: China should seize chance to improve ties with Taiwan: U.S. scholar

TEXT.P: China should seize the opportunity of Ma Ying-jeou's election as president to improve cross-strait relations, said a U.S. scholar, Bonnie Glaser, Tuesday, stressing that it will also benefit the United States and create "win-win-win dynamics" among the three nations.

Glaser is a senior associate at the Washington Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) , as well as with Pacific Forum CSIS in Honolulu, Hawaii. Pacific Forum CSIS was founded in 1975 with the aim of helping to stimulate cooperative policies in the Asia Pacific region.

In her latest article entitled "If Not Now, When? Will China Seize the Opportunity to Improve Cross-Strait Relations" that was sent to the CNA Tuesday, Glaser described Ma's victory and the failure of two referendums in the Mar. 22 elections as "a historic and strategic opportunity for China to transform cross-Strait relations."
"The United States hopes that Beijing will respond positively to the new situation and without delay," Glaser said.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) ticket of Ma and Vincent Siew won a landslide victory with 7,658,724 votes, or 58. 45 percent of the ballots cast in the presidential election. Two controversial referendums on Taiwan's quest for U.N. membership held alongside the president election failed to pass the legal threshold.

Glaser suggested that as Ma and the KMT are eager to press forward first on their economic agenda, China should move fast or it "may deprive Ma and the KMT of the backing they need to sustain a policy approach that has not yet won the support of the 42 percent of Taiwanese voters who cast their votes for the DPP (the ruling Democratic Progressive Party)."

According to Ma, launching direct flights between Taiwan and China, allowing more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan, relaxing the controls on Taiwan investment in China, avoiding double taxation on people doing business on both sides of the strait, improving financial services for businessmen based in China, and initiating currency exchange mechanisms would be his administration's priorities after it takes office on May 20.

As for Taiwan's pursuit of greater international space, Glaser said that the World Health Assembly meeting on May 19, one day prior to Ma's inauguration, would be an early opportunity for China to make a "goodwill gesture."

She said that incumbent President Chen Shui-bian's decision to apply again for both membership and observership in the world health body using the name Taiwan will "likely let Beijing off the hook this year. She however suggested that "an arrangement could be worked out for "the WHA to grant observer status to Taiwan under the name 'Chinese Taipei' on the second or third day of the session."

But, she said, based on conversations with Chinese officials, China may offer Taiwan "only limited participation in international organizations in ways that can be easily reversed, " in fear that the DPP could return to power.
"Such a decision would undoubtedly disappoint the United States, not to mention the Taiwan people," Glaser said in the article.

She further suggested that the competition between Taiwan and China for diplomatic allies "should end immediately" in order improve cross-strait relations, preserve the trust in Ma among his supporters and engender the trust of the 42 percent of the electorate that voted for the DPP.

Meanwhile, Glaser said that even if military or national security issues are not likely to be dealt with right away, the Beijing authorities should "take steps to signal good will" by "declaring a freeze on missile deployments, " before any formal cross-strait talks are launched.
"Once we decide to negotiate a peace agreement, it will be embarrassing if more than 1,000 missiles are targeting us, " Glaser quoted Ma as saying.
The scholar stated that an easing of cross-strait tensions will reduce the chances of a cross-strait war that would likely involve the U.S.
"If Taiwan can become a less contentious issue between Beijing and Washington, this will also benefit U.S. interests," she stated.
"China should avoid seeking to extract unreasonable concessions from Taipei that would undercut support for Ma Ying-jeou," she said.
To realize the opportunity for better triangular relations, "wise and far- sighted leadership on all three sides" is essential, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan develops DNA chip to test bacteria in air

TEXT.P: A new DNA chip developed by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) might be the first of its kind to be able to detect in a few days 10 target bacteria that multiply in indoor air, greatly reducing the examination time, EPA staff said Tuesday.

"So far as I know, foreign countries have not yet used the DNA chip for air quality examination, " said Hong Wen-zong, in charge of the chip project conducted by the Environmental Analysis Laboratory under the EPA.
The chip, smaller than a NT$1 coin, has 10 probes, each containing DNA elements of one of the 10 target bacteria, he said.

"Using the DNA chip, we can greatly reduce the examination time from one month to several days, " Hong said, adding that since each probe on the chip corresponds to one type of bacteria, the researchers no longer need to do tests on one bacteria type after another.

To examine the air quality, researchers take air samples and collect the bacteria from the samples for culture. After several days, researchers obtain the DNA of the bacteria and use the chip to test if the air samples contain the target bacteria, Hong explained.

The 10 target bacteria, including aspergillus versicolor, aspergillus fumigatus, aspergillus flavus and stachybotrys chartarum, can cause several diseases, such as corneitis, asthma, allergies and skin irritations, Hong added.

Hong further said that once an indoor air quality management act is passed by the Legislative Yuan, the EPA will apply the technique, giving priority to classrooms in elementary schools and kindergartens.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien non-toxic agricultural produce to target Chinese market

TEXT.P: Non-toxic agricultural produce produced in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan, is to target a new market -- China -- after gaining support from many local and foreign consumers, a county official said Tuesday.

Tu Li-hua, director of the Hualien county government's Department of Agriculture, said the county government is pushing exports of its non-toxic agricultural products -- which the county government said requires stricter examination standards than organic agricultural produce -- to Shanghai.

According to Tu, the non-toxic agriculture policy adopted by the county government four years ago has also gained the recognition of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who promised during his election campaign to make Taiwan's agriculture wholly non-toxic within 50 years.
"During the promotion process, the incoming government will emulate Hualien's example," Tu said.

In addition, a visit made by Hualien Magistrate Hsieh Shen-san and a delegation to Canada last October to promote Hualien's non-toxic agricultural produce has also borne favorable results, according to Tu.

The county government's plan to seek a new outlet for its non-toxic agricultural produce was inspired by Vice President-elect Vincent Siew, who visited Hualien recently and suggested that the county government export its non-toxic agricultural products to Hong Kong and cities along China's southeastern coast, as well as to Japan and Singapore.

Hualien is well-known for its natural beauty and less polluted land and air, conditions that are favorable for the development of non-toxic agricultural products that require a record of information on origin, production process and pesticide check results.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education minister-designate pledges to help students enjoy studying

TEXT.P: Education Minister-designate Cheng Jei-cheng pledged Tuesday to help students enjoy studying after he assumes his post.
According to Cheng, this is a high goal although it may sound like a simple idea, because it involves lightening the stress load on students while ensuring their performance does not decline.
Cheng made the remarks in his first interview with the media since his appointment was announced Monday.

The former National Chengchi University president said he had not expected he would become Taiwan's education minister, as he thought Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan had approached him to ask him for advice on possible candidates for the position.
Cheng said Liu instead offered him the position and he decided to accept it after discovering that Liu's education philosophy was similar to his own.
Both Liu and himself agree that education should not be subject to influence from outside forces or be involved in politics and elections, Cheng said.

On President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's promise to set up a committee to review the progress of the country's education reforms, Cheng said he prefers setting up a platform similar to the National Council for Sustainable Development to allow discussions on educational issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Auction to help set up children's arts therapy centers

TEXT.P: The World Peace League, a Buddhist organization, and Poya Living Mart -- one of three high-value quality goods chains in Taiwan -- will hold an auction May 3 to raise funds for a program to set up Children's Arts Therapy Centers in nine cities and counties in Taiwan.
The auction will feature more than 30 second-hand name brand handbags, from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at Poya Living Mart's Minsheng branch in Taipei.
The items in the auction include an LV Damier tote bag valued at NT$35,000 and other handbags of famous brands, such as Gucci, Prada, Coach and Dior.
All the proceeds will be donated to a fund to help the World Peace League set up arts therapy centers to help emotionally disturbed children.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic petroleum price likely to hold steady in May: MOEA

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen said Tuesday that it is very possible that the domestic petroleum price will be held steady next month.
Chen's words came amid a continued surge in the price of world crude oil to nearly US$120 a barrel.
Domestic petroleum price has been frozen since December and the state-owned petroleum supplier, CPC Corp., Taiwan, has continued to lose money due to surging global oil prices.
In late March, CPC Corp. sought approval from the government to lift the freeze on a floating oil price mechanism to hike petroleum product price, without success.
Meanwhile, the Formosa Petrochemical Corp. -- Taiwan's sole private fuel supplier -- has adjusted the prices of its petroleum products upwards.

According to the calculations of the CPC Corp., the prices of petroleum and diesel fuel should have been hiked by NT$3.4 and NT$3.7 per liter, respectively, as of last week if currency exchange rates are taken into consideration.

The CPC adopted a floating pricing mechanism in January 2007 under which it adjusted its domestic fuel prices on a weekly basis in response to crude oil price surges in the world market. Formosa Petrochemical usually adjusted its prices in line with CPC's moves.
The system was then replaced by a monthly adjustment mechanism last September.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs ordered a freeze on the floating mechanism in November 2007 out of fear that continuous hikes would fan inflationary pressures.

Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and Economic Affairs Minister-designate Yiin Chii-ming have said that after assuming their posts on May 20, deciding what to do about the petroleum price will be one of the priorities, and any price increase will be done "in one step" instead of in a piecemeal way.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local demand dictates housing prices: industry leaders

TEXT.P: Taiwan's housing market could be heating up in anticipation of greater cross- strait economic activity, but consumer capacity is the key to sustaining a potential long-term rise, industry leaders said at a forum Tuesday.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and his incoming Kuomintang (KMT) government, which will take the office May 20, have pledged to relax cross-strait regulations to promote economic exchanges with China. They have promised to introduce measures such as allowing more tourists from China to visit Taiwan and to permit China nationals to invest in Taiwan real estate -- initiatives that are expected to result in an increase in local property prices.

"Despite the current economic slowdown, local outstanding loans rose to the highest-ever figure of NT$4.6 trillion last year, " said Timothy Y.S. Ma, the chairman and CEO of Kindom Construction Corp. This indicates that there is hot demand in the housing market, he noted.

He urged the incoming administration to allow Chinese investors to purchase residential property in Taiwan, "and at the same time boost the local capacity and confidence of consumers, which will be the key to a potential rise in housing prices."

Billy Yen, general manager of a real-estate consultancy, Debenham Tie Leung International Property Advisors, echoed Timothy Ma's sentiments, saying the KMT's commitment to more open economic relations with China has helped to restore consumer confidence and boost overseas investment. However, low-and- middle wage earners should be taken care of in the process of expanding the housing market, Yen added.
"Housing prices have been rising at a rate that outstrips regular wage earnings in Taiwan," Yen noted.

"In the face of global inflationary pressure, the government should take measures to keep housing prices affordable for the younger generation, " Yen stressed, citing Ma Ying-jeou' s pledge to spur economic growth of six percent and raise the annual national income to US$30, 000.
However, scholars at the forum said that the property market is on the verge of a slowdown.

"Housing supply has gradually exceeded demand, " said Chuang Meng-han, an economics professor at Tamkang University, referring to the 87.83 percent house ownership rate as a sign of the saturated housing market.
Chuang said he has observed a market trend that targets the extremely rich, which he said suggests an M-shaped society in which the middle class is eliminated.

"This trend has led to skyrocketing housing prices in certain parts of Taipei City, with the price per ping (3.3 square meters) reaching NT$1.5 million in some areas, " Chuang said, adding that there might also be a possible trend of housing market segmentation in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmakers worry about disruption of direct flights with China

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators voiced grave concern Tuesday that the appointment of a pro-independence former lawmaker to a key post in the incoming KMT government will disrupt the planned opening of direct weekend charter flights between Taiwan and China July 4.
Hsieh Kuo-liang, acting whip of the KMT's legislative caucus, made the remarks while answering reporters' questions on the issue.

The designation of former Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmaker Lai Hsing-yuan as chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has sparked disputes from within the KMT, which fears that Lai's past pro-independence stance would ruin possible cooperative plans between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

President-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who will assume the presidency May 20, has vowed to establish direct weekend charter flights across the strait and open Taiwan further to Chinese tourists -- both from July 4 -- as well as to remove the 40 percent ceiling on China-bound investment by Taiwanese companies. The three issues are of major concern to Taiwan's public in terms of cross-strait exchanges.
Although the KMT legislative caucus is worried about Lai's political ideology, Hsieh reminded her that she has to deliver on Ma's election promises.
Hsieh urged Lai to made it clear what she meant when she commented a day earlier in an interview that it is necessary to put complementary measures in place if the investment cap is to be abolished.

"Lai must provide a clear explanation in this regard as soon as possible to assuage grave concerns in Taiwan's business community, which has long hoped for such relaxations to be implemented, " Hsieh said.
According to Ma, although Lai is still a TSU member, she now shares his viewpoint of "no unification, no independence and no use of force" concerning the cross-strait status quo.
Later that same day, KMT spokesman Huang Yu-chen announced that the party's Wednesday weekly meeting of its powerful Central Standing Committee (CSC) had been canceled.
According to Huang, the KMT decided Monday not to hold the weekly CSC meeting due to a "lack of discussion topics."
He denied speculation that the meeting's cancellation had something to do with Lai's surprise appointment as MAC chairwoman.

DOC.HEADLINE: Senior Lifestyle and Health Care Show to kick off May 2

TEXT.P: A four-day Taiwan International Senior Lifestyle and Health Care Show will kick off May 2, promoting products tailored to the needs of Taiwan's increasing elderly population.

The show, to be held by Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) at Taipei World Trade Center Hall 3, will display a great variety of health care equipment, health foods and houses suitable for the elderly, and will present financial planning options for aging people.

At a press conference held Tuesday as a prelude to the show, several domestic health care manufacturers presented some of their main products, including newly developed electric wheelchairs and equipment that makes it easier for the physically challenged move around and to climb stairs.

According to statistics compiled by the World Health Organization (WHO), the number of people worldwide over the age of 60 will account for 22 percent of the global population by 2050, and Taiwan's population is aging at a speed second only to Japan's. Taiwan's over-65 population is expected to reach 14 percent of the country's total by 2020, and to exceed 20 percent by 2030, the WHO has estimated.

Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) also estimated that the industry in Taiwan associated with services for elderly people is expected to churn out production worth NT$3.6 trillion (US$118 billion) by 2050.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative watchdog defends itself against criticism

TEXT.P: A local group has vowed to keep monitoring the legislature on behalf of the public, even though opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers blasted it for purposefully citing incorrect information to smear them.
Citizen Congress Watch (CCW) said in a statement issued Monday that it obtained all of its data from the legislature's Web site for its weekly reports to evaluate the performance of lawmakers.
The group also said it indicated in the reports that it welcomed phone calls to correct any mistake it made and that it did make some corrections on issues it raised.
The group urged lawmakers to work with it to make the information about legislative meetings more accurate and transparent.

The statement came after the legislature's transportation committee passed a resolution initiated by KMT Legislator Chen Ken-te to list the group as an unwelcome organization at the committee's meeting earlier in the day in response to the group's allegedly misquoting data.
Due to the group's frequent criticisms, the committee and other committees have already banned the group from attending their meetings prior to the resolution.

Hsieh Kuo-liang, acting secretary-general of the KMT caucus, also lambasted the group at a press conference the same day for launching an online poll, in which he said lawmakers were depicted as "wild dogs" or "rats."
The dispute was sparked by the group's April 24 report on lawmakers' meeting attendance records, which said many legislative committees often started their meetings late.

On average, legislative committees held meetings 9.4 minutes late, the report said, adding that the transportation committee had the worst record among the legislature's eight committees as it held meetings 28 minutes late on average.
On March 31, the transportation committee held a meeting 114 minutes later than scheduled, according to the report.
It also accused Chen, a member of the committee, of having the worst attendance record among all lawmakers from Feb. 1-March 31.
In response, Chen said that the transportation committee did not delay its meeting on March 31, but rather called a two-hour closed door meeting from 9: 06 a.m. that day.
He has demanded the group make a correction.

The group said in the Monday statement that it would run a correction and offer its sincere apology to Chen, but contended that it did not fabricate the information and that the legislature's Web site did not indicate when the secret meeting was held.

On its online poll asking voters to compare the image of lawmakers to animals, the group also explained that there were a number of animals with positive images, such as the "eagle" and the "camel," for the public to choose from.
However, a majority of voters chose "rat, " which the group said should prompt lawmakers to reflect on themselves rather than respond angrily.
Lawmakers, the group said, should not use allegations of "wrong information" presented by the group as an excuse to avoid being monitored.

Citizen Congress Watch, comprised of more than 30 civic groups, stressed that it did not intend to favor or attack any specific political party, urging lawmakers to offer easy access for the public to learn about legislative meetings.
It is appealing to the legislature to allow its members to attend all legislative committees' meetings.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to climb Taiwan's highest mountain in May: aide

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will climb Taiwan's highest mountain, Yushan, in early May to promote the 3,952-meter-high mountain as a symbol of Taiwan, an aide said Tuesday.
Chen came up with the idea when he first took office in 2000, but national security officials discouraged the plan, said Lin Chia-lung, deputy secretary general of the Presidential Office.
It is the best time -- in early May -- for Chen to climb Yushan, also known as the Jade Mountain, in central Taiwan, as his eight-year tenure expires May 20, Lin said.

Chen is also well prepared for the activity, as he has had several training sessions on Yangming Mountain in suburban Taipei, Lin told reporters after a news conference at the Presidential Office to launch an exhibition featuring models of Taiwan's classic buildings and diverse cultures.
Chen wants the trip to symbolize a salute to the land of Taiwan and a renewal of his vow to continue to serve the people, Lin explained.

Describing Yushan as having a unique and noble significance because of its natural environment and history, Lin noted that an increasing number of young people have climbed Yushan to celebrate their adulthood.
People from Japan and the European countries also like to visit the mountain, he observed.

Accompanying Chen will be Presidential Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen, another Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Chi-mai and other presidential aides, Lin said, adding that he will not be making the climb.
He said that it is safe to climb the mountain, but it depends on the weather to see if Chen can top the peak in a three-day trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: Low blood sugar a problem for diabetics: doctor

TEXT.P: Low blood sugar, an outcome of excessive blood sugar control for diabetics, is a bigger factor than high blood sugar among diabetics seeking emergency treatment, a doctor said Tuesday.

Wayne Huey-herng Sheu, president of the Taiwanese Association of Diabetes Educators, said a 78-year-old diabetic in central Taiwan required emergency treatment as a result of low blood sugar earlier this month.

The patient's low blood sugar came about from taking sulfonylureas, an anti-diabetic drug used to control blood sugar, along with going to bed without eating, Sheu said, who is also director-general of Taichung Veterans General Hospital's Department of Internal Medicine.

Sheu said the results of a survey conducted by Taiwan's 17 hospitals among 609 patients with Type II -- adult-onset -- diabetes from January to June last year, show that 29 percent of the respondents had a low blood sugar incident at least once a year.

Diabetes is characterized by disordered metabolism and abnormally high blood sugar resulting from low levels of the hormone insulin. The disease has three types: Type I -- insulin-dependent diabetes; Type II -- non-insulin-dependent diabetes; and gestational diabetes occurring during pregnancy. Only Type II patients can take medication to control their diabetes.

The results also show that 23 percent of the respondents thought low blood sugar caused them serious inconvenience in their everyday lives, while 68 percent-85 percent of the respondents had long-term dissatisfaction with their blood sugar level control.
Sheu pointed out that these patients usually take medicine before meals but sometimes forget to eat or take too much exercise, thus causing low blood sugar levels.
According to Chang Mei-chen, a public health nurse at the Mackay Memorial Hospital in Taipei City, carrying candies or sweets is always lesson one in first aid for diabetics.
She added that high-calorie chocolate, cookies without speedy effects in increasing blood sugar, 500 c.c. juice cans that have too much sugar and sugar substitute, are not suggested.
Chang said there is medicine on the market that helps stabilize blood sugar levels, but it is expensive, with one tablet costing more than NT$70.
She said patients can still seek good control of blood sugar levels through diet and regular exercise.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor remains uncertain about Beijing visit

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said Tuesday that she has yet to make a final decision on whether she will visit Beijing next month to attend an international travel fair in the Chinese capital.

Chen said she remains neutral on the issue but added that she has asked the city's Economic Affairs Bureau to make full preparations for the 2008 Beijing travel expo from June 19-21, in which the Kaohsiung city government has rented 12 booths to set up a Kaohsiung Pavilion to sell the southern port city to Chinese visitors.
However, she made clear that she must be treated on an equal footing with parity and dignity by the Beijing authorities if she makes the visit "for the sake of Kaohsiung City's interests."

It was reported that Chen, of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , will lead a delegation to Beijing for the fair that will include Economic Affairs Bureau Director Liu Hsin-cheng and representatives from the local tourism-related businesses.
Bureau officials said they will submit an application in mid-May to ask permission from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to take part in the travel fair.
However, the officials declined to say whether they will also seek MAC approval for Chen to make the trip.
Taiwan and China have remained under separate rule and have been at loggerheads since 1949, when the Kuomintang retreated to Taiwan after its defeat in the Chinese civil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: Enterovirus situation may worsen in June: health official

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) recorded 14 new enterovirus cases last week, and the situation may worsen this summer, said CDC Deputy Director Chou Jih-haw Tuesday.
The CDC has recorded 53 cases so far this year, with one death occurring in March in Yunlin County, central Taiwan, Chou noted.
"The epidemic is likely to escalate, and may reach its peak in the 23rd to 24th week of the year which fall in mid June," he said.
The 14 new cases registered last week were mostly children under the age of 6 living in southern Taiwan, with five cases recorded in Tainan City and three in Kaohsiung County.
In southern Taiwan this year, Kaohsiung County has recorded 15 cases of enterovirus, Pingtung County 13, and Tainan City 10, Chou said.
He added that all 53 cases so far were children under 10 years old.
The CDC official advised that "frequent washing of hands is still one of the most effective ways" of preventing children from contracting the virus.

Children who have enterovirus infections may exhibit symptoms such as fever, mild rash in the palms of the hands and on the soles of the feet and sores in the mouth. In more serious cases, the children may also have arm and leg spasms.

DOC.HEADLINE: Porject approved to provide free vaccination for children, elderly

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) approved Monday a national vaccine fund project proposed by the Department of Health (DOH) to give free vaccinations to children and the elderly.

Under the project, the government will invest NT$9.18 billion (US$301.97 million) over five years starting 2009 to finance four free vaccinations in addition to the current eight publicly funded vaccines already available, CEPD officials said.
The four free vaccines will be a new pertussis vaccine, a pneumococcus vaccine, five-in-one or six-in-one vaccines, and a pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine given to people aged over 65.

The government will channel the funding over five years, with a budget of NT$800 million for 2009 that will prioritize a new pertussis vaccine for newborns and a pneumococcus vaccine for for high risk children aged under five.

In 2010, the government will introduce five-in-one or six-in-one vaccines for children aged under two, while in 2012 it will introduce combined pneumococcus vaccines and the following year will introduce pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine for people over 65.

DOH officials said the new pertussis vaccine will benefit 200,000 newborns every year, the pneumococcus vaccine will benefit 10,000 children, the five-in-one or six-in-one vaccines will benefit 400,000 children, and the vaccine for those over 65 will benefit 3.5 million elderly people.

Although Wang Yung-ching, founder of the Formosa Plastics Group, has donated 578,000 doses of pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine for those aged over 65, the number of doses is still insufficient, and the DOH is planning to give the free shots to those over 75 from this year.

Vaccines are the most effective health investment, health officials said. It is estimated that vaccinating high risk children under five will cut the number of hospital visits and the mortality rate, providing savings of NT$1.5 billion in medical expenses per year, while the pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine for the elderly will help cut medical costs by NT$1 billion every year.
Health officials said that with limited financial means, Taiwan has only added such free shots as three-in-one vaccine, flu vaccine and smallpox vaccine in nearly a decade.

The new vaccine fund will have government funding of 60 percent, private donations will account for 15 percent, the tobacco health tax will account for 20 percent and the remaining 5 percent will come from other sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC Taiwan to eye oil sand in Canada

TEXT.P: The state-run petroleum company CPC Corp., Taiwan (CPC) is to set its sights on Canadian oil sand in an effort to cope with soaring oil prices, a company spokesman said Tuesday.
The oil company plans to earmark NT$24 billion (US$789 million) over the next five years from this year to set up a joint venture to exploit oil sand in Canada, said CPC Vice President Arthur Kung.
It will be CPC's first oil sand exploitation project, Kung said, predicting that the amount of funding will give CPC a stake of only 20 percent to 40 percent in the joint venture.
However, the company has yet to determine which company it will collaborate with or the investment objective, Kung went on.
According to the company, oil sand can produce heavy oil and thus is regarded as an alternative source of energy.
Oil sand can contain 8 percent to 12 percent oil, with the rest made up of sand and water.

Studies show that the exploitation of oil sand can generate profits when international oil prices surpass US$65 a barrel. As a result, many countries are engaging in oil sand exploitation as oil prices are already approaching US$120 per barrel.

At present, Canada, Venezuela and Russia have the largest deposits of oil sand. Canada, which offers more stable political and economic environments than the other two countries, has attracted more than 30 large oil companies seeking to exploit the reserves.

Canada produces some 1 million barrels of heavy oil from its oil sand daily and the country's oil sand deposits are estimated to be enough to last for 450 years, even if Canada doubles its output to 2 million barrels a day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Textbook disputes challenge education minister-designate

TEXT.P: Minister of Education-designate Cheng Jei-cheng was faced with the thorny issue Tuesday of whether to maintain a long-criticized textbook policy -- one set of guidelines for textbook publishers but with schools allowed to choose from multiple texts -- in his first meeting with the media after his appointment was announced.
Cheng said that he prefers the "one guide-multiple text" concept, despite the controversy, for junior high and elementary school textbooks, but admitted there are still many problems to be fixed.

The former president of National Chengchi University, who is sometimes described as a "philosopher university president" was named to the incoming Cabinet members a day earlier by Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan.
Cheng was asked to talk on the second day of his appointment about his opinions on the dispute surrounding the "one guide-one text" and "one guide-multiple text" policies.

The "one guide-one text" means school education is based on a single version of a textbook, while the "multiple texts" option allows school teachers to select their materials from a variety of different versions of a textbook.

The government began to implement the policy of "one-guide-multiple text" in elementary schools in 2000, expanding to junior high school the following year in order to address the rights of students to a broader education as part of its education reforms.

However, the policy has been criticized as increasing students' learning and financial burdens because they are required to read various different versions of textbooks if they want better academic performance.

The move of allowing private publishers to produce textbooks based on the education authorities-regulated guideline has also caused problems, such as rising textbook prices and the marketing of badly written or compiled textbooks, the critics claim.

To settle the increasing outcry against the "one guide-multiple text" practice, the Taipei city government has decided to revert to the old method of adopting a single version of a textbook in the city's nine-year compulsory education system from the beginning of the new school year in September.

In his meeting with the media, Cheng said he will begin to meet with scholars and experts in high and elementary school education the following day to gain more understanding of the problems in the compulsory education system, including the textbook issue.

Asked about the city government's plan to adopt a textbook policy that contradicts the Ministry of Education, the incoming minister noted that the city and the central government will both be run by a single political party -- the Kuomintang -- after May 20 when the new administration takes office.

Therefore, whether or not the policies adopted by the central and local governments should be identical to each other is now an issue that can be addressed within the party, he said, adding that he will discuss the subject with Liu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Major investments for Q1 exceed NT$341 billion: economic official

TEXT.P: Taiwan's private sector received a total of 417 major investments during the first quarter of the year, amounting to a total of NT$341.35 billion (US$11.22 billion) and reaching 31.61 percent of the country's goal for the whole year, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Tuesday.
Major investments are those with an investment amount of more that NT$5 billion, the official noted.

This year's total investment target is projected at NT$1.8 trillion, an increase of 7.3 percent from the year-earlier level, the official went on, adding that Taiwan also had 458 direct investments from overseas Taiwanese and foreign investors from January to March, accounting for US$1.19 billion.

According to the official the MOEA wants to see the production value of the flexible display sector reach NT$4.92 billion by 2015, with a self-production rate of 60 percent and a boost of NT$2 billion in annual investment from equipment providers, as the government and enterprises have both invested in research and development of production processes and equipment.

Also, the MOEA official predicted, the IC industry, which in Taiwan is now mature, will see its annual production value reach NT$1.58 trillion by the end of this year, an increase of 8.8 percent from last year's figure.

The official added that Taiwan will become the world's leading country in terms of 12-inch wafer production in terms of output value once the country's construction of 12-inch wafer plants is completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: New mango variety developed in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Agricultural experts in southern Taiwan have developed another delicious new mango variety and are trying to encourage fruit farmers to engage in large-scale cultivation of the fruit.

Huang Hsien-liang, head of the Kaohsiung District Agricultural Research and Extension Station, disclosed Tuesday that the new mango variety, formally named Summer Snow on April 9, has some of the characteristics of the three most popular mango varieties -- the indigenous mango, the Irwin mango and the Chin Hwang mango.

According to Huang, the Summer Snow mango, which weighs about 400 to 550 grams, smells like the Irwin mango but tastes like the indigenous mango, while its skin looks like the Chin Hwang mango. Its flesh, however, does not have the coarse fiber of the indigenous mango.
Experimentation on the new variety began in 2000, with the process of cultivation, comparison and screening spanning seven years before researchers confirmed their success in 2007.
The Summer Snow flowers between late December and early February, with its fruits maturing between May and July. The mango's flesh accounts for 75 percent to 80 percent of its weight.
Huang said the new mango variety has the potential to become one of the most popular fruit exports from Taiwan.
At present, Taiwan has about 18,000 hectares of farmland dedicated to the plantation of mangoes, with 7,500 hectares for Irwin mangoes and 2,400 hectares for Chin Hwang mangoes.
Red-skinned Irwin mangoes, weighing about 400 grams each, are a favored fruit not only in Taiwan, but also among consumers in Japan, South Korea, Singapore and Hong Kong.
Last year, Taiwan exported 15,000 metric tons of fresh mangoes to both Singapore and Hong Kong, with Japan and South Korea each buying about half that amount.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shipment of tainted coconuts makes its way to Taiwan's markets

TEXT.P: Some 1,142 cartons of tainted coconuts totalling 21 tons were sold by an importer to retailers in Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County and Kaohsiung City, the Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday.

According to Hsieh Ting-hung, vice director of the Bureau of Food Safety under the DOH, about 400 cartons of coconuts, half of which were rotten or crushed, were sold by an importer to fruit stores, street vendors and night market vendors in Taipei County.

The remaining 700 cartons were sent to Taoyuan County and Hsinchu County in northern Taiwan, and to Kaohsiung City in the south, Hsieh said. The coconuts are more likely to be sold at fruit stores and night markets than at chain hypermarkets such as Carrefour and RT-Mart, he added.

The DOH said that a few days ago it detected residues of the fungicide Carbendazim in the juice and on the meat of the coconuts in the shipment, but that the importer sold the coconuts before health officials could go to the warehouse to follow up on the tests.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect re-affirms no change in cross-strait stance

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Tuesday that the appointment of a former lawmaker of the "center-left" Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) into his administration will not lead to any change in his policy toward China.

Ma made the remarks a day after Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan announced the appointment of Lai Hsing-yuan, 51, as chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- the Cabinet-level body responsible for cross-Taiwan Strait affairs.

As a lawmaker from 2005-2007 with the TSU -- an ally of outgoing President Chen Shui-bian's pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Lai has been an outspoken advocate of strengthening Taiwan's sovereignty and identity. She also led a series of protests against China's alleged dumping of cheap, substandard goods in Taiwan.

Ma campaigned on promises to jump-start Taiwan's laggard economy by improving political and economic relations with China and political analysts have said Lai's selection reflects Ma's hope of placating DPP supporters who fear he will compromise Taiwan's sovereignty and push the island closer toward China.
But the appointment has irritated some of Ma's KMT colleagues and pro- unification diehards, many of whom have been Ma's staunchest supporters.
In an apparent attempt to allay their doubts and indignation, Ma said he took the initiative to recruit Lai in an effort to "expand the social basis" of his incoming government's cross-strait policy.
As a former MAC vice chairman, Ma went on, he is no stranger to cross-strait affairs and fully aware that broad social consensus is very important in launching cross-strait negotiations.

Stressing that Lai agrees with his notions and ideals regarding cross-strait relations, Ma said that "both of us support the tenets of the `no unification, no independence and no use of force' principles in carrying out cross-strait engagements."

Discounting speculation that former President Lee Teng-hui -- the TSU's spiritual leader -- recommended Lai to him, Ma said he took the initiative on his own to appoint Lai. "I consulted with Lee and received his consent to recruit Lai into my administration," said Ma, who will be sworn in May 20.
"If we cannot come to terms and if we continue squabbling over our cross-strait policy, we will be unable to sit down to talk with the other side of the strait," Ma continued.
Noting that he will govern by consultation and consensus, Ma said he believes Lai's appointment will be "of great help to expanding the base of social consensus on cross-strait policy."

"Internal bickering will render impossible any meaningful cross-strait negotiations," Ma noted, urging opponents and critics to be more tolerant and give Lai time and room to demonstrate her ability to work effectively for cross- strait peaceful development.
Stressing that many native Taiwanese voters cast their ballots for him, Ma, whose family came to Taiwan from China less than 60 years ago, urged his traditional supporters to be more inclusive.
"As president of all of Taiwan's people, I must be inclusive in policy formulation, particularly on cross-strait issues that are crucial to the country's future," Ma explained.

He also urged pro-independence diehards to adopt a more positive attitude toward Lai's new assignment, saying that when the TSU declared its decision to transform into what it describes as a "center-left" party last year, Lai has expressed her determination to help the disadvantaged and put aside the dispute over unification or independence.
Following her appointment Monday, Lai again said she supports Ma's platform of seeking neither unification nor formal independence.
"This stance is consistent with mainstream opinion, so I don't see a problem in pushing forward (his) policies," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect reiterates campaign promises to AmCham members

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Tuesday at the annual dinner of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) his commitments of 12 major construction projects, economic reforms, closer ties with China and a schedule for opening up direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights.

Speaking at AmCham's 2008 Hsieh Nien Fan dinner in Taipei, Ma said that he values greatly the concerns raised by AmCham in its annual Taiwan White Paper over the past five years and that his campaign promises, such as the "i-Taiwan 12 projects, " are in alignment with the organization's suggestions.

In its annual Taiwan White Papers, AmCham has appealed to the government to resolve a broad range of legislative, regulatory and enforcement issues that include upgrading Taiwan's infrastructure, improving cross-strait relations, upgrading the regulatory process and protecting intellectual property rights.
Ma said he has outlined a series of strategies to solve Taiwan's stagnant economy.

"This is the time for us to say goodbye to a year of stagnation," Ma told the members of the American business community present at the dinner. "We are looking forward to an `economic renaissance' that we hope we can re-invent our economy."

The "i-Taiwan 12 projects" include building and linking rapid transit networks in cities and counties around the country, turning Kaohsiung into a tariff-free port and eco-park, turning Taichung into a center for maritime and air logistics in the Asia-Pacific region, turning Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport into an "air city " and developing cultural and creative industries.

In addition to these 12 major projects, Ma has vowed to revive Taiwan's economy by restructuring the service industries, establishing a so-called "golden flight triangle" and introducing a series of tax reforms.
He noted that the policy of opening up to Chinese tourists will not only bring in cash but also create jobs and increase mutual understanding between people on either side of the Taiwan Strait.

The president-elect, who is set to take office May 20, reiterated his plan of opening up Taiwan's sky to Chinese carriers, saying that he hopes to realize the weekend charter flights in July, with daily charter flights by the end of the year before moving on to negotiate an air transport agreement with China on scheduled flights.

He went on to say that Taiwan definitely needs to allow currency exchange between the Chinese yuan and the new Taiwan dollar, as that will provide many opportunities not only for cross-relations but also for Taiwan's growth.
"We have all the preparations to cope with that change so that it will not be too fast but rather gradual," he added.

Besides setting up a tax reform commission after his inauguration to review the current tax system, Ma said he will consider the imposition of an energy tax to make Taiwan compatible with the Kyoto Protocol, even though the country is not a signatory to the agreement.
"It is vitally important to our survival, particularly in terms of our exports," he said.
He proposed a timetable for Taiwan to keep carbon dioxide emissions at the volume level of 2008 by 2020, slash the emissions to the level of 2000 by 2025, and to half of the 2000 level by 2050.
"This is a very tough job but I don't think we have any choice, " Ma said. "This is something we have to do to keep up with other countries in the world."

In his conclusion, Ma said that after May 20, his government will try everything possible to not only re-invent Taiwan's economy and harmonious society but also to rediscover the core values that the Taiwanese have cherished for centuries.
