DOC.HEADLINE: KMT honorary chairman, CPC chief meet in Beijing
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/08 23:40:42 (By Huang Chi-kuan and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan and Communist Party of China (CPC) General Secretary Hu Jintao reiterated the peaceful development of relations between Taiwan and China when they met Tuesday in Beijing.

Lien and Hu, who doubles as Chinese president, met in 2005 for the first time, ending 60 years of confrontation between the parties since the KMT retreated to Taiwan after losing a Chinese civil war to the CPC in 1949.
Lien said he has strong faith and is optimistic about peaceful development between Taiwan and China.
He recalled that he and Hu formulated five visions at their first meeting as guidelines for the future development of cross-strait peace.

The KMT later translated the visions into its party policies and Hu also mentioned the signing of a cross-strait peace deal at the CPC's 17th party congress, both setting milestones in cross-strait relations, according to Lien.
He added that the two parties have held several forums since 2005 and that this positive interaction has resulted in the emergence of rational and practical thinking between Taiwan and China.

Since it won landslide victories in the legislative and presidential polls earlier this year, the KMT will work to fulfill its promise to realize cross- strait peace, Lien went on, adding that peaceful development will help narrow the gap in people's lifestyles and thinking on the two sides of the strait.
Hu responded that both sides are now moving toward peaceful development and said it is necessary to treasure and use such a valuable opportunity.
He also said cross-strait negotiations should resume as early as possible on the basis of the so-called "1992 consensus."

The "1992 consensus, " a term coined by former Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi of the KMT in 2000 as a way to skirt sovereignty issues in cross-strait talks, allows different definitions of Beijing's "one China" principle, with Taiwan interpreting "one China" as referring to its official title of Republic of China.

Hu also said ahead of Lien's remarks that as long as both sides seek to build mutual trust, value similarities over differences, put aside disputes and create a win-win situation, China and Taiwan will find a way to resolve cross-strait issues.
He also praised Lien for his efforts to promote cross-strait exchanges and cooperation over the past three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bo Yang praised as `epitome of humanitarianism'

TEXT.P: Prominent author and formal political prisoner Bo Yang, who died Tuesday of respiratory failure aged 89, was "the epitome of humanitarianism, " Education Minister-designate Cheng Jei-cheng said later that day.
"Bo Yang epitomized Taiwan's history and bore witness to the country's hardships," Cheng said.

Cheng said he paid several visits to Bo Yang. "Once I saw him squatting on a corner writing. I was surprised at first.... Later, I came to understand that he was accustomed to doing that. During his nine years in prison, he wrote many of his books that way, "Cheng said.
In a statement issued by the Presidential Office, President Chen Shui-bian mourned the passing of Bo Yang, praising him as one of the leading thinkers in Taiwan's modern history.

"Bo Yang had dedicated his life to literary works and he was also concerned about democratic values and human rights," the Presidential Office statement said, adding that his writings and theories will have profound impact on the later generations.
President-elect Ma Ying-jeou also paid his tribute to Bo Yang, recognizing the essayist's life-long fight for freedom, democracy and rule of law.
Bo Yang had been receiving treatment for pneumonia at Taipei's Cardinal Tien Hospital since February and died on Tuesday, the hospital said. He is survived by five grown-up children.
Originally known as Kuo Yi-tung, Bo Yang was born in Henan in eastern China in 1920. He fled to Taiwan in 1949 when Ma Zedong's Communist Party of China took control of the mainland in a civil war.

He found work as a columnist for the Independence Evening Post, a small liberal newspaper, but quickly ran foul of the one-party Kuomintang dictatorship of the day after he blasted Chiang Kai-shek's government for corruption and abuse of power.
Bo Yang was jailed for nine years from 1969 following his free translation of the American comic strip Popeye, which he used to poke fun at Chiang's refusal to conduct open presidential elections.

Bo Yang's provocative writing also led him to be attacked by the Chinese Communists. Beijing briefly banned his 1985 book "The Ugly Chinaman and the Crisis of Chinese Culture" and several other essay collections, claiming they insulted the Chinese people.

In many of his essays, Bo Yang told Chinese that their culture -- a source of pride for centuries -- has many shortcomings. He criticized the Chinese as selfish and being too willing to tolerate the abuse of power. He argued that those qualities hurt democracy and favored authoritarian regimes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 30, or the 25th day of the third month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1770: David Thompson, the Canadian explorer who followed the Columbia River to its mouth in 1881 and mapped much of western Canada, is born in England.
1777: Karl Friedrich Gauss, the German mathematician and astronomer known for his contributions to algebra, differential geometry, probability theory and number theory, is born in Germany.
1789: George Washington is inaugurated as the first president of the United States in a ceremony at Federal Hall in New York.
1803: The United States buys Louisiana Territory and New Orleans from the French.
1893: Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German politician who was Adolf Hitler's foreign minister, is born.
1900: The republic of Hawaii cedes itself to the United States.
1909: Juliana, queen of the Netherlands from 1948, is born. She abdicated this day in 1980 in favor of her daughter Beatrix.
1919: The Paris Peace Conference allows Japan to take over Germany's prewar rights in China's Shantung Province, whereupon China leaves the conference.
1945: Adolf Hitler, the German dictator known as "Der Fuhrer" who reduced his country and much of Europe to ashes, commits suicide with his mistress Eva Braun after bidding farewell to the few aides remaining with him in his Berlin bunker hideaway.
1946: The national government of the Republic of China issues an order moving the national capital back to Nanking from Chungking.
1948: A total of 21 American nations sign the "Charter of Bogota," setting up the Organization of American States (OAS).
1957: Egypt reopens the Suez Canal to traffic.
1967: Muhammad Ali, who first won the world heavyweight boxing crown as Cassius Clay in 1964, is stripped of his title for refusing to be drafted into the U.S. armed forces.
1968: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek approves a set of "Guidelines for the Lives of Citizens" drafted by the National Committee of Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement.
1973: U.S. President Richard Nixon accepts responsibility for the bugging that took place at the Watergate apartment complex in 1972.
1974: Adm. Maurice F. Weisner, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: The Vietnam War ends with South Vietnam's surrender to the communists after North Vietnamese tanks capture the Presidential Office in Saigon.
1977: Public and private buses begin joint operations in Taipei City.
1989: Finance Minister Shirley Kuo leads an ROC delegation to the 22nd annual Asian Development Bank meeting in Beijing.
1990: Elected ROC officials of all levels are permitted to make private visits to mainland China during recesses. Veterans who were stranded on the mainland after the nationalist government moved to Taiwan in 1949 are allowed to apply for resettlement in Taiwan.
1991: Cyclone hits Bangladesh, killing more than 125,000 people.
1991: ROC President Lee Teng-hui declares the termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion, effective May 1. He abolishes the Temporary Provisions and promulgates the Additional Articles of the Constitution, also effective May 1.
1997: Trains collide at Rongchiawan Station in Yuehyang City, in mainland China's Hunan Province, killing 58 people and injuring hundreds of others.
1998: Secessionist rebels sign a permanent ceasefire with the Papua New Guinea government to end a nine-year rebellion on the South Pacific Island of Bougainville.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou inaugurates Taiwan's first tap water museum.
2001: The Second Asian Physics Olympiad concludes in Taipei after more than 10 days of competition with Seven gold medals, five silvers and 11 bronzes, as well as 16 honorary citations awarded to the winners.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man takes no thought for the morrow, he will be sorry before the day is out."

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier discounts 'no bills to review' allegation

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung dismissed reports that Taiwan's lawmakers have "nothing to do, " saying Wednesday that the Executive Yuan has submitted over 100 draft bills in the last month to the Legislative Yuan for review.

Rebutting reports by some media outlets that "the legislators have nothing to do because the caretaker administration has sent no bills, " Chang said the Cabinet has sent 139 draft bills to the Legislative Yuan since March 28, when it resumed operations after a recess for the presidential election.
Chang's Democratic Progressive Party Cabinet will step down on May 20 when the new KMT administration is inaugurated.
Many of the bills are currently bottled up in the legislature's committees, preventing review by the lawmaking body as a whole.

To expedite the screening of pending bills, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin- pyng called a meeting earlier this month to seek consensus among legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the KMT on revising the lawmaking body's schedule.
He proposed that committee meetings, instead of meetings of the whole legislature, be held in mid-April to review draft bills so that the Legislative Yuan will have "some bills" processed.

During the meeting, it was decided that April 11, 15 and 18 -- originally reserved for whole-legislature meetings -- were to be used for committee meetings to review a total of 26 bills because there were no bills left over from the previous legislature, which ended late last year, for review.

The 26 bills included a central government general budget bill and several related bills, a bill on labor insurance, an amendment on lowering taxes on rice wine and related products, as well as an amendment to statutes regarding the welfare of youths and children.
However, because many Cabinet officials will soon step down, they have refused to appear at committee hearings on the proposed bills, delaying their review in committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Planting fallow farmland will help combat energy crisis: VP-elect

TEXT.P: The incoming Kuomintang (KMT) government will re-cultivate much of the Taiwan's fallow farmland to fight spiking commodity prices and tackle the global energy crisis, Vice President-elect Vincent Siew said Wednesday.

"Reviving Taiwans farmlands could help create a win-win situation to tackle both international soaring food prices and the energy shortage, " Siew said at a forum on food, energy, and agricultural development and their roles in boosting the economy.

Siew indicated the new government will promote genetic research to transform rice and sugar cane, Taiwan's agricultural staples with the biomass potential, into alternative fuels that could replace oil.

The EU nations have subsidized their agriculture sectors to develop bio-energy and plan to mandate that all mass transportation vehicles run on fuels that contain at least 5.75 percent of biofuels by 2010, Siew said, adding that Taiwan should follow their lead.

Citing Haiti's recent upheaval caused by food shortages, Siew noted global food prices have increased by 80 percent in recent years and said the price hikes could worsen inflation and perhaps lead to political unrest and war.
"But crude oil prices surging over US$100 per barrel this year has actually opened up a different way of thinking that agriculture products could be used to produce energy," Siew said.

The vice president's comments seemed to contradict the stance of the incoming head of the Council of Agriculture Chen Wu-hsiung, who said it would be unfeasible to develop fallow lands to produce biofuels because of a lack of economies of scale and high costs.
He indicated, for example, that it cost at least NT$51 (US$1.70) to produce one liter of biofuel from soya in Taiwan, which is much more expensive than abroad.

The vice president-elect acknowledged at the forum that the development of crops to be used as energy was not without problems and could aggravate pollution, but he said the government will balance the harm while finding effective ways to use the land.

Taiwan's Academia Sinica has discovered ways to use the inedible parts of crops, including rice, to produce bio-energy, while genetically transforming the crops to resist pests to reduce pesticide use, Siew said.
"The incoming administration will keep encouraging this kind of research." Siew vowed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's press freedom rated best in East Asia
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 29 (CNA) 04/30/08 14:11:55 (By Lillian Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The media environment in Taiwan is the freest in East Asia and 32nd freest worldwide, according to an annual report released Tuesday by the U.S.-based Freedom House.
The report attributed Taiwan's good performance to the government's commitment to judicial independence, economic freedom and a highly competitive media market.

"Taiwanese media are vigorous and lively, regularly criticizing government policy and top officials, " the report noted, adding that physical violence against journalists is rare and both local and foreign reporters are able to cover news freely.
The Freedom of the Press 2008 report, which rated 195 countries and territories worldwide, covered events that took place between Jan. 1, 2007 and Dec. 31, 2007.

Countries were given a total score from 0 to 100, with the lower the score the better the performance, based on a set of 23 methodology questions divided into three subcategories: legal environment, political environment and economic environment.
Countries scoring 0-30 are regarded as having "free" media, those scoring 31-60 are considered as having "partly free" media, and those scoring 61-100 are viewed as having "not free" media.

Taiwan got a total score of 20, with 7 for legal environment, 7 for political environment, and 6 for economic environment, making it the country with the 32nd highest level of press freedom around the world.
Of the 195 countries and territories rated, 72, or 37 percent, were grouped as free; 59, or 30 percent, were classified as partly free; and 64, or 33 percent, were categorized as not free.

By region, Western Europe continued to boast the highest level of press freedom worldwide, with 24 out of the total of 25 countries rated in the region regarded as free for 2007. Turkey was the only country ranked as partly free in the region.

The Middle East and North Africa continued to be the worst regional performer, with 15 out of the total of 19 countries rated classified as not free and three grouped as partly free. Israel was the only country that got a free rating in the region.

Of the 40 countries and territories rated in the Asia-Pacific region, 16 were categorized as free, 10 partly free, and 14 not free. North Korea and Myanmar were ranked as having the lowest and second lowest level of press freedom in the world.
China was also given a not-free rating, with the level of the country's press freedom ranking 181st worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: Protest held against the arrest of Tibetan activist

TEXT.P: Dozens of Tibetans in Taiwan and supporters of Tibet's autonomy staged a demonstration outside the Japanese representative office in Taipei Wednesday to protest the arrest in Japan of Tashi Tsering, an exiled Tibetan holding a Republic of China passport.

Tashi, also vice chairman of the Taiwan chapter of the Tibetan Youth Congress, was detained incommunicado for 48 hours after being charged with "forcible obstruction of business" for his attempt to approach the Olympic torch during the torch relay in Nagano in central Japan last Saturday.
After the 48-hour detention period was over, Tashi was interrogated by a prosecutor, who decided to extend his detention for another 10 days.

Noting that Japan is a democratic country where people enjoy freedom, Own Su- jei, general secretary of the Taipei Tibetan Exchange Foundation (TTEF) , said the "right to freely express one's opinion should be highly respected there."
Own said that Tashi did not threaten to forcibly remove or harm the Olympic torch, stressing that "what Tashi Tsering did in Japan was peaceful and non- violent.
"He merely approached the torch and shouted what he believes in -- 'free Tibet'. "

To make their stance known to Japanese authorities, the organizers of the protest issued a petition, which was addressed to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan, the Ministry of Justice, and the police authorities of Nagano.
In the petition, the demonstrators asked the Japanese government to follow all required legal procedures when dealing with the case and to provide Tashi with an interpreter.
"Tashi should be represented by an attorney to allow him to fully understand the Japanese legal procedures that he faces, " the petition said.
"He should be granted the right to have visitors as soon as possible, " Own said. "It is unreasonable to put Tashi Tsering in detention with no visitors allowed for 12 days.
"We hereby urge the Japanese government to stand firm behind human rights values, and not to bow to political pressure from China," he added.
The Taipei Office Interchange Association (Japan) assigned a division chief, identified only as Kyoji, to receive three representatives of the group and allow them into the compound.
"This will seriously affect the international image of Japan on human rights," Own said to Kyoji while handing him the petition.

The organizers of the protest were the Taiwan Friends of Tibet, the Tibet Youth Congress -- Taiwan Chapter, the Taiwan Tibetan Welfare Association, the TTEF, the Taiwan Association for Human Rights, the Taiwan Labor Front, and the Taiwan International Solidarity Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Computex Taipei 2008 to be bigger than ever

TEXT.P: Computex Taipei 2008, the largest computer trade show in Asia and the second largest in the world, will open in June with more than 35,000 overseas buyers and is expected to generate US$20 billion in business, organizers said Wednesday at a press conference.

"Computex Taipei always tries to outperform itself, and that progress will come together this year in a new phase for trade events, " said Walter Yeh, executive vice president of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).
"This year's Computex Taipei will be the biggest one ever in terms of the numbers of participating companies and the exhibition space,"he said.

The show will be based at the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) Nangang Exhibition Hall, which just opened in mid-March and is located 20 minutes away from the show's four other venues in the Xinyi District.
It not only doubles as a space for exhibitors but also makes available many state-of-the-art facilities, Yeh said, a good match, he noted, for such an influential trade show.

"Computex Taipei is the most important procurement platform in the world because it is a business-to-business (B2B) trade show and a one-stop shopping center, " Yeh said. "Buyers from all over the world can buy the latest and most advanced Information and Communications Technology (ICT) products."
The show, to be held from June 3 to June 7, will see record-breaking growth this year, with a 25.66 percent increase in exhibitors and and a 53.14 percent rise in the number of booths.

The exhibition's 1,675 vendors occupying around 4,481 booths will display products in a variety of categories, including optoelectronic displays, communication devices, components and parts, and brand new, purpose-designated devices, Yeh said.
"I would like to use the word 'WING' to describe this year's Computex Taipei, " said Chang Li, deputy secretary-general of the Taipei Computer Association's (TCA's) overseas division.

He said "WING, " which stands for Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access (WiMAX) , ICT cross over, new-generation personal computers, and "green IT, " will help propel the trade show to new heights.

Chang said TAITRA and TCA, the organizers of Computex Taipei, will hold the 2008 WiMAX Expo Taipei concurrently with Computex to show the strength of Taiwan's WiMAX industry and create business opportunities, as WiMAX is an emerging technology growing in popularity around the world.
"The next three to five years will be critical for the growth and expansion of WiMAX applications," he said.
Providing excellent service to accommodate domestic and overseas visitors during the fair will be another main task for the organizers, Yeh said.

They will set up a reception center at the airport and arrange free transportation connecting different venues, he said, adding that shuttle bus service will also be running among exhibition centers every five to ten minutes.
There will also be well-designed TAITRA lounges, free wireless Internet service, three press centers, and procurement meetings, he added.

Noting that Computex Taipei is the most important procurement platform in the world, Yeh estimated there trade show will generate US$20 billion in new business during the exhibition and create US$50-60 billion in follow-up business.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT chief hopes for closer cooperation with incoming administration

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan Director Stephen Young said Tuesday that the United States hopes to cooperate with the incoming administration of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou on all important issues.

Speaking at the American Chamber of Commerce's annual "Hsieh Nien Fan" dinner, Young said Taiwan is the United States' ninth largest trading partner, with U.S. exports to Taiwan exceeding US$3.2 billion in 2007.
The AIT head said that talks under the Trade and Investment Framework (TIFA) are the most effective channel for strengthening trade relations between Taiwan and the United States.
Young said he expects efforts to expand the opening of each other's markets and increase investment opportunities will continue under the TIFA talks slated to be held in Taipei this summer.

He specifically expressed the hope that Taiwan will lift its ban and allow the import of all categories of U.S. beef products as well as sign an agreement on pork imports that is in line with international standards and established practices.
As for China-Taiwan relations, Young said that the United States supports closer cross-strait economic ties.

He commended the meeting between Vice President-elect Vincent Siew and Chinese President Hu Jintao at the Boao Forum for Asia held earlier this month on Hainan Island, China, calling it symbolically significant in terms of improving cross- strait ties.
Young also expressed the hope that regular direct cross-strait charter flights could be implemented as soon as possible.

Noting that Taiwan is very important and should not be neglected by the international community, Young said that the United States will do all that it can to let the world understand the many significant contributions that Taiwan can make to the international community.

He also promised that the United States will work to ensure that Taiwan can engage in "meaningful participation" in international organizations and activities, including organizations in which Taiwan does not meet the requirements for membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: Election changes Hong Kong resident's view of Taiwan gov't: poll

TEXT.P: Hong Kong residents' trust in Taiwan's government has increased following the country's March 22 presidential election, according to the results of a University of Hong Kong survey released Tuesday.

The survey conducted by the university's public opinion research department showed that 19 percent of Hong Kong residents trust Taiwan's government, up 12 percentage points from a similar survey carried out prior to the election.
In the survey of 1,000 Hong Kong residents, 29 percent of the respondents said they don't trust Taiwan's government, down 24 percentage points from the previous survey.
Meanwhile, 60 percent of the respondents said they trust the Hong Kong government, down 6 percentage points, while 7 percent said they don't trust the government, up 2 percentage points.
As for the central Chinese government, 55 percent expressed their trust in it, up 3 percentage points from the previous survey, while 13 percent said they don't trust it, down 2 percentage points.

Zhong Tingyue, head of the public opinion research department, said the fact that Hong Kong residents' confidence in Taiwan's government has increased even before the inauguration of the new president shows that they have very high expectations for the incoming administration in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has world's 4th largest sovereign wealth: Global Insight
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 29 (CNA) 04/30/08 15:53:28 (By Jennifer Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was rated the world's fourth largest sovereign wealth generator for 2007, with approximately US$184 billion, according to a report released recently by international economic and financial information company Global Insight.

The Sovereign Wealth Fund Tracker report noted that Taiwan's sovereign wealth, calculated by deducting three months of import spending from a country's foreign exchange reserves, has been expanding at a rate of 4 percent per year on average, up from US$156 billion in 2003.
China remained the largest player, with the country's sovereign wealth having grown by 47 percent annually from US$259 billion in 2003 to US$1.2 trillion in 2007.
Rounding out the top 10 list were Russia, Kuwait, Taiwan, Brazil, India, South Korea, Algeria, Liberia and Nigeria, in that order.
The report said oil exporters have been the fastest-growing sovereign wealth generators over the last five years, with the sovereign wealth of Nigeria having increased by 291 percent.
Sovereign wealth has grown in Oman by 256 percent, in Kazakhstan by 162 percent, in Angola by 84 percent, in Russia by 74 percent and in Brazil by 65 percent.

This newfound wealth has sparked the growth of sovereign wealth funds -- government-controlled funds that invest in stocks, bonds, and commodities around the world -- that many critics believe are not transparent enough and are used by governments to project their influence rather than to maximize value for their citizens.
The report said that sovereign wealth funds worldwide have been increasing by 24 percent annually for the past three years to reach US$3.5 trillion in 2007.

According to the report, in 2007, sovereign wealth funds injected up to US$80 billion into bank shares or bank equity stakes in the United States alone and are expected to provide even more capital in 2008 and 2009.

Jan Randolph, head of sovereign risk at Global Insight, observed sovereign wealth funds are replacing the combined financial muscle of hedge funds and private equity as the new financial power brokers.

"Riding the energy and commodities boom, together with the wilting dollar, sovereign wealth funds will continue to be the key players in the changing financial landscape of the global economy thrown into flux by the credit crunch," Randolph said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 28.18 points, or 0.31 percent, to close at 8,919.92.

Rebounding from losses the previous day, the local bourse opened at 8,917.62 and fluctuated between 8,962.99 and 8,882.57 during the day's session. A total of 5.09 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$148.44 billion (US$4.87 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 1.2 percent. Machinery and electronics shares advanced 0.4 percent, construction issues rose 0.3 percent, and paper and pulp issues gained 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: 45 percent of Taiwan voters favor cross-strait status quo: poll

TEXT.P: Nearly 45 percent of the respondents to a recent survey favor the maintenance of the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, according to the results of the poll conducted by the Global Views Monthly magazine and released Wednesday.

The results of the poll, conducted April 15-18, show that some 45 percent of Taiwan citizens aged over 20 favor the notion that "the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should maintain the political status quo for the time being before any changes are made."
The percentage marks the highest of its kind in the last five years, according to the pollsters.

In the poll that the pollsters claimed could be considered a "score sheet" for President-elect Ma Ying-jeou and the incoming Kuomintang (KMT) administration -- despite the fact that it is one month before the administration is even inaugurated -- some 60 percent of the respondents said they are pleased with Ma's performance in the run-up to his inauguration, compared with 17 percent who said they are not.

Twenty-two percent of the other respondents offered no clear answer to the question, indicating that there is still a group of people who waiting to see what Ma's administration actually does, according to the pollsters.

The poll found that 49 percent of the respondents consider Ma's appointment of Soochow University President Liu Chao-shiuan as premier-designate as "appropriate, " compared to 11 percent who disagree.
The respondents, however, were apparently dissatisfied with the performance of the legislature, where the KMT holds an absolute majority of 70 percent of the 113 seats.
Thirty-nine percent of the respondents said they are not satisfied with the performances of the KMT lawmakers, while 38 percent said they are satisfied, according to the poll.

On the opening policies that Ma has announced toward China, the policy of allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan won the highest support rating from those polled, with 76.8 percent of the respondents expressing approval, followed by 69 percent who approved of the policy of starting weekend cross- strait charter flight services.

Sixty-six percent of the respondents expressed support for the opening of cross- strait cargo flight services and 61 percent said they support the opening of the official exchanges between the new Taiwan dollar and the Chinese yuan.

Many of the respondents said they support Taiwan's opening to Chinese tourists, with those from the northern city of Keelung to the northeastern county of Yilan and the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung -- areas with particularly rich tourism resources -- showing the highest support rate of 80 percent, the poll found.

Of all the notions that could contribute to a thawing of the long-stalled cross- strait relations, the respondents gave the lowest support rate to the notion of Taiwan opening its real estate sector to Chinese buyers.
Only 37 percent of the respondents support the notion, while 63 percent oppose it, the poll found.
The respondents expressed concern that ordinary Taiwanese residents might not benefit from soaring house prices after Chinese tycoons speculate on the real estate market, the pollsters said.

The poll also found that although Ma won the March 22 race by winning nearly 58 percent of the vote, with the pro-independence ruling Democratic Progressive Party suffering a crushing defeat, the map of ideological division in Taiwan remains unchanged.
The poll found that the percentage of respondents who favor eventual unification dropped to a record low of 8.4 percent.

A total of 44.8 percent of the respondents favor the idea that "the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should maintain the political status quo for the time being before any changes are made in the future," the highest percentage of its kind in five years.
The figures indicate that the Taiwanese public are no longer concerned about the issue of independence or unification, the pollsters said.

The Global Views Monthly conducted the survey by telephone among adults randomly selected from 23 cities and counties around the country. It received 1,003 valid responses, with a margin of error of 3.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect assuages controversy over selection of MAC chair

TEXT.P: The spokesman of President-elect Ma Ying-jeou's office reaffirmed Wednesday in an effort to calm the strong opposition to the nomination of Lai Shin-yuan as chairwoman of the Mainland Affair Council that Ma's stance on cross-Taiwan Strait policies will not change and that he hopes the public will give Lai time to act.

Lo Chih-chiang made the remarks in the wake of the controversial designation of Lai, a former legislator of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) who is regarded by critics as lacking the experience necessary to deal with Beijing.

Lai's appointment has been the target of criticism from nearly all fronts, with even the ruling Democratic Progressive Party casting doubt over the rationale behind the nomination, while political pundits have ridiculed Ma's decision on TV talk shows around the clock.
Discounting media reports that Lai's appointment will have a negative impact on cross-strait relations, Lo described all the reports as "presumptive."
Ma's stance on developing and dealing with cross-strait issues will never change, Lou said, adding that "it is usual" that some appointments will arouse divergent responses.
"Ma will take opinions from all sides into consideration, " he added.

Some of Ma's long-time friends also came to his aid. Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin of the Kuomintang (KMT) expressed support for Ma's decision, saying that "I respect the legitimate authority of Ma and Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan to assign personnel."
"We should believe in Ma, since there must be some strategic considerations behind the appointment... and Ma must be confident in implementing his policies," Hau added.
But Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, also of the KMT, said Ma should not be influenced by the TSU when dealing with cross-strait policies, as "he has already been elected president."
Chou further said that "Ma has won the support of more than 7 million voters, empowering him to decide cross-strait policies, " adding that "Ma should not seek compromise with the TSU."

Lai holds a master's degree in international relations and a doctorate in development studies, both earned in the United Kingdom. She has served as Taiwan's negotiator for World Trade Organization accession, as a member of the National Security Council, a legislator and a university research fellow.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei health authority to conduct noise tests at hospital helipad

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government's Department of Health said Tuesday that it will conduct noise level tests at an emergency helicopter pad located next to Taipei City Hospital's Zhongxing branch.

Chiu Wen-hsiang, chief of the department, made the remarks at a city government interpellation session in response to questions raised by City Councilor Lee Wen-Ying about the noise situation in the vicinity of the helipad.
Lee relayed the complaints -- made to her by several parents of students at Taipei Municipal Zhongxiao Junior High School, which is located near the helipad.

According to Lee, the parents have complained that the noise of helicopters landing and taking off from the pad is disrupting classes at the school and that the frequency of the landings and take-offs has been on the rise in recent months.
Liu Hsiou-wen, head of the Zhongxing branch, said the helipad was built in late 2005 to improve the quality of emergency medical services on Taiwan's outlying islands.

He said that although the average number of helicopter landings and takeoffs has increased from around 20 in the first year to approximately 30 at present, the hospital has not received any noise complaints from students or faculty at the school, or from residents in the surrounding neighborhood.

While relaying the complaints from the students' parents, Lee suggested that the city's health department and environmental protection department carry out noise level tests at the site and perhaps install soundproof windows at the school or sound barrier walls -- such as those used to shield noise from freeways and expressways -- between the school and the helipad.

In response, Chiou said that the department will conduct tests at the site and that if it is determined that the noise levels exceed acceptable levels, the department will take appropriate steps to improve the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese, foreign spouses should be treated equally: incoming CLA head

TEXT.P: Chinese spouses in Taiwan should be treated the same as foreign spouses from other countries, the minister-designate in charge of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Wednesday.

Jennifer J. H. Wang said it is unfair that Chinese spouses are treated differently from other foreign spouses in Taiwan, and vowed that, if possible, she would work to allow Chinese spouses the same rights and benefits enjoyed by foreign nationals from other countries who are married to Taiwan citizens.
Wang, nevertheless, pointed out that whether or not her plans could be realized will be up to the Mainland Affairs Council, the country's top China policy planning agency.

Wang made the remarks while addressing a seminar that focused on the rights of working class and disadvantaged laborers in Taiwan, which was sponsored by the Taipei-based Chinese Association for Human Rights.

Among other regulations, the government stipulates that Chinese spouses of Taiwanese citizens must reside in Taiwan for a minimum of three years before they can apply for a work permit. In contrast, foreign spouses from other countries are permitted to apply for a work permit as soon as they obtain their residency in Taiwan.
To redress the situation, intense education and publicity is needed, and the CLA also has to do its part, Wang said.

She suggested that local governments make an effort to educate employers and employees about laborers' rights and interests, while the CLA should upgrade its official Web site so that workers, regardless of whether they are from China or elsewhere, would have easier and better access to the country's top labor affairs agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators oppose health insurance rate hike

TEXT.P: Legislators opposed almost unanimously Wednesday a request to raise insurance premiums by the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) , which warned of a deficit of more than NT$20 billion this year should the rate be maintained at the current level.

Precise calculations conducted by the BNHI show that in the next five years, the income from insurance premiums will record a growth of 2.21 percent per year on average, while medical expenses will increase in the same period by 3.13 percent and the total costs will spike by 4.11 percent.

"If we maintain the current insurance rate of 4.55 percent, an average annual deficit of NT$40.3 billion will occur in the coming five years, " said BNHI President Zhu Zer-min, predicting that in 2012, the total accumulated deficit will have reached NT$214.2 billion.

To avoid plunging the entire system into a financial abyss, he suggested that premiums be raised to 5.18 percent in order to balance the costs and revenues over five years and that the insured should be required to pay 20 percent of the cost of diagnosis and emergency treatment fees.

However, the legislators firmly opposed raising the premiums, saying that the bureau should cover the loopholes in the insurance system, such as a price gap between drugs and illegal practices by doctors, and should take into consideration health insurance reforms before asking people to pay more.
The price gap is the difference between the amount that healthcare providers -- hospitals -- pays for drugs and the amount that the BNHI reimburses the hospitals.
According to Legislator Lin Hung-chih, the BNHI reimburses some healthcare providers for the price of patent drugs even though the hospital prescribes cheaper generic ones.

"Since President-elect Ma Ying-jeou has promised to increase the economic growth rate to 6 percent, more budget should be appropriated to fill the deficit, " said Hwang Yih-jiau, an opposition Kuomintang legislator.
Legislators also said health insurance reforms could be a solution to the deficit problem.

According to the health insurance reforms, dubbed "second-generation health insurance, " insurance premiums are charged in accordance with household income, instead of according to six categories based on professions.
Premiums have only been raised once -- from 4.25 percent to 4.55 percent in 2002 -- since the system was put into effect in 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect vows to attract funds back to Taiwan

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that once his new administration is inaugurated, he will make sure capital and funds that have been diverted out of the country over the past five years are attracted back to Taiwan.

Speaking to a group of representatives from the industrial and business sectors in northern Taiwan at a roundtable meeting, Ma said that "opening and deregulation" will be the main guiding motto of the incoming administration.

Noting that strict regulations have caused capital flight over the past several years and that local funds never return once they leave, Ma said an Asia-Pacific assets management center and fund operational hub will be established before long to "recoup the lost funds."
He also said taxes will be reduced and regulations simplified so that businesses can offer more jobs and better jobs with higher pay.

Ma said various policies will be launched immediately after his May 20 inauguration. "Although we have won the presidential election, what is more important is making sure our campaign platform is delivered into policies that will benefit the people," he said.

Vice President-elect Vincent Siew, a veteran technocrat particularly versed in economic affairs, said he feels an immense responsibility with the huge mandate the voters have given to him and the president-elect.

"I've been thinking day in and day out how to govern the country in a better way, " Siew said, adding that the lineup of the new Cabinet is almost shaped and ready to run the nation with ability and experience.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.041 to close at NT$30.449.
A total of US$1.346 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.435 and fluctuated between NT$30.400 and NT$30.465.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT chairman optimistic about cross-strait relations after Ma takes

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt said Tuesday at a symposium that he is optimistic about the development of cross-strait relations after Taiwan's President-elect Ma Ying-jeou takes office, and asked Beijing to take a "more flexible and imaginative approach" so that the relations could move forward.

"After May 20 -- Ma's inauguration -- we enter a period in which we will have the right to have some optimism," said Burghardt, who also serves as director of the East-West Seminars at the East-West Center (EWC), a Hawaii-based education and research institution.

He made the remarks at a Taiwan Election Symposium, co-hosted by the Pacific Forum under the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) and the Taiwan Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) Tuesday in Honolulu. The seminar examined the implications of Taiwan's recent presidential and parliamentary elections.
Burghardt said that there is an opportunity to reduce tensions across the Taiwan Strait, but that stability will require engagement, which had not been much in evidence over the last 10 years.

"Success will depend on China's decision to take a more flexible and imaginative approach to Taiwan," said the head of the AIT, the quasi-official organization that handles Taiwan-U.S. affairs in the absence of diplomatic ties.
"Beijing must go from crisis management to opportunity management," he said.

Ma's landslide victory on March 22 and an even more lopsided victory by the Kuomintang (KMT) candidates in the January Legislative Yuan elections will allow the KMT to dominate both branches of government in Taipei and herald the return of a conservative government in Taiwan after the KMT lost power to the Democratic Progressive Party in 2000.

Experts and next generation analysts at the forum agreed that Ma's election as president of Taiwan "opens the door to a new and positive cross-strait dynamic between Taipei and Beijing, but the chances of a breakthrough are limited, " according to a press release issued by the symposium.
"Both sides are waiting for a positive gesture from the other to move forward," according to Ralph Cossa, president of the Pacific Forum CSIS.
He argued that the biggest problem for China is that it knows how to deal with an unfriendly government in Taipei, but a friendly government forces it to adopt an entirely new mindset.
"I'm not sure Beijing knows how to handle this situation. The most challenging issue for Beijing is how to show respect for Taiwan without making reunification less likely," Cossa said.
Pacific forum Adjunct Fellow Richard Halloran, a freelance journalist and longtime Asia watcher, also warned against inflated expectations.

"There are opportunities, but there remain profound differences between the two. The fundamentals really haven't changed, " Halloran said. He agreed with the other speakers that the primary responsibility for moving the cross-strait relationship forward lies with Beijing.
Shashan Wang, who is from China and a Vasey Fellow at the Pacific Forum CSIS, provided a next-generation perspective on the election and cross-strait relations.
Describing the elections as "an invigorating phenomenon," Wang said that young people on the mainland see Taiwan's politics as a sign of possible opportunities.

She also urged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to open more channels of communication so that they could better understand each other and to move beyond the misperceptions that color cross-strait relations, a suggestion approved by all on the podium.
The panelists called on officials both in Taipei and Beijing to seize the opportunity to establish better relations between Taiwan and the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmakers wary of controversial MAC chair appointment

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) legislators, skeptical over the designation of a pro- independence former lawmaker as head of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) in the incoming KMT government, urged the appointee to reject the offer to allay grave public concerns about her appointment.

KMT Legislator Chiu Yi, while answering questions from reporters at the Legislative Yuan, said the appointment of former Taiwan Solidarity Union lawmaker Lai Hsing-yuan to the key post has stirred up discontent among Taiwan businessmen in China.
"President-elect Ma Ying-jeou has showed poor judgment in appointing Lai as MAC chief -- something which is very likely to spoil the planned negotiations between the two sides," Chiu argued.

"Lai must resign from the post if Ma's election promises -- establishing direct weekend charter flights across the Taiwan Strait and allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan -- fail to be implemented on time on July 4," he said.

In addition, he predicted that Lai's appointment is likely to create disputes between the MAC and the semiofficial Straits Exchange Foundation (SFF) under its oversight over Taiwan's dealings with China.
"It would be a great disaster if such a development occurs," Chiu warned.
In a legislative committee meeting, KMT Legislator Lee Chia-chin suggested Ma replace Lai, the sooner the better, to avoid possible negative consequences.
"Lai's designation as MAC chief is by no means a trivial matter,' he said.
According to Lee, some Taiwan businessmen in China are very upset about Lai's appointment and might refuse to attend Ma's inaugural ceremony on May 20.
Lee also urged Lai to show up quickly and clarify her stance to KMT lawmakers.
For her part, KMT lawmaker Hsu Shao-ping urged Ma to heed the sentiments of the more than 7.65 million people who voted for him in the March 22 presidential election.
"It would be the best damage control measure for all parties concerned if Lai takes the initiative and turns down the appointment," Hsu said.

Speaking at a news conference held at the KMT's caucus office at the Legislative Yuan, the party's acting caucus whip Hsieh Kuo-liang said the caucus supports Ma's appointment of Lai as MAC chairwoman, but he also asked Lai to explain further, to caucus members, her position in terms of cross-strait relations.

"Lai had better do so quickly in order to bring an early end to the dispute, " Hsieh said, suggesting that Lai need not wait until next week to make the move at a planned lunch meeting with Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan and other Cabinet appointees at the KMT headquarters.

The party's legislative caucus members will ask Lai to delve deeper into her stance on issues concerning Taiwan's opening to Chinese tourists and the establishment of cross-strait weekend charter flights on July 4, Hsieh said.
Hsieh, however, also asked the public to give Lai more time to prove whether she will follow Ma's cross-strait policy direction.
Ma said Tuesday that he still aims to make the direct weekend charter flights and the entry of Chinese tourists a reality on July 4 as projected.

DOC.HEADLINE: President-elect meets with Japanese business leader

TEXT.P: President-elect Ma Ying-jeou met Wednesday with Hiroshi Mikitani, chairman and CEO of Rakuten Inc., one of the largest online shopping mall operators in Japan, to exchange ideas on the subject of electronic commerce.
Mikitani met with Ma and Minister-designate of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming at the Taipei headquarters of the soon-to-be-ruling Kuomintang.

After the 30-minute meeting, Mikitani said in response to media inquiries that he and Ma had discussed how to help medium- and small-sized enterprises to promote their products by means of e-commerce.

He also said that his company is working with President Chain Store Corp., Taiwan's biggest convenience chain store operator, on a business venture to launch a Rakuten Ichiba online shopping mall in Taiwan in May.

The new business will combine Rakuten's existing online marketing and President's retail and home delivery networks to sell Taiwan-made products on the global market, Mikitani said. Taiwan Rakuten Ichiba Inc. will be a "combination of virtual and concrete distribution channels," he said.

The virtual Rakuten Ichiba shopping mall started operations in May 1997 in Japan, and at the end of 2006, the company recorded consolidated revenues of 203 billion yen (US$1.95 billion) and an operating profit of 29 billion yen, according to its Web site.
Touting the fast-growing Rakuten as an enterprise with potential, Yiin said the Japanese company has expanded to cover various fields of business, including retail and stock trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seven days of rain predicted for most parts of Taiwan: CWB

TEXT.P: Most parts of Taiwan will see showers or thundershowers for seven days from May 1, as a moist air mass, brought by southwesterly winds, moves across the Taiwan area, the Central Weather Bureau forecast Wednesday.

CWB meteorologists said that from May 1-4, except for southern Taiwan, all other areas, including the outlying islands of Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu, will have rain, followed by thunderstorms from May 5-6, with southeastern Taiwan experiencing only showers, the CWB said.

Temperatures over the next seven days will vary between 20-27 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan, 21-29 degrees Celsius in central Taiwan, 23-31 degrees Celsius in southern Taiwan, and 21-28 degrees Celsius in eastern Taiwan, according to the weather bureau.
The weather experts explained that the approaching front does not mean that the annual plum rain season is beginning early this year. They added that plum rain fronts usually occur after mid-May.

The plum rain season is so named because it coincides with the ripening of the fruit. Formed when moist air over the Pacific meets cooler continental air masses, the plum rains often last in East Asian countries until mid-summer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q1 economic growth estimated at 5.13 percent: premier

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth rate for the first quarter of 2008 is estimated at 5.13 percent as the government continues working toward the goal of achieving 4.8 percent growth for the whole year, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday.

The country's unemployment rate stood at 3.8 percent for the first quarter, showing a leveling off compared with the same quarter of last year, when the unemployment rate registered 3.9 percent, Chang said.
The premier made the remarks during a weekly Cabinet meeting in which he was briefed on the country's economic situation for the first quarter.

Claiming that the performance of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration over the past eight years has often been underrated because of election or political rivalries, Chang said it is time for the public to look at the issue objectively now that the presidential election is over.
He pointed out that under the DPP's leadership, Taiwan's economic growth averaged 4.1 percent between 2000 and 2007, which was higher than the global average of 3.2 percent for the same period.
With a total of 910,000 jobs created over the last eight years, the country's unemployment rate dropped to 3.91 percent for 2007, the lowest level in the past seven years, he went on.

By the end of 2007, Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves had increased to US$270.3 billion, 1.5 times as much as the US$106.2 billion recorded at the end of 1999 when the Kuomintang (KMT) was last in power, Chang said.
Meanwhile, the volume of foreign trade was doubled from US$232.3 billion in 1999 to US$465.9 billion in 2007, he continued.

Over the past eight years, he continued, the DPP administration has helped domestic banking institutions write off bad debts amounting to nearly NT$2 trillion, lowering their average non-performing loan ratio from a high of 11.76 percent to 1.79 percent.

In terms of the promotion of social welfare, Chang said the DPP administration has funneled an average of NT$290.9 billion per year into programs in this regard over the past eight years, compared with an average of NT$166 billion per year that was spent by the former KMT administration.

The introduction of a NT$3,000 monthly allowance for the elderly by the DPP administration has benefited 950,000 senior citizens, while an increase in the monthly allowance for elderly farmers from NT$3,000 to NT$6,000 has benefited 733,000 people, Chang said.

Meanwhile, the national pension program set to be launched in October is expected to cover 3.53 million people, while the new retirement program introduced during the DPP administration has benefited 6.44 million workers, he said, adding that 1.41 million workers have also benefited from a raising of the minimum wage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan aims to take lion's share of global high-end bicycle market

TEXT.P: Taiwan is projected to capture 60 percent of the world's market for expensive bicycles by 2012, a 240 percent expansion within a five-year period, said the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Wednesday.

At present Taiwan possessed about 25 percent of the global market for high-end bikes, selling 2.5 million of the 5.3 million total units exported worldwide, said Tseng Farn-hann, a senior official of the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau (IDB).
"By 2012, we plan to capture 60 percent of the market by boosting all of our bike makers into high-end ones,Tseng noted.
At the beginning the 21th century, Taiwan's bicycle manufacturers have either moved operations to China or shut down due to competition from the mainland in the low-end bicycle market.
To survive, Taiwanese bike manufacturers have steadily switched to making upscale bikes, which cost around US$250 or more.
This has helped upgrade Taiwan's once-ailing bicycle industry.
The industry has also launched A-Team, a non-profit organization made up of 11 local bike makers, to incorporate advanced car making technology into the manufacturing process.

The achievement of such industry innovations became apparent as Taiwan's bike industry exports reached over US$1.05 billion in value in 2007, a huge jump from the US$580 million in 2003. The exports came from the 11 A-Team members.
With innovation and technology, the prices of Taiwanese bikes exported also rose in price from US$100 per unit in 2002 to US$222 per export unit.
Combining local bike making experience and high-tech manufacturing capacity, the IDB has promoted better production management of bike makers to make high-quality products,said Tseng.

He added the next aspects to work on include streamlining the logistics of makers and promoting further research, which should focus on finding nitch market, designing new products, improving the quality of materials used, and developing more diverse functions, such as the wide application of anti-shock cushions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's biomass energy technology mature: researchers

TEXT.P: Taiwan's genetic modification technology used to enhance ethanol refining is mature and will be able to produce enough biomass energy to cope with the energy crisis, researchers said Wednesday.

As the world is facing both a food and an energy crisis, Taiwanese researchers have been developing technology for genetically modifying plants such as rice and sugar cane in order to reduce growing time and increase the portion available for refining into ethanol, the researchers said.

Since Taiwan has advanced technology, farmers and experts, Taiwan can secure a place in the biomass market, which will be an important powerhouse driving economic growth, Winston Wong, chairman of the board of the Grace T.H.W. Group, said at a press conference.
According to the organizers, only three countries in the world -- Brazil, Sweden and Thailand -- use significant amounts of biofuel as an alternative energy source.
The press conference included a bit of theatrics to show the power generated by ethanol in which a magician made a table float in midair using small box of biofuel.

Asked if the principal costs of biomass development are too high, Yu Su-may, a researcher of the Institute of Molecular Biology at Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's top academic institution -- said they are using low-cost plants, fibrous plants, rice straw and sugarcane waste in order to keep costs down. By doing so, biomass development will not overshadow the need for food production, said Yu.

The Council of Agriculture said last week that its attempts to plant biomass energy plants such as corn, soybeans and sunflowers have failed due to the high principal cost and that it plans to switch to agricultural waste and fibrous plants to produce biomass energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan alpine train resumes operations

TEXT.P: The world famous Alishan alpine train resumed operations Wednesday after a two- week suspension to enable engineers to carry out safety checks, the Chiayi Forest District Office announced later that day.
Around 80 tourists from home and abroad took the train when it restarted operations that afternoon, keen to travel on one of the world's only three narrow-gauge mountain railways.
Chiayi Forest District Office chief Yeh Hsien-liang said he is confident of the train's safety after the office conducted an across-the-board examination of its equipment and personnel training.
The office decided to halt services from April 14 following three derailings since March 30.

The Alishan mountain resort area in southern Taiwan is known for its cherry blossoms, sun rise and its steep railway with numerous hairpin bends. It attracts nearly 900,000 local and foreign visitors every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Statistics show growth in Taiwan's manufacturing industry: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The total production value of Taiwan companies rose by 47.8 percent to NT$24.19 trillion in 2006 compared with 2001, but the growth of the average annual wage slowed to 7.1 percent over the same period, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.
The official assessment of Taiwan's manufacturing and service sectors, held once every five years, compared the statistics for 2006 with the figures for 2001.

"Despite the exodus of local manufacturers in the past decade, data shows a revival of Taiwan's industry productivity, especially in manufacturing where production value increased from 2001 by 60 percent to NT$15.55 trillion in 2007, " said Huang Jiann-jong, deputy director of the Bureau of Census under the DGBAS.
He attributed the strong performance to the soaring output of semiconductor and optics makers, which together accounted for production value of NT1.5 trillion in 2006.

Employment in the manufacturing sector also rose by 12.9 percent to 7.52 million employees in 2006, as a result of an 18.2 percent increase in the number of Taiwan companies to 1.1 million, Huang added.

However, the strong showing in the manufacturing sector was overshadowed by the slow growth of the average annual wage, which reached NT$538,658 in 2006, up by a meager 7.1 percent in the five-year period compared with the 15.3 percent rise in the period 1996 to 2000, he said.

"In face of globalization, Taiwan's wage standard was undercut by lower corporate profitability, " Huang explained. Privatization of many state-owned companies was another contributing factor to the slow average wage growth, he added.

The production value from the service sector accounted for only 29.8 percent growth, rising to NT$8.63 trillion in 2006, a relatively weak performance against the NT$15.55 trillion made in manufacturing, he said.

Touching on the trend of heavy reliance on overseas Taiwan-owned factories, Huang said 47.9 percent of the production value of high-tech manufacturers in 2006 was recorded overseas, up 33 percent from 2001. The production value of traditional manufacturers relied 3.9 percent on overseas factories, he added.

Local traditional manufacturers, which include metals and mechanics, petrochemicals, and the commodity industry, were in good heath, showing production value in 2006 of NT$8.9 trillion, accounting for 64 percent of the overall production value of manufacturers, Huang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Policy Agency engaged in carbon reduction efforts

TEXT.P: The National Police Agency (NPA) will launch a four-month program from May 1 to ask policemen nationwide to carry out effective measures in line with the central government's carbon emissions reduction plan, the agency said Wednesday in a press release.

According to the NPA statement, it is encouraging policemen to walk, take public transportation, or cycle, instead of driving a car when they have to carry out duties over a short distance. When they have to be on duty over a long distance, they should share vehicles, it added.
Policemen are also asked not to carry too much in the trucks of their cars and to turn off their vehicle engines at stoplights, as part of the NPA's efforts to help reduce gasoline consumption.
The NPA said that the program will be implemented until the end of August in the hope of encouraging police authorities to take the lead in the carbon reduction efforts.

In addition, policemen also are being asked to lose weight and to conserve electricity in their use of computers, air conditioners, lights and elevators in office, among other eco-friendly measures, according to the statement.

Citing information provided by the Environmental Protection Administration, the NPA said the consumption of one liter of gasoline produces 2.34 kg of carbon dioxide, while the use of one liter of diesel produces 2.78 kg of the greenhouse gas.
The NPA assured the public that despite its energy saving campaign, it will continue to do its best to maintain public order, as this is still the main concern of most citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dispatch of monitoring vessel shows good deep-sea management: COA

TEXT.P: The dispatch of a monitoring vessel to police Taiwanese vessels operating in the Atlantic and Indian oceans signifies the government's determination to achieve good management in deep-sea fishing, an official said Wednesday.

Sha Chih-yi, deputy director of the Council of Agriculture's Fisheries Administration, said the vessel was sent out April 22 on an annual 183-day mission. This is the third consecutive year that the vessel, called Yushun No. 2, has been sent on the mission, Sha said.
The vessel, carrying fishery observers, will monitor the movements and operations of Taiwanese deep-sea fishing boats and maintain order in fishing zones, Sha said.

The action stemmed from a 2005 resolution by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) to cut Taiwan's bigeye tuna quota for 2006 from 14,900 tons to 4,600 tons in the Atlantic Ocean, which resulted in a loss to Taiwan of NT$10 billion (US$32.89 million).
Taiwan was also given an annual quota for bigeye tuna catch by the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission, which was established under the United Nation's framework.

Although the ICCAT quota was restored to 14,900 in 2007 because of Taiwan's adherence to the commission's regulations, the Yushun No. 2 was dispatched to show Taiwan's resolution to follow the rules set out by international organizations and to display self discipline, Sha said.

Since the ICCAT resolution in 2005, Taiwan has improved its management of deep- sea fishing by deploying monitoring systems on fishing boats, establishing a rapid reporting system and carrying out checks at foreign ports such as Mauritius in the Indian Ocean and Cape Town in South Africa.

The Yushun No. 2 is also carrying Coast Guard Administration officers to enhance its ability to do its work, Sha said. The fishery observers and officers onboard the monitoring ship have the right to board and inspect Taiwan's deep-sea fishing boats, even as they protect the rights of such vessels on the high seas, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tunghai University to hold 15th performing arts festival

TEXT.P: Tunghai University in the central city of Taichung will present 19 performances during its 2008 performing arts festival from May 2-10, according to information posted on its Web site.
The month-long presentations will be part of the 15th annual festival held by the 53-year-old Christian university.

The artists and groups slated to perform at six different locations during the festival include Taichung street buskers, The Chairman rock band, the "piano prince" Chen Kuan-yu, the Insensate Stone Troupe, Dance Forum Taipei, drummers of the renowned U-Theatre, and the internationally known Centro Flamenco Taiwan dance troupe.
Two groups from overseas -- an Indian music band from South America and a student choir of the University of Michigan -- have also been invited to perform at the festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weekly unveils 'best medical doctors' list

TEXT.P: The Business Weekly unveiled Wednesday a list of 131 medical doctors considered by their peers to be the best in their fields, with National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital boasting the largest number on the list.
The list was compiled based on the results of a survey among more than 4,000 attending physicians at regional or higher-level hospitals around the country, a magazine spokesman said.

It marked the first time that the business weekly has published such a list for its readers' reference, the spokesman said, adding that major local medical associations and hospitals had assisted in distributing the questionnaires. The attending physicians surveyed were in 11 different medical branches.

In the survey, each respondent was asked to recommend a short list of three medical doctors they would most likely recommend to their ailing friends or relatives, based on professionalism and work attitude.

More than 600 physicians and surgeons were recommended in the survey, with 131 of them gaining the most recommendations, the magazine spokesman said, adding that their major common characteristics include outstanding professional expertise or competence and kind-heartedness.

According to the survey results, 73 percent of the 131 most recommended doctors are working at hospitals in northern Taiwan; 14 percent are in central Taiwan hospitals; 13 percent are in southern Taiwan hospitals; and only 0.8 percent are in eastern Taiwan.
"The figures show the inequity of our medical resource distribution," the spokesman said.
The survey results show that National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital in Taipei City alone accounts for 30 of the 131 "most recommended" physicians, topping all other hospitals.
Veterans General Hospital in suburban Taipei came in second, with 26 "most recommended" doctors.
Among those recommended in pediatrics were Lee Ping-ying and Chang Mei-hui at NTU Hospital and Huang Fu-yuan at Mackay Memorial Hospital in Taipei.

Lee Jen-chih, director of Tzu Chi Hospital's tuberculosis laboratory in the eastern county of Hualien, was also highly recommended for his professional competence and concern for patients. He is known to visit his patients at their homes to check whether they take their medicines in accordance with his instructions.

Also high on the list is Ho Shih-chu, director of the obsterics and gynecology department at Taichung Veterans General Hospital in central Taiwan who has traveled extensively throughout Taiwan's countryside to conduct smear tests for rural women in a bid to prevent cervical cancer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Efforts made to stabilize prices: premier

TEXT.P: The government has been making efforts to stabilize commodity prices, with special consideration for the disadvantaged, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday.
Chang made the remarks at a ceremony held at the Council of Labor Affairs to commend outstanding laborers.
The premier commented that consumer prices in Taiwan are relatively stable, compared with other countries, although there has been a surge due to the global impact of increasing oil prices.

The government's efforts are also reflected in Taiwan's economic development, Chang said, noting that Taiwan enjoyed a 4.1 percent economic growth rate from 2000-2007, higher than the world average of 3.2 percent.
Last year's economic growth rate was 5.73 percent, with 910,000 job opportunities created, Chang said, adding that last year's unemployment rate of 3.9 percent was the lowest in the last seven years.
Chang said taking good care of laborers, who are the bedrock of the country's economic development, has always been the government's priority.

At an Executive Yuan price stabilizing meeting held the same day, Chang asked the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to supervise a public project for local governments to distribute rice to the the disadvantaged.

At least 620,000 people including those in low-income families, elderly people with lower than average incomes, and the disabled, will be eligible to receive 5 kg to 10 kg of rice twice a year under the project which will distribute a total of 8,427 tons of rice.
The first donations will made May 1 through mid-May, and the second in December, Chang said.
Chang expressed gratitude to the local governments for their cooperation on the project.
He also asked the Fair Trade Commission, the MOI, and the Ministry of Justice to clamp down on monopolization, price fixing, and commodity hoarding, in the interest of consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: PM's challenge to firms: Cut workplace deaths.
Sixty-three workers died while doing their jobs in Singapore last year, mostly in construction or manufacturing. Those tragedies added up to a rate of 2.9 deaths per 100,000 workers here - a slight improvement on previous years.
Those tragedies added up to a rate of 2.9 deaths per 100,000 workers here - a slight improvement on previous years.
Not good enough, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said yesterday. He has set them a target of slashing the death rate to 1.8 per 100,000 workers within 10 years.
The Lianhe Zaobao: PM to set a high standard target for workplace safety standards.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has set a high target of slashing the death rate to 1.8 per 100,000 workers within 10 years for employers.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGMervyn King: Banks paying price for their greed
The days of Cityhubrismust come to an end, the Bank of England cautioned yesterday in an extraordinary attack by Mervyn King, the Governor, on excessive pay packages and heavy risk-taking.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Obama's Break With Ex-Pastor Sets Sharp Shift in Ton
Senator Barack Obama broke forcefully on Tuesday with his former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., in an effort to curtail a drama of race, values, patriotism and betrayal that has enveloped his presidential candidacy at a critical juncture.
The Wall Street Journal: Countrywide Loss Focuses Attention on Underwriting
Countrywide Financial Corp. reported an $893 million loss for the first quarter, amid mounting evidence of serious problems with its underwriting of many home loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post:Siphoning Off Corn to Fuel Our Cars
Erwin Johnson picks up a clump of the dark, rich soil that he has farmed for 35 years, like his father and grandfather before him. In a few months, this flat expanse of northern Iowa will be crowded with corn ready to be trucked to market.
The Washington Times: Bush lays gas blame on Congress
President Bush blamed the Democratic Congress for blocking bills he said would have lowered gas prices, marking a coordinated strategy with congressional Republicans to shift responsibility for the nation's economic woes to Democrats. They, in turn, were quick to strike back.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung County sees poor plum harvest

TEXT.P: Taitung County in eastern Taiwan saw only 20 percent of its usual plum harvest this year due to unusual and unstable climate conditions during the fruit's growth and ripening periods, a plum grower told the CNA Wednesday.

According to Lee To-hai, who grows plums in Luanshan in the county's Yen-ping Township, the area usually produces more than 150,000 kg of plums annually, but this year's production was only 20,000 kg.
What's even worse is that 20 percent of the crop was abnormally shaped plums that cannot be sent to the market, Lee said.

Lee said last summer's dry weather had weakened the roots and trunks of the plum trees, and because of the unstable weather in January this year, pollination of the plants was interrupted, which caused the fruit to grow in abnormal shapes.
Moreover, he said that too much rainfall during the plums' ripening season in March and April had caused the pulps to split.
Lee said his hope was to at least recover the cost of picking the poor harvest of plums.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC chair-designate promises to improve cross-strait relations

TEXT.P: Lai Hsing-yuan, chairwoman-designate of the Mainland Affairs Council, promised Wednesday that she will devote her efforts to the creation of better cross- Taiwan Strait relations, emphasizing that her stance on China policies is in line with President-elect Ma Ying Jeou's.

Lai made the remarks after a meeting with Chiang Pin-kung, the chairman- designate of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , which handles engagements with China in the absence of official ties.
It was also Lai's first public appearance since she was named as the incoming head of the MAC by Premier-designate Liu Chao-shiuan.

The appointment of the former legislator of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) has drawn criticisms by legislators of the soon-to-be- ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and many political commentators.

Saying that her stance on cross-strait issues is based on Taiwan's integrity and the interests of all the Taiwan people, Lai promised that she will do her best to develop better cross-strait relations."

Discounting concerns that she does not share Ma's view that "there is only one China, but with different interpretations, " Lai reaffirmed that she recognizes the so-called 92-Consensus, implying that she shares Mas viewpoint on the issue.

Noting that her previous contact with Chiang started in 1997 when they worked together on APEC issues, Lai lauded Chiang as a respected patriarch and said she believes that "the MAC and the SEF will cooperate well in the future."
"The SEF is the organization authorized to deal with cross-strait affairs, while the MAC will function as the coordinator of a diversity of views," Lai noted.

Saying that he had very good experiences in working with Lai on aspects of international negotiations, Chiang praised Lai at a briefing after their 45-minute closed-door meeting as "professional, hard-working, and tenacious."
Chiang also said he was sure that "both the SEF and the MAC will cooperate well and will be jointly responsible for implementing Ma's cross-strait policies."

Lai holds a master's degree in international relations and a doctorate in development studies, both earned in the United Kingdom. She has served as Taiwan's negotiator for World Trade Organization accession, as a member of the National Security Council, a legislator and a university research fellow.

Lai's appointment has been the target of criticisms on nearly all fronts, with even the ruling Democratic Progressive Part casting doubts over the rationale behind her selection, while political pundits have ridiculed Mas decision on TV talk shows around the clock.
At the news briefing, Lai thanked all those who expressed opinions and offered suggestions regarding her appointment.

As for the view that Ma's policy to launch direct charter flights starting on July 4 may eventually fail, Lai said "I am working very hard and everyone else is also working hard on this issue... we will do our utmost to achieve this goal."
